description: Last Resort for Parents

title: Peter Is Keeping Focus On Remaining a Starter
description: In his fourth year with the Giants, Christian Peter has finally attained the security of a starting job. Just do not tell him that he is under any less pressure.

title: It's Your Taste, Mr. Frick, If, Um, a Bit More Daring
description: The Frick Collection has put on view six paintings from the former collection of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney. The works, by Corot, Manet, Degas, Picasso and Odilon Redon, are in the Garden Court. Several of them relate in a most instructive way to the Frick Collection as it was formed by Henry Clay Frick (1849-1919) and enlarged, according to his wish, after his death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, LILLIAN LEE
description: HOWARD-Lillian Lee. Passed away in her 88th year peacefully Aug. 29, 2000 in Stuart, FL. Devoted wife of 66 years to Mike Howard. Beloved mother of Bob Howard (Jon Wilner) and Sandy Kelley (Mike Marshall). Loving sister of Pearl Fish and Charles Halpern.

title: You're So Hip and Cool, Dudes, but She's Crafty
description: ''Whipped'' may set an all-time record for raw tonnage of sexual fear and loathing spewed per minute by a Hollywood movie. This bottom-feeding monstrosity of a comedy was produced, directed and written by Peter M. Cohen, whose screenplay conjures more leering euphemisms for male body parts and sexual acts than any film in recent memory.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Retracing the Steps Trod at Gettysburg
description: The National Park Service recommends on its Web site that visitors to the Gettysburg National Military Park spend at least four hours touring the battlefield and museum, ''though an entire day is more desirable.''

title: Certified Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: If It's Not One Thing, It's Another; As Tires Are Recalled, Bridgestone Faces Possible Strike
description: Reeling from a crisis over defective tires, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. faces the possibility of a strike tomorrow by 8,000 workers at nine American factories -- a move that could set back the company's efforts to replace 6.5 million recalled tires.

title: Day After Her Father's Outburst, Dokic Coolly Advances
description: Six security guards linked arms and fell into a phalanx around Jelena Dokic, protecting the Australian teenager against the rush of two Australian television crews and a dozen international journalists who had just witnessed her crisp 6-1, 6-4 dismissal of Miriam Oremans on Court 4.

title: New York Lawyer Advances Legal Fiction
description: When writers want to inject a dose of quirky reality into their courtroom dramas, they sometimes turn to law firms to make sure their portrayals are accurate.

title: Crisscrossing Manhattan, Nader Criticizes Corporate Misdeeds
description: Ralph Nader, running for president as the Green Party nominee, railed against big business from the heart of corporate America yesterday, crisscrossing Manhattan to condemn environmental pollution, the exploitation of workers and the abuse of taxpayer dollars through ''corporate welfare.''

title: Volkswagen Mexico in Accord With Union
description: Workers at Volkswagen Mexico negotiated a raise of more than double the inflation rate, ending a two-week battle that included a walkout at their factory in Puebla, the only one in the world that produces trendy Beetles.

title: The Post to Halve Its Newsstand Price
description: The New York Post will reduce its daily newsstand price to 25 cents from 50 cents starting Monday, a move taken two weeks after its main competitor, The Daily News, said it would begin distributing a free afternoon edition.

title: How an Irish Mother Became a Warrior for Peace
description: ''Titanic Town'' is by no means the first film to portray the profoundly disruptive effects on everyday life of the long-running troubles in Northern Ireland. But in its harshly realistic scenes of British Army tanks rolling across the lawns of a middle-class housing development in West Belfast, it stirs your blood. As helicopters hover overhead and armed gunmen dart from house to house to flush out Irish Republican Army guerrillas in the middle of the afternoon, the community appears to be a besieged enclave continually terrorized by a ruthless occupying army.

title: Retailers Post Weak August, Hoping It's Not Holiday Omen
description: After watching business slow for six months, the nation's merchants reported only slight gains yesterday in sales of back-to-school merchandise -- news that may not bode well for the rest of the year and the coming holiday season.

title: Lawyer Advances 'Legal Fiction'
description: When writers want to inject a dose of quirky reality into their courtroom dramas, they sometimes turn to law firms to make sure their portrayals are accurate.

title: Online Service, Record Label to Target Music Listeners
description: Online Service, Record Label to Target Music Listeners

title: Hertz Says Earnings Will Fall Short in 2 Quarters
description: The Hertz Corporation warned today that it expects third-quarter and fourth-quarter earnings to fall short of analysts' estimates because of competitive prices in the car-rental business and canceled flights at United Airlines.

title: Salon.com Shares Find a Taker
description: Salon.com Shares Find a Taker

title: No Headline
CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: If It's Not One Thing, It's Another; Venezuela Asks Criminal Case Against Firestone and Ford
description: Accusing both the Ford Motor Company and Bridgestone/ Firestone of conspiring to hide tire defects that caused dozens of deaths, Venezuela's consumer protection agency asked the nation's prosecutor yesterday to bring criminal charges against both companies.

title: SEGA CUTTING DREAMCAST PRICE
description: Sega Enterprises, the maker of video game consoles, said it would drop the price of its Dreamcast game system 25 percent, to $150, in a bid to spur sales before Sony introduces its Playstation 2 in the United States this fall. The price cut, from $200, comes about a year after the game machine was first sold in the United States.

title: Family Panel Seeks Agency of Record
description: The California Children and Families Commission is beginning a review to find its first agency of record to handle its educational advertising campaign focused on early childhood development and the effects of tobacco use by pregnant women and parents of young children.

title: Lees Run in Queens Began in the Bronx
description: Hyung Taik Lee's unlikely odyssey from obscurity to the third round of the United States Open began on Aug. 11, in the middle of the night, driving from Binghamton to the Bronx.

title: New Video Releases; Any Given Sunday
description: With his legendary quarterback out for the season, Tony D'Amato (Al Pacino, left), coach of the Miami Sharks, turns to the erratic young backup Willie Beamen (Jamie Foxx), while in the stadium's luxury suites the Sharks' cold-blooded owner (Cameron Diaz) plots to get the team's asking price up to $800 million. In sync with a sports-crazed society, Oliver Stone's big, loud movie has fun with the Associated Football Franchises of America, his commerce-crazy equivalent of the National Football League. On the field it's war, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, in a ''crude morality play in the style of Mr. Stone's 'Wall Street.' ''

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Lazio Closes In On Mrs. Clinton In Money Race
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio may be less well known than his opponent in the New York Senate contest (not to mention the Republican who dropped out), but in terms of fund-raising, he has already entered her league. Mr. Lazio collected $10.7 million in just seven weeks this summer, his aides said yesterday, leaving little doubt that he will have the means to battle for the seat despite his late start.

title: CARREFOUR'S PROFIT UP
description: Carrefour S.A., the French-based global retailer, said its first-half profit rose 11 percent. Profit from operations rose to 302 million euros ($270 million) from 273 million euros in the first half of 1999. Including costs for closing shops in Hong Kong, net income rose to 277 million euros from 266 million euros. In the first half, Carrefour paid off two-thirds of the 122 million euros in expenses related to its January takeover of Promodes, said Daniel Bernard, the chairman of the company.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 1
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: UNLEADED GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose on signs that demand from motorists before the Labor Day holiday is eroding inventories. In New York, gasoline for September delivery rose 1.15 cents, to $1.0114 a gallon.

title: CALIFORNIA BILL ON WEB SALES TAX
description: The California State Assembly has passed a bill that would require businesses with stores in California to collect state sales tax on purchases made over the Internet. The bill, approved earlier by the State Senate, passed by a vote of 42-to-31 and was sent to the governor. It focuses on companies like Barnes & Noble, whose affiliated Internet units do not charge or collect the state's 7.25 percent sales tax. While Gov. Gray Davis has not said whether he will sign the bill, he has indicated that he opposes Internet taxes. State officials estimate the measure could add $14 million in tax revenues to the $22 billion the state already collects each year. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

title: John Watkins, 87, Publisher And World War II Fighter Pilot
description: John C. A. Watkins, the longest-serving publisher of The Providence Journal, died Wednesday in Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAM, WILLIAM
description: BEHAM-William. In his 93rd year. Much loved husband of the late Miriam (Marcus). Dear companion of Fanny Glixman. Wonderful father, grandfather, great-grandfather, colleague and friend. Never bored, always learning, he loved life and life returned the compliment. Services Wednesday, September 6, 12:45PM, The Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. Memorial contributions can be made to the NYU Hematology Research Fund, C/O Bruce Raphael, MD, 530 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016.

title: Anthony Corallo, Mob Boss, Dies in Federal Prison at 87
description: Anthony Corallo, the salty and stoical former boss of the Lucchese crime family who went to jail for life after the authorities overheard him chatting to his driver about the mob's control of New York City's construction industry, died Aug. 23 in a federal prison hospital in Springfield, Mo. He was 87.

title: Tenniss Unblinking Eye
description: Tennis fans who dislike the temper tantrums thrown by some top players over line umpires' calls can thank Bill Carlton that there aren't more of them.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Trois Jean, one of Manhattan's handsomest bistros, has ended its long run. In its place an American restaurant has risen with a clean-cut American look (created by Larry Bogdanow), a New American menu (created by Mark Spangenthal, the chef at the Screening Room) and a no-frills American name, the Dining Room.

title: Along a Favorite Route, Window Dressers Get a Dressing Down
description: Store windows, each a fantasy world, are ways to seduce the public into entering the shop's inner sanctum and seeking personal fulfillment by buying the fashionable products on view. Unlike the flat world of magazine advertising, the three-dimensional store window, with life-size mannequins and realistic props, has functioned over the years as a small, though frozen, performance space in which passers-by can imagine themselves as players.

title: CANADA'S ECONOMY GROWS
description: With a surge in business investment, Canada's economy continued to grow at a strong annual pace, 4.7 percent, in the second quarter, slightly below the 5.1 percent gross domestic product advances of the two previous quarters. Spending on machinery and equipment, mainly computers and related high-tech components, grew by 19.5 percent annually. Exports advanced at an 8.5 percent yearly rate, led also by high-tech sales, and imports were 10.2 percent higher. Considering that much of Canada has endured a cool, wet summer, consumer spending was stronger than expected, rising at a 3.6 percent annual rate. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: F.C.C. Widens Radio Spectrum for Wireless Networks
description: In a move that may stimulate development of wireless products for the home, the Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that it had eased restrictions on part of the radio spectrum.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES EFFORT TO REPEAL TAXES ON ESTATES
description: President Clinton today vetoed a Republican-sponsored bill to repeal the federal estate tax and stepped up the election-year sparring over tax cuts and how best to spend the budget surplus.

title: When the Talk Is of Faith, What Is the Message?; Unbroken Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Cut Trading Costs at 2 Key European Exchanges
description: In a move intended to shore up support for the planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges, the clearinghouses for the two markets introduced a plan today that would cut settlement costs by 90 percent for certain trades.

title: Hard Legacy for Japan Sect Leader's Family
description: They were the child princes and princesses of Japan's most notorious religious sect, Aum Shinrikyo, which released deadly sarin gas into the Tokyo subway in 1995. Their pictures were prominently displayed next to their father's portrait above cult shrines, where thousands of Aum disciples hailed them as heirs apparent to the spiritual throne. They were considered child gods.

title: In Capturing Star, Artist Goes for the Spirit
description: WALKING around the National Tennis Center during the United States Open this week, you may happen upon a 14-foot statue of a man, nude, rendered in heroic, classic style. His arm will be raised as if he is about to serve a tennis ball.

title: National News Briefs
description: Interior Dept. Reviews

title: Oregon to Put $1 Billion in Buyout Fund
description: The $40 billion Oregon Public Employees' Retirement System voted yesterday to invest $1 billion in a new buyout fund from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the biggest commitment ever to a private-equity pool.

title: PENTAGON LIKELY TO DELAY NEW TEST FOR MISSILE SHIELD
description: The Pentagon will probably postpone the next test of a national missile defense system until January, administration officials said today. Any decision to deploy the antimissile shield now seems certain to pass out of President Clinton's hands to his successor's.

title: Cheney Urges Rethinking Use of U.S. Ground Forces In Bosnia and Kosovo
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, called today for a re-examination of the nation's role in peacekeeping missions around the world and said it was time to consider recalling American ground troops from Kosovo and Bosnia.

title: Lee's Run in Queens Began in the Bronx
description: Hyung Taik Lee's unlikely odyssey from obscurity to the third round of the United States Open began on Aug. 11, in the middle of the night, driving from Binghamton to the Bronx.

title: Annie Devine, 88, Rights Advocate in Mississippi
description: Annie Devine, a no-nonsense Mississippi trailblazer for the Voting Rights Act of 1965, died on Aug. 22 at a hospital in Ridgeland, Miss. She was 88 and lived in nearby Canton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LAWRENCE E.
description: PHILLIPS-Lawrence E. Jr. 0n August 31, of Ridgewood, NJ. Survived by his wife Doris, 2 sons Lawrence III and Thomas G. of NY, NY, a grandson Lawrence H. and two brothers Nicholas of Wyckoff, NJ and Robert of NY, NY. Mr. Phillips was a graduate of Columbia University and Harvard Business School. He retired as a securities analyst with Lehman Management Co. after serving with other Wall Street firms. A Mass will be held Saturday, September 2, 9:30 AM at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood, NJ. Friends may call Friday, 2-4, 79PM at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 E. Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, NJ. A memorial Mass will be held in New York City in late September.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: 2 at Top of Nordstrom Quit; Family Members Take Over
description: After several years of anemic sales growth at Nordstrom Inc., the chairman and chief executive and the chief financial officer have resigned, the company said yesterday. Two members of the Nordstrom family, which controls roughly one-third of the company's stock, have been named to top executive positions. Blake Nordstrom, 39, will be president, while Bruce Nordstrom, 66, will be chairman of the board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAYTON, DORIS
description: CAYTON-Doris. The partners and staff of Parker Duryee Rosoff & Haft note with sorrow the death of Doris Cayton on August 30, 2000, and express their deepest sympaythies to Bill Cayton and the entire family.

title: Blast Spews Asbestos Near N.Y.U. Library
description: A steam pipe near the entrance to New York University's main library burst yesterday morning, spewing debris and traces of asbestos onto dozens of people and several cars and buildings in the area.

title: Return of the White House Turnstile
description: Well after the 1996 fund-raising scandals brought charges that President Clinton had effectively ''sold'' the Lincoln Bedroom for campaign contributions, big donors continued to gain easy access to the White House in return for their donations. The famous White House turnstile was alive and well at least through last year, when a generous donor named David Chang, who subsequently pleaded guilty to channeling illegal contributions to Senator Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, was granted a number of visits with Mr. Clinton, in both formal and informal settings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLING, DANIEL A.
description: SCHLING-Daniel A. ''Bucky''. Formerly of Edgemont, NY in his 34th year on August 5 in Los Angeles where he resided while pursing his career in film as a screenwriter and film technician. Devoted son of Joseph M. and Phyllis E. Schling of Bolton, MA. Beloved grandson of Mildred Sutain and the late Abraham Sutain. Nephew of Leslie and Cory Sutain and the late Valerie Sutain. Loving cousin of Noren Caceres. Cherished grandson of the late Frederick and Frances Hochhauser Schling. Bucky graduated from Goddard College, received his graduate degree from the Virginia Commonwealth University and did post graduate work at UCLA. Graveside services at the Beit Olam Cemetery, Wayland, MA. on Sunday, September 3 at 2 PM. A scholarship fund has been established in Bucky's name at Goddard College attn: Development Department, 123 Pitkin Rd., Plainfield, VT 05667. For information the Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Postal Work Unfairly Maligned, Study Says
description: There is far less on-the-job homicide in the Postal Service than at other workplaces, and the term ''going postal'' is unjustified and unfair, according to a commission formed to study aggressive behavior at the post office.

title: Warsaw Journal; When Everything Was Gray, Not Red
description: The tables are set with thick, badly painted china, government standard, with silverware of some cheap, scratched metal alloy. A fan of thin, shiny and somehow unabsorbent napkins pokes out of a thick glass; the salt shaker is a jam jar with holes punched in the lid and rice mixed in, to stop clumping. There are other jars, with a few dusty plastic flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICK, STUART
description: DICK-Stuart. Departed this life on August 30, 2000 at home following a long and courageous battle with lung cancer. Beloved husband of Dacota; devoted father of Aviva, Christina, Melissa and Maxwell. Dedicated son to his mother, Frances. He was cherished by his extended families and dear friends. Stuart loved life and most of all considered it a privilege to have been a professor. His work was his passion and he had the wonderful opportunity to have touched many lives through his teaching. His passing leaves a void that will never be filled. He will be fondly remembered by those whom he has loved and by those who have loved him. In lieu of flowers, contribution in his name should be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19 Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Facing Your Mortality at 30,000 Feet
description: To the Editor:

title: Unburied Treasure
description: A powerful queen. A mystical ram. Marauding lions. A gigantic lyre.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: HOW AMAZON USES INFORMATION
description: Amazon.com, the No. 1 Internet retailer, has revised its privacy policy, and in doing so has provided a window into how much it uses the customer data it collects to help it and other companies sell more. In the new policy, Amazon disclosed that it has started sending e-mail marketing messages on behalf of other companies. It also added a long list of data it collects about users, including financial information, Social Security numbers, product searches and the telephone number from which a user calls Amazon's customer service line. And for the first time, Amazon disclosed it can buy information about customers from outside databases. And if the new initiatives do not help stem Amazon's huge losses and the company is put up for sale, the new policy says, anyone who buys Amazon will get its customer data. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Move by Gerber Scientific
description: Gerber Scientific Inc., a computer systems provider to clothing and sign-making companies, said today that it was considering options for its Coburn optical business, including a possible sale. Shares of Gerber Scientific have fallen 56 percent this year. The company said it hired the investment bank C. E. Unterberg, Towbin as an adviser. Gerber said the optical unit is the No. 1 supplier of systems to optical lens processors. The company is based in South Windsor.

title: Paul Yager, 80, a Mediator in Labor Strikes
description: Paul Yager, a veteran federal labor mediator who helped resolve several important labor strikes in the New York City region, died Monday at a hospital in Edison, N.J. He was 80 and lived in Metuchen, N.J.

title: Determined to Play Football, And Finally Able to Prove It
description: The Replacements

title: Numbers Aside, Jeter Still Measures Up
description: The competitive, cutting remarks between them are few and always good-natured, Alex Rodriguez says about the conversations with his good friend Derek Jeter. The shortstops are like brothers and even the most loving brothers push each other inherently, the presence of one driving the other.

title: Federal Agency Finds Workfare Contractor Violated Wage Law
description: The nation's largest operator of welfare-to-work programs violated federal law by paying lower wages to women than to men placed in the same jobs in a Milwaukee warehouse, according to a decision made public yesterday by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Amazon.com Revises Privacy Policy on Consumer Concern
description: Amazon.com Revises Privacy Policy on Consumer Concern

title: Miscellany
description: Houston Helm Fattal & Collins, Los Angeles, was renamed Blackboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, HARRIET
description: BLAUSTEIN-Harriet. On August 30, 2000. You are with us every day. Your everlasting love and care comfort us. Pam, David and Michele

title: Federal Investigators Join Arson Inquiry in New Jersey
description: Arson investigators continued rummaging today through the rubble of a sprawling, unfinished apartment complex ravaged by a fast-spreading fire Wednesday night, trying to determine whether the blaze was an accident or intentionally set.

title: Article 2000090291559531508 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHER, HERMAN
description: FLEISCHER-Herman. Age 78. Suddenly, on September 1, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Fleischer. Much loved father of Madelene (Stan) Towne. Devoted and adored Papa of Adam, Sara and Rachel Towne. You will be forever missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINSSER, BARBARA L. (MRS. HANS)
description: ZINSSER-Barbara L. (Mrs. Hans). The American Farm School of Thessaloniki, Greece's Trustees, staff, students and friends honor the life of Mrs. Barbara L. Zinsser. A major force on the Board of the School, her wit, care, loyalty and keen insight guided us for more than 30 years. To quote the Greek: ''May your memory be eternal!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINA, JEAN
description: MALINA-Jean. The Board of the American Friends of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art note with sorrow the passing of Jean Malina, loving mother of our esteemed officer and dedicated member Michael Malina. May she rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, ELIZABETH WYLIE
description: WEBSTER-Elizabeth Wylie. 92, of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ on September 1, 2000. Graduate of Vassar College and served on the Board of the YWCA of NYC. Wife of the late James H. Case, Jr. and the late Bethuel M. Webster. Survived by three daughters, Elizabeth Case Mills, Susan C. Hyde and Penelope C. Davis; three stepdaughters, 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Services will be private. For more information, A.S. Cole Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, MILTON
description: HALPERN-Milton. On September 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Gladys, loving father of Ava, Toni, Randall and father-in-law to Robert, Matthew, and Naomi. Cherished ''Papa'' to Bradley, Ricki, Heather, Courtney, Sarah, and Lauren. Dear brother of Arthur. Services Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCRUM, CARL
description: ANCRUM-Carl. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Carl Ancrum, associated with The Times since 1982.

title: Theodore Trautwein, Judge in Landmark Press Case, Dies at 80
description: Theodore W. Trautwein, the New Jersey judge who sent a reporter to jail in 1978 in a celebrated case that tested the boundaries of press freedom and fair trials, died on Aug. 17 in Hollywood, Fla., where he had lived for the last two years. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKINS, R. BRUCE
description: HAWKINS-R. Bruce. Of Glen Cove, LI and Boca Raton, FL, on September 20th, 2000, age 70. Husband of Marilyn P., three sons and six daughters. For information, Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Long Island.

title: The Online Commute
description: Six miles south of where I live, in a lovely pastoral setting known as Coyote Valley, Cisco Systems is busy transforming almost 700 acres of fields, orchards and streams into a huge office complex that will eventually house 20,000 of its employees. Such a facility makes obvious sense. When you concentrate bright, skilled people in the same proximate space, they energize one another. And given the intellectual nature of the work, and the brain pool that it will house, it deserves to be called, in familiar Silicon Valley language, a ''campus.''

title: Singing to the Converted: How Creed Inspires Devotion
description: Scott Stapp obviously thinks he deserves to be a rock god. The frontman for Creed, the Florida-based band that packed Madison Square Garden on Monday and plays a sold-out show tomorrow at Jones Beach, works to project the aura of a champion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUOTOLO, ANDREW KEOGH JR.
description: RUOTOLO-Andrew Keogh Jr. November 5, 1952-September 21, 1995. ''For the chosen few, there is no disillusionment. They march on into life with a boyish grace, and their high noon keeps all the freshness of the morning''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, FLORENCE M.
description: KATZ-Florence M. Beloved wife of Jerome. Cherished mother of Alan (Joyce) and Susan (Seth Truwit). Loving grandmother of Marjorie, Brittany, Alison, Elana, Noah and Jillian. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, September 3rd at 11:15 AM.

title: Corrections
description: A music review and a picture caption on Tuesday about the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra's performance of excerpts from an opera by Carl Maria von Weber at Avery Fisher Hall misspelled the title. It is ''Der Freischutz,'' not ''Der Freishutz.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, MILDRED
description: LIPTON-Mildred. On September 10, 2000. Loving sister of Esther Goldberg and Lillian Ott. Dear aunt of Evelyn Roth, Arthur Jacobs, Sydney DeGregory, Carol Ann Leibner, Stephen Jacobs, Barbara Stein, Judy Pace, Alan Jacobs and Sidney Goldberg. Also survived by great nieces and great nephews, cousins and friends. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYETH, LEONARD JARVIS
description: WYETH-Leonard Jarvis. Of Lakeville, CT, died August 29th in Sharon (CT) Hospital. He was the son of the late Leonard J. and the late Priscilla Mullins Bull Wyeth of New York City. He leaves his cherished wife of 59 years, Pamela Evans Wyeth, two daughters, Pamela I. Wyeth of S. Westerlo, NY, and Christina L. Wyeth of New York City, and a son, Leonard J. Wyeth VI of Essex, CT, and two grandchildren, Leonard J. Wyeth VII and Joan L. Wyeth of Essex, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the MPD Research Center, 115 East 72nd Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKARULIS, DR. JOHN A.
description: SKARULIS-Dr. John A. Graduate of and taught at St. Johns University and Professor of Chemistry for over 35 years, accomplished pianist and organist. Survived by two sons, John and Greg, MD, and nine grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, GUY
description: ROBBINS-Guy, M.D. On Sept. 9, 2000. He was widower of Louise, father of Kirk, Kathy and Richard, grandfather of Holly, Clifford and Vivian. He devoted his medical career to the treatment and cure of breast cancer. A former chief of the Breast Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, and consultant at numerous hospitals in the greater metropolitan area. Also active in politics in Westport, Connecticut, where he raised his family. He will be sorely missed by his family, patients, neighbors and all the other people whose lives he touched. Contributions may be made to Memorial Hospital or Northwestern University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLKIE, ARLINDA F.
description: WILLKIE-Arlinda F. Born July 31, 1946; died on Sept 7, 2000 from breast cancer. She was courageous, graceful, loving and beloved. We thank her friends, caretakers, nurses and doctors. She is survived by her family including her daughter, Julia T. Miranda; her brother and sister-in-law Frederick & Ida; her sister Julia; her brother Hall; Tom Craveiro; Riccardo Salmona; and her pug Peg. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Benheim Cancer Center or the Red Cross of Greenwich, CT. Service Monday, September 11 at 4 PM, First Congregational Church Old Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUKSCH, GEORGE S.
description: MAUKSCH-George S. On August 20, 2000, died suddenly of a heart attack while vacationing in the south of France. He would have turned 81 on August 31. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary, his daughters Judith and Jane, their husbands Richard Cotter and Bill Perri, and four grandchildren, Christopher and Jason Cotter, and Justin and Michelle Perri. Born in Vienna, Austria, he came to the United States in 1938. A veteran of WWII, he graduated from Brooklyn Polytechnic and went on to work for Western Electric, AT&T Long Lines, and the ITT Corporation. In 1976, he founded H&M Automation Systems. He will be remembered for his sense of humor, his great charm and for his love of the good things in life.

title: BUSH DEFENDS AD THAT ASSAILS GORE
description: Gov. George W. Bush today defended a new advertisement that challenges the credibility and character of Vice President Al Gore and signaled that his frequent pledge to ''change the tone'' of politics would not prevent him from raising questions about Mr. Gore's truthfulness and leadership abilities in the coming weeks.

title: The Killer's Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, SCOTT A.
description: SCHACHTER-Scott A. 74, of Levittown, NY, died suddenly after surgery on August 31, 2000. Beloved and devoted husband of Justine, for 51 years. Cherished father of Linda Wright, Barbara Costa, Peter Schachter and David Schachter. Treasured father-in-law of Robert Wright, Antonia Schachter and Scott Hunt. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey and Bryan Wright, and Nicholas and Jonathan Schachter. Dearest brother of Paul Schachter. Loving cousin, uncle, nephew, and friend. Scott was a retired NBC audio engineer and two time Emmy Award recipient for his distinguished work in live television. He delighted in traveling the world with his wife, laughter with his family and friends, and doing The New York Times Crossword Puzzles in ink. Visiting on Saturday, 7-9 pm and service on Sunday at 3pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, TAYLOR RASTRICK
description: BRIGGS-Taylor Rastrick. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, L.L.P., mourns with sorrow the September 1 passing of our dear friend, colleague, and former Chairman, Taylor Rastrick Briggs. An immensely gifted litigator, Taylor joined LeBoeuf in 1961, was made Partner in 1963 and served as Chairman for 10 years, from 1978 to 1988. He became Counsel to the Firm in 1995. A leader and mentor who exemplified integrity and grace, Taylor will be missed by all who knew him. We extend condolences to his wife, Jane, their four children, Cynthia, Jennifer, Pamela and Taylor, Jr., and nine grandchildren. A memorial service has been scheduled for 2 PM on Wednesday, September 6, 2000, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEANY, STEPHEN J., S.J.
description: MEANY-Stephen J., S.J. Died of cancer Sunday, September 3 at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Bronx, NY. For the five years prior to his death, Fr. Meany, who recited on the campus of Fordham University, had conducted retreats for lay and religious throughout the Eastern United States and Canada. Born in Queens, NY and a graduate of Regis High School in Manhattan, he entered the Society of Jesus in 1954 and was ordained at Fordham in 1967. For eighteen years he served in Puerto Rico as teacher and administrator at Jesuit schools there. In 1975 he spent a year of intensive training in corporate finance, subsequently filling financial posts in Puerto Rico and at St. Peter's Prep in Jersey City. Fr. Meany was active in the alcohol recovery programs of AA, the National Catholic Council on Alcohol and the Guest House of Rochester, MN. title: KOREAN BANK APPLICATION
description: The Asia Development Bank said North Korea had applied for membership status, which would give it access to low-interest loans to rebuild its outdated infrastructure and feed its people. The development bank said North Korea's application had been referred to its shareholders. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAVCAR, LAWRENCE R.
description: TAVCAR-Lawrence R., 64. A longtime senior public relations executive who was an expert in preparing corporate annual reports, died on August 24 at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital, near his home in Stamford. He managed or was involved in the production of 80 annual reports, sometimes drafting the messages of chief executive officers. Mr. Tavcar was a consultant working from an office in his home since 1990. As a consultant and, earlier, as an account executive, he served such clients as AT&T, Automatic Data Processing, Coca-Cola Bottling, Engelhard, Firestone, H.J. Heinz, McGrawHill, Reader's Digest, Scott Paper, C.I.T. Financial Corporation, and Unilever. In the late 1980's, he was senior director for corporate communications for Paramount Communications, formerly Gulf+Western. From 1978 to 1984, he was a senior vice president of the Carl Byoir & Associates, then the third largest public relations firm in the country. An annual report that he prepared as a consultant to Engelhard received an award from the National Association of Investors Corporation as one of the best from an investor's perspective. ''A masterful job,'' said the judges. Another citation for his work on annual reports, hailed his performance with the comment: ''Of all the talents in the field, none do we respect more than Lawrence R. Tavcar...Not only does he produce good work...but he's one of the industry's true thinkers.''At Paramount, his last corporate position before becoming a consultant, Mr. Tavcar produced six annual reports and was responsible for analyst and annual meeting presentations. The company's reports received awards from ''Institutional Investor'' magazine. He also directed the creation and publication of ONE, the company's quarterly magazine. ''Using spectacular graphics and sheer showmanship,'' the ''Public Relations Handbook'' said, the magazine ''achieves a dazzling impact...as attractive in content as in style.'' He played an instrumental communications role during the company's restructuring from a quintessential conglomerate with farranging operations into an international leader in entertainment (Paramount Pictures) and publishing (Simon & Schuster). Paramount was acquired by Viacom in 1994. As an account executive at Carl Byoir, Mr. Tavcar handled the public relations involved in the recall of the Firestone 500 tire, then the largest product recall in history, an incident that has reverberations in another Firestone recall that is taking place today. Also, early in his career, he conducted some of the research that demonstrated the increasing importance of institutional investors. Thus, when the New York Stock Exchange established its Institutional Investors Department, he was appointed assistant manager. In addition to his specialization in annual reports, Mr. Tavcar during his career managed projects involving corporate magazines, employee information programs, speech writing, and marketing. He won more than 20 awards from professional associations for his work. Mr. Tavcar frequently retained responsibility for the writing end of public relations projects, an activiity often delegated to writing specialists. His writing extended over a broad array of business products, testament to his undergraduate education in journalism and his lifelong appreciation of stellar articles that appeared in newspapers and magazines. Mr. Tavcar was a member of the Public Relations Society of America and served on its honors and awards committee for four years. He also was a member of the National Investor Relations Institute, the International Association of Business Communicators, the Society of Professional Journalists, and the Fairfield County (Conn.) Public Relations Association. He was a former contributing editor of the Corporate Communications Report and the Corporate Annual Report Newsletter and a contributor to many newsletters in the public relations and communications fields. Mr. Tavcar, who was born and raised in Cleveland, maintained a devotion to the Cleveland Browns football team and the Cleveland Indians baseball team through a lifetime spent mostly in the Northeast. He was a graduate of Ohio Universtiy and retained a lifelong loyalty to his alma mater. He served on the board of directors of its national alumni association, as a member of the advisory board to the university's E.W. Scripps School of Journalism, and as president of Ohio University's Greater New York Alumni Chapter. He received two service awards from the university. Mr. Tavcar leaves his wife, Denise, and two sons, Bret of Stamford, and Erik of Arlington, Va. He also leaves four sisters, Francis Tavcar, Dorothy Tavcar, Marge Conetsco, and Pauline Debevec, all of Cleveland, and a brother, Thomas, of Birmingham, Ala. A ceremony celebrating Lawrence Tavcar's life will be held at 6 P.M. on September 23 at the Bruce Museum, 1 Museum Drive, Greenwich. Directions are available from the museum at 203-869-0376. Contributions in memory of Lawrence R. Tavcar may be made to CAP Cure (for the cure of prostate cancer) at 1250 Fourth Street, Suite 360, Santa Monica, CA 90401. Contributions may also be made to the Lawrence R. Tavcar Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Ohio University Foundation, P.O. Box 869, Athens, OH. 45701.

title: China's Dysfunctional Public Relations Barrage
description: As Beijing sees it, the reason China's diplomatic and trade relations with the United States don't always go smoothly starts with unfair American press coverage and hostile politicians in Congress. These forces cause Americans to misunderstand China's efforts to keep ''the motherland'' unified and stable, the thinking goes. Still believing in the efficacy of political propaganda, the Communist Party hopes to change things with the public relations offensive that is currently bringing high-level visitors to the United States: Li Peng, leader of the parliament, and President Jiang Zemin to meetings at the United Nations and Zhao Qizheng, an information minister, to introduce a touring show of exhibits, lectures and events about China.

title: Bush Criticizes Gore's Credibility On the Goals of His Campaign

He graduated from St. John's University and was Captain of the soccer team, and All American Player of the Year. He became a successful realtor and had a wonderful and happy life. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LAWRENCE
description: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-inlaw, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Epstein, she was a YU Guardian and established the Ruth Epstein Scholarship Fund at Stern College. The Stern Board honored her at its inaugural dinner in 1988 for her dedication to the advancement of Jewish education-a legacy she has passed to her four children, all YU alumni. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Martin (and Gloria) Epstein, Gilbert (and Marion) Epstein, Stewart (and Judith) Epstein, and Gloria (and Laurence) Gordon; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Marjorie Diener Blenden, Chairman,SCW Board of Directors

Adored grandfather of Jeffrey and Bryan Wright, and Nicholas and Jonathan Schachter. Dearest brother of Paul Schachter. Loving cousin, uncle, nephew, and friend. Scott was a retired NBC audio engineer and two time Emmy Award recipient for his distinguished work in live television. He delighted in traveling the world with his wife, laughter with his family and friends, and doing The New York Times Crossword Puzzles in ink. Visiting on Saturday, 7-9 pm and service on Sunday at 3pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, DOROTHY
description: KOPPELMAN - Dorothy. The American Jewish Committee is profoundly saddened by the death of a treasured friend and generous benefactor, Dorothy Koppelman. Dorothy and her husband Julius have been longtime members of the AJC family, serving on our national Board of Governors, National Leadership Council, Horizon Society, and national Advisory Board of our Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations, for which they established an endowment in honor of their 50th wedding anniversary. Equally active in her local AJC chapter, she served as a Vice President and Trustee of AJC's Central New Jersey Chapter and was honored in 1995 with their Philip Forman Human Relations Award. A devoted wife to Julius for more than 56 years and a loving mother and grandmother, Dorothy was also an educator who made time to nurture her passion for the well-being of the Jewish people, emphasizing not only Holocaust remembrance but Jewish vitality and identity through learning. She supported, in word and deed, those causes nearest to her heart, and did so with a quiet elegance and grace that were her trademarks. Her legacy of goodness and compassion will long be remembered. We send our deepest condolences to Julius, their four daughters and their families, and all who grieve her passing. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Excutive Director Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: PROFIT AT ATLANTIC COAST AIR TO BE BELOW FORECASTS
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it expected its earnings for the third and fourth quarters to fall short of forecasts, citing the impact of ''adverse publicity surrounding flight cancellations by United Airlines'' and lower bookings in early August. Higher fuel prices and bad weather also hurt earnings, said the company, which is based in Dulles, Va. Atlantic Coast said it expected third-quarter income of 30 cents to 35 cents a share, and 45 cents to 55 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had estimated earnings of 54 cents a share for the third quarter and 64 cents for the fourth quarter.

title: Editorial Observer; The Crisis in Providing Care for the Elderly Ill
description: In Florida, where retirees have been flocking since the 1920's and where 25 percent of the state's population is expected to be over 65 by the year 2010, there are growing feelings of strain and exhaustion among the managers, the nurses and nurses' aides who care for the old and frail. The word most often heard in conversations with elder-care professionals these days is ''crisis.'' With a population calculated to be aging at a rate 20 years ahead of the nation as a whole, the Sunshine State has become a harbinger for a nation growing old and facing problems with long-term care for the aged.

title: CONSECO REACHES ACCORD ON TWO LOAN EXTENSIONS
description: Conseco Inc. said Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bank of America Corporation had agreed to extend until Sept. 22 loans of $155 million and guarantees of $145 million regarding loans to the insurer's directors and officers in connection with a stock purchase program. The company said it was seeking to reschedule about $766 million in bank debt that is maturing this month. The company, based in Carmel, Ind., said last month that it expected to raise $2 billion from asset sales but it would need up to 15 months to do it. Moody's cut Conseco's senior debt rating last month by one notch, to B1, from Ba3, citing uncertainty about how much the company could raise from asset sales. Conseco stock fell 54 cents, or 6 percent, to $8.46 yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAYAS, RICHARD
description: ZAYAS-Richard. Of Brooklyn Heights, NY, left this world on September 8. A graduate of Midwood High School, Brooklyn, and Harvard College, he also attended Harvard Business School and was a management consultant. Formerly served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Empire State Pride Agenda and helped elect the first openly gay member of the New York City Council. Few people enjoyed life as much as Richard. A lover of music, he could dance the night away. A man of great intelligence and charm, he profoundly touched everyone who knew him. Richard is survived by his partner of eight and-a-half years Dick Dadey; his parents, Betsy Padin Jackson and Louis Zayas; his brother, Louis, Jr.; his sister, Melody; his grandmother, Ramonita Detres; and many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. Visitation is on Monday, September 11, from 4-8 PM, at St. Boniface Church, 75 Duffield St, Brooklyn. Funeral mass on Tuesday, September 12, 10 AM, at St. Boniface. Call 212-809-2657 for specific directions and further information about arrangements. Contributions can be made to CallenLorde Health Center, 356 W. 18 St, NY NY 10011.

title: Immortals With Grudges And Endless Back Stories
description: ''The rules have been broken; one of your kind has gone renegade,'' the good guy immortal, Duncan MacLeod (Adrian Paul), of the clan MacLeod, is told in ''Highlander: Endgame.'' The evil immortal, Jacob Kell (Bruce Payne), has gone on a rampage. And such an earthshaking event hasn't transpired on Earth since, well, since the last ''Highlander'' movie, when the evil immortal Kane had to be stopped by good guy Connor MacLeod (Christopher Lambert), of the clan MacLeod. Kell wants to torture Connor for all eternity because Connor killed his father centuries before. (Though, to be fair, Kell and others burned Connor's mother at the stake.)

title: Is Litigation The Best Way To Tame New Technology?
description: ''The growing and dangerous intrusion of this new technology,'' Jack Valenti said, threatens an entire industry's ''economic vitality and future security.'' Mr. Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, was testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, and he was ready for a rhetorical rumble. The new technology, he said, ''is to the American film producer and the American public as the Boston Strangler is to the woman alone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTIVAL, DENISE HENRIETTE SUZANNE
description: ROTIVAL-Denise Henriette Suzanne. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Holt Rotival, their children and grandchildren, The Reverend Denise Rotival Huffman and her children, are saddened to announce the death of their aunt, Madame Denise Rotival. Chevalier du la Legion d'Honneur, Medaille des Forces Francaises Libres, Chevalier de la Sante Publique. Madame Rotival lived a memorable life. Born in Paris April 28th, 1900 she recently celebrated, in Paris, her 100th birthday surrounded by family and friends from both sides of the Atlantic. She came to the United States in 1914 to study at Smith College in North Hampton, Massachusetts, where she received both her Undergraduate and Masters Degrees. Madame Rotival developed life-long family ties with Dr. and Mrs. Hamilton Holt, of Woodstock, Connecticut, including becoming sister-in-law to their daughter Leila Stuart Holt Rotival. During the Second World War, Madame Rotival was the principal advocate and fundraiser in North America for the Free French. A portion of these funds were used for the reconstruction of the hospital in Saint Lo in Normandy. The religious ceremony was Wednesday, September 20th in the Eglise Reformee de Pentemont, 106 Rue de Grenelle, Paris, France.

title: At a U.N. 'Summit,' Lawmakers Urge Stronger Legislative Bodies

description: EDMUNDS-Robert, M.D. Died peacefully September 18, 2000. Born September 14, 1924, Toledo, OH. Graduate Harvard College 1946 and Columbia Univ. College of Physicians and Surgeons 1951. He was a surgeon on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital for 25 years and served on the Faculty of Columbia P&S. He was a fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Member of the N. Y. Surgical Society and N. Y. Academy of Medicine and an Officer of the N. Y. Cancer Society. Subsequent to his private practice, he was a Medical Director for the U. S. Steel Corp. in Chicago and Cleveland. During WWII, he was an officer in the Navy and later served in the Army Medical Corps Reserve retiring as Colonel. He is survived by his five children Nancy Kalal, Priscilla Smith, Elizabeth Bennett, Cynthia Edmunds, Robert Edmunds and four grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 28 at 4PM at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center Chapel, 113 St. between Amsterdam Ave. and Morningside Dr, NYC. title: October Touch Is Back For Yanks' Hernandez
description: Orlando Hernandez induced Cristian Guzman's grounder to Tino Martinez in the first inning, but he started late in covering first base and then stopped running when the ball got to Martinez. But Martinez bobbled the ball, and Hernandez was out of position, about 30 feet from the base. Guzman was safe. Hernandez bowed his head and tapped his hand against his chest, as if to say, ''My bad.''

title: Clinton Handled Military Poorly, Cheney Contends
description: ATLANTA Aug. 30  Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate and former defense secretary, delivered a harsh assessment today of the condition of the armed forces under President Clinton, accusing him of "running down" a military that has succeeded in recent conflicts only because of the military buildup of past Republican administrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LUCILE HALLE
description: YOUNG-Lucile Halle. A native of Cleveland, Ohio; died at the age of 89 on September 1, 2000 after a long illness. She attended Miss Fuller's School in Ossining, NY. She was married to the late Fritz Wolff and the late Lewis B. Young of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert & Co. She began her career in the children's wear department at Jane Engels. Afterwards she started the Infant and Children's Department at Henri Bendel. Lucile was recognized as one of the industry's leading buyers of fine children's clothes until she retired in 1962. She is survived by her daughter Susan W. Spiegel and her husband Andrew of Highland Park, Illinois; and stepdaughter Linda Barnes. Adored grandmother of Sally Spiegel and Jill Spiegel Brozic and her husband Joe of Minneapolis. Stepgrandmother of Andrew and Kimberly and her husband Al and great-stepgrandmother of David Alexander. Friends will be received at 1075 Park Avenue from 6-9PM on Thursday September 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Foundation.

title: In Victory, Venus Williams Is Surprisingly Vulnerable

Usually, they duck well behind the baseline, counting on the distance to increase response time, using the extra space as a cushion against Williams's force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-inlaw, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. title: STANDARD CHARTERED ACQUISITION
description: Continuing a recent buying spree in Asia, where it earns two- thirds of its income, Standard Chartered P.L.C. said it would pay $1.32 billion in cash to buy the Chase Manhattan Corporation's Hong Kong credit card and retail banking division. The acquisition would make Standard Chartered the biggest credit card provider in Hong Kong with one- quarter of the market. The British-based bank said it would finance the acquisition by issuing 50 million new shares at 915 pence and by selling a British subsidiary to Lloyds/TSB for $:627 million. Standard Chartered's shares rose 1 pence, to 955 pence. Alan Cowell

title: GLOBAL CROSSING SHARES UP ON FORECAST OF HIGHER SALES
description: Shares of Global Crossing Ltd. rose as much as 14 percent after the company, a telecommunications provider, raised its forecast for 2000 sales and cash flow. Shares of the company, which owns a worldwide phone and data network, rose $5.06, to $35.13. Global said yesterday after the close of market trading that it expected $5.2 billion in revenue from continuing operations for 2000, up from a previous estimate of $4.84 billion. The company, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, also expects cash flow from continuing operations, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of $1.34 billion, up from a previous estimate of $1.21 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODYEAR, MARY
description: GOODYEAR-Mary. The volunteers and staff of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society wish to express deep sorrow on the passing of Mary Thompson Goodyear, 88, of New Orleans, LA, who died on September 8. Mary Goodyear served as a volunteer for numerous philanthropic and community service groups in New Orleans. Her work with the National MS Society began in 1971 as a member of the National Board of Directors. In 1973, as one of the local founders, she initiated the charter for the Louisiana Chapter of the Society and for 28 years continued to help the Chapter flourish; she was the Chapter's first ever Dinner of Champions honoree last November. She remained steadfastly dedicated to the National MS Society and its work. Her son Charles is presently a member of the National Board of Directors. Mrs. Goodyear is survived by her daughter, Mary Goodyear Glenn; three sons, Charles, David and Andrew; sixteen grandchildren and eighteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on September 30th at 10AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, 1329 Jackson Avenue, New Orleans, LA. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Louisiana Chapter of NMSS. National Multiple Sclerosis Society Richard B. Slifka Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan, General, USAF (Ret) President and CEO

title: Casting Stones at Those Cast in Stone: Where Are the Writers?
description: Public sculpture is a deeply contentious area, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may have recently discovered when he created a ruckus by proposing to install a statue of Frank Sinatra in Times Square. Often the battle lines are drawn between those who favor abstract pieces and those who support more traditional, realistic works. In the summer 1999 issue of City Journal, Francis Morrone, the author of The Architectural Guidebook to New York City, looked at the debate over public monuments and made his own suggestions for commemorative statues for New York City. Excerpts from his article, ''Statues and Civic Memory,'' follow.

title: NEWS CORPORATION BUYBACK
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation may buy back as much as 6.5 percent of its preferred shares, a move that would help the company pay for expansion. It said it would spend as much as $1.5 billion buying back up to 138.2 million shares because it had more cash on hand than it needed. The company has used a mix of cash and stock to finance its global expansion. In buying back the stock, the company may be able to maintain the current value of its preferred shares, making it easier to use them to finance future acquisitions.

title: For Last Dance, Candidates Eye the Wallflower
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 31  Labor Day is the unofficial opening of the general election campaign, but for most voters the race is already over. Strategists on both sides agree that more than 90 percent of the electorate has by now settled on either Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore.

title: Swiftly Channeling a Love Of Abrupt Fragmentation
description: The pianist Orrin Evans creates his sets to leave a lot of room for ad-libbed group interplay, but in his music there is not one single connector between composition and improvisation. There are many: the band is trained to snap back with connective phrases so the listener is kept off balance, wondering about what is undirected and what is premeditated.

title: $300 MILLION TOYOTA OUTLAY IN BRAZIL
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would spend $300 million to triple production of its Corolla passenger model in its main Brazilian factory as demand for cars rises in a growing economy. Toyota aims to increase output of the Corolla at its Indaiatuba plant in Sao Paulo state to 45,000 vehicles a year within two years from 15,000 units now. The investment will create 3,000 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-inlaw, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. title: FIRST UNION TO PURCHASE JWGENESIS FINANCIAL
description: The First Union Corporation agreed to buy the JWGenesis Financial Corporation, a brokerage firm with offices in 34 states, for as much as $110 million to expand in the securities businesses. First Union will pay $10 to $12 a share for JWGenesis, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla. Shares of JWGenesis fell $4.81, to $10.06. First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., is seeking to halt two years of sliding earnings, and has quit the credit card business while expanding securities operations like brokerage, mutual funds and estate planning. Last month it agreed to sell its credit card unit to the MBNA Corporation. It also closed its Money Store Inc. home-equity lending unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFLUG, JOHN RUEGER (JOHNNY)
description: PFLUG-John Rueger (Johnny). One of the last players from the golden age of polo in New York, died September 1,2000 He was 90 years old and lived in Plandome. N.Y. A star athlete at St. Paul's School in Garden City, N.Y. Mr. Pflug was offered a baseball contract by the Brooklyn Dodgers, but chose instead to attend Colgate, where he was an end on the fammous 1932 Red Raiders Football Team, which was undefeated, untied and unscored upon, uninvited to The Rose Bowl that year. Winners of many regattas with his brother Carl in their Star Class sloop ''Wings'' in the early 1930's. The Pflugs were victorious in the trials for the 10th Olympiad in 1932, but decided to return to college, passing up the chance to represent the United States at the Los Angeles games. Polo, however, was John's passion. As a teenager, he and his brother helped win the Junior National Indoor Championship for the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club and later won the National Indoor Polo Championship. He carried an 8 goal handicap and was one of the highest rated active players in the indoor game before the War. Mr. Pflug played for The New York Athletic Club and Squardon A Indoors and Laddie Sandford's Hurricanes among other teams outdoors. Born in Brooklyn on April 10, 1910, he was the youngest son of Dr. Charles J. and Emma R. Pflug. He served as an officer in the Coast Guard during World War II on a landing craft carrier in the Pacific theatre and worked for many years for the Lincoln Savings Bank. He is survived by his sister, Helen Pflug MacKay of Locust Valley, daughters Jane Pflug of Manhattan and Melissa Pflug of Burlington, VT, a son, John R. Pflug of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and a grandson Jock Pflug. Any contributions may be made to Colgate University, Hamilton, N.Y. 13346.

title: Knicks Hire a New Assistant
description: Kevin O'Neill, a college head coach for the past 11 years, has been hired by the Knicks to replace Brendan Malone as an assistant coach on Jeff Van Gundy's staff, General Manager Scott Layden announced yesterday. Malone resigned last month to join the Indiana Pacers' coaching staff. O'Neill, 43, spent the last three years at Northwestern, where he led the Wildcats to a 30-56 record. He has also been the head coach at Tennessee and Marquette. His career record is 190-197.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-in-law, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about low attendance at minor league baseball games in Queens and an article on Aug. 23 about opposition to a Coney Island ballpark referred imprecisely to the cost of a minor league stadium under construction on Staten Island. According to the city's budget for the project, the construction of the stadium, the land purchase and the architectural, engineering and management fees are expected to add up to $53.2 million. Other features, including an esplanade and other site enhancements, put the combined cost for the project above $71 million; that is not the cost for the stadium itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGEN, CHARLES ROBERT
description: HOGEN-Charles Robert, 92. Died on July 16 at his home in Lenox, Massachusetts. His surviving children are Timothy Hogen of New York City, Sherill Covian of Shelburne Falls, MA, Robin Hogen of Westport, CT, Lyn Mason of Seattle, Washington, and Jackson Hogen of Newbury, MA. Charles was born on October 8, 1907, to Fred Neff Hogen and Mae Ladd Hogen in Cleveland, Ohio. He attended Yale University and was on the varsity swim team that set the world record for the 250 yard relay in 1928. He graduated from Yale in 1929 and was active in alumni affairs. With his encouragement, his three sons all graduated from Yale. Upon graduation, Charles' first job was with the Holland American Line as entertainment director for Transatlantic voyages. This was how he met Carolyn Kirtland Hine of Cleveland, whom he married in 1933. In '34 he became an Account Executive for N.W. Ayer in New York City and stayed with this prestigious advertising firm for 38 years. He retired to Peru, Vermont, in 1972, where he enjoyed skiing, golf and his eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on September 30 in Lenox, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mountain Valley Center, (PO Box 310, Londonderry, VT 05148).

He maintained a practice in OB/GYN before entering the Society of Jesus in 1964. He was ordained a priest on June 12, 1969. After ordination he completed an additional residency in psychiatry at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and maintained his practice in New York until his passing. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'' 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Thursday, September 21 and Friday, September 22, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. title: A Summer Chilly Enough To Strain Good Humor; Coolest July Since 1914 and a Breezy, Damp August Keep Swimmers Dry and Whet Thirst for Red Wine
description: If last summer was like a sauna, this summer has been like a plunge into a chilly lake. This summer has made the Top 20 list of cool summers in New York; last summer, by contrast, was the hottest since 1876, when regular weather record-keeping began.

title: Mr. Cheney on Defense
description: Dick Cheney turned up the heat on defense Wednesday with his charge that the Clinton administration had run down the military, leaving it with aging equipment, overextended forces and declining readiness. Those are stinging accusations coming from the man who ran the Pentagon during the Persian Gulf war. But on close examination, many of Mr. Cheney's points seem misleading or exaggerated. America's military forces are the world's strongest and best prepared. To stay that way they must continue adapting to the post-cold-war world, not return to the doctrines and assumptions of a decade or more ago.

title: TELEFONICA PROFIT FALLS
description: The Spanish telecommunications giant Telefonica S.A. reported net profit for the first half of the year at 989 million euros ($881 million), a 3 percent drop from the period in 1999. The company said positive results from its domestic cell phone operations and its international activities helped compensate for weakness in other areas, like traditional services. Earnings from Latin American operations were almost 125 million euros, up 31 percent, reflecting that region's improving economy. On the Madrid bolsa, Telefonica's share prices posted gains of as much as 8.7 percent at the news. Giving in to pressure from the board, Juan Villalonga, the chairman, resigned just over a month ago, ending months of uncertainty over the company's direction. Benjamin Jones

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, MARTIN
description: LANG-Martin. On September 4, 2000. Born January 28, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY. Martin was the devoted husband of Bertha Friedman Lang for 62 years, loving father to Judith Lang Zaimont, Doris Lang Kosloff and Robert David Lang and grandfather to Adam Lang Harris Kosloff, Daniel Max Lang Kosloff, Jordan Scott Berman Lang and Michael Elliot Lang Zamont. In his 40 year career of outstanding service to the City of NY, he served as Commissioner of the Departments of Water Resources, Sanitation, and Park and Recreation, as well as being the first Deputy Administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration. He was the President of the National Water Pollution Control Federation and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering. He became the President of the Management Consultant Division of Camp, Dresser & McKee, consulting worldwide on water quality management. Martin graduated from CCNY (BS) and NYU (MS). He served with distinction in WW II as 2nd Lt. in the Army Engineering Corps, and taught Chemistry at LIU and Engineering Management at CCNY. Among his many awards are CCNY's Townsend Harris Medal in 1973 and the David D. Steinman Medal in 1985. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Association of Kidney Patients, 100 South Ashley Drive, Suite 280, Tampa, Fla. 33602. Services today, September 5 at 12:30 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Employer's English-Only Policy Brings a Settlement of $192,500
description: A St. Louis manufacturer agreed today to pay $192,500 to settle a civil rights suit brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on behalf of eight Hispanic workers who were required to speak only English while on the assembly line. The settlement was the largest involving an English-only policy since the agency began tracking the practice among employers four years ago.

title: MCDERMOTT'S BWX UNIT WINS ENERGY DEPARTMENT WORK
description: McDermott International Inc. said its BWX Technologies Inc. subsidiary, a manager of nuclear sites, and a partner, won a $2.5 billion contract to run the Energy Department's nuclear weapons plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn. BWX and its partner, Bechtel National Inc., will manage the site for five years, starting Nov. 1, the company said. The Oak Ridge plant, which stores nuclear weapons and materials, was previously managed by the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the Energy Department said. McDermott International is a New-Orleans-based company that builds offshore oil platforms and pipelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, DONALD
description: WHYTE-Donald. The New York Philharmonic notes with grief and sadness the death of Donald Whyte, a deeply valued member of the Philharmonic's violin section since 1972. Mr. Whyte's early teachers were Alexander Whyte and Elman Lowe. Prior to joining the Orchestra, Mr. Whyte attended the University of Saskatchewan and Indiana University, where he studied with Josef Gingold. After joining the Philharmonic, he continued his studies with Ivan Galamian and became an active chamber musician, playing with the Gofriller Quartet and the Soho Ensemble. Mr. Whyte was an influential member of various Philharmonic orchestra committees, most recently serving as chairman of the Artistic Committee for several years. He also served as a Philharmonic representative to the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians and was a board member of the Music Assistance Fund, which aids young minority musicians. In addition, Donald Whyte was a successful heart transplant recipient. His love of music and dedication to the Orchestra and fellow musicians will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Noriko, and to his entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Executive Director

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the kidnapping of an American by rebels in the Philippines misstated a comment from a State Department spokesman about the possibility of release negotiations. As the article noted, he said the United States would not ''pay ransom, change policies, release prisoners or make any concessions that reward hostage taking.'' He did not rule out negotiations.

Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-inlaw, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. title: PENTON MEDIA TO BUY UNIT OF FIRST COMMUNICATIONS
description: Penton Media Inc. agreed to buy Professional Trade Shows Inc. from the closely held First Communications Inc. for an undisclosed price to add trade shows aimed at the factory-engineering and maintenance industries. Professional runs 50 regional trade shows in the United States and Mexico. They will complement Web sites and magazines published by Penton, including New Equipment Digest, American Machinist and Material Handling Management. The acquisition is the second that Cleveland-based Penton has announced in three days. Penton wants to have combined trade shows, magazines and Web sites in 11 industries, primarily the Internet and older professions like engineering, Thomas Kemp, the chief executive, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, ROBERT K.
description: O'CONNOR-Robert K. Died on August 22, 2000, in Vero Beach, FL, after a long illness. Born January 13, 1922, in Holyoke, MA, he was a graduate of Amherst College and NYU School of Business. During WWII he was a Navy pilot. After a long career as a stockbroker and securities analyst he retired to Florida from Rowayton, CT. He is survived by his wife, Jean; a son, Douglas O'Connor; a daughter, Judy Gluckstern and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168th St, NY, NY 10032. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 23, at 3 PM, at The United Church of Rowayton, CT.

title: Child Care and Other Traps
description: In the ultimate triumph of family-friendly policies, the white-shoe law firm Chadbourne & Parke has converted a spare office into a nursery for the infant of one of its female partners. Now this mother can visit her baby and still stay on top of what's in her in box. According to a firm press release, when it's time for this mother to feed her baby, she is alerted by an e-mail or a quiet knock on the door from her nanny. The firm has another female partner who works from home a couple of days a week and still another who manages its Moscow office while she is on maternity leave in Washington, D.C. It is receptive to opening more nurseries in its offices as the need arises (imagine the sitcom possibilities).

title: DAEWOO CHARGES POSSIBLE
description: Kim Woo Choong, the former chairman of the Daewoo Group, and as many as 40 executives from the conglomerate may face criminal charges for inflating the asset values of several affiliates, which worsened the assessment of the business group's liabilities, the watchdog Financial Supervisory Commission said. Daewoo Group, which was at one time the second-largest business group in South Korea, is being sold off in pieces to repay debts totaling $79 billion. The state-run watchdog agency said it was considering possible penalties against accounting companies as well. Samuel Len
