title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUROBINER, ALICE
description: TUROBINER-Alice. The worldwide Shaare Zedek family mourns with profound grief and sorrow the passing of a dear friend and benefactor. To everyone who had the good fortune of knowing her, Alice personified the qualities of extraordinary dignity, elegance and grace. Throughout both her professional as well as her personal life, she exemplified the values of integrity and kindness. Ever faithful to Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael, her heart pulsed to the beat of Jerusalem, a city she deeply loved and cared for. Together with her husband Harold, a cherished member of our National Board, the Turobiner's leadership and outstretched hand of friendship benefited so many worthy institutions both in their own community as well as in Israel. The Medical Center had the good fortune to be the beneficiary of their largesse. We will fondly remember Alice's leadership as Vice President of our National Women's Division as well as the ''tight ship'' which she chaired at its Annual Luncheons. Her intelligence, wit and insight greatly benefited the hospital's international Board of Governors on which she served. Through their patronage of the Jesselson Heart Center and the Harry, Judith and Leonard Wilf Woman and Infant Center on ''Charlie's Floor'', the Turobiners have helped to place Shaare Zedek in the forefront of Israel's premier medical centers. Her legacy of charitable endeavors stands as testimony of her commitment to the highest values and ethics of traditional Judaism. Our sincerest condolences to Harold, daughters Carol Finley and Ann Dachs, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: Back to School: Double-Click On Education
description: WHEN students in Bethpage log onto the World Wide Web, they can e-mail questions to featured experts and celebrities, then get the answers posted on their computer screens. Last year, students corresponded with the actor Christopher Reeve, the film director Spike Lee, the television personality Katie Couric and James Watson, president of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

title: Boom Box
description: Yes, TiVo and Replay can gather a great deal of detail about the viewer's program preferences and viewing habits. But do they have the right to sell this information? I think not. The privacy issue has become a very hot topic for Internet-related businesses. I think the same will be true here.

title: Boston Symphony Hall Turns 100 With a Splash
description: A concert and an open house with free performances are two of the events scheduled next month to celebrate the 100th birthday of Symphony Hall in Boston, home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

title: A Welcome to College Freshmen
description: THERE have not been many documented sightings of college students at 8 a.m., but hundreds of them were spotted Monday just inside the entrance to Manhattanville College here at exactly that hour. As you might expect, the occasion was a big one.

title: Stars Come Out In the Kitchen
description: From hairdressers to dog trainers, every profession has its fame specialists. Now, Richard Farnabe of Lotus, the meat-packing district's supper club-of-the-month, is emerging as a chef-to-the-stars -- and he has the writing on the wall to prove it. Since the club opened last June, the owners, David Rabin and Will Regan (of Rex club), along with Jeffrey Jah and Mark Baker (of Buddha Bar), have assiduously escorted various luminaries back to the kitchen, where Mr. Farnabe asks them to autograph a white tile wall with a permanent black Magic Marker. Mr. Farnabe got the idea when working at Daniel, where celebrity autographs are collected in a gold book. ''So, when we opened Lotus, I decided to invite celebrities to sign my wall,'' he said. ''I wanted to create a memory, for not just the crew and the restaurant staff, but for the kitchen itself.'' So far, the list includes Elle MacPherson, Mick Jagger, Serena Williams and Giorgio Armani. Mr. Farnabe says he can fit about a hundred more names on the wall, then he plans to preserve it with a large sheet of glass. Mr. Farnabe's own signature? A paupiette of John Dory fish with foie gras and chanterelles in a spicy sherry reduction. ELLEN TIEN

A longtime independent art dealer and interior designer, she earned a B.S. from Columbia University School of Business. Survived by niece Alexandra Scourby Mackler, great-niece Amanda Mackler, numerous loving cousins, nieces, nephews, and devoted friends who will miss her vast wisdom and humor. Predeceased by sister Mary and brothers Nicholas and Alexander Scourby. Visitation Tuesday, 24 PM and 7-9 PM, at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue. title: Sermin Meskill, Beau Higgins
description: Dr. Lynn Sermin Meskill and Mirabeau Buonaparte Lamar Higgins are to be married today in the Princes Islands in Turkey. Aynur Alyanak, a civil marriage celebrant, will officiate at the Ocean Club in Buyukada.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00: Questions for Tim Draper; Capital Suggestion
description: Q: You made a fortune financing start-up firms like Hotmail. Now you're plunking down $20 million of your money to support a November ballot measure that would give all California schoolkids a $4,000 voucher to use at the school of their choice. That's $20 million just to support the initiative, not to build new schools or anything. Why?

title: Boom Box
description: As a producer of television programs, a former advertising executive, a television viewer and consumer, I read Lewis's article with great interest. It may be a huge wake-up call to everyone in the business, but the picture he painted is just the tip of the iceberg. Although he balanced the ''official'' party line (that new black boxes will merely enable the current rulers to make television an even better place) with ''reality'' (that 88 percent of commercials in programs seen by viewers on their black boxes go unwatched), I know that this ''fringe technology'' is just the beginning of a complete overhaul in the way consumers will receive and perceive entertainment.

title: Wagner's Latest Opera
description: To get any more involved in the battles at Bayreuth, the German theater that Wagner built for his operas only, Alberto W. Vilar would have to grab a sword, jump on stage and give young Siegfried a hand. Wielding a checkbook instead, Mr. Vilar, who runs the Amerindo mutual fund firm, has come to the aid of Wolfgang Wagner, the composer's 80-year-old grandson and long the director of the Wagner Festival. Mr. Wagner would like to install his second wife, Gudrun, as director and retain a major role. But his niece, Nike Wagner, has recruited her own powerful allies to oust him.

title: Fall Reading, From Head To Toe
description: MANOLO BLAHNIK says that the secret to toe cleavage, which he describes as a ''very important part of the sexuality of the shoe'' in ''Manolo Blahnik'' (Harper Collins, this month) by Colin McDowell, is in showing only ''the first two cracks.'' While I don't own a pair of Mr. Blahnik's famous pointy shoes, I know exactly what he means. There's something a little vulgar, a little splayed-looking, about a shod foot with more than three toes exposed.

title: SOAPBOX; At Grandma's Bed and Breakfast
description: WHEN our three grandchildren were small they used to cry every time we left after our visits to them in Maine. They all asked us if we could buy a house near them, so that we could visit more often and stay longer. At that time, we couldn't do this, because my husband and I were still part of the work force. It used to break my heart to hear them cry and beg, as we pulled out of their driveway, and I usually was teary eyed all the way home.

title: Lots of Style, Carefully Prepared Dishes
description: INFERNO in Westport is kin to the restaurant of the same name in Greenwich, but not an identical twin in decor or food. In limited space, Inferno has created a sense of edginess, with paprika- and avocado-painted walls, a water wall that picks up the metallic glints of a copper-faced oven and chimney in the open kitchen, high ceiling, silvery tables and a concrete floor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REFALO, WILLIAM J.
description: REFALO-William J. September 3, 1930-August 5, 1999. Happy Birthday, Dad. I miss you every day. Marilyn

title: Table Tourism
description: IN 1996 the service at Mojave Grill was described in a review as ''in training.'' It's 2000 now, and I wonder if those who graduated from learning the ropes have moved on. Because while shaky service may have been excusable back then, at this stage of the game it is a distracting affront.

title: An Art World Figure Re-emerges, Unrepentant
description: In 1971, Philip Leider, the founding editor of Artforum, walked away at the magazine's peak of influence. During his almost 30-year disengagement from an art world that grew up during the same period, Mr. Leider never spoke publicly about his Artforum years, nor did he agree to be interviewed about them. His involvement with ''Challenging Art: Artforum 1962-1974,'' a book coming out this month from Soho Press, parallels a resumption of his writing in American art periodicals. In 1994, he began a dialogue with the book's author, Amy Newman, a former editor of Artnews. Following are excerpts from a recent conversation about the professional decisions he has made and about his views of contemporary art.

title: What Are the Alternatives to Zero-Tolerance Discipline Policies?
description: EDUCATORS and psychologists agree that after such tragedies as the slayings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., it will be some time before the fear subsides in this country and the pendulum swings back -- even a bit -- to more permissive policies in the schools.

title: Feel a Cold Wind?
description: Begin to pot herbs for winter use: take divisions of chives and mint, and cuttings of woody herbs like rosemary and lemon verbena. If tender plants have outgrown their containers, replant in pots a size or two larger. Use the same type of potting mix. To keep the plant in the same pot, you can carefully trim roots by as much as 25 percent.

title: The Romance Of Remorse
description: Near the end of Emmylou Harris's show at the Birchmere Theater just outside Washington in May, a big black dog -- part poodle, part who knows -- bounds onstage, tail wagging. He finds his mistress standing between Buddy Miller, the nonmainstream country-music star, and the drummer-bassist Daryl Johnson. In an off-white dress and with her white hair shining, Harris looks, as she always does, like Someone. She can't help looking like Someone. Or if she can, she doesn't want to. She's tall and vivid and glamorous, but she also emanates a nearly religious modesty, and when she's not onstage, the combination makes people want to stare at her and try not to. It's a neat (possibly unconscious) trick: the ability to encourage admiration while appearing humbled by it.

title: Beating the Market, Until the Expenses Pile Up
description: IT first blush, the current issue of The Journal of Finance contains good news for the mutual fund industry, and from a most unlikely source: an academic study.

title: This Is Not Your Father's Agricultural School
description: AMID the recognition that basketball has brought the University of Connecticut, as the women's team, then the men's, then the women again won a national championship, it is easy to forget that at its core, UConn is an agricultural school: cows, pigs, chickens, sheep, the whole barnyard.

title: Turnaround in Texas: Two Teams Plunge
description: A certain Texas officeholder who is a candidate for office elsewhere has to hope that he will fare better in his race than the state's two major league baseball teams have this year in theirs.

title: Gambill Plays It Cool to Hold Off Philippoussis
description: The slingshot serve from the hulking Mark Philippoussis crashed into the top of the net, ricocheting into the air on a flight as unpredictable as paper airplane's. But with whipsaw reflexes, and a little luck, a wide-eyed Jan-Michael Gambill managed to leapfrog the wayward serve as it headed toward his body on the fly.

title: Eh, Get a Horse
description: It was a tough week for the Ford Motor Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, CARL E.
description: OLSON-Carl E. Thelen Reid & Priest LLP, mourns the loss of a friend and colleague. Carl joined the former Reid & Priest during WWII and then served in the US Army. Upon his return, he rejoined Reid & Priest and was elected partner. Carl was highly regarded by his peers for his excellent lawyering and drafting skills. He was a leading figure in the firm's Latin America practice, especially in dealing with electric facilities in Latin America. Carl was a person of great integrity and personable character. We extend our most sincere sympathy to his wife Ila Olson and family members.

title: Found: Hideaway Spas
description: Tracie Martyn, a facialist whose mild, electric ''noninvasive face-lift'' technique is sought by Susan Sarandon, Donna Karan and many models, opened on lower Fifth Avenue almost a year ago. The spa's phone number is unlisted, and the only sign of its existence is a buzzer that reads ''T. Martyn.'' The rooms, designed to feel like a cozy apartment, are never frequented by more than two clients at a time. Tracie Martyn is one of a handful of secluded salons around town that are run more like exclusive supper clubs. They are known only to fashion insiders and celebrities who value attractions like no six-month waiting lists and plenty of privacy.

title: The World; Making a Dent in the Demand for Illegal Drugs
description: WHEN Andres Pastrana, the president of Colombia, said last week that the key to winning the war against drugs was taming demand in the United States, he ruffled some American feathers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ALWAYS BEGINNING

title: No Headline
Up-to-Speed Artistry From a Three-Car Atelier
description: IN the still of the night, Marvin Shivnarain paints pictures on automobiles.

title: Glenn Miller
description: To The Editor: You featured an article about a famous musician from Iowa, Meredith Willson (''Out on the Prairie, a Real River City'' July 2). However, another great musician was also born in Iowa, Glenn Miller. His birthplace in Clarinda is now a museum, and every year on the second weekend of June the birthplace society sponsors a Glenn Miller Festival.

title: Safeties Off
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Women Win
description: Nell Fortner, the coach of the United States women's basketball team, told her players that yesterday's tuneup against Brazil in Honolulu could be an Olympic semifinal preview.

title: Lawyers for Ecuador Indians See U.S. Judge Linked to Texaco
description: A federal judge who for four years has been considering whether to hear a lawsuit filed against Texaco by Ecuadorean Indians who say the oil company polluted their lands attended an expenses-paid seminar on environmental issues held by a foundation receiving regular donations from the company, according to federal judicial and tax documents obtained by the Indians' lawyers. A former chief executive of Texaco spoke at the conference.

title: The Hudson, After Years of Cleanup, Lures Swimmers
description: So much sewage floated in the Hudson River in the 1950's that Shabazz Jackson and his friends made up their own version of the breast stroke when they swam along the shore in Beacon, N.Y. They would jump in feet first, then flail their arms to push the stinking mess away from their faces.

title: Toyota Camry Solara SLE convertible; Grown-Up Fun in the Sun, Set to an Easy-Listening Beat
description: TOYOTA is a very successful automaker, of course, and it got that way by making its brand synonymous with dependability.

title: Teaching the Fourth 'R': A Sense of Reality
description: THEY'RE teaching ancient Greek in Riverhead and Chinese in Great Neck. Jericho High School students enroll in an emergency medical technician class. In Syosset, middle-school students are learning how to get rich; in Eastport, elementary-school students are learning how to be virtuous.

title: Maria Celis, Vincent Jeanseaume
description: Maria Elena Celis, the daughter of Dr. Ellen Celis and Dr. Godofredo Celis of Concord, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Vincent Jeanseaume, a son of Marcelle Jeanseaume of La Ciotat, France, and the late Gilbert Jeanseaume. The Rev. Joseph O'Meara performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Rosary in Manhattan.

title: Battle Lines Harden Over Syosset Mall
description: THE six-year battle over an upscale shopping mall in Syosset will draw a little closer to a resolution on Thursday when the Oyster Bay Town Board holds a public hearing on the proposal. The developer, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is asking for a special-use permit to build the 860,000-square-foot project, to be called the Mall at Oyster Bay, on the 39-acre site formerly owned by the Cerro Wire and Cable Company.

title: Nebraska Cornhusker Fans Rush to Cyberspace for Football Fix
description: Nebraska Cornhusker Fans Rush to Cyberspace for Football Fix

title: Ideas & Trends; Most Presidents Had a Counselor. One Had a Shrink.
description: THE only president whose wild mood swings prompted his own secretary of defense to issue orders designed to block him if he called out the Marines for protection against impeachment is also the only president known to have been treated by a psychotherapist.

title: Near Beijing, Three Bears Find Rescue And Refuge
description: For years, the woman heard the moaning of animals. Finally last month she could not stand it any more.

title: Bumper Crop From the Middle Ground
description: ONE of these days, or years, advocates of small-capitalization stocks will be right. One day, the market will again recognize -- and reward -- them as fast-growing companies.

title: OPINION; No Consensus on Future of Power
description: IN addition to great wine, farm products and seafood, Long Island will soon be known for another export, electricity. Approximately 20 generating plants are being proposed for various locations around the Island. If approved by Governor Pataki, the state Department of Environmental Conservation, Chairman Richard Kessel of the Long Island Power Authority, local politicians and others, these plants will imperil our health, safety and quality of life.

title: Growing Frustration in the Computer Aisle
description: MARIA ORTIZ-TABONE has walked out of a half-dozen computer stores empty-handed, qualifying her as either a very cautious shopper or a very frustrated one. Ms. Ortiz-Tabone, a 50-year-old real estate broker, insists she is the latter.

title: Ikea Sues Mamaroneck Over Right of Review
description: Ikea, which wants to build a furniture store in New Rochelle, has filed suit against the town of Mamaroneck, seeking to invalidate a law passed in April that the Town Board claims gives it the right to review major projects on its borders. The city of New Rochelle has already challenged the constitutionality of Mamaroneck's law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, VINCENT D.
description: JOYCE-Vincent D. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent D. Joyce, associated with the Times from 1946 until retiring in 1975.

title: PAROLE DELAYS
description: While the New Jersey Parole Board struggles with its backlog of cases, lawyers for inmates and the Attorney General's office told a federal judge in Camden Wednesday that they were prepared to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of prisoners who have become eligible for parole but not given the hearings required by law. Elaine G. Selan, a prison-rights advocate who has been a liaison between the plaintiffs and their lawyers, said the issue remaining was whether and how the state would pay damages. Laura Mansnerus

title: Monday Night Football's Hail Mary
description: Last spring, newspapers across the country were publishing articles almost daily about ABC's search for a new ''Monday Night Football'' announcer to join the veteran Al Michaels in the broadcast booth. With the N.B.A. playoffs in full swing and kickoff still four months away, this kind of publicity would have ordinarily been a testament to the strength and power of the N.F.L. and its top-rated weekly telecast. But, as the N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, knew too well, exactly the opposite was true.

title: Temps, Unite
description: The labor movement has long been eager to unionize temp workers because they are such a fast-growing group and because they often receive inferior pay and benefits. But for years they were off limits because they were not allowed to join unions unless the user company and temp agency agreed -- something that rarely happened. The National Labor Relations Board opened the door to forming such unions by ruling that they no longer needed the temp agency's permission to do so. Steven Greenhouse

title: Choy Works on Display
description: Katherine Choy was an innovative potter whose work showed the Oriental influence of Hong Kong, where she was born and raised until her teenage years, as well as the experimental and abstract art forms that were just beginning to be explored by potters in the United States in the late 1950's.

title: In Praise of the President, Lieberman Is Unabashed Where Gore Is Reticent
description: The candidate praises President Clinton's ''extraordinary record,'' crediting the president for the muscular economy. He tells audiences that Mr. Clinton has fought crime. He reminds people that he has been the president's friend for 30 years.

title: Personal Business; How Debit Cards Can Burn Holes in Student Pockets
description: TO avoid sending their children off to college with a financial time bomb -- a credit card -- in their pockets, many parents have begun telling them to carry a debit card instead. But though its pitfalls are not as well known, this substitute can be just as dangerous to a student's finances and credit rating.

title: Sports of The Times; For Jocks, Where Is the Dignity?
description: TUCK in your shirt. That's what our moms always told us, but what did they know? Now, there is a great international shirt-raising movement.

title: The French and Corsica
description: A plan by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France to give limited self-rule to the island of Corsica has caused turmoil in France's political class and led Interior Minister Jean Pierre Chevenement to resign in protest.

title: A Truck Stop in Rye
description: If you have a toddler who adores trucks, you're going to love the ''Wheels Go 'Round'' fund-raiser for the Rye Free Reading Room on Sept. 24.

title: The View From/Norfolk; In Elegance and Wit, Friendship for the Ages
description: FOR more than a half-century, James Laughlin and Brendan Gill presided over the literary life of Norfolk, a small but sophisticated hilltop town where Mark Twain once summered and Yale University established a music school.

title: Cherished Drawings Keep Landscapes Alive
description: GARDEN historians often refer to the first third of the 20th century as a Golden Age in the history of American garden design. It was a time when wealthy people, their tastes honed by travel, had both the capital and the confidence to commission elaborate landscapes to match their magnificent homes. In New Jersey and elsewhere in the tristate area, some of the best of those gardens were designed by Ethelbert Furlong (1894-1993), a landscape architect with an unusual name and a singular career, spanning over 60 years.

title: Are School Vouchers the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Avalon XLS; How Do You Say 'LeSabre' in Japanese?
description: IN the 1970's, Japan's automakers made a name for themselves in the United States with small cars that were reasonably priced, economical to own and fun to drive. Detroit sold small cars in those days -- Chevy Vega owners, please stand up -- but its heart wasn't really in it.

title: Grit vs. Glamour On 14th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Suggestions for Mounting Dry Wallboard
description: BEFORE the introduction of gypsum wallboard, interior walls were finished with plaster. Wallboard is essentially a flat sheet of plaster sandwiched between sheets of special paper. Unlike plaster, wallboard is fastened to the studs in a dry state, and for this reason it is frequently called drywall. (It is also sometimes called Sheetrock, but this is a trade name of the USG Corporation and should only be used in reference to its product.)

title: Kael's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Spano's Tax-Cut Goal Questioned
description: WHEN Andrew J. Spano became the second Democrat ever to be elected county executive in Westchester, he did it partly with a pledge to reduce county property taxes by 15 percent.

title: Becoming Fed Up With Zero Tolerance
description: PLAYING mumbletypeg. Whittling a slingshot. Taunting a playground rival. Flinging a paper wad.

title: Some Little-Known Artists Add An Air of Optimism to Exhibition
description: THE co-curators of the New Jersey Fine Arts Annual the Newark Museum's curator of American art, Joseph Jacobs, and the artist Fred Wilson -- have not just adopted the new millennium into the subtitle of their exhibition at the museum here. They've started the new era in an appropriately forward-looking way by representing the state's creative ferment in the present.

title: Emergency Surgery for Big Baby
description: I WATCHED as the door snapped shut behind my wife. She was gone, on her way to an extra-long shift at work, leaving me in charge of our 3-year-old daughter for the next 14 hours. Not that I was sweating it. After all, when it comes to fatherhood, I am as modern as a nanny-cam. Just call me Mr. Dedication, Mr.-Put-in-the-Time, Mr. . . .

title: NEW ROCHELLE: OLYMPIC SWIMMER TO HEAD TEAM
description: Cristina Teuscher of New Rochelle was recently elected one of three co-captains of the United States Women's Olympic Swimming team at its Pasadena, Calif., training headquarters. ''It's an honor,'' Teuscher, who won the 200-meter individual medley at the Trials, said by phone. Jenny Thompson and Lindsay Benko are the other co-captains. Teuscher may also swim in the 800-meter freestyle relay, in which she won a gold medal at Atlanta in 1996. Chuck Slater

title: Loss of Focus
description: With Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario by her side, 43-year-old Martina Navratilova was putting away the young tandem of Jennifer Capriati and Anna Kournikova last night when she realized her skills have not left her, just her memory.

title: The Jewish Wars
description: JEW VS. JEW The Struggle for the Soul of American Jewry. By Samuel G. Freedman. 397 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: Taking After His Father, Sort Of
description: HOWARD G. BUFFETT, the 45-year-old son of Warren E. Buffett, does not spend his days surveying stock charts or analyzing corporate growth prospects. He surveys cornfields from the cab of his John Deere tractor.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Q & A
description: The Joan of Arc Tower

title: When Innocence Died At the Olympics
description: IF the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich had ended on its 10th day, it would have been remembered for Olga Korbut's pixieish dance along the balance beam or Mark Spitz's record run of seven gold medals in swimming. These were to be the Games of peace and camaraderie -- a democratic West Germany's rebuke to Nazism and to Adolf Hitler's fraudulent quest to use the 1936 Berlin Summer Games as a showcase for Aryan physical superiority.

title: HOVNANIAN ACQUISITION
description: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. of Red Bank, the largest home builder in New Jersey, and a developer based in Landover, Md., announced last week that they planned to merge.

title: Writing for a Different Kind of Union Label
description: LAST month, just in time for Labor Day, I did something I haven't done since working my way through college as a doorman. I joined a union.

title: SMOKING BAN
description: A Superior Court judge last week overturned a no-smoking ordinance that essentially banned smoking indoors in Princeton Township and Princeton Borough, ruling that the restriction went beyond what municipal officials are allowed to do.

title: Marin Connor, Andrew Smith
description: Marin Parker Connor, a daughter of Susan Scholle Connor and John T. Connor Jr. of Lake Wales, Fla., was married yesterday to Andrew Alasdair Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Smith of St. Andrews, Scotland. The Rev. Richard Wendel, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in Chicago.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE; Beetles Infesting Its Shade Trees Add to Historic Church's Problems
description: For 50 years, a bronze bust of Peter Stuyvesant, an early leader of New Amsterdam, has sat stoically beneath the boughs of a Norway maple tree in the cemetery at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery. But on Wednesday, the tree was cut down and Stuyvesant's green face, suddenly awash in sunlight, bore an uncanny expression of concern. He was definitely not alone.

title: The Plan for Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Boom Box
description: I've been thinking about buying a Replay or a TiVo. But after reading Michael Lewis's article (Aug. 13), I've decided to wait until someone invents a complementary and equally subversive device -- one that prevents Replay and TiVo from packaging my viewing habits for resale. Why pay to be spied on? I'd sooner let some network suit go through my trash.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Rising Tide, but Some Boats Rise Higher Than Others
description: FOR the labor movement, Public Enemy No. 1 has long been the nation's growing income gap. John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, frequently complains in speeches that the economic boom under Mr. Clinton has left millions of hard-working Americans behind and that corporate chieftains have rewarded themselves richly while downsizing their work forces and clamping down on wages.

title: INVESTING WITH: Edward B. White; GW & K Equity Fund
description: EDWARD B. WHITE is passionate about his golf game. ''Hitting a tiny ball one-eighth of a mile and having it land where you want takes incredible skill,'' Mr. White said. With a handicap of 12, he is no Tiger Woods. ''If I weren't so busy managing money,'' he said of his time-consuming job running the $91.7 million GW & K Equity fund, ''I could get it down to a 4 or 5.''

title: Which Burner?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE
description: Last week, as the United States Open kicked off in Queens, tennis players in Leif Ericson Park rallied around a lesser-known group of courts that the city may make into a roller hockey rink. Proponents say the park's 10 courts are underused, but tennis supporters say they are often full to capacity.

title: Not Quite All-American, Bertelsmann Is Big on U.S.
description: Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann A.G., the media conglomerate, would like to make one thing clear: Bertelsmann is no longer a German company. ''We are really the most global media company,'' he says, with its BMG music unit and Random House based in the United States.

title: Remembering 'Jonah'
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Residents Split Over Civil Unions Law
description: Signs in Vermont are usually sweet: ''Maple Syrup,'' ''Farm Fresh Eggs,'' ''Country Crafts.'' But travelers over the state's winding roads at this summer's end are likelier to encounter signs proclaiming anger, backlash made visible: plain square black-on-white placards, thousands of them, on barns and garages and front porches, declaring ''Take Back Vermont.''

title: For Ethiopians in Morningside Heights, Coffee and Advice
description: TRAVEL posters depicting sun-baked stone castles and obelisks of the ancient holy city of Axum decorate the walls. Nearby are shelves of books that include histories of Ethiopia and the United States, symbolizing the former and new lives of a growing immigrant group in the city.

title: Chef Brings a Taste of the World to Island
description: FRANK COE is a French-trained Irish chef from Cork whose mother was a pastry chef in Lyon. He learned his craft in the kitchens of France, England, Singapore and Australia. Seven years ago he came to this country and was a line chef at Daniel and Le Bernardin before becoming the kitchen commander at Druid's, a Hell's Kitchen hangout where the city's great chefs often gather after their restaurants close.

title: Lauren Eichler, Jonathan Berkun
description: Lauren Elizabeth Eichler, the daughter of Anita and Stephen Eichler of Chevy Chase, Md., and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., is to be married today to Jonathan Wener Berkun, the son of Flora Berkun and Rabbi Alvin K. Berkun of Pittsburgh. The bridegroom's father will perform the ceremony at Congregation Adas Israel in Washington.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: For 20 years Lindblad Expeditions has been guiding travelers on small ships in their exploration of the world, including Alaska.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for ELIZABETH WARREN; Bankruptcy Borne of Misfortune, Not Excess
description: A DECADE ago, in a widely praised analysis of bankruptcy filings, three scholars destroyed the myth that most of those seeking refuge from creditors were blue-collar workers. People in every occupation go bankrupt in rough proportion to their numbers, they found.

title: Political Briefing; Tough Ad Campaign Takes on the Favorite
description: Gov. Gary Locke of Washington, a Democrat, is favored to win a second term this fall whatever the outcome of the Republican primary next Saturday. But Republicans haven't surrendered yet, anything but.

title: Wish You Were There?
description: The postcard print, a colorful travelogue fabric for dresses and skirts, was the whimsical motif of summer. Its strips of postcards circle international monuments in cities like Montreal and Hong Kong, where the designs come from. The most popular depicts St. Peter's Basilica, with Swiss Guards and a papal coat of arms, surrounded by a colonnade of postcards. It was worn for day and evening. The fabric and colors recall dress prints by Marcel Vertes and Christian Berard that Schiaparelli popularized before World War II, worn here throughout the war. This summer, they seemed to be saying, ''Having a marvelous time.''

title: Diaper Bags, Downsized
description: First, the handbag was minified in the form of baguettes and lipstick totes; now, it's the diaper bag's turn. This summer, chic moms have eschewed giant family-size carryalls for self-improvised carry-somes, switching to pared-down pocketbooks with just enough room to hold one or two diapers, a travel-packet of baby wipes and a tube of diaper balm. Presto, change-o -- the diaper baguette! ''City mothers don't want to be weighed down,'' said Fran D'Ambrosio, owner of the 57 Bank Street boutique in Southhampton, N.Y., where the store's embellished straw mini-bag ($64) sold out all summer to beach mothers, and whose beaded baguettes are serving the same purpose for fall. ''Moms are realizing they don't have to lug around the contents of the entire nursery. Now, they pack only the necessities.'' Other popular choices: LeSportsac's reversible zip-up Kiki bag (seen on the shoulders of celebrity mothers like Andie MacDowell and Christie Brinkley -- $55 to $68 at all LeSportsac stores), and Frederic Fekkai's Clementine bag in pastel wools for fall ($480 at Saks Fifth Avenue). For mothers who can't go quite that minimalist, Belly Basics has a drawstring backpack in black or green nylon ($86 at Bloomingdale's and bellybasics .com), with bottle pockets and changing pad -- so you don't have to use your Prada raincoat. ELLEN TIEN

title: Wanderlust
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth certainly touched my heart in ''Home, When the Heart Is Elsewhere'' (July 23). She writes about the ''sly, mysterious and dazzling impulse'' to travel. The German language has a word for it -- fernweh, the exact opposite of heimweh, or homesickness -- and I am smitten with it. I am happy on returning from a trip only when I find a reason to plan the next one.

title: Staten Island Resident Becomes 8th in City With West Nile Virus
description: New York City health officials said yesterday that a 53-year-old Staten Island woman had become infected with the West Nile virus, the eighth victim in the city this year.

title: 'I'd Love to, but I'll Be in Bora-Bora . . .'
description: THERE is one travel perk that no one talks about. Among the various acceptable reasons for taking a trip -- business, family obligation, vacation, spiritual growth -- is a compelling, seldom acknowledged motive: having the world's most perfect excuse at your fingertips. Travel can get you out of virtually anything.

title: A Feeble Croatia Is Battling Its Ex-Leaders
description: The first seven months in power have been sobering for President Stipe Mesic.

title: Immigrant Influx in Nevada
description: By one measure, at least, the future of America seems to be at the gambling table. The Census Bureau estimated that jobs in Las Vegas lured so many people that Nevada grew the fastest of any state in the 1990's, with its population rising 50 percent. Many of those pouring in to build or staff casinos and hotels were Hispanics and Asians, the nation's fastest-growing minority groups. California, though, still has the largest Hispanic population -- 10.4 million, up 36 percent in a decade. Hubert B. Herring

title: The View From the Exact Center of the Universe
description: NEW YORKERS love to wear black for every occasion, but only until something darker comes along. New Yorkers do not socialize with their co-workers and have nothing but disdain for those who do. (If a New Yorker offers a colleague an extra Jets ticket, that colleague may not recognize the offer as a social invitation. He or she may take the ticket and sell it for a considerable profit.) And let it not be forgotten: New Yorkers are arrogant. As Marsha Bickner, a brittle television talk show producer played by Christine Baranski, says to a new employee from the Midwest: ''This is darling, Jim. You're trying to spar verbally with a New Yorker.''

title: Enough Chowder to Swim In
description: FISHIEST of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserves its name; for the pots there were always boiling chowder,'' reports Ishmael, the sea-faring narrator in 'Moby Dick'. ''Chowder for breakfast, chowder for dinner, chowder for supper, till you began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes.''

title: Food; Reality Bites
description: In the shadow of the culinary dogma that dominates how we eat, a revolution is springing up. Little food -- small dishes meant for nibbling -- is starting to threaten, even usurp, the traditional order of courses.

title: Fight Over Fire Siren in Thornwood
description: SEVERAL months after they settled into their new home in this hamlet of Mount Pleasant, Verusha and Michael Raguso first heard the noise: a sustained, primal wail blaring from a siren mounted on a utility pole on the corner of their property.

title: Are School Vouchers the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries begin arriving today for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: Jennifer Tseng, Marc Sabatine
description: Dr. Jennifer Fan-Yu Tseng and Dr. Marc Steven Sabatine, physicians at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. George S. Salzman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Memorial Church.

title: Burma Leader Forced Home; Standoff Ends
description: In a sudden midnight raid, nearly 200 riot police surrounded the car where Myanmar's pro-democracy leader had been stranded by the roadside for a week and forced her and her companions to return home, one of her aides said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIBER, LEOPOLD, M.D.
description: SCHEIBER - Leopold, M.D. (1914-2000) Dr. Leopold Scheiber, a physician, specializing in surgery and urology, was a native of Budapest, Hungary. He had practiced medicine in Budapest and for decades in New York. He died in Budapest on August 7, 2000, a few days after his arrival there on a visit, where he was buried. Dr. Scheiber was from a famous family of rabbis, he was the devoted brother of the legendary scholar, Professor Alexander Scheiber, the former Director of the Jewish Theological Seminary of Hungary. He survived the Holocaust physically, but in his thoughts and feelings he remained a victim. He could never forget witnessing the murder of his mother and friends by Hungarian Nazis in the last days of the war in Budapest. Dr. Scheiber devoted his life, energy, talent and industry to the healing profession, he practiced as a full time physician until his stroke in January 2000. Dr. Scheiber was a philanthropist for many Jewish causes, and a lover of music and the arts. He is mourned by his niece, Doctor Maria Scheiber and her family in Budapest, Hungary, and by numerous friends, relatives and patients in New York, Israel and elsewhere.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Roslyn Bancorp Sells Its Mortgage Subsidiary

title: Habitats/Astoria, Queens; Accident and a Broker's Sacrifice Help Buy a House
description: DONNA WILLIAMS and Michael Lynch love their new house, the first they've ever owned. But if not for an elevator accident, and a real estate broker willing to sacrifice part of his commission to make a sale, the house might never have been theirs.

title: A Philadelphia View
description: To the Editor:

title: Notion of Tax for Super-Rich Hits With a Thud in Trenton
description: Jon J. Shure knows when he's got an idea that absolutely no one in politics is going to take seriously.

title: If It Tries To Escape, Eat It
description: I CAN see it now: killer bamboo marches across Central Park. That was my first reaction when I heard that the Horticultural Society of New York is holding a festival this month, with the American Bamboo Society, that actually encourages people to grow this plant.

title: Ask an American
description: To the Editor:

title: Boom Box
description: In 1985, VCR's were difficult to program, but today's machines can be operated by anyone who can read. And they have this nifty ''fast forward'' button (which, on many models, becomes faster forward when pushed twice) that enables the user to -- ta dah! -- skip the commercials.

title: A Lieberman Asset
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Acid Tongue in Cheek
description: The Bush campaign has dissolved into a whiny puddle. The Austin team put out a press release Friday bawling that Joe Lieberman was a big meanie to compare Governor Bush to Barney Rubble.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: IRON SHOES

title: Two Power Plays By Shakespeare, One Ralph Fiennes
description: IT is almost a rite of passage for promising Shakespearean actors to play ''Hamlet.'' More than most, though, Ralph Fiennes seemed made for the part. Onstage with the Royal Shakespeare Company in a variety of other roles and on screen as the Nazi camp commander in ''Schindler's List,'' he had displayed an intense introspection, a sort of irritable melancholy, that well suited the role of the gloomy Dane. Indeed, when the time came, his ''Hamlet'' was duly acclaimed in London and in New York, where he won a Tony Award for best actor in 1995.

title: Kathryn Nicita, Jonathan Shepherd
description: Kathryn Helen Nicita, a daughter of Helen and William F. Nicita of Brunswick, Me., was married yesterday to Jonathan Choate Shepherd, the son of Joan and Robert Shepherd, also of Brunswick. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery officiated at the Episcopal Church of St. James in Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Luccock, a great-uncle of the bride and a United Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Papa Roach at Stone Pony
description: If you like the sound of Papa Roach's single ''Last Resort,'' you'll probably enjoy the band's debut album, ''Infest,'' and their live performance, which maintains the same sledgehammer energy.

title: Vegetables, Grilled and in Salads, Take on Different Guises
description: BY the time summer ends some people get tired of corn, tomatoes, eggplant, zucchini and beets. I'm not one of them. But I do like to prepare them in less predictable ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, SCOTT A.
description: SCHACHTER-Scott A. 74, of Levittown, NY, died suddenly on August 31, 2000. Beloved and devoted husband of Justine, for 51 years. Cherished father of Linda Wright, Barbara Costa, Peter Schachter and David Schachter. Treasured father-in-law of Robert Wright, Antonia Schachter and Scott Hunt. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey and Bryan Wright, and Nicholas and Jonathan Schachter. Dearest brother of Paul Schachter. Loving cousin, uncle, nephew, and friend. Scott was a retired NBC audio engineer and two time Emmy Award recipient for his distinguished work in live television. He delighted in traveling the world with his wife, laughter with his family and friends, and doing The New York Times Crossword Puzzles in ink. Service on Sunday at 3 PM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: A Golden Glow Surrounds Some Oldies
description: Awoman is having lunch with her grown children at an outdoor cafe when she is transfixed by the familiar tune a street- corner guitarist is playing. The children, who are pretty sure that Mom's going dotty, can't understand why she's suddenly enraptured.

title: British Novelist, Inspired by Westchester
description: ALL of Lee Child's bad guys in his four suspense novels are named for and modeled after the bosses who fired him in 1995 from his 20-year job in British commercial television. He calls his work his lifelong revenge project.

title: Challenge of Picking the Right Look for School
description: A BRIGHT orange tank top, midcalf blue jeans and sneakers then again maybe platform sandals -- are what 16-year-old Erin Rakow plans to wear on the first day of school at Byram Hills High in Armonk.

title: Pets or Appliances? Meeting the Purebred Robot Dogs
description: FIRST, it's Shadow demanding attention, his wee doggie head banging into a chair leg. ''Arf! Whir. Arf!''

title: A Bebop Master Comes to Call
description: IF any one drummer should represent the United States in an international percussion festival, Max Roach is a deserving candidate.

title: Designers Tackle A Colonial House
description: Mount Hope Farm, a Colonial house in Bristol, R.I., has been chosen as the site for the Newport Showhouse Guild's Showhouse 2000. It will be open to the public from Saturday through Oct. 9.

title: A Couple Of Outcasts Get to Shine On CD's
description: THERE are many ways a songwriter today can be unfashionable. Choosing to write for the American musical theater is merely one of the surer routes. Though even here, different songwriters go about being unfashionable in entirely different ways.

title: Not Just Another Gold Medalist
description: Gold medals are showered so profusely in numberless wine competitions that they equal in value the German marks trundled to banks in wheelbarrows during the Weimar Republic.

title: Foes Say Ad Containing Camera Amounts to Absolut Voyeurism
description: A new apartment in NoHo is inviting comparisons to the voyeuristic set of CBS's ''Big Brother.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTSON, LEE
description: ALBERTSON-Lee. Of Savannah, GA, formerly of Rye, NY and Manchester Village, VT, on August 17th. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father to Lee III, Timothy and Hilary Geha. Loving grandfather to Taylor, Sam, Andrew, Jared and Madeline. Dear brother of Shirley Burley and Barbara Wildman. Cousin of Huyler C. Held. Donations to Skidaway Island United Methodist Church Memorial Fund, Savannah GA. 31411.

title: Elevating Ordinary Into Works Of Beauty And of Eeriness
description: THIS year's New Jersey Fine Arts Annual, at the Newark Museum, acknowledges the momentous time period we're in. It's called ''Into the Millennium.'' But there's little that's flashy or futuristic in it. The curators made sure that the art vehicle taking us forward is something like Noah's Ark. The sexes are both well represented, but the 14 artists also represent various ages and modes of art making.

title: Bush's Verbal Slips
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Arden to Open Day Spa in The Westchester
description: Elizabeth Arden, the cosmetics company, will open a day spa at The Westchester mall in White Plains early next year. The spa, known as the Red Door Salon and Spa, will offer hair and skin care products and services, including facials, massages and makeovers. It will join the company's other day spas in Manhattan, Chicago, Phoenix, Dallas and San Francisco.

title: Southside Johnny at Blues Festival
description: Some of the best shore area rock 'n' roll artists have honed their skills with Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes, a lead singer and band that have entertained New Jersey shore blues fans for 25 years and nearly a dozen albums. Southside and the Jukes will be featured next Saturday in the first of two days of Blues, Brews and BBQs at Six Flags Great Adventure.

title: Ashley Marsh, David Pertsemlidis
description: Ashley Gale Marsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. and Scott Marsh III of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. David Stephen Pertsemlidis, a son of Lois Pertsemlidis and Dr. Demetrius Pertsemlidis of Manhattan. Judge Kenneth C. MacKenzie of New Jersey Superior Court in Morristown performed the ceremony at the Somerset Hills Country Club in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Amelida Ortiz, Peter Weinmann
description: Amelida Ortiz and Peter Allen Weinmann are to be married today by Rabbi Lisa Eiduson at Temple Beth Zion in Buffalo.

title: Investing; Will an 'Age Wave' Extend the Bond Rally?
description: THE bond market this year has outperformed the stock market for the first time in a decade, and Dr. Edward Yardeni, chief global economist and investment strategist at Deutsche Bank Securities, forecasts that aging baby boomers will help keep the bond rally going.

title: Investing; Look Who's Smiling in A Sideways Market Year
description: BROKERS, according to a Wall Street truism, prosper when the market goes up and when it goes down. But this year, the market has gone nowhere -- no major average has moved much more than 4 percent from its Dec. 31 level -- and the brokers have done better than ever.

title: MONEY FOR LIBRARIES, STREETS AND HOMES
description: Westchester County has received $6.6 million from the federal government and has awarded about $5.1 million of it for community projects. Part of the remainder will go for repairs or removing health hazards at the homes of low-income residents. Municipal projects include $500,000 for street improvements in Mamaroneck, $450,000 for construction of a senior center in Port Chester, $130,000 for public housing in Greenburgh, $150,000 for playground renovation at the Ossining Children's Center and $70,000 to expand the children's library in Peekskill. Elsa Brenner

title: Work, Not School
description: To the Editor:

title: New Wave of Quarterbacks, New Pressures
description: The place to be for two days this summer was Hawaii, not because of the sandy beaches and the sunsets, but because some of the best young quarterbacks in the National Football League were competing in the Quarterback Challenge, a sort of ''Survivor'' for passers. The sexiest event, by far, was the long-distance throw.

title: Battle of the Mambo Is Bruising Some Toes
description: Kate Shanley and Humberto Lopez met in a nightclub with starfish on the walls and a pulsing Latin beat in the air. They caught each other's eye immediately -- she of the long blond hair, white pants and rabbit fur top; he of the orange shirt and handsome dark looks.

title: POSTINGS: Programs From City's Housing Agency; Learning to Be A Homeowner
description: Programs aimed at providing homeowners and landlords with the information they need to properly manage their properties will be presented at various locations in the city throughout September.

title: Cruise Lines Pressured To Be Kinder to the Seas
description: CRUISE ships were involved in 87 confirmed cases of illegal discharges of oil, chemicals, garbage or plastic in United States waters from 1993 through 1988, the General Accounting Office said in a report to Congress in February. What's more, some cases involved illegal discharges numbering in the hundreds.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 3, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Style; Varsity Blues
Rutgers Gets Off to a Good Start
description: After one game, Rutgers has equaled its victory total for last season. True, this 34-21 triumph was over Villanova, a Division I-AA opponent that usually plays teams a level below the I-A Scarlet Knights. But the result was satisfying nonetheless for Rutgers Coach Terry Shea, who is trying to save his job, and for his starting quarterback, Mike McMahon, who returned from a serious shoulder injury.

title: Monica Azare, David Davenport
description: Monica Faye Azare, a daughter of Dorothy Davenport of Abbeville, La., and Calvin Azare of Lafayette, La., is to be married today to David Glen Davenport, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Davenport of New York. The Rev. E. James Guidry, a Baptist minister, is to perform the ceremony in the chapel at Vermilionville, a Cajun and Creole living history village in Lafayette.

title: A Whiff of a Garden
description: Gold medals are showered so profusely in so many wine competitions that they equal in value the German marks trundled to banks in wheelbarrows during the Weimar Republic.

title: An Unknown Now, He Made Westerns Of Spiritual Depth
description: SO often in the half-dozen low-budget, impeccably made westerns that Budd Boetticher directed in the late 1950's, the opening shot features a lone horseman approaching the camera out of a lunar vastness of rock. We don't know who he is, though his name always has a ring to it: Stride, Brennan, Allison, Buchanan, Brigade, Cody. You do know that he comes bearing the elemental promise of a story.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Quarterback for Irish Has Right Answers
description: The coach wondered how his quarterback would react if he got off tentatively in his first start for Notre Dame. ''What happens when something goes wrong?'' Bob Davie said the other day. ''Just how resilient is he going to be?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, PEGGY
description: ROBERTS-Peggy. We miss your smile, laugh, love, heart and companionship. Stanley, Robin, Jason and Sara

title: Four Prisons and Counting
description: Needing a place to lock up dangerous offenders, the New Jersey Department of Corrections decided this month to take the well-worn path to Cumberland County, already the home of four prisons, more than 8,000 inmates and the recession-proof growth industry they have brought to the far reaches of South Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN KLEIN, MYRNA
description: ROSEN KLEIN-Myrna. Mom, we miss you. You remain forever in our hearts. Wayne and Jeff

title: On Wheels of Fitness and Faith
description: ''You're doing what?'' Bicycling 275 miles in three days. In mid-September, from Boston to New York, for the sixth annual AIDS ride. And I am doing it with 3,000 dedicated souls from around the country, and yes, the vast majority of them are younger and fitter than I am.

title: How Black Comedy Got The Last Laugh
description: In late June, Chris Tucker flew to Los Angeles from his home in Atlanta to meet with President Clinton. Clinton was in Los Angeles, as he has often been, for a frenetic round of fund-raising, but he managed to clear some time for Tucker, who is not a major Democratic donor but a very funny comic film actor with a notion of writing, directing, producing and starring in a movie about the first black president of the United States. Tucker was planning to rendezvous with the leader of the free world at a nightclub in Hollywood called the Garden of Eden. When I spoke with Tucker not long before this planned get-together, he recalled that when he first met the president, in Washington two years before, ''I wasn't even sure if he knew who I was.''

title: A New Long-Distance Plan
description: STELLA IN HEAVEN Almost a Novel. By Art Buchwald. 182 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $23.95.

title: Sona Chong, Harry Jho
description: Sona Sophia Chong, the daughter of Sung Ja Chong and Kwang Hae Chong of Wheaton, Md., was married on Friday to Harry Jho, a son of Judy and Duke Jho of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Haeng Duk Chung, an Evangelical Baptist minister and a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Estherwood, a historic house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Lebanon Challenger Takes On Syria, Too
description: Lebanon is slipping toward a constitutional crisis -- and a tough early test for Syria's new young leader, Bashar al-Assad -- as it goes into a final round of parliamentary elections on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRIGGS, ADRIAN P.
description: DRIGGS-Adrian P. Age 84, died in Naples, FL, September 9, 2000. Loving husband of June & the late Patricia Heffernan Driggs. Loving father of Patricia Driggs Balassi & Adrian P. Driggs, III. Brother of Katherine Purcell; grandfather of John Christopher & Kathryn Balassi. Resident of Naples, FL; formerly of Fayetteville, Brooklyn, & Point Lookout, NY. General counsel to Agway; staff counsel to Lever Brothers; graduate of Brooklyn Prepatory School, 1934. College of the Holy Cross, 1938; and St. John's Law School. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Elizabeth Seton, RC Church, Naples, FL.

title: Where the Arts Still Sustain the Social Compact
description: EARLY in the fall of 1962, when Bernard Olshan was about to move into the Amalgamated Houses in the Bronx with his new bride, he called on an amateur violinist named Herman Leibman. A gangly fellow with a Yiddish accent and a graying cloud of hair that brought to mind Einstein's, Leibman was for lack of a more exact term the culture minister of the complex, which had been built by a garment workers union largely for its rank and file. Mr. Olshan, a painter, wanted to see about renting a studio.

title: Proposal For Battle Of Sexes
description: Donald Trump handed John McEnroe a letter on Friday that contained a proposal for McEnroe, the 41-year-old Hall of Fame player, to meet Venus or Serena Williams in a $1 million winner-take-all match at his Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City.

title: PENN STATION CONCOURSE
description: New Jersey Transit announced last week that the arrival of a new concourse intended to improve comfort and street access for commuters at Penn Station in Manhattan will be delayed. It should be finished by March 2002, rather than the original target of late 2001, said Ken Miller, a spokesman for the rail agency. The $105 million project is taking longer than expected. Steve Strunsky

title: Not All Thrills
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Federal Reserve Bank of New York Gets a Cleaning; Under the Soot, a Colorful Quilt
description: Out of the financial district's monochromatic canyons, an astonishing quiltwork of color has emerged in the last month as the facade of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York undergoes its first cleaning in 76 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 13 about the distribution of keys for Gramercy Park in Manhattan misstated the rarity of its status as a private park. Sunnyside Gardens Park, established in Queens in 1926, is also restricted to its members.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Hate Floats Won't Fly At Firefighters' Parade

title: Genuine Haydn With Real Spirit
description: HAYDN: PIANO CONCERTOS

title: Waiting for Lefty
description: IT DIDN'T HAPPEN HERE

title: Globalization Tops 3-Day U.N. Agenda For World Leaders
description: The stormy battle over globalization that brought protests to the streets of Seattle and Washington moves this week to the heart of the world's only truly global organization, the United Nations.

title: Underwriting, Not Promoting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITZ, HERBERT P., D.D.S.
description: FRITZ-Herbert P., D.D.S. 88. Of Somers, NY, died August 25 at his Chautauqua, NY summer home. A dental professor at Columbia for 50 years with practices in Mount Vernon and Chappaqua, NY, Dr. Fritz is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Marjorie Turnbull Fritz, & his children Janet Hershey of Katonah, NY, Dr. Robert Fritz of Manchester, MA, and Carol Pawlowski of Havertown, PA; nine grandchildren; and brother Robert Fritz of Newbern, NC. Memorial service to be held at Chappaqua First Congregational Church, on September 9 at 2 PM.

title: As I Pronounced It
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCHARRIE, MARGARET
description: McHARRIE-Margaret. Of Blackpool, England. Your birthday today. Greatly missed and always loved and remembered by her family on both sides of the Atlantic. Husband Dennis, her children Judy and Jane, and grandchildren Julia, Alex, Meggie, Jessica and Marcos and Feroze

title: Parking Fines Rise, and Tempers Follow
description: IN East Hampton Town Justice Court last Monday, there were about a dozen people with frustrated looks on their well-tanned faces.

title: Range and Repertory
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAGER, PAUL
description: YAGER-Paul, 80. Of Metuchen, NJ, August 28, 2000. Was a labor mediator for the Federal Mediation & Conciliation Service, in Washington, DC., Philadelphia, & NYC for thirty-five years, and a Navy WW II Veteran. Husband of Naomi (Rosenhaus) Yager. Father of Deborah Yager & Marion Hamermesh. Brother of Florence Levy. Grandfather of Simon and Naomi Kate Hamermesh. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date. Contributions to the Jewish Family Serivces of Middlesex County, NJ. For information, Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Avenue Fords, NJ.

title: On Pro Basketball; Carter Finds It Tough Going in 2 Directions at Once
description: Vince Carter, showman, All-Star and now Olympian, has become basketball's biggest wishbone. The purists and the icons are tugging one leg, telling him he needs to be a more complete player. The National Basketball Association and its highlight-obsessed fans pull hard on the other, shouting: ''Dunk! dunk!''

title: Bills. Thrills. Spills.
description: Governor Whitman has never surfed 40-foot waves or parachuted thousands of feet off a radio tower. At least, if she did, she never issued a press release on it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: As Turnpike Shooting Case Stalls, Time May Favor the Troopers
description: More than two years after two New Jersey state troopers opened fire on three unarmed men on the New Jersey Turnpike, turning racial profiling into a national issue, the criminal case against the troopers is fraying and a series of closed-door decisions by prosecutors and the trial judge during the next several weeks will determine whether the most serious charge, attempted murder, is dropped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUFSON, SHELDON J.
description: MUFSON-Sheldon J. On September 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Loretta. Loving father of Greg, Lisa and Goldine. Dear brother of Beatrice Weiss. Service Sunday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Assessing the Game's Young Guns
description: The National Football League has rarely enjoyed such a surplus of good young passers, which bodes well for the future at the position. Here is a look at the strengths and weeknesses of some of them: MIKE FREEMAN

title: Orthodox Viewpoints: Can They All Be Right?
description: Growing up in the 30's in Woodmere, I remember hearing ''dirty Jew'' called out as I walked through the village, and riding the school bus, I learned that Jews were in the minority and not wanted.

title: NATION'S SCHOOLS STRUGGLING TO FIND ENOUGH PRINCIPALS
description: As the academic year begins for the nation's 53 million students, a growing number of schools are rudderless, struggling to replace a graying corps of principals at a time when the pressure to raise test scores and other new demands have made an already difficult job an increasingly thankless one.

title: Talk Softly, but Carry A Firm Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Vice Adm. Harold G. Bowen Jr. Dies at 87
description: Vice Admiral Harold G. Bowen Jr., who presided over the Navy's investigation into one of the most wrenching episodes in its history -- the seizure of the electronic surveillance ship Pueblo by North Korea -- died on Aug. 17 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 87.

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; A Garden Fence on E. 95th, a Staircase on E. Fourth
description: Fences and Neighbors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, VIRGINIA E.
description: COLE-Virginia E. Of Floral Park, NY, on September 1, 2000. Devoted wife of the late Robert D. Cole Sr. Beloved mother of Carleen, Robert Jr. and Christopher. Loving sister of Raymond Dukes and Marilyn Bilpuh. Cherished grandmother of six. Friends may call Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave., Floral Park, NY (at RR Plaza). Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Footlights
description: Turning 90 and Still Singing

title: Marisa Cerveris and John Savage
description: WHEN Marisa Elena Cerveris and John Mark Savage met five years ago, she was a peripatetic ballerina living out of a tiny suitcase, while he occupied a book-filled room in a five-story communal house known as Aubergine, near Columbia University.

title: How to Escape the Hamptons: Paddle!
description: AS I was gliding over the chop on my surfboard last Saturday afternoon, wearing a red bikini and matching long-sleeve rash guard, hair matted with salt, I greeted the members of the motley bronzed gang I'd known for three months, but whose names I still hadn't caught: ''Hey man, catch any good rides today?''

title: Israel's Best Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxi Troubles
description: To the Editor: My husband, our two sons and I were in Paris several months ago and encountered a problem I had never had when I traveled just with my husband. Most drivers refused to take four passengers, even though there is a surcharge for the fourth. They apparently are not required to do so, although the cars have enough room.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about Bolton Landing, N.Y., the site of a museum dedicated to the soprano Marcella Sembrich, misstated the age difference between her and her husband, Wilhelm Stengel. He was 11 years older, not 13. The article also misstated the size of their family. They had two sons; they were not childless.

title: OPINION; Narrow Mindsets Block Improved Energy Resources
description: AS today's experts seek to divine what energy deregulation will do for our economy in the years to come, it would be best to reread a collection of predictions authored early in the 20th century that made fools out of futurists. Some of the forecasts were so spectacularly bad that an expression -- ''Wasn't the Future Wonderful?'' -- was coined to mock ironclad guarantees of inventors who insisted that we would be enjoying cities suspended in mid-air and household electricity extracted from thunderclouds.

title: Discarded Hindu God Does Not Bless India's Water
description: The Hindu god Ganesh bestower of happiness and eliminator of sorrow -- is a hard man to miss in a crowd. He has four arms and the head of an elephant. His pot belly is Sumo-sized. He fully indulges his fondness for gold jewelry.

title: Two Drinks and You're Cleared for Takeoff
description: The drinks are so strong at Glacken's Bar and Grill, they've bolted the foot rail to the top of the bar because it was doing no good on the floor.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on the new TV technology like TiVo and Replay uncovered surprising support for the old: many readers said the ''impossible'' VCR gets a bad rap. And the report on a culture clash between Jews in Beachwood, Ohio, prompted others to ask, What would Joe Lieberman do?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, HOWARD, JR.
description: BIRD-Howard, Jr. 84. Of New Canaan, Conn. Beloved husband of Shirley Hasler, devoted father of: Frederick, Norman, Michael and Susan. Loving grandfather of Alden and Hayden Bird. Memorial service will be at 11AM at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. on Friday, 8th of September, 2000. Contributions in memory of Howard may be made to either the New Canaan Historical Society, 13 Oenoke Ridge, or to St. Mark's Music Fund at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge: New Canaan, Conn. 06840.

title: Robin Szalwinski, Aitan Goelman
description: Robin Suzanne Szalwinski, a daughter of Susan C. Long and Robert S. Szalwinski, both of Corpus Christi, Tex., is to be married today to Aitan Dror Goelman, a son of Marcella A. Goelman and Dr. Don Goelman of King of Prussia, Pa. Rabbi Yair Hillel Goelman, an uncle of the bridegroom, is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Tiferet Bet Israel in Blue Bell, Pa.

title: How Prints Got an Artist in Hot Water
description: THE last time William Kent, an 81-year-old artist who lives in Durham, exhibited his slate prints in New Haven, it was 1965. The last time Mr. Kent created one of his slate prints -- a process that requires the precision of a sculptor, the strength of a weightlifter, the satiric vision of Jonathan Swift and the patience of Job -- it was 1977.

title: The Winds of Change Stir Crew's Emotions
description: Aboard a giant multihull like PlayStation, Steve Fossett's otherworldly 105-foot catamaran, the anemometer, or wind-speed indicator, not only imparts invaluable information, it also serves as a reasonable guide to the emotional well-being of the boat's 12-man crew.

title: Heather Heiman, Stephen Persell
description: Dr. Heather Lynn Heiman and Dr. Stephen David Persell, residents in internal medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, are to be married today. William D. Persell, the Episcopal bishop of Chicago and an uncle of the bridegroom, is to perform the ceremony at the Deerpark Restaurant in Asheville, N.C.

title: Putting a New Spin On the Old Master
description: WHEN the work of a great artist like Mozart, Chekhov or Petipa is reconsidered by an inspired interpreter, the results often reveal new facets of an original masterpiece. Such may prove to be the case at the Balanchine Festival, which begins in a little over a week at the Kennedy Center in Washington. In a millennium tribute to the choreographer, a remarkable gathering of 6 companies will dance 14 of his ballets from Sept. 12 through 24.

title: Elizabeth Belle, Matthew Bigham
description: Elizabeth Marie Belle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Belle of Town and Country, Mo., was married yesterday to Dr. Matthew Hitchcock Bigham, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Darrel E. Bigham of Evansville, Ind. The Rev. Michael P. G. G. Randolph performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral in St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, PAULINE
description: CARTER-Pauline. Either we have squirrels in the attic, or you've got to stop walking around all night. It's been a year since you sat with me at the kitchen table while I had my Friday night salad, since we've gone for Saturday afternoon lunch at the Diner, since we've gone for Sunday night dinner at Scotto's, since you've listened to me play the piano, since I've seen you smile, since I've heard you laugh. Your tulips came up in May. I hung your geraniums on the terrace, put the pillows on your swing and planted your garden for your birthday. The house is just not the same without you. I miss you dearly. With all my love, Larry.

title: FERRY FOOD SERVICE
description: The Cape May-Lewes Ferry stopped serving prepared food on its five ships this week after the United States Food and Drug Administration threatened court action. The Delaware River and Bay Authority, which operates the five ferries that ply the bay between the New Jersey and Delaware resort towns, voluntarily shut down its cooked and prepared food services aboard the ferries after continued F.D.A. inspections showed violations that might threaten health of passengers. Until food service resumes, passengers can buy prepackaged food on the ferries.

title: On the Stump, the Hot Topic Is Education; In the Schools, Deep Skepticism Is Mixed With Cautious Gratitude
description: No self-respecting candidate for public office -- be it president, congressman or county commissioner -- gets on the stump these days without having something to say about education. Sometimes it seems as if everyone's running for school board.

title: Maria DaBreo, Jamahl Evans
description: Maria A. DaBreo, the daughter of Gloria DaBreo and Brian DaBreo, both of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Jamahl Kwanza Ernest Evans, the son of Judi Adams-Evans of New Haven and Ernest Evans of Manhattan. The Rev. Jean-Miguel Auguste is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral Basilica of St. James in Brooklyn.

title: Western Wildfires Disrupt Vacations
description: The wildfires that have swept through parts of a dozen Western states this summer, destroying homes, businesses and millions of acres of recreational land, have also disrupted or ruined vacations and crippled businesses dependent on the tourist trade.

title: Adding Up the Drawbacks of a Credit Card That Isn't
description: THEY look like credit cards, are accepted in almost as many places, and are now carried by tens of millions of consumers. But debit cards can turn out to be much more expensive to use for any consumer, not just a financial novice like a student. Here are some of debit cards' little-known drawbacks.

title: Pair of Sisters and a Stranger
description: SHE was a recording star, a nightclub star, a television star and then, at 23, a Broadway star. But the show business ascent of Leslie Uggams started at the age of 6, on a television series called ''Beulah.'' One year later she was a warm-up act for Ella Fitzgerald, Louis Armstrong and Dinah Washington at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: Suzanne Lesser, Anthony Phillips
description: Suzanne Lesser, a daughter of Ruth Lesser and Dr. Robert Lesser of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married today at her parents' house to Anthony Phillips, a son of Marion Phillips and Dr. Eduardo Phillips of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Rabbi Richard Eisenberg is to officiate.

title: A Stage-Struck Artist Abroad
description: Al Hirschfeld took temporary leave of Broadway this summer to embark on the QE2, where he lectured about his art, before sampling theater in several cities abroad, sketchbook in hand. His first stop was Berlin, where he saw Drew Sarich, lower left, play the title character in Disney's production of ''Der Glockner von Notre Dame'' (''The Hunchback of Notre Dame''), with a score by Alan Menken and Stephen Schwartz, directed by James Lapine, who wrote the book. In Prague, there was ''Nachove Plachty'' (''Purple Sails''), above center, a maritime drama created and directed by Matej and Peter Forman, at the brothers' barge theater on the Moldau River. The London selections, beginning at top left, included Kathleen Turner and Matthew Rhys in ''The Graduate,'' directed by Terry Johnson; Helen Mirren in ''Orpheus Descending'' by Tennessee Williams, directed by Nicholas Hytner; Lucie Arnez, Maria Friedman and

title: Now and Then, a Taste for Dining on the Run
description: New Yorkers were eating on the run centuries before the creation of fast-food concessions. In the 1600's, when the first Dutch settlers arrived, the bays contained rich stocks of oysters. Oysters measuring a foot or more in length were common. Hungry people could just reach down into the water and grab a couple.

title: CHAPPAQUA: SHUTTLE BUS FOR COMMUTERS
description: A new park-and-ride service for Metro-North riders who use the Chappaqua train station will begin on Tuesday. Passengers can park at Gedney Park in Millwood or at the Willowbrook Swim Club in Mount Kisco and ride a 20-passenger shuttle bus to the station. The shuttle will meet three morning trains, beginning with the 8:46 and 11 evening trains, starting at 5:13. Those who sign up for the service, which is free for holders of New Castle parking permits, will be guaranteed two free taxi rides a month in case they miss the bus. The program mirrors one run by Metro-North that shuttles passengers across the Tappan Zee Bridge to the Tarrytown station. Peter Beller

title: For the Hip-Hop and Fashion Set, An Entire Wall of Mirrors
description: ON a recent weeknight in August, the commotion at Mr. Chow belied all conventional thinking about what goes on in New York during the very end of summer. Presumably, nothing goes on -- and the kind of nothing involving no ones -- because all the someones are busy doing nothing somewhere else.

title: For Last Dance, Candidates Eye The Wallflower
description: Labor Day is the unofficial opening of the general election campaign, but for most voters the race is already over. Strategists on both sides agree that more than 90 percent of the electorate has by now settled on either Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore.

title: Owner of Restaurant in Queens Is Killed During a Delivery
description: The owner of two Chinese takeout restaurants in Queens was bludgeoned to death late Friday during an apparent robbery attempt outside an unoccupied house where he had been summoned to deliver food from one of his establishments, the police said yesterday.

title: Political Briefing; Examining Life, Jerry Brown-Style
description: Here's an update on Mayor Jerry Brown of Oakland, Calif., a k a Moonbeam from two decades back when he was the dreamy philosopher governor of the Golden State, sometimes living in a box (or close to it) but always thinking outside of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBALATA, VICTOR, M.D.
description: BARBALATA-Victor, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mt. Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing and devoted colleague. Dr. Barbalata was a member of the Department of Medicine for more than 30 years. He was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients and will be remembered as a dedicated and compassionate practioner of medicine. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Film Returns Tuckahoe to the 60's
description: LAST week, it was 1964 in Tuckahoe.

title: Collins Ready To Become The Leader
description: This morning in northern New Jersey, Kerry Collins won't be driving his car to the rest of his life.

title: On Pro Football; An Energetic Cowher Lays Foundation To Rebuild The Steelers
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers have already moved their offices into a $10 million complex renovated from an old mill.
