A year from now, the Steelers will leave their game-day home of the last 31 years, rusty Three Rivers Stadium, and play in a glistening new $260 million stadium in downtown Pittsburgh.

title: Martz Finds Plenty to Feed Paranoia Even Before Season Begins
description: When a National Football League assistant suddenly becomes a head coach, two things usually happen: First, his blood pressure skyrockets. Second, he becomes more paranoid than Richard Nixon. We don't know about the blood pressure of Mike Martz, who this off-season replaced Dick Vermeil as head coach of the Super Bowl champion St. Louis Rams, but we do know that on the paranoid scale Martz is already scoring off the chart.

title: Looks Like Late Summer
description: There's tennis in Queens and a beach party in the Hamptons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAM, WILLIAM
description: BEHAM-William. In his 93rd year. Much loved husband of the late Miriam (Marcus). Dear companion of Fanny Glixman. Wonderful father, grandfather, great-grandfather, colleague and friend. Never bored, always learning, he loved life and life returned the compliment. Services Wednesday, September 6, 12:45PM, The Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. Memorial contributions can be made to the NYU Hematology Research Fund, C/O Bruce Raphael, MD, 530 1st Ave., NY NY 10016.

title: Word for Word/Dear Abbie; Or, How He Learned to Stop Worrying And Love to Sell Books
description: ABBIE HOFFMAN, Yippie, media performer and author, was the say-no-to-war, yes-to-drugs face of the 1960's.

title: Paradise Found?
description: To the Editor: Marialisa Calta's essay on the vacation preferences of someone living in a vacation spot (''Taking a Break From Scenic Vermont,'' July 30) brought to mind a trip to Hawaii a few years ago.

title: Japan Orders Residents Out After Tremors Rock Island
description: After two months of sporadic eruptions and frequent, earth-shaking tremors in an island chain south of Tokyo, officials today ordered the complete evacuation of Miyake Island, which has been at the center of the seismic activity.

title: A Spending Account in Need of a Cure
description: SO whatever happened to medical savings accounts?

title: Boom Box
description: Far from ''empowering'' viewers, or ''putting them in control,'' these machines are designed to spy on and manipulate people. Your set will be able to show you something and monitor how you respond, working on you over time, in a cycle of stimulus, measurement and response, until it has you behaving the way it wants. Artificial-intelligence software can do this in the box. Whether any data leave your home or not is unimportant. We should stop the cheerleading and reject this assault on our civil liberties.

title: Laura Dowden, Nigel Edelshain
description: Laura Anne Dowden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll V. Dowden of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Nigel Richard Edelshain, the son of Lisa Edelshain of Swansea, Wales, and the late Gerald Edelshain. Msgr. Robert Fuhrman performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel the Archangel Church in Saddle River.

title: S.A.T. IMPROVEMENTS
description: New Jersey students taking the S.A.T. scored the same in the verbal portion as last year, but gained a few points in math scores, according to results released last week. The average verbal score in New Jersey was 498 in the 1999-2000 school year and 513 in math. Scores from New Jersey and around the nation can be found at www.collegeboard.org. Debra Nussbaum

title: Return Of the Stock Pickers
description: FOR years, investors have won big by following the crowd. Piling into index funds, a handful of big-company technology shares or any stock that happened to be moving up was the name of the game.

title: After Growth Spurt, Athlete Sets Sights on the N.F.L.
description: WHEN he went out for the Roosevelt High football team in Yonkers as a 10th grader, Saif Sabur stood 5 foot 6 and weighed 109 pounds. By his senior year, the figures were 5 foot 9 and 132 pounds -- and still his coach was afraid to put him in a game.

title: Tara Cook, Owen Littman
description: Tara Pam Cook, a daughter of Arleen and Edwin Cook of Easton, Conn., is to be married today to Owen Stuart Littman, a son of Marilyn and Joel Littman of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Leon Waldman is to officiate at Congregation Beth El in Fairfield, Conn.

title: If You're Thinking of Living On/Central Park West; At Every Front Door, a Great Playground
description: IN more than three decades of overlooking Central Park from the fifth floor -- leaf level -- Moisha Blechman has watched the skyline change.

title: The Jewish Tipping Point
description: As a Conservative Jew, I believe that there are as many degrees of Jewish observance as there are Jews, and I applaud and celebrate the path that each takes. But shame on the Orthodox busybody who criticized Si Wachsberger for tending his property on Shabbos. And double shame on Wachsberger and his supporters who feel threatened by a large Orthodox community in their midst.

title: Elizabeth Weir, Mallory Factor
description: Karen Elizabeth Weir and Mallory Factor are to be married today at the Hotel San Pietro in Positano, Italy. Rabbi Joshua Lookstein is to officiate with Positano's mayor, Octavio Fusco.

title: Variations on Italian Theme in Wainscott
description: THE Italians have reclaimed the Tudor-style restaurant overlooking Georgica Pond in Wainscott. For most of the last decade it housed Sapori di Mare; then last summer, Maya's provided a brief Caribbean interlude. Now, it's called Saracen, a restaurant that celebrates the food of Southern Italy and Sicily, those Mediterranean crossroads where so many groups, including the Saracens, left their mark.

title: Trying Out a Different Set of Wheels
description: IN conversations with experts about mobility problems, especially among the elderly, two themes almost always crop up. One is that the choices are scant when it comes to devices that help you get around: you can clomp along with a cane or a walker, or take to a wheelchair, which limits exercise. Second, many people who have trouble walking say they are most comfortable pushing a grocery cart, because it lets them move along with balance and stability.

title: U.S. Faces Argentina in Championship Bridge Playoffs
description: Both United States teams finished strongly at the end of the qualifying stage of the World Bridge Championships here today, and will begin playoff matches Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANLER, NELLIE
description: SHANLER-Nellie. Age 90, of Hollywood, FL, formerly of Hewlett Harbor, NY, on September 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Robert, David & Judith (Randy) Bergen. Cherished grandmother of Marc and Elizabeth. Adored great-grandmother of five. Memorial service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Oradell, NJ, 1 PM, Tuesday, September 5. We will miss your love and guidance.

title: 14 Hurt in Collision of a Bus and a Minivan
description: Fourteen people were injured when a city bus and a minivan collided in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, fire and transit officials said.

title: The Nation; What Hath God Wrought? Lieberman and the Right
description: TWELVE years ago, lashing out at his opponent, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. accused Joseph Lieberman of espousing the ''Jesse Helms-Jerry Falwell-Pat Robertson platform'' by advocating a moment of silence in public schools.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Hidden Cost of Cloak and Dagger Versus Cooperation
description: BEFORE the nuclear-powered attack submarine U.S.S. Memphis embarked on a recent spy mission -- in which, Navy officials have said, it captured the sounds of the explosions that helped sink Russia's Kursk submarine last month -- one unsettling precaution was taken. A bright orange rescue buoy, designed to shoot to the surface and summon help if the Memphis got in trouble, was welded down and rendered unusable.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Few of Their Favorite Things
description: POSSESSION is a strange thing. It begins in childhood. If you ask children anywhere, from Turkey to Thailand, from Siberia to Ivory Coast, they can immediately identify the object they cherish most.

title: Delinquent Common Charges
description: Q: What happens when those who live in a condominium pay extra common charges for owners who do not pay their way? Over a period of 15 or 30 years, a $250 a month additional fee adds up to a hefty sum. Those of us who do pay our share actually wind up paying for those who do not. When this money is recovered at the time of sale because of liens placed on the apartment by the condominium association, do we get reimbursed? What if we move out before the delinquent homeowner sells? Is the board obligated to find us and reimburse us? . . . Jeff Shermer, Plainview, N.Y.

title: Yes! It's Him! (Whaddya Mean, Never Heard of Him?)
description: Despite their statistical rarity, the famous seem to be everywhere in New York. So residents take it for granted that from time to time, they will come face to face with someone famous.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Labor Day

title: Despite Dead Heat, City Zip Earns Sweep
description: For a few anxious moments this afternoon, the rain clouds that rolled in and hovered over Saratoga just before the 96th running of the Hopeful looked as if they would be an omen for Linda Rice's star 2-year-old colt, City Zip.

title: Virtues of Stepmoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Awards After an Uprising
description: More than 500 former inmates who were beaten during the 1971 Attica prison uprising will split $8 million as part of a settlement with New York State, a federal judge ruled. The awards, which range from $6,500 to $125,000, punctuate a protracted legal battle stemming from the uprising, in which 43 people died. Still, the judge said many survivors ''remain casualties because of lingering physical problems and the inability to erase memories of Attica.'' David W. Chen

title: Where the Pilgrims Lived, Megaprojects Now Loom
description: FOR 340 years after the Pilgrims settled here, Plymouth and its neighbors in southeast Massachusetts grew very slowly. Then in 30 years, from 1960 to 1990, the population of this 103-square-mile town, the state's largest municipality and still a sizable slice of cranberry growing country, tripled.

title: A Comeback for a Cracker
description: A taste among Civil War re-enactors for total authenticity, combined with the power of the Internet, has given James F. Pierotti, owner of a baking company in Milton, Mass., a new market. Founded in 1801, his G. H. Bent Company supplied Union soldiers with hardtack crackers. Thick squares made from flour and water, the crackers are tasteless and hard as rocks, acknowledged Mr. Pierotti, whose family assumed ownership in 1944. ''There wasn't much demand for hardtack after the turn of the century,'' he said, so the company quit making it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARFF, MICHAEL
description: SHARFF-Michael. Died August 24, at age 64 in Brooklyn, NY. Devoted owner of Camp Lindenmere in Tannersville, PA for 30 years. Devoted and loving son to Anne Druck. Also survived by his sister Fran Gurowitz and brother Marc Sharff and many lifelong friends. Memorial service to be held shortly. Those interested, contact Fran Gurowitz: 516-872-3348. Donations may be sent to Sloane-Kettering Memorial Hospital or The American Diabetes Association.

title: Curbing Drug Trade: A Proven Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ramble, Without a Car, Through Rhode Island
description: THE brass-bound Louis Vuitton steamer trunk appeared to have the same dimensions as the ice cream freezer at my local Korean grocery -- and no well-outfitted turn-of-the-century traveler would have stepped on board ship without one of these behemoths. Or set foot out the door without her personal whiskey shot glass, cushioned from the bumps of the road by a fitted red leather case.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: ROCKAWAY PARK

title: Great Wall Marathon More Than Just a Race
description: A Chinese proverb says, ''You cannot be called a hero if you've never been to the Great Wall.'' Forty-five athletes who ventured halfway around the world to Beijing believe in a different version: ''You can't be called a marathoner until you've run the Great Wall Marathon.''

title: Son of Hippies, Still Crazy After 26 Years
description: YOU can credit supportive parents or rail against impious youth, but Seth MacFarlane is to brashly irreverent what Marge Simpson is to high hair.

title: INSIDE
description: Tire Workers Stay on the Job

title: The Big Play Comes Back In a Big Way As Offenses Go Vertical
description: When Isaac Bruce caught the game-winning 73-yard touchdown pass in Super Bowl XXXIV, he could have kept running and zipped right into the 2000 National Football League season. Because Bruce and his St. Louis Rams, along with teams like the Minnesota Vikings, the Indianapolis Colts and the Washington Redskins, are swaying offenses back to the vertical passing game.

title: Lean and Refreshing
description: The silver foil covering the cork on Kip Bedell's 1996 chardonnay suggests its quicksilver use at the table.

title: Nasdaq, Calm at Last?
description: August was a tame month for the Nasdaq composite index in comparison with the rest of 2000. The technology-fueled Nasdaq climbed nearly 1,000 points early in the year, to a record 5,132 on March 10, only to tumble over the next two and a half months, to 3,042 on May 24.

title: A Juice Bar For That Natural High
description: With herbal remedies growing in popularity, Elixir, a West Village juice bar, opened a new store in TriBeCa last month. The ultramodern store at 95 West Broadway near Chambers Street serves smoothies and juices made from basic fruits to complex herbal combinations.

title: How a Teacher Can Influence A Whole Life
description: RARE as great performers are, even rarer are great teachers of performance. Today, in the field of violin playing at a supreme virtuoso level, there are only two categories of teachers: Dorothy DeLay and all the rest. Miss DeLay, as she is invariably known (though long married), has been teaching at the Juilliard School for more than half a century, and the roll of her former pupils includes Itzhak Perlman and Sarah Chang, Midori and Kennedy, Gil Shaham and Robert McDuffie, Cho-Liang Lin and Shlomo Mintz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GERALD MORTON
description: SMITH-Gerald Morton. On September 1. Born January 17, 1918, to Samuel Jacob Smith and Sarah Zaslavsky, in Fall River, Mass. He grew up in Webster, Mass., was an accomplished orator and actor in high school, studied international relations at Harvard College ('39, cum laude) and later received his J.D. from Harvard Law School ('42). In World War II, he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and became a pilot and aide to General Tom Hardin, flying the ''Hump'' from India over the Himalayas to China. At war's end, he worked briefly for Taca Airlines in South America and was a government aviation administrator in Washington before settling in New York and pursuing a career in surety law. He retired in 1986 a partner in the insurance specialty firm then known as Gottesman, Wolgel, Smith & Secunda. While at the firm, he acted as an arbitrator for the American Arbitration Association. A devoted husband, a warm and playful parent, a dedicated fisherman, he was always a gentleman, generous and loyal, with an absurdist sense of humor. He was also a fierce believer in truth and right and an inspiration to excellence in all who knew him. He is survived by his adoring wife of 46 years, the former Lorraine Ina Waldman, and by sons Mark Storey Smith and Carlton Malben Smith, in whom his sense of fun & wonder live on; also by his devoted sister Eleanor Mailman, daughter-in-law Mina Mostafazadeh-Asl Smith, grandchildren Larissa Roxanna Smith and Talia Sara Smith and a wide web of friends and family for whom his passing leaves the world a lesser place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUOTOLO, JAMES
description: RUOTOLO-James. On August 31, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Rose Ruotolo (nee Tarantino). Loving father of Charles, George, Barbara and Debra. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Friends may visit, Sunday and Monday, 2:00 to 4:30 and 7:00 to 9:30 PM, at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Rd, New Hyde Park, NY. Funeral Tuesday, 10 AM, at the funeral home. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: States Want Curfew at Airport
description: FORMER adversaries in the airport border wars between Westchester and Connecticut came together last week to fight a common enemy.

title: Orthodox Viewpoints: Can They All Be Right?
description: It's not easy being a Jew in a Jewish neighborhood [''Is It a House or a Synagogue?'' Aug. 20]. Given the orthodox mentality, the same could probably be said about other major religions -- the Muslims and Christians -- in those places where the orthodox versions live juxtaposed with liberal co-religionists.

title: An End-of-Summer Smile on Wall St.
description: Now that many schools are back in session, a pop quiz seems in order. Who is going to win the presidential election? Just kidding. The real question is, what will the stock market do leading up to the election?

title: History 101
description: ISLAM

title: Fashion Central, The East Village
description: Seventh Street in the East Village is becoming a fashion center, with boutiques opening regularly. One new addition is Cherry Bishop, opened in June by the New Zealand-born designer of the same name. She opened her first store, Halo, in the East Village in 1991. The new location is at 117-119 East Seventh, near First Avenue.

title: When Good Eye And Goodly Fortune Come Together
description: BACK in the 1920's, the designer Basil Ionides was one of Britain's brightest aesthetic lights. His books -- ''Color and Interior Decoration'' and ''The Modern English Interior'' -- were best sellers, the former chockablock with watercolor illustrations of his homes, prime examples of a scientific approach to the play of light on bold but carefully graded color schemes. Ionides's professional piece de resistance was the 1929 mirror-and-glass decoration of the Savoy Theater in London, whose icy glitter still staggers the eye.

title: Home-Grown Innovation, Home-Grown Workers
description: THE chronic problem of the nation's high-technology labor force? Simple: There isn't enough of it.

title: Unanswered Questions Could Hound Groh and Jets
description: The Jets' regular season begins today against Green Bay at Lambeau Field, but the restiveness that accompanied an off-season of extraordinary tumult may linger for a while. An almost eerily quiet training camp -- a quiet assured in some part by the trade of receiver Keyshawn Johnson -- gives way to a season in which the Jets will be required to solve their mysteries as a team just as surely as they must solve opposing defenses.

title: All's Fair
description: THE RULES

title: Stock Funds Lose Assets As Money Markets Gain
description: Combined assets of the nation's mutual funds fell by 0.6 percent, to $7.08 trillion, in July, the Investment Company Institute reported last week, with assets of stock funds down 2 percent, to $4.23 trillion. Net new cash into stock mutual funds fell to $17.58 billion, from $22.14 billion in June.

title: Basilicata, Rock Hard And Still Untamed
description: NIGHTFALL does not come gently to Matera. It's more like a flash flood rising from the bottom of the ravine. One minute, I am watching a couple of bats wing over the rooftops beneath the hotel terrace where I sit. The next minute, they are invisible. The houses on the hill go gray as tombstones, and all that is human and terrestrial turns pale and wan.

title: Article 2000090392147126915 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: North Caldwell Journal; Acre by Acre, an Old Family Farm Fades Away
description: If you stand in the middle of James Matarazzo's eggplant patch and gaze up toward his grandfather's farmhouse, which dates to the 1840's, you can almost imagine what life was like here before the split level and the strip mall turned New Jersey into the paradigm of American-style sprawl.

title: Shana Elberg, Erik Weinick
description: Shana Alyse Elberg, a daughter of Judi and Darryl Elberg of New City, N.Y., was married on Thursday evening to Erik Bradley Weinick, the son of Susan and Howard Weinick of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Henry Sosland performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: An Unsettling Murder in Mount Vernon
description: TO her teachers at Nelson Mandela High School here, Rasheda J. Farmer was a good student and a lively presence in class. A pretty 17-year-old with smiling eyes and elegantly braided hair, she was intelligent and polite and seemed likely to do well after graduation.

title: Hannah Ross, Thomas Adelman
description: Hannah Summers Ross, the daughter of Sarah S. Oldham and David A. Ross, both of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Adelman, a son of Margaret F. Adelman and Dr. Jack Adelman of Somis, Calif. Justice Denise R. Johnson of the Vermont State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Inn at the Round Barn Farm in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: E-Business Alters ABC's of Real Estate
description: AS telecommunications companies lease and modify space for their special needs and for the elaborate specialized pieces of equipment that are the backbone and nerves of electronic commerce, landlords and brokers are adapting some of their ways of doing business to adjust to the new conditions.

title: Mary Pratt, John Gustafsson
description: Mary Elizabeth Pratt and John Christopher Gustafsson were married yesterday by Canon John Luce at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: Heading Off High Bills For Heating
description: WITH home heating oil and natural gas prices expected to skyrocket this winter, homeowners now have more incentive than ever to take whatever steps are necessary to keep the cold air out of their houses and the warm air in. Here are some tips for squeezing every last B.T.U. out of every bit of oil or gas your heating system consumes.

title: Dealers Struggle to Cope With Rush to Replace Firestone Tires
description: Tire and car dealers struggled today to cope with customers who wanted to go on driving vacations for Labor Day weekend but were leery of relying on their Firestone tires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOFFATT, MARION MAUSHART
description: MOFFATT - Marion Maushart. Died peacefully on August 31, 2000 at her home in Southern Pines, N.C. She was the beloved wife of the late James V. Moffatt, long time Administrator at The Hill School. Her sister Edna Elsner, three children James V., Jr., Ronald F. and Camille M. Bertram and ten grandchildren survive her. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the MMM Memorial Fund, The Hill School, Pottstown, PA. 19464.

title: It's Time To Make, Uh, Seasonal Resolutions
description: NEW Year's Day has the reputation for renewal, for being the time when we take stock and set goals and cast off bad habits and worn-out socks. But thinking people know that the true moment for such stuff is now, when summer gives way to fall. The three-month-vacation mind-set is reluctantly jettisoned, a collective deep breath is taken, and we all regird our loins, figuratively speaking, except for those of us who play football for a living.

description: MY JULIET

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Elizabeth and After

Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, ALLYN VAN BAALEN
description: ZUCKER-Allyn Van Baalen. 77, wife and best friend of Robert for 58 years. Mother of Micky (Lorry), Alan and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Garrett (Stefani), Douglas Brent (Jasmine), Douglas Alan (Jennifer), Liz (Mark) Gallo and fortunate great-grandmother of Sarah, David, Stephanie, Alexis, Sebastian and Jessica. Service at C.W. Post Chapel, 11 AM, Monday, September 4. Interment private. Contributions in her honor may be made to C.W. Post, L.I. University.

title: In the Paperless Era, the Problem Is Too Much Paper
description: All of his clients old economy or new, law firms or tech firms, hospitals and colleges or cellular phone companies -- have the same problem: Paper.

title: The End Seems Near for Garden State Race Track
description: Back in 1942, an evangelical preacher from nearby Collingswood named Carl McIntyre led a prayer vigil for 30 days of rain in southern New Jersey.

title: MUSIC; Rap Takes Root Where Free Expression Is Risky
description: TO many American fans of the Buena Vista Social Club, the group's lilting melodies and crooning octogenarians embody the heart and soul of Cuban musical culture. But not to the Cuban rapper Irak Saenz. ''With rap I can express everything about my life,'' Mr. Saenz said.

title: The Right to Pray Whenever God Calls
description: What does Joseph Lieberman, the Democratic vice presidential candidate, have in common with public school students who pray at school football games? Both have been accused of violating the separation of church and state -- but both are, instead, proving that the doctrine is alive and well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLINE, CHARLOTTE DALTON
description: BOLINE-Charlotte Dalton. The management and staff of Brown Harris Stevens wish to express our heartfelt sadness at the passing of our associate. Her cheerful nature and able counsel will be missed by her colleagues. Our sincere condolences to her family.

title: New Rochelle Tries for a Comeback
description: WHEN Marc Jerome walks down the street from his office at Monroe College's campus here he passes vacant buildings, reminders of the decline of what was once a favorite destination for Westchester residents.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HEADLONG, by Michael Frayn. (Picador USA, $14.) The author uses his skills as a playwright to create a fast-moving internal novel about a philosopher named Martin who stumbles onto what he suspects to be an unknown Bruegel masterpiece in the home of a country gentleman. With dollar signs in his eyes, Martin plays scholarly detective to uncover the painting's provenance, hiding his scheme from his wife and gambling his career and marriage. In this ''rueful and amusing'' tale, which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1999, ''the big action is Martin turning a page -- movingly, comically, delightfully,'' Randy Cohen wrote here.

title: Two to Preside Over General Assembly
description: Unable to decide whether this year's or last year's General Assembly president should be in the chair for a summit meeting of member nations this week, United Nations members took the diplomatic way out. Both will preside.

title: Teresa Goebel, Michael Zwibelman
description: Teresa Kathryn Goebel, a daughter of Kathryn W. Fuller of Duluth, Minn., and Louis E. Goebel of San Diego, is to be married today to Michael Andrew Zwibelman, the son of Bonnie and Myron Zwibelman of St. Louis. Rabbi Ben Leinow is to perform the ceremony at the Loews Coronado Bay Resort in Coronado, Calif. The Rev. Carolyn Owen-Towle and the Rev. Thomas Owen-Towle, Unitarian Universalist ministers, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Mills in Combat
description: To the Editor:

title: As in Baseball, All the W's Count the Same in the End
description: If you want to take first prizes, remember that quantity counts more than quality. It is the highest score that wins tournamaments, not who played the cleverest or most original game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-in-law, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed, Brigitte Lasky and Hexi Hegewisch-Lasky. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. Services Tuesday, September 5, 1:15 PM at, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: All Work and How About Some Play, Too?
description: AT Yarde Metals, an aluminum and steel distributor based in Bristol, children and dogs sometimes go to work and employees can occasionally be found napping on the job.

title: WEATHER CUTS EARNINGS
description: Park and recreation revenues in Westchester are down sharply because of the weather this spring and summer. The mid-year financial projections show that earnings from Playland, the county center and the county parks, pools and golf courses are down $400,000 so far, from a budgeted $24.8 million to an estimated $24.4 million, Leslie K. Bennett, the county's deputy budget director, said. Low temperatures and rain kept people off the beaches and golf courses. ''We are hoping for a dry fall,'' Kathleen M. Carrano, the county budget director said. Al Baker

title: The Pressure Is on Miller, but Other Analysts Will Also Be Tested
description: Not since Fox snared CBS's former National Football League television heirloom in 1993 has a change in the sport's broadcast landscape provoked as much curiosity as Dennis Miller's hiring on ABC's ''Monday Night Football.''

title: Democrats Smell Blood on the East Side
description: Over the last three decades, State Senator Roy M. Goodman has become a fixture in the politics of Manhattan's East Side and a leader of the moderate wing of the state's Republican Party.

title: Town Says No to Shorts on the Job
description: SANITATION workers in Cortlandt were a little surprised last month when town officials told them they could no longer wear shorts on the job.

title: Hi, There, Um, Laura
description: In a thriving economy many fashion fads are spawned but few survive past a single season. A handful, however, briefly extend their shelf life by crossbreeding. Craze in point: ID hoop earrings, a hybrid of two of last season's jewelry rages (nameplate necklaces and oversize gold hoop earrings). These are chunky, 14-karat-gold bamboo hoops with a nameplate written in cursive across the middle. They are the new hot seller at Patricia Field ($275) at 10 East Eighth Street. Laura Eisen founder of girlshop.com says she has had 150 orders for nameplate earrings since she posted them on her site a week and a half ago. At girlshop .com, the earrings cost $195 and take two weeks for delivery. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Business Exports Its Values to the Classroom
description: WHEN Philip Como walks into Smithtown High School later this week, he plans to welcome his students by dumping a pile of (discarded) textbooks into a wastebasket.

title: Bookend; Formerly Known as Prince
description: Riding the subway home late one night this summer, I looked up from my newspaper and noticed a man in a fedora and a dark pinstriped suit -- it was dirty and frayed, but recently pressed. He was lost in a slender, well-worn paperback adorned with a familiar etching. It was NiccolRated R Machiavelli, peering out from the cover of his most famous work, ''The Prince.''

title: Taxi Troubles
description: To the Editor: In his article ''Within the Walls of Lucca, Both Mystery and Music'' (Aug. 13), Bernard Holland says, on the subject of taxi drivers: ''Minimal fleecing -- the furtive surcharge of unspoken tourist tax -- should be accepted with good grace.''

title: Psychic Hotline

title: Dokic Looks Within in a Comeback Victory
description: Late yesterday morning, Jelena Dokic found herself losing, 4-1, in the first set to Francesca Schiavone. The 17-year-old Dokic looked to the family seats in Louis Armstrong Stadium for encouragement, out of habit, and when no one was there, she had to look inside, again out of habit.

title: MEADOWLANDS MALL
description: The first public hearing by the United States Army Corps of Engineers on the proposal to build a mega-mall, entertainment center and office complex in the Meadowlands drew more than 1,000 people last week. One more hearing will be held Sept. 25 at the Henry P. Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford and written comments will be accepted until Oct. 11.

title: The Long, Strange Trip Continues
description: The jam band phenomenon that has its roots in old-time jazz and blues and was expanded in the 1960's lives on with the band now known as the Other Ones and their current tour, Further 2000.

title: Police Stations Could Ease The Bathroom Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FINED
description: Seton Hall has been fined $12,600 by the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration for failing to train its student residence advisers how to respond to fire alarms and for not providing them with protective gear in the event of a real fire, the agency said last week. A meeting between university and OSHA officials is scheduled for Tuesday to discuss measures Seton Hall has taken to address the violations. Three freshmen died in a dorm fire at Seton Hall in January. Steve Strunsky

title: Mrs. Clinton Seizes a Chance For Publicity at the State Fair
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband sat atop a counter at Gianelli's Sausage stand at the New York State Fair here today and, with dozens of cameras clicking and whirling, consumed two huge, gloppy sausage sandwiches, loaded with onions, peppers and barbecue sauce.

title: The Heavy Metal Joke Not Everyone Got
description: WHEN the makers of ''This Is Spinal Tap'' first showed their movie to test audiences in 1984, the reaction was noteworthy. The people hated it. Shot in deadpan documentary style, the film tells the story of a fictional heavy metal band blazing a spandex trail across America. The audience did not get it. Some objected that the band was too obscure and poor; others thought the filmmakers should have chosen a good band, like Led Zeppelin. One answered every question about the movie with three cryptic letters, DNA. ''It took us a long time to figure out what this meant,'' said Michael McKean, who played the band's singer and guitarist, David St. Hubbins. ''Finally, we realized it meant Does Not Apply. She disliked everything about the movie so much that no possible standards could apply to any part of it.''

title: Another Aspect Of Young Suicides
description: Though commendable, your article on teen suicide (''Working to Stop Suicides of Teenagers,'' July 30) is remiss in failing to address the issue of homosexuality.

title: The Nation: Reality Bites; Hovering Where Rich and Poor Meet, the Mosquito
description: MANY passengers flying out of Africa are familiar with the ritual: the doors close and the flight attendants ask those wearing contact lenses to shut their eyes. Some passengers pull blankets over their heads. Then they pop the tops on two cans of a sickly sweet aerosol and walk quickly down the aisles, a white cloud billowing behind them which the air-conditioning quickly dissipates.

title: A Computer With Star Power
description: What weighs 1.4 tons, lives in Yorktown Heights and is as popular as Larry King and Carmen Electra? Hint: It defeated Garry Kasparov at chess in 1997.

title: A Restaurant That's All Lobby
description: Washington lobbyists, shod in tasseled loafers, once inspired someone to describe their eager, sartorially enhanced gatherings outside the closed doors of Congressional hearing rooms as Gucci Gulch. Now they have their own watering hole, the Caucus Room, and the list of investors is top heavy with a who's who of lobbyocracy.

title: This Is Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Wilcox, Eric Pan
description: Elizabeth Roberts Wilcox, the daughter of Cynda B. Wilcox and Philip C. Wilcox of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Eric Juien-Yi Pan, a son of Grace C. Pan of Pittsburgh and the late Dr. Yuan-Siang Pan. The Rev. Louise J. Lusignan performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bronx River Sentry

title: Science Fiction
description: Overreaching is an occupational hazard for science fiction writers, who regularly create -- and destroy -- societies, worlds, entire universes. BRAIN PLAGUE (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95), by Joan Slonczewski, is a case in point. The underlying premise, borrowed from Slonczewski's 1998 novel ''The Children Star,'' is immediately appealing: sentient one-celled creatures called micros can exist symbiotically within human skulls. Peering out through our eyes, communicating with us via flashes of light, colonies of micros can boost a person's brainpower or, by releasing addictive doses of neurotransmitter, seize control of their host.

title: Not Your Father's Pre-Movie Fare
description: I keep hearing how movie theaters are sprucing up their menus to try to satisfy pickier palates, but how come I never wander into those places? I'm usually packing a horse-like hunger when I go to the movies, foolishly postponing dinner for a dose of unreality. More often than not, the concessions counter is packed with the same provender I've ogled since I wore Buster Browns. Only these days the teenagers behind the counter offer not to butter my popcorn, but to douse it with ''butter-flavored'' goo. No thanks. Salvation, at least in Tenafly, lies in a closet-sized shop next door to Clearview Cinemas. At Cactus Sushi and Fresh Juice, the interior is spotless, spare, inviting. My first time here, I ordered an eight-piece sushi box with a California and Tekka maki roll ($8.50), and braced myself. How good can fast-food sushi be? At Cactus, it's delicious. The food is fresh, the chef engaging, the wait, well, typical. Everything is made to order, as it should be, and you should build time into your foray if you plan to eat first (bistro tables await you on the sidewalk) and catch a movie. There are sushi rolls, veggie rolls, and dozen or so specialty rolls. Cactus also sells about 20 fresh-squeezed juices, fruit shakes and smoothies. At Cactus, you eat abundantly and well without feeling fleeced. And there's not an drop of faux butter in sight. JOSEPH D'AGNESE

title: Judge Savors Low-Key Role In High-Stakes Secrets Case
description: This was a day of high legal drama, as a last-minute government maneuver thwarted defense efforts to free the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee on bail and left the federal district judge hearing the case, James A. Parker, suddenly on the sidelines as the action leapt to an appeals court in Denver.

title: Lives; It's a Mad World
description: When I was 18, I believed that my world and that of my parents could coexist peacefully. It was 1966, the beginning of the blackest period of Brazil's military dictatorship, a period when that external repression was gradually becoming internalized. I did my best to get good marks at my Jesuit school. I worked every afternoon, but at night I wanted to live out my dream of being an artist. Not knowing quite where to begin, I became involved in an amateur theater group. Although I had no desire to act professionally, at least I was among people with whom I felt some affinity.

title: A Child's War
description: GERMAN BOY A Refugee's Story. by Wolfgang W. E. Samuel. Foreword by Stephen E. Ambrose. Illustrated. 357 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $30.

title: Flower Power, With PowerBooks
description: This is the time of year when much of Silicon Valley, and a good portion of the downtown San Francisco establishment, junior division, shift their networking scene to the Black Rock Desert, 100 miles or so north of Reno, Nev. There, about 28,000 people attend Burning Man, a high-tech music and arts festival, of sorts, that has been compared to Woodstock, Carnival and Mardi Gras. Tickets for the festival, which culminates this weekend, are $200 and up.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about cruising the Inside Passage of Alaska on a small ship misstated the range of the author's trip. The ship did indeed stop on the mainland, at the ports of Skagway and Haines. It did not stop only at island ports.

title: From a Cold Spring Patio, a Hudson View
description: SEEING the widening Hudson River Valley through the rain and mists that have plagued our summer has not detracted from its loveliness. As Monet understood and depicted in his many paintings of Rouen's cathedral, every moment and every weather can bring a stirring new impression. And where better to take in this view than from the very edge of the river -- from the lawn or patio of North Gate here, or through the broad windows of its dining room?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMES, DR. JEAN SCHMIDLAPP
description: HUMES-Dr. Jean Schmidlapp. Born December 24, 1924, nee Jean Cooper Schmidlapp, of Locust Valley, NY, died on September 2, 2000, after a long illness. Dr. Humes was the daughter of Carl Jacob and Frances Cooper Schmidlapp, and widow of lawyer and former Ambassador of the United States to Austria, John Portner Humes, Sr., who died in 1985. She was the mother of six sons. Dr. Humes attended the Greenvale School, Foxcroft, Vassar College with a BA in 1945, and Cornell Univeristy Medical College with an MD in 1949. She was a member of the Executive Committee of the AmericanAustrian Foundation, Inc., of which her husband was a founder. She was a member of the Piping Rock Club and the American Medical Association. She is survived by five sons, David Bryant of Woodstock, VT, Carl Schmidlapp of Lattingtown, NY, Christopher Leftwich of West Palm Beach, FL, Andrew Russell of Great Barrington, MA, and Francis Cooper of Mill Neck, NY. Her first son, John Portner Humes, Jr., died in 1990. She had eleven grandchildren. Service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown on September 5, 2000, at 11 AM. Flowers can be sent to St. John's. Interment private.

title: An Abusive I.N.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISICK, DR. MICHAEL
description: DISICK-Dr. Michael. 90, of Scarsdale, NY, August 31. Cherished husband of Mae; devoted father to Barbara Korsen & Elaine Snider; beloved grandfather and greatgrandfather. Former dentistry chief at several noted Brooklyn hospitals. Brother of Drs. David & the late Sol. A man of humor, sincerity, generosity, and love. Dear Mike, you will be missed. Your Loving Family

title: A Wanderer Settles Down, Offering Jewelry
description: Anika Salame, originally from Sweden, has lived in the United States for 10 years, in Miami, New York and Los Angeles. Moving her boutique, Anika, which sells fashion accessories and jewelry, here from Los Angeles last month, she finally decided to stay in the city. ''I just prefer New York,'' Ms. Salame says. ''There's a lot more of everything here.''

description: On Aug. 20, 1986, an Oklahoma postal worker shot and killed 14 co-workers, then himself. In the years since, there have been other incidents of violence and murder, sometimes multiple murder, by current or former postal workers.

Jack Burlison, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Aviara, a hotel in Carlsbad, Calif.

description: In the time it takes to introduce yourself to a potential employer and say, ''I'm a good candidate for the position,'' you may be taking yourself out of the running.

title: Emily Blank, Alec Appelbaum
description: Emily Dora Blank and Alexander Eric Appelbaum are to be married this evening at American Park at the Battery, a restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Lawrence Kushner is to perform the ceremony.

title: YONKERS: CITY SUED ON HOUSING PLAN
description: Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, an environmental group based in White Plains, has sued the city of Yonkers, the county and the state in connection with a plan to build 17 units of low-income housing in Rory O'Moore Park. The housing is to be built as part of the longstanding federal desegregation order. Gudrun Lelash, the group's executive director, said Yonkers had violated the agreement it reached on May 25 with the county, which owns the park. Under the agreement, the city could use 4.25 acres of the 38-acre park for housing on the condition that the city dedicate another 25 acres to its park system within 60 days. But William M. Mooney, Yonkers corporation counsel, said the city had already dedicated 26 acres of parkland in 1998 that satisfy the terms of the agreement. ''The claims by F.C.W.C. are false. We feel this lawsuit has no merit,'' he said. Robert Worth

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay last Sunday with photographs of Africa on display at the Brooklyn Museum of Art misstated the closing day of the exhibition. It is Sept. 24, not Sept. 17.

title: Ideas & Trends: Courts of Public Opinion; The Tennis Balls Were White Once, Too
description: EVERY Grand Slam awards a silver trophy and a hefty pile of green to the player who wins seven straight matches over the course of two grueling weeks. But in front of the television or from the nosebleed seats, fans become armchair umpires of what's really in and out. Their prize? Call it the Golden Hanger.

title: The World; American Justice Tackles Rights Abuses Abroad
description: AS the soldiers raped and beat her in front of her two children, a Bosnian refugee recalled, they taunted her, saying there was nowhere she could turn for help.

title: Puppets Tragic and Funny
description: SOME puppets simply tug at your heartstrings. Others tackle more serious subjects. The marionettes shown here confront religion, AIDS and celebrity worship, among other topics. Ronnie Burkett's Theater of Marionettes production, ''Street of Blood,'' will be staged at the New York Theater Workshop as part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, FLORENCE M.
description: KATZ-Florence M. Beloved wife of Jerome. Cherished mother of Alan (Joyce) and Susan (Seth Truwit). Loving grandmother of Marjorie, Brittany, Alison, Elana, Noah and Jillian. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, September 3rd at 11:15 AM.

description: THE first chapter of ''Joy Shtick,'' Joy Behar's rambling memoir, is called ''Trapped at Exit 60'' and describes, in often hilarious detail, the three years she spent in Centereach, ''totally isolated from civilization, but without the nice scenery.''

title: No Moats Here
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bard of American Politics, Still Campaigning
description: GORE VIDAL wrote ''The Best Man'' in 1959, a time when Joseph McCarthy's legacy endured, when Adlai Stevenson and Richard Nixon were among the nation's leading politicians, and when Mr. Vidal counted as his friend a young senator from Massachusetts named John F. Kennedy. The play, first produced on Broadway in March 1960, eight months before Kennedy was elected president, drew on these influences to become a tale of politics that may seem improbable today: a stark struggle of two men of obvious complexity, set during a national political convention where decisions of consequence were actually made.

title: Making the Movie They Let You Make
description: TO hear Chris McQuarrie tell it, the origins of the new film he wrote and directed, ''The Way of the Gun,'' lay in disgruntlement, frustration and anger. We pick up the story about four years ago, shortly after he was awarded the Oscar for his screenplay ''The Usual Suspects.'' At that point, the project that most enthralled Mr. McQuarrie, who appears to be one of those formidably intelligent people who can produce a trove of well thought out, cogently stated reasons in support of his opinions, was to direct the life story of Alexander the Great.

title: Are School Vouchers the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS; For Better or Worse, Wed to Olympic Rings
description: IT was the Olympic version of ''Say it ain't so, Joe.'' Disgusted by the bidding scandal emanating from Salt Lake City, which will host the 2002 Winter Games, David D'Alessandro, the chief executive of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance, last year ordered the Olympic rings logo stripped from his company's television ads, its annual report, even its stationery -- all the nifty extras intended to help justify a four-year, $55 million sponsorship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APT, TAMI
description: APT-Tami. We are very sad to say that the indomitable Tami, wife of dearly departed Gus, beloved mother of Charles and Ursula Apt, Lee Apt, and Jane Apt Bevans, aunt of Florrie Milan Beldock, Brett Beldock, Gregg Beldock, loving grandmother of Gregory, Sam, Jane, Jeffrey, Jill, Loren and Maggie, greatgrandmother of Sophia, Luke, Gus, Danny, Calvin, Malcolm, Douglas, Gregory and Jack, died on August 28, 2000. A memorial service will be held in late September or early October in New York.

title: A Warrior Whose Only Charm Is His Lack of It
description: AMONG Shakespeare's tragic heroes, Coriolanus stands apart. The others seduce us. This one -- Rome's greatest warrior turned Rome's fiercest scourge -- scorns even to try. When his city casts him out, he joins forces with the enemy, sparing his compatriots not out of clemency but out of deference to his gorgon mother.

title: Can a Ferry Swim With the Fishes? A Discussion Ensues
description: A fast-ferry company and a recreational fisherman's club are squaring off over who will use a $6 million city Parks Department pier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IBARGUEN, PETER ''DONNY''
description: IBARGUEN-Peter ''Donny''. On September 1, 2000. Past-president L.I. Skydivers Association, Secretary of EUZKO ETXEA BasqueAmerican Club, Chairman Pan Am Blood Bank, TWU Senior Shop Steward JFK Local 504. Survived by beloved cousins, Helen, Marie and Joanne Abascal, NYC and many cousins in the Basque provinces Vizcaya, Spain. For further information, call Casey Funeral Home, 718-447-4242.

title: A Finding on Death Row
description: Not all Texas murder defendants get a decent courtroom defense. Not in the case of Delma Banks Jr., who was sent to death row in 1980. His lawyer, a former district attorney, failed ''to investigate or interview punishment-phase witnesses,'' a federal magistrate later found. On Aug. 18, David Folsom, a Federal District judge in Texarkana, Tex., endorsed that finding, which was first reported Wednesday in The Texarkana Gazette, and ordered either a sentence reduction or new sentencing trial for Mr. Banks. Richard A. Oppel Jr.

title: Discrimination by the Scouts
description: The Boy Scouts of America turned to the United States Supreme Court earlier this year to protect its constitutional right, under the freedom of association, to exclude gays from its membership. The Boy Scouts asserted that barring gays was fundamental to its mission. But now, as local governments, corporations and individuals across the country withdraw their support from the Boy Scouts in response to this exclusionary policy, it is obviously time for the organization to reconsider its stance. The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., it is worth noting, does not discriminate against gays.

title: The Jewish Tipping Point
description: In their resentment over what they perceive to be Orthodox intolerance, many liberal Jews have done the unthinkable: they have utilized the legal process as a form of ''payback'' to Orthodox communities. This is an abuse of the very system that we all depend upon for our freedom of worship and freedom of assembly.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00: Counter Culture; All in the Family
description: What are the odds, do you imagine, in a country of around 270 million, that one living president could be directly related to another living one? If you assume that this is a democratic country, and that any adult could potentially be qualified to run for the highest office in the land, and you assume further that the job is open only once every four years and that only one person can fill it, then I think the odds are about the same as the likelihood of a meteorite hitting the White House. And yet here we are in one of the oldest democracies in the world with an even chance of electing in 2000 the son of the man who was elected president in 1988.

title: THE GUIDE
description: In Essex, Ships Ahoy!

title: For Chiefs in Crisis, It's Survival of the Sorriest
description: IT seems that you cannot turn on the television or open a newspaper these days without some sober-eyed chief executive offering a personal act of corporate contrition.

title: The Jewish Tipping Point
description: Now that Joseph I. Lieberman has been picked as the vice-presidential candidate on the Democratic ticket, I hope that the American electorate will be more tolerant of Orthodox Jews than Si Wachsberger is (Samuel G. Freedman, Aug. 13). If Lieberman were living in Beachwood, Ohio, I'm certain he would be voting in favor of building the Orthodox campus.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: MEDITERRANEAN AUTUMN -- First European Cruises has seven discounted sailings out of Genoa aboard its 800-passenger Flamenco this autumn. The 11-night trips sail the western Mediterranean, and among the ports of call are Almeria (for a trip to Granada), Malaga, Funchal, Tenerife and Lanzarote in Spain; Safi (for Marrakesh) and Casablanca in Morocco, and Marseille. Departures are Oct. 12 and 23; Nov. 3, 14 and 25 and Dec. 16 and 26. Rates range from $890 to $2,590 a person, based on double occupancy, for the October and November sailings (versus $1,710 to $3,690 originally); December cruises are $1,520 to $2,650 a person, double ($2,000 to $3,690 originally). Round-trip air fare to Genoa is extra. A package of eight shore excursions costs $491 a person. The Flamenco has a fitness center, movie theater and casino. Cabins have phones and TV. Call First European, (888) 983-8767.

title: A Gap in Analysts' Coverage
description: Shareholders of Gap Inc. may well wish that their brokers had advised selling months ago -- the stock is down 56.3 percent from a 52-week high of $53.75 on Feb. 4.

title: Patricia Keim, Peter Weingard
description: Patricia Hattie Keim, a daughter of Virginia and Richard Keim of New York, will be married today to Peter Ward Weingard, the son of Myra and Robert Weingard of Boynton Beach, Fla. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman is to officiate at the TriBeCa Rooftop in New York.

title: Prime Crop of Corn Is a Traffic Hazard
description: With green acres of cornstalks rolling as far as the eye can see, these few weeks just before the fall harvest are probably the loveliest time of the year here.

title: CARTER POWERS U.S. MEN
description: Vince Carter wowed a sellout crowd at the University of Hawaii yesterday in Honolulu, throwing down malicious dunks and dropping in long 3-pointers as the United States defeated a select team of American college players, 111-74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNER, ARLENE
description: PENNER-Arlene. Passed away August 26, 2000 at the age of 64. She was born January 17, 1936 in New York City and has resided in California since 1991. She is survived by her sons, Ethan and Joseph, & grandchildren, Rebecca & Daniel. Her unique spirit will always remain with those fortunate to have known her.

title: Bargain Flights Within Europe
description: FLYING around Europe has never been cheaper, especially for visitors from abroad. A new Oneworld Alliance air pass offers bargain fares to non-European visitors to 200 destinations in 50 countries in Europe and North Africa on member carriers -- including Aer Lingus, British Airways, Finnair and Iberia -- and a raft of regional affiliates.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Scenes From a Savage Nation
description: The images are almost unbearably repulsive -- charred human remains lying in coals, naked corpses dangling from the end of ropes slung over trees, bare-footed men hanging in groups, grotesquely mutilated bodies tied to poles. But what is most shocking is the crowds of perpetrators and witnesses -- many of them children -- posing casually without masks or shame, even smiling, next to the victims. ''Between 1882 and 1968, an estimated 4,742 blacks met their deaths at the hands of lynch mobs,'' the historian Leon F. Litwack writes in WITHOUT SANCTUARY: Lynching Photography in America (Twin Palms, $60), a harrowing record of racism and savagery drawn from the Allen-Littlefield Collection at the Robert W. Woodruff Library at Emory University. The photographs were taken between 1883 and 1960, and nearly all originally appeared on postcards, some with handwritten messages like, ''This is the barbecue we had last night,'' which was scrawled on the back of a card showing a burned torso dangling from a pole. Not blacks alone were killed: one postcard showing two Italian immigrants hanged in 1910 carries the inscription, ''Labor agitators lynched during the cigar makers' strike, Tampa Fla.'' Mob justice was carried out against men, women and entire families, in a kind of participatory public theater that featured picnicking, trophy collecting and ''excursion'' trains that brought in spectators. Litwack makes the troubling suggestion that the culprits and observers were not monstrous aberrations but more or less common people united in their fear and hatred of blacks and determined to protect their way of life against an outside threat. ''The photographs stretch our credulity, even numb our minds and senses to the full extent of the horror,'' Litwack writes, ''but they must be examined if we are to understand how normal men and women could live with, participate in and defend such atrocities, even reinterpret them so they would not see themselves or be perceived as less than civilized.'' Scott Veale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, SEYMOUR
description: ROSE-Seymour. Died in San Diego, CA., on July 13, at age 79. Son of Elias and Elsa Rose, Sy leaves loving sister and brother-in-law Sandra and Gene Arden.

title: In Search of Winning Issues
description: By tradition an intense new phase of the presidential campaign starts this weekend. Since experience suggests that whoever is ahead in the polls after Labor Day usually wins the race in November, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush are scrambling hard to gain traction on defining issues -- fiscal responsibility, health care and retirement security for Mr. Gore, and schools, tax cuts and defense for Mr. Bush. But a new measure of the Texas governor's troubles in the last two weeks came with his decision to launch a tough television ad with a personal attack on Mr. Gore's integrity. Suddenly a tone of alarm could be detected in a once-confident Republican campaign that had promised to remain positive.

title: The Yale Bowl: the Place Is Often the Draw
description: ONE of the state's richest autumn traditions is watching a football game at the Yale Bowl. It's a tradition that has changed very little since 1914 when the Bowl opened to 71,000 fans eager to see the Yale-Harvard game.

title: Philippine Captors Say American Hostage Is On a Hunger Strike
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines, Sept. 2  An American man kidnapped by Muslim rebels in the southern Philippines has gone on a hunger strike, the guerrillas said today.

title: FIRST PERSON; Teaching Chess, and Life
description: IF you were to walk down West 160th Street in Washington Heights, you would see drug dealers whistling to people in cars and handing off small packages to passers-by. As you walk further down the block, you would see residents who are too scared to sit and talk to their neighbors on the front steps. These families stay inside most of the time. You would see parents pick up their children from P.S. 4 and hurry off the block before trouble can start. This is my block and this is my neighborhood.

title: In the Region/Westchester; A Waterfront Project Gets the Go-Ahead in Ossining
description: AFTER two years of public hearings, a $35 million plan to redevelop a part of this village's downtown waterfront with a mix of rental housing and retail space has won a vote of approval from the village board.

title: Holocaust Exhibit at London Museum
description: A permanent exhibit devoted to the Holocaust has opened in a new five-floor wing of London's Imperial War Museum.

title: Fish Must Find New Homes As Pond Gets a Makeover
description: In 1858, when Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux were designing Central Park, the southeast entrance presented an uphill challenge, literally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, TAYLOR RASTRICK
description: BRIGGS-Taylor Rastrick. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, L.L.P., mourns with sorrow the September 1 passing of our dear friend, colleague, and former Chairman, Taylor Rastrick Briggs. An immensely gifted litigator, Taylor joined LeBoeuf in 1961, was made Partner in 1963 and served as Chairman for 10 years, from 1978 to 1988. He became Counsel to the Firm in 1995. A leader and mentor who exemplified integrity and grace, Taylor will be missed by all who knew him. We extend condolences to his wife, Jane, their four children, Cynthia, Jennifer, Pamela and Taylor, Jr., and nine grandchildren. A memorial service has been scheduled for 2 PM on Wednesday, September 6, 2000, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, MA.

title: A Partner Who Will Follow Your Lead
description: THERE are two bloodlines in modern puppetry: the ''low'' subversive tradition of Punch and Judy, which is sometimes called ''marketplace puppetry''; and the ''high'' tradition of Asian religious ritual and court ceremony, including Indonesian shadow puppets and Japanese Bunraku. Punch and Judy tend to bang into each other; the movement is bawdy and slapstick, and the action and speech are often explicit and violent in a way that would not be tolerable or feasible in human theater. High puppetry (which is not necessarily better than low puppetry) is gestural and exploits the same kind of control that is meaningful in ballet: it is a language for the superhuman, for gods and heroes, for stories told time out of mind to audiences that frequently know the narrative by heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHORY, WILLIAM J.
description: CHORY-William J. On September 1, 2000. Resident of Pawling, NY, formerly of NYC. Father of James, Robert and Susan Chory and Cynthia Zavras. Grandfather of Jennifer, Ashley and Robert Chory and Zachary Zavras. Funeral arrangements are incomplete at this time. Contact Horn & Thomes Funeral Home, 914855-3550.

title: Napa and Sonoma
description: Summer in Napa and Sonoma Counties is all giant blue skies, lush green vine-covered hills -- and crowds. Lots of crowds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAUENGLASS, TILLIE K.
description: FRAUENGLASS-Tillie K. On September 1, 2000. Devoted and beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Richard. Dear grandmother of Neil Frauenglass and Andrew Betts. Thanks, mom. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For further information contact ''The Riverside,'' 212-362-6600.

title: When a Train Station Is the Backdrop
description: THE trains might not always run on time, but Art/Place Gallery, in the Southport train station on the New York-bound side, is to all appearances a smooth running operation. It is a co-op that periodically elects new members. This year, eight artists joined the fold; it was a hefty increase bringing the membership to a still-manageable 30. Members have a one-person show once every three years. Some of the most interesting offerings of the gallery, however, are the kind of show that's up now, a sampling titled simply, ''Eight New Members.''

title: Welcoming a Maestro
description: To the Editor:

title: County Posts Gasoline Prices On the Internet
description: WESTCHESTER residents can now find the lowest prices for gasoline on a Web site run by the county.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00: The Ethicist; A Criminal Past
description: A few years back, I was convicted of assault, a felony. I was in college and had been drinking. I've since moved on to the professional world and, to secure my last two corporate jobs, I had to lie on my application regarding my criminal history. I hate the daily anxiety of being discovered but believe I had no recourse. What should I do? -- Anonymous

title: China Protests U.S. Rights Suit Against a Leader
description: China is demanding that American officials dismiss a federal civil lawsuit charging a high-ranking official with human rights abuses stemming from the 1989 military crackdown that killed hundreds of student protesters in Tiananmen Square.

title: In Wildwood, Another Fire Is Questioned
description: A blaze on the Wildwood boardwalk -- an area that has seen a disproportionate number of unexplained fires -- raged for about 12 hours last week, destroying four novelty stores and causing an estimated $1 million damage.

title: Editorial Observer; Attracting New Immigrants to the Heartland
description: Iowa isn't a crowded place. It wasn't crowded when I was growing up there in the 1950's and early 60's, and it isn't crowded now. In 1960, when I was in third grade, the state population was 2,757,537 and still slowly climbing, as it had been all century, until it reached a peak of just less than three million people in 1980.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONGELB, IRVING
description: KRONGELB-Irving. Died August 29, 2000, in New York City, age 82. He had a long career as Professor of Psychology and Director of Student Counseling at Brooklyn College, retiring in 1981. He was a devoted father, son, brother, husband, companion and friend, and dedicated his life to helping others. Irving is survived by his beloved parter, Ethel Elkin; son and daughter-in-law, Malcolm and Judy Krongelb of Acton, MA; daughter, Dory Beatrice of La Jolla, CA; and four sisters, Beatrice, Adele, Paula and Roslyn. He is remembered dearly by scores of friends and family who knew him as a nurturing, giving, gentle person. It was a privilege to have him in our lives.

title: In Chinatown, Bulgarian Red Means Wine, Not Politics
description: IT was 7 p.m. on a Tuesday, so Alex Dimitrov lounged in the corner booth of his then-quiet restaurant, Mehanata, smoking one Rothman's Special cigarette after another.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about spearfishing around Montauk misattributed a quotation. The spearfishing enthusiast who compared the sport's popularity in the 1940's and 1950's with its relative obscurity today was Chris Miller, not Jason Behan. A picture caption misidentified a man shown swimming with speargun in hand. It was Mike McCarthy, not Mr. Behan.

title: Annual West Indian Parade Set for Alcohol-Free Revelry
description: Revelers at the West Indian American Carnival Parade tomorrow will accept, although grudgingly, a ban on alcohol at their festivities, organizers say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHGORN, FRANK
description: GERSHGORN - Frank. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Allan (Elinor), Eleanor, Norman (Eileen) and Mark (Mary Beth), caring grandfather of Renee, Jennifer, Dana, Dyane, Jason, Ian, Neil, Thomas, Rachel and Luke & brother of Ida and Elsie. Services (Boulevard - Riverside Chapel), 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 10:30 A.M. Sunday.

title: Crime Continues to Decline
description: Violent crime in the United States dropped last year to its lowest level since the government began its annual national crime survey 26 years ago. Law enforcement officials credited crime-prevention programs, anti-gun campaigns, more police on the street, tougher sentencing and a healthy economy producing jobs. The rate of violent crime declined 10.4 percent in 1999, the Justice Department said, while crimes against property dropped 8.9 percent. But there still were an estimated 28.8 million violent and property crimes committed last year. Warren E. Leary

title: No Simple Answers to Rising Cost of Drugs for the Elderly
description: On the campaign stump, Vice President Al Gore pushes his plan for a Medicare prescription drug benefit as a humane effort to help older Americans who are being gouged by profit-hungry pharmaceutical manufacturers. In television commercials, Gov. George W. Bush's campaign characterizes the Gore plan as another example of bureaucracy run amok.

title: In the End, Cardinals Top Mets Once Again
description: Two inches, one hop and one foot separated the Mets from a shutout victory this afternoon. That is what they thought, at least, after falling to the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-1, losing in the ninth inning for the second game in a row.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PETERMAN, TOMMY DAVID
description: PETERMAN-Tommy David. September 3, 1992 In fond, loving memory. Douglas

description: A Labor Day parade will begin tomorrow at the American Labor Museum in Hale don, which was the rallying point for 24,000 striking silk workers in 1913, and end at the Great Falls in Paterson, the first planned industrial city in the United States.

title: Jessica Stretton, Charles Mackenzie
description: Jessica Mabel Stretton and Charles Rudd Mackenzie were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church in Providence, R.I. The Rev. Carson G. Taylor, a minister of the Universal Life Church and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: For the User Who Has Everything
description: Once Apple Computer's multicolored iMacs and sleek G4 Cubes had injected hip fashion sense into computer hardware and peripherals, it was only a matter of time before someone came up with a way to give the stuff the decadent gleam of conspicuous consumption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVEMBER, BARBARA
description: NOVEMBER-Barbara, 67. Of Great Neck, on August 31, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Peter, devoted mother of Michael (Debbie) and Ellen (Peter) Rigby. Grandmother of Adam, Pauline and Hannah. Sister-in-law of Robert and Eleanor. Funeral services were held on September 1. The family will be sitting Shiva Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to COPAY of Great Neck, or Temple Emanuel.

description: Weeks

title: Next, the Aryan Nations
description: In an attempt to seize the compound of the Aryan Nations, Morris S. Dees Jr. went to court in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. Mr. Dees, founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center, has won a series of civil right suits against the Ku Klux Klan and other racist organizations in a campaign to drive them out of business. The Aryan Nations compound has been a base for white supremacists for more than 20 years.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DAVID THEWLIS'S character Johnny in NAKED (1993) isnot easy to be around. As Vincent Canby wrote in his original New York Times review of the film, this is a man about ''as capable of expressing love as Jack the Ripper.'' Johnny is an angry, scruffy 27-year-old from Manchester, homeless in London, and people keep inviting him in, especially women. To whom he is not nice. But he's a great talker, he has some interesting observations (that the bar code is literally a sign of the Apocalypse, for instance), and eventually his pain and his journey begin to look like a microcosm of something all too familiar. This is an ugly film; it's also the director, Mike Leigh, at his best - Friday at 10:30 p.m. on IFC.

title: Career in the Balance, Gore Focused His Energy on a Book
description: One of Al Gore's Senate colleagues was worried about his late-night comings and goings.

title: Boom Box
description: I have had ''ad zapping'' technology in my house for years. It's one of the great inventions of the last 25 years, yet it gets no press. It's called the mute button.

description: Dr. Rita Evelyn Landman, a daughter of Josephine Landman and Dr. Silviu Landman of Vestal, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael Louis Gitlitz, the son of Sheila Gitlitz and Dr. George Gitlitz of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Lance J. Sussman is to perform the ceremony at Lyndhurst, a historic house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Odd Bedfellows Lead German Movement
description: BERLIN, Aug. 30  They are the unlikeliest of bedfellows: a former West German army officer trained in the United States and a longtime member of the East German Communist Party who spent much of his life teaching Marxist theory.

title: His Roots Still Local, Beetle Bailey Turns 50
description: FIFTY years ago tomorrow, a college kid named Beetle Bailey was introduced to comic strip readers in a dozen newspapers. He was first seen that day heading for Rockview University with his buddy, Freshman. As they reach the campus, Freshman asks Beetle about his luggage and Beetle holds up a toothbrush. Freshman then asks what Beetle proposes to do about clothes. ''Haven't you ever heard of roommates,'' Beetle said, thereby setting the tone for the ensuing decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, PHYLLIS BENAIM
description: O'DONNELL-Phyllis Benaim. In West Haven, Ct., on September 1, 2000. Of Guilford, CT; formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Wife of the late Edward J. O'Donnell. Friends may call Sunday, September 3rd from 2-4 PM at the Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT. Burial Private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, BERTRAM
description: SCHWIMMER-Bertram. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died August 24, 2000 at age 90, in Los Angeles, CA. Survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Beatrice; his son and daughter-in-law, Arthur and Arlene; and grandchildren, Elinor and David. Lawyer, musician, golfer, wit, he was cherished by his family, friends and clients, and will forever remain in our hearts.

title: Boom Box
description: Lewis's article reveals exhilarating prospects. I can't help thinking of my 6-year-old son, who stays glued to the set during pitches for Pokemon Pop-Tarts and the like. But the box will give me the ability to change all that. My parental powers will now include the ability to filter content and the ads he sees. There follows the dilemma of whether I should steer my little consumer toward the programming and products I want him to see, creating a kind of consumer clone of myself.

title: Sierra Leone Troops Added By the British
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Sept. 2  British officials said today that more troops are due to arrive in Sierra Leone next week, but that they are part of a routine rotation and not being sent to help free six British soldiers who have been held hostage by rebels in the West African country for more than a week.

description: The latest presidential preference poll by Gallup, like most recent preference polls, has George W. Bush and Al Gore virtually tied, 46 percent for Mr. Bush and 45 percent for Mr. Gore. But this time Gallup had some other questions, too, and here's what voters really think:

title: Where Saltwater Flows in Bluebloods' Veins
description: AFTER working all day at the Book Mark Cafe in Oyster Bay, Liz Roosevelt, 69, a retired history teacher from Cove Neck, stopped by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in Centre Island to pump water out of her 28-foot ketch, Glory. Nearby, 10 fellow club members played croquet on the artificial grass tennis courts. Diane McGaw, a 40-ish temporary employment agency owner with homes in Oyster Bay Cove and Manhattan, nursed a drink on the clubhouse's broad veranda. By the dock, Gary Van Dis, 47, of Brooklyn, the corporate creative director for Conde Nast, and Mark DeNigris, 47, a dentist from Lloyd Neck who came to the club by boat, puffed on cigars.

title: Boom Box
description: I suppose the pace of change described in Lewis's article will be frightening to some. What scared me more was the assertion that no one knows how to program a VCR! My technical skill is at best limited, but I've never had a problem with any VCR I've owned.

title: On a Summer Stage, Learning More Than Lines
description: IT was three hours before showtime, and the cast of ''West Side Story'' was making dinner at the Surflight Theater cast house in Beach Haven. Officer Krupkey was at the kitchen sink and Maria was eating takeout with some of the Jets' girlfriends. Suddenly they all broke out in song, like in a musical. After living together and performing in six musicals in three months, they had become an irrepressible ensemble.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGURI
description: IMBARRATO-Aurelia Caliguri. September 2, 1917-August 28, 1992. ''Love is something eternal-the aspect may change, but not the essence''. Valerie and Julia

title: Don't Call It a Gym
description: JOSH FINK always wanted to be a doctor. As a child he was weaned on TV shows like ''Medical Center'' and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.'' He was a biology major in college and went to medical school soon afterward. By the time he was 33, he was board certified as both an internist and a pulmonologist.

title: Finally Getting the Good Vibrations Back Again
description: FOR a guy known for fighting mental demons most of his life, Brian Wilson sure sounds happy.
