description: Catherine Christie Neuger, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Christie Cozad Neuger and Win J. Neuger, of both New York and Minneapolis, is to be married today to Gregg Anthony LeBlanc, the son of Regina M. and Roger G. LeBlanc of Waltham, Mass. The bride's mother, a Methodist minister, will perform the ceremony at the Memorial United Methodist Church in White Plains.

title: The Nation; A Sampler: Invoking an Even Higher Authority
description: George W. Bush, at the annual convention of B'nai B'rith International in Washington on Monday.

title: Band Hopes to Pioneer 'Long Island Sound'
description: AFTER winning WBAB's homegrown-talent contest in 1996, the rock band Nine Days went on to sign a contract with 550/Epic Records, and its debut single, ''Absolutely (Story About a Girl)'' became a Top 10 hit.

title: The Splatterer's Wife
description: Modern Art

title: Beautiful Trees From Ages Past
description: I enjoyed reading your article about the giant sequoia trees (''A Tree Grows Where?'', Aug. 6).

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00; Estate of The Nation
description: Seldom do good liberals face so stark a conflict between principles and pocketbook as I've been facing this summer. I'd known that the Republican Congress, with considerable Democratic support, was determined to repeal the federal estate tax. But then I learned that the property where four generations of my family have lived now has a market value of around $2 million, twice what it was when I last checked. Suddenly, the estate that my sisters and I stand to inherit began to look seriously taxable.

title: A Steam-Powered Landscape
description: JUST my luck,'' I muttered, gazing at the unattended welcome sign to Lassen Volcanic National Park in Northern California. ''STOP. Pay $10 here,'' it said. All I had was a $20 bill.

title: Where A Teenager Gives Orders
description: FOOTBALL season is here again, and as anyone who has been to a high school or college game in recent years knows, this is not your Aunt Gidget's cheerleading squad anymore. Today's cheerleaders tumble, vault, build human pyramids -- and sometimes exhibit higher athletic skill than the teams they're rooting for. Like gymnasts, cheerleaders work with coaches, choreographers and physical trainers, often attending summer boot camps to prepare for both the sidelines and competitions with other squads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURNAGHAN, FRANCIS D. JR.
description: MURNAGHAN-Francis D. Jr. On August 31, 2000. Husband of Diana Edwards Murnaghan; father of Sheila, George, and Janet Murnaghan, Mark and Daria Maneche. Father-in-law of Hugh Gordon, Elizabeth Chen and Alan Feinberg; brother of Patricia Robertson. A memorial service will be held at Walters Art Gallery on Wednesday September 6 at 5pm. Memorial contributions may be made to the Walters Art Gallery, 5 West Mt. Vernon Place, Baltimore, MD 21201.

title: PROVIDENT BUYS RIDGEWOOD
description: Provident Savings Bank, a Jersey City-based mutual savings bank founded in 1839, last week bought the 115-year-old Ridgewood Savings Bank of New Jersey, in a deal valued at $22.4 million.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00: On Language; Wired
description: After Bill Clinton expressed contrition at a preconvention interview at a church gathering in Illinois, the Rev. Bill Hybels, one of his pastoral advisers, put his hand on the president's shoulder and prayed with him, saying, ''Thank you, God, that you wired him up the way you did.''

title: Orthodox Viewpoints: Can They All Be Right?
description: In response to the Aug. 27 letter ''Building the Five Towns Through Mutual Respect'': Parking meters on Central Avenue and all side streets are in operation on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-03-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Melissa Basho, Sarah Stevens, Mendham, N.J., July 2000

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WestSide

title: The Too-Short Life Of a Roadside Garden
description: As I rode east on Sunrise Highway, today, I saw the band of chicory near the shoulder of the road, and it reminded me that John Updike had written that Foxy's eyes were as blue as chicory. I was soon looking at the other flowers. The yellow goldenrod was coming into full bloom. The thoroughwort was white in contrast. The grasses were reddish brown, and a reminder that there was a rush to flower, to set seed, and to complete the cycle that perpetuates life. I found a charming and insignificant orchid among the showier, larger inflorescences. It was a late-summer bloomer, Spiranthes or ladies'-tresses. What a delight!

title: A New Trial for American
description: After an election marred by charges of voter fraud, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru no doubt needs all the friends he can get. That could well explain Peru's decision to grant a new trial to Lori Berenson, the New Yorker who in 1996 was tried in secret before masked judges and sentenced to life imprisonment for terrorism. The case has been a thorn ever since in relations between Washington and Lima, but human rights officials remained wary, fearing that a new trial would be no fairer than the first. Hubert B. Herring

title: Where the Jobs Are On This Labor Day
description: IN a nation bent on shrinking government, no industry in the private sector generated as many new jobs over the past year as the federal government. Census takers, hired temporarily to count the population, bloated the federal payroll from the spring of last year through the spring of 2000, accounting for nearly 600,000 of 3.1 million jobs created during that period.

title: Ideas & Trends: Bombshells; Are There Any Nuclear Secrets Left to Steal?
description: THE abrupt turnaround in the public image of Wen Ho Lee from villain to victim, from atomic spy endangering the nation's security to computer nerd unfairly put behind bars for downloading harmless minutia, is raising new questions about what constitutes a nuclear secret these days. More than half a century after the making of the atom bomb, millions of former secrets have been either declassified or posted willy-nilly on Internet sites, even as the nuclear club has grown to at least eight members, with many more wanabees in the wings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIGSBERG, MOSES, PH.D.
description: KONIGSBERG-Moses, Ph.D. Of Framingham, MA, died at the age of 87 on September 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Sue, cherished father of Alan and Sheryl, he is also survived by brothers and sisters, Polly, Cissy, David, Saralee and Charles. He was predeceased by brothers Raphael and Haskell and sister Fannie. Dr. Konigsberg was a leader in the chemical, adhesives and packaging industries for over 50 years. He was founder and President of Polymer Industries, Inc. (1946-1965) and later founder and President of Metro Adhesives, Inc. (1965-1986).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIPILIS, NIKOLAOS (CAPTAIN NICK)
description: PIPILIS-Nikolaos (Captain Nick). Died Tuesday, August 29, 2000 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He is survived by his wife Peggy; four children Dite, Peter, Nicole, Christopher; two grandchildren Jordan and Austin; three sisters Loy, Chrisanthi, Mimika and brother George. Funeral services were held in his hometown of Pyrgos Elias, Greece on Saturday, September 2, 2000. For information call Litras Funeral Home: 718-658-4434.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Amanda Peet; Whipped Into Spotlight
description: THERE she was, Amanda Peet, but in the crowd on Tuesday night at the premiere of her new movie, ''Whipped,'' there was some confusion about which one she was. A stunning woman in a tight black, backless dress posed for the cameras. ''Is that her?'' one photographer asked.

title: Rewards of Volunteering Outweigh the Sacrifices
description: Re: ''The Brave, and Now the Few'' [Aug. 27]. Yes, it's imperative that we sustain membership in volunteer fire departments to ensure protection.

title: Selling Wall Street Wiles to a Mass Market
description: In last week's episode of ''Bull,'' the Wall Street-centered drama series that had its premiere on Aug. 15 on TNT, one of the show's principals, Hunter Lasky, a takeover artist played by Stanley Tucci, explains the facts of life to Carson Boyd, a junior associate played by Christopher Wiehl.

title: Police at Rally Far Outnumber Sparse Crowd
description: The third so-called Million Youth March, a Harlem rally that two years ago exploded in violence and was the subject of a fierce legal battle in 1998 and 1999, drew only a few hundred people yesterday.

title: Teen Queen In Concert
description: Christina Aguilera is a teenage sensation who might be precocious and pretentious, but at least she can sing. Unlike some of her more famous peers, the 19-year-old Ms. Aguilera can hold a note and even soar with it. But she tries too hard to imitate Mariah Carey. And some of those mannerisms and vocal tics don't even work for Ms. Carey.

title: A.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: TALKING MONEY with JOHNNIE L. COCHRAN JR.; Finding a 'Dream Team' for His Finances
description: BILL COSBY has a jet named Camille, for his wife, and even Oprah got a jet,'' Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. said recently over lunch at City Hall, a restaurant near his law office in Lower Manhattan. ''She wanted a plane just like Bill Cosby's. It's, like, amazing. He goes to sleep on the plane. It's wonderful.''

title: Learning by Just Being There
description: ''Accountability'' has become the favored solution to the nation's educational problems. For schools, accountability usually means that standardized tests identify failing schools, which then become candidates for administrative shakeups, closure or voucher programs.

title: Putting Wallboard in Its Place
description: BEFORE the introduction of gypsum wallboard, interior walls were finished with plaster. Wallboard is essentially a flat sheet of plaster sandwiched between sheets of special paper. Unlike plaster, wallboard is fastened to the studs in a dry state and for this reason it is frequently called drywall. (It is also sometimes called Sheetrock, but this is a trade name of the USG Corporation and should only be used in reference to its product.)

title: Unranked Bruins Stun Crimson Tide
description: They were coming off an injury-riddled 4-7 season and a year in which their defense was more porous than all but seven Division I-A teams. Just 75 seconds into a new season, the hard-luck U.C.L.A. Bruins lost their starting quarterback and allowed a 71-yard punt return by Freddie Milons.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel and Groh on the Spot, Even Before the Season
description: AS they prowl the sideline, Al Groh and Jim Fassel will each be surrounded by invisible jackals for different reasons: Groh in his first year as the Jets coach, Fassel in what could be his last year as the Giants coach.

title: Amy Zelson, Kurt Mundorff
description: Amy Sara Zelson, a forensic anthropologist, and Kurt Daniels Mundorff, a child-abuse investigator, are to be married today by Rabbi Charles D. Lippman at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: An Irony-Free New Jersey
description: Readers would be forgiven for assuming the title ''The Lost Legends of New Jersey'' announces an all-too-familiar exercise in Jersey Irony. But the author, Frederick Reiken, a native of the state, intends no irony. The setting is indeed New Jersey, and the novel focuses on the Rubin family, living in Livingston in the late 1970's and early 80's and their tangled relationships among themselves and with other families. Central are two teenagers, Anthony Rubin and his moody next-door neighbor, Juliette Dimiglio. The novel starts as the families share a house at the Jersey Shore in 1979 against a background of a tide of syringes that closes the beach. But that is historical realism, after all. Still Gary Krist, reviewing the novel in The Times, says that Mr. Reiken ''captures the poetry of the New Jersey condition.'' Poetry and New Jersey, in the same sentence, without irony. Imagine that. ''Lost Legends of New Jersey (Harcourt) is $24 in hardback.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You start adding things up and saying, 'Jeez, this isn't fun anymore.'''

title: Marianne Bailliet, Christopher Williams
description: Dr. Marianne Bailliet and Dr. Christopher Gerald Williams are to be married today at Branch Point Farm, in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. R. Tucker Bartholomew III, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GINGOLD, JEFFREY I.
description: GINGOLD-Jeffrey I. August 31, 1987. Much loved, much missed and always remembered. Your sisters, Arlene Letterman-Visakay and Bonnie Klein and their families.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: With more than 570,300 square miles of land mass, Alaska is about one-fifth the size of the continental United States. These facts add perspective to Timothy Egan's story, ''A Land So Wild, It's Getting Crowded'' (Aug. 20).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SACHAR, RUTH
description: SACHAR-Ruth. 9/3/99. Our MomYour wisdom, beauty and love is cherished and gives you the gift of eternal life. Randi and Michael

title: Energy Company to Open Offices in White Plains
description: With the opening of its regional headquarters in White Plains, Entergy Nuclear Northeast, a subsidiary of the New Orleans-based Entergy Corporation, will generate millions of dollars in taxes and local spending, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. The company, which in March bought the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor in Buchanan and the James A. FitzPatrick nuclear plant in Oswego, will move into three floors of the AT&T. building on Hamilton Avenue, said Carl W. Crawford, a company spokesman. The move will establish 50 new jobs. He said the company has a two-year lease and is committed to staying in New York State for at least seven years. Al Baker

title: Where G.E. Falls Short: Diversity at the Top
description: IN a few months, John F. Welch will step down as chief executive of the General Electric Company, leaving behind a remarkable 20-year run of earnings growth and near cultlike devotion. And the three front-runners to succeed this 20th-century business icon fit a pattern. All are gung-ho results-getters for the company -- and all are white men.

title: Steinbrenner's Rage Finds Knoblauch
description: George Steinbrenner did not even go to Yankee Stadium yesterday for Old-Timers' Day, but his words still hovered over the Yankees in a weird yet hardly shocking manner. Steinbrenner squawks when things bother him, which was what he did Friday and yesterday, and which was why the Boss became the focus over baseball, past and present.

title: Don't Use E-ZPass and Win a Prize
description: Usually, Robert Jones rolls pretty quickly through the toll plaza on the Garden State Parkway here, just west of Ocean City, flinging his 35 cents in the toll bin and going on his way.

title: In Astoria, Egyptian and Other North African Pleasures
description: FOURTEEN years ago, when Tony Meloni was setting up his immigration advocacy office on Steinway Street, he thought he would introduce himself to his neighbors at Alex's Deli. Naturally, he asked for Alex. But Alex was, in fact, Alexandria, Egypt, the native city of the owners, Mohammed, Maunir and Eddie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLO VEGO, GREGORIO
description: BELLO VEGO-Gregorio. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gregorio Bello Vego, associated with the Times from 1967 until retiring in 1991.

title: Spano in Drive to Maintain Airport Curfew
description: FORMER adversaries in the so-called airport border wars between Westchester and Connecticut came together last week to fight a common enemy.

title: Political Briefing; Playboy at Center Of New Political Spat
description: Remember the incident in which Representative Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat from Southern California's 46th Congressional District, took so much heat over scheduling a fund-raiser at the Los Angeles Playboy Mansion that she retreated to an innocuous film studio hall -- and then withdrew in a huff as a Democratic National Convention speaker?

title: The Pursuit of Less
description: AT dusk on a midsummer evening, not long after trading on Wall Street has closed for the day, nine people gather in a Greenwich Village living room to talk money. But this group speaks not of wringing more profits out of a bull market. They want to make do with less.

title: Russian Resistance a Key To Delay on Missile Shield
description: On Tuesday afternoon, visibly tired after an 11-hour flight from Cairo and still focused on the Middle East, President Clinton met at the White House with two of his closest advisers to hear Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen appeal one last time for making the bold decision to build a national missile defense.

title: Tracy Williams, Brendan Kennedy
description: Tracy Ann Williams, a daughter of Ethel and Kenneth Williams of Naples, Fla., is to be married today to Brendan Christopher Kennedy, the son of Dana Kennedy and William Kennedy, the novelist, of Averill Park, N.Y. The Rev. Derik J. Roy will perform the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Ballston Spa, N.Y.

title: Mr. Goodthumbs To the Rescue
description: SHOCKING but true: We paid a guy $82.50 to figure out how to plug in our DVD player.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: The article ''Sometimes, Smaller Is Better'' (Aug. 20) seemed to overlook the advantages of being on a large cruise ship. We have just returned from Alaska, where we spent a week on land and a week cruising the Inside Passage.

title: On His Stages, Life Is but a Dream
description: MARK LAMOS belongs to two worlds, in more ways than one. First, he seemed headed for a career as a classical violinist, a phase that lasted through four years at Northwestern University on a music scholarship. Then he discovered the theater, where his acting career lifted off in felicitous fashion, with an early Broadway appearance as the heartthrob Christian de Neuvillette opposite the Cyrano de Bergerac of Christopher Plummer and a subsequent Hamlet at the Old Globe in San Diego. Next, Mr. Lamos settled down as a director, first of straight plays, then also of opera. At 54, he works steadily in both genres. The combination, while not unique, is scarcely common. The track record, be it said, is exceptional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SY
description: SCHWARTZ-Sy. The entire staff of the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis and the Buoniconti Fund join in mourning the passing of our dear friend and colleague, our Public Relations Legend, Sy Schwartz. Our sincere gratitude for his passion and tireless efforts in the advancement of our message and our cause. He was the consummate professional and will be missed. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Sheila, his sons, Laurence and Matthew, to all his friends and family, and to his extended family of associates at Howard J. Rubenstein.

title: A Texas Game Park For Four-Wheeled Viewing
description: NOTHING quite grabs your attention like a giraffe poking his head in your car window and uncoiling his 17-inch-long black tongue in search of tasty tree bark. Or an eight-foot-tall, 300-pound ostrich pecking at that same window (now rolled up).

title: Modern Comforts, Ancient Sites
description: SPRING or autumn, Sicily heads my short list of holiday destinations. It combines sun; good, plain food; natural beauty; and enough history, art and architecture to leave me reeling. What it doesn't promise is a selection of great hotels. Apart from a handful of deluxe establishments in the larger cities and in Taormina, Sicily's innkeepers have been getting a bad press since Goethe bemoaned their shortcomings two centuries ago.

title: Museum's Plan Jars Harmony With Neighbors
description: The relationship between the Museum of Modern Art and the residents who live near its towering, grand white complex has for the last decade been one of cordial appreciation.

title: No Terminator, Please
description: The computer scientists at Brandeis University have created the first robotic system that can design and build other robots with almost no human help. The technique will merely speed up the process of designing robots, said Dr. Jordan B. Pollack, a professor of computer science at Brandeis and one of the researchers, and sharply drop the cost. Kenneth Chang

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, WILLIAM B.
description: MILLER-William B. Died on September 1, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn, devoted father of Rebecca and Louise, stepfather of Laura, Judy and Bob, and grandfather of Natalia and Kira, loving brother of Murray and Sue, cherished uncle of Lowell, Greg and Max. Services 10 AM Sunday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Is That Sky Behind the Billboards? New Zoning Rules Are Proposed
description: The sprawl of outdoor advertising has prompted a new citywide zoning effort.

title: A Missile Defense Strategy That Will Have to Wait
description: President Clinton left to his successor the decision on whether to deploy a national missile defense system. He said he would not do so himself because of test failures and diplomatic disputes. The president, speaking at Georgetown University, said he had decided not to act after two huge $100 million tests of the system failed to intercept incoming missiles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNETT, ALTON R.
description: BURNETT-Alton R. 9/3/05-5/7/90. Dear father and grandfather. We miss you always. The family

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about restaurants in the German wine country misstated the direction of the Mosel River. Its source is in the Vosges Mountains in France, and it flows northeast to the Rhine at Koblenz.

title: How de Kooning Built On His Ideas Over Time
description: De Kooning: In Process

title: The Money Pit
description: AS the mother of small children I have tried to keep my writing free of bathroom humor, but there are times it is irresistible. This is one of them.

title: A Club Too Good For Tiger Woods
description: IN the world of golf club design, Richard Helmstetter has a clear objective: ''inventing new stuff.'' Mr. Helmstetter, senior executive vice president and chief of new products at the Callaway Golf Company in Carlsbad, Calif., is in charge of a research-and-development team that produced the ERC Forged Titanium Driver, a club so powerful that it violates equipment rules set by the United States Golf Association.

title: Tatiana Riabouchinska, 83, Ballerina and Disney Model
description: Tatiana Riabouchinska, an international ballet star who was the model for the dancing hippopotamus in the 1940 film ''Fantasia'' and the oldest of the three ''baby ballerinas'' who brought fame to the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in the 1930's, died on Aug. 24 in Los Angeles. She was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Broadway Star Heads for Paper Mill
description: IF the audience for ''Anything Goes'' has anywhere near as much fun watching the show as the star and the director seem to be having in putting in on, the Paper Mill Playhouse will have an entertaining season opener.

title: The Silver Lining in Chernobyl's Cloud
description: There was a time when Leonid Aniskin was frightened of radiation. But that was before he went to work at the Chernobyl nuclear power station. He still remembers his first day on the job. It was in 1987, a little over a year after an explosion had ripped the roof off the plant's fourth reactor block. ''The trees in the forest behind the station had all died,'' he recalls. ''The pine needles had turned red and dropped off.''

title: BackTalk; Skepticism Is Taking A Vacation
description: Astronomers tell us that the light from dead stars reaches us long after those bodies are useless and cold, a metaphor we do not want to deal with this coming autumn in New York when Patrick Ewing and Mark Messier may once again be the suns around which their teammates and fans orbit. It could be time to call Madison Square the Gray Garden.

title: Showing On a TV Near You
description: ONE of the great things about having pay cable is the opportunity it provides for discovering little films that were denied theatrical release. Films like the awkwardly titled ''And Then You Die,'' a hard-as-pig iron 1987 gangster drama that used to pop up on HBO well past the shank of the evening.

title: Marna Bunce, Silas Beane III
description: Marna Kristin Bunce, the daughter of Dr. Marna Louise Crim of Monroe, Ga., and Roy Karl Bunce of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Silas Robert Beane III, the son of Rosa and Mr. Beane Jr. of Far Hills, N.J. The bride's father, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at Stanley Congregational Church in Chatham, N.J.

title: Taking a Closer Look At the Peril of Plum Island
description: Re: ''Plum I. May Test 'Mad' Sheep'' [Aug. 13].

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Andrea Jill London and John Jay Gilstrap misstated the number of the fire unit in the South Bronx from which the bridegroom's father, John Gilstrap, retired as a captain. It was Engine Company 92, not 82.

title: Re-examining Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Living Is Algebra
description: Madeleine St. John has a deft touch with dense topics. In her new novel, A PURE CLEAR LIGHT (Carroll & Graf, $22), St. John -- whose novel ''The Essence of the Thing'' was a finalist for the Booker Prize in 1997 -- casts a wry yet unwary eye on faith and fidelity, two cornerstones of existence that are, her characters discover, as transient and conditional as they had suspected. Not long after Simon Beaufort, a television director who is married with three children, takes up with a single and sophisticated accountant named Gillian Selkirk, Simon's generous and frazzled wife, Flora, takes up with the Anglican Church. For each, a new flirtation injects some needed vitality and uncertainty into an unbalanced life. Simon's affair is grounded in the physical; Flora's in the intellectual and spiritual. His growing fear of being discovered with his lover runs in tandem with Flora's determination to uncover something meaningful from her once-lapsed faith. As the vicar at Flora's church preaches, living is not simple and exact, like arithmetic. It's more like algebra, ''with all its x's and y's and z's: with all its unknowns.'' Simon and Flora have sophisticated and funky friends, interesting children and the ability to articulate dissatisfaction and disaffectedness without sounding droll or whiny. St. John's knack for smart dialogue speeds this story effortlessly along. Maggie Galehouse

title: With Clinton Due, Holbrooke Defends U.N.
description: With President Clinton preparing to visit New York this week for a meeting of world leaders at the United Nations, the American ambassador, Richard C. Holbrooke, said on Saturday that the United States must focus more on its ties with the organization, which he called ''indispensable'' to American foreign policy.

title: Young and 'Scary Smart' Policy Aide Earns Gore's Ear
description: THE wispy young woman paces at the back of the crowd, nodding incessantly as Al Gore makes another arcane point about the intricacies of Medicare. She claps gently and gives her fist a half-pump, almost as if afraid that someone will see. It is not every 27-year-old, after all, who can be driven to ecstasy by a candidate's pledge to put the Medicare surplus in a lock box.

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTRO, ANDRES
description: CASTRO-Andres. Died on September 2, 2000. Born July 27, 1917, in Havana, Cuba. Founder of the theater company ''Las Mascaras.'' Graduated from the Senior Dramatic Workshop of the New School for Social Research, B.F.A. Emigrated to the U.S. in 1961. Director of the Senior Dramatic Workshop at Carnegie Hall. Founder of the Westside Repertory Theater, which he directed for 25 years. Acting teacher of generations of actors. Married for 50 years to actress Antonia Rey. Visiting hours Monday, 3-5, 7-9 PM, at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street.

title: 'Big Brother' Hopes to Engineer an Exit, Then Add a Face
description: Trying to ignite viewer interest in ''Big Brother,'' the CBS reality television show whose ratings have paled in comparison with those of CBS's summer runaway hit, ''Survivor,'' the producers plan to pay one of the six remaining contestants $10,000 to quit this week, allowing the show to introduce a fresh face.

title: Robert H. Montgomery Jr., 77, Entertainment Lawyer, Dies
description: Robert H. Montgomery Jr., 77, a lawyer for prominent film, theater and art figures and the trustee of the Cole Porter Musical and Literary Property Trusts, died on Saturday at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y.. The cause was lung cancer, said his wife, Henriette.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, WILLIAM F.
description: LEAHY-William F. On Saturday, September 2, 2000, of Sag Harbor, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of the late Catherine (nee Carlin). Dear father of William C. and Michael J. Leahy. Loving grandfather of William G., Michael J. Jr., Lorraine Winsor and Christa. Also survived by eight greatgrandchildren. Mr. Leahy was retired from Met Life after 46 years of service. Served in Army Air Corps from 1940-1945, retiring as a lieutenant colonel. The family will receive friends Tuesday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, at Cecere Funeral Homes, 356 Westbury Ave, Carle Place. title: Quarreling Over Monuments

In the Arizona Cardinals, the favored Giants recognized a team in disarray and quickly stomped to a large early lead they gingerly protected in a 21-16 victory.

His most recent book was ''We Have Just Begun to Not Fight,'' about conscientious objectors during WWII. He is survived by his loving wife Marjorie, his treasured children John and wife Josefina, Michael and wife Allison, Shelagh, and Daniel; cherished grandchildren John Joseph, Isabel, Lacey, and Bailey; and his niece and nephew Patty Mele and Jimmy Keogh. title: MEDIA; Radio Station Leaves Earth And Enters Cyberspace

''We'll see you on the other side,'' Ms. Sandler told listeners, and moments later, the adult-alternative-format station ceased on-air transmission and began broadcasting exclusively on the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANDEE, SEYMOUR R. ''SY.''
description: CANDEE-Seymour R. ''Sy.'' A man of great courage and wisdom. His word was his bond, as was his reputation. He was a kind and loving husband to Peg, son Robert and Eileen, and grandsons Jason, Brian and Kevin, brother Morton. He graduated from St. John's University and was Captain of the soccer team, and All American Player of the Year. He became a successful realtor and had a wonderful and happy life. Services will be on Tuesday, September 5, at 1 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Donations to the Frank and Edith Dickstein Cancer Pavilion, White Plains Hospital, White Plains, NY. title: The Founders and the Torah
description: I don't know who the critics of Joe Lieberman's use of religious references in his vice presidential campaign talk to. Everybody I know, right and left -- especially right -- is cheering his view that America needs a constitutional space for religion in public, that Americans should talk more about religion in public, that this is the most religious nation on the planet and that secularists who wince at religion in public are to religion what Victorians were to sex.

title: Winning Streak Shows Few Signs of Stopping
description: It is now 23 matches and counting, but Venus Williams didn't know much about her winning streak until a reporter mentioned it to her last week.

title: A Confident Gore Sets Off on a Grand Tour
description: Vice President Al Gore begins the fall stretch of the campaign buoyant in the polls and brimming with confidence. Perhaps the strongest sign of this self-assurance is the Gore campaign's grab for Florida, a state that has been perceived as pro-Bush for months and where Gov. George W. Bush's brother Jeb is the governor. Mr. Gore will pop into Tampa in a 24-hour Labor Day tour and plans to pay frequent calls to other swing states, including Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan. PAGE A14

title: Radio Station Leaves Earth and Enters Cyberspace
description: Radio Station Leaves Earth and Enters Cyberspace

title: A Short, Welcome Season
description: Sometimes it seems as though summer is just three days long: Memorial Day, Independence Day and Labor Day. Where the rest of summer goes is anyone's guess, but such is the headlong life we live. Summer was once an endless tract of time. Now, there is one day to set out the lawn furniture, one day to sprawl on it, and one day to put it away and get out the Christmas tree stand while you're at it. The last of those days has come. The ark of one's leisure is about to run aground. The September fashion bibles -- fat as phone books -- are already on the newsstand. School buses are already on the road. A chill is in the air, or so they are saying somewhere much farther north.

title: Bush Adapts and Goes on the Attack
description: After watching his lead in the polls evaporate, Gov. George W. Bush is adjusting and adapting his campaign strategy. In the past, when Vice President Al Gore belittled him, Mr. Bush expressed something akin to bemusement. No more. A new Republican commercial casts Mr. Gore as an untrustworthy, untruthful chameleon. And in his own whirl of campaign trips, Mr. Bush plans to pick apart Mr. Gore's policies and raise more pointed questions about his leadership. PAGE A14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-in-law, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed, Brigitte Lasky and Hexi Hegewisch-Lasky. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. Services Tuesday, September 5, 1:15 PM at, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Media Talk; Co-Anchor of 'Moneyline' Moves West
description: With CNN in flux after a corporate restructuring that was announced last week, Willow Bay, an anchor on its ''Moneyline News Hour'' program, will begin doing her job from Los Angeles tomorrow.

title: Political Memo; A Battle About Finances And the Lack of Finances
description: In the three months since the New Jersey primaries, Representative Robert D. Franks, the little-known Republican candidate for United States Senate, has managed to raise just over $1 million for his campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 26 about Carl Barks, the cartoonist who created Scrooge McDuck, misstated the surname of the author of a book about him, and a cartoon panel with the obituary carried an erroneous credit. The author is Edward Summer, not Summers. The cartoon was from his book ''Uncle Scrooge McDuck, His Life and Times (Celestial Arts, 1980), not from Walt Disney Productions.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries are gathering this week for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: Opposition Leader Scores Upset in Lebanon Elections
description: Former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri dealt a crushing electoral blow to Lebanon's Syrian-appointed government in final parliamentary voting today, early results showed, sweeping all of Beirut's seats and gaining a powerful majority of backers in Parliament.

title: Man Held in Weekend Attacks On Four Women in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with attacking four young women as they jogged or walked alone in Park Slope and nearby neighborhoods over the weekend, the police said yesterday.

title: 5 Arrested Near U.N. On Eve of Gathering
description: Five people were arrested yesterday near the United Nations headquarters in scuffles that appeared to have been aimed at the Iranian delegation to the Millennium Summit, one of the largest gatherings of national leaders, which begins today.

title: Abbey National to Buy Scottish Provident
description: Abbey National, Britain's second-largest mortgage lender, has won a bidding contest to acquire Scottish Provident, an Edinburgh-based mutual life insurer for about $:2 billion, or $2.9 billion, executives close to the deal said today.

title: Two Artists, Sharing a Museum but Worldviews Apart
description: It's hardly a surprise to be told that every good artist creates a world of her or his own. But to move from the world of Alice Neel to that of Barbara Kruger (separated by a single floor at the Whitney Museum of American Art) is to feel you have moved from one species to another, from people who claim their individuality as a natural right to people who see the world as one big central casting agency in which everyone, not least themselves, is a desirable or an undesirable type.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Milosevic Foe Leading Field In Yugoslavia
description: Vojislav Kostunica, a constitutional lawyer, was fired from the Belgrade University law faculty in 1974 for defending a senior professor jailed for criticizing the government. In 1989, when Serbia's new leader, Slobodan Milosevic, tried to co-opt intellectuals and offered to rehire those fired then, only Mr. Kostunica refused.

title: In a Second-to-Second News World, Bloomberg Takes Stock
description: Noon, Wednesday, Aug. 30. The ''Page 1'' meeting for Bloomberg News is in full swing at a conference room in Bloomberg's Midtown Manhattan headquarters. Linked by Webcams and video screens, editors in Europe and the United States chew over the day's hot news, discussing what stories belong on Bloomberg's main screen.

title: Tiny Tuvalu Profits From Web Name
description: At the height of the Internet land rush in 1998, an unusual story stood out from the rest: the tiny nation of Tuvalu sold, for $50 million, the rights to its chunk of cyberspace. Tuvalu, a string of islands halfway between Hawaii and Australia with a population of just 10,600, had rarely made world headlines. But the multimillion-dollar sale, to an ambitious Web entrepreneur in Canada, changed all that.

title: New Economy; Whose name is it anyway? Arbitration panels favoring trademark holders in disputes over Web names.
description: IN a little noticed decision in July, the World Intellectual Property Organization forced an American woman, Virginia Comito, to hand over the Internet address www.tonsil.com to Sud-Chemie, a German chemicals company that had held a trademark on the word since 1952. The address was deemed ''identical or confusingly similar'' to a bleaching product called Tonsil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINIFIE, JONATHAN
description: MINIFIE-Jonathan. 50. English teacher at Groton School. Died of a heart attack on August 30. Son of the Rev. Benjamin and Frances Minifie, formerly of Grace Church, NYC. Graduated from Williams College, Oxford University and Harvard University Graduate School. He is survived by his wife Mary Hampson Minifie, his two sons Joseph and Samuel, his mother Frances, and brothers, the Rev. Charles, the Rev. Thomas, Edward and William, and sister Katherine.

title: The Perceptions of Race, Real or Not
description: IT'S THE LITTLE THINGS

title: Japan Builder May Seek Debt Relief
description: A major Japanese construction company, Kumagai Gumi, is expected to ask its creditors to forgive 450 billion yen in debt, or $4.25 billion.

title: Empowering Pakistanis
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000090493485571838 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORENO, JAMES M.
description: MORENO-James M. Beloved companion of Dorothie Strauss. Loving uncle. Friend to all. A site planner and landscape architect by trade, he assisted Robert Moses on the construction of the highways and byways of New York. Services at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L), Brooklyn, NY, on Tuesday, September 5, at 11 AM.

title: For Immigrants, Next Stop Iowa?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFOR, MICHAEL WILLIAM
description: LEFOR-Michael William. Of Storrs, CT, died Sunday, September 3, 2000, at Hartford Hospital after a brief illness. He is survived by his brother Guy Lefor of Storrs, CT, and several cousins. Born April 1, 1943, and a graduate in botany of Hobart College and the University of Connecticut, he recently retired from the faculty of the Geography Department of the University. At the time of his death, he was President of Aton Forest, Inc., an environmental research facility in Norfolk, CT, and a consultant on coastal wetlands to the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. He was a longtime member of St. Mark's Episcopal Chapel at the University of Connecticut, a member of its choir, and the maintainer of its pipe organ and was a member of the American Guild of Organists. For information, contact St. Mark's Chapel in Storrs (860429-2647).

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Why We Need the SAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Personal Online Advice on Selecting a College
description: Live, one-on-one college advisory services, offered until now primarily offline, became available on the Internet last Friday through a new Web site, PureAdvice.com. It is offering tools and services to help high school students identify and apply to colleges appropriate for them and apply for and obtain financial aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, ROSE
description: SILVERMAN-Rose. 92, of New York City, NY, on September 2nd, 2000. Loving sister of Phyllis; loving aunt to Stephanie, Roger, and George; great-aunt to Kate, Jennifer, Ilyssa, Benjamin, and Eric. Services will be private.

title: Progress Is Reported In Talks at Firestone
description: Negotiators for Bridgestone/Firestone and the union representing 8,000 of its workers continued talks in St. Louis yesterday as they sought to reach a tentative contract and avert a threatened strike.

title: In a Divided Israel, Thousands Rally for the Ex-Shas Party Leader as He Goes to Jail
description: It was quite a send-off for a felonious politician.

title: Progressive Rock Prevails In Bursts of Pure Metal
description: It's not unusual in New York to see people lining up around the block for artists few outsiders know exist. But Dream Theater, which attracted a crowd that waited five hours or more to get the best view for the show on Wednesday night at Roseland, holds a strange position in the maze of music undergrounds.

title: Vermont Journal; A Taxing Question: Assessing Millionaire's Retreat
description: A couple of years ago, a very wealthy couple finished building a very large house in this southern Vermont hamlet.

title: Other Systems Might Provide a U.S. Missile Shield
description: In putting off a decision on a national missile defense on Friday, President Clinton said the earliest such a shield could be put in place was 2006 or 2007. But the president made a decision on just one system. What he did not say, and what the debate over that system has obscured, is that a number of lesser-known antimissile weapons might be candidates for the same job.

title: Traffic Alert
description: WEST INDIAN DAY PARADE

title: Twins Steal a Victory With Help From Rivera
description: Upset with himself for walking Torii Hunter in the 10th inning yesterday, Mariano Rivera tried to get back into his normal routine: he glanced toward the runner at first from the set position, then looked away, all the while deciding where to throw the ball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, ROBERT
description: KRINSKY-Robert. Beloved husband of Thelma, adored by his children Mark and Karen, and his son-in-law Donald Sussman. ''Zayde'' cherished his grandchildren Joel, Kenny, David, and Lloyd. Dear brother of Rhoda Taffet. Honored and respected as an advocate by the autism community. Founder of GASAK (Grandparent Advocates Supporting Autistic Kids). Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Movie Theaters Build Themselves Into a Corner
description: For New York moviegoers weary of long lines, sticky floors and poor sight lines, the two huge new theaters facing each other on 42nd Street near Eighth Avenue -- a block once home to several theaters with X-rated movies -- are a welcome improvement. They offer comfortable stadium seating, clean surroundings and the latest digital sound technology. Together, they have 38 screens and more than 8,100 seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKIS, JOHN S.
description: BOOKIS-John S. Passed away on September 2, 2000, at age 79. Survived by his wife Sophia, his children George, Mary-Kay, Susan and Joan. His brothers Gregory and Blaise, his sister Suzie, his grandchildren, his nephews and nieces. His courageous spirit will always live in our hearts. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, on Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 343 East 74th St, on Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: Essay; The Whining Strategy
description: The difference between the presidential candidates is not, as Ralph Nader claims, between Tweedledum and Tweedledee. As the strategy of calculated whining has been adopted by both campaigns, the main difference is between Namby and Pamby.

title: Two Killed in Fire at Brooklyn Building
description: A fast-moving fire, apparently set by an arsonist who doused a staircase with flammable liquid, roared through a Bedford-Stuyvesant building early yesterday morning, killing a woman who was trapped behind a locked window grate in a third-floor apartment and a man in the building, the authorities said.

title: Pressure Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: For Immigrants, Next Stop Iowa?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Alec Guinness on Aug. 7 misstated the name of a character played by Martita Hunt in the 1946 film ''Great Expectations.'' It was Miss Havisham, not Habersham.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's efforts on behalf of Jonathan Pollard, the convicted spy, misstated the date on which she met with the New York Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and with Assemblyman Dov Hikind. It was Aug. 23, not Aug. 30. The article also misstated the date Mr. Hikind was informed of Mrs. Clinton's intervention. It was Aug. 26, not Sept. 1.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Adam Roberts, a Long Island man who pleaded guilty to having killed his parents and then having set fire to their vacation home, included an erroneous date from the district attorney for the murders. They occurred on Nov. 13, 1999, not Nov. 14.

title: Tokyo Politician's Earthquake Drill Is a Military Moment
description: As smoke pots simulating fires spewed yellow fumes from the buildings, military trucks rumbled today into Shirahige Nishi, a dilapidated quarter of Tokyo, rushing in olive-uniformed reinforcements for civilian rescue squads overwhelmed by the wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORN, ROBERT W.
description: BORN-Robert W. Cherished husband of Esther Born; devoted father of Rita and Fred Distenfeld, and Richard and Deborah Born, and loving grandfather of Michael, Caroline, Jennifer, Claire, and Max. We mourn the passing of our irreplaceable husband, father, and grandfather. He made each of our days special with his warmth, wisdom and wonderful humor, and will remain forever in our hearts. Shiva will be observed at the Born residence.

title: The Stars Uptown To Dance Downtown
description: The term ''downtown dance'' takes on a whole new meaning with the ''Evening Stars'' dance week that opens on Sunday in an outdoor theater at the World Trade Center Plaza. True, the kind of avant-garde dance that is usually meant by the term, created in lofts and studios south of 14th Street, will be represented in the new series. But the six ''Evening Stars'' programs include an impressive range of uptown stars and styles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMER, GEORGIA
description: ZIMMER-Georgia. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member and benefactor Georgia Zimmer, beloved wife of Max J. Zimmer, who until his death served with distinction as Trustee. Deepest sympathy to Joel and Karen, Anita, Gary and Jill, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice-President Jack Rosen, Vice-President

title: Exploring 5 Decades of a Composer's Challenges
description: One of the many things that make Milton Babbitt's music so thoroughly and delightfully old-fashioned is how it addresses the performer civilly as a colleague. For though a score of Mr. Babbitt's may look at first glance like a presumptive demand, full of awkward rhythmic turns, extreme oscillations of line and erratic dynamic markings, longer acquaintance reveals it as a set of proposals, even questions. How is this interval going to work at this point in the texture and continuity? Where is the accent in this figure and where the direction? What kinds of resemblance matter?

title: Health Care For Every Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, ROBERT H., JR.
description: MONTGOMERY-Robert H., Jr. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison greatly mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Robert H. Montgomery, Jr. Bob was the head of our Entertainment Department for many years and a member of the Paul, Weiss family for 50 years. Bob was also the Trustee of the Cole Porter Musical Literary Property Trusts for 23 years. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Henriette, daughter, Margaret, son, Sam and two grandchildren, Roland and Robert.

title: Barber Shifts Direction And a Star Is Reborn
description: Things were so different at Cave Spring High School in Roanoke, Va. Tiki Barber knew he was the best player on the football field then, which usually meant that every other player chased him around.

title: In America; Working Harder, Longer
description: There's a lot of good news to report this Labor Day. Unemployment is very low and wages are rising. The benefits of the booming economy are being widely distributed. Workers at the bottom are finally enjoying significant increases in their inflation-adjusted wages. Better yet, the U.S. is experiencing a surge in the growth of labor productivity which, as noted in a book-length report from the Economic Policy Institute, is ''probably the best indicator of an economy's capacity to provide for the material needs of its population.''

title: Grass Field Takes a Beating
description: The new grass at Giants Stadium had a shaky National Football League debut. After the portion down the middle of the field was replaced last week, heavy showers Saturday apparently loosened some of the sod. Two gaping pieces came out after a pileup caused by a fumble by Arizona quarterback Jake Plummer late in the first half. One resembled a New York City pothole.

title: Iverson Haunts Brown, Even Across the Pacific
description: Larry Brown was reminiscing recently about a much simpler time in international competition, when an Olympic basketball player for the United States had no one to carry his bags during training camp in Hawaii, when you could not order coconut shrimp as an appetizer.

title: FOREIGN WORKERS AT HIGHEST LEVEL IN SEVEN DECADES
description: As employers clamor for more foreign-born workers and as tens of thousands of Mexicans slip across the border each year, the percentage of immigrant workers in the nation's labor force has climbed to its highest level in seven decades.

title: Political Memo; 2 Races for Senate, One Marked by Exposure, the Other by Money
description: In most political contests, Labor Day is a point of embarkation: the start of a two-month journey during which the candidates campaign in earnest, when the themes and issues that will shape the race fall into place, and when voters start to judge who the candidates are and what they are saying.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the rise in minority enrollment in Florida colleges since the state ended race-based admissions misstated the year in which California voters ended affirmative action. It was 1996, not 1997.

title: Icahn's Move Forces G.M. To Consider Hughes Deal
description: When General Motors announced last month that Carl C. Icahn was buying its stock, Wall Street analysts quickly surmised that he saw potential in the Hughes Electronics Corporation, the satellite-television unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, NAT
description: BERG-Nat. On September 1, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Judy and Howard. Dear brother of Jack. Loving grandfather of Julie and Jennifer. Funeral service from ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' corner of Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, September 5, at 11 AM.

title: It's Steinbrenner Who Spits the Bit
description: The full-page, front-page picture and the blaring tabloid headline instantly took one reader back more than 20 years, back to a Saturday afternoon at Yankee Stadium when a George Steinbrenner minion tapped him on the shoulder in the press box and said: ''George is in his office. Why don't you go see him?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, TERRENCE P.
description: COSTELLO-Terrence P. Of Monroe, NY, a retired Mailer for the New York Times for 40 years; on September 2, 2000. He was the former Chairman of Mailers Union Local #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNON, ROBERT
description: VERNON-Robert. Beloved son of Sylvia. Dear brother of Kenneth, Michael, Russell and Joanne. Loving uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. Services Tuesday, at 12 noon, at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Nassau Looks To Its Leader For a Route Out Of Fiscal Maze
description: Nassau County's long road back to fiscal health starts Tuesday, when County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta is to present the outlines of a fiscal plan intended to bring the county back from the brink of bankruptcy,

title: Sports of The Times; Ward Proves He's Big Enough for Expanded Role
description: EVER since Keyshawn Johnson departed to Tampa Bay in a flurry of contract demands, the question has hovered over the Jets: could Al Groh and Dedric Ward justify the deal?

title: Article 2000090491977409206 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''With all today's technology we really feel we have most of the faults located. But then something like this happens and we go, 'Oops, I'll be darned.' ''

title: McBride's Goal Gives United States a Reason to Believe
description: Two strategic substitutions by United States Coach Bruce Arena turned out for the best and for the worst in a World Cup qualifying game this afternoon against Guatemala.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the origin of President Clinton's deferral of a decision on a national missile defense system misstated the date of the only previous instance an official could recall in which Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen was overruled within the administration's foreign policy team. That instance -- in which he argued against imposing sanctions on Myanmar -- occurred in 1997, not 1996.

title: A Big Finish Gives the Jets a Winning Start
description: Curtis Martin wanted to do more this season, wanted to squeeze more power and strength from his compact body to fill the chasm in the Jets' offense created by the departure of receiver Keyshawn Johnson. He had run in the stairwell of his Florida condominium in preparation for this season and then had the best preseason of his career.

title: Quake Hits California on New Fault, Startling the Experts
description: An earthquake with a magnitude of 5.2 rattled Northern California's wine country before dawn today, taking place along a previously undiscovered fault line and surprising seismologists.

title: Mob's Shadow Still Falls Across Building Projects
description: Several months ago, the city suspended more than $80 million in contracts with a construction company that has a key role in closing the Fresh Kills landfill so that officials could investigate allegations that the company had ties to organized crime.

title: E-Commerce Report; Sporting goods Web sites, last year's costly rage, are turned over to the professionals.
description: THE holiday weekend signals the start of a peak season for sports fans, who can finally supplement their baseball-only diets with smatterings of professional football, basketball and hockey.

title: Humbled in Atlanta, I.B.M. Hopes to Rebound in Sydney
description: When the computer system I.B.M. built to report results at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta malfunctioned, the proud computing giant learned the hard way what it is like to stumble with the whole world watching.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Milestones And Tears
description: Quarterback Vinny Testaverde felt the rush of emotion as he left Lambeau Field and then he sat in his locker crying yesterday, the relief of his comeback checkered by memories of his father Al, who died in February 1999 and to whom he has dedicated the season. With his 44 attempts, Testaverde passed Phil Simms to take over 15th place on the National Football League's all-time pass attempts list.

title: For Jews Lost in War, Flowers on the Sea
description: Ogen Rintzler came from Israel to the blue-green waters of the Black Sea this afternoon to say farewell to his parents and to heal a wound even deeper than their loss. Chefner Tudor made the journey in memory of his best friend. Ilana Blum came to acknowledge the father whose death she had long refused to accept.

title: Stricter Rules for Tire Safety Were Scrapped by Reagan
description: After the last huge recall of Firestone tires in 1978, when tread separation problems resulted in hundreds of crashes and dozens of deaths, Congress and regulators made a series of proposals to tighten federal tire standards. But the standards were not revised, and many of the same problems, including some that the proposals were designed to address, have arisen again in the 14.4 million Firestone tires being recalled now.

title: The Gateway City
description: New York City has long held a special place in American life as a metropolis that perpetually renews itself with waves of foreign immigration. That has never been truer than today, when the city is brimming with newly arrived residents. At the end of a decade in which one million newcomers swept into the city, 40 percent of New Yorkers are now foreign-born, the highest level since 1910. The city is enriched by the immigrants, but it also faces major challenges in helping to integrate them fully into the life and economy of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIER, JOSEPHINE
description: BLIER-Josephine. On September 3, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Julius; loving mother of Malcolm Blier and his wife Victoria, and Steven Blier and partner James Russell. Devoted grandmother of Samuel and Zachary; dear sister of Florence Horlick and Janice Schulman. Cherished aunt and cousin; devoted friend to many. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at Riverdale Temple, Independence Ave and 246th St, Riverdale.

title: Fingerprints for Medicaid
description: New York was among the first states to require electronic fingerprinting of welfare recipients as a way to prevent fraud. But as Nina Bernstein of The Times reported last week, there is little solid evidence that finger imaging actually deters welfare fraud, particularly when stringent work rules, shortened eligibility times and other antifraud measures are already pushing people off public assistance rolls at a brisk pace.

title: Drug-Policy Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMES, DR. JEAN SCHMIDLAPP
description: HUMES-Dr. Jean Schmidlapp. Born December 24, 1924, nee Jean Cooper Schmidlapp, of Locust Valley, NY, died on September 2, 2000, after a long illness. Dr. Humes was the daughter of Carl Jacob and Frances Cooper Schmidlapp, and widow of lawyer and former Ambassador of the United States to Austria, John Portner Humes, Sr., who died in 1985. She was the mother of six sons. Dr. Humes attended the Greenvale School, Foxcroft, Vassar College with a BA in 1945, and Cornell Univeristy Medical College with an MD in 1949. She was a member of the Executive Committee of the AmericanAustrian Foundation, Inc., of which her husband was a founder. She was a member of the Piping Rock Club and the American Medical Association. She is survived by five sons, David Bryant of Woodstock, VT, Carl Schmidlapp of Lattingtown, NY, Christopher Leftwich of West Palm Beach, FL, Andrew Russell of Great Barrington, MA, and Francis Cooper of Mill Neck, NY. Her first son, John Portner Humes, Jr., died in 1990. She had eleven grandchildren. Service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown on September 5, 2000, at 11 AM. Flowers can be sent to St. John's. Interment private.

title: Gore and Lieberman, Framing Themselves as Working-Class Heroes, Rally Round the Clock
description: Like college students pulling an all-nighter together, Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today kicked off a round-the-clock Labor Day campaign swing designed to portray them as the ticket for the working class.

title: Listening Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Cave Dwelling
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Schedule of Bond Offerings for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: F.T.C. Lawyers Pressing for Concessions From AOL and Time Warner
description: F.T.C. Lawyers Pressing for Concessions From AOL and Time Warner

title: Knoblauch Just Wants To Quiet Doubters
description: Chuck Knoblauch found no simple way to describe his desire to play again when he had a conversation with Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, on Sunday. Knoblauch finally settled for an analogy. ''Imagine something you want more than anything else in the world,'' he said to Cashman. ''That's how much I want to play again.''

title: Dementieva, the Unknown Russian, Reaches Quarterfinals
description: She is a tall Russian teenager with long blond hair who crushes her forehands into the corners and now finds herself in the quarterfinals of the United States Open.

title: Metal Piece in Concorde Crash May Be From Continental DC-10
description: A metal strip that investigators believe may have led to the fiery crash of an Air France Concorde in July apparently came from a Continental Airlines DC-10 that had taken off from the same runway minutes before the Concorde, the French agency investigating the disaster said today.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Voice Sounds Familiar

title: Article 2000090591912453315 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Hints of Alzheimer's Found in the Nose
description: In recent months, researchers have pointed to possible signals of Alzheimer's disease that could allow doctors to detect the ailment before symptoms start. They have spoken of small areas of the brain that appear to shrink, and psychological tests that yield subtle clues.

title: Bucs' Opening Statement Is Loudest of All
description: The first game is all about striding toward establishing an identity. Usually, 8 to 12 games are required to decide what your team is and what it does best.

title: Hey, This Band Says, We're Pumped Up and We've Got Feelings
description: Alcoholism, wife-beating, attention deficit disorder, suicidal thoughts -- they're not just talk show topics any more. Papa Roach, which headlined at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night, writes songs about them, with Coby Dick bellowing insights like, ''I am a mess! I've made a huge mess! I can't control myself!''

title: Unbowed, if Soggy, Parade Goes On
description: As they have for years on Labor Day, tens of thousands of New Yorkers, and the politicians who court them, descended on Brooklyn yesterday to watch or take part in the West Indian American Carnival Parade in Crown Heights, with the city's largest street spectacle dampened only by a sudden downpour that brought a brief halt to the festivities.

title: Bragging Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, MILDRED
description: HALPERT-Mildred. Age 96. Cherished wife of the late Benjamin. Beloved mother of Frances Wolk, mother-in-law of Bruce. Grandmother of Marianne, Jonathan and Allison Wolk. Great grandmother of Brandon and Carly Wolk. Graveside service 1 PM Tuesday, Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: SOUTH AFRICA RESERVES REMAIN STEADY
description: South Africa's gold and foreign exchange reserves were little changed in August as its trade surplus narrowed and the reserve bank did not increase foreign borrowings to bolster gross reserves. Reserves rose to 52.1 billion rand ($7.5 billion) at the end of August from 52 billion rand in July. The bank used some of its foreign currency reserves to reduce the size of its dollar commitments, known as the forward book. It has said it wants to reduce its dollar commitments because they increase volatility in the rand.

title: Mets Still Seek September Victory
description: If the Mets' punchless hitters need an example, they might want to look to Timoniel Perez. Perez, a 23-year-old outfielder, is in his first week in the major leagues and may not know what it means to press.

title: The Power in TV Confessions
description: The success of shows like ''Survivor'' has many wondering where reality television is headed. This question has recently come up with our own program, ''Confessions,'' which takes an unfiltered look at convicted murderers and other violent felons.

title: Technology's Gender Gap
description: The barriers that keep minorities from enjoying full access to the technological revolution have been widely commented on. Less talked about is another ''digital divide,'' the fact that fewer women are entering today's booming technology fields.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROITMAN, LEO
description: ROITMAN-Leo. Born March 20, 1907 in Russia, to David and Sonya Roitman. Died on August 31 in Encinitas. Beloved husband of May (died 1946) and Ethel (died 1989). Beloved brother of Vera Spiegel and Claire Hotchner. Beloved father of Judy and David. Beloved grandfather of Ben Lombardo and Jonathon Roitman. Preceded in death by his parents, brother Louis, sister Chayishka, and sister Rachel Kahn. Production Control Manager at Ideal Toy Corporation. Cantor for Little Neck Jewish Center, his integrity and kindness will be greatly missed. Services 10:30AM Sunday, September 10, at Schwartz Funeral Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the San Diego Hebrew Home, Seacrest Village, 211 Saxony, Encinitas, California 92024.

title: INSIDE
description: No Strike but More Recalls

title: Journalists Under Siege
description: The editors of two opposition newspapers in Congo are facing the death penalty. Emile-Aime Kakekese Vinalu's crime was writing two articles that analyzed a tiff between high-level officials, complained of disunity in the opposition and said that those who speak their minds get arrested for crimes against state security. The government of Laurent Kabila then proved him right. Then Jean-Pierre Ekanga Mukuna was arrested, apparently for refusing to give authorities Mr. Vinalu's home address. Both men are charged with high treason.

title: Alcohol Ban? Still Many Ways to Drink at a Parade, and to Greet the Mayor
description: Winfield Pierre was reaching deep into his iced drinks barrel for his bottle of F & J Brandy yesterday. As he fished in the ice, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ambled past him in the West Indian American Carnival Parade.

title: As Prescriptions Pile Up, Risks Do, Too
description: At 88, Nathan, a New York businessman with a sharp, clear mind, was still going to work every day. Then an episode that resembled a ministroke landed him in the hospital, where numerous medications were administered.

title: MetroStars Must Plug Their Hole in the Goal
description: With the injured Mike Ammann out for the season and Tim Howard joining the United States Olympic team, the MetroStars will finish the regular season this week and go into next week's playoffs with two unproven goalkeepers.

title: THE DEMOCRATS Gore and Lieberman, Framing Themselves as Working-Class Heroes, Rally Round the Clock
description: FLINT, Mich., Sept. 3  Like college students pulling an all-nighter together, Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today kicked off a round-the-clock Labor Day campaign swing designed to portray them as the ticket for the working class.

title: More Cautions on Skin Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: How, but Not Why, the Brain Distinguishes Race
description: After a decade of mapping brains in tasks like recalling numbers, perceiving facial expressions and using verbs, neuroscientists have recently homed in on a much more controversial subject: the act of categorizing other human beings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENGLER, THOMAS EDMUND
description: GENGLER-Thomas Edmund. On September 1, 2000 of Malverne, N.Y. Devoted husband of Eleanor for 49 years and father of Tom (Mary), June (Jay), Bill, Jane (Kevin) and Barbara. Grandfather of Marie, Nancy, Tommy, Ed, Laura, Matt (Jaime), Joe, Robin, Kevin, Ryan, and George. Also survived by his brother Al and his wife Liz, his sisters Madeline & Rosemary his sisters-in-law Marge and Jackie, his brother-in-law Harold, (Loretta) and served in the U. S. Army in WW II in Italy and Africa. Active alumni and friend of Pace University, Class of '49. Semi-retired since 1981, after 19 years as President of Year Round Sales, a Tupperware distributorship. Tom and Eleanor traveled extensively for Tupperware, including two years in Malaysia. Tom will be greatly missed by his family, his Tupperware family, and many other friends from all over the world. Friends may visit Macken Mortuary, 516-766-3300, 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral mass will be held at Our Lady of Lourdes Church, Malverne, Wednesday at 11:15 AM. Interment St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFLUG, JOHN RUEGER (JOHNNY)
description: PFLUG-John Rueger (Johnny). One of the last players from the golden age of polo in New York, died September 1,2000 He was 90 years old and lived in Plandome. N.Y. A star athlete at St. Paul's School in Garden City, N.Y. Mr. Pflug was offered a baseball contract by the Brooklyn Dodgers, but chose instead to attend Colgate, where he was an end on the fammous 1932 Red Raiders Football Team, which was undefeated, untied and unscored upon, uninvited to The Rose Bowl that year. Winners of many regattas with his brother Carl in their Star Class sloop ''Wings'' in the early 1930's. The Pflugs were victorious in the trials for the 10th Olympiad in 1932, but decided to return to college, passing up the chance to represent the United States at the Los Angeles games. Polo, however, was John's passion. As a teenager, he and his brother helped win the Junior National Indoor Championship for the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club and later won the National Indoor Polo Championship. He carried an 8 goal handicap and was one of the highest rated active players in the indoor game before the War. Mr. Pflug played for The New York Athletic Club and Squardon A Indoors and Laddie Sandford's Hurricanes among other teams outdoors. Born in Brooklyn on April 10, 1910, he was the youngest son of Dr. Charles J. and Emma R. Pflug. He served as an officer in the Coast Guard during World War II on a landing craft carrier in the Pacific theatre and worked for many years for the Lincoln Savings Bank. He is survived by his sister, Helen Pflug MacKay of Locust Valley, daughters Jane Pflug of Manhattan and Melissa Pflug of Burlington, VT, a son, John R. Pflug of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and a grandson Jock Pflug. Any contributions may be made to Colgate University, Hamilton, N.Y. 13346.

title: Bridgestone Agrees to Recall 62,000 Tires in Venezuela
description: Facing the threat of criminal and civil actions here, Bridgestone/Firestone agreed today to recall 62,000 tires that the Venezuelan government says had defects that appear to have played a role in the deaths of at least 60 people in automobile accidents.

description: Germany's T-Online Buys Spanish Internet Operator

title: The Scourge of Guns
description: We live in a nation awash in guns where more than 30,000 Americans die annually by gunfire, a toll that includes about 4,000 children and teenagers. Yet despite these horrible statistics, Americans are allowed, as in few other industrialized countries, to buy and keep an unlimited arsenal of firearms with very few restrictions and little government regulation.

title: ELTEK TO ACQUIRE POWER CONVERSION
description: Eltek A.S.A., a Norwegian power supply company, said it would buy Power Conversion Products of the United States for about $330 million in stock. The deal brings together two suppliers of power to the Internet and telecommunications industries. After the merger the new company would derive nearly 40 percent of its revenue from the United States. Eltek's founder, Alain Angelil, controls 46.8 percent of the company's shares, and the merger is subject to his endorsement. Suzanne Kapner

description: Penelope Russianoff, a psychotherapist, writer and lecturer who advised women on how to assert themselves, died on Aug. 28 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 82 and also had a home and practice in Sherman, Conn.

title: Fall Campaign Raises Pressure On Capitol Hill
description: Aware that what they do in the next few weeks may help determine who controls the federal government next year, members of Congress return from recess this week for a final session compressed by the election campaigns and dominated by tax cuts, education, health care and government spending.

title: Israel Loosens Telephone Monopoly's Grip
description: The Israeli government announced today that it was ending the state telephone company's monopoly on domestic telephone and Internet service, taking a long-resisted deregulatory move that sets the stage for the company's sale to private investors later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, TAYLOR RASTRICK
description: BRIGGS-Taylor Rastrick. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, L.L.P., mourns with sorrow the September 1 passing of our dear friend, colleague, and former Chairman, Taylor Rastrick Briggs. An immensely gifted litigator, Taylor joined LeBoeuf in 1961, was made Partner in 1963 and served as Chairman for 10 years, from 1978 to 1988. He became Counsel to the Firm in 1995. A leader and mentor who exemplified integrity and grace, Taylor will be missed by all who knew him. We extend condolences to his wife, Jane, their four children, Cynthia, Jennifer, Pamela and Taylor, Jr., and nine grandchildren. A memorial service has been scheduled for 2 PM on Wednesday, September 6, 2000, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, MA.

title: Whipped Into Spotlight
description: THERE she was, Amanda Peet, but in the crowd on Tuesday night at the premiere of her new movie, "Whipped," there was some confusion about which one she was. A stunning woman in a tight black, backless dress posed for the cameras. "Is that her?" one photographer asked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVEMBER, BARBARA
description: NOVEMBER-Barbara, 67. Of Great Neck, on August 31, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Peter, devoted mother of Michael (Debbie) and Ellen (Peter) Rigby. Grandmother of Adam, Pauline and Hannah. Sister-in-law of Robert and Eleanor. Funeral services were held on September 1. The family will be sitting Shiva Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. description: NORCROSS-Elizabeth Gordon. On September 3, 2000, 94. Of Adamstown, MD. Well known editor of ''House Beautiful'' magazine. Survived by her goddaughter Brooke Shearer Talbot and husband Strobe Talbot, Washington, DC; sister-in-law Gertrude Norcross, San Diego, CA. Also survived by close friends Eleanor and John McGuire, San Francicsco, CA; Jane Chapman, San Diego, CA; Rowena and Robert Tebbe, Lakeland, FL; Alfred Browning Parker, Gainesville, FL; and Skip and Marva Shearer of Los Angeles, CA. For more information, contact the Keeney and Basford Funeral Home, Frederick, MD. Services are private.

title: Sports of The Times; Hingis Leads By Example In Anonymity
description: MARTINA HINGIS sprayed her trademark winners around the Grandstand Court yesterday, played her sharp angles, and quietly moved on to the quarterfinals of the United States Open, a sly cat under a white baseball cap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DAVID R.
description: ALTMAN-David R. On August 30, 2000 in New York City. David loved life. Beyond all others, he made the everyday extraordinary. He found joy where others could not see it. He turned strangers into friends and friends into family. And then there is Floria. His wife, his life, of over 53 years. Floria and David. David and Floria. One and the same. Emily & Dara had the matchless chance to be his children, with Floria, the loves of his life. He made his sons-in-law, Michael Lennon and Michael Kahan, his sons. He cherished his grandchild Asher. He was dearest brother-in-law, more like brother, to Melvin Lasky. Brother-in-law to Joyce Lasky Reed, Brigitte Lasky and Hexi Hegewisch-Lasky. Incomparable uncle and great-uncle to Rosalind, Richard, Lionel, Samantha, Vivienne, Rachel, Adam, Oliver, Amanda, Nicholas, Sasha & Carla. David walked among us and left very large footprints. We are fortunate to have walked with him. In memory of David R. Altman and in honor of Dr. David R. Schwartz for the benefit of the Medical Intensive Care Unit contributions may be made to Tisch Hospital, NYU Medical Center, Development Office, in care of Myra Biblowit, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016. Services Tuesday, September 5, 1:15 PM at, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Williams Hurt; Pettitte Wins Again
