title: More Fans For Drugs That Fight Cholesterol
description: In the 13 years since they were introduced in the United States, the cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins have revolutionized the treatment of heart disease. Study after study has shown these drugs prevent heart attacks and prolong lives, with very few side effects. It is estimated that five million people are taking the drugs, which have rapidly become the best-selling prescriptions in this country.

title: The Dining Room
description: Trois Jean, one of Manhattan's handsomest bistros, has ended its long run. In its place an American restaurant has risen with a clean-cut American look (created by Larry Bogdanow), a New American menu (created by Mark Spangenthal, the chef at the Screening Room) and a no-frills American name, the Dining Room.

title: Valuing Humanity and Rituals
description: To the Editor:

title: In Papers of Newton, a Portrait Of the Physicist as a Young Sage
description: In one letter, Isaac Newton, still in his 20's, sketches out the beginnings of calculus. Other scribblings show Newton's early thoughts on subjects ranging from gravity to optics to comets. If stacked up, the assemblage of letters, notebooks and other documents would be about 15 feet high.

title: Lebanese Surprise: Syria's Man Loses by Landslide
description: The landslide defeat of the Syrian-appointed government by the billionaire builder Rafik Hariri in elections that concluded on Sunday has changed the political map of Lebanon overnight.

title: People
description: Jerry Solomon was named to the new post of senior advertising sales executive at JAGfn, New York, a Webcast network of JagNotes.com. He had been president for national broadcast at SFM/Media Planning, New York, part of the Media Planning Group division of Havas Advertising.

title: Stocks in Europe Push Indexes to Records
description: European stocks rose, pushing indexes, including the French benchmark CAC 40 and the Dutch AEX, to records. Phone companies and communications-equipment makers like France Telecom and Nokia led gains as investors snapped up companies whose profits may climb even as economic growth slows.

title: Is Smoking Just About Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONDERLING, ARTHUR, C.P.A.
description: SONDERLING - Arthur, C.P.A. Died peacefully at home on September 2, 2000. Loving husband of Lillian, cherished father of Edward and Harlan, beloved father-in-law and grandfather. A gentleman and a lifelong New Yorker, born August 18, 1914, graduate of Dewitt Clinton High School and NYU, 1935. Defended his country, 1941-1945, in North Africa as Staff Sergeant in the U.S. Army. Compassionate and wise, a scholar and a lover of life, language, and people. Trusted and esteemed by all who knew him. We miss you, Dad. Gather in Manhattan after funeral Wednesday, 4-8 PM. Call 212-308-5033. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL. 33486.

title: Man Fishing in Channel Drowns During a Storm
description: Rains and heavy winds were partly responsible for the drowning death of a Bronx man yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Where Blood Is as Thick as Money; The Sculleys Forge New Careers Financing Internet Start-Ups
description: One evening last summer, Dennis M. Lynch, a young entrepreneur, was waiting to meet two potential investors at his company headquarters in Edgewood, N.Y., where he sells used computer and office equipment over the Internet.

title: Bridgestone, Averting Strike, Reaches Accord With Union
description: Negotiators for Bridgestone/Firestone and the union representing 8,000 of its workers reached a tentative settlement yesterday, averting a strike that could have deepened the tire maker's crisis.

title: Vegas Cheese, or Just a Spread?
description: ''A little bit of eye candy'' is how the singer Kevin Aviance modestly characterized himself as he paraded around the pool of the Hard Rock Hotel on a sultry desert night wearing patent leather thigh-highs, a buttocks-baring leopard-print jump suit and a glittery fedora rakishly cocked on his shaved skull.

title: Bush Derides Gore for Rejecting Debate Plan
description: Declaring ''it's time to elect people who say what they mean,'' Gov. George W. Bush swept through two hotly contested states today and derided Vice President Al Gore for rejecting his proposal for three handpicked debates.

title: Friends of the Earth Decides To Back Gore, Reluctantly
description: The Friends of the Earth, an environmental group that had endorsed Bill Bradley in the Democratic primaries and seriously flirted with supporting Ralph Nader in the general election, has decided to endorse Vice President Al Gore, officials with the group said.

title: New Guidelines for Reducing Caesareans
description: With the rate of Caesarean sections on the rise, a leading group of obstetricians has issued guidelines that may reduce the number of operations.

title: Teaching Hospitals Too Busy for Curiosity
description: Last year, when I was an intern, I took care of a man in his 70's with a peculiar problem: When he was sleeping, he would periodically stop breathing. When he was awake, he was lethargic and disoriented, sometimes psychotic. No one on my team knew what was wrong with him. I still don't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LUCILE HALLE
description: YOUNG-Lucile Halle. A native of Cleveland, Ohio; died at the age of 89 on September 1, 2000 after a long illness. She attended Miss Fuller's School in Ossining, NY. She was married to the late Fritz Wolff and the late Lewis B. Young of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert & Co. She began her career in the children's wear department at Jane Engels. Afterwards she started the Infant and Children's Department at Henri Bendel. Lucile was recognized as one of the industry's leading buyers of fine children's clothes until she retired in 1962. She is survived by her daughter Susan W. Spiegel and her husband Andrew of Highland Park, Illinois; and stepdaughter Linda Barnes. Adored grandmother of Sally Spiegel and Jill Spiegel Brozic and her husband Joe of Minneapolis. Stepgrandmother of Andrew and Kimberly and her husband Al and great-stepgrandmother of David Alexander. Friends will be received at 1075 Park Avenue from 6-9PM on Thursday September 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Foundation.

title: Woodstock on the Volga: Protest Ages Into Singalong
description: A sea of music fanatics and thrill-seekers drink and sway blissfully to songs of peace and love in a muddy field. It could be a Grateful Dead concert, or Woodstock just half a world away. Call it Woodstock on the Volga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, IRENE (NEE SCHWARTZ)
description: ABRAMS-Irene (nee Schwartz). Of Forest Hills, New York, on September 3, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Jay. Dear aunt of Fern Schwartz Thomas. Graduate of New York University Law School Class of 1926. A Committal service is on Wednesday, 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Glories of Underworld Are Under Siege; Science Armed a Cave For Its Public Debut
description: Take a sopping wet underground cavern in a remote corner of Arizona. Add a man-made entrance with heavy steel doors to keep out the hot desert air, a misting system to keep the cavern damp and lights to show off a wonderland of spires, flowstone, soda straws and other phantasmagorical cave formations.

title: T-ONLINE TO ACQUIRE JAZZTEL
description: Europe's largest online service, T-Online International, agreed to pay 550 million euros ($494 million) in cash and stock for Jazztel's Web access service to gain customers in Spain and Portugal. T-Online, Deutsche Telekom's Internet unit, will pay 15.25 million new shares worth 450 million euros and 100 million euros in cash for Ya.com Internet Factory, the No. 2 Spanish Web access provider. T-Online, which first sold shares to the public in April, will also assume debt of 23 million euros. The purchase will increase its subscriber base by 7 percent, to 6.4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, CHARLES H.
description: DIAMOND-Charles H. Beloved husband of Hana (nee Mackler). Devoted father of Susan Nathanson and father-in-law of Barry. Cherished grandfather of Richard Nathanson and Laurie (Greg) Kaufman. Services on Tuesday, 1:30PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Playing, but Not in Queens or the Bronx
description: Woke up yesterday and decided to go to a baseball game. It was a holiday, didn't have to work, and what a better way to spend the day than watching a game? Went around the house looking for a schedule but couldn't find one. Desk was so overrun with newspapers and magazines and piles of papers it could be the 2002 season before schedule surfaces.

title: McDonald's pushes to get its money's worth on Olympic tie-ins.
description: THOUGH its brand is quintessentially American, its business, increasingly, is not. So McDonald's is turning these days to international promotional opportunities -- like the Summer Olympic Games, coming soon to a television set near you -- and to nearly everybody else's on the planet, too.

title: For Preschool, a Wealth of Benefits and a Dearth of Space
description: Three years after the state established an ambitious prekindergarten program, New York City has more money than ever to carry it out, but virtually no space in school buildings for the classes.

title: Hearing About God but Wondering About Issues
description: All the talk of faith and religion in the presidential campaign might be expected to gain the attention of a voter like Sarah Dotson, 28, who rose early this morning to attend Mass at Holy Ghost Roman Catholic Church here.

title: TNT POST BUYS CTI LOGISTX
description: Europe's second-largest express package delivery company, TNT Post Groep, said it had bought CTI Logistx from the CSX Corporation, the United States railroad concern, for $650 million in cash. The deal was announced in concert with TNT's first half earnings. The company said its income, including profits on the sale of noncore business, grew 25.1 percent, to 229 million euros. Revenue jumped 19.5 percent, to 4.7 billion euros. The acquisition of CTI is TNT's largest purchase since it went public in 1998. It brings TNT one step closer to a transformation from a regional post office to a global logistics company. Suzanne Kapner

title: Urban Sprawl Threatens the Solitude and Fragile Lands of Georgia's State Parks
description: Before metropolitan Atlanta began its relentless march north, bulldozing forests of loblolly pine and soybean fields, the Etowah Indian Mounds here was a remote state historic site where children visited the ancient burial grounds, and astronomers viewed the stars.

Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped off into their general election campaigns today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRITER, JOSEPH F.
description: FERRITER-Joseph F. Retired Securities Analyst and longtime resident of New York died Friday, September 1 in Alexandria, VA. following a lengthy illness. He was 89 years old. Mr. Ferriter was born in Brattleboro, VT, in 1910. Following service in the U.S. Army in World War II he worked for many years on Wall Street. After his retirement he maintained residences in Charlestown, R.I. & Naples, FL. Mr. Ferriter is survived by his wife, Lucy Katt Ferriter of Alexandria, VA. A son, John (Olivia) and two grandchildren, Matthews and William.

Bush today announced a schedule of three hand-picked debates that he would do, only one of which is guaranteed to be broadcast on the three major networks.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Gore's Marathon: 5 Cities in 28 Hours
description: The best things about a marathon are the little events that keep people amused along the way.

title: Discovering Early Clues to Where an Albatross Wanders on Its Year Off
description: The wandering albatross did not earn its name by just sitting around. The seabirds, the largest in the world, spend more than 90 percent of their life over the oceans of the Southern Hemisphere, and through banding and satellite tracking have been shown to cover tens of thousands of miles in a breeding season foraging for food.

title: Unspectacular, but Advancing
description: After Todd Martin managed to conclude his rain-suspended match against 10th-seeded Cedric Pioline yesterday, he was asked at his news conference about unforced errors in his 7-6 (5), 6-3, 6-2 victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSENOW, ADOLPH PETER
description: NUSSENOW-Adolph Peter. On Sept. 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Marion. Devoted father of Dinah and his grandchildren, Daniel, Benjamin and Lea. We will never forget him. Funeral private.

title: An Australia Beyond Shrimp on the Barbie, Mate
description: For those of us steeled against an Olympic onslaught of kangaroos, koalas and Crocodile Dundee kitsch, ''Australia: Beyond the Fatal Shore'' offers a protective coating for the brain. Robert Hughes's six-part series is not the only program to ride the coattails of the Sydney games, but it is the only one to explode the myths and cliches that others mindlessly indulge. ''Croc Hunter Holiday,'' the title of a Travel Channel documentary, says it all about the standard glimpse at Australia.

title: Plan Aims to Foster Electronic Commerce Between Businesses
description: Seeking to promote the rapid development of electronic commerce between businesses, I.B.M., Microsoft and Ariba plan to announce a proposal on Wednesday to create a huge set of online registries of products and services to help automate business transactions.

title: Calypso Wits Bombard a New Target
description: Calypso's long tradition of genial protest found its latest target close to home during the annual Dimanche Gras concert on Sunday night on the grounds of the Brooklyn Museum of Art. It's hard to get more topical than commenting on something due the next morning on the same block.

title: Speed Helps Rams Squeak by Broncos
description: The Rams threw a pregame party tonight. It featured eight cannon shots, each one sounding like a stick of dynamite being detonated. There were fireworks, rock music and the St. Louis owner, Georgia Frontiere, raising the Lombardi Trophy above her head and giving it a smooch.

title: Lookin' Out For the Right Sound
description: Antonio Hart had already worked through a number of different styles -- bebop with a free time feeling, powerhouse rhythm-and-blues, a bit of gospel -- but a song dedicated to the recently deceased pop-jazz icon Grover Washington Jr. gave him the opportunity to take his set in yet another direction.

title: Insider Trading Is Charged on Intel Deal
description: Insider Trading Is Charged on Intel Deal

title: Style Fantasies Show the Influence Of a Photographer's Stark Reality
description: In the half-dozen or so fashion shoots he has done, most of them for W magazine during the past few years, Philip-Lorca diCorcia has staged unnerving narratives like one titled ''A Perfect World,'' in which things don't seem perfect at all. Here, a patrician housewife, frozen looking, her face harshly lighted, appears as if she'd need no more than a few shots of Tanqueray and a splash of Schwepps to push her into doing something Medea-like. In another series, set in Havana, a model is cast as a disconsolate-looking Batista-era office worker who is equally blank in her nighttime job as a call girl. Should the reader forget that there are dresses to be looked at, the text alerts you: ''Havana was once a nightclub hot spot. These days, it's the perfect backdrop for sober day clothes or racy little evening looks. Think brief, briefer, briefest.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, BARBARA (NEE BALANOFF)
description: PASTERNACK-Barbara (nee Balanoff). On September 3 after a brief but courageous struggle with cancer. Beloved mother of Michael and Jonathan. Aunt, sisterin-law & cousin. Adored Professor Emeritus of Long Island University. Author, cherished mentor and dear friend to many. Services are today at 1 PM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment to follow at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. Donations can be made to SHARE.

title: GRIDLOCK IN THE SKIES: A special report.; Crisis for Air Traffic System: More Passengers, More Delays
description: Today ends the second straight summer travel season of chronic flight delays and cancellations across the United States. Yet despite the expenditure of billions -- and repeated warnings over the last decade that the air traffic system was approaching gridlock -- there is still no relief in sight for frustrated fliers.

title: TV Networks Jilted by Bush Won't Take Part in 2 Debates
description: Two television networks that were left out of Gov. George W. Bush's plan to impose his own schedule of debates declared yesterday that they had no intention of carrying presidential debates sponsored by rival networks.

title: Valuing Humanity and Rituals
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Man Held in Deaths of Girlfriend and 2 Children
description: A Yonkers man who the police said had a history of domestic violence was charged today in the stabbing deaths of his live-in girlfriend and two of her young children, officials said.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: McConnaughy Stein To Be Acquired
description: Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, is acquiring McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE RUNNING MATES

title: Groh Controls Emotions At an Emotional Time
description: For prodigious emotion, the Jets have Vinny Testaverde, who wept as he sat at his locker after Sunday's victory at Lambeau Field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNTY, ROBERT
description: MOUNTY-Robert. August 6, 2000. The world has lost a treasure. Rest peacefully, dear friend. Roberta Cole

title: For Exercise, Every Minute Counts
description: People who want to start exercise programs but feel they don't have enough time or energy to begin should think again.

title: For a Japanese Gymnast, Honor Thy Father
description: Naoya Tsukahara bounced up and down on the trampoline that had been lowered into the floor. Up and down and up and down again, then suddenly, in a split second, he lofted himself high into the air and did two graceful, twisting, vertical somersaults before landing, like a butterfly, on his tiny feet.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Coated Seeds for Farming

title: CLINTON PLANNING DIPLOMATIC WHIRL ON NEW YORK TRIP
description: President Clinton's foreign policy aides say he plans a diplomatic whirlwind in New York over the next three days, including what one senior official called ''the last real chance'' to jump-start the failed talks between Israel and the Palestinians and what may be prove to be a tense session with China's president over Beijing's continued missile exports to Pakistan.

title: Daimler Seeks More Control Of Mitsubishi
description: DaimlerChrysler, which has based its hopes for Asian expansion on a partnership with Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, is demanding more control in the wake of a scandal over defective cars that has engulfed Mitsubishi.

title: 2 Candidates, 1 Plan: Spend the Surplus
description: As we head full force into the presidential campaign, one thing is certain. George W. Bush and Al Gore both seem determined to spend a significant portion of the nation's budget surplus.

title: Rocks From Mars
description: Q. How do scientists determine that a rock on Earth came from Mars rather than someplace else?

title: Poll Watch: Numbers Spell Out Who the Voters Really Are
description: In modern politics it has become de rigueur to explain a candidate's popularity or lack thereof by characterizing pockets of American voters.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: BROOKLYN

title: Case of Joined Twins Moves to England's Court of Appeal
description: England's Court of Appeal heard a request today to decide whether doctors can proceed with an operation separating joined twins that would sacrifice the life of one to save the other. The infants' parents have objected to the plan, even though doctors say both children will probably die if the surgery is not performed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the evacuation of the Japanese island of Miyake during volcanic eruptions referred incorrectly in some copies to the year a big earthquake struck Kobe, Japan. It was 1995, not 1985.

title: Air-Travel Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Evangelicals Flock To Hear a Force in Their Faith
description: In wheelchairs, on crutches and standing shoelace-deep in the mud, several thousand Latino evangelicals waited nearly all afternoon yesterday in a South Bronx park for a former bodybuilder turned faith healer who is widely known as the Spanish-speaking Billy Graham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASMAN, DENNIS N.
description: FASMAN-Dennis N. Beloved husband of Barbara. Cherished father of Kenneth, Judy, Steven, Carol, Glen and Roger. Devoted grandfather to Jennifer, Anna, Matthew and Adam. Funeral at the New City Jewish Center, Old Schoolhouse Rd, New City, NY at 11 AM today. Contributions in his name to the American Cancer Society.

title: New York Heads Back to School As Shortage of Teachers Worsens
description: New York City's 1.1 million public-school children return to class this week to face a worsening shortage of fully qualified teachers, even as tougher standards, including a newly required Regents mathematics exam, make the path toward graduation more arduous.

title: Nigerian Leader Seeks Peacemaking Role
description: Fifteen months after restoring democracy to Africa's most populous nation for the second time in 20 years, President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria said today that he was ready to step into a larger role in mediating an end to his continent's debilitating wars, beginning with Congo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKIS, JOHN S.
description: BOOKIS-John S. Passed away on September 2, 2000, at age 79. Survived by his wife Sophia, his children George, Mary-Kay, Susan and Joan. His brothers Gregory and Blaise, his sister Suzie, his grandchildren, his nephews and nieces. His courageous spirit will always live in our hearts. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, on Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 343 East 74th St, on Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: The Ultimate, Apocalyptic Laptop
description: For all the corporate enthusiasm over the unveiling of each new generation of computer chip (last month Intel announced that its Pentium 4 would be packed with 42 million transistors performing as many as 8.4 billion operations per second), consumers may be more apt to feel a sense of dread. Once again the expensive desktop computers and laptops they were so proud of have become outmoded, destined to join the scrap piles of unsalable equipment accumulating in closets everywhere.

title: Through Northwest Passage in a Month, Ice-Free
description: During World War II, when Henry Larsen took a Royal Canadian Mounted Police ship, the St. Roch, into the fabled Northwest Passage, his boat was frozen in Arctic ice through two winters, only emerging at the eastern end after 27 months.

title: Frances Le Monde Wins Rights to Internet Address
description: France's Le Monde Wins Rights to Internet Address

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, HARRIET
description: BLAUSTEIN-Harriet. On August 30, 2000. You are with us every day. Your everlasting love and care comfort us. Pam, David and Michele

title: Cincinnati Has Answers For the New-Look Army
description: They had something old an 0-4 record in season openers away from West Point. They had a bunch of new stuff -- a head coach for one, Todd Berry, who brought a one-back, multiple-spread offense to put the ball in the air. They had something borrowed -- a gray stripe added to each jersey sleeve to represent the United States Corps of Cadets, as well as the uniforms worn by its championship teams of the 1940's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNER, MARVIN
description: PENNER-Marvin. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Judith & son-in-law James Broach, and Amy and son-in-law John Walker. Cherished grandfather of Sara & Matthew Broach & Adam Walker. He was with the ILGWU for 30 years. Donations in his memory can be made to the Hospice Center of Northern Westchester and Putnam, A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Contest for Albany Seat Hinges on a Veteran Legislator's Relevance
description: By noon, Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve had already put in a full morning of campaigning and seemed more than a bit weary. He had spent hours today shaking the hands of supporters and had just completed a caravan through the humid streets of Buffalo with a dozen cars carrying loudspeakers imploring people along the way to vote for him.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Inmates Battling West's Fires Help States and Themselves
description: Back in Utah, they are inmates at Bluffdale State Prison. But out here in the fire zone, they strut proudly in black T-shirts proclaiming themselves members of the Flame 'N' Go Hotshots.

title: British Utility Is Said to Acquire Niagara Mohawk
description: The National Grid Group, a British energy company, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has agreed to acquire Niagara Mohawk Holdings, an upstate New York power concern, for about $3 billion in cash and stock, according to executives close to the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANDEE, SEYMOUR R. ''SY''
description: CANDEE-Seymour R. ''Sy''. A man of great courage and wisdom. His word was his bond, as was his reputation. He was a kind and loving husband to Peg, sons Glenn and Robert and Eileen, and grandsons Jason, Brian and Kevin, and his brother Morton. He graduated from St. John's University and was Captain of the soccer team, and All American Player of the Year. He became a successful realtor and had a wonderful and happy life. Services will be on Tuesday, September 5, at 1 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, New York. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Donations to the Frank and Edith Dickstein Cancer Pavilion, White Plains Hospital, White Plains, NY. Family will be receiving friends Tuesday and Wednesday only at the Candee residence in Purchase, NY.

title: WorldCom Said to Agree on Intermedia Purchase for $39 a Share
description: WorldCom Inc., the No. 2 U.S. long-distance company, has agreed to buy Intermedia Communications Inc. for about $3 billion, or $39 a share, in cash and stock to gain its controlling stake in the World Wide Web-hosting company Digex Inc., people familiar with the situation said yesterday.

title: Fighting Off Fevers, Aggressively
description: Real men don't get colds.

title: Philips to Release DVD Recorder in 2001
description: Philips to Release DVD Recorder in 2001

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, BERTHA
description: FRANK-Bertha, 94. Of Deerfield Beach, FL. On September 3, 2000. Loving wife of the late Benjamin, devoted and cherished mother of Phyllis and Matthew Taubin, Edwin and Lynda Frank, Jerome Frank, Marvin and Marilyn Frank. Adored grandmother of Marc and Lana, Gregory, Jonathan and Aerin, Gregory, Melissa, Lauri, Jeffrey, Debbie and Gary. Adored great-grandmother of Jennifer, Brian, Alexandra, Alisha, Jessie and Tyler. Cherished by her extended family and friends, she was a pillar of the family and will be dearly missed by all.

title: Honors
description: The Promotion Marketing Association, New York, named Robert W. Fallon chairman and president for a one-year term. He is a partner and chief marketing officer at the Millennium Lifestyle Marketing Group, Boston, part of Devine & Pearson.

title: Accounts
description: * United Distillers and Vintners, Harlow, England, part of Diageo P.L.C., to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, 49 percent owned by the B Com3 Group, to handle creative work for its Gordon's Gin brand in Britain, which had been at the London office of Leo Burnett Worldwide, also part of B Com3 . Billings were estimated at $4.5 million.

title: AIR FRANCE PROFIT RISES 20%
description: The French carrier Air France said operating profit in the quarter ended June 30 rose 20.2 percent, to 185 million euros, or $166 million, on a 20 percent increase in revenue, to 3 billion euros, fueled by a 33 percent rise in traffic over the North Atlantic. Air France's president, Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, said the increases came despite a sharp rise in fuel costs, and attributed much of the North Atlantic growth to a recently announced alliance with Delta. Net income in the quarter, the first in Air France's fiscal year, rose 85 percent, to 267 million euros, helped in part by the sale of a stake in the Amadeus reservation system. John Tagliabue

title: What Ancient Thing Lies Buried?
description: On a road with suburban homes, swimming pools and minivans, a 12,000-year-old mastodon has turned a quiet backyard pond into a pit of scientific inquiry.

title: Preventing Forest Fires
description: To the Editor:

title: Neon Surrealism Required; Clothing Optional
description: It was the middle of the night in the middle of nowhere, and under a frigid Nevada sky about 75 men and women wearing nothing but body paint and their own bravado were cavorting on the barren lake bed here in temperatures that would make your average coyote flinch.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, MRS. ELVERA, A
description: DAVIS-Mrs. Elvera, a/a ''Baby Sanchez''/d. New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Dance Day mourns September 2 passing of its Advisory Committee member. Mother of Sammy Davis, Jr., strong supporter of our efforts for more public appreciation of the tap dance skill, Mrs. Davis was our link between today's young dancers and the older masters. We will miss her council and influence.

title: Public Interests; Ohio Gets Ready to Commit
description: We waited a long time for the public to get interested in this election, but now in southern Ohio you can see the signs. Literally. The lawns are full of ads for candidates who want to be the next congressman or state representative. This must be what they mean when they talk about grass-roots politics.

title: Los Angeles Journal; The Battle of the Hollywood Bowl
description: No one has conducted more performances at the Hollywood Bowl, under the stars and with the Santa Monica Mountains as a backdrop, than John Mauceri. ''The Bowl,'' Mr. Mauceri, conductor of the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra, said the other day, ''is magic.''

title: Security Council Looking At Its Peacekeeping Bills
description: The five permanent Security Council members plan to use their collective influence this week and call for a revision of how peacekeeping costs are divided among member nations, a move that would -- at least on paper -- help Washington in its battle to reduce American assessments.

title: In a Lobby-Happy Washington, Politics Can Be Even Thicker Than Blood
description: Politics can sometimes turn brother against brother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEANY, STEPHEN J., S.J.
description: MEANY-Stephen J., S.J. Died of cancer Sunday, September 3 at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Bronx, NY. For the five years prior to his death, Fr. Meany, who recited on the campus of Fordham University, had conducted retreats for lay and religious throughout the Eastern United States and Canada. Born in Queens, NY and a graduate of Regis High School in Manhattan, he entered the Society of Jesus in 1954 and was ordained at Fordham in 1967. For eighteen years he served in Puerto Rico as teacher and administrator at Jesuit schools there. In 1975 he spent a year of intensive training in corporate finance, subsequently filling financial posts in Puerto Rico and at St. Peter's Prep in Jersey City. Fr. Meany was active in the alcohol recovery programs of AA, the National Catholic Council on Alcohol and the Guest House of Rochester, MN. He is survived by sisters Patricia Rand of New Haven, Joanne Handy of Boston, Mary Ann Santos of San Francisco and twenty nieces and nephews. His three brothers predeceased him.

title: Trailing Noxious Gases
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, MARTIN
description: LANG-Martin. On September 4, 2000. Born January 28, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY. Martin was the devoted husband of Bertha Friedman Lang for 62 years, loving father to Judith Lang Zaimont, Doris Lang Kosloff and Robert David Lang and grandfather to Adam Lang Harris Kosloff, Daniel Max Lang Kosloff, Jordan Scott Berman Lang and Michael Elliot Lang Zamont. In his 40 year career of outstanding service to the City of NY, he served as Commissioner of the Departments of Water Resources, Sanitation, and Park and Recreation, as well as being the first Deputy Administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration. He was the President of the National Water Pollution Control Federation and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering. He became the President of the Management Consultant Division of Camp, Dresser & McKee, consulting worldwide on water quality management. Martin graduated from CCNY (BS) and NYU (MS). He served with distinction in WW II as 2nd Lt. in the Army Engineering Corps, and taught Chemistry at LIU and Engineering Management at CCNY. Among his many awards are CCNY's Townsend Harris Medal in 1973 and the David D. Steinman Medal in 1985. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Association of Kidney Patients, 100 South Ashley Drive, Suite 280, Tampa, Fla. 33602. Services today, September 5 at 12:30 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Is Smoking Just About Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Systems Might Provide a U.S. Missile Shield
description: In putting off a decision on a national missile defense on Friday, President Clinton said the earliest such a shield could be put in place was 2006 or 2007. But the president made a decision on just one system. What he did not say, and what the debate over that system has obscured, is that a number of lesser- known antimissile weapons might be candidates for the same job.

title: Fabini Guards His Words After Sunday's Debacle
description: Left tackle Jason Fabini timed his arrival in the Jets' locker room today perfectly -- just as reporters were leaving.

title: No Headline
Russian Media Mogul Says Kremlin Is Trying to Silence Him
description: One of the country's media moguls, Boris Berezovsky, said today that a senior Kremlin official had ordered him to transfer his holdings in Russia's primary state-owned television channel to the state or face the prospect of going to jail.

title: STAKE SOLD IN SOUTH KOREAN BANK
description: A consortium led by the global investment firm the Carlyle Group and J. P. Morgan has become the largest shareholder in South Korea's KorAm Bank after acquiring a 40 percent stake for 455.9 billion won ($412.6 million), the South Korean bank said. In a statement to the Korea Stock Exchange, KorAm Bank said it had signed an investment agreement to sell the stake to the consortium in the form of Global Depository Receipts. Earlier, a sole bid by Carlyle to acquire a stake in KorAm Bank was rejected by the South Korean government on the grounds that the investment firm was not a banking institution. Currently, the Samsung Group and Bank of America each hold a 16.8 percent stake in KorAm. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, LUCIA (VELEZ)
description: ENGEL-Lucia (Velez). On September 2, 2000 of Washington Twp, N.J. Wife of the late Herbert Engel, Sr. Mother of Richard Engel, his wife, Patricia, and children, Richard Arthur and Patricia Alba. William Engel and sons, William Jr and Hans Jr. Frank Engel and sons, Frank Jr and Alex, the late Herbert Engel Jr, and children, Rochelle, Herbert III and Joseph. Lucy Vippolis, her husband, Bruno, and son Andre. Mary Taerstein & daughter, Erica. Elizabeth EngelRiggi, her husband, Louis, and daughter, Ashley. Walter Engel. Hans Engel. Loving friend, Lila. Funeral from Trinka-Faustini Funeral Home, 439 Maywood Avenue, Maywood, New Jersey, Wednesday, September 6 at 9:15AM. Mass St. Andrew's RC Church, Westwood 10 AM. Entombment Garden of Memories. Visiting Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Online Deliveries Lighten Burden for the Disabled; Empowerment, Not Just Convenience, For an Unexpected Class of Consumer
description: Mary West stumbled across YourGrocer.com, an online grocery store, one afternoon a few years ago and quickly became a fan of its fresh blueberry muffins and fast deliveries.

title: GO SPORT TO MERGE WITH COURIR
description: Go Sport, a French distributor of sporting goods, said it agreed to merge with the sports shoe retailer Courir, to become Europe's second-largest publicly traded sporting goods retailer. Courir will exchange five of its shares for every six in Go Sport. Charles Setboun, managing director of Courir, will head the new company, which will have 4,350 employees. Shareholders will vote on the merger in December.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Russian Dinosaur
description: The sinking of the Russian submarine Kursk was a tragic but incredibly illuminating example of the transition the world, and Russia, are now going through from the cold-war system to the globalization system. Unfortunately, there's always some guy down the line who hasn't gotten the word yet. In this case it was Russia's president, Vladimir Putin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISOM, OLE C.
description: RISOM-Ole C. A memorial mass will be held Thursday, September 7, 11 AM, at St. Mary's Church, Roslyn Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Children International, Box 219055, Kansas City, MO. 64121.

title: U.S. Women Squeak By In Bridge
description: Both United States bridge teams were in action here today at the World Bridge Championship, although one of them came within a hair of being eliminated on Sunday night.

title: Time's Up for Qualifier as Sampras Asserts Himself
description: It was just after the rain delay, in between the exiting day crowd and the incoming night-session fans, when Hyung-Taik Lee's made-for-television adventure began to unfold in a studio setting of sorts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chronic Flight Delays Tied to Deregulation

title: Sick in the Head, and in the Stomach
description: Feeling sick to one's stomach may have more to do with the brain than the stomach. Researchers at Ohio State University say in a new study that they may have uncovered the reason that, often, people feel nauseated, even though what ails them has nothing to do with their digestive tracts.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's gotten down to a big fingerpointing contest. The reality is, everybody's got blame to share.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, ALLEN A.
description: LIPTON-Allen A. Died September 3, 2000. He was 83. He was born February 12, 1917, in Brooklyn, to Hyman and Mary Lipkowitz. He leaves his wife Dorothea (nee Glaser), son Leonard of Bethel, CT, daughters Linda Bergeron of Discovery Bay, CA, Lois Sheppard of Seal Beach, CA, his sister Sally Kligfield of Rockville, MD, granddaughter Nichole Ellyson, and great-granddaughter Emily Ellyson. Al, an avid sailor all his life, enjoyed sailing on the Long Island Sound. He was a Boy Scout troop leader, as well as being active in the Coast Guard Auxiliary and Power Squadron, Orienta Yacht Club, and a past Commodore of Sheldrake Yacht Club. The family would be honored if contributions were made to the Long Island Sound Keeper.

title: Dokic Ignores Father, Then Loses to Williams
description: Jelena Dokic built a fortress these past six days, shutting out her unruly father's ejection from the United States Open and then dealing with its lonely consequences by striking the ball without forgiveness.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries are gathering this week for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: Religion and Public Life
description: To the Editor:

title: As Diplomacy Loses Luster, Stars Flee State Dept.
description: At 32, Mona Sutphen, smart, driven and possessed of that quality so elusive in Washington, an easy personality, was known as one of the best and the brightest in the West Wing of the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHER, HERMAN
description: FLEISCHER-Herman. Age 78. Suddenly, on September 1, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Fleischer. Much loved father of Madelene (Stan) Towne. Devoted and adored Papa of Adam, Sara and Rachel Towne. You will be forever missed.

title: Vaulting Into Olympic History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ballet Choreographers Emerging From Within
description: It is no secret that gifted choreographers have been in short supply in recent years. Ballet has suffered most. Traditionally ballet choreographers have been dancers who developed simply by working with performers in their companies. Today, however, ballet is more a profession than a vocation and, with unionization, the days of sometimes brutal open-ended rehearsals are gone.

title: Trying to Prevent the Next Killer Rampage
description: It was nearly four years ago when the police climbed the creaky stairs to Deborah Stagg's apartment in response to calls from neighbors who had heard her screaming and raving alone in there. Ms. Stagg was known around town as a woman so disturbed that she had once delivered her own baby by cutting her womb open with a penknife.

title: How to Create a Shortage In a Skilled-Labor Market
description: TO alleviate apparent shortages of computer programmers, President Clinton and Congress have agreed to raise a quota on H-1B's, the temporary visas for skilled foreigners. The annual limit will go to 200,000 next year, up from 65,000 only three years ago.

title: Senator Admits To Joint Filing After Divorce
description: State Senator Larry B. Seabrook, who is a candidate in a bitter race for Congress, allowed reporters yesterday to see his tax documents, which indicated that he had filed joint tax returns for two years after his divorce became official in 1993.

title: BANK CHARGED WITH PRICE FIXING
description: National Australia Bank Ltd., Australia's biggest lender, was charged with unlawful price fixing on its credit cards, according to the Competition and Consumer Commission. The commission filed charges against the bank in federal court, an action that could cost the institution as much as 10 million Australian dollars ($5.7 million) in penalties. Frank Cicutto, National's chief executive, denied the charges. ''Taking action against the National, alone, for alleged price fixing is absurd and is an unwarranted slur against our company and employees,'' he said. The commission did not rule out charges against other major banks. The commission said the nation's banks charge 600 million Australian dollars ($347 million) a year in interchange fees -- fees the card issuing bank charge a merchant's bank for processing transactions and reimbursing the merchant.

title: Beijing Journal; For a Prize That's Olympian, China Jumps the Gun
description: It seems recently that all of Beijing is flushed with Olympic fever, busy making preparations. The posters are up at Beijing International Airport. Commemorative stamps have been issued. Taxi drivers are learning English to prepare for the influx of foreign guests. The logo is cropping up on key chains and bumper stickers.

title: Missile Decision: Don't Rest Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, ROBERT H.
description: MONTGOMERY-Robert H., Jr. The Board and Staff of the Alliance for the Arts mourn the passing of our beloved Chairman, Robert H. Montgomery, Jr. Since 1986, Bob guided us with gentle wisdom and steadiness. He was fatherly in his compassion, lawyerly in the clarity of his advice, but above all, elegant in his dealings with everyone. Having led a remarkable life, as friend and counsel to many important people, he was the most modest of men, always interested in others. His pride was in the accomplishments of his wife and children. We offer our profound sympathy to Henriette, Margaret and Sam. Bob was a mentor to many in his profession and encouraged the staff of the Alliance to think for themselves and to aim high. Our cultural life is diminished by his loss, but the Alliance will continue its work in Bob Montgomery's honor. We will miss him. Paul Beirne, Acting Chairman Randall Bourscheidt, President Anita Contini, Vice Chairman Karen Gifford, Vice Chairman

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Not What You Think

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEXIS-NEXIS, Dayton, Ohio, the legal information provider owned by the international publishing company Reed Elsevier P.L.C., said it acquired Press Access Inc., Boston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAFFEY, EILEEN P.
description: LAFFEY-Eileen P. (Brouthers/ Johnson). Beloved wife of James, born to Mary (Cudahey) and Addison J. Brouthers on August 18, 2000. Died on her 81st birthday, August 18, 2000. Eileen attended St. Joan of Arc Parish and School in Jackson Heights and graduated Newton High School with honors. Eileen's only brother, Addison F. Brouthers was killed May 23, 1944 in Italy during W.W. II. Within months, she was devastated, learning her husband Lt. Howard W. Johnson had been killed in France, August 18, 1944. Being a ''dyed in the wool'' baseball NY Giants fan inherited from her grandfather, a member of the Cooperstown Hall of Fame, ''Big Dan'' Brouthers. Eileen perservered, elevating herself to General Office Manager of the most preeminent management consulting firms of its day. On April 22, 1950, James and Eileen were wed in a ceremony at St. Boniface RC Church. Eileen subsequently applied for and was accepted serving as Librarian for several years at Hunter College. Suffering from osteoporosis necessitated total hip replacement of both hips. After the operations, it became necessary for her to retire. Congestive heart failure developed, necessitating hopsitalization on several occasions. She persisted until visiting New York Presbyterian Emergency Room. After receiving her last rites, she passed on to her heavenly reward. Friends and relatives called at John Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Ave., NY, NY on Monday August 21, 2000 from 25PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated at 10AM August 22, 2000 at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68 St. Interment followed at Gate of Heavenly Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: MetroStars Hope Goalie Is a Keeper
description: One game may not be enough evidence, but the MetroStars have most likely found a goalkeeper for the Major League Soccer playoffs that start next week. The problem is they will have to share Paul Grafer with the Long Island Rough Riders of the A-League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, NEIL
description: WILSON-Neil. Operatic tenor, died August 21st. Husband of Linda Munguia. (See New York Times obit August 25.) A New York memorial service will be held September 9, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 346 W. 20th St. 3:00 PM.

title: Honeywell to Sell Its Brake Product Business
description: Questor Partners Fund II, a private investment firm, has agreed to buy the brake-products business of Honeywell International Inc., which is selling units to increase its profits.

title: Business Travel; Wine is taking on a bigger role in the business- and first-class cabins of international flights.
description: YOU probably don't want to be reading this if, like so many hard-pressed business travelers these days, you're crammed into some awful middle-row seat in coach on an international flight, counting the hours till arrival and wondering how you're going to squeeze past that fat guy sleeping in the aisle seat to get to the bathroom.

title: Disarmament Group's Ads Attack Candidates Favoring Missile Defense System
description: President Clinton may have deferred the question of whether to build a national missile defense system to his successor, but opponents of such a system are not satisfied. In television advertisements that are to begin running on Wednesday, the nation's largest pro-disarmament group is attacking candidates in 13 competitive House and Senate races who favor a missile shield.

title: H.M.O. Costs Spur Employers To Shift Plans
description: Health insurance premiums are increasing by 10 percent to 30 percent across the country, according to employers, insurers and regional business groups familiar with the rates being paid by dozens of companies. Driven largely by escalating drug costs, the double-digit increase in annual premiums is the third consecutive one for many companies.

title: A New Fishing Encyclopedia Covers All Angles for Anglers
description: The recently published "Ken Schultz's Fishing Encyclopedia: Worldwide Angling Guide" (IDG Books Worldwide) is a major accomplishment, a book that any wide-ranging and curious angler would want in his library.

title: THE CHEF; Eberhard Muller
description: RIGHT now, I'm harvesting young fennel on my farm. Unlike the swollen, tough bulbs you find in supermarkets, these tiny ones are tender and their flavor is more intense. The bulbs are small enough to fit into a child's palm.

title: Creamy Sauce With a Bite
description: CREAMY horseradish sauce is everywhere these days, from fast-food joints to serious restaurants. It doesn't seem to be in the repertory of many home cooks, however, even though it's absurdly easy to make with not much more than horseradish and sour cream.

title: The Founders and the Torah
description: Idon't know who the critics of Joe Lieberman's use of religious references in his vice presidential campaign talk to. Everybody I know, right and left  especially right  is cheering his view that America needs a constitutional space for religion in public, that Americans should talk more about religion in public, that this is the most religious nation on the planet and that secularists who wince at religion in public are to religion what Victorians were to sex.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC SHARES JUMP AS PURCHASE IS CALLED OFF
description: Shares of Fisher Scientific International Inc., a leading seller of laboratory equipment, rose 44 percent yesterday on news that it had ended its plan to buy PSS World Medical Inc. for $746.9 million. The shares rose $9.63, to $31.56. The stock had fallen 13 percent this year. Shares of PSS, a medical products supplier, fell $1.53, to $4.81. Fisher, based in Hampton, N.H., and PSS in Florida said the ''transaction is not in the best interest of their respective shareholders.'' Fisher had announced on June 22 that it would buy PSS to increase its sales of medical products to doctors and nursing homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIMICKE, VICTOR W.
description: EIMICKE-Victor W., PhD. Of Bronxville, NY on Sept. 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Maxine. Dear father to Laura Klimley and Alicia Barbieri. Loving grandfather of Spencer James Barbieri, Zoe Brooks, Graham Sutherland and Preston William Klimley. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Thursday, Sept. 7 at 4 P.M. The family has requested that memorial contributions may be made to The Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Joined By Hip: Food And TV
description: MY biggest disappointment while previewing the Food Network's new fall lineup last week was that the ''Naked Chef'' was dressed. If I dedicate a full half-hour of my life to a scrupulous inspection of a new Generation Z (yes, he looks that young) kitchen whiz from England, I expect more in return than a winning smile and a recipe for vodka-soused watermelon.

title: Metro Business; Purchase Saves Paper Mill
description: The Empire Paper Group will spend $20 million to buy the century-old Appleton Coated Paper Mill at Newton Falls in Potsdam, N.Y., preserving 130 jobs and creating an additional 120, state officials have said. The mill's operation shrank last year when part of it was shut down, and the former owner had threatened to close it altogether if it could not find a buyer.

title: Ward Proves Hes Big Enough for Expanded Role
description: GREEN BAY, Wis. -- Ever since Keyshawn Johnson departed to Tampa Bay in a flurry of contract demands, the question has hovered over the Jets: could Al Groh and Dedric Ward justify the deal?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MARGA
description: STONE-Marga. We extend sincerest condolences to our dear friend and Silver Founder, Bernard Stone, on the loss of his beloved wife. May the warm memories of this kind and special person provide solace to Mr. Stone, her son Ernst Weglein and the entire family, and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Michael S. Strauss, Chrmn., Metro. N.Y. Bd.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell after Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany said he welcomed the currency's decline. In New York, the euro settled at 89.06 cents, down from 89.95 cents on Friday.

title: Miami-Dade Mayor Wins Bulk Of Votes but May Face Runoff
description: Seeking re-election as mayor of Miami-Dade County, Alex Penelas today won the bulk of votes in an open primary contest against nine opponents. But hours after the polls closed, it was still unclear whether he had the 50 percent needed to win a second term without a runoff.

title: Controversial Education Study
description: Anew analysis of recent research into the use of technology in the classroom is being praised by some educators and policymakers, but critics are already questioning its conclusions and its credibility.

title: Ford Chief Executive Declines to Testify in Congressional Inquiry on Bridgestone Tires
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29  The Ford Motor Company said today that its chief executive and president, Jacques A. Nasser, had declined invitations to testify next week before Congressional committees investigating tire failures, mainly on Ford Explorers. This prompted criticism from one lawmaker who is leading inquiries into the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires.

title: Miller's Monday Night Debut A Less Than Divine Comedy
description: Now we know what Dennis Miller sounds like in a great game when he has consciously dialed back his shtick.

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Fall, Time to Hunker Down
description: Correction Appended

title: Doubts About 'Real' Voters
description: This is a new 15-second commercial, called ''The Ringer,'' that the Lazio campaign began broadcasting statewide yesterday. The advertisement responds to a recent commercial by the New York State Democratic Party that says it features interviews with ''real'' New Yorkers, who express surprise and dismay with the voting record of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican candidate for United States Senate. The Lazio commercial tries to sharply question the credibility of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, pointing out that one of the ''real voters'' featured in the Democratic advertisement is a former employee of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly.

title: Addenda
description: Two Agencies Form E-Services Unit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOLN, PETER G.
description: LINCOLN-Peter G., Clinical psychologist in private practice in Manhattan and active member of the New York State Psychological Assn. Formerly with St. LukesRoosevelt Hospital Center and Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy. Graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1965, and recipient of a doctorate in clinical psychology from NYU Graduate School of Arts and Science. Father of Justin Lincoln, Sloatsburg, NY, and Kara Lincoln, Seattle, WA; son of Jerome and Ray Lincoln, Elkins Park, PA; brother of Joseph Lincoln, Penn Valley, PA and Lisa Lincoln, NYC; life partner of Mary McCorry, NYC. Predeceased by his son, Kai Lincoln. We mourn his passing on August 6, 2000. All who knew him are invited to a memorial service that will be held on Saturday, September 9, 2000 at 1:00 P.M. in the auditorium of The New York Society for Ethical Culture at 2 West 64th Street. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021, toward the devel. of a hospice for its long-term patients.

title: French Nazi Memorabilia Case Presents Jurisdiction Dilemma
description: In Europe, where memories of World War II are still fresh in the minds of those who lived through it, the sale of Nazi and Fascist memorabilia often sparks indignation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPORE, MICHAEL J.
description: LEPORE-Michael J., M.D. gifted clinician, internist, and educator, died at home on September 2, 2000. He received his M.D. with Honor in 1934 from the University of Rochester, served as Lt. Col in the Pacific 1942-46, and was director of the Gastroenterology Service at St. Vincent's Hospital 196675 and Professor at N.Y.U. School of Medicine since 1971. Honors include M.J. Lepore Professorship in Gastroenterology at University of Rochester, St. Vincent dePaul Distinguished Physician Award, FACP, AOA, SIGMA Xi. He was predeceased by his wife Ardean Everett Lepore. He is survived by his son Frederick and wife Adlynn, grandchildren Addie and Meredith, sisters and brothers-in-law Lucille and Ignazio Russo, Annette and Edward Urban and Phyllis Russo. Reposing Volk-Lieber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, N J. Funeral Mass Thursday September 7, 2000 at 10: A.M. St. Cecelia R.C. Church, Englewood, N J. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. Contributions can be made to: Lepore Memorial Fund, 36 7 Ave., Suite 402 NY, NY 10011 Attn: Mrs. Phyllis Bloise.

title: Neatness Counts When You're Making P's, B's and J's
description: Connoisseurs of the peanut butter and jelly sandwich know how to achieve perfect, even layers: they use knives with wide, flexible stainless steel blades. The knives also do a terrific job with spreadable cheeses, and some have serrated edges, to handle tomatoes, too.

title: Making Student Data More Efficient
description: Trying to free schools to spend more time on education and less on paperwork, more than 80 makers of educational software, including Apple and Microsoft, are working to develop uniform standards so their programs will work with each other.

title: Credit Suisse Group to Acquire DLJ
description: The Credit Suisse Group announced today that it will buy Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a Wall Street investment bank, for about $12.8 billion.

title: Hingis Cruises to Face Venus Williams
description: Martina Hingis sat in traffic for one agonizing hour yesterday afternoon getting to the United States Open.

title: The Ultimate, Apocalyptic Laptop
description: For all the corporate enthusiasm over the unveiling of each new generation of computer chip (last month Intel announced that its Pentium 4 would be packed with 42 million transistors performing as many as 8.4 billion operations per second), consumers may be more apt to feel a sense of dread. Once again the expensive desktop computers and laptops they were so proud of have become outmoded, destined to join the scrap piles of unsalable equipment accumulating in closets everywhere.

title: After Woeful Summer, First Day Back Is Even Worse
description: Life got real again yesterday. Bummer.

title: Annan Says All Nations Must Cooperate to Solve Problems Like War and Poverty
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan warned today that the perennial problems of war, disease, poverty and pollution will never be resolved unless all countries cooperate, and he stressed that neither they nor the United Nations can accomplish the tasks unaided.

title: Pakistani Leader Voices Little Hope for India Talks
description: Pakistan's military ruler said today that he saw no hope of solving the explosive issue of Kashmir through negotiations with India and that he would appeal to world leaders on Wednesday for the type of international mediation that ended the Indonesian occupation of East Timor.

title: People
description: * Alyce C. Alston was named vice president and publisher at W magazine, New York, part of the Fairchild Publications unit of Advance Publications, succeeding Susan Blank, who left. Ms. Alston had been publisher at O: The Oprah Magazine, New York, the co-venture between the Harpo Entertainment Group and Hearst Magazines. She is succeeded there by Jill Seelig, who had been advertising director.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Plans for a 'Server Farm' Take Developer Upstate
description: There has been a lively trade over the last few years in converting old industrial buildings so telecommunications companies can use them to house switching devices that connect one party with another in the heart of this densely populated region.

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Latest U.F.T. Bid for Higher Pay

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about plans by the Museum of Modern Art for a large expansion misstated the position of the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, toward zoning changes that would allow it. Ms. Fields supports the changes; she does not oppose them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICKMAN, MAURICE
description: BRICKMAN-Maurice. Of Wooster, Massachusetts, beloved husband of Libby, devoted father of Steven & Meryl, and Rabbi Kenneth, of Scarsdale, cherished grandfather of Jean & Jonathan. Dear brother of Sally Blumenstein, of the Bronx. For further information please contact Perlman Funeral Home at: 508-756-2200.

title: Caregiving Families
description: To the Editor:

title: For a New Flavor, 1 Part Fruit, 2 Parts History
description: SHRUB was the thing to drink in the 18th and 19th centuries. Anyone who was feeling parched could add this acidic-sweet fruit syrup to cold spring water, or splash a shot of it into rum or brandy. It had real appeal in those days before refrigeration and sodas. But shrub has merit even in this Sub-Zero world, and as much more than a beverage.

title: Yanks Rest Rivera, and Pay the Price
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 6  Chuck Knoblauch returned to the lineup tonight to test his sore right elbow, but the Yankees tried to get by without Mariano Rivera and paid the price.

title: Cheney More Generous by His Own Numbers
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, today defended his charitable contributions as ''appropriate'' and insisted he should be given credit not only for direct contributions but also for speaking fees he directed to charity and for corporate gifts that matched his own donations.

title: President Decides to Put Off Work on Missile Shield
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  President Clinton said today that he did not believe that the technology was yet ready for an effective national defense system, and passed the decision on moving ahead with the politically charged and diplomatically delicate project to his successor.

title: Navratilova Loves This
description: Twenty-five years ago, Martina Navratilova left the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center after losing in the semifinals to Chris Evert, and traveled to the Immigration and Naturalization Service office to ask for political asylum. The 18-year-old from Czechoslovakia did not tell her family that she was defecting.

title: National News Briefs
description: Scooter Injuries Rise, Especially Among Young

title: A Saber Rattler Teaching Sportsmanship
description: ''LOOK at me!'' the Olympic fencing champ and coach Peter Westbrook is demanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, MATTHEW J.
description: MURRAY-Matthew J. September 4, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Rita C. Murray. Devoted father of Thomas M. Murray, Rita V. Meyer, Matthew J. Murray, Peter E. Murray, Christopher K. Murray and Vincent P. Murray. Loving brother of Elizabeth Fontaine, Thomas Murray and Mary Martin. Cherished grandfather of eighteen and great-grandfather of six. He was a New York Attorney, former Special Agent of the FBI, co-founder of New York Racing Olympic Parking Service & an Economics professor at Fordham University for over 20 years. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, September 6, 2000, 10 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Cemetery service private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to St. Vincent Ferrer Church.

title: True North Acquires Howard, Merrell
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that it had acquired Howard, Merrell & Partners in Raleigh, N.C. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Village Refuge That's a Throwback
description: HEALTH implications aside, the smell of tobacco smoke can sometimes be comforting. In the old days, aromas of strong tobacco, leather and perhaps a touch of aftershave conveyed warm and reassuring images of paternal strength. Today, even though I generally abhor cigarette smoke while I'm eating, a tobacco haze sometimes seems perfectly appropriate.

title: Pentagon Security Gate Misfires, Injuring German
description: Germany's defense minister was injured and briefly hospitalized today after a steel security barrier sprang up beneath his motorcade as it arrived for an honors ceremony at the Pentagon.

title: WEB CONSULTANT ISSUES EARNINGS WARNING
description: Echoing a familiar refrain in the Web consulting industry, Xpedior warned that it expected revenue in the third quarter to drop about 10 percent from the $62.9 million in the second quarter of this year, largely because of diminished demand from dot-com clients. Wall Street, in turn, reacted as it did when it first heard that concern last week from two other companies: Xpedior's stock dropped $2.56, or 23.7 percent, to close at $8.25, well off its 52-week high of $34.75. It did not seem to matter that the company estimated that third-quarter revenue would climb 65 percent from the $34.5 million posted in the 1999 quarter.

title: Skepticism Is Taking a Vacation
description: Astronomers tell us that the light from dead stars reaches us long after those bodies are useless and cold, a metaphor we do not want to deal with this coming autumn in New York when Patrick Ewing and Mark Messier may once again be the suns around which their teammates and fans orbit. It could be time to call Madison Square the Gray Garden.

title: Attacking Bush's Record On Children's Health Care
description: The Democratic National Committee announced yesterday that it would begin running a new commercial tomorrow that takes a critical look at Gov. George W. Bush's record of providing health care for children in Texas. The 30-second spot is to run in nine states that Democrats and Republicans have focused on most heavily : Arkansas, Delaware, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin.

title: Opener Shows Rams Are Still Not Solved
description: The popular thought in the off-season was that teams would take the offense of the St. Louis Rams and dismantle it, the way scientists stick bacteria under a microscope and investigate its genetic structure for weaknesses. Based on what the Rams did Monday night against the Denver Broncos -- displaying an offensive explosion rarely seen in the sport -- apparently no defensive coordinator has yet to devise the football equivalent of penicillin.

title: Hit by Cab, a Grandson of Harry Truman Dies
description: A grandson of President Harry S. Truman died on Monday from injuries he suffered when a cab hit him on Park Avenue in the East 70's over the weekend, his family said. The accident is still under investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWLEY, JOHN
description: HOWLEY-John. Age 93, a founding partner of the law firm of Hall, Casey, Dickler & Howley, died Sept. 1, 2000. Funeral services will be held at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Lithgow, NY, Thursday, September 7, at 10 A.M.

title: TV Rivalry Stifles the Debates
description: Every four years the men who would be president squabble over the presidential debates. What format? Which journalists should ask questions? Chairs versus lecterns?

title: Questions on Tire-Defect Data Arise as Hearings Draw Near
description: The Bridgestone/Firestone tire defect now blamed for 88 deaths, mainly in Ford Explorers, eluded detection for so long because it occurred infrequently, even though it proved deadlier than many problems that occur more often in vehicles, Ford Motor and Congressional investigators said today.

title: Arguing Against Net Trespass
description: Concerned that a recent federal court ruling dangerously extends the ancient law of trespass to cyberspace, 28 leading Internet legal scholars are arguing in an appellate court that the decision "threatens the very foundations of the Internet."

title: Lucille Fletcher, 88, Author Of 'Sorry, Wrong Number'
description: Lucille Fletcher, who transfixed a national audience with her radio drama ''Sorry, Wrong Number'' on CBS's ''Suspense'' in 1943, died on Thursday in Langhorne, Pa. She was 88 and lived in Oxford, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIFER, DR. HERMAN
description: ZEIFER-Dr. Herman. On September 5, 2000 of Chappaqua, New York. Beloved husband of Dorothy Livingston Zeifer. Loving father of Dr. Barbara Zeifer Luis and F. Ellen Zeifer Funk. Devoted grandfather of Alexander John Funk and Christopher Alan Funk. Private funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mount Kisco, New York. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: CYTEC TO SELL PAPER CHEMICAL DIVISION TO BAYER AND CIBA
description: Cytec Industries said it planned to shed paper chemical operations through two sales to Bayer A.G. and Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., totaling about $115 million. Bayer of Germany will pay about $90 million for parts of the business, while Ciba of Switzerland will pay about 38 million Swiss francs, or $23 million, for the rest, excluding accounts receivable, according to statements released by the companies. Cytec, based in West Paterson, N.J., said the agreements with Bayer and Ciba would yield cash of about $115 million and after-tax proceeds of about $75 million.

title: Hingis Disappoints Gambill
description: Martina Hingis called Jan-Michael Gambill on Monday night with the bad, but expected news, that she was pulling out of their mixed doubles partnership, which meant an abrupt end to Gambill's 2000 Open. He was not pleased.

title: Infonet Said to Be in Talks About a Dutch Acquisition
description: Infonet, a data communications company in California, has had exploratory talks about buying Equant, the Dutch telecommunications company born from an airline reservations system, people close to the talks said today.

title: Diplomatic Erosion
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivera Finds It Hard to Live Up to Himself
description: It used to be that an appearance by Mariano Rivera comprised three batters, one or two strikeouts and at least two broken bats. More and more, however, there have been hits and walks and some runs.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHLIN, EDGAR
description: RACHLIN-Edgar. Of Holmdel, NJ. On September 4, 2000. Graduate of the University of Chicago and The Kennedy School of Harvard University. Beloved son of the late Abraham H. and Bertha L. Rachlin. Loving brother of the late Susan R. Neubauer. Loving, wonderful uncle of Joshua and Alexander Neubauer. Dear friend to so many people and so many animals. We will all miss our Uncle Eddie. Memorial service will be held at a later date. Joshua and Alexander Neubauer

title: Philadelphia Teachers Will Vote Today on Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4  The city teachers union said today that it would ask members to authorize a strike in a vote on Tuesday.

title: The Rapper's Life on the Hip-Hop Road: Attitude, Revelry and Togetherness
description: ''I came to blow it down, and I'm gonna blow it down,'' DMX says of his turn onstage in the concert documentary ''Backstage,'' which follows the 1999 ''Hard Knock Life'' tour headed by Jay-Z and several other rappers, including the likable and funny Beanie Sigel, Redman, Memphis Bleek and others, along with a cameo by an effusive Busta Rhymes, who has the cheerfulness of new money.

title: President of Iran Praises His Country's Civilization
description: As a battle between supporters and opponents of democratic reform rages at home, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran came to the United Nations today to promote his campaign for a global ''dialogue among civilizations'' and to praise his country as one of the world's oldest.

title: State Audit Questions Value, and Evaluation, of Improvement Plans
description: As failing schools in New York City and State have increasingly turned to costly prepackaged school improvement programs as an answer to their shortcomings, local school officials have failed to evaluate how well those programs work, according to an audit released yesterday by the state comptroller.

title: I.B.M. TO USE AT&T DATA CENTERS
description: To help meet growing demand from business customers that outsource management of their Internet operations to I.B.M.'s Global Services unit, I.B.M. said it agreed to lease space in nine AT&T data centers . I.B.M. said that the deal, valued at $450 million, would allow it to begin selling Internet services and computer capacity at AT&T centers in the New York, Chicago, and Phoenix areas by the end of the year and in six other cities by the third quarter of 2001. I.B.M. now operates 12 Web-operation sites in the United States, 6 of them in partnership with other vendors. Earlier this year, it announced plans to create 56 more sites around the world, including 28 sites in the United States with Qwest Communications. Barnaby Feder

title: Sweeping Indictment Unsealed in Construction Investigation
description: The Manhattan district attorney charged 38 union officials, contractors and reputed mobsters today with bribery, bid-rigging or other racketeering schemes that siphoned millions of dollars from public and private building projects throughout the city over the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBEN, ROBERTA J.
description: CORBEN-Roberta J. On September 2; cherished daughter of Jeanne Corben; loving sister of Rima. Memorial service Sunday, September 10, 10AM, The Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 W. 106 St.; visitation September 6, 7; 3-5; 68PM. Contributions to the Roberta Joy Corben Memorial Fund will perpetuate her spirit through the dental service at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: 4 Warlords Wont Accept Somali Leader
description: SANA, Yemen, Sept. 2  Leaving this capital after a four-day visit, four Somali warlords today warned foreign nations not to recognize the election of a new president in their country, saying it could lead to civil war.

title: A Window on the World; Colleges Broaden Freshman Orientation, Pushing Students to Focus on Social Issues
description: Time was when freshman orientation consisted largely of campus tours and introductions to the football team and the student newspaper. But in recent years, college officials have been trying to squeeze extra mileage out of those early hours on campus when students are most open to new ideas and experiences, offering them serious social issues to digest, not just choices of fraternity rushes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE JONG, BASTIAAN
description: De JONG-Bastiaan. On Sept. 3, 2000 in Chatham, MA. Beloved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Alison, Jennifer, Martha and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Elizabeth van der Boon of The Netherlands. Memorial Service Thursday, September 14th at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, Chatham, MA. at 1:30 P.M. Contributions in his memory to Hospice of Cape Cod, 923 Route 6A, Yarmouthport, MA. 02675.

title: Workplace Homicides Are Rare, but Watch Out for Flying Objects
description: A study released last week on post office violence also sheds light on aggressive behavior in other industries. And there was plenty to report.

title: Privacy Plan Likely to Kick Off Debate
description: The goal of the plan announced by President Clinton's chief of staff, John Podesta, sounded admirable: to overhaul the nation's privacy laws, harmonizing a patchwork of inconsistent rules and extending to e-mail and mobile phone messages the same strict safeguards against government snooping that now apply to telephone calls.

title: Whose God Is It, Anyway?
description: IT was sorely tempting to go straight to the source and ask God what he (or she, if you prefer) thinks about being dragged so boldly into the presidential campaign. But then a friend pointed out how it is obvious from ample evidence that God never speaks to columnists.

title: CIENA MAY TAKE A CHARGE FOR DEBT IT MIGHT NOT COLLECT
description: The Ciena Corporation said yesterday that it might fail to collect up to $28.2 million from a European customer, forcing the company, a maker of fiber optic equipment, to take a fiscal fourth-quarter charge against earnings of as much as 13 cents a share. Ciena shares fell $13.80, or 6 percent, to $216.33 after plummeting 13 percent, to $200, earlier yesterday. Ciena said a London court had placed outside administrators in charge of the telecommunications service provider iaxis Ltd., an order that might make the iaxis debt to Ciena uncollectible. Ciena, based in Linthicum, Md., expects to take a one-time charge in the quarter after Ciena's 2-for-one stock split on Sept. 18.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is one square mile that's different. The people who don't want that can live in the rest of the country.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, HERBERT & MARJORIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Herbert & Marjorie K. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are saddened to learn of the passing of Herbert Bernstein and his wife, Majorie, in a car accident on August 19th. Mr Bernstein was the director of the Bronx Jewish Family Service office prior to its merger with JBFCS. We extend our deepest sympathy to their children and members of their family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, PhD, Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Assoc Exec VP

title: How Long Ago Did They Cook This Stuff?
description: If you were a youngster in the 1940's or 1950's, you may remember the expression ''mystery meat'' coming up in the school cafeteria line. (At least there was a carton of milk -- sometimes even chocolate.) Nostalgia buffs, or younger folk curious about The Time Before Pizza, might want to visit an exhibition on the federal school lunch program running through October at the Staten Island Ferry terminal in St. George.

title: Unabridged Version Of Gore Budget Plan
