description: Vice President Al Gore plans to release today a detailed 200-page economic blueprint for the next decade. The plan calls for a $300 billion rainy day fund and the elimination of the national debt. The plan also sets forth a broad variety of socioeconomic goals, like increasing family income, reducing poverty and narrowing the gap in wages between men and women.

title: New Haven Readies For Playoffs
description: New Haven geared up for the Eastern League playoffs by taking the last three games of a four-game series with the Binghamton Mets, the Ravens' opponent in the three-of-five-game Northern Division championship series that begins tonight in Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Dot-Com Recruiting Woes: Part 2
description: If executives of e-commerce companies thought they were having a hard time finding employees last year, this year's Summer of the Dot-Com Shakeout has brought even more misery to the group.

title: Airwave Auction Raises $320 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had raised about $320 million from the auction of airwaves to 14 companies for mobile wireless data services, dispatch, mobile telephony and other services.

title: Bush Derides Gore for Rejecting Debate Plan
description: ROMEO, Mich., Sept. 4  Declaring "it's time to elect people who say what they mean," Gov. George W. Bush swept through two hotly contested states today and derided Vice President Al Gore for rejecting his proposal for three handpicked debates.

title: Kiefer and Safin Win, but Who Is Watching?
description: In one hermetically sealed pocket of Manhattan, Nicolas Kiefer spent an unsettling Sunday night in a hotel where guards were eyeing everything but the floor tiles, where security alerts were shaking his sense of safety, and where the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, had taken up residence for the United Nations Millennium Summit.

title: Sweeping Indictment Unsealed in Construction Investigation
description: The Manhattan district attorney charged 38 union officials, contractors and reputed mobsters today with bribery, bid-rigging or other racketeering schemes that siphoned millions of dollars from public and private building projects throughout the city over the last two years.

title: Firestone Struggles in Center Of an Ever-Widening Storm
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 31  Rarely has a leading global company faced such an extraordinary confluence of problems: its flagship product blamed for scores of deaths; its biggest customer undermining its every defense; its stock price plunging along with consumer confidence; its top executive summoned before an angry Congress.

title: STRONG SALES GAINS FOR SEMICONDUCTOR CHIPS
description: Worldwide semiconductor sales rose 50 percent, to a record $17.3 billion in July from a year earlier on higher demand for cell phones, digital set-top boxes and electronics gear, an industry group said. Sales in the Asia-Pacific region rose 57 percent, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. European sales grew 47 percent, while the United States, Canada and Latin America rose a combined 46 percent. Japan sales climbed 52 percent. Intel and others have struggled this year to meet demand for the thumbnail-sized chips.

title: Texan Who Backed Bush Ads Helps Lazio in Raising Funds
description: When John McCain lost the New York Republican presidential primary last spring, he placed a large part of the blame on what he asserted was an illegal $2.5 million advertising campaign that attacked his environmental record and had been financed by two wealthy Texas brothers with close ties to Gov. George W. Bush, Mr. McCain's opponent.

title: Dry Muscadet, Oysters' Foil
description: It's hard to imagine a better meal on arriving in Paris than a plate of oysters and a carafe of muscadet, the house white of many cafes. The wine's dry, almost saline quality seems to come directly from the sea. In fact, the vineyards, at the western end of the Loire around Nantes, are close to where the river empties into the Atlantic.

title: New Ferry Offers Rockland Commuters an Option
description: Leaning back in his seat, coffee in hand, Gregory Schmidt was savoring the ride on the first day of a long-awaited ferry service for Manhattan-bound commuters. No more traffic jams. No parking hassles. And best of all, no Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Incumbent With Party Backing May Still Be Vulnerable
description: Pauline Rhodd-Cummings won her seat in the State Assembly two years ago by prevailing in a special election against three other candidates. Five months later, she beat back a primary challenge, and then defeated two other candidates in the general election.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Recycling Deep-Frying Oil

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Soft Landing With More Growth Than Usual
description: As the summer ends, the corporate earnings outlook is being undermined by signs that the economy is slowing. And some stock market analysts are warning that while profit growth will remain strong, the current projections for the last quarter of this year and the first of next year are too optimistic.

title: Sports Sites Revamp Strategy
description: The holiday weekend signals the start of a peak season for sports fans, who can finally supplement their baseball-only diets with smatterings of professional football, basketball and hockey.

title: The Crisis in Providing Care for the Elderly Ill
description: In Florida, where retirees have been flocking since the 1920's and where 25 percent of the state's population is expected to be over 65 by the year 2010, there are growing feelings of strain and exhaustion among the managers, the nurses and nurses' aides who care for the old and frail. The word most often heard in conversations with elder-care professionals these days is "crisis." With a population calculated to be aging at a rate 20 years ahead of the nation as a whole, the Sunshine State has become a harbinger for a nation growing old and facing problems with long-term care for the aged.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: GENERAL MOTORS WILL LAY OFF 200 WORKERS IN MICHIGAN
description: General Motors said yesterday that it would lay off about 200 workers and dismiss another 20 at a Michigan plant in late October as the company halves production of slow-selling Cadillac Eldorado coupes. G.M. plans to eliminate one of two shifts at the Lansing, Mich., plant, idling more than a third of the 550 production workers, who build about 40 of the luxury cars daily. Those being dismissed are salaried and contract workers, who will be offered other jobs at the company, a spokeswoman said. G.M. sold 7,576 Eldorados this year through August, down 20 percent from 9,488 in the 1999 period. G.M. shares fell 19 cents, to $72.94.

title: Net Companies Learn to Personalize
description: Ask a handful of Internet executives to define the term "personalization," and invariably the conversation turns to the analogy of a shopkeeper who knows not only his customers' names, but how much they can afford to spend and what size shirt they wear.

title: But Do They Have a Honey Pot for "Winnie-the-Pooh"?
description: Food for mind and body is on the menu in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Read, 158 Bedford Avenue (North Eighth Street), a slightly threadbare but friendly used-book store and cafe. There, you might find an old copy of "Slaughterhouse-Five" by Kurt Vonnegut, to read while nibbling the chicken- walnut salad sandwich ($6) named after him. (Don't worry: the Melville sandwich features tuna, not whale.)

title: Mothers at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence Fellows, 75, Foreign Correspondent for Times and Editor
description: Lawrence Fellows, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times and later an editor at local newspapers in Connecticut, died on Saturday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 75.

title: THE BOSS; If Only I Could Be Foreman
description: I think most people believe there is a formula for success, and it goes something like this: You do well in school, you work hard, you stay focused, you take risks. A good formula, but not the only one.

title: Teenagers Accused of Hate Crime Assault
description: In an attack that the authorities described as a hate crime, three black Staten Island teenagers were charged with assault and robbery yesterday in an attack on a group of white teenagers.

title: EARTHGRAINS SAYS MORE WORKERS JOIN SYMPATHY STRIKE
description: The Earthgrains Company, the maker of IronKids and Heiner's breads, said workers walked off the job at eight more plants, bringing the total to 15 plants honoring a strike that began 10 days ago at its bakery in Fort Payne, Ala. About 2,700, or 12 percent, of the St. Louis company's 22,000 employees in the United States are not working, Earthgrains said. About 680 members of the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers union walked out at the Alabama plant on Aug. 26, in part to protest mandatory overtime and a lack of days off. All of the 15 plants are operating, except one in Tennessee, Earthgrains said. Its shares fell 69 cents, to $16.81.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Feminist Takes the Vows

title: Gore's Campaign Releases Extensive Economic Blueprint
description: The Gore campaign today released a detailed economic blueprint for the next decade, including a new proposal for a $300 billion hedge against overly optimistic budget projections.

title: Democrats Dig In on Capitol Hill, Determined to Push Agenda
description: Democrats took the offensive today and said they would remain on Capitol Hill as long as necessary this year to push their agenda, from overhauling managed care to bumping up the minimum wage.

title: The Mt. Everest Of Yard Sales
description: THE pin on Mimi Mannix's hat said it all. "Junk 'til you drop" it read, which is why Ms. Mannix  "spelled like the detective," she said  was outside the Strudel Haus in Covington, Ky., on a Thursday afternoon painting a giant pig. Like a multitude of less colorful people, Ms. Mannix, an Indiana collectibles dealer, and her capacious yellow porker, a mascot long ago rescued from the roof of a Piggly Wiggly grocery store, had come to this musty little town across the Ohio River from Cincinnati to shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEANY, REV
description: MEANY-Rev. Stephen James, S.J. Survived by his loving sisters, Patricia Rand, Joanne Handy and Mary Ann Santos. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigal Hall, 515 East Fordham Road, Bronx, on Wednesday, 7-9 PM, and Thursday, 3-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will take place in the Murray-Weigal Hall Chapel, Thursday, 7:30 PM. For information, contact: Farenga Bros, Inc., Directors.

title: Man to Admit To Murdering 3 L.I. Patients
description: A former physician who the authorities say poisoned patients from Ohio to Zimbabwe but continued to find medical jobs will plead guilty in federal court Wednesday to charges that he killed three patients at a Long Island hospital in 1993, prosecutors said today.

title: On Wheels of Fitness and Faith
description: D"You're oing what?" Bicycling 275 miles in three days. In mid-September, from Boston to New York, for the sixth annual AIDS ride. And I am doing it with 3,000 dedicated souls from around the country, and yes, the vast majority of them are younger and fitter than I am.

title: Emphasizing Basic Values
description: The campaign of Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate in New Jersey, began running two new commercials on New York and Philadelphia television stations on Monday. Both ads -- ''Diner'' and ''Our Values'' -- present his major proposals while saying he is in touch with the traditional values and everyday concerns of middle-class families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMILLY, CHRISTOPHER JAMES K.
description: ROMILLY-Christopher James K. Beloved husband of Linda Jean Abbey, and inspirational friend to those who knew and loved him, Christopher James Kenworthy Romilly passed away September 5, 2000 after a long and brave battle with cancer. Chris will be remembered for his giant heart, his broad intellect, his great kindness, wide-ranging curiosity, and enormous passion for living. We thank the staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering for their compassionate assistance in Chris's battle. Chris is also survived by his aunt and uncle, Alice and Peter Peterson, and his cousins: Charles Hunt, John Hunt, Sara Hunt, Peter Romilly, Martin Romilly, Mary Bain, John Peterson, Larry Peterson, and Sara Romilly. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Charitable donations in Chris's memory can be made to the S. Kent Legare Library at Suffield Academy, Alumni Office, Suffield, Connecticut.

title: The Very Model Of Conciliation
description: In the early 1990's, the United States Postal Service had an employee crisis on its hands. Not the workplace shootings that made headlines and added the phrase ''going postal'' to the American vocabulary of violence. Those incidents, while often deadly, were isolated.

title: How, but Not Why, the Brain Distinguishes Race
description: After a decade of mapping brains in tasks like recalling numbers, perceiving facial expressions and using verbs, neuroscientists have recently homed in on a much more controversial subject: the act of categorizing other human beings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Health Insurance Premiums Are Increasing 10% to 30%

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE INTEREST GROUPS

title: Governments Business Goes Online
description: Last December, when the government was in the throes of Year 2000 anxiety, e-commerce initiatives barely crossed the minds of many federal officials. Not that e-commerce executives particularly cared: with their companies' stock prices climbing and much larger markets in their sights, they could afford to look past the government as a place to do business.

title: Sports of The Times; Renovate Lambeau? Yes or No
description: MORE and more, the password in sports is ''stadium.'' If a franchise doesn't have a new or renovated stadium or arena, it wants one. The Yankees and the Mets do. The Jets and the Islanders do. The Devils and the Nets want to share one. There has even been talk of a new Madison Square Garden for the Knicks and the Rangers. New ballparks opened this year in Detroit, San Francisco and Houston; another will open next year in Milwaukee.

title: The Last Meow: A Fence Sitter Sums Up
description: o I see with my own very eyes a man who's not heard of a jellicle cat?"

title: The Publicity For 'Jazz'
description: About a year ago Ken Burns, the documentary filmmaker, sat down with his public relations advisers as well as executives from General Motors, his corporate sponsor, and PBS to figure out how best to promote his documentary ''Jazz,'' which is to begin running on PBS in January.

title: U.N. Millennium Summit Opens
description: UNITED NATIONS -- The largest gathering of world leaders in history convened Wednesday, turning New York into a global kaleidoscope of Falun Gong protests, Mideast peace talk, traffic-snarling motorcades and bigwig shoulder rubbing.

title: 2 U.S. Teams Win Decisively, And Bridge Semifinals Start
description: Both United States teams won convincing victories in their quarterfinal matches at the World Bridge Championships here this afternoon, and the semifinal play began this evening.

title: U.S. Rights Report Faults China For Harassing Religious Groups
description: As more and more Chinese seek to practice faiths including Tibetan Buddhism, Christianity and Islam, government officials there have increasingly responded with harassment, extortion, detention and even torture, the State Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, TAYLOR R.
description: BRIGGS-Taylor R., Esq. The New York Law School community is deeply saddened by the death of Taylor R. Briggs, Esq., former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and a true friend of New York Law School. Taylor Briggs played a vital role in supporting the School's mission in legal education and ensuring its future. He will be greatly missed for his friendship and kindness and for his invaluable contribution to the School as a Trustee and as a member of the Advisor Board of the Center for New York City Law.

title: Marketers Turn To E-Mail Experts
description: Among Internet companies struggling to retain customers they have worked so hard to get, e-mail marketing is seen as the next best thing to being on the home page each time a customer goes online.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ANTONIO, GLADYS
description: D'ANTONIO-Gladys. Of Amity Harbor, LI on September 4, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Frank J. D'Antonio, (retired Director of Purchasing for Pfizer, Inc.). Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Richard G. and Maria; William J. and Virginia and David F. and Caroline D'Antonio. Fond sister and sister-in-law of Clifford and Eudolia Smith and sister of the late Ruth Duernberger. Also survived by six grandchildren and seven great - grandchildren. Reposing, 7:00-9:30 PM Wednesday and 2:004:30 and 7:00-9:30 PM Thursday at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Route 110), Amityville. Funeral Mass Friday 10:30 AM at Saint Martin of Tours RC Church, Amityville. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERN, PHILIP
description: BERN-Philip. Of Boynton Beach, FL. Died September 5, 2000. Born 1920 in Newark, NJ. Worked 40 years for Swank. WW II pilot. Shot down January, 1944. Liberated from prison camp in September, 1945. Beloved husband of Beatrice for 50 years. Loving father of Douglas and Deborah Schachter. Grandfather of Kenneth Schachter and Jonah Bern. Services in Lake Worth, FL. Interment is in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Discovering Early Clues to Where an Albatross Wanders on Its Year Off
description: The wandering albatross did not earn its name by just sitting around. The seabirds, the largest in the world, spend more than 90 percent of their life over the oceans of the Southern Hemisphere, and through banding and satellite tracking have been shown to cover tens of thousands of miles in a breeding season foraging for food.

title: Clear Choice for Voters
description: Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to redesign Medicare and offer drug benefits to the elderly puts him squarely in line with his party's drive to reshape the program by reducing the role of government, increasing the role of insurance companies and giving elderly people more choices.

title: Poll Watch: Numbers Spell Out Who the Voters Really Are
description: In modern politics it has become de rigueur to explain a candidate's popularity or lack thereof by characterizing pockets of American voters.

title: Brazil's Internationally Ambitious Oil Company Hires Pele
description: When Edson Arantes do Nascimento was 18, he used to run onto the soccer field with a 130-pound sack of coffee beans on his back. Even then, in the days before Colombia's Juan Valdez stole the limelight from Brazilian coffee, the young man known as Pele was already using his fame to promote his country's products abroad.

title: Davenport Outmuscles Serena Williams
description: It was deep in the third game of the second set when desperation started to creep into the usually airtight confidence of Serena Williams. In a panic, she was trying sliced forehands, spinners and ill-conceived drop shots on her way to having her serve broken once again.

title: Through Northwest Passage in a Month, Ice-Free
description: NUUK, Greenland, Sept. 4  During World War II, when Henry Larsen took a Royal Canadian Mounted Police ship, the St. Roch, into the fabled Northwest Passage, his boat was frozen in Arctic ice through two winters, only emerging at the eastern end after 27 months.

title: America Offers Opportunities for Foreign Females
description: The success of the women's game has turned the world of soccer on its head and made the United States a most desired destination.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FALK, EUGENE
description: FALK-Eugene. Memorial services (1913-August 30, 2000). Professor of French and Comparative Literature, Friday September 8, 2000 at 3 P.M. at University United Methodist Church, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Your wisdom and dedication will live forever. Students and Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, PHILIP
description: SCHULTZ-Philip. We deeply mourn the passing of Philip Schultz, father of Daniel Schultz, member of the Board of Directors and Assistant Treasurer of American Friends of The Hebrew University. On behalf of AFHU, we extend our deepest condolences to Daniel and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Exec V.P.

title: Not Bad, Not Bad: A Rookie's Baptism
description: Al Groh was watching for the signs Sunday: a flicker of fear, a moment of indecision.

title: Women Are From Venus, Horses Are From Heaven
description: DARK HORSES AND BLACK BEAUTIES

title: UNIVERSAL SEEKS BIG PENALTY AGAINST MP3.COM
description: The Universal Music Group urged a federal judge to order the online music provider MP3.com to pay up to $450 million for copyright violations. A lawyer for Universal told the judge, Jed S. Rakoff in Manhattan, that the Internet music site willfully violated copyrights through its My.MP3.com service. ''This sophisticated corporate defendant realized exactly what it was doing,'' said the lawyer, Hadrian Katz, in his summation. He urged the judge to deter future violators by imposing a large penalty. MP3.com's lawyer, Michael Rhodes, countered that a large judgment would bankrupt the San Diego-based company.

title: Ex-Importer Accused of Diverting Money
description: The former president and co-owner of Domecq Importers, at one time the United States unit of the world's second-largest liquor company, was accused yesterday in a federal indictment of conspiring to divert more than $14 million from the company into personal offshore bank accounts.

title: U.N. Workers Killed in Timor; Reverberations Felt at Summit
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 6 -- An armed mob of 1,000 people stormed into a United Nations refugee operation in West Timor today, demolishing the office and beating to death three unarmed United Nations workers, including an American, and touching off outrage at the summit meeting of world leaders here.

title: Working Harder, Longer
description: There's a lot of good news to report this Labor Day. Unemployment is very low and wages are rising. The benefits of the booming economy are being widely distributed. Workers at the bottom are finally enjoying significant increases in their inflation- adjusted wages. Better yet, the U.S. is experiencing a surge in the growth of labor productivity which, as noted in a book-length report from the Economic Policy Institute, is "probably the best indicator of an economy's capacity to provide for the material needs of its population."

title: A Chef Delivers His Own Private Austria
description: IT took a few twists and turns before Kurt Gutenbrunner found his way back to Austria. He intended to take the direct route, moving from Bouley, where he served as sous chef for five years, to the post of executive chef at Danube, David Bouley's ambitious, bejeweled shrine to the cooking of Austria-Hungary. When the project stalled, however, Mr. Gutenbrunner became restless and left. He took over the kitchen at Monkey Bar, putting a Viennese spin on the menu that never felt quite right, given the restaurant's roots in the New York of the 1930's and 40's. Now he has found a new setting in Wallse, a corner restaurant in the far West Village that he has turned into a modest showcase for the Austrian cooking he grew up with.

title: U.S. to Withhold Money for Haiti's Presidential Election
description: The United States will not send observers or financial aid to Haiti for that country's presidential elections in November, a senior American diplomat said today, citing the Haitian government's unwillingness to recalculate the results of recent legislative elections that gave an overwhelming and disputed majority to the party of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Reckonings; There He Goes Again
description: The commentariat seems shocked by George W. Bush's brazenness in the debate debate. Not only has he casually tossed aside the longstanding principle that the question of when and how the candidates will debate should not be a political issue; not only is he shamelessly insisting that 60 minutes of shmoozing with Larry King is the moral equivalent of 90 minutes of serious debate carried on all major networks; but then he turns around and accuses Al Gore of refusing to debate. What, ask my colleagues, makes him think he can get away with this?

title: Web Entrepreneurs Stepping Aside
description: Like many senior-level Internet executives, Christine Harmel, chief executive of Interactive Resource, a firm in Manhattan that matches Web site developers with clients, was present at the birth of e-commerce. Working on the Net since 1995, Harmel, 32, has experienced years of 80-hour workweeks and has watched the industry transform itself from a stomping ground for young workaholics who wanted to change the world, into a stomping ground for young workaholics who want to change their tax brackets.

title: BRAZIL'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UP
description: Brazil's industrial output grew for a 12th consecutive month in July with durable goods like automobiles and air-conditioners leading the charge. Production rose 6.8 percent compared with last year, with July being the third consecutive month that the recovering Brazilian economy has had output above 6 percent. Production of nondurable goods, including food and tobacco, continues to lag growth elsewhere in the economy as high unemployment and low wages affect consumer purchasing power. Consumer prices rose 1.55 percent in Sao Paulo in August, according to the Economic Research Institute. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: National Grid Announces Niagara Mohawk Purchase
description: So far, the names have stayed the same among the small utilities that serve communities from the Mississippi to the Atlantic, and from Maine to Florida. But that masks the efforts of the large, ambitious electricity concerns that are rapidly swallowing local companies to fashion regional giants. Yesterday's acquisition of Niagara Mohawk, in upstate New York, by the National Grid Group, of Britain, emphasizes that trend.

title: Article 2000090691746581122 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, BERNARD
description: GOLD-Bernard. On Monday, September 4 at his home in New York. Bernard, an honest and gentle man, the strength of his family and friends. So loved by his wife Frederica, daughters Marianne Kaplan and Caroline, sonin-law David, grandchildren Phillip and Joseph, his sister Thelma Hurwitz and brother and Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Gold, nieces and nephews. Forever in our hearts and the hearts of many.

title: Article 2000090691370000805 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Hospital Chief To Lead Aetna Managed Care
description: John W. Rowe, who oversaw one of the largest hospital mergers in New York City and in the process became one of the industry's most prominent executives, was named president and chief executive of Aetna U.S. Healthcare late yesterday.

title: INVESTMENT COMPANY WILL BUY WISE, MAKER OF SNACKS
description: Palladium Equity Partners, a private investment company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wise Holdings Inc., a maker of snacks like Wise potato chips and Cheez Doodles. Wise is owned by the leveraged-buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, which acquired Wise as part of its buyout of Borden Inc. in 1995. Wise, based in Kennesaw, Ga., had sales of about $336 million last year and employs more than 1,950 people. Palladium, based in New York, said it would pay for the acquisition through its $300 million Palladium Equity Partners II fund. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Speech Outlining His Proposal to Revise Medicare
description: Following are excerpts from remarks prepared for delivery today by Gov. George W. Bush in Allentown, Pa., announcing his plans for revising Medicare:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about each party's legislative goals for Congress this fall misspelled the surname of an official at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research institution, who said he thought the Democrats were working more closely with their presidential candidate than were the Republicans with theirs. The official is Marshall Wittmann, not Wittman.

title: Stepping Aside at an Operatic Oasis; Founding Director of the Santa Fe Opera Looks Back on 43 Years of Innovation
description: The costumes, props and scenery used in the Santa Fe Opera's five summer productions are being packed for storage, and the singers and choristers who held the spotlight are en route to their next engagements. But as the company's backstage staff wraps up the loose ends, a more figurative curtain is descending, slowly and gracefully, on a long stretch of the company's history. On Sept. 30, just as the new concert season gets under way in the world's arts centers, John Crosby will step down as the general director of this adventurous company, which he founded in 1957 and has run since.

title: But Do They Have a Honey Pot for ''Winnie-the-Pooh''?
description: Food for mind and body is on the menu in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Read, 158 Bedford Avenue (North Eighth Street), a slightly threadbare but friendly used-book store and cafe. There, you might find an old copy of ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' by Kurt Vonnegut, to read while nibbling the chicken-walnut salad sandwich ($6) named after him. (Don't worry: the Melville sandwich features tuna, not whale.)

title: Distance Learning Goes Niche
description: With the market for adult education growing at an explosive rate, colleges and universities are finding it necessary to develop finely-tuned programs that cater to identified niches.

title: Questions to Prince Philippe and Princess Mathilde of Belgium
description: Written Questions From The New York Times:

title: Stonyfield Farm tries to change the world and sell some yogurt.
description: PROTECTING the rain forest. Ending child labor. Preserving a healthy planet. They all sound like political promises made by candidates. But they are also subjects touched upon in the first national campaign for Stonyfield Farm Inc. Yes, that's right, the company that sells yogurt.

title: Food Surfing
description: The Food Network is unveiling six new shows this season. Two were not available for preview: a dessert show called ''Sweet Dreams,'' scheduled for next month, and one yet unnamed starring Wolfgang Puck, to have its premiere in January. I watched episodes of the other four. All times are Eastern.

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Washington lobbying company, Podesta.com, in which two partners have brothers in high positions in the Clinton White House, referred incorrectly to Heather Barbour's connection with the company. She is no longer there, having left at the end of July for a job in California. And she is not a daughter (or other relative) of Haley Barbour, former chairman of the Republican Party.

title: U.S. Sees No Final Climate Deal at The Hague
description: LONDON Sept 5 - The United States on Tuesday reiterated its committment to endorsing a global climate change treaty but said it did not expect a watertight agreement to be forged at a key conference in the Hague in November.

title: Few Would Pay More for Irradiated Meat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.5 -- Half of American consumers surveyed were willing to buy meat and poultry treated with irradiation to kill foodborne diseases, but only one- fourth were willing to pay extra for the products, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: U.N. Gathering and Traffic Manage to Coexist
description: As foreign dignitaries around for the United Nations summit meeting began to descend on the streets of New York City yesterday, the police issued their post-rush hour traffic diagnosis with a sigh of relief: the run-up to the gathering was, more or less, a success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNER, MARVIN
description: PENNER-Marvin. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of the father of our partner, Judith P. Broach. He was a dedicated accountant & an invaluable advisor to the firm, and a dear friend of us all. We will miss his wisdom, wit, generosity and kindness. Our heartfelt sympathies to Judy, her mother, Ethel Penner, and the entire family. The partners, associates and staff of Broach & Stulberg, LLP

title: Article 2000090691933915347 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: STEEL MAKER REPORTS LOSS
description: Corus Group P.L.C., Europe's second-largest steel maker, reported an unexpected loss in the third quarter, hurt by a rise in the pound and a lower demand for carbon steel. The company lost $:93 million ($135 million), or 3 pence a share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with a loss of $:96 million in the period a year earlier at British Steel P.L.C., the predecessor to Corus. While profits at other steel makers more than doubled in the quarter, Corus suffered from the strength of the pound, which is 18 percent higher than when the euro was introduced in 1999. ''The trading environment for our U.K.-based carbon steel unit has been and continues to be extremely difficult,'' said John Bryant, the joint chief executive of Corus. Corus said it would continue to look for cost savings after announcing in the last three months its plans to cut about 4,000 jobs in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNGEN, RUTH
description: LUNGEN-Ruth. The Summer Club of Fire Island mourns the loss of our cherished leader, neighbor, and dear friend Ruth. Our community will be forever grateful for her extraordinary vision and eternal love of Summer Club. We will miss her dearly. She was & will always be the spirit of our community. Our deepest condolences to her husband and our friend Gary, to her devoted daughter Debbie and to her entire family.

title: INSIDE
description: Hingis vs. Venus Williams

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOSS, DAVID
description: MOSS-David. September 6, 1999. Loving you always. In our hearts forever. June and Geoffre

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, STEVEN J.
description: HIRSCH-Steven J., 105. Died in San Francisco, September 2nd. Mr. Hirsch was born in New York City, January 25, 1895 and was a resident of New York for 101 years before moving to San Francisco to be with his family. He is survived by two daughters and their husbands, Barbara and John Rosston and Dorothy and James Loebl, as well as five grandchildren, Steven and Gregory Rosston, Jeffrey Loebl, Susan Grasso, and Ellen Loebl, and seven great-grandchildren. He was a member of Princeton University's Class of 1917 and became the oldest living alumnus of the University. He served in both World War I and World War II and left the service as a Lieutenant Colonel. For his service in France in World War I, the French government recently awarded him the Legion of Honor. During his long life, he worked in investment management and was an ardent opera enthusiast and golfer. He was devoted to his family, friends and in recent years his caregivers. Mr. Hirsch's wife Dorothy Bloch, the love of his life, died in 1964. Services are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Steven J. Hirsch '17 Scholarship fund at Princeton University, Office of the Recording Secretary, Princeton, New Jersey 08540, or a charity of choice.

title: Where Time Lay Frozen
description: To some ears, the Northwest Passage still sounds like an old-fashioned geographic fiction, an article of faith for which men died rather than a real path through real waters. Victorian England never showed its true colors more truly than in its fervent response to the disappearance of Sir John Franklin's last Arctic expedition, which sailed from England on May 18, 1845, in search of the Northwest Passage and whose fate remained essentially unknown for a dozen years afterward. Rescue missions were staged, poems written, funds raised, theories proposed and contested. The very duration of uncertainty about Franklin became an element of the region in which he and his crew perished.

title: 2 Officers Suspended for Drinking at Parade
description: The West Indian American Carnival Parade, held in Crown Heights each year on Labor Day, has long attracted its share of public drinkers. So when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Police Department announced last month that they were banning alcohol sales and drinking at city parades, they expected to catch a few offenders.

title: Article 2000090694264203773 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Article 2000090691523285891 -- No Title
description: BY BOB TEDESCHI

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AVX CORP., Myrtle Beach, S.C., named Kurt Cummings, corporate controller, to the post of chief financial officer, succeeding Donald Christiansen, who is retiring. Also, Carl Eggerding was named chief technology officer.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas rose as a heat wave in Texas increased demand for the fuel to generate electricity for air-conditioning. In New York, natural gas rose 11.5 cents, or 2.4 percent, to $4.95 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Virus Charges Dropped
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 21  Philippine authorities dismissed all charges today against Onel A. de Guzman, the 24-year-old college dropout whom investigators had accused of responsibility for a destructive computer e-mail program that wreaked billions of dollars in damage on companies worldwide in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIVITERA, MSGR. SANTI J.
description: PRIVITERA-Msgr. Santi J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Bernadette's Church, 8201 13th Ave., Brooklyn, on September 4. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn, Wednesday, September 6, from 2 to 5 p.m. Mass of Transferral at St. Bernadette's Church, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Thursday, September 7, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Little Cause for Hope On a Mideast Accord
description: President Clinton will meet separately today in New York with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, but there is little sign that their standoff will end soon.

title: 650 Professors Strike
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Sept. 5 (AP)  More than 650 full- time faculty members at Eastern Michigan University went on strike today after contract talks broke off.

title: Meddling or Empowerment?
description: National education groups and library advocates are claiming a federal proposal that would require the installation of filtering software on school and library computers connected to the Internet would only complicate an issue that is already being addressed at the local level.

title: Dinner as Scrum: Could This Be London?
description: They do it harmlessly in Wodehouse, and horribly in Waugh. But behaving badly while eating well is more than a literary tradition in England, where dining clubs like Oxford's rich and arrogant Assassins still play at being lordly decadents by getting expensively sick over shattered crockery.

title: Strawberries Confound the Seasons
description: AT the Greenmarket, where a long attention span is difficult to keep, it is easy to overlook them as your eyes search for peaches, tomatoes and corn. What you may miss are Tristar strawberries, tiny berries with an unusually late harvest and a flavor that makes regular strawberries seem dull. They taste like a cross of strawberries, fraises de bois and raspberries -- a mixture that's juicy and concentrated, almost jammy in the thimble-size ones.

title: Princeton Coach Reported Leaving
description: Bill Carmody, who has posted a 92-25 record in his four years as head coach at Princeton, will be introduced today as Northwestern's new basketball coach, The Associated Press reported, citing a person close to Carmody. He would replace Kevin O'Neill, who resigned five days ago to take a job as an assistant with the Knicks.

title: BY THE BOOK; From a Certain Island Vineyard
description: WHEN a T-shirt concession replaces the cloakroom in your favorite restaurant, it may be time to find a new hangout. Institution status, for even the best-run brasserie, can be lethal to the spirit of the place.

title: Metro Business; Lawsuit Ruled Groundless
description: A New York State appeals court has ruled that the Foster Wheeler Corporation, a construction and engineering company, has no grounds for suing Broome County in upstate New York over the collapse of a deal in which the company was to build and operate a garbage-to-energy plant in the county.

title: Nigerias Women
description: Nigeria's Women

title: Tread Failures Lead to Recall Of 6.5 Million Firestone Tires
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 9 -- The company that makes Firestone tires said today that millions of tires it had produced since 1991 seemed unusually prone to flinging off their treads, sometimes with catastrophic results. Facing 50 lawsuits, 46 deaths, 80 injuries and a federal investigation, the company said it would provide free replacements for the 6.5 million tires still on the road.

title: Clyde Sukeforth, 98, Is Dead; Steered Robinson to Majors
description: Clyde Sukeforth, the Brooklyn Dodger scout and manager who accompanied Jackie Robinson through two of the Hall of Fame player's milestones as the first African-American in modern baseball, died on Sunday at his home in Waldoboro, Me. He was 98.

title: Nigerian Leader Seeks Peacemaking Role
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4  Fifteen months after restoring democracy to Africa's most populous nation for the second time in 20 years, President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria said today that he was ready to step into a larger role in mediating an end to his continent's debilitating wars, beginning with Congo.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: WESTCHESTER

title: Lawyers Fight Denial of Bail for Scientist in Lab Secrets Case
description: Lawyers for the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee filed a brief today with the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver urging that it reject as disingenuous government arguments against granting bail to Dr. Lee, because prosecutors had shaped many of the terms of his proposed home detention.

title: Nassau Executive Proposes a Tax Increase and Layoffs to Keep County Afloat
description: In an attempt to bring Nassau County back from the brink of bankruptcy, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta released an outline today showing how he would cut about $75 million from the 2001 budget by laying off more than 350 county employees and raising property taxes by an average of $33 per household.

title: Long Hours, More Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Bordeaux That Requires No Bodyguard
description: IF you are one of those pessimists who react with fear and trembling to even the slightest sign that the economy is cooling, take some comfort from Bordeaux wine. Prices are just as high as ever.

title: A Quiet Forum at Town Hall Opposes the East River Forum
description: If the 150 or so national leaders assembled at the United Nations yesterday were curious about where globalization was really taking the world, they could have ambled over to Town Hall, the concert auditorium on West 43rd Street.

title: For Comella, A Work Ethic Is Paying Off
description: Greg Comella joined the Giants two years ago as a free agent. He toiled on special teams, banging around the frenzied free-for-alls until someone noticed. Now, after two seasons of anonymity, Comella is the starting fullback.

title: MP3.com Loses Copyright Case
description: Ruling that the online music startup MP3.com had willfully infringed the copyrights of Universal Music Group, a federal judge on Wednesday ordered the company to pay potentially crippling damages in one of the first cases to test the legal boundaries of digital music distribution.

title: Teenager Appears at Hacker Trial
description: The person who kicked off a huge legal battle involving Hollywood and the Internet is a skinny, 16-year-old Norwegian computer programmer who, with his serious face, wire-rimmed glasses and almost-there mustache, could maybe pass for 17.

title: To Keep Sandwiches, Like, So Cool
description: If a sandwich thrown into a backpack simply won't do, Igloo makes a lightweight red and blue plastic box with insulated compartments big enough to hold an overstuffed sandwich and a sizable drink. There's also a spot for stowing keys -- or some cookies. It's $10.98 at Zabar's, 80th Street and Broadway.

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: Weighed Down by School Supply Costs
description: As they strode out of a Staples office supply store here, Bart Cirino lugged a plastic bag full of folders and binders, while his mother, Anna, clutched a yellow list that she had been carrying for more than two months.

title: Challenge to Wine Sale Law Can Proceed in U.S. Court
description: A federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to dismiss a legal challenge to New York State's laws barring the direct shipment of wine from out-of-state wineries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLMAN, RUTH PSATY
description: GELLMAN-Ruth Psaty, 65. Of Irvington, NY, died September 4, 2000. Wife of the late Arthur Gellman. Survivors include two daughters Michelle Gellman and Jeanne Gellman-Goyenechea and a cousin Mary Gilbert. Funeral service Thursday, 11:30AM. EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Emma Lazarus Chapter Hadassah, 515 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522.

title: Article 2000090690405778918 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Yankees' Williams Reinjured
description: For the next week, and perhaps a few days more, Bernie Williams's life at the ballpark will consist of heating pads and other medical treatment. Williams again aggravated a strain on the right side of his rib cage while swinging Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 29 and an editorial on Sunday about a falloff in support for the Boy Scouts because of their exclusion of gays misstated two cities' reactions to the ban. Chicago no longer lets the Boy Scouts use parks, city buildings and schools without charge. The public schools of San Francisco no longer sponsor Scout recruitment drives or other programs during school hours. The Scouts are not barred from using parks, schools and other sites.

title: The Glories of Underworld Are Under Siege
description: BENSON Ariz.  Take a sopping wet underground cavern in a remote corner of Arizona. Add a man-made entrance with heavy steel doors to keep out the hot desert air, a misting system to keep the cavern damp and lights to show off a wonderland of spires, flowstone, soda straws and other phantasmagorical cave formations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOARE, ROSE E.
description: HOARE-Rose E. On September 3, 2000. Formerly of Aighe, Ardara Donegal, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late John T. Loving mother of John and Fr. Richard Hoare and Kathleen Morrongello. Dear mother-in-law of Lois and James. Cherished grandmother of John, Keriann, Daniela & Kelly. Devoted great grandmother of Layla. Friends may call Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Inc., 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, N.Y. (at R.R. Plaza). Mass of Christian burial Friday 10:30 AM at Our Lady of Victory RC Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEELEY, GEORGE
description: FEELEY-George. Beloved husband of Elizabeth C. of Dennis, MA; dear father of Richard T., Mark A., and Betsey A.; passed away at age 84 in Hyannis, MA, on Friday, September 1, 2000. Dad, we will miss your warm heart and big personality. Memorial to be scheduled in Bourne, MA, in late October. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dennis Rescue Squad, 883 Main Street, West Dennis, MA. 02670

title: Whipped Into Spotlight
description: THERE she was, Amanda Peet, but in the crowd on Tuesday night at the premiere of her new movie, "Whipped," there was some confusion about which one she was. A stunning woman in a tight black, backless dress posed for the cameras. "Is that her?" one photographer asked.

title: Stymied by Senate, Would-Be Envoy Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  A career diplomat, Peter Burleigh, retired today, tired of waiting for confirmation of his ambassadorial nomination to the Philippines. The nomination has been tied up in the Senate for nine months by a Republican legislator retaliating over the State Department's treatment of a whistle-blower at the United Nations.

title: What War-Ready Means, In Pentagons Accounting
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 3  Gov. George W. Bush kicked off a heated political debate when he declared that 2 of the Army's 10 active divisions were "not ready for duty, sir." Had he wanted to highlight the complexities of measuring military readiness, however, he could have looked closer to home.

title: New York Still Faces Wine Suit
description: A federal judge refused yesterday to dismiss a lawsuit that accuses New York State of illegally barring direct-to-customer shipment of wine from out-of-state producers.

title: Fighting for a Carrier-Free Zone
description: This is a town that cultivates eccentricity like a rare organic tomato. Ever since it was discovered by artists, writers and assorted free spirits nearly 100 years ago, people have been drawn to this precious-as-a-poodle community beside the Pacific Ocean for the touches of modernity it does not have: street lights, illuminated signs, parking meters, neighborhood sidewalks, street addresses and door-to-door mail delivery.

title: No Optimism About Mideast Talks
description: President Clinton is planning to hold separate meetings with the Israeli and Palestinian leaders in New York on Wednesday, but none of those three parties to the long-suffering peace negotiations are optimistic that things will advance much.

title: The World's Meeting Place
description: The United Nations Millennium Summit this week brings to New York City the largest gathering ever of world leaders to address the most serious of global afflictions. It is an occasion calling for hope and perseverance, but most New Yorkers cannot get past the ominous numbers: 91 scheduled protests, at least 175 motorcades, 245 dignitaries requiring Secret Service and police protection, and 3 days of President Clinton stopping traffic in Manhattan. It is no wonder many residents welcome the meeting with the same grousing accorded the West Nile virus, the Atlanta Braves or a ride on the No. 4 subway line.

title: Tory Party Leader Issues A Euroskeptical Manifesto
description: The Conservative leader, William Hague, set out 100 policy proposals today that his party hopes will help it defeat Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Labor Party in the coming national election.

title: With Clinton Due, Holbrooke Defends U.N.
description: With President Clinton preparing to visit New York this week for a meeting of world leaders at the United Nations, the American ambassador, Richard C. Holbrooke, said on Saturday that the United States must focus more on its ties with the organization, which he called "indispensable" to American foreign policy.

title: BUSH SPELLS OUT MAJOR  OVERHAUL IN MEDICARE PLAN
description: Gov. George W. Bush today proposed a fundamental overhaul of the 35-year-old federal Medicare program that would encourage recipients to choose subsidized private health insurance plans that include prescription drug coverage.

title: Iverson Haunts Brown, Even Across the Pacific
description: HONOLULU -- Larry Brown was reminiscing recently about a much simpler time in international competition, when an Olympic basketball player for the United States had no one to carry his bags during training camp in Hawaii, when you could not order coconut shrimp as an appetizer.

title: Child Care and Other Traps
description: In the ultimate triumph of family- friendly policies, the white-shoe law firm Chadbourne & Parke has converted a spare office into a nursery for the infant of one of its female partners. Now this mother can visit her baby and still stay on top of what's in her in box. According to a firm press release, when it's time for this mother to feed her baby, she is alerted by an e-mail or a quiet knock on the door from her nanny. The firm has another female partner who works from home a couple of days a week and still another who manages its Moscow office while she is on maternity leave in Washington, D.C. It is receptive to opening more nurseries in its offices as the need arises (imagine the sitcom possibilities).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, TESS
description: CAPLAN-Tess. One year gone from us. Missed and loved each day. The Gilbert Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALLEY, JULIE AND SAMUEL
description: PALLEY-Julie and Samuel. The trustees and staff of the Museum of American Folk Art record with deep sorrow the sudden loss of their dear friends and valued colleagues, Julie and Samuel (''Sandy'') Palley, devoted supporters of the Museum and thoughtful advocates of its growth and development as a major cultural institution. A member of the Board since 1995, Julie captured our hearts from the first day of her service as a trustee with her generosity of spirit, resourcefulness and respect for excellence. In her commitment to the Museum, Julie was joined by Sandy, her husband and true partner in life. His engaging wit, ready smile and quiet wisdom never failed to encourage us. Their tragic deaths deprive the Museum of the strength and inspiration of two of its brightest lights. They will always be remembered with affection and respect by a grateful Museum family. To their daughters, Margot, Kyra and Alix, we extend our most profound and heartfelt condolences. Ralph O. Esmerian, Chairman L. John Wilkerson, President Board of Trustees Gerard C. Wertkin, Director

title: It Gets Worse for Raymond
description: As Lisa Raymond walked briskly off the court after a disjointed doubles performance, sympathetic cheers became a scattering of chiding boos. The top-seeded team of Raymond and Rennae Stubbs had fallen to the 10th-seeded Cara Black and Yelena Likhovtseva, 6-3, 6-4, in the quarterfinals of the U.S. Open.

title: Fire Debris Is Sent To U.S. Lab for Tests
description: Sodden debris from the unfinished apartment complex destroyed by a fast-moving fire Wednesday night in Edgewater has been sent to a federal laboratory for analysis, the authorities said today.

title: NEW FUNDS FOR MILLENNIUM DOME
description: Threatened once again with bankruptcy, the operators of Britain's ill-starred Millennium Dome attraction won a fresh injection of $74 million from National Lottery funds to remain open until the end of the year. The dome has so far cost about $957 million in public financing but has failed to attract enough visitors to cover costs. It was sold in July for $157 million to a consortium led by Nomura International of Japan, which takes over at the end of the year with plans to change the attraction into a theme park. An opposition politician, Peter Ainsworth, said the debacle had ''gone well beyond a national joke.'' Alan Cowell (NYT).

title: World War III? Now?
description: Now that decisions on deploying a missile defense system will be put off until at least early next year, it's time to deal with a less sweeping but more immediate life-and-death issue: the crumbling of satellites that can prevent accidental launches of Russia's nuclear weapons.

title: An Army at the Ready
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Agencies Form E-Services Unit
description: MARC USA in Pittsburgh and Change Technology Partners in Greenwich, Conn., have invested $20 million in cash and stock to start eHotHouse, an e-services agency that will focus on strategy, application systems and marketing.

title: Recipe: Almond Plum Tarts
description: Adapted from "New Food Fast," by Donna Hay (Whitecap Books, 1999)

title: Why the 15-Student Class Is Just a Nice Theory
description: More than 78,000 New York City public school teachers reported for work yesterday, preparing for the arrival tomorrow of 1.1 million students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUDINE, FRANK R.
description: BEAUDINE-Frank R. Born December 20, 1923 in New York, passed away Sept. 2, 2000 in Plano, Texas. Frank was Chairman of Eastman & Beaudine, a Major Int'l Executive Recruiting Firm he cofounded in 1967. He was a pioneer in the retained search industry. Frank was a Chaminade and Notre Dame grad, McKinsey & Co. alum, author of best selling book ''Ultimate Success''. He is survived by wife Martha, three sons and a daughter and 9 grandchildren. Service is Wed., Sept. 6 in Dallas.

title: World Leaders Arrive, and a City Sits Up and Notices
description: The summit meeting of world leaders gets under way today at the United Nations, but most of New York and its thousands of visitors could not wait to open the curtain on what promises to be a world-class sideshow.

title: That Comment by Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Advances Legal Fiction
description: When writers want to inject a dose of quirky reality into their courtroom dramas, they sometimes turn to law firms to make sure their portrayals are accurate.

title: Drop in Applicants to Medical Schools
description: CHICAGO Sept. 5  The number of applicants to the nation's 125 medical schools fell for the third consecutive year in 1999, an annual survey by the American Medical Association shows.

title: Liberties; Minor-League Mouth
description: Here at The New York Times, we were exceedingly dismayed at the news that George W. Bush had called our redoubtable reporter Adam Clymer ''a major-league (expletive deleted).''

title: Swiss Physicists Face Decision In Race for Atomic Particle
description: Suspicions that they are seeing sketchy evidence for a long-sought particle has put physicists in Geneva in a quandary over whether to proceed with building a $4 billion particle accelerator or to continue experiments with the current equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOW, MICHELE
description: LOW-Michele. In loving memory of Michele Low, a memorial service will be held on September 8 at 2:30 PM at North Stamford Congregational Church, 31 Cascade Road, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in Michele's memory to the National Dance Institute, 594 Broadway, Room 805, New York, NY 10012.

title: For Martin, Late Night Becomes a Small Party
description: It was well after 1 a.m. when a few hundred huddled but hardcore tennis junkies inside Arthur Ashe Stadium witnessed the resilient 30-year-old, fist-pumping Todd Martin pull off a spellbinding comeback to advance to the quarterfinals of the United States Open with a 6-7 (3), 6-7 (7), 6-1, 7-6 (6), 6-2 victory against Carlos Moya of Spain early this morning.

title: Aid to Nigerian Women
description: To the Editor:

title: President Decides to Put Off Work on Missile Shield
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  President Clinton said today that he did not believe that the technology was yet ready for an effective national defense system, and passed the decision on moving ahead with the politically charged and diplomatically delicate project to his successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, WILLIAM F.
description: MANNING-William F., Rev., CSP. On September 4, 2000 in New York at age 83. Born in Richmond Hill, Long Island, NY, he was ordained a Paulist priest on January 25, 1944. Fr. Manning spent seven years in mission work in Minnesota and Tennessee. His perceptive counseling talents showed themselves in the years he served in the Paulist formation program at the major and minor seminaries. He served parishioners in Grand Rapids, MI, San Francisco, CA, Minneapolis, MN, Greely, CO, Houston, TX, and during his senior years at Saint Paul the Apostle parish, NY. A wake will be held on Wednesday, September 6, 2000 from 2 to 9 P.M. at Saint Paul the Apostle Rectory, 415 West 59th St. New York. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Thursday at 10 A.M. at Saint Paul the Apostle Church, 60 St. & Columbus Ave., NY. Burial will be at Mount Paul Cemetery, Oak Ridge, NJ.

title: Defenseman Jonsson Signs One-Year Deal
description: Islanders defenseman Kenny Jonsson signed a one-year contract with the club yesterday. Terms were not disclosed.

title: China Rebukes Taiwan Over Talk of Separation
description: A Chinese spokesman attacked Taiwan's president today for suggesting that his island's unification with China is not inevitable, calling the remarks ''very dangerous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIVITERA, REV. MONSIGNOR
description: PRIVITERA-Rev. Monsignor Santi Joseph. On September 4, 2000. Born on September 21, 1903 in Sciacca, Agrigento, Sicily, Italy. Son of the late Antonio and Marina Russo. He was ordained a priest on April 2, 1927 and was conferred with the title of Monsignor in 1961. He was Pastor Emeritus of the Shrine Church of St. Bernadette in Brooklyn, NY. Reposing at The Andrew Torregrossa and Sons Funeral Home, 1305 79 Street, Brooklyn, NY. Visiting Tuesday 7-10PM and Wednesday 2-5PM. Mass of transferral Wednesday 7:30PM and funeral Mass Thursday 10:30AM at St. Bernadette R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Calvary cemetery.

title: Computer Science Brain Drain
description: Weeks before the beginning of the upcoming fall semester, Benjamin Kuipers, chairman of the University of Texas at Austin Computer Science Department, was scrambling to find two professors to teach core courses. The alternative was to cancel classes students needed to meet graduation requirements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKE, EMANUEL
description: LOCKE-Emanuel. Of Riverdale, NY. Died on September 3 at age 95. Husband, brother, father, grandfather, great - grandfather and uncle. He is survived by his wife, Ethel; by his sister Sarah Kapner of Flushing, New York; by his son Gordon & his wife, Karen, of New Rochelle, NY, with their sons Jeffrey, Scott, and Steven and his wife, Laura; by his son Stanley Locke and his wife, Jane, of Norwalk, CT, with their children Ilene; Cathy-Lynn, her husband, Louis Schwartz, & son, Alexander; Peter, his wife, Noelle, and children Peter and Shelley; and by a stepson, Norman Weitzman, of Manhattan. Services will be on Wednesday, September 6 at noon at The Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Shiva will be observed by Gordon, Ethel, Sarah and Norman on Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9; Friday, 3-5; Saturday 79; and Sunday 1-4, at 74 Sheldrake Place, New Rochelle. By Stanley on Wednesday 5-9:30; and on Thursday, at 17 Deerwood Court, Norwalk.

title: Zeile and the Mets Burst Free of Their Slumps Together
description: The key, Todd Zeile said this afternoon, is to realize you will come out of it eventually. Don't lose confidence. Don't change the mechanics of your swing. Don't panic. The hits have come before, said the Mets' first baseman, and they will come again.

title: I Just Ate My A B C's, Tell Me What You Think of Me
description: Homework was never this delicious. Colorfully iced sugar cookies in the shape of the letters A, B and C, a pencil, an eraser, an apple and a sheet of lined paper (but, alas, no Pokemon cards) are tucked into a small tin lunchbox from Once Upon a Tart, 135 Sullivan Street (Prince Street).

title: Students Show Few Gains in Reading Skills
description: Despite years of efforts to improve education, American students today read no better than their predecessors a generation ago, and their basic math skills have advanced only slightly, according to a new analysis of standardized tests given since the early 1970's.

title: New Yorker Describes Harsh Imprisonment in Peru
description: In her only interview from a Peruvian jail, Lori Berenson describes the harsh conditions of her confinement and tells how her captors have mistreated her fellow prisoners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEGLEIN, MARGA
description: WEGLEIN-Marga. The Yeshiva University Museum family is greatly saddened by the passing of Marga Weglein, a prized senior member of its docent team, whose commitment to the Museum transcended weather and distance, and whose vitality and enthusiasm never flagged. YU Museum

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Transactions

title: Indigestible? France's Unmovable Feast Begins
description: So the long vacation is over, classes have resumed, and the French are once again being bombarded with books. Not schoolbooks, please note, but no fewer than 557 new novels, all published within a two- or three-week period, all timed to coincide with ''la rentree'' -- the return -- to work, to school, to the theater, to restaurants -- that takes place en masse across France in early September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PHYLLIS
description: SIEGEL-Phyllis. On September 5th, 2000. Beloved wife of Sam, mother of Marsha and Gary Kressin, Sharon and David Carr, Siew and Yongsuk Lertratanakul, grandmother of Brian and Deena Kressin, David Kressin, Vanessa and Gregg Botelho, Claudia Carr and Marc Richardson, Michael Carr and Jamie Carr, Jeera and Apinya Lertratanakul, sister of Henry Coretz, Irving Coretz and Esther Eisenstein. Services Thursday, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: More Fans For Drugs That Fight Cholesterol
description: In the 13 years since they were introduced in the United States, the cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins have revolutionized the treatment of heart disease. Study after study has shown these drugs prevent heart attacks and prolong lives, with very few side effects. It is estimated that five million people are taking the drugs, which have rapidly become the best- selling prescriptions in this country.

title: Technology Briefings
description: INTERNET

title: Poll Watch: Numbers Spell Out Who the Voters Really Are
description: In modern politics it has become de rigueur to explain a candidate's popularity or lack thereof by characterizing pockets of American voters.

title: Where the Mountains Are Almonds
description: THEY are among the oldest cultivated foods on earth, the stuff of Greek myths, a prized ingredient of the pharaohs' breads, a staple of Biblical feasts. They are believed to have originated in China and Central Asia, and their pinkish white blossoms and graceful branches call to mind the cherry trees whose botanical family they share. Transported to the Mediterranean by the traders of the Silk Road, they have been an important commodity since the Middle Ages.

title: 40 China Athletes Out of Olympics; 7 Tied to Drugs
description: Forty of China's 300 Olympic athletes have withdrawn from the Summer Games, seven of them rowers who failed blood tests at home indicating that they were using performance-enhancing drugs, Olympic officials said today.

title: With Dislocated Left Shoulder, Is Cone Done?
description: After a doctor struggled to shove David Cone's left, nonthrowing shoulder back into place tonight, Cone stifled the inevitable sadness over his latest setback and mustered some levity. ''I guess this makes your decision about the post-season roster a lot easier,'' he joked to Yankees Manager Joe Torre, while sitting on the trainer's table.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, material was omitted from Page F2 in some copies of Science Times yesterday. The omissions were a picture caption with the article about cholesterol-lowering drugs and a headline and a picture for the article about dolphins' communication. Any reader wishing a replacement page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, PAMELA A.
description: SHIELDS-Pamela A. Age 44, of NYC, formerly of Staten Island, on September 2nd, 2000, of breast cancer. Hair colorist in Manhattan for 26 years. Survived by her sister, Elizabeth, & brother, Richard (Lissa), nephews, Dominic, Salvatore and Richard, nieces, Mycaela and Maura. Memorial service to be held at St. Stephens of Hungary, E. 82nd St., Sunday, September 10th, 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.

title: 'Big Brother' Cash
description: Now, the producers of the CBS reality series ''Big Brother'' are getting really serious.

title: 'Cats' and 'Prufrock,' Now and Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: CRH's PROFITS INCREASE
description: The Irish building materials company CRH P.L.C. reported first-half pretax profit of 180 million euros ($160 million), an increase of 14 percent over the comparable period of 1999, and one that beat analysts' estimates by about 5 million euros ($4.44 million). Earnings per share increased 21 percent, to 0.3726 euro. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: U.N. Workers Killed in Timor; Reverberations Felt at Summit
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 6 -- An armed mob of 1,000 people stormed into a United Nations refugee operation in West Timor today, demolishing the office and beating to death three unarmed United Nations workers, including an American, and touching off outrage at the summit meeting of world leaders here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, EVELYN DINGFELDER
description: MARTIN-Evelyn Dingfelder. On August 31, Hallandale, Florida. Loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Memorial service Sunday, September 10.

title: Turning the Tables, the Establishment Takes On Hip-Hop
description: Robert Krulwich, a ''Nightline'' correspondent, shows a group of teenagers a snapshot of Al Gore and draws a collective blank. Then he pulls out a photograph of Russell Simmons, a corporate executive. Instant recognition all around!

title: Limits May Soon Emerge For AOL Deal
description: Government regulators are finishing work on a list of conditions they would like to impose on America Online and Time Warner for the $165 billion merger of the companies to be approved, people involved in the talks between the government and the companies say.

title: Question: Where Is the Dignity?
description: Tuck in your shirt. That's what our moms always told us, but what did they know? Now, there is a great international shirt-raising movement.

title: Recipe: Almond-and-Hazelnut-Chip Macaroons
description: Adapted from "Desserts: Mediterranean Flavors, California Style,"

title: Senate to Vote On Trade Bill For China Soon
description: As senators resumed debate on a major bill establishing permanent trade relations with China, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that he would try to schedule a final vote by the end of next week.

title: Internet Helping Home Schoolers
description: Through the vehicle of a unique "virtual" school, teachers and administrators in the Basehor-Linwood School District are providing families that teach their children at home the guidance of public school teachers, the validation of state standardized tests and the purchasing power of a large public school.

title: ADVANCED MICRO OFFERS NEW LOW-COST CHIP
description: Advanced Micro Devices introduced a faster version of its low-cost Duron chip. The Duron competes with Intel's Celeron. Advanced Micro's new chip runs at 750 megahertz and costs $181 apiece in quantities of 1,000, the company said. Compaq Computer and I.B.M. are expected to offer PC's with the new chip.

title: CALENDAR
description: Hudson Valley Showcase

title: First, Three Big Debates
description: No events in a presidential campaign are more crucial to public involvement in the electoral process than the cycle of debates involving the major candidates in the fall. This week, however, Gov. George W. Bush is demanding that instead of three televised encounters sponsored by the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates that has run the events since 1988, only one such debate take place, coupled with two other joint appearances with Vice President Al Gore -- one on ''Meet the Press'' and the other on ''Larry King Live.''

title: NASA Starts Countdown for Shuttle Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept 5 - NASA began its three-day countdown on Tuesday toward launch of the space-shuttle Atlantis on an assembly and supply run to the International Space Station, a $60 billion science outpost that is under construction.

title: Style Fantasies Show the Influence of a Photographers Stark Reality
description: In the half-dozen or so fashion shoots he has done, most of them for W magazine during the past few years, Philip-Lorca diCorcia has staged unnerving narratives like one titled "A Perfect World," in which things don't seem perfect at all. Here, a patrician housewife, frozen looking, her face harshly lighted, appears as if she'd need no more than a few shots of Tanqueray and a splash of Schwepps to push her into doing something Medea-like. In another series, set in Havana, a model is cast as a disconsolate-looking Batista-era office worker who is equally blank in her nighttime job as a call girl. Should the reader forget that there are dresses to be looked at, the text alerts you: "Havana was once a nightclub hot spot. These days, it's the perfect backdrop for sober day clothes or racy little evening looks. Think brief, briefer, briefest."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GERALD MORTON
description: SMITH-Gerald Morton. It is with sorrow that we note the passing of Gerald Morton Smith, a longtime partner of our predecessor firm Gottesman Wolgel Smith and Secunda who enriched the law and lives of those who labored with and learned from him. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife, Lorraine and his family. Gottesman Wolgel Secunda Malamy and Flynn P.C.

title: Pinochet Appeal for Unity
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 84, facing a possible trial for human rights abuses during his 17-year dictatorship, urged Chileans today to put the past behind them and focus on the future.

title: Reaching for the Stars, Selling Drugs on Earth
description: It's been called screen presence, star quality and charisma. But a more apt word for the buzz exuded by the stars of the rickety rap melodrama ''Turn It Up'' might be attitude. The projection of attitude (with a capital A) is a basic ingredient of hip-hop performance, and it's one reason rappers seem able to make the transition from music to movies far more easily than their rock-and-roll forerunners. Long before appearing in the films, they were already rehearsing their roles.

title: Hillary Clinton Is Endorsed By Sierra Club as Better Ally
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton today won the endorsement of the Sierra Club, one of the nation's oldest environmental groups, whose backing set off a duel between the Senate candidates over who has done more to protect natural resources.

title: Benitezs Best Is Not Good Enough
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 6  Armando Benitez throws heat. Every hitter knows it, and every hitter has to expect it. When the Mets' closer came into the game with the bases loaded and one out in the eighth inning today, protecting a one-run lead, he had to throw the fastball.

title: BROADCOM CALLS INTEL PATENT SUIT SPECIOUS
description: Responding to a patent infringement lawsuit filed last week by Intel, Broadcom issued a statement saying the suit was specious litigation aimed at discouraging Intel employees from seeking jobs at Broadcom. Broadcom said that it had not infringed upon any Intel patents. ''The notion that we need to misappropriate Intel's technology to compete is nonsense,'' Henry T. Nicholas, Broadcom's president and chief executive, said in the statement. He said it was ''widely recognized in the industry and investment community that Broadcom, not Intel, is the leader'' in digital cable TV, cable modem ''and other key 21st-century technologies.'' Mr. Nicholas said Broadcom would defend itself vigorously. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: What Would the Founders Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: Concerns Over Intel's Growth Help Send Nasdaq Lower
description: Technology stocks fell broadly yesterday, sending the Nasdaq composite index lower. Intel led the decline after an analyst said that its sales growth would be slower than forecast.

title: Handyman 101: English a Must
description: I set out for America 10 years ago with my new wife and $500 that I had borrowed from friends. My wife's uncle picked us up at Kennedy Airport. He was the only person we knew in this country -- and he was unemployed. My wife soon got a part-time job as a cleaning lady for a family in Brooklyn. I couldn't find work, so I helped her out. I did whatever I was told to do: sweeping the walk, washing windows, changing bulbs. As payment, we received free room and board, but no money. The family didn't speak Polish, but somehow we were able to communicate through sign language and an English-Polish dictionary that I always carried with me.

title: Guerrilla Attacks Raise Worries in Central Asia
description: Deadly clashes between guerrillas and the armies of two former Soviet republics in Central Asia last month are deepening concerns that an effort is under way to destabilize the region.

title: Survey Lauds Midwestern Schools
description: Sparsely populated Midwestern states are challenging the stereotype of the isolated rural school, leading the nation in the use of technology to connect classrooms to the nation and the world, a recent study suggests.

title: GABELLI FUNDS TO VOTE AGAINST LIBERTY PLAN TO SELL UNITS
description: The Liberty Corporation's biggest shareholder, the group of funds managed by Mario Gabelli, said it planned to vote its stake of almost 20 percent against Liberty's plan to sell insurance operations for $650 million. Liberty plans a Sept. 29 shareholder vote on its agreement to sell its Liberty Life Insurance Company and Liberty Services Insurance Corporation units to Canada's largest bank, the Royal Bank. Based in Toronto, the bank plans to pay Liberty shareholders $580 million in cash and $70 million in dividends from Liberty Life. Closing the sales requires two-thirds of Liberty's outstanding common and preferred shares to be voted in favor, according to a company filing last month with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries are gathering this week for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: Its Fall, Time to Hunker Down
description: Perry Nagle, 35, a lawyer specializing in corporate finance, is taking the rest of the year off. Having already earned more than enough money to tide him over until next year, he has packed his bags and is heading for the beaches of Indonesia where, he said, the ocean is "bath-water warm."

title: VODAFONE AND MICROSOFT IN WIRELESS DEAL
