description: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest mobile phone company, said it was teaming up with Microsoft to develop wireless Internet services. The products will offer Microsoft applications for access to the Internet using mobile devices and will be commercially available next April. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Scranton, Pa., Milwaukee, Indianapolis and Detroit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINN, PHILLIP
description: KINN-Phillip. The League Treatment Center mourns the loss of Phillip Kinn, Jewish Holocaust resistance fighter, born in Iwje, Poland. Through his great acts of courage and loyalty Phillip was relentless in saving family and friends. He fought in three armies against the Nazis, and as a resistance fighter blew up bridges and train tracks. He was a hero. He and his late wife Sonia, also a resistance fighter, will be profoundly missed by his son Dr. Mark Kinn, daughter, author Gail Kinn, daughter-in-law Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, and her sister Linda, and his treasured granddaughter Sarah Frieda Kinn. His strength remains an inspiration. Funeral services were held Tuesday, Sept. 5 at 11:30 AM at Parkside Funeral Home, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Broooklyn, NY.

title: A Sore Sight for Eyes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Net Companies Learn to Personalize
description: Ask a handful of Internet executives to define the term "personalization," and invariably the conversation turns to the analogy of a shopkeeper who knows not only his customers' names, but how much they can afford to spend and what size shirt they wear.

title: Survey Lauds Midwestern Schools
description: Sparsely populated Midwestern states are challenging the stereotype of the isolated rural school, leading the nation in the use of technology to connect classrooms to the nation and the world, a recent study suggests.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Power in TV Confessions
description: The success of shows like "Survivor" has many wondering where reality television is headed. This question has recently come up with our own program, "Confessions," which takes an unfiltered look at convicted murderers and other violent felons.

title: Judge Keeps Texaco Case
description: A federal judge has rejected a motion filed by lawyers for Ecuadorean Indians requesting that he withdraw from handling their seven-year-old lawsuit against Texaco Inc. The suit accuses Texaco of polluting the Indians' Amazon lands.

title: Microsoft Device Shows Gamers Just Who's Talking the Talk
description: For online gamers, the ability to speak through the Internet to other players while playing has obvious advantages. But it also has the potential for trouble. ''If you're in the middle of a combat game and you're strategizing with your team mate, it's important not to let your opponents hear that,'' said Isabella Carniato, Microsoft's Game Voice marketing manager.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert performance of Aaron Copland's opera ''The Tender Land'' today at the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College misidentified a cast member. Laurie Moss is a character in the opera; the role will be sung by the soprano Tammy Tyburczy.

title: 2 Companies Under Inquiry On Generic-Drug Actions
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it was investigating whether Bristol-Myers Squibb and a small California company called American Bioscience might have illegally colluded to keep the lower-cost, generic version of Bristol's top-selling cancer drug, Taxol, off the market.

title: Speedy Connections: Cable Versus D.S.L.
description: Q. Is there any difference between a D.S.L. and a cable-modem connection for high-speed Internet access?

title: Sports Sites Revamp Strategy
description: The holiday weekend signals the start of a peak season for sports fans, who can finally supplement their baseball-only diets with smatterings of professional football, basketball and hockey.

title: Article 2000090792733952379 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil jumped on speculation that any output increase adopted by OPEC would be too small to meet demand. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose $1.07, or 3.2 percent, to $34.90 a barrel.

title: Order in the Court, and at the A.C.L.U.
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Award in Online Music Case

title: Interiors With the Midas Touch
description: MUCH of what will glitter this fall will be gold. ''Gold is a neutral color that is warm and flattering, like candlelight,'' said Sherri Donghia, the design director of Donghia Furniture and Textiles. ''Gold is no longer a color just for holidays.''

title: Feeding the 'Energy Eater'; Atlantic Canada's Oil Boom Helps the Northeastern U.S.
description: From this unexpected corner of the North Atlantic, American consumers could soon see a ray of relief from shortages that have kept oil and natural gas prices stubbornly high. But even though the new energy supplies will be welcome, they are not expected to bring prices down soon.

title: Bush Vows to Stick to His Debating Plan
description: The wrangling over the presidential debates intensified yesterday, as Vice President Al Gore continued to insist that Gov. George W. Bush accept an independent commission's schedule of debates, while Mr. Bush vowed to show up next week for a television debate he helped to set up regardless of whether Mr. Gore was there.

title: 'New Elmore Leonard?' 'Yeah. You Know. Punks.'
description: PAGAN BABIES

title: Despite Study, Final Word on Gulf War Syndrome Is Elusive
description: The question of what has caused the array of symptoms called Gulf War Syndrome was muddy before, and a report from the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences released today did little to clear the waters.

title: APB Online Finally Bought
description: SafetyTips.com purchased the assets of APB Online for $575,000 today, two weeks after withdrawing a higher offer for the beleaguered operator of crime news site APBnews.com.

title: Article 2000090790406421322 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Privacy Plan Likely to Kick Off Debate
description: The goal of the plan announced by President Clinton's chief of staff, John Podesta, sounded admirable: to overhaul the nation's privacy laws, harmonizing a patchwork of inconsistent rules and extending to e-mail and mobile phone messages the same strict safeguards against government snooping that now apply to telephone calls.

title: Corrections
description: The Cuttings column in Sunday Styles this week, about growing bamboo, misstated the dates of Bamboo Fest 2000 at the Horticultural Society of New York. It will be held from the evening of Sept. 15 through Sept. 17, not this weekend. Information: (212) 757-0915, extension 200.

title: Investors Bail Out of Technology and Semiconductors
description: Investors bailed out of semiconductor stocks again yesterday, driving the Nasdaq composite index, which rallied 11.7 percent last month, to its second consecutive decline and its biggest since late July.

title: Debates, and Other Skirmishes
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tire Hearings Scrutinize Firestone and Ford Motor

title: Teenagers Flying High, But Staying Grounded
description: Lleyton Hewitt and Elena Dementieva, both born in 1981, grew up idolizing Andre Agassi and Monica Seles.

title: A Spreading Techno-blight of Wires
description: Richard C. Youngken, a city planner with an eye for design disasters, pulled into a parking lot next to a busy four-lane road in Middletown, R.I., and looked up.

title: For Assembly and Civil Court Judge
description: As candidates campaign vigorously before crucial primary elections next Tuesday, here are our endorsements in four Democratic contests -- two for Assembly races that have drawn increased public attention in recent days and two for Civil Court judgeships. Winning these races is usually tantamount to election.

title: Cone Hopes to Return Before the Season Ends
description: His left shoulder throbbing, and tired from a night of trying to sleep in a chair, David Cone had an M.R.I. test today and, medically, the news was good. The test showed that his dislocated, nonthrowing shoulder, pushed back into place after being hurt in Tuesday's game, did not appear to have much damage beyond the injury itself.

title: Competing to Make Medicare Worse
description: The health care debate has heated up in earnest with George W. Bush's detailed proposal to overhaul Medicare. On this issue, Mr. Bush seeks to meld the best of the open market with what he terms the nation's ''moral obligation'' to secure the health needs of the elderly.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Soliciting Billions for Fund
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is returning to some of its oldest customers to start what may be the world's top buyout fund.

title: Productivity In 2nd Quarter Grew Faster Than Estimate
description: American workers were even more productive than first thought in the second quarter, government figures showed today, reinforcing last month's decision by Federal Reserve policy makers to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: BNP PARIBAS PROFIT RISES
description: The French banking group BNP Paribas, buoyed by its asset management and retail banking business outside France, said first-half operating income rose 24 percent, to 2.81 billion euros, or $2.5 billion, from a pro forma 2.27 billion euros a year earlier. The report combined first-half results for the first time since the takeover of Paribas by Banque Nationale de Paris a year ago. The combined bank's chairman, Michel Pebereau, sought to counter reports of high-level defections from the Paribas investment banking arm, saying that integration of the banks was proceeding satisfactorily ''despite the inherent difficulties associated with such a merger.'' John Tagliabue

title: Prosecutors Say Doctor Killed To Feel a Thrill
description: Most people in the courtroom knew how the small, skittish man had managed to murder at least four of his patients without getting caught: he injected them with poison, he admitted today. The question observers wanted answered was ''Why?''

title: Lawyer Advances Legal Fiction
description: When writers want to inject a dose of quirky reality into their courtroom dramas, they sometimes turn to law firms to make sure their portrayals are accurate.

title: The State of the World, and the World to Be, in 149 Chapters
description: The question hangs out there: Why would 149 world leaders leave their not-always-stable governments unattended to come to New York and make five-minute speeches, mostly to each other and the television cameras from back home?

title: GORE OFFERS VISION OF BETTER TIMES FOR MIDDLE CLASS
description: Unveiling a book-length plan that hinges on optimistic fiscal forecasts, Vice President Al Gore today offered his economic vision for the future, painting an image of a prosperous middle class that enjoys higher incomes, with more home ownership, more high-tech jobs and more people going to college.

title: In Two Weeks, Lazio's Tax Plan Undergoes Deductions of Its Own
description: With television cameras and photographers crowded around him, Representative Rick A. Lazio settled behind a green plastic picnic table in the Caracci family backyard here to talk up what he calls the most dramatic component of his tax cut plan: allowing taxpayers to deduct their payroll tax from their federal income taxes.

title: Elections Near, Rivalries Split Opposition to Milosevic
description: A split in the opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic is putting at risk its main achievement so far: its control over Serbia's major cities, including radio and television stations.

title: Helping the Cold-Nose Crowd
description: ROCCO arrived for physical therapy at Bonnie's K9 Swim Center in Manhattan, prancing with excitement, a bandana knotted around his thick furry neck and metal wheels strapped to his withered hind legs. Rocco, a 10-year-old German shepherd, had lymphoma last summer, followed by a ruptured disk requiring emergency surgery.

title: Confessions on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Love From a Distance
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ultimate, Apocalyptic Laptop
description: For all the corporate enthusiasm over the unveiling of each new generation of computer chip (last month Intel announced that its Pentium 4 would be packed with 42 million transistors performing as many as 8.4 billion operations per second), consumers may be more apt to feel a sense of dread. Once again the expensive desktop computers and laptops they were so proud of have become outmoded, destined to join the scrap piles of unsalable equipment accumulating in closets everywhere.

title: Defending Napster To the Editor:
description: Re ''Taking Sides in the Napster War'' (Aug. 31): Both sides in the debate over Napster glaringly neglect the benefits of innovation and progress that would be likely to sprout if Napster was left alone. If we submit to the argument of the few -- musicians and record companies -- we ignore the possibility of long-term benefits for the many. By doing so, we would be neglecting the oft-repeated lessons of history. Once the artists and record companies open their minds and embrace the inevitable, I am certain that they will find new streams of revenue, as always.

title: WEB ENCRYPTION PATENT INTO PUBLIC DOMAIN
description: RSA Security said it had placed the RSA public key encryption algorithm into the public domain, permitting programmers to freely incorporate the technology into their products. The RSA algorithm -- named after three computer scientists: Ronald Rivest, Adi Shamir and Leonard Adelman -- has been widely used for more than a decade to protect the privacy of digital commerce and communications. The technology was originally awarded a United States patent on Sept. 20, 1983, and the patent is due to expire this month. Known as public key cryptography, the technology, also pioneered independently by researchers at Stanford University, makes it possible for two people who have never met to exchange information securely. John Markoff

title: Debates, and Other Skirmishes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Village Refuge Thats a Throwback
description: HEALTH implications aside, the smell of tobacco smoke can sometimes be comforting. In the old days, aromas of strong tobacco, leather and perhaps a touch of aftershave conveyed warm and reassuring images of paternal strength. Today, even though I generally abhor cigarette smoke while I'm eating, a tobacco haze sometimes seems perfectly appropriate.

title: Southeast Asia Losing Ground In New Economy, Report Says
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations has released a report warning that despite a level of economic recovery, globalization threatens the region's competitiveness as an exporter and a place to invest.

title: Young Techies Say No to College
description: While his fellow seniors at Tiffin Columbian High School spent last year preparing for college, John- Thomas Gaietto set his eyes on heading straight to the pros. Distracted in school, Mr. Gaietto focused his energy and extracurricular time honing his skills and nurturing his natural gift.

title: Sampras Awakes To Stop Krajicek
description: Pete Sampras was staring across the net at the one player who has been able to defuse his atomic serves with his own, and the one opponent who has been able to emerge from their matches with barely a scratch over the years.

title: Turkish Police Bar Gay Americans From Visiting Aegean Port
description: The Turkish police barred several hundred gay Americans today from visiting tourist sites near an Aegean port, Kusadasi, and ordered them back aboard their cruise ship, prompting complaints from the State Department, officials said.

title: Cheerleading? Bah!
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulators Back Claritin Patent, Maker Says
description: Schering-Plough said today that regulators had confirmed the validity of a patent on Claritin, the world's top-selling allergy drug. The patent had been challenged by generic-drug makers.

title: Three Cops, Retired but Yearning For Action
description: The cock-of-the-walk score for ''The Bulls' Night Out,'' performed by the Swing Daddies, gives the film a focus and energy that its filmmaking lacks. (The music sounds like a bouncing-on-the-balls-of-its-feet Las Vegas fanfare for a Sinatra entrance at the old Aladdin Hotel in Las Vegas.) The picture's title is explained in the very first scene, when a barkeep, George (Jack Marnell), tells a customer why the Bulls' Night Out banner hangs in Ruby's Bar, his establishment. ''Off-duty retired cops show ID, drink for free -- they do it once a month,'' George explains. Satisfied, the customer downs a vodka, drops off the mail and heads off into the streets.

title: New Lilly Effort on Insulin
description: Eli Lilly & Company, one of the world's top sellers of diabetes medicines, said yesterday that it would work with the Generex Biotechnology Corporation to try to develop a form of insulin that can be taken orally. Lilly will make initial payments to Generex and pay the company royalties if the drug makes it to the market. Lilly received worldwide rights to the compound and will be responsible for continuing studies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICKERSON, HELEN LIVINGSTON
description: NICKERSON-Helen Livingston. Born San Francisco. NYC resident more than 50 years. Passed September 2nd, after short illness. Moved to NY to study at Neighborhood Playhouse. Worked in Broadway Theatre production. For 17 years she was assistant and eventually General Manager for David Merrick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APUZZO, FRANCES M.
description: APUZZO-Frances M. Of Bronxville, New York on September 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Apuzzo. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9 P.M. Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday, September 8 at 10 A.M. Interment St. Raymonds Cemetery.

title: Proposed Transfer For Gas Line Stake
description: The DTE Energy Company and the MCN Energy Group proposed transferring an interest in a natural gas line to the Unicom Corporation to resolve concerns raised by the Federal Trade Commission over DTE's purchase of MCN.

title: 4 Warlords Wont Accept Somali Leader
description: SANA, Yemen, Sept. 2  Leaving this capital after a four-day visit, four Somali warlords today warned foreign nations not to recognize the election of a new president in their country, saying it could lead to civil war.

title: PUBLIC MEETINGS ABOUT INTERNET
description: The Internet Policy Institute, a Washington-based independent research organization, plans to hold eight ''town hall'' meetings to gather grass-roots information on Internet policies and will present its findings to the next president after the November elections. The meetings are being held jointly with eight universities across the country to get ''outside the Beltway'' views on the Internet, said James L. Barksdale, former president and chief executive of Netscape Communications and chairman of the institute, which is nonpartisan.

title: MORE INDICATIONS HAZARDS OF TIRES WERE LONG KNOWN
description: Documents released today provided additional evidence that Bridgestone/Firestone and possibly Ford knew about a pattern of tire failures long before a recall was announced in August, and lawmakers began calling for tighter regulation of the auto and tire industries.

title: New Police Commissioner Removes Two Chiefs
description: Moving quickly to shake up the leadership of the Police Department, Bernard B. Kerik, the new commissioner, announced yesterday that he was removing the assistant chief in the Bronx, where there has been a rise in murders, and the chief of uniformed officers.

title: American Topics : Remembering the Orphan Trains
description: In the mid-1800s, many of the immigrants who poured into America found an unforgiving reception. There were few jobs to be had, and thousands of children ended up living on the streets or in overcrowded orphanages.

title: A Wired World Awaits The Olympics in Sydney
description: THREE years ago, while touring Britain, Philip Dean had to use Internet connections at local universities to e-mail home.

title: Nets Give Samake A Multiyear Deal
description: The Nets signed their second-round draft pick, center Soumaila Samake, to a multiyear contract, the team announced yesterday.

title: John Alexander Simpson, 83, Nuclear and Cosmic Scientist
description: John Alexander Simpson, a nuclear physicist and astrophysicist whose instruments have been sending data back from space for nearly 40 years, died on Aug. 31 in Chicago. He was 83 and lived in the Hyde Park neighborhood of Chicago.

title: The Glories of Underworld Are Under Siege
description: BENSON Ariz.  Take a sopping wet underground cavern in a remote corner of Arizona. Add a man-made entrance with heavy steel doors to keep out the hot desert air, a misting system to keep the cavern damp and lights to show off a wonderland of spires, flowstone, soda straws and other phantasmagorical cave formations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DECHOVITZ, JUDITH
description: DECHOVITZ-Judith: You left us September 7, 1994, but are with us always. We miss you. Susan, David, Sheila, Tony

title: GERMAN UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS
description: The number of unemployed people in Germany fell for the 10th time in 11 months in August as an economic expansion encouraged companies to hire. Unemployment fell by 18,000 from July, after dropping a revised 12,000 the previous month, the federal labor office said. The jobless rate, adjusted for seasonal swings, was unchanged at 9.5 percent, the Bundesbank reported. The report may ease concerns that German expansion is losing its momentum.

title: The Ad Campaign: Attacking Bushs Record on Childrens Health Care
description: The Democratic National Committee announced yesterday that it would begin running a new commercial tomorrow that takes a critical look at Gov. George W. Bush's record of providing health care for children in Texas. The 30-second spot is to run in nine states that Democrats and Republicans have focused on most heavily : Arkansas, Delaware, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin.

title: Senate Panel Alleges HUD Used Program to Jab Mayor
description: A Senate subcommittee report yesterday accused the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development of playing politics with programs for the homeless in New York City to harass the Giuliani administration.

title: Through Northwest Passage in a Month, Ice-Free
description: NUUK, Greenland, Sept. 4  During World War II, when Henry Larsen took a Royal Canadian Mounted Police ship, the St. Roch, into the fabled Northwest Passage, his boat was frozen in Arctic ice through two winters, only emerging at the eastern end after 27 months.

title: New Search Technology Will Allow Normal Language
description: Searching within Web sites is often just as frustrating as searching the whole Web. Dead ends and unrelated links are common. But a new technology that is being unveiled this week on the Public Broadcasting Service's Web site could help change that.

title: Right-Hand Man at U.N. Behind the Summit
description: IMAGINE that you threw an unprecedented three-day party on the banks of the East River, invited the heads of a world's worth of nations -- 189 presidents, premiers, prime ministers, princes and kings -- and almost all of them showed up. With princely demands, agendas and motorcades. Some with protesters in tow. All of them protected by a multimillion-dollar blanket of security that makes exceptions for no man, not even the host.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, MAX
description: SCHORR-Max. Beloved Palm Beach and former New York City attorney, 92, died Tuesday afternoon in Palm Beach from complications of prostate cancer. A counsel at Edwards & Angell, Max was one of Florida's oldest practicing attorneys. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he practiced from the early 30's until 1972 in New York City and White Plains. He is survived by two sons; Tony of Rye, New York, and Andrew of Mercer Island, Washington; 10 grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Thursday at 2PM at Temple Beth El in West Palm Beach. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, ALFRED
description: APPEL-Alfred. Of New York City, on September 6, 2000 in his 95th year. Beloved husband of Beatrice with whom he celebrated their 69th wedding anniversary on Sunday, September 3rd. A graduate of Townsend Harris High School at age 15, Cornell University, Class of 1926, Cornell Law School, Class of 1928, he was a former managing partner at Proskauer, Rose, Getz and Mendelson where he practiced law for over 65 years. In addition to being a member of the Cornell Law School Advisory Council, he was National Chairman of The Cornell Law School Fund and served on several boards of directors of prominent companies. He was also a member of the Great Neck Board of Education and a trustee of the Society for Hillside Hospital. A gentle and wise friend and advisor, he is also survived by his children, Professor Alfred Appel, Jr. and Dean Nina Appel, Betty and Paul Schaffer, and John S. Appel and Barbara Wolkowitz, his grandchildren Karen and Gene Oshman, Richard J. Appel and Mona Simpson, Dr. Mark A. Schaffer, Catherine Schaffer and greatgrandchildren Stephen and Katherine Oshman and Gabriel Jandali Appel and Grace Appel Jandali; also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Dr. Burton and Lynn Hoffman and numerous nephews and nieces. Service on Friday, September 8, 2000 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: A VCR That Won't Accept Peanut Butter and Jelly
description: A videocassette recorder and a child can be a hazardous combination -- for the VCR. The tape slot has been known to attract foreign objects, including the occasional peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Sony Electronics has introduced a new machine with a tape slot that can be locked to keep wayward objects out.

description: Robert Gottlieb, one of the most powerful agents in book publishing, resigned as head of the William Morris agency's New York literary group to start his own agency and multimedia management company, a blow to the venerable William Morris's presence in the book business.

title: Critics Urge Regents to Reject CUNY's Four-Year Master Plan
description: Critics of the City University of New York yesterday urged the State Board of Regents to reject the university's master plan for the next four years, saying it would turn CUNY into an elite university and shut the door on the city's most educationally needy students.

title: U.S. Open Webcams Put Viewers at the Controls
description: People attending the United States Open this month at Flushing Meadows Tennis Center must choose among several matches happening simultaneously. But tennis fans can hop from court to court online, browsing the action at will. With the Slam Cam, the online cameras at Usopen.org, users can direct up-to-the-minute still cameras and even determine the zoom intensity on three courts: the Arthur Ashe Stadium, the Louis Armstrong Stadium and the Grandstand. The cameras use TrueLook software developed in 1996 by a Chicago company, Perceptual Robotics, and installed by technicians from I.B.M., the sponsor of the Web site. I.B.M. also uses the Slam Cam at Wimbledon, the French Open and the Australian Open. The cams have been operating on Usopen.org since 1997, but this year they have become one of the site's most popular features, especially during rain delays and when two popular matches are in progress at the same time. COREY KILGANNON

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP TO BUY MERCHANTS BANK
description: Valley National Bancorp, a regional New Jersey bank, said it would acquire Merchants New York Bancorp Inc. for $375 million in stock to expand in the New York City area. Merchants New York is the parent company of Merchants Bank of New York, which has seven branches in Manhattan and $1.4 billion in assets. Valley National, based in Wayne, N.J., owns Valley National Bank, which has 117 branches in New Jersey and $6.2 billion in assets. Shares of New York-based Merchants New York rose $1.88, to $19.38. Valley National's stock traded at $26.13, up 19 cents.

title: La Scala Bids Addio to the Favorite Haunt of Catcalls
description: These days the real drama at La Scala in Milan is taking place in the auditorium and not onstage. When the season starts up again with Puccini's ''Boheme'' on Tuesday, the 200 standing-room places of the first and second galleries will no longer be occupied. This is tragic news for its habitual dwellers, the feared and respected ''loggionisti,'' the ardent opera buffs who sit or stand in the galleries and are said to dictate the failure or success of a performer, a conductor or even an opera at the theater.

title: Sports of The Times; Bronze Guy Stands Tall Sans Towel
description: ARTHUR ASHE was not one for fig leaves -- symbolic fig leaves, anyway. His views regarding human and race relations -- as well, as I recall, virtually any other subject -- were never anything but direct. You asked Arthur Ashe a question and he gave you not only what was on his insightful mind, but what was in his heart, as well.

title: Arms Across the Atlantic
description: EVER since Madonna landed the hunky British director Guy Ritchie and declared Britain her second home, the English tabloids have been full of self-congratulatory prose. It's their metaphorical way of kicking sand in the face of the single, commitment-minded American male, who according to Time magazine, is practically as rare a sighting as the American osprey.

title: Seeing the Light Throughout the Tunnel
description: Fukuoka, Japan, has been called the Venice of Asia for its extensive network of canals and bridges. It might also be called the Seattle of Asia, since it is a rainy city. Thus there are underground pedestrian tunnels connecting stores to hotels, and office buildings to train stations. But tunnels don't have to be gloomy. In 1997, the Iwataya department store chain hired the Walker Group/CNI, an architectural firm in Manhattan, to design a new store in Fukuoka. The Iwataya Passage, connecting the store to a train station, was a bonus: a passageway suffused with light. ''We came up with a metaphor of bridges and evoking the character of water,'' said Jay Valgora, a designer at Walker Group/CNI. The 400-foot-long passage, 10 1/2 feet high and 16 feet wide, shimmers. The center part, top left, has glass panels coated with fine metal particles, which act like prisms. Panels are tilted at angles and suspended on stainless steel cables. ''The colors change, and the reflections of the people change,'' Mr. Valgora said. The ceiling, left, has glass pieces suspended from steel cables. As people walk through, they hear music, Haiku poetry whispered in three languages and the sounds of water. Motion detectors also trigger sounds. The tunnel's $1 million cost was shared by Iwataya and the city of Fukuoka. Mr. Valgora collaborated on the tunnel with two Manhattan design companies, FTL/Happold Architects and Engineers, and Art in Commerce, which did the music installation.

title: Dot-Com Recruiting Woes: Part 2
description: If executives of e-commerce companies thought they were having a hard time finding employees last year, this year's Summer of the Dot-Com Shakeout has brought even more misery to the group.

title: TOTAL FINA ELF PROFIT DOUBLES
description: Total Fina Elf S.A. of France said its first-half profit more than doubled because of higher oil prices, a drop in the euro and low inventories of processed fuels, which increased refining margins. Net income rose to 3.4 billion euros ($3 billion), or 4.83 euros a share, from 1.28 billion, or 1.83 euros a share, in the period a year earlier. Total's growth in earnings reflects its $49 billion takeover of Elf Aquitaine S.A. last year and a 14 percent rise in the dollar against the euro.

title: FRENCH BANK SHARES FALL
description: Shares in Credit Commercial de France fell almost 15 percent after HSBC Holdings, the London-based banking group that acquired control of Credit Commercial in April, said it would acquire the 1.4 percent of Credit Commercial shares it did not yet own for 150 euros ($135) a share. Credit Commercial said its net profit rose 30 percent in the first half, to 296.4 million euros ($266.7 million). Yet the news of HSBC's bid, intended to withdraw Credit Commercial shares from the bourse, caused the share price to drop 14.9 percent, to 151.1 euros. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATON, BRUCE ROSS
description: ATON-Bruce Ross. September 1, 2000. Age 82. At Southern Ocean County Hospital, Manahawkin, N.J. Born in Reedsburg, WI. Resident of Brant Beach, N.J. for the past six years. Formerly of Mahwah, N.J. Marketing V.P. for Rheem Manufacturing, Linden, N.J. and New York City. Survived by wife Helen Marie (nee Fay), and four sons and one sister, eight grandchildren. Funeral was from Thos L. Shinn Funeral Home, 10 Hilliard Drive, Manahawkin, NJ.

title: Attack on U.N. Refugee Office Recalls Violence in East Timor
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Sept. 7 -- The mob rampage that killed three United Nations workers in West Timor Wednesday seemed to some aid workers like the terrifying flashback of a trauma survivor: in many respects it replicated the the violence, exactly one year ago, in East Timor.

title: Debating Detailed Plans for Hypothetical Money
description: In releasing a detailed economic blueprint today, Vice President Al Gore reignited a debate with Gov. George W. Bush about who can better apportion the projected federal budget surplus without driving the government back into the red and running the good economy off the rails.

title: Building Outside the (Gray) Box: A Legacy of Curves and Colors
description: WHEN Morris Lapidus, who is 97 and architect of the iconic, mid-50's Fontaine bleu Hilton and Eden Roc hotels in Miami Beach and more than 1,000 other projects, was in town recently, he had lunch with his colleague Philip Johnson as well as his former clients, the brothers Tisch. Between lunches with friends and meetings with manufacturers to discuss licensing his product designs, Mr. Lapidus sat briefly in Central Park, recounting some of his most memorable New York projects and looking back on his life as a contrarian.

title: Have Your Mommy Call My Mommy
description: Veronika Dorothea Kramer, 2 months, has something most babies do not -- a business card. Profession: baby. Her mother, Sarah Delson, a graphic designer at St. Martin's Press in Manhattan, put Veronika's footprints on a digital scanner, reduced the image, then designed and laser-printed the cards. She and her husband, Larry Kramer, a law professor at New York University, sent out 150. ''Anyone can do this on a computer,'' Ms. Delson said: $39 for 1,000 blank cards at Staples.

title: Congress Takes Up Defective Tires
description: The precise reason that the treads on certain Firestone tires on Ford Explorers have been peeling off with deadly consequences is not yet clear, but evidence emerging in Congressional inquiries is making it increasingly apparent that both companies were aware of the safety problems long before they took action to address them. Equally worrisome is the fact that even once the companies did act in some foreign markets, they refrained from doing so in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELSH, VERNON M.
description: WELSH-Vernon M., 92. Of Old Lyme, CT, died peacefully at his home on September 4, 2000. Mr. Welsh, formerly of Ridgefield, CT, was a resident of Old Lyme for many years. He served as chairman of the Old Lyme Historic District Commission and his home on Lyme Street is on the National Register of Historic Places as a Historic District Property. He also was past Vice President of the Library Board in Old Lyme. Mr. Welsh was past Vice President of Communications at General Dynamics and was one of three editors of Dynamic America, a history of the General Dynamics Corporation. He also was a consultant for CEIR and Boeing Corporation before he retired. He graduated Cum Laude from Dartmouth College in 1931. Mr. Welsh was preceded in death by his wife, Glenna M. Welsh, his grandson Calley Grant Nickerson and his granddaughter Victoria Welsh. He is survived by his wife Marcia Welsh of Old Lyme, Connecticut, daughter Jane Hamlin of Austin, TX, son Michael Welsh of Helena, MT, daughter Suzy Nickerson of Chatham, Massachusetts, son Mathew Welsh of Alexandria, Virginia, nine grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made, in his name, to the charity of your choice.

title: PC SALES STRONG IN LATIN AMERICA
description: Sales of personal computers in Latin America this year will increase by 30 percent over 1999, according to the International Data Corporation. Laptop sales alone will increase nearly 50 percent over last year, IDC estimated. PC sales are rising, in part, because of falling prices and the increasing availability of systems in local stores, said Alexandra Martinez of IDC. She also said growing Internet use was helping to drive sales. America Online-Latin America, a unit of AOL, which has invested heavily in South America this year, reported that its fourth-quarter revenue rose 55 percent over the previous quarter. Catherine Greenman

But in the last few years, that circle has expanded to include people who watch DVD movies on their computers or edit digital photographs or videos on the weekends. And yes, some of them may even be tempted to play the occasional game of Quake III.

title: Guarding Your Identity

description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries are gathering this week for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS WORKERS STRIKE
description: About 350,000 telecommunications workers in India began a countrywide strike, forcing companies to come up with alternative plans to cope with a likely disruption in communications. The workers are protesting the government's plan to turn the country's telecommunications department into a company without offering assurances that jobs and benefits will be protected. Ram Vilas Paswanm, the communications minister, met with union leaders in a bid to head off the strike, but the unions said assurances were not adequate.

title: Racketeering Is Tied To City Construction
description: Thirty-eight people were charged yesterday in connection with racketeering schemes that prosecutors said siphoned millions of dollars from New York City construction projects and diverted it to the Lucchese family and its partners, corrupt union officials and contractors.

title: George Musso, 90, a Hall of Fame Lineman
description: George Musso, a Hall of Fame lineman and captain of the Chicago Bears when they ruled professional football before and during World War II, died Tuesday in Edwardsville, Ill. He was 90.

title: Teamsters Officials Say Union Is Ready to Endorse Gore
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the most powerful union to withhold a presidential endorsement, will vote today to support Vice President Al Gore, several Teamster officials said yesterday.

title: Budget Plan for Nassau Draws Fire Immediately
description: The budget rescue plan of Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, is so flimsy and lacking in detail that more work needs to be done, soon, to save the county from bankruptcy or from a takeover by a financial control board, critics of the plan said today.

title: Yanks Give Rivera a Rest and Pay the Price
description: Boston could sweep this weekend and the Yankees would still be in first place, so Manager Joe Torre can afford to be judicious and take advantage of the growing division lead. He began the process of reinstalling second baseman Chuck Knoblauch into his lineup tonight, and was intent on resting the closer Mariano Rivera.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rise in Rates Is Not Stemming The Euro's Slide
description: Higher interest rates don't seem to be helping.

title: Life Change for A.C.L.U. Chief. Not That Words Fail Him.
description: FINALLY, Ira Glasser clams up. For several entire nanoseconds, he is embarrassed and fumbling for words.

title: The Words of Many Government Leaders, and Many Views of the World
description: These are excerpts from speeches of world leaders yesterday at the United Nations, drawn from official transcripts:

title: Article 2000090790770272954 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Discovering Early Clues to Where an Albatross Wanders on Its Year Off
description: The wandering albatross did not earn its name by just sitting around. The seabirds, the largest in the world, spend more than 90 percent of their life over the oceans of the Southern Hemisphere, and through banding and satellite tracking have been shown to cover tens of thousands of miles in a breeding season foraging for food.

title: Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume next week.

title: BB&T AGREES TO BUY FIRSTSPARTAN FINANCIAL
description: The BB&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the FirstSpartan Financial Corporation for $103.9 million in stock. FirstSpartan shareholders will swap each of their shares for one BB&T share. The offer values FirstSpartan at $26.88 a share. FirstSpartan owns First Federal Bank, which has 11 branches in South Carolina. The company, based in Spartanburg, S.C., has $591 million in assets, bringing BB&T's total assets in the state to $5.8 billion. The acquisition is BB&T's ninth this year, said Bob Denham, a BB&T spokesman. FirstSpartan shares rose $6.38, to $26.75. BB&T's shares rose 50 cents, to $27.38.

title: Globalization Tops 3-Day U.N. Agenda for World Leaders
description: The stormy battle over globalization that brought protests to the streets of Seattle and Washington moves this week to the heart of the world's only truly global organization, the United Nations.

title: Clinton, At the U.N.: 'Aspirations Pile High'
description: Following is a transcript of the address given today by President Clinton at the United Nations, as provided by the White House:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about arrests of protesters in advance of the Millennium Summit at the United Nations, including that of a man accused of throwing yellow paint at the Iranian delegation's motorcade, misstated the starting day of the meeting. It was yesterday, not Monday.

title: Controversial Education Study
description: Anew analysis of recent research into the use of technology in the classroom is being praised by some educators and policymakers, but critics are already questioning its conclusions and its credibility.

title: Selective School Prayer
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefings
description: INTERNETPUBLIC MEETINGS ABOUT INTERNET The Internet Policy Institute, a Washington-based independent research organization, plans to hold eight "town hall" meetings to gather grass-roots information on Internet policies and will present its findings to the next president after the November elections. The meetings are being held jointly with eight universities across the country to get "outside the Beltway" views on the Internet, said James L. Barksdale, former president and chief executive of Netscape Communications and chairman of the institute, which is nonpartisan. Leslie Wayne (NYT)

title: 3 U.N. Aid Workers Killed In Attack in West Timor
description: A mob led by militiamen brandishing automatic rifles and homemade firearms attacked a United Nations refugee office in West Timor today, killing three staff members, including a person from Puerto Rico, and possibly another aid worker. The attack prompted outrage halfway around the world at a summit meeting of world leaders here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, PHILIP
description: SCHULTZ-Philip. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of our beloved member and supporter, Philip Schultz. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Mark Goldstein, President

title: Bridge Tournament
description: The semifinals of the World Championship of bridge in Maastricht, the Netherlands, ended too late yesterday for inclusion in this section. A report appears in Section B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPORE, MICHAEL J.
description: LEPORE-Michael J., M.D. The Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital mourns with sorrow the passing of a dear friend, mentor and esteemed colleague. Dr. Lepore joined our faculty in 1966 as Chief of the Section of Gastroenterology and Director of the Upjohn GI Unit. Dr. Lepore's research and medical practice enhanced the lives of thousands of grateful patients. He authored over 65 publications and textbooks. In 1982 he wrote ''Death of the Clinician'' a book in which he examined how education overemphasizes the science of medicine to the neglect of the art of caring for the sick. A physician of great courage, wisdon and intensity, he was a fierce and vocal advocate of the private practice of medicine and the sacred patient-physician bond. We will forever cherish the memory of this champion of medicine and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his son Frederick. Joseph M. Jabbour, M.D. President of the Medical Staff St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center

title: Senate Run Is Ruled Legal for Lieberman
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 6 -- Senator Joseph Lieberman can run for both the vice presidency and re-election to the Senate, the Connecticut Elections Enforcement Commission decided today.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE INTEREST GROUPS

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER HYUNDAI STAKE
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. has been given approval by the Hyundai Motor Company of Korea to buy a 9 percent stake in the company, giving the German company a place in Asia's truck market. DaimlerChrysler will pay 430.9 billion won ($389 million), or 20,900 won a share, for the stake and will set terms to buy an additional 0.99 percent soon, Hyundai Motor said. The price is a 25 percent premium to Hyundai Motor's closing price of 16,700 won.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the finances of Dick Cheney, the Republican candidate for vice president, misstated his reason for having rejected $89,500 in honorariums from 1992 to 1999 and having directed them to charity. The action was voluntary, not required.

title: Bush Says Hell Shift Approach To Interact More With Voters
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 7  Gov. George W. Bush today dismissed criticism from some Republicans over the direction of his campaign, but said he would reshape his effort to show him in more settings interacting with voters.

title: Economic Scene; It's good times, not bad, that nurture the enemies of the free market.
description: IN a recent speech to economists gathered in Jackson Hole, Wyo., the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned that neither continued economic liberalization nor high economic growth was inevitable. Recent productivity gains have been above the norm, he said, driven by the ''accelerating application of new insights'' in technology. As those innovations reach their limits, he suggested, growth will drop to a lower, historically more normal level.

title: An Independent Taiwan
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Agency And Con Ed Faulted in Leak At Indian Point
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 31  In the most scathing report prompted by the accident at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in February, an independent monitor has found that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission conducted inadequate plant inspections as far back as 1997 and relied on flawed analyses, inexperienced staff members and the company it was supposed to regulate.

title: Brasilia Journal; Crusading Prosecutor Delights and Amazes Many
description: To his enemies, whose numbers seem to be growing by the day, Luiz Francisco de Souza is ''the Torquemada of Brasilia,'' a reincarnation of the fanatic priest who commanded the Spanish Inquisition.

title: Robert Kennedy Jr. Endorses Hillary Clinton
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate candidacy yesterday, declaring that she would show leadership on environmental concerns he champions and would overcome the ''carpetbagger'' tag that also threatened his father's bid for a Senate seat from New York in 1964.

title: French Nazi Memorabilia Case Presents Jurisdiction Dilemma
description: In Europe, where memories of World War II are still fresh in the minds of those who lived through it, the sale of Nazi and Fascist memorabilia often sparks indignation.

title: Teenagers Accused of Killing for a Free Meal
description: It looked at first like a botched robbery: the owner of a Chinese takeout restaurant making a food delivery was lured late Friday night to a dark dead-end street in Queens, where he was jumped and bludgeoned to death. The killers left him with $600.

title: Sierra Club Endorses Hillary Clinton as Better Environmental Ally
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 5  Hillary Rodham Clinton today won the endorsement of the Sierra Club, one of the nation's oldest environmental groups, whose backing set off a duel between the Senate candidates over who has done more to protect natural resources.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: EUROCLEAR ACQUISITIONS
description: Euroclear, the world's largest securities clearing and settlement company, has agreed to acquire 51 percent of the settlement agencies for the Brussels and Amsterdam stock exchanges as it streamlines its activities in anticipation of the merger of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels Exchanges on Sept. 22. Terms were not disclosed. Suzanne Kapner

title: Article 2000090791302004810 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: NASA Pushes Back Space-Station Finish
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. - NASA has again extended its deadline for completion of the International Space Station, which is now targeted for 2006, a space-station official said Wednesday.

title: Governments Business Goes Online
description: Last December, when the government was in the throes of Year 2000 anxiety, e-commerce initiatives barely crossed the minds of many federal officials. Not that e-commerce executives particularly cared: with their companies' stock prices climbing and much larger markets in their sights, they could afford to look past the government as a place to do business.

title: Excerpts From a Memo About a Possible Recall
description: Following are excerpts from an internal Ford Motor Company memorandum dated March 12, 1999, referring to concerns about the possibility of a tire recall in Saudi Arabia. In the first section, which was made available to reporters on Tuesday, Ford indicates that Firestone opposed a recall there for fear that the tire maker would have to report it to United States regulators.

title: Why the 15-Student Class Is Just a Nice Theory
description: More than 78,000 New York City public school teachers reported for work yesterday, preparing for the arrival tomorrow of 1.1 million students.

title: Questioning the Labor Shortage
description: To alleviate apparent shortages of computer programmers, President Clinton and Congress have agreed to raise a quota on H-1B's, the temporary visas for skilled foreigners. The annual limit will go to 200,000 next year, up from 65,000 only three years ago.

title: Justice Won't Keep Wrestler Off Team
description: Rejecting an emergency request by the United States Olympic Committee, a Supreme Court justice refused to keep the Greco-Roman wrestler Matt Lindland off the American team soon to leave for Sydney, Australia.

title: Bush on Issues and Tactics in the Presidential Race
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ANNE M.
description: ROSENTHAL-Anne M., 93. Died September 1, 2000 at Waterside Retirement Estates in Sarasota, Florida. She was born November 11, 1906 in New York City and lived in Sarasota since 1972. A graduate of Hunter College, she worked as a teacher of children with impaired vision and later as an accountant at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Her survivors include two nephews, Stephen and Eugene Rosenthal. She was predeceased by a brother, Joseph Rosenthal and a sister, Ruth Feiring.

title: NORDSTROM TO BUY FACONNABLE, A TOP SELLER IN ITS STORES
description: Nordstrom Inc., the Seattle-based department store chain, said yesterday that it planned to buy the French clothing company Faconnable S.A. for undisclosed terms. The purchase would give Nordstrom worldwide control of the Faconnable brand, which is sold in the United States and 23 other countries and is one of the retailer's top sellers. Nordstrom already owns exclusive rights to distribute Faconnable products in the United States. Nordstrom is trying to remake its image after fashion missteps and inventory problems alienated shoppers and hurt its profit.

title: Clinton Talks With Barak And Arafat: No Progress
description: In back-to-back sessions this evening, President Clinton met with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and then the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to salvage the progress made in peace talks last month, but afterward the White House said there was little movement.

title: Defending Napster To the Editor:
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZILIAN CAR SALES
description: Sales of cars and trucks in Brazil rose in August from a year earlier as a decline in interest rates bolstered economic growth and increased demand for big-ticket items. Sales of Brazilian-made and imported vehicles to dealers rose 15 percent, to the highest level since March 1999, and production of cars, trucks and buses rose 27 percent, to the highest level in more than two years.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Fret at Lapses In Bush's Race
description: Prominent Republicans around the country, including several who advise Gov. George W. Bush, say they are worried that his candidacy has floundered in recent weeks, allowing Vice President Al Gore to build on his velocity from the Democratic convention in a way that they never expected.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column last Thursday about the return of Roger Cedeno, the Houston Astros outfielder, to Calidad Latina, a Manhattan restaurant he frequented when he played for the Mets, misspelled the surname of the Houston teammate who joined him. He is Tony Eusebio, not Escibio.

title: Large L.C.D. Monitor Built for Work, Not Fun
description: There is one major drawback to conventional cathode ray tube monitors: as the screen size expands, so does the plastic box out back. Flatter liquid crystal displays, which take up less desk space, eliminate that problem.

title: Sex and the Sitting Room
description: I JUST hope I don't pick up a fake English accent,'' Candace Bushnell said, reaching for a glass of Champagne. It was proffered by a dapper butler on hand one evening to serve her and some 25 British and American guests cocktails and blinis laden with caviar.

title: Launching of Shuttle Will Begin Push to Complete Space Outpost
description: The space shuttle Atlantis is set to head for the International Space Station on Friday, beginning an intense push to finish the long-delayed orbital research outpost.

title: In Sharp Debate on Freedoms, Top Hong Kong Educators Resign
description: Two top officials at Hong Kong University resigned today after an investigation found that they and an adviser to the territory's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, had pressed a prominent pollster not to publish surveys critical of Mr. Tung.

title: 650 Professors Strike
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Sept. 5 (AP)  More than 650 full- time faculty members at Eastern Michigan University went on strike today after contract talks broke off.

title: Metro Business; Foster Wheeler Wins Drug Plant Contract
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation has been awarded a $200 million contract to build a bulk pharmaceuticals plant for the Schering-Plough Corporation in Singapore.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: The Illusion of Outdoor Living, A Splash Away From Falling Water
description: When John and Ann Bender bought 5,000 acres near San Isidro, Costa Rica, they wanted a transparent home opposite a 600-foot waterfall. ''They want to feel that they are living outside,'' said Ismael Leyva, a Manhattan architect who is designing the 8,000-square-foot house, rendered below. The walls will be glass panels framed by steel cables; there will be nine rooms on five levels, all facing the waterfall, 150 feet away. The translucent woven fiberglass roof will be tensile. Inside, there will be a reflecting pool and water cascading down interior walls. Completion is set for 2002, at a cost of over $2 million.

title: Raymond James Buys Canadian Firm
description: Raymond James Financial Inc. has agreed to acquire Goepel McDermid Inc., a closely held securities firm based in Vancouver, British Columbia, for 125 million Canadian dollars ($84.7 million). Raymond James, based in St. Petersburg, said the acquisition would reduce its earnings per share ''slightly'' in the first year after closing and add to profit after that. The company will pay for the amount in cash and up to one million of its common shares. Goepel McDermid, one of Canada's largest securities firms not owned by a bank, will help Raymond James, which has just one Canadian office in Calgary, Alberta, extend its brokerage, underwriting and advisory services through 25 branches across the country. Goepel McDermid has 250 investment advisers.

title: Risking Chinas Ire, Taiwan Leader Questions Unification
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 1  Since he came to power in May, Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, has labored to convince China that he is not a wild-eyed separatist, driven by dreams of Taiwanese independence.

title: Contraptions' Hardest Puzzle: How to Stop
description: AFTER a week immersed in Return of the Incredible Machine: Contraptions, I found strange thoughts bubbling up in my head.

title: Chinese Withdraw 6 Runners And Coach
description: Ma Junren, the controversial coach of China's female distance runners, was removed from the Olympic team along with six of his athletes following suspicious results in domestic drug tests, Chinese officials said today.

title: More Fans For Drugs That Fight Cholesterol
description: In the 13 years since they were introduced in the United States, the cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins have revolutionized the treatment of heart disease. Study after study has shown these drugs prevent heart attacks and prolong lives, with very few side effects. It is estimated that five million people are taking the drugs, which have rapidly become the best- selling prescriptions in this country.

title: Wired World Awaits Olympics
description: THREE years ago, while touring Britain, Philip Dean had to use Internet connections at local universities to e- mail home.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Debates, and Other Skirmishes
description: To the Editor:

title: Life on Earth (Condensed)
description: READING the telephone book used to be a joke until List magazine, also exclusively a collection of lists, appeared in June. Four thousand copies later (at $15 a pop), the new magazine's last laugh is the next item on the editors' list: Issue 2 arrives in October. The white pages, at least, are free.

title: A Plea for Early Intervention In the Hot Spots of the World
description: Less than two weeks after experts told the United Nations that it needed an in-house policy center to work on areas of tension before they turn into international crises, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda came along this week with a case in point.

title: Budget Plan for Nassau Draws Fire Immediately
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 6  The budget rescue plan of Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, is so flimsy and lacking in detail that more work needs to be done, soon, to save the county from bankruptcy or from a takeover by a financial control board, critics of the plan said today.

title: Web Entrepreneurs Stepping Aside
description: Like many senior-level Internet executives, Christine Harmel, chief executive of Interactive Resource, a firm in Manhattan that matches Web site developers with clients, was present at the birth of e-commerce. Working on the Net since 1995, Harmel, 32, has experienced years of 80-hour workweeks and has watched the industry transform itself from a stomping ground for young workaholics who wanted to change the world, into a stomping ground for young workaholics who want to change their tax brackets.

title: Corzine Gains Endorsement, But Not Without a Stumble
description: Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, stopped by the New Jersey State House today for what looked like an easy afternoon's work: accepting the endorsement of the state's largest environmental group, the Sierra Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, THOMAS LELAND
description: HUGHES-Thomas Leland. 19242000. He graduated from Yale College and Yale Law School and served in WWII in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific. He revalidated his law degree in Venezuela, where he spent 45 years, and headed one of the prominent, originally American law firms. He was dedicated to his profession and worked for the advancement of the underprivileged. He dedicated his life to help people. He was very active in all civic activites and was President of AACLA (Association of American Chambers of Commerce of Latin America) and President of the Venezuelan/ American Chamber of Commerce and the North American Association. His generosity and fairness will never be forgotten. He was a most loving husband to Erika and loving father to Maria. Funeral service Friday, September 8th, Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave and 81 St at 11AM.

title: At Harlem School, Add Camby to the Roll Call
description: Even as he was leaping high above the rim and leading Hartford Public High School to two state championships, Marcus Camby never counted on playing in the National Basketball Association. Instead, Camby planned for a more realistic career.

title: REGULATORS CLEAR PURCHASE OF AXENT BY SYMANTEC
description: The Symantec Corporation, the largest maker of computer security software for consumers, said it had cleared an antitrust hurdle in its plan to buy a rival, Axent Technologies Inc. Symantec said the regulatory waiting period for examining antitrust issues had expired, and the government did not object to the purchase. The acquisition, expected to be completed by the end of the year, still needs approval by both companies' shareholders. Symantec, based in Cupertino, Calif., makes Norton AntiVirus software. Axent sells software for blocking and monitoring hacker attacks on corporate networks.

title: F.B.I. DEFENDS E-MAIL TAPPING PROGRAM
description: Officials from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department defended the Carnivore e-mail surveillance system yesterday, asserting that the program was used only after all other investigative methods had been exhausted. In remarks before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Kevin V. Di Gregory, deputy assistant attorney general, urged the continued use of the program ''as criminal activity migrates to the Internet.''

title: Newark Group Seeks Downtown Development
description: The foundation started more than two years ago to help spur and direct further redevelopment after the New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened here is seeking developers to help create a downtown residential and retail district.

title: Bush Sets Campaigns Sites on Washington Military Policy
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 7  Fighting to regain his footing after weeks of setbacks and missteps, Gov. George W. Bush said today that he was reshaping his campaign to show him in more settings interacting with voters.

title: No Concessions to Clear Its Merger, America Online Says
description: Despite unusually sharp criticism from European antitrust regulators, executives of Time Warner and America Online do not plan to offer any concessions to clear their proposed merger plans when they meet regulators behind closed doors here on Thursday, company executives said today.

title: Daimler to Review Chrysler Accounts
description: The DaimlerChrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. -- known as the Chrysler Corporation before being acquired by Daimler-Benz -- said unexpectedly last night that it would begin a review on accounts with billings estimated at $1.2 billion. The assignments, now divided between two agencies, may be consolidated at a single shop.

title: Tracking TV Preferences
description: To the Editor:

title: Summit Watching: Who Was That Man in the Suit?
description: The television cameras and reporters raced across the marble lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria and swarmed around the Chinese man in a dark suit. Was he a high-ranking party official? Perhaps President Jiang Zemin himself?

title: Judge Rules Against MP3 On CD Copying
description: Ruling that the online music start-up company MP3.com had willfully infringed the copyrights of the Universal Music Group, a federal judge yesterday ordered the company to pay potentially crippling damages in one of the first cases to test the legal boundaries of digital music distribution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABRICANT, DOROTHY
description: FABRICANT-Dorothy. On September 5, 2000. Beloved wife of Benjamin Fabricant and the late Frank Benjamin. Mother of Carole Kasmin, Dr. Stephen Benjamin, Laura Benjamin and Susan Hess. Sister to Dr. Harold Zweighaft and the late Sidney Zweighaft. Motherin-law to Allan Kasmin, Barbara Benjamin, Barbara Schwartz and Sam Hess. Sister-in-law to Dorothy Zweighaft and Renee Zweighaft. Treasured grandmother and great grandmother, aunt and cousin. Passed away after a long, dignified and brave battle with cancer. She will be proudly remembered by all those she touched with her caring, concern and love. Her dignity in life and in passing remains our legacy. Her passion for living, our example. Her intellect and curiousity for life our goal. She will be sorely missed. Services at The Riverside, 180 West 76 Street, NYC on September 7, at 12:45 PM.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: An Overload On a Party Circuit

title: John Thompson III Gets Princeton Job
description: John Thompson III was named coach of the Princeton men's basketball team yesterday, following the career path of his father, who built Georgetown into a basketball power. The appointment came on the same day Bill Carmody left to become coach of Northwestern.

title: Fast Women, But Watch It
description: A small British magazine recently ran a cover feature on the Berlin-based female trio Chicks on Speed that didn't sit well with the band. The image on the cover was of a vivacious female model on a motorcycle with the words ''We've Got Chicks on Speed'' serving as a tag line.

title: Ariane Rocket Launches Satellite
description: KOUROU French Guiana, Sept 6 - Western Europe's 132nd Ariane rocket blasted off on Wednesday from French Guiana to place in orbit a satellite for the Paris-based satellite operator Eutelsat.

title: Newark Group Seeks Downtown Development
description: NEWARK, Sept. 6  The foundation started more than two years ago to help spur and direct further redevelopment after the New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened here is seeking developers to help create a downtown residential and retail district.

title: U.S. and Europeans Raising the Stakes in Trade Impasse
description: The European Union and the United States are holding fast in several trade disputes, their continued standoff threatening a more punishing confrontation between the two trading blocs, the world's biggest.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's; Clarion Calls To Honor Armstrong's Centennial
description: Louis Armstrong is receiving the treatment he deserves in his centennial year: a thorough sonic overhaul and repackaging of most of his major work. Here are three Armstrong sets that have emerged in recent months.

title: It's a Soap Opera in Shoulder Pads Offers a New Episode on Monday
description: There are enough subplots here to fuel a prime-time soap opera, enough tightly wound coaches to require a stress-management clinic, enough thinly veiled salvos to mandate a flak jacket.

title: The Ad Campaign: Doubts About Real Voters
description: This is a new 15-second commercial, called "The Ringer," that the Lazio campaign began broadcasting statewide yesterday. The advertisement responds to a recent commercial by the New York State Democratic Party that says it features interviews with "real" New Yorkers, who express surprise and dismay with the voting record of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican candidate for United States Senate. The Lazio commercial tries to sharply question the credibility of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, pointing out that one of the "real voters" featured in the Democratic advertisement is a former employee of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly.

title: Court to Consider Bail for Scientist In Secrets Case
description: An appeals court announced today that it would hold a hearing on Monday on whether Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets, could be released from prison on bail pending trial.

title: Style Fantasies Show the Influence of a Photographers Stark Reality
description: In the half-dozen or so fashion shoots he has done, most of them for W magazine during the past few years, Philip-Lorca diCorcia has staged unnerving narratives like one titled "A Perfect World," in which things don't seem perfect at all. Here, a patrician housewife, frozen looking, her face harshly lighted, appears as if she'd need no more than a few shots of Tanqueray and a splash of Schwepps to push her into doing something Medea-like. In another series, set in Havana, a model is cast as a disconsolate-looking Batista-era office worker who is equally blank in her nighttime job as a call girl. Should the reader forget that there are dresses to be looked at, the text alerts you: "Havana was once a nightclub hot spot. These days, it's the perfect backdrop for sober day clothes or racy little evening looks. Think brief, briefer, briefest."

title: MetroStars Hope Goalie Is a Keeper
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5  One game may not be enough evidence, but the MetroStars have most likely found a goalkeeper for the Major League Soccer playoffs that start next week. The problem is they will have to share Paul Grafer with the Long Island Rough Riders of the A-League.

title: Teenager Appears at Hacker Trial
description: The person who kicked off a huge legal battle involving Hollywood and the Internet is a skinny, 16-year-old Norwegian computer programmer who, with his serious face, wire-rimmed glasses and almost-there mustache, could maybe pass for 17.

title: Defending Napster To the Editor:
description: To the Editor:

title: Assessing Linking Liability
description: As law professors love to say, consider the following hypothetical case:

title: Golota Prepares for Tyson
description: Andrew Golota, whose most notable and most notorious moments as a heavyweight involved low blows that twice got him disqualified in bouts with Riddick Bowe in 1996, would seem to be the ideal lighted match to toss into the Mike Tyson powder keg in their 10-round bout Oct. 20 at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: 38 Are Charged In Mob Control Of Construction In the City
description: The Manhattan district attorney charged 38 union officials, contractors and reputed mobsters yesterday with bribery, bid-rigging or other racketeering schemes that he said siphoned millions of dollars from construction projects in the last two years.

title: How, but Not Why, the Brain Distinguishes Race
description: After a decade of mapping brains in tasks like recalling numbers, perceiving facial expressions and using verbs, neuroscientists have recently homed in on a much more controversial subject: the act of categorizing other human beings.

title: ENRON IN DEAL TO SUPPLY ENERGY TO 6 STARWOODS HOTELS
description: The Enron Corporation, the country's largest buyer and seller of natural gas, said yesterday that its Enron Energy Services unit had received a 10-year, $1 billion contract from Starwoods Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. for energy management services. Enron, based in Houston, with $40.1 billion in revenue last year, said it would supply electricity and natural gas to six Starwoods-owned hotels in North America and would manage the energy infrastructure at the hotels. Starwoods is based in White Plains.

title: COATS VIYELLA TO CUT JOBS
description: The Coats Viyella Group P.L.C., Britain's biggest textile maker, with brands that include Van Heusen and Jaeger, said it would sell off clothing and other divisions and cut about 1,900 jobs, dealing a blow to the ailing British textile industry. The move follows a decision by Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the largest British clothing retailer and Coats Viyella's biggest customer, to trim inventories as its business slumps. Coats Viyella said it would focus on its global threads business. Alan Cowell

title: New Data Suggests Some Cannibalism By Ancient Indians
description: Scientists have found what they say is the first direct evidence of cannibalism among prehistoric Indians in the American Southwest, belying the image of these people as steadfastly peaceful farmers.

title: Students Show Few Gains in Reading Skills
description: Despite years of efforts to improve education, American students today read no better than their predecessors a generation ago, and their basic math skills have advanced only slightly, according to a new analysis of standardized tests given since the early 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIMICKE, VICTOR W.
description: EIMICKE-Victor W. The Trustees and Staff of the National Bible Association express a profound sense of loss and sorrow upon the death of Dr. Victor W. Eimicke, their colleague and friend. Dr. Eimicke began his relationship with the Association as a volunteer in 1969. Elected to the Board of Trustees in 1975, he has served as treasurer, president and chairman of the Board. His love for the Scriptures informed and shaped his life and character, making him the family man, churchman, and business leader whom we loved and respected. His wise counsel and generous spirit will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our prayers and deepest sympathy to his wife, Maxine, his daughters Laura and Alicia, and the other members of his family. ''Well done, thou good and faithful servant: enter thou into the joy of thy Lord.'' Thomas R. May, President Stewart S. Furlong, Chairman National Bible Association

title: U.N. Summit Focues on the Divide Between Rich and Poor Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7  Resentment at a widening gap between rich and poor nations came to the fore today as a succession of leaders attending the United Nations' millennium summit meeting demanded, with passion and often eloquence, that the industrialized world show more tangible charity toward the countries being left behind.

title: Agassi Out Of Olympics
description: Andre Agassi, the defending Olympic gold medalist in men's singles, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing from the Sydney Olympics, and made it clear that he was doing so because both his sister, Tammee, and his mother, Elizabeth, have breast cancer.

title: This Is Not Your Parents' Bathroom
description: Tile is the focal point of two new stores. When the Dia Center for the Arts reopens on Sept. 13, the bookstore and gallery will be tiled in dazzling colors, below left. Jorge Pardo, a Los Angeles artist who designed the tilework, believes the all-white gallery space is a cliche. ''I wanted to set up a different aesthetic,'' he said. ''The raw material of the space is color.'' The gallery will exhibit ''Jorge Pardo: Project,'' a show of his tiles and art, through June, 2002. Trompe l'oeil Bisazza tiles arranged to look like the belly of an alligator turn up at Tardini, a new SoHo shop that sells handbags made from alligator, lizard and python. Fabio Novembre, an architect from Milan who designed the shop, is the art director of Bisazza, a tile manufacturer in Vicenza, Italy. Dia is at 548 West 22nd Street; Tardini is at 142 Wooster Street (near Houston Street.)

title: Pinochet Appeal for Unity
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 84, facing a possible trial for human rights abuses during his 17-year dictatorship, urged Chileans today to put the past behind them and focus on the future.

title: Cheney More Generous by His Own Numbers
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 5  Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, today defended his charitable contributions as "appropriate" and insisted he should be given credit not only for direct contributions but also for speaking fees he directed to charity and for corporate gifts that matched his own donations.

title: First, Three Big Debates
description: No events in a presidential campaign are more crucial to public involvement in the electoral process than the cycle of debates involving the major candidates in the fall. This week, however, Gov. George W. Bush is demanding that instead of three televised encounters sponsored by the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates that has run the events since 1988, only one such debate take place, coupled with two other joint appearances with Vice President Al Gore  one on "Meet the Press" and the other on "Larry King Live."

title: In a break from its meat-and-potatoes past, ABC creates a unified front for sales and marketing.
description: THE No. 1 television network in viewers and advertising revenue, ABC, is reorganizing and expanding its sales and marketing efforts. The goal is to offer sponsors an easier way to buy everything from commercials during ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and ads in Disney Adventures magazine to banner ads on ESPN.com and spots on a giant video screen perched atop the ''Good Morning America'' studio in Times Square.

title: GUARDIAN LIFE PLANS TO TAKE OVER BERKSHIRE LIFE
description: The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, a New York insurer with $31.7 billion in assets under management, said yesterday that it planned to take over the Berkshire Life Insurance Company, based in Pittsfield, Mass., with $1.5 billion in assets under management. There will be no exchange of cash in the merger, but Guardian will assume responsibility for Berkshire's operations. Both companies are highly rated mutual insurers formally owned by their policyholders. Joseph D.
