Sargent, the chief executive of Guardian, will serve as the chief executive of the combined company, which will operate under the Guardian name. Joseph B. Treaster

title: Metro Business; Software Center in India
description: The Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation, an Internet software maker based in Teaneck, N.J., said yesterday that it had opened a center in Bangalore, India, its ninth in the country. The center will provide wireless and mobile commerce technology to telecommunications companies.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: QUEENS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the finances of Dick Cheney, the Republican candidate for vice president, misstated his reason for having rejected $89,500 in honorariums from 1992 to 1999 and having directed them to charity. The action was voluntary, not required.

title: New Image Technology Can Drive Shadows Away
description: THE megapixel race has been the whole game in digital cameras for the past two years, as the cameras have gone from one megapixel or less to sharper, clearer images of nearly four megapixels.

title: The Bush Prescription Drug Plan
description: Gov. George W. Bush announced a proposal on Tuesday to provide prescription drug benefits as an option under comprehensive Medicare reform. But since he does not expect such reform to happen anytime soon, he wants state governments to deal with the problem while a new White House task force works out the details of future reforms.

title: Texan Who Backed Bush Ads Helps Lazio in Raising Funds
description: GREECE, N.Y., Sept. 5  When John McCain lost the New York Republican presidential primary last spring, he placed a large part of the blame on what he asserted was an illegal $2.5 million advertising campaign that attacked his environmental record and had been financed by two wealthy Texas brothers with close ties to Gov. George W. Bush, Mr. McCain's opponent.

title: Australian Action Reopens Dispute on Human Rights Monitors
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 30  A decision by Australia to limit its cooperation with the United Nations on human rights reporting has reopened a debate about whether international monitors are sometimes harder on democracies than on closed societies.

title: Citigroup to Buy Associates First for $31 Billion
description: Continuing its campaign to become the dominant financial services provider around the globe, Citigroup said yesterday that it would buy the Associates First Capital Corporation, the biggest American consumer finance company, for about $31.1 billion in stock.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS BUYING REST OF MERIDIAN
description: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., the No. 2 United States supplier of sand and gravel, said yesterday that it would buy the remaining stake in the Meridian Aggregates Company, a producer of crushed stone, for $193 million. The deal will help Martin Marietta, based in Raleigh, N.C., expand in the southwestern and central United States. Martin Marietta got an option to buy all of Meridian, based in Denver, by investing $42 million in 1998.

title: Clinton Warns U.N. of a New Age of Civil Wars
description: President Clinton opened the summit meeting of world leaders at the United Nations today, urging the huge gathering to prepare the institution for a new age in which international forces will have to reach regularly and rapidly inside national boundaries to protect threatened people.

title: U.N.'s Global Compact
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Leads Security Council To New Definitions, Solutions
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7  Led by President Clinton, the Security Council moved unexpectedly but certainly today toward a new role for itself in a world where the rules of war have been rewritten by warlords, where the poor kill the poor over dwindling natural resources and most of the dead are civilians.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Bush Spells Out Major Overhaul in Medicare Plan
description: SCRANTON Pa., Sept. 5  Gov. George W. Bush today proposed a fundamental overhaul of the 35-year- old federal Medicare program that would encourage recipients to choose subsidized private health insurance plans that include prescription drug coverage.

title: State Dept. Says Payoff of Colombian Anti-Cocaine Offensive Is Years Down the Road : Drug Flow Will First Get Worse, U.S. Predicts
description: WASHINGTON  U.S. officials said Wednesday that the flow of illicit drugs from Colombia might get worse over the next year or two before the new Colombian plan, supported by substantial U.S. military and development aid, begins to bring it down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTKESKI, JESSIE CLEVERDON
description: MINTKESKI-Jessie Cleverdon. Of Manhasset, NY, born 1914 in New York City, died on August 30, 2000. Beloved wife of Eugene Mintkeski. Loving mother of Walter Mintkeski and his wife Vicki. Devoted grandmother of Tyler and Charles. Mrs. Mintkeski graduated from Wellesley College in 1935 and is a member of Wellesley on Long Island. Contributions in her memory may be made to Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass. Private memorial service was held at the family home.

title: NORTHROP ACQUIRING CARLYLE'S FEDERAL DATA UNIT
description: The military contractor Northrop Grumman agreed yesterday to buy the Federal Data Corporation from the Carlyle Group, a private investment firm, for about $302 million to strengthen its information-technology business. Northrop will pay about $127 million in cash, assume $157 million in debt and cover $18 million in transaction costs. Federal Data, based in Bethesda, Md., provides computer networking to government agencies including the Veterans Administration, the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Northrop, based in Los Angeles, plans to fold Federal Data into its Logicon information-technology unit.

title: C.I.A. Is Said to Find Iraq Gives Contracts to Nations That Want to End Economic Sanctions
description: The Central Intelligence Agency says Iraq has consistently used the United Nations' oil-for-food program to reward countries that call for ending economic sanctions against Iraq, and to punish those that oppose lifting the embargo, administration officials familiar with the findings have said.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Westland, Mich.; Dayton, Ohio, and Pittsburgh

title: Notre Dame Coach Is Calm Facing Pressure
description: In the past week, he was upstaged by a nun who earned a standing ovation at the kickoff luncheon. He has offered acts of contrition, as well as faith, about his ability to coach and recruit. He uncharacteristically pumped his arms in the air asking for more celebration after a season-opening victory. He has ignored the names rocketing through cyberspace and landing in newspapers about his possible replacement.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: In Some States, Speeders Cool Their Heels in Online Classes
description: SUE WELSH got a speeding ticket this year. Facing a point on her license and a possible increase in insurance rates, she had two options. She could go to a state-sponsored traffic safety school to wipe out any penalty on her license or go to court to contest the charge and take her chances with the judge.

title: S.E.C. Names 33 in Internet-Fraud Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused 33 companies and individuals today of fraudulently using the Internet to make more than $10 million in illegal profits by driving up the prices of more than 70 small stocks.

title: On Some Corporate Internet Sites, It's Not All Business
description: WORK and play have a wonderful way of merging on the Internet. Take the prosaic corporate site. There is probably not much you can do to liven up, say, North American Veeblefetzer: product pictures, locations, corporate staff, how to order, shareholder information, Our Founder, and so on.

title: High-Tech Systems for Keeping Your Keys Safe
description: WHEN three apartments in an Upper East Side building were burglarized this spring, it was clearly an inside job by someone with keys, detectives from the 17th Precinct decided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHEA, ALEXANDER DODSON
description: RHEA-Alexander Dodson, III. Mr. Rhea of New York City and The Greenbrier, West Virginia, died in New York City Friday, September 1, 2000. He was born in Whitney, Texas. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne Menocal Rhea. He is also survived by his sister, Dorothy Rhea of Fort Worth, Texas. Mr. Rhea graduated from Princeton University. During World War II, he served with the United States Navy with rank of Commander in the North Atlantic and Pacific Theaters. His career with General Motors Overseas Operations covered assignments in the New York office, Mexico, South America, Europe and Australia. He was Chairman and Managing Director of Vauxhall Motors, Limited in the United Kingdom and Chairman of the General Motors Corporation European Advisory Council in London.

title: Back From the Beach and Bound for Toronto; Film Festival Has Enough Prestige That It Can Virtually Ignore Its Own Anniversary
description: The beach chairs are back in the garage, the children have returned to the custody of their teachers, summer's hot breath has taken on the faint scent of autumn and, once again, the publicists are returning to Ontario.

title: Debates, and Other Skirmishes
description: To the Editor:

title: Renovate Lambeau? Yes or No
description: MORE and more, the password in sports is "stadium." If a franchise doesn't have a new or renovated stadium or arena, it wants one. The Yankees and the Mets do. The Jets and the Islanders do. The Devils and the Nets want to share one. There has even been talk of a new Madison Square Garden for the Knicks and the Rangers. New ballparks opened this year in Detroit, San Francisco and Houston; another will open next year in Milwaukee.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKE, EMANUEL
description: LOCKE-Emanuel. Of Riverdale, NY. Died on September 3 at age 95. Husband, brother, father, grandfather, great - grandfather and uncle. He is survived by his wife, Ethel; by his sister Sarah Kapner of Flushing, New York; by his son Gordon & his wife, Karen, of New Rochelle, NY, with their sons Jeffrey, Scott, and Steven and his wife, Laura; by his son Stanley Locke and his wife, Jane, of Norwalk, CT, with their children Ilene; Cathy-Lynn, her husband, Louis Schwartz, & son, Alexander; Peter, his wife, Noelle, and children Peter and Shelley; and by a stepson, Norman Weitzman, of Manhattan. Services will be on Wednesday, September 6 at noon at The Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Shiva will be observed by Gordon, Ethel, Sarah and Norman on Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9; Friday, 3-5; Saturday 79; and Sunday 1-4, at 74 Sheldrake Place, New Rochelle. By Stanley on Wednesday 5-9:30; and on Thursday, at 17 Deerwood Court, Norwalk.

title: For This Couple, The Royal Tour Starts Here; Belgian Prince and Princess Have New York in Sight
description: The royals are coming.

title: Attacking Gore Over Debates
description: Gov. George W. Bush's campaign announced yesterday that it would begin running a new commercial attacking Vice President Al Gore's credibility on the issue of debates. The 30-second spot is to run in select markets in some, but not all, of the 17 closely contested states where the Bush campaign is already running commercials. But campaign officials declined to name the states.

title: Temptation, in Spike Heels And a Devilish Price Tag
description: HERE is how I am used to shopping on the Internet. I arrive at an online store that reminds me of a file cabinet, with all the merchandise tucked away in tabbed folders. I click on the appropriate folder. Inside I find a brochure for each item, with a short description, a price and sometimes a simple image to confirm that yes, this is the specific thing I have been trying to track down.

title: Article 2000090793198012821 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: School Board, Facing Suit, Agrees to Recognize Gay Club
description: A suburban Los Angeles school district has reached an agreement to recognize a group of gay students and their supporters. The decision would settle a federal lawsuit challenging the district's refusal to allow it to meet as a student club.

title: Equal Pay on the Tennis Court
description: It may not have Wimbledon's all-white dress code or perfectly manicured grass, but the United States Open is the classiest of all Grand Slam tennis tournaments. That is because the tournament, currently being played in Queens, is the only one to allot equal prize money to men and women.

title: Basalt Journal; This Land Is Their Land: Bears Are Everywhere
description: It was bad enough when Steve Solomon and his wife, Bates, found the skunk crawling around under their bed at 2 a.m. That they could deal with. Sooner or later, Mr. Solomon figured, the critter would make its way out the front door, which they routinely left open for the breeze. But was the door still open? Mr. Solomon had to check.

title: H.M.O. Costs Spur Employers to Shift Plans
description: Health insurance premiums are increasing by 10 percent to 30 percent across the country, according to employers, insurers and regional business groups familiar with the rates being paid by dozens of companies. Driven largely by escalating drug costs, the double-digit increase in annual premiums is the third consecutive one for many companies.

title: Where A Teenager Gives Orders
description: FOOTBALL season is here again, and as anyone who has been to a high school or college game in recent years knows, this is not your Aunt Gidget's cheerleading squad anymore. Today's cheerleaders tumble, vault, build human pyramids  and sometimes exhibit higher athletic skill than the teams they're rooting for. Like gymnasts, cheerleaders work with coaches, choreographers and physical trainers, often attending summer boot camps to prepare for both the sidelines and competitions with other squads.

title: Small Audiences Seen for Bush's Debates
description: If the presidential debates were held on the networks and days chosen by George W. Bush, the Republican candidate, they would almost surely be seen by the fewest number of people ever to have watched them.

title: U.S. Is Reported to Hand Russia Secret Details on Sub That Sank
description: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, has provided his Russian counterpart with a written summary of what American naval and intelligence officials believe caused the nuclear-powered submarine Kursk to sink last month in the Barents Sea, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELBERG, NORMAN
description: SPIELBERG-Norman. The kindest of men. Deeply missed by wife Carol (Maskin); sister Betty; children Henry, Elinor, Mitchell; two grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Service Friday, September 8 at 12 noon, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, STEWART
description: BENNETT-Stewart. Died on September 3, 2000 in Dallas, TX after a long illness. Born January 6, 1927 Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Harvard College and the Harvard Business School. Until he became ill some years ago Mr. Bennett was engaged in oil and gas exploration and production. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann Fisher Bennett & was the devoted father of Stewart Bennett, Jr., Martha B. Huffman, Katherine Bennett, Elizabeth B. Pascal, all of Dallas as well as two grandchildren and a brother Robert Bennett of Washington, D.C. Funeral services and interment will be in Dallas, TX on September 7, 2000. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the American Lung Assoc., 8150 Brookriver Dr., Dallas, TX 75247.

title: Distance Learning Goes Niche
description: With the market for adult education growing at an explosive rate, colleges and universities are finding it necessary to develop finely-tuned programs that cater to identified niches.

title: Heinz Shares Fall On Profit Warning
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its second-quarter profit would be lower than analysts expected, and its shares fell nearly 5 percent.

title: Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTZ, DOROTHY
description: GANTZ-Dorothy. On September 6, 2000. Beloved wife of Harry. Dear mother of William Gantz and Judy Jacobs. Step-mother of Ronald and Bruce Gantz. Dear sister of Jack and Ralph Caprow and Frances Glaser. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral services will be Friday, September 8, 2000, 1:30PM at Riversville Cemetery, Glenville, CT. For further information contact Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, New York 10977. 914-356-8600.

title: Choosing A Salary Or Tuition
description: WHILE his fellow seniors at Tiffin Columbian High School spent last year preparing for college, John-Thomas Gaietto set his eyes on heading straight to the pros. Distracted in school, Mr. Gaietto focused his energy and extracurricular time honing his skills and nurturing his natural gift.

title: Debates, and Other Skirmishes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Web Tool For Giving
description: AFTER years of rising values of stocks, real estate and other assets, Americans overall are richer than ever, but this wealth has not spawned a new generosity. Giving to charities continues at its historic level of about 2 percent of income, tax data show. But a new Web tool, being announced today, will let people with assets see how much more they could give without economic pain.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day on Monday about sports Web sites that sell merchandise misstated the date for the reopening of ESPN.com's online store. It is mid-September, not mid-December.

title: Fuhr Retires After 19 Seasons
description: Goalie Grant Fuhr of the Calgary Flames retired after 19 National Hockey League seasons and was named the team's goalie coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ESTHER
description: FRIEDMAN-Esther. AMIT is saddened by the passing of the beloved mother of our most devoted Board of Directors member, and generous benefactor of our AMIT Children in Israel, Marcia Weinblatt. A true Woman of Valor, Esther Friedman epitomized loving kindness, Torah values and a love for family and community. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PHYLLIS
description: SIEGEL-Phyllis. On September 5th, 2000. Beloved wife of Sam, mother of Marsha and Gary Kressin, Sharon and David Carr, Siew and Yongsuk Lertratanakul, grandmother of Brian and Deena Kressin, David Kressin, Vanessa and Gregg Botelho, Claudia Carr and Marc Richardson, Michael Carr and Jamie Carr, Jeera and Apinya Lertratanakul, sister of Henry Coretz, Irving Coretz and Esther Eisenstein. Services Thursday, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Co-Founders of Africana.com Sell Venture to Time Warner
description: Facing an uncertain climate for Internet start-ups, the founders of Africana.com Inc., the Harvard University professors Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Kwame Anthony Appiah, have sold their venture to Time Warner Inc.

title: Not a Game to the 'Stolen Generation'
description: Valerie Murphy stood in the alley behind her modest house on the tattered fringe of downtown, smoking nervously, looking away as if to keep tears from coming into her eyes. Even now, four decades later, she said she could hardly speak of the time when her life had been stolen.

title: 2 Cigarette Makers Are Said to Discuss Settling All Smokers' Suits
description: Two of the nation's major cigarette companies have been engaged in preliminary talks with plaintiffs' lawyers as part of a bid to reach a nationwide settlement of all smokers' claims against the tobacco industry, lawyers involved with the talks said yesterday.

title: U.S. Urges OPEC to Increase Oil Production
description: With oil prices surging to their highest level in a decade, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson called on oil-exporting nations today to increase their production.

title: In Victory, Martin Hits His Stride
description: It did not matter to Todd Martin if the Nielsen families had turned in for the night, or how many people were missing the amazing revival he was staging inside Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Built-In Telnet
description: To the Editor:

title: The Graphics Card Game
description: Until recently, the only home computer users who cared about seeing high-quality images on their monitors were hard-core gamers. But in the last few years, that circle has expanded to include people who watch DVD movies on their computers or edit digital photographs or videos on the weekends. And yes, some of them may even be tempted to play the occasional game of Quake III.

title: Profitability Seen at Bluelight.com
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- Bluelight.com Inc., the Internet access service and sales site started by the Kmart Corporation, expects to reach profitability next year on $100 million in projected sales, its chief executive said today.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES SAYS PROFIT WILL MISS FORECASTS
description: Litton Industries, which builds ships for the Navy, said profit in the current quarter and the rest of fiscal 2001 would be below forecasts because of cost overruns on warships and tankers. The company's shares plunged 24 percent, the biggest decline since the stock market crash of October 1987. Litton said fiscal first-quarter profit would be 10 percent to 20 percent below the comparable level a year earlier. The company said earnings per share in 2001 would increase no more than 5 percent. Analysts had expected earnings to increase as much as 12 percent. Shares of Litton fell $13.06, to $41.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: An Umbrella Stand With an Unlikely Muse
description: Archimedes theorized on the displacement of water in the bathroom. In 1998, Giovanni Andrea Panizon, an Italian architect, made a new discovery there: a hairbrush can hold things in its bristles. ''I immediately envisaged an umbrella -- to stick into that thicket of steel rods.'' The $400 stand, made with Maurizio Martinelli, is 24 inches high and 10 square; MOMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street, (800) 793-3167.

title: Summer Box Office Lacked Buzz
description: In the end, the summer movie season was neither as lucrative as it looked at its onset nor as disastrous as it appeared at its midpoint, but what exactly was it?

title: Variety of New Latin Music Sites Seek English-Speaking Audience
description: WHEN Ricky Martin swiveled his hips at the 1999 Grammys, he set off a tide of Latin pop record sales in this country. A year and a half later, on the eve of the first Latin Grammys, a new group of Internet entrepreneurs is trying to ride that tide by offering Latin music Web sites that include crash courses in the different rhythms of mambo, bomba and merengue and also sell the latest salsa and rock en Espanol CD's. And while many Spanish-language music sites originate from Brazil and Mexico, these upstarts from the United States are in English to attract a new audience: bilingual Hispanic-Americans as well as fans who do not speak Spanish.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FAIRCHILD SEMICONDUCTOR CORP., South Portland, Me., whose chips are used in cellular phones, air bags and personal computers, agreed to buy the closely held Kota Microcircuits Inc., based in Loveland, Colo., and the Power Management unit of Micro Linear, based in San Jose, Calif., for $21 million in stock and cash.

title: DEBT RELIEF FOR TAIWAN DEVELOPER
description: The Ever Fortune Group, a Taiwan property developer that has run short of cash, reached agreement with creditors to extend payments and reduce interest on $836 million worth of debt. Ever Fortune executives met with counterparts of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank and 15 other banks after the company appealed to Taiwan's Ministry of Finance for a bailout.

title: Soft Curtains Lend Mystery To a Hard-Hat Area
description: Last year, when the Museum of Modern Art in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., began a $2.2 million expansion, the typical construction barriers went up on the site: 4-by-8-foot movable plywood panels. Kathleen Harleman, the museum's director, found the barriers boring, so she hired OpenOffice, a Manhattan art and architectural firm, which designed a blue vinyl-coated mesh curtain hung on aluminum pipes that jut out a foot from the plywood. The fabric falls in deep folds ''to add mystery,'' said Lyn Rice, a partner at OpenOffice, who collaborated with Gwynne Keathley, a design consultant, on the curtain. The cost of the project was $7,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, WILLIAM WALLACE
description: DANIEL-William Wallace. Born May 19, 1959, died September 5, 2000. With profound heartfelt sadness we mourn Will: Great friend, Wild friend, Sweet friend, El Jefe, Captain, Wolfman, Our Ace. 20 year member of the Cats & Dogs Softball League. Founding member of The Fetchers, Bad DogsMad Dogs. Sunday's and league play will never be as enjoyable without you. You will be sorely missed both on and off the field. Services will be held on Friday, September 8th, 4PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Cats & Dogs friends

title: Defending Napster To the Editor:
description: To the Editor:

title: Marketers Turn To E-Mail Experts
description: Among Internet companies struggling to retain customers they have worked so hard to get, e-mail marketing is seen as the next best thing to being on the home page each time a customer goes online.

title: No Optimism About Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 5  President Clinton is planning to hold separate meetings with the Israeli and Palestinian leaders in New York on Wednesday, but none of those three parties to the long-suffering peace negotiations are optimistic that things will advance much.

title: Work Cut Out For You
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Splendid Maya Palace Is Found Hidden in Jungle
description: In a remote jungle of Guatemala, among the remains of a little-known ancient city with a name meaning Place of Serpents, archaeologists have uncovered one of the largest and most splendid palaces of Maya kings ever discovered. Its 170 high-ceiling rooms were built around 11 courtyards and spread over an area greater than two football fields.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FELIX I.
description: BERNSTEIN-Felix I. ''Phillie''. On September 6, 2000. Loving and beloved husband of Nikki for more than 57 years. Devoted father of Mitchell and Steve. Brother of Sylvia and the late Sidney and Charles. Proudly served his country as a pilot in the United States Army Air Corps during World War II. A native and lifelong resident of Brooklyn, New York, whose love of travel made him a man of the world. He was a man of good nature, wit and charm, who truly cared for his fellow man. His family and many friends will miss him greatly. Funeral services will be private.

title: The Big City; A Liberal Case For Vouchers (No Kidding)
description: ROBERT B. REICH, the Democratic policy guru and friend of organized labor, entered enemy territory this week with a peace proposal of sorts. He wrote an article on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal proposing a scheme for school vouchers.

title: Diamond Traders Act on Africa War Issue
description: The world's biggest diamond traders said today that they expect to set up a computerized global registry before the Christmas shopping season that will help curb the sale of gems used to finance wars in Africa.

title: Sports of The Times; System Fails, But Player Prospers
description: FINDING a franchise player in the National Football League draft is one of the great challenges of our time, even more difficult than deciphering the latest rap lyrics or discovering intelligent life on other planets. A scout once compared the excitement of watching a top quarterback prospect to the day that he got married. It is true the scout needs to get a life, but his words explain just how desperate teams are to select that special player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERUSCH, PHILIP E.
description: BERUSCH-Philip E. Cherished and beloved husband of Mimi. Devoted father of Betsy Day, Peter (Jill), and Steven. Dear brother of Joyce Sutton. Loving grandfather of Benjamin, Lindsey and David. Services at 10 AM, Sunday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Metro Business; Con Edison Refunds Delayed for 4 Months
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday postponed for up to four months refunds of more than $100 million that Consolidated Edison must give its customers as a result of an accident at one of its generating plants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Millennium Summit Ends With Call for Fundamental Values
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 8 -- Three days and about 200 speeches after it opened, the United Nations Millennium Summit, billed as the largest gathering of world leaders in history, prepared today to adopt a declaration of the world's hopes for the 21st century.

title: Postal Service and FedEx Discuss Partnership
description: The United States Postal Service and the FedEx Corporation are discussing a partnership that would help the service increase revenue while giving FedEx a low-cost way to reach millions of residential customers.

title: Seasonal Pleasures, Including Naked Men
description: After a long, somnolent summer, Broadway came alive again this week. Just hours after Labor Day turned into that terrible Tuesday, rehearsals began for ''The Full Monty,'' the musical version of the hit 1997 movie and a show promising more male nudity than any Broadway production since ''Love! Valour! Compassion!''

title: Eminem Wins Best Video
description: Foul rapper Eminem performed ``The Real Slim Shady'' while walking into Radio City Music Hall with an army of lookalikes Thursday, then walked out with the top honors on the MTV Video Music Awards.

title: TRW SAYS EARNINGS WILL BE WELL BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: TRW Inc., a maker of auto parts and military equipment, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit would be below forecasts by 19 to 24 cents a share because of currency fluctuations, production cutbacks by Ford Motor and slower electronics sales. Profit may also be hurt in the fourth quarter. TRW is forecast to earn $1.05 a share, according to analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. TRW, based in Cleveland, disclosed the news after the close of market trading. Its shares fell $5.75, or 13 percent, to $39.50, on electronic networks and regional exchanges after exchange trading had ended.

title: Strategic Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Streets of Baltimore, the Word on Medicare Is 'Expand,' Not 'Overhaul'
description: The shuffleboard players here at the John T. Booth Senior Center all have a horror story or two about how they, a friend or a relative has been saddled with crushing prescription drug costs. And so they are thrilled that the issue has moved center stage in the presidential contest between Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore.

title: N.H.L. to Change Its Draft Order
description: The National Hockey League's Board of Governors voted to change the selection order for the entry draft and to limit the ability of linesmen to call penalties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, PHILIP
description: ROSENBERG-Philip. Died on September 4, 2000, at age 79. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of son, Eric, and his wife, Linda, son, Douglas, and daughter, Amy. Loving grandfather of Kyle. Dear brother and cherished uncle and grand-uncle of Diane and Nicole. He was a graduate of New York University. As a parishioner of St. Helen's R.C. Church in Howard Beach, he was a proud and active member of the Holy Name Society. Mr Rosenberg was co-founder and former president of BPC Management Corp. Mass of the Resurrection today, 9:45 AM, at St. Helen's R.C. Church in Howard Beach, Queens. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. It was Philip's wish that memorial contributions be made to St. Helen's R.C. Church, PC Support Group, 157-10 83rd St., Howard Beach, NY 11414.

title: The Sound of Gunfire in America
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADERS DEBATE BROAD NEW ROLE FOR U.N. COUNCIL
description: With President Clinton and other government leaders filling seats usually occupied by their envoys, the Security Council moved today toward a new role for itself in a world where the rules have been rewritten by warlords, and the poor kill the poor over dwindling resources.

title: Giuliani Asks U.S. to Assume Security Costs
description: Citing what he called the ''extraordinary security measures'' that are being provided by New York City during the United Nations Millennium Summit, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday wrote to President Clinton asking for $25 million in federal reimbursement. He said the State Department had traditionally shortchanged the city in United Nations security.

title: The Sound of Gunfire in America
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Qwest Stock Dips on News of 13,000 Layoffs
description: Qwest Communications, a fast-growing provider of telecommunications services, said yesterday that it would lay off nearly 13,000 employees and increase capital spending in an effort to heighten efficiency after its $44 billion acquisition of U S West.

title: Clinton Won't Meet His Goal Of Mideast Peace, Aides Fear
description: After a sustained effort to seal a Middle East peace accord, the White House has begun to sense that a solution is slipping away, and senior administration officials say they are preparing themselves for the likelihood that a deal will not come during President Clinton's time in office.

title: Yankees Pad Lead in Al East
description: BOSTON -- Roger Clemens kept winning, David Justice and Derek Jeter kept hitting and the New York Yankees padded their comfortable lead in the AL East.

title: TENNECO JOINS EFFORT TO CREATE AN AUTO-PARTS WEB SITE
description: Tenneco Automotive has joined other makers of auto parts in an effort to form an Internet site that would cut costs in the replacement-parts business, the Internet venture said yesterday. Tenneco, a leading maker of shock absorbers and exhaust systems, joined the Dana Corporation, Delphi Automotive Systems, TRW Inc., the Timken Company, Valeo S.A. of France and Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany in the venture, as yet unnamed. Tenneco, which makes Monroe shock absorbers and Walker mufflers, and the other companies want to cut their costs for goods and services and for distribution.

title: F.D.A. Acts Against Internet Sale of Laetrile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  The Food and Drug Administration is warning Internet users to beware of a concoction made of apricot seeds that is promoted as a cancer cure.

title: Ventura Needs a Few Timely Hits
description: With a .226 batting average, Robin Ventura accepts that the math is against him. Time has run out for Ventura, the Mets' third baseman, to raise his average to its normal level, which hovers around .277 for his career. Almost certainly, this will go down as the worst offensive season of his distinguished career.

title: FORD TO BUILD $400 MILLION PARTS PLANT IN CHICAGO
description: Ford Motor said yesterday that it planned to build a $400 million manufacturing and distribution complex for its suppliers near a Taurus and Mercury Sable plant in southeast Chicago. The new complex will add about 1,000 jobs to the area by its completion in 2003. About 2,500 hourly and salaried employees work at the nearby plant. The $400 million will be made up of investments from Ford, parts suppliers and a development partner, CenterPoint Properties. The complex is designed to provide the automaker with a steady supply of parts while reducing potential damage and the costs of shipping.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Secret Oil Talks
description: The heads of state from the OPEC oil countries will gather in Venezuela Sept. 26 to 28 for only their second top-level meeting since OPEC was founded in 1960. The meeting comes as oil prices hit a 10-year high this week at $34 a barrel. Venezuela's president, Hugo Chavez, the host of the summit, just broke the ring of isolation around Iraq and personally flew to Baghdad to consult Saddam Hussein. Here's what I imagine was their conversation.

title: C. Philip Wilson, 79, Expert in Treatment Of Eating Disorders
description: Dr. C. Philip Wilson, an expert in the treatment of eating disorders and other severe psychosomatic problems, died on Aug. 17 at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Great Fun, Strings Attached
description: Mention the name Henson, and the lovable Muppets of ''Sesame Street'' come to mind. But at this time every other year, the family enterprise has another connotation: puppets. The Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater is back, and along with its adult productions, it offers four children's shows and three that bridge the generations.

title: Patient Confidentiality at Issue in 1985 Murder Case
description: In a case that has pitted medical privacy against the demands of legal disclosure, two more psychiatrists reluctantly testified yesterday that they warned a wife of potential danger after briefly treating her angry husband, a plastic surgeon who is now accused of killing her.

title: Mens Olympic Tournament: A Battleground on and Off the Field
description: Mention the sport of soccer and the Olympics in the same sentence, and reactions are likely to vary. The Summer Games are more closely associated with individual pursuits -- track and field, swimming -- than with the world's most popular sport.

title: Sprucing Up A City Park
description: Target Stores has given $1 million to a contemporary art program at Madison Square Park. The initiative, part of a restoration of the park between 23rd and 26th Streets from Madison to Fifth Avenues, will feature work by an international group of artists including Tony Oursler, Ron Mueck, Janet Cardiff and Yutaka Stone.

title: TV's Bad Boy, Underground and Underfoot
description: FOR those of you reading this on the subway, a warning: don't look up. In a few moments, the doors will open, and it very well might be Tad Low getting on, trailed by a camera crew. Draw your newspaper up a little higher. Because if Mr. Low sees you, he will talk to you.

title: Small Museums Yield Big Rewards In Massachusetts
description: Among the banquet of star museums offered by the culture-conscious state of Massachusetts, a feast that spreads from Boston and Cambridge to Worcester and Williamstown, a number of mini-institutions are often overlooked. They inhabit smaller towns and cities like Framingham, Fitchburg and Brockton; their annual budgets are under $2 million, and their collections -- where treasures can nevertheless be found -- are apt to lack depth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COWEN, JOSHUA LIONEL
description: COWEN-Joshua Lionel. Born 1880, departed September, 1965. Heroes, not many today. Lionel 1900, here it is year 2000. Christmas 2000, Madison Park, Joshua, Larry, A.C., Harry, Louis. My hero is still around. Thank you Joshua. A friend from Boston, Neil.

title: A Physicist Of Big Ideas And Humor
description: Shot in limpid black and white, studded with symbols and contemplative vistas of sea and sky, ''Clouds'' is a small movie with large pretensions. It concerns a young physicist named Robert St. John, who, to work out a radical new cosmology (''It may subvert basic models,'' he tells a colleague), takes a leave from his teaching post and sets himself up in a quiet town on the Northern California coast. There Robert (Michael Patrick Gaffney) meets a painstakingly selected cast of eccentrics: a chatty, pious landlady, a profane and cynical artist and a mysterious woman who claims to have known him in the past.

title: Schools Try To Smooth The Bumps On Day 1
description: As Harold O. Levy, the freshman chancellor, arrived at Central Park East, a public elementary school in East Harlem, on the first leg of a back-to-school tour, he was startled yesterday morning to find the school's administrator mopping up spilled coffee in a cafeteria swirling with excited children and their anxious parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHMAN, DIAN DINCIN
description: BUCHMAN-Dian Dincin. Alternative medicine pioneer, writer and activist, author of ''Herbal Medicine'', ''Complete Book of Water Therapy'', ''Complete Guide to Natural Sleep'', and many other books on complementary medicine and other subjects. Past President of American Society of Journalists and Authors (ASJA), a founder of the Council of Writers Organizations. She was the adoring and adored mother of Caitlin Dincin Kraft Buchman, beloved sister of Zola Dincin Schneider and Jerry Dincin, a cherished aunt, loving grandmother, and friend extraordinaire. A lover of life and a woman of wisdom, she will be forever missed by her family and friends. Service Friday, September 8, 11:30AM at Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.S. and Italy Are Ahead in Bridge Tourney
description: The finals of the World Bridge Championship began here this afternoon, and the United States took the lead in one match and Italy took the lead in the other.

title: Excitement as Hamrlik Signs
description: With a four-year, $13 million contract that makes him the highest paid player on the Islanders, defenseman Roman Hamrlik will finally join the team, but it won't be in time for the start of training camp, which gets under way today at the Olympic Center in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: U.N. Speakers Urge Increase In Charity To the Poor
description: A succession of leaders speaking on the second day of the United Nations' Millennium Summit today demanded, with passion and often eloquence, that the industrialized world show more tangible charity toward the world's poor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an inquiry into money laundering in Liechtenstein misstated the number of banks there. Sixteen are licensed, and 14 are operating; the number is not 300.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar listing in the Dining section on Wednesday about a wine tasting and dinner on Sept. 16 at Clinton Vineyards in Clinton Corners, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (518) 827-8495.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIFER, DR. HERMAN
description: ZEIFER-Dr. Herman. The Beth Israel Medical Center and New York Eye & Ear Infirmary communities join with the physicians and staffs of their respective Departments of Radiology in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Dr. Herman Zeifer, father of our dear friend and respected colleague, Barbara Zeifer, M.D. To Barbara, her mother Dorothy, her family, and all of her father's loved ones we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President & CEO, BIMC Joseph P. Corcoran President & CEO, NYEEI Michael M. Abiri, M.D. Chairman, Dept of Radiology

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bush Has a Point on the Debates
description: In the current argument about sponsorship of this year's presidential debates, too little attention has been paid to the cramped schedule imposed by the fall calendar of televised sports events. Nobody wants to force Americans to choose between these valuable debates, on the one hand, and ''Monday Night Football,'' the World Series or the Olympic Games on the other.

title: Lost Youth, Lost Friend, Lost Chance
description: ''Went to Coney Island on a Mission From God . . . Back by 5'' is, thank goodness, not as gawkily clever as its title, but it is an odd mixture of boyish high spirits and grown-up melodrama.

title: Settling Suit, Louisiana Abandons Private Youth Prisons
description: The State of Louisiana agreed in Federal District Court in Baton Rouge yesterday to sweeping changes in the way it runs its juvenile prisons, including steps to protect inmates from abusive guards and promises to provide medical, dental and mental health care.

title: Fragile: Handle With Dreams
description: ''Nurse Betty'' takes the most hackneyed dramatic ploy of soap opera, a case of amnesia, and spins it into an irresistibly heady mixture of sadness and hilarity. At its giddiest peaks the movie, directed by Neil LaBute, produces that shivery feeling when your heart melts but at the same moment you want to burst out laughing. This whimsical rose-colored fairy tale with tragic undercurrents suggests a contemporary ''Wizard of Oz'' for grown-ups. It is easily the finest American comedy since David O. Russell's ''Flirting With Disaster,'' another road movie that never ran out of poignantly funny surprises.

title: Giants Engage in Battle for Billings as DaimlerChrysler Conducts Assignment Review
description: The battle lines are already being drawn in one of the biggest confrontations in Madison Avenue history.

title: To Nurture the Worker, and the Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Can Cost Too Much
description: After 88 deaths and who knows how many serious injuries, the temptation is almost irresistible to bring the boot of government down more heavily on the neck of Firestone and, by extension, other tire makers and auto-related industries. But the current environment -- perhaps best characterized as near-hysteria -- is precisely the wrong one in which to be formulating new regulations. We need to step back and take a dispassionate look at both the pluses and minuses of granting the federal government yet more authority in this area.

title: Judge Rules Doctors Can Discuss Marijuana Use
description: A federal judge in San Francisco ruled today that federal officials may not interfere with the freedom of California doctors and patients to discuss the potential medical benefits of marijuana, or of doctors to recommend its therapeutic use, under the terms of a state ballot initiative approved by voters in 1996.

title: Editorial Observer; Taking the Train From Maine to Memphis
description: One of the pleasures of an end-of-summer vacation is unessential reading. I'm not talking about the melt-in-the-mind bonbons called ''beach books,'' but those more ambitious and alluring books that linger on the shelf from year to year, only to be pushed aside again and again by volumes that seem more essential to one's workaday life. In my case, one of those I'll-get-around-to-it books has been ''Last Train to Memphis,'' Peter Guralnick's well-reviewed biography of the young Elvis Presley. It has been on my shelf since its publication in 1994, and a few weeks ago my musician son wanted to borrow it for an upcoming road trip. Thus prodded, I bought him a new copy and took my own long-neglected book along on a Maine vacation.

title: Jesus May Pull the Strings in This Town, but This Marionette Has Other Ideas
description: Is there any relationship so intimate as that between a puppet and its master? Whether controlled by hand, strings or sticks, puppets are famous for providing bolder alter egos for those who manipulate them. ''My Puppet, Myself'' could easily be a subtitle for everything from the cheery television shows of Shari Lewis to those homicidal ventriloquist movies that show up every decade or so.

title: Article 2000090890695973526 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN
description: STEIN-Martin. Of Lake McGregor Mahopac, NY. Survived by his wife Renee, daughter Deborah and her husband Roger, grandchildren David and Rachel, mother Mary Barishansky and brothers Arnold and Richard. Also survived by his loving nephews and greatnieces. Services 11 AM, Friday at King David Memorial Chapel, Mt. Kisco, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABRICANT, DOROTHY
description: FABRICANT-Dorothy. Our fabulously special and elegant grandmother and great grandmother. We have adored you our entire lives, and will cherish our memories of you forever. Franklin, Esther, Rebecca & Devorah

title: Elvera Davis, 95, Tap Dancer And Mother of Sammy Davis Jr.
description: Elvera Sanchez Davis, a tap dancer and the mother of Sammy Davis Jr., died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Familiar Circumstance
description: As a familiar sinking sensation began to seep in, Pete Sampras was standing in the middle of Arthur Ashe Stadium on Wednesday night in need of a trap door to escape from the seemingly unconquerable Richard Krajicek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, ALFRED
description: APPEL-Alfred. Of New York City, on September 6, 2000 in his 95th year. Beloved husband of Beatrice with whom he celebrated their 69th wedding anniversary on Sunday, September 3rd. A graduate of Townsend Harris High School at age 15, Cornell University, Class of 1926, Cornell Law School, Class of 1928, he was a former managing partner at Proskauer Rose Goetz and Mendelsohn, where he practiced law for over 65 years. In addition to being a member of the Cornell Law School Advisory Council, he was National Chairman of The Cornell Law School Fund and served on several boards of directors of prominent companies. He was also a member of the Great Neck Board of Education and a trustee of the Society for Hillside Hospital. A gentle and wise friend and advisor, he is also survived by his children, Professor Alfred Appel, Jr. and Dean Nina Appel, Betty and Paul Schaffer, and John S. Appel and Barbara Wolkowitz, his grandchildren Karen and Gene Oshman, Richard J. Appel and Mona Simpson, Dr. Mark A. Schaffer, Catherine Schaffer and greatgrandchildren Stephen and Katherine Oshman and Gabriel Jandali Appel and Grace Appel Jandali; also survived by his brother-in-law Dr. Burton Hoffman and wife Lynn and numerous nephews and nieces. Service on Friday, September 8, 2000 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Gore Gets Powerful Help From Cabinet
description: Vice President Al Gore may be trying to rid himself of President Clinton, but he is making no attempt to escape from the Clinton cabinet.

title: Hingis Forms an Alliance Worthy of 'Survivor'
description: Martina Hingis plopped down at a table in a restaurant outside Hilton Head, S.C., to lay a fork on some Southern cooking for the first time. But before the waiter could take her order, she noticed a palm-sized wooden triangle next to the salt and pepper. It was a pegboard stuffed with colorful golf tees, one stuck in every hole but one.

title: Mens Olympic Tournament: A Battleground on and Off the Field
description: Mention the sport of soccer and the Olympics in the same sentence, and reactions are likely to vary. The Summer Games are more closely associated with individual pursuits -- track and field, swimming -- than with the world's most popular sport.

title: Indonesian Leader Apologizes for U.N. Deaths in West Timor
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 8 -- Two days after three United Nations refugee workers were murdered in their office in West Timor, Indonesia's president Abdurrahman Wahid today formally conveyed his nation's "very deep sorrow" for their "horrific death" and promised to prosecute the killers.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Primary Rival Imagines a September Surprise
description: Next Wednesday, Dr. Mark S. McMahon says, he fully expects to sit next to Katie Couric or perhaps Dan Rather, gloating just a touch as he dispenses a batch of ''I told you so's'' to the world.

title: Residential Real Estate; A Tower With Housing And a Publishing House
description: Reflecting the strong demand in Manhattan both for luxury housing and for new office space, the tower taking shape on the west side of Broadway from 55th to 56th Street will contain the new headquarters for Random House on its lower floors and be topped by 111 luxury condominium apartments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELBERG, NORMAN
description: SPIELBERG-Norman. The kindest of men. Deeply missed by wife Carol (Maskin); sister Betty; children Henry, Elinor, Mitchell; two grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Service Friday, September 8 at 12 noon, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: The Sound of Gunfire in America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mother's Selfless Love and Dignity
description: One of the good things that can come with age, if we're lucky, is a growing capacity to feel and to give our unconditional love. And Benito Zambrano's quietly moving film ''Solas'' explores this gift with a depth and subtlety that remind you, indirectly, of why the movies are so infatuated with violence.

title: It's a Handshake and Small Talk for Clinton and Castro
description: The last time President Clinton and Fidel Castro were in the same room, in October 1995 at a United Nations reception in New York, the Secret Service deftly kept the two men apart. Not a word or a handshake was exchanged.

title: Koppel to Stay With 'Nightline' But Will Appear Less Frequently
description: Ted Koppel, the anchor of the ABC News ''Nightline'' program since it made its debut in 1980, has agreed to stay with the program for the next five years, though he will appear as the anchor less frequently, executives announced yesterday.

title: That Mystery That No One Wants to Think About Is Getting More Complex
description: In America, a nation of strivers, people want to believe that everything is subject to improvement, even dying. But while death remains (presumably) a constant, the act of dying has become more complex. Medical advances have prolonged life, but often in an undesirable form, forcing doctors to reconsider their roles and obligations. Terminally ill patients may think they want to take control of their mortality with physician-assisted suicide, then find they are afraid.

title: Everything's Updated, Stylized or Sent to the Bayou
description: Dance Theater of Harlem has popped up at City Center for a two-week engagement, which was announced only recently. It is good to have a major ballet company back in New York in the fall, a season increasingly low on classical dancing.

title: ASK ROGER COLLIS : Avoiding Malaria and Staying Well While on Business Trips
description: From Max Zimmermann in Cannes:

title: Late Arrivals on U.S. Airlines Rose in July
description: The on-time performance of the nation's leading airlines fell in July, dragged down as United Airlines missed the schedule on more than half its flights, the Department of Transportation said.

title: U.S.-China Trade Bill Inches Closer to Passage in the Senate
description: The Senate took an important step closer today to a final vote on President Clinton's major trade bill with China, as momentum built for final passage next week after months of delay.

title: Leading Jewish Scholars Extend a Hand to Christians
description: A large group of influential Jewish scholars and rabbis have signed a theological statement to be released this weekend calling on Jews to relinquish their fear and mistrust of Christianity and to acknowledge church efforts in the decades since the Holocaust to amend Christian teaching about Judaism.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, NORMAN M.
description: KRAMER-Norman M. Passed away at age 87 on September 6. Devoted husband of Bernice, loving father of Joan Tucker and father-in-law of Barry Tucker , adoring grandfather of Amy Tucker Meltzer (Jonathan) and Robert Scott Tucker. Great-grandfather of Alexa and Matthew Meltzer and devoted brother of Milton J. (Buddy) Kramer. Services Friday, September 8 at 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Yonkers to Cut Bus Service for 2,000 Students
description: The Yonkers school system has announced that it will eliminate bus service for about 2,000 students, prompting leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to charge that the move violates a court-ordered desegregation plan that has controlled the schools there for 14 years.

title: Lose One, Win One
description: Jared Palmer was tired and depressed. He and his Olympic partner, Alex O'Brien, who were seeded third, had just lost their men's doubles semifinal match in a crushing third-set tie breaker, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (7), to the unseeded team of Max Mirnyi and Lleyton Hewitt.

title: When It's Time to Debate, Add Nader's Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Union Backs Lazio, Citing First Lady's Statement
description: The 27,000-member New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association endorsed Representative Rick A. Lazio for Senate yesterday. Patrick J. Lynch, the president of the association, said that Mr. Lazio ''does not jump on the bandwagon of criticism unreasonably at a time when it's difficult to be a New York City police officer.''

title: CHINESE PHONE PROFITS
description: China Unicom Ltd., a unit of China's No. 2 phone company, said earnings fell 37 percent, to 171 million yuan ($20 million) in the first half after taking a one-time charge of 1.2 billion yuan for compensation to investors. ''The sustained healthy and rapid development of China's economy, further reorganization of China's telecommunications industry and gradual formation of orderly competition have resulted in a better environment for the company'' Unicom's chairman, Yang Xianzu, said in a statement.

title: Bulls Sign a Center
description: The Chicago Bulls signed center Brad Miller, one of the top free agents still available. Undrafted out of Purdue, Miller was a surprise for the Charlotte Hornets during the lockout-shortened 1998-99 season when he averaged 6.3 points and 3.1 rebounds. He averaged 7.7 points and 4.4 rebounds last season.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rebounded after Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said Germany wanted a strong common currency, contradicting earlier remarks. In New York, the euro settled at 87.39 cents, up from 87.01 cents.

title: Quarterly Net To Fall Short At Campbell
description: The Campbell Soup Company, the world's biggest soup maker, said today that its first-quarter profit would miss estimates because of higher spending intended to increase demand.

title: Recovery Slow, But Martin Gains Semis
description: When he stormed to a two-set lead in last night's quarterfinal match of the United States Open, Todd Martin forgot his legs felt as if they were attached to cinder blocks, his broken-down body hastily repaired by intravenous fluids and massages for the previous 48 hours.

title: While Lieberman Baits Bush on Stump, Gore Rarely Mentions Him
description: On a day the Democrats devoted to trumpeting their economic goals, Vice President Al Gore, speaking in Cleveland, never mentioned the Republicans.

title: Advocates Say City Is Failing in Efforts to Shelter the Homeless With AIDS
description: Dozens of people with AIDS have been turned away from emergency housing despite a November court order that requires the city to provide such shelter, homeless people and their advocates told a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: To Nurture the Worker, and the Child
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sound of Gunfire in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, ROGER
description: ROBINSON-Roger ''Robbie'' Wolcott, age 83, who retired after thirty-seven years as a Special Agent and Supervisor of the FBI, died on August 18th of injuries sustained as a passenger in an automobile accident. He lived in Briarcliff Manor, New York. Roger graduated from Duke University and played on the legendary ''Iron Dukes'' Rose Bowl team. During the 1938 season, the team went undefeated, untied and unscored upon. He was primarily assigned to the Bureau's New York office where he worked counter-espionage cases and later served as head of firearms instruction and defensive tactics. Roger won the New York State Pistol Championship four times and was awarded the Distinguished Medal by Congress. His first wife ''Bunny'' (Mary Grace) Pethick died in 1965. Survivors include his wife of 19 years Elly (Cattell), three children from his first marriage: Sandy Robinson, Faye Robinson, Roger Robinson, Jr., a stepdaughter Susan Herring, a daughter-in-law Joan Robinson and grandchildren Grace and Roger III. Friends are invited to a memorial service at the Briarcliff Congregational Church, at South State Road, Briarcliff Manor, on September 16th at 12 noon.

title: Woods Finds the Going Tough in Canada, Again
description: For some reason, when Tiger Woods has traveled north to Canada, his performance has headed south.

title: Technology Briefings
description: INTERNETDISPOSABLE CREDIT CARD NUMBERS American Express said that within a month it plans to begin offering a free service that will generate random numbers that can be used instead of account numbers for cardholders making online purchases. A cardholder would be able to obtain a "private payment number" that could be used at any site that accepts American Express cards. To save a few clicks, cardholders would be able to download software from the company's Web site that would automatically produce a payment number for purchases at selected e-tailers, a spokeswoman said.

title: AN AVENGER'S PATH: A special report.; Lawyer in Holocaust Case Faces Litany of Complaints
description: Less than four years ago, a little-known personal-injury lawyer named Edward D. Fagan stood next to an Auschwitz survivor at a news conference in New York and announced an audacious lawsuit, accusing Swiss banks of stealing money 50 years ago from those who died in the Holocaust.

title: CIRCUIT CITY SAYS REVAMPING WILL CUT INTO EARNINGS
description: Circuit City Group said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter profit at its consumer electronics stores would be hurt because costs to leave the appliance business were greater than expected. The company's chief executive, W. Alan McCollough, is getting rid of appliances because they are less profitable than consumer electronics like big-screen television sets. Profit was hurt by the price markdowns Circuit City took to clear appliances from its stores, the company said. Circuit City's stock has dropped 17 percent since it said in July that it would eliminate appliances and begin remodeling its 573 superstores -- the biggest makeover in more than a decade. Circuit City's stock was down 81 cents, to $26.94.

title: Paris Dealers Are Toasting The Season
description: Attention, jet setters: Better get to Paris next week (if you can find a hotel room). The opening of the French social season begins on Tuesday, when more than 90,000 international collectors -- from the the Prince of Lichtenstein and the Princess of Kent to Baroness Philippine de Rothschild and Quentin Tarantino -- are expected to congregate for a two-week extravaganza of openings, parties and special events connected to the 20th edition of the Biennale International des Antiquaires, the Super Bowl of antiques fairs.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The last thing anybody wants to be is a rat. But you know something? I'll be a rat and I won't be in prison. I'll be a rat and I'll be alive.''

title: Serena Williams Pulls Out Of Doubles
description: A little more than three hours after Serena Williams lost in the quarterfinals to Lindsay Davenport, ending her bid to defend her 1999 United States Open singles title, publishers of the daily draw sheet learned Wednesday night that she had withdrawn from playing in the doubles tournament with her sister Venus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, STEWART

Until he became ill some years ago Mr. Bennett was engaged in oil and gas exploration and production. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann Fisher Bennett & was the devoted father of Stewart Bennett, Jr., Martha B. Huffman, Katherine Bennett and Elizabeth B. Pascal all of Dallas as well as two grandchildren & a brother Robert Bennett of Washington, D.C. Funeral services were in Dallas. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the American Lung Assoc, 8150 Brookriver Dr, Dallas, TX 75247

title: West Timor Killings Seem to Mirror East Timor Rampage in '99
description: The mob rampage that killed three United Nations workers in the West Timor region of Indonesia on Wednesday seemed to some aid workers like a terrifying flashback: in many respects it replicated the violence, exactly one year ago, in East Timor.

title: Study Fails to Reveal the Causes of Gulf War Syndrome
description: A panel of expert scientists reported yesterday that after studying what were regarded as the leading suspected causes, it could not say what had brought on the array of symptoms called gulf war syndrome in thousands of veterans of the war against Iraq.

title: The Economic Scoreboard
description: Ronald Reagan turned ''tax and spend'' into a near-fatal label for traditional Democrats. One of President Clinton's big achievements has been to rebuild his party's reputation for budgetary restraint and fiscal discipline. Vice President Al Gore, with his carefully crafted economic plan, has been careful to preserve the political capital inherited from Mr. Clinton's success in reducing the federal debt. To be sure, the hefty document Mr. Gore released on Tuesday is as much a campaign manifesto as it is an economic blueprint. Indeed, by combining his previously proposed spending and tax-cutting ideas in one package, he directed attention to the stark differences between his policies and those of Gov. George W. Bush. What emerges is an economic program that is cautious almost to a fault, yet determinedly progressive in its general thrust. Mr. Gore has, properly, focused spending on families most in need.

title: Italian-Dutch Deal Creates Internet Giant
description: In a race to become the America Online of Europe, Italy's second-largest Internet service provider, Tiscali S.p.A., said today that it had agreed to acquire the troubled Dutch Internet company World Online N.V. for $5.1 billion in stock. The move makes the combined company the second-largest Internet service provider in Europe behind T-Online, a unit of Deutsche Telekom of Germany.

title: Use of Breast Cancer Drug Questioned in Dutch Study
description: Researchers in Holland are questioning the safety of a practice that has been widely endorsed by cancer experts in the United States: prescribing the drug tamoxifen to prevent breast cancer in healthy women who are at high risk for the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERGER, LOIS

Lois and her husband, Eli, have been generous friends and supporters of the Museum throughout the years, and we have admired her great strength in the face of her recent illness. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Eli and their extended family. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT RISES
description: National Semiconductor reported fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday that handily exceeded analysts' estimates. For the quarter ended Aug. 27, National had earnings of $144.2 million, or 74 cents a diluted share, more than tripling the $47.1 million, or 25 cents a share, it reported in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 33 percent, to $640.8 million. Excluding one-time items, National had earnings of $149.4 million, or 76 cents a diluted share. Analysts had expected the company to earn 65 cents a share on the same basis. Its shares rose $2.13, to $47.13. National's strong results partly reflect its exit last year from the personal computer microprocessor business, but they also reflect the large portion of revenue that comes from analog semiconductors, which are used in cellular telephones and other hand-held devices. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

title: Mr. Kerik Sends a Message
description: Many New Yorkers are still smoldering about the Police Department's failure to contain the mobs of drunken men who assaulted several women in Central Park just after the Puerto Rican National Day Parade in June. The outgoing police commissioner, Howard Safir, took an important step this summer when he disciplined more than a dozen officers, including six supervisors, for failing to deploy their officers properly during the event. But the incoming commissioner, Bernard Kerik, sent an even more powerful message this week when he transferred the officer who was in command during the parade, as part of a shake-up in the department that displaced 30 senior managers.

title: HEARST-ARGYLE AGREES TO BUY NEW HAMPSHIRE STATION
description: Hearst-Argyle Television Inc., an operator of 26 television stations, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an ABC-network-affiliated station in Manchester, N.H., WMUR-TV, for $185 million. The purchase of the station, from the closely held Imes Communications, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2001 and will add immediately to Hearst-Argyle's after-tax cash flow per share, the company said. Hearst-Argyle, based in New York, said $160 million of the purchase price would be financed through the sale of its three radio stations in Phoenix, a deal that was announced in June.

Investors interpreted the news as a sign of cash problems. The company, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., said it had hired Bank of America to help it get financing. Shares of Restoration Hardware, which operates about 90 stores in 30 states and Canada, fell $1.19, or 19.8 percent, to $4.81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKUN, MORDECAI A.
description: BERKUN-Mordecai A., MD. A cardiologist and independent businessman. Died on Wednesday, September 6, on Long Island. He was 73 and lived in Great Neck, NY. Loving husband of his late wife Judy. Devoted father of Alicia and Geza, Edward and Joanne, Leslie and Jose, Margarita, Barry and Leslie, Robin and Rick and the late Norman. Grandfather of Alexander, Neal, Robbie, Ben, Noah, Araceli, Sarah, Suzanne and Sam. Brother Ben and sister-in-law, Annette. Dr. Berkun received his medical degree from New York University College of Medicine in 1951. Following service in the U.S. Navy, Dr. Berkun practiced medicine as an internist and cardiologist with partners Rosenthal and Conovitz in Great Neck, NY. After private practice, Dr. Berkun served as Medical Director at Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield in New York City for almost 10 years. Throughout his medical career he held positions within North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, NY and Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, NY. He was a Teaching Fellow in medicine at Harvard University early in his career. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: 20 Feared Dead in Latest West Timor Attack
description: ATAMBUA, Indonesia -- U.N. officials said Friday they feared 20 villagers had been massacred by pro-Indonesian militias in West Timor, the day after rampaging mobs killed three foreign aid workers. In East Timor's capital, Dili, U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees spokesman Bernard Kerblat said militias were terrorizing local West Timorese people and refugees from neighboring East Timor. ``There are 120,000 individuals in a hostage-like situation'' because of the militias, he said. Thursday's attack happened in the village of Betun, about 30 miles south of Atambua _ where militias stormed the UNHCR office Wednesday, stabbing three workers to death. ``There are unconfirmed reports of 20 casualties. Civilian or refugees, we don't know,'' Kerblat said, adding that with U.N. staff evacuated from the area, confirmation was difficult. Indonesian military and police were not immediately available for comment. ``I think it is quite evident that Indonesian authorities are not in control in West Timor,'' said U.N. Peacekeeping spokesman Norwegian Col. Brynar Nymo. Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid, humiliated by the surging violence that coincided with his participation in the U.N. Millennium Summit in New York, has promised to crack down on militias. He claims the killings were orchestrated to derail his democratic reforms. The burned and ransacked U.N. compound in Atambua was under police guard Friday as the Cabinet held an emergency meeting to discuss security arrangements in the territory. About 250 foreign aid workers were evacuated to U.N.-administered East Timor after the attack. They had provided humanitarian assistance to an estimated 90,000 East Timorese refugees housed in West Timor camps. East Timor was wracked by violence last year following an independence referendum, as militias backed by the Indonesian army destroyed much of the territory. Militiamen dressed in Indonesian military jackets and brandishing machetes and daggers set up blockades Friday and extorted money and cigarettes from motorists on the road to Atambua. Residents said the gangs were searching for remaining foreigners. At the United Nations on Thursday, President Clinton and other world leaders called on Indonesia to disarm and disband the militias and to boost security in the region. Wahid said the international community must help remove the militia gangs, and that he wants assistance resettling the ``criminal elements'' from West Timor to other parts of the nation. ``The international community demands we do this or that, but they don't give us the necessary tools to do so,'' said Wahid, a guest speaker at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs on Thursday. Human rights groups say the militias are backed by hard-line elements of Indonesia's army, and that they use refugee camps in West Timor as bases for cross-border raids. U.N. officials warned Thursday that with the suspension of aid operations, refugees who live in the squalid camps face potentially disastrous shortages of food and medicines. Armed forces commander Adm. Widodo Adisutjipto said an extra battalion of troops had been dispatched to the region to protect the refugees. The government sent 600 soldiers and 100 policemen to the region Wednesday.

title: Life Flings Tough Lessons Into the Face of a Dedicated Educator

The son of a miner, Daniel fills his journals with meditations on nature and history that provide, as they are read on the soundtrack, a kind of poetic counterpoint to, and relief from, the misery and deprivation that dominate Daniel's professional life, and much of the movie.

title: AVON SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK UP TO $1 BILLION OF STOCK
description: Avon Products Inc., the world's largest direct seller of cosmetics, plans to buy back up to $1 billion of its common shares, which have fallen 13 percent in the last year. Avon, the maker of Anew and Skin-So-Soft beauty products, said the repurchase, equal to about 11 percent of the company's shares, would be financed by cash generated from operations over the next five years. The company plans to buy back up to 25.3 million shares, based on yesterday's closing price. Avon, which sells in 137 countries, had 1999 sales of $5.3 billion. Its products include fragrances, jewelry, apparel, gifts and collectibles. The shares of Avon, based in New York, rose 94 cents, to $40.50.

title: Yankees Try a New Line On Royals: 000 000 007
description: The playing field was out of sight from where Denny Neagle rested during the ninth inning tonight, in the tunnel behind the visitors' dugout, next to a bathroom. There was a radio broadcast coming from somewhere nearby and this is the way Neagle followed the Yankees' perpetual and decisive rally.

title: CKE RESTAURANTS IS SELLING TACO UNIT FOR $90 MILLION
description: CKE Restaurants, owner of the Hardee's and Carl's Jr. hamburger chains, said yesterday that it planned to sell its Taco Bueno unit for more than $90 million. Taco Bueno, which has 125 locations in Texas and Oklahoma, is to be sold to an affiliate of Commercial Revolution, a closely held company based in San Diego. The transaction is expected to close by Jan. 31. CKE, based in Anaheim, Calif., also said that its chief executive, Thomas Thompson, had resigned and would be replaced by Andrew F. Puzder, who will continue as head of CKE's Hardee's Food Systems unit.

title: Cone Is Healing Quickly, While Mendoza's Hopes Fade
description: David Cone can't catch but he can throw, and Ramiro Mendoza can catch but he can't throw. When the two right-handers teamed up to toss the ball with the pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, in the outfield here this evening, Cone grinned broadly, encouraged about his chances of quickly coming back from a separated left shoulder. Mendoza, on the other hand, was dour, knowing his season was probably finished.

title: DaimlerChrysler Acts to Exert More Control Over Mitsubishi
description: TOKYO Sept. 8 - DaimlerChrysler AG, which recently formed an alliance in Mitsubishi Motor Company, took several steps today to change the terms of the deal and increase its control over the automaker.

title: David R. Altman, 85, Is Dead; His Ads Built Several Brands
description: David R. Altman, a fashion advertising executive whose tag lines did for bolts of fabric what tigers in tanks had done for gasoline, died on Aug. 30 in New York. He was 85.

title: CMGI, the Big Internet Investor, to Alter Holdings
description: CMGI, one of the earliest and savviest investors in the Internet, announced a sweeping restructuring yesterday meant to reassure disenchanted investors that it was moving toward becoming profitable and was picking the winners among the plethora of companies it owns.

title: Album of the Week
description: EVERCLEAR: "Songs From an American Movie, Volume I: Learning How to Smile" (Capitol). What are memories for? Art P. Alexakis of Everclear ponders that question on "Songs From an American Movie, Volume I." Mr. Alexakis, 38, isn't afraid to admit he has a long past, and he seesaws between weighing what he has done and trying to forget it. In the album's single, "AM Radio," he borrows the strutting riff from Jean Knight's "Mr. Big Stuff" to rap-sing fond reminiscences of the 1970's. But in "Here We Go Again," he fends off a new girlfriend's questions, saying, "I do not want you to know me the way I used to be."

title: James Caan And the Kids
