''If there's anybody who has any kind of moral backbone, it's him, because he's caught in a dilemma between serving his boss and taking care of his boss's daughter.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, STEPHEN C.
description: HARTMAN-Stephen C., 58. Of West Orange, NJ, formerly of Randolph, NJ, suddenly on September 5, 2000. Loving father to Dana, Abigail and Nedda and lifetime friend to former wife Anne Hartman. Mr. Hartman is also survived by his brother Roger of Mill Valley, CA & uncle Ralph Spritzer of Tempe, AZ., and was the devoted son of the late Leonard and Geraldine Hartman. Mr. Hartman, a ranked tennis player and avid fisherman was a graduate of Hewlett High School and earned his undergraduate & MBA degrees from Columbia University. Services 12:00 noon today at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Shiva at the Hartman residence, 62 Meadowbrook Road, Randolph, NJ. For further information and directions please call 1-800-525-3834.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a contract for energy management services received by a unit of the Enron Corporation misspelled the name of the company that awarded the contract. It was Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., not Starwoods. The report also misstated part of the terms. The Enron unit will supply electricity and natural gas to six brands of Starwood-owned hotels in North America, not six hotels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTON, THOMAS J.
description: HUTTON-Thomas J. Died of cancer in Santa Barbara, CA on August 23, 2000 after a long lingering illness. After graduating from The Hill School in 1960, he attended Union College for two years. He enlisted in the U.S. Marines and served two years in the Reserves. He lived abroad for four years in Rome and London. He moved to California where he resided until his death. He was a talented photographer, pianist and composer. For those who knew him he taught us a lesson in bravery and integrity. Funeral services will be private.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Middle East peace talks referred incorrectly to United Nations resolutions on the Arab-Israeli conflict. While Security Council Resolution 242, passed after the 1967 Middle East War, calls for Israel's armed forces to withdraw "from territories occupied in the recent conflict," no resolution calls for Israeli withdrawal from all territory, including East Jerusalem, occupied in the war.

description: LEVY-Fannie (nee Kaplan). Died on September 6, 2000, two days short of 106 wonderful years. Her husband, Dr. Herman Levy, predeceased her twenty years ago. She is survived by son Edgar and daughter Francine Kalb, son-inlaw Sandy, grandchildren Gary Kalb and Bonnie, Shoshanna Smith and Robert, great grandchildren Heather and Shannon Kalb, and Justin Smith. We all wish her everlasting peace. She will be sorely missed.

title: Stalked by a Serial Killer, He Pursues Talk Therapy
description: One night last spring, fighting insomnia in a North Carolina hotel room, I spent a few hours flipping back and forth between ''The Matrix'' and ''Devil's Advocate,'' which were showing on competing cable stations. After a while they began to run together into a single montage of Keanu Reeves dressed in black clothes, furrowing his smooth brow in bewilderment as he grappled with one metaphysical conundrum after another.

title: Low-Profile Consumer Protection
description: The offices at the decaying headquarters of the government consumer protection agency here are threadbare and sparsely furnished, and the elevators do not always work. The concept of class-action suits does not exist in the local legal code, and even if it did, there is no network of consumer advocacy groups or lawyers to promote them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUTYMAN, WILLIAM
description: BEAUTYMAN-William, M.D. Of Blue Bell, PA and Winter Harbor, ME, died on September 5, 2000, of prostate cancer. Born in Northumberland, England on January 4, 1920, he took top honors at Christ College, Cambridge University and received medical training at University College and St. Bartholomew's Hospitals in London. After serving as a Captain in the Royal Army Medical Corps in the Mediterranean during WW II, he came to the U.S. in 1951 and became Chief Pathologist, Director of Laboratories and Chairman of the Pathology Department at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, MA. There, in 1957, he created a freestanding Residency Program in Pathology that maintained its accreditation throughout the 35 years of his leadership. He was also praised for the early introduction of computers and molecular genetics into the pathology laboratory. Private passions included studying the lives of Sir Thomas More and Cardinal John Newman and the works of Shakespeare. He is survived by his sons William, Jr. of Stockbridge, MA, and Michael of Flourtown, PA, his daughter Elizabeth of New York City, and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Winter Harbor Public Library C/O Alan Smallidge, Treasurer, Winter Harbor, ME. 04693.

title: How Worshipers, Too, Can Denature Nature
description: As soon as nature began to shrink under ingenious human efforts to dominate it, imagination magnified the charms of untouched land. In the mid-19th century, Hawthorne in the Massachusetts woods and Thoreau at Walden Pond were made uneasy by the intrusive sound of locomotives and the French painter Theodore Rousseau, in the Barbizon forest, said: ''Let the civilized world go to the devil! Long live nature, forests and ancient poetry!''

title: INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED
description: With signs that economic growth is easing, the Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 6 percent for the seventh consecutive month. The decision had little impact on foreign exchange markets, where the British pound has slipped by 6 percent against the dollar in the last three months. The bank's decision coincided with data suggesting that car sales are falling and both retail prices and wage increases are slowing. The combination left inflation in July at an annualized 2.2 percent, below the government's target of 2.5 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: DuPont Shares Drop 10% as Company Warns on Profits
description: The DuPont Company, the nation's biggest chemical company, warned yesterday that soaring costs for fuel and raw materials, the declining value of the euro and potentially lower sales would push earnings for the rest of the year below Wall Street's expectations.

title: I.B.M. EXPANDING VENTURE WITH RETEK
description: Shares of Retek, a maker of software for the retail sales industry, surged yesterday after I.B.M. said it would take an undisclosed equity stake in the company. Retek shares gained $9.25, or 29 percent, to $41.38. The alliance, begun in March, originally called for software, hardware and services to aid e-commerce in the food and drug segment of the retail industry. Under its new terms, it will be expanded to other segments and I.B.M. will quintuple, to 300 from 60, the number of professional staff members devoted to it.

title: U.S. Report Will Criticize I.O.C. on Drugs
description: With the Summer Games set to open a week from today, a report financed by the White House office of national drug policy has issued a stinging rebuke to the International Olympic Committee as ineffectively combating the pervasive use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: DISPOSABLE CREDIT CARD NUMBERS
description: American Express said that within a month it plans to begin offering a free service that will generate random numbers that can be used instead of account numbers for cardholders making online purchases. A cardholder would be able to obtain a ''private payment number'' that could be used at any site that accepts American Express cards. To save a few clicks, cardholders would be able to download software from the company's Web site that would automatically produce a payment number for purchases at selected e-tailers, a spokeswoman said. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

To Susan, her father Leonard, her sisters Carol Rose and Linda Hartmann, and all of her mother's loved ones we extend our heartfelt condolences. Suzanne Toor Karpas Irving D. title: Leaders of Aryan Nations Found Negligent in Attack
description: Issuing a verdict that civil rights organizations hope will bankrupt one of the nation's largest white-supremacist groups and limit its ability to preach hate, a state jury in northern Idaho today ordered leaders of the Aryan Nations to pay more than $6 million to the victims of an attack two years ago by men who were serving as security guards at the group's compound near here.

title: China's New Culture Starting To Take Shape, Minister Says
description: For Sun Jiazheng, the Chinese culture minister, the emergence of a global culture wears many faces. On the one hand, moviegoers in Beijing can swoon at screenings of ''Titanic.'' On the other, computer jockeys in Shanghai might surf Web sites that carry ''unhealthy'' material.

description: HESSEL-Marek, Dr. The Dalton School community is saddened by the death of Dr. Marek Hessel, husband of Helena Hessell and father of Daniel. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire family.

title: Teamsters Endorse Gore; Hoffa Says Choice Was Easy
description: Long after most other unions had backed Vice President Al Gore for president, the Teamsters' executive board gave him its endorsement yesterday. Despite the long wait, James P. Hoffa, the union's president, said the decision was easy.

title: ONLINE HOUSEHOLDS APPROACH 300 MILLION
description: More than 295 million people in 20 countries around the world have Internet access from a residential personal computer, according to findings from a new Nielsen/NetRatings global Internet trends service. In 14 European markets, an estimated 82 million people have access to the Internet from a home PC. David Day, director for analytics at ACNielsen eRatings.com, said the figure equated to one household in five, and noted that 22 percent of European households had access via more than one source. In four leading Asia- Pacific markets, an estimated 37 million people have access to the Internet from a home personal computer. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Documents Show Firestone Knew of Rising Warranty Costs
description: Internal documents from Bridgestone/Firestone show that officials of the company were briefed as early as February about rising warranty costs for the tires that the company recalled last month.

title: Veto of Estate-Tax Repeal Survives Vote in the House
description: Supporters of a bill to repeal the federal tax on large estates failed today to overturn President Clinton's veto of the measure, killing the issue for the year in legislative terms but leaving it very much alive politically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIPKE, DOROTHY
description: KRIPKE-Dorothy. The entire Jewish Theological Seminary community mourns with sorrow the death of Dorothy Kripke, a JTS graduate, rebbetzin and children's boo k author. Dorothy and Rabbi Myer Kripke were married at JTS in 1937. In 1996, she and her husband donated $7 Million to restore and renovate JTS's library tower, destroyed by fire in 1966. Their gift resulted from a modest nest-egg investment she encourged her husband to make with financier Warren Buffet, a friend from the Omaha, Nebraska neighborhood where they had settled. Dedicated to building a Jewish home and community far from her native New York, she is survived by her husband and their three children, Saul of New Jersey, Madeline of New York and Netta Stern of Connecticut, son-in-law Yossi Stern and two grandchildren. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: 20 Killed in Latest West Timor Attack
description: ATAMBUA, Indonesia, Sept. 8 -- The United Nations said 20 people were killed in fresh fighting in Indonesian West Timor on Friday, two days after the murder of three U.N. aid workers. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) agency in the East Timor capital, Dili, said the latest clashes occurred at the refugee camp of Betun, which had been taken over by pro-Jakarta East Timorese militias the previous night. ``The 20 casualties reported have been killed...we have no information so far about the wounded. We don't know whether they are Indonesian citizens or East Timorese," UNHCR operations manager for East Timor Bernard Kerblat told reporters. Betun is a stronghold for the militias which razed East Timor after it voted in August, 1999, to end Indonesia's military rule and who fear returning to their homeland, now under U.N. rule. The camp is just south of the West Timor border town of Atambua, where militias butchered three foreign UNHCR workers on Wednesday and mutilated their bodies. FUNERAL MAY HAVE BEEN TRIGGER About 1,000 people attended the funeral in Betun of a militia leader whose murder earlier this week is believed to have triggered Wednesday's violence. ``The funeral was quite tense because the mob, mostly in trucks and motorcycles, roamed the town first, forcing shops to close and residents to stay inside," an army intelligence officer said in Atambua. But he denied there had been any clashes. Kerblat said no aid workers were among the latest victims but gave no further information. The United Nations pulled more than 240 workers and dependents out of West Timor after Wednesday's slayings. Indonesia's cabinet spent most of the day on the issue but came up with nothing new to appease international anger over the militias and the murders. ``Indonesia will take wise, fair and realistic steps to seek a permanent solution," top security minister Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said afterwards, adding investigations were continuing. President Abdurrahman Wahid did not attend the meeting. He is in New York for a special U.N. summit, where he faced angry world leaders over Wednesday's murders in Atambua. The killings overshadowed the start of the U.N. summit in New York, where a minute's silence was held for the three men from the U.S. commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Croatia and Ethiopia. At least six West Timorese residents also died in Wednesday's bloodshed and scores of houses were torched. REFUGEES ON THEIR OWN Atambua, about 2,000 km (1,200) miles east of Jakarta, was tense and deserted on Friday with almost no traffic and most residents shut up in their houses, fearing further trouble. The handful of people on the streets were too afraid to speak to visiting journalists, who were also turned away by hotels afraid their presence would bring trouble from the militias. The U.N. withdrawal leaves more than 120,000 East Timorese living in refugee camps in West Timor without any outside help. They were among more than 300,000 people the militias forced across the border from their homes in East Timor in a rampage that followed the territory's independence vote. Indonesian newspapers on Friday condemned the brutality as a national disgrace. The Jakarta Post demanded the military disband the militias it created in a failed bid to swing last year's East Timor vote. ``The Indonesian military, being the chief sponsor of the militias must be made to rein in its proxy soldiers, disarm them and arrest their leaders who have perpetrated the campaign of terror," it said in an editorial. And it urged the government to bring the army officers and militias behind last year's bloodshed to trial. ``Surely the government must now realise the shame and disgrace which the Atambua killings have brought on the entire nation is simply too high a price to pay to shield the dozens of murderous generals, colonels, lieutenants and militia leaders from having to appear in court," it said. U.S. President Bill Clinton, in New York for the U.N. summit, raised the killings at a Security Council debate on peacekeeping. ``I ask the Indonesian authorities to bring those responsible to justice, to disarm and disband the militias and to take all necessary steps to ensure the safety of those continuing to work on humanitarian goals there," Clinton said. Authorities have arrested 15 people over Wednesday's murders. Provincial military chief Colonel Jurefar told Reuters a company of reinforcements -- about 90 men -- had arrived in West Timor and the rest of the battalion was due later on Friday. ``They will establish order there with the police," he said. ``They will confiscate weapons."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, ARTHUR A.
description: MANNING-Arthur A. Died September 4, 2000 after a courageous battle with diabetic complications. Arthur served as a forensic detective in the New York City police department and retired with honors approximately 15 years ago. As a youth, he rose through the ranks of the Boy Scouts serving as a leader and a mentor to the Bronx young men of his home base. He was instrumental in the development of the Ranachqua Foundation, a growing group of scout alumni who attended the Ten Mile River scout camps. The foundation's efforts over the past 60 years provided the funds to send young scouts from the Bronx to the same Camp Ranachqua that they attended when they were their age. Arthur was chairman of the board of directors. Contributions in Arthur's memory may be made to Ranachqua Foundation, 1732 Astor Avenue, Bronx, NY 10469. Memorial service will be held on Monday, September 11, 2000 at 11:30AM at Thomas Montera Funeral Home 1848 Westchester Avenue, Bronx, NY.

title: Indian Affairs Bureau Delivers Apology to Native Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  The Bureau of Indian Affairs marked its 175th anniversary today in a ceremony that blended sorrow, hope and a remarkable apology from the bureau's director.

title: Airliner Is Forced To Evade Stealth Jet
description: A United Airlines passenger plane leaving Los Angeles for Boston today was forced to take evasive action when it came too close to an Air Force stealth fighter shortly after takeoff, airline and federal officials said.

title: SUPERMARKET ACQUISITION
description: The Dutch supermarket retailer Royal Ahold N.V. is to expand its operations in Spain with the purchase of the Superdiplo chain of food and general merchandise stores for 1.2 billion euros ($1 billion) worth of shares. Once it is complete, the purchase will add hundreds of stores to the operations Ahold already has in Spain and is expected to generate sales of about 2 billion euros, Ahold said.

title: A Battle of Egos Over 'Kane'
description: Famous for gathering the Hollywood elite at San Simeon, his California estate, the press baron William Randolph Hearst was once asked why he didn't devote himself fully to movies rather than journalism. ''He said: 'You can crush a man with journalism, but not with motion pictures.' That was his answer,'' Douglas Fairbanks Jr. says in the documentary ''The Battle Over Citizen Kane.'' Released on tape this week by WGBH Boston Video, the 1996 Academy Award-nominated film depicts two gifted egomaniacs in the process of discovering that, whether by movie or newspaper, those most damaged could include themselves.

title: Concerns Given Time to Stop Order on Drug
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and American BioScience Inc. have been given six days to try to stop a judge's order that could clear the way for a generic version of the cancer drug Taxol.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: SONY SAYS CHIP WILL ADD BATTERY LIFE
description: Transmeta, the upstart chip maker, will announce its first major design victory today when Sony plans to bring out a new version of its 2.2-pound Vaio C1VN PictureBook Computer. The machine will use a 600-megahertz Transmeta microprocessor and will be priced at $2,299.99. Sony executives said the Transmeta chip would roughly double the battery life of the system, now ranging up to 5.5 hours. Earlier this year, Transmeta announced several Intel-compatible microprocessors designed to consume less power than comparable Intel chips. Since then, Intel has responded with its own low-power microprocessors. John Markoff (NYT)

title: How Does This Manhattan Love Story End? Flip a Coin.
description: Stephen Spoonamore, the playwright responsible for last year's torturous ''Noah's Archive,'' has done it again. That is to say, he has written another tedious play.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; CELLULAR PHONE SPINOFF
description: The Mexican telecommunications giant Telefonos de Mexico said that it would create a spinoff company called America Movil which will undertake all of Telmex's foreign investments, principally in Latin American cellular phone services. Telmex's cellular phone subsidiary, Telcel, will become part of America Movil, which will take over Telmex's existing wireless services in Brazil, Puerto Rico and Guatemala. The Telmex president, Carlos Slim Domit, Latin America's richest man, said that the separation would give his cell phone businesses more independence and flexibility. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: President of Mitsubishi Announces Resignation
description: Katsuhiko Kawasoe, the president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, said today that he was resigning to take responsibility for a 20-year cover-up of customer complaints that led to the recall of one million vehicles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, BERNARD J.
description: AXELROD-Bernard J.Of Larchmont, NY, on September 7, 2000. Born, April 11, 1909, New York City, graduated Columbia College and Columbia Law School. Engaged in private law practice, trustee of Bard College, active in the Alumni Association of Columbia University and in the affairs of the Village of Larchmont and on the board of the Empire State Foundation. Beloved husband of the late Rita Teitelbaum, father of Peter, Nancy and Jane, grandfather of Lisa, Brenda, Roland, Helena and great-grandfather of Connor. Funeral Services at the Larchmont Temple, Sunday, at 1 PM.

title: ASSETS OF CRIME NEWS SITE ACQUIRED
description: A closely held safety-issues Web site, SafetyTips.com, said it had acquired the assets of APBnews.com, a Web site specializing in crime and legal issues, for $575,000 in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. SafetyTips.com, based in Waltham, Mass., withdrew an offer to acquire APBNews.com for $950,000 on Aug. 24. APBNews.com filed for bankruptcy in July.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Middle East peace talks referred incorrectly to United Nations resolutions on the Arab-Israeli conflict. While Security Council Resolution 242, passed after the 1967 Middle East War, calls for Israel's armed forces to withdraw ''from territories occupied in the recent conflict,'' no resolution calls for Israeli withdrawal from all territory, including East Jerusalem, occupied in the war.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Dream Maker, Heartbreaker, She's Crossin' You in Style
description: Although Karen Mason left Chicago many years ago to pursue a musical theater career in New York City, this likable, high-strung performer still exudes the zany effervescence of an ambitious hometown drama student from the Midwest who has just arrived in town, bursting with a starry-eyed optimism. The locus of her sensibility is 1966 or thereabouts, and the Manhattan of her dreams is a ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' world of madcap romantic sophistication.

title: Article 2000090893902436012 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Evidently Plate 347 has arrived with barely a moment to spare. In an area that is neither one neighborhood nor another, the menu at this shining copper bar and bistro has drawn local diners like an offer of free money. To seek the reason, one need only look around. Until now the area has been defined by the police station and the ceaseless traffic headed downtown.

title: When It's Time to Debate, Add Nader's Voice; Bush, Mano a Mano
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE BOND DOWNGRADE
description: Moody's has downgraded yen-denominated Japanese government bonds to Aa2 from Aa1. The agency cited the fact that Japan has the highest ratio of debt as a percentage of gross domestic product among the leading economies and uncertainty over Japan's economic recovery. There was a brief sell-off of stocks and bonds after the rating announcement and then a recovery. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Spadea Accepts Olympic Invitation
description: Vincent Spadea accepted an invitation yesterday from the United States Tennis Association to take the open singles spot on the American Olympic team vacated by Andre Agassi, the 1996 gold medalist, who withdrew for personal reasons. Spadea, who was approved by the International Tennis Federation, was still awaiting approval from Olympic officials last night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CROFTON, GRACE
description: CROFTON-Grace (McDermott). Mom I think of you everyday, love you and pray for you dearly. Your son John and daughter Virginia.

title: Steinberg Is Sued by Mother Over a Debt
description: The financier Saul Steinberg, a onetime corporate raider whose Reliance Group Holdings Inc. has fallen on hard times, is being sued by his mother, who says he has failed to pay her a $4.7 million debt.

title: In Nassau County, Doubts Grow on Avoiding State Takeover
description: Three days after the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, presented his plan to rescue the county's finances, the question facing officials here today was not whether the county still faces a budget crisis. It was whether there was any way out of it short of a humiliating state takeover of the county's finances.

title: Woman Hurt in Subway Fight Is Recovering
description: An 18-year-old woman was recovering yesterday from injuries she suffered in a vicious brawl on a Manhattan subway platform Tuesday afternoon, the police said.

title: Whitman Seeks New Policy on Bears After Protests About Hunt
description: New Jersey's first bear hunt in 30 years appeared doomed yesterday, 10 days before its planned start, after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked the state's Fish and Game Council to cancel it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT O.
description: WHITE-Robert O., 77. Died September 8th, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara O'D White, devoted father of Peter, David, Thomas, and Robert Jr. and loving grandfather of Peter Jr., Timothy, Eric, and Louisa. Funeral Service on Tuesday, September 12th, 2 P.M., St. Luke's Church, 1848 Post Road, Darien, CT.

title: India and Pakistan Continue War of Words, Minus Names, Over Kashmir
description: Two days after Pakistan used the United Nations summit meeting to deliver a blistering attack on India over its occupation of Kashmir, India's prime minister counterattacked today without mentioning the name of his country's bitter enemy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, NORMAN
description: SCHWARTZ-Norman. The Chamber of Commerce of Washington Heights/Inwood is saddened by the passing of Board Member, Norman Schwartz. Our condolences to his wife, Hilda, and family.

title: Unorthodox Lefty Will Give Jones a Fight
description: At first glance, Eric Harding appears to be another notch in Roy Jones Jr.'s legacy, a worthy challenger gunning for an upset against one of boxing's greatest champions.

title: David Charny, 44, Harvard Law Professor
description: David A. Charny, a Harvard Law School professor who was an expert on employment and corporate law and who advised student demonstrators, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ALLA
description: JACOBSON-Alla (nee Moldover). Of Danbury, CT., on Wednesday, September 6, 2000 after a prolonged struggle with ALS. Beloved wife of Felix Jacobson. Services 12:00 noon Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the ALS Charity Fund.

title: Police Leader To Move 300 To Patrol Duty
description: The city's new police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, plans to move at least 300 officers from quality-of-life enforcement to street patrols as part of a larger reassignment that will also beef up the city's overburdened detective squads, police officials said yesterday.

title: Not the Ordinary Kind, In Politics or at Harvard; A Flawed Social Scientist With a Political Agenda? Or a Politician Whose Insights Buttress His Science?
description: When the United States Senate convenes in 2001, a familiar face will be missing for the first time in 24 years. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the four-time senator from New York, is retiring, to be replaced by either Hillary Clinton or Rick Lazio.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROBEX CORP., -- Dallas, a motor oil recycler, agreed to acquire for an undisclosed price almost all the assets of Specialty Environmental Services Inc., a unit of the Houston-based Pennzoil-Quaker State Co. The Specialty unit, based in Shreveport, La., collects used motor oil for Pennzoil-Quaker State, a maker of the two top motor oil brands.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESS INCREASE
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 7.1 percent in August from 6.8 percent in July and 6.6 percent in June, a surprising trend that has raised concerns about the strength of the economy. An estimated 27,000 jobs were added in August, but more than three times as many people joined the work force. The influx of job seekers was a sign of confidence, economists said. But they noted that the number of new jobs in August did not make up for the 31,000 lost in June and July -- and that last month's additions were mostly part-time jobs.

title: Local Scandals Govern Hong Kong Vote
description: Law Hing shifted restlessly from one foot to the other as he listened to the candidates trade accusations in a debate at a housing project here this week. ''These guys are without integrity,'' he said, shaking his head at the litany of supposed wrongdoing and chicanery.

title: No Love Song For Blue Eyes In Bronze
description: A STATUE it may be, but not a statue of limitations. This is the large bronze representation of Frank Sinatra that the Giuliani administration, in concert with the Sinatra family, hopes to put in the heart of Times Square.

title: Awards for Pop and Soul, So Different and So Alike
description: Two awards shows came to New York City on successive nights this week, and they were as different as the pop moment and the soul heritage. The MTV Video Music Awards on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall had giant production numbers, bared navels, lip-synching and hype. The Rhythm and Blues Foundation's Pioneer Awards on Wednesday at the Hammerstein Ballroom offered modesty, a good heart and great unassisted voices.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: QUEENS

title: More Plain Folks React
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the New York State Democratic Committee plans to begin broadcasting today.

title: Yanks Compile Manager List
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre has said he assumes he is coming back next year, the last year of his contract. But at least one Yankee executive has made some very informal inquiries about possible replacements, just in case Torre decides to leave after this season.

title: Journal; Membership Has Its Privileges
description: You can understand the young George W. Bush wanting to dodge Vietnam, as he did by joining the Texas Air National Guard, a k a the Champagne Unit. But what does it say that the middle-aged Mr. Bush was scared to go to Boston?

title: Rutgers On a Roll With a 1-0 Beginning
description: Rutgers has a big football game Saturday night. Not big in a national powerhouse kind of way. The Scarlet Knights took one small, but precious, step forward last week. Now they can take another.

title: Best Come to Battle It Out As Belmont Meeting Opens
description: Racing returned to the metropolitan area yesterday after six weeks at Saratoga, as Belmont opened a 33-day meeting of shakedown tests for some of the country's leading horses on the road to the Breeders' Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ESS, MARGARET EGAN
description: VAN ESS-Margaret Egan suddenly on Sept. 7, 2000 of Plandome. Beloved wife of Greg. Cherished daughter of Thomas Sr. and Catherine. Loving sister of Thomas and William. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Monday 10 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Entombment Calvary Cemetery. Donations may be made to Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 1 Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, New York, NY 10119-0165.

title: Congress Poised for Big Increase in U.S. Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Cushioned by a growing surplus, Congress is poised to approve large increases in spending by federal agencies, pushing the national budget to record levels.

title: Should a Fetus's Well-Being Override a Mother's Rights?
description: The war on drugs arrived with a vengeance in the obstetrics department of the Medical University of South Carolina in the fall of 1989. Distressed by evidence of increasing cocaine use by women receiving prenatal care at the university's public hospital in Charleston, and fearing for the fate of abandoned or impaired crack babies, the staff began testing the urine of patients who aroused their suspicions. Positive test results were turned over to the local prosecutor and the police, and women were arrested on the spot, sometimes at the hospital just after giving birth.

title: Brokerage Firm Executive Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: Randolph Pace, a brokerage firm executive charged with enriching himself through a wide-ranging securities fraud conducted between 1994 and 1997, pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan federal court to 13 felony counts of conspiracy, money laundering and securities fraud.

title: Voter Profiles Selling Briskly As Privacy Issues Are Raised
description: At the end of an alley on a nondescript street, a political consulting firm with the unusual name of Aristotle International has compiled the nation's largest voter databank, the names of 150 million Americans registered to vote. And it is selling them to politicians like George W. Bush, Joseph I. Lieberman and John McCain in ways that many fear removes too much privacy from the voting booth.

title: Clinton and China Leader Meet but With Little Gain
description: President Clinton yesterday urged China's president, Jiang Zemin, to open a dialogue with the new government of Taiwan and put a stop to China's missile exports to Pakistan.

title: Williams and Davenport Advance to Open Final
description: In a rematch of the Wimbledon final in July, Venus Williams and Lindsay Davenport will meet in the United States Open final today.

title: V.I.P.'s Are Helped Through Kennedy by a V.B.P. (Very Busy Person)
description: Yasir Arafat had deadlines to meet. Take, for instance, the fact that he was planning to declare an independent Palestinian state this month. So perhaps such business spurred him to move up his flight to depart from New York from yesterday evening to noon. Or maybe he just missed home cooking.

title: YankeeNets Asks MSG Network a Billion-Dollar Question
description: The company that owns the Yankees made a new offer to the Madison Square Garden Network yesterday in an attempt to break a legal deadlock over who will broadcast the team's games over the next decade.

title: Oil Slips From 10-Year Peak As Saudis Talk of More Output
description: Crude oil fell for the first time in five sessions yesterday, retreating from a 10-year high, after Saudi Arabia signaled that OPEC would agree to expand production to trim prices at a meeting this weekend in Vienna.

title: Technology Pay Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Announces New Transportation Commissioner
description: Iris Weinshall, a 20-year veteran of New York City government, was appointed commissioner of the Department of Transportation by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday. She succeeds Wilbur L. Chapman, who resigned in July to become police commissioner of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: DEVILS GO TO WORK
description: Larry Robinson divided his team into three groups to open camp in West Orange, N.J. Two groups scrimmaged in the morning and the third practiced drills in the afternoon.

title: INSIDE
description: An Apology to Indians

title: WOLVERINE, HUSH PUPPIES MAKER, SEES LOWER EARNINGS
description: Shares in Wolverine World Wide Inc., the maker of Hush Puppies shoes, fell nearly 24 percent after the company said that it expected earnings for its current quarter to miss analysts' estimates. The shares fell $2.94, to $9.50. Earnings for the quarter, which ends today and is the third quarter of Wolverine's fiscal year, will be about 28 cents a share before charges, roughly equal to last year's results, the company said. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected the company to earn 33 cents. Sales in the casual and boot wholesale business were less than expected as retailers appeared to have deferred purchases in a cautious approach to the fall season, Timothy O'Donovan, the chief executive, said in a statement.

title: George Sandell, 88, Musician And Inventor of Gee-Bee Sponge
description: George Edmund Sandell, a versatile viola and violin player, teacher and inventor, died on Aug. 26 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Santa Monica.

title: Corrections
description: The Mixed Media column of the Dining section on Wednesday, about the increased popularity of the Food Network on cable television, misspelled the surname of its founder. He is Reese Schonfeld, not Schoenfeld. The column also misstated the first year in which the network received a Nielsen rating. It was 1995, not 1999.

title: Stalled Contract Sidelines Chara
description: The biggest player in the National Hockey League has a big problem.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas; The Military
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Meeting Ends With Declaration of Common Values
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 8  Three days of brainstorming by the leaders of virtually all the world's nations ended tonight with a brave attempt to agree on a set of goals for the next millennium, and common values by which to govern.

title: Count Inserts Himself Into History in U.N. Summit Photo
description: It might take a magnifying glass to spot him, that man in a navy-blue suit, his chest puffed out, among 180 other world dignitaries in the official photograph of the United Nations Millennium Summit group. But he is there, right next to the foreign minister of Niger, and he is not supposed to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, NORMAN
description: KRAMER-Norman. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their past President and former member, and extend their sympathy to his family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Article 2000090993213872744 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Sound Verdict in Idaho
description: The $6.3 million verdict against the Aryan Nations, the white supremacist group, and its leader Richard Butler may well put the organization out of business. The defendants argue they should not be punished for their racist and anti-Semitic ideology. But this case was not about free speech or the right to hold odious views, which the First Amendment protects. It was about holding an organization responsible for assaults committed by its security guards.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: YASHIN TO RETURN
description: The Ottawa Senators said that Aleksei Yashin, a two-time All-Star, would return in time for the start of training camp today, ending a yearlong holdout.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What else are we not knowing about, and when don't we know it?''

title: Article 2000090992809399813 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Nader Endorses Legal Marijuana
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 8 (AP)  Ralph Nader, the Green Party presidential nominee, spoke out today for the legalization of marijuana as part of an overhaul of the nation's "self-defeating and antiquated drug laws."

title: Why the Best Don't Teach
description: The quality of teachers has been declining for decades, and no one wants to talk about it. Principals know the truth and have to deal with it as best they can, but unions are reluctant to admit weaknesses in any of their members, colleges are loath to acknowledge the poor quality of their education programs, and administrators are afraid that confronting the problem will further erode confidence in public education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SIDNEY R.
description: GREENE-Sidney R. On Sept. 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Lola Greene. Dear father of Mindy Blum and Shari Greene. Cherished grandfather of Noah and Samuel. Father-in-law of Mitchell Blum. Dear brother of Yale Greenberg. Services Sunday, September 10, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, EVELYN SANDEA
description: KRAMER-Evelyn Sandea. Of Adventura, FL. Born Chicago, IL 7-1212 to 9-7-2000. Designer extraordinary of Millinery for Lili Dache and Creative Manager of the late Goodfriends Stores of Chicago. She is survived by her daughters, Sandra J. Cole of Malibu, CA., and East Hampton, NY and Dr. Estyne Del Rio Diaz of New York. Died September 8th in her daughter's home in East Hampton in her sleep. She was a great lover of Arts and Poetry, and wrote her own poems throughout her life. She loved Dancing and won many dance contests throughout her life even as a senior citizen in Florida.

title: PARK-OHIO CITES LABOR AND SLOW GROWTH IN DOWNTURN
description: The Park-Ohio Holdings Corporation, a maker of fasteners and aluminum products, said it would not meet analysts' forecasts for 2000, citing labor issues, slow sales of aluminum products and increased energy costs. Second-half earnings will be 10 cents to 15 cents a share lower than expected. The Cleveland-based company said it had been expected to earn $1.65 a share for the year. The company's chief executive, Edward Crawford, said a recent rise in fuel prices had increased production costs in its aluminum business, while demand had slowed for fasteners used in large tractor-trailers.

title: Work or Family? Both.
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000090994032479033 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: New Owners to Reward Donaldson's Chief
description: Credit Suisse Group A.G. guaranteed Joe L. Roby, chief executive of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the investment bank it is buying for $13.4 billion, compensation of at least $66 million over the next four years.

title: Safety Agency Wants Increase In Authority
description: The head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that she would ask Congress next week for additional money and new authority to ferret out safety problems like the ones that have plagued Firestone tires.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas; Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERUSCH, PHILIP E.
description: BERUSCH-Philip E. Cherished and beloved husband of Mimi. Devoted father of Betsy Day, Peter (Jill), and Steven. Dear brother of Joyce Sutton. Loving grandfather of Benjamin, Lindsey and David. Services at 10 AM, Sunday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Putin Proposes a System for International Help in Submarine Disasters
description: With the loss of the nuclear submarine Kursk and its 118-member crew, President Vladimir V. Putin has begun consultations with other leaders on an international agreement in which nations that operate warships under the sea would come to one another's aid during disasters.

title: In a Verdict, a Sign That His Town Is No Haven for Hate
description: STEVE JUDY was all of 28 years old, and less than a month into his job as mayor of Coeur d'Alene, when he had his first official brush with the Aryan Nations, a white supremacist group that he and countless other people in this northern Idaho city describe as an awful thorn in the side of the community. The group wanted a permit for a parade down the town's main street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, HERBERT
description: WASSERMAN-Herbert, 69. Died September 8, 2000 at his home in Tyringham, MA., after a two year battle with colon cancer. Born on July 30, 1931, he graduated from Harvard College & Harvard Law School. Lawyer, producer/impresario, and business executive, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Cecille; daughters Emily, Stefanie & Wendy and son-in-law Michael Schiffer. A daughter, Julie, died in 1973. Memorial service Sunday, September 10th at 4:00 P.M., at Hevreh Temple, Route 23, Great Barrington, Massachusetts.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: RALPH NADER -- Montrose, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLENS, DR. BERTRAM
description: POLLENS-Dr. Bertram. Sept. 8, 2000. Age 90. Renowned psychologist. Devoted husband of Polly for sixty years. Loving father to Martin, Richard, Linda Sherman and grandfather to Jason Pollens, Daniel and Benjamin Sherman. Services Sunday 11:15 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 31 about a regulatory agency investigation of defective Firestone tires misstated the name of the agency. The error also occurred in an editorial on Thursday and an Op-Ed article yesterday. The agency is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, not the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration.

title: Sorry, Mother, But Get in Line For Your Money; Suit Says Steinberg Sons Failed to Repay Loans
description: It is no secret that times are tough in the once-gilded world of Saul P. Steinberg, the portly plutocrat who with his third wife, Gayfryd, personified a 1980's sort of excess. After all, they sold the contents of their living room at public auction in May, and the insurance company that provided their lavish standard of living is on the brink of bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLIN, FLORENCE
description: SERLIN-Florence, Ph.D. Community Guidance Service and a host of friends and patients mourn her passing on September 7, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHMAN, DIAN DINCIN
description: BUCHMAN-Dian Dincin. Alternative medicine pioneer, writer and activist, author of ''Herbal Medicine'', ''Complete Book of Water Therapy'', ''Complete Guide to Natural Sleep'', and many other books on complementary medicine and other subjects. Past President of American Society of Journalists and Authors (ASJA), a founder of the Council of Writers Organizations. She was the adoring and adored mother of Caitlin Dincin Kraft Buchman, beloved sister of Zola Dincin Schneider and Jerry Dincin, a cherished aunt, loving grandmother, and friend extraordinaire. A lover of life and a woman of wisdom, she will be forever missed by her family and friends. For info call Plaza Memorial 212-769-4400

title: Article 2000090991419558123 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Once Before, Bush Balked at Debating
description: His Democratic opponent needled George W. Bush for months about being ''afraid'' to debate. The opponent said he would debate the Texas governor any time, anywhere.

title: Mets September Slump Continues
description: NEW YORK -- Maybe the New York Mets should put up calendars in the clubhouse that say: "August." They certainly have trouble with September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLKIE, ARLINDA F.
description: WILLKIE-Arlinda F. Born July 31, 1946; died on Sept 7, 2000 from breast cancer. She was courageous, graceful, loving and beloved. We thank her friends, caretakers, nurses and doctors. She is survived by her family including her daughter, Julia T. Miranda; her brother and sister-in-law Frederick & Ida; her sister Julia; her brother Hall; Tom Craveiro; Riccardo Salmona; and her pug Peg. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Benheim Cancer Center or the Red Cross of Greenwich, CT. Service Monday, September 11 at 4 PM, First Congregational Church Old Greenwich, CT.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Thursday about Vice President Al Gore's economic plan misstated the title of Robert D. Reischauer, who spoke of it favorably. He is president of the Urban Institute, not an analyst there. In some copies, the article misidentifed the office of which he is the former director. It is the Congressional Budget Office, not the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the decision of Ted Koppel, anchor of ABC News's ''Nightline,'' to sign a new five-year contract with the program misstated the given name of a new executive producer who will oversee it. He is Leroy Sievers, not Tom.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Inside Art column of Weekend yesterday about the Downtown Arts Festival misstated the role of the NYC Lab School, at 333 West 17th Street. It is giving out festival schedules, not operating an information line. The festival information number is (212) 243-7656.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRILL, SANFORD
description: GRILL-Sanford. On September 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Harry and Fern. Devoted father-in-law of Betsy and Richard. Adoring Papa of Rachel, Avery, Allison, Corey and Hannah. Service Sunday, 12:45PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: With Some Victories in Hand, Battered Labor Flexes Muscle
description: It has been a big month for big labor, judging from the bargaining results at some of the nation's best-known companies.

title: Rebert Harris, 84, Soul Singer And Model for Sam Cooke
description: Rebert H. Harris, the lead singer for the Soul Stirrers, whose style was the fountainhead for generations of gospel and soul singers, died on Sept. 3 in Chicago. He was 84 and lived in Chicago.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: MPOWER SHARES FALL 28% ON REDUCED FINANCIAL OUTLOOK
description: Shares of the Mpower Communications Corporation fell 28 percent after the company forecast lower cash flow and sales, citing delays in gaining access to digital telephone lines and poor planning. Mpower, which has never made a profit, fell $3.44, to $8.88, on the Nasdaq. Mpower, which sells phone and Internet services to businesses using other companies' networks, expects to lose $53 million to $58 million before interest, taxes, stock-based compensation, depreciation and amortization in the third quarter, and $52 million to $55 million in the fourth. Sales are forecast at $38 million to $39 million and $43 million to $46 million, respectively. Mpower is based in Rochester.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Wonders What Became of Quality Control
description: Since a crisis at Firestone over dangerously faulty tires erupted in the United States early last month, shareholders of Bridgestone, the large Japanese tire maker that owns Firestone, have watched in horror as the value of their shares has been sliced in half.

title: California Upholds Rule For Pollutionless Car by '03
description: California regulators voted today to keep a rule requiring that 10 percent of cars offered for sale in the state starting in 2003 emit little or no pollution, a goal that the industry has said is unreachable.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 31 about a regulatory agency investigation of defective Firestone tires misstated the name of the agency. The error also occurred in an editorial on Thursday and an Op-Ed article yesterday. The agency is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, not the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration.

title: Supreme Court to Review Sentencing Issue for Repeat Offenders
description: In an early first act to the new term that begins next month, the Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a growing dispute over federal court review of state criminal convictions.

title: Mr. Lieberman's Campaign Hedge
description: Joseph Lieberman is now running for two national offices at the same time -- his Senate seat from his home state of Connecticut and the vice presidency as the Democratic Party nominee. The Connecticut Elections Enforcement Commission decided this week that this double campaigning is legal. That still does not make it fair to Connecticut voters or smart for the state's Democrats.

title: Modern-Day Slavery
description: By a conservative estimate, there are 27 million people working under various forms of slavery in the world today, and the number is growing. In contrast to the slavery America knew, today's slaveholders mainly exploit people of their own race. But as in the American past, they use violence and threats to force people to labor for no pay. Slavery is illegal everywhere, but it thrives because of the corruption of police and government authorities. Many people are unaware that modern slavery exists.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Foreign dignitaries are gathering this week for the Millennium Summit at the United Nations.

title: In a Style Change, Bush Talks More Directly to the Voters
description: First thing this morning, Gov. George W. Bush stared out at a group of workers and said, ''I have a confession to make. I'm here to ask for your vote.''

description: To the Editor:
