description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 31 about a regulatory agency investigation of defective Firestone tires misstated the name of the agency. The error also occurred in an editorial on Thursday and an Op-Ed article yesterday. The agency is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, not the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, ABRAHAM
description: SCHULMAN-Abraham (Milo). Beloved husband of Edith & devoted father of Francine Haddad and Steven. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Suzanne and Michael. Loving brother of Bessie Perkal. Dear uncle of Marjorie and greatuncle of Luisa. Services Sunday, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: GERMAN TV STAKES SOLD
description: Prince Walid bin Talal, left, a nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, and the Capital Research and Management Company have agreed to buy stakes worth 796.6 million marks ($357 million) in the closely held KirchPayTV G.m.b.H., Germany's biggest pay-TV company, Kirch said. The prince, through his investment company Kingdom Holdings 8 B.V., agreed to pay 346.6 million marks for a 3.2 percent stake in the company, controlled by the closely held KirchHolding. Capital Research, a fund management company based in Los Angeles, will pay 450 million marks for 2.76 percent.

title: Working Families Strain to Live Middle-Class Life
description: When Vice President Al Gore incorporated "working families" into his rhetoric last month and "hard-working middle-class families" this month as pivotal campaign phrases, he pointed a finger  unintentionally perhaps  at a central fact of American life: most of the nation's 72 million families feel they cannot make ends meet.

title: Martin's Sprained Knee Could Slow Jets' Offense
description: Curtis Martin remained stashed in the trainer's room today, away from prying eyes, his sprained left knee receiving treatment until the final moments before practice.

title: DaimlerChrysler Tightens Reins On Management Of Mitsubishi
description: DaimlerChrysler moved today to tighten control over the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth-largest automaker, which has been reeling from last month's disclosure that it had concealed customer complaints about auto defects for more than two decades.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas; The Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Steps Down at J. P. Morgan
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said last night that its chief financial officer, Peter Hancock, had resigned after one year in that position. Morgan, the fifth-largest United States bank, has become a subject of increasing merger speculation.

title: Joseph Louis Marino Lawyer and Legal Educator, 85
description: Joseph Louis Marino, a lawyer and legal educator, died on Sept. 1 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 85.

title: RANK PROFIT FALLS
description: Rank Group P.L.C., the owner of Hard Rock Cafes, said its first-half profit fell 50 percent after it sold Odeon cinemas and other businesses to cut debt and focus on restaurants and gambling. Profit from operations fell to $:29.5 million ($42.4 million) from $:64.9 million in the period a year earlier. Sales at Hard Rock rose 7.4 percent, to 127.6 million pounds.

title: The Joys of September
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Jackson Confronts Leader Of Peru Over Prisoner's Case
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he intended to go to Peru to meet with Lori Berenson, a New Yorker who has been imprisoned on charges of treason for more than five years, and to negotiate with the Peruvian authorities for her release.

title: Venus Williams Beats Davenport in U.S. Open Final
description: NEW YORK -- A glittery tiara in her hair and menace in her strokes, Venus Williams tightened the family grip on women's tennis Saturday night, capturing the U.S. Open title her sister won a year ago.

title: National Briefs
description: Carmel Council Leaves

title: Give the U.N. an Island
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Front Page Raises Issue of Journalistic Ethics
description: The front page image on The New York Daily News yesterday captured the moment almost every newspaper across the country wanted to get: Fidel Castro nearly shaking hands with President Clinton.

title: Woods Back in Contention, Saving His Best for Last
description: In a remarkable span of four holes, Tiger Woods went from the doldrums into contention today.

title: Knight, Under Fire, Denies Manhandling Student
description: The embattled Indiana University Coach Bobby Knight last night denied an allegation that he physically and verbally assaulted a student on Thursday afternoon after the student addressed him by his last name.

title: East Timor Athletes Enjoy Independence
description: It was the starting line, not the finish line, that once seemed beyond the reach of Aguida Amaral in the Olympic marathon. A year ago, she did not even have shoes, much less hope, to participate in the Summer Games.

title: A Killing, and the Anguish Of Families of the Accused
description: They were parents and grandparents who thought they had fully grasped the perils facing their teenagers in the tough working-class streets north of Kennedy Airport in Queens. They said that they understood the power of peers, the lure of gangs and drugs, the impact of movies and music and television that with relentless repetition depicted a culture of casual violence.

title: Cheney Gets Odd Thank-You for Showing Up
description: How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is to share the stump with a thankless Congressional candidate, Dick Cheney learned today.

title: Dwindling Student Body, In More Ways Than One
description: Any dummy who didn't already know that dissecting a corpse is a lot like having sex is instructed to study ''Anatomy,'' the clumsy German horror movie that sneaked into the AMC theater complex yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about preparations in Manhattan for the trial of Dr. Robert Bierenbaum, who is accused of having killed his wife, Gail Katz-Bierenbaum, misstated prosecutors' arguments for allowing testimony by two psychiatrists who treated him before she disappeared in 1985. The prosecutors argued that because Dr. Bierenbaum permitted the psychiatrists to warn his wife and his parents that Ms. Katz-Bierenbaum might be in danger, he had waived his right to confidentiality. The prosecutors did not argue that the psychiatrists had waived it.

title: Negative Impressions Influence a Senate Race
description: Ellen Lehman really wanted Rick Lazio to be her man. Though she identifies herself as a Democrat at heart, Ms. Lehman said she was fed up with the Clintons and hoped that Mr. Lazio, the young Republican congressman with the nice family, would be the one to represent her in the United States Senate.

title: In Statement by the U.N.: The Need for Balance
description: Following are excerpts from the United Nations Millennium Declaration from the General Assembly:

title: Clemens Dismantles Red Sox With a Revitalized Fastball
description: The 122nd and final pitch thrown by Roger Clemens tonight was a 96 mile-an-hour fastball, and when Carl Everett swung and missed, Clemens glared briefly at the Red Sox center fielder before strolling toward the Yankees' dugout. Somebody should have rolled out a carpet in his path.

title: Pooling Political Wrath, Giuliani and Koch Make Up
description: In a cease-fire after five years of hostilities, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and former Mayor Edward I. Koch took to the airwaves yesterday to declare a common bond in trying to unseat certain Democrats in the New York State Assembly. Their targets are Assembly members who voted last year for the repeal of the commuter tax, which has carved deeply into New York City revenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ELVERA M.
description: DAVIS-Elvera M. aka Baby Sanchez. Beloved mother of the late entertainer Sammy Davis, Jr., passed away at home September 2, 2000. She will be missed by many family & friends. Visitation will be held at Benta's Funeral Home, Inc, 630 St. Nicholas Ave, NYC, Monday, September 11, 2 PM to 8 PM. Chapel service will be held on Tuesday, September 12, at 10 AM. Interment will follow in the Restland Memorial Park.

title: On Top of Game, and Life, Sampras Seeks 14th Title
description: A decade ago, Pete Sampras was a California teenager about to barge into sports history. A record 13 Grand Slam titles later, Sampras has returned to the site of his tennis breakthrough a different man, having reached a different place: happiness, and comfort.

title: Shares Decline on Concerns Over Slowing Profit Growth
description: Stocks fell yesterday as evidence of slowing profit growth prompted investors to sell shares that have driven recent gains. Benchmark indexes had their first weekly decline since July.

title: Dayne Clings to Dream Of a Shot at Olympics
description: Ron Dayne says that one day he wants to qualify for the Olympics as a discus thrower.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE STATES

title: INVESTING IN TURKEY
description: Financial institutions from Greece, Turkey and the United States will form a private equity fund to invest in Turkey. Bosphorous Capital Partners was created by J. P. Morgan Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of J. P. Morgan & Company; the National Bank of Greece; and Garaniti Securities, a leading Turkish securities firm. The limited partnership will start with capital of $45 million, and it intends to raise an additional $55 million by fall 2001. The fund plans to invest in small- and medium-size businesses in Turkey. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, EUGENE B.
description: DIAMOND-Eugene B. September 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Louise for 56 years. Cherished father of Margery and Michael Katz, and Beth and Mark Feldman. Devoted grandfather of Erica and Betsy. Loving brother of Melvin. His family and friends will miss his generosity, compassion and wisdom.

title: A Danish Identity Crisis: Are We Europeans?
description: VEJLE, Denmark -- "For Krone and Fatherland" scream the giant posters at the annual congress of the nationalist Danish People's Party, exhorting Danes to defend their currency and their very nationhood.

title: A Populist Pitch Helps Gore Woo Back His Party's Base
description: In the three weeks since he faced open criticism at the Democratic National Convention about his centrist platform and his running mate, Vice President Al Gore has silenced much of the grumbling among core Democratic constituencies and generated an unexpected level of enthusiasm, political analysts and Democratic activists say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Goldman Sachs Is In Talks To Acquire Spear, Leeds

title: Goldman Said to Be in Talks To Acquire Spear, Leeds
description: The Goldman Sachs Group, the investment banking firm, is in serious talks to acquire Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the biggest maker of markets in listed stocks and one of the biggest traders on the Nasdaq stock market, according to a person with knowledge of the talks.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUCHS, RICHARD
description: FUCHS-Richard. July 10, 1945 to September 9, 1995. For five years a light has been gone from our lives, but we make each day a little brighter talking about you and thinking about you. Always in our hearts

title: Politics Without Piety
description: Across the Atlantic, the role of religion in the American presidential race has been followed with a mixture of interest and polite puzzlement. What Europeans find so striking is not that there is a Jewish vice presidential candidate, but that Joseph Lieberman wears his piety on his sleeve, just like other American politicians of recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKUN, MORDECAI A.
description: BERKUN-Mordecai A., MD. A cardiologist and independent businessman. Died on Wednesday, September 6, on Long Island. He was 73 and lived in Great Neck, NY. Loving husband of his late wife Judy. Devoted father of Alicia and Geza, Edward and Joanne, Leslie and Jose, Margarita, Barry and Leslie, Robin and Rick and the late Norman. Grandfather of Alexander, Neal, Robbie, Ben, Noah, Araceli, Sarah, Suzanne and Sam. Brother Ben and sister-in-law, Annette. Dr. Berkun received his medical degree from New York University College of Medicine in 1951. Following service in the U.S. Navy, Dr. Berkun practiced medicine as an internist and cardiologist with partners Rosenthal and Conovitz in Great Neck, NY. After private practice, Dr. Berkun served as Medical Director at Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield in New York City for almost 10 years. Throughout his medical career he held positions within North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, NY and Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, NY. He was a Teaching Fellow in medicine at Harvard University early in his career. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: A Copland Foray Into an Alien Genre
description: Whenever Aaron Copland spoke of his one true opera, ''The Tender Land,'' given its premiere in New York in 1954, he sounded rather defensive. He used to say that for composers like himself not hopelessly drawn to ''la forme fatale,'' as he dubbed the genre, writing an opera was a very problematic business.

title: Text of the Declaration
description: UNITED NATIONS -- Text of the declaration being adopted by the U.N. General Assembly at the Millennium Summit:

title: Indonesia Is Pressed To End Terror By Militias
description: The Security Council tonight condemned the murder of three United Nations refugee workers in West Timor on Wednesday and insisted that the Indonesian government take immediate steps to disarm and disband the militias that are believed to be responsible for the killings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BJOERLING, JUSSI
description: BJOERLING-Jussi, though you died 40 years ago, the glory of your voice lives on. You can never really leave us. Amor ti vieta

title: MERGER CONCESSIONS
description: Officials at the European Commission said yesterday that America Online Inc. and Time Warner Inc. had proposed concessions in their attempt to overcome European antitrust objections to their merger. A spokeswoman for Mario Monti, Europe's commissioner in charge of competition affairs, said there had been concessions. European officials refused to say what the proposed concessions were or whether they would be sufficient. But industry executives thought AOL might have offered to strengthen its earlier proposal to limit its ties to Bertelsmann A.G., the German media company.

title: A.P. Burke, 95, Appeals Court Judge, Dies
description: Adrian P. Burke, a former associate judge of New York State's highest court who was also New York City corporation counsel, died last Sunday at his retirement home in Lauderhill, Fla. A former resident of Manhattan, he was 95.

title: Brazil Shows It Can Be Classical, Too
description: As anyone who has spent time in Brazil can attest, Brazilian celebrations don't usually require elaborate justifications. Still, several were offered as reasons for the concert of Brazilian orchestral music that the consulate general of Brazil sponsored at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Vice President Al Gore's economic plan misstated the title of Robert D. Reischauer, who spoke of it favorably. He is president of the Urban Institute, not an analyst there. In some copies, the article misidentifed the office of which he is the former director. It is the Congressional Budget Office, not the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Bronx Principal Arrested in Child Pornography Investigation
description: The principal of a Catholic elementary school in the Bronx was arrested today on charges that he distributed child pornography over the Internet, becoming the latest man snared by a long-running investigation by Westchester officials into Internet pedophilia.

title: Medicare Puts Off Cuts In Cancer Drug Payments
description: Under withering criticism from doctors, patients and Gov. George W. Bush, the Clinton administration backed away today from a plan to cut Medicare payments for cancer drugs given to hundreds of thousands of patients in clinics and doctors' offices each year.

title: U.N. MEETING ENDS WITH DECLARATION OF COMMON VALUES
description: Three days of brainstorming by the leaders of virtually all the world's nations ended tonight with a brave attempt to agree on a set of goals for the next millennium, and common values by which to govern.

title: Friendly Crowd Provides Castro With a Soapbox
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba stepped away from the formalities of the United Nations summit meeting and back into his familiar battle fatigues last night to address a crowd of flag-waving supporters who hung on his every blistering criticism of the world's superpowers.

title: Peeking at Someone Who Thinks He's Alone
description: ''The Far Side of the Moon,'' a theater piece written, directed and performed by the Canadian theater artist Robert Lepage, is being offered as part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater, but it's not puppetry that commands the stage -- it's Mr. Lepage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, DAVID J.Y.
description: CHANG-David J.Y., passed on September 7, in New York City. For information call Beecher Funeral Home, (914) 769-0001.

title: Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Turn Up Vitriol in Ad War
description: The combative tone of the Senate campaign in New York has escalated this week with an exchange of television and radio advertisements as the candidates battle to redefine their own images and those of the opponent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMLE, LEO K.
description: LEMLE-Leo K. On September 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Trude. Loving father of Laura and Robert. Dear father-in-law of Grant and Roni. Devoted grandfather of Zach, Joanna, Ariel, David and Noah. He will be deeply missed and live in our hearts forever. Service Sunday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corzine Says He'll Debate With Franks 3 Times on TV
description: Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, agreed today to appear with Representative Bob Franks, his Republican opponent, in three televised debates in October, including two on major network affiliates.

title: End Blockade, French Union Head Says
description: A truckers' strike protesting the rising cost of fuel, which had begun to cripple supplies around the country, seemed to lose some of its momentum today when the leader of France's largest truckers' group urged its members to lift their blockades at more than 90 of the country's major fuel depots.

title: An Apology and a Milestone at Indian Bureau
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs marked its 175th anniversary today in a ceremony that blended sorrow, hope and a remarkable apology from the bureau's director.

title: Bush, Facing Criticism, Abandons Debate Stance
description: Gov. George W. Bush abandoned his effort to impose his own schedule of presidential debates today, and his campaign said it was prepared to sit down with aides to Vice President Al Gore to work out an agreement for debating under the auspices of a bipartisan commission.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Venus Williams Outduels Hingis Into Final
description: It was in the thick of the third-set delirium, and a desperate Venus Williams was churning her sinewy limbs as if they were oars to reach one sideline of the court and then sprint to the other.

title: Stalinesque Lines, But a Silky Sound; Man, That's One Ugly Microphone
description: A small Soviet-era factory called Oktava has a well-known fan: the musician Sting. The reason? Its microphones.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 26 about renewed interest in the lynching of Leo M. Frank 85 years ago in Marietta, Ga., referred incorrectly to the grandfather of Philip M. Goldstein, a property owner there. The grandfather, also named Philip Goldstein, did not testify at the Frank trial; the character witness was Max Goldstein, who was not a relative.

title: Report Clears Way For Europe to Drop Austrian Sanctions
description: A panel of experts assessing human rights and political life in Austria cleared the way today for the European Union to lift diplomatic sanctions that were hurriedly imposed last January after the Austrians allowed a far-right party into national government.

title: Candidates Singing Same Tune (Sort Of)
description: Some critics have complained that there's no difference between the two major parties. If music can be any indication, they may be right. Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have picked nearly identical songs as their theme music for the presidential campaigns.

title: Verizon to Grant Stock Options to Most Workers
description: Verizon Communications said in a statement yesterday that it would grant 210,000 employees options to buy 55 million shares of stock, giving them a stake in the telephone carrier's financial performance.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN PROFIT IS UP
description: Buoyed by increased platinum prices and growing demand for diamonds, Anglo American P.L.C., the world's largest mining company, said its first-half profit rose 77 percent to $951 million. The increase outstripped analysts' forecasts and the performance of its rivals Billiton and Rio Tinto, both based in Britain. Analysts attributed the demand for Anglo's mining products and for the diamonds mined by De Beers, in which Anglo holds about one-third of the stock, to the booming United States economy. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Germany Says Wal-Mart Must Raise Prices
description: German competition regulators accused Wal-Mart Stores of being too competitive today, and ordered the giant retailer to raise its prices for household staples like milk, flour, butter, rice and cooking oil.

title: REALNETWORKS AND STREAMBOX SETTLE LAWSUIT
description: RealNetworks Inc., the No. 1 maker of software for playing video and audio online, said it had settled a lawsuit accusing Streambox Inc. of violating the copyrights of content providers. Under terms of the settlement, the closely held Streambox has agreed to modify future software products in a way that complies with RealNetworks' copy protection technology, both companies said. Streambox, which makes software programs that allow DVD-quality video to be delivered to cable modems and DSL modems, will also pay RealNetworks an undisclosed sum. Both companies are based in Seattle. (Bloomberg News)

title: Religion Journal; Affirming Values Without Religion
description: Health care, education and the military have all been -- not surprisingly -- major topics in the presidential campaign. But so has personal religious belief.

title: Rare Bone Disorder Found in H.I.V. Patients
description: An uncommon disorder that destroys bone is turning up with surprising frequency among people infected with the AIDS virus, federal researchers reported yesterday.

title: Mets Continue Their Traditional September Swoon
description: Mike Hampton stalked off the Shea Stadium mound, his disappointment and rage growing with each steady stride. There was polite applause from the fans for Hampton's gritty effort, but Hampton did not hear it. He still heard the sound of Scott Rolen's bat connecting for a two-run homer that eventually guided the Phillies to a 2-0 victory last night over the Mets. It was a sick sound to Hampton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IRVING
description: SHAPIRO-Irving. Beloved father of Barbara Meyerson and Amy Shapiro. Devoted father-in-law of Marvin Meyerson and Jonathan Kandel. Loving grandfather of Elizabeth Kandel. Services at 12:30 PM, Sunday, at Sigmund Schwartz Funeral Home, 152 Second Avenue, Manhattan.

title: One Way to Fill the House: Better Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Talks for Ewing Are Heating Up Again
description: The Knicks, the Seattle SuperSonics and the Los Angeles Lakers have resurrected trade talks concerning Patrick Ewing. The clubs are discussing a three-team deal that would send Ewing to Seattle, Glen Rice from Los Angeles to the Knicks and Horace Grant from the Sonics to the Lakers, three National Basketball Association officials said last night.

title: Article 2000090991632347608 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Lieberman Denounces Bush On Children's Health Care
description: Venturing deep into Gov. George W. Bush's home state, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today painted a dismal picture of Mr. Bush's record on children's health care, and said the governor could not be trusted with the issue on a national scale.

title: Incumbent Snubbed by Her Party
description: As she strode about the tables at the Sunnyside Senior Center in Queens on a recent morning, Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan was greeted by the crowd, mostly women, as though she were their favorite daughter. They asked about her 2-year-old son, they admired her necklace and they cheered lustily as she asked for their continued support.

title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Anhalt, 86, 'Becket' Screenwriter
description: Edward Anhalt, a prolific Academy Award-winning screenwriter best known for his work on the films ''Becket'' and ''Jeremiah Johnson,'' died on Sunday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 86.

title: Article 2000090992304174036 -- No Title
description: BY BOB TEDESCHI

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND FALLS. The British pound fell to a seven-year low after investors decided British interest rates would not change and shifted money out of the currency. The pound settled at $1.4194, down from $1.436 on Thursday.

title: If Politics Is Theater, You Have to Play to the Cheap Seats, Too
description: To clinch his election as a Roman consul, Coriolanus has only to master a bit of political theater. Shakespeare's warrior has the support of the patrician class and the military leaders; he has proved himself fearless in battle, magnanimous in victory and unimpressed by flattery. Now all he must do is perform a pro forma ritual: don a ''gown of humility'' and stand before the plebeian populace, responding to the questions of their delegates, courting their approval, displaying the scars of his many war wounds as testimony to his worth. This public encounter, an early form of the political convention, involves far less theatrical posturing and far fewer inflated balloons than its more recent counterparts. But Coriolanus so scorns Rome's common people that he is powerless on the political playing field. He doesn't just fail, he flails.

title: U.S. Women Defeat Canada To Win World Team Title
description: The United States won the World Women's Team title here tonight, defeating Canada by 32 imps.

title: In an Instant, a Game Can Become Secondary
description: The outcome of the game boosted the Yankees' division lead over Boston to a season-high seven games and left the Red Sox two games behind the Cleveland Indians, who also lost, in the wild-card chase. Excuse the Red Sox if those races were not the prevalent thought in their minds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HELEN
description: WEISS-Helen. A true lady whose grace, dignity and zest for life will always be an inspiration to all of us. She was a role model and grandma to our family as well and will be greatly missed. May Billy and Louis be comforted among the mourners of Zion. We extand our condolences and love to Marion, Suzanne, Jacob, Judith, Danny, Eliana and Dara. George, Miriam, Jason, Chani, Shari, Ian, Jordan, Andrew and Ben.

title: MAXIMUM SECURITY ADOLESCENT
description: The juvenile justice system, founded on the idea that childhood is a distinct stage of life, is being dismantled, with more teenagers imprisoned alongside adults. The ''tough on crime'' side has won, but what kind of society has resulted? A report by Margaret Talbot in The Times Magazine.

title: Bob Cummins, 68, a Producer In Manhattan's Loft-Jazz Scene
description: Bob Cummins, who ran the small jazz record label India Navigation, which documented much of the avant-garde loft-jazz scene that blossomed in Manhattan during the 70's and 80's in underused buildings downtown, died on Aug. 17 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: Commercial Property/Long Island; A Proposed Industrial Park Is Stalled in Riverhead
description: IN the two years since the Navy, authorized by an act of Congress, transferred ownership of its 2,900-acre Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant here on Swan Pond Road over to the town of Riverhead Community Development Agency, redevelopment has moved at a glacial pace.

title: The Sydney Olympics
description: When the 2000 Olympic Summer Games begin Friday in Sydney, Australia, the season in the Southern Hemisphere will still be winter, fading into spring. In addition to being the first Olympics in a new century -- a new millennium -- the Sydney Olympics will be the last Games in the era of Juan Antonio Samaranch. Mr. Samaranch, head of the International Olympic Committee since 1980, will step down, belatedly, next year.

title: Cranking Out Comanecis
description: When the Olympics get under way next week in Sydney, the young women of Romania will once again challenge the great powers of the gymnastics world for supremacy. To a television audience accustomed to seeing tiny Romanians soaring through the air to capture gold medals, this is hardly surprising.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Suzanne Lesser and Anthony Phillips included an outdated reference to the site of the ceremony. It took place at the New Haven Lawn Club. It was moved from the home of the bride's parents in Woodbridge, Conn., because of bad weather.

title: Clinton Is Angry and Dispirited Over Disbarment Fight, Friends Say
description: For his final months in office, President Clinton will remain enmeshed in a battle over his license to practice law that friends and associates say has left him especially angry and dispirited.

title: RESTORING STATE'S IDENTITY
description: The federal Office of Management and Budget has reversed a proposal for interpreting census data that would have made New Jersey a statistical nonentity. The Metropolitan Area Standards Review Committee, a federal panel that reviews how census information is classified, planned to define areas with a million people or more as ''megapolitan,'' which would have absorbed North Jersey into New York City and South Jersey into Philadelphia. Under the latest plan, a region with at least two and a half million people will be subdivided into ''metropolitan divisions,'' with at least 50,000 people, thus giving New Jersey communities an identity. The Office of Management and Budget will release its final guidelines by Dec. 31. Angela Starita

title: Penny Liebman, Mark Aaron
description: Penny Dee Liebman, a daughter of Nancy Liebman and Dr. Norman C. Liebman of Miami Beach, is to be married today to Mark Mordecai Aaron, the son of Carol A. Goldberg and Arthur Aaron Goldberg of New York. Rabbi Marc D. Angel is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel in New York.

title: Kirstie Krall, Gregory Joseph
description: Kirstie Robin Krall, a daughter of Ruth and Martin Krall of New York, was married last evening to Gregory Saul Joseph, a son of Barbara and Martin Joseph of Lido Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Barton Shallat officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: San Francisco
description: On Thursday and Friday nights, Luna Park is like a Broadway theater just before show time. Limousines and taxis pull up out front, disgorging happy, pretty people dressed in black. The wait for a table is an hour; the crowd is five-deep at the bar, and people huddle outside the door as if they were waiting for scalpers to sell them seats.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: The Ethicist; Perk Up
description: Two of us at work travel to the same city to check on our project. One stays at an expensive upscale hotel and receives hotel credits. The other chooses to stay at a much cheaper hotel, closer to the job and equally nice, but without that bonus. Is the first person taking advantage of the corporation? -- B. K., St. Paul

title: From Quail Eggs to Caribou, Toronto Serves Up Uncommon Flavors
description: VISITORS to Toronto who are interested in tasting authentic Canadian cuisine may find the search like rummaging through the clothes dryer for a missing sock -- you know it has to be there, but it isn't in the obvious places. Aside from an occasional caribou steak or maple-cured salmon, many leading Canadian chefs, at least in Ontario, point their antennae south, toward trend-setting cities in the United States and beyond. The result is a roster of restaurants that turns out eclectic, international fare, and more ''fusion'' than an auto welding shop.

title: For Adults Only
description: DREAMS OF BEING

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE LONGEST SILENCE

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 10, 2000
description: Weeks

title: A Gathering of New Isms, Old Masters and Noodles
description: A * indicates an event of special note.

title: Where 60's Values Still Hold Sway
description: ORGANIZERS of this year's Eli Whitney Folk Festival, on Friday and Saturday in New Haven, have more than music on their minds. As they see it, they're part of a movement to promote justice, love, and community -- all those values from the 60's. But they couldn't do it, they acknowledge, without 21st-century technology.

title: South Indian Fare, Flavorful and Diverse
description: COROMANDEL, a new restaurant in Darien, is the latest Indian arrival this year, and it is already proving itself by bringing a new level of creativity to this venerable cuisine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONSHIK, JACOB
description: DONSHIK-Jacob, M.D. Gone but not forgotten. 4/19/12 to 9/10/98. Much loved, much missed. Sharon

title: Sharpen Your Pencils. We're Having a Quiz.
description: THE good news is you made it through a summer of constant rain, mosquito paranoia and summer camps that charge about what it costs to send a kid to Harvard. The bad news is you have to come back to the real world, which is far worse. Assuming you survived the first week of school, here's a back-to-school quiz to help you realign your brain with those of your children.

title: Polly Roberts, Andrew Golden
description: Polly Ann Roberts, a daughter of Susan and Gene Roberts of Washington, is to be married today to Andrew Paul Golden, the son of Dr. Howard Golden of Miami and the late Sheila Lubin Golden. Rabbi Mitchell Chefitz is to officiate at the Miami Beach Rod and Reel Club on Hibiscus Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAYAS, RICHARD
description: ZAYAS-Richard. Of Brooklyn Heights, NY, left this world on September 8. A graduate of Midwood High School, Brooklyn, and Harvard College, he also attended Harvard Business School and was a management consultant. Formerly served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Empire State Pride Agenda and helped elect the first openly gay member of the New York City Council. Few people enjoyed life as much as Richard. A lover of music, he could dance the night away. A man of great intelligence and charm, he profoundly touched everyone who knew him. Richard is survived by his partner of eight and-a-half years Dick Dadey; his parents, Betsy Padin Jackson and Louis Zayas; his brother, Louis, Jr.; his sister, Melody; his grandmother, Ramonita Detres; and many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. Visitation is on Monday, September 11, from 4-8 PM, at St. Boniface Church, 75 Duffield St, Brooklyn. Funeral mass on Tuesday, September 12, 10 AM, at St. Boniface. Call 212-809-2657 for specific directions and further information about arrangements. Contributions can be made to CallenLorde Health Center, 356 W. 18 St, NY NY 10011.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; French Towns Compete With (and for) Flowers
description: There's a fairly common road sign in France that guidebooks and maps aren't much help with. Wherever a major roadway enters a city, town or village, there is a sign stating the name of the community in bold black and white -- easy to understand. But right under the name of about 1,600 communities, you will also see one to four cartoonish flower symbols, five-lobed daisies of the sort that used to adorn VW Beetles 30 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOBLON, JEANNE
description: YOBLON-Jeanne (Hollande r). On September 8, 2000. Devoted wife of Marvin Yablon and loving mother of Douglas Yoblon and Olivia (Yoblon) Kronhaus. Mother-in-law of Nancy Yoblon and Dr. Richard Kronhaus and grandmother of Kerri and Melissa Yoblon and Victoria (Kronhaus) Harms and Alexis Kronhaus. A woman of great dignity and strength, she will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Encounter on the Subway
description: FUNNY how the city can involve you in the life of a stranger and then leave you to forget, catch the 6:15 express and return to your exurban lair. Or challenge you to help in any way you can. Regard this story of rarefied love.

title: Indianas President Fires Coach Knight
description: Bob Knight's storied career as basketball coach at Indiana University ended abruptly yesterday when the university president, Myles Brand, dismissed him for demonstrating a pattern of "uncivil, defiant and unacceptable" behavior since May that culminated with a student's allegation that Mr. Knight had physically and verbally assaulted him last week.

title: On Staten Island, Party Leader Runs, but Some Do Not Follow
description: John W. Lavelle, the Democratic Party chairman on Staten Island, has put together an impressive list of supporters and a formidable operation in his first campaign for public office.

title: Boom Box
description: There is no reason for the black box to be packaged with a surveillance device that records viewing choices. No, thanks. I will await the arrival of the improved VCR, without the surveillance feature.

title: Mixing Freshly Baked With Still Warm
description: PETER SERKIN has never been an ordinary virtuoso. His deep concern with the music of living composers has brought him to work more than most solo pianists in collaborative contexts (his modest demeanor has surely helped here) and encouraged him to be unconventional in his programming. He is more likely to be found playing the piano part in Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire'' than that in a Rachmaninoff concerto, and any recital of his will probably include at least one contemporary piece.

title: Please Go to the Principal's Office

title: Amid the Quick Hits, a Dose of Earnestness
description: IS music a momentary thrill or is it a long-term companion? Popular music has always answered yes to both options.

title: A Rare 'Sell' Rating
description: Wall Street analysts seem to use the word ''sell'' less often than devout grandmothers use profanity. But it happened last week. Neil Currie of UBS Warburg downgraded the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to ''sell'' from ''hold.'' His was the only ''sell'' rating among 103 rating changes or new ratings reported by Bloomberg News on Thursday. A.& P.'s stock, which closed at $12.06, has fallen 64.9 percent this year.

title: Will, Grace and Malcolm Take the Winning Walk
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10  In the early Emmy Awards given tonight, voters brushed aside veteran comedy shows like "Friends" and "Ally McBeal" and presented awards to newer comedy series like "Will and Grace" and "Malcolm in the Middle."

title: Bulbs Here, Bulbs There, Bulbs Everywhere
description: TRADITION has it that the sight of the first robin means that spring is on its way. Yet so many of these friendly birds stay around all through the winter months, they have lost their springtime significance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ELVERA M.
description: DAVIS-Elvera M. ak a Baby Sanchez. Beloved mother of the late entertainer Sammy Davis, Jr., passed away at home September 2, 2000. She will be missed by many family & friends. Visitation will be held at Benta's Funeral Home, Inc, 630 St. Nicholas Ave, NYC, Monday, September 11, 2 PM to 8 PM. Chapel service will be held on Tuesday, September 12, at 10 AM. Interment will follow in the Restland Memorial Park.

title: Pamela Loman, Mark Homicz
description: Pamela Ann Loman, a daughter of Diana and Thomas Loman of Harrington Park, N.J., is to be married today to Mark Raymond Homicz, the son of Sandra and Raymond Homicz of Palos Verdes, Calif. Rabbi Jerry Winston is to officiate at the Viansa Winery in Sonoma, Calif. David Loman, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: South Africa Warns Group After Fatal Attack on Judge
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 9  South Africa's minister of justice, incensed by the assassination this week of a judge who has presided over an important terrorism trial in Cape Town, has said he will ban the organization suspected in the slaying if the group continues what authorities say is a two-year campaign of bombings and terror.

title: POSTINGS: On 34th St. Between 10th and 11th; High-Tech, Short-Term
description: Three New York real estate companies will open a 45,000-square-foot building on the west side of Manhattan this week that is aimed at attracting high-tech companies interested in short-term commitments as tenants. The gutted and rebuilt six-story building, at 535 West 34th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues, will offer 59 furnished office suites and will have available high-speed dedicated Internet services, conference rooms with video conferencing and on-site technical support.

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on piracy prompted mail asserting that capitalism is not to blame for the resurgence but is merely another victim. Readers said yes to Gov. Gary Johnson's campaign for partial drug legalization but no to his ''bootstrap'' approach to poverty. And Stephen King has second thoughts.

title: Laura Gasiorowski, David Downie Jr.
description: Laura Kathleen Gasiorowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Gasiorowski of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Collins Downie Jr., a son of Leslie Strickland Downie of New York and Mr. Downie of San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. Kevin Keelen performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: DELAWARE BAY EXPERIMENTS
description: The University of Delaware has set up equipment to generate high-frequency sound waves beneath the Delaware Bay to learn how such waves act underwater. The experiment, being conducted with the assistance of the United States Navy, is being done off of the 112-year-old Coast Guard lighthouse in the middle of the bay between Delaware and New Jersey. The university received permission for the experiment from the environmental departments of New Jersey and Delaware, which required monitoring of undersea animals and fish during the tests.

title: Urbane Renewal
description: THE opening of the Robert Treat Hotel was one of the grandest moments in Newark history. It was 1916 -- the 250th anniversary of Newark's founding by Robert Treat, who in 1666 had led a band of Puritans out of New England to settle on the green banks of the winding Passaic River. Now this brawny, thriving capital of industry and finance had just passed a quarter-million population. It was feeling good about itself, and it decided to give itself a party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LAWRENCE
description: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.

title: Boom Box
description: I very much enjoyed Michael Lewis's article (Aug 13). But let's get real: the mass market has already been blown apart, thanks to all the new cable choices, the Internet and our busy lives.

title: An Adventure Can Start With a Click
description: ADVENTURE travelers represent the fastest growing segment of the $447 billion leisure travel market, according to the nonprofit Travel Industry Association. It is no surprise, then, that Internet entrepreneurs have flocked to this category with all the reckless abandon of the travelers they hope to serve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, ROSELYN
description: TAYLOR-Roselyn. Beloved wife of Irwin, passed away Sunday, September 3 at their home in Lake Worth, Fla. She was a dear friend for many years, I will miss her very much. My family shares my sentiment. Our condolences to the entire family. Florry, Carolyn, Bill, Michele & Peter.

title: Sept. 3-9; A Tragedy Is Remembered
description: Resurrecting a World War II tragedy, 70 relatives and friends gathered on the Black Sea to honor 778 people who died when a Russian submarine, for reasons unknown, sank a defenseless steamer carrying Jews fleeing Romania.

title: Sotheby's Trying to Tame Its Noisy Air-Conditioner
description: Sotheby's has one more chance to fix its noisy air-conditioning system, or the city will block the unit's power, officials said last week after issuing a fourth violation against the auction house.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHMAN, DIAN DINCIN
description: BUCHMAN-Dian Dincin. Alternative medicine pioneer, writer and activist, author of ''Herbal Medicine'', ''Complete Book of Water Therapy'', ''Complete Guide to Natural Sleep'', and many other books on complementary medicine and other subjects. Past President of American Society of Journalists and Authors (ASJA), a founder of the Council of Writers Organizations. She was the adoring and adored mother of Caitlin Dincin Kraft Buchman, beloved sister of Zola Dincin Schneider and Jerry Dincin, a cherished aunt, loving grandmother, and friend extraordinaire. A lover of life and a woman of wisdom, she will be forever missed by her family and friends. For info call Plaza Memorial 212-769-4400

title: Claudia Mesrop, Eric Zeller
description: Claudia Anne Mesrop, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden Mesrop of Pelham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric William Zeller, a son of Ann Mooney of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Stephen Zeller of New Rochelle, N.Y. Justice Elaine Jackson Stack of the State Supreme Court in Mineola, N.Y., performed the ceremony at a private home in Quogue, N.Y.

title: Jacobs Won't Battle Russian in 1,500
description: Finally, Regina Jacobs would break the cycle of brilliant Olympic trials and unsatisfying Olympic Games. At 37, she was at the peak of her running career. Having won a pair of silver medals in the 1,500 meters at the world championships, she would challenge for gold in the Sydney Games.

title: A Tough Abstractionist on Her Own Merits
description: WHEN the Lee Krasner traveling retrospective arrives at the Brooklyn Museum of Art on Oct. 6, it will be a homecoming for this Brooklyn-born painter. Over the years, different shows have kept her work in sight, but this is the first museum survey in New York in a long time, and no doubt it will come as a revelation to some people. New Yorkers will see what the rest of the country has seen while the exhibition made its cross-country tour: that Krasner's best paintings are as beautiful as any abstract paintings America has produced.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9  Keith Primeau lost millions of dollars last season sitting out as a National Hockey League restricted free agent.

description: I built my first harpsichord when I was 22. I did it to impress a girl.

title: Is the No. 7 a Good Line? Or Poor? It All Depends
description: Is the No. 7 train the city's best subway line, or do its trains tend to bunch up and arrive inconsistently? Oddly, the answer is both, say two transit advocacy groups.

title: Fly-Fishing in Montana Makes Indelible Memories
description: My wife's family reunion out West in Wolf Point was a great excuse for a fishing trip back to Montana after a four-year absence. Joan did not have to twist my arm. We left New York, where I am a guide on the Fourth of July and tag-teamed up for the marathon drive to the Rockies.

title: Palestinians Meet on State
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9  A Palestinian leadership body opened a two- day, closed-door assembly in Gaza City today, at the end of which they are expected to defer the declaration of Palestinian statehood originally set for next week.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9  Unshaded, winner of last month's Travers Stakes, will be sidelined until next year because of a strained tendon in his left foreleg.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column last Sunday about Kitty Carlisle Hart referred incorrectly to the collaborators of her husband, the playwright Moss Hart. They were George S. Kaufman and Irving Berlin. (The Hart who worked with the composer Richard Rodgers was Lorenz.)

title: Comas Scores Hat Trick In the MetroStars' Loss
description: The MetroStars lost to the New England Revolution, 4-3, tonight at Foxboro Stadium and wound up improving from the worst record in Major League Soccer last season to the third best this year.

title: From the Voice of Dogma Comes the Sound of Music
description: LARS VON TRIER'S ''Dancer in the Dark,'' which opens the New York Film Festival on Sept. 22, is the story of Selma, a factory worker who is losing her sight. Played by the Icelandic pop singer Bjork, Selma escapes her life of drudgery with fantasies that place her at the center of an idiosyncratic movie musical. In the conversation that follows, the critic Dave Kehr, who writes the At the Movies column for The New York Times and was a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee, talks with Mr. von Trier about the form and function of the musical and how ''Dancer in the Dark'' confronts that tradition.

title: Old Southern Strategy Faces Test in Selma Vote
description: After 35 years, Mayor Joseph T. Smitherman's high-wire act above the city's churning racial politics had begun to settle into routine. Every four years, he would hold barbecues in black neighborhoods, boasting about the number of black department heads he had appointed, while reminding white voters that he would be ''the last white mayor of Selma,'' hinting that the racial deluge was around the corner.

Caroline Parkinson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Church of The Plains. The Rev. Lawrence Burns, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the service.

title: Clinton Calls for More Aid To Cure Wildfire Problems
description: After what he called ''one of the worst fire seasons in memory,'' President Clinton said yesterday that he would seek to more than double federal spending on wildfire programs in the year ahead. He asked Congress for nearly $1.6 billion more to aid affected communities and to try to prevent future blazes.

description: ARMING AMERICA

title: Brookhaven Mega-Center: Paradigm or Pariah
description: IN 1972, Wilbur Breslin bought 1,150 acres of land near Exit 68 of the Long Island Expressway and continued shopping until he had accumulated over 2,000 acres in the Town of Brookhaven. The property sprawled across the L.I.E. and into the heart of the undeveloped Pine Barrens.

title: A Center of Backstage Calm in a Sea of Frenzy
description: CURTAINS will rise and fall this season. There will be new shows and new stars. Old reputations will be polished. But one thing will remain constant: Backstage, on any given night, a stage manager will be calling a quiet ''Places.''

title: Allison Dubin, Christopher Tracy
description: Allison Jill Dubin, a daughter of Lisa and Daniel Dubin of New York, was married yesterday to James Christopher Tracy, the son of Marie Therese and James Tracy of Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. Debra Steen Ross, an interfaith minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents in Hampton Bays, N.Y.

title: In Chicago, an Attempt to Upgrade a Neighborhood
description: A NEW housing development rising on the city's North Side is the first step in what city officials hope will be the transformation of one of Chicago's most notorious public housing projects into one that mixes the economic classes and makes the area more like Old Town or Lincoln Park, two gentrified neighborhoods it borders.

title: Hitting Executives Where They Live
description: Suppose you have a corporate infrastructure software product to sell to top executives at big, technologically adept companies  a notoriously hard bunch to reach. How do you stand out from the other thousand companies clamoring for their attention?

title: Nerissa Guballa, Timothy Dutta
description: Dr. Nerissa Sylvia Guballa, a daughter of Dr. Sylvia Pagulayan and Francisco M. Guballa Jr. of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Timothy Chandra Dutta, the son of Dorothy Dutta and Dr. Paritosh C. Dutta of Dallas. Rabbi Jerry Heller officiated, with the participation of the Rev. Gerald Heinen, a Roman Catholic priest, at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Afterward, Gopal Bhattacharya, a Hindu priest, performed a Hindu ceremony.

title: Messier's Return Dominates Rangers' First Day
description: Had it not been for Mark Messier's presence here today, the biggest story as the Rangers opened training camp might have been the rookie defenseman Dale Purinton's two fights with an overmatched antagonist named Marty Melnychuk, one on the ice and one in the trainer's room later.

description: Amy Jennifer Satin, a daughter of Roberta and Irwin Satin of West Orange, N.J., was married on Monday to Alexander Michael Spinelli, a son of Eva Spinelli and James Spinelli, both of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Marc Jagolinzer performed the ceremony at the Castle Hill Inn and Resort in Newport, R.I.

title: Reggae in Ortley Beach
description: In the world of reggae, you can't get more real than Frederick (Toots) Hibbert, who is credited with coining the term reggae. Now celebrating his 34th year in the business, Toots and the Maytals, will make their way from Kingston, Jamaica, to the Jersey Shore.

title: Lives Transformed By Leaps and Bounds
description: YOU seldom come across a film in which a father advises his son to forget about going to medical, law, or business school and, please, to concentrate instead on learning to dance Siegfried in ''Swan Lake.'' (Of course this could change if anyone ever films ''The Peter and Nilas Martins Story,'' about the father and son who are, respectively, ballet master and principal dancer at the New York City Ballet.) Furthermore, in the traditionally masculine working-class screen world of coal miners, steelworkers and meatpackers, real men who sweat for their pay by day don't dream that their sons will abandon wrestling or football to perfect their tours jetes.

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; A Witness to the Final Journey
description: TWO gentle, unobtrusive voices unite the many seemingly disparate threads that are woven into Bill Moyers's magisterial documentary on death, ''On Our Own Terms,'' which begins tonight on PBS. The first is the voice of Moyers himself, the temperate sound of a compassionate understanding that never treads roughshod on the boundaries of another's sorrow. It does not probe so much as it simply asks and wonders. Though it is the voice of a stranger, it speaks in the tones of a fellow seeker, which are tones not only of one who yearns to know but also of one who yearns to ease the burden of an inescapable passage, and an inescapable loss. It is in the unaffected honesty of his questions and his spoken thoughts, whether uttered to those who are to die or to those who are to lose them, that Mr. Moyers brings to the harsh medium of television a level of humanity and truth that will leave few viewers unchanged.

title: Brooke Ackerman, Ross Bick
description: Brooke Ilana Ackerman, a daughter of Judith and Leonard I. Ackerman of East Hampton, N.Y., was married there last evening to Ross Michael Bick, a son of Marcia Bick of Stamford, Conn., and the late David Bick. Rabbi David Gelfand performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

title: Alabama Headlines Big Bang Concert
description: The twang of country music guitars, not the crack of the bat, will be heard at the Sandcastle Stadium in Atlantic City next Saturday as the country band, Alabama, takes the stage to headline the first of two days of the Big Bang Concert Series.

title: The Chill Isn't Gone For 2 Quarterbacks
description: Rob Johnson of the Buffalo Bills was taking a beating. By the end of the third quarter in the brutal opener against a hard-hitting Tennessee Titans defense, Johnson had a noticeable limp and looked woozy. It got so bad that some of his teammates on the sideline were saying to each other, ''Better get Flutie ready.''

title: A Filmmaker Both Promising and Forgotten at 64
description: FEW authentic American filmmakers have done as much to absorb and employ non-American ways. Yet Philip Kaufman deserves to be regarded as an American filmmaker. ''The Right Stuff'' examined our power, our progress and all our brands of heroism. And it had that old American acid -- irony. But America didn't really enjoy that movie: the taste for irony had faded. So Phil looked farther afield: he made ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' a Czech film done in France; he did ''Henry and June,'' about Americans in Paris and that stranger country called Sex. Again, America managed not to be impressed. But now, I think, he's got it: he has an Australian playing the Marquis de Sade in a picture made in England. Now only the dunces can miss the irony and the charming way in which ''the English movie'' has become the equivalent of an American genre.

title: A Champion From the 1928 Games
description: WHEN the Olympics begin in Sydney, Australia, this week, George Baird will be watching as the athletes confront the blend of nerves, international attention and world-class competition that is the Summer Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPORE, MICHAEL J.
description: LEPORE-Michael J., M. D. The Gastroenterology Dept. of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital was saddened to hear of the loss of Dr. Michael Lepore, the former Chief of Gastroenterology at Roosevelt Hospital (1962-1966). He was an outstanding educator and an inspiration to many of our trainees and attending physicians. Heartfelt condolences to members of the family and friends. Peter Holt, M.D. Albert Attia, M.D. Gastroenterology Section St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital

title: OPINION; Carnies, Those Sterling Citizens
description: ONE of the first books I remember reading on my own was a paperback I bought for a quarter from a stationery store in Patchogue some 50 years ago. It dealt with a carnival -- principally with the characters who made up its work force, their mores, their mind-set. I can't remember too many of the details anymore, but I do remember the ''carnies'' were depicted as a colorful, closely knit band of brothers -- hard-working, lacking much formal education, necessarily poor.

title: Don't Tell Moynihan
description: To the Editor:

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: Moscow
description: The Russian word for ''bar'' is ''bar.'' That should suggest how foreign the concept initially was. Choosing Moscow's best bar is like choosing Russia's best 10-year-old physicist. They're there. Just give them time to grow up.

title: BATTERY MAKER MOVING
description: Exide Corporation, the world's largest maker of automobile and industrial batteries, will begin within a month moving its corporate headquarters to Princeton from Reading, Pa., said Michael S. Geylin, corporate spokesman. The company, which sells batteries through such outlets as Kmart, Pep Boys and the National Automotive Parts Association, is in the process of restructuring and relocating personnel. About 50 of the 325 people who work in the Reading offices will be moved to Princeton, which was selected because of its proximity to New York City and the financial markets. Others will be relocated to offices in Chicago and Atlanta, while an undetermined number will be laid off, Mr. Geylin said. The company is currently negotiating for space in Princeton. The move is to be phased in over several months.

title: Armonk Company Building New Studio
description: Cine Magnetics, an Armonk company that copies videocassettes to DVD and creates videos for airlines, is spending $250,000 to build a studio for creating DVD's. The company already has three specialized studios. The new studio will handle projects requiring high-quality sound reproduction. It will also be used to create movies that airlines make available to passengers on personal screens. Peter Beller

title: Rise, Fall and Rise of Glassmaking
description: WITH automation, the World Wars, the Great Depression and the rise of plastics, the 20th century was almost the worst of times for glassmaking. However, over the past few decades, glass has enjoyed a renaissance. Now it seems like the best of times. Gay LeCleire Taylor, the curator of the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village here, has organized an exhibit surveying American glass since 1900

title: Final Solutions
description: MIRRORS OF DESTRUCTION

title: A Pair of Pop Guerillas Who Flaunt Bad Taste
description: WHEN Claudia Schiffer posed for them, she became ''Venus,'' framed by sparkling plastic flowers, two lovely tears running down her porcelain cheeks. The pop singer Nina Hagen metamorphosed, improbably, into a beatific Virgin Mary and, in another image, into a bondage victim, dressed in latex and roped to a kitchen chair. Catherine Deneuve turned into the ''White Queen,'' floating among clouds in a gown and tiara.

title: Time Is Nibbling at Sunken Railroad Bridge in Hudson
description: ''The gribbles are gribbling and the borers are boring,'' warned Edward Kirkland, a Chelsea resident who is concerned about a historic sunken bridge in the Hudson River off West 26th Street.

description: Gail Hope Moss and John Stuart Baymiller were married Monday in Thira, on the Greek island of Santorini. John Kavallaris, a civil marriage celebrant, officiated at Kastro, a restaurant.

description: It was a half-hour after match point, near the front row inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, when a group of smitten fans and nudging camera operators were circling Marat Safin as if they were surrounding a campfire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINNOTT, PATRICIA NELLY

But the report did not encompass another growth area: the gray market, where legally marketed weapons slip into unintended hands. Nor did it take note of the number of wars being fought with homemade tools. Here is a sample of some of the weapons included in the official survey, and others that weren't, as they may appear in an international arms catalog.

title: Bandits in the Global Shipping Lanes
description: Hitt writes that piracy is ''a troubling symptom of a new world order, one shaped by a fierce Darwinian struggle in the feral markets of modern international trade.'' In so doing, Hitt seeks to assign a rational, and moral, motivation to the acts of these pirates. He says, in effect, that since these people do not achieve their aims within the confines of capitalism, it is all right for them to resort to violence and theft to achieve their aims. This is absurd!

title: Ideas & Trends; The Miniskirt as a National Security Threat
description: THEY have been under siege for quite some time. This summer in Swaziland, they were identified as a reason for the spread of AIDS and banned from schools. In the past, they have been eliminated from government offices by the likes of former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, who saw them as signs of Western influence, and purged by Idi Amin in Uganda. In 1967, the legendary designer Edith Head, who felt they lacked elegance, banned them from the Academy Awards.

title: Am I Blue? Are You?
description: The blue denim Western-style jacket has become a mass uniform for young women, replacing the tailored sports jacket, a trend shown here in the spring of 1999. Last week's fall-like weather cemented this fashion shift for the dress-down generation. The jackets have been recut by clothing manufacturers for a stylish short, snug fit. Ninety-nine percent of them are in shades of blue, with the occasional jolt of color. And one young innovator came up with a new way to stow it when the weather turned warmer: buttoning the sleeves together and wearing it like a sling bag, below left.

title: The Park Ave. Princesses of Brooklyn
description: AUTUMN LUCAS was the picture of leisure, sitting in a courtyard cafe under the spreading branches of a dogwood tree, sipping a soy latte. Though it was midmorning on a Wednesday, when most people are bustling about their offices, she was chatting with a friend about Shu Uemura face cleanser and a play she had seen the night before. The wind made the silk scarf on her head flutter prettily behind her. Only the drumming of her manicured hand gave away a strain of impatience, as she was expected in a few minutes for a luncheon to plan a charity event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILICH, AURA

Our sympathies are extended to her husband Marvin and their daughters Danielle, Jennifer and Lori and her husband Marc. She was the daughter of Harriet and Leonard Gold, sister of Karen Gold, Janet Siegel and Jeffrey Gold. She was a warm and wonderful human being to all who knew her. She will be sorely missed in this world. Services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY, at 2:30, on Sunday, September 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, ROBERT K.
description: O'CONNOR-Robert K. Died on August 22, 2000, in Vero Beach, FL, after a long illness. Born January 13, 1922, in Holyoke, MA, he was a graduate of Amherst College and NYU School of Business. During WWII he was a Navy pilot. After a long career as a stockbroker and securities analyst he retired to Florida from Rowayton, CT. He is survived by his wife, Jean; a son, Douglas O'Connor; a daughter, Judy Gluckstern and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168th St, NY, NY 10032. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 23, at 3 PM, at The United Church of Rowayton, CT.

title: Bandits in the Global Shipping Lanes
description: As an ensign aboard the United States Navy supply ship Pollux (and sailing regularly to and from Manila, Cebu, Taiwan and Borneo), I had the distinction of being ordered to form a squad of heavily armed boatswain and gunners' mates to fight pirates. I still remember our training program, which started with the shrill of the boatswain's pipe and the announcement, ''This is a drill: now prepare to repel boarders, starboard side.'' Happily, we were never called upon to perform other than a drill.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: FANS of ''E.T.'' were annoyed, but Sir Richard Attenborough's GANDHI swept the 1982 Oscars. It took best picture, best director, best actor (Ben Kingsley, new to American movie audiences, in the title role) and even best costume design. Which is odd for a picture about a man in a loincloth. The story covers Mohandas K. Gandhi from his days as a young lawyer in South Africa to his assassination in Delhi in 1948. This is a conventional middlebrow biography, but the story of Gandhi, whose pacifism changed the course of India's history, is so powerful, and Mr. Kingsley's performance is so precise, that the film holds together. - Saturday at 9 p.m. on Channel 13.

title: Fantastic Light Turns It on in Man o'War

Crown Prince Faisal of Saudi Arabia arrived in the afternoon with an entourage from the United Nations, and presented the winner's trophy after the Man o'War Stakes. And finally, the road to the Breeders' Cup opened wide with three stakes races crammed with star horses and high drama.

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction; At Play in the Cemetery
description: Abandoned cemeteries, mossy tombstones, weary gravediggers leaning on their shovels: anyone familiar with the work of Eudora Welty will not find the subject matter of her latest book particularly unusual. What may come as a surprise is that the content is not prose but photography. COUNTRY CHURCHYARDS (University Press of Mississippi, $35) is a slim book of nearly 100 black-and-white photographs of Mississippi cemeteries. Welty took the pictures more than 50 years ago, long before she became known for her novels and short stories, many of which included just the kinds of settings depicted here. Several of the pictures are accompanied by quotations from Welty's writings. A line from her novel ''Losing Battles'' was apparently inspired by a bleak graveyard near Natchez: ''An army of tablets, some black as slate, marked half a hill-load of husbands and wives buried close together.'' Welty's interest in graveyards predates her passion for both photography and fiction. As a child, she played in the Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Miss., where she grew up. ''For me cemeteries had a sinister appeal somehow,'' Welty told Hunter Cole in an interview that serves as a preface to the book. But eventually she started taking aesthetic note of the marble effigies and solemn stone angels that inhabited the graveyards of the old country churches surrounding Jackson. All of it appealed to what Elizabeth Spencer, who wrote the introduction to the book, calls Welty's ''sense of reverence for life's mysteries, death being one of those.'' Suzanne MacNeille

Davis said, but he added, ''We're trying to promote a respect for the law.'' The city, which will begin to boot more cars, recently raised increased fines for littering. Peter Beller

title: Appearances; The Sky's the Gimmick
description: It's a construction site on Greene Street in SoHo. Yet another gallery giving way to a face-paint emporium, you think, until you see the slick black letters on white background: ''Helmut Lang.'' Such is the power of the name of this designer of lean, clean apparel that suddenly even the cement-crusted wheelbarrows stacked at the entrance acquire a Duchampian significance. On Aug. 1 there are plywood sheets laid over floor joists. By late September, there will be a concrete floor, white walls and a long black counter, as Lang's ''house for perfume,'' as he calls it, opens directly across the street from his clothing store. Marching along that counter will be high-shouldered bottles of perfume, cologne and after-shave. Two floors of prime retail space devoted to two fragrances -- and there won't even be bath beads or scented candles! There will be, however, a large white pill in a metal box, something that might be called a room freshener if it weren't found in such haute surroundings.

Houellebecq is France's biggest literary sensation in 20 years -- and his suffering is enormous.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Unlight Verse
description: ''We know where love is by its stillness,'' Fanny Howe writes in one of the spare, muscled poems gathered in SELECTED POEMS (University of California, cloth, $40; paper, $15.95), work culled from 20 years of her poetry. Indeed, it's stillness more than anything else that tempers this volume; its quiet, forceful poems carry an existential weight that belies their small size. Among other things, Howe has made a long-term project of trying to determine how we fit into God's world, and her aim is both true and marvelously free of sentimental piety. ''Mad God, mad thought / Take me for a walk,'' she writes, ''Stalk me. Made God, / Wake me with your words. / Believe in what I said.'' Her work is fueled by a persistent need to find out not the meaning of life itself, but how to ask what it is. ''A feeling triggers a feeling, then the heft / Of the hand to work,'' Howe states in a typically Dickinsonian moment. It's as if she can't help herself -- these fierce poems demand to be put forth. Taken together, they create a world of their own, a series of structures that dot the landscape Howe travels. ''My vagabondage / is unlonelied by poems'' she confesses at one point, as if to justify her questioning. She's on a private quest through the metaphysical universe, and the results are startling and honest. ''If goals create content stealth creates form,'' she writes. Her ''Selected Poems'' proves she's absolutely correct. Melanie Rehak

title: Dressing Up the Store Flier
description: Following European style-makers like Chanel and Galleries Lafayette, which produce fashion magazines for customers, two retailers with stores in the United States, Bergdorf Goodman and Sephora, are branching out into publishing this fall. A step up from hip ''catazines'' put out by companies like American Eagle Outfitters, the Bergdorf Goodman publication is designed to resemble a magazine, with lush fashion and beauty spreads by high-end photographers including Peter Lindbergh (albeit with unusual captions directing readers to ''the Third Floor'') and a smattering of articles on subjects like Giorgio Armani. The premiere issue, produced by the Paris-based publisher Assouline, will be mailed to 300,000 of the store's customers on Sept. 12; copies are also sold at Rizzoli bookstores for $10. Sephora's Sephora.Com, based on the content of its online magazine, showcases products sold at the store, but also offers standard magazine service features from beauty tips to horoscopes. It will be available Sept. 15 at Sephora stores. The Bergdorf magazine's mission, according to its ''Welcome'' page, is ''to provide more useful information'' and ''stimulate dialogue.'' Yeah, stimulating dialogue like ''Oooh, I love that coat! Don't you?'' ELLEN TIEN
