description: With his control of the Venezuelan government assured in a landslide election five weeks ago, President Hugo Chavez is now moving to replace independent civic and labor groups with equivalents under the control of the ''revolutionary'' movement he leads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HELEN
description: WEISS-Helen. AMIT mour ns the passing of Helen Weiss, mother of William and Louis and mother-inlaw of our dear Senior Vice President and Executive Board Member Marion. Helen was an esteemed member of AMIT, and devoted to the cause of saving Israel's forgotten children. She was a true friend. May her family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: West Virginia Puts Women on River
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Sept. 9  In the first hour of her first official practice, Coach Nancy La- Rocque is rethinking her approach. Motoring along the Monongahela River just 10 feet from her team, LaRocque sees only the vaguest outlines of heads and shoulders.

title: Navigating through the Driftless
description: MOVING to Wisconsin after 15 years in Manhattan, my partner, Anne, and I were charmed by the idea of the new way of life Madison would offer. But beyond the state's capital, our knowledge of Wisconsin amounted to a few hours spent on I-90 and a grab bag of cliches about cheeseheads, badgers, blizzards and lakes, mostly frozen ones. We felt apprehensive about living in a landscape without vertical dimension: neither of us is fond of the legato drone of the flat Midwest. So ranking high among the many startling pleasures of our move has been our discovery of the Driftless, Wisconsin's hilly southwest quadrant.

title: THE COST OF SPRAYING
description: The cost of battling the West Nile virus in the county is expected to be about $1.5 million, Larry S. Schwartz, the chief adviser to County Executive Andrew J. Spano, said. The total includes $966,000 for both ground spraying to kill adult mosquitoes and the use of larvicide to prevent mosquito breeding. But more than $600,000 will be reimbursed through a state grant and other state aid, Mr. Schwartz said. The remaining costs were either budgeted or will be provided for through savings in other budget lines, he said, adding, ''Protecting people from getting West Nile is not going to negatively impact the budget.'' Al Baker

title: Among Unpaid Wages of a Revolution: Competing Claims on Land in Nicaragua
description: Where Emilio Aguilar once raised cattle, hundreds of families now raise their children. Small houses line bumpy dirt roads cut through what were the pastures of Mr. Aguilar's 200-acre ranch. He fled to Honduras after the Sandinistas declared him a counterrevolutionary in 1979, and since then mayors in this town about 25 miles northwest of the capital of Managua have handed out plots to the poor.

title: With a New Release, A Reluctant Makeover
description: THE woman who greets you in front of a Manhattan soul food joint is not someone you would recognize. She is tall and imposing, beautiful but remote. She wears slender black stretch capris and a chic blue three-quarter-sleeve gingham shirt with matching decorative eyeshades. Her posture is so perfect she could balance books on her head; her cheeks have a spa-fresh glow. Demure honey ringlets frame her face. She tells you that this home-cooking place is a bit crowded and noisy for her liking; she would prefer the upscale French boite across the street. She glides into a booth, tucks her Bebe shopping bag under the table, orders a cappuccino -- no food today; she is staying slim for some forthcoming television appearances -- and fixes you with a humorless, rather unhelpful stare. You feel perplexed, a little thrown off. You look over her shoulder, half expecting a wild-haired, grinning, explosive, bluejeans-clad hippie babe to leap out from behind a pillar and rescue you. You're not sure what to say to this creature. How about: Nice to meet you -- now where's Joan Osborne?

title: Strike Ends at the Modern In a Spirit of Compromise
description: The union representing 250 striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art voted to end its 134-day walkout yesterday, just hours after reaching an agreement in which both sides made significant concessions.

title: Snead Steals His Way to Royalty
description: When it comes to the St. Louis Cardinals and big numbers, most fans think of Mark McGwire and home runs.

title: A Clean Sweep
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKUN, MORDECAI A.
description: BERKUN-Mordecai A., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleage and friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Avi Barbasch, M.D., President Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Honest, That Was Rutgers Piling Up the Big Numbers
description: Rutgers scored almost at will, overcame the few mistakes it made, laid claim to the line of scrimmage and laid siege on the other team's quarterback, and buried Buffalo tonight, 59-0.

title: Unlike Father
description: To the Editor:

title: London Museum Addresses Digital Age
description: London's Science Museum has recently opened a 107,640-square-foot addition that explores such topics as genetics, digital technology and artificial intelligence. Designed by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard, the four floors of the new Wellcome Wing contain six exhibition areas and a 450-seat Imax theater.

title: Can Respect Be Mandated? Maybe Not Here
description: FOR a short but trying time a few years ago, this town made national headlines. Horrifying stories had emerged from the Mitsubishi automobile assembly plant that sits amid the fertile cornfields here. On its factory floor, some workers contended, some men felt free to grope women or to ask them to bare their breasts. Men would display lewd photographs and commonly refer to women in the crudest of terms, workers said.

title: Teenage Shoppers (Purses by Brinks)
description: I OWN a Prada messenger bag, I have two Kate Spades, a Gucci belt and a Prada belt, and several pairs of Sisley jeans. I have a lot of Clinique makeup, Bobbi Brown eyeliner, MAC lip gloss and Angel perfume -- that's by Thierry Mugler.''

title: My Kid's Never Bad and Other Sandbox Tales
description: MY son and I were playing in Riverside Park, reveling in the sunshine and the green, when a shriek rang out. From the corner of my eye I saw a mother in distress, muttering wildly. She had grabbed her toddler and bent down to admonish a small boy of maybe 3.

title: Protecting Religions
description: To the Editor:

title: Old-News Bags
description: Maria Capotorto, the designer behind Your Sister's Mustache, a line of home and women's accessories, is giving new meaning to news you can use.

title: Fearless Fanny
description: FANNY KEMBLE'S CIVIL WARS

title: Blood Money
description: The Guilt of Nations

title: Sharing a Recipe For Philanthropy
description: Is that Paul Newman at the head of the B-school class? Sure enough, one day last week, the blue-eyed box-office legend was advising budding moguls on how to give -- even before they make their millions.

title: Why a Soft Landing Could Be Worse This Time
description: WITH economic data pointing to a slowdown, it seems more and more evident that the Federal Reserve Board is piloting the economy to the soft landing that everyone has hoped for.

title: Hewlett-Packard May Seek Deal for Consultants
description: Hewlett is in negotiations to acquire the consulting unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers for as much as $20 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Ski Resorts Pledge To Protect Natural Areas
description: AT the nation's biggest ski resorts, trail maps this season will be emblazoned with a proclamation of environmental good will. ''Sustainable Slopes,'' the new program, is the product of a ski industry association campaign to quiet critics and to reassure visitors that its members are committed to protecting natural areas.

title: Beans and Rice for Lunch: As American as Apple Pie
description: In 1952, when city officials adjusted New York's school lunch menu to reflect the growing Puerto Rican population, they went to the experts. They consulted Puerto Rican students, who suggested beans and rice, and they chose a Puerto Rican kitchen employee to cook with ingredients bought in her own neighborhood, just as she would at home.

title: Pac-Man, Phone Home
description: While video game enthusiasts may be pulling all-nighters battling three-dimensional demons in the new Diablo II, more nostalgic game players are rediscovering a simpler bygone joystick: Atari. To play Pac-Man, Missile Command and other games left for extinct in the 80's, some are digging ancient Atari systems out of their closets, others are buying them on eBay (about $30). While classic cartridges like Asteroids, Combat and Space Invaders can still be bought for a couple of dollars at many electronics stores, rarer Atari games like Quadran, from 1983, can fetch up to $400 on online auctions.

title: Mounting a Feast That Can Satisfy Other Hungers
description: IN the scentless, flavorless language of film, the dinner table is often used as an excuse to assemble the cast: it becomes the stage for spilling secrets, for acting out ancient dramas and measuring loyalties by shifts in appetite. Take the ritual Sunday dinners in Ang Lee's ''Eat Drink Man Woman'' (1994), or the freighted family gatherings in the films of Woody Allen. ''What's Cooking?,'' one of four food-centered movies coming this fall, tells its story of multicultural Los Angeles through four intersecting Thanksgiving feasts, their changing turkey recipes a metaphor for families struggling not to break apart.

title: Where Buttons Are Only the Beginning
description: IN 1896, the Republican boss Mark Hanna distributed phony half dollars bearing the likeness of the Democratic presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan and the legend ''In God We Trust . . . for the other forty seven cents.'' It was the Republicans' way of warning what would happen to the economy should free silver champion Bryan defeat William McKinley in the coming election.

title: Wen Ho Lee Will Plead Guilty to Lesser Crime at Los Alamos
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist held in prison for nine months on federal charges that he had stolen a virtual library of nuclear weapons secrets, has agreed to plead guilty to one lesser felony count and to cooperate with government investigators, people involved in the case said today.

title: Must-Sees: Everybody Has an A-List
description: ROB MORROW

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: Questions for Neil LaBute; Into the Light
description: Q: Your production company is called Contemptible Entertainment. Why?

title: Gates's Party Animal? Basic Donkey
description: Steve Ballmer jumped out of a giant birthday cake. And Bill Gates showed off a computer program he wrote in the Basic code language a long, long time ago for a video game (involving a car and a donkey) that seemed, well, more than a bit primitive today.

title: Peekskill Newspaper Folds In Face of Competition
description: Unable to compete with a Gannett newspaper in northern Westchester, the 14-year-old Peekskill-Cortlandt Herald folded late last month.

title: Thin Ice
description: DROWNING RUTH

title: Travel Advisory: Ski Resorts Pledge to Protect Natural Areas
description: At the nation's biggest ski resorts, trail maps this season will be emblazoned with a proclamation of environmental good will. "Sustainable Slopes," the new program, is the product of a ski industry association campaign to quiet critics and to reassure visitors that its members are committed to protecting natural areas.

title: In Norway, Cod, Caves and White Nights
description: THE ocean seemed calm, the voyage promising. Bits of blue peeked from the mist around the spiky green and granite mountains, the geological backbone of the Lofoten Islands of Norway, rising from the water like the spine of some ancient sea creature. The boat was waiting in the Reine harbor, next to a small warehouse where we could see, and smell, stacks of dried cod.

title: Women Box, Men Dive, Dogs Preen and a Boy Pirouettes
description: September

title: Giuliani Questions Account of Spraying
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani acknowledged yesterday that a woman had been treated at an emergency room on Monday after she complained of being sprayed with a pesticide used to kill mosquitoes that spread the West Nile virus. But the mayor said there was ''obviously a discrepancy'' between the city's spraying schedule and the woman's account of when she was sprayed.

title: What Is Stephen King Trying to Prove?
description: The chief hazard of the interview process is that there is never a chance for a second draft, where one may revise or delete badly expressed and sometimes downright idiotic comments. In the course of my talk with Stephen J. Dubner (Aug. 13), I spoke slightingly of my daughter's hard-won religious beliefs and, in an effort to express my admiration for my younger son's fiction, managed to make it sound ephemeral instead. His stories, witty and sharply observed, are fine examples of craft and character. The reason I didn't say that in the interview, so far as I can tell, was that my mouth was too full of my own foot. I apologize to my kids, who deserved better from their old man.

title: Julie Schonfeld, Aytan Bellin
description: Rabbi Julie Schonfeld and Aytan Y. Bellin, a lawyer, are to be married today in New Haven. Rabbi William Lebeau, a vice chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, is to perform the ceremony at the Joseph R. Slifka Center for Jewish Life at Yale University.

title: Tuned In to Cable And Grateful for It
description: To the Editor:

title: Maybe Charity Is Contagious
description: Not far away, in San Jose, executives at Cisco Systems took a step in the same direction, announcing that the company would have an on-site philanthropy consultant to guide employees.

title: Pop (and Mom) Quiz
description: PSHEW.

title: He Just Said No -- To the Drug War
description: How refreshing! A politician who takes a public stand on an unpopular issue. Perhaps Gary Johnson's courage will provoke study of the results of legislation in countries that have decriminalized drugs and an open discussion of the ramifications of such legislation in our own country.

title: The Maggot Talks
description: A Fly for the Prosecution

title: Design That Coaxes Buildings Out of Themselves
description: THE term ''contextual'' having become debased by those who fundamentally despise the whole idea of architecture, the time has come to speak of ''relational'' design -- buildings that interact with their surroundings in full dimension instead of dumbly mimicking the scale and form of their next-door neighbors. We should think of architecture as a supremely interactive art -- a participatory medium that transforms configurations of scale, dimension, shape, proximity, space, time, energy, cultural meaning, economic value and land use.

title: The All-State Olympic Team
description: KAREN SCAVOTTO, 18, of Enfield, peeled down her white sock to display the Olympic rings tattooed on her right ankle. A white billboard with a red-and-blue striped border bid her well on the lawn not far away.

title: Few Big Treats, but Many Small Pleasures
description: HOLDING your breath in anticipation is rarely a healthy exercise, and in the theater it is usually suicidal. A mere few months ago, an improbably rosy horizon seemed to glow before those rich or fanatical enough to attend Broadway shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUKSCH, GEORGE S.
description: MAUKSCH-George S. On August 20, 2000, died suddenly of a heart attack while vacationing in the south of France. He would have turned 81 on August 31. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary, his daughters Judith and Jane, their husbands Richard Cotter and Bill Perri, and four grandchildren, Christopher and Jason Cotter, and Justin and Michelle Perri. Born in Vienna, Austria, he came to the United States in 1938. A veteran of WWII, he graduated from Brooklyn Polytechnic and went on to work for Western Electric, AT&T Long Lines, and the ITT Corporation. In 1976, he founded H&M Automation Systems. He will be remembered for his sense of humor, his great charm and for his love of the good things in life.

title: A Last-Ditch Effort to Save Cos Cob Plant
description: ALTHOUGH these are probably the last days of the Cos Cob Power Plant in Greenwich, the 1907 plant that provided power to the trains that took generations of commuters into Manhattan, a band of residents have mounted a last-ditch effort to save the historic building.

title: Christina Smith, Robert DiSabato Jr.
description: Christina Bardwell Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Joseph DiSabato Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. DiSabato of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Michael Moynihan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: On Language; Old Guard
description: 'Let others argue the case for the old guard,'' Al Gore said in his Los Angeles acceptance speech. ''We're the new guard.''

title: No Tricks For Army At Home
description: Maybe Army should have reverted to the wishbone against Boston College today in the Black Knights' loss at Michie Stadium.

title: Drugged-Out American Dreamers
description: THE 31-year-old director Darren Aronofsky explains the kinetic, brazen style of his second film, ''Requiem for a Dream,'' with a bit of background: ''I grew up in Coney Island riding the Cyclone, which is the best roller coaster in the world. And the one thing it taught me is that you've got to keep the thrills coming.''

title: Meaghan Dowling, Michael Chorske
description: Meaghan Hundley Dowling, the daughter of Hebe and John L. Dowling of New York, was married yesterday to Michael William Chorske, a son of Gayle and William W. Chorske of Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Thomas P. Thorne performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn.

description: When Mayor Giuliani visited the Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in 1995 and saw the Panorama of New York City, billed as the largest scale model in the world, he did the same thing that many first-time visitors do.

title: Ideas & Trends: Global Waffling; When Will We Be Sure?
description: WHEN several eminent scientists returned recently from a tourist cruise to the North Pole aboard a Russian icebreaker and reported finding water, not ice, at the top of the world, the image resonated far and wide, providing a call to arms for scientists and environmentalists who for years had been trying to convince politicians and the public that heat-trapping gases from tail pipes, power plants, even methane-belching cattle, could disrupt the climate.

title: Investing; Gauging the Allure Of Tradable Funds
description: THERE is no question that exchange-traded funds are a hot investment. Their assets have nearly doubled this year, to $52.6 billion; so has the number of the offerings, which now exceeds 60, according to Strategic Insight, a fund consulting firm in New York.

title: Please Go to the Principal's Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Saluting Czechs' Freedom At Landmarks to Liberty
description: Within sight of the statue that has symbolized freedom to millions of immigrants, Czech-Americans from around the country gathered yesterday to meet Vaclav Havel, the man whose words, wisdom and will gently edged Communism from Czechoslovakia, returning to them a nation and a spiritual home that many thought they had lost forever.

description: OKWUI ENWEZOR

title: Corrections
description: Acontinuation line in the Dance listing on Page 26 of Arts & Leisure today and the first line of a January entry are overprinted and illegible. The affected entry should begin this way: "Dance at Japan House. A rare taste of Japanese dance today, both avant-garde and newly revisited traditional." The entry continues on Page 37.

title: Remembering Vietnam
description: WHEN Patricia Kolodi started teaching history in the 1980's at Haddonfield Memorial High School, she remembers a student raising his hand during a lesson on Grover Cleveland and saying, ''When are we going to get to the good stuff?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUROBINER, ALICE
description: TUROBINER-Alice. The worldwide Shaare Zedek family mourns with profound grief and sorrow the passing of a dear friend and benefactor. To everyone who had the good fortune of knowing her, Alice personified the qualities of extraordinary dignity, elegance and grace. Throughout both her professional as well as her personal life, she exemplified the values of integrity and kindness. Ever faithful to Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael, her heart pulsed to the beat of Jerusalem, a city she deeply loved and cared for. Together with her husband Harold, a cherished member of our National Board, the Turobiner's leadership and outstretched hand of friendship benefited so many worthy institutions both in their own community as well as in Israel. The Medical Center had the good fortune to be the beneficiary of their largesse. We will fondly remember Alice's leadership as Vice President of our National Women's Division as well as the ''tight ship'' which she chaired at its Annual Luncheons. Her intelligence, wit and insight greatly benefited the hospital's international Board of Governors on which she served. Through their patronage of the Jesselson Heart Center and the Harry, Judith and Leonard Wilf Woman and Infant Center on ''Charlie's Floor'', the Turobiners have helped to place Shaare Zedek in the forefront of Israel's premier medical centers. Her legacy of charitable endeavors stands as testimony of her commitment to the highest values and ethics of traditional Judaism. Our sincerest condolences to Harold, daughters Carol Finley and Ann Dachs, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: Scout Traditions: To Uphold or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: RECOMMEND BANISHING EXECUTIVE
description: The Division of Gaming Enforcement last week recommended that the president of Caesars Atlantic City Hotel Casino, who has admitted to a longstanding gambling problem, lose his casino licenses, the first such recommendation to be made the 22 years of legal gambling in Atlantic City. The Casino Control Commission agreed to hold a hearing to consider the recommendation. A 65-page report said Gary DiBartolomeo, 45, lied to the division, gambled on at least 23 occasions when he had promised not to, and ran up $389,000 in debt in one 18-month period.

title: A Father of the Grand Skyline
description: THE ''City Beautiful'' movement was in full flower a century ago, and the architect Cass Gilbert (1859-1934) brought its ideals into tangible form. His United States Custom House on Bowling Green (shown above in a 1900 rendering) is a grand monument to New York's role in world trade. That celebrated structure and Gilbert's Gothic-styled Woolworth Building are among the subjects of an exhibition opening Tuesday at the New-York Historical Society, ''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert.''

title: Premier Of India Hails Summit
description: The prime minister of India, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, took to a stage on a Little League baseball diamond on Staten Island yesterday at a rally for about 2,000 Indian-American supporters. He spoke for about an hour, and in American political lingo, he seemed to succeed in pleasing his base.

title: 'The Little Prince': Born in Asharoken
description: A PILOT crash-lands in the Sahara Desert in the 1940's and crawls out of the wreckage quite alive. He sets about fixing his engine, when a child, dressed like a prince, suddenly appears. The little prince is from a distant asteroid, no bigger than a house, and has been moved by the beauty of a rose to travel the universe in search of the important things in life.

title: Ben Affleck Shocker: I Bargained With Devil for Fame
description: THE door of the Hollywood Hills Cafe opens and Ben Affleck appears like an usher remembered from a 3 a.m. awakening in some all-night moviehouse. You sort of expect him to have a flashlight in his hand as he points you toward the back room, a dim alcove with the faintly menacing air of a Capone-era speakeasy. ''If you say the code word,'' he jokes, ''you can go in and they'll serve you gin.''

title: Trying to Be Brilliant, Scary and Thrifty. Twice.
description: JOE BERLINGER, a respected documentary filmmaker who was itching to make his first fictional feature, was delivering his pitch to the executives at Artisan Entertainment last Thanksgiving, thinking everything was going just fine.

title: In Israel, Suddenly Cucumbers Are Not Kosher
description: Rabbi Shlomo Shmulevitz is director of the commandments related to the Land of Israel for the Jerusalem rabbinate.

title: Online Feedback
description: We asked readers of Matthew Miller's article on Gov. Gary Johnson of New Mexico for their reactions to his position on drugs. Here are some responses from , a New York Times online knowledge network.

title: A Character Actress Trapped in an Ingenue's Body
description: RENEE ZELLWEGER, from a distance, has all the trappings of a rising Hollywood starlet: the blond hair, the thin frame, the bee-stung lips, the colorful but homespun childhood in Texas, no formal acting training and a boyfriend who gets $20 million per picture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, BEATRICE
description: SILVERMAN-Beatrice, 9 3. Of Aventura, FL formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away September 8, 2000. Predeceased by her loving husband Morris. Survived by her loving children: Alvin (Shelley) Silverman, Rhoda (Emile) Wanich, and Dr. Barry (Judy) Silverman; Grandchildren: Michael (Robbi), David (Sabrina), Tammi (Mark), Amy (Max), Ronni (Paul) & Laurie; 13 great-grandchildren; Sister Rose Podell; and brother Ruby Schwartzberg. Graveside Services will be held Monday, Sept. 11, 2000, 1 PM at Wellwood Cemetery, LI. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center.

title: Reform at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: All-American Final in Boys Competition
description: For the first time since 1977, three Americans reached yesterday's semifinals of the United States Open boys' championship.

title: It's the 'Serious' Season, and Other Myths
description: EVERY culture cherishes the myths and rituals by which it marks the change of seasons, and associates different times of the year with appropriate modes of expression. According to the literary critic Northrop Frye, each of the four seasons of the Northern Hemisphere has given rise to a correlative genre: satire belongs to winter, comedy to spring, romance to summer and tragedy to fall. Our present civilization has little appetite for tragedy, but a wispy shadow of Frye's theory persists, as the coming of autumn sends children back to school and putatively serious movies back into the multiplexes. As the days grow shorter, the running times grow longer. Special effects give way to feats of costume and set design. The box office sprints of the Memorial and Independence Day weekends, and the damaged-goods studio yard sales of late August, are soon forgotten as the long march toward Christmas -- and the Oscars -- begins. Hollywood, after a three-month revel in expensive triviality, knits its brow and dons its glasses to signal a renewed commitment to expensive importance.

title: Philadelphia's Troubled Schools Reopen as a Showdown With Teachers Nears
description: This city's deeply troubled public schools reopened near cliff's edge this week as the teachers union authorized a strike in the face of a powerful new bargaining-table coalition of state and city political leaders determined to overhaul the system.

title: Ideas & Trends: Swallow Hard; What if There Is No Cure for Health Care's Ills?
description: WHEN Vice President Al Gore outlined his economic vision for America in a speech in Cleveland last week, he did not even mention health policy. That was quite a change from 1992, when controlling health costs and providing health insurance for all Americans was one of the driving forces of the Clinton-Gore campaign.

title: Deborah Dougherty, Jason Roth
description: Deborah Jane Dougherty, a daughter of Barbara and John Dougherty of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Jason Charles Roth, a son of Judith and Morris Roth of Chicago. Andrew Aurigemma, a town justice of Esopus, N.Y., officiated at the West Park Wine Cellars in West Park, N.Y.

title: Syria: Dead Cities And Lively Aleppo
description: I approached Aleppo from Antakya, Turkey. In historical terms this is the logical thing to do, since Antakya is ancient Antioch, which throughout the Hellenistic, Roman and Byzantine periods was the capital of Syria. Not surprisingly, the Syrians would like it back. As a result, the border can be tense. As we neared it, I was more than a little nervous, having visions of surly border guards who would insist on examining my luggage down to the last item of underwear. Leyla, my Turkish traveling companion, was dismissive: she had been to Syria many times before, and had never had a problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUKS, A. FORREST
description: LOUKS-A. Forrest. Of St. Croix, Virgin Islands, formerly of Fairfield, CT, died at Emory Hospital in Atlanta, Georgia, on August 22. He was the beloved husband of Katharine J. Ward and devoted father of Dr. Carolyn Bondy of Bethesda, MD., and grandfather to Eric and Peter Bondy. He is also survived by his stepsons Marshall, Jeff and Jon Ward. Upon retirement from Louks, Josephson and Fitzgerald, Insurance Agency in Fairfield, CT, he enjoyed golf and membership at St. Croix Yacht Club. During World War II his tour of duty was with the Navy upon the battleship Luce in the Pacific. A memorial service will be held at a later date when his ashes will be scattered at sea.

title: Susan Glasser, Peter Baker
description: Susan B. Glasser and Peter Baker, both journalists, were married last evening in Washington at Meridian House, an early-20th-century house designed by John Russell Pope. Judge Stephen F. Eilperin of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 27 about the Pendleton Round-Up, a rodeo in Pendleton, Ore., misstated the site of the National Finals Rodeo. It is in Las Vegas, not Oklahoma City.

title: In 2 Nassau Races, It's a Family Affair
description: USUALLY, the job of a candidate's spouse is to be supportive. That may be a tricky task for two Nassau County couples who have found themselves running husband against wife in Tuesday's primaries.

title: Political Briefing; The Same Old Song With a Different Beat
description: During the 1976 presidential election, when Gerald R. Ford was trying to fend off a challenge by Jimmy Carter, Mr. Ford's White House chief of staff, Dick Cheney, helped draw up the defense plan.

title: INVESTING WITH: Rajeev Bhaman; Oppenheimer Developing Markets Fund
description: RAJEEV BHAMAN was born in Bombay, has lived in England and was educated in the United States. As a teenager, he traveled the world with his father, the captain of a cargo ship. So he is not fazed by the travel required in his job, running the $170.8 million Oppenheimer Developing Markets fund.

title: Martha Fanning, Bryan Smith
description: Martha Eleanor Fanning, a daughter of Muffie Van Voorhis of Barter's Island, Me., and the late James Erskin Fanning, was married yesterday to Bryan Macleod Smith, a son of the late Lorna Macleod Smith and Stephen Smith. The Rev. Peter B. Panagore performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Booth Bay Harbor, Me.

title: Greenport Painter's Art Spared From Obscurity
description: Whitney M. Hubbard

title: The World; Out in Front, Serbia's Opposition Prepares to Lose
description: DEMOCRACY is about choice, but in the Yugoslav version, which is now playing itself out with Slobodan Milosevic's future at stake, there are likely to be more choices than usual.

title: Sports of The Times; Super Saturday Turns Into Women's Day
description: SUPER SATURDAY at the United States Open has always been a noisy, hectic experience that often leaves me with a giant tennis hangover, but as a concept, I can't knock it. The other Grand Slams give the women their own day to play for the big prize, but they also pay them less than they do the men.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE MURDERED HOUSE

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column on Aug. 20, about the marriage of Althea Allison Beaton and Malik Shabazz Ducard, referred incompletely to A Better Chance, a nonprofit educational organization that awarded them scholarships to private schools. It places and guides minority students in public middle and high schools as well as private ones.

title: Fashions of The Times
description: I was shocked and saddened by an advertisement in your fashion issue (Part 2, Fall 2000) for Perry Ellis that depicted a stunned woman lying disheveled on the floor as a naked man crouched over her. It was a horrible glamorization of rape and a perfect example of the fashion industry's willingness to go beyond the boundaries of good taste to sell clothing. This is not an ad for clothing; it is an ad for violence.

title: William A. Lubbers, 75, Lawyer For U.S. Labor Relations Board
description: William A. Lubbers, the National Labor Relations Board's general counsel from 1979 to 1984, died on Aug. 26. He was 75 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: A Chance to Bid For More Than Just a Car
description: They haven't rolled off a production line since 1958, but Packard automobiles remain popular with collectors. So it is not surprising that a search of eBay and other auction Web sites can turn up hundreds of Packard items for sale: classic cars, parts, memorabilia -- and, for a few days last week, the whole company.

title: New York
description: There are reasons they write songs about autumn in New York. And make sentimental movies about it. (Like the current one, with Richard Gere and Winona Ryder, they usually involve a series of sightseeing-driven Manhattan dates.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, MAX
description: SCHORR-Max. Beloved Palm Beach and former New York City attorney, 92, died Tuesday afternoon in Palm Beach from complications of prostate cancer. A counsel at Edwards & Angell, Max was one of Florida's oldest practicing attorneys. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he practiced from the early 30's until 1972 in New York City and White Plains. He is survived by two sons; Tony of Rye, New York, and Andrew of Mercer Island, Washington; 10 grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Mafiosi Haven Becomes Fashionista's Heaven
description: As SoHo seeps eastward and NoHo southward in Lower Manhattan, Amy Chan, a women's accessory boutique at 247 Mulberry Street, is typical of the chic shops and cafes that have been moving into northern Little Italy, now promoted by real estate marketers as NoLIta.

title: Food; Missing Home Plate
description: I grew up in New York and was such a Yankee fan that in the fifth grade I insisted on being called Allie because of the great pitcher. In the sixth grade, I was so besotted that I asked the headmaster -- a gruff megalomaniac -- if I could be excused from classes to attend the opening day at the stadium. To my astonishment (and the whole sixth grade's), he said yes. Although many of the players were before my time, I knew the Yankee numbers up to 30 by heart, and still do. Twenty-two years later, I wrote my first play, ''Yanks 3 Detroit 0 Top of the 7th,'' about a Yankee pitcher having a nervous breakdown on the mound.

title: Beauty Editor
description: Now that prints are in style, Pucci power is back in full force. But connoisseurs of its colorful swirling designs, like Veronica Hinman, insist there's an art to wearing the label. Ms. Hinman, the beauty editor of Glamour, says she prefers vintage Pucci to current styles because the retro patterns are more distinctive. She also buys unusual silhouettes, rather than basic tanks and leggings, or ''Pucci for dummies,'' as she called them. And Ms. Hinman never pairs Pucci with other logos, like a Chanel bag or an Hermes belt. ''You can't mix it up with the rest of Fifth and Madison,'' she explained. ''Otherwise you'll look like a consignment shop on heels.''

title: Streetscapes/Castle Village and Hudson View Gardens in Upper Manhattan; Shadows of an Uptown Castle, and Its Builder
description: THE day I moved in someone knocked on my door and said, 'You've got to start working on this,' '' said Thomas Navin, an architect and garden designer who bought an apartment in 1998 at Castle Village on Cabrini Avenue north of 181st Street in upper Manhattan.

title: Counting Eyes (of Newt) and Toes (of Frog) in a Special Census
description: This summer about 500 volunteers have been combing the woods, bogs and parks of New Jersey looking for snakes, frogs, salamanders and other crawly things as part of the Herpetology Atlas project of the state Division of Fish and Wildlife. The volunteers have been counting amphibians and reptiles to see what kinds live in the state and where they make their homes. Those interested in volunteering can call (609) 628-2103 or e-mail nongame @nwip.net. Jason Tesauro, assistant biologist with the Division's Endangered and Nongame Species Program, recently discussed the project.

title: Robyn Brown, Thomas Forman
description: Robyn Ann Brown, a daughter of Joel S. Brown of Bloomfield, Mich., and the late Rosalie D. Brown, was married yesterday to Thomas Perry Forman, a son of Jane P. and Charles D. Forman of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Tamara R. Kolton performed the ceremony at the Cliffside Beach Club in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Clinic Conducts Studies On Sleep and Smoking
description: CAN nitrous oxide sometimes called laughing gas -- help a person stop smoking?

title: It's Hard Adapting Henry James. Still, They Keep Trying.
description: LADIES with lacy parasols, twilit mansions with topiary mazes: there's no huge mystery about why filmmakers would be attracted to Henry James novels. Adapting James is a more dignified undertaking than filming ''Lethal Weapon IV''; Henry James shot-puts us into the land of Art, of substance and gravitas. Besides, there are only so many Jane Austen novels.

title: The Human Side of a Hedge Fund's Tumble
description: ON Aug. 21, 1998, a little-known investment partnership in Greenwich, Conn., lost $553 million. The loss on that single sunny Friday left the behemoth fund with $2.9 billion in capital, down from $4.67 billion just months earlier.

title: Autumn is Mellow Deep in Normandy
description: A JOURNEY to inland Normandy began in a promise I made myself some years ago. My brother and I were tearing through the Norman countryside in a rental car, bound for the coast: for Mont-Saint-Michel, for Bayeux and the tapestry, for the tragic beaches and Rommel's still, grim emplacements above them, for the stately strand at Deauville, for the picturesque harbor at Honfleur, for Etretat.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AUGUSTINE, ARTHUR
description: AUGUSTINE-Arthur. 9/11/91 . Infinitely remembered and loved. Every joy shared adds more love. You are never alone. Six hearts linked forever. Love, wife Kathleen, Lizabeth, Arthur, David and first grandchild Megan Augustine McEvoy.

title: Moving Up the Street, a World Away
description: IN terms of distance, the Jersey City Museum is moving a few hundred feet west.

title: DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Zero Tolerance Works If Terms Are Defined
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: BACK TO THE 70's; The Extraordinary Adolescence of Cameron Crowe
description: FOR Cameron Crowe, it has always been about rock 'n' roll. That has been the story of his life and work, starting with his precocious stint as a teenage journalist with Rolling Stone magazine in the 70's, right on through his current filmmaking career as a writer and director. In all his films -- from ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High'' (his impressive 1982 screenwriting debut), which details the normal adolescence he never had, to ''Almost Famous'' (his newest and most autobiographical film), which describes the extraordinary adolescence he truly had -- rock helps people come of age.

title: OPEC to Boost Its Oil Output By 800,000 More Barrels a Day
description: VIENNA, Sept. 10  Faced with growing international pressure to drive down stubbornly high oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to increase its crude production by 800,000 barrels a day, spokesmen for the group and delegates said.

title: It's September and, for the Mets, the Fall Has Arrived
description: If the frustration was going to show on the Mets last night, at least they expressed it safely. Unlike Mike Hampton, who had whipped his glove and toppled two water coolers in his rage on Friday night, Turk Wendell walked off the mound and merely tossed his glove into the stands at Shea Stadium.

title: Ideas & Trends; Copyright and Copying Wrongs: A Web Rebalancing Act
description: WHEN Michael Robertson emerged last week from a Manhattan court, pale beneath his California tan, the chief executive of the MP3.com online music service told reporters that consumers want to be able to listen to their music from wherever they are. That MP3.com's technology allows them to do that. And that the law shouldn't get in the way.

title: Not-So-Mellow Yellow
description: Peggy Jones was taking her usual route down Lincoln Avenue in this small Camden County borough when she suddenly bolted upright and spilled her coffee.

title: Wen Ho Lee Will Plead Guilty to Lesser Crime at Los Alamos
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist held in prison for nine months on federal charges that he had stolen a virtual library of nuclear weapons secrets, has agreed to plead guilty to one lesser felony count and to cooperate with government investigators, people involved in the case said today.

title: New Moves From a Land Beyond Category
description: DIVERSITY, thy name is individuality. That may well be the message of ''France Moves,'' a major festival of French contemporary dance that will spread some 10 experimental troupes over three boroughs in New York from April 24 to May 6.

title: Leading Research Lab Imperiled by State Cutback
description: AT low tide, marine biologists monitor wooden racks and silos full of tiny oysters and clams on the mud flats outside the weather-beaten houses of this remote hatchery on the Delaware Bay north of Cape May.

title: OPEC to Boost Its Oil Output By 800,000 More Barrels a Day
description: Under pressure from the United States and other nations to reign in soaring oil prices, the OPEC cartel of oil-producing countries decided today to boost their official output by an additional 800,000 barrels a day.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00; Bluestocking Blues
description: To many voters, but especially to women, Hillary Clinton used to seem like a victim of bad casting. Her attempts at wifeliness, from visiting sick children to gazing lovingly upon her wayward husband, struck people as fake, and her attempts at leadership failed entirely. In the last year or so a very different Hillary has come into focus. Instead of talking about the White House Christmas tree, she talks about important policy issues. Instead of touting the work of others, she touts her own behind-the-scenes accomplishments and seeks a prominent position from which to accomplish more. And instead of those dowdy Easter Sunday pastels, she favors a much more slimming palette of browns and blacks.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FORT WASHINGTON

title: High Jumps
description: To dance, to take the hurdles, to fling oneself into Gucci: ah, galas.

title: Federal Report Criticizes Entertainment Marketing
description: The Federal Trade Commission plans to release a report on Monday that harshly criticizes the film, recording and video game industries for marketing violent, adult-rated entertainment to young people, said several officials familiar with the report.

title: The Billionaire's Buyout Plan
description: For five decades, I've looked for undervalued stocks. But if I'd been interested in the biggest bargain around, which I wasn't, I would have bought political influence. For many a year, it was far cheaper than anything to be found in the stock market. A relatively modest contribution -- say, $25,000 -- was enough to make the donor a V.I.P. in the political world. And really big amounts? As a fund-raising senator once jokingly said to me, ''Warren, contribute $10 million and you can get the colors of the American flag changed.''

title: Sept. 3-9; A Rebuke for Haiti
description: Rather than revive Haiti's political fortunes and unblock hundreds of millions of dollars in desperately needed foreign aid, the swearing-in of a new Parliament has accomplished the opposite: the United States announced it will scrutinize any further foreign aid and withhold millions of dollars in assistance for November's presidential elections. American officials acted because they and other international donors could not persuade the Haitian government to recalculate the results of the May 21 legislative elections, in which international observers said 10 of the 18 senate seats won by the party of former president Jean-Bertrand Aristide should have gone to a run-off. David Gonzalez

title: CONGRESS POISED FOR BIG INCREASE IN U.S. SPENDING
description: Cushioned by a growing surplus, Congress is poised to approve large increases in spending by federal agencies, pushing the national budget to record levels.

title: Hampton Halts Howard in Classic
description: Hampton tailback Montrell Coley rushed for 2 touchdowns and 91 yards as Hampton held on to defeat Howard, 26-24, today at the 30th New York Urban League Classic at Giants Stadium.

title: Interior Paint, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: BEFORE the introduction of modern latex and acrylic-based paints, oil-based paint was the most common type of paint used for commercial and residential applications. There was also another type of paint that was made and used around the home, although today few people have even heard of it. This was milk paint, and it was made, as the name implies, with a milk base.

title: Sept. 3-9; If It Moves, Impale It
description: The Pentagon is struggling with all sorts of technological challenges -- from designing a national missile defense that works to perfecting new aircraft like the F-22. But its most embarrassing technological failure these days is popping up right outside its front door.

title: A Missile-Free Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMETZ, EUGENE
description: STEINMETZ - Eugene. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed member, Mrs. Doris Glick, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: Samaranch's Legacy: An Olympic Savior or a Spoiler?
description: When the Summer Games begin here on Friday, Juan Antonio Samaranch will preside over his final Olympiad before retiring next year, having transformed the modern Olympic movement to where it has never been more successful, or more threatened.

title: Greece At Its Most Greek
description: I believe that a traveler in a new place should buy something, preferably through bargaining. Buy something, make a friend, get information. It's the human contact, not the acquisition, that counts. Consequently, and not to satisfy any low material desires, I was bargaining for a hand-woven cotton tablecloth in Nafplio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNES, DANIEL
description: BARNES-Daniel. Of Rye, NY, and Stony Creek, CT. Beloved father of Caroline Henningsen of Rye, NY, David Barnes of Boulder, CO, and Melissa Janssen of Darien, CT. War hero, avid pilot, brilliant engineer and short order cook for his five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Connecticut Hospice, 61 Burban Drive, Branford, CT 06405. Funeral service on Tuesday, September 12, at 11 AM, at Trinity Episcopal Church, 1109 Main St, Branford.

title: In Water and on Land, Women Hope for Medals
description: ONE is an Olympic veteran and a lifetime county resident. The other is a newcomer to the Games and a part-timer in Westchester. But by water and on horseback, two women will carry local hopes at the Summer Olympics.

title: A High C And A 'Swing Low'
description: LOWELL LIEBERMANN

title: Workfare Victory for a Recovering Addict Holds Promise for Others
description: Meet Theresa Banchieri: At 36, she has been on welfare her entire adult life, and for much of that time she's also been a drug addict. Sometimes she stripped and occasionally she stole to support a heroin habit.

title: Bookend; Drinking Gin With the Dead
description: When do popular writers officially qualify as forgotten? It can't simply be when their books fall out of print, since plenty of authors exist in a kind of literary limbo, with their works slipping in and out of circulation depending on the whims of a fickle publishing industry. Perhaps the best gauge of forgottenness these days is the World Wide Web, where even the most arcane interests flourish among cells of true believers, and (thanks to Amazon.com) sweaty-palmed authors can track their daily ups and downs with the click of a mouse. It's fair to assume that if a writer's tree falls on the Internet and no one hears it crash, his existence has become an open question.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Are Not Helping to Keep Hampton
description: WHEN it's time for Mike Hampton to decide where he wants to pitch next season, he'll remember Friday night's frustration.

title: Means to an End
description: First Bill Moyers did beginnings, in the television series ''Genesis: A Living Conversation.'' Now he is turning his attention to endings with ''On Our Own Terms: Moyers on Dying,'' a four-part look at options for dying with comfort and dignity. Bringing the subject closer to home, Channel 13 has developed programs especially for the tristate area exploring options in end-of-life care. The Moyers series will be broadcast at 9 p.m. from today through Wednesday; the Channel 13 programs will follow immediately afterward at 10:30 p.m. And still closer to home, in New Jersey, are several related discussion groups. In Morristown, the Atlantic Mind Body Center is sponsoring a Sept. 26 workshop called ''Let Evening Come'' for clergy, seminarians, hospital chaplains and nurses; information: (973) 971-4575. In Jersey City, Christ Hospital is offering a training program for clergy and community leaders on four Tuesdays beginning Oct. 3; information: (201) 795-8397. In Hackensack, Christ Episcopal Church is planning a program called ''Angel's Eve'' on Oct. 29; information: (201) 342-2365.

title: Eleanor Acquavella, Morgan Dejoux
description: Eleanor Hope Acquavella, the daughter of Hope Brown and William R. Acquavella, both of New York, was married yesterday to Morgan Andre Grace Dejoux, a son of Mrs. William H. Brinckerhoff of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jacques H. Dejoux of Lyon, France. The Rev. Robert Pollard III performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Food of Central Asia From the Lost Tribes
description: Don't be alarmed if you can't find listings for Bukharan or Uzbek cuisine in Zagat's. Make your way to 74 West 47th Street, near the Avenue of the Americas, pass the hustler from the diamond shop on the ground floor, up the black stairway to the third floor, and you can find what you are looking for at Gan-Eden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLENS, DR. BERTRAM
description: POLLENS-Dr. Bertram. S ept. 8, 2000. Age 90. Renowned psychologist. Devoted husband of Polly for sixty years. Loving father to Martin, Richard, Linda Sherman and grandfather to Jason Pollens, Daniel and Benjamin Sherman. Services Sunday 11:15 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Judicial Caprice in China: 4 Families Share Stories
description: Their voices cracking with outrage and disbelief, the parents gathered in a village farmhouse, chronicling four years of fear and frustration as they battle to keep their four sons from being executed for the killing of two taxi drivers six years ago.

title: A Clean Sweep
description: Riesling and the Finger Lakes triumphed in this year's New York Wine and Food Classic, the major contest devoted to New York wines. All the most important awards went to Seneca Lake wineries, the first time one region swept everything in the contest's 15-year history. Most winning wines cost less than $20; all can be shipped inside the state.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen Passat 4Motion; Signs of Cannibalism In the VW Family
description: BY now, the auto-buying public largely understands that few makes and models are unique, but that they are assemblages of parts shared with other products from the same manufacturer. What may be surprising is the extent to which different cars use the same pieces.

title: Antigua Guatemala's Colonial Charm
description: So much of travel is an experience not of space but of time. This is why for a decade I had wanted to go back to Antigua, the volcano-rimmed colonial city in Guatemala's highlands. Once one of the Spanish capitals of the New World, Antigua was so repeatedly shattered by earthquakes that, in the late 18th century, it was evacuated by government edict and largely abandoned.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Alexandra Kean, Benjamin Strong
description: Alexandra Dickinson Kean, the daughter of Thomas H. Kean, the former governor of New Jersey, and Deborah B. Kean of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Benjamin Brewster Strong, a son of Ann S. Strong of Setauket, N.Y., and the late Raymond B. Strong Jr. The Rev. Ralph Merrill performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Julie Schoenberg, A. J. Jacobs
description: Julie Ruth Schoenberg and A. J. Jacobs were married yesterday in East Hampton, N.Y., at the home of the bridegroom's maternal grandparents, Ann Kheel and Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator. Judge Michael B. Mukasey, chief judge of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, performed the ceremony.

title: Liberties; The Tao of Dick
description: Gertrude Kovak, who says she is ''89 and a half,'' sat in her wheelchair at the Methodist seniors home here, up in the front row where she could get a good gander at Dick Cheney.

title: The Long Road From Whoville to Broadway
description: FOR the Broadway of right now, the notion seemed irresistible: an original musical out of the pages of Dr. Seuss that would turn Horton the Elephant and the Cat in the Hat into theater animals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLIN, FLORENCE RHYN
description: SERLIN-Florence Rhyn, P h.D. Director/psychotherapist-30 yearsCommunity Guidance and Referral Service. Mentor, guide and inspiration. She will deeply and profoundly missed for her wisdom/ elan. Author, animal lover. Died September 7, 2000. Burial Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, September 11, 2000. Donations in her memory to Rockland County ASPCA. Dr. Lynne Friedman

title: Amanda Southon, Brett Miller
description: Amanda Maria Southon, the daughter of Priscilla J. Southon of Manhattan and the late Michael D. Southon, was married yesterday to Brett Hudson Miller, the son of Marcia E. Miller of Manhattan and Samuel H. Miller of Bloomington, Ind. The Rev. Vernon C. Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Friends Meeting House in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEDDARD, ANITA
description: BEDDARD-Anita. You are in my heart, mind and soul always. I love you so. Devon

title: Urging Less Truck Traffic In South Salem Area
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, DAVID JIH, YUAN
description: CHANG-David Jih-Yuan. With great sadness, we announce the passing of David Jih-Yuan Chang on September 7, 2000, in NYC after a brief illness. An accomplished civil engineer, David designed many distinguished projects including the Crystal Cathedral in California, the majestic tented roof of the Denver International Airport, and the Newark Airport international arrivals terminal. A loving husband for over 30 years to Margarita; father to Rudolph; grandfather to Jonas; brother to Chi-Deu, Kenny, John, and Robert; son to K.; father-in-law to Jamie and brother-in-law to Ana. David also had a great love for the family's dogs, Badger and Dixie, and had countless friends. He will be sorely missed. For further information contact Beecher Funeral Home (914) 769-0001.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about new books on style misstated the magazine to which one author, Brooke de Ocampo, is a contributor. It is Harper's Bazaar, not Vogue. The article also referred incorrectly to her part in writing the narratives that accompany the photographs in her book, ''Bright Young Things,'' about Manhattan luxury apartments. She did have a role in writing them; she collaborated with Shax F. Riegler.

title: Rising Productivity Challenges Notions on Limits of Growth
description: PRODUCTIVITY.

title: Bumpy Days for Mr. Bush
description: It is too soon to tell whether Gov. George W. Bush's campaign has simply hit a rough patch or is heading into a steep dive. He was smart to listen to alarmed Republican elders and open talks with the presidential debate commission about meeting Vice President Al Gore. He also promised to be more spontaneous and hold town meetings. But the larger problems faced by Mr. Bush's campaign may be harder to solve, since they have to do with substantive issues and electoral geography.

title: Miami of Ohio, Home of Coaching Elite, Faces a Demotion
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Sept. 9  Miami University carved a place in college football history by producing such coaching legends as Woody Hayes, Bo Schembechler, Paul Brown, Weeb Ewbank and Ara Parseghian.

title: Woods Is Ready To Conquer Canada
description: Tiger Woods made plenty of birdies today, but he had plenty of company on the leader board.

title: From Front Office to Front Desk
description: MAGNESIUM white by day, coral red by night, the letters P S F S float over Center City as they have for 68 years. But they no longer mark the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society.

title: Nob Hill Landmark Unveils Renovations
description: The Mark Hopkins Inter-Continental Hotel in San Francisco is scheduled to complete a yearlong renovation by the end of this month. Although the 19-story hotel, a Nob Hill fixture for more than 75 years, has remained open during the project, up to 75 percent of its rooms were closed at a time.

title: Salvadoran Menu With Italian Overlay
description: RUDI'S FAMILY RESTAURANT is an idea in the making and a good one. With Central American restaurants popping up all over Long Island -- and most diners largely ignoring them -- the folks who run DiMaggio's and Il Forno in Port Washington are trying a creative new approach to lure non-Hispanic diners as well as Spanish-speaking patrons.

title: Minnesota Democrats Racing Against Time
description: When the Democratic Party looked for Congressional seats it could pick up in the November elections, the one held by Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota was high on the list.

title: Do These Salary Figures Compute? Some Old Habits in Baseball Die Hard
description: As the Yankees stockpiled one new player after another this season, their cash register kept ringing up higher and higher numbers. Except this was the register that was paying out cash to the players.

title: The Lava Lamp Goes Here, Near The Fridge
description: JOSEPHINA FINAMORE, an 18-year-old sophomore from Wilmington, Del., thinks she has done a good job of making her small dormitory room at the University of Maryland in College Park feel like home. When the family's metallic gold Plymouth Voyager was unpacked two weeks ago, she and her parents unloaded, among other things: a computer, two suitcases of clothes, a box of sweaters, a plastic storage bin full of running clothes and a trash bag full of shoes. She also brought items for the kitchen and bathroom, a CD player, photo albums, framed pictures and a light brown teddy bear that sits atop her blue, pink, yellow and green plaid sheets.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with an article about living on Central Park West reversed the positions of two apartment buildings. The Dakota is on the north side of 72nd Street, the Majestic on the south.

title: Checking Title Insurance
description: Q: We purchased a home in Nassau County 50 years ago and have a title insurance certificate. How do I know if this title insurance company is still in business and, if so, how to get in touch with it? Also, can these title insurance companies go out of business in New York and leave us without coverage? . . . William F. Greis, Malverne, N.Y.

title: Editorial Observer; When Dogs Are More Important Than People
description: I moved to Brooklyn 15 years ago and have since spent several mornings each week walking, running or just greeting the day in Prospect Park. In recent years, these tranquil mornings have been too often disrupted by snarling dogs who are permitted off their leashes in the early morning during what the park system refers to as ''courtesy hours.'' In the last year alone, I have been cornered four times by ill-behaved dogs -- two of them pit bulls -- who were clearly unfit to run loose in a public park.

title: Still Seeking Payment From Bernard Goetz
description: Darrell Cabey, who was awarded $43 million by a jury for his injuries from being shot by Bernard H. Goetz in a Manhattan subway train in 1984, has not received that money from Mr. Goetz. Mr. Cabey and three others were shot by Mr. Goetz, an electrical engineer, while riding the subway. Mr. Goetz, who used an unlicensed handgun, told the police that he feared the young men were going to rob him.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: A Density of Souls

title: THE ANNOTATED LIST: ARCHITECTURE
description: Buildings

title: It's Time to Attack
description: The time has come for that old baseball man, George W. Bush, to recall the words of another old baseball man, Leo Durocher: ''Nice guys finish last.''

title: Slimebusters
description: Yellow, gray or orange slime mold growing in wet, decaying organic matter looks alarming, but just shovel it up and discard it. It rarely harms plants on which it grows. On tree trunks or woody stems or in turf, wash off with a strong stream of water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MIRIAM
description: WHITE-Miriam, much beloved mother of Judith Ross and Jo Anne White, grandmother of Jason Ross, sister of Evelyn Freeman. Retired secretary Samuel Field Y, travel consultant, secretary MAPTA. Memorial Sept. 23, 11AM, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St. Information 216-291-3259

title: Political Briefing; A Nader Supporter Voices 2nd Thoughts
description: The way Bert Garskof of Bethany, Conn., saw it during the 1996 presidential election, another Connecticut boy, Ralph Nader, was the best man for the job. So Mr. Garskof, a psychology professor at Quinnipiac University, working on the Internet, worked with Nader supporters in a dozen states.

title: Again, Nosferatu, the Vampire Who Will Not Die
description: WHEN E. Elias Merhige's ''Shadow of the Vampire,'' with its attention-snagging stars John Malkovich and Willem Dafoe, opens on Dec. 29, it will mark at least the fourth time that filmmakers have resuscitated this particular version of the vampire: Nosferatu, that disturbingly peculiar and apparently iconic figure created by an odd little group of Germans 79 years ago.

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: Rio De Janeiro
description: In a city blessed with a gorgeous landscape and climate, much of life is lived out of doors, and in Rio de Janeiro, no setting brings more people together than the botequims. These open-air neighborhood bars are so much a part of the city's fabric that the mayor's office sponsors a hotly disputed annual competition to designate the best one, in which hundreds of saloons, from the humble to the elaborate, take part.

title: Crossing The Oresund
description: One day, perhaps, the Oresund Fixed Link, the newly opened bridge, tunnel and road that has reunited Denmark with Sweden after a 7,000-year hiatus, will find its Hart Crane, who will rhapsodize about it in the way the American poet sang the praises of the Brooklyn Bridge. But probably not. While it is an engineering marvel, one bringing to fruition nearly 100 years of dreaming and planning and politicking, aesthetically speaking at least, the new span is not the stuff of verse. It is too long (10 miles) and too much of it -- nearly the first 4 miles heading east out of Copenhagen -- is under water. When it does surface from its tunnel, most of what's visible is an elevated causeway. Its middle section looks like a bridge, but its simple concrete towers, the tallest in Sweden, and the cables strung from them, are more elegant than mighty. And since the raised span is so far from shore, for all its size it seems small and slight, a few strokes from a finely pointed pen. If it inspires poetry, it will be less for its looks and more for what it portends: a Europe whose borders are slowly evaporating.

title: Silly World, Dark Underpinnings
description: AUDIENCE members likely to leave their cell phones and beepers activated during a Mump and Smoot show better think twice. The ''clowns of horror,'' as the duo bills itself, is known to make any such distractions a part of the act.

title: With His Art, One Can Find A River's History on a Sign
description: WHEN Richard Mills, a Teaneck artist and environmentalist, takes children on tours of the Hackensack River, he likes to ask them to draw pictures of what paradise looks like. They draw the sun, birds, ducks, flowers, green grass and a river. That, he says, is pretty much the way the land around the Hackensack River used to look.

title: The Burning House, and Other Tales From the Van
description: THE old film story has a crew shooting a car on top of a mountain. It is the ''magic hour'' shot, which is to say, sunset. The shot is set up when the location manager says, ''This spot is good, but the spot 100 yards away is superb.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A STAR CALLED HENRY: Volume 1 of 'The Last Roundup,' by Roddy Doyle. (Penguin, $14.) The first novel in a planned trilogy recounts the coming of age of Henry Smart, born into wretched poverty in the Dublin slums at the turn of the century and caught up as a teenager in the 1916 Easter Rebellion. Before long he is enlisted by Michael Collins to recruit a rebel army by day and assassinate the movement's enemies by night. This ''witty, furious and bitingly detailed story,'' chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1999, plays subversive tricks with history as it punctures Ireland's national legend, Richard Eder wrote in these pages.

title: Bulbs Here, Bulbs Everywhere
description: TRADITION has it that the sight of the first robin means that spring is on its way. Yet so many of these friendly birds stay around all through the winter months, they have lost their springtime significance.

title: Correspondence/My Media Moment; A Bush-League Aside Vaults An Onlooker Into the Campaign's Glare
description: I HAVE been writing newspaper articles for four decades. Broadcasting has never tempted me, except for bit parts on such sober outlets as C-SPAN and WQXR-FM. So what was I doing with an invitation to appear on the ''Late Show With David Letterman''? And seriously thinking about doing it, before saying, no thanks?

title: Sept. 3-9; Glacial School Improvement
description: A study showed that if American eighth graders continued to improve their basic math skills at the pace they have since 1973, it would take 125 years for them to catch up with their peers in Singapore -- assuming those students don't raise their own scores. The study, by the National Assessment of Educational Progress (the standardized tests known as the nation's report card), showed that while scores on a new test emphasizing problem-solving and geometry have risen steadily throughout the 1990's, performance on a test stressing arithmetic has improved only slightly, and reading scores have been practically flat since 1971. Jodi Wilgoren

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: Economics Of The Actors Strike; The Unkindest 'Cut!'
description: REALITY TVWhen Ann Carlton Bose used to catch commercials, she saw . . . commercials. Now she sees trouble. The owner of the L.A.-based Estate Funding Inc. gets about a third of her revenues, some $10 million last year, from entertainment clients. ''When the entertainment guys are insecure about their future, they don't buy houses,'' she says. What's making them insecure -- and what has pushed Hollywood studios to accelerate film production lately -- is the strike that began on May 1 by commercial actors in the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. The actors are protesting advertisers' plans to replace their pay-per-play royalties with a flat quarterly fee, which they say neither rewards them for a successful commercial nor compensates them for any typecasting aftereffects. SAG also says that the new plan would cut actors' pay an average of 5 percent, thereby reducing the number of actors eligible for health care coverage. The advertisers counter that the union's bottom half, earnings-wise, would actually make 30 percent more. They claim the current payment system is outdated because the proliferation of cable channels now requires that commercials air more frequently to reach as many viewers as before.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Neptune, a Tech Park Plan for Route 66
description: THE 167 hilly acres dotted with wetlands and thick woods along Route 66 in the north-central portion of this Monmouth County township have long defied development. But now, a group of New Jersey investors has advanced a plan to turn most of the property into a four-million-square-foot technology and office park.

He has agreed to donate 74 acres of land to the state, grant an easement across his property for a recreation trail, and preserve another 591 acres in its natural state. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAVCAR, LAWRENCE R.
description: TAVCAR-Lawrence R., 64. A longtime senior public relations executive who was an expert in preparing corporate annual reports, died on August 24 at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital, near his home in Stamford. He managed or was involved in the production of 80 annual reports, sometimes drafting the messages of chief executive officers. Mr. Tavcar was a consultant working from an office in his home since 1990. As a consultant and, earlier, as an account executive, he served such clients as AT&T, Automatic Data Processing, Coca-Cola Bottling, Engelhard, Firestone, H.J. Heinz, McGrawHill, Reader's Digest, Scott Paper, C.I.T. Financial Corporation, and Unilever. In the late 1980's, he was senior director for corporate communications for Paramount Communications, formerly Gulf+Western. From 1978 to 1984, he was a senior vice president of the Carl Byoir & Associates, then the third largest public relations firm in the country. An annual report that he prepared as a consultant to Engelhard received an award from the National Association of Investors Corporation as one of the best from an investor's perspective. ''A masterful job,'' said the judges. Another citation for his work on annual reports, hailed his performance with the comment: ''Of all the talents in the field, none do we respect more than Lawrence R. Tavcar...Not only does he produce good work...but he's one of the industry's true thinkers.''At Paramount, his last corporate position before becoming a consultant, Mr. Tavcar produced six annual reports and was responsible for analyst and annual meeting presentations. The company's reports received awards from ''Institutional Investor'' magazine. He also directed the creation and publication of ONE, the company's quarterly magazine. ''Using spectacular graphics and sheer showmanship,'' the ''Public Relations Handbook'' said, the magazine ''achieves a dazzling impact...as attractive in content as in style.'' He played an instrumental communications role during the company's restructuring from a quintessential conglomerate with farranging operations into an international leader in entertainment (Paramount Pictures) and publishing (Simon & Schuster). Paramount was acquired by Viacom in 1994. As an account executive at Carl Byoir, Mr. Tavcar handled the public relations involved in the recall of the Firestone 500 tire, then the largest product recall in history, an incident that has reverberations in another Firestone recall that is taking place today. Also, early in his career, he conducted some of the research that demonstrated the increasing importance of institutional investors. Thus, when the New York Stock Exchange established its Institutional Investors Department, he was appointed assistant manager. In addition to his specialization in annual reports, Mr. Tavcar during his career managed projects involving corporate magazines, employee information programs, speech writing, and marketing. He won more than 20 awards from professional associations for his work. Mr. Tavcar frequently retained responsibility for the writing end of public relations projects, an activiity often delegated to writing specialists. His writing extended over a broad array of business products, testament to his undergraduate education in journalism and his lifelong appreciation of stellar articles that appeared in newspapers and magazines. Mr. Tavcar was a member of the Public Relations Society of America and served on its honors and awards committee for four years. He also was a member of the National Investor Relations Institute, the International Association of Business Communicators, the Society of Professional Journalists, and the Fairfield County (Conn.) Public Relations Association. He was a former contributing editor of the Corporate Communications Report and the Corporate Annual Report Newsletter and a contributor to many newsletters in the public relations and communications fields. Mr. Tavcar, who was born and raised in Cleveland, maintained a devotion to the Cleveland Browns football team and the Cleveland Indians baseball team through a lifetime spent mostly in the Northeast. He was a graduate of Ohio Universtiy and retained a lifelong loyalty to his alma mater. He served on the board of directors of its national alumni association, as a member of the advisory board to the university's E.W. Scripps School of Journalism, and as president of Ohio University's Greater New York Alumni Chapter. He received two service awards from the university. Mr. Tavcar leaves his wife, Denise, and two sons, Bret of Stamford, and Erik of Arlington, Va. He also leaves four sisters, Francis Tavcar, Dorothy Tavcar, Marge Conetsco, and Pauline Debevec, all of Cleveland, and a brother, Thomas, of Birmingham, Ala. A ceremony celebrating Lawrence Tavcar's life will be held at 6 P.M. on September 23 at the Bruce Museum, 1 Museum Drive, Greenwich. Directions are available from the museum at 203-869-0376. Contributions in memory of Lawrence R. Tavcar may be made to CAP Cure (for the cure of prostate cancer) at 1250 Fourth Street, Suite 360, Santa Monica, CA 90401. Contributions may also be made to the Lawrence R. Tavcar Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Ohio University Foundation, P.O. Box 869, Athens, OH. 45701.

title: Sins of the Marketplace
description: Who Are We?

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: New York City
description: Great bars come in every possible guise. There are great pickup bars, great bars for retro cocktails and even great dives, when you're in the Charles Bukowski frame of mind. My favorite genre is the sumptuous hotel bar, and my favorite New York hotel bar is Mark's Bar, at the Mark Hotel on East 77th Street.

title: Bandits in the Global Shipping Lanes
description: Jack Hitt's article (Aug. 20) is a heart thumper, a wonderfully written crime tale. But how piracy relates to ''the inequities of the free-trade economy'' is opaque at best.

title: A Finger Lakes Gold Rush
description: Riesling and the Finger Lakes triumphed in this year's New York Wine and Food Classic, the major contest devoted to New York wines. All the most important awards went to Seneca Lake wineries, the first time one region swept everything in the contest's 15-year history. Most winning wines cost less than $20; all can be shipped inside the state.

title: Program Promotes Jewish Schools
description: MORE than 200 people from around the United States who have pledged at least $100,000 to a Jewish day school through the Partnership for Excellence in Jewish Education will gather in White Plains next Sunday and Monday to be recognized for their generosity and to learn how to expand the pool of donors for the cause of Jewish education.

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: Hong Kong
description: When the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten opened an outpost of his restaurant, Vong, in Hong Kong in 1997, there was a predictable scramble for tables. But today, the real action is at the bar -- a sleek, dimly lighted oasis where a chic crowd gathers to knock back the stiffest martinis in town (about $12.50, plus tax).

title: Saving Heat In Multiunit Buildings
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to cut their heating costs usually have several options; they can make sure all windows remain closed when the heat is on; they can set the thermostat to whatever temperature they want, day or night; they can avoid heating unused rooms by selectively shutting off radiators or heat registers; and they can make sweaters and thick socks mandatory attire for occupants during the winter months.

title: Final Weekend Provides Peek Into Grand Slam Future
description: The 2000 United States Open started with dramatic exits. It continued with stubborn refusals to leave. But it could be remembered most for its new beginnings.

title: Sparring Partners
description: Rope Burns

title: Nantucket, Aglow In Shades Of Gray
description: The roses and foxgloves were muted splashes of color in the evening's last light, and I wandered through the town of Nantucket a little in awe. I'd never seen so many gray houses. The term ''weathered gray siding,'' frequently used to describe their restrained beauty, doesn't do them justice. Nantucket houses seem to know weather: they've been intimate with rain squalls gusting off the Atlantic and the fog that periodically enshrouds the island, with winter's northeasters and, of course, resplendent sunny summer days.
