title: The Jaguars Finally Get a Bruiser
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 9  Sometimes, a single hit can set the tone for a whole season. Sometimes, one player can change the attitude of an entire team.

title: Interior Paint, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: BEFORE the introduction of modern latex and acrylic-based paints, oil-based paint was the most common type of paint used for commercial and residential applications. There was also another type of paint that was made and used around the home, although today few people have even heard of it. This was milk paint, and it was made, as the name implies, with a milk base.

title: Word of Warning on Camden From Someone Who Knows
description: It has been 10 years since Randy Primas left office, but the people up in Trenton still call him from time to time. They ask him what it was like when he was mayor here, what he thinks they should do now that the city is prostrate once again, and what the chances are for the state's most desperate city to recover some semblance of prosperity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MARTIN

title: Kathryn Golden, Mark Nowakowski
description: Kathryn Sutton Golden, a daughter of Maureen and James Golden of Decatur, Ga., was married there yesterday to Mark Joseph Jerzy Nowakowski, a son of Maja and Jerzy Nowakowski of Port Washington, N.Y. The Rev. Frank Richardson performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: When Jefferson Alexander Stackhouse was 3 years old, good luck entered his life for the first and maybe the last time. Abandoned as a 2-week-old infant by a schizophrenic mother, Jeff had lived by then in eight different foster homes. But in 1988, he was taken in by a woman who quickly made up her mind to love him and who adopted him two years later. The fact that Jeff came to her ''with all his worldly possessions in one very small box'' and called every adult female Mommy ''not only broke but stole my heart,'' his adoptive mother, Leslie Stackhouse, says now. Leslie and her then husband, Norman, adopted two more ''special needs'' children, a girl named Christin and her brother, Casey, who had been taken away from abusive parents when they were toddlers. Leslie's training as a foster parent helped her to go slowly with all three, giving them time to trust her. Though Jeff was withdrawn at first, prone to banging his head against the wall and biting himself, he grew into a happy little boy with a powerful loyalty to his mother.

title: Donald Gallup Dies at 87; Bibliographer of T. S. Eliot
description: Donald Gallup, the Yale literary bibliographer who in 1968 confirmed the discovery of the long-lost manuscript of T. S. Eliot's ''Waste Land,'' died in Branford, Conn., on Wednesday. He was 87.

title: A Bumpy Ride This Summer
description: At the end of a rainy season that cut sharply into their profits, amusement park operators say it was not just the weather but the State Division of Community Affairs that bogged down their industry.

title: Boulez and the Vienna: Opposites Unopposed
description: THE cleft dividing the composers of the 19th century from those of the 20th is arguably the most prominent geographical feature of our musical landscape. Two attitudes -- on how music should sound, how it should feel and what its purpose should be -- have split audiences, musicians and commentators so decisively that in still a third century, the 21st, the gap is only marginally narrower than it was 100 years ago.

title: With Hopes Fading Fast, Clinton Meets With Barak
description: President Clinton and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, held brief impromptu talks yesterday at Mr. Barak's hotel in New York, rounding out a week of discussions on the Middle East peace negotiations and the security relationship between the United States and Israel.

title: Late Into Politics, Retiring Too Soon
description: PEARL CRYSTAL SCHER had a strong opening gambit for her first campaign for elective office. Approaching voters with her hand outstretched and an impish grin, she would say, ''You know, I'm running for office for the first time at the age of 80.''

title: The Boston Pops Make Fairfield County Debut
description: WHAT will Keith Lockhart do this time? Will the 40-year old conductor of the Boston Pops make his Fairfield County debut on a scooter? Will he reprise the Rollerblades? Might Elvis reappear?

title: An Uncle's Adventures in Paradise
description: Some see it as never-never land. To me, Fire Island Pines seems more like an Island of Lost Boys, a place with the lowest per capita body fat this side of the Olympics. Without pecs, abs or a fixation with house music, you can feel pretty invisible there, at least that's what I decided in June, when I tried out my summer share. At 42 with a 34-inch waist, how could I feel at home there?

title: Documenting Flowers of the West
description: WHEN one meets Patricia and Noel Holmgren of White Plains, a Greek myth comes to mind. As a reward for their decency, mutual dedication and hospitality to the gods, a couple named Philomon and Baucis were granted a wish before they died. What they wanted: to stand guard outside the temple together for eternity, one as an oak and the other as a linden tree.

title: A Boom Market In Travel Scams
description: THE vacation swindle business is booming, according to law enforcement agencies, consumer advocates and travel industry organizations. The bait for unsuspecting victims ranges from nonexistent trips to identification cards offering anyone the kind of discounts only travel agents can get legitimately.

title: TOUGHER CIGARETTE LAWS
description: Saying it will make retailers ''think twice before they sell cigarettes to our children,'' Gov. George E. Pataki has signed into law a bill that will strengthen the state's efforts to keep cigarettes from children. The law imposes stricter penalties and fines for the sale of tobacco products to minors. It increases the civil penalties for first-time violators, establishes more stringent penalties for repeat violators and imposes a new fine for retailer who sell cigarettes to minors while their registration is suspended or revoked. Elsa Brenner

Putin returned from New York to meet with top advisers, and detailed proposals for the cuts will be on his desk in coming days, Russian military officials said.

Lynn Representatives, a plumbing supply house, which relocated from Long Island; and Wald Optics Laboratory, a precision optics company, which moved from Pleasantville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERGER, LOIS
description: SCHONBERGER-Lois. The Officers, Board of Directors, and Staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Lois Schonberger, beloved wife of our long time friend and supporter, Eli Schonberger. We wish to express our sorrow and deepest sympathy to Eli; to their children Mark, David, and Stuart; their daughters-inlaw Nadine, Diane, and Carmen; and their grandchildren Zach, Alison, Scott, Jacob, Annie, and Talia. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair Barry Effron, Chair, Westchester General Campaign John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Prime Time For Private Collections
description: AMERICAN collectors in the late 20th century went bonkers over art. Week after week they chalked up records, buying Rembrandts, Renoirs and Rauschenbergs and becoming instant celebrities at black-tie auctions in New York and London. The consumer society had met the art world head on, and collecting evolved into a sport of mass buying more reminiscent of the style of William Randolph Hearst than of Andrew Mellon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHITTENDEN, GEORGE H.
description: CHITTENDEN-George H. In Branford, CT, September 7, of 155 Buffalo Bay, Madison, CT, formerly of Rye, NY. Husband of Sarah Parker Chittenden and the late Laura Carey Chittenden. Retired international banker, having served with J.P. Morgan for many years. He was a Yale University graduate of 1939, and an Army Air Force veteran of World War II. Besides his wife, he leaves children, George H. Chittenden, Paul W. Chittenden, Carey C. Curtis and Laura C. Lyons, and sisters, Dr. Elizabeth C. Lowry and Marjorie C. Jones. Services in Congregational Church of Madison, Tuesday, September 12, at 12 noon. Memorials to Project ALS, 511 Avenue of the Americas, PMB 341, New York, NY 10011.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; A High-Volume Home Builder Avoids Uniformity

title: Giants' New Line Carries Renewed Hope for Offense
description: The bottles of wine, about 2,000 of them, are in storage somewhere in a New Jersey warehouse. Glenn Parker just bought a house in Somerset County, N.J., and is awaiting their delivery before he invites his new co-workers over to sample his cooking and an evening of wine-tasting. He is considering making ''Monday Night Football'' the backdrop.

title: Goodbye, High School. Hello, Life.

Then Ms. Murray and her mother, Eva, 40, along with her two younger sisters and her aunt and uncle, began filling two cars and a pickup truck with Ms. Murray's belongings. At 9 a.m., just as check-in for the dormitories began for the class of 2004, the Murrays pulled up in front of Mendelsohn Quad at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Political Briefing; Prayers Are Answered If Only Symbolically
description: Religion is back in the political news, this time in Louisiana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLKIE, ARLINDA F.
description: WILLKIE-Arlinda F. Born July 31, 1946; died on Sept 7, 2000 from breast cancer. She was courageous, graceful, loving and beloved. We thank her friends, caretakers, nurses and doctors. She is survived by her family including her daughter, Julia T. Miranda; her brother and sister-in-law Frederick & Ida; her sister Julia; her brother Hall; Tom Craveiro; Riccardo Salmona; and her pug Peg. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Benheim Cancer Center or the Red Cross of Greenwich, CT. Service Monday, September 11 at 4 PM, First Congregational Church Old Greenwich, CT.

title: The Gladiator as Economist
description: Brian Grazer, the Imagine Films producer, and Ron Howard, the director, last week signed Russell Crowe, star of ''Gladiator'' and one of Hollywood's hottest leading men, to play John Forbes Nash Jr., who won the Nobel Prize in economics in 1994. The movie, based on the biography ''A Beautiful Mind'' by Sylvia Nasar, a former reporter for The New York Times, recounts how Mr. Nash, who was 21 when he wrote the Ph.D. thesis that made his reputation, suffered for years from paranoid schizophrenia before miraculously recovering in his early 60's -- without drugs or other treatment.

title: Priests of the 60's Fear Loss of Their Legacy
description: Msgr. Thomas Leonard remembers the day in 1962 when, inspired and enthusiastic, he celebrated Mass facing the congregation for the first time.

title: Against the Tide
description: Memoir

title: A Corner of New France
description: THE French roots of St. Louis slip into focus at unexpected moments. On a hot afternoon in May, as a radio announcer was warning rush-hour commuters that traffic was snarled on Interstate 270 going through Chouteau Island in the Mississippi River, I was reminded of a time 200 years ago when the river was filled with flat-bottomed boats laden with furs and skins to be exchanged at trading posts operated by the Chouteau family.

title: A Designer Who Lives Like Her Clients
description: IT is a fashion cliche for designers to say they design for themselves, but in Eileen Fisher's case, it's true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWAR, ROBERT E.
description: DEWAR-Robert E. Age 7 7, died peacefully at home on September 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of Robert and his wife, Alison, Jane and John. Dearly loved grandfather of Bessie and Charlotte. Brother of Dale Dewar. Memorial service at Kirk in the Hills, 1340 W. Long Lake Road, Bloomfield Hills, Monday, September 11th, 2pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Coleman Foundation, 313 S. Church St, Hudson, Michigan 49247 or Michigan Opera Theatre, 1526 Broadway, Detroit, Michigan 48226. For information contact Lynch & Sons Funeral Directors 248-435-0660.

title: Kings of the Hill
description: THE HEAD GAME

title: A Few That Look Worth the Extra Wait
description: IN a television season whose big names include Bette Midler, Geena Davis and Gabriel Byrne, all starring in sitcoms, the most promising series belong to Andre Braugher, David E. Kelley and some guy who looks like David Letterman. Their shows are not entirely original; let's be realistic, that is not what most television series do. Yet they accomplish something equally good, breathing fresh life into traditional genres.

title: The Earthbound Crew That Chases Balloonists
description: TWO Rye residents are about to board a hot-air balloon. They are Steven Cadenhead and his wife, Melanie, who is looking less than thrilled. The ride was actually Mrs. Cadenhead's idea, a birthday gift for her husband, but you wouldn't guess it from her ''not good with heights'' mumbles. Unlike his wife, Mr. Cadenhead, camera in hand, is a cyclone of excitement. He is carrying forth on the magical beauty they are about to experience. Mrs. Cadenhead looks a touch green.

title: A Little Nearer Redemption
description: The Blackwater Lightship

title: Football And Other Guilty Pleasures
description: KEVIN SMITH

title: Bandits in the Global Shipping Lanes
description: Only in Gilbert and Sullivan operas are people forced into a career of piracy.

title: POSTINGS: A Block-by-Block Atlas; All of Manhattan, in 172 Pages
description: Want to find the highest hill in Manhattan? The deepest subway station?

title: Campaign Laugh Track
description: A running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night, Sept. 1, through Thursday night, Sept. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODELL, JUDY
description: MODELL-Judy. A native of Philadelphia, on September 6, 2000 after a long illness. She is survived by her sister Evelyn Pantell and a nephew Richard Straff. She was an avocational watercolor landscape artist, former model, public relations executive and more recently a real estate salesperson. Funeral to be held at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave., at 11AM on September 11.

title: HARRISON: NORTHWEST BOWS TO CURFEW
description: After objections from neighbors and the county, Northwest Airlines has rescheduled its early flight out of Westchester County Airport in Harrison to comply with the county's voluntary curfew. Northwest's first flight of the day -- to Detroit -- will leave the gate at 6:29 a.m. but will not take off until after 6:30. The flight had left the gate at 6:15 a.m. County officials are urging residents to exert pressure on Delta Airlines, which still has a 5:59 a.m. flight. Elsa Brenner

title: The View From/Newington; Ham Radio Community Spreading Its Signals
description: WHEN telephones became commonplace, amateur radio did not go the way of the dinosaur as people had predicted. It did not leave the scene when television arrived. Even the Internet and e-mail messages have not lured ham radio hobbyists from the airwaves.

title: In a Kennedy's Legacy, Lessons and Pitfalls For Hillary Clinton; Carpetbagger Issue Has Echoes of '64, But Differences Could Prove Crucial
description: He stepped out of the shadows of another political era one morning last week, a familiar silhouette walking at the side of Hillary Rodham Clinton along the Hudson River in the Upper West Side neighborhood that had so rallied around his father, Robert F. Kennedy, when he ran for senator 36 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about an infestation of beetles in trees at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery misstated the writer's given name. She was Kelly Crow, not Sherri.

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction
description: Noodling for Flatheads

title: Knicks Are Vague About Trading Ewing
description: Two weeks ago, Scott Layden said he expected Patrick Ewing to play his 16th professional season with the Knicks. That conviction may be changing, though.

title: Article 2000091091012214144 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The prosperity that I keep hearing about is not what keeps money in my bank account and my bills paid every month; it is the fact that we are spending carefully. If I don't need new shoes, I don't buy them.''

title: Going Negative With a Lava Lamp, and Other G.O.P. Ad Discussions
description: Harold Kaplan, a Madison Avenue advertising executive who is an unpaid consultant to Gov. George W. Bush's campaign, said the ideal way to attack Vice President Al Gore popped into his head in late August when he was reading the obituary of the creator of the Lava Lamp.

title: EASTCHESTER: DOMESTIC PARTNERS WIN BENEFITS
description: The Eastchester Town Board has voted 5 to 0 to offer health benefits to same-sex domestic partners of town employees. The action came after the board heard protests and support for the measure. ''We saw it as an issue of treating all employees the same,'' Town Supervisor James E. Cavanaugh said. ''We didn't mean it to be a social crusade.'' The benefits were requested by Teamsters Local 456, which represents the police force, and they apply to all 200 full-time town employees. No other municipality in the county offers the benefits, though the county, state, and New York City governments do. Robert Worth

title: Think Spring And Plan Ahead
description: Fall planting makes eminent good sense. Gardeners are less likely to overheat and perennials are more likely to get a head start on next year.

title: Investing; Judging the Odds On Those Battered Phone Stocks
description: DEATH warmed over: That is how one analyst has described the battered long-distance and local telephone sector of the telecommunications industry. In a sharp reversal, the Standard & Poor's 500 communications services index, which rose 18.2 percent last year, has dropped 28.9 percent from a mid-December high, to 173.55.

title: A New Jersey School District Gets Strict About Residency
description: For years, the Englewood School District has spent thousands of dollars in a court fight to create a school intended to draw students from wealthier communities. Now it is going to great lengths to weed out students from outside its boundaries.

title: SPOTLIGHT; How To Liven Up The Emmy's: Shandling
description: AFTER one of television's strangest summers in recent memory, a season in which words like Tagi and Pagong somehow wormed their way into the lexicon, leave it to Garry Shandling to put the reality-based craze in perspective.

title: Israel's Next Palestinian Problem
description: The expanse of green lawn that stretches to the door of the Israeli Knesset rippled in the breeze, uncharacteristically empty of lawmakers and lobbyists. It was Israel's Memorial Day, when the country honors its fallen soldiers, and Parliament had dispersed to the country's military cemeteries for its annual somber reflection on the human cost of the Zionist enterprise.

title: Philippine Rebels Free Last of Vacationing Westerners
description: More than four months after 21 people were seized in their beach clothes from a remote diving resort, the last four Westerners were freed today from the jungle by Muslim rebel kidnappers.

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction
description: WAITING

title: Celebrated in Verse and Song
description: Where the remote----- ride In th' ocean's bosom unespy'd: Andrew Marvell

title: Jets Have Options In Lucas
description: The Jets will probably use the younger, more mobile Ray Lucas in place of Vinny Testaverde to confuse the New England Patriots at times on Monday night, but they may need more than occasional confusion. The Jets learned today that their top receiver, Wayne Chrebet, is injured, joining running back Curtis Martin in the trainer's room.

title: Sara Echaniz, Peter Krause
description: Sara Ann Echaniz and Dr. Peter Carl Krause were married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard. Nicholas Basden, a friend of the couple who was appointed a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents in Chilmark, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZSCHILD, SARA
description: SCHWARZSCHILD-Sara Horenstein Stromberg. Suddenly August 28. Survived by husband Ludy, son Ben Horenstein, daughter Doby Charnin, stepson Darryl Stromberg, their spouces and her grandchildren. Donations in her memory to Alper JCC, 11155 S.W. 112th Avenue, Miami, Florida 33176. We are incomplete without her.

title: Russia Poised to Cut Military by One-Third
description: Late last month, President Vladimir V. Putin faced a room full of angry Russians, the relatives of the 118 men who perished on the nuclear submarine Kursk. He told them bluntly that Russia ''had to have a smaller army,'' one that was better equipped and ''technically perfect'' to protect soldiers and sailors from disaster and defend national interests.

title: Reckonings; Gore's Tax Problem
description: The bad news about the detailed economic plan the Gore-Lieberman campaign released last week is that it does contain some smoke and mirrors. The good news is that the smoke and mirrors are there not to conceal the true cost of extravagant promises, but to make a modest, not particularly exciting plan sound like something more.

title: Crime
description: The youthful spring in Dick Francis' literary step has a lot to do with his relish for depicting physical punishment. You can almost see the gleam in his 80-year-old eye as he dispatches four thugs, led by an Amazonian sadist named Rose, to break the wrists of a young glass blower who runs afoul of a rough racetrack crowd in SHATTERED (Putnam, $25.95). As the latest in a long line of decent and honorable (and virtually indistinguishable) heroes who achieve their moral majority by standing up to bullies, Gerard Logan eludes the wrist snappers, but only because Francis has more tortuous tests in store for him.

title: Political Briefing; Nasty Divorce Battle Finds Home in Politics
description: Representative Albert R. Wynn of Maryland's Fourth Congressional District almost certainly will win a fifth term this fall. He is a black Democrat and his district, on the outskirts of Washington, is mostly black and mostly Democratic. Further, his Republican opponent, John Kimble, who is white, has failed in two earlier challenges to draw more than 15 percent of the vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, ARNOLD
description: BECKER-Arnold. 68, died September 8, 2000. Devoted son of Yetta and his late father Wolf, husband of Margaret, father of John and stepfather of Denise and Sara. Grandfather of Kai and Harry. We will remember him with love. Services today, 10:30 AM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC. Memorial donations to New York University Medical Center.

title: Late Shows At Multiplex Are Irritant
description: When plans were announced last year for a 12-plex cinema at 106 Court Street, neighbors welcomed the idea. Still, some people worried about late-night noise and crowds in the quiet neighborhood, and wanted assurances of no after-midnight screenings. Residents say no promises were made, but that there was an understanding.

title: Vintage Washington
description: A two hours' drive east of Seattle, the land turns from green to beige, the coffee from cappuccino to cup of joe and a most curious sign appears, welcoming visitors to ''The Palm Springs of Washington.'' But I couldn't find any palm trees in the Yakima Valley, and certainly nothing approaching the ubiquity of golf courses and streets named for celebrities that define the Palm Springs of Southern California.

title: Claire Laverge, Peter Petitt
description: Claire Antoinette Laverge, the daughter of Regine A. Laverge-Schade of Washington Depot, Conn., and Hendrik J. Laverge of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Andrew Petitt, the son of Ann Petitt Webber of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Phil A. Petitt. The Rev. Cheryl P. Anderson performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: Phenomenon; No Room At the Inn
description: On the last Sunday night in August, the crowds surged into the Desert Inn's Crystal Showroom to see a nostalgia revue starring Frankie Avalon, Fabian and Bobby Rydell. The seats were filled with old and current employees and sort of familiar -- or mostly forgotten -- Vegas faces, like those of the comedian Steve Rossi, the Sinatra crony Sonny King and the hotelier Bob Stupak. Only one booth was empty, No. 23, always reserved for Steve Wynn, the owner of the D.I., as the casino is known locally. When Fabian invited the audience to twist -- Let's do it!'' -- the audience rushed the stage to hug and kiss the former teen idol. ''There's no better way to close a place down,'' Rossi hollered. Unless you count swiping souvenirs, perhaps. Room service couldn't bring Champagne because the coveted gold-handled ice buckets with the hotel's logo were gone. The crowds snagged everything from swizzle sticks to slot-machine tokens. A security guard sold his badge for $300. An employee was rumored to have bought 500 Don Rickles souvenir poker chips with plans to sell them on eBay.

title: The Least Likely Burning Man
description: THERE aren't many rules at Burning Man -- the weeklong cyberhippie carnival in the middle of the Nevada desert that ended on Labor Day. But one of them is ''No logos.'' I was warned about this before I went. Unfortunately, I don't own any clothing without logos. Who does? So as an anti-anticommercial statement on my first morning there, I wore an old Creative Artists Agency T-shirt.

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe: London
description: If bars were to be classified on a scale from restful to raucous, the Fifth-Floor watering hole at Harvey Nichols, the upscale department store in London's Knightsbridge, would probably rate something like: not for the faint-hearted.

title: Making More Air Time for Water Polo, Archery, Team Handball and Canoeing
description: Devoted CNBC and MSNBC viewers may be surprised when soccer players, boxers, weight lifters, kayakers and wrestlers start to replace Ron Insana, Chris Matthews, Matt Lauer, and Maria Bartiromo at strategic intervals during the next few weeks. But the NBC mother ship doesn't mind shoving aside some of its cable mainstays for two weeks to broaden its Summer Olympics coverage from Sydney.

title: He Just Said No -- To the Drug War
description: For me, Matthew Miller's article on New Mexico's governor, Gary Johnson (Aug. 20), both supplied a definition and raised a question. The definition is for ''hubris.'' Surely this describes his bootstrap and willpower solutions for poverty and drug treatment, and especially his business philosophy. It would be nice to see him earn $100,000 a year cleaning houses. The question is: What's he smoking?

title: Tian-Wei Chen, Haohui Wang
description: Tian-Wei Dianna Chen, the daughter of Shu and Xia Chen of Manhattan, was married there yesterday to Haohui Wang, the son of Xiaoyan and Yucheng Wang of Brooklyn. The Rev. Jeffrey Earnshaw, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Between Fire and Water In Idaho
description: OUR flotilla of three large rafts and an assortment of eight kayaks had successfully negotiated the four-foot drop of Tappan Falls, a difficult rapid on the Middle Fork of the Salmon River in Idaho, when fire, rather than water, grabbed our attention. It was late on the third day of our four-day raft trip in mid-August, a vacation my husband, Michael, and I and our teenage daughters, Hilary and Ariel, had squeezed into a few of the days remaining before Hilary left home to start her freshman year of college in Indiana.

title: For Health Insurers, a Surprisingly Strong Pulse
description: IF investors followed the advice of Warren Buffett and bought stocks only in businesses they understood, the market capitalization of companies that provide health insurance would probably be anemic.

title: Jones Remains Light Heavyweight Champion After Stopping Harding
description: Roy Jones Jr. raised his championship belts high above his head again tonight. Across the ring, Eric Harding was left clutching his injured left arm and wondering how close he might have come to an upset.

title: How an Unpretentious Family Car, the Passat, Got So Hot
description: FAMILY sedans generate big sales, but seldom do they create a buzz. The Volkswagen Passat, however, has gained most-wanted status, thanks to glowing reviews from automotive writers, high ratings from consumer publications and positive word-of-mouth among owners.

title: Rebecca Lowell, John Edwards III
description: Rebecca Marie Lowell, a daughter of Jacqueline L. Lowell and Thomas J. Lowell of Barnstable, Mass., was married yesterday to John Jacob Edwards III, a son of Glorine Dobbins Edwards of New York and Mr. Edwards Jr. of Fearrington Village, N.C. The Rev. Marek Chmurski performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Centerville, Mass.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Stephen Sprinkle, 48

title: Present to Meet Future In Sampras-Safin Final
description: Pete Sampras backpedaled toward the baseline and sprang above the court, levitating for an instant in the rarefied air he alone seems to inhabit. And then Sampras shattered the idyllic moment by blistering the ball, his feet landing about the time his overhead crashed to earth.

title: Open Your Checkbook, Then Just Open a Vein
description: THE developing short story Bill Eville took to writing class that night was so personal he might as well have shown up naked.

title: Burning Down the House
description: ASSORTED FIRE EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, BEATRICE
description: MELTZER-Beatrice. On September 9, 2000, of Roslyn, New York. Beloved wife of the late Larry. Devoted mother of Judi and Jay. Loving grandmother of Bradley and Lyndsey. Serives today, 2 PM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, New York. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Enough About Angels: The Devil Gets His Due
description: ANGELS have been gracing pop culture fairly ostentatiously these last several years -- ''Touched by an Angel,'' ''City of Angels,'' ''Angels in the Outfield,'' ''Angels in America,'' John Travolta spectacularly spreading his wings in ''Michael,'' the elevation of ''It's a Wonderful Life'' to a basic text of American civilization. But lately, and almost unnoticed in the seraphic swell, the Devil has been getting his due.

title: PRESIDENTIAL RACE IS BEING RUN HARD IN KEYSTONE STATE
description: ''Battleground Scranton,'' said a banner headline in The Tribune here on Tuesday.

title: WATER GAP CRAFT BAN
description: As of Sept. 30, personal watercraft will be prohibited in the 37 miles of the Delaware River that is part of the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area. Following a series of public hearings, the parks service said personal watercraft like Jet Skis or Wave Runners were disturbing to visitors who wanted a quiet, parklike setting. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULZ, LANGDON W.
description: SCHULZ-Langdon W. September 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Mildred. Former Senior Vice President of Finance at Otis Elevator Company. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, September 11, 2000, 7-9PM. Service, Tuesday, September 12, 2000, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Sorting Out the Danger of the West Nile Virus
description: ONE year after West Nile virus arrived in the New York area, scientists continue to prove, week after week, that it is all over the state. What they have been unable to prove is what exactly that means.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for BOB WRIGHT; Going Not for the Gold, But for the Cachet
description: BOB WRIGHT, the president of NBC, is wrapping up a few last-minute details stateside this week before he heads off with about 800 of NBC's biggest advertising clients for Sydney, Australia, and his network's biggest production of 2000, the Summer Olympics.

title: Stacey Green, Jason Alper
description: Stacey Fran Green, a daughter of Regina and Gerald Green of New York, was married last evening to Jason Matthew Alper, the son of Wendy and Neal Alper of Pembroke Pines, Fla. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattlebaum officiated at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Yanks Complete Sweep As Rookie Wins Debut
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10  Randy Keisler's major league debut lasted five innings today, long enough to qualify for his first victory, too short to satisfy youth's ambition. told before the sixth inning that he was finished for the day, Keisler sat next to the bench coach Don Zimmer and asked, in a roundabout way, why he had been taken out so soon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA ANN
description: WEXLER-Melissa Ann. 5/ 9/54 to 9/12/81. Missy, the memories of your sweetness and strength help us to live on without you. Love Mommy, Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri and Larry

title: Theme Out of Africa and Fire-Grilled Meat
description: IF one's idea of dining is merely to ''eat at Joe's,'' then this is probably not the right Joe. As at most theme restaurants, Mighty Joe Young's tries for spectacle: beyond the torches at the entrance, diners pass a couple of life-size stuffed wild animals, then encounter film posters and a lounge resembling a colonial outpost on the edge of the veld. The mise-en-scene -- Africa via Hollywood -- suggests the primal and the slightly dangerous, but the hunt is only through the menu.

title: 1 Killed and 4 Hurt In Newark Shootings
description: One man was killed and four other people were wounded last night when two gunmen opened fire on a car parked near an intersection in Newark, the police and witnesses said.

title: Elizabeth Wadsworth, Barry Wine
description: Elizabeth Anne Wadsworth and Barry Wine are to be married today at Mr. Wine's weekend house in New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis W. Jones, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUTUORE, DOLORES
description: AUTUORE-Dolores. Wife of the late Joseph Autuore, died September 4, 2000. A NYC resident for 50 years and a featured performer with the Katherine Dunham Company appearing on Broadway in Truman Capote's ''House of Flowers''. Dolores is survived by her daughters Gina and Julie, grandchildren Joshua and Maya. A Memorial Service, Sunday, September 17, 2000, at 12:30PM in Congregation B'nai Israel, 2710 Park Ave., Bridgeport CT.

title: Political Briefing; Arizona G.O.P. Race Rife With Dirty Tricks
description: Representative Matt Salmon, a Republican, is not running for re-election this year in Arizona's First Congressional District. But the betting is that the district will remain in Republican hands -- unless the Republicans battling for their party's nomination in Tuesday's primary self-destruct and the lightly regarded Democratic nominee, David Mendoza, ekes out a victory come the fall.

title: Portrait of a Turnip
description: GEORGE MOORE, 1852-1933.

title: Pitcher Hit by Line Drive Suffered Retinal Damage
description: Red Sox pitcher Bryce Florie, hit in the face by a line drive in Friday's game with the Yankees, underwent surgery today and, the team said, there was extensive damage to his right eye.

title: Style; Class Distinctions
description: Something was up at the fall men's shows / something that was telegraphed as much through the music played as through the clothes parading down the runway. Frank Sinatra crooning for Puff Daddy's jeans line? Billie Holiday wailing ''God Bless the Child'' at virtually every stop? Clearly designers were in a mood for the classics, but, to paraphrase Frank, they did it their way. And the overall effect, witty indulgences and all, was completely elegant and satisfying.

title: Redefining a 208-Year-Old Bank
description: DAVID A. SPINA is the corporate incarnation of a soccer referee. He is also out to change the rules of the game at the State Street Corporation, the financial services company he heads.

title: Hillary Clinton Stars, Unrivaled, at Labor Day Parade
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was the belle of New York City's somewhat belated Labor Day parade yesterday, just as union leaders had planned.

title: Sept. 3-9; A New Concorde Clue
description: Could the culprit behind the fiery crash of the Air France Concorde in July be a slender 17-inch-long piece of metal that fell off a Continental Airlines DC-10? French investigators said a metal strip they found among the debris from the Concorde appeared to match the description of a piece missing from a DC-10 that had taken off only minutes before on the same runway. Investigators believe the strip gashed a tire on the supersonic jet, causing huge chunks of rubber to smash through the Concorde's fuel tanks and triggering a fire. Suzanne Daley

title: Scott Simon and Caroline Richard
description: THE host of ''Weekend Edition With Scott Simon'' on National Public Radio has a voice that's just right for reading a bedtime story to a child. Yet Mr. Simon's observations and questions never put you to sleep, whether he is reporting on Al Gore, a hospital in Kosovo, surfing or the death of his cat. (He did an obituary for her on the air.)

title: Washington Heights Journal; Dominican Food Vendors: Culture Is Clustered
description: Jose Ramirez, 17, and his cousin Paul Suazo, 16, spun down Amsterdam Avenue on their bikes. They bounced over the cracked pavement, dodging the trucks and cars, many of them with their windows open and Latino rhythms thumping from the sound systems, until they reached 179th Street.

title: By Day, a Candidate; by Night, a Fund-Raiser
description: By day, Al Gore will be talking about education. By night, he will be raising money.

title: The Nation; The Clinton Administration's See-No-Evil C.I.A.
description: WHEN the Clinton administration began planning its first major military campaign, the 1994 American invasion of Haiti, the Central Intelligence Agency was left out until the last minute, when administration officials suddenly asked for help.

title: Reliance Bank in White Plains Given Poor Rating by Agency
description: A report by Weiss Ratings Agency ranks Reliance Bank in White Plains as the state's weakest bank. The agency gave Reliance an E-, with E denoting ''very weak,'' indicating a risk to depositors or creditors. The rating was based on an analysis of quarterly financial statements. Philip E. Zegarelli, president of Reliance, said: ''The report is way off. We're doing very well, so well that in 1999 we underestimated our state franchise tax.'' He also said the bank expects an infusion of $4.25 million next month from Avant Financial of Syracuse, which will become majority owner. Elsa Brenner

title: Lining Up for a Shot for Meningitis
description: LIKE most 18-year-olds, Heather Lynn had scarcely heard of meningitis when she applied to college last fall. But after being accepted at the University of Massachusetts, she received a letter from the school recommending that she be vaccinated for the disease. And when she discovered that all her college-bound friends in New Rochelle were getting the vaccination, she went to the Sound Shore Medical Center and got one herself.

title: Sept. 3-9; A Gigantic Gathering Of World Leaders
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan called it ''a remarkable convergence of views.'' When about 150 government leaders representing a large majority of the world's nations ended their first no-frills working summit on Friday night, there was not much disagreement over the lopsided effects of the global economy. That was the easy part. Now, what to do about it.

title: Straight Out of Brooklyn
description: It's midafternoon in Manahawkin and a hungry shopper at the Kmart Shopping Center steps into Trupia's Italian Pizzeria Restaurant for a slice of pizza and a slice of life. Doo-wop music is on the CD player, old news clippings about the Yankees are on the wall, there's a photograph of Frank Sinatra, and behind the counter, there's a retired New York City policeman in an apron. He's Bob Trupia, who left the force a couple of years ago and brought his Flatbush dreams and family from Brooklyn to the Jersey Shore. Trupia's is a pizzeria in front and a trim Italian restaurant in the back. Mr. Trupia's pizza has Brooklyn flair. There are 20 varieties, from the tried and true (the menu calls them ''New York style'') to the unexpected, like bacon, chicken parmigiana and steak. It is prepared with imported Italian tomatoes and with mozzarella made in the kitchen, and comes by the slice ($1.25 to $1.45) or pie $4.50 for a ''personal'' size to $15 for some Sicilian pies) or stromboli ($4 or $4.50). Where Mr. Trupia truly gives reign to his culinary imagination is in his ''gourmet'' pizzas. One standout is pizza alla vodka, made with mozzarella and vodka cream sauce. He has also immortalized his family in crust by naming pizzas after them. One of them, named for his daughter, is Danielle's Delight, fresh tomatoes, bacon and pepperoni slathered with mozzarella. Sometimes policemen who come in to eat will spot Mr. Tropia's N.Y.P.D. retirement plaque on the wall and introduce themselves. Mr. Trupia will come out and shake their hands. ''It is a bond that never goes away,'' he says, and then it's back behind the counter. MARGO NASH

title: Sara Golier, Douglas Schneider
description: Sara Catherine Golier, a daughter of Sue W. Golier and Robert T. Golier of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Douglas Jonathan Schneider, a son of Carol E. Schneider and Dr. William J. Schneider, both of Manhattan. Kenneth E. Keskinen, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Cream Hill Association, a club in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Theres More Tennis to See
description: Today conclusion of the United States Open is not the end of professional tennis in this area. A women's satellite event will be held this week in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

title: New Nuggets and Piles of Old Gold
description: A * indicates an event of special note.

title: All Singing, All Dancing, All Surprising
description: THIS fall will be a season of radical departures, with an astonishing number of musicals from directors new to the genre and an action film from a director who made his name with finely tuned pictures based in the comedy of manners.

title: War in Colombia Creates a Nation of Victims
description: Something terrible happened to Venecia Barona Mosquera, something senseless but horribly common among the people who have been displaced from the parts of Colombia brutalized by war and who have sought uncertain refuge here in the squalor of a shantytown named Nelson Mandela.

title: Veggies vs. a Courthouse: Worries and Reassurance
description: Fans of the first and only Greenmarket on Staten Island are worried that the market may lose its spot in a parking lot to an incoming courthouse. But city officials say that plans for the courthouse are not yet firm and that there is plenty of time and room for compromise.

title: Hitting Executives Where They Live
description: Suppose you have a corporate infrastructure software product to sell to top executives at big, technologically adept companies -- a notoriously hard bunch to reach. How do you stand out from the other thousand companies clamoring for their attention?

title: Football Crisis: Kids, No Equipment and Vice Versa
description: Nathan Andrews, 13, says playing football makes him feel closer to his friends.

title: Following Up: Mafiosi Haven Becomes Fashionistas Heaven
description: As SoHo seeps eastward and NoHo southward in Lower Manhattan, Amy Chan, a women's accessory boutique at 247 Mulberry Street, is typical of the chic shops and cafes that have been moving into northern Little Italy, now promoted by real estate marketers as NoLIta.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Confronting the High Cost of Divorce
description: FROM paying lawyers to hiring expert witnesses to appraising a home or business, divorce can be expensive anywhere. But it can be even more costly in an affluent suburb like Westchester County.

description: Water for Gotham

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Cases Raise Issues of Competence
description: Are today's technology issues too complex for the typical judge to judge?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, RABBI BENJAMIN
description: FELLER-Rabbi Benjamin. On Aug. 29, 2000, age 79 in NYC, N.Y. Child care caseworker, W.W. II veteran. Beloved husband of Rabbi Renee, father of Karen, stepfather of Barbara, Alice and Pamela.

title: No Headline
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE; Two Writers, Plaques for One, So Far
description: When E. E. Cummings returned from Europe in 1923, he moved to quarters at 4 Patchin Place, a tiny court off 10th Avenue near Greenwich Street, where he lived until his death in 1962. The house is adorned with two plaques reminding visitors of the court's most famous resident.

title: Three Discounters Open New Air Routes
description: Three discount airlines are establishing new routes this autumn -- AirTran Airways is adding service to Toledo, Ohio, from its hub in Atlanta; JetBlue Airways is expanding its service between Kennedy International Airport and Florida; and the Las Vegas-based National Airlines will begin flying to Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington.

title: Voters Unhappiness Inhibits Election Turnout in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 11 -- Disillusioned by their leaders and a system that still heavily favors vested interests, Hong Kong residents turned out in far smaller numbers than expected on Sunday to vote in the second legislative election since this former British colony reverted to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: One-Stop Shopping For the Civic- Minded
description: GOTHAM GAZETTE

title: Sept. 3-9; A Gambler Loses
description: Millions of Americans who play slot machines understand that if you keep playing you will eventually lose. The machines are programmed that way. In a case decided in United States Tax Court, the I.R.S. stipulated that William T. Praytor of Fairhope, Ala., was in the ''trade or profession'' of slot machine gambler even though the tax returns that Mr. Praytor and his wife filed bore out the inexorable mathematics of one-armed bandits: Mr. Praytor had won $318,750 from 1994 through 1996 and lost $392,763. But when he tried to deduct his $74,000 in losses plus $23,000 in interest on gambling markers, he lost again. Judge Lewis R. Carluzzo ruled that professional gamblers can deduct losses and gambling expenses only until their winnings reach zero. He ordered the Praytors to pay $25,000. David Cay Johnston

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Catching Heaven

title: Good Coach, Then Bad Coach
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9  Tommy Tuberville left the University of Mississippi without saying goodbye to his football team.

title: Dede Gardner, Jonathan Berg
description: Dorcas Wright Gardner, a vice president of production at Paramount Pictures in Los Angeles, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Jonathan Boris Berg, the owner of Berg-Saccani Entertainment, a film production company in Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Frank M. McClain, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Old Agricultural Hall in West Tisbury, Mass.

title: Martinez Not Enough To Save Sinking Sox
description: Pedro Martinez's fingers are not fat enough to fill the holes in the Fenway Park dike. Not even he can halt the flood that threatens to sweep the Red Sox out of playoff contention.

title: Masur's Mendelssohn, a 'Great Day' and a New Grove
description: September

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DOROTHY
description: GOLDBERG-Dorothy (nee Weinstein). Of Cranford, N.J. beloved wife of the late Lester. Devoted mother of Jean Goldberg, Judith Caseley, Bara Swain and Larry. Loving grandmother of Jessica, Jenna, Benjamin, Michael, John & Emily. Services Sunday, 10 AM, ''Bernheim Apter Goldsticker'', Maplewood, N.J., Sunday, 10AM. For information call ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Role Reversals
description: A BLIND MAN CAN SEE HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU Stories. By Amy Bloom. 163 pp. New York: Random House. $22.95.

title: Dana Jonson, Brett Steen
description: Dana Amy Jonson, the daughter of Anne Stambaugh Satterthwaite of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Kevin Joe Jonson, was married yesterday to Brett Robert Steen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Steen of Roswell, Ga. The Rev. Michael Jude Fay officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John in Darien, Conn.

title: Ideas & Trends; God and Politics: Nothing New Under the American Sun
description: THE polite disagreement over the proper place of religion in politics summons us once again to the works of those ever-useful observers of American life, Alexis de Tocqueville of France and James Bryce of Britain. Both of their classic studies, Tocqueville's ''Democracy in America'' (1835) and Bryce's ''The American Commonwealth'' (1888) attend the matter in a spirit that should elicit an amen from Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who has stirred the issue anew with his avowal that religious faith supports a moral foundation for public policy.

title: Construction at Garden Site Shakes Co-op, Members Say
description: Early on Aug. 24, Joe Richman said, he was asleep in his fifth-floor apartment at 219 East Seventh Street, between Avenues B and C, when he was awakened by rumbling and vibration from construction next door. From his window, he watched a man operating a big tractor with a 70-foot-high pile driver. He went back to bed but was soon awakened again, this time when an 8-by-3-foot section of plaster fell from his ceiling, gashing his forehead, knocking over a lamp and scattering dust and debris.

title: Forward Isbister Warned on Holdout
description: Brad Isbister, the Islanders' lone remaining holdout now that Zdeno Chara has been locked out, has been given the same ultimatum Chara received: accept the team's final offer or sit out the season.

title: Elizabeth Jacks, Kenneth Dow
description: Elizabeth Bond Jacks, the daughter of Elizabeth Jacks Scott of New York and the late Robert Leroy Jacks, was married yesterday to Kenneth James Dow, a son of Laura and Harry Dow of Hanover, N.H. Thomas Dias, a town justice of Ancram, N.Y., officiated at the house of the bride's parents in Livingston, N.Y.

title: A Season For Merce; A Building For Morris
description: GEOFFREY BEENE

title: Making E-Signatures An Investment Reality
description: Now that Congress has passed legislation that allows it, the giants of the mutual fund industry are preparing to let investors buy funds with an electronic signature.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 6 about efforts to achieve Arab unity misstated the date and purpose of the formation of the Arab League. A letter dated Sept. 1 from its Washington representative points out that the treaty establishing the league was signed on March 22, 1945; the date was not 1949 and the purpose was not to organize opposition to the state of Israel, which had not yet been founded. The treaty spoke only of strengthening relations among members in financial, communications, cultural, health, social, nationality and social areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMLE, LEO K.
description: LEMLE-Leo K. On Sep tember 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Trude. Loving father of Laura and Robert. Dear father-in-law of Grant and Roni. Devoted grandfather of Zach, Joanna, Ariel, David and Noah. He will be deeply missed and live in our hearts forever. Service Sunday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SPORTS; Melting Pot With Baselines
description: At 6:30 in the morning, they start arriving one by one or in pairs -- stretching, running in place, limbering up along the dewy chain-link fence, practicing serves and popping sharp volleys back and forth.

title: Q & A/Dr. Sonia Diaz Salcedo; Superintendent Ready for an Uphill Battle
description: WHEN Dr. Sonia Diaz Salcedo took over for the long-time Bridgeport School Superintendent John Connolly on July 1 it was suggested by some that the former superintendent of School District 1 in lower Manhattan was leaving one troubled district for another.

title: Tourists Take Another Look at Riverhead
description: FOR decades, downtown Riverhead more closely resembled a ghost town than a bustling business center. Now, with new attractions and the restoration of some older buildings, people are returning, commerce is reviving and residents are hoping that their town will no longer be one of the most run-down places on Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Aug. 27 listing the lowest air fares for popular routes omitted a flight between New York and Tel Aviv. T.W.A. offers a discount fare of $1,090, and an unrestricted fare of $1,970.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: All the City, and a Stage

title: Palestinian Council Opts to Delay Statehood Declaration
description: GAZA CITY, Sept. 10  Bowing to international pressure, a Palestinian leadership assembly decided tonight, as expected, to postpone a declaration of statehood and recommit to the Mideast peace effort despite deeply deadlocked negotiations.

title: The Improviser's Art In the Realm of Jazz
description: A NEW concert series will offer jazz aficionados something rare in the suburbs: a chance to indulge in the improviser's art in a small, homey and, most importantly, stress-free setting.

title: Sept. 3-9; Fish Weds Bicycle
description: Sometimes, it seems, a fish really does need a bicycle. The feminist Gloria Steinem, 66, and David Bale, 61, a businessman and political activist, were married in Oklahoma. It was the first time for her, the third for him and was a spontaneous decision taken while the two were at a spiritual retreat. ''Honestly, she is as stunned as we all are,'' Suzanne Braun Levine, a former writer for Ms. Magazine, said. Neil MacFarquhar

title: Sept. 3-9; Firestone's Tough Week
description: Even as it confronted lawsuits, Congressional hearings and public anger over its defective tires, Bridgestone/ Firestone got one piece of good news. The Japanese-owned tire maker reached a settlement with the United Steelworkers of America, avoiding a strike by 8,000 workers. Eager to avert a strike during its current crisis, Bridgestone gave most workers raises of at least 15 percent over three years.

title: Virginia Retirement System Bolstered by Private Equity
description: Buoyed by private equity gains, the Virginia Retirement System said it earned 15.4 percent on its investments in the year ended June 30, surpassing both its 12.2 percent return in the previous 12 months and the 10.5 percent return of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, known as Calpers, the nation's largest public pension fund.

title: Why Not Cut Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Sharp Play Like This, Who Needs an Endgame?
description: The crowning event of the 33rd Biel Chess Festival in Switzerland, from July 24 to Aug. 4, was a double-round all-grandmaster invitational tournament with six players. Peter Svidler of Russia took first place with 7 1/2-2 1/2.

title: VIDEOTAPE IN CIVIL COURT
description: In an effort to get civil trials to court more quickly, a State Supreme Court committee issued rules that as of last week restrict more than one trial postponement if an expert witnesses is not available. After that, the expert's testimony may be given on videotape or not at all. Although videotaping has been allowed for 20 years, some lawyers say videotaped evidence lacks the impact of live witnesses. John Holl

title: And the Winners Are . . .
description: Seventeen of the East End's 25 producers participated in this year's New York Wine and Food Classic, the state's major contest devoted only to New York wine, but the outcome belonged to the Finger Lakes region.

title: Terra Incognita
description: False Papers

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MUSEUM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINTZ, NORMAN I.
description: PRINTZ-Norman I. On September 5, 2000. Age 78. Most beloved husband of Irene (Reyburn). Dearest father of Stephen and Zoanne, Michael and Lori, Elizabeth and Steven Freeman. Doting grandfather of Jordan, Eryenne, Jaclyn, David and Aimee. Devoted brother of Leonard. Private burial held on September 8.

title: Patient Coulthard Contends for a Title
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 9  A recent interview with David Coulthard, Scotland's greatest hope for another Formula One driver's title, was interrupted by a visit to the McLaren motor home of Jackie Stewart, Scotland's last world champion.

title: Playing the Fool and Connecting Cultures
description: TO quench his unquenchable thirst for comedy, surrealism and otherworldly experiences, Eliot Osborn of Salisbury got into the business of merry-making in far-flung places. In time he and his wife, Louise Lindenmeyr, began using humor, music and drama to address issues like the AIDS crisis in Africa.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Kings Super Markets Opening First L.I. Store

title: Please Go to the Principal's Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A continuation line in the Dance listing on Page 26 of Arts & Leisure today and the first line of a January entry are overprinted and illegible. The affected entry should begin this way: ''Dance at Japan House. A rare taste of Japanese dance today, both avant-garde and newly revisited traditional.'' The entry continues on Page 37.

title: Small but Bold: Theaters That Dare
description: THE surprises of the new season are likely to be found in the state's small, out of the way theaters, or in performance centers where a play is a sometime thing.

title: YONKERS: N.A.A.C.P. SCHEDULES RALLY
description: The Yonkers branch of the N.A.A.C.P. will hold a demonstration in front of Yonkers City Hall on Thursday at 6:30 p.m. to protest inadequate busing, overcrowded classrooms, failing students and vestiges of segregation, said Julie Weiner, a spokeswoman for the organization. ''Increasingly, many parents are leaving the public school system,'' Ms. Weiner said. Educators, politicians and parents are scheduled to speak during the rally. Elsa Brenner

title: Sailors Can Opt To Dock And Click
description: In the last Around Alone solo round-the-world race, the winning skipper, Italy's Giovanni Soldini, showed his prowess not only at the helm but also on his laptop computer. Soldini spent hours poring over his favorite Internet weather Web sites, and his ability to predict favorable systems and trends proved to be a significant advantage.

title: Those Raises, Adjusted for Oil Inflation, Are a Mirage
description: HARDLY any description of the booming economy fails to include this upbeat observation: Wages have been rising faster than inflation for most workers since January 1996. The boom has lifted all boats, and that is its great social gift.

title: New Jersey Symphony Looks Back and Ahead
description: THE 20th century has passed into history. From now on, its musical works -- serialism, minimalism, warts and all -- will have to be excavated or exhumed, unless their beauty and worth float them to the surface. Picking his way through the rubble, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's music director, Zdenek Macal, has pulled up a season of nuggets and curiosities, combined with far-off 19th-century repertory of solid gold.

title: Q. and A.
description: Quest for the Grail

title: Habitats/Westchester; From a Barnard Dorm To a Tudor in the Suburbs
description: JONATHAN KELLY and Janice Gates Kelly had never paid a mortgage, let alone rent. Nor had they ever ripped open a telephone bill, cable bill or electric bill. For those who dream of college life going on forever, they had it down: living in a dorm, all the services they needed, and an army of potential friends.

title: The Problem Is, Allan Has Solutions
description: SOME people have lots of ideas. Writers think of stories. Mathematicians come up with proofs. Financial planners find practical solutions for life's basic problems -- like making sure you don't have to eat cat food in retirement.

title: Hewlett-Packard May Seek Deal For Consultants
description: Hewlett is in negotiations to acquire the consulting unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers for as much as $20 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: IN THE WORKSHOP WITH/Ker Berdimurat-Beckley; Helping Children in Need Talk It Out in Pictures
description: VISUAL art has long been considered to be a window to the artist's soul. Art therapists use the pictures that their clients create to open a dialogue, hoping to clarify the root of their pain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORCH, CLAIRE
description: LORCH-Claire. On Septe mber 9, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Lorch, cherished mother of Gloria Nimetz, Leonard Lorch and Evelyn Sabin. Treasured grandmother of Alexandra Nimetz, Lloyd Nimetz, Jennifer Sabin and Michael Sabin. Loving sister of Al Weil. Funeral arrangements to be announced.

title: Liquid Soul in Hoboken
description: Liquid Soul is a brass-driven, acid-jazz band from Chicago, whose funky live performances are electrically charged. Their inventive melodies snake around a wide assortment of free-flowing loops, rhythms and beats.

title: Hasek Plays Waiting Game on Retirement
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 9  Dominik Hasek is not prepared to make the same mistake he made last year regarding his retirement.

title: MP3-Ring Circus
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: SPECIAL TODAY -- SYDNEY 2000
description: At the Summer Olympics in Australia, Marion Jones is trying to do what no other woman has done: win five gold medals in track and field. But when the Games start on Friday, the spotlight will not fall solely on Jones. Australian athletes will be carrying the expectations of a sports-crazy populace, and little-known competitors will be catapulted into Olympic stardom. Today's special report looks at each Olympic sport. SECTION F

title: Sports of The Times; Degrees of Separation For Coach and Indiana
description: ZERO tolerance, after nearly 29 years of maximum tolerance at Indiana University, may not have much wiggle room. And after an incident last May -- one of scores involving Bob Knight over the years -- the president of the university, Myles Brand, said that Knight deserved a ''last chance.'' If he does anything that is deemed embarrassing to the school, Brand said, he will be dismissed.

title: Leiter Keeps His Focus And Gains The Victory
description: When Al Leiter faces one of baseball's best pitchers, he knows his team will have few chances to score. So Leiter, the Mets' energetic left-hander, consciously tries to rein himself in and pay attention to everything. He knows there is no room for error.

title: Uneasy Leaders Whose Downfall Lay Within Themselves
description: If anyone could elevate petulance to the status of tragic flaw, Ralph Fiennes would seem to be the man. Throughout his fertile career in movies as the bluestocking's heartthrob, he has consistently found the combustibility in being sullen, taciturn and socially ill at ease. Think of those unhappy adulterers he played in ''The English Patient'' and ''The End of the Affair,'' in which he struck erotic sparks just by peevishly knitting his brow.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Pesky Themes Will Emerge When You're Not Looking
description: I've been going around doing readings from a new novel (''Le Mariage''), and often, on these occasions, I've been asked surprising questions about its themes. At first I was somewhat confounded by this. The novelist may be the last to know the theme of her work, may even have avoided thinking about it too particularly, lest, like happiness, it disappear on too close examination or seem too thin and flimsy to live.

title: Regulators Accuse Entertainment Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Producers of movies, video games and music aggressively try to attract children and teen-agers to entertainment that contains violent themes, federal regulators said today.

title: Lagos Journal; Nigeria Echoes to the Beat That Defied Tyrants
description: Downstairs, the dancer in the tight orange tank top and white pants, her naked navel in between, lay languidly on a couch. The man slumped beside her snored gently. The others passed around joints that filled the room with the strong whiff of marijuana.

title: In America; Persecuting One of Their Own
description: Sidney Quick is an inmate at the Wallkill Correctional Facility in upstate New York.

title: ASSEMBLY IN GAZA DEFERS DECLARING PALESTINIAN STATE
description: Bowing to international pressure, a Palestinian leadership assembly decided tonight, as expected, to postpone a declaration of statehood and recommit to the Middle East peace effort despite deeply deadlocked negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 31 about aides to President Richard M. Nixon who expressed skepticism about assertions in a new book that the president took the antiseizure drug Dilantin misstated the tenure of one aide, John H. Taylor. Mr. Taylor, now director of the Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif., worked for President Nixon from 1979 until the former president's death in 1994. Their association did not begin in the mid-1980's.

title: Modern Pentathlon
description: THIS SPORT, which goes back to 600 B.C., tests five skills of a 19th century military courier. To make room for women to compete in the Olympic pentathlon for the first time, the fields were reduced, and all 24 men and 24 women had to qualify.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, GERALDINE M.
description: RUBENSTEIN-Geraldine M. Beloved wife of Leonard. Devoted mother of Alan, Elaine, Philip, Ruth and Jennie. Loving daughter of Sally Porper. Dear sister of Rebecca Porper. Adored grandmother of seven. Service Monday, 2:30 PM, Plaza Memorial, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: ROCKLAND COUNTY

title: Avoid the Lines. Vote Now!
description: Dear Voter:

title: Cycling
description: THIS WAS to have been the perfect Hollywood ending for the coming movie on the improbable life of Lance Armstrong. Brash young Texan rides his bike to the world road-racing championship; then miraculously survives testicular cancer that had spread to his abdomen, lungs and brain; then makes an amazing comeback and wins the Tour de France last year and again this year; then wins a gold medal in Sydney.

title: Table Tennis
description: IN MANDARIN Chinese, the term for table tennis translates to ''national ball,'' and the last Olympic tournament in Atlanta did indeed bear a strong resemblance to a domestic competition as the Chinese swept all four events: men's singles and doubles, and women's singles and doubles. More domination is hardly out of the question in Sydney.

title: Boxing
description: RIVALRIES make for good sport, and in boxing there is a last remnant of an old fashioned Cold War-like battle of wills. The Cuban national boxing team, still shrouded in mystery because of the secrecy surrounding its training, is feared and respected. But this year's American team could be the strongest since the charismatic crew led by Sugar Ray Leonard in Montreal 24 years ago. The Americans have three reigning world champions, the Cubans have Felix Savon, the six-time world titlist, and two other world champions. The clash of these two powerful, experienced teams will highlight the competition at Sydney's Exhibition Center, but in boxing there are always surprises and enigmatic judging decisions -- enough twists and turns for a Tom Clancy novel.

title: Wrestling
description: CONTROVERSY surrounded selection of the United States Greco-Roman wrestling team when welterweight Matt Lindland protested the third match of his 2-1 loss to Keith Sieracki in the 167.5-pound class at July's Olympic trials.

title: 'West Wing' Dominates Television's Big Night; NBC Drama Carries Off 5 Emmy Awards As Newer Shows Find Their Niche
description: It was the First Family versus the Soprano family at the annual Emmy presentation tonight. And the First Family -- or NBC's ''West Wing'' -- almost bludgeoned HBO's ''Sopranos.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: OPEC Agrees to Increase Production of Oil by 3%

title: 2000 SYDNEY GAMES/Gymnastics; A Daunting Task, A Mystical Coach
description: Normally, the effusive Bela Karolyi rambles on in glorious hyperbole but in such a thick Transylvanian accent, a toy decoder ring is required to untangle his words. But after watching Shannon Miller's comeback at the United States Olympic Trials last month end with an inglorious fall, and seeing three other top gymnasts take spills on the balance beam in Boston, Karolyi was short on words.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
