description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, ELISABETH R.
description: WOODS-Elisabeth R. Beloved wife of James A. Woods for 44 years. Mother of James A. Woods Jr., of Alexandria, VA, Robert L. Woods of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, Elisabeth W. Leonard of North Palm Beach, FL, and William R. Woods, of Huntington Bay, NY. Grandmother of seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 12, at 11:30 AM, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to St. John's Church, PO Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

title: Article 2000091190259794498 -- No Title
description: E-COMMERCE REPORT

title: White House Enters Senate Race With Release of Photo of Lazio and Arafat
description: Stepping squarely into the New York race for Senate, the White House this weekend released an official photograph showing Rick A. Lazio, the Republican opponent to Hillary Rodham Clinton, enthusiastically shaking the hand of Yasir Arafat during an official visit to the Middle East nearly two years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 1 about the role played by Congressional candidates at the Republican National Convention, and a chart listing their speeches, misspelled the surname of the Republican who is challenging Representative James Maloney in Connecticut. The name was also misspelled in a picture caption on March 4 about the campaign for the House. The challenger is Mark Nielsen, not Nielson. The errors were discovered last week during research for another article about House races.

title: In Defense, Small but Dedicated Team
description: There have been few light moments during the battling in the case of the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee, but in one climactic showdown last month a slight crinkle brightened the normally stolid visage of John Cline, one of the defense lawyers, as the government fought Dr. Lee's release on bail. A prosecutor was insisting that if Dr. Lee were placed in home detention, as the judge had proposed, every arriving package ought to be inspected, including flowers.

title: Article 2000091192763237503 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Robert E. Dewar, 77, Who Led Kmart in 70's Expansion, Dies
description: Robert E. Dewar, the former chairman and chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, who led the company's huge expansion of retail stores nationwide, died at his home on Thursday. He was 77 and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Basketball
description: FORTY AND 0. Since the United States was first represented by National Basketball Association players in 1992, Olympic men's basketball has been a coronation rather than a competition.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration in Science Times on Aug. 29 with an article about space swirling around a neutron star carried an incomplete credit. It was based on an illustration by Joe Bergeron for Sky & Telescope.

title: Field Hockey
description: THE GAME is ''hockey'' to aficionados, who defensively insist on calling the version played on skates with a puck ''ice hockey.'' But the aficionados should feel appreciated at these Olympics, where field hockey will be more visible than ever because of Australia's affection for and proficiency at this hard-running, low-scoring game.

title: Coca-Cola Signs Deal On Programming TV's
description: Coca-Cola, the world's largest soft-drink company, has signed a two-year strategic partnership agreement with Replay TV in Mountain View, Calif., which sells a service and digital video recorder that allows consumers to pause, replay, rewind and fast-forward through live television programming. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Father's Footsteps Echo Throughout a Son's Career
description: As the thrill of his father's election to the presidency in 1988 began to fade a bit, George W. Bush began to wonder what it would mean for him.

title: Swimming
description: THE AMERICAN and Australian teams -- with its stars Ian Thorpe, Susie O'Neill and Kieren Perkins -- will battle for the unofficial team title for most gold medals, although there are no engaging head-to-head matchups looming. Both countries are strongest in events where the other is weakest.

title: When Diplomats Flee to Dot-Coms
description: To the Editor:

title: Documents Portray Tire Debacle As a Story of Lost Opportunities
description: More than four years before Firestone gave the Ford Motor Company or federal regulators any hint of a problem with its tires for sport utility vehicles, the company's engineers had been alerted by the State of Arizona that the tires' treads tended to separate in hot weather.

title: Track and Field
description: POPULAR IN Europe but largely off the American radar screen between Olympic years, track and field continues to be the flagship sport of the Games. This year there is added spice as Marion Jones attempts to become the first woman in track and field to win five gold medals in one Olympics. Cold, windy weather may prevent any world records.

title: Reverberating Handshake
description: The White House stepped into Hillary Clinton's Senate race, releasing a photograph of Rick A. Lazio shaking Yasir Arafat's hand. Page B1.

title: Unfriendly Skies: What to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugs, an Olympic Event
description: Recently I was asked if anything about doping in sports has changed since the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. My initial instinct was to say no, since there will still be drugs at the Olympics this year. But something has changed: The public has learned even more about this epidemic, including the recent revelations about doping programs of the Chinese and the East Germans, as well as drug use by Tour de France participants.

title: RANGERS SWING INTO ACTION
description: The highlight of the Rangers' second day of training camp in Burlington, Vt., was two heavyweight bouts featuring Dale Purinton and Sandy McCarthy.

title: Article 2000091190397373642 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: Sports of The Times; A Drama in Three Sets: The Passing of the Torch
description: THESE things are never easy, the passing of a torch from aging champion to rising star. And make no mistake, that's exactly what this was, the ceremonial anointing of a 20-year-old Russian named Marat Safin, following the kind of hard-court pounding Pete Sampras hasn't taken even in his most fitful night of sleep.

title: Rebels Without a Childhood in Sri Lanka War
description: Renuka, a 13-year-old wisp of a girl, said she is afraid she will be scolded because she chose not to swallow her cyanide capsule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, CAROL S.
description: HABER-Carol S. Of Manhattan, NY, died on September 9, 2000. She was a social worker dedicated to helping adolescents and their families. Ms. Haber was a director at a children's service agency, Youth Consultation Services. Previously, she had been the director of mental health services for children and adolescents at St. Clare's Hospital. An adjunct faculty member at Iona College, Carol was a mentor and friend to all. She is survived by her sister, Meryl Schwartz, brother-in-law Sidney, nieces Dana and Ronnie, grandnieces Casey and Sydney, grandnephews Joshua and Noah, and many friends. Memorial contributions can be sent to Ronald McDonald House, 405 East 73rd St., NYC 10021.

title: Police Say Gang Offered Buffet of Guns and Drugs
description: Seven people were being held yesterday on drug and weapons charges after police raids in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that resulted from an undercover investigation into one of the few surviving factions of the Latin Kings gang, the authorities said.

title: A Day of Terror, Not Brotherhood, at the Olympics
description: The world became both smaller and bleaker on Sept. 5, 1972. That day an international television audience watched a real-life drama unfold in real time, as a group of Palestinian terrorists murdered two Israeli Olympians at the Summer Games in Munich, holding nine more as hostages. Those old enough will surely remember that the episode ended more horribly than it began. After a chaotic gunfight at a German air base, all the Israelis, five of their eight captors and a German police officer were dead.

title: The Price of Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Equestrian
description: ONCE, THESE were tests for military men on horseback. Now, the riders are usually civilians and often women, and age is no barrier. The four riders on the American jumping team are women, ages 42, 40, 34 and 23. The United States eventing team includes David and Karen O'Connor, husband and wife from The Plains, Va., who won team silver medals in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORCH, CLAIRE
description: LORCH-Claire, on September 9, 2000, at her home. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Lorch, devoted mother of Gloria Nimetz, Leonard Lorch and Evelyn Sabin, loving grandmother of Alexandra Nimetz, Lloyd Nimetz, Jennifer Sabin and Michael Sabin, cherished mother-in-law of Matthew Nimetz and Jeffrey Sabin, adored sister of Al Weil. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 13, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Israel, 140 Central Ave., Lawrence, LI. Contributions may be made to: Selfhelp Community Services Inc., 440 Ninth Ave., NY, NY 10001.

title: The Town That Prosperity Forgot; Blighted, Broke and Crime-Ridden, Irvington Seems Helpless to Help Itself
description: Like many of those who live in this fraying suburb of Newark, Margaret Jackson moved her family here two decades ago to escape the lawlessness, decay and despair then spreading through the city that nearly surrounds it. With its no-nonsense police force and racially mixed neighborhoods, Irvington beckoned middle-class Newark residents with the promise of safe, suburban-style living.

title: Yanks Complete Sweep As Rookie Wins Debut
description: Randy Keisler's major league debut lasted five innings today, long enough to qualify for his first victory, too short to satisfy youth's ambition. Told before the sixth inning that he was finished for the day, Keisler sat next to the bench coach Don Zimmer and asked, in a roundabout way, why he had been taken out so soon.

title: The Price of Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana's President Fires Coach Knight, Citing Bad Behavior
description: Bob Knight's storied career as basketball coach at Indiana University ended abruptly yesterday when the university president, Myles Brand, dismissed him for demonstrating a pattern of ''uncivil, defiant and unacceptable'' behavior since May that culminated with a student's allegation that Mr. Knight had physically and verbally assaulted him last week.

title: Sales Rise at Small Bookstores. But Why?
description: For years, the American Booksellers Association has filed lawsuits asserting that large bookstore chains are driving independent stores out of business. Now, shifting tactics, the association is trumpeting what it says is a comeback at some independents.

title: Addenda
description: Coca Signs Deal on Programming TV's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, HERBERT
description: WASSERMAN-Herbert. The Partners of CA Associates extend their sincerest condolences to Cece and her family on the untimely passing of our partner, Herb Wasserman.

title: The Unraveling of a Career
description: Myles Brand, right, the president of Indiana University, said Coach Bob Knight's behavior over the last 17 weeks was "uncivil, defiant and unacceptable." According to Brand, there were several instances that violated "the letter and spirit of the guidelines set out on May 15," when the university instituted a "zero tolerance policy" for Knight's behavior:

title: Woods Goes For Broke And Makes It
description: The situation called for something spectacular, which meant the situation was perfect for Tiger Woods.

title: The Fight for a Sound Education
description: Nearly 50 years have passed since the Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that the practice of confining black students to inferior, racially segregated schools violated the Constitution and barred African-Americans from full participation in civic and professional life. But some of the same inequalities cited in Brown are still evident as 50 million children return to the public schools this month, many of them to failing schools that fall far short of new academic standards being adopted in just about every state.

title: More Egyptian Mummies Keep Telling Their Secrets
description: After a year of further excavations at the Valley of the Golden Mummies, Egyptian archaeologists have opened seven more tombs and found 102 more mummies, including members of elite and middle-class families and a woman with a wooden tablet at her feet that depicts a scene of what appears to be her resurrection.

title: Article 2000091190220406247 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Four Years of Police Work Yielded a Racketeering Indictment of 38
description: For nearly four years, detectives using 38 laptop computers tracked thousands of telephone calls between reputed mob figures, the union officials they are accused of bribing and contractors charged with helping them siphon millions of dollars from construction projects around New York City.

title: Intuit Plans Small-Business Marketplace
description: Intuit, a supplier of tax and business management software, plans to announce today that it is starting an electronic marketplace for the small-business owners who use Intuit's QuickBooks software. The marketplace would offer special deals on computers and office supplies and make it easier to for users to do business online with other small companies that use the software.

title: Tennis
description: FOR SOME reason, patriotism didn't motivate some of the top men to rearrange their schedules and accommodate a trip to Sydney.

title: $120 Million Stock Deal for Drug Company
description: Human Genome Sciences, a company that is developing drugs based on discovery of genes, said yesterday that it had acquired privately held Principia Pharmaceutical for about $120 million in stock. Principia, based in Norristown, Pa., is developing a technology that could enhance the effectiveness of human proteins used as drugs.

title: Low-Price, Highly Ambitious Digital Chip
description: Suddenly, the future of digital photography seems to be becoming much clearer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, EUGENE B.
description: DIAMOND-Eugene B. New York University's Stern School of Business mourns the passing of a member of the Commerce Class of 1941, Eugene B. Diamond at age 79 on September 7, 2000, in Media, Pennsylvania. A loyal and supportive alumni, we remember his entrepreneurial spirit and generosity to the Undergraduate College. We send our sincere sympathies to his family.

title: Hewlett-Packard May Seek Deal For Consultants
description: Hewlett-Packard is in negotiations to acquire the consulting unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers for as much as $20 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, SAUL, MD.
description: JARCHO-Saul, MD. On September 10, 2000. Survived by his wife, Irma S., his sons, Tom and Andrew, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Also survived by his sister, Grace J. Ross and many nephews and nieces. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 79 PM. Funeral service on Wednesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Academy of Medicine, 1216 5th Ave., NYC 10029 or the National Library of Medicine, 8600 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD.

title: Taekwondo
description: THIS SPORT originated as a self-defense art in Korea, where its name means ''the way of foot and fist.''

title: Tips on Love (With Oohs And Ahs)
description: Desire and self-control battled it out in the songs Christina Aguilera performed at the Jones Beach Theater on Friday night. ''Hormones racing at the speed of light,'' she sang in ''Genie in a Bottle,'' her opening song, ''but that don't mean it's gotta be tonight.'' She strutted across the stage, promising love and pumping her hips, giving lessons in sexual brinkmanship to her audience of squealing young girls.

title: In Aisle 3, Meet-and-Greet With Belgian Royals
description: It was just another ho-hum supermarket promotion until the royals arrived in the cheese aisle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABAO, MARY C.
description: DABAO-Mary C. The partners and staff of 524 Broadway Co. LP extend heartfelt condolences to our esteemed colleague, Sony Dabao Salvador and to the members of her family upon the passing of her dear mother, Mary C. Dabao. May her memory leave a legacy of blessings. M.J. Propp, Partner

title: Bipartisan Role in Debate Fight for Veteran G.O.P. Leader
description: NOBODY looking over the paraphernalia that fills Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr.'s office would ever question his political loyalties. The place is stocked with mementos from his time as chairman of the Republican National Committee during the presidency of Ronald Reagan. There are photos of Mr. Fahrenkopf with Mr. Reagan aboard Air Force One, outside the Oval Office and at the lectern of the Republican National Convention. There is nary a Democrat in sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, LOUISE C.
description: CONNELL-Louise C., age 94. Died at home in New York City on September 9, 2000. Wife of the late Raymond M. Ohmer and the late James R. Connell. Beloved mother of Carol Collins, Louise Mills, Katherine Sincerbeaux and the late Raymond Ohmer. Grandmother of Carol Malone, Bradley Collins, Lee Collins, James Collins, Carolyn McHugh, James Mills, Jennifer Mills and Carolyn Sincerbeaux. She is also survived by seven great-grandchildren. Funeral service on Wednesday, September 13, at 11 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave. Please omit flowers.

title: Coral Gables Journal; Uproar on Rules for Civic Decorum
description: The well-to-do city of Coral Gables, where even the hue of house paint must be approved by the city, has always been a place of rules. Roxcy Bolton, 74, believes in rules, mostly.

title: Israeli Jews To Outnumber Those in U.S.
description: Jews in Israel will outnumber Jews in the United States in two decades, part of a shift in Jewish population by which Israel will become home to a majority of the world's Jews by 2050, says a study in the new edition of the ''American Jewish Year Book.''

title: Helping the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulators Accuse Entertainment Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Producers of movies, video games and music aggressively try to attract children and teen-agers to entertainment that contains violent themes, federal regulators said today.

title: Creators and Copyright
description: To the Editor:

title: Handball
description: LONG AFTER the Canadian James Naismith dreamed up a winter-time diversion called basketball, the Europeans went to work codifying another winter-time diversion. Initially an 11-on-11 outdoor game like soccer, team handball was first played at the Olympics in 1936 in Berlin at the Germans' request.

title: Calendar
description: MONDAY

title: Why Do Boys Kill?
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Agrees to Increase Oil Production by 3 Percent
description: Faced with growing international pressure to drive down stubbornly high oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to increase its crude production by 800,000 barrels a day, spokesmen for the group and delegates said.

title: Fencing
description: FENCING ENDURES: it is only one of four sports to have been competed in each modern Summer Olympics dating to 1896. More popular in Europe than in the United States, fencing is ancient combat fought behind wire-mesh masks and bulletproof vests.

title: Growth of Texas Cities Pushes the Dead Aside
description: Twenty-five years ago, anyone in the market for a tomb with a view would have been hard pressed to top Williamson Creek Cemetery, perched on a shady hill in a grove of cedar trees, looking out over a peaceful valley of rolling pasture just south of town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULZ, LANGDON W.
description: SCHULZ-Langdon W. September 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Mildred. Former Senior Vice President of Finance at Otis Elevator Company. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, September 11, 2000, 7-9PM. Service, Tuesday, September 12, 2000, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Shooting
description: THIS HAS always been a strong Olympic sport for the United States, which has won 69 individual medals, 30 gold. The Americans are solid again with shotguns (skeet and trap), where for the first time men and women have separate competitions. When women competed against men, they sometimes won.

title: Credit Suisse Assigns Executives
description: Ten days after Credit Suisse First Boston's parent company agreed to buy Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the securities firm has picked co-heads of banking, mergers and other departments by taking one chief from each firm.

title: At Last, Joness Golden Moment Is Here
description: As Marion Jones tells the story, she was an 8-year-old in Southern California when the Olympics first entered her head like a song that would not leave. Her family drove to see the Olympic torch as the relay made its way to the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles. At home that same night, she went into her room and wrote ``I want to be an Olympic champion'' on a chalkboard.

title: Badminton
description: MAJOR IN Asia, minor throughout most of Europe and virtually invisible in the United States, badminton is a fast-twitch indoor feast of lunging gets and leaping smashes that bears only a vague resemblance to the dilettante's diversion.

title: Gore Takes Tough Stand on Violent Entertainment
description: Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, said today that if the entertainment industry did not stop marketing violent films, recordings and video games to children they would propose legislation or new regulatory authority allowing the federal government to sanction the industry.

title: Schwann Is Revamping Its Recording Catalogs
description: The Schwann catalog, for more than 50 years the primary consumer listing of classical, jazz and pop recordings, is replacing its quarterly Opus (classical) and Spectrum (pop) catalogs with annual issues, supplemented by both a constantly updated Web site and a monthly magazine, Schwann Inside.

title: Chrebet Sheds the Wrap And Puts on a Uniform
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept 11  Wayne Chrebet walked on to the field at Giants Stadium about two hours before kickoff tonight in shorts and a T-shirt, a big white wrap from the middle of his left calf down. Chrebet moved well while catching warm-up passes and, while he appeared to walk somewhat gingerly, there was no pronounced limp. Chrebet, who had been listed as questionable for the game with a "lower leg injury" to his left leg, played, although the location and extent of the injury was not clarified before the game. The wrap was gone by kickoff.

title: Judo
description: LIKE ITS fellow Olympic sports of wrestling and taekwondo, judo is one of the variations of hand-to-hand combat. It limits mayhem, with no punching or kicking. Japan, which won 8 of the 16 gold medals in the last world championships, should dominate.

title: Canoe-Kayak
description: THIS SPORT involves men and women in two distinct disciplines: sprint (flat-

title: MERTO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Italians Defeat Polish Team To Take World Championship
description: The final of the World Team Championships which ended on Saturday in Maastricht, the Netherlands, was one of the most exciting in the history of the game. The Italians seemed to be heading for a comfortable victory, but their Polish opponents fought back and were leading by 10 imps with seven deals remaining. A final surge gave a victory by 20 to the Italians: Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace.

title: A Big Week for the MetroStars
description: This is a crucial week for the MetroStars. Before they play host to the Dallas Burn in the first round of the playoffs on Friday night at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., the MetroStars will meet the Miami Fusion in the semifinals of the United States Open Cup tonight at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y. A victory would put the MetroStars in the final against the Chicago Fire, giving the MetroStars a chance to win the American double -- the Open Cup and the M.L.S. Cup.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with the At the Movies column misspelled the given name of the actor starring in the French film ''Pola X,'' which opened at the Angelika Film Center. As noted in the article, he is Guillaume Depardieu, not Guillame.

title: Baseball
description: WHEN OLYMPIC officials determined that professionals would be allowed to play baseball at the Sydney Games, there was talk of an American dream team, with visions of Ken Griffey Jr. and Mark McGwire swinging away. Wrong. September is for pennant races stateside.

title: Big Feet, Bigger Splash for Australian
description: In a country where swimming is the most popular Olympic sport, where important meets draw prime-time television exposure and exorbitant ratings, it is a 17-year-old named Ian Thorpe who has Australia entranced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, JACK
description: IMBERMAN-Jack. Of Kew Gardens, NY, on September 8. World War II veteran. ''Unc'' will be deeply missed by the Landou and Imberman families. Services will be held at Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ, on Monday, September 11, at 1:30. For information ''Wein & Wein,'' 800322-0533.

title: Brodeurs Load May Be Lightened
description: The Devils are contemplating a reduction in the number of games played by Martin Brodeur, their premier goaltender.

title: Soccer
description: ONE OF the grand and sometimes hoary traditions of soccer is that every tournament no matter how big or small, must have a Group of Death. That is to say, one bracket is inevitably stronger than the others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, JOHN J.
description: CASHIN-John J., on September 9, 2000. Retired Battalion Chief, FDNY. Devoted husband of Marie (nee Phillips). Beloved father of Sr. Mary Ann Cashin, CSJ, Thomas and wife Sharon, John and wife Leslie, Brian and wife Kathleen, Delia Christgau, Terence and wife Maureen, James and wife Gerianne. Loving grandfather of 21 and great-grandfather of two. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Thomas More, Breezy Point. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Sisters of St. Joseph, Brentwood, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZER, HYMAN HARRY
description: GLAZER-Hyman Harry. Gently passed away in Delray Beach, FL. Loyal husband to Ida, proud father of Drs. Ilsa & Miriyam Glazer, Alyne Bat Haim & Phyllis Glazer, dear Zaydie to six, loving brother of Minnie Krassner. Owner of S&H Glazer Bros., Brooklyn. In our hearts, lives and stories always. Service Wednesday, September 13, 12:30 PM, Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. Shiva through Friday at the home of Ilsa in Rockaway Beach.

title: Diving
description: ONCE A BODY OF water controlled by high-flying Americans, the Olympic diving tank has belonged to the Chinese since Greg Louganis made the perfect exit in 1988 after so many perfect entries. Since then, the only American to win a gold medal has been Mark Lenzi, in 1992 on the springboard. In 1996, the Americans could muster only two bronze medals; Sydney should not change their or the Chinese's luck.

title: AOL-Time Warner Rivals Preparing for Interactive TV Fight
description: After a decade of false starts, interactive television may be heading into tens of millions of living rooms in the United States over the next two years. But even before most people have the chance to click their remotes to check a sports score or order a pizza, an industry battle is brewing over who will lay claim to the tens of billions of dollars in new revenue that interactive advertising is expected to yield.

title: Spirent Buys Zarak to Help Web Strategy
description: Spirent, the maker of high-speed telecommunications testing equipment, has agreed to buy Zarak Systems of California for $403 million in stock to expand into transmission of human voice over the World Wide Web.

title: Water Polo
description: THIS IN-THE-water member of the soccer/hockey/basketball family can be ultra physical. It certainly was in 1956 in Melbourne, the last time the Olympics were held in Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDSTON, DR. ROBERT
description: REDSTON-Dr. Robert. September 9, 2000. Age 82. Revered physician. Beloved husband to Leona for 57 years. Loving father to Terry Cohen and Audrey Iselin. Caring father-in-law to Norman Cohen and David Iselin. Doting grandfather to Abby, Noah, Josh, Alex, Leora, Mali and Ilan. His memory will be for a blessing.

title: Rhythm Rules the Roost In an Odd Sort of Way
description: Sometimes jazz groups have their own messy, expansive personalities, bigger than the compositions they're playing. This was the case with Donny McCaslin's quartet, which played at Smalls on Tuesday night. Its musicians can do many things, but they elected to construct a thick mesh of music that negotiated around jazz and funk and rock.

title: At Long Last, Her Golden Moment
description: AS MARION JONES TELLS the story, she was an 8-year-old in Southern California when the Olympics first entered her head like a song that would not leave. Her family drove to see the Olympic torch as the relay made its way to the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles. Back at home that same night, she went into her room and wrote ''I want to be an Olympic champion'' on a chalkboard.

title: An Executive With Synergistic Vision
description: On Thursday night at the MTV Music Video awards. Down on the stage of Radio City Music Hall a rap artist hip-hopped around with the back of his pants worn at thigh level, revealing his gray undies in all their glory. One band performed accompanied by dozens of gyrating midgets. A host exposed his naked rear end on camera.

title: Standards Are Set Up On Sharpness of HDTV
description: After 10 months of debate, shifting alliances and back-door lobbying, the nation's major television manufacturers have finally agreed on a series of revised definitions for digital television sets.

title: Springer & Jacoby Sells A Stake to True North
description: In another big change involving agencies working for DaimlerChrysler A. G., Springer & Jacoby in Hamburg, the agency for Mercedes-Benz in Germany, has agreed to sell a minority interest to True North Communications in Chicago, which learned last week that its DaimlerChrysler Group accounts, including the Chrysler and Jeep brands, would be placed in review. Terms of the agreement, to be announced today, were not disclosed.

title: Article 2000091193237002357 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Rowing
description: THIS HAS BEEN a big Olympic sport for the United States, especially in the men's eight-oared competition. This time, the United States is the only nation to have qualified in all 14 events (six for women), and it ranks behind Germany and Romania among the team favorites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVENTOFF, HYMAN
description: EVENTOFF-Hyman. Survived by two daughters, Doreen Hurwitz and Barbara Gardner, four grandchildren, Amy Weisman, Shari Sollender, Gary Young and Jodi Young, three great-grandchildren, Jared, Julia, Paige, brother Al Eventoff, sister Rose Hellman and cherished companion Beverly Kahn and her loving family. He enjoyed life to the fullest. We will all miss him and always love him. Funeral services today at 1 PM at Menorah Chapel at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ. (908) 964-1500.

title: Silicon Alley Hopes an Event for Democrats Will Raise Its Profile
description: For New York's technology community, eager to extract itself from Silicon Valley's shadow, Friday's fund-raiser for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee at a penthouse loft in NoHo was a heady taste of power. Especially because Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, brought her husband.

title: Shot Put Champion Withdraws From Olympics
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 11 -- C.J. Hunter, the reigning world champion in the shot put and the husband of sprinter Marion Jones, became the latest in a growing number of athletes to withdraw from the Sydney Olympics today, a week after undergoing orthoscopic surgery on torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: Spotlight on Sydney
description: NBC is obsessed with making Sydney an essential character in its coverage of these Olympics in a way that Barcelona, Spain, and Atlanta never were in 1992 and 1996. The attempts to make the city a star -- from elaborate features to a tower-mounted camera focused on the Olympic caldron with downtown Sydney in the background -- began in April 1995 when NBC, ABC, Fox and CBS officials first visited the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Monday about a culture boom in the warehouse district of New Orleans misstated a previous title of J. Richard Gruber, director of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art, and referred incorrectly to his former museum. Mr. Gruber was founding director of the Center for the Study of Southern Painting at the Morris Museum of Art, not founding director of the Morris Museum of Southern Art.

title: Disillusioned, Many Hong Kong Voters Shun Elections
description: Disillusioned by their leaders and a system that still heavily favors vested interests, Hong Kong residents turned out in smaller numbers than expected on Sunday to vote in the second legislative election since this former British colony reverted to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: Treasury Schedules Regular Auction Of Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Gymnastics
description: THERE IS a different look to these Olympics. The compulsories have been eliminated, and the so-called 6-5-4 rule (six gymnasts are on a team, five compete on each apparatus and the four highest scores count) means event specialists are much more important.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDMAN-Sylvia. Died September 9 at age 96 in Boca Raton, FL. Devoted and loving wife of the late Sol. Cherished mother of Florence Katz (Sidney) and Myron Goldman (Carol). Adoring grandmother of Steven Zinaman (Nan), Dr. Michael Zinaman, Dr. Robert Goldman (Gail), Pamela Goldman and William Goldman (Sherri). Proud great-grandmother of Jamie, Kimberly, Rachel, Owen, Benjamin, Cynthia and Samantha. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends to whom she was devoted throughout her life. Funeral services to be held on Tuesday, September 12, 1 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., NY.

title: When the Judge Can't Really Judge
description: Are today's technology issues too complex for the typical judge to judge?

title: U.S. Basketball Team Villains Down Under
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- It was a good scrum, a spirited encounter between an Australian basketball legend and perhaps the most breathtaking player in the world. Andrew Gaze versus Vince Carter, for everything in the national-pride kitty.

title: Barber Gives Giants a Real Offense
description: In the minutes before an offensive explosion by the Giants against Philadelphia that might have made even the St. Louis Rams wink with appreciation, running back Tiki Barber, while being tackled, had his head slammed into the turf. It was not your normal football tackle, but something much more vicious. The fans at Veterans Stadium were quiet because they could sniff the offensive storm that was coming, so when Barber's head hit, the vibrations reverberated high in the stands, a cracking sound that resembled a car wreck, and Barber lay motionless on the ground.

title: At Last, Joness Golden Moment Is Here
description: As Marion Jones tells the story, she was an 8-year-old in Southern California when the Olympics first entered her head like a song that would not leave. Her family drove to see the Olympic torch as the relay made its way to the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles. At home that same night, she went into her room and wrote ``I want to be an Olympic champion'' on a chalkboard.

title: Gore's Economic Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the opening of public schools in New York City misstated the location of Public School 212 in Queens. It is in Jackson Heights, not Forest Hills.

title: No Headline
From Here to There
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch missed his bus, but Marie Stewart and 80,000 other sports fans Saturday night gave an Olympics-eve passing grade to Sydney's recently troubled public transport system.

title: When Diplomats Flee to Dot-Coms
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfriendly Skies: What to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Madison Avenue cranks into high gear, with some major accounts shifting agencies.
description: IN an uncertain advertising world, one truth remains: the days just after Labor Day are unusually hectic as Madison Avenue gears up for the busy fall season. That was certainly the case last week, as assignments with billings estimated at more than $250 million changed hands.

title: Wetlands in City's Watershed Fall Under New Federal Controls
description: The federal government has announced tougher restrictions on building in wetlands within the New York City watershed.

title: Bit of Relief In Trenches
description: The Giants were pleased after their opening-game victory over Arizona last week. Yesterday, they were satisfied that they had beaten a superior opponent. No unit was more relieved than the offensive line, whose members admitted last week that they had not been truly tested.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I still believe we had to give him one last chance. He failed to live up to that. That was his decision.''

title: Archery
description: THERE IS NO Robin Hood, no William Tell, not even Geena Davis, although the actress, a nationally ranked archer, promises to try again to make the 2004 United States Olympic team. There is no Justin Huish because the flamboyant Californian, a 1996 gold medalist, withdrew after a marijuana arrest. There are no complicated rules, either, just a matter of shooting arrows at a target 70 meters away.

title: 2000 SYDNEY GAMES: Basketball; The Star Left Out in the Cold
description: The overmatched college players wanted to pay homage after being beaten by more than 60 points by Team USA. They were not searching for a Women's National Basketball Association player of the week, however. After quickly shaking the hands of Lisa Leslie and Sheryl Swoopes, the young players kept moving through the arena corridor.

title: Article 2000091193096341951 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Lions, the Lesser Lights, Stop the Redskins' Stars
description: The first play of the second quarter in the Silverdome today looked like the one that would decide this brawl between the Washington Redskins and the Detroit Lions. Kelvin Pritchett, the Lions' 6-foot-3-inch, 319-pound defensive tackle, caught a deflected pass thrown by Brad Johnson and ran with it. He labored down the left sideline, all the way inside the Redskins' 1-yard line. That was where he was finally caught and tackled -- after a 78-yard return -- by guard Tre Johnson.

title: In the Final, Youth Serves
description: It was a half-hour after match point, near the front row inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, when a group of smitten fans and nudging camera operators were circling Marat Safin as if they were surrounding a campfire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, W. PAGE
description: THOMPSON-W. Page. Of New York City, on September 10. Husband of Pat. Father of Steve, Page and Charles. Grandfather of five. Religious service at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, Wednesday, September 13, at 10 AM. Visitation hours on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Interment private.

title: Regulators Accuse Entertainment Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Producers of movies, video games and music aggressively try to attract children and teen-agers to entertainment that contains violent themes, federal regulators said today.

title: Jets Try to Anticipate Belichick's Game Plan
description: If Bill Parcells still casts his enormous shadow over the Jets, then Bill Belichick is the coach who confounds the franchise's psyche. While the Tuna Bowl has lost some of its bile with the specious declaration of a truce in the border war between the Patriots and the Jets, the family feud that has its latest chapter tonight at Giants Stadium is compelling in large part because Belichick still generates such enormous veneration -- and a bit of foreboding -- in the Jets' locker room.

title: British Free 7 Hostage Soldiers in Raid in Sierra Leone
description: British troops today made a surprise dawn attack on the jungle base of a renegade guerrilla gang in Sierra Leone and in a 90-minute gun battle freed seven soldiers who had been taken hostage there last month, the Ministry of Defense said.

title: For the Giants, There's No Disputing the Facts on the Ground
description: The challenge came after another Giants loss last November, to Washington. Linebacker Jessie Armstead's patience had been tried again, and he finally erupted. Armstead questioned the offense's toughness and said the defense had spent all day on the field trying to carry the team. Armstead's blistering words were quickly seconded by defensive end Michael Strahan, and soon the Giants were embroiled in a family squabble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLKIE, ARLINDA F.
description: WILLKIE-Arlinda F. Born July 31, 1946; died on Sept 7, 2000 from breast cancer. She was courageous, graceful, loving and beloved. We thank her friends, caretakers, nurses and doctors. She is survived by her family including her daughter, Julia T. Miranda; her brother and sister-in-law Frederick & Ida; her sister Julia; her brother Hall; Tom Craveiro; Riccardo Salmona; and her pug Peg. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Benheim Cancer Center or the Red Cross of Greenwich, CT. Service Monday, September 11 at 4 PM, First Congregational Church Old Greenwich, CT.

title: Siphoning Money From Medicaid
description: New York and 16 other states are manipulating Medicaid reimbursement laws to pull billions more dollars out of Washington than Congress intends. Some states use the largesse to treat the poor. Others use the windfall to pay ordinary bills. Either way the practice should be curtailed before it undermines political support for the always-embattled Medicaid program.

title: Mets Get a Chance to Breathe
description: The discussion between Steve Phillips and Bobby Valentine took place in Valentine's office. That much, Phillips and Valentine agreed upon. After that, the details got murkier. Just what the general manager might have told the manager concerning how the Mets need to win soon remained uncertain because each offered scant insight and claimed that sort of chat was normal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUROBINER, ALICE
description: TUROBINER-Alice. For the past 30 years our families have shared the Simchas and good times as well as the difficult ones. We would be remiss if we didn't send this final farewell to an elegant, regal woman whose Mitzvot and charity and philanthropic deeds were done in a quiet, yet legendary way. Your honesty, style and grace, both in your personal and professional life, as well as your wonderful friendship, will be sorely missed and will remain as part of your legacy to your family and friends. May your family truly take solace and comfort from your remarkable accomplishments and beauty and warmth during the years you shared with us as well as from the visionary words of the Prophet Micah, when longing for the Messianic Era, ''May G-d perish and banish death from this world forever and may He wipe away the tears from all of our faces.'' The Merlis Family

title: Patents; From behind the wheel of a cab, an immigrant doctor sees a new way to mend blood vessels.
description: WHILE awaiting a license to practice medicine in New York, Pepi Dakov spent several years driving a taxi around the city for 50 hours a week, working two jobs at once: ferrying passengers and envisioning a way to mend severed blood vessels without sutures.

title: When Diplomats Flee to Dot-Coms
description: To the Editor:

title: Running for Her Country, Her People, Herself
description: The biggest Olympic stadium in history rises up all around you at Homebush Bay: 110,000 seats amid gentle sea breezes that can become gusts in the time it takes for a sprinter to lean forward and plant his splayed fingers and great expectations behind a thin white line.

title: Entertainment Web Sites Facing Failures and Cuts
description: The announcement last week that Shockwave.com, one of the most frequently visited entertainment sites on the World Wide Web, was laying off 15 percent of its staff and shifting its emphasis toward more interactive diversions, was bad enough. But coming just days after Pop.com, the dot-com brainchild of some of Hollywood's most famous names, announced it was shutting down before it ever opened for business, many in this new, once-growing Internet sector are beginning to wonder if the party is over before it has really had a chance to begin.

title: Content Sampras Gracious In Defeat
description: Pete Sampras ducked into the tunnel and shuffled toward the locker room, his racket bag slung over his left shoulder. His left hand cradled an envelope and an odd two-dimensional silver plate that reflected a face resigned to his fate.

title: Sports of The Times; Whatever Happened to Duce Staley?
description: AS the final seconds of the Giants' 33-18 stampede flashed away yesterday, their general manager, Ernie Accorsi, stared at the Veterans Stadium message board with the out-of-town scores.

title: Sailing
description: THE 1996 American team had high expectations in its home waters, but managed only two bronze medals in Savannah, Ga. The United States squad hopes to return to prominence in Sydney. In 1992, the team claimed nine medals in 10 classes.

Beloved husband of Katherine (Dawida) Walsh; devoted father of Kathleen and Jack Stanley, Janet and George Massie, and Caroline Walsh and George Rosenberg; loving grandfather of Jack, Paul, Lara and Brooke. He served as a paratrooper in the Korean War. Friends received 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Readshaw Funeral Home, Inc., 1503 Brownsville Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15210-3971. title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 1 about the role played by Congressional candidates at the Republican National Convention, and a chart listing their speeches, misspelled the surname of the Republican who is challenging Representative James Maloney in Connecticut. The name was also misspelled in a picture caption on March 4 about the campaign for the House. The challenger is Mark Nielsen, not Nielson. The errors were discovered last week during research for another article about House races.

title: Cheney Varnishing a Campaign Style Seen as Wooden
description: It may be too early to talk about the reinvented Dick Cheney. But the Republican vice-presidential nominee, who has found himself fighting a reputation for woodenness not unlike that of the vice president he is trying to replace, has been making a few readjustments lately.

title: Gaviola Extends Streak
description: Gaviola may not be headed for the Breeders' Cup, but the 3-year-old filly achieved a short-term goal yesterday when she won a Grade I stakes and ran her winning streak to six races.

description: Very early in this college football season, a couple of things can be surmised. Wise voters in the national polls, as well as wise guys on bar stools, have learned that their safe picks at the top of the national rankings weren't so safe and that their smart picks weren't so smart.

title: Local TV Uncovered National Scandal
description: Local television news programs rarely break news of national consequence. In fact, they are often accused of being superficial and sensationalistic and of relying on ''scare tactic'' consumer reports whose promotional spots warn of dire consequences should viewers miss them.

description: CARBONE-Pietro J. Late of New York City's Village String Shop. Died September 6, in Miami. He made and restored violins and guitars, was in the center of the folk movement and inspired the young. He started a union for women electricians.

description: Zdeno Chara will be playing for the Islanders this year, after all. So will Brad Isbister.

title: Volleyball
description: THE Americans will be looking for signs of a rebirth. In the mid- and late-80's, the Americans were led by Karch Kiraly, a young player from Southern California. In 1984 and 1988, Kiraly helped the United States win consecutive gold medals. Then he started to hit the beach looking for competition, and, perhaps coincidentally, the United States slowly lost control of the sport to teams like Italy.

title: Jones, in Victory, Is Looking Down

Shortly after registering a victory when Eric Harding could not answer the bell for the 11th round because of a torn left biceps, Jones unloaded a plan more intriguing than any punch he threw in the ring in New Orleans.

description: Greetings from Sydney, I'm going to be sending a daily electronic postcard every day on the feel of the Games.

description: SHE IS 5 feet 10 inches tall, weighs 300 pounds and is only 17 years old. Her combination of strength, flexibility and explosiveness also makes Cheryl Haworth the United States's best chance for a women's medal as the sport makes its Olympic debut for the female lifters.

description: PARIS  The standards are set, the licenses are being awarded, the smart handsets are on their way.

title: Clash Time in the Senate Race
description: New York's Senate race had settled recently into a tediously safe campaign between two cautious candidates. All that changed over the weekend with the politically motivated White House decision to release a 1998 photograph of Representative Rick Lazio shaking hands with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. As a result, Mr. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton will likely use their debate in Buffalo on Wednesday to continue their highly charged battle for the Jewish vote and to defend the tactics being used in that competition.

title: Triathlon
description: LIKE Marion Jones, triathlon figures to play an outsized role in its first Olympics. It might be a niche endurance sport with a short history -- the first official triathlon was held in 1974 in San Diego -- but it is a sport at which Australians excel and which dovetails nicely with their sun-and-sea culture. That explains why triathlon has been given pride of place on the Olympic schedule. The women's event is the first gold-medal event of the Games; the men compete the next day.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LAWRENCE
description: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGEN, CHARLES ROBERT
description: HOGEN-Charles Robert, 92. Died on July 16 at his home in Lenox, Massachusetts. His surviving children are Timothy Hogen of New York City, Sherill Covian of Shelburne Falls, MA, Robin Hogen of Westport, CT, Lyn Mason of Seattle, Washington, and Jackson Hogen of Newbury, MA. Charles was born on October 8, 1907, to Fred Neff Hogen and Mae Ladd Hogen in Cleveland, Ohio. He attended Yale University and was on the varsity swim team that set the world record for the 250 yard relay in 1928. He graduated from Yale in 1929 and was active in alumni affairs. With his encouragement, his three sons all graduated from Yale. Upon graduation, Charles' first job was with the Holland American Line as entertainment director for Transatlantic voyages. This was how he met Carolyn Kirtland Hine of Cleveland, whom he married in 1933. In '34 he became an Account Executive for N.W. Ayer in New York City and stayed with this prestigious advertising firm for 38 years. He retired to Peru, Vermont, in 1972, where he enjoyed skiing, golf and his eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on September 30 in Lenox, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mountain Valley Center, (PO Box 310, Londonderry, VT 05148).

title: E-Commerce Report; For online retailers, close-out sales are becoming a reliable and safe source of revenue.
description: RETAILERS have always been ambivalent about close-out items. On the one hand, the racks of last season's worst sellers and returns are constant reminders of buying blunders, lost sales opportunities and wasted floor space. On the other hand, these goods can be magnets for some customers who might come to the store for bargains but leave with a carload of full-price items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLIN, MAURICE F.

Volin of New York, NY, Rochelle B. Suflas of Moorestown, NJ, and Nancy Volin Simon of New York, NY, dear brother of Irwin Volin and Robert Volin and cherished grandfather of three grandchildren. That title went to Denver, where rival papers tried to starve each other into submission by offering themselves for a penny a day.

description: Australian athletes will not begin competing in Sydney until Saturday, but two Olympic competitions that matter a great deal to their country will be decided before the first ball is struck or the first wall is touched.

title: Softball
description: FOUR YEARS ago in Atlanta, the United States women's softball team, with one defeat in the previous 10 years of international competition, was supposed to win the Olympic gold medal in a walkover. Then the Australians defeated the United States, 2-1, in 10 innings of an early-round game. Then it was up to the Chinese women to press the Americans in the gold-medal game. The Americans narrowly avoided a stunning upset when America's fiery infielder Dot Richardson hit a dramatic game-ending home run.

title: Experts Fear a Brutal Season For Heating in the Northeast

Electricity experts had predicted power failures and brownouts, but neither happened. Bills went up, but not as much as they could have, because air-conditioners were not running round the clock.

title: Weather May Slow Track Events
description: Popular in Europe but largely off the American radar screen between Olympic years, track and field continues to be the flagship sport of the Games. This year there is added spice as Marion Jones attempts to become the first woman in track and field to win five gold medals in one Olympics. Cold, windy weather may prevent any world records.

title: New Economy; When the Internet businesses shake, the next domino is the companies that provide them with consulting services.
description: IN the current climate for technology stocks, it is not surprising that the troubles plaguing other sectors of the industry have now fallen on the consulting companies that help businesses build and manage their Internet operations. What is remarkable, though, is how quickly the pall has descended.

title: SAUDI INVESTS $50 MILLION MORE IN PRICELINE

The latest agreement also calls for the prince to receive warrants from Mr. Walker to buy an unspecified stake in Walker Digital, which makes the software Priceline.com uses.
