title: Option Boards Are Censured By the S.E.C.
description: The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that the four major options exchanges agreed for years to restrain competition by not seeking to trade options already traded on other exchanges.

title: Boeing Plan for St. Louis
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would invest as much as $250 million in upgrades at its St. Louis military-aircraft division and sell some other facilities to the St. Louis Airport Authority to cut costs. Boeing, the second-largest defense contractor in the nation, plans to build a new hangar for flight tests and expand another building for assembly work. It will sell 1.8 million square feet of facilities to the operator of the adjacent St. Louis airport, cutting the amount of space it uses by 20 percent. The plan is part of a continuing consolidation of Boeing's operations. The company said in June that it planned to sell a 1,700-worker parts-fabrication unit in St. Louis. Boeing is also shutting some rocket facilities in California. The new operations are scheduled to open in mid-2002.

title: VITAL SIGNS: BEHAVIOR; Men, Women and Battles of the Bulges
description: When men and women think about their extra poundage, they see it in different terms, a new survey suggests: to women, the fat embodies character flaws; to men, it's not their fault, it's those darn business lunches.

title: Dispute by Lawyers Delays Guilty Plea by Wen Ho Lee
description: A last-minute dispute between the government and defense lawyers over a plea agreement for Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear secrets, delayed for at least two days a guilty plea that would allow him to walk out of court a free man.

title: No Headline
German Stock Exchange Delays Vote on London Merger
description: What had been presented as a fait accompli five months ago faced a new setback today when the Frankfurt stock exchange's parent company decided to postpone a shareholder vote meant to ratify a planned merger with the London Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUFANO, PASCAL
description: TUFANO-Pascal. Of New Springville, S.I., on Sept 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Rosa. Loving father of Doctors Ralph and Sylvia Tufano. Dear brother of Steve, Sal, Manny, Joe and John Tufano, Christina Caliendo, Elsie Papadoupolous and Irene Tufano Tomassetti. Funeral from Matthew Funeral Home, Inc., 2508 Victory Blvd at Willowbrook Road, S.I. on Wednesday 9AM. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Pity Church 9:30AM. Interment Ocean View Cemetery. Friends may call Tuesday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERMAN, IRVING
description: LERMAN-Irving ''Lefty''. Age 83. Of Merrick, N.Y. and Fort Lauderdale, FL. died Sunday, September 10, 2000. Beloved and devoted husband to Anne for 60 years. Cherished father of Ilene Shotland and Sidney Lerman. Loving father-inlaw to Carole. Adored grandfather of Michelle and Bill Christian, Brian and Adam Shotland, Michael, Steven and Nicolette Lerman, Michelle and Jeffrey Zober. Wonderful and caring brother, brother-in-law and uncle to his family. Loyal friend to many. President of Lerman Bros., Inc., a family-run company for more than 50 years. His memory will endure in our hearts forever. He will be especially missed but will always be remembered. Services today, 1PM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Dont Touch the Fruit Bats
description: For months we have been hearing ominous tales about the dangers of Australia during these Summer Games -- ferocious sharks preparing to gobble up triathletes in the harbor, lethal snakes slithering around the outback, to say nothing of avaricious I.O.C. delegates looking for their cut.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CONSEQUENCES; Knee Injury in Youth and Arthritis in Age
description: People who injure their knees as young adults may suffer for it twice: once at the time, and later on through substantially higher rates of arthritis, according to a study that tracked more than 1,000 doctors for almost 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUROBINER, ALICE
description: TUROBINER-Alice. Yeshiva University, its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, and the YU Women's Organization are deeply grieved by the passing of a dynamic, gracious, and selfless leader on behalf of our institution. With her beloved husband, Harold-who was a member of the YU High Schools Board-she was a YU Guardian. She played a major role in strengthening the YUWO, serving on the executive council, as honorary national president and past copresident. She will be sorely missed by her YUWO coworkers. Mr. and Mrs. Turobiner established a YUHS scholarship in their names and were honored with the YUHS Centennial Achievement Award in 1986. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Harold; children, both alumni, Carol (and John) Finley and Ann (and Jonathan) Dachs; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower, Chairman National Board, YUWO

title: Choices for the New York Primary
description: New York State's primary today gives voters a chance to pick party candidates for the Nov. 7 election. Because of low voter turnout in the past, some races, even for Congress, have been won by margins of only a few hundred votes. Here are our choices in 18 contested primaries, one Republican and the rest Democratic. These choices do not imply endorsement in the general election. The polls will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: New Embarrassments Put I.O.C. on Defensive
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 12  In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal and diminished credibility over its resolve to reduce the use of performance-enhancing drugs, the International Olympic Committee has faced a barrage of new embarrassments this week that raises questions about its ability to change significantly.

title: Article 2000091293464931712 -- No Title
description: An article on Sunday about the importance of Pennsylvania in the presidential race misstated the name of the Wilkes-Barre newspaper in which a columnist, Steve Corbett, wrote about a meeting between George W. Bush and Bishop James C. Timlin of Scranton. It is The Times Leader, not The News-Leader.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZAGAT, EUGENE H.
description: ZAGAT-Eugene H. ''All I know of love is love is all there is.'' Liz and Lori

title: A Talk-Show Bad Boy Opts for Punditry
description: CHARLES GRODIN was once notorious as the talk-show guest who zinged the host; the guy with the ironic sidelong look who would say anything. But as the man whose own cable talk show got canceled and received some of the most vicious reviews in television, he's got a thin skin.

title: Back to Square One
description: An investigation that began eight years ago as an effort to determine how China obtained highly classified information from American weapons labs about one of the country's most advanced nuclear warheads appears to be back where it started, with the mystery still unsolved.

title: Once More Against The World
description: Until this season, Siri Mullinix had played exactly one game at goalkeeper for the American women's soccer team. She was among the final cuts from the 1999 World Cup squad, knowing that, at age 22, she would have to wait her turn. Goalkeepers, like plumbers and electricians, require extensive apprenticeships.

title: Sports of The Times; Vultures Serenade Belichick
description: ABOVE the west tunnel in Giants Stadium, several dozen fans, many in Jets jerseys, were perched like vultures, waiting for Bill Belichick to appear. And when the Patriots' coach did appear, the boos descended. Heavy, hearty boos. Cruel boos. Among the serenade of those boos a heavy, hearty voice could be heard above the others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, HENRIETTA
description: FLYNN-Henrietta (nee Buck). Age 89. Of Litchfield, CT., born in Conception Harbor, Newfoundland. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Died suddenly on September 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late James Bernard. Loving mother of James Bernard, Jr., Ann Marie Crossman and Madeline Patenge. Dear mother-in-law of Julie Maher Flynn, Edgar O. Crossman and David Patenge. Also survived by six grandsons James Bernard III, Michael, Matthew and John Flynn and Robert and Luther Patenge. Visiting Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:15AM at St. Ephrem's R.C. Church.

title: A Reason to Smile
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch chuckled twice in public today, evidence, perhaps, that he is comfortable that the I.O.C. he leads is past being in a perpetual state of siege. Samaranch's cheerful gesture came early in the opening day of a three-day I.O.C. session leading up to the opening ceremony of the Summer Olympics.

title: OIL DRILLING PURCHASE
description: The Precision Drilling Corporation, Canada's largest oil well driller, said it agreed to buy a rival well-service company CenAlta Energy Services Inc., for about 207.9 million Canadian dollars ($140.7 million) in stock to expand in the western part of the country. Precision Drilling will pay 0.1432 common share, or about 7.88 dollars, for each CenAlta share, the company said. CenAlta gives Precision more rigs that provide specialty services like well maintenance at a time when oil prices near 10-year highs have prompted more exploration in western Canada's oil fields.

title: Maxxcom and GCI Make Acquisitions
description: Two acquisitions are being made for undisclosed terms.

title: BRAZIL INTERNET OFFERING
description: Brazil's largest Internet service provider, UOL Inc., plans an initial public offering of shares on the Nasdaq by the end of the year to finance regional expansion. The company, which is controlled by the Abril and Folha media groups, still has to file paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has opened an international headquarters in Argentina, as well as offices in most major Latin American countries, as part of a plan to build a presence in the regional market. Jennifer L. Rich

title: To Help Bush, N.R.A. Withholds Backing
description: Defying expectations, the board of the National Rifle Association declined to endorse Gov. George W. Bush for president at its final meeting of the year on Saturday. The development makes it very unlikely that Mr. Bush will receive the group's formal approval before Election Day, N.R.A. officials said today.

title: Fashion Week: One for the Money, Two for the Show; John Varvatos Reaches Out To the Man in the Middle
description: At the Gucci men's show in Milan earlier this summer, Dylan McDermott, the actor who isn't Dermott Mulroney but the one who plays a Boston lawyer on ''The Practice,'' sat in the front row in the kind of attenuated black suit (Gucci, needless to say) his character would only wear if he were delivering a summation to 12 jury members who also happened to be putting together the next Whitney Biennial.

title: Coach Plays Down Rivalry
description: The Australian swim coach Don Talbot dismissed talk of a rancorous rivalry developing between his swimmers and those from the favored American team today. Responding to questions about trash-talking between the teams, Talbot said:

title: Article 2000091290452634866 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDMAN-Sylvia. Died September 9 at age 96 in Boca Raton, FL. Devoted and loving wife of the late Sol. Cherished mother of Florence Katz (Sidney) and Myron Goldman (Carol). Adoring grandmother of Steven Zinaman (Nan), Dr. Michael Zinaman, Dr. Robert Goldman (Gail), Pamela Goldman and William Goldman (Sherri). Proud great-grandmother of Jamie, Kimberly, Rachel, Owen, Benjamin, Cynthia and Samantha. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends to whom she was devoted throughout her life. Funeral services to be held on Tuesday, September 12, 1 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., NY.

title: For Giants, No Gloating In Game Plan
description: As he stood by his locker at Giants Stadium, quarterback Kerry Collins had every reason to be pleased. He was running the offense with efficiency and dazzle. He had won over the once skeptical defense. The Giants were undefeated.

title: Cheers for the Boys and Girls of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving Charges For Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry, currently suspended from baseball for violating terms of his drug program and still recovering from treatment for a cancer relapse, was arrested yesterday in Tampa, Fla., and charged with reckless driving and leaving the scene of an accident.

title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: California Enacts Expansive College Aid Plan
description: California today enacted the most generous college financial aid plan in the nation, guaranteeing needy high school students with good grades grants for full tuition at the state's public colleges and universities, or nearly $10,000 a year toward tuition at one of the state's private institutions. The plan will cost the state more than $1 billion a year.

title: Living and Learning At Dishwasher U.; Whirlpool Trainees Prepare for Real World
description: Tony Barbee has never enjoyed household chores. Even in college, he regularly brought his laundry home to Mother, and he shunned the stove in favor of the local Burger King or Kentucky Fried Chicken.

title: On the Eve of the Olympics the I.O.C. Tries to Polish Its Image
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 12 -- In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal and growing fears that the use of performance-enhancing drugs is widespread, the International Olympic Committee has faced a barrage of new embarrassments this week that raise questions about its ability and resolve to change significantly.

title: Article 2000091290496300023 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Britons Running Out of Patience as Costly Gas Runs Out
description: By the time George Scott abandoned work, jumped into his car and steered it to the Shell station on the Old Brompton Road, most of the gasoline pumps were already festooned with ''Not in Service'' signs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DONALD J PLINER, New York, named Len Pesko chief operating officer. He had been president at Enzo Angiolini.

title: Tires and Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewlett-Packard Is in Talks to Buy Consulting Unit
description: Hewlett-Packard and PricewaterhouseCoopers confirmed yesterday that they were discussing the sale of the PricewaterhouseCoopers management and information technology consulting practice to Hewlett-Packard.

title: Panel Urges Monitoring of Chronic Diseases
description: The Pew Environmental Health Commission and 13 top public health groups have proposed that the United States establish a system to count and monitor chronic diseases like birth defects, asthma and Alzheimer's.

title: FLEET TO OFFER VISA 'SMART CARD'
description: FleetBoston Financial, one of the nation's biggest banks, plans to announce today that it will offer a Visa credit card with a microchip that can store account information and can be used, with a swipe through a magnetic-stripe reader, to make purchases on the Internet. The card, named Fusion, will be available starting next Monday and will be the first mass-produced ''smart card'' to carry the Visa brand in the United States, said Joseph Saunders, chief executive of Fleet's credit card operations. The card's chip will keep track of credit balances, frequent-flier miles and other data, he said. American Express has issued a Blue card meant for electronic purchases, but for the most part, American consumers have been slower than those in Europe and Japan to accept smart cards. Patrick McGeehan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RUTH NEE PRESSNER
description: EPSTEIN-Ruth nee Pressner, 81. Of West Orange, NJ and Deerfield Beach, FL, on September 8, 2000. Survived by her sister, Bernice Goldin, beloved mother of four children and their spouses, grandmother of 13, and great-grandmother of 11. She proudly served as Chairwoman of New Jersey Council of AMIT Women, National Vice President of AMIT Women & Board member of Stern College for Women. Interment was at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey, Sept. 8th. Shiva will be observed through Thursday morning. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Weak Brewers Outmuscle Struggling Mets
description: Rick Reed had last pitched at Shea Stadium in the Mets' final game in August. They won that night, and by their next game, they were alone in first place. Life was grand.

title: KENNAMETAL TO BUY REMAINDER OF JLK DIRECT DISTRIBUTION
description: Kennametal, a maker of industrial tools and equipment, agreed to buy the remaining shares of another toolmaker, JLK Direct Distribution, for $37.6 million, a 31 percent increase to Kennametal's prior offer. Kennametal, which owns about 83 percent of JLK, said it would pay $8.75 a share in cash for each of the 4.3 million JLK shares it did not already own. The bid is 40 percent more than JLK's closing price Friday of $6.25. Kennametal, based in Latrobe, Pa., said in July that it would pay $6.70 a share for JLK. Shares of JLK rose $2.38, or 38 percent, to $8.63. JLK, also based in Latrobe, makes metalworking tools. It had sales of $499.3 million in the year ended June 30. Kennametal had sales of about $1.85 billion in the year ended in June.

title: Primary Day in New York Features the First Lady on Her First Ballot
description: Around New York today, voters cast ballots in a handful of contested local elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, DONALD
description: WHYTE-Donald. The New York Philharmonic notes with grief and sadness the death of Donald Whyte, a deeply valued member of the Philharmonic's violin section since 1972. Mr. Whyte's early teachers were Alexander Whyte and Elman Lowe. Prior to joining the Orchestra, Mr. Whyte attended the University of Saskatchewan and Indiana University, where he studied with Josef Gingold. After joining the Philharmonic, he continued his studies with Ivan Galamian and became an active chamber musician, playing with the Gofriller Quartet and the Soho Ensemble. Mr. Whyte was an influential member of various Philharmonic orchestra committees, most recently serving as chairman of the Artistic Committee for several years. He also served as a Philharmonic representative to the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians and was a board member of the Music Assistance Fund, which aids young minority musicians. In addition, Donald Whyte was a successful heart transplant recipient. His love of music and dedication to the Orchestra and fellow musicians will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Noriko, and to his entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Executive Director

title: A Critical Meeting on Nassau County Finances
description: If there is a way for Nassau County to avoid a state takeover of its finances, the outlines may begin to take shape Tuesday when the man who Gov. George E. Pataki selected to help rescue the county's finances is to meet with Republican and Democratic officials.

title: CENTEX SAYS 2001 EARNINGS WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: The Centex Corporation, one of the largest homebuilders in the United States, said it expected 2001 earnings per share might be 25 cents to 50 cents above current analysts' estimates. Centex, which is based in Dallas, is expected to earn $3.74 a share in the fiscal year ending March 31, based on the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. The stock rose $2, to $31.75. Centex will close on the sale of 20,500 homes during the fiscal year, 1,000 more than previously expected, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, LOUISE C.
description: CONNELL-Louise C., age 94. Died at home in New York City on September 9, 2000. Wife of the late Raymond M. Ohmer and the late James R. Connell. Beloved mother of Carol Collins, Louise Mills, Katherine Sincerbeaux and the late Raymond Ohmer. Grandmother of Carol Malone, Bradley Collins, Lee Collins, James Collins, Carolyn McHugh, James Mills, Jennifer Mills and Carolyn Sincerbeaux. She is also survived by seven great-grandchildren. Funeral service on Wednesday, September 13, at 11 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, at 84th Street and Park Avrnue. Please omit flowers.

title: Landlord Is Charged in Slaying of Tenant
description: A 69-year-old elementary school librarian was shot and killed yesterday by the landlord of the Madison Avenue brownstone where she had lived for more than 29 years, the authorities said.

title: A Hormone Therapy Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Week: One for the Money, Two for the Show; The Season's Hottest Runway Accessory: Her Own Nose
description: If there is one look that won't be hitting the runways during the spring 2001 collections in New York, which begin on Thursday and run through Sept. 22, it's that of the exaggeratedly thin models who reached a kind of apogee (or nadir, depending on your viewpoint) during the eras of heroin chic, grunge and the waif. Fashionable standards of beauty fluctuate -- within a narrow range -- but among the largely unremarked, and salutary, changes in the modeling business, insiders say, is a renewed appetite for women who do not look fundamentally ill.

title: NAPSTER USE QUADRUPLED IN 5 MONTHS
description: The number of people using the Napster music file-sharing application reached 4.9 million United States home users in July, according to Media Metrix. That compares with 1.1 million in February, the first month the Internet audience measurement service tracked use of the Napster application. Those numbers came before the service gained notoriety because of litigation over its use as a means to trade copyrighted music files. Napster use also grew steeply among those at work, Media Metrix found. Susan Stellin

title: Director of Medicare Will Quit For a Teaching Job at Harvard
description: Nancy-Ann Min DeParle, administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, the federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, announced today that she was resigning on Oct. 1 to take a temporary job teaching at Harvard University.

title: VODAFONE STAKE FOR SALE
description: The Hong Kong conglomerate, Hutchison Whampoa, said it would sell part of its 3.4 percent stake in Vodafone AirTouch, which it acquired through the sale of Orange P.L.C. to Mannesmann. of Germany and Vodafone's subsequent takeover of the German telecommunications conglomerate. Hutchison Whampoa said it would sell a $2.5 billion three-year bond that would be convertible into Vodafone shares. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Experts See Fix for Medicare As One Tough Proposition
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas confidently proposed last week that as president he would put an overhaul of Medicare on the ''fast track,'' directing a new White House task force to send legislation to Congress within nine months to transform the 35-year-old government insurance program into an efficient, largely private health care marketplace.

title: Plan to Put Olympics In New York Draws Fire; Site for 2012 Games Outlined by Backers, Including City Hall
description: Call them delirious, but if organizers of the effort to bring the Olympics here get their way, 12 years from now New Yorkers might pass the month of September traipsing to beach volleyball along the East River, taking in dressage on Staten Island or cheering triathletes swimming a mile around the Central Park Reservoir. That's right, the Reservoir.

title: New York's Uninsured
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur May Get Help
description: The Devils are contemplating a reduction in the number of games played by Martin Brodeur, their premier goaltender.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Different Politics, But Same Praise

title: OBITUARY : Paul Bianchini, 72, Pop Art Dealer, Dies
description: SENS, France  Paul Bianchini, 72, for decades a leading figure in the art worlds of New York and Paris who in the 1960s brought Pop Art to worldwide attention and later introduced a new wave of postwar American painters to Europe, died here last Tuesday of liver cancer, his widow said Friday.

title: Monk Contest Puts Focus On Latin Rhythms
description: The 14th musicians' competition sponsored by the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz began on Saturday with a consecration. Renato Thoms, a 33-year-old competitor from Panama, who now lives in Brooklyn, read aloud from Corinthians. ''Be anxious for nothing,'' he said, asking God to bless the festival and the competitors. Then he started to play, not drums, saxophone or trumpet or any of the the usual instruments of jazz that have been the basis of past competitions, but congas.

title: Iraq Won't Let Outside Experts Assess Sanctions' Impact on Lives
description: Iraq will not allow independent experts into the country to assess the living conditions of Iraqis a decade after economic sanctions were imposed, Secretary General Kofi Annan told the Security Council today.

title: After 75 Years, a Radio Show Is Dropped
description: John R. Gambling, the host of a talk show that had been heard on WOR-AM radio continuously for 75 years, went off the air yesterday, prompting an outpouring of calls and e-mail messages from listeners upset at the passing of an institution in New York radio.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: There They Go, Bad-Mouthing Divorce Again
description: Several years ago at a party, I asked a woman I had just met how her Christmas had been. She said, ''First good Christmas in 25 years.''

title: Protesters Attempt to Sabotage World Economic Forum
description: MELBOURNE Australia, Sept. 12 -- It was supposed to be a stimulating group chat about the global economy, held here a few days before the opening of the Olympics to allow the corporate executives, central bankers, and other notables to hop over to Sydney for some world-class sporting events.

title: Indonesia Rejects Meeting With U.N. Officials Investigating Timor Deaths
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 12  As the Security Council prepared to send its own mission to Indonesia and West Timor to look into the slaying of three United Nations refugee workers last week, an Indonesian official said today that his government would refuse to receive the delegation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORPORA, JUDITH
description: PORPORA-Judith (nee Schroeder). Age 51, of Cold Spring Harbor. Suddenly on September 9, 2000. Beloved wife of Stephen, loving mother of Devon and Mairin. Cherished daughter of Peggy and George Schroeder, dear sister of Sandra Schroeder. Visitation on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM, at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington. Mass of Christian Burial, on Wednesday 9:45AM, St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Interment St. Patrick's cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Judi Porpora Scholarship Fund, in care of Cold Spring Harbor High School, 82 Turkey Lane, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724, Attention Marty Rowley are appreciated.

title: Yankees Are Just Killing Time Until Postseason Comes Around
description: If Yankees Manager Joe Torre carried a daily organizer for his business, these would be the first two lines on his to-do list:

title: Fired Diplomatic Employee Can Sue Saudis, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that a former employee of the Saudi Mission to the United Nations who claimed that she was fired for espousing women's rights may sue for discrimination despite Saudi claims that her suit is barred under diplomatic immunity.

title: Prime-Time Politics, Ready or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: British Gas Stations Run Dry, in Crisis Spawned by Protests
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  Britain was gripped by chaos today as more than 6,000 gas stations ran out of fuel following mass blockades of oil refineries and depots across the country.

Bush and Bishop James C. Timlin of Scranton. It is The Times Leader, not The News-Leader.

title: Tribulations and Triumphs in Sports
description: Baseball and football have yet to produce their main story lines for 2000, and the summer Olympics that open this week in Australia will generate many of the year's most memorable athletic images. But for sports aficionados this past weekend provided plenty of nourishment. The University of Indiana finally summoned the gumption to fire Bob Knight as basketball coach, a gifted young Russian tennis player gave the sleepy world of men's tennis a badly needed jolt and Tiger Woods added another golf title to one of the greatest championship years anyone has ever achieved in sports.

title: G.E. DEAL SEEN FOR SCOTTISH LIFE
description: The financial services arm of the General Electric Company, GE Capital, is close to announcing a deal worth $:1 billion, or about $1.42 billion, for Scottish Life Assurance, the mutual pension provider, people close to the situation said. Details of the deal are likely to be announced late in the week. GE Capital approached Edinburgh-based Scottish Life after it decided not to pursue a bid for Scottish Provident, another Edinburgh mutual life insurer that agreed last week to sell itself to Abbey National for $:1.8 billion. Scottish Life, with assets of $:9.7 billion, would give GE Capital a foothold in the British pension market. Suzanne Kapner

title: COLOMBIAN ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: Colombian industrial output rose in the first seven months of the year, a trade group said, another sign the economy is pulling out of recession. Output rose 8.5 percent through July from the year-earlier period, the National Industrialists Association said. The gain, after a 10 percent rise through June, is the seventh increase in 24 months, the group said, based on a survey. The figures are the latest to show Colombia is emerging from a recession that began last year and led to a 4.5 percent shrinkage of the economy.

title: CYBERONICS BOARD REJECTS OFFER FROM MEDTRONIC
description: Cyberonics, a maker of devices that treat epilepsy, said yesterday that its board rejected a $480 million buyout offer from Medtronic, the No. 1 pacemaker manufacturer, because it wanted to keep its management. Medtronic, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had made the offer, of $26 a share, for Cyberonics to expand its neurological and spinal product lines. Cyberonics is based in Houston. Cyberonics's president, Robert Cummins, said the board had rejected similar offers from Medtronic in July and August.

title: Are Troubles Off Field Hurting Mets On Field?
description: Because Bobby Valentine is in the last year of his contract with the Mets, his future status with them has been a frequent topic of conversation this season. Whether or not the talk has served as a distraction is a matter that has often been addressed and disputed by people who are paid to watch the Mets and analyze them.

title: Brodeurs Load May Be Lightened
description: The Devils are contemplating a reduction in the number of games played by Martin Brodeur, their premier goaltender.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Miss Albania U.S.A. Pageant in New York and a picture caption in some copies misidentified the Albanian national symbol, which was emblazoned on T-shirts worn by the contestants. It is a two-headed eagle, not a two-headed lion.

title: The European Union Lifts Sanctions Against Austria
description: PARIS, Sept. 12  The European Union lifted its sanctions against Austria today, eight months after hurriedly imposing a diplomatic freeze on Vienna for bringing a far-right party into its ruling coalition.

Muldoon, beloved father of our dear friend and colleague Thomas Muldoon, MD. To Tom, his family, and all his father's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Robert G. Newman, MD President

title: U.S. Request for Antismoking Data Slows British Drug Merger
description: Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham said today that their planned merger into one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies is again facing delay as American regulators examine their products to stop smoking.

description: CIRCUITS

title: Finding Defect Was Complex, Firestone Executive Testifies
description: An official from the Bridgestone/Firestone Company told a Senate committee today that discovering the pattern of tire failures that has been linked to 88 deaths nationwide took longer than the company would have wished because of the complexity of the problem and the fact that, statistically, only a tiny number of tires failed.

title: Indonesia Rejects Meeting with U.N. Officials Investigating Timor Deaths
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 12 -- As the Security Council prepared to send a delegation to Indonesia and West Timor to look into the slayings of three United Nations refugee workers last week, the Indonesian government said today that it would refuse to meet the delegation.

title: Japanese Economy Expands For 2nd Consecutive Quarter
description: Japan's economy expanded 1 percent in the April-June quarter, the government said today, a stronger-than-expected performance driven by higher government and consumer spending.

title: Protesters Attempt to Sabotage World Economic Forum
description: MELBOURNE Australia, Sept. 12 -- It was supposed to be a stimulating group chat about the global economy, held here a few days before the opening of the Olympics to allow the corporate executives, central bankers, and other notables to hop over to Sydney for some world-class sporting events.

title: Pharmacia to Add Offices in New Jersey
description: The Pharmacia Corporation, further expanding its corporate and pharmaceutical headquarters in New Jersey, has leased more office space in Somerset County.

title: David E. Bell, Budget Director For Kennedy, Is Dead at 81
description: David Elliott Bell, who was President John F. Kennedy's director of the Bureau of the Budget and then his administrator of the Agency for International Development, died on Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 81.

title: Can Robots Rule the World? Not Yet
description: Bees do it. Birds do it. Bacteria do it.

title: A Deal That Helped Make One Team and Helped Break Another
description: Few people in the upper ranks of the New England Patriots organization had gotten much sleep one particular week early in 1998. Bill Parcells, the former head coach and someone many in the organization despised, was the cause. Behind his back, some Patriots employees used to joke about adding a holiday to the calendar called ''Punch Bill in the Face Day.''

title: U.S. Approves Formation of Supply Web Site for Automakers
description: Federal antitrust regulators approved today the establishment of an online venture that would allow five major automakers -- including the top three in America -- to buy supplies through a single Internet portal.

title: HAMRLIK CHIPS IN
description: Although he had been at the Islanders' training camp less than 24 hours, by the time defenseman Roman Hamrlik stepped onto the ice yesterday at the Olympic Center in Lake Placid, N.Y., he felt like part of the team.

title: MetroStars Could Cap Season With 2 Cups
description: This is a crucial week for the MetroStars. Before they play host to the Dallas Burn in the first round of the playoffs on Friday night at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., the MetroStars will meet the Miami Fusion in the semifinals of the United States Open Cup tonight at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y. A victory would put the MetroStars in the final against the Chicago Fire, giving the MetroStars a chance to win the American double -- the Open Cup and the M.L.S. Cup.

title: Sun Microsystems Seeks New Agency
description: Sun Microsystems in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it would begin a review for its account, with billings estimated at $100 million.

title: Tests Fail to Support Theory on AIDS and Role of Chimpanzees and Vaccine
description: Tests have failed to support a theory that the worldwide AIDS epidemic was touched off because an experimental oral polio vaccine used in Africa more than 40 years ago was made from chimpanzee tissue, scientists reported yesterday in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMANN, CHARLES FOOTE
description: FLEISCHMANN-Charles Foote. On September 4, 2000 in Fairfield, CT. Mr. Fleischmann was born in 1916 in New York City, the son of Charles Maximilian Fleischmann and Alice Dumont Foote. He graduated in 1935 from St. George's School and immediately began a career in business which included positions with Young & Rubicam, The Nestle Company and lastly as a partner with Ward Howell & Associates in New York from which he had retired. He resided for many years in Wilton, CT. He was married in 1939 to Constance Crosby Worrall who died in 1991. He is survived by a daughter, Constance F. Viti of Italy; a son, Charles W. Fleischmann of Fairfield, CT; a son Andrew L. Fleischmann of Winsted, CT; four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

title: Real Estate Market Is Tough Even for a Kingdom
description: In the annals of relations between the West and Bhutan, a remote Buddhist kingdom in the Himalayas, a vote yesterday by the Manhattan Borough Board may not rank up there with the opening of that country to tourists in 1974 or the debut of its first television network last year.

title: J. G. DURAND INDUSTRIES TO BUY MIKASA FOR $280 MILLION
description: J. G. Durand Industries, the world's largest glass and crystal manufacturer, said it would buy Mikasa, a marketer of dishes, crystal and silverware, for $280 million in cash. Under the terms of the agreement, Mikasa stockholders will receive $16.50 a share in cash, a 69 percent premium to Friday's closing price of $9.75. Durand is the parent company of Verrerie Cristallerie d'Arques, which owns several brands including Cristal d'Arques, J. G. Durand, Luminarc, Arcoroc and Salviati. Mikasa stock is down 17 percent over the last 12 months. Founded in France in 1825, Verrerie Cristallerie d'Arques said it had sales in 1999 of 1 billion euros ($861 million). Mikasa produces dishes, silverware and accessories under the brand names of Mikasa, Studio Nova, Home Beautiful and Christopher Stuart. The company is a marketing and design company that contracts out its production.

title: Bid for Medical Company
description: HEI Inc., a maker of microelectronic devices for medical products, said today it had offered to buy the shares of Colorado MEDtech Inc. it did not own for $12 a share, or about $132.7 million. MEDtech, which makes medical software and products like catheters and respiratory devices, closed today at $9.50. HEI said it owned 9.9 percent of Colorado MEDtech after buying 1.21 million shares today. HEI, based in Victoria, Minn., owned no Colorado MEDtech shares previously.

title: TIME WARNER TO SELL MUSIC ONLINE
description: The Warner Music division of Time Warner said it would sell digital music over the Web, becoming the last of the major music labels to do so. Warner's artists include Barenaked Ladies, Manhattan Transfer and Phil Collins. Wal-Mart said it would sell the music from its Web site next year. (AP)

title: Chase Manhattan Said to Be in Talks to Acquire J.P. Morgan
description: Chase Manhattan is close to reaching a deal to acquire J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc., for $30 billion or more executives close to the deal said today. Details of the negotiations were not immediately available, although these executives said an announcement could come as early as Wednesday morning.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: '''Rats' is not a message. 'Bad plan' or 'seniors lose' might be. But 'rats?' We're just not that clever. I just watched it five times in a row. Hard as I looked, couldn't see 'rats.'''

title: Dropping In on Old Friends, but With a Slightly New Attitude
description: Dance Theater of Harlem's second program in its current season, which continues through Sunday at City Center, is an experiment in rethinking familiar material.

title: Island Insect Trove Could Spur Revival of Mainland Populations
description: Ask people on Martha's Vineyard about insects and they are likely to talk about mosquitoes, no-see-ums and green-headed flies, all of which can make life miserable here. But the island's insect population comprises far more than pests. In fact, entomologists hope to use it to re-establish rare and endangered insect populations wiped out elsewhere in New England years ago.

title: Goldman Sachs to Acquire Top Firm on Trading Floors
description: The Goldman Sachs Group confirmed yesterday that it planned to make its most expensive acquisition to date by paying as much as $7.4 billion to buy Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the biggest trading firm on the floors of the nation's stock and options exchanges.

title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000091290302741163 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Voters Hope Senate Face-Off Clarifies Options
description: Tom Smith is one of many undecided voters counting on the Senate debate tomorrow night to clarify a murky situation. A fusillade of critical advertising by both candidates has angered him, Mr. Smith said, and he remains as confused as ever about the voting record of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican latecomer to the race.

title: Oprah Show Lets Gore Reach Out To Women
description: Oprah Winfrey knew that it might be a rough day at the office. Before introducing Vice President Al Gore to her audience today, television's high priestess of self-revelation told her fans that she had always ''stayed away from politicians'' as guests because she never felt she could have an honest conversation with them. ''After 15 years,'' she said, ''I thought, O.K., I need to try to penetrate that wall.''

title: Bush Pushes Health Plan To Attract Older Voters
description: Gov. George W. Bush told older residents in Florida today that his plans for changing Medicare and providing prescription drug benefits would give them control over their health care, while Vice President Al Gore would give them only ''a government-run'' health maintenance organization.

title: NEW SBC-COVAD AGREEMENT ON DSL
description: Hoping to increase sales of high-speed Internet services, SBC Communications yesterday agreed to pay Covad Communications $600 million over six years for the ability to resell its digital subscriber lines. In addition, SBC will acquire a stake of about 6 percent in Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., for $150 million. Covad also said it would add 30 percent more D.S.L. phone lines than expected this quarter. Simon Romero

title: Mexico Sets Telecommunications Rules
description: Mexican regulators issued new rules aimed at ensuring that operators can compete fairly against Telefonos de Mexico S.A., the country's largest telephone company.

title: McLEAN SPASMS A WORRY
description: If Kirk McLean was not concerned, Coach Ron Low sure was. ''Very much so,'' Low said, after McLean came up with back spasms in the Rangers' camp.

title: Archaeology on Center Stage
description: Last week's most interesting science stories concerned archaeology and this week's were mostly about - archaeology.

title: Chase Is on the Verge of Finishing Deal to Acquire J. P. Morgan
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the third-biggest banking company in the United States, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the most storied banks, for $30.9 billion in stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: City Block Puts Its Thumbs to Work as Crime Busters
description: If a perpetrator on the Upper East Side were to track a woman home late one night, follow her past the Pookie & Sebastian Clothing Boutique on 77th Street and pounce just as she enters her building, then that perpetrator could be in for an unpleasant evening of crime.

title: Cheers for the Boys and Girls of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Unworthy Pandering by Mr. Gore
description: In threatening to aim punitive legislation at the entertainment industry, Vice President Al Gore has crossed a line that no Democratic presidential candidate should ever cross. His party has a tradition of protecting free expression. Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph Lieberman, betray that tradition by advocating what would amount to government censorship.

title: Injury Doesn't Faze Chrebet
description: Wayne Chrebet walked on to the field at Giants Stadium about two hours before kickoff last night in shorts and a T-shirt, a big white wrap from the middle of his left calf down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORCH, CLAIRE
description: LORCH-Claire, on September 9, 2000, at her home. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Lorch, devoted mother of Gloria Nimetz, Leonard Lorch and Evelyn Sabin, loving grandmother of Alexandra Nimetz, Lloyd Nimetz, Jennifer Sabin and Michael Sabin, cherished mother-in-law of Matthew Nimetz and Jeffrey Sabin, adored sister of Al Weil. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 13, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Israel, 140 Central Ave., Lawrence, LI. Contributions may be made to: Selfhelp Community Services Inc., 440 Ninth Ave., NY, NY 10001.

title: Some Say Morgan Lost Independence by Trying to Be True to Founders Goals
description: Nearly a century ago, the House of Morgan and its founder, J. Pierpont Morgan, preserved the American financial system in the midst of a widespread panic.

title: Mountain Storms
description: Q.: Why does there seem to be a thunderstorm in the Rocky Mountains every time I try to have a summer picnic?

title: The Big City; No Rest For an Outlaw In Name Only
description: JOHNNY SANTIAGO, an actor and an owner of Torch, a restaurant on the Lower East Side, has been a wanted man for most of his adult life. His outlaw career began in January 1994, just before his 24th birthday, when he made the mistake of taking a vacation in Italy and returning to Kennedy Airport with a passport bearing his name.

title: Letters: A Hormone Therapy Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Eve of the Olympics the I.O.C. Tries to Polish Its Image
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 12 -- In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal and growing fears that the use of performance-enhancing drugs is widespread, the International Olympic Committee has faced a barrage of new embarrassments this week that raise questions about its ability and resolve to change significantly.

title: Latest Talk About a Ewing Trade Appears to Be Over
description: Like the others before it, the latest Patrick Ewing trade scenario seems to be dying a slow death.

title: British Gas Stations Run Dry, in Crisis Spawned by Protests
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  Britain was gripped by chaos today as more than 6,000 gas stations ran out of fuel following mass blockades of oil refineries and depots across the country.

title: GENZYME TO PURCHASE GELTEX PHARMACEUTICALS
description: The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy GelTex Pharmaceuticals for $1 billion in cash and stock, gaining full control of a dialysis drug. GelTex shareholders will receive 0.7272 share of Genzyme's stock, or $47.50 in cash, for each GelTex share, with the cash portion fixed at $500 million, according to a Genzyme spokesman, Bo Piela. The offer represents a 27 percent premium to GelTex's closing price Friday of $37.38; its shares rose $5.88, to $43.25, yesterday. The deal will give Genzyme full ownership of Renagel, a dialysis treatment it marketed with GelTex .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, SAUL
description: JARCHO-Saul, MD. On September 10, 2000. Survived by his wife, Irma S., his sons, Tom and Andrew, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Also survived by his sister, Grace J. Ross and many nephews and nieces. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 79 PM. Funeral service on Wednesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Academy of Medicine, 1216 5th Ave., NYC 10029 or the National Library of Medicine, 8600 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD.

title: Endangered Treasures
description: To the Editor:

title: Corny Punch Lines but Solid Musicality
description: It's unbelievable that Dan Hicks gets laughs for his one-liners. Like this one, tossed out on Thursday at the Bowery Ballroom, where the singer-songwriter brought his re-formed band, the Hot Licks, for a long-awaited comeback.

title: Democrats See, and Smell, Rats in G.O.P. Ad
description: At first glance, the Republican television commercial on prescription drugs looks like a run-of-the-mill attack advertisement.

title: HUFFY PREDICTS IT WILL SELL 1.5 MILLION SCOOTERS
description: The Huffy Corporation, a maker of bicycles whose shares have almost tripled since June, said it expected to sell at least 1.5 million Micro scooters this year, more than expected. The forecast exceeds the million-unit estimate Huffy gave about a month ago, said Chris Snyder, the president of the Huffy Bicycle Company. Scooters sell for about $99 each at retailers, he said. Demand for the scooters is strong among adults as well as children, Huffy said. The company estimates the market for scooters will surge to $500 million this year from about $5 million to $10 million in 1999.

title: The State vs. the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Feet Stomp, Arms Flap, and Confidence Grows
description: Inside a makeshift locker room, 18 members of the Nubian Gents put on their game faces. Within a few minutes, the serious-looking young men in the black-and-bronze uniforms file into the hushed sanctuary of the Church of God of East Flatbush.

title: I.B.M. SOFTWARE MAY SPEED NETWORKS
description: I.B.M. has brought out software -- a snippet of code under 100 lines long -- that sharply increases the performance of its PowerNP network management microprocessor. The software gives the processor more flexibility in allocating bandwidth priority on computer networks like the Internet. If it works as planned, network operators could segregate and give priority to functions like live video or important business transactions in periods of peak demand. That could eventually allow Internet service providers to charge higher prices for speedier service, much like the Postal Service and Federal Express. Barnaby Feder

title: Montenegro Leaders Balk At Taking On Milosevic
description: The Clinton administration says it worries that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia might move against Montenegro before or after the Yugoslav elections scheduled for Sept. 24.

title: Disparities Are Seen In U.S. Death Penalty
description: In the first official review of the federal death penalty since it was reinstated in 1988, the Justice Department has found troubling disparities by race and geography, according to officials who have seen the report.

title: Congressman Gets Help Of President
description: President Clinton attended a fund-raiser and political rally here today to support the re-election campaign of Representative James H. Maloney, hoping to tip the scales in a tight Congressional race that has drawn intense interest from both major parties nationally.

title: Some Air Bags In 2 Models Are Flawed, G.M. Reports
description: The driver-side air bags on 115 Oldsmobile and Buick cars have inflated spontaneously when the car was started or during normal driving conditions, and 268,000 cars in the 1995 and 1996 model years are vulnerable to the problem, General Motors said yesterday.

title: William W. Quinn, 92, General and Former Intelligence Officer
description: Lt.Gen. William W. Quinn, an intelligence officer during World War II and an infantry commander in the Korean conflict, died today at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 92.

title: Triathlon Tries to Shed Its Extreme Image
description: Whether you make the pilgrimage by way of Circular Quay or by way of the Royal Botanic Gardens, the Sydney Opera House, with its jutting shells, is the first-day objective of most tourists here.

title: Pennsylvania Launches Competition for "Digital School District" Funding
description: In an effort to spur innovation, maximize buying power and concentrate technology resources, officials in Pennsylvania have launched a statewide competition to create two cutting-edge digital school districts.

title: Fashion Week: One for the Money, Two for the Show; On Seventh Ave., the Buzz, the Ropes and the Seams
description: If every Seventh Avenue building is a hive of activity before Fashion Week, then 550 Seventh Avenue is certainly the home of the queen bees. Michael Kors has his studio there. So do Donna Karan and Oscar de la Renta. But just because everyone is working in close proximity doesn't mean that anyone knows the buzz.

title: Lazio's Education Proposal: $97.7 Billion Over 10 Years
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio tonight proposed spending $97.75 billion on education over 10 years if elected senator, with a substantial amount devoted to disabled students and programs to make teachers more accountable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, EUGENE E.
description: KENNY-Eugene E. Died at the age of 86 on September 9, 2000 at his home in Manhasset, NY. Gene was born in Manhattan and raised in Brooklyn. Loving husband of Ursula. Cherished father of Constance, Eugene and Michael. Dear brother of Margaret Butler. He graduated Manhattan College in 1937. Gene joined the NYC fire Dept and rose through the ranks to Battalion Chief. In 1958 he was awarded the William Todd Memorial Medal for Valor. He served as a naval officer in Pearl Harbor in WW II. After retiring from the Fire Dept in 1965 he joined the real estate firm of Helmsley Spear Inc. where he bacame a Vice President, retiring in 1994. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Friday, St. Marys R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Donations would be appreciated to A.C.L.D. Adults and Children with Learning and Developmental disabilities, 807 S. Oyster Bay Road, Bethpage, New York 11714.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNIK, DINAH
description: RESNIK-Dinah. Sutton Place Synagogue extends condolences to our devoted members, Richard, Elise, Dara and Samantha Resnik on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother. May they be comforted by their cherished memories. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: At Indiana, Players Dig In Over Firing of Knight
description: Indiana University's campus in Bloomington was rainy and calm yesterday after a night of angry demonstrations over Bob Knight's ouster as basketball coach and threats against the student whose accusations were a factor in Knight's dismissal.

title: Unknowns Nag After Fires Near Atomic Sites
description: Fires in and around nuclear facilities understandably make people nervous. So this has been an unnerving summer in parts of the American West, where some of the wildfires that ravaged millions of acres also scorched several major nuclear complexes in New Mexico, Washington, Colorado and Idaho.

title: Soaring Prices of Oil Roil U.S. and Europe
description: Despite the decision over the weekend by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase crude oil production, the price of home heating oil in the United States surged to a 10-year high, and alarm over gasoline costs erupted in panic buying and demonstrations across Western Europe.

title: PANEL DOCUMENTS HOW VIOLENT FARE IS AIMED AT YOUTH
description: Deploring what it called the ''pervasive and aggressive marketing'' of violent entertainment to children, the Federal Trade Commission said today that the vast majority of the best-selling restricted movies, music and video games were deliberately marketed to children as young as 12.

title: Domingo Giving Coast Opera A Burst of Hollywood Magic
description: Richard Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle'' is meeting ''Star Wars.''

title: National News Briefs; Atlanta Transit Allows Ads on Abortion Rights
description: Advertisements supporting abortion rights began appearing in subway stations and bus shelters in Atlanta this week under an agreement between the transit authority and the National Abortion Federation. But they will be the last noncommercial advertisements in the transit system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, IRENE
description: EPSTEIN-Irene. On September 11, 2000 at age 105. Beloved aunt and great aunt, and great, great aunt. Services today 5:30 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Economic Talks Open Minus 200 Delegates : Demonstrators Harass Melbourne Conference
description: MELBOURNE  At least eight people, including five police officers, were injured in clashes Monday when protesters disrupted an international business meeting by stopping some political and business leaders from attending.

title: Monarch Butterflies Lose Much of Their Wintering Grounds
description: Over the past 20 years, biologists have voiced increasing concern about the monarch butterfly's most threatened and critical habitat, a single stretch of Mexican forest to which hundreds of millions of these butterflies migrate from the United States each year to spend the winter. Yet in spite of intense interest in this region, which is thought to be the species' Achilles' heel, little had been known about how these forests were actually faring.

title: Johannesburg Journal; South Africa's New Poor: White and Bewildered
description: Martin van Niekerk wakes with a start and his sleepy blue eyes wander lazily from the fraying curtains fluttering over the window to the sagging ceiling and the shabby walls lined with brown cardboard. And then he remembers.

title: Shot-Putter Pulls Out
description: C. J. Hunter, the reigning world champion in the shot-put and the husband of the sprinter Marion Jones, became the latest in a growing number of athletes to withdraw from the Sydney Olympics today, a week after undergoing surgery on torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; A Village Visited Often by Alzheimer's
description: An Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease suggests that a recessive gene plays a role in the condition, one that must be carried by both parents to take effect, according to a new study in the journal Neurology.

title: Annan Meets With West Africans Over Sierra Leone Crisis
description: As the Security Council prepared to expand the United Nations' peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone, Secretary General Kofi Annan met today with a group of nine West African countries to coordinate efforts to resolve the crisis created by a brutal insurgency.

title: Buchanan Hoping for Political Lift to Rival Physical One
description: With his ''pitchfork brigades'' gone the way of his gall bladder, Patrick J. Buchanan, the persistent presidential candidate, was feeling well on the mend from surgery today when his doorbell rang and he was greeted with another subpoena from the tireless antagonists he has stirred in the Reform Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DAVID W.
description: LEWIS-David W. Of Oradell, NJ on September 10, 2000. Graduated Cornell University in 1929. A vicepresident for Bankers Trust Company from 1934-1973. Husband of the late Eleanore Brett Lewis. Father of Patricia Bodnar and Eleanore M. Lewis. Grandfather of Kevin Bodnar and Allison Patterson. Funeral Service Wednesday, 8 PM at Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Oradell, NJ. Interment Mount Olivet Cemetery, Kenmore, NY. Visiting Wed, 2-4/7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to National Tuberous Sclerosis Association, 8181 Professional Pl., Suite 110, Landover, MD. 20785-2226.

title: For Toronto, Film Festival Is Its Passion
description: On the opening day of the 25th Toronto International Film Festival, a sunny and muggy Thursday afternoon, a minor miracle took place. At the corner of Bay and Bloor Streets, by the Varsity Theater, a festival site, a sprinkle of water fell to offer relief from the irritating heat.

title: Madison Square Garden Names Executive
description: Seth Abraham, who helped officiate at the profitable marriage of boxing and cable television during two decades at Time Warner and its subsidiary Home Box Office, has been named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Madison Square Garden.

title: Sports of The Times; Amid Bumps and Spikes, A Labor of Friendship
description: ON a gorgeous morning at Bondi Beach, two solitary figures stepped inside the 10,000 seat arena built for Olympic beach volleyball competition. They stood and looked.

title: New Homes for the 'Charters of Freedom'; A Challenge for the Engineers: Protect the Documents but Display Them Too
description: After more than five years of concerns and planning, the first of a new set of cases to protect the original United States Constitution and other key national documents is ready to replace older encasements that have begun to break down.

title: Undoing the Damage of the Wen Ho Lee Case
description: The case of Wen Ho Lee is coming to an end, with the government backing off on virtually all the accusations against him. But the underlying problems of the case are unlikely to disappear once it is resolved, and the government must rethink how it deals with the central conflict between democratic principles and national security.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH Dianne Murphy; Trying to End Guesswork In Dosing Children
description: Many parents might be surprised to learn that most of the drugs prescribed for children, from allergy relievers to asthma inhalants and antidepressants, have never been formally tested on children. Starting this December, however, a new Food and Drug Administration rule mandates that any new adult drug that could be used by children with the same disease must undergo pediatric study, and its manufacturers must list doses for children on the label. In addition, if an adult drug already on the market has the potential to help children with the same disease, or if it is widely used in children and the absence of labeling seems dangerous, the F.D.A. can require pediatric tests.

title: Web Site Offers Cartoons That Interact, With Feeling
description: In an effort to fuse entertainment, education and artificial intelligence, a company in Newton, Mass., is starting a Web site of interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion.

title: The Money Is Flying Over Guam
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- WHERE is everybody?

title: Leave of Absence Taken at Fitzgerald
description: Jim Paddock, executive vice president and chief creative officer at Fitzgerald & Company in Atlanta, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is taking a one-year leave of absence, the agency said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SIDNEY MATTHEW
description: WEISS-Sidney Matthew, 91. Died early on Monday at Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, Connecticut, after a brief illness. A pioneer advertising executive, Mr. Weiss is survived by his devoted wife Sylvia and son Charles, both of Greenwich. He is also survived by a sister, Selma Bettin of La Jolla, California. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT.

title: Missing Flag Returns to Glory, Courtesy of a Prankster
description: Harry Prieste took the dare. Challenged by his friend, the swimmer Duke Kahanamoku, Prieste shinnied up a 15-foot flagpole at the end of the 1920 Summer Olympics in Antwerp, Belgium, and stole the official flag. The Irish linen flag came home with Prieste to Los Angeles, the fruit of his athletic prank and further evidence of his presence at the seventh Summer Olympiad, where he won the bronze medal in platform diving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HELEN
description: SHAPIRO-Helen (Crown). On September 10, 2000. of Providence, RI. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Shapiro. Devoted mother of Judith Greenblatt of Providence, Susan Prohafsky, Indiana. Adored grandmother of 7. Great grandmother of two. A graveside service will be held on (today) Tues at 1:00 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Says Pesticide Spraying Victim Was Right
description: After reprimanding a woman doused by pesticides for not paying more attention to the city's spraying schedule, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani corrected himself yesterday, saying that the city had in fact been spraying in the woman's area without warning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RUTH
description: EPSTEIN-Ruth. Yeshiva University & its Stern College for Women are saddened by the passing of a dear friend, a highly respected leader of the Jewish community who was a member of the SCW Board of Directors for over a decade. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Epstein, she was a YU Guardian and established the Ruth Epstein Scholarship Fund at Stern College. The Stern Board honored her at its inaugural dinner in 1988 for her dedication to the advancement of Jewish education-a legacy she has passed to her four children, all YU alumni. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Martin (and Gloria) Epstein, Gilbert (and Marion) Epstein, Stewart (and Judith) Epstein, and Gloria (and Laurence) Gordon; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Marjorie Diener Blenden, Chairman,SCW Board of Directors

title: Article 2000091293886058130 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Prime-Time Politics, Ready or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: PSA Shares Drop in Mistaken-Identity Case
description: Sometimes two companies can have the same name, and sometimes news services can make mistakes.

title: Primary Day in New York Features the First Lady on Her First Ballot
description: Around New York today, voters cast ballots in a handful of contested local elections.

title: Sinking in Venice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, MARIE GAFFNEY
description: BARRY-Marie Gaffney, 81. Of New Canaan, died Sepember 7, 2000. Born October 22, 1918 in Binghamton, NY. Daughter of the late Ray and Mary Gaffney. Aunt of David Gaffney, Hamilton, Mass., Phillip Gaffney Madison, NJ, James Gaffney, Pennington, NJ. Service will be held Thursday, September 14, 11AM in the First Presbyterian Church, New Canaan. Contributions to the charity of ones choice or the Jr. League of Stamford-Norwalk, 748 Post Road, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: Prison and Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Loaves And Wishes
description: My wife was buying groceries at the Giant supermarket shortly after Al Gore chose Joe Lieberman as his running mate. It was a Friday, and as the checkout lady bagged my wife's groceries, she was left at the end with two breads -- one a Sabbath challah and the other a Roman Meal sandwich loaf. The checkout lady picked up the two breads, put them in a bag together, looked at my wife with a little smile and said: ''I think the Roman Meal and challah can go together, don't you?''

title: Rockland Democratic Leader Arrested on Corruption Charges
description: The chairman of the Democratic Party organization in Rockland County was charged today with public corruption after prosecutors said he had enriched himself by almost $375,000 through a series of real estate transactions tainted by fraud, bribery and extortion.

title: Technology Briefings
description: DIGITAL I.B.M. SOFTWARE MAY SPEED NETWORKS I.B.M. has brought out software  a snippet of code under 100 lines long  that sharply increases the performance of its PowerNP network management microprocessor. The software gives the processor more flexibility in allocating bandwidth priority on computer networks like the Internet. If it works as planned, network operators could segregate and give priority to functions like live video or important business transactions in periods of peak demand. That could eventually allow Internet service providers to charge higher prices for speedier service, much like the Postal Service and Federal Express. Barnaby Feder (NYT) FLEET TO OFFER VISA `SMART CARD' FleetBoston Financial , one of the nation's biggest banks, plans to announce today that it will offer a Visa credit card with a microchip that can store account information and can be used, with a swipe through a magnetic-stripe reader, to make purchases on the Internet. The card, named Fusion, will be available starting next Monday and will be the first mass-produced "smart card" to carry the Visa brand in the United States, said Joseph Saunders, chief executive of Fleet's credit card operations. The card's chip will keep track of credit balances, frequent-flier miles and other data, he said. American Express has issued a Blue card meant for electronic purchases, but for the most part, American consumers have been slower than those in Europe and Japan to accept smart cards. Patrick McGeehan (NYT) DEALS SAUDI INVESTS $50 MILLION MORE IN PRICELINE Priceline.com said Prince Walid bin Talal, a nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, planned to invest $50 million in the Internet service that lets consumers bid for items like airline tickets and hotel rooms. The prince will purchase a forward contract to buy two million shares at $25 each from company's founder, Jay Walker, above. The prince also invested $50 million in the company in May. The latest agreement also calls for the prince to receive warrants from Mr. Walker to buy an unspecified stake in Walker Digital , which makes the software Priceline.com uses. (Bloomberg News) NEW SBC-COVAD AGREEMENT ON DSL Hoping to increase sales of high-speed Internet services, SBC Communications yesterday agreed to pay Covad Communications $600 million over six years for the ability to resell its digital subscriber lines. In addition, SBC will acquire a stake of about 6 percent in Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., for $150 million. Covad also said it would add 30 percent more D.S.L. phone lines than expected this quarter. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Primary Day Today
description: Today is primary day in New York and Connecticut.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: PHARMACEUTICALS ACQUISITION
description: The Dublinbased drugmaker the Elan Corporation acquired Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc. of San Diego, for $1.8 billion in stock, paying 0.6715 of an Elan A.D.R. for each Dura share. The purchase, Elan's third acquisition this year, raises its North American sales force to more than 1,000. Dura's antibiotics and its Spiros brand of inhaler had sales of $301 million in 1999. The products will broaden Elan's offerings, which are now focused on painkillers and treatments for breast cancer and Alzheimer's disease. Brian Lavery

title: Article 2000091292385926439 -- No Title
description: E-COMMERCE REPORT

title: Added Sugars Are Taking a Toll on Health
description: The Sugar Association is trying to convince Americans that consuming large quantities of sugar-sweetened soft drinks and snacks does not harm one's nutritional status, body weight or long-term health. But the research the association cites to support its contentions shows how statistics can often be misleading if they present only part of the story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, BERNARD E.
description: SINGER-Bernard E. On September 10, 2000. Amongst his many accomplishments in the field of law and his humanitarian efforts, he was past President of B'nai B'rith Harrison chapter. Devoted husband of Rose. Beloved father of Henry and Amy Singer, Elizabeth and Dennis Hevey, Margery and Steven Honig. Adoring grandfather to Priscilla and Jamie Halper, Andrew and Nancy Singer, Stefanie & Brad Ebner & Lauren Singer, Gillian and Jennifer Mosely and Casey and Jillian Honig. Cherished great-grandfather to Paige, Maxwell, Matthew, Adam, Daniel, Sabrina, Brooke, Alexa, Grant and Samantha. Pop Pop Bernie will be missed by everyone whose life he touched. Services Tuesday, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ESSAY; In Wake of Genetic Revolution, Questions About Its Meaning
description: Labor Day has come and gone, and I am chagrined to find that I haven't made it through my summer reading. My list comprised only a single book, but a rather unusual one: the text is three billion years old, has six billion copies in print, runs three billion letters long (about one million pages), and is written entirely in four characters (A, T, C, G) with no spaces or punctuation. The book, of course, is a great classic, The Sequence of the Human Genome.

title: ALBANIA JOINS TRADE GROUP
description: Albania has become the 138th member of the World Trade Organization, eight years after it applied to join. Mike Moore, director of the Geneva-based global trade group, said the accession of the formerly Communist-ruled country means the W.T.O. can ''help foster greater peace, stability and development in southeastern Europe.'' Albania was one of the last redoubts of orthodox Communism until 1992, when it was transformed by elections and free-market economic changes. But Albania remains one of the smallest and weakest countries in the region, hurt by years of isolation and proximity to the armed conflicts in the Balkans. Elizabeth Olson

title: PROFIT UP AT TARGET OF CEMENT TAKEOVER
description: A leading building materials manufacturer, Blue Circle P.L.C. of Britain, reported a 14 percent rise in profits for the first half of the year, to $:125.8 million, or about $179 million, helped by cost- cutting and a recovery in Asia. But the results were hurt by the company's extensive spending to thwart a hostile takeover by a French rival, Lafarge S.A. Blue Circle's chief executive, Rick Haythornthwaite, had persuaded investors to reject Lafarge's takeover offer in May, telling them that Blue Circle, which makes about half the cement used in Britain, was better off independent. Suzanne Kapner

title: Seybourn Lynne, 93; Ruled in Civil Rights Case
description: Seybourn H. Lynne, the federal judge who in 1963 prohibited Gov. George C. Wallace from barring two black students from attending the University of Alabama, died on Sunday in Birmingham. He was 93 and was the longest serving active judge on the federal bench.

title: Metro Business; Defense Contract for DRS
description: DRS Technologies Inc., a maker of electronic defense systems, won a $2.2 million contract to develop an infrared targeting system on tanks for the United States Marine Corps.

description: But where were they?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETZFELD, ROBERT
description: GETZFELD-Robert, 74. Died on September 10th, 2000. Devoted husband to Paula, father to Lisa and Andrew. Adoring grandfather to Emily, father-in-law to Gabby and Ken, loving brother to Florence. You will always be remembered for your wisdom, strength of character, & generous, energetic spirit. Services were held Monday, September 11 at Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: School Report Sees Flaws In Teaching of English
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he had ordered community school district superintendents to stop switching non-English-speaking students between bilingual and English-as-a-second-language classes because doing so could can stunt their academic growth.

title: The Beat Fit, So a Brazilian Still Wears It
description: Since he started his career nearly 40 years ago, the Brazilian singer Jorge Ben Jor has gone through a few deep stylistic changes.

title: Consolidation Changes Industrys Face
description: Ageneration ago, six major commercial banks dominated the financial world in New York, which itself was the financial capital of the world's largest economy.

description: BECKER-John M. Of Mamaroneck, NY on September 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Alice, devoted father of Scott and Robin. Loving grandfather of Meghan Jerrild. Memorial service Saturday, September 16 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Mamaroneck, NY at 11 o'clock AM. Contributions in his memory to Mystic Seaport, P.O. Box 6000, Mystic, CT. 06355.

title: Flashbulbs and Interviews Are Safin's New Companions
description: Marat Safin rubbed his glassy hazel eyes yesterday afternoon, attacked by a barrage of flashbulbs for what seemed like the four billionth time since he won the United States Open only 17 hours earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, WALTER J.
description: MURPHY-Walter J. The Board of Directors and Staff of The National Counsel on Alcholism and Drug Dependence, Inc, mourn the passing of Walter Murphy, a former Executive Director, and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Debbie, and family. Walter dedicated his later life to fighting the stigma associated with addiction and will forever be remembered for his role in ''Operation Understanding'', a watershed event in the nation's capital, when more than fifty prominent individuals publicly acknowledged their recovery from alcoholism. Gorden Steinhauer, Chair Stacia Murphy, President

title: The Euro Falls Below 86 cents; Lack of Intervention Cited
description: The euro fell to still another low against the dollar yesterday as traders and investors concluded that the European Central Bank would not soon intervene in the markets to buy the currency and lend it support.
