description: * Toshiba America Consumer Products, Wayne, N.J., to Towne Silverstein Rotter, New York, to handle its strategic, creative and media account, which had been at Ferrell Calvillo Communications, New York. Spending was estimated at $15 million.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Less Pacifier Use, Fewer Ear Infections
description: Saving the pacifier for when a baby is trying to fall asleep may cut down on ear infections, a new study from Finland has concluded.

title: Prenatal Nutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTATOS, MATHILDE
description: CHRISTATOS-Mathilde. Died on Sept. 6, 2000 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Robert. Private service was held at Kensico Cemetery. Donations can be made in her name to the Metropolitan Opera Association or The N.Y. Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Pervasive Disparities Found In the Federal Death Penalty
description: In the first comprehensive review of the federal death penalty since it was reinstated in 1988, the Justice Department has found significant racial and geographical disparities, say officials who have seen the report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRACCIANO, ALEXANDRA
description: TERRACCIANO - Alexandra Flowerton. Age 100, on Saturday September 9, 2000, in Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved wife of the late Baron Guglielmo Terracciano, of Naples, Italy, survived by niece Nina Foch, of Beverly Hills, CA, and a grand nephew, Dirk Dewell. Memorial services to be announced. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHARDT, WALTER
description: STEINHARDT-Walter. Beloved husband of Minna. Devoted father of Louis (Nadine) and Phillip (Diane). Cherished grandfather of Michael, Jay, Casey and Andrew. Services today 1PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: Kerik Says He Wants to Reward Hardest-Working Officers
description: Bernard B. Kerik, the city's new police commissioner, said yesterday that his changes in the department since taking office had been part of a larger plan to create an incentive system by which the most active officers would be rewarded for hard work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMLE, LEO
description: LEMLE-Leo. The Trustees, Museum Council and Staff of The Jewish Museum are deeply saddened by the passing of a longtime friend, generous supporter and member of the Museum Council, Leo Lemle. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Gertrude, an active member of the Volunteer Association, their son Robert and daughter Laura, and the entire Lemle family. His enthusiastic encouragement and vital spirit will be greatly missed. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Joan Rosenbaum, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Director

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SELLS CHLORASEPTIC TO PRESTIGE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's leading maker of household products, said yesterday that it had sold its Chloraseptic line of sore-throat remedies to the closely held Prestige Brands International as it sheds smaller brands. Terms were not disclosed. While Chloraseptic is the top-selling sore-throat spray and also sells lozenges, its sales pale compared with Procter's billion-dollar product lines like Tide detergent and Charmin tissue, said a company spokesman, Bryan McCleary. Prestige Brands has contracted with Procter & Gamble to continue to manufacture the products, he said.

title: Chrebet Returns From Injury to Hurt Patriots
description: The pleasantries of this family feud had been dispensed with early tonight, the back slaps and handshakes exchanged among the eternally intertwined teams. But then the muscling began, and the Jets showed that the end of the Tuna Bowl era may not mean the end of this passionate rivalry.

title: Documents Indicate Ford Knew Of Engine Defect but Was Silent
description: When thousands of car owners complained in the 1980's and 1990's that their Fords unexpectedly stalled, often on highways and while making left turns across oncoming traffic, top company executives repeatedly assured regulators that there was no way to know what might be causing the problem.

title: Poll Shows Gore Overcoming Voter Concerns on Likability
description: Vice President Al Gore has shaken the persistent sense that he is not particularly likable and is now as highly regarded as Gov. George W. Bush on matters of character, leadership and overall personal popularity, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: E-ZPass Nears Debut on New Jersey Turnpike
description: After a two-and-a-half-year delay and $16 million in cost overruns, electronic tolls will make a debut later this month on the New Jersey Turnpike, one of the nation's most heavily used roadways, officials announced today.

title: Tennis Star Puts Russia In Heaven
description: In a country where there are but two sports soccer, and everything else -- Russians were positively glowing with pride today over the athletic prowess of 20-year-old Marat Safin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLINGHAM, MARIE
description: DILLINGHAM-Marie. Of North Chelmsford, MA., Sept. 10. Beloved wife of Charles Yassemedis. Loving mother of Walter Dillingham of Forest Hills Gardens, N.Y., John Dillingham of New York City, Joan Cody of Burlington, MA, and Carol Tagliaferri of Andover, MA. Funeral from the Sullivan Funeral Home, 43 Winn Street, Burlington, MA., 781-272-0050.

title: On the Eve of the Olympics the I.O.C. Trys to Polish Its Image
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 12 -- In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal and growing fears that the use of performance-enhancing drugs is widespread, the International Olympic Committee has faced a barrage of new embarrassments this week that raise questions about its ability and resolve to change significantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBONS, MICHAEL J.
description: GIBBONS-Michael J., Jr. On September 10, 2000, of Staten Island, N.Y., formerly of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Beloved son of Maureen (nee Gallagher) and Michael J. Dear brother of F. Kelly (Jeanine), Theresa A. (Alexander Furman), Justin P. (Melissa), Ashley C. and Trevor B. Gibbons. Loving uncle of Conor, Jack, and Alexander Gibbons. We will remember him with love, and we will love him always. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. today only 2-4, 79 PM. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral Wednesday 11 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, N.Y. Family requests in lieu of flowers, friends may make donations to Daytop Village, Inc., 54 W. 40th St., NYC 10018 or to Mt. Manresa Retreat House, 239 Fingerboard Road, Staten Island, N.Y. 10305

title: Many big brand names steer clear of the 'Dr. Laura' show.
description: THE premiere episode of the Dr. Laura Schlessinger syndicated television series, which ran across the country yesterday, clearly suffered from a summer's worth of protests by gay and lesbian activists as well-known advertisers mostly shunned the show.

title: Cheers for the Boys and Girls of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGILL, ANN ROWE
description: McGILL-Ann Rowe. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of Ann Rowe McGill, the wife of our late former President, William J. McGill. Columbia University pays tribute to her memory and extends its profound sympathy to her daughter, Mrs. Thomas B. (Rowena) Springer, her son, William R. McGill, and her two grandsons. George Rupp, President of the University Stephen Friedman, Chair of the Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WICKS, LUCY A.
description: WICKS-Lucy A. Born March 20, 1951; died September 9, 2000, from breast cancer. She was a skilled clinical psychologist and enthusiastic education activist, as well as an artist, spiritual seeker, devoted wife and mother and loving friend. Memorial donations may be made to the Friends of the Manhattan School for Children, 154 West 93rd St., New York, NY 10025. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, September 16, at 8 P.M., at Paul's Chapel on Columbus University Campus, 116th Street and Broadway.

title: Efforts to Test Drugs on Children Hasten Drive for Research Guidelines
description: Researchers give a 6-year-old girl who suffers from asthma attacks a promising new drug in addition to her old medicine, then withdraw it to see how she will do without it. A depressed teenager enrolls in a study for an antidepressant, but does not know if he will get a sugar pill or the real thing. The parents of an epileptic youngster enroll her in a test of a new drug that has worked well in adults. But no one knows whether she will get the new medication, or the one that has worked only moderately well for her in the past.

title: A Trend on the Sidewalks, and in the E.R.
description: Lots of youngsters are zipping down sidewalks and darting through the streets on shiny, foot-propelled scooters, the must-have sports item for the under-15 set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, JOHN WRIGHT
description: BARRY-John Wright, MD. Died September 8th. Attending physician at North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove for 36 years and beloved community member. Survived by sons Stephen & Peter, daughter Lynn Barry Hyson, and grandson Sean Hyson. Mass Thursday, September 14th, 11AM, St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dr. Barry's name to North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove.

title: Out From the Shadows of the Imperial Mystique
description: For anyone who has read his new biography of the Japanese emperor Hirohito, Herbert P. Bix, cuts an almost jarringly unassuming figure.

title: Group Founded by Sun Myung Moon Preaches Sexual Abstinence in China
description: For several years now, a small New York-based foundation has aggressively spread its conservative message in China: sex before marriage is immoral, fidelity in marriage is essential and abstinence is the only way to prevent AIDS.

title: Prime-Time Politics, Ready or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite OPEC Decision, Home Heating Oil Reaches 10-Year High
description: The price of home heating oil surged to a 10-year high yesterday as traders discounted the impact of a decision over the weekend by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase crude oil production by 800,000 barrels a day.

title: Giuliani Criticizes Lazio Over Arafat Handshake
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it was a mistake for Representative Rick A. Lazio to have enthusiastically shaken the hand of Yasir Arafat during a visit to the Middle East nearly two years ago.

title: Financial Trouble-Shooter Named New Chief at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has named Alan J. Lacy, a financial trouble-shooter, to succeed Arthur C. Martinez as president and chief executive, effective Oct. 1.

title: MERIDIAN INSURANCE BOARD VOTES TO REJECT HOSTILE BID
description: The Meridian Insurance Group said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected a hostile $157 million takeover bid from a minority shareholder, saying the offer did not reflect the company's value. The decision by the property-casualty insurer blocks the latest overture from Gregory M. Shepard, who owns 1.6 million Meridian shares. Mr. Shepard's offer valued Meridian at $20 a share. Meridian's chief executive, Norma J. Oman, said the board concluded that the offer did not reflect the company's true value. Ms. Oman also said the Meridian Mutual Insurance Company, Meridian's largest shareholder, as well as the company's officers and directors, were unwilling to tender their shares. Meridian Mutual owns 49 percent of Meridian.

title: Police Name Suspect in 11 Subway Robberies
description: The police are looking for a man who they say has been robbing women at knife-point on subway trains in Brooklyn and Manhattan for the last six weeks.

title: Ebersol Is the One Who Decides What Will Be Seen From Sydney
description: When the Olympics come to American television Friday, the maestro overseeing the five-hour nightly extravaganza will be Dick Ebersol.

title: The Peace That's Within Our Grasp
description: United Nations meetings are famous for accomplishing nothing concrete, and some observers have cited last week's millennium forum as a prime example. Still, Secretary General Kofi Annan could rightly claim that he gained a measure of support for one of his most ambitious and controversial proposals: that the United Nations regularly intervene in civil wars when the human stakes are high. President Clinton came as close as he has come to endorsing the idea, and other leaders embraced, in vaguer terms, a toughened U.N. role in imploding states.

title: Tough Message From Annan Opens U.N. Assembly Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 12 -- Buoyed by support from world leaders last week for policies that would take the United Nations in new directions, Secretary General Kofi Annan delivered a tough message today to the opening session of this year's General Assembly debating season.

title: A Vanishing Security Case
description: The criminal investigation and prosecution of Wen Ho Lee, which largely collapsed last weekend with his agreement to plead guilty to a single felony count, must be reviewed by an independent examiner to determine if racial profiling or other unfair tactics were used by the government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, GUY
description: ROBBINS-Guy, M.D. On Sept. 9, 2000. He was widower of Louise, father of Kirk, Kathy and Richard, grandfather of Holly, Clifford and Vivian. He devoted his medical career to the treatment and cure of breast cancer. A former chief of the Breast Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, and consultant at numerous hospitals in the greater metropolitan area. Also active in politics in Westport, Connecticut, where he raised his family. He will be sorely missed by his family, patients, neighbors and all the other people whose lives he touched. Contributions may be made to Memorial Hospital or Northwestern University.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHOENIX INVESTMENT PARTNERS LTD., Hartford, said it had accepted a $296 million offer from Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Co., Hartford, to buy the shares in the asset manager that it did not already own.

title: INSIDE
description: Unusual Alliance in China

description: NEW YORK

title: Separate Lives
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A 'Survivor' on Mir
description: Perhaps the most daring reality show of all now looks as if it will become a reality.

title: Report Faults Federal Web Sites on Privacy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Most federal Web sites do not meet the commercial standards for Internet privacy set by the Federal Trade Commission, including the commission's own site, a new government report has found.

title: U.S. and Lawyers for Scientist Battle Over Plea Deal
description: The government and defense lawyers continued their 11th-hour battle today over how to interpret a plea agreement in which Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist, has admitted to one count of improperly downloading nuclear secrets in return for his freedom.

title: ULCER DRUG WORKS IN TRIALS
description: Human Genome Sciences said yesterday that its drug for wound healing had accelerated the repair of chronic venous ulcers in an early Phase 2 clinical trial. The drug, repifermin, is a natural human protein and is believed to be the first drug discovered using genomics that has shown effectiveness in a randomized clinical trial. In a test of 94 patients, 63 percent of patients who received the high dose and 71 percent who got the low dose achieved 75 percent wound closure after 12 weeks, compared with 45 percent of the patients who got a placebo. Andrew Pollack

title: A Spread That Betters Butter and Oil
description: IT seems no one expects butter at the table in an Italian restaurant these days. Balsamic vinegar or olive oil is the typical spread for bread, and the best it gets is with a basil infusion.

title: A Deal Built on Weakness, and Strength
description: A generation ago, six major commercial banks dominated the financial world in New York, which itself was the financial capital of the world's largest economy.

title: Lazio and Hillary Clinton Clash on Donations, Taxes and Trust
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 13  Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio slashed into each other for nearly 60 minutes on national television tonight, attacking each other's credentials, integrity and political views. Near the debate's end, Mr. Lazio walked over to the first lady, waving a piece of paper at her, and unsuccessfully challenged her to sign a pledge, on stage, to renounce the use of soft money in her campaign.

title: Bordeaux Edges Closer to the Napa Valley
description: FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA marked his 25th anniversary in the wine business on Saturday with a daylong party at his Niebaum-Coppola Winery here. The festivities included a dinner with vintages of his prestigious Rubicon red wine dating back to 1978, served in magnums, followed by a screening of his film ''One From the Heart.''

title: Ground Game Gives Receivers Wide-Open Spaces
description: In the final minute of the first half on Sunday, Amani Toomer started from the Eagles' 25-yard line, slanting from the line of scrimmage toward the center of the Philadelphia defense. As the defenders peered toward the Giants' backfield and their suddenly dangerous running attack, and they spied Kerry Collins pumping his arm once, Toomer sailed toward the end zone all alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, EUGENE F.
description: WEISS-Eugene F. Passed away September 11, 2000 in his 94th year. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn B. Devoted father of Bruce, Joshua and Doris. Loving grandfather of Charles, Rodney, Andrew, Meredith, Stephanie and Matthew and great-grandfather of Jaden. Cherished brother of Milton. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Bway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30 AM today. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: With Sympathy For the Devil, A Rock Writer Finds His Way
description: The power of popular music -- its ability to give shape, meaning and intensity to the inexpressible emotions of daily life -- is something of a motif in Cameron Crowe's career as a director. Think of John Cusack hoisting his boombox aloft outside Ione Skye's window in ''Say Anything'' or Tom Cruise hurtling down the highway in ''Jerry Maguire,'' spinning the radio dial in search of a song to suit his mood and happening upon Tom Petty's ''Free Falling.'' Mr. Crowe has always used rock not merely as soundtrack decoration but also as a window into the souls of his characters.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Landlord and Tenant in Fatal Shooting Had Feuded for Decades
description: She was a school librarian with a knack for nurturing students who were learning English at the Chinatown elementary school where she had worked since 1967. She lived in the same apartment for more than 30 years, although her colleagues remembered that she often spoke of problems with her landlord.

title: Mourning and Teammates Battle Legacy
description: PENRITH Australia -- Alonzo Mourning acknowledged today what his teammates already know: getting motivated to annihilate other inferior basketball nations is hard work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISS, PEARL
description: PREISS-Pearl. Beloved wife of Edmund. Devoted mother of Byron & Sandi. Loving grandmother of Karah and Blaire. Darling sister of Thelma and David. A fighter. Service 11 AM today, Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51 Street, NYC. Shiva observed at 50 Sutton Place South, #

title: Fuel Standoff in Britain Eases, but Supply Still Short
description: LONDON Sept. 13 -- Fuel tankers resumed limited deliveries from picketed refineries and storage depots Wednesday, but the crack in the siege that has left almost all the country's filling stations dry was doing little to restore the normality that Prime Minister Tony Blair has promised British motorists.

title: Fried Veggies? Something's in the Oven
description: THE all-fat-is-bad theory of eating has gone the way of the grapefruit diet, but the calories-do-count theory is still with us. And that leaves fried foods where they have always been, generally out of reach for those who would prefer not to gain weight. Still, the results of perfect deep frying are hard to resist: most people prefer a plateful of French fries to boiled potatoes.

title: AOL TAKES STAKE IN CYBIKO
description: America Online has invested in Cybiko, Inc., a Bloomingdale, Ill.-based maker of Palmlike hand-held devices aimed at teenage consumers. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Don Wisniewski, president of Cybiko, said that as a result AOL had become a ''significant shareholder'' in the company. The two companies have also agreed to work together to give users of the Cybiko devices access to AOL features like Instant Messaging. Catherine Greenman

title: Dishes for an Emperor at Every Meal
description: GRAND SICHUAN INTERNATIONAL in Chelsea not only prepares excellent and authentic Sichuan food but also goes to extraordinary lengths to explain the cuisine's finer points to Americans. Now, it has opened a branch uptown in Clinton, which is great news for lovers of Chinese food.

title: LENDERS IN TAX BATTLE
description: A group representing Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Sumitomo Bank and other Japanese banks said it would sue the Tokyo metropolitan government or its governor over a new tax on the lenders. The Japan Bankers Association, which represents 248 lenders, said it would prepare a lawsuit on behalf of 21 of its largest members this month. Banks say a new tax violates local tax laws and the Constitution as the city is only aiming at major banks. ''We are filing a lawsuit against Tokyo as its new tax plan violates the principle of fairness in the Japanese Constitution,'' said Mamoru Mitsuhashi, a Japan Bankers Association official. ''The Tokyo governor's new tax bill would cost the 21 banks as much as 90 billion yen a year.''

title: Bush Says Rats Reference In Ad Was Unintentional
description: As yet another of his campaign days skidded onto unexpected ground, Gov. George W. Bush today defended a Republican television commercial that, in attacking Vice President Al Gore's plans for health care, includes a fleeting, almost undetectable image of the word ''rats.''

title: Annan Tells General Assembly to End Barriers
description: Buoyed by support from world leaders last week for policies that would take the United Nations in new directions, Secretary General Kofi Annan delivered a tough message today to the opening session of the General Assembly debating season.

title: Condemned by the Nazis, but Not for Religion
description: To the growing body of invaluable cinematic literature documenting for posterity the hideous barbarity of Nazism may now be added ''Paragraph 175.''

title: Corrections
description: A headline and a picture caption on Saturday with an obituary of Rebert H. Harris, lead singer of the Soul Stirrers, characterized their music incorrectly. They were gospel singers, not soul singers.

title: Nassau Needs $50 Million To Balance Budget on Time
description: Facing a deadline Friday to come up with a plan to solve Nassau County's budget crisis, top county officials said today that they had agreed on more than $90 million of the roughly $140 million in budget cuts and new revenue they need to balance next year's budget.

title: Accusations of Misconduct In 2 Justice Dept. Programs
description: Top Justice Department officials responsible for teaching foreigners about American-style justice and democracy engaged in ''egregious misconduct,'' including a visa-fraud scheme to slip Russian girlfriends into the United States, according to a report by the department's inspector general.

title: Bomb Blast at Indonesian Stock Exchange Kills Seven
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 13 -- A powerful car bomb exploded today in the Indonesian Stock Exchange building, killing at least seven people and wounding dozens.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: It Was No Busy Signal

title: Storied Bank Failed to Move With Times
description: Nearly a century ago, the House of Morgan and its founder, J. Pierpont Morgan, preserved the American financial system in the midst of a widespread panic.

title: LIFETIME INVESTS IN WOMEN.COM
description: In a deal that could lengthen the life span of the beleaguered Web site Women.com, the company announced yesterday a joint equity and promotions agreement with Lifetime Entertainment Services, a joint venture owned by Hearst and Walt Disney. Lifetime Entertainment Services said it would purchase a 4.6 percent equity position in Women.com, while Women.com will purchase $10 million in advertising on Lifetime Television over three years. Hearst now owns 46 percent of Women.com. Susan Stellin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECHT, LISA M.
description: SPECHT-Lisa M. Of Westtown, New York, artist, died September 11, 2000. Loving sister of Mary Cambra, Helen Reiser and Henry Peschel. Devoted aunt of seven nieces & two nephews. Memorial services to be determined at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORDYK, JOHN GERARD
description: HORDYK-John Gerard. Of Armonk, NY, died on September 8, 2000. He is survived by his wife Catherine Marie (nee Brown). Also survived by his daughter Avril A. Dannenbaum. For information call Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY, 914-666-4840.

title: Ex-Superintendent Files Suit Contending Race Led to Firing
description: A former New York City school superintendent has filed a federal lawsuit accusing former Chancellor Rudy Crew of firing him because he is white and because the chancellor needed a scapegoat to appease Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a powerful business group at a time when the school system was under fire for low test scores.

title: Anti-Free-Trade Protests Disrupt Economic Forum in Melbourne
description: It was supposed to be a stimulating group chat about the global economy, held here a few days before the opening of the Olympics to allow the corporate executives, central bankers and other notables to hop over to Sydney for some world-class sport.

description: After 22 years as a producer for HBO Sports, Ross Greenburg was named the president yesterday, succeeding Seth Abraham, who is leaving to become chief operating officer of Madison Square Garden.

title: 3 More in City Are Sickened by West Nile Virus
description: Three more people, two of them still hospitalized, have been sickened by the West Nile virus, bringing the total number of people infected in the city this year to 11, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Dresdner Bank is said to be in talks to acquire the investment boutique Wasserstein Perella.
description: AS J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan captured the spotlight yesterday, a smaller proposed union signaled the passing of another era on Wall Street.

title: McKesson HBOC Files Suit Against Rival
description: McKesson HBOC Inc., the largest United States drug wholesaler and a leading health care software designer, said today that it had sued a rival, the W3Health Corporation, and 12 former McKesson HBOC employees, accusing them of stealing software trade secrets.

description: MISHLER-Arnold. Beloved brother of Anne M. Warren, loving uncle of Wendy Tooker, Heidi Goldstein, the late Betty Jane Soltano and Arthur Walsh. Interment September 12, 2000 at the Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY.

title: Just Another Day for Gazans Instead of a Moment in History
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 -- On the day that Palestinians had hoped to declare their state, some feuded among themselves instead, blocking intersections, burning tires and hurling stones at cars in the Gaza Strip.

description: Austrian Sanctions Ended

description: To the Editor:

title: FRESHMAN CLASS GROWS AT CUNY, REVERSING TREND
description: The number of new freshmen in the senior colleges at the City University of New York this fall has risen by 5 percent, and at some campuses by more than 20 percent, according to preliminary figures provided by the university.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGILL, ANN ROWE
description: McGILL-Ann Rowe. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of Ann Rowe McGill, the wife of our late former President, William J. McGill. Columbia University pays tribute to her memory and extends its profound sympathy to her daughter, Mrs. Thomas B. (Rowena) Springer, her son, William R. McGill, and her two grandsons. George Rupp, President of the University Stephen Friedman, Chair of the Trustees

title: BANKRUPT MALL OWNER NOW EMBRACES SPURNED INVESTOR
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., an owner of strip malls that is liquidating, named Jay Schottenstein, a shareholder, as board co-chairman under an agreement with an investor group he has organized. Mr. Schottenstein's group has agreed to vote its 9.8 percent stake in favor of Burnham's liquidation plan. Earlier this month Burnham, which is based in San Diego, said the company would sell 15 properties to Prudential Real Estate Investors for $355 million. More than a year ago, Burnham rejected a takeover offer of $13.50 a share from Mr. Schottenstein, saying it was too low. Since then the shares have lost more than half their value, and closed at $6 yesterday.

title: Europe Lifts Sanctions on Austria, but Vows Vigilance
description: The European Union lifted its sanctions against Austria today, seven months after hurriedly imposing a diplomatic freeze on Vienna for bringing a rightist party into its governing coalition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Article 2000091390516293003 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: Senate Defeats Last Major Obstacle to China Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Senate today brushed aside the last significant obstacle against normal trade relations with China, rejecting a measure that would have imposed sanctions on Chinese companies caught exporting nuclear arms, long-range missiles and other deadly weapons.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dresdner Bank in Talks

title: Now on the Small Screen: The Scent of a Kitchen
description: I HAVE been to the future and it smells. It smells like . . . But I'm getting ahead of myself.

title: Iraq Warned on Arms Inspections
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13  France has warned Iraq not to expect any weakening of the Security Council's determination to send United Nations inspectors back into Iraq to eliminate weapons of mass destruction before sanctions can be lifted.

title: Special Teams Could Use Recovery
description: If there is anyone out there who has had any success playing special teams -- returning punts or defending punt returns -- Jets Coach Al Groh would probably take a glance at your job application this week.

title: Best Crowd-Pleaser For Gore Is Lieberman
description: Before Vice President Al Gore set foot on the stage this afternoon in front of a raucous crowd of 2,000 supporters at Cincinnati State Technical and Community College, there came The Testimonial.

title: In Akron, the Talk Is About Treads
description: When the International Tire Exhibition and Conference opened here today, more than 2,500 people gathered in small meeting rooms to listen to scientists deliver papers on ''Metallic Coagents for Bonding Rubber to Metal and Synthetic Fibers'' or ''Tire Shearography.''

title: Unlikely Mediator in Strike at the Modern
description: FIRST, the confession: Bruce Raynor, the union leader who helped last week to end the long strike at the Museum of Modern Art, has never been to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Prosecutors Deny Hounding Muslims in Terrorism Case
description: The office of the chief federal prosecutor in Manhattan strongly denounced criticism this week that it had unfairly singled out Muslims during its broad investigation of Osama bin Laden, whom the authorities believe masterminded the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa in 1998.

title: Agreement Nearing in Long Yonkers School Case
description: For nearly two decades, a lawsuit accusing this city of intentionally segregating its schools has shaped almost every educational decision here -- from bus routes to curriculum to spending -- and kept a perpetual flame under debates about race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUSEIGNEUR, JAY
description: BEAUSEIGNEUR-Jay. On August 20th. Survivors are his wife Ursula, sister Bette, three nephews and a niece. A graduate of the Univ. of VT, he was a PanAm spokesman for 18 yrs; and later became Assist Editor and Correspondent for Hearst's NY bureau. A memorial Mass is scheduled for September 16 at 2:30, Goldwater Hospital.

title: Wen Ho Lee Case: A Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef: Sweet and Spicy Pepper Stew
description: LIKE most chefs, I've spent countless hours charring peppers over an open flame, steaming them in a covered bowl, then scraping off their skins and pulling out every last seed. Although tedious, this process is magical. Roasting transforms crunchy, crisp peppers into soft, smooth vegetables that melt in your mouth.

title: Poll Watch: Gender Makes a Difference When the Votes Are Counted
description: The growing support of women has propelled Al Gore from the doldrums to a dead heat with George W. Bush. Yes, there is a gender gap.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about the Eastern Pequot Indians' acknowledgment that they hope to build a casino if they receive formal recognition by the federal government misattributed a statement to them. It was another Connecticut tribe seeking recognition, the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots, that expressed gratitude to Donald J. Trump and his organization in March for supporting its efforts. The Eastern Pequots say they have had no dealings with Mr. Trump or his company.

title: Judge Bars Testimony of 3 Psychiatrists in Murder Case
description: A Manhattan judge ruled yesterday that the law must not intrude on the confidential doctor-patient relationship and excluded the testimony of three psychiatrists about the violent impulses of a young man they treated 17 years ago who is now facing a murder trial.

title: Congressman Forbes, a Former Republican, in a Tight Democratic Race
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes -- the former Republican who drew national attention by switching parties last year -- trailed by 39 votes out of nearly 12,000 cast in unofficial primary returns last night for the Democratic line in November's general election.

title: Article 2000091392861888178 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Pennsylvania Launches Competition for 'Digital School District' Funding
description: In an effort to spur innovation, maximize buying power and concentrate technology resources, officials in Pennsylvania have launched a statewide competition to create two cutting-edge digital school districts.

title: Nomura Abandons Financing Of Britain's Spendthrift Dome
description: As Britain approached the new millennium, the centerpiece of its efforts to draw the eyes of the world to a cool Britannia was the Millennium Dome -- a huge tent beside the Thames River shaped like an inverted wok and packed with exhibits.

title: A Synagogue Next Door To Auschwitz
description: For the first time since World War II, a synagogue opened its doors today in the vicinty of the Auschwitz death camp, and was hailed as a symbol of the healing of the long troubled relationship between Poles and Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, HERBERT
description: WASSERMAN-Herbert. The Symphony Space staff and Board of Directors mourn the loss of our esteemed board member and good friend Herb. We extend our deepest sympathies to Cece Wasserman and her family. Isaiah Sheffer, Artistic Director Joanne Cossa, Managing Director Bevis Longstreth, Chairman

title: When Bad Things Happen to Good Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: DE BEERS REASSURES RUSSIA
description: Top executives from De Beers, the supplier of half the world's rough-cut diamonds, met with Russian executives and government officials yesterday in Moscow to persuade them that its new company strategy would not harm the diamond trade in Russia, the world's second-largest producer of diamonds. Russia's monopoly producer, Alrosa, said it would continue to work with De Beers and expected to conclude a new contract before the current one expires late next year. That was in contrast to comments by Russian government officials in July that Russia may change its relations with the South Africa-based producer. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, LEON
description: SAMUELS-Leon. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Leon Samuels. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Sandy, and his entire family. Len Shendell, President Judith Tarter, Secretary

title: Judge Warns Lawyer to Pay Past Penalties
description: A New York state judge threatened on Monday to hold a lawyer involved in the Holocaust-related reparations lawsuits in criminal contempt for failing to pay court-imposed penalties in a personal injury case.

title: Shun Fujimoto, Gymnastics, 1976 Montreal
description: The men's gymnastic team competition, and a fifth straight victory for Japan, distilled itself to the outcome of the horizontal bar routines. The famous Japanese star, Mitsuo Tsukahara, scored a 9.9 and ensured victory over the Soviets. However, it was not known until after the team competition that Fujimoto had broken his leg at the knee during the end of his floor exercise routine.

title: London Exchange Drops Plan for Merger With Frankfurt
description: The London Stock Exchange scrapped its proposal today to merge with the Frankfurt stock exchange, abandoning at least for now a vision of creating the first pan-European stock market.

title: STRIDE RITE WARNS THAT PROFITS WILL BE BELOW FORECASTS
description: The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes Stride Rite, Keds and Sperry shoes, said it would report profits below estimates for its most recent quarter, in part because of lower sales at department stores. The company said it earned 17 cents to 19 cents a share in the period ended Sept. 1. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had forecast a profit of 26 cents a share. Sales fell 7 percent to about $145 million. The shares of Stride Rite, which is based in Lexington, Mass., fell 50 cents, to $5.25.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CITIGROUP, New York, named Barbara Yastine chief financial officer at its investment bank, Salomon Smith Barney, and its Citibank corporate global relationship bank.

title: Two Campaigns, Two Misfires; The Message in 'Rats'
description: To the Editor:

title: Making History at the Polls, Selma Elects a Black Mayor
description: Joseph T. Smitherman, the former segregationist who has been mayor of Selma, Ala., through 35 of the most restless years in the Deep South, lost his tenth bid for re-election tonight after a newly unified black electorate threw its support to James Perkins Jr., a former computer consultant.

title: With Tua Next Up, Lewis Keeps to His Busy Schedule
description: Nobody can accuse Lennox Lewis of resting on his laurels.

title: WORKING OUT THE KINKS
description: Soreness set in ever so subtly at the Rangers' camp in Burlington, Vt., yesterday as Mark Messier and Radek Dvorak removed themselves from a scrimmage because of stiffness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCHBECK, PETER GERALD
description: PINCHBECK-Peter Gerald. Died in his home on September 8, 2000. A painter, father, Professor at Manhattan Community College, member of The American Abstract Artists Association. His son Daniel will never forget his great and gentle spirit.

title: A Supportive Environment
description: Having pets has had a profound impact on how I manage. I expect a lot of out an animal in terms of love and affection, and I give a lot of love and affection in return. It involves effort but is also effortless.

title: Gore's War on Business
description: I've known Al Gore and Joseph Lieberman for years. They are smart, capable men who have a pretty good handle on what makes our economy tick. But judging from their comments in recent days, I'm a bit bewildered. In his speeches, Mr. Gore attacked ''big oil,'' ''the pharmaceutical companies,'' ''big polluters'' -- in short, corporate America in general.

title: TOYOTA PLANTS SHUT
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would temporarily close 13 auto assembly factories in central Japan because rain storms from a typhoon had disrupted delivery of auto parts. Toyota, Japan's largest automaker, halted production at factories in the Nagoya area for about a day, a move that will affect production of about 17,000 vehicles. The storm has created logistics problems for Toyota, which relies on ''just in time'' deliveries of auto parts.

title: Linda Grey, 54, a Publisher Who Led the Ballantine Group
description: Linda Grey, a top publishing executive who rose from editorial assistant to president and publisher of the Ballantine Publishing Group, died on Aug. 30. She was 54 and lived in New York.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Political Advice, Centuries Old

title: Volunteers in White Collars With Political Stripes
description: Every Thursday evening, Marilyn Robinson, executive director of the Nashville Minority Business Center, drives from her office to the Gore-Lieberman campaign headquarters and works the phones for three hours, canvassing voters throughout the country.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Monroe, Wash.; Long Beach, Westminster and Irvine, Calif.

title: 'A' Is for Arafat, 'B' Is for Bethlehem
description: Inside a modern, secular private school here, the first-grade boys and girls stuffed their Pokemon and Barbie backpacks into their cubbies and gathered on the blue rug for story time.

title: Article 2000091391893914258 -- No Title
description: An article yesterday about Oprah Winfrey's interview with Al Gore used a misspelled pen name and a nonexistent given name for the author of "The Red and the Black," which Mr. Gore described as his favorite book. The pen name is Stendhal, not Stendahl; Robert is not part of it.

title: Article 2000091391222688766 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, IRWIN
description: COOPER-Irwin. Age 74, of Fair Lawn, NJ on September 11, 2000. Practicing certified public accountant and partner at Kutell and Cooper in New York City for 42 years. Survived by his wife Joan, daughters Sherry and Iris, son William, brother Sidney and sister Vivian. Services are private. Family will be receiving through Sunday. Donations to the charity of your choice that benefit children.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPENO RELIEF IN IRISH INFLATION The inflation rate in Ireland remained at 6.2 percent in August, the highest in the European Union, according to figures released by the Central Statistics Office. The government said the rate would moderate by the end of the year, but Irish economists predicted that the worldwide increase in oil prices would push inflation up to 7 percent within the next few months. In response to the figures, three of Ireland's largest trade unions called for a renegotiation of the national wage agreement put in place when inflation ran at 2.5 percent.

title: PRI OFFERS EARNINGS WARNING
description: Shares of PRI Automation plummeted $16.8125, or 39.4 percent, to $25.875, yesterday after the semiconductor industry supplier warned of lower-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. The company, which provides automation systems and software for the semiconductor industry, said it expected its net income for the fourth quarter, excluding extraordinary items, to be slightly above the break-even point. Analysts' consensus estimate had been for earnings of 52 cents. PRI cited manufacturing, capacity and supply chain problems as reasons for the shortfall.

title: U.S. to Move Against Japan Over Whales
description: The White House plans to declare on Wednesday that Japan has violated international whaling rules by expanding its whale hunt this year, and will start a process that could lead to economic sanctions against Japanese imports within two months, Clinton administration officials said.

title: Real Estate Industry Gains Said to Eclipse Job Losses
description: A union between Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan & Company would probably mean the elimination of only a few jobs and free much-needed real estate space, people in the industry say.

title: Anderson's the Name
description: COMPARED with some of California's better-known wine regions, the Anderson Valley doesn't get much attention, except when it's mistaken for the Alexander Valley. The Alexander, in northern Sonoma County, is home to many big wineries like Clos du Bois and Jordan. Anderson Valley, in Mendocino County, is roughly the same size as the Alexander but with far fewer grapes planted, and it is home mostly to small, little-known wineries that deserve a higher profile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JANE B.
description: LUBIN-Jane B. 12/21/34-9/12/00. Survived by her beloved husband Warren; sons and daughter-in-law Peter Ente and William and Lisa Ente; stepsons and daughters-inlaw Mark and Rhonda Lubin and Gary and Wendy Lubin, and grandchildren Zachary and Jacob, Randy, Audrey and Greg, and Julie and David. Services today at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. Donations can be made in her memory to the charity or health organization of choice.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Revised In Bid for Passage in Senate
description: Congressional supporters of a patients' bill of rights said today that they had revised the legislation passed by the House last year, in a bid to win the votes of a few more Senate Republicans needed to enact the measure this fall.

title: In Quest for Tickets, It Pays to Be Patient
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 13  Jerry Patel, a retired coach from Orlando, Fla., reached Sydney late Tuesday without Olympic tickets. Early Wednesday he joined the long, last-minute lines for seats to the Games.

title: Nomura Spikes Deal for Millennium Symbol : Dome's New Doldrums
description: LONDON  After months of withering reviews, disappointing crowds and steadily mounting subsidies, the Millennium Dome suffered a devastating new blow Tuesday when Nomura International PLC announced that it was withdrawing its agreement to buy the tourist attraction for pounds 105 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGEN, RUTH D.
description: BOGEN-Ruth D. Died September 5. A memorial service will be held at the Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY, on Sunday, September 17, at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Friends of the Port Washington Public Library, 1 Library Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050 or to ALS Association, 116 John Street, Suite 1304, New York, NY 10038.

title: Police Dept. Shake-Up
description: To the Editor:

title: On Unmean Street, Thumbs Will Work as Crime Busters
description: If a perpetrator on the Upper East Side were to track a woman home late one night, follow her past the Pookie & Sebastian Clothing Boutique on 77th Street and pounce just as she enters her building, then that perpetrator could be in for an unpleasant evening of crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ALBERT
description: JACOBS-Albert, 87, died September 7,2000 in Atlanta, where he had resided for the past 17 years. Previously of New York and New Jersey. In the furniture business for over 50 years before his retirement. Beloved and devoted husband of Miriam Wernick Jacobs, father of Drs. Marcia Jacobs (Atlanta); Francine Jacobs (Newton, Ma.) and Steven Jacobs (Alamo, Ca.), father-in-law, and grandfather. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of choice or the Eliot-Pearson Deaprtment of Child Development (Jacobs Fund), Tufts University, Medford, Mass. 02155.

title: Acquisitions On Two Fronts
description: Two acquisitions are being made.

title: Most Incumbents Prevail Over Primary Challengers
description: Several New York lawmakers fended off challenges in the Democratic primary yesterday, once again demonstrating that when it comes to elections, the State Legislature is usually an incumbents' paradise. But there were a few exceptions, notably an East Harlem assemblyman who was defeated by former Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, a son of one of the most famous politicians in city history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WICKERSHAM, REV. DR. GEORGE W. II
description: WICKERSHAM-Rev. Dr. George W. II. Of Rockbridge Baths, VA. on September 9th, 2000 at age 87. Husband of Elizabeth Craighill, father of Nancy Leonhard and the late George W. III. Also survived by three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Former Rector of parishes in Norristown, PA., Tamworth, N.H., and Hot Springs, VA; honorary associate of TrinitySt. John's Church, Hewlett and Honorary Canon Emeritus of Cathedral of St. John Divine. U.S. Marine Chaplain in World War II. Memorial service Sunday, September 24, at 12:30 at Trinity-St. John's Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. In lieu of flowers contributions may be given to Friends of Salisbury Cathedral, 6 The Close, Salisbury, Wiltshire, SP12EF, England.

title: World Corruption Index Shows an Image Isnt Rebuilt in a Day
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13 -- When a country gets the reputation of being deeply corrupt, it takes more than the election of a reform-minded government to improve its image, a new report from Transparency International said today.

title: INVESTMENT IN CHINA
description: Foreign investment in China fell nearly 8 percent, to $22.79 billion, in the first eight months of the year compared with the same period a year earlier, the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said. But it said new contracts for investment not yet delivered rose 31.27 percent, to $33.25 billion, as foreign companies position themselves for what is expected to be a friendlier business climate after China joins the World Trade Organization. The country's W.T.O. membership is expected to be finalized this year. Craig S. Smith

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. -- Crude oil fell after President Clinton said emergency reserves of heating oil would be filled next month. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 86 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $34.28 a barrel.

title: Widely Outspent on TV Ads, Franks Focuses on Corzine's Recent Stumbles
description: While Jon S. Corzine is blanketing New Jersey with sunny television commercials promoting his ''fiscal discipline'' and his ''faith in the American dream,'' his Republican opponent in the race for the United States Senate, Representative Bob Franks, has zeroed in on Mr. Corzine's finances and his apparent lack of forthrightness as inviting targets for what is becoming a sharply focused line of attack.

Services will be held Thursday, 11 AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: 'Dancer in the Dark' to Open Film Festival
description: ''Dancer in the Dark,'' Lars von Trier's fable about a single mother and factory worker who is losing her sight, will open the 38th New York Film Festival, which runs Sept. 22 through Oct. 9. The winner of the Palme d'Or at this year's Cannes film festival, the film stars the pop singer Bjork, who also wrote the score, and features Catherine Deneuve as her best friend and co-worker and David Morse as a policeman and her landlord.
