description: The ''Y Dance!'' series in tribute to Osceola Bragg closed on Sunday afternoon with a second program.

title: New Treatment Offers Promise Against Kidney Cancer
description: An experimental treatment for advanced kidney cancer has shrunk tumors or wiped them out completely and prolonged life in some patients for whom conventional therapy failed, doctors are reporting.

title: Republicans Fail to Override Veto Of Marriage Penalty Bill
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 14 -- House Republicans fell short today in their attempt to override President Clinton's veto of the "marriage penalty" bill. But while the bill is dead, the issue it addresses is very much alive politically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITT, WILLIAM H.
description: PITT-William H. Philanthropist and real estate magnate of Greenwich, CT., and Palm Beach, FL, died on September 9 following a brief illness. The beloved husband of Pauline Baker Pitt. He was predeceased by his first wife, Theodora Ward Pitt and his son William H. Pitt III. He was the stepfather of Sandra Pine Doubleday of Hobe Sound, FL, Hope Pine Kelly of Darien, CT, Serena Boardman of NY, and Samantha Boardman of NY. The son of the late William H. Pitt and Regina Mulgrew Pitt. William Pitt was born in Stamford, CT on October 16, 1926. He founded the William Pitt Real Estate Company in Stamford in 1949, which today is one of the largest privately held real estate companies in the country. He was largely responsible for the development of Stamford into a bustling corporate business center, bringing a number of major corporations to southwestern CT in the 1970's including GTE, Xerox, and Price Waterhouse. He established The William H. Pitt Foundation in 1985 in memory of his son to benefit deserving youth in Fairfield County, CT primarily through education. Evidence of his generosity stands throughout Fairfield County, CT: The William Pitt Health & Recreation Center at Sacred Heart University, The William Pitt Family Medicine Center at Stamford, former St. Joseph Hospital, The William Pitt Child Development Center at Hillandale School and The William Pitt Youth Center at the Stamford YMCA. He was a member of the National Golf Links of America, the Racquet Club of NY, the Brook Club of NY, the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, FL, and the Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, FL. A Requiem Mass will be held at St. Mary's Church, Elm Street, Stamford, CT at 11:00 AM, Wednesday, September 13. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The William H. Pitt Foundation, Inc., P.O. Box 120063, Stamford, CT 06912, would be appreciated.

title: An Indian Idyll, Filmed in Switzerland, of Course
description: In take after take, Preity Zinta pivoted into the arms of Sunny Deol, bringing to life the heroic tale of an Indian policeman's struggle to win the love of his life. A 30-member film crew hovered protectively to make sure that this musical dream sequence, integral to Indian cinema, was captured in perfection.

title: CHINA INTERNET MERGER
description: China's Nasdaq-listed Sohu.com Inc. has reached a preliminary agreement to acquire rival ChinaRen.com, in what would be the first major merger in an expected consolidation of China's fledgling Internet industry. Neither company is making money and Sohu.com's share price plunged shortly after it sold stock to the public for $13 a share in July. The company's stock now trades at about half that price. Craig S. Smith

title: Putting That Kick Back Into Salsa
description: FOR decades in this country, the most beloved condiment was ketchup, bottled ketchup. But the American palate woke up, a great national craving for a spicy Mexican sauce took hold, and ultimately it supplanted ketchup in many homes.

title: A Prize for the Emmys
description: The Emmy Awards struck back this week against all those who have denigrated the award as all but meaningless: with 21.8 million viewers, the broadcast Sunday on ABC was the most-watched Emmy Awards show since the Nielsen company started using the people-meter ratings system in 1986.

title: Transcript of the Debate Between Mrs. Clinton and Rick Lazio
description: Following is a transcript of the debate Wednesday night between United States Senate candidates from New York Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio in Buffalo, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Pop Godmothers, Burnished by Experience
description: Maybe it never really changed, but the popular music business has unequivocally returned to judging female artists by their pounds of flesh. Yards of young midriff define the female presence in pop, overshadowing not just talent but personality as well. This is sad, not only because it shuts out those with better voices than abs, but also because it makes sexuality dull, as false and uniform as the scent of deodorant.

title: The Mystery of the Pickle Jar
description: WILFRED KEAN is famous for his dill pickles, but on one particular day last fall, he couldn't make them by himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, SAUL, MD
description: JARCHO-Saul, MD. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health deeply mourn the passing of this highly-esteemed physician-historian whose career with Mount Sinai covered over half a century. Dr. Jarcho joined Mount Sinai in 1931 holding appointments in the Department of Medicine until 1980. He was fulltime assistant to the Chiefs of Medical Service from 1946 to 1951 and was in charge of cardiovascular research for two years beginning in 1949. Dr. Jarcho was known for his keen insights as a clinician, teacher and researcher of medical history. In 1970 he was awarded the coveted Jacobi Medallion by the Mount Sinai Alumni. A prolific writer of 200 articles and 10 books, Dr. Jarcho's last book, ''Concepts of Contagion'', was recently released. He will be remembered fondly and sorely missed by patients and colleagues. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Irma, his sons, Tom and Andrew, and to the entire family. Helene L. Kaplan, Chair, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stephen M. Peck, Chair, Mount Sinai NYU Health Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh., Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine John W. Rowe, MD, President Mount Sinai NYU Health Barry R. Freedman, President The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: Malcolm K. Hughes -- News Agency Editor, 66
description: Malcolm K. Hughes, a former editor in chief of United Press International, died on Monday in Arlington, Va. He was 66.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EATON, HOWARD
description: EATON-Howard. Died June 7, 2000. Friends and colleagues (Loomis School, Yale 1951, Ogilvy & Mather, National Association of Broadcasters) memorial service, September 14th, 3:30PM, Yale Club, New York City.

title: Rancor Grows Between Ford And Firestone
description: Ford and Firestone, partners for a century, fell into bitter sniping before a Senate committee today, with top executives trading accusations about how the companies should divide responsibility for the dozens of deaths in rollover crashes involving Ford Explorers and Firestone tires.

title: Archaeologists May Have Found Woman Gladiators Grave
description: LONDON -- No one knows her name, or how she died, but archaeologists think she was a gladiator in Roman London.

title: Jefferson Gets His Wish: At Last, a Decent Bottle Of Virginia Wine
description: LUCA PASCHINA and a few other Virginia farmers are succeeding in one of the few endeavors at which Thomas Jefferson failed: winemaking.

title: Buchanan Is Recognized By Election Commission
description: Offering a moral victory but no immediate cash, the Federal Election Commission today upheld Patrick J. Buchanan's claim to $12.6 million in disputed federal campaign funds earmarked for the Reform Party's presidential nominee.

title: MetroStars Ousted From Tournament
description: The MetroStars saw one of their goals for this season end last night when they were eliminated by the Miami Fusion, 3-2, in the semifinals of the United States Open Cup at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y.

title: Joseph H. Lewis, 93, Director Who Turned B-Movies Into Art
description: Joseph H. Lewis, whose gritty, fast-paced low-budget films so transcended the conventions of the B-movie that filmmakers and screenwriters like Martin Scorsese, Peter Bogdanovich and Jay Cocks were moved to elevate him to the pantheon of auteurs, died on Aug. 30. He was 93 and lived in Marina del Rey, Calif.

title: THE BOSS; A Supportive Environment
description: Having pets has had a profound impact on how I manage. I expect a lot of out an animal in terms of love and affection, and I give a lot of love and affection in return. It involves effort but is also effortless.

title: CHASE IS REPORTED ON VERGE OF DEAL TO OBTAIN MORGAN
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the third-biggest banking company in the United States, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the most storied banks, for $30.9 billion in stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefings
description: ECOMMERCE LABEL OWNER SUES MP3.COM Zomba Recording said it had filed a lawsuit against MP3.com , the online music distributor that only last week was found in violation of copyright law in a similar suit filed by the Universal Music Group . The lawsuit accuses MP3.com of willful copyright infringement in relation to its MyMP3.com site, a service that lets users listen to the company's CD collection over the Internet. Zomba's Jive label records some of the biggest pop acts today, including Britney Spears, above, the Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. A sister company, Zomba Music Publishing, filed a separate suit on the same ground. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT) LIFETIME INVESTS IN WOMEN.COM In a deal that could lengthen the life span of the beleaguered Web site Women.com , the company announced yesterday a joint equity and promotions agreement with Lifetime Entertainment Services, a joint venture owned by Hearst and Walt Disney . Lifetime Entertainment Services said it would purchase a 4.6 percent equity position in Women.com, while Women.com will purchase $10 million in advertising on Lifetime Television over three years. Hearst now owns 46 percent of Women.com. Susan Stellin (NYT) BIOTECHNOLOGY ULCER DRUG WORKS IN TRIALS Human Genome Sciences said yesterday that its drug for wound healing had accelerated the repair of chronic venous ulcers in an early Phase 2 clinical trial. The drug, repifermin, is a natural human protein and is believed to be the first drug discovered using genomics that has shown effectiveness in a randomized clinical trial. In a test of 94 patients, 63 percent of patients who received the high dose and 71 percent who got the low dose achieved 75 percent wound closure after 12 weeks, compared with 45 percent of the patients who got a placebo. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Reno Troubled by Death Penalty Statistics
description: Saying she was ''sorely troubled'' by stark racial disparities in the federal death penalty, Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered United States attorneys to help explain why capital punishment is not applied uniformly across ethnic groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNELL, NICK
description: PARNELL-Nick, 74 years. Of 104 East 37th Street, New York City, on September 9. Professional dancer. Brother of John Pantazelos of Lynn, MA, Louis Pantazelos of Peabody, MA, and the late Sela Pantazelos and Sylvia Zambouras. Uncle of many. Funeral from the Solimine, Landergan and Rhodes Funeral Home, 67 Ocean Street (Rt. 1A) Lynn on Friday at 9:00 AM followed by funeral services in St. George Greek Orthodox Church, So. Common Street, Lynn, MA at 10:00 AM. Burial is in Pine Grove Cemetery, Lynn, MA. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited. Visitation Friday at 9:00 AM. Directions and guest book at www.legacy.com.

title: Strawberry Sentenced To Home For 2 Years
description: Darryl Strawberry was at home in Tampa, Fla., yesterday, which is where he must remain for most of the next two years after being sentenced to house arrest for violating his probation by admittedly driving under the influence of medication and then leaving the scene of an accident on Monday.

title: Wells Fargo in G.E. Deal
description: Wells Fargo & Company agreed to buy most of the General Electric Company's mortgage business and to collect its loan payments, becoming the biggest processor of mortgage bills in the nation. Terms were not disclosed. The Wells Fargo Home Mortgage unit will administer $78.6 billion of loans for GE Capital Mortgage Services. San Francisco-based Wells Fargo will buy G.E.'s mortgage center and loan-origination business, as well as its loans awaiting approval.

title: Congress's Obligation to Nature
description: Before adjourning next month, Congress should approve two of the most important conservation bills in many years. One bill, the Conservation and Reinvestment Act, would guarantee $45 billion over 15 years for a range of environmental purposes, including wilderness protection. The other could save the Everglades.

title: The Latest Oil Shock
description: The high price of oil is both a testament to the current global economic boom and a threat to its continuation. The heartening news is that the oil-producing nations themselves seem to realize this, and are intent on trying to drive prices lower. Whether there is enough unused production capacity to accomplish this in the short run remains to be seen, but the political will to try is welcome.

title: Apple Releases Beta Version of Its Mac OS X
description: The last time Apple Computer introduced a fundamentally new operating system was in 1984, when System 1.0 shipped with the original Macintosh computer. Ronald Reagan was president, Steve Jobs was the chairman of Apple, and the consumer embrace of Windows was still several years away. (In those days many computers ran on the DOS platform, which involved a lot of typed commands instead of pointing and clicking.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLESSER, MORTON
description: PLESSER-Morton, 75. On September 12. We will miss his love of life, wonderful sense of humor, generosity of spirit, and inspiring loyalty to his wife and family. Survived by his devoted wife of fifty years, Frances, his cherished children, Bruce, Amy, Fredda, and their loved ones, seven grandchildren, two sisters and many nieces and nephews. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KANEB PIPELINE PARTNERS LP., -- Richardson, Tex., said it bought a storage terminal near Philadelphia from GATX Corp., Chicago, for an undisclosed price to expand in the eastern U.S.

title: With Few Exceptions, Incumbents Win Handily in Primaries
description: Attacked from all sides, United States Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Republican turned Democrat from Long Island, was locked in a dead-even struggle with his primary challenger last night and was one of the few incumbents who did not easily prevail in contests that were unusually rancorous.

title: Producers Walk Out
description: After not developing any new comedy hits last year, NBC is still struggling with the genre it rode to prominence in the 1990's.

title: ING SELLING SHARES
description: The Dutch financial services company ING Groep said it was selling shares worth about 2.7 billion euros ($2.3 billion) in ABN Amro Holding, the Dutch bank, to finance recent acquisitions. Amsterdam-based ING has been selling stakes to finance the purchases of the ReliaStar Financial Corporation and two units of Aetna Inc.; the deals totaled $13.8 billion.

title: TV Notes: An Insurrection
description: On 'Big Brother'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUTTERMAN, HOWARD S.
description: FUTTERMAN-Howard S. On September 11, 2000, of Westbury, NY. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Ellen and Jeff, Gary and Karen. Dear brother of Robert. Cherished grandfather of Samantha and Jackson. Services on Thursday, 11:30 A.M., at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, 21 Old Westbury Road, Old Westbury, L.I. Interment in Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Blast Hurts 7 in Cape Town
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 12  A bomb exploded in a parking lot near a mosque and a hall where an opposition party meeting was being held tonight, in the latest in a series of attacks in this coastal city. Seven people were injured, though only slightly.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: ROCKLAND COUNTY

title: Seeking the Right Child Care Formula
description: In October, Marriott International will fire its second salvo in the nation's work-family conflict, opening a $2.5 million, 120-place day care center in a refitted historic building in downtown Washington.

title: Plan for Swiss to Pay Nazi Victims
description: In a significant step for thousands of Holocaust victims who have fought for decades to recover their savings from Swiss banks, a special master appointed by a federal judge overseeing a class action lawsuit submitted a complex plan yesterday for distributing $1.25 billion in settlement payments from the banks.

title: Piazza Knows He Must Shoulder the Burden
description: The best September Mike Piazza ever had was in 1997, when he batted .406 with eight homers for the Los Angeles Dodgers. But the Dodgers still missed the playoffs that year, and the example backs up Piazza's case that the Mets do not just follow his lead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORCH, CLAIRE
description: LORCH-Claire, on September 9, 2000, at her home. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Lorch, devoted mother of Gloria Nimetz, Leonard Lorch and Evelyn Sabin, loving grandmother of Alexandra Nimetz, Lloyd Nimetz, Jennifer Sabin and Michael Sabin, cherished mother-in-law of Matthew Nimetz and Jeffrey Sabin, adored sister of Al Weil. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 13, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Israel, 140 Central Ave., Lawrence, LI. Contributions may be made to: Selfhelp Community Services Inc., 440 Ninth Ave., NY, NY 10001.

title: Sometimes A Handshake Is Just Polite
description: WATCHING political candidates on the prowl used to be simple. They kissed babies, and that was it. Now, we have to put up with all kinds of kisses, along with endless pontificating over what each one means.

title: Mentoring Our Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Rules Out Force Over Iraq Inspections
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking with reporters after addressing the United Nations General Assembly, said the United States would not use force to make Iraq allow the resumption of international arms inspections. The decision may help to maintain an international consensus on dealing with Iraq.

title: Target Chooses Arnold for 3 Chains
description: The Target Corporation in Minneapolis has named Arnold Communications in Boston to handle the first corporate branding campaign for three department store chains, Dayton's, Marshall Field's and Hudson's. Spending was estimated at $40 million.

title: Swing, Swing, Swing: The Mets Finally Break Out
description: When the Mets reached first place at the end of August, they did not get there by bludgeoning opponents. Good pitching and a few timely hits were enough. When the hits stopped coming this month, the Mets started losing. The players got worried, and the veterans sensed that this made no sense.

title: Mexico Cement Giant Plans Internet Emphasis
description: Cemex S.A., the big Mexican cement producer and one of Latin America's most successful multinational companies, expects today to announce the formation of a subsidiary that will consolidate its Internet strategies and expand the company into online procurement services, the chief executive said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNIDER, SAM
description: SNIDER-Sam. The Malverne Jewish Center mourns the passing of Sam Snider, longtime member and friend. Condolences to his wife Rhoda and children Barry and Joan. Cecile F. Vinik, President Moshe Berger, Rabbi

title: Republicans' Request to Cut Debt Surprises Democrats
description: With the demise of their large-scale tax cut, Republican leaders in Congress met today with President Clinton at the White House to discuss unfinished legislation and request that he set aside 90 percent of this year's surplus to pay down the national debt.

title: CABARET IN REVIEW
description: Pack a Wallop, Hold the Sugar

title: Article 2000091392990397487 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Patriots Get a Lesson On How to Get It Done
description: Besides the muddled rivalry, the verbal war, the mutual respect mixed with envy that color nearly every facet of the Jets-Patriots relationship, their meeting Monday night was more about which team would gain the jump on its new course.

title: Clinton and Lazio Take On Health Care in First Debate
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 13  Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio met this evening in the first debate of this year's Senate election.

title: FRENCH PRICES ARE UP
description: French consumer prices rose in August as an increase in the costs of clothing, shoes and other manufactured goods more than offset a decline in fresh food products. An index measuring the prices of consumer goods, seasonally adjusted and based on European Union standards, rose 0.2 percent from July, the national statistics office said. Prices rose 2 percent from a year earlier, maintaining the four-year high reached in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUROBINER, ALICE
description: TUROBINER-Alice. Ohr Torah Stone Institutions of Israel records with great sorrow the untimely passing of Alice Turobiner, a most beautiful, elegant, generous and sensitive benefactor of our people. The students of Midreshet Lindenbaum in Jerusalem will forever be grateful for the Auditorium which Alice and her beloved and caring husband Harold dedicated last year. May the Almighty comfort the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Shlomo Riskin Chancellor

title: A Shelter Plan Tests the Limits Of the Tax Law
description: Treasury officials say abusive corporate tax shelters are the government's biggest tax enforcement problem, costing billions of dollars annually. Now, a company called the Tax People is teaching similarly dubious tax avoidance techniques to middle-class Americans at a time when the Internal Revenue Service's ability to enforce the tax laws is at a historical low.

title: Mentoring Our Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Elusive Charms of a Belittled Capital
description: Canberra gets a bum rap. Australians make jokes about their capital, making it sound as sterile as Brasilia or anything built by Donald Trump. Aside from the fact that it doesn't come close to resembling a city, Canberra has its charms.

title: Witty Chasing a Special Double
description: It took only a few minutes for Chris Witty to discover she was a prodigy in speed skating. As a 10-year-old in West Allis, Wis., she entered a 500-meter race wearing her brother's figure skates. Still, she won so easily that she was showing the gold medal to her mother by the time the second-place skater reached the finish line.

title: Accounts
description: * Farmland Industries, Kansas City, Mo., to Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo., to handle the consolidated account for Farmland Foods pork products, which had been divided between Bernstein-Rein and several smaller agencies. Spending was estimated at $12 million.

title: Metro-North Electrical Fire Delays 35,000 in Evening Rush
description: A thick, smoky electrical fire on a Metro-North train near New Rochelle shut down the railroad's New Haven line for almost an hour at the height of the evening rush yesterday. About 35,000 commuters on the line, Metro-North's busiest, were delayed by an hour or more, said Dan Brucker, a railroad spokesman.

title: Bush Finds a Minus to Coziness With Reporters
description: The presidential race may be neck and neck, but there is one place Gov. George W. Bush has cut back on his campaigning. The rear of his own plane.

title: Cheney Has Now Cashed In Most of His Stake in Halliburton
description: Dick Cheney realized a profit of $20.6 million last month as he cashed in most of his stake in the Halliburton Company, which he ran until he left to become the Republican candidate for vice president, he reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: LA-Z-BOY TO SHUT A PLANT IN OHIO, LAYING OFF 130 WORKERS
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., a leading maker of reclining chairs, said it plannned to close a plant in Swanton, Ohio, and lay off about 130 people as it scales back production of inexpensive furniture. The Swanton plant belongs to La-Z-Boy's Pilliod Furniture subsidiary, which also operates plants in Nichols, S.C., and Selma, Ala. Furniture imported from Asia cut into sales of Pilliod furniture, which is made from wood with a plastic veneer, said La-Z-Boy's treasurer, Mark Stegeman. Higher interest rates discouraged people from buying furniture on credit, he said. La-Z-Boy, which is based in Monroe, Mich., has about 22,000 employees, Mr. Stegeman said. It had sales of about $1.72 billion in the fiscal year ended April 29.

title: DiPietro to Play Against the Flyers
description: The Islanders begin their preseason against Philadelphia tomorrow night and Friday night, and Coach Butch Goring has not let the venues influence his decision on which goalie will start.

title: LABEL OWNER SUES MP3.COM
description: Zomba Recording said it had filed a lawsuit against MP3.com, the online music distributor that only last week was found in violation of copyright law in a similar suit filed by the Universal Music Group. The lawsuit accuses MP3.com of willful copyright infringement in relation to its MyMP3.com site, a service that lets users listen to the company's CD collection over the Internet. Zomba's Jive label records some of the biggest pop acts today, including Britney Spears, above, the Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. A sister company, Zomba Music Publishing, filed a separate suit on the same ground. Laurie J. Flynn

title: An Insurrection On 'Big Brother'
description: The cast of ''Big Brother'' continues to drive the show's producers batty. Last week an effort to bribe one of the six remaining contestants to leave the camera-filled house where they have been confined for two months failed because they decided they would present a united front to thwart the producers' main goal of inserting a new participant.

title: A MANAGER OF POWER PLANTS WILL SELL ITS AVIATION UNIT
description: The Ogden Corporation, a manager of power plants that is shedding other businesses to focus on energy, agreed to sell its aviation fixed-base operations unit to Consolidated Lamda Holdings S.A. for about $27.1 million in cash. The transaction includes Ogden's Flight Services Group in Connecticut and assets of its Transair unit based at Le Bourget Airport outside Paris. The purchase by Consolidated Lamda Holdings, an affiliate of Latsis Group of Greece, is expected to close by the end of the year. Ogden, which is based in New York, will use most of the proceeds to pay down debt, which totaled $603.8 million as of June 30. Ogden plans to end the year with about $400 million in cash or cash equivalents earmarked for debt payment.

title: Reckonings; Bush Gives No Quarter
description: George W. Bush has lately taken to explaining his economic plans by pulling out four dollar bills to represent the projected budget surplus. Two dollars, he explains, will be used to support Social Security; one to pay for new programs like prescription drug insurance; and one will be used to cut taxes. ''I think it's fair, I think it's right that one quarter of the surplus go back to the people who pay the bills,'' he declared last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, NORBERT MARTIN
description: FORD-Norbert Martin. Died unexpectedly in Dublin on Sunday, Sept. 10, 2000. Dearly beloved husband of Ludlow. Father of Andrew and Carol and grandfather of Jared, Martin, Robert, Geoffrey and Anne. Mr. Ford was a businessman who designed and manufactured mens and womens apparel. He was an Infantry Captain in the U.S. Army in World War II. He served in Europe until 1946. May he rest in peace. The funeral will take place in Dublin on Friday, September 15 followed by cremation. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Arthritis Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Tie Is Savored as Victory for U.S.
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 13  Brad Friedel remembers the United States soccer team that went to the Summer Games in Barcelona eight years ago. "Two professionals on the entire team," he recalled tonight.

title: THE CHEF
description: LIKE most chefs, I've spent countless hours charring peppers over an open flame, steaming them in a covered bowl, then scraping off their skins and pulling out every last seed. Although tedious, this process is magical. Roasting transforms crunchy, crisp peppers into soft, smooth vegetables that melt in your mouth.

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Investor Upgrades Kennedy Airport Space
description: The changes most in the spotlight at Kennedy International Airport lately have involved a $9 billion redevelopment project at the passenger and cargo operations. But there are also changes under way within the roughly five million square feet of commercial and industrial space that surround the airport, home to dozens of airline support companies, freight forwarders, warehouse companies and distributors.

title: National News Briefs
description: Utility Must List Houses in Mercury Accident

title: Most British Gas Stations Close as Protests Grow
description: Spreading protests over high fuel prices all but halted gasoline deliveries across Britain today, forcing most service stations to close for lack of fuel.

title: A Showdown On Cleanup Of the Hudson
description: With only three months left before the Environmental Protection Agency is to release a decision on the decades-old problem of PCB contamination in the Hudson River, a fight in Congress that some politicians and E.P.A. officials say could delay the ruling yet again -- perhaps into the next presidential administration -- is reaching a showdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDIN, RITA
description: BENDIN-Rita. 71. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Died on August 15, 2000. She was the daughter of the late William and Estelle Bendin and the sister of the late William Bendin Jr.

title: Poll Shows Gore Overcoming Voter Concerns on Likability
description: Vice President Al Gore has shaken the persistent sense that he is not particularly likable and is now as highly regarded as Gov. George W. Bush on matters of character, leadership and overall personal popularity, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Reaching for Better Tequila
description: HEARD about the tequila shortage? It seems that because of a shortfall in the supply of agave plants, from which tequila is distilled, the demand for this liquor is exceeding the supply.

title: Journey to the Planet Brasserie
description: MY vote for the hardest-working banana split in town goes to Brasserie 8 1/2. It's a strenuously conceptual dessert, a plateful of allusions, feints and inside jokes, the main one being the almost total absence of banana. From right to left, one encounters a small dome of caramelized banana on a quarter-size sable pastry disk, a medium-size puck of strawberry ice cream topped with strawberry slices and a large stack that begins with caramelized pineapple and ascends, in many chapters, through vanilla ice cream, almond sable, chocolate ice cream and chocolate syrup, with fascinating asides. If a split could sweat, this would be a three-towel production.

title: Hewlett Introduces a Powerful Computer
description: After months of buildup, the Hewlett-Packard Company yesterday rolled out the powerful computer it is counting on to lift sales to e-commerce operations, multinational companies and Internet service providers that need systems capable of handling vast amounts of data around the clock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOW, ROSALYN C.
description: KRASNOW-Rosalyn C. On Sunday, September 10, 2000, of Silver Spring, MD. formerly of Scarsdale, NY; beloved wife of the late Kenneth I. Krasnow; devoted mother of Steven Jed (Rose G.) Krasnow, Andrew Krasnow, Stuart Krasnow and the late Daniel and Elaine Krasnow, loving sister of Helen (Arthur) Zeldin; also survived by 5 grandchildren, Evelyn, Andrea, Kevin, Kimberly and Elena Krasnow. Graveside funeral services were held on Tuesday, September 12, at Sharon Gardens, a division of Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Family will be receiving friends Wednesday and Thursday at 7:30 P.M. at the residence of Steven Jed and Rose G. Krasnow. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Elaine Beth Krasnow Foundation, 9071 Wonderland Park Ave., Los Angeles, CA 90046. For information Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc., 800-217-9403.

title: Disney Bans R-Rated Movie Ads Before 9 P.M. on ABC Network
description: The Walt Disney Company announced yesterday that it would no longer accept advertising for R-rated movies on any programs on its ABC television network that are broadcast before 9 p.m., Eastern time.

title: Exploring Cuisine From India's Spice Coast
description: THE first taste of the coriander chicken on coconut pancakes from Maya Kaimal's new book, ''Savoring the Spice Coast of India'' (Harper Collins, $27.50), evokes a number of responses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, MARTHA
description: GREENWALD-Martha. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Cherished mother of Harvey and Alan, loving grandmother of Jonathan, Michael, Suma, Dara and Cora. Funeral services Thursday, September 14th at 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Mentoring Our Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Progress Made in Teacher Strike Talks
description: Striking public school teachers here continued to defy a judge's back-to-work order and mounting anger from parents and students today as they pushed the state's seventh-largest school district into its second week of a strike over salary issues.

title: Wen Ho Lee Case: A Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Money, Perhaps, Is En Route
description: WHERE is everybody?

title: Latin Grammys' Border Skirmish; New Awards Face Complaints About Slighting a Mexican Genre
description: The first Latin Grammy Awards show, tonight on CBS, will be the first multilingual broadcast on a major American network: the talk will be mostly in English and Spanish, the singing in Spanish and Portuguese. It is also the first time the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has allowed recordings released outside the United States to be Grammy nominees.

title: Article 2000091391136307563 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Tufts University President Is to Retire
description: John DiBiaggio, a Detroit-born dentist who has helped promote public service in higher education, yesterday announced his plans to retire as president of Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title: Two Campaigns, Two Misfires
description: To the Editor:

title: How Tests Can Drop The Ball
description: MIKE PIAZZA, batting .332, could win this year's Most Valuable Player award. He has been good every year, with a .330 career average, twice a runner-up for m.v.p. and a member of each All-Star team since his rookie season.

title: Airline Shifts Hub Schedules To Cut Delays
description: American Airlines, the nation's second-largest airline, said yesterday that it would rearrange flights at its two largest hubs to improve its overall reliability after this summer's high number of delays and cancellations.

title: PARMALAT TO BUY MOTHER'S CAKE AND ARCHWAY COOKIES
description: The Specialty Foods Acquisition Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Mother's Cake and Cookie Company and Archway Cookies to Parmalat Finanziaria of Italy for $250 million. The two brands share management teams based in Oakland, Calif. Officials at Specialty Foods, which is based in Deerfield, Ill., declined to provide yearly sales of the cookie brands. Parmalat Finanziaria, which is based in Milan, is the world's largest dairy company and had 1999 sales of about $6.8 billion. It operates in 31 countries.

title: S.& L. Profits Fell 5 Percent in 2nd Quarter
description: Savings and loan associations earned $2 billion for the second quarter of 2000, down 5 percent from $2.1 billion a year earlier, the Office of Thrift Supervision reported today.

title: Two Campaigns, Two Misfires
description: To the Editor:

title: PRI AUTOMATION SHARES FALL SHARPLY ON PROFIT WARNING
description: PRI Automation Inc. shares fell 39 percent yesterday after the company's disclosure that its sales and profit in the most recent quarter will miss forecasts. PRI's stock dropped $16.81, to $25.88 a share. Profit will be slightly above break-even, less than analysts' forecasts of 52 cents a share. PRI blamed manufacturing and supply problems with a new product that helps chip makers move wafers around a plant. The problems will take two quarters to resolve, Mitch Tyson, the chief executive, said Monday. PRI, based in Billerica, Mass., makes automation tools for semiconductor plants.

title: U.S. Forswears Force Over Iraq Inspections
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States would not use force to make Iraq allow the resumption of international arms inspections.

title: Article 2000091390435880332 -- No Title
description: EDUCATION COLUMN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEEG, PAUL S.
description: STEEG-Paul S. On September 12, 2000, three weeks before his 97th birthday and after 64 years of marriage to his beloved Margaret. Born Karlsruhe, Germany October 3, 1903. Father of Dr. Carl Steeg (Rhonda) and Dr. Frank Steeg (Maralyn), grandfather of Jennifer, Julie, Jason (Stacey) and Deborah. Great-grandfather of Danielle and Peter. Long-time devoted member of Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing. Service Wednesday, September 13, 12:45PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH H. (NEE WEISS)
description: BERGER-Ruth H. (nee Weiss). On September 12, 2000, of Belle Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late Irving Berger. Devoted mother of Stephen (Maria) Berger and Kenneth (Renee) Berger. Loving grandmother, aunt and sister. Donations in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice. Graveside Serv today at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, 1pm.

title: Indonesia May Bar U.N. Inquiry in Staff Killing
description: Indonesia's defense minister said today that his government would not meet with United Nations representatives when they visit Indonesia to look into the killings of three United Nations refugee workers in West Timor last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, IRVING M., ESQ
description: MOSS-Irving M., Esq. Former partner at Richenthal, Abrams and Moss. Beloved brother of Rashie Flax, Esther Fuss and Shirley Mangel and the late Harry, David, Julius and Louis Moss and Beatrice Solodkin. Cherished uncle of many nieces and nephews. Services on Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Close Calls, But the Jets Will Take 'Em
description: The National Football League released a fascinating little nugget of information today: the average margin of victory so far this season is 9.93 points, the lowest since 1970.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about the loss of habitat for the monarch butterfly showed an incorrect species. It was a queen butterfly, not a monarch.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: IRELAND PILOTS WANT MORE MONEY
description: Pilots for Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, demanded pay increases that would make their salaries comparable with pilots in other airlines that belong to the One World Alliance, of which Aer Lingus is a member. In the case of top-earning pilots, who currently make 87,000 Irish pounds ($95,000) a year, the demands called for a near doubling, to more than 160,000 pounds. The Irish Airline Pilots' Association said that its members share work with employees of other airlines and that it had received complaints that Aer Lingus salaries were lowering the industry average. Brian Lavery

title: Payton Ends Drama With Home Run in 10th
description: The Mets' 10-inning 4-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday was a Jay Payton production in three acts. Mixing tragicomedy with suspense, Payton presented the Brewers with a gift run in the first inning, then wrote himself award- winning parts in the ninth and 10th innings.

title: Liberties; Grilled Over RATS
description: It's the year of the rat.

title: Correction
description: A word was omitted last Wednesday from an article in this section about almond farming in California. The affected sentence should have read, ''Almonds were first brought to the state in the 18th century, by the Franciscan padres who founded the chain of coastal missions, but the trees suffered in the misty, moist conditions near the Pacific, and only a hundred years later were successfully planted inland.''

title: Two Campaigns, Two Misfires
description: To the Editor:

title: Evil and Frailty in a Corsican Mystery
description: LOST

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Representative Rick A. Lazio's plan for new education spending if he is elected senator misstated the total for new spending on education proposed by his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mrs. Clinton's proposals, taken together, would cost $129.6 billion over 10 years, not $123 billion.

title: U.S. Defeats South Korea
description: The United States Olympic baseball team routed South Korea, 15-0, yesterday to finish its pre-Olympic exhibition schedule with a 5-1 record in Gold Coast, Australia.

title: A Leaf, Not a Powder
description: AS the dishes of other countries become part of American cooking vernacular, so do the ingredients that define them. Curry leaves, which are used in Indian, Sri Lankan and Malaysian cooking, are beginning to appear in mainstream cookbooks just as Mexican cilantro and Southeast Asian kaffir lime leaves did a while ago.

title: Fuel Standoff in Britain Eases, but Supply Still Short
description: LONDON Sept. 13 -- Fuel tankers resumed limited deliveries from picketed refineries and storage depots Wednesday, but the crack in the siege that has left almost all the country's filling stations dry was doing little to restore the normality that Prime Minister Tony Blair has promised British motorists.

title: William A. Nierenberg, 81, Physicist and Military Policy Adviser
description: Dr. William A. Nierenberg, a physicist with a passion for the ocean who spent five decades striving to mesh science, technology and policy as an adviser to presidents, military agencies and NATO, died Sunday at his home in San Diego. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAILOVE, MATHILDA F.
description: BRAILOVE-Mathilda F. On September 12 at home in Elizabeth, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Dr. S. Alexander Brailove, mother of Susan Brailove, Linda Kneucker and the late Marjorie Horowitz. Grandmother of seven and great grandmother of eight. A founder of the modern Jewish movement, Mrs. Brailove worked passionately and tirelessly for Israel and for Jews around the world as a fund raiser and global activist for the United Jewish Appeal from the 1930's through the 1980's. Mrs. Brailove helped rally opposition against Hitler during the Holocaust and was a member of the first UJA delegation to visit Israel after the state was formed in 1948. After the war, she helped oppressed Jews around the world emigrate to Israel and the United States. In 1950, she was named Chairman of the National Women's Division of the UJA and was a host of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's visit to the U.S. A funeral will be held Thursday at 11 A.M. from the Higgins-Bonner Funeral Home, 414 Westminster Ave, Elizabeth. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the UJA Israel Education Fund for the Mathilda F. Brailove Kindergarten in Bersheva, 111 8th Ave, Suite 11E, NYC 10011.

title: Metro Business; Paperboard Mill Closing
description: Caraustar Industries Inc., a maker of recycled paperboard and packaging products, said yesterday that it would close its mill in Camden, N.J., because of a contract dispute with its largest customer for gypsum board facing paper.

title: Family Needs Far Exceed The Official Poverty Line; Study Lays Out Costs of Getting By in City
description: Carol Williams did not need an economic study to prove that her $24,000-a-year job as an administrative assistant could not support three children in New York, even when squeezed into a one-bedroom, $600-a-month apartment in the Bronx.

title: NO RELIEF IN IRISH INFLATION
description: The inflation rate in Ireland remained at 6.2 percent in August, the highest in the European Union, according to figures released by the Central Statistics Office. The government said the rate would moderate by the end of the year, but Irish economists predicted that the worldwide increase in oil prices would push inflation up to 7 percent within the next few months. In response to the figures, three of Ireland's largest trade unions called for a renegotiation of the national wage agreement put in place when inflation ran at 2.5 percent. Brian Lavery

title: Herbert Friedman, 84, Leader in Astronomy, Dies
description: Dr. Herbert Friedman, a pioneer in X-ray astronomy who received some of the country's top scientific honors over a 60-year career, died on Saturday.

title: American Basketball Teams Check Out
description: With their preparation time dwindling and concern mounting, the United States Olympic basketball teams vacated the men's and women's team hotel in Melbourne yesterday and arrived in Sydney Tuesday afternoon.

title: Knight Defends Himself; Indiana Names Coach
description: Indiana University tried to look to the future yesterday, naming Mike Davis as the interim head basketball coach of the Hoosiers.

title: POSSIBLE DEAL FOR INFOSTRADA
description: The British mobile phone company Vodafone AirTouch is talking to Wind S.p.A. about buying Infostrada, an Italian fixed-line phone company that Vodafone inherited as part of its purchase of Mannesmann of Germany. Wind's bid of 11.5 billion euros, or about $9.7 billion, exceeded a 9 billion euro offer from Albacom, a business phone consortium that is 23 percent owned by British Telecommunications. Specializing in wireless, fixed-line and Internet operations, Wind is controlled by the Italian state-owned electricity utility Enel and by France Telecom. Should the sale not go through, Vodafone could revert to its original plan of selling a 49 percent stake of Infostrada through a share offering. Suzanne Kapner

title: Clemens Stakes Claim as No. 1 Starter
description: Unless the Yankees experience a monumental collapse this month, they will play their first postseason game in 19 days. Joe Torre basically knows what his starting lineup will look like that night. Bernie Williams should be healthy, Chuck Knoblauch is easing back at second base and Jose Canseco or Glenallen Hill could start as the designated-hitter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULDOON, THOMAS W.
description: MULDOON-Thomas W. The Officers and members of the Alumni Association of the New York Eye & Ear Infirmary are saddened by the passing of Thomas W. Muldoon, father of esteemed member and Surgeon Director, Thomas O. Muldoon, MD. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Muldoon family. Jeanne L. Rosenthal, MD, Pres. Solomon Liebowitz, MD, Past-Pres Melissa Pashcow, MD, Vice Pres. Douglas Buxton, MD, Secretary

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The euro rose after the president of the European Central Bank said the currency did not reflect prospects for economic growth in Europe. In New York, the euro settled at 86.29 cents, down from 85.78 cents.

title: Black Bear Hunt Is Canceled After the Governor Intervenes
description: New Jersey's first black bear hunt since 1970 was canceled yesterday as the state agency that sets hunting rules acceded, with some unwillingness, to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's wishes and voted narrowly to ban it.

title: The always restless Burger King again has the urge to take a new approach in its marketing.
description: FOR months, Burger King has sought to stimulate flagging sales of its fast fare with a seductive appeal carrying the theme ''Got the urge?'' Yesterday, it was Burger King that had the urge -- the same old urge the company has had so often, to place the creative duties for its general market advertising account in review.

title: Business Travel; As costs escalate, corporate travel departments are becoming more creative and aggressive.
description: LATELY, dealing with my corporate travel department is like being pecked to death by a duck,'' said a senior executive I know who travels over 100,000 miles a year on business and feels that he is being increasingly second-guessed by the bean counters when he tries to exercise some personal choice in his airline and hotel arrangements.

title: POSTAL STAKE FOR SALE
description: Germany said it planned to sell about 25 percent of Deutsche Post, Europe's biggest postal service by revenue. Deutsche Post has set a provisional date of Nov. 6 for its initial public offering. The postal service has hired HypoVereinsbank, Commerzbank, Dresdner Bank and 13 others to help to manage the offer. Neither the ministry nor Deutsche Post would say how much revenue the sale was expected to generate.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Oprah Winfrey's interview with Al Gore used a misspelled pen name and a nonexistent given name for the author of ''The Red and the Black,'' which Mr. Gore described as his favorite book. The pen name is Stendhal, not Stendahl; Robert is not part of it.

title: Found: Possible Pre-Flood Artifacts
description: Scientists said today that they had discovered remnants of human habitation under the Black Sea that they believe is the first proof that people thrived along an ancient shoreline before it was inundated by a great flood thousands of years ago.

title: New Embarrassments Put I.O.C. on Defensive
description: In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal and diminished credibility over its resolve to reduce the use of performance-enhancing drugs, the International Olympic Committee has faced a barrage of new embarrassments this week that raises questions about its ability to change significantly.

title: Captain Is Back Where He Belongs
description: Between most hockey players, it would have been just a routine encounter in the corridor on the first day of training camp. But Mark Messier is not like most players. Even his small gestures carry nuance and significance.

title: Clinton and Lazio Take On Health Care in First Debate
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 13  Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio met this evening in the first debate of this year's Senate election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ROY
description: SHAPIRO-Roy. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving and devoted father of Lily, Alexander and Amanda Pirot. Devoted stepfather of Lance & Frank (Mindy) Mayer. Cherished grandfather of Max, Stefanie, and Adam. Adored brother of Sunny Soloff and the late Armin Speer. Loyal friend to many. We are forever blessed by your love & kindness. Services at 1 PM Thursday at the ''Riverside Chapel'', 181 West 76 St., NYC.

title: Caribbean, Badly Hurt, Is Promised Help on AIDS
description: With the Caribbean facing the highest rate of H.I.V. infection outside of sub-Saharan Africa, international donors and banks have pledged at least $120 million to support a regional strategy to combat the disease, they announced today.

title: Recipe: Sweet and Spicy Pepper Stew
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page A23 was omitted from some copies in the New York region yesterday and replaced by a page reprinted from the Monday paper. The omitted page carried the continuation of the front-page article about the political issue of overhauling Medicare; an article about Gov. George W. Bush's campaign emphasis on health care; and an article on the National Rifle Association's decision to help Mr. Bush by withholding its official endorsement. Any reader wishing a copy of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Taking Power Over Oil
description: The cost of oil is rising again, and the conventional wisdom in the industrialized countries is that prices can only come down if OPEC increases oil production. President Clinton, meeting with the Saudi crown prince, Abdullah, last week in New York, followed this line, cautioning the prince that high oil prices threaten the global economy. The finance ministers of European Union nations echoed his warnings and called on OPEC to pump more oil.

title: PEPSICO SAYS VICE CHAIRMAN WILL RETIRE IN EARLY 2001
description: PepsiCo Inc. said yesterday that its vice chairman, Karl von der Heyden, who returned to the company four years ago to help direct its restructuring and divestitures, will retire and leave its board as of Jan. 31. Von der Heyden played a central role in spinning off Tricon Global Restaurants Inc. and the selling of PepsiCo's other restaurant operations. He also guided the 1997 acquisition of Tropicana and the 1999 initial public offering of Pepsi's bottling operations. PepsiCo's chairman, Roger Enrico, enlisted von der Heyden, 64, in September 1996 for the special role to help direct the company's restructuring.

title: A Chronicle of Uneasy Access
description: FOR the last six months, I have been stalled on the entrance ramp to the information superhighway. Back in February I signed up for my very own digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., an Internet connection so fast that it leaves last century's must have, the 56K modem, in the dust. At least that's what the ads say. When and if I ever get D.S.L., I hope it's faster than the companies that supply it.

title: A Burst of Diversity Reanoints a Center
description: ''Y Dance!'' exclaimed the title of the dance series offered last weekend at the Sol Goldman Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of the Educational Alliance. If there was a question implied by those words, the reason for the performances soon became clear.

title: Knoblauch Gets Back in Groove as Yanks Rout Blue Jays
description: He had his passion for playing baseball criticized by the blustery principal owner of the Yankees, so he barked back. He has been bothered by so many elbow, wrist and forearm injuries that he could do a cameo on ''E.R.'' He had such a terrible defensive game one night in June that the manager mercifully suggested he leave Yankee Stadium before the contest was even over.

title: Wavering Senators Feeling Pressure on China Trade Bill
description: Corporate leaders and several of President Clinton's cabinet officers intensified pressure today on wavering senators to reject an amendment that could jeopardize passage this year of a trade bill with China.

title: BRAZIL INFLATION EASES
description: The inflation rate in Brazil fell in August, reassuring investors that a spike in consumer prices the month before had faded. The benchmark IPCA inflation index rose 1.31 percent in August, down from a 1.61 percent increase in July, as the effects of government-regulated increases in electricity, telephone and gasoline prices dissipated. Gasoline prices made the largest contribution to August inflation, rising 7.54 percent. For the first eight months of the year, the Brazilian inflation rate was 4.6 percent. The Brazilian government's goal is to keep the rate from exceeding 6 percent in 2000. Jennifer L. Rich

title: CALENDAR
description: Food Fairs

title: You Can Bank on It
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, MRS. JEAN BEGLEITER
description: WOLF-Mrs. Jean Begleiter. 102. Of Hallandale, Fl. Passed away September 12, 2000. Cherished mother of Martin (Joy) Beale of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Dear sister of Hilda Blumberg and Sidney Alter of New York. Adored grandmother of David and Judith. Loving great-grandmother of Janna, Joshua, Elana, Gregory and Jonathan. Graveside services Friday, September 15 at 1PM at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel 718-645-9800.

title: Gore Bides Time, Leaving Bush in Spotlight
description: As his allies worked to make the most of Gov. George W. Bush's campaign troubles, Vice President Al Gore went about the hard work of not making news today, manufacturing gauzy pictures in a Maine high school and re-emphasizing policy positions that seem to be touching a chord.

title: Article 2000091490537038056 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREISS, PEARL
description: PREISS-Pearl. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Pearl Preiss, beloved mother of Byron Preiss. We extend our deepest condolences to Byron and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: KODAK APPOINTS PRESIDENT OF CONSUMER IMAGING
description: The Eastman Kodak Company named Daniel P. Palumbo, 42, president of its consumer imaging division. Mr. Palumbo, who joined Kodak from Procter & Gamble less than four years ago, had been the division's chief marketing officer, and worked for the last year on Internet-based photographic services. Mr. Palumbo replaces Robert J. Keegan, 53, who said only that he had accepted a position elsewhere. Kodak also named Matthias Freund, 52, chief operating officer of consumer imaging. Mr. Freund had been running Qualex, Kodak's wholesale photo-finishing subsidiary. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDWARD CAREY II
description: COHEN-Edward Carey II, late of Greenwich Village passed from us Sept. 12 at 77, one week shy of his 78th birthday. Noted Creative Dir. for Reply-O-Letter, avid photographer and bon vivant, he will be sorely missed by his many friends; his cousins, Chris Harter and Harriet Venus; his nephew Dr. Robert Jacobson; his loving companion, Irma Stecher; and by his children and son-in-law, C. Alexander Cohen, Stephanie and Tom Lewis, who survive him. Services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St (at Amsterdam Ave. on Fri., Sept. 15 at 10 am.

title: Addenda
description: Two Executives Leaving Saatchi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECHT, LISA
description: SPECHT-Lisa. The Art Students League of New York mourns the passing of Lisa Specht, League instructor, board member and president from 1968 to 1976. Lisa was a gifted artist, inspired teacher and gracious leader.

title: Games Are Nearly Here
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Sept. 15  A beleaguered Olympic movement sought to sustain its viability and to shift its focus toward the possibilities of international brotherhood and the achievements of the world's greatest athletes as the 27th Summer Games open today in what is late winter in the Southern Hemisphere.

title: 27 Million Slaves
description: To the Editor:

title: NIEDERMAYER'S HOLDOUT MAY HELP DEVILS' HOPEFULS
description: The longer defenseman Scott Niedermayer stays out of training camp as an unsigned restricted free agent, the better the chances for several candidates to earn a job with the Devils.

title: Primary Winner Faces Trial on Use of Funds
description: Pedro Espada Jr., State Senate candidate, spent the weekend making a last campaign swing through the 32nd District in the Bronx. Lawyers for Pedro Espada Jr., defendant in a criminal case, spent the weekend preparing for his trial in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Metro Business
description: New York City yesterday won another endorsement of its improved financial health when Standard & Poor's raised the city's bond rating to the highest level since the fiscal crisis of the mid 70's.

title: Suppose Cinderella Doesn't Want to Marry the Prince?
description: Cinderella rejects the prince, Little Red Riding Hood has a crush on the wolf, and Rapunzel cuts her hair. Three New York artists wondered how fairy tales might be retold by their characters. ''Fair E-Tales,'' put online last week (three.org), lets readers pick multiple viewpoints for each story. ''If you only have one story, you think that's the only way it could be,'' said Joline Blais, who created the project with Keith Frank and Jon Ippolito. And not all the stories end happily. ''The happy ending that Walt Disney gives us is neither true nor helpful -- nor satisfying to children,'' Ms. Blais said.

title: Moynihan's Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: All Eyes Will Be on One Pool
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 14  There are more than 100 municipal pools in this sprawling city where Dawn Fraser and Ian Thorpe learned how to swim astonishingly fast. On any given day in any season, you can find someone doing laps with a sense of purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGRATTO, JOAN
description: DeGRATTO-Joan. The Continuum Health Partners family is saddened over the passing of Joan DeGratto, beloved mother of our friend and colleague, Frank DeGratto, Corporate Vice President for Patient Accounts. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Frank, his family and loved ones. Peter A. Kelly Executive VP/COO Thomas J. Hayes Executive VP/CFO

title: JUDGE ATTACKS U.S. CONDUCT
description: The former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee pleaded guilty today to a single charge of mishandling nuclear secrets and left court a free man with an apology from a federal judge, who accused administration officials of abusing their power and misleading him into thinking that Dr. Lee posed a threat to national security.

title: Silk for Today, From Another Time and Place
description: Just in time for this fall's color craze: a reintroduced collection of brilliantly colored hand-woven Thai silk plaids, designed in the 1950's and 60's and out of production since the mid-70's. Jim Thompson, an American architect who moved to Thailand after World War II, turned the local silk textile business into an international triumph. In 1967, Mr. Thompson disappeared while on vacation in Malaysia. By then his company employed 20,000 weavers. The large plaids are $67.50 a yard at the Jim Thompson showroom (to the trade only), 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (800) 262-0336 for other locations.

title: A Day to Be Nervous as Some Job Cuts Seem Certain
description: Moments after e-mail messages went out to tens of thousands of employees of Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan yesterday morning announcing a proposed union of the two companies, Fritz Georges was one of the few willing to discuss publicly what many preferred remain private.

title: Bush Challenges Clinton-Gore Record on Protecting the Environment
description: Gov. George W. Bush aggressively challenged Vice President Al Gore today on one of his signature issues, calling Mr. Gore's commitment to the environment into question by saying that the Clinton administration had seriously neglected the upkeep of national parks.

title: Fans of the Flame
description: Ray Gardoll saw the Olympic torch six weeks ago. His mate, Leon Gusling, ran with it in Broken Hill where they both live, about 800 miles from Sydney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, IRVING M.
description: MOSS-Irving M., Esq. Former partner at Richenthal, Abrams and Moss. Beloved brother of Rashie Flax, Esther Fuss and Shirley Mangel and the late Harry, David, Julius and Louis Moss and Beatrice Solodkin. Cherished uncle of many nieces and nephews. Services on Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: An Unassuming Player Who Prefers to Exert a Quiet Control
description: For one of the nation's top bank executives, William B. Harrison Jr. is surprisingly accustomed to the background.

title: Article 2000091491677529722 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Janus's Too-Popular Flagship Fund Is Closed to New Money
description: The money keeps coming, but the number of Janus funds keeps shrinking. Yesterday, Janus Capital closed its flagship Janus Fund to new investors, its fifth fund closing this year.

title: PPG SAYS 3RD-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL MISS ESTIMATES
description: PPG Industries Inc. said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter earnings to fall below Wall Street's estimates because of a slowdown in the automotive and construction markets. PPG makes paint, coatings, windshields and glass for buildings. PPG, based in Pittsburgh, said it also had been hurt by higher oil and raw material costs. PPG said it expected to earn 85 cents to 90 cents a share for the third quarter. Analysts had expected the company to make 95 cents a share. Shares of PPG traded at $39.75 each, down 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EATON, HOWARD
description: EATON-Howard. Died June 7, 2000. Friends and colleagues (Loomis School, Yale 1951, Ogilvy & Mather, National Association of Broadcasters) memorial service, September 14th, 3:30PM, Yale Club, New York City.

title: 12 Hurt as Buses Collide Near Lincoln Tunnel, Snarling Traffic
description: Two buses collided head-on yesterday morning in the express bus lane leading into the Lincoln Tunnel from New Jersey, injuring the 2 drivers and 10 passengers and snarling traffic for several hours in the morning rush.

title: Apple Breaks The Mold
description: THE last time Apple Computer introduced a fundamentally new operating system was in 1984, when System 1.0 was shipped with the original Macintosh computer. Ronald Reagan was president, Steve Jobs was the chairman of Apple, and consumers' embrace of Windows was still several years away. (In those days many computers ran on the DOS platform, which involved a lot of typed commands instead of pointing and clicking.)

title: CADBURY IN PEPSI DEAL
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of Britain will buy Pepsi Cola Bottlers Australia to increase its market share in carbonated soft drinks. Terms were not disclosed. The deal will make Cadbury, through its Australian subsidiary, Schweppes Cottee's, the exclusive bottler of such brands as Pepsi, Diet Pepsi, 7 Up and Mountain Dew. John Sunderland, Cadbury's chief executive, said the expansion would enhance the efficiency and profitability of Schweppes Cottee in the 2.5 billion Australian dollar soft-drink market and nearly double its market share to 25 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Camera That Reads Text Without Moving Its Lips
description: Document scanners that can convert a page of text into an electronic file made their debut several years ago, and they have been saving businesses time, money and treatment bills for repetitive-stress injuries since then. But while text scanners tend to be big and bulky, Philips Electronics recently introduced a small portable camera for the PC that can scan images and text on the go, even with a laptop PC.

title: 2 Men Charged With Defrauding Immigrants
description: Calling themselves ''the pastor'' and ''the apostle,'' two Brooklyn men stole at least $500,000 from immigrants by promising them permanent visas if they trained to be church workers, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Wall Street Gossips Over Other Takeover Candidates
description: Who will be next?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRONNINGSATER, ARNE
description: GRONNINGSATER - Arne. The trustees, faculty and administration of Riverdale Country School extend their deepest sympathies to the children of Arne Gronningsater, who passed away on August 30, in Westport, NY. Beloved teacher and friend to generations of students, his spirit remains at Riverdale Country School. Memorial service, Saturday, September 23, 2:00 PM, All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave., NYC.

title: Is Divorce Truly a Salvation?
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER INFUSION FOR DOME
description: British authorities acknowledged that more public financing would be given in subsidies to keep the ill-starred Millennium Dome open until the end of the year. A spokeswoman said the grant -- the sixth this year -- would total around $110 million, including funds previously announced and new money to compensate for the collapse this week of a $157 million deal for the project to be sold to a division of Nomura, the Japanese investment bank. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Chinas Internet World Shrinks As Sohu.com Purchases Rival
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 14  One of China's leading Internet companies announced the purchase of a smaller rival today, setting the stage for what is expected to be a sweeping consolidation of China's fledgling Internet industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDABLE, JOHN E.
description: MANDABLE-John E. (Jack) 1922-2000. On Wednesday, September 6, 2000, at Hospice of Northern Virginia, Arlington, VA. Jack Mandable, dearly beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Rodriguez Mandable; a son, J. Burk Mandable, and a daughter, Barbara J. Livingston, from an earlier marriage; also five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Born in Chicago, Ill, Mr. Mandable lived in Westport, Ct. for almost 40 years prior to moving to Arlington, Va in 1991. He spent most of his professional life in publishing, most recently with Newsweek as Advertising Director, until retiring from that magazine in 1985. He possessed an encyclopedic knowledge of jazz, a lifelong, abiding passion for that music and the utmost respect and appreciation for its musicians. His family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made payable to: Center for Jazz Studies, referenced ''The Jack Mandable Jazz Collection'' and mailed to Columbia University, 602 Philosophy Hall, 1150 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10027

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURKIN, MARY M.
description: DURKIN-Mary M. On Tuesday, Sept. 12, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late William and Anna Durkin. Dear sister of Catherine Moran, and her brother-in-law Joseph Moran. Sister of the late James Durkin and the late Dr. Joseph Durkin. Reposing at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection at The Epiphany Church, 22 Street and Second Avenue, Saturday 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Rapp Collins Acquires Innovyx
description: Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had acquired Innovyx in Seattle, which offers e-mail application services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: It's Sting's World: Exoticism, Torchy Ballads and the Good Life
description: The general mood surrounding Sting can be read almost as an economic indicator, like the number of new cars recently sold. In austere times the enduring hit-maker's gentility seems pompous, the privilege of an aristocrat in need of a quick beheading.

title: Chase Seeks to Join Elite in Morgan Deal
description: On Wall Street, Chase Manhattan has long been considered an investment banking also-ran, disparaged by rivals as a declasse commercial bank. Now, with its proposed $30.9 billion purchase of J. P. Morgan, which was officially announced, Chase hopes that it will finally break into the club of financial firms with enduring global influence.

title: Donald Whyte, 68, Philharmonic Violinist
description: Donald Whyte, a violinist in the New York Philharmonic, died on Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: $33 Billion Stock Deal To Form a U.S. Giant In Investment Banking : J.P. Morgan Being Sold To Chase Manhattan
description: NEW YORK  Chase Manhattan Corp. said Wednesday that it would buy J.P. Morgan & Co. for about dollars 33 billion in stock, positioning two of the most venerable names in American commercial banking to compete with the world's biggest securities houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, SIDNEY
description: SOKOL-Sidney. Died September 12, 2000 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Dorothy for over 65 years, cherished father of Eileen Schwartzburg, Jacqueline Fleischman and Monte Sokol. Grandfather of six and great-grandfather of three, he will be dearly missed by us all. He was a valued employee of Ex-Lax Inc. for over 50 years. A memorial service in his honor will be held at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Rd., Plandome, NY on Friday, Sept. 15th at 9:45AM. Donations in his memory may be made to Council Center for Senior Citizens, 1001 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn, NY 11223.

title: Gigantic Banks, Evocative Names
description: The proposed takeover of J. P. Morgan by Chase Manhattan to form the country's third-largest financial services institution is the latest in a series of mergers that have wiped out many of New York City's great banks of the past. Gone as independent banks are Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Bankers Trust and Guaranty Trust. Indeed, some of the great banks survive in name only. Once Chemical took over Chase in 1996, an independent Chase ceased to exist. But Chemical ditched its own name in favor of one that evoked images of Abraham Lincoln's Treasury secretary, after whom Chase Bank was named, and the Rockefeller family. After this latest takeover, an independent J. P. Morgan will also cease to exist, though the merged corporation will be called J. P. Morgan Chase. That sounds more impressive than Chemical.

title: At Long Last, Apple Unveils New Mac Software
description: After years of false starts, Apple Computer introduced its first radically changed operating system since the original Macintosh entered the market in 1984. The much-anticipated new system, called Mac OS X, was released to the public in an evaluation version for $29.95.

title: INSIDE
description: Bomb Blast in Indonesia

title: System Lets Traffic Lights Wave Buses Through
description: AS the growing number of people on the roads in the Los Angeles area clogs traffic, often to glacial speeds, a form of transportation that is invisible to most members of the middle class in that car-oriented megalopolis is helping people travel faster: the bus.

title: The Safety Calculus
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Delays Punitive Duties On European Luxury Goods

title: The Mahogany King's Brief Reign; Business Interests Lurked Behind Fiji's Haphazard Coup
description: This South Pacific archipelago is best known for its fine-grained white beaches and cloudless vistas of cobalt sea. But a cockscomb range of steep-sided mountains divides the main island of Viti Levu, and nothing looks the same on the far side.

title: Palm Offers a System Upgrade, But It's Not Free This Time
description: When Palm Computing introduced a batch of new Palm handhelds in February with a new operating system, Palm OS 3.5, it said the new system would be posted on its Web site in about 30 days or so. As in the past, owners of earlier Palm models would be able to download it for free.

title: Fixing Up a Co-op Is Tougher Than Nails
description: IN a building near Union Square, the co-op board had absolutely no problem approving a couple's plan to combine their old apartment with the one they had bought on the floor below.

title: But the Catalog Claimed It Would Convert Into Bunk Beds
description: The Better Business Bureau says there were 9,123 complaints against furniture retailers across the country in 1999, ranking them third, close behind computer dealers (9,538), but far behind auto dealerships (17,686). Ronna D. Brown, president of the Better Business Bureau serving the New York City region (which itself had 1,209 complaints about furniture retailers), said most involved late delivery or customers' receiving the wrong goods, or goods they thought were of unacceptable quality. Ms. Brown sees reason to be hopeful, however: ''Two out of every three complaints we receive are resolved to the customer's satisfaction,'' she said, ''so things could be a lot bleaker.'' BONNIE SCHWARTZ

title: European Central Bank Moves to Prop Up Sliding Euro
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 14  The European Central Bank took a limited step today toward intervening in world markets on behalf of the downtrodden euro, using money from its foreign reserves to buy $2.5 billion worth of euros and briefly halting the currency's tailspin against the dollar.

title: Bypassing College
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Agrees to Act On Speaker Fee Ban
description: Senate Republicans have agreed to a request from Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to introduce legislation repealing an 11-year ban on speaking fees for members of the federal judiciary, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAILOVE, MATHILDA F.
description: BRAILOVE-Mathilda F. The officers and staff of United Jewish Communities (UJC) deeply mourn the passing of Mathilda Brailove, a renowned local and national leader. Since the 1948 UJA study mission to Palestine, she always felt a deep sense of commitment to the State of Israel, and devoted much of her life on its behalf. Her love of the Jewish people was the source of her tireless efforts to raise funds for Israel and the Central Jersey Jewish Federation. As a lifelong supporter of UJA (the predecessor organization to UJC), Mrs. Brailove helped found the National Women's Constituency, and went on to become its president. Later, she became the chair of the Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey's Women's Division and was responsible for launching the federation's Lion of Judah program. In the early years of UJA, Mrs. Brailove devoted considerable time travelling across the country speaking about humanitarian and philanthropic initiatives. Her active role in federation, and her dedication to the Jewish people will be greatly missed. She has left a very rich legacy. Tens of thousands of people will benefit from her leadership and generosity for many years to come. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughters Susan and Linda, to her seven grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, UJC Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, UJC Chairman of the Exec. Comm Robert M. Schrayer, UJC Campaign/FRD National Chairman Ann-Louise Klepper UJC Chairman, Nat'l Women's Constituency Carole Solomon, UJC Campaign/FRD Pillar Committee Chairman Stephen D. Folender, UJC Pres & Chief Exec. Officer
