title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a hearing of the New York City Council's General Welfare Committee, at which homeless people with AIDS testified that they had been turned away from emergency shelters, misstated the date of a second hearing scheduled on the complaints. It is Sept. 29, not Sept. 28.

title: Details Begin to Take Shape From Nassau Budget Plan
description: Nassau County residents would pay more property taxes next year under a budget plan being considered by the County Legislature, but they would see more uniformed police officers out on street patrol, instead of working desk jobs.

title: G.M. to Double Stake in Suzuki Motors
description: General Motors said today that it would spend $653 million to double its stake in the Suzuki Motor Corporation to increase its share of the fast-growing auto market in the Asia-Pacific area.

title: Rome Journal; English Without Tears, Thanks to TV
description: Jason Priestley, the slouching star of ''Beverly Hills 90210,'' is not best known for his mastery of proper English diction. But in Italy his high school angst has been put to use to help Italians learn English. Computer users can freeze a frame on a CD-ROM version of the show and pause his mumbled delivery. If that doesn't help, students can click to a more precise, mid-Atlantic voice-over.

title: Cautious Assessments Favor the Performance of Mrs. Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton won the admiration of a small group of undecided voters tonight for what they called an assured, good-natured performance in her face-off with Representative Rick A. Lazio, who struck them as too acerbic.

title: Dream Team Seeks a Challenge
description: Alonzo Mourning acknowledged today what his teammates already knew: getting motivated to annihilate inferior basketball nations is hard work.

title: Primary Results Seen as Blow to the Bronx Democratic Leader
description: His name was not on a single ballot in Tuesday's primary election. But Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic Party chairman, had as much at stake as any candidate whose fate was determined at the ballot box.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a new board co-chairman of Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. referred incorrectly to the company's status. It is liquidating its business; it is not in bankruptcy.

title: TV You Need Not See
description: As the fall TV season gets under way, network honchos find themselves trapped in their own version of ''Survivor,'' with a nemesis more treacherous than a rat, a snake or a fat naked guy: a new electronic device called TiVo, which eliminates TV commercials. But TiVo may just be the beginning. If it proves successful, it is only a matter of time before manufacturers produce other TV-altering devices to complicate network executives' lives even further:

Survived by her beloved husband Warren; sons and daughter-in-law Peter Ente and William and Lisa Ente; stepsons and daughters-inlaw Mark and Rhonda Lubin and Gary and Wendy Lubin, and grandchildren Zachary and Jacob, Randy, Audrey and Greg, and Julie and David. Donations can be made in her memory to the charity or health organization of choice.

title: Movie Theaters Seek Happy Ending
description: If it were a Hollywood production, ''The Plight of the Megaplex'' would be a tear-jerker starring companies brought to ruin because they sought to bring hourly show times, reclining seat backs, retractable armrests and stadium seating to every last corner of America.

Survived by his daughters Fredda Sacharow and Deborah Klein Batelli, brothers Abraham and Marvin, and grandchildren Rachel, Leah and Joshua. Services are today, 10:00 am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Wheels and Their Inventors
description: The automobile factory as theme park is gaining ground. In Wolfsburg, Germany, Volkswagen has opened the 62-acre, $400 million Autostadt museum, designed by Gunter Henn, with a manufacturing plant, lakes, cafes and a hotel. In December, Audi's $20 million Automuseum, above, will open in Ingolstadt. The glass-clad museum will trace Audi history since it began as Horch in 1899. Billed by the company as a comprehensive tourist concept (pick up a car, go on a factory tour, have a meal), the museum, also designed by Mr. Henn, will house exhibits on the relationship between man and technology (according to Julius Von Ingelheim, the project director, even stronger than that between man and woman). Some 60 cars and 20 motorcycles will be on view, including the 1939 Horch 855 Roadster, the 1927 Horch 303 and the 1923 Audi G. BONNIE SCHWARTZ

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I sincerely apologize to you, Dr. Lee, for the unfair manner you were held in custody by the executive branch.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, BERNARD
description: SINGER-Bernard. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime former member, Bernard Singer, and extend our sincere condolences to the members of his family. Jeffrey Citron, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Suits Charge Conspiracy by Maker and Doctors' Group to Expand Ritalin Use
description: Lawyers involved in class-action lawsuits against the tobacco industry, gun makers and health maintenance organizations filed two lawsuits yesterday against another target, the widely used drug Ritalin.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOWE'S CO., Wilkesboro, N.C., the No. 2 U.S. home-improvement chain, said it would build an $80 million regional distribution center in Findlay, Ohio, that would employ more than 500 people. The 1.25-million-square-foot center will supply products to about 100 Lowe's stores in the lower Great Lakes region. Construction is expected to be completed in October 2001.

title: European Countries Resist Cutting Fuel Taxes
description: Truckers and farmers around continental Europe continued their protests today, but political leaders dug in their heels against cuts in the gasoline tax.

title: NAPSTER FILES ARGUMENTS
description: Napster, the Web-based music software company whose program lets consumers download and share music files, made its final written presentation yesterday to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco. The presentation was in reply to the brief filed last week by the Recording Industry Association of America, the plaintiff in the case. Napster, based in Redwood City, Calif., is seeking to overturn a lower court decision in July that threatens to shut down the company by blocking major-label songs from being traded on the Napster service. Napster's presentation asserts that its service does not diminish the value of the music copyrights, insisting rather that the RIAA is trying to maintain control over music distribution. Oral arguments in the case are scheduled for Oct. 2. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Article 2000091491425981515 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: RAMBUS JUMPS ON LICENSING DEAL
description: Shares of Rambus rose yesterday after the memory chip designer said it had reached a licensing agreement with NEC of Japan. NEC is the world's second-largest chip maker and the biggest one to sign a licensing agreement with Rambus, which is embroiled in lawsuits over licensing royalties. It is the fourth such deal for Rambus, which designs but does not make memory chips. Rambus shares finished up $6.50, or 8 percent, at $83.31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, SAUL
description: JARCHO-Saul, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague and mentor. Dr Jarcho came to Mount Sinai as an intern in 1931 and served the institution and its patients for more than 50 years. A highly respected scholar and teacher, he will be remembered as an outstanding medical historian as well as for his clinical contributions. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARONSON, BENJAMIN
description: AARONSON-Benjamin. 86, passed away September 11, 2000, in Aventura, Fla. Service Friday in Florida. For information call 1-800-226-9905.

title: A Place to Go When There's a Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On
description: WHEN an earthquake roused tens of thousands of Northern California residents from their sleep early in the morning on Sept. 3, hundreds of those rattled souls went straight to their computers and logged onto the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLON, JOHN A.
description: SELLON-John A. Rye, New York. A retired executive of the American Reinsurance Company died Monday at his home in Rye, New York. Mr. Sellon was the Senior Underwriting Officer of American Re until his retirement in 1972. Born May 20, 1910 in London, England, Mr. Sellon arrived in the United States with his family in 1918 and established residence in Rye, New York. He graduated from Rye Country Day and the Choate School in Wallingford, CT. He attended Princeton University for one year, but left to pursue his professional career during the Great Depression. Starting at American Re in 1931, he rose through the underwriting ranks until he became the Senior Underwriting Officer in the 1950's. He remained active in the insurance industry after his retirement, cofounding Sellon Associates, a reinsurance brokerage in 1973 with his son, Peter. Sellon Associates co-founded MISC (the municipal bond insurance service company), which is one of the predecessor entities of MBIA, Inc., the municipal bond insurance firm headquartered in Armonk, NY. Mr. Sellon remained active and involved in the re-insurance industry through his association with Sellon Associates and MBIA well into his 80's. Mr. Sellon was a benefactor to many charitable insititutions, in particular the Theosophical Society of America, which is headquartered in Wheaton, Illinois and especially the Society's Lodge in New York City. He was instrumental in the founding and development of the Theosophical Society's retreat in the Berkshires of upstate New York. Mr. Sellon made numerous international trips to theosophical gatherings in the company of his wife, the former Emily B. Sellon. Mrs. Sellon, who was a noted lecturer on Theosophy, passed away in 1993. In addition to his three sons, Peter, Michael and Jeffrey, Mr. Sellon is survived by nine grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A memorial service for Mr. Sellon will be planned at a later date. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made to The New York Theosophical Society, 240 East 53rd Street, New York, NY 10022, in Mr. Sellon's memory.

title: Bush Tax Cut Loses Appeal For Republicans in Congress
description: Many Congressional Republicans have decided that the big across-the-board tax reduction advocated by their party's presidential nominee does not play well in their races for re-election and have instead adopted a strategy that emphasizes debt reduction and bite-size tax cuts.

title: HUGHES WINS SATELLITE WORK
description: New ICO, the satellite communications company soon to merge into Craig O. McCaw's ambitious Teledesic satellite venture, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Hughes Space and Communications Company on plans for Hughes to produce 14 satellites. The agreement includes 3 new satellites and modifications to 11 spacecraft that Hughes had in production when ICO Global Communications, New ICO's predecessor, filed for bankruptcy just over a year ago. Mr. McCaw led a group that brought the company out of bankruptcy for $1.2 billion and forged plans for a satellite system capable of offering a range of data and Internet services in addition to the voice traffic ICO Global had envisioned. The network is now scheduled to begin operations in 2003. Hughes said the satellite design was one of the most complex ever undertaken. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Boxing Showdown Is Set
description: SYDNEY Australia -- One of the most anticipated matchups of the Olympic boxing tournament  the American heavyweight Michael Bennett and the two- time Olympic heavyweight champion Felix Savon of Cuba  will not take place in a gold medal bout. If Bennett and Savon advance through their first two preliminary fights, they would face each other in the quarterfinals Sept. 26.

title: White House to Revisit Chile Files That C.I.A. Wants to Block
description: The White House ordered a new look today at several hundred files that the Central Intelligence Agency intends to withhold when it releases American documents about the 1973 military coup in Chile.

title: Inktomi to Buy FastForward In $1.3 Billion Stock Swap
description: The Inktomi Corporation, which specializes in Internet infrastructure, said today that it had agreed to acquire FastForward Networks Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $1.3 billion. FastForward, based in San Francisco, has developed software technology for the distribution and management of live broadcasting over the Internet.

title: The Jukebox Comes Home
description: MENTION the word jukebox and most of us imagine some garish, pot-bellied machine that spins a few records (or compact discs) for a handful of coins.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS EXPECTS TO MISS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The Sherwin-Williams Company said its third-quarter earnings would probably miss estimates because of higher raw-material costs and price competition in South America. Sherwin-Williams expects to earn 66 cents to 69 cents a share in the third quarter, said Conway Ivy, a company spokesman. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected Sherwin-Williams to earn 73 cents. The company earned 66 cents in the third quarter of last year. The company's shares fell $1.63, to $22.25. Sherwin-Williams, based in Cleveland, joined the DuPont Company and the Rohm & Haas Company in warning that materials costs will hurt earnings. Mr. Ivy said the raw materials are more expensive because of the higher costs of natural gas and oil, which are used to make raw materials for paint.

title: BERTELSMANN'S CASH CACHE
description: Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, Europe's largest media company, has 30 billion marks ($13.3 billion) available to spend on buying more media properties and online commerce units, the chief executive Thomas Middelhoff said. Mr. Middelhoff, speaking at a news conference, did not specify what kind of companies Bertelsmann would look for. Bertelsmann, which owns the book publisher, Random House, and BMG Entertainment, also reported that its net income in the year to June 30 rose 45 percent to 1.3 billion marks.

description: The biggest smirks in politics today are on the faces of participants in the rhetoric of ridicule known as ''the snickering campaign.''

description: Buffalo quarterback Rob Johnson sounded just fine on the phone today, his voice not betraying the aches his body endures after being sacked 10 times in two games, his confidence not darkened by the prospect of more hits to come.

title: SAP SYSTEMS RALLIES
description: SAP Systems Integration A.G.'s shares nearly tripled on the first day of trading after demand for the stock of the computer-systems integrator outstripped supply about 56 times. The shares rose as high as 53.5 euros on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt. SAP SI, which is owned by SAP A.G. and Software A.G., sold the shares at 19 euros each, raising 166 million euros ($143 million) in an initial public offering. The stock was priced at the top end of the range used to canvas investor interest.

title: France Warns Iraq on Weapons Inspections
description: France has warned Iraq not to expect any weakening of the Security Council's determination to send United Nations inspectors back into Iraq to eliminate weapons of mass destruction before sanctions can be lifted.

title: With Monorail Out, Fliers at Newark Find Bus Isn't So Bad
description: When Danielle Gaydos, an executive for a film production company, went to Newark International Airport Saturday for one of her frequent trips to Los Angeles, she parked her car in Lot D and took the monorail to Terminal C. When she returned this morning at 6:30 on the red-eye, she was surprised to be greeted by red-jacketed customer service representatives who directed her instead to a shuttle bus back to the parking lot and even helped with her luggage.

title: INFLATION IN CHINA
description: China's consumer prices rose for a fourth month in August, as faster economic growth increased demand for everything from food to computers. The consumer price index rose 0.3 percent from a year earlier, the National Statistics Bureau said. That was down from the 0.5 percent increase in July and less than economists' expectations of a 0.7 percent gain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LIEBOFF, JANET
description: LIEBOFF-Janet With undiminished love and memory you are always in my thoughts. Harry

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPEFEWER BRITISH JOBLESS Britain said the number of unemployed fell to a 25- year low of 3.6 percent in August from 3.7 percent in July as a further 18,000 people found work. The figures reflect the contrast between Britain and continental Europe, where the average unemployment rate is almost three times as high, but the fall is causing problems for manufacturers unable to find skilled workers. Other figures showed wage increases also fell in the three months through July to an annualized 3.9 percent, down from 4.1 percent in the previous quarter, reducing worries about the likely impact of inflation on interest rates. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: SWISS REINSURANCE PROFIT
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said its first-half earnings rose 27 percent, beating analysts' forecasts, as the company profited from investments and generated more revenue from life reinsurance. Net income rose to 3.24 billion Swiss francs ($1.83 billion), or 229 francs a share, from 2.56 billion francs, or 179 francs, in the period a year earlier.

title: There's a Silver Lining in Empty Nests
description: TWO weeks ago, we packed our daughter's sneakers, CD's, laptop and rice cooker and drove her to college, doing our bit to contribute to the biggest youth exodus since Woodstock. During the weeks bracketing Labor Day, more than 13 million students enrolled as college undergraduates, the first loud rumblings of a baby boom echo that will have social ramifications for years to come.

title: Relatives of Dorismond File Civil Suit Against Police
description: NEW YORK -- The family of a man shot to death by police has sued the city and the officers involved for $300 million, aiming particular criticism at the mayor for attacking the man's character after his death. Relatives of Patrick Dorismond blamed the city, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, former Police Commissioner Howard Safir, and the officers for violating Dorismond's civil rights during a drug buy-and-bust on March 16. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn, described the officials' actions as illegal, malicious, callous and negligent. Dorismond, a 26-year-old security guard, became the fourth unarmed black man shot to death by police in little more than a year when he was killed during a struggle with an undercover detective outside a bar. Attorney Johnnie Cochran said the shooting was an example of racial profiling and blamed Giuliani for releasing Dorismond's sealed juvenile records to ``dirty up his character and reputation.'' ``We're going to take him to task for demonizing a person who was an altar boy,'' Cochran said. The mayor at one point suggested that Dorismond had caused his own death and refused to offer the family condolences. Giuliani has since acknowledged he made a mistake by not expressing appropriate sympathies. Lorna Goodman, a lawyer for the city, had not seen the lawsuit and had no comment Wednesday. The police department also declined to comment. Marie Rose Dorismond, the victim's mother, said she was pleased that the civil lawsuit had been filed. ``I guess it's time for the justice to start,'' she said.

title: Chinese for Young Collectors: High Style, Lower Prices
description: SINCE the late 19th century, when Westerners began trading extensively with China, there have been established wealthy collectors seeking Chinese antiques. But in the last 10 years, a group of younger, less affluent collectors has emerged. ''There are two separate markets,'' said James Godfrey, the director for Chinese works of art at Sotheby's auction house in Manhattan. ''There are buyers of classical furniture -- 16th-, 17th- and 18th-century material of huanghuali and zitan,'' two of the most sought-after hardwoods. (In 1996, a 17th-century Chinese huanghuali and marble screen sold for $1.1 million at Christie's.)

The debate was held in Buffalo and broadcast live on NBC stations across the state. Its moderator was Tim Russert of NBC. title: The Ultimate Remote Means Never Having To Leave the Couch
description: DAVID ALPERT, president of an Internet startup called MarketingInfo, admits that he is addicted to remote controls. He estimates that the members of his gadget-oriented family have accumulated about 55 remote controls over the years around their house in Old Westbury, N.Y. There was one for the air-conditioning, one for the lights. They needed 5 remote controls to watch a movie and 12 to listen to the stereo, with separate controls for components like the subwoofers and the equalizer.

description: THE Mac OS X beta software comes neatly packaged from Apple inside a clean white folder with a big blue X on the front. Even though Apple says X should be pronounced ''10,'' the enigmatic appeal of the letter X seems vaguely more appropriate. X, after all, is the unknown -- and the unknown is both the joy and the curse of beta-ware.

title: Lustrous, Supple Leather, Made to Last a Lifetime
description: LEATHER furniture and home accessories can be as comfortable as a pair of old leather gloves. Yet leather is also durable. ''Leather has an old-rich look that only gets more beautiful with age,'' said Teddy Edelman, an owner of Edelman Leather in New Milford, Conn. The look is classic, and good leather properly cared for will last a lifetime. How do you care for leather properly? Clean it gingerly with very little saddle soap, Murphy's Oil Soap or a solution of water and mild soap powder like Ivory Snow, said Mary Ellen Pinkham, author of Mary Ellen's Complete Home Reference Book (Crown, 1994). Never, she said, use detergent or wax.

It is the book as litmus test, used mostly but not always in measuring a lurking romance.

title: TUPPERWARE TO BUY BEAUTICONTROL TO ENTER NEW MARKET
description: The Tupperware Corporation said it had agreed to buy BeautiControl Inc. for about $60 million so it could begin selling cosmetics and nutritional products. Tupperware will pay $7 a share for BeautiControl stock, the companies said. BeautiControl, based in Carrollton, Tex., had retail sales of $130 million in 1999. Shareholders holding about 47 percent of BeautiControl agreed to tender their stock, the companies said.

title: The Reclusive Beach Boy Revisits a Breakthrough
description: Most Brian Wilson fans never expected to see him onstage performing the Beach Boys' groundbreaking 1966 album, ''Pet Sounds,'' from beginning to end. He made the album in isolation after he stopped touring with the Beach Boys, working in the studio oblivious to commercial prospects or to whether the elaborately orchestrated songs could ever be played in concert. Yet there he was on Sunday night at the Jones Beach Theater with a band and orchestra behind him, introducing ''Pet Sounds'' as ''about 40 minutes of really nice music.''

title: A Reviving Malaysia Gives Foreign Investors New Jitters
description: Efforts by Malaysia to strengthen its banking system by forcing its 54 financial institutions to merge into just 10 appear to be backfiring, as concerns about government interference revive doubt about the industry's health and the risks of investing in the country.

Forbes in the Democratic primary in the First Congressional District on Long Island misidentified the incumbent Congressman who was defeated in 1994 by Mr. Forbes. He was George J. Hochbrueckner; Thomas J. Downey was defeated by Rick A. Lazio in the Second Congressional District in 1992.

title: Two Countries Under One Banner
description: Athletes from North and South Korea will march into Sydney's Olympic Stadium as one nation tomorrow, in what should prove one of the emotional highlights of the Games' opening ceremony. Though the two nations will compete separately, their decision to march together under a single white flag with a blue depiction of an undivided peninsula should be greeted as another significant step toward reconciliation. The joint march will also be a tribute to the Olympic aspiration that sports can break down barriers between people.

title: Design Chosen for Memorial to Dr. King
description: A monument with a ''stone of hope'' that represents the nonviolent civil rights movement was selected tonight as the memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that will be built on the Washington Mall.

title: Kayaker to Carry Flag
description: Cliff Meidl, a sprint kayaker who has survived more than just turbulent waters and stiff competition, was chosen as the flagbearer for the United States Olympic team in the opening ceremony on Friday. Meidl was elected in a vote by the American team, and chosen over a list of other candidates that included Brandi Chastain, Teresa Edwards and Dara Torres.

title: 30 Fall Ill After Race Through A Jungle
description: Participants in the Eco-Challenge expedition race in Malaysian Borneo that ended Sept. 1 got more than they bargained for, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. The C.D.C. said that at least 30 of the 155 Americans who participated in the event have come down with a bacterial infection, leptospirosis, and many have been hospitalized.

title: N.B.A. ADDS TO WEB PRESENCE
description: Intel and the National Basketball Association announced an agreement yesterday to create a combined venture that will include broadband programming and interactive game broadcasts. Officials said the deal would give fans access to daily N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. highlights as well as archived N.B.A. highlights. In May, Intel, the world's largest computer chip maker, and Excalibur Technologies, an Internet company, announced that they would form a new company, the Convera Corporation, to enable owners of valuable content to produce and securely sell audio, video and other information. According to the agreement yesterday, the N.B.A. will receive a 10 percent equity stake in Convera and the basketball association's commissioner, David Stern, will join the company's board of directors. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: 400 Ideas in Search of Clarity
description: Neon-colored worms are running amok in architecture, if ''10 x 10,'' a sampling of recent projects around the globe, is to be believed. The publisher (Phaidon Press, $59.95) asked 10 critics on five continents to name 10 hot, youngish architects, then devoted four pages to each. Many nominees, like Neil M. Denari of Los Angeles, submitted similar-looking neon-colored proposals (bottom). Whether they are going to be built, or even could be, I'm not sure. Some project descriptions come not with specifics but with theoretical praise for the designers' ability to, say, ''reverse the failure of much 'negative space' by attempting to offer a critique of the notion of fragmentation and deformation as well as the potential discovery of a new spatiality,'' as Roger Connah describes Anamorphosis' work in Athens. Equally impenetrable are layouts involving white text on a black background. It buzzes before the eyes like Op Art.

title: Jornada Handheld Gets a Makeover
description: They're smaller than a laptop -- and a breadbox -- but bigger than a Palm Pilot. Unlike their digital siblings, however, handheld PC's never fulfilled predictions that they were destined to become mass-market gadgets.

title: BARNESANDNOBLE.COM BUYING FATBRAIN
description: Barnesandnoble.com, the second-largest online bookseller, behind Amazon.com, said yesterday that it would buy the technology and business bookseller Fatbrain.com for $64 million in stock and cash. The price will be $4.25 a share. That price was a discount from Fatbrain's closing price of $4.39 a share yesterday. The terms are 75 percent of the price in stock and the rest in cash. The company said the acquisition will help it expand its sales to corporate customers.

title: Payton Ends Drama With Home Run in 10th
