title: A British Woolworth's Hangs On in the Modern Marketplace
description: One of the last vestiges of the Woolworth's empire lives on in a British company, Kingfisher P.L.C., and though it has managed to outlast its American parent, the chain of five-and-dime stores is still searching for its place in modern retailing.

title: Aalto Room May Be Shown the Door
description: AN architectural gem is in danger of becoming an architectural millstone. A suite of conference rooms designed in 1964 by Alvar Aalto could join the list of extinct legendary New York interiors, now that their owner has announced that it would like them removed from an office building near the United Nations. The interior is not protected by landmark status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, MARK
description: FORBES-Mark. One of a kind. His passion for theatre, friends and life is forever. Died Sept 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ROY
description: SHAPIRO-Roy. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving and devoted father of Lily, Alexander and Amanda Pirot. Devoted stepfather of Lance & Frank (Mindy) Mayer. Cherished grandfather of Max, Stefanie, and Adam. Adored brother of Sunny Soloff and the late Armin Speer. Loyal friend to many. We are forever blessed by your love & kindness. Services at 1 PM Thursday at the ''Riverside Chapel'', 181 West 76 St., NYC.

title: It Seems the MetroStars Peaked a Month Too Soon
description: The MetroStars were the best team in Major League Soccer last month. And they had aspirations of capturing a soccer triple: finishing first in the regular season, winning the league championship and taking the United States Open Cup.

title: New Hope for a Life Lost to War
description: BUDAPEST Sept. 13  The world's longest-serving prisoner of war smiles and his lips slowly form a name. "Hitler," he says. "He had a bird on his cap."

title: Technology Briefings
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS HUGHES WINS SATELLITE WORK New ICO , the satellite communications company soon to merge into Craig O. McCaw's ambitious Teledesic satellite venture, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Hughes Space and Communications Company on plans for Hughes to produce 14 satellites. The agreement includes 3 new satellites and modifications to 11 spacecraft that Hughes had in production when ICO Global Communications, New ICO's predecessor, filed for bankruptcy just over a year ago. Mr. McCaw led a group that brought the company out of bankruptcy for $1.2 billion and forged plans for a satellite system capable of offering a range of data and Internet services in addition to the voice traffic ICO Global had envisioned. The network is now scheduled to begin operations in 2003. Hughes said the satellite design was one of the most complex ever undertaken. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: City Called Too Aggressive On Health Care Repayment
description: The Giuliani administration's pursuit of reimbursements from city residents whose spouses benefited from government-paid nursing home care drew charges of cruelty and insensitivity yesterday from city officials, a former top federal health care regulator and some of the people who have been the subject of recent collection efforts.

title: Article 2000091490277095600 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Only Footsteps From Those Big Empty Lofts
description: Scarlet rose petals mark the sidewalk in front of BoHoCo (below right), a home furnishings shop on one of SoHo's quietest streets, and stone lions flank the door. ''Crosby Street is not a busy, busy street,'' said Jacqueline Hewitt, an owner of the store, whose acronym stands for Bohemian Home Colonial. Exoticism, as a style of decor, is crucial here. Except for the lions, which are new and were carved in America, everything is imported in the two-story, 1,000-square-foot shop, fragrant with incense. A late 19th century Chinese rickshaw ($25,000, above) idles behind a bed draped with a 16-foot antique magenta sari ($550); on the bed is an Indian beaded patchwork pillow ($185). Saris are also sold as tablecloths and, for one couple's wedding, a runner for the aisle. From France, a new gilded wood chandelier, above, is 5 by 4 1/4 feet ($2,500). And from Dubai, there are velvet doorstops, designed as poufs holding desert sand and topped by brass-tipped glass knobs. The poufs come in various sizes, including 4 inches high and 5 3/4 inches across, and 5 1/2 inches high and 8 1/2 inches across; they are $100 to $130. BoHoCo is at 91 Crosby Street (near Prince Street); (212) 431-4304. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Lazio Battles Mrs. Clinton on Education
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, will begin broadcasting this 30-second advertisement, ''Education Compare,'' statewide today. It follows his speech on education Monday night. Mrs. Clinton and the state Democratic Party began running ads last week praising Mrs. Clinton's education proposals and assailing Mr. Lazio's Congressional voting on the issue.

title: Los Angeles Times Closing 14 Papers
description: Executives of The Los Angeles Times said yesterday that they were closing 14 money-losing ''Our Times'' local newspapers, laying off 125 employees and abandoning the strategy of winning new readers and advertisers with hyperlocal coverage of traffic, schools and community groups.

title: Swiss Take Gold and Bronze in Triathlon
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Switzerland's Brigitte McMahon outswam the sharks, bicycled with the pack and outsprinted the field to win the inaugural Olympic women's triathlon.

title: As Fuel Protests Widen, Blair Takes On Demonstrators
description: Facing the most serious challenge to his leadership, Prime Minister Tony Blair called on protesters tonight to lift their virtual siege of oil refineries and storage depots, saying their actions were paralyzing the country and endangering lives.

title: WHAT'S NEXT; Giving Chips a Lesson in Power Management
description: THE trouble with microprocessors today, according to Dr. David Albonesi, a professor of electrical and computer engineering at the University of Rochester, is that they are just too powerful. Most of the programs they run tap only a fraction of a processor's capacity, yet the unused portion exacts a price, as every notebook computer owner who has raced against a fading battery knows. Powerful means power-hungry.

title: Into the Medicare Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: A Changing City, A Changing Mindset; Met Exhibit Chronicles New York's Rise
description: Even 141 years ago, New York City was the most conceited city in the hemisphere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VENDETTI, RALPH
description: VENDETTI-Ralph. On September 12, 2000 of Manhattan Beach, California. Formerly of Westfield and Newark, NJ. Husband of Marti (Nee Galindo). Father of Christian Silva, Nicole and Alexa Vendetti. Son of Carmen and Josephine (Fi Fi) (Nee Fallone) Vendetti. Brother of Lori Ann Vendetti and the late Carmine Vendetti. Visitation at the Galante Funeral Home, 2800 Morris Ave., Union, NJ on Friday from 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. James Church, Springfield, NJ on Saturday at 9:15 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to the charity of your choice.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- San Diego, Santa Ana and Pomona, Calif.

title: Games Need New Blood to Survive
description: SYDNEY Australia -- The sun is setting on fading empires. Gerontocracies are going out of style. The Olympic movement is starting to resemble the Soviet Union in its final days, just before people attacked the Berlin Wall with sledgehammers. In this case, the cracks are appearing from within.

title: In Challenge, Iraqi Jet Flew Over Saudi Desert, U.S. Says
description: An Iraqi fighter jet flew into Saudi Arabian airspace last week in what officials here suspect was an attempt to provoke a confrontation with the United States on the eve of the United Nations summit meeting in New York, State Department and military officials said today.

title: The Grandfather, the Father, the Donald
description: THE TRUMPS

title: Metro Business; New York City Bonds Get Higher Rating
description: New York City yesterday won another endorsement of its improved financial health when Standard & Poor's raised the city's bond rating to the highest level since the fiscal crisis of the mid 70's.

title: Lucy A. Wicks, 49, Psychologist And Alternative School Founder
description: Lucy A. Wicks, a psychologist who worked with people infected with H.I.V. and the founder of the Manhattan School for Children, one of the most innovative and sought-after alternative public schools in Manhattan, died Saturday at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center. She was 49.

title: Warren J. Wolfe The Times's Former Ad Director, 83
description: Warren J. Wolfe, a former advertising director at The New York Times, died on Sept. 1 in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Bypassing College
description: To the Editor:

title: Lazio and Hillary Clinton Clash On Donations, Taxes and Trust
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio slashed into each other for nearly 60 minutes in a nationally televised debate tonight, attacking each other's credentials, integrity and political views. Near the debate's end, Mr. Lazio crossed the stage to the first lady, waving a piece of paper in his hand as he unsuccessfully challenged her to sign a pledge renouncing the use of soft money in her campaign.

title: West Takes a Stand Against Clinton Plan
description: The federal government calls this stretch of the Upper Missouri River ''a priceless remnant of primitive America.''

title: 'Rats': No Accident
description: To the Editor:

title: House Backs Adding Gays to Hate Crime Law
description: The House of Representatives today endorsed for the first time a measure to make attacks on gays a federal hate crime, a move that was one of President Clinton's legislative priorities.

title: The Bad and the Ugly
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Chips a Lesson in Power Management
description: The trouble with microprocessors today, according to Dr. David Albonesi, a professor of electrical and computer engineering at the University of Rochester, is that they are just too powerful. Most of the programs they run tap only a fraction of a processor's capacity, yet the unused portion exacts a price, as every notebook computer owner who has raced against a fading battery knows. Powerful means power- hungry.

title: Clemens Stakes Claim As Yanks' No. 1 Starter
description: Unless the Yankees experience a monumental collapse this month, they will play their first postseason game in just 19 days. Joe Torre has a feel for what his starting lineup will look like that night. Bernie Williams should be healthy, Chuck Knoblauch should be easing in at second base and Jose Canseco or Glenallen Hill could start at designated hitter.

title: Is Divorce Truly a Salvation?
description: To the Editor:

title: MICROSOFT ACQUIRES MUSIC WEB SITE
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had acquired MongoMusic, a Redwood City, Calif., producer of Web-based digital music technology. The MongoMusic.com Web site allows consumers to sample music and create their own ''stations'' of favorite tunes. Founded in June 1999, the company was originally financed by Nokia and Sony. Microsoft officials said they found MongoMusic attractive because of its history of strong relationships with the recording industry. With the acquisition of MongoMusic, Microsoft is expanding its MSN network of Web sites, which already includes the WindowsMedia.com music site. The value of the acquisition was not disclosed, but industry sources estimated it at $65 million. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Russia Loses Its Treason Case Over Nuclear Whistle-Blower
description: As onlookers applauded from the gallery, the Supreme Court today rebuffed a final government plea to reopen a treason case against Aleksandr Nikitin, the former navy captain who gave nuclear opponents details of radioactive pollution by Russian submarines.

title: Postal Service Picks 3 Agencies
description: After choosing agencies to handle duties involved in mass-market campaigns, the United States Postal Service has selected three New York agencies to handle multicultural advertising. Each has a one-year contract with four one-year options; billings were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a new digital camera chip made by Foveon misstated the type of film cameras that it might be able to challenge. Images made from the chip could one day be comparable to those made by so-called medium-format cameras, made by Hasselblad and others, which use film that is 6 by 6 centimeters. The chip images are not comparable to those made from film that is 4 by 5 inches, which produces a higher resolution. Hasselblad does not make a 4-by-5 camera.

title: Heads Roll, Hands Wring In Donizetti's Tale of Desire
description: The British Isles were ripe territory for Italian Romantic melodrama. Verdi made his visits to Shakespeare, but Donizetti came before him, with his fascination with dark Scottish castles (''Lucia di Lammermoor'') and lethal Tudor politics (''Anna Bolena,'' ''Maria Stuarda''). Add to the latter his opera ''Roberto Devereux,'' which opened the New York City Opera's fall season on Tuesday night.

title: Milbrett Free and Fancy in Victory
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14  She delivered the winning goal in the 1996 Summer Olympics and led the Americans in scoring during the 1999 Women's World Cup, yet Tiffeny Milbrett has always felt like something of an outsider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, LEON
description: SAMUELS-Leon. Of natural causes, of Delray Beach, Florida formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Age 82. Loving husband of Sandy. Devoted father of Marilyn (Hobart), Carol and David (Dorianne). Beloved grandfather of Robert, Rebecca, Leslie (Josh), Sasha, Jenna and Noah. Proud great grandfather of Jake and Jessica. Founder with his father, Nathan, and brothers, Julius and Seymour of Blue Ribbon Fish Company in NYC's Fulton Fish Market. A decorated veteran of WWII. Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, Florida.

title: In Bid for House, Parties Eye Same District
description: Democrats held the Congressional seat in this northwest Washington district for 30 years until the Republican tide of 1994 brought in Jack Metcalf, a state legislator and former high school history teacher who made it to the House of Representatives 26 years after his first attempt.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL DROPS. Heating oil fell on a report that United States supplies rose for a fifth week. In New York, heating oil for October delivery fell 3.61 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $1.0107 a gallon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIANT, FREDDA
description: BRIANT-Fredda (nee Smith). Of Guttenberg, NJ on Sunday Sept 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Rosalie Hill. Loving grandmother of Peter Lahm. Visitation will be on Friday Sept 15, 9am-10am with a service beginning at 10am, at the Vainieri Funeral Home, 5923 Kennedy Blvd (Corner of 60th St.), North Bergen, NJ. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

title: French Farmer Is Sentenced to Jail for Attack on McDonald's
description: The farmer who became something of a national hero last year for leading an attack on a McDonald's restaurant was convicted of criminal vandalism today and sentenced to three months in prison.

title: CARNIVORE CHOICE DUE SEPT. 25
description: The Justice Department plans to make a final decision on Sept. 25 on which university will conduct a technical review of the Carnivore surveillance system, a department spokeswoman said yesterday. The department posted the standards and specific expectations for the academic review on its Web site (www.usdoj.gov) in late August. The Carnivore program, used by the F.B.I., can intercept and search private e-mail for words and phrases, allowing agents to quickly sift through many messages for evidence of possible criminal activity.

title: A Tie Is Savored as a Victory For the U.S. Against the Czechs
description: Brad Friedel remembers the United States soccer team that went to the Summer Games in Barcelona eight years ago. ''Two professionals on the entire team,'' he recalled tonight.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about talks over the possible acquisition of Wasserstein Perella & Company by Dresdner Bank of Germany, misstated the given name of Wasserstein's chief executive. He is Michael Biondi. (Frank Biondi Jr., his brother, is a senior managing director at WaterView Advisors in Santa Monica, Calif.)

title: Galley, a Veteran, Joins the Islanders
description: Garry Galley has decided to become an Islander.

title: Is Divorce Truly a Salvation?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pong Redux With Sweat and Swagger
description: WHAT right does that Tommy Haas have to be so smug? Look at him, with his cocky walk and his stupid baseball hat on backward, thinking he's so great because he slammed that ball past me and won the match.

title: F.A.A. to Call For Changes In Rudders Of 737 Jets
description: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to announce on Thursday that it will require replacement of the rudder control system on the Boeing 737, the most widely used airliner in the world.

title: RANGERS' SCRIMMAGE REVEALS A MIXED BAG
description: Coach Ron Low of the Rangers said that last night would provide another chance for prospects to impress the front office and the coaching staff. Manny Malhotra and Filip Novak made the most of it, as did, to a lesser extent, Francois Fortier, Jeff Ulmer, Jason Doig and Pavel Brendl.

title: Canada Tries to Define Line Between Human and National Rights
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan shocked many nations last year by arguing that leaders who abuse citizens can no longer escape reckoning by hiding behind national sovereignty. Now Canada is about to announce that it has asked a panel to write the first concrete guidelines for making the tough calls between human rights and national rights.

title: In Quest for Tickets, It Pays to Be Patient
description: Jerry Patel, a retired coach from Orlando, Fla., reached Sydney late Tuesday without Olympic tickets. Early Wednesday he joined the long, last-minute lines for seats to the Games.

title: Rookies at the Wheels
description: First it was Sydney's trains that troubled Olympic organizers, but now with the railroad mostly running on time, it is the city's buses that are making the officials anxious.

title: Airlines Call for Tighter Limit on Pilots Daily Work Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The nation's major airlines said today that the Federal Aviation Administration should tighten restrictions on how many hours a day a pilot could work. They also said the agency should repeal a "regulatory loophole" that allows crews to ferry empty airplanes at the end of the day without regard to how many hours a pilot had already flown.

title: Metro Business; Casino Plan Approved
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission approved a four-year license renewal and bankruptcy restructuring plan yesterday for the Sands Casino Hotel in Atlantic City.

title: A Classic Improved
description: Nothing could be groovier than a lava lamp, that 60's icon of the psychedelic slo-mo lane. Except perhaps, a Fluidium lamp, right, around $125. This updated edition is designed by Ross Lovegrove for Mathmos, the British company that produces the original Astro lamp. Mr. Lovegrove, known for the sensual curves in his designs, went high tech, using new heatproof plastics and making the colored ooze match its container. Fly to London to buy the lamp, or look for it in the States soon. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: Art or Advertising? Either Way, Seoul Is Mesmerized
description: A digital and media art exhibition here features not only museum pieces but also work shown on huge electronic screens on streets throughout the city and on walls and pillars in subway stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, JOSEPH A.
description: DORAN-Joseph A. of Bronx, NY, on September 12. Beloved husband of Claire Griffin. Devoted father of Mary Anne Denon, Claire Azzolin, Joseph, Timothy, Christine Wyllie and Steven. Reposing Barnes-Sorrentino Funeral Home, 539 Hempstead Ave., West Hempstead (1 mile North Exit 17N SS Pkwy). Mass St. Thomas RC Church, Saturday, 9:45AM. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fordham University Law School are appreciated. Visitation 2-4:30 and 7-9:30PM Friday.

title: Statement by Judge in Los Alamos Case, With Apology for Abuse of Power
description: Following is a transcript of a statement yesterday by Judge James A. Parker of Federal District Court in Albuquerque to Dr. Wen Ho Lee, who pleaded guilty to mishandling nuclear secrets, as recorded by the court reporter. At one point the federal prosecutor in the case, George Stamboulidis, defended his dealings with the defense lawyer Mark Holscher:

title: Wolves' Smith Has Secret Pact Undercutting N.B.A. Cap
description: When Joe Smith signed with the Minnesota Timberwolves in January 1999, he accepted a one-year contract worth only $1.75 million, a small sum for a 6-foot-10-inch forward with immense potential who had been the first pick in the 1995 draft.

title: Memo Linking Political Donation And Veto Spurs Federal Inquiry
description: Vice President Al Gore attended a Houston dinner in November 1995 to promote a budding relationship between the Democratic Party and a handful of powerful Texas trial lawyers. The relationship blossomed, producing $4 million in donations from the lawyers' firms since 1996. But it also produced some heavy-handed fund-raising that has recently drawn the scrutiny of federal campaign finance investigators.

title: A Place to Go When Theres a Whole Lotta Shakin Goin On
description: When an earthquake roused tens of thousands of Northern California residents from their sleep early in the morning on Sept. 3, hundreds of those rattled souls went straight to their computers and logged onto the Internet.

title: Is Divorce Truly a Salvation?
description: To the Editor:

title: STARMEDIA TO CUT 125 JOBS
description: In pursuit of profitability, StarMedia Network said yesterday that it planned to cut 125 jobs, or 15 percent of its staff, and take a one-time charge of $2 million to $4 million in the third quarter of this year. StarMedia, a New York-based company that aims at Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking audiences around the world, said the job cuts were expected to save the company $15 million to $20 million in 2001, helping it to record a profit in the fourth quarter of 2001, a year earlier than expected. StarMedia's stock fell 50 cents, or 4 percent, to $11.50.

title: Economic Scene; Fewer workplace injuries and illnesses are adding to economic strength.
description: WITH little fanfare, the workplace has become a safer place to be. Since 1992, the number of work-related injuries and illnesses has fallen 25 percent, to 6.7 per 100 full-time workers from 8.9. This unexpected improvement translates to at least a $125 billion annual lift for the economy.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Diluted Earnings But New Energy
description: The immediate verdict by investors on the decision by Chase Manhattan to take over J. P. Morgan was a resounding hiss; Chase's share price fell 11 percent the last two days, after rumors of the deal began to spread.

title: PRESIDENT DELAYS NEW IMPORT DUTIES FOR EUROPE GOODS
description: President Clinton has delayed new punitive duties on European luxury goods, including Scottish cashmere, British shortbread and Italian pecorino cheese, after Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain shifted his position on two festering trade issues to help the United States, administration officials said today.

title: J. C. PENNEY PLANS TO CUT DIVIDEND TO 12.5 CENTS A SHARE
description: The J. C. Penney Company, one of the country's largest department store chains, said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to 12.5 cents a share from 28.75 cents and invest the extra money in its department stores and Eckerd drugstores. Penney cited ''industry conditions'' for the move and said the new rate will be in line with the dividend rates of its competitors. The company's shares fell 44 cents, or 3 percent, to $14.13 on the New York Stock Exchange after the news. The dividend cut is Penney's second in less than a year. In December, the company, based in Plano, Tex., reduced its quarterly dividend to 28.75 cents a share from 54.5 cents, also to spend more on operations.

title: Olympic Glory Australia's Priority
description: The weather and the lifestyle have always been hospitable to sports in Australia. The sun shines frequently and temperatures in the major cities enable Australians to play all manner of games year-round.

title: FEWER BRITISH JOBLESS
description: Britain said the number of unemployed fell to a 25-year low of 3.6 percent in August from 3.7 percent in July as a further 18,000 people found work. The figures reflect the contrast between Britain and continental Europe, where the average unemployment rate is almost three times as high, but the fall is causing problems for manufacturers unable to find skilled workers. Other figures showed wage increases also fell in the three months through July to an annualized 3.9 percent, down from 4.1 percent in the previous quarter, reducing worries about the likely impact of inflation on interest rates. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, DEAN WILLIAM C.
description: WARREN-Dean William C. The Partners of Roberts and Holland are deeply saddened by the death of our Founder and esteemed colleage Dean William C. Warren. For decades our firm was blessed by Dean Warrens' brilliant legal mind and astute business sense. Dean Warren shared his deep knowledge of the tax law with generations of law students through The Surrey and Warren Texts, but we were priveleged to share his knowledge and insights for our entire careers. We celebrate his unique style, his prolific career, and his unforgettable personality. He will be profoundly missed.

title: QUEBEC CABLE DEAL
description: The Quebec government's pension fund and a private-sector partner, Quebecor Inc., have won control of the province's largest cable television company, Groupe Videotron Ltd., with a $3.3 billion all-cash offer. The two topped a bid by Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto. Rogers withdrew its bid yesterday and will be paid a $163 million breakup fee. The value of its offer had fallen below the all-cash counter-bid of about 4.9 billion Canadian dollars from the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, the provincial pension fund, and Quebecor, a Montreal media company. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: A Fierce Opening Debate
description: In a debate last night that put a fresh jolt of personal confrontation into the New York Senate race, Representative Rick Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed sharp policy differences and engaged in some surprisingly tough talk about each other's trustworthiness. Both were composed and vigorous, but Mr. Lazio came across as a smoother, more aggressive performer. He attacked Mrs. Clinton's health care and education record while defending his charge in a fund-raising letter that the first lady had ''embarrassed our country.'' But Mrs. Clinton did not fold. She countered that Mr. Lazio was waging a campaign of insults, and sought to lash him to the policies of Newt Gingrich.

title: A New Bloc of Little-Guy Votes
description: When doctors, insurance agents and auto dealers form unions, organize boycotts and otherwise band together against larger corporate forces, economic changes are at work that can also alter the political landscape. Why are these groups of traditional Republican voters behaving like working-class Democrats of old? Because they face a greater threat to their livelihood than big government ever posed. And it could change their votes.

title: JAPAN-GERMAN INTERNET ALLIANCE
description: Japan's leading Internet service provider, the Nifty Corporation, agreed to a cooperative alliance with T-Online International A.G. of Germany, Europe's largest Internet service provider. Nifty, owned by Fujitsu Ltd., and T-Online, owned by Deutsche Telekom A.G., will make available to each other's customers access points in Japan and Europe. Nifty has 3.9 million subscribers, while T-Online has 6 million spread through Germany, France and Austria. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLAUF, JOSEPH CRAIG
description: POLAUF-Joseph Craig. On September 13, 2000. Devoted husband of Jackie. Adored father of Stephen and Hannah. Son of Martha and Joseph. Dear brother of Ann and Mary. Reposing Court Street Funeral Home, 230 Court St., Brooklyn, NY. Service Friday 9AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Strahan, Without a Sack, Remains Confident
description: Michael Strahan wore a big smile and his eyes grew big as he gazed at Giants fans standing above the tunnel at Veterans Stadium last Sunday. He pumped his fist, urging them to cheer louder.

title: Law Permitting Civil Unions for Gays Proves a Factor in Primaries
description: In a sign that voters in Vermont remain divided over the state's new civil union law, five Republican state legislators who supported the gay-rights law were defeated in Tuesday's primary, while four other Republicans and one Democrat who backed the law won.

title: Two Executives Leaving Saatchi
description: Two senior executives at Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, which was acquired this week by the Publicis Groupe S.A., are leaving at the end of November as part of a reorganization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDWARD C.
description: COHEN-Edward C. My cherished companion, a very special man. Thanks for the memories. Irma Stecher

title: Republican Leader Tries to Force Corzine to Disclose Details of Gifts to Charity
description: Intensifying the pressure on Jon S. Corzine to disclose more about his personal finances, the New Jersey Republican chairman asked the Internal Revenue Service today to compel Mr. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, to reveal which groups received millions of dollars from his private foundation last year.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L.'s Elite Are Caught In the Cap
description: IN San Francisco, defensive players apologized to the team and fans on Sunday for falling behind the Carolina Panthers, 14-0, at the end of the first quarter, and 28-0 by the end of the first half. When 49ers quarterback Jeff Garcia was benched in favor of Rick Mirer, as big a bust on the West Coast as he was in the East, Joe Montana must have been considering a comeback.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Side Dish Of Rodent

title: Piazza Is 'Numb' After 4 Strikeouts
description: Standing in front of his locker after the game yesterday, Mets catcher Mike Piazza did not look frustrated or fatigued, symptoms that could be expected as the season winds down. And he seemed more amused than angered by his troubles.

title: A Play, Like Its Ghost, Forever Young
description: Some froth is simply more durable than other froth. The Pearl Theater Company, in a production so reverent to the published text that it is almost a genuflection, is demonstrating that after 60 years Noel Coward's ''Blithe Spirit'' still arouses steady waves of gentle laughter right through its two and a half hours, and it is hard to say why. Some lines are witty, but on the whole the dialogue is not Coward's most sparkling. He boasted that he wrote it in less than a week, and it reads that way.

title: Luring Fashion Designers Under U.S. Tent
description: Watch out, here comes Fern J. Mallis, first lady of American clothiers, deeply tanned (Southampton and Cyprus) and deep into her fashion-as-armor mode (she wears Calvin like a second skin), barging into her cannily cluttered office at the Council of Fashion Designers of America on Broadway at 40th Street. And there's more Fern in photo-op heaven over on the credenza: basking in Liz Taylor's orbit; projecting gal power with Hillary Rodham Clinton; beaming beside President Bill; gazing up at a snazzily suited basketball icon she distractedly refers to as Magic Irving.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Power, Pitfalls and 'The Great White Hope'; A Washington Company Revisits a Shining Moment From a Decidedly Different Era
description: When Arena Stage, the leading nonprofit theater here, presented the world premiere of ''The Great White Hope,'' the regional theater movement was in its infancy even though Arena itself, founded by Zelda Fichandler in 1950, was already a teenager. It was December 1967, and the show, directed by Edwin Sherin and starring James Earl Jones and Jane Alexander, and financed partly by the fledgling National Endowment for the Arts, made history.

title: Cell Phone Radiation Levels Now Published on the Web
description: Do-Mode, a search engine company in Los Angeles, has published a list of specific absorption radiation, or SAR, levels for many cell phone models. In 1996, the Federal Communications Commission mandated a requirement limiting SAR levels on phones sold in the United States to less than 1.6 watts per kilogram of human tissue. According to the list (www.sardata.com/sardata.htm), which was compiled from information on the commission's Web site, the cell phone with the highest SAR level in digital mode is Ericsson's T28 World model (1.49 watts per kilogram); Motorola's StarTAC 7860 has the lowest level (0.24 watts per kilogram).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, JAMES BARR
description: AMES-James Barr. Of Lincoln, Massachusetts. On September 8, 2000 at age 89. Distinguished lawyer with the Boston firm of Ropes & Gray, president of the Boston Atheneaum, treasurer of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, and president of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Survived by his wife Suzannah Ayer Ames; his sister Phyllis Cox of South Brooksville, Maine; his sons Richard and Charles Ames, both of Brookline, Massachusetts; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Memorial Church in Cambridge on Friday, October 13, at 3:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Ames-Wollan Scholarship Fund at Harvard College.

title: Let the Games Begin
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Showman Who Turned Interiors Into Atmospheres
description: The ebullient architect and designer Alexander Girard (1907-1993) once declared himself more interested in atmospheres than in buildings. And atmospheres are what his work is about. A designer of fabrics, graphics, interiors, furniture, tableware, radio cabinets and much else, he brought to his creations a vivid sense of civilized living with more than a touch of panache.

title: Film in Review: A Piece of Eden
description: Directed by John Hancock

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCK, CORNELIA ROBB
description: BROCK-Cornelia Robb, age 76, on September 11, 2000, after a short illness. Born on June 4, 1924 in New York City. Mrs. Brock was married to the late Josiah V.K. Thompson of Uniontown, PA and Alexander Biddle Brock of Philadelphia, PA. She is survived by three children; Cornelia Thayer Mellin of Annapolis, MD, Josiah V.K. Thompson III and Beatrix H. Jakotich both of Portland, OR; one grandhcild Joshua A. Dunivant; one sister, Mrs. Robert Wolcott of Boston, MA; one brother, Mr. Bayard Van Rensular Robb of Vero Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held Friday, September 15, 2000 at the Springfield Residence, 551 East Evergreen Avenue, Wyndmoor, PA 19038 at 10:00 a.m. Kirk & Nice Funeral Home, Inc., Stenton Avenue and Butler Pike, Plymouth Meeting, PA 19462.

title: Philippine Markets Shaken By Rebellion and Joblessness
description: Concerns about rising unemployment, inflation and lawlessness in the southern islands of the Philippines badly hurt the country's financial markets today, sending the value of its currency to the lowest level since the depths of the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORKIN, CLAIRE
description: DWORKIN-Claire. Died peacefully September 13, 2000. Beloved mother of Susan Rubenstein and Maxine Polyocan. Adoring grandmother of Nicole and Jennifer. Cherished sister of Gladys Lena.

title: The Games Are Finally Here, Even if They Are Over There
description: A beleaguered Olympic movement sought to sustain its viability and to shift its focus toward the possibilities of international brotherhood and the achievements of the world's greatest athletes as the 27th Summer Games open today in what is late winter in the Southern Hemisphere.

title: Nike Deal For Woods Said to Be The Richest
description: Tiger Woods signed a five-year endorsement contract with Nike yesterday that is believed to be worth $85 million, making it the richest endorsement deal in sports history.

title: A Year Later, Giuliani Criticizes Clemency Offer for Puerto Ricans
description: Saying that he was noting the first anniversary of the release from prison of members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday for their positions on the action.

title: British Fuel Protest Halts, but Scarcity Of Gas Isn't Ended
description: A blockade of British refineries and storage depots broke up today and oil trucks rumbled past company gates unimpeded for the first time in a week. But Prime Minister Tony Blair warned there was still ''some way to go'' before most drivers would see gas back in their neighborhood pumps.

title: Foreign Affairs; Give a Little, Get a Little
description: When I was a reporter covering Lebanon's civil war there were mornings when the fighting was so bad I just wanted to write a one-line story: ''Lebanon ended today -- period, paragraph, goodbye.'' But the Lebanese people's indefatigable quest for a normal life always proved me wrong. I've been reminded of that reading all the recent doom-and-gloom stories about how the Palestinian-Israeli peace process is over -- period, paragraph, goodbye. How many times do we have to bury this thing for people to realize that if you think it's over -- you don't understand it?

title: Lets Go to the Opener
description: Walk into Central Station. Speakers booming, "Next train to Olympic Park leaves from Platform 4....Next train to Olympic Park leaves from Platform 4...." Even factoring in the Australian accent, I can actually understand what the speaker is saying. It would never go over in New York.

title: U.S. Moves to Revive Mideast Peace Talks but Plays Down the Prospects for Success
description: The Clinton administration moved today to reopen peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians at an informal working level in New York, but Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright played down prospects that progress would be substantial enough to lead to an accord in the near future.

title: Our Thirst for Oil: It's Time to Cut Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers See Hope for Help On Death Cases
description: Bolstered by findings that even Americans who favor capital punishment worry that innocent people might be put to death, several lawmakers vowed today to renew their push for a law to see that defendants in death-penalty cases have competent lawyers and access to DNA testing.

title: Triathlon Debuts on Steps of Opera House
description: SYDNEY Australia -- The Sydney Opera House was the site of the inaugural Olympic triathlon Saturday morning. Crowds gathered on the shores of the harbor and in boats to watch 48 women start the race.

title: Marathon by Torchlight
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckless Isn't Glamorous, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean
description: Clacking freight trains silhouetted against a fading late autumn sunset, the peripheral blur of trees speeding by a moving boxcar, the hollow glare of anonymous gas stations and bus depots, and the desolation of shabby bars and luncheonettes on the wrong side of the tracks: these are some of the recurrent images that lend Ed Radtke's melancholy road film ''The Dream Catcher'' an enveloping sadness.

title: AT&T to Begin New Image Campaign
description: Reflecting efforts to transform the company from a focus on long distance to broadband services, AT&T begins its first corporate image campaign in about two years today. The budget for the campaign was estimated at $50 million.

title: Frederick Koch, 88, Who Found A New Way to Stage Theater
description: Frederick Henry Koch Jr., a professor of drama at the University of Miami who is credited with creating the first fully flexible theater building in the round in the United States, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Miami. He was 88.

title: Gooden Gets Help in Stretching Arm and Career
description: For almost a decade, Dwight Gooden would wake up each morning, get out of bed and twist his right arm around and around like a windmill. Gooden wanted to know how much tightness or pain he would have to endure to throw a baseball that day. He accepted this ritual as part of being a major league pitcher.

title: The Televised Olympics
description: When the Olympic Games were first broadcast live, from Cortina in the winter of 1956, the final torch-bearer at the opening ceremony tripped and fell over a television cable laid across the stadium. There is something deeply emblematic in that moment. It captures what has been, at times, an awkward synergy between television and the Olympics. And yet for nearly all of us, the Olympic experience is fundamentally a television experience, and it is television revenue that has driven the expansion of the Games, as it has driven the expansion of all sports.

title: U.S. Puts Uzbek Group on Its Terror List
description: The Clinton administration has added the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan to its list of foreign terrorist organizations, saying the group has ties to the Saudi financier Osama bin Laden, administration officials said today.

title: CLINTON CRITICIZES OFFICIALS' ACTIONS AGAINST SCIENTIST
description: In a stinging and highly unusual rebuke of his Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, President Clinton said today that he was ''quite troubled'' by the government's actions in the Wen Ho Lee case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTREICH, ISAAC
description: ESTREICH-Isaac. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member Isaac Estreich. May the Almighty console the family together with the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: RESPITE IN CANADIAN INFLATION
description: Canada's annual inflation rate slowed to 2.5 percent in August from 3 percent in June, as the rise in energy prices abated. Economists had expected less than the half-point drop in the consumer price index for August, but warned that the latest jump in oil prices would push it higher again for September. Excluding energy, Canada's inflation rate was 1.7 percent in August, up slightly from 1.5 percent in July. Energy costs are 11.9 per cent higher than a year ago. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Australian Cuisine Is a Delicious Mix : A Worldly Flavor Fusion
description: ONCE A boring meat-and-potato country, Australia has witnessed a food revolution in the last 20 years as a unique blend of occidental and oriental techniques has created a truly Australian cuisine out of the riches of the country's seafood, meats and produce.

title: Alice Neel
description: 'The Last Years'

title: Better Than Affirmative
description: As college students around the nation began classes earlier this month, the incoming class at Florida's 10 public universities made headlines just by showing up. In the first year that Florida universities stopped using race as a factor in admissions decisions, minority enrollment increased by 12 percent for students entering the system for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, MURIEL K.
description: WEINBERG-Muriel K. of Dobbs Ferry on September 14, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel (died July 30, 2000). Loving mother of Beth Rose of Boston, MA and Adam Weinberg of Dobbs Ferry. Devoted grandmother of three. Service today 1:00 p.m. EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Av. (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry

title: Our Thirst for Oil: Its Time to Cut Back
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Causes Cited in Tire Recall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROTKI, SHIRLEY
description: KROTKI-Shirley. On September 13, 2000 at age 86. Beloved wife of Carl, devoted mother of Saul Krotki and Isaac and Judith Putterman and cherished grandmother of Amanda Krotki, Chad and Jessica Haller and Karen Putterman. For 35 years respected teacher of English at Salanter Yeshiva. She leaves behind family, friends and former students enlightened by her wit, wisdom and courageous spirit.

title: Modest Purchases by Central Bank Briefly Lift the Euro
description: The European Central Bank took a limited step today toward intervening in world markets on behalf of the downtrodden euro, using money from its foreign reserves to buy $2.16 billion worth of euros and briefly halting the currency's tailspin against the dollar.

title: Album of the Week
description: EVERCLEAR: ''Songs From an American Movie, Volume I: Learning How to Smile'' (Capitol). What are memories for? Art P. Alexakis of Everclear ponders that question on ''Songs From an American Movie, Volume I.'' Mr. Alexakis, 38, isn't afraid to admit he has a long past, and he seesaws between weighing what he has done and trying to forget it. In the album's single, ''AM Radio,'' he borrows the strutting riff from Jean Knight's ''Mr. Big Stuff'' to rap-sing fond reminiscences of the 1970's. But in ''Here We Go Again,'' he fends off a new girlfriend's questions, saying, ''I do not want you to know me the way I used to be.''

title: Milbrett Free And Fancy In Victory
description: She delivered the winning goal in the 1996 Summer Olympics and led the Americans in scoring during the 1999 Women's World Cup, yet Tiffeny Milbrett has always felt like something of an outsider.

title: People
description: * Peter Bemis, president and creative director at Frankfurt Balkind West, Los Angeles, was named to the additional new posts of partner and chief executive.

title: Sports of The Times; Needing New Blood To Survive
description: THE sun is setting on fading empires. Gerontocracies are going out of style. The Olympic movement is starting to resemble the Soviet Union in its final days, just before people attacked the Berlin Wall with sledgehammers. In this case, the cracks are appearing from within.

title: Hurley Wins McGuire Award
description: Coach Bob Hurley, who has guided St. Anthony's of Jersey City to 19 New Jersey state basketball championships, was named a winner of the Frank McGuire Award yesterday along with four other metropolitan area high school coaches.

title: As History and Artifice Mate in a Hothouse
description: It may almost be too late for the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles to get the credit they deserve in the United States. The cross-pollination between high and popular culture that they exemplify has accelerated so dizzyingly over the last decade that their exquisitely hand-finished photographs of impossibly, sometimes scarily, beautiful men and women seem oddly creaky and routine. At the same time, it may also be too soon to know just what credit Pierre et Gilles are owed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASKIND, DAVID
description: RASKIND-David, M.D. Dr. David Raskind died September 13 at the age of 100. He is survived by his children, Dr. Josephine Raskind VonHippel and Dr. Renee Richards and two brothers, Ben Raskind and Albert Raskind as well as three grandchildren David & James VonHippel & Nicholas Raskind, and three great-grandchildren. Services are being held at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills NY at 10 AM Friday September 15. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to U.S. Tennis Center, Super Seniors Division.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ITALY: CARDINAL CALLED RACIST -- A leading cardinal has set off a political furor by suggesting that Italy favor Roman Catholic immigrants over Muslims to ''preserve the identity of the nation.'' Many center-left government ministers condemned Cardinal Giacomo Biffi's pastoral letter to his Bologna archdiocese as dangerous and racist. But some center-right politicians agreed with his proposal and the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi said the cardinal's ideas ''were deemed worthy of attention.'' Elisabetta Povoledo (NYT)

title: G.M. Doubles Its Stake in Suzuki Motor to 20%
description: The General Motors Corporation doubled its stake in the Suzuki Motor Corporation to 20 percent today and G.M.'s top executive joined Suzuki's board.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Paychecks Bounce At Rainbow Room

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNDELL, KERT F.
description: LUNDELL-Kert F. Born in Malmo, Sweden, lived in Greenwich Village, NY. Beloved husband of Bretta, devoted father of Erik and Kate, died September 11 of lung cancer. A set designer and artist who had a long and highly acclaimed career. We will miss him for his warmth and humanity. A memorial service will be held on September 27 at 1:00 at St. Luke's Church, 487 Hudson St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the National Trust for Historic Preservation would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, RICHARD LLOYD
description: DAVIES-Richard Lloyd. On Saturday, September 9, 2000, in Washington, DC, Richard Lloyd Davies, husband of the late Mary Margaret (Peggy) McKee Davies; father of two sons, The Rev. John David McKee Davies, his wife Susan Manypenny Davies, of Center Sandwich, NH, their three children, Martha Lindley Davies of Fairfax, VA, Elizabeth Davies Clark and her husband, Gregory Michael Clark, of San Francisco, CA, and Peter John Brindle Davies of Louisville, KY; and son, Richard Bonar Davies, his wife, Diane Andruszko Davies of Sandy, UT, their three children, Christopher Allen Davies and his wife , Cheryl Kallenberg Davies, of Sandy UT, Andrea Davies Stolfa and her husband, Chuck Stolfa, of Draper, UT, and Jennifer Lynn Davies-Ross and her husband, Christopher Matthew Ross, of Salt Lake City, UT; great-grandfather of Erin Elizabeth Clark, Michael Thomas Clark and Noel Margaret Clark of San Francisco, CA, Evan Davies Stolfa and Connor Davies Stolfa of Draper, UT; brother of Ted Davies and Dr. Dean Davies. Services will be held at Georgetown Presbyterian Church, 3115 P St., NW, Washington, DC, on Saturday, September 23, at 11 a.m. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his name to a charity close to your heart. For more information contact Joseph Gawler's Sons, Washington, DC.

title: Children in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GARAGE SALE' MODEL FOR WEB SALES
description: Aiming to mimic the deals available at yard sales, where prices tend to decline as the afternoon wears on, the online trading site WebSwap.com introduced a new ''Garage Sale'' service yesterday through which prices of goods for sale decline over time. Sellers set starting and minimum prices for an item, and the service automatically decreases the price by a set amount every hour over the course of seven days -- or until someone snaps up whatever is being offered for sale. WebSwap.com also offers a regular listing service where sellers can post an item for sale at a set price, without charge for 30 days or, for a 25-cent fee, for 90 days. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Charles Spurrier
description: Feigen Contemporary

title: Article 2000091590340420199 -- No Title
description: The Ultimate Remote Means Never Having To Leave the Couch

title: Space Station Has New Power Problem
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. - One of eight batteries used to power the International Space Station's newest module showed signs of malfunction on Thursday, a day after astronauts from the space shuttle Atlantis installed three of them.

title: Ice Core Study Shows High Mountain Warming
description: WASHINGTON -- In another indication that the Earth may be warming, an analysis of ice samples drilled from deep inside a glacier shows that the last century has been the hottest period in 1,000 years high in the Himalayan Mountains.

title: FORMER KODAK EXECUTIVE NAMED PRESIDENT AT GOODYEAR
description: Goodyear Tire and Rubber named a former Eastman Kodak executive as its president and chief operating officer yesterday. The executive, Robert J. Keegan, 53, will assume the posts on Oct. 1. He resigned Wednesday from Kodak, where he was credited with helping turn around the company's main film business. Goodyear's chairman and chief executive, Samir F. Gibara, will give up the titles of president and chief operating officer. Shares in Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio, were down 25 cents, to $22.56. The company's shares have dropped 57 percent in the last year.

title: Giuliani Undergoes Implant to Treat His Prostate Cancer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani underwent treatment for his prostate cancer this morning, and after the procedure his doctor said the prognosis was good.

title: What Is Marriage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Strange things happen on Williamsburg's northern fringes. For a brief, shining moment last year, the Southside neighborhood brought forth Crisci, a wildly ambitious, very promising restaurant that reverted to its Italian red-sauce roots within a matter of weeks. Now, hard by the East River, Fernicola Osteria is giving new wave Italian cuisine a showcase.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Inktomi Corporation's deal to acquire FastForward Networks misstated Inktomi's base. It is Foster City, Calif., not Forest City.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: High Fidelity

title: Article 2000091591242123452 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, DEAN WILLIAM C.
description: WARREN-Dean William C. The Officers and Directors of Barnwell Industries, Inc. are deeply saddened and mourn the death of our Director and friend who served for many years on the Board. His brilliant legal mind and keen business sense contributed greatly to the success of the company. In addition to his role in the operation of the company, he was always available with advice and help to those of us who had a personal relationship with him for many, many years. All of us wish to extend our sympathy and condolences to his family. Morton H. Kinzler, Chairman

title: Mom Wields a Mean Knife, On a Roast, Dad, Whatever
description: In addition to its title, there are a few other things about ''Crime and Punishment in Suburbia'' that might lead you to believe it has something to do with Dostoyevsky, including a portentous quotation from the Russian novelist that appears on the screen before the action starts, and the name of the film's heroine, which is Roseanne Skolnik (Monica Keena) -- kind of like Raskolnikov, get it? But you will search in vain for Dostoyevskian themes, or indeed any themes at all. The Russian writer whose influence is most in evidence may be Chekhov, and then only because his oft-cited remark that a gun on the mantelpiece in the first act of a play must be fired in the third act is given an indie-film paraphrase: the electric carving knife used by Mom to slice up the roast in an early scene will be used to slice up Daddy later on.

title: W. Page Thompson, 73, Former Executive in Publishing
description: W. Page Thompson, an executive in the publishing industry, died on Sunday in New York. He was 73. The cause of death was cancer, said his son Page.

title: Yenidogan Journal; As Turkey's Schools Open, a Million Are Left Out
description: Murat Kilic summoned all the bravado a 14-year-old could muster, shook his head back and forth vigorously and said he never liked school anyway and he was proud to be working to help support his family.

title: Airline Competition Over China
description: As the Senate takes up permanent normal trade relations with China, the Department of Transportation is on the verge of awarding an additional United States carrier the valuable right to fly to that nation. Lamentably, the aviation deal negotiated by President Clinton and Zhu Rongji, China's prime minister, in April 1999 does not reflect the spirit of the trade agreement. It is so restrictive that the Transportation Department, for the first time ever in such a bilateral route-awarding proceeding, is being forced to pick between cargo and passenger carriers. Chinese negotiators refused to differentiate between the two.

title: The Big City; The Language Of the Clintons In the Debate
description: ''OBVIOUSLY, I didn't mislead anyone,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton said in Wednesday's debate, referring to her past denials of any liaison between her husband and Monica S. Lewinsky. If Mrs. Clinton's latest conclusion doesn't seem so obvious to you, that's because Clintonian language can be idiosyncratic. It depends on what the meaning of ''mislead'' is.

title: For Wen Ho Lee, a Tarnished Freedom
description: Is this America? To think of Wen Ho Lee in his nine months of solitary confinement is to think not of Horatio Alger, but of Kafka. Has the American dream turned into the American nightmare? We are treated today to the pictures of Wen Ho Lee free to go fishing but are haunted by our private visions of him shackled and alone.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Accounts
description: * Amtrak, Washington, to the Chisholm-Mingo Group, New York, as the first agency to handle specifically multicultural marketing communications. Billings were not disclosed.

title: William H. Pitt, 73, Real Estate Executive
description: William H. Pitt, a real estate executive and philanthropist, died on Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 73 and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD BUYS STAKE IN INDIGO
description: In an effort to extend its business from office printers to business publishing, Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it would invest $100 million in Indigo, a Dutch maker of digital color printing systems. The move, which a company vice president said was the largest investment that Hewlett's printing division has made in at least 18 months, sent Indigo's American depository receipts soaring 17.6 percent, to $7.7188. Hewlett shares gained $1.25, to $106.25. (NYTimes.com/TheStreet.com)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWES, CATHERINE
description: LOWES-Catherine, 93, died September 12th, 2000, in Allihies, Ireland, where she had lived for 13 years. Formerly of Chappaqua, NY, beloved wife of the late Marvin McCord Lowes, she will be sadly missed by her children Susan, Tony, and Gillian, her daughter-in-law Christa Jo and son-inlaw Milton, her brother John, and her grandchildren Socony, Francis, Will, Derek, Sam, Susanna, Sara Jing, and Mikey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAWRENCE, JACOB
description: LAWRENCE-Jacob. (1917-2000) Memorial service on Thursday September 28th at 4:30pm Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Dr (at 120 St), NYC. Reception to follow. For more info call the Lawrence Foundation at 617-367-5044

description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, MAGNA
description: FRIEDLAND-Magna. On September 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Melvin (Carole) Friedland. Cherished grandmother of Michael and Elizabeth. Loving great grandmother of Robert, Nathan and Steven. Service today, 10 AM ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn NY (near Ave V).

title: Writing on the Wall, and on the Soul
description: BY image-obsessed Western standards, one picture is worth, absolute minimum, a thousand paltry words. But in China, where words are images, writing has traditionally been the highest art form of all, and a source of profound political and emotional power.

title: Gas Deposits Off Israel and Gaza Opening Vision of Joint Ventures
description: Drilling deep below the seas off Israel and the Gaza Strip, foreign energy companies are discovering gas reserves that could lift the Palestinian economy and give Israel its first taste of energy independence.

title: Motorola Unifies Global Advertising
description: Motorola said yesterday that it had consolidated its global advertising, with billings estimated at $150 million, by naming Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, to handle those duties.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Slater Bradley
description: 'Charlatan'

title: Giuliani Pulls His Charts Out For a Review Of New York
description: It is one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's favorite exercises: with laser pointer in hand and a City Hall chamber packed with reporters and top aides, twice a year he runs through dozens of charts that he says illustrate how New York City is in better shape than it has been in decades.

title: In the Tao of Karaoke, Life's Often Out of Tune
description: Most bad movies -- and there is no shortage -- are content to amble along the well-trodden path of mediocrity hoping, at best, to remind their audiences of other, better pictures. About such movies there is little to say. But every so often a movie comes along that's bad in such original and unexpected ways that it inspires an almost admiring fascination. You leave the theater in a state of amazement, and say to yourself, ''Well, I've certainly never seen anything like that before,'' a response that's not unrelated to the thrill you feel after having seen something truly wonderful.

title: Giuliani Undergoes Implant to Treat His Prostate Cancer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani underwent treatment for his prostate cancer this morning, and after the procedure his doctor said the prognosis was good.

title: Survey Links Teen Sports and Healthy Behavior
description: There may be something to the stereotype of the clean-cut high school jock.

title: Metro Business; Clothing Store Opens
description: Urban Outfitters, a clothing and accessories retailer that caters to young men and women, opened a three-level store this week at the corner of 72nd Street and Broadway.

title: Leonardo and Verdi On Olympic Runs
description: THE Olympic Arts Festival runs for six weeks before and during the Olympic Games. It mixes the excellence and diversity of Australian arts with some famous international talent.

title: Dropping All of His Objections, Bush Agrees to Panel's Debates
description: Gov. George W. Bush withdrew all his objections to a bipartisan commission's debate schedule yesterday, agreeing to three 90-minute prime-time encounters with Vice President Al Gore next month on college campuses in Boston, Winston-Salem, N.C., and St. Louis.

title: Profitable Anticipation
description: Who says plays don't pay?

title: Opening Ceremonies Sparkle on Australian Television
description: SYDNEY, Sept. 15 - Every Olympic host city brings its own vision, its own sense of itself to its opening ceremony. What is said by the local Olympic network's commentators during the show sounds natural but would it sound right when said by NBC's Bob Costas and Katie Couric, who will call the ceremony Friday night to an American audience?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIKELY, AUDREY
description: LIKELY-Audrey. On Aug. 17, 2000. Beloved mother of Roger Shelley (Nancy); loving companion of Lawrence Bickford. A Memorial service on Monday, September 18, 3 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: Julius Schulman, 84, Violinist Who Performed Worldwide
description: Julius Schulman, a widely traveled violinist who played in several major American orchestras, including the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Boston Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, died on Saturday at Brotman Hospital in Culver City, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Culver City.

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Economists Give Far Higher Cost of Gun Violence
description: Gun violence costs Americans $100 billion a year, according to a new book by two economists that is the first effort to make a comprehensive estimate of the price the nation pays for criminal shootings, gun accidents and suicides committed with guns.

title: One-Man Showcase For Jets: Anderson
description: In this perfect (2-0) Jets world, Richie Anderson tries to be all things: a wide receiver, a fullback, a tight end, a tailback. He has to be in order to make a living. Once, though, he was a Saturday hero as a Penn State running back, the second-leading collegiate scorer in the nation.

title: Katy Grannan
description: 'Dream America'

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fungi May Have Joined First Plants on Land
description: WASHINGTON - Fossils dating back 460 million years show that plants may have had friendly allies, in the form of fungi, helping them make the move to land from the sea, scientists said on Thursday.

title: Buffalo Teachers Walk Out for a 2nd Time in a Week
description: A judge ordered Buffalo's public school teachers back to their classrooms yesterday after they announced a strike in the hour before school started for the second time in a weeklong and increasingly bitter dispute.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Columbia May Expand Onto Trump Riverfront Site
description: Columbia University is talking with Donald J. Trump about creating a satellite campus near Lincoln Center at the developer's vast Trump Place project on the Hudson River.

title: Court Orders Medical Test for Absent Suharto
description: A court ordered an independent medical team today to determine whether the former president, Suharto, is fit to stand trial for corruption after he again declined a summons to appear in court, citing ill health. Mr. Suharto failed to appear when the trial began on Aug. 31.

title: Oracle's Results for Quarter Beat Wall St. Estimates
description: The Oracle Corporation posted fiscal first-quarter results today that handily surpassed Wall Street estimates. The company also announced a 2-for-1 stock split, the 10th since Oracle's initial public offering in March 1986.

title: Bush on Spot as G.O.P. Pushes to Pull Out G.I.'s From Kosovo
description: House and Senate negotiators are fighting over a deadline for withdrawing American troops from Kosovo, renewing a clash with President Clinton and putting Gov. George W. Bush on the spot again, since he lobbied Senate Republicans to drop a similar provision earlier this year.

title: Murdoch Reduces Stake in EchoStar
description: Rupert Murdoch sold seven million EchoStar Communications Corporation shares worth $343 million this month, according to a government filing.

title: Bear Stearns Income Down 5.7% in Quarter
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell 5.7 percent on a decline in investment banking that was partly offset by gains in its trading business.

title: Lemon Drop Kid Faces Small Woodward Field
description: Lemon Drop Kid drew only four rivals for tomorrow's $500,000 Woodward when entries were filed yesterday at Belmont Park. But the 4-year-old star is clearly being aimed toward a prize that eluded him last year, the ultimate prize in racing, Horse of the Year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, EDWIN NILS
description: TEICH-Edwin Nils. On September 14, 2000. The family deeply mourns the passing of Edwin Nils Teich. Adored brother of Buddy and Jack; beloved brother-in-law of Janet; cherished uncle of Marc, Michael, Jaime, Allison, Jennifer and baby Jacob. Mr. Teich grew up in Great Neck, NY. He was graduated from the University of Vermont. In his early career, Mr. Teich worked with his brothers at Acme Architectural Products, which was founded by their father, Joe Teich, in 1924. It is with profound sorrow that we kiss him goodbye. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Pediatric Cancer Foundation, White Plains, NY or the Friars Club Foundation, NYC. Services today (9/15) at 11:45AM, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76th St., 212-362-6600.

title: Congressman Challenges Opponent's Out-of-District Office
description: There would almost certainly be nothing to say about the nondescript one-story office building here that is the campaign headquarters for Mark Nielsen, the Republican Congressional candidate -- nothing, that is, if it were in Mr. Nielsen's district.

title: Disney Redesigns Go.com In a Push to Attract Surfers
description: Go.com is starting up again after a nine-month pit stop.

title: FIRST UNION REAL ESTATE IS SELLING PROPERTIES TO RADIANT
description: First Union Real Estate Investments said yesterday that it had agreed to sell properties in seven states to Radiant Investors for about $79.9 million in cash and $125.1 million in assumed mortgage debt. The properties are in Texas, Virginia, Ohio, Tennessee, Colorado, Illinois and Louisiana. First Union Real Estate is a New York-based real estate investment trust that buys and manages apartment buildings, shopping malls and parking properties. It had assets of $461.45 million in 1999.

title: Cows, Virgil and the Italian Countryside, All in Drawings by Claude Lorrain
description: Opinion now seems to be divided on whether this is the 400th anniversary of the birth of Claude Lorrain (as one would suppose from the inscription on his gravestone in Rome). But the chance to see nearly 40 of his drawings and eight of his etchings at the Pierpont Morgan Library is always timely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABBAGH, JOSEPH
description: SABBAGH-Joseph. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Joseph Sabbagh beloved father of our devoted members Moses and Felice Sabbagh. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Politics for Millionaires
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000091591679197241 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Asian Giants May Struggle for Gold
description: TOKYO  China has 1.2 billion people to choose from and Japan is the world's second richest country. With such manpower, money and history, you might expect the two nations to be gearing up for a flood of gold medals at the Olympics.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: U.S. Team Assessed Penalty
description: The United States soccer team's loss at Costa Rica on July 23 in a World Cup qualifying game turned out to be more severe than the result. Yesterday, the world governing body of soccer suspended Coach Bruce Arena for three qualifying matches and Claudio Reyna, the team captain, for two for arguing with officials after the 2-1 loss.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on Monday about the settlement of a dispute over some types of digital television sets made by Hitachi and Toshiba referred incorrectly to the adjoining picture. It showed a standard high-definition TV, which has a wide screen -- not the type covered by the settlement. The companies gained the right to use the high-definition label for sets that have nearly square screens, so long as they notify buyers that the picture will have a lower resolution than that of a standard high-definition set.

title: With Fred Astaire to Emulate, Can Golf Be That Hard?
description: Until the current craze for golf brought the game into high visibility, everything I knew about golf technique I learned from a dancer: Fred Astaire. Astaire was a passionate off-screen golfer and in ''Carefree,'' his 1938 movie with Ginger Rogers, he included a golf solo for himself, to a tune by Irving Berlin. The choreography is built around two golf actions, the warm-up waggle and the swing, and its wit depends upon the conceit that an analogy can be made between a swing in golf and swing in jazz.

title: Fallout in Texas From Bosnia Duty
description: Dalinda Halkowitz's husband filed for divorce the day in February that he and nearly 700 other soldiers from the 49th Armored Division of the Texas National Guard assembled to go to Bosnia.

title: NEW WINDOWS VERSION RELEASED
description: Microsoft began selling the new Windows operating system for consumers yesterday, giving the world's largest software maker a new product for home computer users in time for the holiday shopping season. Windows Millennium Edition, or Windows Me, is now available in stores and will be included in new machines from PC makers including Compaq Computer, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. The new operating system replaces Windows 98.

title: World Business Briefs
description: AMERICAS

title: Shifting Tactics, Bush Uses Issues to Confront Gore
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Faced with an opponent who has managed to deflect questions about his character and trustworthiness, Gov. George W. Bush has shifted tactics and begun confronting Vice President Al Gore head-on over the issues, an area long considered to be Mr. Gore's greatest strength.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on concern that a storm approaching the Gulf of Mexico could develop into a hurricane and threaten platforms. In New York, natural gas rose 14 cents, to $5.195 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: School Cleared After Spill
description: A Brooklyn elementary school was evacuated yesterday after a small bottle containing the pesticide malathion shattered inside a janitor's closet in a second-grade classroom, the authorities said.

title: Pitch to Ventura or Piazza? Expos Make Wrong Choice
description: When his season was at its worst, Robin Ventura would play mind games at the plate. If he told himself to be aggressive, he would swing at a ball in the dirt. If he tried to be patient, he would let a strike go by. His mind was cluttered, and his mechanics were messed up, too.

title: Bettina von Zwehl
description: Lombard Freid Fine Arts

title: Pace Artist Is Designing New Gallery
description: On Jan. 10, PaceWildenstein plans to close its 10-year-old gallery at 142 Greene Street in SoHo and migrate to Chelsea, opening in mid-March at 534 West 25th Street. While Pace will keep its sleek 57th Street space, its new location will be something of an artwork. Arne Glimcher, chairman of PaceWildenstein, has commissioned the California artist Robert Irwin to design the space.

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Search Uncovers Huge Arsenal, Police Say
description: Police officers investigating a burglary complaint at a home here discovered more than 160 guns, a variety of explosives and fuses, rocket engines, and at least 150 pounds of gunpowder, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said today.

title: Residential Real Estate; Multiple Listings Sought For Homes in Brooklyn
description: Much like Manhattan, Brooklyn has never had a boroughwide multiple listing of homes for sale. Now, reflecting a lack of inventory at a time when prices -- especially in Brooklyn's historic brownstone districts -- have been rising, the three multiple listing services that loosely divide the borough plan to merge by the end of the year.

title: Clinton to Visit Hanoi
description: President Clinton plans to visit Vietnam soon after the November elections, becoming the first president to go there since the war ended.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Firestone Workers Cite Lax Quality Control
description: In April 1990, just months before the Bridgestone/Firestone plant here began making tires for Ford Explorers, John J. Boettner, the plant manager, gave a speech at the local Kiwanis club saying that the company had spent millions to modernize the 30-year-old plant.

title: EATING OUT
description: New This Year

title: Not Waiting for the Next Floyd; A Year Later, Flooded New Jerseyans Take U.S. Buyout
description: Even after a year, the emotional scars from Tropical Storm Floyd's ravaging flash floods are still so raw that a routine rainstorm frightens some people here.

title: The Euro Experiment: A Bold Idea That Isn't Working
description: THE euro is a grand experiment, a paper currency without a government. And that lack is one reason the euro has sunk far below any reasonable level.

title: Physicists Give Themselves One Last Try at Tantalizing Discovery
description: GENEVA -- Scientists searching for an elusive particle believed responsible for the mass of everything in the universe extended their quest for another month Thursday rather than leave the field -- and a probable Nobel Prize -- to their main American rival.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 3
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Producer Prices Fell in August And Retail Sales Slackened
description: Producer prices fell unexpectedly and retail sales cooled in August, the government reported today, indicating that the economy, in a record 10th year of expansion, is growing at a pace that is unlikely to ignite inflation.

title: Ford Chairman Speaks Out On Tires for the First Time
description: During his first news conference since Bridgestone/Firestone announced the recall of 6.5 million tires used mainly on Ford Explorers, William C. Ford Jr., Ford Motor's chairman, today defended his decision to let the company's president, Jacques Nasser, handle all public appearances concerning the tire problems. The company also announced that it would buy back $5 billion of its stock.

title: Before High Tech, There Was a Higher Authority
description: THE TALMUD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JULIUS
description: SCHWARTZ-Julius, who practiced internal medicine and cardiology for 54 years, died in Hollywood, Fla., on Sept. 6, at the age of 91. The funeral service was private. A 1933 graduate of Syracuse University's College of Medicine (now Upstate Medical University), he was one of that school's oldest surviving graduates. Dr. Schwartz served in the U.S. Army during WWII, receiving the Bronze Star upon his discharge as a Major in 1946.
