He practiced medicine in Brooklyn for over 30 years, during which time he served as an attending on the staff of Maimonides Hospital and an Asst. Adjunct Professor at Downstate Medical School. In 1975, he relocated to Hollywood, Fla., where he continued to practice medicine until his retirement in 1983. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Louise Judith of Hollywood, Fla., his daughter, Dr. Susan Schwartz McDonald of Haverford, Pa., and three grandchildren, Elizabeth, Nora, and Geoffrey. Donations in his name may be made to: The Endowed Scholarship on behalf of Julius Schwartz, M.D., Class of 1933, Syracuse Medical Alumni Foundation of Upstate Medical University, 155 Elizabeth Blackwell Street, Suite 306, Syracuse, NY 13210.

title: Going Where the Pickings Are Good
description: My husband and I are certainly not farmers, not even the weekend-in-the-backyard variety. But there are moments, especially as the air starts to chill, when I survey the obscenely generous mounds of lettuce, eggplants and apples at the Union Square Greenmarket and feel a twinge of longing. I imagine us in rough clothes standing in an orchard laden with autumn fruit, plucking just-ripened pears from a tree and tossing them into straw baskets. Tilling the soil might not be for us, but harvesting -- we could handle that.

title: Accord Ends Dispute Between Regulators
description: Federal regulators have signed an accord on how to oversee single-stock futures, ending an 18-year dispute between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: POST-MORTEM AT LONDON EXCHANGE
description: Senior members of the London Stock Exchange's board managed to hang on to their jobs during a heated shareholder meeting that came a few days after the exchange's decision to scrap merger plans with the Deutsche Borse in Frankfurt. The combination would have formed the first pan-European stock exchange. It had faced increased opposition from both retail brokers and large institutions who were uncertain how the regulations, the technology and the clearing and settlement systems of the two exchanges would meld. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Public Interests; Winging It in Buffalo
description: Rick Lazio, the New York Senate Republican nominee, was supposed to be the likable candidate. Then this week, at a debate in Buffalo, the Congressman morphed into a political predator. Darth Vader with dimples. A suburban Stone Cold Steve Austin. The Long Island Lex Luthor. Richard Hatch with clothes on.

title: Creatures of Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine Is Reluctant On Hamilton
description: Darryl Hamilton was healthy and feisty enough to play basketball with some teammates in an alcove of the visiting clubhouse at Olympic Stadium today. Manager Bobby Valentine listened to the thump-thumps from his office and grudgingly let the games go on.

title: The Televised Olympics
description: When the Olympic Games were first broadcast live, from Cortina in the winter of 1956, the final torch-bearer at the opening ceremony tripped and fell over a television cable laid across the stadium. There is something deeply emblematic in that moment. It captures what has been, at times, an awkward synergy between television and the Olympics. And yet for nearly all of us, the Olympic experience is fundamentally a television experience, and it is television revenue that has driven the expansion of the Games, as it has driven the expansion of all sports.

title: Pentair Lowers Its Earnings Estimates
description: Pentair Inc., a maker of power tools and electrical equipment, lowered its earnings estimates for the rest of the year and next year because of slower-than-expected sales in its power-tools business.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Master of Political Attack Ads Is Under Attack Himself
description: Even in the spike-elbowed world of political consulting, Alex Castellanos, the chief advertising architect for the Republican National Committee, stands out as a uniquely bad-boy strategist.

title: Definitely More Aware, Guys, In an Innocent Sort of Way
description: A teenager trying to concentrate on learning the riff to ''Crosstown Traffic'' hates to be interrupted by Mom shouting into the basement that he needs to clean his room. Imagine how Isaac, Taylor and Zachary Hanson must have felt as they played that Jimi Hendrix chestnut on Monday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom. They were slamming away at guitar, keyboards and drums, trying to grab that groove, and the girls just kept screaming! And they wouldn't stop during Hanson's entire set!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNER, MAX
description: DONNER-Max. Died July 13, 2000 in El Paso, TX at the age of 91. Husband of the late Florence. Sister of Helen Dickman, brother of David Friedman. Father of Matthew and Robert. Grandfather of Gregory, Sandra, Andrew, Caroline and Kevin. Great-grandfather of Ori.

title: G.O.P. Debt-Reduction Plan Has a Rapid Impact
description: Democrats deride it as a gimmick. Republicans acknowledge that it is a Plan B fallback position from their cherished tax cuts. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle give it little chance of passing the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, CAROL
description: WALD-Carol. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Carol Wald. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Giants Trying To Think On Track
description: All week the Giants have guarded against the danger of looking past Sunday's game in Chicago to a matchup the following weekend with the Washington Redskins. But for the Giants' defense, which is riding high, the biggest challenge may be taking the Bears (0-2) seriously.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Donald Whyte, a violinist in the New York Philharmonic, misstated his age. He was 58, not 68.

title: For Fans of the British Classic, Less Truly Is More
description: THE big news in Detroit in 1960 was the arrival of the Big Three's first compact cars: the Chevrolet Corvair, Ford Falcon and Plymouth Valiant. But a truly tiny car, the Mini, arrived in the United States that year, and it has proved to be much more significant.

title: Auschwitz Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, HELENE SULLIVAN
description: WALKER-Helene Sullivan, 97, died August 30 at her summer home Ashfield, MA. Wife of the late Norman S. Walker of New York City and Ashfield, she was born in Paris and grew up in Northern Italy. Amony many accomplishments, she was food editor of Flair Magazine and helped establish the American Museum at Bath, England. Survivors include four sons, ten grandchildren and seven great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODENHEIMER, DR. ERNST L.
description: BODENHEIMER-Dr. Ernst L. We extend sincerest condolences to his wife, Clementine, and his children. As a former Vice President of the American Committee, Dr. Bodenheimer was instrumental in planning the building of the present Medical Center complex. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit Doubles at Oracle And Exceeds Projections

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Sept. 2 about public sculpture in New York City included a name erroneously among native New York writers to whom New York has no memorials. There is indeed a memorial to Herman Melville: a bronze bust with a plaque is set into the wall of 17 State Street at an outdoor sitting area and looks over the site of his birthplace at 6 Pearl Street.

title: Turning From Horror to the Kindness and Bravery Shown During the Holocaust
description: In recent years -- perhaps the turning point was ''Schindler's List'' -- films about the Holocaust have undergone a noticeable change in tone toward a redemptive, even hopeful reckoning with historical catastrophe. The change has been especially evident in documentaries about the period. Claude Lanzmann's ''Shoah'' confronted viewers with the vast, unfathomable horror of genocide, emphasizing the indifference and complicity of European gentiles, a theme further explored in Marcel Ophuls's ''Hotel Terminus'' and ''The Sorrow and the Pity.'' But lately the emphasis has shifted to stories of survival, and testimonials to the courage of those who tried to protect European Jews from the Nazis.

title: Seeing the Cars Of Old New York
description: NEW YORKERS who like old cars -- aside from those on the C train -- have several opportunities this month to see vintage models up close.

title: STRONG RESULTS AT CAP GEMINI
description: Shares in one of Europe's biggest computer service groups, Cap Gemini of France, rose sharply after the company announced strong sales and profit growth in the first half and said results were helped by a tax credit related to its $11.1 billion acquisition earlier this year of the consulting practice of Ernst & Young. Cap Gemini's chief financial officer, Frederic Lemoine, said Cap Gemini would benefit from the deductibility over 15 years of as much as 1.6 billion euros ($1.3 billion) from United States taxes as a result of good-will amortization related to the Ernst & Young acquisition. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Approval and Wariness in Poll on Police
description: Although most New Yorkers approve of the job the Police Department is doing and are optimistic that crime in the city will continue to decline, a strong majority of residents also think that the department cannot effectively police itself and needs an independent monitor, according to the results of a poll commissioned by the City Council.

title: Teams Shoot for the Gold and Try to Behave
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 15  Lisa Leslie, the starting center for the United States women's basketball team, was asked if she thought Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal should be here to represent the American men.

title: More at CUNY Are Passing Teacher Tests
description: The City University of New York, the city's largest supplier of teachers, is doing a better job of producing graduates who can pass certification examinations than it did just a few years ago, the State Education Department said yesterday.

title: City Transit Proposes a 3-Minute Rule to Gauge Performance
description: New York City Transit officials said yesterday that they were considering replacing the yardstick they have used for the last several years to measure the reliability of subway and bus service.

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000091593765481358 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Tests by Genentech and Novartis Of Asthma Drug Are Suspended
description: Genentech Inc. and Novartis A.G. have partly suspended clinical trials of what is considered a highly promising drug for asthma and allergies after extremely high doses of the drug or of a related molecule caused low blood platelet counts and some deaths in monkeys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, THE REV. CANON JOHN R.
description: RAMSEY-The Rev. Canon John R. Age 93 of Marblehead, Massachusetts, died on Wednesday, September 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara (Barker) Ramsey of Marblehead, MA. Loving father of Peter R. Ramsey and his wife Isabel B. Phillips of Andover, MA and Christopher V. Ramsey of Cohoes, NY. Loving grandfather of Stephen J. Freeman of Albany, NY and Andrew H. Ramsey of Andover, MA and dear brother of Alice Ramsey Bruns of Largo, FL. A memorial service will be on Saturday, September 16, 2000 at 11:00 AM at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 13 Summer St., Marblehead, MA. Eucharist and interment will follow on Sunday, September 17, 2000 at 1:00 PM in the Cathedral of All Saints, Albany, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Holy Trinity School-Haiti, c/o Agape Flights, 7990 15th St. E., Sarasota, FL 34243-2718 or to Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH 03833-2460

title: Democrats Raise Money; Republicans Make Hay
description: Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, headlined a star-spangled musical benefit for their party last night, highlighting a spree of copious fund-raising that Republicans said undercut this week's Democratic crusade against the entertainment industry's marketing practices.

title: Addenda
description: MUnifies Global Advertising

title: Colgate Shares Drop 16% After Reports by Analysts
description: Shares of Colgate-Palmolive tumbled nearly 16 percent yesterday after analysts expressed doubts that the company would meet sales targets, citing the yearlong plunge in the euro.

title: William Warren, 91, Ex-Law Dean, Dies
description: William Clements Warren, a former dean of Columbia Law School who rebuilt it as it entered the modern era, died on Monday. He was 91.

title: First Urban Legends, Then Real Dangers
description: One way of looking at Jon Shear's harrowing and indelible film ''Urbania'' is to think of it as ''Sex and the City'' turned inside out. This menacing erotic fantasy, set in Manhattan on the evening of the switch from daylight saving to standard time, adding an extra hour to the night, suggests a surreal cinematic answer to one of Lou Reed's rock 'n' roll walks on the wild side.

title: John Morris
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: Metro Business; Employment Fell During Phone Strike
description: The number of people working in New York fell sharply in August, but government economists attributed most of the decline to striking telephone workers.

title: Taking On Gore on Trust and Education
description: The Republican National Committee began broadcasting a new commercial, ''Let's See/ Education,'' in Michigan and Pennsylvania on Monday. The spot, produced by Alex Castellanos's firm, takes aim at the investigation into fund-raising by the Clinton-Gore campaign in 1996 and then offers a critical assessment of Vice President Al Gore's education proposals.

title: Havas Acquires Vickers & Benson
description: Havas Advertising in Paris said yesterday that it had acquired Vickers & Benson in Toronto, a large agency company with advertising, direct marketing and interactive operations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: China Announces Arrest of a Senior Aide
description: Chinese authorities announced today that a former senior national police official had been arrested in connection with the government's investigation of corruption and smuggling in Xiamen, a southern port city.

title: American Woman Is the First Gold Medalist
description: LIVERPOOL, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 16  Nancy Johnson said she had planned to walk in the parade of American Olympians at Friday night's opening ceremony, but changed her mind because she knew the ceremony would end late with athletes not returning to the Olympic athletes' village until well past midnight. Since her event, the 10-meter air rifle competition, began at 9 a.m. today, at the last minute, Johnson decided to remain in the athletes' village.

title: Hard to Ban, Soft Money Is Even Difficult to Define
description: ''Let's just get this deal done right now,'' Representative Rick A. Lazio told Hillary Rodham Clinton at their debate on Wednesday night, trying unsuccessfully to persuade her to sign a pledge barring the use of so-called soft money in their Senate race. With a stroke of the pen, Mr. Lazio declared, the two could alter the landscape of modern-day politicking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NORMAN A.
description: MILLER-Norman A. died in August 2000 in his Tuxedo Park home where he had lived with his loving and beloved wife of 48 years, Adelaide B. Miller. A brother predeceased him. Born in 1926 in Euclid, Ohio, son of the late George R. and Anna Miller of Cleveland, he served in World War II in the U.S. Navy and studied at Stanford and N.Y.U. He was a retired executive for Grumman Aircraft. Mr. Miller served for many years as a Vestryman and Treasurer of St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church, as Chairman of the Republican Committee for the Town of Tuxedo and as Commander of the Tuxedo Post of the American Legion. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Mary's at a later date to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, NY 10987 or to the American Legion Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 1055, Indianapolis, IN 46206

title: With No Room to Maneuver, Grim Choices for Nassau Chief
description: What Gov. George W. Bush did today was an extraordinary turnabout. After weeks of objections to the debate schedule that the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates had been proposing, he suddenly agreed to all of it: three encounters with Vice President Al Gore, on the dates that the commission proposed, in the locations that the commission specified.

title: Beijing Lists Charges Against Sect Leader Who Fled to Guam
description: Chinese officials released details today surrounding the rape charges that have been filed here against the leader of a besieged healing sect who sneaked into American territory in January and is seeking political asylum in the United States.

title: HEAVY LOSSES AT NUCLEAR FUEL MAKER
description: Britain's ill-starred state-owned nuclear fuel company, BNFL, reported heavy losses for a year clouded by scandal over the falsification of quality control data on shipments of nuclear fuel. In what the company called ''poor results'' for the year ended March 31, pretax profit fell from $:218 million ($307 million), to a loss of $:337 million. BNFL, which has contracts for a range of nuclear decommissioning projects in the United States through its Westinghouse subsidiary, said it was unlikely to proceed with plans for a partial privatization until late 2002. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Threat to Judicial Ethics
description: At a moment when the federal judiciary needs to tighten its ethical prohibitions on accepting money or gifts from private interests bent on influencing judicial thinking, Chief Justice William Rehnquist has been quietly collaborating with Senate Republicans to move in the opposite direction. With Justice Rehnquist's approval, Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, tucked a provision into a spending bill in July that would lift the 11-year-old ban on judges' collecting honorariums for appearances. The ban was imposed in 1989 to protect the integrity and impartiality of the judicial system against outside influence.

title: Boxing Showdown Is Set
description: One of the most anticipated matchups of the Olympic boxing tournament -- the American heavyweight Michael Bennett and the two-time Olympic heavyweight champion Felix Savon of Cuba -- will not take place in a gold medal bout. If Bennett and Savon advance through their first two preliminary fights, they would face each other in the quarterfinals Sept. 26.

title: Olympians Hope High-Tech Gear Will Give Them an Edge : Can the Clothes Make a Difference?
description: PARIS  The Olympics might have been born from a desire to revive the virtues of ancient Greece, but at the turn of the millennium, the Games have become a showcase for new  and not so new  technology.

title: Article 2000091593265331260 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, MARGARET REGINA
description: STACK-Margaret Regina (Jean). Died September 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late William A. Stack, loving mother of William A.,III, Peter, Mary, Joseph, Christopher, Suzanne, Margaret Ann Warde, Regina Kane, Joan Kovach, and Kathy Lambert, loving grandmother of 28 and great-grandmother of 8. Services Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at O'Shea's Funeral Home, E. Meadow, L.I. Funeral Mass to be held at St. Anthony's Church, Nanuet, N.Y., 11AM, Saturday, September 16th.

title: Allegheny Technologies
description: The specialty metals maker Allegheny Technologies Inc. said today that it had expanded a 20-million-share stock buyback program by another 5 million shares, worth about $103 million based on recent prices. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 6 percent of Allegheny's 82 million shares outstanding.

title: Melbourne Finds Itself in Sydneys Shadow
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14  It has been a bittersweet week for Australia's other Olympic city. While Sydney was dressing itself up for the opening ceremony of the Summer Games and basking in the world's attention, Melbourne, which played host to Australia's first Olympics, in 1956, watched from the sideline.

title: U.S. Officials Say Bank of New York Transfers Involved Money in Russian Tax Cases
description: After about two years of investigating the movement of billions of dollars through the Bank of New York, federal law-enforcement officials now say much of the money involved tax evasion by Russian businesses, and the investigators are prepared to help Moscow if Russia wishes to pursue its own cases.

title: Setting a Goal of Reconciliation, Clinton Plans a November Trip to Hanoi
description: The White House said today that President Clinton would visit Vietnam shortly after the November elections, becoming the first president to step onto Vietnamese soil since the end of the war there that took 58,000 American lives. The trip would complete a reconciliation with the Communist government that has unfolded over the past six years.

title: Playboy Ruling Recognizes Limits to Online Rights of Trademark Holders
description: In an important decision that recognizes limits to intellectual property rights online, a federal judge earlier this week ruled that a company's well-known trademarks may be used without authorization by search engines in some programming and sales practices.

title: A Night for All of Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 15  The 27th Summer Games opened tonight with a spirit of inclusiveness and reconciliation in a ceremony that addressed Australia's discriminatory treatment of its indigenous people, celebrated the unprecedented number of female Olympians and applauded a march of unity between North Korea and South Korea.

title: Choice Words Keep Coming From Rivals In Contest
description: Fresh from their contentious first debate, the Senate candidates today continued firing at one another -- from a distance -- as they sought to capitalize on the momentum they both claimed from their encounter Wednesday night.

title: Home Video: Womens Work in the Silent Era
description: New VHS and DVD editions of "This Is Spinal Tap," Rob Reiner's 1984 parody of a rock documentary, were released on Tuesday, but some of the better entertainment issued this week can be found in two new series from the silent era: "First Ladies: Early Women Filmmakers 1915-25" from Kino and "Equal Time: The Women of Cinema" from Milestone

title: Goya's Dark Genius, Conjured Up in Spirit And in Fiery Canvases
description: In the surreal opening sequence of Carlos Saura's visual knockout of a film, ''Goya in Bordeaux,'' a bull's carcass in a field of red dirt mysteriously begins to twitch. Gradually stirring to life, it drags itself across the ground and hangs itself on an outdoor meat rack that resembles a gallows. As this raw hunk of flesh and bone is stretched to the breaking point on cables, a chalky human face begins emerging from its exposed rib cage and is revealed to be that of the 18th-century Spanish painter Francisco Goya.

title: RIDING THE INFORMATION HIGHWAY
description: A fleet of 10 Internet-enabled taxis hit the streets of New York yesterday in a venture between Yahoo; Team Systems, a large taxi fleet operator; and Medallion Financial, which provides loans for taxi operators. The purple and yellow taxis, with purple upholstery, are equipped with Palm hand-held computers, offering passengers access to the Internet at no extra cost. ''This will be a great opportunity for taxi passengers to stay on top of their business and personal lives while riding in the comfort of a taxicab,'' said Andrew Murstein, president of Medallion Financial. The venture, which follows a similar effort by Yahoo in San Francisco, is part of a trend by many companies. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Around a Pampered Queen, a Busy Buzz
description: THE zaftig woman in the waffle-weave bathrobe, gray sweat pants and bowling shoes is being attended to by more handlers than this Midtown hotel suite can handle: there are three -- make that four -- publicists, a hairdresser, a makeup artist and a wardrobe coordinator, all hovering around Queen Latifah, a k a Dana E. Owens from Newark, like a herd of worker bees.

title: Dwight Undergoes Surgery
description: Wide receiver Tim Dwight of the Atlanta Falcons had to undergo an emergency appendectomy yesterday in Flowery Branch, Ga..

title: Our Thirst for Oil: It's Time to Cut Back
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Paradise Now'
description: 'Picturing the Genetic Revolution'

title: Top European Luxury Goods Retailers Report Strong Profit Gains
description: As booming economies around the world fuel the consumption of luxury goods, some of Europe's biggest retailers of luxury goods are reporting strong gains in sales and profits.

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Isles' Top Draft Choice To Miss 7 to 10 Days
description: Rick DiPietro will not make his first start in goal Friday night against the Philadelphia Flyers. DiPietro, the 18-year-old whom the Islanders made the top pick in the June draft, will be out 7 to 10 days after he pulled a groin muscle on Wednesday, the final day of camp, in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Torch Relay Brings Out Patriotism In Norman
description: At first light today, Greg Norman, one of the best-known Australian athletes, accepted the Olympic torch in the middle of the Sydney Harbor Bridge as the torch relay began its final 12 hours of a 100-day journey to tonight's opening ceremony.

title: A Prospect Surprises Rangers and Himself
description: Not only was Filip Novak the biggest surprise of Rangers training camp, but he also turned out to be the most surprised player when he learned this morning he would accompany the team to New York instead of returning to Regina, Saskatchewan, to rejoin his junior league team.

title: Whoa, Trigger! Auteur Alert!
description: THE six-by-eight-foot flickering rectangle of light turns the white wall to amber above Quentin Tarantino's fireplace. Not far away, back through a Spanish archway, a 16-millimeter projector rattles with a persistent click that never quite disappears beneath the bleating of the soundtrack, like static on a short-wave radio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACOVELLI, PEARL
description: IACOVELLI-Pearl ''Dixie''. Died on September 4, 2000, in Atlantic City, NJ. Loving mother of John and James. Devoted wife of Peter, who died in 1987. Survived by a brother, Al Schomer. She was a resident of Pembroke Pines, Fla., and Atlantic City, NJ. Fondly remembered as an employee of New York Magazine, The Village Voice, and The New York Times, and volunteer at Broward County Library. Memorial donations may be made in Pearl's memory to The New York Times Neediest Cases.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- San Diego and Albuquerque

title: Melbourne Finds Itself in Sydneys Shadow
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14  It has been a bittersweet week for Australia's other Olympic city. While Sydney was dressing itself up for the opening ceremony of the Summer Games and basking in the world's attention, Melbourne, which played host to Australia's first Olympics, in 1956, watched from the sideline.

title: Jose Cuervo plans a global campaign to elevate its image from a mere 'party catalyst.'
description: IT is a drink whose brand name has long evoked images of salt-covered hands, limes and single shots, college parties and some none-too-pleasant mornings after.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, GEORGE
description: ROSS-George. On September 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara. Cherished father of Stacy and Stephen Fleischner and Lisa and Logan Ross. Devoted grandfather of Alex, Taylor, Madison, Tyler and Dylan. Dear brother of Sylvia Lehmann. Services Sunday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Article 2000091592781361281 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: NEW PLAN TO LURE RETIRED TEACHERS
description: In a stark concession to the seriousness of New York State's shortage of qualified teachers, the Board of Regents said today that it would ask the Legislature to approve a measure allowing retired teachers to return to the classroom and draw a full salary while continuing to receive their pension benefits.

title: Clinton and Reno Will Discuss Handling of Wen Ho Lee Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Clinton said today he would talk soon with Attorney General Janet Reno about his reservations over the way the government handled the case of Wen Ho Lee.

title: A Dwindling Faith In Deregulation; New Ways to Harness Electricity
description: Over a few sultry days in the summer of 1997, the state of Wisconsin got an early taste of the electricity shortages that now threaten several other regions of the country. An unusually large number of nuclear plants that supply the northern Midwest were closed for maintenance just as an unexpected heat wave drifted into the area. Wisconsin Electric, which serves Milwaukee, shut off electricity to 80 businesses; every few hours, it beseeched consumers to limit their energy use.

title: Technology Briefings
description: HARDWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, JOSEPH A.
description: DORAN-Joseph A. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Joseph A. Doran, a life member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Trafficking In the Past
description: On a typical weekday a bus may be only a means of getting to work. But tomorrow, in Brooklyn at least, it will be much more: a nostalgic vehicle to transport you back to your childhood and to offer today's youngsters an extraordinary ride.

title: WELLS FARGO AND FIRST SECURITY AGREE TO SELL 37 OFFICES
description: Wells Fargo & Company and the First Security Corporation have agreed to sell 37 branch offices with about $1.4 billion in deposits to win Justice Department approval for their merger. In exchange for Wells Fargo's divesting itself of the branches, which are in New Mexico, Utah, Nevada and Idaho, the Justice Department said it would not challenge the company's $2.9 billion purchase of First Security, Utah's biggest bank, on antitrust grounds. The merger still requires approval by the Federal Reserve System's board of governors.

title: Democrats Rake It In; G.O.P. Makes Hay
description: Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, headlined a star-spangled musical benefit for the Democratic Party that was sponsored by three top entertainment executives, a move that Republicans said undercut recent Democratic criticism of the industry's marketing practices.

title: Yanks Deny Wells, but Allow Cruz to Play Hero
description: Angry shouts erupted from the showers after the Yankees' extra-inning loss to Toronto last night, the raging voice belonging to catcher Jorge Posada. He was infuriated by the decision of a team official to allow reporters into the clubhouse about five minutes sooner than usual. If not the breach of protocol, something else probably would have ignited Posada's kindling emotions.

title: Beginning Tomorrow, All Eyes Will Be Focused on One Pool
description: There are more than 100 municipal pools in this sprawling city where Dawn Fraser and Ian Thorpe learned how to swim astonishingly fast. On any given day in any season, you can find someone doing laps with a sense of purpose.

title: Choice of Freeman Another Inspired Gesture
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 15  Sporting ceremonies tend to give me the willies, what with the attempts to gloss over centuries of genocide and homicide and fratricide.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Porcelain An Emperor Would Love
description: Qing porcelain can be a neglected stepchild in the family of Chinese porcelains. Qing is the name given to porcelain produced during the Manchu Dynasty (1644-1912). The pieces were made for the imperial court, for domestic use in China and for export to the West. They differ in quantity and artistry.

title: 'A Piece of Eden'
description: Directed by John Hancock

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURKIN, MARY M.
description: DURKIN-Mary M. On Tuesday, Sept. 12, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late William and Anna Durkin. Dear sister of Catherine Moran, and her brother-in-law Joseph Moran. Sister of the late James Durkin and the late Dr. Joseph Durkin. Reposing at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection at The Epiphany Church, 22 Street and Second Avenue, Saturday 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: '30 Days'
description: Directed by Aaron Harnick

title: The Televised Olympics
description: When the Olympic Games were first broadcast live, from Cortina in the winter of 1956, the final torch-bearer at the opening ceremony tripped and fell over a television cable laid across the stadium. There is something deeply emblematic in that moment. It captures what has been, at times, an awkward synergy between television and the Olympics. And yet for nearly all of us, the Olympic experience is fundamentally a television experience, and it is television revenue that has driven the expansion of the Games, as it has driven the expansion of all sports.

title: Another Clinton War Room, Ready for Battle
description: It is a windowless, unmarked room on the third floor of an office building across the street from Madison Square Garden. The shabby office, five flights down from Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign headquarters, is scattered with desks, computer terminals, televisions, hanging cable wires and telephones. There is at least one campaign official posted there 24 hours a day, monitoring the television news, wire services, newspapers, the Internet and, ultimately, the campaign activities of Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: Metro Business; Construction Up in City
description: A report issued by the New York Building Congress estimates that construction in New York City will jump about 38 percent this year, to around $16 billion.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE MEDIA

title: RUSSIAN REVERSAL ON MOBILE PHONES
description: The Russian government suspended a decision to seize frequencies of the country's two biggest mobile phone providers in a move investors said showed the government had not lost sight of protecting property rights. The two companies, Vimpelcom and Mobile Telesystems, were told last week by the Ministry of Telecommunications to relinquish frequencies they had already been awarded; the action drove their stock prices down as much as 24 percent. Though the government did not explain why it had recalled the frequencies, analysts said Moscow's third mobile phone provider, Sonic Duo, which is owned partly by a government-controlled company, would have been the most likely recipient. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: 'On the Run'
description: Directed by Bruno de Almeida

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDINGER, REGINA
description: RUDINGER-Regina (Rose). On September 14, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Dear sister of the late Alex, Sophie and Bertha. Loving aunt of Allyn Quagliano. Services Sunday, September 17, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: From Prawns to a Pawn, A Thief's Bumbling Journey
description: One of the running jokes (or what passes for a joke) in the numbingly incoherent comic action thriller ''Bait'' has to do with the distinction between prawns and shrimp. You see, when Alvin Sanders (Jamie Foxx), a paroled thief, and a partner are caught red-handed stealing $2,000 worth of prawns from a Brooklyn warehouse, everyone, including the police, insists on calling them shrimp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEERS, VINCENT THOMAS
description: PEERS-Vincent Thomas. On September 11, 2000. Retired New York Times Pressman (1988). Survived by his loving wife, Dolores (nee Roberts); Devoted father of Claire Murphy, Dolores Scism, Joanne Burnett, Gerard and Vincent Peers. Cherished grandfather of Stessa, Jaycee, Aram, Andrew, Carrie and Tatiana. Brother of SR. Claire Peers D.W., Margaret Wenz, Rosemary Hagens, Ellen Firsching, George, Joseph and the late FR. William Peers. Viewing and funeral will be in Spring Hill, Florida, Friday. Condolences can be sent to 95-26 Horizon Drive, Spring Hill, Florida, 34606

title: Youngest of Clarks Joins Olympic Family
description: Hazel Clark is a Clark, which means many things, but mostly that she is a runner. Her father ran cross-country in high school, and her half brother and half sister have forged distinguished track careers, particularly in the 800 meters. Her sister-in-law even has an Olympic gold medal for the 4x400 relay and holds the American record in the 800, two laps in 1 minute 56.04 seconds.

title: From the First, a Feud Between Justice Dept. and the F.B.I.
description: Assailed by President Clinton and the federal judge who presided over the nuclear secrets case of Wen Ho Lee, Attorney General Janet Reno and the F.B.I. director, Louis J. Freeh, are once again under the hot glare of criticism for their handling of an important criminal case.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HICKS, MUSE, TATE & FURST INC., Dallas, and UnitedGlobalCom, Denver, are planning to combine their Latin American cable assets into a holding company, which would then raise $800 million to $1 billion in an initial public offering in New York.

title: Two Devils Reject Final Offer
description: Jason Arnott and Scott Niedermayer today rejected what they called the Devils' final offer and will not play until their demands are met, said their agent, Don Meehan. The two unrestricted free agents and General Manager Lou Lamoriello are far apart in their negotiations, Meehan said. Meehan said Lamoriello told him that he terminated negotiations and will reduce his offers for every day the players are unsigned.

title: Sex-Abuse Lawsuit Names Ex-Teacher and Archdiocese
description: In the 1980's, in the quiet parish of St. Frances de Chantal in Throgs Neck, the Bronx, Linda Baisi was teaching junior high school. A former nun, she had left the convent and rented an apartment from the parish school secretary.

title: New Doubt Is Cast on Study That Backs Voucher Efforts
description: Two weeks ago, prominent researchers released a study showing significant gains by black students who had been given vouchers to help pay for private school. The finding lent support to backers of voucher programs at a time when they have become an election-year issue.

title: When Father Is a Union Man and His Son, Management
description: ''Human Resources'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 5. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Loews State, Broadway at 45th Street, Manhattan.

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks From a Debate, in New York and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH SOFTWARE MAKER ACQUIRED
description: The Irish security software company Baltimore Technologies acquired Content Technologies Holdings, a London-based developer of e-mail security products, in an all-stock transaction valued at $:702.5 million ($992 million). The deal increases Baltimore's North American presence, through Content Technologies' four United States offices. Content Technologies' MIMEsweeper software, which protects against junk e-mail and computer viruses, has an installed base of six million users at 6,000 customer sites. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Israelis used to joke about how Moses wandered in the desert for 40 years and ended up in the one place that had no energy. All of a sudden they have energy. It is an extraordinary change.''

title: Bush Cites News Article to Renew Attack on Gore's Fund-Raising
description: Gov. George W. Bush quickly turned a news report that raised fresh questions about Vice President Al Gore's fund-raising efforts into a bludgeon against Mr. Gore today, saying the vice president ''may have crossed a serious line.''

title: Stars to Watch Out for During the Crowded Tumult of the Games : SVETLANA KHORKINA:(folo)
description: SVETLANA KHORKINA: Stylish gymnast. Age: 21 Country: Russia

title: National News Briefs
description: Crime Recount May Lift Philadelphia to No. 2

title: A Judge's Indignation
description: Last December, Judge James A. Parker of the Federal District Court here had two crucial encounters with John Kelly, then the United States Attorney for New Mexico, in hearings in the nuclear secrets case of Wen Ho Lee.

title: Mrs. Clinton Denies Visits Rewarded Gifts
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged today that supporters of her Senate campaign had spent the night at the White House and at the Camp David presidential retreat, but she denied that the visits were rewards for political contributions.

title: Interrogating The Detective
description: Morgan Freeman knows how to give people the fisheye. When you say something a little unexpected or maybe even a little silly (as people sometimes do when in the presence of, say, a celebrity or one of the country's finest actors), he will cock his head slightly and look at you out of the corner of his eye. Like: Say what? And then, if you're lucky, he'll break into a broad laugh.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Women's Work In the Silent Era
description: New VHS and DVD editions of ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' Rob Reiner's 1984 parody of a rock documentary, were released on Tuesday, but some of the better entertainment issued this week can be found in two new series from the silent era: ''First Ladies: Early Women Filmmakers 1915-25'' from Kino and ''Equal Time: The Women of Cinema'' from Milestone

title: Article 2000091593558985237 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZINSSER, BARBARA L.
description: ZINSSER-Barbara L. On August 1, 2000. Memorial service at Calvary Church, Park Avenue at 21 St., Thursday, September 21, 5:30 PM

title: INTERNET TAKEOVER IN CHINA
description: One of China's leading Internet companies announced the purchase of a smaller rival yesterday, setting the stage for what is expected to be a sweeping consolidation of China's fledgling Internet industry. Sohu.com, which went public on the Nasdaq market in July, said it would buy ChinaRen.com for 4.4 million shares, or about 12.5 percent of Sohu.com's shares outstanding. The deal values ChinaRen.com, an operator of information and e-commerce web sites popular among Chinese college students, at about $30 million. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: POTENTIAL DEAL FOR DHL
description: Deutsche Post, the postal and logistics company controlled by the German government, is in talks to gain control of DHL International by substantially increasing its 25 percent stake in the company, a courier concern that has operations in the United States, people close to the negotiations said. The deal would value Brussels-based DHL at about 11 billion euros ($9.4 billion), far less than what had been speculated. DHL would give Deutsche Post, which is planning to go public in November, a global delivery network and pit it against the FedEx Corporation of Memphis and United Parcel Service of Atlanta. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: U.S. Checking if Conoco Violated Sanctions With Iran Contract
description: The Treasury Department is investigating whether an American oil company, Conoco, violated sanctions in dealing with Iran, Clinton administration officials said today.

title: New Mini: Retro in a Smaller Role
description: WITH American roads full of vehicles that are high, long and heavy, the time might not seem right to bring out a car that is low, short and light. Still, even as General Motors is planning a family of hulking, aggressive Hummers, BMW is polishing off the first member of a family of diminutive, amiable Minis.

title: A Youthful Wolfe Filled With Outrage
description: Thomas Wolfe was a long-winded playwright before he took to writing long-winded novels, which he did at least in part because he couldn't get anyone to produce his work for the stage. ''Welcome to Our City,'' a play he wrote while in graduate school at Harvard, was performed twice by his fellow students in 1923 and only once after that, in Zurich in 1962, translated into German. This, in any case, is the claim of the Mint Theater Company, which has resurrected the work in honor of the centennial of Wolfe's birth on Oct. 3.

title: Arrest Ordered for Suharto Son in Indonesian Bombing Cases
description: JAKARTA Indonesia, Sept. 15  Seeking to restore confidence in his beleaguered government, Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid ordered the arrest today of former president Suharto's youngest son in connection with a spate of deadly bombings, including a blast on Wednesday that killed 15 people at the Jakarta Stock Exchange building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRONNINGSATER, ARNE
description: GRONNINGSATER - Arne. The trustees, faculty and administration of Riverdale Country School extend their deepest sympathies to the children of Arne Gronningsater, who passed away on August 30, in Westport, NY. Beloved teacher and friend to generations of students, his spirit remains at Riverdale Country School. Memorial service, Saturday, September 23, 2:00 PM, All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave., NYC.

title: 2 More Illnesses Linked to Bottled Water
description: As two more people in the region were hospitalized after drinking bottled water yesterday, city officials said that they had not revealed three earlier incidents until this week because the cases had been regarded as isolated.

title: Elian Redux: Step Right Up
description: It has the political heft of a Disney cartoon, the dramatic tension of ''Saturday Night Live'' and is so upbeat it should have been called ''Everybody Loves Elian.'' Still, the Fox Family Channel movie ''The Elian Gonzalez Story'' is significant merely because it exists. The little boy had hardly set foot on Florida's shore before the course of his life became inseparable from the television circus around him. This simple-minded film, the latest turn in the media extravaganza, displays how television shapes and reshapes events.

title: With No Room to Maneuver, Grim Choice for Nassau Chief
description: Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, has been loath to propose an increase in county property taxes over the last several years. On Friday, he will.

title: LONDON EXCHANGE LEADER QUITS
description: Gavin Casey, the chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, resigned in the wake of a botched plan to merge with the Frankfurt exchange. Mr. Casey's resignation came a day after shareholders barely re-elected him, with 56 percent approval. The chairman of the exchange, Don Cruickshank, who also narrowly won re-election, will take over Mr. Casey's duties until a replacement is named. The London exchange is preparing to defend against a hostile bid from OM Gruppen, a Swedish technology company that runs the Stockholm exchange. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Gore Meets With India Leader And Prods Senate on Test Ban
description: Mixing election politics and international diplomacy, Vice President Al Gore told Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India today that as president he would make passage of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty his first foreign policy initiative in Congress, and he urged India to adopt the treaty as well.

title: Yearning to Be Great, India Loses Its Way
description: In the last two years, the Indian government, dominated by the Hindu nationalist party, Bharatiya Janata, has tried to establish an exalted position in the world for India. It has conducted nuclear tests, lobbied hard for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council and played up the West's high demand for India's skilled information-technology workers. Atal Behari Vajpayee, the Indian prime minister, who met with President Clinton in Washington and addressed the Congress this week, hopes to achieve, among other things, an American endorsement of India's claim to superpower status.

title: Consumer Prices in August Registered a Rare Decrease
description: For the first time in more than 14 years, it cost American consumers a bit less last month to fill their market baskets with goods and services than it did the month before.

title: Bush's Tune Is the Same Even as the Pitch Varies
description: For much of the presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore has been cast as the desperate master of morphing and derided for earth-toned makeovers and alpha-male aspirations.

title: Those Eyes! Those Sighs! Lypsinka, What a Dame
description: Such graceful, cheerful hands they are, as they bob and arc and flutter through the air, keeping time to the music. They're like a pair of well-trained pet doves, so domesticated that you could take them to a nightclub or restaurant.

title: He Was Crazy Like a . . . Genius?; For Henry Darger, Everything Began and Ended With Little Girls
description: He has inspired a book of poetry (''Girls on the Run'' by John Ashbery), fashion designs (by Anna Sui), a British rock band (the Vivian Girls), a Hawaiian dance (''The Valley of Io''), a video game (Sissy Fight at www.sissyfight.com), an opera (being composed by Douglas Cuomo), a play (''Jennie Richee'' by Mac Wellman, opening in February at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago) and a movie prospect (now canceled). He has been compared to Lewis Carroll, Fra Angelico, Andy Warhol, Balthus and Dr. Seuss. The word ''genius'' has often been used near his name, but so, occasionally, have the words ''mind of a serial killer.'' His work has been called part ''Child's Garden of Verses,'' part ''pedophilic fantasy.'' He drew tribes of little girls, and gave some of them little penises.

title: NEW YORK: THE FIRST YEAR
description: The decision to move to New York City remains both irrational and quasireligious. A special issue of The Times Magazine reports on more than a dozen people who made that decision a year ago, like a star athlete and Israeli dot-commers and a gay teenage runaway. In every case, New York was the place that people hoped would transform their lives.

title: Flawed Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs
description: Accidents Lead Navy to Review Ship Safety

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. The price of crude oil rose more than 5 percent, reaching a 10-year high for the second time this week. The October contract increased $1.85, to $35.92 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: On Campus, Gore Stresses Need to Invest In Education
description: Vice President Al Gore concluded a tightly controlled week devoted to fund-raising and education policy by telling an enthusiastic crowd of students at Howard University today that improving schools and access to college must become a major federal priority in coming years.

title: Melbourne, the Host of the 1956 Olympics, Finds Itself in Sydney's Shadow
description: It has been a bittersweet week for Australia's other Olympic city. While Sydney was dressing itself up for the opening ceremony of the Summer Games and basking in the world's attention, Melbourne, which played host to Australia's first Olympics, in 1956, watched from the sideline.

title: F.D.A. Weighing New Limits on Acne Drug Accutane
description: WASHINGTON - The prescription drug Accutane, a popular treatment for severe acne, could face new restrictions to keep pregnant women from taking it and risking serious birth defects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, VICTOR
description: SIEGEL-Victor, of W. Orange, NJ, in his 91st year on September 15. Proud husband of Elaine for 65 years. Revered father, grandfather, great-grandfather and fatherin-law of Daniel, Eileen, Royce, Shepard, Stuart, Jill, Craig, Susan, Jon, Jennifer, Zoe and David. Services, Sunday, Schoems Chapel, Paramus, NJ, at 9:30AM. Dad, there was never a day you were not loved.

title: Side Effects Are Fewer In Therapy With Pellets
description: Like other prostate cancer patients deciding on treatment, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had to weigh both medical and personal factors. In choosing to have radioactive pellets implanted in his prostate yesterday morning, he selected an effective treatment with far fewer side effects than surgery.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of destinations in Weekend yesterday with an article about visiting the Hudson Valley misstated the hours at Alison Wines and Vineyards in Red Hook, N.Y. It is open 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Mondays through Saturdays and 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sundays.

title: Canadian Scientists Clone Famous Bull
description: QUEBEC CITY - Canadian researchers said Friday they cloned a male calf from the cells of Canada's world-renowned Starbuck Holstein bull, which sired more than 200,000 cows, bulls and calves before dying in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUICKSHANK, ROBERT W.
description: CRUICKSHANK-Robert W., August 27. Beloved brother of Carol Martin, Scarsdale, New York. A special gentle gentleman, husband, father and grandfather. Memorial Mass 12 Noon, Saturday, September 23, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale.

title: Piazza Stuck in September Slump As the Mets Fall to the Expos
description: Javier Vazquez was the equalizer tonight, the hot starting pitcher who could lift an also-ran over a contender for a night in September. The Mets accepted that part of their 4-3 loss to the Montreal Expos.

title: Aaron W. Warner, 92; Helped Shape New Deal and Columbia
description: Aaron W. Warner, a left-leaning lawyer who began his career as one of Felix Frankfurter's ''bright young men'' in the New Deal, and then switched careers at 46 to be a Columbia University professor and administrator for almost half a century, died on Aug. 25 in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: The Battle of Buffalo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SCHUYLER GEORGE
description: KOHL-Schuyler George, MD. 87, died on September 14, 2000. Devoted husband of 57 years of Blossom, adored father of Eileen, father-in-law of Eric. Grandfather of Erin and Elinore Kaufman. Distinguished Professor, dedicated teacher and helper to patients, nurse mid-wives, medical students and faculty members at Downstate for 50 years. Funeral service Sunday 2pm at Congregation Kol Ami (Chapel in the Woods), Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Family will receive friends at home in Scarsdale from 6:30 until 9pm Saturday, September 16. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Westchester or United Cerebral Palsy of NYC.

title: Indians Thrive on the Thrill of the Chase
description: Squashed for the ninth straight time by Pedro Martinez on a frustrating Thursday night, the Indians dragged themselves onto a plane that carried them from Cleveland to New York, where they could not land because of the rain. The plane circled for several minutes, then flew to Hartford to refuel and finally landed in Newark.

title: SCOTTISH LIFE TALKS COLLAPSE
description: Merger negotiations between GE Capital, the financial services arm of General Electric, and Scottish Life, an Edinburgh-based mutual life insurance company, have been abandoned, people close to the negotiations said. GE Capital had been near a deal to buy Scottish Life for more than $:1 billion ($1.4 billion), but negotiations soured when new bidders emerged at the last minute, these people said. Scottish Life said that it had received proposals from interested parties, but declined to identify them. Likely candidates are Royal London Mutual Insurance Society Ltd. and Liverpool Victoria Friendly Society. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, CHARLES ABBOTT
description: CARTER-Charles Abbott, III, age 54, passed away in N Y C, September 6th. Memorial Services will be held at 11a.m. Saturday, September 23 at Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, NYC. He is survived by parents, Mr.& Mrs. Charles Abbott Carter, Jr., of Kansas City; sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Gibby and brother, Stephen Carter of N Y. He was an insurance broker in N Y C.

title: The Mayor's Prostate Treatment
description: New York City's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, ended months of deliberation yesterday over the best course of treatment for his prostate cancer by receiving radiation implants at Mount Sinai Medical Center rather than undergoing a more invasive surgical removal of the prostate gland. The mayor had a slew of radiation seeds implanted in the prostate and will follow up later with five weeks of external radiation. Although neither the mayor nor his doctors have elaborated on the reasons for this course of treatment, it is almost certainly designed to give him the best balanced outcome between curing the cancer and avoiding the debilitating side effects -- incontinence and impotence -- that can make the treatment seem almost as bad as the disease.

title: In This Sport, Even the Judges Will Be Judged
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 15 -- As members of the Amateur International Boxing Association -- Olympic boxing's governing body -- arrived in Sydney early last week, they were greeted by a large cartoon published in the national newspaper, The Australian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, ANDREA
description: RICHMAN-Andrea. On September 14, 2000. Beloved wife of Murray, adoring mother of Stacey and Nicky, dear mother-in-law of Len Ellis, devoted sister of Arnold Shasun, beloved aunt and caring friend. An incredible person whose touch gave effervescence to life. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Service Sunday 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Political Memo; Energized Lazio Shows New Vigor in Campaign
description: The campaign bus he calls the Mainstream Express displays fresh detailing -- not to mention, finally, New York plates to replace the Alabama ones that reflected its owner's roots.

title: Australians to Honor Winners
description: Within hours of receiving Olympic gold medals, the likenesses of victorious Australians will appear on postage stamps throughout Australia.

title: Bottled-Water Complaints Multiply
description: Complaints of possibly tainted bottled water mounted in the metropolitan region yesterday, even as law enforcement officials said that thus far they had not discerned any link or pattern to the reports.

title: As Electoral Vote Takes Shape, Campaigns Focus on Perceptions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Vice President Al Gore, who has erased Gov. George W. Bush's lead in most national polls, has also edged ahead of him in the battle for electoral votes, according to independent and partisan analysts. But despite the postconvention trend in Mr. Gore's favor, enough states are either tossups or held so narrowly that the race remains fiercely competitive.

title: Patient Tennessee Understudy Gets the Lead
description: As a 5-year-old, he survived an accident in which a trailer full of hay thumped onto him. Last year, Crohn's disease gnawed 20 pounds off his frame. After spring practice, he was the third choice to quarterback the Tennessee Volunteers. Two weeks ago, in the season opener, he had made it to the second team.

title: MetroStars Get First Playoff Victory Since '96
description: The MetroStars went on the attack in an attempt to offset their recent defensive deficiencies. The strategy paid off handsomely in a 2-1 overtime victory tonight in the opening game of this Major League Soccer playoff series against the Dallas Burn.

description: Who owns a story? The inventor? Or does each teller lay claim to it simply by virtue of the telling? This is an issue that Redmoon Theater, a Chicago company, decides in its own favor in ''Hunchback,'' a captivating adaptation of the Victor Hugo novel ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame.''

title: Chinese Womens Streak Is Spiked
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 -- Once the wide-eyed nervousness wore off, Logan Tom started to relax. That's when the balls started flying over the arms of Chinese players.

title: Rutgers Jumps Up in Class For a Battle of Unbeatens
description: Rutgers and Virginia Tech are 2-0. The Scarlet Knights already know the similarities between these two football teams end right there.

title: Australia Aglow as Youthful Star Gets Two Golds
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 16 -- His arms slicing through the water with languid purpose in the 400-meter freestyle, his size-17 feet kicking up the wake of a paddlewheel boat, Ian Thorpe won Australia's first gold medal at these Olympic Games and pumped his fists lightly, as if to conserve his energy for a more exuberant celebration.

title: Beah Richards, 80, Actress in Stalwart Roles
description: Beah Richards, whose distinguished career as an actress on stage, screen and television over 50 years was capped this month when she won an Emmy as a guest actor on ''The Practice,'' died on Thursday in Vicksburg, Miss. She was 80. She was born in Vicksburg and lived in Los Angeles until Memorial Day, when she returned to her home city.

title: Women Grab Gold and Bronze for Switzerland
description: Michellie Jones sprinted down Macquarie Street: past the boxing kangaroo flags, past thousands of her fellow Australians who were packed four rows deep to watch the first Olympic triathlon in history.

title: Board Passes CUNY Plan Establishing 6 Priorities
description: The Board of Regents voted 10 to 4 today to approve a new four-year master plan for the City University of New York that advocates said would strengthen a network of community and senior colleges that has served as a gateway to higher education for generations of New York City residents.

title: A Plight Understood By Elders
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY, the recovering drug user, cancer survivor and sometime baseball player, was back in the news this week for all the usual reasons. He was in trouble with the law.

title: REGISTER.COM IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE AFTERNIC.COM
description: Register.com Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Afternic.com, which resells Internet domain names, for $48.6 million in stock and cash. Afternic.com is a privately held company that auctions domain names that already have been registered. Register.com sells domain names on a subscription basis. Both companies are based in New York. Register.com said it had agreed to pay $10 million cash and issue 4.38 million shares to purchase Afternic.com. The company said all of Afternic.com's employees would be offered positions with Register.com. Register.com's stock fell 25 cents, to $8.5625.

title: I.O.C. Anticipates TV Bidding
description: The International Olympic Committee probably will open bidding on its next American television contract, rather than hold secret negotiations as it did with NBC in 1995, I.O.C. vice president Dick Pound said.

title: Albright Sits Face to Face With Iranian
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Iran's foreign minister, Kamal Kharazi, found themselves in rare agreement today when they sat down together with senior diplomats from six other countries to discuss what to do about Afghanistan and its ruling Taliban.

title: Mathis Ends Drought At an Opportune Time
description: When Clint Mathis was in front of the Dallas goal in the 34th minute tonight and the ball came to his left foot, he did not stop to think. If he had, he might have remembered how he had been in this sort of spot before, and how he had been unable to score.

title: Bias Case Against Morgan Stanley Settled
description: Ending one of the most embarrassing chapters in its history, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has settled litigation with a former analyst whose complaints about his firing led to an investigation by the Manhattan district attorney and a public apology from the firm.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 6 Others On Busy Street in Sri Lanka
description: The suicide bomber's head, with its neatly barbered and combed black hair, lay today in the middle of a busy thoroughfare in this capital city, a grisly warning from separatist Tamil rebels at a time when campaigning for Oct. 10 parliamentary elections has gone into full swing.

title: It's Only the Bears, Right? Giants Take Them Seriously
description: National Football League coaches tend to be more overly dramatic than they need to be, so it is sometimes difficult to take what they say seriously. But Jim Fassel said this week that his team had reason to worry Sunday, when the Giants face the seemingly hapless Bears in Chicago.

title: Lieberman Lends His Voice To Mrs. Clinton's Campaign
description: Joseph I. Lieberman campaigned in Coney Island on behalf of Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday, offering testimony to her character and commitment to Israel. Her aides hope it will be the first in a series of New York appearances by the Democratic vice presidential candidate over the next two months.

title: Games Open With Ceremony and Tribute
description: The 27th Summer Games opened tonight with a spirit of inclusiveness and reconciliation in a ceremony that addressed Australia's discriminatory treatment of its indigenous people, celebrated the unprecedented number of female Olympians and applauded a march of unity between North Korea and South Korea.

title: Devils End Talks With Two Players
description: The Devils have been in training camp for a week. But Jason Arnott and Scott Niedermayer, the team's unsigned restricted free agents, have yet to make an appearance and there is no reason to think they will any time soon.

title: It's Nearly Time To Bring in Plants
description: Get out the shovel, the backhoe, or whatever tool is necessary and clear some space in your house or apartment. It's almost time to bring in the delicate specimens.

title: The Powerhouse Teams Are Picking Up Where They Left Off Last Season
description: While the high school football season begins in earnest this weekend, powerhouse programs like St. Anthony's of South Huntington, N.Y., Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island, Poly Prep of Brooklyn and Hackensack in New Jersey appear to be in midseason form. They notched impressive victories in their openers last weekend.

title: SHIFTING TACTICS, BUSH USES ISSUES TO CONFRONT GORE
description: Faced with an opponent who has managed to deflect questions about his character and trustworthiness, Gov. George W. Bush has shifted tactics and begun confronting Vice President Al Gore head-on over the issues, an area long considered to be Mr. Gore's greatest strength.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKTON, JOHN DUDLEY
description: LOCKTON-John Dudley. Retired Treasurer of General Electric. Died of natural causes September 12, 2000, in Greenwich, Connecticut. Mr. Lockton was born in Logansport, Indiana, in 1903. The son of an Episcopal clergyman, he was one of five brothers, all now deceased. He graduated from the University of Michigan, joined GE in 1926 and rose to Treasurer in 1948. During his long and varied career at GE, Mr. Lockton was responsible for many of the financial departments of GE, including the General Electric Foundation and being Chairman of the Board of GE Credit Corporation. While at GE Mr. Lockton developed the corporate cash management practices which are now widely copied by corporations around the world and was the subject of numerous articles including appearing on the cover of Business Week. Mr. Lockton was New York State Chairman of the U.S. Treasury Department's Savings Bond Division for many years, was a Director of numerous public corporations including Arkwright Mutual Insurance and Booth Computing, was a Trustee of Russell Sage College and Bennett College, served as a business director of the Metropolitan Opera and was a Vestryman of Christ Church, Greenwich. His charitable activities included serving the Boys and Girls Club of America in various Director and Finance positions. His club memberships included the Union and University Clubs, New york; the Round Hill and Field Clubs, Greenwich; Blind Brook Club, Purchase; Clove Valley Club, Millbrook. He married Alice Hanson, now deceased, in 1931 and Catherine Baker MacGregor, now deceased, in 1960. He is survived by a son, John D. Lockton, a daughter, Mrs. Judith Jones, a stepdaughter, Mrs. Robin Morton, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Greenwich at 2:00 p.m. September 16, 2000.

description: Season-opening programs of musical institutions are a genre unto themselves. A dinner for patrons typically follows, so the concert is, if not necessarily secondary, generally kept short and undemanding.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  President Clinton said today that he did not believe Wen Ho Lee was singled out for prosecution because he was Chinese-American, but said he planned to talk to the attorney general about concerns that the Los Alamos nuclear scientist was not treated properly by prosecutors.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about criticism of a research study that showed significant gains by black students given vouchers to help pay for private schools misstated the surname of a professor of education and economics at Stanford University who raised questions about it. He was Martin Carnoy, not Conroy.

title: MAYOR UNDERGOES CANCER TREATMENT
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had radioactive seeds implanted in his prostate gland early yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center, then appeared six hours later at a news conference with the relief and good humor of a patient who had gone through a cancer treatment that was not as bad as he had feared.

title: Sport and Spectacle on the Sand
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 -- There may have been a sweeter place to spend the first morning of the Olympic Games. But it was not readily apparent from the sun-drenched bleachers at Bondi Beach, where a sell-out crowd of 10,000 whooped it up on the opening day of women's beach volleyball.

title: SINGER REORGANIZES AND EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: The Singer Company, the world's No. 1 maker of consumer sewing machines, said yesterday that it had completed a reorganization and emerged from bankruptcy protection. The 149-year-old company filed for Chapter 11 protection in New York last September, blaming an ill-timed purchase of the German sewing-machine maker G.M. Pfaff in 1997 that sapped its cash. Singer said a global decline in the industrial-sewing market that year, and shrinking economies in Asia, Brazil and Europe, coincided with its $157.5 million purchase of Pfaff. The company's restructuring plan was approved by more than 95 percent of its voting creditors and was confirmed by a federal bankruptcy judge last month, the company said.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 -- There are powerful images that can be fleeting, and those that are unforgettable and real. One night after choreographing a utopian multiculturalism that smacked of fiction, the host Australians trotted out the real deal for the world to behold.

description: A car driven by an unlicensed teenager crashed into a scaffold in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday afternoon, injuring three people, including two who were left in critical condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, EDMUND V.
description: BURNS-Edmund V. On September 13, 2000. Retired math teacher at Power Memorial H.S. Beloved husband of the late Margaret. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at The William's Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx on Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday in Visitation Church at 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; A Symbol More Than a Gesture
description: Sporting ceremonies tend to give me the willies, what with the attempts to gloss over centuries of genocide and homicide and fratricide.

title: Latin Faces Light Up TV Courtesy of The Grammys
description: Bonbons were shaken and God was thanked in Spanish and English when the first Latin Grammy Awards show was broadcast on Wednesday night. It may well have been the most well-meaning awards show in history. It was a harbinger of a 21st century in which a growing Hispanic population will make the United States increasingly bilingual. And it showed a lot of famous faces and passionate voices that North Americans would never find on MTV.

title: BOISE CASCADE ADDING UNITS OF U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, a leading forest products company, said that it planned to buy the U.S. Office Products Company's Australian and New Zealand units for about $115 million. The purchase of the units, Blue Star Business Supplies Group, includes its office products distribution and educational supplies businesses in Australia and New Zealand. In New Zealand, the company had $300 million in revenue for the fiscal year ended April 29. The acquisition is expected to close within 30 days, and will give Boise Cascade, which is based in Boise, Idaho, a stand-alone presence in those countries.

title: Corrections
description: A film review headline in Weekend yesterday about ''Crime and Punishment in Suburbia'' misidentified the character who kills Fred, the father. It is not the mother, Maggie; it is the daughter, Roseanne, with her boyfriend, Jimmy.

title: The I.M.F. Will Revamp Its Lending
description: The International Monetary Fund approved a plan today to overhaul its loan programs and keep more money available for emergencies, a victory for Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who had been pushing for the changes since late last year.

title: Antidrug Program's End Stirs Up Salt Lake City
description: For all the decisions Ross C. Anderson has made in his first year as mayor of Salt Lake City, none has caused a bigger furor than this one: Over the summer, he terminated the city's involvement with the antidrug program in public schools known as DARE, saying that it was ineffective and a poor substitute for programs that he contends do more to discourage drug use by young people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NORMAN A.
description: MILLER-Norman A. died in August 2000 in his Tuxedo Park home where he had lived with his loving and beloved wife of 48 years, Adelaide B. Miller. A brother predeceased him. Born in 1926 in Euclid, Ohio, son of the late George R. and Anna Miller of Cleveland, he served in World War II in the U.S. Navy and studied at Stanford and N.Y.U. He was a retired executive for Grumman Aircraft. Mr. Miller served for many years as a Vestryman and Treasurer of St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church, as Chairman of the Republican Committee for the Town of Tuxedo and as Commander of the Tuxedo Post of the American Legion. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Mary's at a later date to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, NY 10987 or to the American Legion Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 1055, Indianapolis, IN 46206

title: Anger Doesn't Catch On
description: Fears of widespread demonstrations on the opening day of the Olympic Games proved unwarranted, as several protests fizzled today amid the buoyant spirits in this city.

description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik is conducting an intensive review of the Police Department's antidrug efforts, focusing on how tens of millions of dollars in overtime are being spent and on the high percentage of minor arrests being made by narcotics detectives, according to several senior law enforcement officials.

title: Ghosts of War in a Placid Park; Mock Refugee Camp Dredges Up Horrors of the Past
description: Nina Behtic, 16, and Sozana Selimaj, 17, are immigrants from the former Yugoslavia. They speak the same language. They go to the same high school. They bear inside of them, usually wrapped in the cotton wool of forgetfulness, the same memories of war and death. But when they grieve, as they did yesterday morning on Cherry Hill in Central Park, they grieve alone.

description: Less than 24 hours after presiding over the opening ceremonies of the 2000 Sydney Games, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, left for his native Spain today to join his ailing wife.
