It was the San Francisco office of Brann Worldwide, part of Snyder Communications (which is being acquired by Havas Advertising), not Digitas in Boston.

title: Pavarotti and His Fans Rendezvous at the Garden
description: Since 1850, when P. T. Barnum arranged a lucrative American concert tour for the renowned soprano Jenny Lind, dubbed the Swedish Nightingale, opera has occasionally produced a superstar who wins fans from outside the ranks of opera buffs. Luciano Pavarotti has been that star in our time. Many singers and rock bands crave the kind of success he has enjoyed with concert gigs at huge stadiums around the world. Of course, ever since Mr. Pavarotti realized he could reach more people and make more money through the Three Tenors concerts, he has scaled back his individual stadium appearances.

title: Triathlon Winner
description: Brigitte McMahon of Switzerland outsprinted Michellie Jones of Australia to win the gold medal at the Sydney Games in the inaugural women's triathlon. Page D7.

title: Special Teams for Jets Have Been Anything But
description: They may be unbeaten thanks to a pair of late comebacks, but the Jets know these heroics go just so far. And it might be especially dangerous to wind up trailing late in the game against the stingy defense of the Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

title: VW PLANS A BIG SHARE BUYBACK
description: Pleasantly surprising investors, Volkswagen A.G. said it would repurchase up to 10 percent of its shares, one of the biggest buybacks ever planned in Germany. The move, which helped push VW shares 4.3 percent higher, to 49 euros, or $42.14, on the Frankfurt exchange, is a departure for Volkswagen, which has in the past shown little interest in strengthening the price of its shares. Company executives said they hoped to use the shares they reacquire as a currency to make other acquisitions. Volkswagen has long wanted to expand its trucking operations, and already owns 18 percent of the shares in Scania A.B. of Sweden. Volkswagen has also made overtures to BMW A.G., the Bavarian car manufacturer, but BMW's controlling shareholder -- the Quandt family -- has rejected all approaches. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: With Minutes Left, Gulotta Submits Nassau Budget
description: Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, submitted a four-year budget plan at 11:58 p.m. Friday night, two minutes before an end-of-the-day deadline set by state fiscal monitors overseeing his administration's troubled finances.

title: Teachers In Buffalo Back to Work For Now
description: Pushed by an angry judge and prodded by a state labor mediator, Buffalo's striking teachers went back to class yesterday and promised to remain on the job until Tuesday, when a mediator is expected to propose a settlement.

title: Henderson Moves Up As the Mariners Win
description: Rickey Henderson scored two runs to pass Babe Ruth and Hank Aaron and move into second place on the career list as the Seattle Mariners beat the Baltimore Orioles, 10-2, last night at Camden Yards.

title: Nonprofits Facing Ethical Challenges Over Sales of Land
description: Spurred by a booming real estate market, some philanthropies, universities and other nonprofit groups have in recent years made land deals that critics say harm the environment and contradict the institutions' missions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VANADIUM INTERNATIONAL INC., Reno, Nev., a company that explores for precious metals, said it agreed to buy the closely held Reno-based Cleartron Corporation, which is building a wireless communications network that uses low bandwidth to monitor remote devices like gas meters. The price would be about $81.8 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, WILLIAM
description: ZIMMERMAN-William. Of North Palm Beach Florida, died September 9, 2000. He was 80. Survived by his sisters, Ida Rubin, Rose Zimmerman and Sarah Tepper, his three children, Stuart Zimmerman, Marc Zimmerman and Susan Chroman, and ten loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Mr Zimmerman rose from a modest background to become one of America's most successful retailers, founding closeout specialist Pic 'N' Save (now part of Consolidated Stores) in 1950 and managing it until his retirement in 1985. A great supporter of children's causes and entrepreneurial education, Mr Zimmerman and his foundation were significant contributors to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship. Memorial services to be held in Los Angeles Sunday September 24.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOCHBERG, CAROL ELAINE
description: HOCHBERG-Carol Elaine. September 16, 1998. Another year has passed. but not a day goes by when we don't think of you. With smiles on our faces and love in our hearts as we try to do for others what you have done for us. We love you. Scott H. Comely, brave young men, the champions of their city-states, would hurl their javelins down a playing field, instead of at one another. The winners were crowned with laurel and carried on the shoulders of an adoring populace, and all was as it should be.

title: When Left Turns Right, It Leaves The Middle Muddled
description: No movement lasts forever, but how do we know when the end has come? Consider the case of the neoconservatives, the network of liberal and leftist intellectuals who were disillusioned by the convulsions of the 1960's -- or ''mugged by reality,'' in the famous expression -- and drifted steadily rightward, emerging in the 1980's as an informal brain trust for the Reagan Administration.

title: Web Sites' Merger Signals Consolidation of China's Internet Industry
description: China's Internet industry, serving one of the most promising markets, is about to undergo a sweeping consolidation after the first major merger of the industry's short life.

title: Clinton Doubts Scientist's Race Influenced Case
description: President Clinton said today that he did not believe Wen Ho Lee was singled out for prosecution because he was Chinese-American, but said he planned to talk to the attorney general about concerns that the Los Alamos nuclear scientist was not treated properly by prosecutors.

title: Post-Olympic Goal: Saving Americas Children
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Back home in the States, the Summer Games may be a temporary fascination on the television screen, with their emphasis on gold medals, plus the added suspense of post-match drug testing for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Paradise Lost, Again
description: If you want to take your lunch out in Bryant Park and sit in the sun over the next few weeks, you can just forget about it. That goes for the rest of the month, the entire holiday season, and much of February, too.

title: Chilly Conditions Do Not Deter Jones
description: Despite the cool, windy conditions here that sprinters do not generally like, Marion Jones said today that she believed she could significantly lower her personal best in the 100 meters in winning a gold medal next week at the Olympics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTER, NEDRA
description: ALTER-Nedra. Cherished daughter of Helen and Sydney. Dear sister of Phyllis Malino. Services at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Cooper & Cypress Avenues, Brooklyn, Sunday at 11 AM.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of William C. Warren, a former dean of Columbia Law School in New York, misspelled the surname of the current dean, who commented on Mr. Warren's five decades of influence on the school. He is David W. Leebron, not Leebrun.

title: Article 2000091690575504772 -- No Title
description: The Ultimate Remote Means Never Having To Leave the Couch

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH, DICK CHENEY -- No appearances scheduled

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are going for work, but always in tension. Anytime, shelling or bombing comes from all directions. We are frightened, but what are we to do?''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the race for Washington State's Second Congressional District seat, from which Jack Metcalf is retiring, referred incorrectly to his first race, 32 years ago. He ran unsuccessfully for the Senate, not the House.

title: U.S. Tops South Korea; Holdsclaw Is Sidelined
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 -- Skittering across the floor, penetrating without regard for their bodies and kicking the basketball out for 22 3-pointers, the undersized players from Korea entertained a near-sellout crowd on the opening night of the Olympic women's basketball tournament.

title: Soft-Money Travesties
description: With so much attention focused these days on the issues and personalities in the presidential race, it is too often forgotten that a record fund-raising campaign is being waged by the candidates with far less public scrutiny. Once again big unregulated donations from corporations, unions and rich individuals are pouring into party treasuries and being used for campaigns in violation of the campaign laws. Whether it is the Democrats getting money from trial lawyers for killing a bill that would curb personal-injury lawsuits, or Republicans getting money from corporations to get such a bill passed, the ''soft money'' loophole has corrupted the whole political system.

title: Young Americans Need Focus and Luck
description: The night Kerri Strug turned a bad ankle into a very good final vault at the 1996 Summer Olympics, Kristen Maloney was already asleep.

title: Thorpe Sets New World Record
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Australian Ian Thorpe won the 400-meter freestyle at the Olympics in 3 minutes, 40.59 seconds, breaking his own world record Saturday.

title: A Duel of Epees and Epithets
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 16 -- Marcel Fischer had just lost his chance for Olympic gold in fencing, and reacted as if he were Charles Oakley faced with the flop-to-the-floor acting skills of Reggie Miller.

title: George Christopher, 92, Dies; Lured Giants to San Francisco
description: George Christopher, who as San Francisco's mayor persuaded the New York Giants to move to California, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 92.

title: Third Man on Podium Recalls 68
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 -- Peter Norman felt as if he were flying, an exhilaration that today, 32 years later, he can barely describe. He churned around the curve and blazed down the backstretch on a warm night in 1968 in Mexico City. He burst across the finish line, looked at his time of 20.06 seconds in the 200 meters and shook his head in disbelief. He had run the race of his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEGLITZ, BARBARA
description: STIEGLITZ-Barbara aka; Ma, MeMa, Bobby, Bobs; caring daughter, loving wife, proud mother, peer of her grandchildren, friend; died in her sleep Thursday, September 14, 2000. Gentle, interested, kind, genuine describe her well. It is best to fight and win, but to fight knowing you cannot win is courageous. She will be missed. Service Sunday, 12 noon at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck 914-381-1809

title: Sports of The Times; An Olympian In Word and Deed
description: ON a mild, clear Thursday evening, thousands of spectators with a sense of anticipation crowded around Sydney Harbor to celebrate the arrival of the Olympic flame. The opening ceremony would take place the following evening, but Sydney's passions were ignited on this night.

title: Counterfeit Parking Placards Lead to Arrest
description: A police officer from the Department of Defense was charged this week with possession of counterfeit parking placards from law enforcement agencies. The placards are displayed in car windshields to gain official parking privileges at government buildings.

title: The Battle of Buffalo
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Chancellor Hires Lieberman's Daughter for Project
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has hired the elder daughter of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, to help match city schools with corporate partners that can provide volunteers and financial support.

title: Religion Journal; Back From Africa With Cry for Help
description: A month ago, three Roman Catholic bishops from the United States embarked on a fact-finding journey through the Great Lakes region of eastern and central Africa, an area that for several years has seemed to produce only bad news.

title: Aide Says Debate Talks Continue but an Agreement Is Near
description: Negotiators for Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore neared agreement today on formats for the three presidential debates, although ''some sticking points'' remain, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush said.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''The Dream Catcher'' misstated the name of the series in which it is appearing at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. It is the American Independent Visions series. (The Independent Feature Project is one of four presenters of the film.)

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Marrying for Love
description: To the Editor:

title: 30,000-Gallon Fuel Spill Largely Washes Out to Sea
description: The Jersey Shore caught a break.

title: Busting Crime, or Just Eardrums?
description: To the Editor:

title: School and Archdiocese Ignored Ex-Teacher's Molesting of Pupil, Lawyer Says at Trial
description: Proceeding without a former teacher accused of molesting a 12-year-old boy, lawyers representing the former pupil in a civil suit he brought years later said yesterday that they would show that school officials ignored obvious signs of a bizarre relationship between the two.

title: BRAZILIAN BREWER'S NEW YORK SPLASH
description: American depository receipts of Latin America's leading brewery, Companhia de Bebidas das Americas of Brazil, rose 3.3 percent, to $21.6875, in their debut on the New York Stock Exchange, where company officials generated some publicity by ringing the closing bell with the Brazilian model, Gisele Bundchen, and distributing 6,000 cans of the brewery's Guarana Antarctica tropical soft drink to passers-by outside on Wall Street. Ambev, as the company is known, is the world's fourth-largest beer company, a result of a $7 billion merger of Brazil's two largest brewers, Companhia Cervejaria Brahma and Companhia Antarctica Paulista, earlier this year. It controls 70 percent of Brazil's beer market and 25 percent of its soft-drink market. Rick Gladstone (NYT)

title: Dubrovnik Journal; Without the Shellfire, The Beach Looks Fine
description: It is a scene from the old, peaceful days before the Yugoslav wars: a beach crammed with overweight bodies, children whizzing down water slides, people eating packed lunches from plastic bags and fantastically loud music pumping out of loudspeakers. A holiday from hell for some, but Croatia's seaside resorts -- largely dormant for 10 years -- are booming again.

title: Religious Freedom in Russia
description: This year in the Russian town of Kostroma, a panel of university professors, local government officials, a psychiatrist, a psychologist and a lawyer met to ponder whether two local Pentecostal churches should be legally registered. After watching a video of church services, the group concluded that the church leaders used ''psychological manipulation.'' The two churches were not allowed to register, and court proceedings are beginning to ban them. If this happens, their members would be able to meet in a home to pray, but they will be second-class religious citizens. Their community will not be able to distribute literature, rent or own a building, invite foreigners to preach or carry out other activities integral to religious freedom.

title: Troops Help With Rush Hour
description: Sydney used soldiers to help transport some of the 114,000 people who attended the Olympic Games opening ceremony Friday.

title: OPEC States Want to Be Paid if Pollution Curbs Cut Oil Sales
description: At the latest round of international talks aimed at shaping a treaty on global warming, delegates from oil-producing countries insisted that any final accord include a commitment to compensate them if efforts to cut emissions of heat-trapping gases resulted in a drop in the use of oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERVINO, SERAFINO
description: GERVINO-Serafino. ''The Maestro.'' Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Camille Romita, Armand, Rosemarie Brueckner and the late Kathleen Gervino Beker. Loving grandfather of Carla Romita, Michael N. Romita, Paul Romita, Alexandra Brueckner, and great-grandfather of Katherine. Reposing at Loyd Maxy & Son Beauchamp Chapel, 16 Shea Lane, until Monday, 9 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at the Holy Family Chapel of the College of New Rochelle, Monday, 10 AM. Contributions to the Kathleen Gervino Beker Scholarship Fund at the College of New Rochelle will be appreciated by the family.

title: List Shows Corruption Is Lingering
description: When a country gets the reputation of being deeply corrupt, it takes a lot of time -- and more than just the election of an anticorruption government -- to improve on its negative image, a watchdog group says.

title: Well-Rested, American Wins the First Gold
description: Nancy Johnson said she had planned to walk in the parade of American Olympians at Friday night's opening ceremony, but changed her mind because she knew the ceremony would end late and athletes would not return to the athletes' village until well past midnight. Because her event, the 10-meter air rifle competition, began at 9 a.m. today, Johnson decided at the last minute to remain in the athletes' village.

title: Staley Is a Player as Well as a Coach
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Late this fall, with whistle in hand, Dawn Staley intends to halt practice and take a young Temple University recruit aside. She wants to give the freshman a message.

title: U.S. Shoots for Gold, And Please Behave
description: Lisa Leslie, the starting center for the United States women's basketball team, was asked if she thought Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal should be here to represent the American men.

title: 1st Annual Latin Grammy Awards Winners
description: Record of the Year

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the race for Washington State's Second Congressional District seat, from which Jack Metcalf is retiring, referred incorrectly to his first race, 32 years ago. He ran unsuccessfully for the Senate, not the House.

title: It's a Harsh Political Climate for a Believer in Nonbelief
description: ELLEN JOHNSON lives in a ranch house here with her husband and two children and a dog that follows her from room to room. Children's bicycles are sprawled on the lawn, and an apple pie is waiting in the kitchen. All in all, some may see it as a rather wholesome setting for the most outspoken atheist in America.

title: Starting to Hammer Away, At Rivals and on Message
description: After spending a bumpy month trying to deflect criticism of everything from the conservative votes he cast in Congress to his business affairs to his spotty voting record in Dallas, Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, has decided that the best defense is a strong offense.

title: Lieberman, Known Crusader for Propriety, Appears on Imus's Show
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman often calls for less vulgarity and meanness in popular culture. But yesterday, Mr. Lieberman appeared on the radio with Don Imus, the raunchy morning-show host, continuing the Democrats' tightrope walk of criticizing the entertainment industry while using it as a source of support.

title: ALTAVISTA TO CUT A QUARTER OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: The AltaVista Company, a unit of CMGI Inc., said it would cut 225 jobs, or about a quarter of its work force, as the company, which operates a popular Internet search service, seeks to become profitable before selling shares to the public. AltaVista, which has about 900 employees, will take a charge of about $7.5 million in the quarter ending Oct. 31 for the job cuts and for consolidating its four offices into one location, said Rod Schrock, AltaVista's chief executive. He said he expected the business to be profitable by Jan. 31.

title: Witness To a Killing Seeks Asylum
description: A witness to the assassination of the leading Mexican presidential candidate in 1994 has requested asylum in the United States. He is pleading to avoid deportation to Mexico, where an arrest warrant has been issued against him and where he says his life would be in jeopardy.

title: A Bush Anecdote
description: To the Editor:

title: Paradise Lost, Again
description: If you want to take your lunch out in Bryant Park and sit in the sun over the next few weeks, you can just forget about it. That goes for the rest of the month, the entire holiday season, and much of February, too.

title: KOREAN STEEL CONCERN
description: South Korea will try for a third time next month to sell its 6.84 percent stake in the Pohang Iron and Steel Company. The Korea Development Bank, the state-owned lender that owns the stake, said that it planned to sell shares in Pohang, the world's biggest steel maker, in the form of American depository receipts. About a month after the sale, the government plans to abolish a 30 percent ceiling on foreign stock ownership in the company. The sale's completion is viewed as a crucial move in the drive to sell state assets by the end of the year, a condition of the $57 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund in 1997.

title: Indians Deliver Cone a Setback And Silence Yankee Bats in Rout
description: The injuries nagging at the Yankees seemed like nothing more than a nuisance a week ago, but with the playoffs on the horizon, some of the trouble threatens to overlap into the postseason. Exhibit A: Paul O'Neill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Disappointing Oracle Sales Pummel Technology Sector

title: Endless War Again Laps at Sri Lankan City
description: The dull, explosive thud of mortar fire and the roar of MIG-27's are the white noise of this war-weary city. Separatist rebels have advanced to near the outskirts of this, the imagined capital of the Tamil homeland that they have fought, killed and died for. The ethnic conflict that has tormented Sri Lanka for 17 years is once again knocking on Jaffna's door.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIPS. The euro declined to a new low as purchases of the currency by the European Central Bank failed to provide support. In New York, the euro settled at 85.63 cents, down from 86.41 cents on Thursday.

title: Indonesia President Orders Arrest of Suharto's Son in Corruption Investigation
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid ordered the arrest today of the youngest son of former President Suharto in connection with a series of deadly bombings, including one on Wednesday that killed 15 people at the Jakarta Stock Exchange.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Questions Raised About Ford Explorer's Margin of Safety
description: On the wide-open highways of the South and West, drivers often push their Ford Explorers toward the vehicle's maximum speed -- 99 miles an hour -- for hours at a time. Yet the Firestone tires on millions of Explorers are certified to last only 10 minutes at a slightly higher speed -- 106 miles an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, PATRICIA STRASSBURGER
description: SIMON-Patricia Strassburger. 71, died September 14 peacefully at home in Montgomery, AL; formerly of White Plains, NY. She leaves behind her husband Ed; daughter Linda Cohen & son-inlaw Henry Cohen of Montgomery; daughter Patty Benator and sonin-law Gene Benator of Atlanta, GA; brother Julien Strassburger and sister-in-law Joyce Strassburger of Montgomery; brother-inlaw and sister-in-law Carol and Ted Diamond of Westport, CT; & 5 grandchildren, Andrew, Daniel, Adam, Brian & Jaime. Funeral services will be private. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Montgomery, 1111 Holloway Park, Montgomery, AL 36117.

title: Price for Crude Oil Gains More Than 5%
description: The price of crude oil rose more than 5 percent yesterday, reaching a 10-year high for the second time this week. The jump came amid tensions in the Persian Gulf and concern that a storm would intensify as it moved toward rigs and refineries along the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Packing a Meeting About Oyster Bay Mall
description: On Sept. 7, I attended a Town of Oyster Bay meeting regarding the shopping mall proposed for the Cerro Wire site on Robbins Lane [''Battle Lines Harden Over Syosset Mall,'' Sept. 3]. Initially, I was among the 800 or more residents forced to remain outside Syosset High School for hours, despite the many empty seats in the auditorium. Later, when I gained entry, I was frustrated to learn that the town was allowing the Taubman Company, the developer, to complete its presentation first. By drawing out its presentation, Taubman was able to prevent opponents from being heard until 10 p.m.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats in Utah Take Aim at Seat
description: Few states are more Republican than Utah, where the party controls the governor's office, both houses of the state legislature and all five of the state's seats in the United States Senate and House. But Democrats think they have a good shot this year at capturing the state's Second Congressional District, which covers Salt Lake City.

title: An Abstractionist Maintains the Faith In a Skeptical Era
description: IN his diaries from the heyday of abstract painting in the 1950's, Ad Reinhardt (1913-1967) observed that each time he started a new canvas, he felt a frisson of awe -- and an inevitable weight of familiarity. He suggested that each new work was, perhaps inescapably, one and the same with those that came before it.

title: DAM INSPECTIONS
description: The state Department of Environmental Protection has ordered all of the state's dams inspected, even the 1,400 considered ''low hazard.'' Previously, the agency had been more concerned with 187 ''high-hazard'' dams, but during last month's floods in Morris and Sussex Counties, three of the four dams that failed had been classified as ''low risk.'' Angela Starita

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00: The Ethicist; School Dance
description: My full-time (but not live-in) baby sitter hinted that she would like to use my address to enroll her daughter in my excellent local public elementary school; her neighborhood school is awful. The alternative is for her to send her daughter to private school, a financial burden but not an impossibility. Should I offer my address? -- L.A.B., Brooklyn

title: Vines Threaten Trees Along Highways
description: AN invasive vine that came to this country more than a century ago is threatening trees lining Westchester's scenic highways.

title: Where Films Made In English Can Seem A Cultural Betrayal
description: WHEN Denys Arcand stepped onto the red carpet outside Roy Thomson Hall here earlier this month, he had reached the end of a long road. His first major film in seven years, ''Stardom,'' was the opening-night offering at the Toronto International Film Festival, and Mr. Arcand, 59, a French-Canadian Montrealer, was enjoying a welcome reserved for native sons. Local newspapers had plastered photographs of Mr. Arcand and interviews with him all over their arts sections, heralding the film's arrival, and on the red carpet Mr. Arcand himself seemed to glow amid the adulation.

title: The Richmond Creek Bridge: Built, 1845; Future Uncertain
description: Officials at Historic Richmond Town, a 100-acre historic village with dozens of 18th- and 19th-century buildings, concede that traffic congestion is severe at the nearby intersection of Richmond Hill Road and Richmond Road. But they fear that the city might try to fix the problem by demolishing Staten Island's only arched fieldstone bridge.

title: Giants' Offense Purring Under Payton
description: Sean Payton was a senior when he walked into Coach J. R. Bishop's office at Naperville Central High School outside Chicago. Bishop started to fume when Payton, his starting quarterback, told him the team had too many plays. Bishop relented, trimmed the playbook and the Redskins won their next game in a rout.

title: Olympic Reign of Pocket Hercules Ends
description: SYDNEY Sept. 17 -- He is 33 years old, smokes 50 cigarettes daily for his inner peace, and has won the gold medal in weightlifting in the featherweight class, in three consecutive Olympics.

title: Ideas & Trends; And Now, a Few More Words About Breasts
description: FLIPPING through late-night talk shows, glancing at advertising billboards or even walking the streets in Midtown Manhattan, it is hard to escape the conclusion that the nation is witnessing an epidemic of buxomness.

title: Reckonings; Britain's Stormy Petrol
description: Tony Blair showed real backbone last week. Faced with a stunningly effective blockade by truckers protesting high fuel prices, the British prime minister flatly refused to give in to demands for tax cuts. The initial result was extensive disruption -- not just closed gas stations but shortages of bread and milk in supermarkets, delays in medical procedures and in general a state of chaos all too reminiscent of the U.S. gasoline shortage of 1979. By the end of the week, however, the protests seemed to be subsiding in Britain (though similar protests were still growing elsewhere in Europe). So for the time being Mr. Blair has won -- though no good deed goes unpunished, and he is likely to pay a heavy political cost for his stand on principle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILBERT, CHARLES A.
description: GILBERT-Charles A. Remembering Charlie. D

title: The Air-Conditioned Reverie of a Fundamentalist
description: SUMMERTIME in Houston. This is what it's like to be a martyr to city-love. Heat and mugginess drive the body into underground streets and climate-controlled rooms, behind sealed windows and closed doors. The mind feels trapped, too. Intellectually, you know that you're in a great American city. Physically, you feel absent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPPER, GERTRUDE
description: TAPPER-Gertrude. In her 91st year. She will be remembered as an exceptional wife and mother who devoted her life to her family. Beloved wife of the late Alec, devoted mother of Arthur Tapper and Elaine Geller, Marcia and Stan Bell. Adored grandmother of Jill Wolf, Nancy and Oscar Sison, David and Elyse Bell and Garey and Kim Bell. Cherised greatgrandmother of Lindsay, Eric, Jordan, Joshua and Aaron. Dear sister of Harry Galler, Shirley Schecter, Belle Schleider and the late Fay Stillman. Serivces today 12:45pm, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Contributions in her memory can be made to your local Hospic Association.

title: Arrest Last Week of Catholic Bishop in China
description: BEIJING, Sept. 17  An 81-year-old Roman Catholic bishop in southern China, who spent a total more than 30 years in prison for his loyalty to the Vatican, was re-arrested last week, a Catholic foundation in the United States said today.

title: 'I'm Not Afraid Of Anything Anymore'
description: Name: Anna FishmanAge: 14Looking for: A bright future

title: Wielding the Ax, When a Tree Endangers Life and Limb
description: Whom should you call when a tree or bush blocks a road sign? As Corinne and David Geffner recently discovered, it can be complicated.

title: The Concrete Beneath His Feet
description: Name: Salman RushdieAge: 53Coming from: EnglandLooking for: A place to write

title: Valerie Tom, Warren Hrung
description: Dr. Valerie Tom, a daughter of Shuet Chun Tom and Fu Kueng Tom of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Warren B. Hrung, the son of Yang-Chih Hrung and Dr. Paul Hrung, both of Midwest City, Okla. The Rev. John Graf Jr., a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: There at The Kickoff
description: Partygoers welcome the new season with a flurry of outings.

title: Children's Books
description: STARGIRL

title: Don't Worry About It, Girl, You're History
description: YOU have to feel sorry for HBO's latest young heroine. Her preoccuppied and self-centered father is in danger of losing his job. She may have to move out of her home. Her cat disappears. One of her older sisters has it in for her.

title: Soprano's Piano
description: To the Editor: I would take issue with the assertion in the article that Marcella Sembrich is ''virtually forgotten'' today. Her career at the Metropolitan Opera (1883-1909) was one of the longest. Also, after her retirement from the opera, Marcella Sembrich was a central figure (together with Paderewski) in re-establishing the independence of Poland.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGEN, EUGENE DEBS
description: COGEN-Eugene Debs, on September 14, 2000. Cherished father of Alisha. Dear brother of Robbie. Benefactor of many. Life enhancer to multitudes. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Medicaid in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Streets Paved With Vodka and Caviar
description: ''I'm afraid the whole world will be my enemy,'' the old man sang in Russian under the yellow street lights.

title: In the Region/Long Island; New Front Opened in Hamptons Preservation Battle
description: CILE DOWNS, an artist from the hamlet of Springs, set aside her brushes recently and took up a pen to enlist her neighbors in a drive to preserve 4,500 acres of watershed land in the South Fork towns of East Hampton and Southampton.

title: Matsuzaka Pitches 10 Innings but Cant Stop U.S.
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 17 -- Of the many cultural differences between the United States and Japan, one of the most noticeable is the approach to baseball pitchers.

title: Was It Citizen Hearst or Citizen Welles?
description: AS I made my way through ''The Chief,'' David Nasaw's new life of William Randolph Hearst, a premonition crept up on me. This long, careful book was loaded with shot that might carry further than Mr. Nasaw intended. I could not place the feeling at first, or see how so reasonable and persuasive a narrative was setting off such large creaks and groans within me. But then the prospect dawned -- that the election itself might be affected -- and I began to feel hopeful.

title: Sports of The Times; The Real Goal Is Protecting The Children
description: BACK home in the States, the Summer Games may be a temporary fascination on the television screen, with their emphasis on gold medals, plus the added suspense of post-match drug testing for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: When Sitcoms Had Magic: The High-Concept Era
description: ONCE, when an uptight advertising executive decided to settle down, he married a witch. Now, when an uptight lawyer weds, he marries a hippie.

title: Sept. 10-16; The End of a Knight Era
description: After 29 years and three national titles, Bob Knight, the iconic and notorious college basketball coach, was fired by Indiana University after several charges of ''uncivil, defiant and unacceptable behavior.'' The university's students did not let him go quietly: thousands marched to the president's house in protest, which brought out police officers in riot gear. Joe Drape

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00: On Language; Slurvian
description: What students of the New York accent now categorize as ''first-stage Slurvian'' was reported in the 1938 Federal Writers Project ''Almanac for New Yorkers.'' An example given was onnafyah.

title: Critic of Army Is Assassinated in Secessionist Region of Indonesia
description: A prominent Islamic university rector who was a leading candidate for governor of Aceh, a province roiled by secessionists, was assassinated early today, underscoring the violence that has plagued the region and all Indonesia in recent months.

title: MORE ON THE OLYMPICS
description: 500 METERS OF GOLD

title: Unsatisfied by Drop in Crime And Asking for More Police
description: John A. Fratta has been the district manager for Community Board 11 in the northern Bronx for five years, and each year when he helps put together the budget request, one item tops his list: more police.

title: A Prescription For Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: So You Want to Be President?

title: New Subway For Istanbul Raises Specter Of Old Fears
description: When the Ottoman sultan, Abdul Hamit II, opened the first subway here 125 years ago, some of his devoutly religious subjects refused to use it because they feared going underground before they died.

title: A Memory Vault Rich in Lore of the Stage
description: ERIC BENTLEY, the eminent theater critic, playwright and Brecht translator, has cause for celebration: his 84th birthday (which was last Thursday) and the recent publication of a volume of his theater criticism, ''What Is Theater? 1944-1967'' (Hill & Wang). Most of the essays in this portrait of New York theater, drawn mainly from the 1950's, appeared in The New Republic.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Dark Horses and Black Beauties

title: Fall Planting
description: Fall is ideal for planting: root systems have time to settle in still-warm soil before hard freeze. Evergreens are best planted before the end of September; most deciduous trees and shrubs can be planted through early November.

title: A G.O.P. Opportunity In New Hampshire
description: New Hampshire could fall either way. Mr. Bush had been leading slightly in recent months, but the latest poll by the University of New Hampshire Survey Center has Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore tied at 42 percent. About 10 percent said they preferred other candidates and 6 percent remained undecided.

title: Sept. 10-16; Death Penalty Under Review
description: A Justice Department study of the federal death penalty prompted Attorney General Janet Reno to order follow-up reviews to see why most death cases originate in a handful of judicial districts across the country and why minorities are far more likely than whites to face the federal death penalty. The last federal execution was in 1963. There are 19 people on federal death row. Marc Lacey

title: Overcrowded Schools, Cold Shoulders
description: School overcrowding has become so bad in Queens that Borough President Claire Shulman has called for a Marshall Plan of new school building. She also convenes what she calls War Room meetings each month to ensure that no school construction project has fallen behind schedule. And she has declared the boroughwide deficit of 27,688 school seats a state of emergency.

title: Saturday Gladiators
description: BEER AND CIRCUS

title: Streetscapes/7 East 96th Street; A French-Style 1913 Town House, in Limestone
description: OGDEN CODMAN wanted to turn 96th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues into an elegant Parisian ensemble, with wide, French-style town houses lining the wide block, almost like a European square. Codman, an architect and decorator who collaborated with Edith Wharton, achieved his goal only fractionally before moving to France in the 1920's, when apartment buildings took over the block.

title: Autumn Bloom in Shades of Pink or White
description: YOU don't see the fall-blooming Japanese anemones (Anemone Japonica) in every garden, but you do see them in a lot of interesting gardens. One such place is a little butterfly garden tucked beside an elementary school near my house. A local designer, who is noted for her lush layouts, sense of history and stellar plant selections, designed the plot. As I walked by the other day, I noticed a tall white anemone, its delicate single flowers standing high above a whorl of dark green leaves. As befits a plant that grows to be 2 to 3 feet tall, the anemone was at the back of the bed of shorter specimens. It faced south, but I am sure at some times of the day it is shaded by the neighboring butterfly bushes. The anemone was a pleasant surprise, perfect in that place at this time of year.

title: My First Year in New York; 1957
description: I was 20 years old and had come from five months working as a crane operator at the Bethlehem Steel Mills in Sparrows Point, Md., near Baltimore. I had managed to save about $1,200, and that would be my stake to get started in music school in New York. It would carry me for about only half a year, so I immediately began a series of day jobs to supplement my savings. And that's how I managed for most of the next 21 years -- working as a truck loader, furniture mover, plumber, artist's assistant (to Richard Serra) and, yes, taxi driver. Looking back, I think it was the furniture moving that provided me with my most intimate knowledge of the life of the city. I started a moving company with my friend and cousin, the artist Jene Highstein. We discovered early on that the secret of success in the moving business was the company's name. After a few false starts we came up with ''Chelsea Light Moving.'' The name seemed to evoke feelings of confidence in our customers and gave us an air of professionalism, which wasn't exactly accurate.

title: New Editor at Digest Draws Attention
description: Reader's Digest is not known for its racy articles, but it did become the subject of an edgy item in the tabloid gossip pages last week. The magazine, based in Chappaqua, recently hired Catherine Romano as its deputy editor. Ms. Romano, as executive editor at Maxim, Details and Cosmopolitan, wrote and edited articles about sex and relationships.

title: Soft Money Buys New Anti-Clinton Ad
description: Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton clashed yesterday over the use of so-called soft-money contributions in their campaigns, even as the state Conservative Party prepared to broadcast a new commercial today, financed with soft money, that for the first time attacks Mrs. Clinton's failed attempt to create a national health care system.

title: The Rangers' Faces Look Different, the Results Do Not
description: Other than a little emotion infused by Dale Purinton's fists, the Rangers' 5-1 drubbing by the Philadelphia Flyers in a preseason game today could have easily been confused with any number of games from last season.

title: Thrust Into the Spotlight, MetroStars' Goalie Shines
description: The MetroStars kept reminding themselves the last few days how their top players -- Lothar Matthaus, Adolfo Valencia, Clint Mathis and Tab Ramos, to name a few -- had to raise their level in the playoffs after the team's dismal finish in the Major League Soccer regular season. No one spoke about Paul Grafer, the goalkeeper who joined the team with two games left in the regular season because of a season-ending injury to Mike Ammann and the absence of Tim Howard, on duty with the United States Olympic team in Australia.

title: Sept. 10-16; Raising the Kursk
description: Russia's atomic energy minister, Yevgeny Adamov, says he has absolute confidence that the giant twin reactors sealed inside the Kursk pose no radiation risk to the fishing grounds of the Barents Sea. But a day after Mr. Adamov suggested that leaving the nuclear submarine where it sank on Aug. 12 might be safer than raising it, Deputy Prime Minister Ilya Klebanov declared that Russia still intends to raise the Kursk. Mr. Klebanov said that he, too, believed in the safety of the shutdown reactors, but acknowledged that the public, and Russia's neighbors in Norway, would feel better if the sub were raised. The salvage work will follow attempts to recover the remains of the 118 who died in the sub, and might not begin until the spring. Patrick E. Tyler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, SHIRLEY (SANDY)
description: HAFT-Shirley (Sandy). On September 15. Beloved wife of the late Steve. Cherished Mom and great friend to Jerry Haft and Cindy Somasunderam. Dear mother-in-law of Uday. Devoted and proud Grandma of Ilana. Also survived by her loving brother Ron and many friends who were blessed to have had her in their lives. Memorial contributions may be made to Leukemia Society of America.

title: Deadly Disparities
description: Last week's report from the Justice Department confirming stark racial and geographic disparities in the imposition of federal death sentences has underscored the arbitrariness of the nation's death penalty system. The Clinton administration ought to impose a moratorium on the death penalty in federal cases until existing flaws are remedied.

title: Stiff Fight to Sway New Mexico Voters
description: New Mexico has been a reliable national bellwether in presidential politics. In every presidential race except one since it became a state in 1912, New Mexico has supported the winner, often close to the margin as the nation as a whole. The lone exception came in 1976 when the state backed Gerald R. Ford.

title: Estate's Lush Gardens Blur Lines of History
description: THE country begins to look delightful,'' a Princeton gardener wrote to a friend in May 1785. ''Our shrubbery is all putting out, the hyacinths, narcissus, jonquils and Daffy, in fully bloom with the verdure of the grass in contrast make a most delightful scene.''

title: Nathalie Gimon, Amir Farman-Farma
description: Nathalie Flora Gimon, the daughter of Eleanor Hewlett Gimon and Jean-Paul Georges Gimon of Greenwich, Conn., was married at the New York City Municipal Building on Thursday to Dr. Amir Ali Farman-Farma, the son of Haroon Al Rashid Farman-Farmaian of London and Manijeh Mir Damad of Southampton, N.Y. Yesterday, Dr. Iraj Anvar led an Islamic and Persian ceremony in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about Ken Kurson, founder and editor of Green, a personal finance magazine, misstated the name of the distributor of ''Marketplace,'' a radio program on which he has appeared. It is Public Radio International, not National Public Radio.

title: Europeans Debate Inner-City Airports
description: THE fatal crash of a supersonic Concorde northeast of Paris on July 25 has renewed debate over the construction of a third major airport to serve the French capital. The fact that the Concorde could easily have come down on top of a small town, with even more than the four deaths that resulted among people on the ground, is also raising questions about the safety of existing airports in or near cities, about their further development and about the location of future airports elsewhere in Europe.

title: Clinging to a Dream of Success on the P.G.A. Tour
description: HE doesn't go around talking about it, but Bill Van Orman went swing for swing with Tiger Woods at the U.S. Open at Pebble Beach in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEERS, VINCENT
description: PEERS-Vincent of Spring Hill, FL. A longtime resident of Massaqequa, NY, he was 75 when he died on Monday, September 11, of complications related to his heart and lungs. Vincent retired as a pressman from The New York Times and Daily News, where he was well known for his sense of humor and strong work ethic. He never let a day go by without doing the Times' crossword puzzle and any others he could find. Vincent served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and felt a strong, unwavering allegiance to his country. After moving to Florida in 1989, Vincent co-founded the Delta Woods Bocci Club and was an avid player, winning several awards. He made quick and fast friends with his club mates and the members of his church and the New York Club. Vincent leaves behind many friends both in Florida and in New York. He lived for his wife, children, and grandchildren. Vincent leaves his wife, Dolores; children Clare, Gerard, Dolores, Vincent, and Joanne; his daughterin-law, Marla; his sons-in-law Tim, Scott, and Harry; and his truly adoring and adored grandchildren, Stessa, Jacey, Aram, Andrew, Carrie, and Tatiana Rose. His children and grandchildren are grateful for having been given the gift of spending his last weeks with him. Vincent also leaves his sisters, Frances (Sr. Clare) Ellen, and Rosemary; and his brothers, George and Joe (a brother, William (Fr. Bill), predeceased him.) Vincent Peers was cremated and buried in Florida on Friday after a Catholic service. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Ronald McDonald House in his memory.

title: Seana Wyman, Frank Bradley
description: Seana Lee Wyman, the daughter of Rosemarie A. Wyman of Brooklyn and Henry E. Wyman of Buffalo, was married in New York yesterday to Frank Nelson Bradley, a son of Noel and William J. Bradley, also of Buffalo. Michael Gage, a former administrative judge of the New York City Family Court, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPOL, BENJAMIN
description: TOPOL-Benjamin. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Hollace Cohen and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: 6 Scientists Honored With Prize In Research
description: Two scientists whose work helped virtually eliminate the risk of transmitting viruses that cause hepatitis through blood transfusions were among six winners of this year's Albert Lasker medical research awards being announced today.

title: Titans Have the Weapons; The Trick Is Blending Them
description: NASHVILLE Sept. 16  Eddie George knows how to run. So does quarterback Steve McNair. With Carl Pickens, Yancey Thigpen and Kevin Dyson, McNair has a lot of passing targets, too.

title: Sept. 10-16; Clinton's Vietnam Visit
description: President Clinton spent much of his youth trying to stay out of Vietnam, and much of his presidency figuring out how to draw it into America's orbit. Now, he is finally planning a visit, scheduled for after the presidential elections, in his waning days as commander in chief. The agenda includes putting a new trade deal in place and encouraging the search for the bodies of soldiers still listed as missing in action, but that may be overshadowed by the drama of the first visit by an American president since the war's end. David E. Sanger

Beck of Monroe, Conn., and Gilbert A. Beck of Stamford. Rabbi Sharon L. Sobel officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A Man of Ideas Searches for Musical Metaphors
description: THE critic Whitney Balliett once wrote that jazz is ''the sound of surprise.'' A performance by the jazz pianist Uri Caine and his ensemble at the recent San Sebastian Jazz Festival here bore out Mr. Balliett's point. The ensemble performed Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations, a work consisting of 30 inventive treatments of one theme for solo keyboard. Mr. Caine used the piece as a jumping-off point, interspersing his own concoctions for horns, strings, a DJ and a choir with some of the original Bach variations.

title: Soprano's Piano
description: To the Editor: My husband and I have been opera fans for many years, and we visited Marcella Sembrich's studio at Bolton Landing, N.Y., last summer (''A Voice From the Met's Final Season,'' Aug. 20). The curator, Richard Wargo, was most informative, and when I asked him if I could play a few notes on Miss Sembrich's Steinway, he kindly gave me permission. Imagine my thrill as I sat at the very piano on which she played and gave lessons.

title: Lane Is Arrested Again
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 16  Deidra Lane, already charged with murdering her husband, the National Football League running back Fred Lane, has been arrested on bank larceny charges.

title: Kari Van Nevel, Matthew Buckard
description: Kari Andrea Van Nevel, a daughter of Lois E. Van Nevel and J. Paul Van Nevel of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Matthew Hall Buckard, the son of Penelope D. Buckard and Donald L. Buckard of Watchung, N.J. The Rev. Ervin Brown performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

description: Alison Walker Jahncke, a daughter of Elizabeth C. Jahncke and P. Roger Jahncke of New York, was married yesterday to Per Stefan Strandlund, the son of Lizzie Ingegard Hasth Strandlund and Sven E. Strandlund of Hoganas, Sweden. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Investigation Of Ex-Chief Of the C.I.A. Is Broadened
description: John M. Deutch, who is under investigation by the Justice Department for admitted computer security violations when he was the director of central intelligence, may have committed the same kind of security breaches years earlier when he was a senior official at the Pentagon, according to government investigators and several confidential Defense Department documents.

description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 16  It won't be your typical round of golf  about 11 hours to play 18 holes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sept. 3 about the new CBS series ''Welcome to New York'' referred incorrectly to the background of Jim Gaffigan, a star of the show. While he was born and reared in Indiana, he was not a weatherman there.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Better Angel

title: Judge Does What Rain and Sleet Can't: Halt Postal Operation
description: The post office promises that ''neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of nights stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.'' Lawsuits are not on that list, however, and one has stopped the mailman, at least for now.

title: Satirical Scalpel Is Used in Senate Race
description: The Conservative Party of New York has begun broadcasting a 30-second spot on behalf of the Senate campaign of the Republican Rick A. Lazio.

description: THE singer-songwriter Kevin Briody always considered himself a writer rather than a performer.

title: Lauren Simmons, Craig Feldman
description: Lauren Joyce Simmons, the daughter of Sandra Simmons and Dr. Howard Simmons of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Craig Daryl Feldman, the son of Karen Feldman and Dr. Donald Feldman of Lynnfield, Mass. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, N.Y.

title: Article 2000091793862430160 -- No Title
description: The Ultimate Remote Means Never Having To Leave the Couch

title: Escaping Leases Made By Sponsors
description: LAST May, a Federal Appeals Court in Manhattan rendered a decision that could save some co-ops and condominiums hundreds of thousands of dollars, real estate experts say. The decision -- based on a 1980 federal law enacted to protect shareholders and unit owners from sponsors who give themselves lucrative, long-term leases on building amenities at the time of conversion -- has expanded a co-op's or condominium's ability to end such leases without the consent of the sponsor.

title: Making a Tragedy With a Happy Ending
description: BJORK GUDMUNDSDOTTIR hopes that people realize that ''Dancer in the Dark'' is not a tragedy. Despite this Icelandic singer's blood-and-guts-spilling performance in the role of Selma, which won this year's best-actress award at Cannes, Bjork says the film's final vision is of one of her favorite spiritual states: joy.

title: Working Family of One
description: To the Editor:

title: A Haven in the Heart of the Left Bank
description: Suite 801 of the Pont Royal, according to a manager of the Left Bank hotel, is the only hotel room in Paris with a view over the entire city -- or at least its heart and its major monuments, from the Invalides to Sacre-Coeur to Notre-Dame. Among the viewing points in the suite, done in mauve toile de Jouy, are two terraces and even the bathroom, which has two windows.

title: Investing the Family Fortune
description: IN the spring of 1997, when Sue Morrow Flanagan first saw what is now the Kitchawan Institute here, it did not look promising. A storm had strewn tree limbs all over the property. The main building had been abandoned six years earlier by its previous owner, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Field Research Station. Inside, there were so many leaks that water could be heard trickling all over the building.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Amsterdam; Red Lights, green drinks and a taste of Bourbon Street blues
description: With legal prostitution in the famed Red Light District and marijuana sold openly in the so-called coffee-shops, Amsterdam lives up to its reputation as a freewheeling pleasure capital. Amsterdam is one of Europe's premier club towns, and the Dutch are very serious about house music. Late-night action is centered in the Rembrandtplein and Leidseplein districts, both within walking distance of the city center. With Amsterdam's popular informal ''after parties,'' Saturday night can last well into Sunday morning.

title: My First Year in New York; 1963
description: I was 19 and had worked my way across the country for the previous six months driving a bus for a small repertory company called the Bishops, out of Southern California. I abandoned the bus in the middle of Times Square and I remember watching the red butt of it move away from me down 42nd Street and thinking, ''Now Im really in for it. One hot tip Id picked up from a tall, skinny actor on the bus was about the Burns Detective Agency. Hed told me it was a sure-fire job opportunity if everything else failed. My immediate mission, though, was a cheeseburger, but I had zip in my pocket.

title: Beauty or Beast? The Truth, Wherever It Lies, May Not Be Pretty
description: TAKE my S.U.V. -- please.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, WARREN J. WARREN J.
description: WOLFE-Warren J. Warren J. Wolfe of Great Neck and Westhampton Beach, died on September 1st at the age of 83 due to emphysema-related complications. Prior to his retirement in 1976, Mr. Wolfe was the Director of Advertising for The New York Times. Mr. Wolfe served as Board President of both his residences - Park Point Cooperative Apartments, Inc. in Great Neck and Harbor House in Westhampton Beach. In addition, he served as a Trustee of the Village of Westhampton Beach. In earlier years, Mr. Wolfe was a boating enthusiast and enjoyed some of his most pleasurable times on the waters surrounding Westhampton Beach. He leaves a number of very close friends, but no family survivors. Memorial contributions may be sent to the American Lung Association.

title: Still Shunning the Glare but Speaking His Mind
description: While he may never take a courtside seat at Madison Square Garden, Bill Russell still follows the National Basketball Association closely, watching from his home in Mercer Island, Wash., where he has a satellite dish that beams games to him from every corner of the league. And he has watched the Patrick Ewing saga unfold this summer, hearing how Ewing cannot return to the Knicks for another season and be subjected to the boos of the New York crowd and the taunts of the tabloid newspapers. Russell just shrugs.

title: Rachel Etess, Jason Green
description: Rachel Michelle Etess, the daughter of Lauren Etess-Schwartz of East Hampton, N.Y., and the late Mark Grossinger Etess, was married last evening to Jason Samuel Green, the son of Francine Green and Robert I. Green of Aspen, Colo. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANE, SHIRLEY
description: LANE-Shirley. September 17, 1997. We love you madly.

title: Nicole Migdon, David Finkel
description: Nicole Felice Migdon, the daughter of Hermine and Sidney Migdon of Manhattan, was married yesterday evening to David Seth Finkel, the son of Lois and Frank Finkel of East Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Michael White officiated at the New York Botanical Gardens in the Bronx.

description: Name: Alex Aborlleile

description: A DIFFICULT site, a resourceful developer and the current flush times in the real estate market have come together in a condominium project now rising on a steep waterfront site overlooking the Hudson River where apartment prices average $1 million.
