description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Base Instincts; When Taste Imposes a Limitation on Statues
description: IT seemed like a good idea at the time.

title: A Fashion Show to Chamber Music
description: IT was the archetypal fashion show: guests perched on the edge of their white-lacquered chairs, craning to catch every nuance of the dresses about to drift into their midst. Seated front row center, Pauline Trigere peered intently at the procession of black cocktail dresses swaying to the accompaniment of ''Begin the Beguine.''

title: The World; Even in Euroland, Money Isn't Everything
description: THE 15-member European Union, it has often been said, resembles a bicycle. If it does not move forward, it falls. Right now, the bicycle is wobbling dangerously as Europe's persistent push for ever deeper integration wavers.

title: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ALONE
description: New Jersey parents are less likely to leave their young children at home alone after school than working parents in the 11 other states studied by the Urban Institute, according to a survey released last week. Nationally, 21 percent of children aged 6 to 12 whose parents work are left alone after school,the institute said, compared with 14 percent in New Jersey. ''We think more children in New Jersey are left with relatives, partially because of the density of the population and partially because of the large immigrant population that keeps close family ties,'' said Jeannette Russo, fiscal policy analyst for the Association for Children of New Jersey. Karen DeMasters

title: Amy Kershaw, Adrien Finzi
description: Amy Alexander Kershaw, a daughter of Dr. Nancy L. Goldner of Brooklyn and the late David N. Kershaw, was married yesterday to Adrien Claude Finzi, a son of Anna and Bernard Finzi of Princeton, N.J. Paula Gilmure, a justice of the peace in Brewster, Mass., officiated at the High Brewster, an inn there.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: London; Hot spots that make you feel as if you belong
description: There is nothing easy about going out for an evening in London. Sure you can always belly up to the bar at the local pub, but painting the town red here takes much more effort than that.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Dublin; Talk or funk, whatever your taste, there's always Guinness
description: Against a tide of gaudy international discotheques, the traditional Irish pub has no problem holding its own in Dublin. Historic watering holes and polished nightclubs are learning to live side by side.

title: Conserving Furniture With an Artist's Touch
description: ALTHOUGH he is not a painter or sculptor, Dean Squires is an artist whose work is prominently featured in the Newark Museum. Mr. Squires, 48, is one of the few high-end furniture conservators in the state, and the one the museum's decorative arts curator, Ulysses Dietz, trusts.

title: Orthodox Angels Are Aiding Women in Childbirth
description: Mirrel Eissenberg, vice president of a real estate management firm, was wearing a floppy blue smock with teddy bears printed on it at the Maimonides Medical Center in Borough Park.

title: Love and Other Quantum Leaps
description: Properties OF LIGHT

title: The View From Scuffletown
description: Nowhere Else on Earth

title: Festival to Blend Poetry and Rap
description: Your heart thrills to the sestina and the villanelle; haiku and blank verse quicken your senses. Now, O lover of poetry, are you ready for Toni Blackman's Hip-Hop 101?

title: Please the Mind, Please the Eye
description: THE artist Jane de Jonge does more than tease the eye. She creates witty, thought-provoking assemblages that focus on the fleeting pleasures of life and taking a chance as well as expressing the hopes and terrors of the computer age. In ''Impossible Dreams,'' a one-woman show at Art/ Place in the Southport train station, her works will engage the mind and beg the dream.

title: A Diverse Bill of Fare in White Plains
description: TO be all things to all diners: such ambition has doomed many a restaurant. City Limits, however, that protean eatery in the hub of White Plains (a branch by the same name has opened in The Westchester), seems to accomplish the impossible with ease and panache. In terms of clientele and menu, this is, perhaps, the most diverse restaurant in the county -- the ne plus ultra diner. Lawyers lunch on poached salmon and salad alongside squirming children eating franks and ice cream sundaes. The place always seems to be hopping.

title: GREENBURGH: ORDER TO HALT PROJECT UPHELD
description: Neighbors recently won another round against two Greenburgh developers who may have to tear down four houses because they failed to seek subdivision approval from the town's Planning Commission. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn agreed with a lower court's order to halt construction on the houses until the developers, William and Edward Baker, obtain subdivision approval. Greenburgh's building inspector has issued a permit for the project, but Justice Peter M. Leavitt said that the Planning Board should decide because the project involved combined lots. The developers have until tomorrow to submit their subdivision proposal.

title: Gun Plan Shows Bush Isn't Solid in Colorado
description: One of the early signs that Colorado's eight electoral votes may no longer be a sure bet for Mr. Bush is a ballot initiative to require background checks of those buying guns at weekend shows.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATZ, DR. HYMAN M.
description: KATZ-Dr. Hyman M. Next Sunday, September 24th, at 2PM, rain or shine, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, Section 2.

title: Sept. 10-16; Tales From the Dark Side. Of Golf.
description: The urge to say that CBS Sports has egg on its face is strong, but that would be sophomoric wordplay. So here are the simple facts. The network has been dubbing recorded bird sounds into the background of televised golf tournaments, and some clever bird watchers figured it out.

title: Yonkers Judge Backed by Spencer Gets on Ballot
description: THOUGH Mayor John D. Spencer wasn't on the ballot in Tuesday's primary, many in Yonkers see him as a big winner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE-Celia In loving memory of your birthday, September 19. Grandchildren

title: Sept. 10-16; One Less Primate
description: Dozens of endangered monkeys, apes, lemurs and other primates in the tropics have endured decades of forest destruction and intensifying hunting, with not a single species or subspecies vanishing in the 20th century -- until now. A concerted search through every suitable scrap of forest in Ghana and the Ivory Coast ended without turning up a trace Miss Waldron's red colobus, a boisterous tree dweller, which has not been seen since the 1970's. It is the first announcement of a primate extinction since Jamaica lost its one indigenous monkey species in the 1700's. Andrew C. Revkin

title: In the Northwest, Nader Could Be Factor
description: Though voters in Oregon and Washington State rejected Mr. Bush's father in both 1988 and 1992 and gave President Clinton a wide margin of victory four years ago, the Texas governor has repeatedly said he expects the Pacific Northwest to be highly competitive.

title: Elizabeth Senior, Charles Hayward
description: Elizabeth Anne Senior and Charles Evans Hayward were married yesterday at Inn by the Sea in Cape Elizabeth, Me. Ron Ward, a justice of the peace in Portland, Me., officiated.

title: On CUNY's Campuses, The Subject Is Change
description: WITH the academic year now at full speed on its 19 campuses, some 200,000 City University of New York students are finding themselves threading their way around cement mixers, pile drivers, cranes and jackhammers, in some places circumventing holes in the ground where buildings will rise, in others attending lectures in temporary trailers or at odd hours while classroom buildings undergo renovation.

title: Candidates Agree on Formats for 3 Debates
description: After three days of negotiations, officials from the Gore and Bush campaigns agreed today on the formats and structure of three presidential debates in October and selected Jim Lehrer, the anchorman of PBS's ''News Hour,'' as the moderator for all three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, LEONARD, D.D.S.
description: MARCUS-Leonard, D.D.S. On September 15, 2000, at age 84. Beloved husband of Sydney, cherished father of Peggy, Barbara and her husband Michael Pollack, loving grandfather of Miranda Hammer and Lucy and Ava Pollack, and dear brother-in-law of Gerald and Phyllis Lakow. We will remember him for his love of life and family, and his sense of adventure. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to a charity of your choice. Services to be held at the Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY, 12 noon, Sunday, September 17, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, JEFFREY
description: BRYER-Jeffrey. In my heart and thoughts on this, your birthday and everyday of my life, my dearest Jeff. Love, Mother.

title: My First Year in New York; 1968
description: That fall I started commuting, two hours each way, from suburban New Jersey to a Jesuit high school on the Upper East Side. I would emerge every morning at 8 from the PATH station, the old Hudson Terminal, where construction was just beginning on the World Trade Center, and walk down John Street to the Lexington Avenue IRT, which I would ride up to 86th. I wore a coat and tie and carried a briefcase. I was 14 years old.

title: Mark Eitzel at Maxwell's
description: Mark Eitzel is the former tempestuous frontman for a wildly popular, but never commercially successful California band, American Music Club. His songs are regarded as some of the best of modern rock, combining the simplistic beauty of folk music with the intensity of punk and the over-the-top emotional drama of lounge-styled fare. Be prepared for an unwavering, darkly lyrical evening when he performs Saturday at Maxwell's in Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Article 2000091792453318109 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Falling in Love With Exquisite Venetian Glass
description: On the way to the airport for a skiing holiday in 1989, Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu stopped at Sotheby's in Manhattan to pick up catalogs for the coming contemporary art sales. ''There, across the salesroom, I saw a vivid blue and green Venetian hourglass in the same tonality as the flowers in my Andy Warhol painting,'' Ms. Olnick said. ''We went to investigate, and the maker's name -- Paolo Venini -- rang a bell.'' She was delighted; Mr. Spanu was not.

title: Caroline Mulroney, Andrew Lapham
description: Caroline Anne Mulroney, the daughter of Brian Mulroney, the former Canadian prime minister, and Mila Mulroney of Montreal, was married yesterday to Andrew Polk Lapham, a son of Joan and Lewis H. Lapham of New York. The Rev. Gregory A. MacKinnon performed the ceremony at St. Leon de Westmount Roman Catholic Church in Westmount, Quebec.

title: Jeanne Wesel, Thomas Ross
description: Jeanne Lisabeth Wesel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfried E. Wesel of Upper St. Clair, Pa., was married yesterday to Thomas Steven Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ross of Closter, N.J. The Rev. William DeBiase, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. James in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Mexican Modern: Back to a Future That Fell Behind
description: THERE was a point between the two world wars when politics and economics pushed experimental modernism in the visual arts into a corner or simply squashed it in the Soviet Union, Germany, Italy and America. For a while in the 1920's the modernist adventure was still going full throttle. Although many artists in Europe and the United States pulled back toward stylistic reason and classicism immediately after the chaos of World War I, avant-garde experiments like Dada, Suprematism, abstraction and Surrealism continued to strike sparks in much of Europe and the U.S.S.R. in the 1920's and even in the 1930's where dictators did not forbid them or social causes overshadow them. Mexico was a special case. Early 20th-century art movements had a negligible influence there before the 1920's. Just when they began to have an effect, the Mexican muralist movement spread across the country's walls and by its artistic power, nationalistic appeal and its very size and visibility, marginalized the modernist currents pulsing through the country.

title: Nicole Morris, Keil Merrick
description: Nicole Edwards Morris, the daughter of Elena and Mark Morris of Snedens Landing, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Keil Merrick, the son of Cynthia and Fred Merrick II of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Edward Anderson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated, and the Rev. Laurie Ferguson, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: My First Year in New York; 1980
description: I lived that first year in a cheap, unheated loft on Water Street, literally in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, with my friends Francis O'Shea and Darrah Cloud. This was 20 years ago, before the South Street Seaport, when Water Street looked like the set of a movie about postwar Berlin, when at most hours its only visible inhabitants were a tribe of scrappy but prosperous cats.

title: YONKERS: PROTEST SENTENCE STAYED
description: Justice Joseph K. West of State Supreme Court in White Plains has stayed Leonard Buddington's sentence of 40 hours of community service for disorderly conduct, pending the determination of his appeal. Mr. Buddington, a lawyer and the president of the Yonkers branch of the N.A.A.C.P., was sentenced by Judge Edmund Fitzgerald of Yonkers City Court last month for his role in a prayer demonstration at a school board meeting in June. On June 16, Mr. Buddington and other members of the Yonkers 13 group protested the firing of Yonkers' first black superintendent of schools. Randolph Scott-McLaughlin, a civil rights lawyer and the director of the Social Justice Center at Pace University, said the city was better served by Mr. Buddington's being allowed to work as a lawyer and president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VATTER, HAROLD GOODHUE
description: VATTER-Harold Goodhue. Age 89. On September 8, 2000. At his home in Portland, Oregon. Professor of American Economic History at Portland State University for 35 years. B.A. University of Wisconcin, M.A. Columbia, Ph.d University of California at Berkeley. Survived by Rita Jett of Holbrook, Arizona, Terry Vatter of Dundee, N.Y., Marc Vatter of Providence, R.I., three grandsons and Dr. Joy Spalding and her family.

title: In a Working-Poor Town, Candidates Are Dismissed as Being Out of Touch
description: The Greyhound seems to carry more people away from here than it ever brings back. Cindy Lamb works the cash register at the bus stop, and, one ticket stub at a time, she sells young people a way out of Dixie County.

title: Mets Enjoy Themselves Despite the Glum Setting
description: It was the kind of inning the Mets have seen too often this month. They had the bases loaded in the first inning tonight, with one run in, nobody out and their 5-6-7 hitters coming up. And they squandered the opportunity.

title: Campaign for More Minority Police
description: FACED with what they call minimal efforts by the county to recruit minority police officers, Servando Rodriguez Jr., Luis Muniz and Frank Alfonso, members of the Westchester Hispanic Law Enforcement Association, spent last Saturday recruiting for a Dec. 9 civil service examination on their own.

title: A Biotechnology Sprout In Arid Market Ground
description: THE business of using biotechnology to make hardier, more bounteous crops has long been a graveyard for small, undernourished companies.

title: A High-Tech Vision Lifts Fidelity
description: CROSS HAIRS are trained on the green-and-yellow home page of DLJ Direct, the online brokerage firm. Literally. It is a Tuesday in late August at the new Fidelity Center for Applied Technology here, specifically, in a ''usability'' lab of the ''human interface design department.'' This is where Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund manager, does some of its most important research and reconnaissance.

title: Small Step Is a Big Lump in a Parent's Chest
description: ONE Wednesday afternoon, I put on my CD ''Diana Ross and the Supremes Greatest Hits.'' Then my son and I danced around the dining room table to the warble of Diana's transistor-perfect ''I Hear a Symphony.'' It was a glorious moment. Outside we could hear and feel the energy of rush hour. The light pouring through the window was the golden color of the day fading to evening.

title: Australia Aglow As Young Star Gets Two Golds
description: His arms slicing through the water with languid purpose in the 400-meter freestyle, his size-17 feet kicking up the wake of a paddle-wheel boat, Ian Thorpe won Australia's first gold medal at these Olympic Games and pumped his fists lightly, as if to conserve his energy for a more exuberant celebration.

title: Move One Step to the Left
description: There that's it. Hold up your right hand. Hold it while I crouch down.

title: Robin Segal, John Edelman
description: Robin Lynn Segal, the daughter of Dr. Joy Segal and Michael Segal of Chicago, was married on Friday to John David Edelman, a son of Ruth and Daniel Edelman, also of Chicago. Judge Anne Burke of the Illinois Appellate Court in Chicago, officiated at the Jens Jensen Preserve, a landmark and a home of the bride's parents in Ravinia, Ill.

title: Footlights
description: Bassoonist Turned Jazz Artist

title: Works by Faberge In Wilmington Show
description: One of the world's largest exhibitions of the work of the jeweler and goldsmith Peter Carl Faberge has opened at the Riverfront Arts Center at 800 South Madison Street in Wilmington, Del. ''Faberge'' features more than 1,000 works from museums and private collections, including objects from the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg and the Moscow Kremlin Museums that have never been seen in the United States.

title: Where the Sidewalk Ends?
description: In this seaside town of 2,600 people which swells to 30,000 in the summer, where Joe Pesci bought a house for his mother and where the mayor strolls around in shorts -- you wouldn't expect a dispute over what a sidewalk is.

title: Preparing Red Bell Peppers During Their Peak Season
description: RED bell peppers, now at their peak season, have a thick flesh and sweet mild taste. But they aren't at their best eaten raw. They should be toasted over wood or charcoal or charred under a broiler until their skins blacken. Then they should be put in a paper or plastic bag where they steam in their own heat for a few minutes. This loosens their skins and makes them juicy and easy to peel.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sea Gate; 'Hamptons West' in Brooklyn
description: HARBOR seals bobbing in the water. Freighters from all over the world floating by. Cormorants spreading their wings on pier pilings and diving for fish. A sandy beach, right in the backyard.

title: Sarah Mason, Terrence Burgess
description: Sarah Montague Mason, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Appleton Adams Mason III of Albany, was married there yesterday to Terrence Michael Burgess, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Burgess of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Charles W. Sheerin performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church. The Rev. David V. Berberian, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: With Young Rhythm in His Bones, A Drummers' Drummer Turns 80
description: Sam Ulano hates wooden drumsticks. They are too light, he says, too easy on the arms. He always plays with metal ones. Except there he was at his 80th birthday party at the Red Blazer Hideaway on West 37th Street last month, rapping away on ''South Rampart Street Parade'' with a pair of wooden sticks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMANT, DAVID W.
description: BERMANT-David W. On this day we honor and celebrate your life, and the passion with which you loved life. You live on in all of us. We miss and love you very much. Contributions may be made to the Dream Foundation, 621 Chapala St., Ste D, Santa Barbara, CA 93101 Annie, Jeff, Wendy and Andy

title: This Royal Ballet, The Other One, Likes Being No. 2
description: HIS confidence is no trick. Few choreographers today have the same fiery belief in the power and the possibilities of ballet to function as a grown-up form of entertainment. At 43, David Bintley has already created eight full-evening story ballets. The ninth is in rehearsal, and he is plotting his tenth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROWBRIDGE, LEE CLAIRE DORAN
description: TROWBRIDGE-Lee Claire Doran. Of Bedford, NY. Died at home on September 13, 2000. She attended Briarcliff Junior College and a graduate of Tufts University. She has lived in Bedford, NY, since 1979 and previously before that in Bronxville, NY; Los Angeles, CA; Chicago, IL; Cambridge, MA; and Wellesley Hills, MA. She is survived by her loving husband Calvin Durand Trowbridge, Jr., and her children Calvin Durand Trowbridge III, Lee Crane Trowbridge Gwyn, David Kenyon Webster Trowbridge and Nina Ripley Trowbridge. She is also survived by her grandchildren Alexandra Hayley Trowbridge and Catherine Durand Trowbridge. She is also survived by her loving parents Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Clements Doran and five siblings. Lee will be remembered for her love of her husband, children, grandchildren and friends, her sense of humor, her love of tennis and broad interest. Memorial service at St. John's Parish in South Salem, NY, 11 AM, Tuesday, September 19. Reception at Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, Bedford, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Dr. Jackie Bromberg Research Fund, Breast Cancer Clinic, 64th Street, General Post Office, PO Box 26352, NY, NY 10087-6352 or St. John's Parish, The Lee Claire Doran Trowbridge Memorial Fund, PO Box 394, South Salem, NY 10590 or Veteran's of Foreign Wars, Post 2285, 433 White Plains Rd., Eastchester, NY 10709.

title: Looking for a Place So Mom Can Be Closer
description: LAST weekend I spent about $700, flew six hours, spent three additional hours in airports waiting for late planes and slept on a fold-out sofa, all so I could go grocery shopping for my mother, buy her a stack of novels and take her out to dinner.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about cultural programs in New York City public housing misspelled the name of the park in the Bronx near which several workers' housing projects were built. It is Van Cortlandt Park, not Van Cortland. The article also misstated the date of the premiere of the opera ''The Mill Girl'' at the Amalgamated Houses. It was Aug. 11, not later this fall.

title: Turned Collar
description: PAGAN BABIES

title: A Subversive in Verse
description: COLLECTED POEMS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINER, SYLVIA
description: FINER-Sylvia. On September 15. Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Beloved mother of Myra (Ed) and Ellen (Robert). Adored grandmother of Robert, Kenneth, Scott and Eric. Cherished grandmother of Dale, Andrew and A.J. Loving sister of Irving Goldstein. Dear sister-in-law of Estelle Goldstein. Services today, 1:30 PM, at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Making the Best Choice For Beloved Old Trees
description: THESE great old trees really define the character of the landscape, so we do everything we can to preserve them,'' Todd Forrest, the curator of trees and shrubs at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, said the other day.

title: Caitlin Simon, Gregory Huber
description: Caitlin Jill Simon, a daughter of Susan R. Simon and L. Linfield Simon of Stockbridge, Mass., was married there yesterday at Wheatleigh, a hotel owned by her parents, to Gregory Alain Huber, a son of Jean B. Huber and Peter J. Huber of Rockford, Ill. Judith Patti, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: In Pursuit of Canine Perfection
description: THE big white poodle with the pow der puffs on her hips called rosettes in the trimming trade -- was sniffing around the Eukanuba booth, trying to get a fix on whether she liked beef or chicken best.

title: Goddess Theory
description: The Myth of Matriarchal Prehistory

title: Music Enhances Art's Appeal
description: ART and music are finding their way to one another in museums. Many of the state's museums are discovering that the people who walk through their doors are more sophisticated than ever and exhibition-driven musical events sell out repeatedly, indicating a hunger for knowledge and a challenged intellect.

title: Anne Carman, E. J. May
description: Anne Colby Carman, a daughter of Linda Wemyss Carman of Williamstown, Mass., and Edward Caton Carman Jr. of Boston, was married yesterday to Edward John May, a son of Annette and James Francis May of Jamesburg, N.J. The Rev. Peter T. Elvin performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown.

title: To Swim With the Sharks, Have a Big Tank
description: It was so big that they used a crane to hoist it up from the street, hauling it over the 11-story building, down into a central courtyard, and through a window. They went through all the trouble, not to mention the $150,000 expense, because the boss thought it was essential to the company's image.

title: Children's Books
description: Brother Sun, Sister Moon The Life and Stories of St. Francis. By Margaret Mayo. Illustrated by Peter Malone. Little, Brown, $16.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: The Nation; Searching Only in Profiles Can Hide a Spy's Face
description: WHEN investigators were trying to find out who might have given sensitive weapons secrets to China, they paid special attention to Wen Ho Lee in part because of his Chinese ancestry. But last week, when the Taiwanese-born American scientist pleaded guilty only to downloading sensitive information onto an insecure computer and prosecutors conceded they had no further case to make against him in open court, the quick association of Mr. Lee's ethnic origins with suspicions about his loyalty seemed mostly an embarrassment for the government.

title: MEGAN'S LAW UPHELD
description: The constitutionality of Megan's Law, the first nationally known sexual predator notification law in the country, was upheld by a federal appeals court judge last week. Notifying neighbors who promise not to divulge the information and school and community organizations of the whereabouts of a sex offender does not violate the offender's right to privacy, said Judge Maryanne Trump Barry of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals. Karen DeMasters

title: My First Year in New York; 1936
description: I remember very clearly coming through the Holland Tunnel that first time. It had been an overnight journey in a 1936 Chevy all the way from Cleveland, where I'd just finished an engagement. I was 12 years old and consumed with excitement about seeing New York, where, it had been pointed out, I would be a grand success and become a child star.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about the choice of Russell Crowe to play the leading role in a film about John Forbes Nash Jr., the 1994 Nobel laureate in economic science, misstated the surname of the screenplay writer. He is Akiva Goldsman, not Goldman.

title: Freshwater Aquarium Opens on Lake Superior
description: The Great Lakes Aquarium, which says it is the first aquarium in the United States with all freshwater tanks, recently opened on the shore of Lake Superior in Duluth, Minn. It examines the geology and plant and animal life of the lake, as well as the effects climate and humans have had on it. The aquarium contains 70 species of fish along with otters, frogs and turtles.

title: Alisha Berger, Christoph Gorder
description: Alisha Lauren Berger, the daughter of Julie and Richard Berger of Trumbull, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Christoph Lyle Gorder, the son of Gordeen Gorder and the Rev. John Gorder of Chicago. Rabbi Larry Milder will officiate at the Oceanside Meadows Inn in Prospect Harbor, Me.

title: Geraldine Hugo, Edward Mohr
description: Geraldine Patricia Hugo, a documentary film writer and producer, and Edward Lloyd Mohr, an investment banker, were married yesterday by the Rev. Boniface Ramsey, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, JAMES BARR
description: AMES-James Barr. Of Lincoln, Massachusetts. On September 8, 2000 at age 89. Distinguished lawyer with the Boston firm of Ropes & Gray, president of the Boston Atheneaum, treasurer of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, and president of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Survived by his wife Suzannah Ayer Ames; his sister Phyllis Cox of South Brooksville, Maine; his sons Richard and Charles Ames, both of Brookline, Massachusetts; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Memorial Church in Cambridge on Friday, October 13, at 3:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Ames-Wollan Scholarship Fund at Harvard College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LOUIS M.
description: JACOBS-Louis M. 99 years old. Former Chief Clerk of New York City Medical Examiners Office. Veteran of WWII and 2nd Lt. in U.S. Medical Corp. Services were held on Friday.

title: Tools and Techniques for Tree Pruning
description: IT is essential to prune the shade trees around your house at least once a year. Sometimes the reasons for pruning are obvious. A severe storm can break limbs and leave them dangling from the trunk. Trees near the house with long limbs that hang over the roof offer a path into your home for squirrels and raccoons. Also, leaves falling from these limbs can collect in the gutters and clog the downspouts. Even if these conditions do not exist, careful pruning of diseased or dead limbs can produce healthier, fuller shade trees.

title: Sept. 10-16; Buying Power
description: In a deal that ends the independence of one of the proudest firms on Wall Street, the Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed to buy J. P. Morgan & Company for $30.9 billion in stock. Chase hopes the deal, the fourth huge financial merger recently, will enhance its global standing as a provider of financing to major corporations. It should have little effect on consumers, a shrinking share of Chase's business. Chase is keeping Morgan's renowned brand -- derived from founder John Pierpont Morgan -- and renaming itself J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. Patrick McGeehan

title: Much More Expensive Than a Gold Watch
description: When employees quit or retire, their companies may lose more than valued workers. In some instances, the turnover can mean sharp declines in profits and market value, according to Sibson & Company, a management consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, PATRICIA STRASSBURGER
description: SIMON-Patricia Strassburger. 71, died September 14 peacefully at home in Montgomery, AL; formerly of White Plains, NY. She leaves behind her husband Ed; daughter Linda Cohen & son-inlaw Henry Cohen of Montgomery; daughter Patty Benator and sonin-law Gene Benator of Atlanta, GA; brother Julien Strassburger and sister-in-law Joyce Strassburger of Montgomery; brother-inlaw and sister-in-law Carol and Ted Diamond of Westport, CT; & 5 grandchildren, Andrew, Daniel, Adam, Brian & Jaime. Funeral services will be private. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Montgomery, 1111 Holloway Park, Montgomery, AL 36117.

title: The Nation; Deep Pockets: How Corzine Spent $35 Million on a Primary
description: IN TV commercials, Jon S. Corzine, the Wall Street multimillionaire and Democratic nominee for United States Senate, is reassuring New Jersey voters who might be concerned about the costs of his progressive social programs that he has the ''fiscal discipline of a successful businessman.''

title: A Heralded Quarterback Gets to Start
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Sept. 16  One of the state's most heralded high school quarterbacks in decades, Tyler Watts was anointed an instant starter by Alabama fans hungry for a premier passer.

title: $240,000 for 3 Bedrooms: How 'Affordable' Is That?
description: AFFORDABLE is a relative concept, especially when it comes to housing in Westchester. Even modest family homes here can carry price tags that would guarantee luxury real estate in other parts of the country.

title: Pack Rats Get No Respect These Days
description: IT'S not often you'll hear someone compare herself to a maggot and mean it as a boast. But that's just how Carol Royal describes the role she and two associates are trying to fill with the Trenton Materials Exchange, a shoestring operation that seeks to keep us from drowning in our own abundance.

title: For Public Library, New Building Within the Old One
description: IN the 89 years since the New York Public Library opened at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, not a single permanent structure has been added to it. But that is changing. For almost a year, a four-story building made mostly of glass has been under construction on the library site, and it is scheduled to open next fall.

title: Sept. 10-16; Fighting the Fire Next Time
description: Drawing fresh lessons, as well as big bills, from this year's wildfires, President Clinton asked Congress for $1.6 billion in new spending next year to repay firefighting costs and to ease future fire dangers. The proposal, for a 130 percent budget increase, would help pay for aggressive new efforts to thin forests near urban areas that face severe fire risks. Republicans had said that the White House's aversion to logging had contributed to this year's fires. Douglas Jehl

title: Corrections
description: The Dining Out column last Sunday, about the Coromandel restaurant in Darien, misstated the price range for entrees. They run from $10.95 to $21.95, not $19.50 to $31.50.

title: Liberties; Her Brute Strength
description: After the Buffalo debate Wednesday night, a woman in the audience came up to Tim Russert, the moderator. She said she had liked Rick Lazio until he stalked Hillary Clinton, pestering her to sign his soft-money pledge.

title: Speak,Memory
description: Name: Samantha FishkinAge: 22Coming from: ConnecticutLooking for: Recovery

title: Madonna Encounters Virtual Earth
description: THE notion of an objective, natural reality, separate from human intervention, was damaged beyond repair in the 20th century. It was besieged on all sides by art, philosophy and technology: by Cubism and post-modernism, by film and sound recording, by television and synthesizers, by video games and plastic surgery, by all the gizmos of the computer era. Any separation between natural and artificial has grown fuzzy and, in practice, irrelevant. Now, everyone lives on the cusp of the physical and the virtual.

title: Proposed Raise for Librarians Dropped After City Objects
description: The city's largest union of librarians is angry that the New York Public Library has withdrawn a proposal that would have raised their salaries by 15 percent and greatly narrowed the pay gap with the suburbs.

title: Life Is Beautiful ... When You're Beautiful
description: Name: Daisy O'Dell BarkowAge: 21Coming From: Canada, by way of LondonLooking for: Thrills

title: Unions Turn To Celebrities For Support
description: For actors, there is nothing worse than feeling invisible, and with two unions representing 135,000 actors locked in a little-noticed strike against the advertising industry for the past 20 weeks, the actors moved decisively last week to make their struggle more visible.

title: With Stanley Steamers, It's All in the Details
description: BETWEEN 1897 and 1927, nearly 11,000 Stanley Steamers were built and sold in the United States and overseas. And, some estimate there are between 400 to 600 still running after extensive restoration and repair.

title: In a Detective Tale Involving a Town's Birth, the Clue Was Framed
description: On Dec. 14, 1667, the first Europeans to settle in what is today Atlantic Highlands decided to lay out 10 lots in an area they called Portland Poynt on the Navesink peninsula. They wrote their decision on a deed: ''The Lotts on Portland Poynt being unto No. 10 are layed out and are in breadth twenty pls [poles] each Lott, and run up from the banck into the woods upon A strait line W. & N. with corner as the land is good, about 60 to 70 poles.'' The deed also stated there was a swamp nearby. But where had these lots been? Paul Boyd, a Ph.D. candidate in cultural geography at Rutgers University who is the historian of the Atlantic Highlands Historical Society and chairman of the Atlantic Highlands Environmental Commission, worked on the problem for five years. He recently spoke about a breakthrough featuring an old painting.

title: Craig Wipes Away Tears and Fights
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17  Dreams, even Olympic ones, come with a price.

title: Be More Clear On What's in Soup Cans
description: To the Editor:

title: After Qualifying, U.S. Gymnasts Are in Disarray
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17  Perched in a row far removed from the porcelain- like figures across the arena, a grim-faced Bela Karolyi could only fidget with his gunslinger's mustache.

title: $400 Million Man a Socialist? Don't Tell That to a Socialist
description: Running for office as a Socialist is the ultimate exercise in egalitarianism, so Greg Pason, the Socialist Party USA's candidate for U. S. Senate seat from New Jersey, has no complaints about shuttling around the campaign trail aboard New Jersey Transit trains.

title: Things Turn Against U.S. in World Cup Rematch
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 17  A year ago, Kristine Lilly saved the World Cup for the United States with her head and then helped to win it with her feet. But soccer is a mercurial game. Victory can seem like a yo-yo trick, presenting itself only to be yanked away.

title: All Together Now
description: ORIGINALLY my girlfriend, my mother and I were going to Spain for a week, a combination whose wisdom had been called into question by some skeptical parties. (''Your girlfriend and your mother?'') Then it turned out that my girlfriend's best friend and her husband were going the same week, with their 1-year-old daughter. Why not all go together?

title: Priests Haven't Forgotten the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding to Ruths Record
description: Rickey Henderson is not quite as close to Babe Ruth's walk record as some people think. While many sources list Babe Ruth's career walk total at 2,056, the commissioner's office added six walks for Ruth last year after some research. Henderson entered last night eight walks shy of tying Ruth's record.

title: Sept. 10-16; Gay Rights, Here and There
description: Vermont -- the current ground zero for this nation's gay-rights struggle -- remains divided over its new civil-unions law, as a number of the bill's backers were ousted in primaries. And that mixed message was echoed across the Atlantic. The Dutch decided to allow gay marriages and other rights surpassing those in any other country. But hundreds of gay Americans on a cruise were barred by Turkish police from tourist spots on the Aegean, prompting diplomatic outcries. (They were later welcomed in Istanbul.) And an official on the Greek island of Lesbos, of all places, tried to turn away a group of British lesbians, saying that his town was not the ''paradise of gay love'' promised by the tour operator. Hubert B. Herring

title: INVESTING WITH: Jerome J. Heppelmann; PBHG Mid-Cap Value Fund
description: VALUE stocks have been struggling back after nearly two years in the dumps, and Jerome J. Heppelmann, manager of the $116.6 million PBHG Mid-Cap Value fund, thinks he knows why. ''Deep value hasn't worked because there haven't been any positive catalysts to get investors interested in the cheapest of the cheap names,'' Mr. Heppelmann said. ''I look for companies with good near-term business dynamics, like rising earnings, new products or stock buybacks. That gives the buyer good news, which hopefully will attract other buyers.''

title: Potsdam, Refuge of Prussian Kings
description: SOLDIER-KINGS of Brandenburg-Prussia and emperors of modern Germany for fewer than 50 years, the Hohenzollerns have gone down in history as war makers who came late to the top table of Europe, and were forever trying to catch up. This is a bit unfair. Sometimes they longed to escape from all that straining and campaigning: they were passionate art collectors and, perhaps less well known, creators of spectacular gardens and parks. Around the royal garrison city of Potsdam they devised a huge private arcadia that remains exceptionally harmonious and casts a deep, romantic spell.

title: Limiting Cell Phones On the L.I.R.R.
description: Re the Sept. 10 article ''Cell Phone Abuse Is Riding the Rails:''

title: Political Briefing; Going to the Mat In Minnesota Politics
description: Is this something straight from flex-your-pecs Wrestlemania, or what?

title: Faces in Photographs; A Region Vividly Portrayed
description: VIEWERS might have to continually reassure themselves that the show at the Yale University Art Gallery is ''The Persistence of Photography in American Portraiture,'' not ''The Persistence of Portraiture in American Photography.'' The two possibilities, rather than cause confusion, however, underline the fluid, open-ended nature of the exhibition.

title: POSTINGS: Work Continues on Rail Route to JFK; First Test Nears for AirTrain
description: The train to the plane is about to leave the station.

title: Columbia Offense Rumbles In Opener
description: Columbia tailback Johnathan Reese rushed for 172 yards and 2 touchdowns and quarterback Jeff McCall threw for three scores and ran for another as the Lions defeated Fordham, 43-26, in their season opener last night at Wien Stadium. It was the most points for Columbia since a 44-0 victory over Fordham in 1972.

title: Caller No. 1
description: Ghostwritten

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Berlin; In a city of constant change, the latest trend is a bit of discretion
description: An aquarium seems almost de rigueur in Berlin bars these days, an indication perhaps that the high-energy, low-sophistication scene of the 1990's is giving way to the quieter comforts of a leather chair, a fine martini and a touch of fish gazing. Not that the adrenaline is gone from Berlin; it is merely being channeled in more refined directions. The all-night techno parties still burn, but an after-work scene of neophyte government and e-business types has also come to life in the new capital.

title: Ow!
description: Why We Hurt

title: The Nation; A Political Rarity: Seven Weeks of Maybe
description: AMERICANS this year are getting a chance to see something rare: a presidential dead heat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, IRWIN
description: COOPER-Irwin. Age 74, of Fair Lawn, NJ. On September 11, 2000. Practicing certified public accountant and partner at Kutell and Cooper in New York City for 42 years. A World War II navy veteran. Survived by his wife Joan, daughters Sherry and Iris, son William, brother Sidney and sister Vivian. Services are private. Family will be receiving through Sunday. Donations to the charity of your choice that benefit children.

title: BENEFITS
description: Tending a Garden

title: Pleasant Surprise: Anemones in the Fall
description: YOU don't see the fall-blooming Japanese anemones (Anemone Japonica) in every garden, but you do see them in a lot of interesting gardens. One such place is a little butterfly garden tucked beside an elementary school near my house. A local designer, who is noted for her lush layouts, sense of history and stellar plant selections designed the plot.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Claire Blaydon, Anthony Florence

Blaydon of Hanover, N.H., was married yesterday to Anthony Angelo Florence Jr., a son of Marilyn Hospodar of Wexford, Pa., and Mr. Florence of Pittsburgh. The Rev. William P. Gallagher performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Putting a Life Together 2 Years After Attack
description: His jaw is held in place by two steel plates. He is on medication for chronic back pain. But two years after he was severely beaten on a Queens street in what the authorities called a bias crime, Rishi Maharaj, now 22, does not like to complain. ''It could have been so much worse,'' he said in an interview on Friday. ''How can I complain about the little ailments?''

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Prague; If the caffeine doesn't keep you awake, the music will
description: A town swarming with tourists does its best to cater to their nighttime whims and to make some money besides. But it's still possible to find a few places to drink, sup, listen or dance where not everyone is foreign or wearing a baseball cap backward or tripping out on Ecstasy.

title: Nadia Nagib, Christian Wallace
description: Nadia Ahmed Nagib and Christian Downing Wallace were married yesterday in the garden of Fernbrook, an 18th-century estate, in Bordentown, N.J. Judge Anne E. Thompson, the chief judge of the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, officiated.

description: From Herzl to Rabin

description: Weeks

title: Bush Assails Gore, Calling Ideas 'Tired'
description: Gov. George W. Bush sharply attacked Vice President Al Gore's positions on tax cuts, Social Security, Medicare and education as triumphs of federal control over choice.

title: My First Year in New York; 1978
description: I'll never forget the first day I came to New York. I was actually wearing a straw hat. I had a room at the Roosevelt Hotel, and in the late afternoon I was in the bar drinking a Singapore sling. There was a huge bang and then sirens and a big commotion outside, and someone ran in and said that a helicopter had fallen off the Pan Am building across the street. I thought, ''Oh, these kinds of things always happen in New York -- helicopters fall off buildings.'' That was when I decided to run away from college and move here.

description: To the Editor:

title: Firestone's Crisis Is Other Dealers' Opportunity
description: DANIELLE ANDERSON'S quest to find replacement tires for the Firestones on her Ford Explorer was coming up short. Turned away by her Ford dealer, who had no tires to offer, she wound up at the end of a waiting list at her Firestone dealer. But he could not promise new tires before Christmas.

title: Island's Only Bank Window To Stay Open, for a While
description: Roosevelt Island has one pharmacy, one pizzeria, one video store, one deli, one of just about everything. This allows the 9,000 people who live or work on this sliver of land in the East River to do errands without taking the subway to Queens or the tram to Manhattan. So when Chase Manhattan announced in July that the one bank branch would close on Oct. 20, residents and merchants were upset.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Battle of Stonington

title: MEDICAID
description: More people with disabilities who enter the workplace will be able hold on to their Medicaid benefits, under a law signed by Governor Whitman last week. States and the federal government share the cost of Medicaid, and the New Jersey measure is permitted under a federal program that lets states grant continued benefits to people who work in wheelchairs, on Braille-encoded keyboards or with any recognized disability and earn up to 250 percent of the federal poverty level. Without the measure, disabled people whose incomes exceed the poverty level, which is $8,350 for an individual and $11,250 for couples, lose their Medicaid benefits. Steve Strunsky

title: To Avoid Disputes, Even the Judges Will Be Judged
description: As members of the Amateur International Boxing Association -- Olympic boxing's governing body -- arrived in Sydney early last week, they were greeted by a large cartoon published in the national newspaper, The Australian.

title: New Look for Harms Center
description: The marquee and the facade of the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood has a new look -- and the people who paid for it had their names up in lights for an afternoon.

title: Cubas Legna Verdecia Beats North Koreas Kye Sun Hui
description: SYDNEY, September 17 -- North Korea's Olympic judo champion Kye Sun Hui was supported emotionally but not successfully here today by a surprising cheerleading squad  a charter jet-load of South Koreans.

title: U.S. Tops South Korea; Holdsclaw Is Sidelined
description: Skittering across the floor, penetrating without regard for their bodies and kicking the basketball out for 22 3-pointers, the undersized players from South Korea entertained a near-sellout crowd on the opening night of the Olympic women's basketball tournament.

title: THREE MORE BICYCLE SUNDAYS
description: Bicyclists have three more Sundays this season to pedal or skate -- without the interference of motor traffic -- on the Bronx River Parkway. Besides today from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., the other dates are Sept. 24 and Oct. 1. Under New York State law, bicyclists and skaters under 14 must wear a helmet approved by the American National Standard Institute, and children who are under 1 are not allowed on bicycles or separate seats attached to bicycles. The Bronx River Parkway from the County Center south to Scarsdale Road is set aside for bikes; north from the County Center to Fisher Lane is for skating.

title: Bookend; All-Century Team
description: OF the making of lists there is no end. Now that it is possible to speak of the 20th century as a whole, it seems irresistible to compile and swap lists of our favorite poems (or novels or plays or movies) of the last 100 years. Which works are indispensable? Which stand the best chance of enduring? Which do we simply like the best? Which have come to mean the most to us? To assemble a list of great 20th-century poems would, if it did nothing else, direct attention to important works. It might also stimulate discussion, even controversy. And as I conceived it, the project would record the taste of some of our leading poets surveying the monuments of what Henry Luce called the American Century.

title: Georgia Could Be Big Test for Bush
description: Georgia has not spent much time this year on anyone's list of hotly competitive states, but its unusual demographics could make it an important testing ground for Mr. Bush's ability to hold on to his base. Though Mr. Bush is still ahead here, his lead is narrow, and political professionals say there is no better place to gauge his national strength in the weeks ahead.

title: Swiss to Vote On Plan to Set Limit on Influx Of Immigrants
description: Bannered across the photograph of angry young men, heads shaved and arms extended in Nazi salutes, is the appeal, ''Xenophobia isn't Swiss.'' In smaller print, the newspaper advertisement urges voters to reject a quota on foreigners in Switzerland.

title: After Government Attack, Philippine Rebels Suggest New Talks
description: JOLO, the Philippines, Sept. 17  Pitched battles between government troops and Muslim rebels holding 19 hostages in the southern Philippines resumed at dawn today with ferocious mortar shelling of guerrilla positions, residents said.

title: Bush, in a Broad Attack on Gore, Paints Him as the Candidate of Big Government
description: Gov. George W. Bush sharply attacked Vice President Al Gore's positions on tax cuts, Social Security, Medicare and education today, casting them as triumphs of federal control over individual choice.

title: Rapist Sought in Two Attacks in Brooklyn
description: Detectives in Brooklyn are seeking the public's help in catching a man who they said sexually assaulted two teenagers in Flatbush on consecutive Sundays, attacking the young women at gunpoint in elevators.

title: Word for Word/Newsboy Nostalgia; Flash! Street Urchins Hawk Tabs on City Streets!
description: ''EXTRA! Extra! Read all about it!'' Remember that cry from those old movies in which scrappy urban newsboys held up papers with screaming headlines?

title: Paper, Dolled Up
description: As the spring 2001 fashion shows approached, eye-catching invitations once again went out. This season, however, designers are scaling back from the more elaborate attention grabbers of yore -- crates of grass, candy necklaces, CD-ROM short movies -- and going the old-fashioned paper route. Granted, paper that's more dressed up than just plain engraved cards. Saks Fifth Avenue is inviting guests to its Fashion Targets Breast Cancer event with a three-dimensional paper doll that stands upright, arms akimbo, with the information printed in swirls on her circle skirt. Also in the paper doll theme, the notice for Walter van Beirendonck's summer 2001 show features a Keith Haringesque cardboard punch-out figure with the words ''Starship Earth'' printed on it. Sara Kozlowski of Cake sent her invitations with a scented Chinese paper fan; the show's where-and-when is printed inside the lid of its box. And Kenneth Cole, with his signature advocacy, issued voter registration cards and pencils with his invitations, packaged in a clear plastic bag printed in large block letters: ''Be Seen. Be Heard.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Syracuse Endures Another Close Loss
description: Syracuse fans are ripping into Coach Paul Pasqualoni's Orangemen again. Things were bad enough after a 24-21 overtime loss to Rutgers last season, but last week's 12-10 loss to Cincinnati is bringing out the toughest of Orange critics.

title: The City of Romance? Yeah, Right!
description: Name: Lisa FragnerAge: 30Coming from: Los AngelesLooking for: Love

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, GEORGE E.

Grandfather to Claire Shubik, Daniel, Alex and David Stadler. Great-grandfather to Henry and Lily Stadler. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, September 19, 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Long Island Caddie Scholarship Fund c/o John Buckley, 15 Homestead Drive, Wheatley Heights, NY 11798 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Tennessee Ends Some Abortion Curbs
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 16 (AP)  The Tennessee Supreme Court has struck down parts of the state's abortion law as overly burdensome to women, including a two-day waiting period and mandatory counseling.

title: Altman's Dallas Foxes
description: In Robert Altman's new movie, ''Dr. T and the Women,'' which opens Oct. 6, Richard Gere plays Dr. T, a Dallas gynecologist whose women (family and patients) are so merrily overdressed that one patient lies on the examining table for a Pap test still in her pheasant-feather hat. The look in the film seems like a timely sendup of the ladylike styles that are the rage this fall. The women, played by Laura Dern, Janine Turner and Tara Reid, among others, wear suits -- but in red stamped leather and leopard print or edged in zebra. They wrap their necks with cascades of fox tails and blow-in-the-wind curly lamb boas, and their heads in saucer-shaped hats trimmed with iridescent coq feathers. They carry gloves.

title: Coach's Two Selections Come Through for the U.S.
description: In the unsettling early stages of the competition, America's tattooed star Blaine Wilson had morphed into an invisible-ink creation while a disastrous floor exercise by the team had left its spirits frayed.

title: Amy Metsch, Paul Schnee
description: Amy Helen Metsch, the daughter of Penny Metsch and Dr. Jonathan Metsch of Hoboken, N.J., is to be married today to Paul Schnee, a son of Doris and Carl Schnee of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson will officiate at the TriBeCa Rooftop in New York.

title: Following Up: Woman Hurt in Parade Will Finally Go to Court
description: In November it will be three years since Kathleen Caronna, an investment analyst, was injured when a six-story-tall balloon was swept out of control by strong winds at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Her lawyer says Mrs. Caronna has yet to recover from her injuries, and the lawsuit filed on her behalf is finally scheduled for trial, on Nov. 8.

Kelser. She is survived by a daughter Sylvia and son-in-law Laurence Eisenlohr of Phila.;three grandchildren, nine great grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be sent to Wellesley College 106 Central St., Wellesley, Ma. 02181.

title: Nice View, but Watch Where You Step
description: As the warm breath of summer gives way to crisp autumn breezes, people who love the outdoors put on their hiking boots and head for the hills. But this fall, a favorite mountain in the New York region, Storm King -- prized for rugged terrain and panoramic views of the Hudson River -- will be off limits.

title: Children's Books; So Watch Your Step
description: Is there a grown-up alive who has not scraped off a redolent shoe and cursed the darkness -- the light, too -- after walking blindly where dogs have walked before? Well, it's your own fault, and you should be ashamed of yourself. It seems that since time began, small furry creatures called Gigglers have been keeping their baby-sized eyes on children, following them everywhere to make sure that adults treat them fairly. And if the big people don't, they get the Treatment, courtesy of the Gigglers.

title: Freeing Men From the Fear Of Touching
description: AS Charles Wright sees it, one of the greatest disparities between men and women has to do with touch. ''Women have the freedom to touch in public, and men don't,'' Mr. Wright, the artistic director of the downtown school Dance Space Center, says. ''Words like brotherhood are a little corny, but men do need a forum to be able express whatever they want.''

title: Jean Cacciabaudo, William Maiorino Jr.
description: Dr. Jean Marie Cacciabaudo, a cardiologist, was married yesterday to Dr. William Maiorino Jr., an anesthesiologist. The Rev. Martin Klein officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Babylon, N.Y.

title: On a New Map, the Income Gap Grows
description: DESPITE all the talk about prosperity in this digital age, tax return data indicates that the rising tide of bits and bytes is lifting the yachts much more than the rowboats.

description: Milan Levar always knew he might be killed and gave a trusted friend a letter naming the 4 men he thought were most likely to order his assassination and 10 more who would carry it out.

title: First, Take a Piece of Paper
description: IT is always interesting to see the results when several artists are given a project in common. Their efforts begin with some similarities, and then their imaginations and proclivities go to work. At the Hammond Museum here, ''Unfolding Visions'' displays the results of giving artists ''fan paper'' to work on. The paper was then made into the 10-ribbed fans used primarily in Japanese dance.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Aug. 27, about the Brandywine Valley, referred imprecisely to the site of the Battle of Brandywine, in 1777. Washington had his headquarters in what is now Brandywine Battlefield Park, and troop movements indeed took place there. But the fighting itself went on in other sections of the 10-square-mile National Historic Landmark that includes the park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SALLY
description: STERN-Sally. In loving memory of Sally Stern, beloved wife, mother, daughter, mother-in-law and cherished grandmother, deeply loved friend of many, and a gifted teacher and giver to all. Remembered by Burt, Frances, Steven, Susan, Elise, Sam, Danielle and Rachel. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, at 1 PM, at Gutterman's of Woodbury, LI.

title: Shoe Maven
description: Cleavage has always been hot, but the starlets at the Emmys and the MTV Awards showed that necklines have plunged to new levels of low. While they can get away with baring all, women who travel in more buttoned-up circles, like Tamara Mellon, the managing director of Jimmy Choo shoes, have to tone down the racy, rock 'n' roll look. At a recent company dinner in Southampton, N.Y., the guest list included the techno rocker Moby as well as members of the social establishment, like Anne Hearst. Ms. Mellon's turquoise outfit by Celine, which is covered in Swarovski crystals, has a neckline to the waist and a skirt with a keyhole just below the navel. ''It fits on the right side of sex if your arms and back are covered,'' explained Ms. Mellon, who lives in London, where Jimmy Choo's headquarters are. ''I would definitely not wear a low V-front with spaghetti straps or a low back or short skirt. It would be too trampy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBREICH, FLORENCE
description: HALBREICH-Florence. Passed away peacefully at home on September 15. Devoted wife of Otto Halbreich who predeceased her in 1980. Loving and doting mother of Irwin ''Sonny'' Halbreich of NYC and Mildred Katleman of Beverly Hills, CA. Proud grandmother of Sanford Herzfeld, Patricia Herzfeld Van Der Leun, Kathy Halbreich Kohring and John Halbreich and great-grandmother to Meredith, Joanna and Jason Herzfeld, Justine Van Der Leun, Henry Kohring and Gillian and Hannah Halbreich. She is also survived by her sisters Ann Finley, Rose Shedlin, Helen Kobel and brother Harold Sheldon, and her devoted companion of nine years, Ning Agustin. In April of this year, this quiet, gracious lady celebrated her 100th birthday surrounded by family and friends at her home at Central Park West, New York City. We will always have loving memories of you. Memorial services will be held Sunday, September 17, at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Israel Ponders Constitution With Head Throbbing
description: For 52 years, Israel has avoided drafting a constitution for fear of provoking a civil war between secular and religious Jews. But when Prime Minister Ehud Barak returned empty-handed from his latest frustrations with the peace effort, he switched to an agenda of civic reform and proposed a constitution, just like that.

title: Rocking Roots, but Don't Call It Retro
description: THE singer-songwriter Deke Dickerson does not like to be categorized, which is too bad, considering that musical labels suit him well. As a roots rocker, he has become used to having his music called country, alternative country, rockabilly, hillbilly, blues, Western swing and rock 'n' roll. The fact is, his style does incorporate all those musical genres, and does so in an entertaining mix that translates very well to live performance.

title: Two Struggling Gators Team Up to Shock Vols
description: They were an unlikely pair to bail out Florida: a quarterback who had perhaps lost his nerve and a wide receiver who indeed had lost his scholarship. But that was what Jesse Palmer and Jabar Gaffney did in the final 2 minutes 14 seconds here today against Tennessee in what is annually the most important game on the Southeastern Conference schedule.

title: One Last Chance Not to Go Down With the Ship
description: TWO years ago, Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi said he was ecstatic when he welcomed the Regina Maris to Glen Cove. The three-masted barkentine would be a symbol of Glen Cove's ambitious waterfront revitalization, he said, and it would be restored to its former splendor.

title: Anarchists Summon Joe Hill's Spirit in Loss of a Bookstore
description: For six years, readers from across the city went to Blackout Books at 50 Avenue B in search of volumes like ''Bakunin on Anarchism'' and zines like ''Black Flag'' and ''Slingshot.'' The small, cluttered store, on the ground floor of a walkup between East Third and East Fourth Streets, was also a place where neighbors gathered to post and read fliers or talk over local issues.

title: When It's All About Money
description: TALK about market watchers. She is at the New York Stock exchange by 7 a.m. every weekday for ''Squawk Box,'' her early report. By 10 a.m., she has already broadcast 15 updates for CNBC as well as affiliates in the United States and Asia. At 2 p.m., she becomes the anchor of ''Street Signs'' from the CNBC Fort Lee, N.J., studio; at 4 p.m., ''Market Wrap.'' And on Fridays, she heads back to the exchange for a look ahead on ''Market Week,'' her newest show (which returns to its 7:30 p.m. slot after CNBC's Olympic coverage had ended).

title: Diary: Score 1 for the Law in Accounting Rule Fight

description: TIGER WOODS is not just the world's best golfer; he's also the world's best conglomerate.

title: Flat Amsterdam Is a Biker's Nirvana
description: AS Dutch as tulips and considerably more fun, bicycles -- or fietsen, as they're called in Amsterdam -- are ideally suited to the brick-paved canal streets of the old central city and to the flat landscape surrounding the urban area. They're everywhere: chained to bridges, parked by the hundreds outside Centraal Station, rolling steadily by (often with one or two small passengers aboard) as you sit in outdoor cafes. Because municipal policy actively promotes bicycle commuting, lanes and paths reserved for their use abound.

title: As Hot Economy Pushes Up Overtime, Fatigue Becomes a Labor Issue
description: In his last two and a half days of life, Brent Churchill slept a total of five hours. The rest of the time he was working.

title: Fare Wars in Australia's Skies
description: THE recent arrival of two new Australian carriers, Impulse Airlines and Virgin Blue, ending the longtime duopoly of Ansett and Qantas, has dramatically cut domestic air fares in the country. On a one-way flight between Sydney and Melbourne, the regular economy fare is $184, at 1.74 Australian dollars to the United States dollar; in recent weeks, seats on that route have been selling for as little as $38.

title: A Prescription For Health Care

title: Stocks Behaving Badly
description: Yet another unlikely publication has jumped on the stock-picking bandwagon -- Maxim, Dennis Publishing's hot-selling journal of beer and babes.

title: Sutton River Is a Delight for Trout Fisherman
description: ATTAWAPISKAT, Ontario - Xavier Chookomoolin is a 40-year- old Cree Indian who is trying to return to "the old ways" of his people. On the diminutive, but uniquely crystalline Sutton River, set in an unbelievably verdant valley in the isolated northwest corner of Ontario, he, his wife, two sons and an extended family live in a cluster of small buildings at the outlet of Hawley Lake.

title: 'Surf and Turf' Gets a New Definition
description: THE Waterzooi Belgian Bistro in Garden City was an almost instant hit with diners, and now its lower-priced next-door neighbor, the Victory Oyster Bar and Smoke House, which has the same owners, is headed for the winner's circle as well. This cavernous, vaguely retro spot at 860 Franklin Avenue (516-739-7660) has two unlikely culinary partners: icy cold fresh oysters, clams, crab, shrimp and lobsters, staples of traditional New York and New England raw bars, are paired with the smoky, spicy barbecue dishes of the South and Southwest.

title: Elizabeth Gordon, 94, Dies; Was House Beautiful Editor
description: Elizabeth Gordon, the influential editor of House Beautiful magazine for more than 20 years, a missionary of taste to the American homemaker and an indefatigable supporter of Frank Lloyd Wright, died on Sept. 3 in Adamstown, Md., where she lived. She was 94.

title: U.S. Women Ponder Medal Sweep in Tennis
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16  Less than a week after winning her second Grand Slam title at the United States Open, Venus Williams was not only on top of the world, but also on the other side of the world. Williams and her teammates on the United States Olympic tennis squad arrived here Friday, just in time to drop off their luggage and march in the opening ceremony at Stadium Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, DEAN WILLIAM C.
description: WARREN-Dean William C. The Officers and Directors of Barnwell Industries, Inc. are deeply saddened and mourn the death of our Director and friend who served for many years on the Board. His brilliant legal mind and keen business sense contributed greatly to the success of the company. In addition to his role in the operation of the company, he was always available with advice and help to those of us who had a personal relationship with him for many, many years. All of us wish to extend our sympathy and condolences to his family. Morton H. Kinzler, Chairman

title: Lilly Farahnakian, James Copland IV

title: My First Year in New York; 1994
description: I was afraid to leave New York City for at least a year after moving here. I didn't even like to sleep, I was so madly in love with the place. I barely knew anyone and at first would do nothing but walk, miles up and down and across the city, obeying the commands to walk and not walk, letting the lights direct the route.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Madrid; With so many spots to choose, there's one that really stomps
description: At night, Madrid overflows with life, as the city's residents take to the avenues and winding cobblestone streets, eager to enjoy good food and wine, lively conversation, music and dance. After the lights come on along grand, tree-lined Paseo de la Castellana and flicker in the baroque Plaza de Cibeles fountain, crowds fill the outdoor restaurants and tapas bars in the spacious 17th-century Plaza Mayor and the smaller Plaza Santa Ana.

title: Child's Love of Ships Becomes Man's Passion for Marine Artwork
description: At one time, the Hoboken waterfront was filled with ships and the Hudson River was a busy highway. Antonio Jacobsen, a Danish artist who lived most of his life in Hoboken, loved to paint the ships. John McMullen, a youth whose father owned a ship repair shop in Hoboken, loved to look at them.

title: Head-Spinning Evil Gets a New Twist
description: WHEN William Friedkin's ''Exorcist,'' based on William Peter Blatty's best-selling theological-horror novel, opened on Dec. 26, 1973, it was not only the movie event of the Christmas season that year; it also became the dominant pop-culture phenomenon of the final days of Richard M. Nixon's presidency. One wouldn't want to make too much of this: to suggest, for example, that Mr. Blatty's tale of the expulsion of a possessing demon from the body of a 12-year-old girl in any way enhanced the national will to eject rascals from the White House would be stretching a point. You could do that. But it would be wrong.

title: The Other Australia
description: It was a splendidly diverse and inclusive face Australia presented to the world in the Olympics' opening pageant, particularly by having the Aboriginal sprinter Cathy Freeman carry the torch on the final leg of its journey. As if seeking a mirage, Freeman walked through a pond toward an idyllic waterfall to light the Games' caldron. This progression of the Olympic flame could well serve as a metaphor for the quest of Aborigines to achieve social justice and historical reconciliation in today's Australia. Unfortunately, in this quest the idyllic waterfall-like destination remains somewhat of a mirage.

title: A Canadian Hits His Best Stride When It Matters the Most

By the end of the second stage, the bike leg, he was still more than a minute from contention. But in the 77-degree temperatures of the 10-kilometer run, he had coolly and methodically charged within sight of the lead.

title: Racing Nuts Never Fall Far From Tree

He revved the motor, and as the lights on the ''Christmas tree'' flicked from red to yellow to green, he floored the accelerator. His 12 1/2-foot, 225-pound Junior Dragster flew down the track, hitting 65 miles an hour in 9.8 seconds.

description: AMONG the most oil-dependent regions in the country, Long Island is bracing for a potentially bruising fall and winter that could chill the still-surging regional economy and empty consumers' pockets as oil prices rise.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17  Matt Lindland prefers to look ahead at his competition in the Olympic greco-roman wrestling tournament, and not behind at the summerlong saga that determined his eligibility for the United States team.

title: PULSE; Beads Of Comfort
description: First, macaroni and cheese and meatloaf went chic. Now, the latest 50's-era, so-wrong-it's-right comfort food to hit the scene: tapioca pudding. No longer found only on hospital menus, the famously bland pudding is turning up at dining hot spots. Village, a new brasserie on West Ninth Street, serves a tapioca that resembles large pearls floating in a sticky lake of Elmer's glue.

And if it delivers on its promises, the school could become a model to emulate statewide.

He will be greatly missed by his daughter, Judith, and grandchildren Ari and Rachel of Las Vegas, and friends and family internationally. Memorials to Chabad of Southern Nevada.

The 22-year-old Swiss epeeist with the platinum blond hair jawed at his victorious opponent, the Frenchman Hugues Obry, then fulminated for an hour in three tongues.

title: Dream Team 2000 Slams China 119-72
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17 - Thirty minutes had passed since the American professional basketball players bedazzled in their Olympic debut, when the Chinese journalist decided to pose one last question to United States Coach Rudy Tomjanovich .

description: Q: On your new show you play a character -- curiously enough, a character named Jim Gaffigan -- who comes to New York from Indiana. Aside from your name, how much of your own experience is in this character?

title: Dolan and de Bruijn Set Swimming Records
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17  It was a boom-and- bust evening at the Sydney World Record Factory, officially known as the Sydney International Aquatic Center.

title: The Third Man In Mexico City
description: Peter Norman felt as if he were flying, an exhilaration that today, 32 years later, he can barely describe. He churned around the curve and blazed down the backstretch on a warm night in 1968 in Mexico City. He burst across the finish line, looked at his time of 20.06 seconds in the 200 meters and shook his head in disbelief. He had run the race of his life.

title: Veteran U.S. Sailors Are Seeking Redemption in Sydney Harbor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NORMAN A.
description: MILLER-Norman A. died in August 2000 in his Tuxedo Park home where he had lived with his loving and beloved wife of 48 years, Adelaide B. Miller. A brother predeceased him. Born in 1926 in Euclid, Ohio, son of the late George R. and Anna Miller of Cleveland, he served in World War II in the U.S. Navy and studied at Stanford and N.Y.U. He was a retired executive for Grumman Aircraft. Mr. Miller served for many years as a Vestryman and Treasurer of St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church, as Chairman of the Republican Committee for the Town of Tuxedo and as Commander of the Tuxedo Post of the American Legion. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Mary's at a later date to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, NY 10987 or to the American Legion Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 1055, Indianapolis, IN 46206

title: A New Plan Recalls The Old Nasdaq
description: OFFICIALS at the Nasdaq stock market have proposed a new system for handling investors' trades in such popular stocks as Cisco Systems, Dell Computer and JDS Uniphase. The question is: Will investors be better off under the system, or will the large brokerage firms that execute their trades be the bigger beneficiaries?

title: After a Hedge Fund's Fall, Is Wall Street the Wiser?
description: TWO years ago this Friday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York convened an extraordinary meeting of the heads of most of the major Wall Street banks. After two days of rancorous debate, the bankers agreed to invest $3.65 billion in Long-Term Capital Management, an obscure hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn., to save it from imminent collapse.

title: Bordeaux, to Drink in 2002
description: Since man proposes and Nature disposes, buying bottles and cases of wine, and futures, is always a gamble. But the globalization of cutting-edge grape-growing and winemaking methods, with Bordeaux out front, has so diminished the chances of unacceptable wines that vintage chart generalizations are losing value.

Mr. Ibanez was a retired postal employee, who served in WWII in Europe. He is survived by his daughters Grace Friedman, Martha Baas Wahmann, Aida Regan, Vivian Rodriguez and Miriam Burgos. He is also survived by seven grandchildren and his sole surviving sister, Elsie Pena. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, at the Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church. Interment Mount Carmel Cemetery, Englewood, NJ.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 16  Detroit Tigers reliever Doug Brocail will miss the rest of the season with inflammation in his pitching elbow, the team said today.

title: Food; Kitchen Confidential
description: There are those who celebrate the ''melting pot'' -- a mythic caldron constantly bubbling far-flung flavors until they become bland and commonplace -- and there are those who worry the caldron. The authentic, say the latter, is, by definition, ''unmeltable,'' and can exist only apart from mainstream taste.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Character Building
description: Though the cover-up of a deadly crime propels the plot of DIAMOND DOGS (Little, Brown, $23.95), Alan Watt's dark, sparklingly written first novel, an emotionally fraught father-son relationship gives the book its depth. In his hometown, Carmen, a dingy Las Vegas suburb, Neil Garvin is a star high school quarterback -- and a notorious bully. Driving while drunk one night after a party, Neil accidentally hits and kills a lone pedestrian, who turns out to be a shy classmate Neil had roughed up and humiliated earlier that evening. After Neil hides the body, the story transforms into something far more complex than how a criminal covers his tracks. The local sheriff is none other than Neil's father -- a man who appears to be respectable, but at home terrorizes Neil with threats and violence, and whom Neil blames for chasing off his mother years earlier. Yet when this law enforcer discovers Neil's predicament, he coolly and methodically conceals the crime -- thus unhappily bonding Neil to him even further. Watt, a former stand-up comic, injects Neil's numb, guilt-ridden voice with a subtle, deadpan humor and slyly evokes telling details -- Diamond Dogs,'' for example, describes rabid Neil Diamond fans like Neil's father, disappointed middle-aged men who live for ''the greatest lounge act on earth.'' Despite some minor flaws in the pacing (the resolution involving Neil's mother feels slightly forced), Watt delivers a moving, multifaceted story that sharply explores the legacy of violence, distorted forms of love and the high cost of genuine freedom. Megan Harlan
