title: Julie Johnson, Brent Staples
description: Julie Williams Johnson and Brent Andrew Staples were married yesterday at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn. The Rev. Sharon P. Blackburn, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Mobilizing to Stage an Epic, Brutal Trojan War
description: IN the shadow of the Rocky Mountains, the ancient Greek epic of the Trojan War is being played out in all its gore and anguish. On an open stage littered with dirt and debris, against a background of hand-painted slide projections of smoke, rain and wind, ancient passions are coming to life. Chilling scenes of murder, capture and enslavement take place on an immense disc covered with sand and surrounded by reflective black walls. Rocks and driftwood are scattered about, along with statuary: the eyes of Zeus and the broken head of Apollo. And in one climactic scene Troy burns and the surviving women, screaming with pain, are branded before our eyes, while Hecuba, the defeated Trojan queen, ferociously buries her murdered son with her bare hands.

title: Sept. 10-16; A Palestinian Dream Deferred
description: Sept. 13 came and went as another missed deadline in the protracted Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. It was to have marked the end of 52 years of bitter conflict and the achievement of a permanent treaty. But the conflict continued and so did the peace talks, in as much of a stalemate as ever. Originally the Palestinians had pledged to make a unilateral declaration of statehood if there was to be no agreement. But, bowing to international pressure, they quietly retreated and vowed to give negotiations a couple more months. Deborah Sontag

title: Conspicuous Absences
description: All the talk at a Merrill Lynch analysts conference last week seemed to be about the people who weren't there.

title: Everyday Plastic, Spun Into Gold
description: IT wasn't too long ago that credit cards were reserved primarily for major purchases like furniture, appliances or fine jewelry. But these days, many a consumer routinely pulls out plastic for a cup of coffee, a movie ticket or even a cab ride.

title: Chinese Farmers Rebel Against Bureaucracy
description: More than 10,000 angry peasants converged on the two-story, white-tiled town hall here in August, demanding relief from high taxes and administrative fees that eat up any profit from farming.

title: Oxford Journal; 25 Flavors On a Farm That Won't Give Up
description: Dave Rich, an old-fashioned dairy farmer who long ago perfected his thousand-yard stare, has a simple explanation for why he hasn't sold his 100-plus green acres to developers.

title: Of We I Sing
description: Quick, think of a song about New Jersey - no, not one by that Springsteen character. Not so easy is it? Imagine, then, coming up with three hours of songs about the state. Thats what John Weingart is doing, and he will broadcast them on WPRB, Princetons campus radio station, tonight starting at 7. On his ironically named ''Music You Cant Hear on the Radio'' show, which started its 27th free-form, mainly folkish season last Sunday night, Mr. Weingart (who is associate director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers) will present''Songs of New Jersey.'' Selections will include Dave Van Ronk's''Garden State Stomp,'' whose entire lyrics are the names of Jersey towns; ''Jersey Bound'' by Mike Sinatra (no relation, we think); and ''The Long Branch of the Red Bank Bank which was written by Dick Levine of Middletown, who was Mr. Weingarts mothers dentist. The stations signal, at 103.3 FM carries about 40 miles from Princeton and can be heard any-where at WPRB.com.

title: Tools and Techniques for Tree Pruning
description: IT is essential to prune the shade trees around your house at least once a year. Sometimes the reasons for pruning are obvious. A severe storm can break limbs and leave them dangling from the trunk. Trees near the house with long limbs that hang over the roof offer a path into your home for squirrels and raccoons. Also, leaves falling from these limbs can collect in the gutters and clog the downspouts. Even if these conditions do not exist, careful pruning of diseased or dead limbs can produce healthier, fuller shade trees.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGULIES, ESTELLE
description: MARGULIES-Estelle. My beautiful sister Estelle, gone two long years. Miss you. Eternal love. Diane

title: Sept. 10-16; Apple's Work in Progress
description: Apple Computer released a work-in-progress version of its new operating system -- Mac OS X -- which had Macintosh addicts and computer-industry analysts buzzing. The beta software, publicly available from Apple's Web site for $29.95, is the first look at a complete overhaul of the system that was first released in 1984 with the original Macintosh. Mac OS X combines an intuitive user interface on top of a robust infrastructure based on the Unix operating system. The final version is scheduled for release in 2001, when it may help restore Apple's shine as an industry innovator in a marketplace dominated by Microsoft Windows. J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Neuheisel Goes Back to Boulder After Bitter Departure
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 16  Rick Neuheisel returned to Boulder today with his ninth-ranked Washington Huskies, hoping the focus would be on football and not his abrupt and bitter departure from Colorado 20 months ago at the height of recruiting season.

title: Books That Jump Up at You
description: CONEY ISLAND is one of the many Brooklyn locales that gets a three-dimensional treatment (above) in the new book ''Brooklyn Pops Up!,'' a publication of the Brooklyn Public Library and Little Simon/Simon & Schuster. The library is also presenting the exhibition ''Brooklyn Pops Up! The History and Art of the Movable Book,'' curated by the Movable Book Society. Books on display include ''La Cosmographia,'' circa 1575, which focused on math and science, and ''Elvis: Musical Pop-Up Book,'' from 1985.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Happy Bottom Riding Club

title: Editorial Observer; When Devotion Counts More Than Doctrine
description: Vice President Al Gore's selection of Senator Joseph Lieberman as his running mate has significantly undermined the conventional wisdom that vice-presidential candidates don't matter much. That is due in part to the fact that Mr. Lieberman has looked like a bundle of energy in comparison with the leaden presence of Dick Cheney, the former Secretary of Defense, on the Republican ticket.

title: Candidates' Budget Numbers Rely on Optimistic Outlook
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have made clear the differences in how they would use the federal budget surplus, the much-anticipated but as yet unrealized bounty of prosperity.

title: Viloria Wins Difficult Opener
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 17 - American light flyweight Brian Viloria survived a tough first-round opponent in the Olympic boxing tournament today as he out-pointed European champion Serguei Kazakov of Russia in a close fight, 8-6.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Flashman and the Tiger

title: For Central Islip, a Renaissance
description: THIRTY years ago, motorists driving north on Carleton Avenue past Central Islip State Hospital would have seen vacant and vandalized red-brick buildings and just up the street, abandoned and burned-out houses.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in the New Season issue last Sunday misstated the phone number for a concert by the Tallis Scholars at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan on Dec. 7. It is (800) 627-0655.

title: Quick Bite/North Bergen; A Sliver of River and a Big Piece of Cheesecake
description: In spite of its name, the River View Diner in North Bergen is not the place to go for a spectacular view of the Manhattan skyline and the Hudson River. Yes, the diner is nestled near the river, but the truth is, most of its win- dows face north and south and offer just a glimpse of the skyscape, not the panorama the name suggests. The real reason to stop at the River View has to do with something else proclaimed on its sign ''baking on premises.'' Six days a week, John Tsilikas arrives at 6 a.m. and spends five hours in the basement whipping up eye-popping pies and cakes. His repertory includes strawberry pie, Boston cream pie, cheesecake, blueberry cake and the favorite of the owner, Tammis Mavronasios Black Forest cake. Mr. Tsilikass smooth cheesecakes and rich chocolate tortes match up well against anything a Hoboken patisserie can offer. The River View does not display the desserts in the standard rotating case, which Mr. Mavronasios says, tend to dry out the sweet concoc- tions. At the River View, Mr. Tsilikass works of art are shown off in a climate-controlled trophy case at the center of the restaurant. Oops, dont call the River View ''a restaurant'' or a Greek Diner. Its an American diner, says Mr. Mavronasios, who is proud of the 157-year history of diners in America. Stop in at the River View on a Sunday or Monday, and a prime rib dinner, complete with soup or salad and vegetables, is $12.50. You can top it off with a slice of pie ($2.10), a piece of cake ($2.25) or a slab of cheesecake ($3.25), or buy a whole pie ($15) or cake ($20) to take home. CARLA BARANAUCKAS

description: Over the years, Pfizer, the drug maker, has established a factory in Brooklyn, headquarters in Manhattan and laboratories in Connecticut. Now it has opened the Pfizer Learning Center at the Arrowwood Conference Center in Rye Brook.

title: Flora Feng, Jeffrey Slater
description: Flora Wei-Chun Feng, the daughter of Natalie and Dan-Ho Feng of Taipei, Taiwan, was married Friday to Jeffrey Andres Slater, the son of Carmen Slater and Alfred Slater Jr. of Geneva. The Rev. Vernon C. Nichols, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at Atlantica, a restaurant in Westhampton Beach, N.Y.

description: SOMMER-Irma. Beloved wife of the late Hillard Pollack and Louis Sommer in West Palm Beach. Devoted mother of Peter and David N. Pollack, adored grandmother of Kenneth, Jacob, Jane and Rachel Pollack, loving great-grandmother of Ryan. Service private.

title: Blinding Them With Smiles
description: AT first glance, Bridget Fojut's teeth are so perfect -- two rows of straight, big, white Chiclets -- it's hard to believe she is in the chair of Dr. Jeff Golub-Evans, a cosmetic dentist on the Upper East Side, to undergo a bleaching treatment. But Ms. Fojut, 28, an artist and bartender at the W Hotel, believes that her teeth have a slightly yellowish cast, particularly when she wears her favorite lipstick -- ''a Barbie doll pink by Christian Dior.''

title: A Mark of Authenticity For Aboriginal Art
description: In an attempt to steer tourists away from fake Aboriginal art -- much of it mass-produced in Asia -- a nonprofit group representing indigenous Australian artists has introduced a label to help visitors recognize the real thing. The National Indigenous Arts Advocacy Association's labels have begun appearing on individual souvenir items such as boomerangs and T-shirts with Aboriginal designs, and also on the windows of approved shops. The association hopes the program will also boost indigenous artists' shares of an industry that generates more than $120 million a year.

title: To Hold Fares, N. J. Transit Plans to Make Cuts
description: New Jersey Transit plans to reduce its staff by attrition and eliminate some contingency funds that would have been available to boost service to keep its promise not to raise fares, Jeffrey A. Warsh, New Jersey Transit executive director, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIZEN, AARON
description: REIZEN-Aaron. July 6, 1935-September 16, 2000. Champion of words, champion of wit. He made life more interesting for others, simply by being himself. Goodbye dear friend.

description: There are powerful images that can be fleeting, and those that are unforgettable and real. One night after choreographing a utopian multiculturalism that smacked of fiction, the host Australians trotted out the real deal for the world to behold.

Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son Funeral Home, 1275 65th Street (corner 13th Avenue), Brooklyn. Reposing Sunday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, St. Mary Mother of Jesus R.C. Church, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, MURIEL RITA (NEE KRAWITZ)
description: RUBENSTEIN-Muriel Rita (nee Krawitz). Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Hartsdale, NY, passed away September 6, 2000. A ''profile in courage'' who fought colon cancer with dignity and bravery for three years. Beloved wife of Bert; most cherished mother of Daniel (Leah) and Kenneth (Linda); adored grandmother of Harry, Deborah, Emily, Eric and Jason. Devoted sister of Selma Friedland, brother Herman Krawitz, and the late Seymour Krawitz; special sister-in-law; most favorite aunt to her nieces and nephews; and irreplacable friend. We have all been blessed to have had Muriel in our lives and she will never be forgotten. Services were held September 10, 2000.

title: Minor Injury on Major Stage
description: An American athlete's minor injury was verbally probed and prodded for 30 minutes by reporters today, perhaps becoming, in the process, the world's most famous strained hamstring.

title: My First Year in New York; 1965
description: When I moved into my first New York apartment, my uncle gave me a cot and a folding chair. I had been working as a copy editor for a divorce lawyer for two weeks to build up rent money. With $200 in my pocket, I quit and got the apartment ($45 a month) with a friend. It was one room with a bathtub. The bathroom was in the hall and unusable. We took electricity from the hall lighting fixture. There was no heat, but there was a window that overlooked the street three floors below.

title: Spreading The Risk As Gains Broaden
description: THE group of stocks that is leading the market higher is growing, and Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, sees new opportunities for investors as a result.

title: Immigrants With an I.P.O.
description: Name: Avner and Maskit Ronen

title: Crime in the Street
description: To the Editor: Crime cast a dark shadow on my family's vacation in Italy. One morning in bustling Pisa, we were accosted by a group of gypsies: women with babies in body slings, teenagers and a mature woman who feigned scolding the gang. Their touching became pushing and turned into a shoving match. My husband's wallet, in the zippered interior compartment of a zippered body pouch, was stolen. This once-busy piazza became a ghost town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAY, BARBARA CLAAR
description: GALLAY-Barbara Claar. Devoted wife of Samuel Gallay and the late Morris Claar. Loving mother of Alice Claar and the late Sheldon. Adored grandmother of Nancy Hochman, Courtney Claar and Jamie Claar. Service Monday, 2PM, Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson. Contributions to the ALS Association of Greater New York, 116 John St, Suite 1304, NYC 10038, would be appreciated.

title: Backing Away From Free Trades
description: American Express has discovered that giving away unlimited amounts of a service that costs money is not such a great strategy after all.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Faith, Hope and Caridad
description: BY now, the scene is far from unusual: a customer arrives at the Caridad Restaurant at 145th Street and Broadway, only to find his takeout order isn't ready. But busy nights, slow cooks or poor management aren't necessarily to blame. More often, the restaurant never got the call. La Caridad 78 at 78th Street and Broadway did.

title: The View Is 3-Star at These London Restaurants
description: CALVIN TRILLIN, one of America's most entertaining humorists and a certified foodie who introduced the world to Kansas City barbecue, says he ''won't eat in any place that's over 100 feet off the ground.'' Generally one should accept Mr. Trillin's sage advice: the higher off the ground you eat, the worse the food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SCHUYLER GEORGE, MD.
description: KOHL-Schuyler George, MD. 87, died on September 14, 2000. Devoted husband of 57 years of Blossom, adored father of Eileen, father-in-law of Eric. Grandfather of Erin and Elinore Kaufman. Distinguished Professor, dedicated teacher and helper to patients, nurse mid-wives, medical students and faculty members at Downstate for 50 years. Funeral service Sunday 2pm at Congregation Kol Ami (Chapel in the Woods), Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Family will receive friends at home in Scarsdale from 6:30 until 9pm Saturday, September 16. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Westchester or United Cerebral Palsy of NYC.

title: Turin
description: A city of faded grandeur, Turin has a reputation for stodginess, which is not helped by the fact that it is best known as the home of a major automaker, Fiat. This autumn, however, with the Shroud of Turin on display as part of the Roman Catholic Holy Year, Turin is trying to change that image by opening some of its long hidden charms for the first time, making the fall an excellent time for a visit.

title: Belarus Players Bow Out Early
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept 16 -- Vladimir Samsonov's quest for Olympic glory got off to a losing start today as he crashed out of the men's doubles tournament here.

title: Crime in the Street
description: To the Editor: Unfortunately, the scenarios described in ''Crime Takes a Vacation (Yours)'' (July 16) became a reality for us. While our group was in Madrid in August, I witnessed three episodes of street crime. In the Plaza Mayor we were approached by a mother-son pickpocket team. In the second, while walking in the Puerta del Sol, my friend was bumped by someone holding up watches supposedly for sale, followed immediately by his associate dangling keys in front of my face and then dropping them. When I failed to respond to this ploy, he grabbed my leg. After I struck him, he fled.

title: MUSIC; A Passion To Teach, And So To Learn
description: A LARGE rehearsal room at Carnegie Hall: a young string quartet plays through a movement of Brahms. The players are nervous. On the other side of the room is the reason. Seated in a line behind a barricade of music stands is the workshop faculty: the violinist Isaac Stern, the violist Samuel Rhodes of the Juilliard String Quartet, the cellist Timothy Eddy of the Orion String Quartet and I -- our own quartet of the moment. Although no one else is present, the room does not feel empty to any of the eight inhabitants. The student group finishes the run-through, and for the next hour, in a classical-music version of ''Bambi Meets Godzilla,'' faculty members question every aspect of its playing. This is the first day of the 1997 Isaac Stern Chamber Music Workshop, presented by Carnegie Hall, and we are a long way from having to worry about putting the pieces back together.

title: Freeman's Emotional Moment
description: Keeping your cool while standing amid cascading water and rising flames would be a tough task for anyone, especially with the world watching. Cathy Freeman, the Australian track star, acknowledged that her heart was pumping as she stood with the Olympic torch and lighted the caldron at the opening ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Relentless Printmaker
description: Walter Sickert, Britain's foremost Impressionist painter, was also its foremost printmaker. In 1915 he wrote: ''Now there are two things in etching. There is the value of an etching as a drawing, and there is its value as revelation of a sense of the medium.'' As demonstrated in WALTER SICKERT: Prints. A Catalogue Raisonne (Yale University, $120), by Ruth Bromberg, Sickert's particular talent was to unite both elements of etching, endowing prints with an astonishing depth of expression. The book documents the whole of Sickert's printmaking career, starting with his tutelage under Whistler through the development of his own style, influenced by Degas. Throughout, Sickert (1860-1942) experimented with new techniques and subject matter. Beginning with his early sketches of London theater life, he explored architecture and cityscapes as well as intimate domestic scenes. But while Sickert was intent on exploiting the possibilities of the medium in every etching, he was not concerned with aesthetics only; his subject matter was often a vehicle for satire or social commentary. Bromberg highlights the seminal prints in Sickert's body of work and provides salient details of his biography to explain shifts in theme or technique as they occurred. As a scholarly work, however, the emphasis is on detail rather than overview. Some prints are reproduced in as many as 16 different states, testifying to Sickert's relentless curiosity as well as his prolificacy. With characteristic British understatement, he once said of himself, ''I have always known that I was, potentially, the only living etcher, but I was quite prepared never to have the energy to prove it.'' Anna Rohleder

title: Reeling In Syosset's Catch of the Day
description: CHALK up another success for Tom Schaudel. Both the sign at the door and the business cards of Coolfish, his new restaurant in Syosset, accurately proclaim ''It's hot.'' Mr. Schaudel, one of the Island's most enterprising chefs, currently owns Lemongrass in Roslyn, Maxwell's in Garden City and now Coolfish. This latest venture replaces 107 Ocean Bistro, his Locust Valley restaurant that closed earlier this year, and like its predecessor, it showcases seafood.

title: Milestones; Pure Joy: He's 16 and Licensed to Drive
description: BY this weekend, Eric Schlakman will have $4,500 in the bank. The last paycheck from his six-day-a-week lifeguard job will have cleared, and the stage will be set for something he says he has anticipated for virtually all of his 16 years: buying his own car.

title: Score 1 for the Law In Accounting Rule Fight
description: The battle between accounting firms and the Securities and Exchange Commission escalated last week when Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney and an expert in battling money laundering, boiler room brokerages and other seamy sides of the financial world, testified at hearings in New York on the subject of auditor independence.

title: Lemon Drop Kid Outduels Behrens to Win Woodward
description: Was that the Horse of the Year flying through the homestretch at Belmont Park yesterday to wrest the Woodward from Behrens by the length of his head?

title: From MacArthur, a Bonanza in Business Travel
description: LONG ISLAND business travelers are increasingly choosing MacArthur Airport in Islip over La Guardia, Kennedy or Newark, opting for convenience over frequent flights. Passenger traffic through newly renovated MacArthur is expected to reach two and a half million this year, up from less than two million last year. The growth reflects the robust local economy and the national upsurge in business travel.

title: The Nation; Keeping Friends and the Faith
description: HOW should religious believers respond to the plurality of faiths around them? It's a question that has grown in urgency as waves of immigration and emigration around the world have brought people of very different theologies into the same work places, schools and neighborhoods.

title: Books to Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Diary: Much More Expensive Than a Gold Watch
description: When employees quit or retire, their companies may lose more than valued workers. In some instances, the turnover can mean sharp declines in profits and market value, according to Sibson & Company, a management consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NABER, JAMES H
description: NABER-James H, 67, of Litchfield, Connecticut, formerly of Fairfield and Easton, died on Sunday, September 10. He was President and CEO of Glendinning Companies from 1975 to 1985, previously holding positions including Managing Director of International Operations and President of U.S. Operations, beginning the relationship as a founding member in 1963. He was widely recognized as an innovator, changing the way companies market their products globally. Prior to joining Glendinning, he worked in brand management at Procter & Gamble. His professional and personal interests included serving as a member of the People - to - People Presidential marketing delegation to China and as a lecturer at Oxford University and the University of Illinois Graduate School. He acted as President of the Citizens for Easton and was Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Nature Center in Westport. An avid fisherman, he was a seasonal resident of Great Harbour Cay, Bahamas and served as President of its Property Owners Association. He is survived by his wife Donna and his sons and their wives, J. Mark and Jodie Naber of Easton and Stuart Naber and Mary Kaeding of Minneapolis. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Dave & Pat Naber of Brownsville, TX. Services will be private. Memorial donations may be made to his alma mater Carlton College, Attention: Elisa Chaffee, One North College Street, Northfield, MN 55057.

title: Sept. 10-16; European Tempers Flare Over Taxes on Costly Gas
description: With the price of crude oil surging to a 10-year high of $35 a barrel, truckers and farmers across Europe erupted in fury at the soaring cost of their highly taxed gas and diesel fuel, barricading refineries and depots and bringing urban centers to a halt with slow-moving convoys. Britain saw 90 percent of its 12,500 filling station go dry before the siege ended. France, Italy and Belgium gave in to protesters' demands for tax breaks while Britain, Ireland, Spain, Germany and the Netherlands held the line. Warren Hoge

title: Sept. 10-16; The Three R's of the Moment
description: Reversals, reading and rats.

title: Chasing Ever-Changing American Dream
description: IN 1983, Jozsef Domeny bought a one-way ticket from communist Hungary to capitalist West Germany. The long road that he followed has led him, 17 years later, to Floral Park and a successful career as a builder.

title: Sprechen Sie Francais?
description: Talk about hitting close to home. Wasserstein Perella & Company, the investment boutique started by the deal makers Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph Perella in the late 1980's, is in talks to be acquired by Dresdner Bank of Germany. Wasserstein's headquarters, however, are at 31 West 52nd Street, the home of Deutsche Bank's offices here. Deutsche is not only a Dresdner competitor, but it failed in its own attempt to merge with Dresdner earlier this year.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds: Paris; Starting at a stylish bar, ending on a hot dance floor
description: ''You have to go to Queen,'' my friend said. ''It's the baddest club in Paris.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, CLARICE W.
description: HARRISON-Clarice W. On September 16, 2000. Cherished wife of Gerald. Loving mother of Andrew, Robert and Steven. Adoring grandmother of Bryan, Scott, Brett, Justin and Elyse. She will be profoundly missed. Services Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Restoration of Tombs Completed on Malta
description: The Hal-Saflieni Hypogeum, a Neolithic site in the town of Paola, Malta, reopened to the public last month after a nine-year restoration. The 6,000-year-old Hypogeum, discovered in 1902, is thought to be one of the largest and most complex examples of prehistoric rock-cut chamber tombs in Europe.

title: INSIDE
description: Fatigue a Labor Issue

title: The Nation: American Graffiti; Behind the Wheel and Driving the Nation's Culture
description: AMERICA is obsessed with youth, awash in the largest generation of young people since the baby boomers themselves passed through. More than 70 million strong and growing, young people today constitute both an irresistible market and a powerful marketing tool. Teenage tastes set the tone for mass culture from hip-hop to South Park, and teenage bodies are used to sell cars, clothes and the promise of perpetual youth to people old enough to be the models' parents.

title: Boomers Are Job-Hopping, Too
description: It's not only younger workers who are flying the corporate coop.

title: Night Moves of All Kinds
description: The club scene in seven cities: Berlin, Amsterdam, Madrid, Dublin, Paris, London and Prague.

title: Rory O'Dea, John Murphy
description: Rory Beth O'Dea, a daughter of Eileen and James J. O'Dea of Seaford, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Belfield Murphy, a son of Mary and Robert G. Murphy of Convent Station, N.J. Msgr. Peter V. Kain performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Guevara to Reagan, and Beyond
description: IN the 1960's, David A. Stockman borrowed a bus from his pastor to drive fellow Michigan State students to an antiwar protest. He got the bus free, but he charged his fellow travelers $18 a head. ''We used the profits for a Che Guevara memorial fund to do good works,'' Mr. Stockman recalled.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: GOD'S PERFECT CHILD: Living and Dying in the Christian Science Church, by Caroline Fraser. (Owl/Holt, $16.) A former Christian Scientist traces the history of the religion founded by Mary Baker Eddy, which in its heyday drew many followers with its spiritual approach to healing. Fraser ''does a splendid job of explaining the reasons for Christian Science's rise and fall,'' Philip Zaleski wrote here in 1999.

title: Well, No, He Won't Go . . . Without Confronting Protesters
description: At the three-day Asia-Pacific Economic Summit in Melbourne, Australia, last week, Thomas Russo, vice chairman of Lehman Brothers, learned something about international diplomacy when he confronted a lively group of demonstrators. And the protesters learned not to mess with a New Yorker.

title: Blurring Distinctions Between Real and Artificial
description: Cindy Sherman: Early Work

title: The Student, the Sleuth and the Mysterious Pillow
description: YAO CHENG wears no scarlet letter. When she crisscrosses the campus of Columbia University these days, she blends in easily with the fresh-faced students scurrying to class. She, too, is young, just 25, and pretty and smart. But along with her armful of books, Ms. Cheng carries the whisper of scandal and, possibly, the clue to a mystery. Until two months ago, this mystery barred her from setting foot on College Walk. It involved her radioactive pillow.

title: The Difference A Year Makes
description: Name: Eddie Klaynberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, EDMUND V.
description: BURNS-Edmund V. On September 13, 2000. Retired math teacher at Power Memorial H.S. Beloved husband of the late Margaret. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at The William's Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx on Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday in Visitation Church at 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

description: Less than a week after winning the United States Open, Venus Williams was not only on top of the world, but also on the other side of the world. Williams and her teammates on the United States Olympic tennis squad arrived here Friday, just in time to drop off their luggage and march in the opening ceremony at Olympic Stadium.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Salt and Peppier
description: On New Year's Day in 1967, seeking an advantage against Georgia Tech at the Orange Bowl in Miami, the University of Florida football team started quaffing a flavored drink filled with replacement salts that had been developed by researchers at the university.

title: Sarah Greene, Paul Lehman
description: Sarah Ann Greene, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard C. Greene of Green Bay, Wis., was married yesterday to Paul Henry Lehman, the son of Beatrice Lehman of New York and Theodore H. Lehman of Honolulu. The Rev. Gery G. Meehan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Church in DePere, Wis., with Rabbi Michael V. Tillman taking part.

title: Bookshelf
description: NIGHT LIGHTS. By Steven Schnur. Illustrated by Stacey Schuett. Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 3 and up) Here's a counting book in the form of a bedtime ritual as one little girl, Melinda, counts the lights each night, starting with her night light and moving out of her room into the world and the dark sky. Lush, dark illustrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRY, NANCY V.
description: AGRY-Nancy V. Suddenly, on September 14. Survived by husband Warren Agry of Greenwich, CT, son Bradford W. Agry, of New York, brother Peter A. Vogt of Lake View, NY, as well as four nieces and two nephews. A memorial mass will be celebrated at Saint Michael Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT on Tuesday, September 19th at 10AM with the Reverend Michael R. Moynihan officiating. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Middlebury College (VT), or Saint Michael Church.

title: IN THE CLASSROOM WITH/Mary Frei; Teaching Art to Everyone's Benefit
description: THE first time the 10-year-old boy performed, there wasn't a dry eye in the house.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00: Map: Immigration; Moving In
description: Between 1990 and 1996, 794,400 immigrants settled in New York City. That's 15 per hour -- and those are only the official, documented newcomers. They did not spread out evenly across the city. Two-thirds of them settled in Brooklyn and Queens, especially in the neighborhoods of Flatbush, Bay Ridge and Astoria; another 20 percent took Manhattan, particularly the neighborhoods of Washington Heights (31,850 new residents from the Dominican Republic, for example) and Chinatown (21,833 new Chinese). This map shows some of the greatest concentrations of new arrivals by country. It is based on data from the New York City Department of City Planning, which tracked green-card requests between 1990 and 1996 (the most recent years for which this data is available), and from anecdotal information provided by New York-based foreign consulates. -- Nina Siegal

title: Finishing Strong
description: The American welterweight Dante Craig overcame a slow start yesterday to dominate Fadel Showban Showban of Egypt for a victory in the opening round of boxing. Craig, fighting for the first time since surgery on his right hand in April, was cautious and tentative early, but a stinging right hand to Showban's head midway through the second round altered the fight's momentum. Bill Pennington

title: Witty Finishes Out of Spotlight In the Summer
description: Chris Witty was going after posterity tonight. Some of her competitors were going after her.

title: U.S. Ponders Small Holes In Cheese
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)  Anyway you slice it, the Swiss on your ham and cheese is not going to be the same.

title: Clinton Calls for U.S. Aid to Improve Staffing at Nursing Homes
description: President Clinton said today that nursing homes were so understaffed that many patients were endangered, and he asked Congress to provide more money to enable homes to hire and train more nurses and nurses' aides.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE CLOSE

title: On the Street, Knishes Are Becoming an Endangered Species
description: The potato knish, among the most stalwart and traditional of New York street foods, has become an increasingly troublesome item for neighborhood vendors and is slowly but surely fading from the sidewalk scene.

title: Ideas & Trends: Don't Tread on Me; A Road to Truth Paved With Fingerpointing
description: ONE of Thomas Nast's most famous political cartoons of the last days of the corrupt Tweed Ring, which ran the Tammany Hall political machine and New York City from 1866 to 1871, shows the group's leaders standing in a circle, each pointing a finger at the man to his right. The cartoon's label reads, '' 'Twas Him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, JACK
description: IMBERMAN-Jack. Of Kew Gardens, N.Y. on September 8, 2000. He was a veteran of W.W. II. ''Uncle'' will be deeply missed by the Landou & Imberman families. Services were held at the Beth El Cemetery on September 11th.

title: Article 2000091790393843643 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: The Nation; Kids Watch the Darnedest Things
description: KIDS are growing up faster. Sort of.

title: Nancy Furman, Marc Paul
description: Nancy Elisabeth Furman and Marc Adam Paul, lawyers in Washington, are to be married today by Rabbi Julie Zupan at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Penn State Stumbles Heading Into Big Ten
description: The Pittsburgh Panthers are 3-0 in nonconference games, impressive as they approach their Big East schedule. ''Our football team exorcised a lot of demons today,'' Coach Walt Harris said after a 12-0 victory over Penn State at Three Rivers Stadium, which was full and giddy. ''A sleeping giant is starting to wake up again. We're thrilled.''

title: U.N. Forsakes Effort to Curb Poppy Growth By Afghans
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 15  Frustrated by declining support from Western donors and the indifference of the ruling Taliban, the United Nations is winding down efforts to persuade farmers in Afghanistan, the world's largest producer of opium, to switch to alternative legal crops.

title: Singer Gives Voice to Ivory Coast Anger at Leader
description: The country's most popular singer nowadays is also the first victim of censorship by the country's military rulers since they grabbed power last Dec. 25. It happened a few weeks ago after Tiken Jah Fakoly, a young reggae star who sings in French and in the languages of this troubled West African nation, came out with a recording called ''Chameleon.''

title: A Close Match Almost Takes Back Seat to Sand and Sun
description: There may have been a sweeter place to spend the first morning of the Olympic Games. But it was not readily apparent from the sun-drenched bleachers at Bondi Beach, where a sellout crowd of 10,000 whooped it up on the opening day of women's beach volleyball.

title: Ailing Yanks Can Rest Easy As Hernandez Stops Indians
description: Orlando Hernandez strolled from his locker to the trainer's room with so much ice wrapped around his arm from his right shoulder to his elbow that it looked as if he were lugging watermelons underneath the Ace bandages. Hernandez was preparing for his start against the Cleveland Indians by using enough ice for a small barbecue.

title: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'; Laundry Kept On Going After a Father Died
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Campaign Laugh Track
description: A running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night, Sept. 8, through Thursday night, Sept. 14.

title: Parties Spar Over Lieberman's Senate Seat
description: THE debate between Gov. George W. Bush and Al Gore is almost a side issue in the presidential race around here compared to the fireworks over how the Senate seat of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman should be filled should he be elected vice president.

title: Abstract Expressions
description: The hip-hop rappers have set off another raw fashion fad, doing to the sweatshirt and T-shirt what they did to the baseball cap, wearing them every which way but forward. The results echo the Paris fashion world's deconstruction of classic clothing that was set in motion 12 years ago. There is also a nod to the art world's abstract approach. For most wearers, the neck is the anchor, through the traditional hole for the head, while one or both sleeves are left dangling in the front, the back or the side. When only one sleeve is used, it pulls the sweatshirt into a draped angle. For others, the neck hole becomes a porthole on the wearer's back. The style is achieved by the wearer's imagination and has much to do with beating the heat. This fad is generations apart from wearing a sweater over the shoulders or tied around the waist. The hip-hop world has not exhausted its supply of rebellious fashion.

title: Elisabeth Wing, Matthew Stone
description: Elisabeth Allyn Wing, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Wing of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Thomas Stone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Stone of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Barbara Edgar, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Christopher's Church in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Richard Roy, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Once Ice Was Nice, But Now . . .
description: THIS is a hymn to one of the joys of modern life: the humidity-removing, heat-defeating, allergy-freeing, work-enabling, sleep-assuring, noise-buffering invention named by a southern textile engineer nearly 100 years ago -- air-conditioning.

title: Greeley's Home Becomes a Museum
description: Horace Greeley, the 19th-century journalist and presidential candidate, has long been Chappaqua's favorite son. The high school and the main street are named for him, and an imposing statue of Greeley clutching a newspaper overlooks his former land holdings.

title: The West End Is Starstruck
description: WANT a big theatrical success? Hire yourself a celebrity, preferably a film star. This blunt wisdom has recently brought Kevin Spacey, Cate Blanchett, Nicole Kidman and others to London, and, with Jerry Hall replacing Kathleen Turner as the seductive Mrs. Robinson, is currently ensuring that a none-too-brilliant adaptation of ''The Graduate'' is packing the Gielgud Theater. And the trend is set to continue this fall.

title: SYDNEY 2000: PERSPECTIVE; Hurdles Dream Dashed, Dillard Turned a Chance Into Gold in 1948
description: The gold medal hit the concrete floor with an alarming ''clang!'' and began rolling across the London locker room with three guys in pursuit. Naturally, the freshly anointed ''world's fastest human'' got there first, and reclaimed his prized disc.

title: Learning That Stays
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOMBLE, CLEM
description: WOMBLE-Clem. March 3, 1920Sept. 17, 1988. We think of you always. Memories of you remain in our hearts forever. Family and friends of Clem Wombl

title: Hotels in Sicily
description: To the Editor: Many thanks to Catharine Reynolds for her article about new Sicilian hotels among the island's glorious historic locales (''Modern Comfort, Ancient Sites,'' Sept. 3).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Sentiments of love and gratitude to a mother who gave so much of herself in bringing joy to me & many others.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Keeping Hackers' Hands Off Your Card Numbers
description: THE disclosure last weekend sounded like a wired consumer's nightmare: A technical lapse at Western Union left its cash-transfer Web site vulnerable to hackers, and someone downloaded credit and debit card numbers for about 15,700 customers. Western Union was advising them all to cancel their cards and start fresh, just in case.

title: A Mother's Memories
description: RETURNING from the Farmers' Market in Hartsdale, I noticed that the strange large van that had been parked at the side of our house for the last two days had moved to the neighbor's driveway. The parents and son were packing so many bags and boxes that it looked like a major move.

title: Ground Shifts In Fight to Gain Electoral Edge
description: Vice President Al Gore, who has erased Gov. George W. Bush's lead in most national polls, has also edged ahead of him in the battle for electoral votes, according to independent and partisan analysts. But despite the postconvention trend in Mr. Gore's favor, enough states are either tossups or held so narrowly that the race remains fiercely competitive.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Damien Hirst; Ghoulish Laughter
description: IN a huge, white space not far from the meatpacking district, Damien Hirst was up to his eyeballs on Thursday evening, setting up his first major art show in four years. The eyeballs, which were a crucial part of two pieces, had not yet been installed, but they will be fully operational before Mr. Hirst's show opens at Larry Gagosian's new Chelsea gallery this week. Despite Mr. Hirst's propensity for animal body parts in his work (bisected cows suspended in formaldehyde and whatnot), the eyeballs in question were not real but mere Ping-Pong balls.

title: Finding a Secret Weapon In the Old Queen's Gambit
description: The traditional Politiken Cup International Open Tournament in Copenhagen, July 17-28, was won jointly by Boris Gulko of Fairlawn, N.J., Lars Bo Hansen of Denmark and Jonny Hector of Sweden.

title: City Gets a Scolding Over a Long-Stalled Renovation
description: The city has taken more than six years to renovate a building it owns in Downtown Brooklyn, and Howard Golden, the borough president, who called the lengthy project ''a particular embarrassment,'' wants the work finished fast. But city officials say they need nine more months.

title: Fancy Fiddling
description: GRILLED fare has always struck a chord with me. Hamburgers just aren't the same out of a pan -- and they're even tastier on a grilled rather than toasted bun.

title: Kentucky Troubadour
description: CAN'T YOU HEAR

title: Out on the Road to Burning Man
description: I HAVEN'T yet seen a Burning Man sticker on a Cadillac. But when I do, it won't surprise me. That is because Burning Man, the annual weeklong festival of arts, music and ''radical self-expression'' in the Nevada desert, is rapidly seeping into mainstream American culture -- or is it the other way around?

title: From 'Jekyll and Hyde' to Mark Antony
description: ''I'M Mark Antony, damn it!'' proclaims romantic lead Robert Cuccioli during a recent rehearsal for the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's production of ''Antony & Cleopatra.''

title: Eventually, Everyone Gets Here
description: Just when you thought it was safe to cross roads like Route 10 on a Saturday afternoon, the retail chain Best Buy is about to give you pause.

title: Nassau Leader Submits Plan To Raise Taxes
description: In the end, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta whose repeated resistance to raising property taxes helped bring Nassau County to the edge of fiscal ruin -- has turned to tax increases to help bail the county out.

title: The Big Fish That Didn't Get Away
description: YOU and I will not be having this discussion after Labor Day,'' Paul B. Guenther, the chairman of the New York Philharmonic, bravely declared last April. ''Either that or you'll be talking to my successor here.'' In effect, Mr. Guenther was promising that the orchestra would have named its next music director by now. But who's keeping track? (Probably no one on the Philharmonic's board; who would want to take over Mr. Guenther's position and its problems just now?)

title: Priests Haven't Forgotten the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Intellectual Forum Brings Jerry Brown to the Table
description: The phrase ''back to school'' has acquired new meaning here. It's time to grab the ballpoints, the highlighters and the 450-page binder of reading materials and head over to the mayor's house for a little ''Medieval Philosophical Latin: Part 1.''

title: Harrigan No-Hitter Puts Odds In United States Team's Favor
description: When Lori Harrigan isn't firing 60-mile-an-hour fastballs, she is a security officer for a casino in Las Vegas. It is the kind of experience that helps one find work for the United States softball team, which has turned home plate and most bases into a no-trespassing zone.

title: The Values Statement vs. Corporate Reality
description: At the heart of the recently settled strike between Verizon Communications and its telecommunications workers were the high stress levels experienced by service representatives. One possible culprit -- and something not explicitly addressed by the settlement -- was the fact that a companywide values statement clashed with reality in the area of customer service.

title: Jennifer Abcug, Mitchell Brody
description: Jennifer Elise Abcug, the daughter of Lynne and Leslie Abcug of Parsippany, N.J., was married last evening to Mitchell Gary Brody, the son of Herbert Brody of Middletown, N.J., and the late Diana Brody. Rabbi Henry Wiener officiated at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

title: Remembering a Teacher Who Led by Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Packages Come With Asterisks
description: THOSE who found few bargains on travel to Europe last summer, when flights were full and coach fares to Lisbon, for example, were running over $900, are likely to welcome fall, when low-cost packages arrive. For less than the price of a round-trip air ticket in summer, tour companies in off season sell combinations of flights, hotels and elements like sightseeing tours or transfers between the airport and the hotel.

title: CANADIAN MOUNTIES
description: The State Police may not have plans to turn out a crop of Dudley Do-Rights, but the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have been called in to develop training that has begun at the State Police Training Academy in Sea Girt. Members of the mounted police, noted for their training methods, were in New Jersey this summer to instruct academy teachers. Class sizes were reduced from more than 100 to 30 and training was extended from 21 to 26 weeks. Karen DeMasters

title: ON THE SCENE WITH/Sloan Wainwright; Doing What Comes Naturally, Singer-Songwriter Drops Day Job
description: SLOAN WAINWRIGHT of Katonah has managed to step out of the shadow of her famous family and build a career as a singer-song writer-band leader. Her father, the author Loudon Wainwright, was a long-time Life magazine columnist. Her brother Loudon was hailed 30 years ago as ''the new Bob Dylan'' and has enjoyed a successful career as a singer-songwriter and actor.

description: To the Editor:

description: NO GOOD-BYES

title: Maggie McGuire and Kurt Wallace
description: FRIENDS say it is nearly impossible to discourage Maggie McGuire. She could read the darkest novel while rain poured outside and still not lose hope or humor.

title: In East Hampton, 'Play Ball' Vies With 'Save the Land'
description: ALL was quiet back in April, when the East Hampton Town Board made two applications for Suffolk County ''greenways'' funds. One application called for preservation of scenic farmland; the other was to develop a sports park with playing fields.

title: Growth Reshapes School Districts
description: FACED with rising student populations and inadequate or aging school buildings, both the Harrison and Hastings-on-Hudson school districts recently announced efforts to handle the problem.

title: Habitats/Avenue C Near Ninth Street; In Alphabet City, a Co-op Gives a Couple an 'A'
description: HWA-SHIH LEE and Reginald Tucker, both 25, have known each other for years, since meeting as first-year students at New York University. They had been living together in rentals and decided it was time to buy their first place.

title: Olympic Events for Chiefs: Sunning and Burger Flipping
description: If you're a chief executive attending the Olympics, where do you stay? Forget the local Ritz-Carlton. Get yourself a yacht, or better yet, an entire cruise liner and dock it next to Sydney's landmark Opera House. That's what Louis Gerstner of I.B.M. did. Mr. Gerstner is staying on a giant cruise liner that I.B.M. rented for the Olympics; he will play host to dozens of parties and meetings there. As a major sponsor of the Games, I.B.M. is flying about 2,000 employees and clients to Sydney to show off the technology it developed for the Games.

title: Hollow Claims About Fantasy Violence
description: The moral entrepreneurs are at it again, pounding the entertainment industry for advertising its Grand Guignolesque confections to children. If exposure to this mock violence contributes to the development of violent behavior, then our political leadership is justified in its indignation at what the Federal Trade Commission has reported about the marketing of violent fare to children. Senators John McCain and Joseph Lieberman have been especially quick to fasten on the F.T.C. report as they make an issue of violent offerings to children.

title: Article 2000091792037287376 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

description: To the Editor:

title: Sore Knee Puts Bell on Bench Against the Expos
description: After aggravating an injury to his left knee on a slide at home plate on Friday night, Mets right fielder Derek Bell was a late scratch from the lineup tonight and does not expect to play again until Monday in Atlanta.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 4.0 percent in August, up from 3.7 percent in July. The national unemployment rate was 4.1 percent. According to the New Jersey Department of Labor, jobs in the private sector rose by 2,000 employees despite the Verizon workers' strike, while 2,800 government employees lost their jobs because of the completion of the census. John Holl

title: Leaders of the Pack Mentality
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS call it projection -- attributing to others the behavior that we refuse to recognize in ourselves. And the practice is widespread on Wall Street.

title: For Rutgers, It's an Insult And an Injury
description: A long and fruitless afternoon for the Rutgers football team ended with its top player, quarterback Mike McMahon, hunkered somberly on the bench. He had pulled the hood of his black jacket over his head, and his valuable right arm was in a sling once again.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00; A Street Grows In Brooklyn
description: A few years ago, when I moved near Smith Street -- a dusty stretch running through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens -- it seemed happily mired in the 1950's. Dotted with members-only social clubs and old men playing cards in front of shuttered storefronts, the area felt untouched by the relentless pace of Manhattan life. That's what persuaded me, and many people like me, to trade in a hip downtown address for space, charm and refuge across the river.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about classes for writers referred incorrectly to a teaching method of the Gotham Writers' Workshop. The teachers do not leave the room while the students are evaluating one another's work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, EDWIN N.
description: TEICH-Edwin N. Our dear friend of many years. A cultured man of integrity. He will be missed . Our hearfelt condolences to his brothers, Buddy and Jackie & families. Arnold and Dawn Pohl

description: Name: Rebecca Smith

title: Three Generations Active In Track at the Same Time
description: IT was at the Loucks Games at White Plains High School last spring. Gene Fulton, now 81, a track and field official for 45 years and before that a high school sprinter in the Bronx in the early 1930's, looked across the field. An earnest young man, not much older than the teenage athletes he was talking to, was gesturing.

title: A Season With Many Stops Becomes a Trial
description: When this baseball season is over, Dave Martinez's main objective will be finding a way to repay his wife for her patience and sacrifice.
