description: ZWERLING-Edith (Goldberg), of Deerfield Beach, FL, died September 3, 2000. Beloved by her husband, Dr. Samuel Zwerling. Cherished aunt of Mimi Zwerling and Molly Z. O'Byrne. Her loving spirit will always remain in our hearts.

title: The Nation; What Makes Soft Money Soft?
description: ONCE, there was the smoke-filled room. These days, unsavory politics is epitomized with the phrase soft money.

title: Rallying Behind Call To End Fire Sirens
description: Having been a visitor to the town of Thornwood recently (and several times before), I found the article regarding the problem of blaring fire sirens in Westchester (and apparently elsewhere) quite interesting [''Fight Over Fire Siren in Thornwood,'' Sept. 3].

title: From the Hudson Valley
description: Soon the Seyval blanc grapes at Clinton Vineyards, in a pastoral niche of Dutchess County, will be picked, destemmed, crushed and fermented in Ben and Phyllis Feder's green barn.

title: Myriamne Coffeen, Mark Vandeven
description: Myriamne Nicola Coffeen, the daughter of Dr. Yola E. Coffeen and Dr. David L. Coffeen of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Hermann Vandeven, the son of Elisabeth and Donald W. Vandeven of Syracuse. Mayor Richard A. Watson of Morris Township, N.J., officiated at Silver Spring Farm, a restaurant in Flanders, N.J.

title: Made for America
description: To the Editor:

title: Fur Flies off the Rack at 'Cats' Sale
description: They laughed, they cried, but it was not quite better than ''Cats.'' They were there, after all, to buy Memories.

title: A Sheridan Square Complaint: Garbage In, But Not Enough Out
description: To many residents of Greenwich Village, tourists are pests. When double-decker tour buses began peering into second-story windows, for example, tenants along West Fourth Street screamed and forced some routes changed. ''The tourists are an annoyance, especially in the summer,'' said James LaVigne, who lives near Sheridan Square. ''There's too many people. It's more noise and more garbage, too.''

title: An Abrupt Resignation in Putnam
description: THE last time someone resigned from the Putnam County Legislature more than a decade ago, it was after angry civic debate concerning issues of welfare and housing.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 17, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Cartwheels All the Way to Sydney
description: There is news this week that cheerleaders want to be included in the Olympics, and to that I say: ''California oranges, Arizona cactus, we play Kuala Lumpur just for practice!''

title: Destination: N. Y.
description: ''How the lunatics flung up their caps and roared in sympathy with the headlong engine and the driving tide!'' -- Charles Dickens, on arrival in New York, passing the insane asylum on Blackwell's Island aboard the steamboat New York

title: Turf Wars Forgotten, It's Time for a Picnic
description: IN the 1950's and 60's, a gathering in New Britain of young toughs meant a drag race or rumble. Now in their 50's and 60's, these aging rebels have a new cause: a picnic reunion.

title: My First Year in New York; 1949
description: The prospect of New York terrified me to the roots. I had no clear idea of what I wanted to do, just that I wanted to be successful and rich and move in the right circles and go to the Stork Club and El Morocco. It was one thing to have been the darling of my class at Williams (where I sang and danced in Stephen Sondheim's first musical), but quite another thing to earn a living for the first time in my life.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILLETTE, NOETH B.
description: GILLETTE-Noeth B. 9/17/25-6/17/ 93. A man of great integrity, good humor, warmth and intelligence. Dearly loved, much missed, always remembered. Happy birthday, Papa.

title: A Priceless Art Collection Finds Itself Strapped for Cash
description: With more than 300 Cezannes, Renoirs and Matisses glowing pricelessly from its gallery walls, the news is stunning to the tightly controlled stream of visitors: the Barnes Foundation is broke.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: My First Year in New York; 1995
description: My father was the first; he arrived in Nueva York at the start of the 70's, in the Years of the Puerto Rican Obituary. He had the ''usual'' Caribbean immigrant experience: he worked lousy jobs, his hands bled almost constantly (the stigmata of the factory), he slept in unheated buildings and he starved himself thin. All around him buildings exploded into fire. Fortunately he wasn't in them, but it didn't help his sleep any knowing that a family of seven had been roasted to death the week before one block over. The stench of the smoke, of those destroyed lives, seeped into his dreams.

title: Most Federal Web Sites Fail on Privacy Standards, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Most federal Web sites do not meet the commercial standards for Internet privacy set by the Federal Trade Commission, including the commission's own site, a government report has found.

title: Sept. 10-16; Nowhere to Flutter
description: In the first scientific study of the monarch butterfly's most threatened habitat, researchers found evidence that a stretch of forest in the mountains of central Mexico, to which millions of the butterflies migrate from the United States each year, has been whittled down to remnants in a sea of development and deforestation. Researchers found that nearly half of what was intact forest 30 years ago has suffered partial to complete deforestation. Carol Kaesuk Yoon

title: France via Britain For Hungry Americans
description: Though the name is French for ''ready to eat,'' the founders of Pret a Manger -- Sinclair Beecham and Julian Metcalfe -- are British, and the chain's more than 100 locations are in the United Kingdom and Scotland. Until this summer, that is, when the company started serving New York's financial district its menu of fresh sandwiches ($2 to $5), baguettes ($3.75 to $4.50) and wraps ($4.25-$4.75).

title: Wealthy Nations Plan a Doubling of Debt Relief
description: In an era of unprecedented prosperity for rich nations, their financial leaders are promising a high-profile campaign to double the number of poor nations granted debt relief by year's end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIFFE, HELEN MOTT, SMITH
description: EIFFE-Helen Mott-Smith, 93, of Hampton Bays, NY, on September 6. Survived by daughters, Helen Paty Eiffe, Susan E. Edmondson, and son, John Eiffe. Helen Eiffe will be remembered for her hospitality. She was respected and loved by all who knew her. Marianne and Seymour Schnell

title: Israeli Land and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: LAWRENCE KASDAN, still best known for ''Body Heat'' and ''The Big Chill,'' must have been in sunnier mood when he wrote and directed MUMFORD (1999). The setting is a small Midwestern town, and the hero is a newly arrived young psychotherapist (Loren Dean, a charmer), who seems to work wonders. His patients include a lovely young woman (Hope Davis) whose catalog shopping has taken over the house, and the local baby billionaire (Jason Lee), who likes to spend his days skateboarding. The film is irreverent in a playful way, and the message seems to be that the best therapy in the world is inventing a new life and finding the right person to share it - Saturday at 8 p.m., Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:20 a.m. on Starz.

title: M.T.A. Seeks Proposals For Hotel Project in Harrison
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is soliciting proposals to build a hotel and parking garage on 3.3 acres next to the train station in Harrison.

title: A Plea for Help On Regional Planning
description: The Long Island section publishes numerous articles about different real estate development proposals. One recent article was about a plan to build a power plant, another about a proposed shopping mall. The common theme s the concern of neighbors about how the proposed development will affect traffic, health or quality of life.

title: SWIM FOR MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS
description: Swimming across the Hudson River, 65 people -- from 10 to 60 -- raised close to $25,000 in pledges for the Southern New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. The swimmers were accompanied by 55 kayakers, eight support powerboats, members of the Coast Guard, three diving teams and rescue teams from the Irvington Fire Department and the Croton-on-Hudson Police Department, said Sgt. Dennis Chillemi of the Irvington police. The swimmers included Leslie Erskine, a Somers resident who suffers from multiple sclerosis; Jean Pierre Koenig, an amputee from Greensboro, N.C.; and Dennis Cahill, commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: A Guide to Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills' Fierce Defense Limits Jets in Playing Catchup
description: Quarterback Brett Favre of the Green Bay Packers knew the truth about the fourth-quarter comeback last season. A boost for morale, a thrill for fans, but a flimsy construct on which to build a successful season.

title: Moliere, the Start (And the Finish) Of Stage Season
description: WHATEVER defines the new season, it is Moliere who frames it. And however the new plays and musicals or the revisited ones fare, the state's professional theater calendar begins and ends with the forever stylish 17th-century playwright.

title: 111 Sex Offenders, No Takers
description: By month's end, a court order will force the state Department of Corrections to remove 111 high-risk sex offenders from a temporary lock-up in Kearney. The problem is, the state is still looking for a place to put them.

title: Commercial Property/Greenwich, Conn.; The Changing Face of a Renowned Shopping Street
description: FOR generations, Greenwich Avenue, the shopping hub of this upscale town, was a place where clerks in the local stores knew their regular customers by name, size and personal taste. Now, though, much of that has changed, as in recent years many of the independent stores have been replaced by large national chains.

title: Patricia Haneman, Chappy Cox
description: Patricia Stevens Haneman, a daughter of Nancy J. Haneman of Rye, N.Y., and the late William Floyd Haneman, was married yesterday to Brian Wesley Cox, a son of Trudy and Ted Cox of Moore, S.C. The Rev. David Harkness, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the American Yacht Club in Rye.

title: A Few Words in Greek Tell of a Homeland Lost
description: Sano Halo, 90, her shock of thick white hair barely poking above the lectern, pulled the microphone down to her level and began reciting the Lord's Prayer in Greek.

title: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'; A Neighborhood Not Historic but Special
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Chances: A Roundup of Revisits
description: THINGS change, to quote the title of a David Mamet movie, and in the restaurant business change is virtually built in. That is why from time to time we like to look in at places that provided memorable dining experiences in the past. Following are observations from several of our most recent revisits.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS -- UPDATE; Children's Learning Center Finds Space at Last Minute
description: The Children's Learning Center celebrated its first day of classes for 2000-2001 recently. It was an auspicious occasion marked by a festive open house. It was also a day that nearly never happened.

title: Red Bell Peppers Are At Their Best Now
description: RED bell peppers, now at their peak season, have a thick flesh and sweet mild taste. But they aren't at their best eaten raw. They should be toasted over wood or charcoal or charred under a broiler until their skins blacken. Then they should be put in a paper or plastic bag where they steam in their own heat for a few minutes. This loosens their skins and makes them juicy and easy to peel.

title: Olympic Events for Chiefs: Sunning and Burger Flipping
description: If you're a chief executive attending the Olympics, where do you stay? Forget the local Ritz-Carlton. Get yourself a yacht, or better yet, an entire cruise liner and dock it next to Sydney's landmark Opera House. That's what Louis Gerstner of I.B.M. did. Mr. Gerstner is staying on a giant cruise liner that I.B.M. rented for the Olympics; he will play host to dozens of parties and meetings there. As a major sponsor of the Games, I.B.M. is flying about 2,000 employees and clients to Sydney to show off the technology it developed for the Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, WILLIAM
description: ZIMMERMAN-William. Of North Palm Beach Florida, died September 9, 2000. He was 80. Survived by his sisters, Ida Rubin, Rose Zimmerman and Sarah Tepper, his three children, Stuart Zimmerman, Marc Zimmerman and Susan Chroman, and ten loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Mr Zimmerman rose from a modest background to become one of America's most successful retailers, founding closeout specialist Pic 'N' Save (now part of Consolidated Stores) in 1950 and managing it until his retirement in 1985. A great supporter of children's causes and entrepreneurial education, Mr Zimmerman and his foundation were significant contributors to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship. Memorial services to be held in Los Angeles Sunday September 24.

title: SOAPBOX; Missing the Bus
description: I HADN'T felt that bad since I had to take that sick little kitten to the vet for its last ride. I had just finished painting out the school district's name and the number off bus No. 14. It had to be put out of service after 12 years, by state law. It would be going to the auction and sold for whatever use.

title: OPINION; Playing the West Nile Blame Game
description: TO one who thought he had put plague-ridden Long Island behind him this summer in favor of the healthy, rugged outdoors of New York's mountains, it was more than a bit sobering to learn that the West Nile virus has been discovered upstate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURBEE, GILES
description: TURBEE-Giles, Reverend Brother O.S.F. On September 15, 2000. Beloved son of the late Felix Turbee and Rose Sapia. Loving nephew of Anna Greenberg and cousin of Ann Marie Rezzonico. Reposing in Friary, 185 Joralemon St., Brooklyn, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10 AM, in Friary Chapel at 185 Joralemon St. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: More Than Music in Philharmonic Search
description: AS conducting jobs go, on paper the music directorship of the Long Island Philharmonic is not exactly top-drawer. Unlike most regional orchestras, the Philharmonic doesn't perform a full season in a hall it can call its own with the same musicians on the roster. It has no city behind it, supporting it as a source of civic pride. And the pay, by classical music standards, is only average: $70,000 to $80,000 to conduct about a dozen concerts a year.

title: Diane Davis, John Otter IV
description: Diane April Davis, an editor at Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, was married yesterday to John Martin Otter IV, a reporter and columnist there. The Rev. Steven Jay Yagerman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Thomas in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Alice McClellan, Joseph Trowbridge
description: Alice Braislin McClellan, a daughter of Elizabeth B. Powers of Weston, Vt., and James O. McClellan of Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Joseph Bell Trowbridge, a son of Susan B. Trowbridge and James W. Trowbridge of Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton by the Rev. Gordon S. McClellan, a Presbyterian minister and a brother of the bride, with the Rev. Tom Hagan, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: GUN AMNESTY NETS 224 WEAPONS
description: The county's gun buy-back program has netted 224 weapons, and many knives, handcuffs and ammunition, Westchester County District Attorney Jeanine Pirro reported Tuesday. The program, financed with $50,000 in seized assets, paid out $9,350 to residents: $50 for each handgun and $25 for each rifle or shotgun. Pellet guns, starter pistols, BB guns, knives, chukka sticks and other weapons are accepted, but no compensation is offered for them.

title: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'; Laundry Kept On Going After a Father Died
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place for Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about a television remake of ''High Noon'' included a film incorrectly among those in which the actor Lee Van Cleef appeared. He did not appear in ''Once Upon a Time in the West.''

title: The View From/Stamford; Center Aims to Educate On Long Island Sound
description: THE brown ducks swimming in the inlets, the gulls swooping low in the sky, the herons stalking fish in the shallows -- all are testimony to the diverse ecology of Long Island Sound. They could also be advertisements for the environmental center about to open in a 200-year-old converted house in Cove Island Park in Stamford.

title: TURNPIKE E-ZPASS
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority last week announced the arrival of electronic tolls starting Sept. 30, after a two-year of delay and $16 million in overspending. Drivers with the pass will be able to drive from Boston to Philadelphia without having to stop at toll plazas. But motorists are also getting a toll increase and a system of 8 percent discounts that rewards drivers who use the turnpike during off-peak hours. For those without the windshield-mounted tags, the price increase will be 20 percent. Andrew Jacobs

title: Big Ideas for Apollo Theater Are Held Up by Internal Squabbles
description: It has been a year since United States Representative Charles B. Rangel agreed -- after a rancorous legal battle -- to step down as chairman of the nonprofit organization that runs the state-owned Apollo Theater and turn over control of the board to Time Warner.

title: A Brisk March for the Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, confounding predictions that he would take the weekend off, briskly marched 23 blocks up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. The only sign that he had had radioactive seeds implanted in his prostate gland a day earlier was his staying away from children.

title: A Nebraska Linebacker Welcomes the Attention
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 16  Nobody has ever accused Nebraska's Carlos Polk of being shy.

title: Aimee Nassau, Sargent Gardiner
description: Aimee Elizabeth Nassau and Sargent Collier Gardiner were married yesterday by the Rev. Jack S. Miller, a Presbyterian minister, at the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn.

title: Life Was Art, Art Was Life
description: MARCEL PROUST

title: Priests Haven't Forgotten the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF
description: Leslie Alexander Buys 20 Acres From Grumman

title: For These Linemen, Teammates Come First or the Wallet Comes Out
description: Personnel men are saying the Giants' Ron Stone is playing as well, if not better, than any guard in football.

title: Look Homeward
description: WHEN Philip Roth sent his fictional alter ego, Neil Klugman, from Newark to Short Hills to visit Brenda Patimkin in 1959, he sounded a literary theme that would reverberate for decades. The tension between gritty urban life and the wealthier -- but ultimately vacuous -- nearby suburbs has become a classic theme of modern American storytelling.

title: The Old Electoral College Try
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fashion Week Diary; Arbiters of Style: Bjork to Polly Mellen
description: A fresh tar smell rose from the roadway to Pier 92 at West 55th Street on Thursday night, and upstairs in the public restrooms, Escada Homme had been used for high-end fumigation. Models racing off the street in their denim skirts and flip-flops ran the gantlet of paparazzi, who couldn't be bothered since there were celebrities to be bagged. Escada is to German fashion roughly what St. John Knits is to Americans -- important advertisers and a formidable retail force, but hardly a house to make editors' antennas quiver. Perhaps for that reason, the front rows of its show, staged on the day before Fashion Week officially opened at the pier where Cunard liners tie up, were occupied not by editorial priestesses but with B-list celebrities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, BEATRICE CHAPNICK
description: MARKOWITZ-Beatrice Chapnick. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Barry R. and Naomi Mark. Devoted grandmother of Robert Mark and Stu Markowitz. Services were held on Sunday.

title: Spread of Violence Against Journalists
description: After years of listening to death threats on his answering machine, Michel Auger learned to live the elusive life, varying routes to work, sleeping in hotels, listing his office address as his home address. But, deep down, Mr. Auger, a seasoned, 56-year-old reporter, always believed he was protected by his work, printed under the best-read byline in his city's best-read paper.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; For China, Basketball Is on Ascent
description: YOU'VE got to close your eyes and stretch the imagination -- and I mean, really lay it out there -- after a blowout the magnitude of 119-72, but here goes. If the Dream Team has a date with destiny, a time and place when the cocky American basketball professionals look up at an Olympic scoreboard that casts them as losers, the country that is going to achieve this miracle is China, the one that took a brutal drubbing here last night.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Thompson Pushes Too Hard, Too Soon
description: JENNY THOMPSON'S lip quivered last night as she held back the tears. Once again the 27-year-old American swimmer had been thwarted in her quest to win the individual Olympic gold medal that had eluded her so long.

title: Richard Thomas, 69, Led Time Magazine and Helped Start People
description: Richard B. Thomas, a former publisher of Time magazine who helped start People magazine, died Thursday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 69.

title: Norwalk Paper Shifts To Morning Delivery
description: After 105 years as an afternoon newspaper, the local daily paper, The Hour, will shift to morning publication on Monday.

title: Jets Go With a Big Man on a Big Play to Set Up a Big Game
description: When the Jets practiced desperation heaves in training camp, quarterback Vinny Testaverde noticed that Wayne Chrebet and Dedric Ward, the receivers who would sprint for the end zone and hope to come down with the ball in the final seconds of a game, were being outjumped. So Testaverde turned to his coaches with an idea: give him the 6-foot-2-inch cornerback Marcus Coleman, who has the vertical leap of a basketball player and a bit of experience as a receiver, going back to his sophomore year in high school, the last time he caught a pass.

title: Seeking Access To Data on Doctors
description: Fortune magazine's review of ''Blind Eye: How The Medical Establishment Let a Doctor Get Away With Murder'' (Simon & Schuster, 1999) was decidedly mixed. ''This is not a subtle book,'' the reviewer wrote, ''but then, Jim Stewart books never are.''

title: In Upstate Town, Out With Graft, In With Rancor
description: When voters here upended a 7-to-0 Republican town board last fall in favor of a 5-to-2 Democratic majority, they hoped to break a cycle of corruption and scandal epitomized by William L. Paroli Sr., the jailed former chairman of the local and Dutchess County Republican parties.

title: This Time, the Defense Wins a Game for the Giants
description: The week of practice for Giants defensive players leading to the Chicago game was a physical one. There was extra hitting, and the shoulder pads stayed on a tad longer. The Bears had lost twice, but the Giants weren't taking any chances. ''Some of the drills were rough,'' said defensive lineman Michael Strahan, who then flashed his bright smile before adding, ''It was good for us.''

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: National News Briefs
description: Space Mission Ends, and Shuttle Plans Return

title: Another Dangerous Mission for a Veteran Israeli Warrior
description: ON the wall of his office in the Israeli Embassy in Washington, Ambassador David Ivry has a place of honor for a framed photograph of rubble. It is an American satellite photo of what was left of an Iraqi nuclear reactor after it was destroyed by Israeli warplanes in 1981.

title: Help for a Friend in Need
description: SYDNEY Australia -- It wasn't the first time that Esther Kim had given her hand to Kay Poe in a moment of urgent need. Eleven years of friendship, of virtual sisterhood, began with that very gesture, with a touching demonstration of precocious compassion.

title: Lieberman Sees Colorado As Swing State
description: Making his campaign premiere in the Rocky Mountain states, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said today that the Democrats now see Colorado, long dominated by Republicans, as a swing state, and they plan to contest it vigorously.

title: The Gore Ticket And Big Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Cadbury to Pay $1.45 Billion For Snapple
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British candy and beverage company, is expected to disclose today that it will buy Snapple and two other brands from the Triarc Companies for $1.45 billion in cash and debt, executives close to the deal said.

title: Clinton Asks Black Leaders To Aid Gore as They Did Him
description: He said he had come merely to listen, clap and say thank-you. But President Clinton was the headliner of the show, and he put his star power to work on Saturday night doing what many Democrats think he does best: rousing black voters to come out to the polls to help Democrats, particularly Vice President Al Gore.

title: A Rosier Outlook for Online Holiday Sales
description: Despite the failures and finacial constraints that cast gloom over the e-commerce sector this summer, the outlook for the holiday shopping season may give some Internet retailers reason for cheer.

title: The Night Thorpedo Went Down
description: SYDNEY Australia -- This is a nation that loves swimming -- and not just cooling off in the backyard pool and not just swimming laps so you can go out and eat a dish of linguini without feeling guilty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, MARTIN BLAIR
description: GOLDSTONE-Martin Blair. 40, of Grove City, OH, formerly of Great Neck, Long Island, passed away Friday, September 15, 2000. From his loving brothers, Marc and Mitchell Goldstone

title: UNCERTAIN TIMING FOR PERU ELECTION GIVES U.S. CONCERN
description: The sudden decision by Peru's president, Alberto K. Fujimori, to call new elections and not run in them himself took the United States and all of Latin America by surprise, officials said today. While welcoming the move, they expressed concern that Peru might face a period of unrest and voiced uncertainty about what role its influential army might play.

title: European Soccer Roundup
description: The almost surreal plight of Steve McManaman again came to light in the Spanish Primera Liga this weekend when the English wing played briefly as a substitute in Real Madrid's 3-3 draw with Malaga.

title: Article 2000091892895930373 -- No Title
description: TECHNOLOGY

title: Agency Investigates 'Rats' Ad
description: Responding to complaints from two Democratic senators, the Federal Communications Commission has begun an investigation into a Republican campaign television commercial to determine whether it used subliminal advertising techniques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKE, JUDI
description: LAKE-Judi. A longtime resident of North Woodmere, NY, died on September 15. She was the beloved wife of Herbert, devoted mother of Edward, Marla and Robert. Loving grandmother to Perri, Rebecca and Risa. Dear sister of Martin Rowe. Caring mother-in-law of Minda, Modi and Tracy. Her loving and graceful spirit will always remain in our hearts. ''Everything in moderation.''

title: Allied Domecq Talks Reported With Swedes
description: Allied Domecq, the British beverage conglomerate, has discussed teaming up with Vin and Sprit, the Swedish company that owns Absolut vodka, to bid for the wine and spirits business of Seagram, people close to the talks said today.

title: Metulla Journal; It's Raining Not Rockets but Rocks: This Is Peace?
description: For those living in this community at the point where Israel narrows into a slim finger of territory jutting into southern Lebanon, there were many hardships during the 18 years when Israeli soldiers, confronting Palestinian guerrilla groups and heavily armed groups of Lebanese Islamic militants, occupied a deep buffer zone across the border.

title: Pollard's Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENDERGAST, KEVIN J.
description: PRENDERGAST-Kevin J. On September 9, 2000, after a long illness. Tax attorney, specializing in executive compensation. For most of his career, practiced law with the firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, where he was described by a partner as a person of emense integrity and ability. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Donations in his memory may be made to Washington University in support of lung transplant research through Randy Farmer, Medical Alumni & Development Programs, Washington University, Campus Box 8509, 4444 Forest Park Ave, Saint Louis, MO. 63108.

title: Verizon Awards Work To Burrell Agency
description: Verizon Communications, formerly Bell Atlantic, has named the Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, 49 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe S.A., to handle its brand introduction campaign. Spending was estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIALA, RUDOLPH J.
description: FIALA-Rudolph J. Of Pound Ridge, NY, on September 14. Beloved husband of the late Susan for 51 years. Loving father of Jennifer, Christopher, Pamela, Timothy and Geoffrey, and cherished grandfather of Sarah, Andrew, Peter, Robin, Wendy, Emily, Deborah, Colleen, Marina, Thomas and Maggie. Born January 25, 1922, in Berwyn, IL. Basketball star and debating champion of Pontiac High School, Pontiac, IL. Recipient of the Distinguished Flying Cross, six Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart as 1st Lieutenant and navigator of ''Miss Nadine,'' a B-17 in the 11th Bombardment Group of the 42nd Squadron of the 7th Air Force, completing more than 40 missions in the Pacific arena during WWII. Graduated Knox College, Galesburg, IL, 1946. Advertising career spanned four decades as award-winning copywriter and creative director, principally with Doyle Dane Bernbach and Lois Holland Calloway. A memorial service will be held at 1:30 PM, on Thursday, September 21, at the Pound Ridge Community Church in the Pound Ridge Hamlet. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Hiram Halle Memorial Library, Pound Ridge, NY 10576.

title: Rivals Battle Over Soft Money and Hard Ads
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, after leisurely strolling through two parades in the Bronx and on Long Island, yesterday repeated his promise to ban soft money from his Senate campaign if his opponent would do the same.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, GERALD R.
description: ROSENFELD-Gerald R. On September 16, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Brooke W. Rosenfeld. Loving father of Alexandra. Brother of Ernest and the late Mort. Also beloved by ten nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday at 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Let's Not Play 2, Indians Say of Makeup Plan
description: John Hart, the Cleveland general manager, spent some time on the telephone yesterday, asking major league officials why, considering a new scheduling development involving the Oakland Athletics, the Indians should have to play a makeup game as part of a day-night doubleheader next Monday. ''He's trying, but he's not making any headway,'' another Indians official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAHLMAN, HELEN
description: DAHLMAN-Helen. On September 15, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dudley. Loving mother of Jules and Lynn. Dear sister of Mignon Lehman. Grandmother of Karen, Alison, Adam, Steven and Paul. Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Nassau Budget Outlines Details of Job Cuts
description: There is the $11,000 laborer's job, the $30,162 position as bus driver for the elderly and the $73,825 slot for a rehabilitation counselor in the office of drug and alcohol addiction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SALLY
description: STERN-Sally. You were a wonderful friend to all of us and we will all miss you terribly. With much love, Renay and Leo, Jill and Gary and Lori and Richard

title: F.B.I. Is Under Scrutiny For Conduct in Lee Case
description: To critics of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Wen Ho Lee case, in which agents tracked the nuclear scientist for years and at times pressed him to confess, revived memories of the J. Edgar Hoover era when the F.B.I. was accused of intimidating and abusive tactics.

title: Princess Cruises Starts Review of Account
description: Princess Cruises, part of Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation, is beginning a closed review for an agency of record to handle its account, with billings estimated at $20 million.

title: Mother and Son Dead, American Puts Anger to Good Use
description: Dreams, even Olympic ones, come with a price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, LEONARD
description: MARCUS-Leonard. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Review/Fashion; Boldly Colored or Sedate, Men's Wear Loosens Up
description: No matter how comfortable the modern eye is supposed to be with the meagerly attired male form, no matter how many Calvin Klein ads and episodes of ''Baywatch'' it has registered, there's still something very peculiar about seeing a male model lope down a runway in swim trunks the size of a tennis shoe.

title: Change For Sake Of His Changeup
description: Orlando Hernandez is inventive by nature, but he still managed to surprise a few people with a new pitch in Saturday's complete-game victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: From Favorites, Drama and Some Doubts
description: For even the most promising young race horses, it is a long way to the Breeders' Cup (six weeks) and the Kentucky Derby (seven months). But it seemed even longer at Belmont Park yesterday for the trainers of the heavy favorites in the prime races for juveniles: Raging Fever in the Matron and City Zip in the Futurity.

title: Cleric Uses Weapon of Religion Against Iran's Rulers
description: Despite his turban and cloak, or perhaps because of it, Mohsen Kadivar is a very dangerous man for the Islamic Republic of Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERBERGER, EDWARD
description: WASSERBERGER-Edward. On September 17, 2000. Beloved father of Mark and Simon. Dear brother of Eve Finley and George Wasserberger. President Emeritus of Mark Cross Inc. Service Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, ETTIE
description: BRAVERMAN-Ettie. On September 16, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harris. Loving mother of Edward and Roslyn. Caring motherin-law of Myra. Sister of Samuel Steinberg and Ray Fennesey. Devoted grandmother of six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Her love and energy will be dearly missed by her family and friends.

title: Working Families, Going Without
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, DONALD NELSON
description: KING-Donald Nelson. Age 66. Of Mantoloking, NJ, passed away Thursday, September 14, in Darby, Montana. Donald was a graduate of Columbia University. He served as Managing Director for J. P. Morgan Investments, and Managing Director for Trust Company of West. He was a member of the Bay Head Yacht Club, a Korean War veteran and an avid fisherman. Surviving include his wife Patricia; daughters Christina McCarthy, Dorothy H. King and Karen P. Moran; granddaughter Katie Magee; mother Alfhild King; two brothers and one sister.

title: There's No Letdown as Giants Remain Upbeat and Unbeaten
description: The Giants are not nearly so confident to think they should win any game easily, so squeaking by the Chicago Bears today did not provide a relief as much as it did a boost to their egos.

title: Spotlight, As Always, Is On Sanders
description: LANDOVER, Md., Sept. 17 (AP)  Deion Sanders loves Monday nights. After a less than dazzling start with Washington, the player sometimes called Prime Time takes his position at center stage again in a renewal of the Redskins-Cowboys rivalry.

title: Bessies, Performance Awards, Honor Innovative Efforts
description: The 16th annual New York Dance and Performance Awards, familiarly known as the Bessies in honor of Bessie Schonberg, a noted teacher of dance composition, were given on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. This year's awards, presented by Dance Theater Workshop, celebrated both innovation and continuity.

title: What's More Exciting: Rockets or Revenue?
description: For his next act, Mark Burnett, television's hottest producer thanks to ''Survivor,'' wants to send an endurance-contest winner into outer space.

title: Working Families, Going Without
description: To the Editor:

title: Tested and Occasionally Tripped, Bush May Yet Rue a Mirror Crack'd
description: Now that voters have finally begun to pay close attention to the presidential race, many strategists say that Gov. George W. Bush has to be particularly careful not to lose control of what has long been his most potent advantage over Vice President Al Gore: his personal image.

title: Wrestler Wants To Look Ahead
description: Matt Lindland prefers to look ahead at his competition in the Olympic Greco-Roman wrestling tournament and not behind at the summer-long story that determined his eligibility for the United States team.

title: Miami Defense and Weather Thwart Ravens
description: If this is Pro Player Stadium in September, then the Miami Dolphins must be winners.

title: Dangerous Movies?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tragedy Of 'Butterfly,' Highlighted By Simplicity
description: The new season of the New York City Opera offers a veritable festival of productions by Mark Lamos, a theatrical director whose work for the operatic stage has yielded intermittent magic. By some reports that magic was scarce on opening night Tuesday, in Mr. Lamos's new staging of Donizetti's ''Roberto Devereux.'' But on Friday, the second evening, Mr. Lamos's still-fresh re-imagination of Puccini's overworked ''Madama Butterfly'' returned to the New York State Theater.

title: The Gore Ticket and Big Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HENRY
description: FRIEDMAN-Henry. The gentlest of men. On September 16, 2000. Captain U.S. Army, WWII, a graduate of City College, Mr. Friedman had maintained a CPA practice for over thirty-five years and was also Head Counselor at Surprise Lake Camp during the mid-1930s. Devoted husband of the late Doris; loving father of Carol Siegel, Peter and Mark; father-inlaw of Arthur Siegel and Joan Allen; dear brother of Herbert and sisters-in-law Sylvia and Evelyne; cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Jocelyn, Daniel and Sadie. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Olympic Powers Collide
description: China's Wei Pui, left, fought to get past Lorrie Fair of the United States yesterday in a preliminary round soccer game. The teams played to a 1-1 tie. Sydney 2000, Page S1.

title: Poison in Bottled Water? New Yorkers Are Thirsty and Unfazed
description: New Yorkers seem to have a warrior mentality even when it comes to contaminated water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERDONCIN, PETER
description: PERDONCIN-Peter. It is with great sorrow and loss that his friends and colleagues at Montefiore note the passing of Peter Perdoncin, who headed the Medical Center's construction team for over three decades. An outstanding leader, exemplary engineer, supportive colleague and great friend, Pete inspired all who had the good fortune to work with him. Forcefully but quietly, he guided the design and construction of all the modern facilities at Montefiore, from the smallest to the new Children's Hospital, now under construction. His tireless efforts to ensure the finest facilities for our patients set a standard by which all of us will continue to be measured. Above all, Pete will be remembered for his integrity, good humor and friendship. We will miss him, no one who worked alongside him will forget him. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his loving wife Irene, son Mark and daughter Lisa. Maurice E. LaBonne Vice President for Real Estate & Facility Development Charles Balancia Vice President for Facility Services Montefiore Medical Center

title: INSIDE
description: Hurricane Loses Steam

title: Asian-Americans Demanding Bias Inquiry in Scientist's Case
description: Leaders of Asian-American groups are planning to seize the opportunity of a long-scheduled meeting with White House officials in New York on Monday to express their outrage over the treatment of the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee and to press for a full inquiry on whether racism played a role in his investigation and prosecution.

title: The Gore Ticket And Big Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenmarkets: A Slice of Country in the City
description: There are 24 greenmarkets spread across the city, bringing produce, plants, baked goods and other products to residents starved for farm-fresh food. Here is a look at some of the better-known locations.

title: Article 2000091892781553545 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: In America; The Truth About Justice
description: Over the past 15 to 20 years there has been a tremendous shift in power in the criminal justice system from judges to prosecutors.

title: Freelance Consultants Tap Rich Services Niche
description: FRANKFURT  Until computers learn to fix themselves, Harry Scherbach will be one of the unsung heros of the new economy. His laidback, three-person business, which supports Macintosh users from a converted century-old bread factory in Frankfurt, has tapped into a boom niche for independent consultants who thrive in the shadow of the Internet.

title: Mrs. Cheney Criticizes a Gore Event
description: Lynne V. Cheney, the wife of the Republican vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, accused Vice President Al Gore of ''hypocrisy'' today for attending what she described as an ''X-rated'' fund-raiser in New York City last week after he had chided the entertainment industry for marketing inappropriate materials to children.

title: Tall Ship of Small Means Looks for a Winter Berth
description: OpSail 2000, the grand parade of tall ships, ended six weeks ago. But long after other ships have returned home, the ramshackle Ukrainian schooner Bat'kivshchyna remains in port here, awaiting a berth in dry dock for badly needed repairs and negotiating to spend the winter just up the Thames River in Norwich.

title: Fitting a Dream of Years Into 10 Short, Brutal Hours
description: For years, Lisa Lax had dreamed of the day she would produce the women's Olympic triathlon. That two-hour event made its Summer Games debut Saturday, and Lax's crew had 10 hours to turn a live race contested by 48 women and tracked by 45 cameras into a compelling prime-time tale cut into three major taped segments and narrated by Al Trautwig.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTAS, ATHENA
description: PETTAS-Athena. 9/18/73. Gone. All the boys and girls are gone now. Your Daughter

title: Mission Ends, and Shuttle Plans Return
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 17  The space shuttle Atlantis' astronauts closed the doors to the international space station today after accomplishing their scheduled chores and more.

title: Torre and Fans Try to Make the Most of an Awful Day at the Park
description: Yankee Stadium patrons graded on the curve yesterday, contrary to their notorious reputation. They saw the Indians pummel Denny Neagle and Randy Keisler for 10 runs before there was anybody out in the fourth inning, and when Craig Dingman struck out the first Cleveland batter he faced, fans stood to cheer, some with sarcasm, some in sincere appreciation.

title: U. N. Reassessing Safeguards After Official Killed in Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 18  The murder of a fourth United Nations refugee worker in less than two weeks is prompting the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to reassess how best to safeguard staff members worldwide who come to the aid of refugees trapped in the vortex of war, violence and chaos.

title: The Changing Olympics
description: Part of the lifetime pleasure of playing and following sports is the measuring of one's own athletic trajectory against a steadily shifting peak of performance. There is hardly a lunchtime basketball player or weekend golfer or early-morning jogger who does not quietly assess the effect of the years, for better or worse, on his or her game or condition. We look back at our best selves, but we also look to the athletes who redefine what a best self might mean -- to the individuals who virtually reinvent the games they play. Sports may seem like the pursuit of transcendence, but they are also the accepting of obsolescence. That is what the old saying -- records are meant to be broken -- means.

title: 2 Romanian Lifters Fail Their Drug Test
description: The International Olympic Committee's top anti-doping official said today that he was cautiously optimistic about a new resolve to catch athletes who are using illicit performance-enhancing substances.

title: Working Families, Going Without
description: To the Editor:

title: China Is Said to Rearrest Bishop Released for Clinton's '98 Visit
description: An 81-year-old Roman Catholic bishop in southern China, who spent a total of more than 30 years in prison for his loyalty to the Vatican, was rearrested last week, a Catholic foundation in the United States said today.

title: For Japanese, Gospel Music Sets Spirits A Bit Freer; They Flock to Harlem To Sing, and Feel God
description: As a Japanese Buddhist, Yuko Ichioka knows she has developed an odd passion. But she says she can't help herself; she loves to sing black gospel music.

title: Bustos Powers Americans to Victory
description: Crystl Bustos homered twice as the United States defeated Cuba, 3-0, today to extend its winning streak to 112 games.

title: Congo's War Triumphs Over Peace Accord
description: It takes nearly nine hours to get here from the next big town, in a boat that leaks its slow way through swampland and walls of jungle with few hints of human life. But then, there it is: a war rarely seen up close, and getting worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAY, BARBARA CLAAR
description: GALLAY-Barbara Claar. Devoted wife of Samuel Gallay and the late Morris Claar. Loving mother of Alice Claar and the late Sheldon. Adored grandmother of Nancy Hochman, Courtney Claar and Jamie Claar. Service Monday, 2PM, Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson. Contributions to the ALS Association of Greater New York, 116 John St, Suite 1304, NYC 10038, would be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You show me a kid who's not sneaking into R-rated movies, and I'll show you a failure in the making. The future C.E.O.'s of America are all sneaking into R-rated movies.''

description: E-COMMERCE REPORT

title: Microsoft Loses Key Strategist To Retirement
description: With the retirement last week of Paul Maritz, Microsoft lost a field general from the company's bitter computer wars of the 1990's.

title: Hollywood Insiders Give Thumbs-Down to Critics
description: While senators fumed about movie moguls who failed to show up for hearings in Washington last week, and shell-shocked studio executives kept their heads low and their lips locked in advance of a second round of hearings next week, many of those who work in the Hollywood trenches, actually making the movies, were beginning to chafe at the politicians' barrage.

title: Mets Should Forget a Year Ago
description: Well, here they go again, but is there any reason to think the ending will be any different this time? After all, a film buff can watch ''Casablanca'' over and over, and each time Ingrid Bergman will leave Humphrey Bogart at the airport.

title: A National Drunken Driving Standard
description: An important fight over highway safety is heating up on Capitol Hill. At issue is a sensible measure long championed by Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, to establish a uniform national standard for drunken driving. The measure, whose fate now rests with the House-Senate conference committee working on the transportation appropriations bill, would require states to lower their standards for drunken driving to a .08 blood alcohol concentration within three years or lose a portion of their federal highway money.

title: Winning Together By Pulling Together
description: Recall that third-quarter kickoff that whistled in the wind two Januarys ago in Mile High Stadium, the football that fluttered and fell in front of the Jets on that windy afternoon in the 1999 American Football Conference championship game, the one Denver recovered that helped turn a 10-7 Jets advantage into 16 consecutive Broncos points and a 23-10 Jets loss. From that point forward, we can easily acknowledge that most of these current Jets players and coaches have experienced a personal brand of torture. From that point forward -- and little did the Jets know it -- there would be tricky obstacles strewn their way that, collectively, could have swallowed them. Maybe should have swallowed them.

title: Pocket Hercules Finds No One Is Invincible
description: Naim Suleymanoglu is 33 years old, smokes 50 cigarettes daily for his inner peace and won the gold medal in weight lifting in the featherweight class in three consecutive Olympics.

title: Dangerous Movies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tycoon Takes to the Road With Media-vs.-Moscow Wars
description: Vladimir V. Gusinsky, the Russian media tycoon whose brief arrest in June on corruption charges put a harsh spotlight on the Russian government's blunt use of its powers against media critics, came to New York last week and urged journalists and politicians not to let the spotlight go out.

title: Lilly Off the Mark as Rematch With China Ends in a Tie
description: A year ago, Kristine Lilly saved the World Cup for the United States with her head and then helped to win it with her feet. But soccer is a mercurial game. Victory can seem like a yo-yo trick, presenting itself only to be yanked away.

title: A Tale of the Tape From the Days When It Was Still Micro Soft
description: As Microsoft celebrates its 25th anniversary this month, the company is unlikely to call attention to another formative event 25 years ago: the day someone stole Bill Gates's software.

description: FRASER-Glen, December 1970September 1999. Although you are no longer with us, you're forever in our hearts. Till we meet again, we love you, Jim, Liz and Gary

description: To the Editor:

title: Six Events That Show a Brutal Century Wasn't All Bad
description: ''A Force More Powerful,'' a new two-part PBS documentary, wants to clean up the nasty record the 20th century left behind. Yes, it was a brutal hundred years, marked by horrendous destruction. But the project's filmmakers (led by the writer, producer and director Steve York) point out that morality sometimes prevailed over evil without violence, that righteousness could flatten the enemy as effectively as a tank.

title: Kicking Unit Is Criticized
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel called the field-goal unit atrocious following the game, and he wasn't exaggerating. The Giants missed three field-goal attempts that could have turned a tight 14-7 victory into an easier afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIRRECA, JOHN A.
description: PIRRECA-John A. Age 65. Passed away Wednesday, September 13, 2000, at Odyssey Hospice in Las Vegas, NV. Born October 14, 1934, in the Bronx, NY. Mr. Pirreca was a resident of the Port Washington and Old Bethpage areas for 62 years. Mr. Pirreca was a Navy veteran. He is survived by his son John Pirreca of Northport, NY, and his companion Carole Fischer of Las Vegas, NV. A memorial service will be held at Palm Mortuary-Cheyenne, in Las Vegas, NV, on Saturday, September 16, 2000, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to Odyssey Health Care Inc., 4011 McLeod Dr., Las Vegas, NV 89121. Contact Palm Mortuary - Cheyenne at 702 464-8480 for further information.

title: Hurricane Huffs and Puffs And Then Blows Itself Down
description: Ragged Hurricane Gordon, never a particularly frightening storm to begin with, lost power as it crept toward Florida's gulf coast today and became more of a nuisance than a threat.

title: Mrs. Clinton Works Hard on Her Spontaneity
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton had just finished holding a news conference at an Upper West Side park in Manhattan the other morning and, with a glance at the rather large audience in front of her -- reporters, Secret Service agents, aides, even a few citizens who had found their way past the security ropes -- she burst forth with an invitation:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SOPHIE
description: DAVIS-Sophie. Beloved wife of Leonard Davis, died at home on September 16, 2000, in Palm Beach, FL. She was 74. Born Sophie Kesten in the Bronx, Sophie and her husband Leonard succsesfully founded the Colonial Penn Group in 1963. Sophie and Leonard became the most generous living donors in the history of CCNY. They funded its performing arts center as well as the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education. Sophie served as Trustee of the Norton Museum of Art. She and Leonard spearheaded the drive to build Palm Beach's first major performing arts center, the Kravis Center. The Davises founded the Regional Arts Foundation and Sophie served as its President for twenty years. Sophie was also involved with the Jewish Federation, the Jewish Community Center and Hebrew University. She was one of the founding members who built the Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC. Sophie is survived by her husband of fifty-four years; her two sons, Alan and Michael; and four grandchildren, Jaimee, Paul, Nettizanne and Nyracai Davis. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El in Palm Beach on September 19, at 11 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at CCNY.

title: History for Sale, Dents and All; Publishers Part With Vintage Prints, Thanks to Digitizing and Demand
description: ''Made for America (Part 1),'' the summer show at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo, included the work of photography giants like Margaret Bourke-White, Edward Steichen, Robert Capa, Edward Weston and Robert Frank. All the images were vintage prints from the Time Inc. picture collection, many taken for publication in Fortune or Life, and all were for sale at prices ranging from $1,500 to $65,000.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

description: FOR more than 40 years, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency has had the daunting assignment of making sure that no enemy  or, for that matter, any current friend  has access to tomorrow's technology faster than does the Defense Department.

title: Global Meeting Planned for Better Public Toilets
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 17  Relief may finally be on the way for one of life's most common minor horrors: the public restroom.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The White House expressed alarm today at the possibility that Congress might provide money to the states to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, as Gov. George W. Bush has proposed, and administration officials said such an approach was unworkable.

description: Representative Rick A. Lazio's Senate campaign has begun broadcasting this 30-second ad.

description: The last box from the move from Los Angeles had been unloaded only a day when the telephone rang in Garry Galley's rented home in Ottawa. On the other end was Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury, who asked: Want to come play in New York?

title: Sapiens and Ness to Merge
description: Sapiens International and closely held Ness Technologies, which both make software and provide services to help companies do business on the Internet, have agreed to merge, the companies said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARACH, FRIEDA
description: JARACH-Frieda. On September 16, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Mario. Survived by sons Dr. Alan and Richard. Mother-in-law of Gail and Maxine. Adored grandmother of Lawrence, Michele, Maura, David and Jennifer. Loving great-grandmother of Dexter. Services were held.

title: Metro Matters; It's Showtime On Financing Campaigns
description: TIME for a new installment in the ''Let's Get Real'' column series, aimed at clearing the political air.

title: Market Place; AT&T retreat, a spawning ground for big moves, faces depressed shares and possible restructuring.
description: IN recent years, many of the most important decisions at AT&T, the nation's biggest communications company, have taken shape during the board's annual retreat the third week of September.

title: 'Dr. Laura' Pulls In Weak Ratings and Ads
description: The marketers that did not buy commercial time on Dr. Laura Schlessinger's new syndicated daytime television show may want to thank the gay and lesbian activists who pressured them to bypass the show. The series so far seems to be as big a miss with viewers as it has been with advertisers.

title: Rafter Delights Home Team
description: SYDNEY Australia -- American Vince Spadea blew an overhead on set point, and that was the only break Australian Pat Rafter needed.

title: Fulmer Wins Games, but Not the Game
description: He has the highest winning percentage of any active football coach in Division I. He has a 28-12 record against ranked teams and has won a national title. Phillip Fulmer, in his ninth season as Tennessee coach, has lost only 15 games. But there he was once again shuffling to midfield, a heartbreaking 27-23 loss only seconds old, to shake the hand of the man whose team beat him -- Florida Coach Steve Spurrier.

title: The Right Strategy for Fox; Conservative Cable Channel Gains in Ratings War
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: China Troupe Overcomes, As Did Man Behind It
description: In 1968, at the height of China's Cultural Revolution, Deng Pufang, then a student of physics at Beijing University, fell, jumped or was pushed from a fourth-floor window after being savaged by Red Guards who had singled him out as the son of a ''capitalist roader.''

title: How a Sport Saved Itself
description: PENRITH Australia, Sept. 18 -- It is a relatively long journey here from downtown Sydney: about an hour in a car; about the same in a train and a big change in mood and sophistication. But for the whitewater canoeists and kayakers who competed for medals here today, any commute is better than what they were facing two years ago: no Olympic journey at all.

title: Greenlanders Wary of a New Role in U.S. Defenses
description: First, the French foreign minister jetted into this seaside capital, which currently has more humpback whales in the fjord (two) than stoplights (one). Then a knot of Washington officials, dressed in business suits and smiles, arrived for what one newsweekly here headlined in Danish as the American ''Charmoffensiv.''

title: Frustration Grows With Cost of Health Insurance
description: Eddie Williams, 30 years old, counts himself lucky to have a good job, making $17 an hour as a deliveryman for the Bowman Oil and Propane Company. He and his wife are careful about their budget, and so have been able to sock away some savings for their daughter, Tianna, 6, and their son, Kendan, 4. They were able to vacation in Southern California this summer and visit relatives in Nevada.

title: High Fashion Goes on Sale On the Web
description: In its September issue, Vogue magazine declared that the look of the moment was knee-length tweed coats. Starting today, Vogue's corporate parent will set out to show that the business of the moment is selling those coats, and other must-have fashions, on the Web.

title: Bucking the Swing-State Trend, Ohio Holding Steady, Polls Show
description: Pennsylvania and several other swing states may have shifted toward Vice President Al Gore in the presidential race in the last three weeks, but so far Ohio has more or less stayed put, if surveys of voters are to be believed.

title: Hollywood Insiders Chafing at Criticism
description: Studio executives have been staying largely silent before a second round of Senate hearings into violent films, video games and recordings. But many of those who work in Hollywood are beginning to chafe at the politicians' barrage.

title: A Timeless Morality Tale Cloaked in Politics
description: When an ambitious young senator who would soon be president first saw ''The Best Man'' 40 years ago, he was quick to point out to its author that the play's vision of politicians wasn't exactly authentic. ''You know,'' John F. Kennedy is reported to have said to Gore Vidal, ''in a campaign we don't have all that much time to talk about the meaning of it all.''

title: Mets Are Searching for Positive Sign After Disappointing Split With Expos
description: The Mets left for Atlanta tonight having proved nothing much in four games with the Montreal Expos. Twice, they punished the Expos by scoring 10 runs. Twice, they were mastered by a tough, young starter.

title: As Melville Told Marlene, the Muse Leads the Music
description: Artists are always invoking the muses and usually overlooking the goddess who (with the help of the ever-ready Zeus) gave birth to them. She was Mnemosyne, the goddess of memory, and she is having her day now. Never has art sought so many ways of remembering its past, and never have artists or audiences been exposed to so many pasts. (The Information Age doesn't just expand what we know; it restores to us long-buried knowledge.)

title: Big names at major agencies make moves, as rapid change continues on Madison Avenue.
description: SEVERAL well-known senior managers at major agencies are making moves -- some voluntarily, some not -- in shifts indicating the frenetic pace of change in the executive suites of the leading Madison Avenue shops.

title: Anti-Eviction Programs Pushed by City Hall Are in Disarray
description: The storefront office of Community Law Advocates, a group in the South Bronx that was established to keep poor families from being evicted into homelessness, has been shuttered since July, when state criminal investigators seized everything from its desktop computers to records on the center's welfare clients.

title: Two Americans Win Gold and Dutchman Denies Thorpe
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 18 -- Even on the victory stand, with a gold medal around his neck, the national anthem of the Netherlands playing and his country's flag being raised above the pool, Pieter van den Hoogenband shook his head as if he could not believe he had beaten the great Ian Thorpe.

title: Patents; Training ligaments and heart valves in the laboratory, so they perform well after transplants.
description: IN her laboratory, Gail Naughton grows body parts. She nurtures cells until they divide and grow into heart valves, blood vessels, ligaments and tendons that she says look like they ''would have grown in your own body.''

title: New Economy; A military agency spends billions on seemingly fantastic projects to ensure U.S. battlefield supremacy.

description: SHAPIRO-Roy. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving and devoted father of Lily Alexander, Amanda Pirot. Devoted stepfather of Lance and Frank (Mindy) Mayer. Cherished grandfather of Max, Stefanie, and Adam. Adored brother of Sunny Soloff and the late Armin Speer. Loyal friend to many. We are forever blessed by your love and kindness. Services were held.

description: JULY 28, 1990 Alberto Fujimori, a little-known agricultural engineer, defeats the novelist Mario Vargas Llosa to become president.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Footballs for Williams
description: PERCHED on the top shelf of his locker, the football had a strip of white tape with ''Kevin Williams #23'' across it. And now, after the Jets' free safety had changed into a yellow T-shirt and black warm-up pants after the 27-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills, he tossed that football to Mike Kensil, the Jets' director of operations.

title: Brash Newcomer Rolls Out Latest Incarnation of Details
description: It is wonderful to be the new gunslinger in town, young and unafraid to speak your mind. Take Daniel Peres, the 28-year-old editor in chief of Details magazine, which after a four-month hiatus and an overhaul will arrive on newsstands this week.

title: Douglas T. Jacobson, a Hero of Iwo Jima, Is Dead at 74
description: Douglas T. Jacobson, who received the Medal of Honor as a Marine private for single-handedly storming enemy positions on Iwo Jima, an action resulting in the deaths of 75 Japanese soldiers, died Aug. 20 at a hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla. He was 74 and lived in North Port, Fla.

title: More Patients in Hospice Care, But for Far Fewer Final Days
description: The number of Medicare patients receiving hospice care more than doubled in the last decade, but they are not getting the full value of the services because they often sign up for hospice benefits just a few days or weeks before they die, federal investigators said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNDELL, KERT
description: LUNDELL-Kert. The Board of Trustees and membership of Ensemble Studio Theatre mourn the loss of our great friend and Trustee, Kert Lundell. A distinguished designer and long-time supporter of new theatre and design talent, he will be sorely missed. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife Bretta, his son Eric and daughter, Kate. Curt Dempster, Artistic Director Daniel Selznick, Board Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, WILLIAM
description: ZIMMERMAN-William. Of North Palm Beach Florida, died September 9, 2000. He was 80. Survived by his sisters, Ida Rubin, Rose Zimmerman and Sarah Tepper, his three children, Stuart Zimmerman, Marc Zimmerman and Susan Chroman, and ten loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Mr Zimmerman rose from a modest background to become one of America's most successful retailers, founding closeout specialist Pic 'N' Save (now part of Consolidated Stores) in 1950 and managing it until his retirement in 1985. A great supporter of children's causes and entrepreneurial education, Mr Zimmerman and his foundation were significant contributors to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship. Memorial services to be held in Los Angeles Sunday September 24.

title: Old Ties to Serbia Still Bind Many in Montenegro
