title: Essay; 'America's Moderator'
description: In a Jim Borgman cartoon, Al Gore is pictured grabbing and passionately kissing George Bush as the debate moderator says, ''I know it worked for you at the convention, Mr. Gore, but traditionally debates begin with a handshake.''

title: Our Graying Budget Priorities
description: The presidential candidates and the voters are now happily engaged in an orgy of self-congratulation for finally touching the third rail of American politics, Social Security and Medicare. We are told that we are confronting the hard choices that others less courageous have been unwilling to make.

title: Everglades Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Addenda
description: Verizon Awards Work To Burrell Agency

title: Bush Campaign Turns Attention To Middle Class
description: Gov. George W. Bush said today that he was determined to convince middle-income voters that they would fare better under his proposals than under Vice President Al Gore's, and he vowed to spend the coming days making that case as emphatically as possible.

title: Japanese Halt American Softball Streak
description: SYDNEY Australia -- A team that had been invincible and a streak that had seemed unbreakable both hit a wall today as the United States softball team lost to Japan, 2-1, in a tense duel that played out over 11 innings in the Olympic Softball Stadium in Sydney, Australia.

title: The Wrong Methods
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucs' Johnson Now in View
description: It was just 30 minutes after their 27-14 victory over Buffalo, but it was not too early for the Jets to be peppered with questions about you-know-who.

title: Moving From New Jersey to the Ivy League, Wryly
description: JOE COLLEGE

title: Unity Is Not Enough
description: Kye Sun Hui of North Korea, the defending gold medalist in the 52-kilogram judo division, yesterday was supported by a large, surprising cheering squad -- a jet-load of South Koreans who were supporting national unity as well as Kye.

title: No Mountains to Conquer, So U.S. Chops Down Wall
description: Thirty minutes had passed since the American professional basketball players bedazzled in their Olympic debut, and the Chinese journalist had one last question for United States Coach Rudy Tomjanovich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, DONALD
description: WHYTE-Donald. The New York Philharmonic notes with grief and sadness the death of Donald Whyte, a deeply valued member of the Philharmonic's violin section since 1972. Mr. Whyte's early teachers were Alexander Whyte and Elman Lowe. Prior to joining the Orchestra, Mr. Whyte attended the University of Saskatchewan and Indiana University, where he studied with Josef Gingold. After joining the Philharmonic, he continued his studies with Ivan Galamian and became an active chamber musician, playing with the Gofriller Quartet and the Soho Ensemble. Mr. Whyte was an influential member of various Philharmonic orchestra committees, most recently serving as chairman of the Artistic Committee for several years. He also served as a Philharmonic representative to the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians and was a board member of the Music Assistance Fund, which aids young minority musicians. In addition, Donald Whyte was a successful heart transplant recipient. His love of music and dedication to the Orchestra and fellow musicians will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Noriko, and to his entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Executive Director

title: Chinese Finally Claim Team Gymnastics Gold
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 18 -- The last event of the night was unfolding when the usually stoic Chinese gymnasts suddenly tilted their heads to the rafters like dustbowl survivors welcoming the first raindrop.

title: U.N. Forsakes Effort to Curb Poppy Growth By Afghans
description: Frustrated by declining support from Western donors and the indifference of the ruling Taliban, the United Nations is winding down efforts to persuade farmers in Afghanistan, the world's largest producer of opium, to switch to alternative legal crops.

title: Store's Do-It-Yourself Way To Lower Its Power Costs
description: Faced with a doubling of his electricity costs this summer, an East Harlem supermarket owner found a creative way to try to remain in business. ''We're going to generate our own electricity,'' said Alfredo Rodriguez, 39, who owns the Associated Supermarket on East 116th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues.

title: NBC Is Doing Its Business With Style and Skill
description: SYDNEY Australia -- It's unfashionable to praise NBC at Olympic time. The network is scorned for showing the Olympics on tape, for chopping up events to serve its prime-time needs, for being as jingoistic as Georgie Jessel, for sacrificing action for weepy profiles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANCELLIERE, M.A.
description: CANCELLIERE - M.A. (Cancy). Loving and much loved husband. Always missed. Leah

title: In a Hand or a Coat of Arms, Six Hearts Are Distinctive
description: A leading bridge journalist, Herman De Wael of Belgium, noted an interesting fact when the European Championship was played in Villamoura, Portugal, in 1995. The coat of arms of that town has six hearts on each side, and since then he has been looking for a Villamoura hand. It must feature a 6-6 heart fit, and he finally found the deal shown in the diagram. It was played at the end of the qualifying stage of the world championships this month in Maastricht, the Netherlands.

title: Wolfe and Omnicom Make Acquisitions
description: Two agency companies are making acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, GEORGE E.
description: SANDS-George E. Died peacefully in his 100th year on September 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Marjorie U. Sands. Devoted stepfather of Charlotte Stadler and Julia Shubik. Grandfather to Claire Shubik, Daniel, Alex and David Stadler. Great-grandfather to Henry and Lily Stadler. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, September 19, 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Long Island Caddie Scholarship Fund c/o John Buckley, 15 Homestead Drive, Wheatley Heights, NY 11798 or to a charity of your choice.

title: People
description: * Maggie Williams was named president at Fenton Communications, Washington, succeeding David Fenton, who becomes chairman, a new post. Ms. Williams had most recently been consulting; before that she served as chief of staff to Hillary Rodham Clinton and assistant to the president.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Peacekeeping With Honor
description: The notion of strengthening and expanding United Nations peacekeeping forces to quell foreign conflicts is a fine idea. But as President Clinton and other world leaders work toward that goal in the wake of their recent summit meeting in New York, they will have to overcome a host of political, military and financial obstacles, not the least of which is determining the appropriate American role.

title: Singing in the H2O
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: As Ford Abandons Daewoo, South Korea Stocks Fall 8%
description: Unnerved by the Ford Motor Company's decision last week to abandon a takeover of the ailing Daewoo Motor Company, investors sold off South Korean securities today, pulling the stock market here to an 18-month low.

title: Classical Ballet, With Just a Hint of Modern Dance
description: Dance Theater of Harlem concluded its season at City Center on Sunday afternoon with a program that was shrewdly chosen to display the eclecticism of its repertory and the versatility of its dancers.

title: Cohen Warns Indonesians To Disband Timor Militias
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen warned Indonesia today that this troubled country could face severe diplomatic and economic reprisals if it did not disband militia groups accused of killings and of causing havoc in the divided island of Timor.

title: Day 3 of Los Angeles Transit Strike Is a Work-Day Headache for Poorest Angelenos
description: Compton Chester stood on Wilshire Boulevard, squinting in the morning sun, craning his neck for the bus that never came.

title: With a Little Help From Friends, Pandas Hang On
description: It is not just extensive habitat loss nor is it just poaching for its plush pelt that is doing in the giant panda. It is also evolution. Evolution simply has not done right by one of the world's most popular animals, now a critically endangered species with only about a thousand believed to exist in the wild.

title: Putting a Darwinian Spin on the Diesel Engine
description: To engineers, the silent machinery of a living cell is a humbling reminder of the crudeness of their own designs. Every cell is a tiny, elegant engine that converts chemical fuel to energy while emitting innocuous byproducts. By contrast, a diesel engine, the most efficient type of internal combustion engine, is a monument to waste.

title: Johnson Hopes to Better His 400 Meters Record
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- Recent workouts have indicated that Michael Johnson is fit enough to break his own world record in the 400 meters on Monday at the Sydney Games, the sprinter and his coach said today.

title: National News Briefs; Steelworkers and Kaiser Reach a Settlement
description: Kaiser Aluminum and the United Steelworkers of America yesterday settled one of the nation's longest labor disputes, a 20-month lockout of 2,900 workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLEN, ANTHONY P.
description: MALLEN-Anthony P. On September 18, 2000. Beloved son of the late Bernard J. and Elizabeth Mallen. Cherished brother of Edward of Andover, MA, and the late Sr. Angela Mallen and the late Maria Mallen Hefele. Dearest uncle of Jessica, Noel, Lauren, Michael and Ian. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Center for Special Studies at New York Presbyterian Hospital, 526 East 68th St., Box 566, New York City, NY 10021, or D.I.F.F.A., 150 West 26th Street, Suite 602, New York City, NY 10001.

title: Corrections
description: One map yesterday in a grouping with an article about the importance of Ohio in the presidential race showed erroneous calculations of population density by county. A corrected version appears today, on Page A20.

title: William Little, 58, Buyout Firm Founder, Dies
description: William Brian Little, an investment banker who was a founding partner of Forstmann Little, the New York leveraged-buyout firm, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 58 and maintained residences in Manhattan; Amagansett, N.Y.; and Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Thorpe Comes Up a Big Hand Short to a Flying Dutchman
description: Even on the victory stand, with a gold medal around his neck, the national anthem of the Netherlands playing and his country's flag being raised above the pool, Pieter van den Hoogenband shook his head as if he could not believe he had beaten the great Ian Thorpe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oil Prices Approach $37 On Iraq-Kuwait Tension

title: Charles Grodin, Praised
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIESER, REV. ELLWOOD E.
description: KIESER-Rev. Ellwood E., CSP. On September 16, 2000 in Los Angeles at age 71. Philadelphia, Pa-born, he was ordained a Paulist priest by Cardinal Spellman on 5/3/56 at Saint Paul the Apostle Church, New York City. The Hollywood priest/producer worked in film production for over forty years. Famous for promoting the gospel through television and films, he created and produced the weekly anthology series, ''Insight'', and originated the Humanitas awards for TV programs that stressed values. He was executive-producer of ''Romero,'' ''Entertaining Angels,'' and ''The Dorothy Day Story'' and dramatic specials ''We are the Children,'' and ''The Fourth Wiseman.'' There will be a wake service on Thursday, September 21 at 7:30 P.M. at Saint Paul the Apostle Church, Westwood, CA. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, September 22, at 7:30 P.M. at the same site. Burial service will be at Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City, CA on Saturday, 9/23/00 at 11 A.M. There will be a memorial service tribute at the Writer's Guild of America West in October (date to be announced). In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to The Human Family Educational and Cultural Institute (Humanitas Prize) 17575 Pacific Coast Hwy, Pacific Palisades, CA. 90272 and The Paulist Fathers, or Catholic Relief Services.

title: JAPANESE INSURANCE ALLIANCE
description: The Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, the Asahi Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Nichido Fire and Marine Insurance Company, agreed to form an alliance, a move that could create Japan's largest insurance group. The three companies have combined assets of 19 trillion yen ($177 billion). The alliance, which could give the companies a combined 25 percent share of Japan's insurance market, will help the companies compete in Japan and abroad, said Kokei Higuchi, Tokio Marine's president.

title: Politics and the Genome
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CB RICHARD ELLIS SERVICES, Los Angeles, the largest American commercial property broker, said its mortgage banking unit, Houston-based L. J. Melody Inc., bought Boston Mortgage Capital to expand into New England. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: JUNIPER AIMING ANEW AT CISCO
description: Juniper Networks, a leader in Internet switching technology, intends to announce a new line of products today, mainly routing switches that are smaller, less costly and more efficient than its previous models. In doing so, Juniper will expand its rivalry with Cisco Systems. Juniper has made its name by developing routers for the core of Internet networks that can handle flows of up to 10 billion digital bits a second. Cisco's fastest commercially available routers can handle flows of only 2.5 billion bits a second. Still, Cisco has remained the dominant provider of Internet switches that connect to paying customers rather than only to other big switches at a network's heart. Juniper's two new Internet switches are aimed squarely at that market. Seth Schiesel

title: Corrections
description: A front-page announcement on Saturday about the contents of the next day's Times Magazine misstated the timing of Men's Fashions of The Times. It will appear this Sunday.

title: Fugue for Five Pianos: Siblings Excel Contrapuntally; Two Brothers and Three Sisters Attend Juilliard at Once
description: Their suburban house, crammed with five grand pianos, sounds like a conservatory. Shelves in the den are lined with plaques and trophies from music competitions. So many of them attend the Juilliard School that their teachers have trouble keeping them straight.

title: Nutrition: When Lead Supplements a Supplement
description: Some people who take calcium supplements may be getting more than they bargained for: small amounts of lead.

title: Hartford's Costs Are Soaring For Workers' Eye Operations
description: For officials holding the purse strings in this financially strapped city, the numbers are cause for concern: in the last four years, 415 Hartford city employees have undergone cosmetic laser eye surgery, a procedure fully covered by their generous union-negotiated health plans, at a cost of $1.4 million, records show.

title: Even Without His Jersey, It's Old No. 11
description: There was no fanfare, no No. 11 stitched onto his back. Mark Messier was wearing no number at all.

title: SYDNEY 2000: NOTEBOOK -- WATER POLO; Australians Edge Americans
description: The last chance slid just beyond Coralie Simmons's fingers this morning as the United States lost, 7-6, to Australia in the qualifying round.

title: Japanese End U.S. Softball Streak on Two Errors by Richardson
description: A team that had been invincible and a streak that had seemed unbreakable both hit a wall today as the United States softball team lost to Japan, 2-1, in a tense duel that played out over 11 innings in the Olympic Softball Stadium in Sydney, Australia.

title: Bush Says Plan on Taxes Would Aid 2-Job Parents
description: Gov. George W. Bush began his bid today to gain the allegiance of the middle class, arguing that his tax-cut plan would relieve the pressure on parents who were forced to hold more than one job to make ends meet.

title: Oil Prices Hit New 10-Year High on Fear of Persian Gulf Strife
description: Oil prices surged yesterday to their highest levels in a decade, on fears that rising tensions between Iraq and Kuwait would disrupt the flow of crude oil from the Persian Gulf at a time when petroleum supplies around the world are extremely tight.

title: Movie Violence: Too Much Ado?
description: To the Editor:

title: Idling With Gambling, and Taking Stock
description: NOW that his rambling days are over at least on WOR-AM, where he followed his father and grandfather beneath the ''on the air'' sign -- John R. Gambling has more than enough time to chat while sitting on the deck of his home here. No more worrying about finishing a sentence in less than a minute. No more cutting himself off at 9 a.m. sharp. But Mr. Gambling's voice sounds the same as always, even without a microphone.

title: Senates Vote on China Trade Reflects a Changing Reality
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate's overwhelming vote today to give permanent trade benefits to China ended a decade-long clash between America's global economic interests and the notion that the United States could use the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Beijing's behavior.

title: Colon Turns The Yankees Into 1-Hit Wonders
description: The night was calm and 70 degrees, nothing like October, and at the outset, offered no indication of the drama about to brew in the Bronx. The Yankees were anxiously peering past the game toward the postseason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKINS, FRANCES MARY ZOECKLER
description: AKINS-Frances Mary Zoeckler. Died September 17, 2000, peacefully of natural causes. Born October 31, 1916, she was a champion swimmer and diver from the University of Iowa where she was instrumental in developing the butterfly kick for the Olympic Games. She was a pioneer in social welfare work reaching out to countless families in the Midwest. She resided in California from 1952 until 1998 where she was an accomplished couturier. Mrs. Akins is survived by her daughter and sonin-law Dr. Bruce and Sarah Charash, and ''Cap''; her son Lewis Akins; her brother and sister-inlaw General and Mrs. John L. Zoeckler; her sister and brother-inlaw Mr. and Mrs. L.G. Chrysler; her grandsons Michael and David Akins; and her beloved nieces and nephews. No services and no flowers please. Contributions can be made to the P.E.O. Home or to the American Red Cross. She was the embodiment of grace and beauty.

title: Medical Fun Lost, Alas, In a Shuffle
description: Let a doctor of a certain age talk long enough and you're bound to hear the gloomy pronouncement that medicine just isn't as much fun as it used to be.

title: Faulty Assumptions Led Bush to Err on Debates
description: When Gov. George W. Bush initially announced that he wanted to take part in only one of the three debates proposed by the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates and two others on individual television networks, he and his senior aides made two central assumptions.

title: A World Champion Is Thrown For a Loss
description: Jimmy Pedro had lost his chance for an Olympic medal half an hour before, but the crushing finality did not hit until now. Pedro was doing an interview when the Italian national anthem began to play, and a huge screen showed a tearful Giuseppe Maddaloni stepping forward to accept the gold medal in judo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLENATHEN, WILLIAM MER RICK
description: MacLENATHEN - William Mer rick. Of Danbury, CT and Mt. Sinai NY died September 18, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Carol Mansfield MacLenathen and his sister, Dr. Elizabeth James of Brooklyn. Calling at Tomlinson Homestead, 336 Main St, Danbury CT, Wednesday, 7-8:30 PM, services Thursday 11 AM at Central Christian Church, West Street, Danbury, CT.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; The Wonder of a Simple Gesture
description: IT wasn't the first time Esther Kim had given her hand to Kay Poe in a moment of urgent need. Eleven years of friendship, of virtual sisterhood, began with that very gesture, with a touching demonstration of compassion.

title: Chirps, Crackles and Pops at an Exhibition
description: Three years ago, Jack Weisberg, a sound engineer who had worked for 25 years designing sound systems for theaters, stadiums, studios and even boats, walked into a shell of a building at 173 Franklin Street in TriBeCa and had a vision. The four-story structure, once a firehouse, had been abandoned for years. The roof was patchy and leaking. There was no plumbing or heating system. It was a wreck.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN TO BUY STERLING SOFTWARE
description: Northrop Grumman, a leading military contractor, agreed to buy Sterling Software from Computer Associates International for $150 million to offer more services to the United States government. Sterling's Federal Systems Group sells information technology services to intelligence, military, aviation, and space agencies. Northrop Grumman said it would integrate the group with its Logicon unit, based in Herndon, Va. Federal Systems, based in McLean, Va., had 1999 revenue of $159 million. Shares of Northrop Grumman, based in Los Angeles, fell 62.5 cents, to $80.6875.

title: Correction: Ohio Population
description: One map yesterday in a grouping with an article about the importance of Ohio in the presidential race showed erroneous calculations of population density by county. Here is a corrected version.

title: Neither Good nor Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, BARBARA B.
description: CHASE-Barbara B. (Buttimer). Age 83, of Marblehead, MA, died peacefully Sunday, September 17, 2000 in Salem, MA. Wife of the late Howard W. Burns, and the late John P. Chase. Survived by a son, Howard W. Burns, Jr., and his wife, Karen A. Murdock, of Cedar Grove, N.J., and a daughter, Nancy Mae Hurley, and her husband, Donald Hurley, Jr., of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and three grandchildren. Memorial remembrances may be sent to the Dana-Farber Jimmy Fund, 1309 Beacon St., Brookline, MA. 02446, or to the Star of the Sea Church, 85 Atlantic Avenue, Marblehead, MA. 01945.

title: Article 2000091991981451786 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Ford and Another Tire Maker Facing New S.U.V. Problems
description: Even as Firestone and Ford struggle to recall millions of defective tires on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, the Ford Motor Company and another tire maker, Continental A.G., are preparing to replace another brand of tire on 40,000 Lincoln Navigator full-size sport utility vehicles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLFSON, SUSAN
description: WOOLFSON-Susan. Passed away August 17, 2000. A memorial service will be held on September 23, at 2 PM, at the First Unitarian Church on Pierrepont St at Monroe Place, in Brooklyn Heights.

title: U.S. Investigating Possible Jail Threats to Torricelli Contributor
description: On a Friday afternoon in December, F.B.I. agents arrested one of the Democratic Party's most generous contributors as he picked up his Mercedes from a garage in suburban New Jersey. Within hours, the man was locked in a nearby jail, charged with making illegal donations to Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY, N.Y.

title: SULZER TO SELL INDUSTRIAL UNITS
description: Sulzer A.G., which helped develop diesel engines more than a century ago, said it would sell most of its industrial units and would focus on medical devices to lift sagging profit. The company's shares fell 8.5 percent. The businesses for sale, which account for two-thirds of the company's revenue, include a maker of oil pumps and textile machines. Sulzer said that it would concentrate on its medical technology unit, Sulzer Medica A.G., and that it planned to make acquisitions in orthopedics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, PETER
description: BROWN-Peter. Delaire Country Club announces with deep regret the passing of their esteemed member, Peter Brown and extend their sincerest sympathy to his wife, Dorothy and his beloved family. Mal Levenson, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, DONALD
description: WHYTE-Donald. A memorial service celebrating the life of Donald Whyte will be held in the auditorium of the New York Society of Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, Friday, Sept. 22, 2000 at 5 PM. Contributions can be made in the memory of Donald Whyte to Music Assistance Fund, c/o American Symphony Orchestra League, 33 W. 60th St, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10023 or A Gift Of Life For Heart Transplant Program, P.O. Box 49, Madison Square Station, NYC 10159.

title: Braves Continue Turner Field Domination of Mets
description: ATLANTA -- Javy Lopez tripled and singled during a season-high seven-run second inning and the Atlanta Braves once again beat the New York Mets at Turner Field, 12-4 Tuesday night.

title: Police See No Pattern In Water Complaints
description: The number of complaints about possible contamination in bottled water rose to 45 yesterday, but investigators said there was no evidence that they were linked or that there had been widespread tampering.

title: Experts to Pepper Seas for Clues to Climate and Weather
description: Next month, a research ship will drop six instrument-laden yellow cylinders into the Pacific Ocean west of Peru, opening the initial phase of Argo, an international project aimed at illuminating one of the sea's best-kept secrets -- how the deep circulation of cold and warm water influences long-term climate and short-term weather.

title: Fox Sports Is a Sideline Viewer in Olympic Games
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- Five years ago, Fox Sports thought it had a chance of winning the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics. The attraction was more than just about showing a prestigious event for 17 days. It was about Rupert Murdoch televising the Olympics from his native country to his adopted nation.

title: Book Maps a Nation's Spurts of Clean Living
description: In the fall of 1977 the American Cancer Society organized the first national ''Great American Smokeout,'' urging smokers to quit for a day. Within five years, Jerry Falwell founded the Moral Majority and Jane Fonda sold millions of aerobics videos. Dr. Ruth Clifford Engs, a professor of applied health science at Indiana University in Bloomington sees a connection.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCARDLE, JOAN F.
description: McARDLE-Joan F. On September 17, 2000. Beloved daughter of James Joseph and Mary G. McArdle. Loving sister of the late Mary Ruth, James J., Richard W., Sheila Byrons and Vincent. Also survived by twenty-four nieces and nephews and thirty-three great-nieces and nephews. Retired President of McCarthy and Associates. Reposing at Dennis S. O'Connor Inc, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Genevieve's Church, Wednesday, at 10 AM. Interment, St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Americans Advance Into Soccer Quarterfinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 19 -- There is no such thing as a golden boy in sports. Too many bottles of peroxide have been dumped on too many athletes' heads.

title: A Flawed Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Judoka Surprises Field
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Makoto Takimoto of Japan surprised the field and won the gold medal in men's 81-kilogram judo Tuesday night.

title: Shadow of Auschwitz
description: To the Editor:

title: Television campaigns are creating some controversy during the Summer Games.
description: THE presentation of the Summer Olympics by NBC is making waves on Madison Avenue as well as in Australian pools as the network accepts a commercial it had rejected before the Games and pulls a second spot it had accepted pending viewer reaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBS, LINDA
description: GIBBS-Linda. 47, on September 10, 2000. Born in Dodge Center, MN. She moved to NYC in 1981, where she worked as a bookkeeper and singer. She is survived by her devoted husband Patrick McKearn, her loving siblings, Raymond, Richard, Darlene, Phyllis and Ron, her extended family and many dear friends. Memorial service on September 20, 4-8PM at St Mark's Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th St, NY, NY 10003.

title: Judge Warns Teachers in Buffalo Strike
description: A state judge warned officers of the Buffalo teachers' union yesterday that they would face trial on contempt charges if they failed to assure him that teachers would keep working while a state mediator developed a plan to reconcile the two sides of this month's teacher strike.

title: Letters: Politics and the Genome
description: To the Editor: The proposal that the ultimate meaning of the human genome will be fought out in the arenas of art and culture ignores the growing political battle and debate over the application of biotechnology to the food supply ("In Wake of Genetic Revolution, Questions About Its Meaning," Sept. 12).

title: Teaching the Gringos to Follow the Beat in Love and Desire
description: There is a type of picture postcard that vacationers in tropical resorts love to send, especially to friends in colder climes. The colors in the landscapes are brightened to the point of luridness; the people shown always look happy, sexy and silly. Exuding warmth and giddiness, these kitschy images usually do just what they're supposed to do: they make the postcards' recipients smile despite themselves.

title: CANADA TRADE SETBACKS
description: The World Trade Organization dealt Canada two losses, with a ruling against the country's handling of certain patents and another ruling in favor of France's ban of Canadian building-product exports containing asbestos. A W.T.O. panel upheld an earlier ruling that a Canadian law limiting some patent protection to 17 years, instead of 20, violated global trade rules. The decision primarily affects pharmaceutical patents. In the asbestos case, the W.T.O. published the official ruling allowing France's ban, even though such prohibitions are usually not permitted, on grounds it was justified by exceptions for protecting human health. Elizabeth Olson

title: Article 2000091991744995491 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: SPECIALTY FOODS IS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Specialty Foods Corporation, a leading maker of cookies, filed for bankruptcy protection. Officials of the company, a unit of GWI Inc., did not list assets and liabilities in its Chapter 11 petition. In an August filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company listed $303.9 million in assets and $799.6 million in debts. Much of that debt is tied to a $1.1 billion leveraged buyout of eight food companies by Robert M. Bass, the Texas billionaire, that led to the formation of Specialty Foods in 1993, said Lisa Gaffney, a bond analyst at Deutsche Bank in New York.

title: Paula Yates, 40, British Television Host and Rock-Scene Celebrity
description: Paula Yates, a British television personality known for her outrageously flirtatious interviewing style and for her relationships with the rock stars Bob Geldof and Michael Hutchence, was found dead at home here on Sunday. She was 40.

title: Judge Says Texas Can't Act On H.M.O. Doctor's Ruling
description: A federal judge has ruled that Texas regulators cannot discipline a medical director at UnitedHealthcare, one of the nation's largest health insurers, for denying treatment to a boy whose doctor had said the treatment was medically necessary.

title: An Olympic Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys Fight Before and During Game
description: The Dallas Cowboys did not wait until the actual game to beat up on the Washington Redskins, the best team money thus far cannot buy. While both teams were headed to the locker room after pregame warm-ups, a group of Cowboys shoved several Redskins, and a full-fledged scrum broke out. There was pushing, the grabbing of face masks, and other naughty acts.

title: To Tap the Wisdom Of Veteran Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Deep Peril for Deep-Sea Corals
description: For nine miles along a submerged ridge, the corals rise in lumpy hillocks that spread out 100 yards or more, resembling heaped scoops of rainbow sherbet and Neapolitan ice cream. The mounds, some 100 feet tall, sprout delicate treelike gorgonians that sift currents for a plankton meal. Fish, worms and other creatures dart or crawl in every crevice.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK BUCHANAN -- Lansing and Warren, Mich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, WILLIAM F.
description: BERRY-William F. The board of directors and officers of United Rentals, Inc. announce with great sadness that William F. Berry, president and a director, has died following a courageous battle with cancer. He was 48 years old and had been on medical leave since February 1999. He spent more than 30 years in the equipment rental industry including as president, director and chief executive officer of U.S. Rentals, Inc. before its merger with United Rentals in September 1998. Our industry has lost an outstanding business leader as well as an individual with tremendous honesty and integrity. Bill always kept his eye on the human side of the business, and his contributions to the success of United Rentals were immeasurable. He was an outstanding role model for people in the industry and understood that a business can succeed only when its employees are treated with respect and dignity. We will miss him deeply, and on behalf of all of our employees, extend our profound sympathies to his wife, Susan, and their children, Scott, Ann and David. United Rentals, Inc.

title: For Old Liberty, a New Guard
description: The New York Liberty, a team deemed too old to seriously contend for the Women's National Basketball Association title this past season, continues to get younger by the day.

title: Clicking Outside the Box
description: THE clock in the dimly lighted control room flashes 20:00. J. R. Gant, the director, nods, an assistant pushes some buttons and the image of Regis Philbin flashes on a bank of monitors on the wall as another episode of "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" begins.

title: Hijacked Cuban Plane Crashes Off the Florida Keys
description: Ahijacked Cuban plane with perhaps 18 people aboard crashed in international waters off the Florida Keys this morning, and Cuba asked for help in searching for survivors, United States officials said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Euro Slides, So Do Earnings Across the U.S.
description: The beleaguered euro continued its relentless decline yesterday as the impact of that currency's weakness spread across the American corporate landscape, cutting into sales and profits.

description: TORONTO -- Even with David Wells sidelined, the New York Yankees couldn't do much against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Shrugging Off Atlanta's Edge
description: The Atlanta Braves are the team the Mets talked about after the breathless end to last season, the team they discussed at the hopeful start of this season and the team that has stayed above them and on their minds during this familiar season. Actually, the Braves have hovered over the Mets, tweaking them here and teasing them there, for the last decade.

title: Whitewater Proves It's No White Elephant
description: The journey here from downtown Sydney is relatively long: about an hour in a car, about the same in a train, and a big change in mood and sophistication. But for the whitewater canoeists and kayakers who competed for medals here today, any commute is better than what they were facing two years ago: no Olympic journey at all.

title: Job Growth Sets a Record In the Region
description: Private employment and job creation in the New York region hit an all-time high in 1999, surpassing the national rate of job growth for the first time in nearly two decades, according to an annual economic study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: DRESDNER BANK BUYING WASSERSTEIN, PERELLA
description: Dresdner Bank agreed to buy Wasserstein, Perella & Company for $1.56 billion, turning to the 12-year-old merger advisory firm to bolster its investment-banking business after two failed mergers at home. The bank, based in Frankfurt, will pay $1.37 billion in stock and set aside $190 million to retain key members of the firm's staff, which is majority-owned by Bruce Wasserstein, one of the stars of the buyout industry in the 1980's. Mr. Wasserstein will be executive chairman of the investment bank, which will be renamed Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, the company said. Wasserstein has offices in 12 cities and a staff of about 600.

title: No Technology Funds for Poor Schools
description: Anew study suggests that the nation's smallest and poorest schools are unable to take advantage of the federal funding discounts that have helped to link 95 percent of the country's schools to the Internet.

title: Fitness Gap Is America's Recipe for Fat Youth
description: Two distressing facts about the nation's youth bode ill for their future well-being: American children today are fatter than ever and less fit than they were in the 1960's, when John F. Kennedy established the President's Council on Physical Fitness. The fitness bug that bit many adults has not carried over to the younger generation.

title: Islanders See Daylight Down the Road
description: For the first time in years, the Islanders can realistically talk about making the playoffs without eliciting giggles.

title: Kidney Cancer Experiment Appears Promising
description: To John Sirmans, the CT scan that doctors showed him last December looked like a pair of socks full of golf balls.

Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to The Center for Advanced Holocaust Studies, U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raul Wallenberg Place S.W., Washington, DC 20024.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

Captain U.S. Army, WWII, a graduate of City College, Mr. Friedman had maintained a CPA practice for over thirty-five years and was also Head Counselor at Surprise Lake Camp during the mid-1930s. Devoted husband of the late Doris; loving father of Carol Siegel, Peter and Mark; father-inlaw of Arthur Siegel and Joan Allen; dear brother of Herbert and sisters-in-law Sylvia and Evelyne; cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Jocelyn, Daniel and Sadie. title: Cheney Finds That Bush Plan For Public Schools Hits Nerves

title: A Ban on Assisted Suicide
description: The Senate will soon vote on a bill making it a federal crime to prescribe drugs to assist a patient's suicide. Any doctors convicted would serve a mandatory 20 years in prison. The House approved the bill, known as the Pain Relief Promotion Act, last year. President Clinton should veto the bill if the Senate passes it.

title: The Shadowy Politics of Peru
description: After a wave of mass street demonstrations and diplomatic protests failed to persuade Alberto Fujimori to call new presidential elections in Peru, palace intrigue has apparently caused his fall. The manner of Mr. Fujimori's demise is fitting, for the aide who helped keep him in power -- Vladimiro Montesinos, the chief of Peru's intelligence police -- seems to have played a central if unintended role in the president's decision to call new elections and renounce his own candidacy. This happened over the weekend after a Peruvian television channel broadcast a videotape that apparently showed Mr. Montesinos bribing a member of Parliament.

She lived for many years in Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Gifts in lieu of flowers, may be sent to St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Coral Gables, Florida.

title: China Trade Vote Roll Call
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Following is the 83-to-15 roll call vote by which the Senate supported extending permanent normal trade relations to China. On this vote, a "yes" vote was a vote to approve permanent trade and a "no" vote was a vote to reject it. Thirty-seven Democrats and 46 Republicans voted yes. Seven Democrats and eight Republicans voted no. Two Democrats did not vote.

description: The rivalry between the country's two largest bookstore chains is popping up in Paramus, N.J., with the Borders Group, the No. 2 bookseller, soon to open a superstore that could draw customers from two nearby Barnes & Noble superstores.

Avon, which sells mainly through door-to-door sales representatives, will sell a new line of cosmetics at Sears, Roebuck and at J. C. Penney in 2001, said Victor Beaudet, a spokesman. The stores will not sell Avon's current products.

title: Bomb Kills 16, Injures 80 in Pakistan Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- A powerful bomb placed in a crate of grapes ripped through a crowded market Tuesday morning, killing 16 people and wounding more than 80 in Pakistan's capital, police said. The blast was the deadliest of 40 bombings that have rocked Pakistani cities this year, and the government has blamed archrival India for many of the previous attacks. Pakistan's military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf condemned Tuesday's ``dastardly act of terrorism,'' but did not place blame. The explosion, the first in Islamabad this year, occurred while workers were unloading the crates from a truck, witnesses said. The blast triggered a stampede of workers and shoppers from the city's largest fruit and vegetable market. ``I heard the explosion and saw fruit flying in the air,'' said Hasan Khan, a shop owner who was just 20 yards from the blast. ``People started running and screaming. We pulled down the shutters on our shop and left.'' No group immediately claimed responsibility, and police were investigating. The truck arrived from Kurram Agency in Pakistan's northwestern tribal region bordering Afghanistan, police and witnesses said. The vegetable market is located on the city's outskirts in a relatively poor neighborhood. Many of the victims were Afghan refugees who work unloading trucks. Pakistan has been plagued by political violence, including periodic bomb blasts, for years. However, since Musharraf seized power last October, ousting an elected civilian government, overall political unrest has declined. And Islamabad has traditionally been calm even when other Pakistani cities were aflame.

title: Washing Up Is Down, Study Shows
description: Was it the guy fiddling with his trouser button while carrying a briefcase, shopping bag and satchel as he left the men's room at Grand Central Terminal yesterday? Or the man who exited with an open can of diet soda? Circumstantial evidence would seem to exonerate the fellow who hurried out, wringing a paper towel.

A child who complained that water made him sick was described by his parents as having ''a fertile imagination.'' In a third incident, a Brooklyn woman who complained of a sore throat after drinking Poland Spring was found to have a cold sore in her mouth.

title: Brazil's Port For Slaves Now Sings Of Freedom

Ms. Mercury has made herself the pop ambassador of Salvador, the capital of Bahia, Brazil. At the Roxy she praised her hometown in song after song and danced herself into a sweat to bring the exhilaration of Bahian carnival into a New York club.

description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 -- Israel canceled a scheduled meeting with Palestinian negotiators today, raising concerns that the fragile peace effort had reached another potential breaking point, but by day's end it had arranged another meeting for Wednesday.

title: Fidelity With Country Twang and Disco
description: Al and Tipper Gore's big kiss at the Democratic National Convention isn't the latest public display of affection by a well-known couple from Tennessee. They're being outdone by Tim McGraw and Faith Hill, the married, multimillion-selling pop-country singers whose shared tour came to Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. Each sang an hourlong solo set; then, after a video about their marriage and children, they returned to share duets and clinches. Their image of lusty fidelity, translated into songs, is just what suburban America -- or at least the program directors of country radio stations -- wants to hear.

The most compelling was John Taras's version of ''Firebird,'' for which he used Stravinsky's revised ''Firebird'' Suite of 1945 rather than the original, longer score of 1910. Yet all of the story is there. Transplanting the action from Russia to a lush tropical forest designed by Geoffrey Holder, Mr. Taras makes events move along excitingly.

title: Dominant U.S. Men Win Again, but Lose Fans
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 19 - Bill Gates paid the United States men's basketball team a visit in their locker room tonight, moments after another nettlesome competitor tried to toy with their global monopoly. The world's richest man did not commiserate with the American multi-millionaires over high tax brackets or being trapped in a Melbourne hotel by protesters of the World Economic Forum last week. But with all these uppity foreign opponents grabbing at their jerseys and making them come across as bullies when the superior Americans respond, the kinship is natural. ``These guys don't even ask for autographs anymore,'' Gary Payton lamented after Italy begrudgingly went down, 93-61. World domination is clearly beginning to wear on the United States men, who won the game but hardly won over the crowd of 8,368 at the Dome in Olympic Park. Yes, Vince Carter threw down a tremendous, alley-oop dunk in the first half that had the building in a state of disbelief. And with 22 points off the fastbreak, they entertained everyone. But the masses jeered in the second half when Carter and the feisty Italian guard Allesandro Abbio grabbed and held each other until Carter planted a forearm in his throat and knocked him down. Miffed at Italy's defiance or not, coach Rudy Tomjanovich of the United States quickly sicced a full-court press on the Italians with less than 9 minutes left. The score at the time: 78-46. Team USA apparently feels it does not merely have to win; it must win so convincingly that not a single soul comes away with the notion that America was ever in trouble. ``There are good international players,'' Tomjanovich began matter-of-factly, ``but the other countries don't have 12 of them on the same team.'' There is an ornery resilience creeping into international play, though. You can see it with each game. Whether they have been watching Heat-Knicks playoff contests on tape is unclear, but somewhere Italy and the other nations are beginning to learn the art of the well-placed elbow in the small of the back. From the opening tip, when Italy's best player, Gregor Fucka, caught Alonzo Mourning with a open hand to the face, the Italians showed none of the great respect afforded other international teams comprised of N.B.A. players. Payton, Carter and Kevin Garnett took the physical challenge to heart, going at their opponents hard. It was not uncommon to see the 7-foot Garnett bodying up his man near halfcourt, trying any tactic to take away the ball. The Minnesota Timberwolves All-Star afterward bristled at one reporter's suggestion that the Americans should begin sending college players again to make it fair. ``It's like fighting,'' Garnett said. ``I get my five, you get your five from the neighborhood. I'm going to try and find the grimiest, dirtiest cats I can.'' And whether it plays or not back home, that is how the gold-medal pursuit is apparently going to go. With three preliminary games left, the U.S. men moved to 2-0 in Group A. Carter had 13 points, Mourning added 12 points and six blocked shots and Jason Kidd contributed 7 assists. In the first half, Carter rose for an alley-oop pass from Garnett on the left side of the rim. The ball was out of his grasp, so he waited for it to come off the backboard before slamming it through for the cameras. Even Abbio was impressed, despite the forearm in the throat. ``A wonderful personality,'' he said through a translator. ``He is a special player.''

title: Americans Lucky in Losses
description: SYDNEY Australia -- They call Americans Rob Heidger and Kevin Wong the ``lucky losers'' of the Olympic men's beach volleyball competition, and in this case, the label has real resonance.

title: White House, in Study, Assails G.O.P. Prescription Drug Plan
description: The White House expressed alarm today at the possibility that Congress might provide money to the states to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, as Gov. George W. Bush has proposed. Administration officials said such an approach was unworkable.

title: A Museum Fountain You Can Touch
description: New York City has fountains by the hundreds. Some are modern, and some antiquated; some have water that gushes, while others spray and sprinkle. But however hot the afternoon, however tempting the sight of the cool, flowing water, do not even think of getting wet, as touching the water is forbidden at nearly every fountain in the city.

title: Mr. Bush's New Strategy
description: Gov. George W. Bush's task for the next week or so is simple. He has to get his arrhythmic campaign back on a steady beat before he gets typecast as a Republican version of Michael Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988. For a long time, Mr. Bush counted on his personality and his promise to restore ''honor and dignity'' to undermine public regard for Vice President Al Gore. But now that he is behind, Mr. Bush plans to battle on issues outlined in his new ''Blueprint for the Middle Class,'' such as his proposed tax cuts, education reforms and plans to overhaul Medicare and Social Security. This may well be the right strategy, but it will not be an easy one. Not only is this Mr. Gore's preferred terrain, but on most of these subjects, polls show that voters favor Mr. Gore.

title: How People See Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Violence: Too Much Ado?
description: To the Editor:

title: Free to Be in My Home Land
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Cathy Freeman was wonderfully poetic yesterday afternoon as she described the feeling of the final tension-filled seconds before a big race, the feelings shooting through her mind and body as they became one.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the interest shown by foreign companies in the Korean automobile industry omitted details about a decision by the Ford Motor Company. On Friday, Ford withdrew its $6.9 billion bid to buy the Daewoo Motor Company of South Korea. A related article appears today on Page C4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, DOROTHY
description: KOPPELMAN-Dorothy, 82. Of Princeton, NJ on September 16, 2000. Cherished wife of Julius, beloved mother, grandmother, aunt, sister and friend. Dedicated communal leader and generous benefactor to a raft of civic and Jewish causes. She will be deeply missed by her children, grandchildren, sisters, brothers, sisters-in-law and their families, numerous nieces, nephews and friends. Born in New York City, Mrs. Koppelman was a resident of Princeton the past twenty-eight years. She was a graduate of the City College of New York. Mrs. Koppelman was former president of Lawrenceville Hadassah and Temple Avoda Sisterhood. She served on the board of directors for The Center for Jewish Life (Princeton), United Jewish Appeal, American Jewish Committee and its Leadership Council and Greenwood House. She served as a docent of the Princeton Historical Society, and principal of the Temple Micah Religious School and was a member of ORT and National Council of Jewish Women. She and her husband endowed the Holocaust Center at Rider College. Mrs. Koppelman taught religious school for over thirty years in several congregations and temples. Memberships include Congregation Avoda (Fairlawn, NJ), Shir Ami Bucks County Jewish Congregation (Newtown, Pa), Congregation Beth Chaim, B'nai Israel and Temple Micah (Lawrenceville, NJ). Daughter of the late Victor and Flora Barocas, she is survived by her husband of fifty-six years Julius, four daughters and three sons-in-law Estelle and Richard Blumberg of Ft. Lauderdale, Fla, Vicki and Howard Cabot of Phoenix, Arizona, Marcia and Colin Moor of South Natick, Mass Nancy Koppelman of Wynnewood, Pa, two brothers Ralph Barocas of Potomac, Maryland, Joseph Barocas of Delray Beach, Fla, three sisters Eleanor Pellman of New York City, Mathilda Friedman of Baltimore, Maryland, Rita Levin of Glen Rock, NJ, grandchildren Stacy and Sandy Blumberg, Heather, Melissa, Courtney & Tyler Cabot, Jennifer, Zachary and Taylor Moor, Gabriel Koppelman Siegal, sister-in-law Miriam Sandlofer. Services on Tuesday 11AM at Congregation Beth Chaim, Village Road, Princeton Junction, NJ. Period of mourning at the Koppelman residence Tuesday thru Thursday. Memorial contributions to Greenwood House, 53 Walter St., Trenton, NJ 08628, American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th St., New York, NY 10022, United Jewish Federation, 3131 Princeton Pike, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648 or the Julius and Dorothy Koppelman Holocaust Resource Center, c/o Rider University, 2083 Lawrenceville Rd, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648. For more information Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400.

title: NET2PHONE FORMS VENTURE WITH CISCO
description: Net2Phone is branching out beyond its core business of providing low-cost voice and data calls over the Internet in forming a software venture with Cisco Systems. The new company, called Adir Technologies, will sell software to communications companies seeking to route calling traffic over the Internet. With the venture, in which Cisco has a minority stake, Net2Phone hopes to receive revenue from software licensing fees. The diversification of Net2Phone's activities is an effort to make the company, which is based in Newark, less vulnerable to the fierce competition gripping the Internet telephony industry. Simon Romero

title: Article 2000091993690518040 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Venus Williams in Her Olympic Debut Captures Another Victory
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- "Citius, altius, fortius," read the words over the players' entrance at the New South Wales tennis center, and even though Venus Williams was no faster, higher or stronger than usual in the first Olympic tennis match of her career, she was still too much for her first-round opponent Henrieta Nagyova of Slovakia.

title: United Way Faces Crisis As President Plans to Leave
description: Betty S. Beene resigned last night as president of the United Way of America as it grappled with its worst crisis since 1992, when a former president was found to be stealing charitable funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TINKER, ROBERT LEE
description: TINKER-Robert Lee. Born October 6, 1926 in Teaneck, NJ, son of the late Teresa and Malcolm Tinker, died at home suddenly on Sunday, September 10, 2000. He is mourned by his many friends and colleagues. Funeral services will be private. A memorial will be announced.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Elephant Birth Control

title: National News Briefs
description: Altered Corn Entering Human Food, Group Says

title: Metro Business; Telemarketer Settles Claims of Deception
description: MemberWorks Inc., a national telemarketing company based in Stamford, Conn., that provides memberships in discount programs for credit card holders, has settled allegations of abusive sales practices brought by the New York State attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results on Sunday misstated a number in some copies for the Saturday Powerball drawing. The numbers were 1, 19, 40, 47 and 49, and the powerball, 14. No. 59 was not drawn.

title: Despite Delay, Sydney Helps NBC's Image
description: It's unfashionable to praise NBC at Olympic time. The network is scorned for showing the Olympics on tape, for chopping up events to serve its prime-time needs, for being as jingoistic as Georgie Jessel, for sacrificing action for weepy profiles.

title: The Miracle Kid
description: The one thing a teenager can count on is change, abrupt and ongoing, but even by that hormonal standard, Tasha Schwikert-Warren's Olympics were extreme. She came to Sydney as an alternate, a dreamer, a 15-year-old with metal in her smile. By late last night, she was hailed as the foundation and future of the United States women's gymnastics team.

title: GOVERNMENT SITES LAGGING, SURVEY SAYS
description: Most government Web sites do not offer search capabilities, technical help or citizen services, like the ability to register a vehicle online, according to an analysis by researchers at Brown University. The study of 1,813 state and federal government Web sites concluded that government at all levels was not making full and effective use of commonly available information technology. Specifically, the survey found that 78 percent of the sites surveyed offered no online services, only 15 percent allowed some form of disability access and just 4 percent had foreign-language translation features. The survey, completed at Brown's Taubman Center for Public Policy and American Institutions, found that the largest states had the most comprehensive presence online. Matt Richtel

title: Kaiser Will Cut 540 Jobs
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation, the nation's No. 2 aluminum maker, will cut at least 540 jobs, or 19 percent, of its hourly work force at five plants in Ohio, Louisiana, and Washington, after settling a two-year strike. A federal arbitrator reached a settlement today between the company and the members of the United Steelworkers of America. Under the five-year contract, workers will get wage and benefit increases that average 2.6 percent a year, Kaiser said. The company will take a third-quarter pretax charge of $30 million to $40 million for the costs of the labor settlement. The plants employed about 2,800 workers before the strike began in September 1998.

title: Cadbury Reaches for Growing Market
description: Anyone wondering why Cadbury Schweppes is so eager to break into noncarbonated beverages that it is willing to spend $910 million to acquire Snapple need only ask Nice N Easy Grocery Shoppes about its Woodstock days.

title: Movie Violence: Too Much Ado?
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Approves Bill Lifting Trade Restrictions on China
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- In a major triumph for the Clinton administration and American business, the Senate today voted away restraints on trade with China that stood for more than 20 years in anti-Communist policy.

title: Fatal Explorer Accidents Involving Bad Tires Soared in '99
description: After rising steadily since the mid-1990's, the number of fatal accidents involving Ford Explorers with tire problems more than doubled last year, a trend that provides strong indications that the overall death toll from defective Firestone tires is higher than previously reported.

title: TV Spots Are Concentrated In Bush-Gore Battlegrounds
description: The precise geographical middle of America is hundreds of miles to the south and west of here. The media capitals of the country are on the far-off Atlantic and Pacific Coasts. But as far as marketing presidential candidacies is concerned, this is the nation's epicenter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONROE, SYLVIA (FOXTOW)
description: MONROE-Sylvia (Foxtow). 9/19/92. Her radiant smile divinely watches over us causing her celestial lamp to lighten up the world. Barbara, Eric and Scott Mogelof and Harold Monroe

title: Peru Spy Chief Is Still Unseen; Rumors Abound
description: Dozens of protesters held a vigil today outside the compound of Peru's shadowy and powerful intelligence chief, demanding his arrest. He is believed to be at the heart of President Alberto K. Fujimori's unexpected call for new elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOOB, FREDERICK T., D.D.S.
description: DOOB-Frederick T., D.D.S. Born June 5, 1913. September 16, 2000. Dr. Doob practiced in NYC. A loving husband and father, survived by his wife Joyce, four children, six grandchildren and one great grandson.

title: Article 2000091991133657666 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE TRAVEL LOG

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is Mount Everest. It's great to know for the rest of your life you had this journey and it is completed. That is the most beautiful thing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RABBI SHLOMO
description: KAHN-Rabbi Shlomo. We extend sincerest condolences to Eva Kahn on the lost of her beloved husband. For nearly forty years, first as a founding member of the original American Committee Board, the Medical Center was the beneficiary of his advice and wise counsel. We shall miss his warm smile. May Mrs. Kahn, daughters Rachel Furst and Yaffa Ungar, and the entire family, be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: 2 Time Warner Mergers Facing Peril in Europe
description: Antitrust regulators at the European Commission are threatening to block the $165 billion merger of Time Warner and America Online, as both sides prepare to negotiate a possible settlement over the next week.

title: NEW WIRELESS SERVICE PLANNED
description: ScreamingMedia, a company that gathers content like news stories and photos and filters it into client Web sites, is expected to announce plans today to provide wireless services for its network of about 2,800 content providers and 1,100 subscribers. In a deal with OracleMobile, a wireless Internet subsidiary of the Oracle Corporation, a software company, ScreamingMedia will develop and operate wireless services for media companies. Simon Romero

title: Boys of Autumn
description: These are intoxicating times for New York sports fans. The city's two professional football teams have started the season with three straight victories. The Yankees seem assured of another division title. The Mets are causing the usual last-minute heartburn, but barring a collapse in two three-game matchups against the Atlanta Braves, they should at least capture a wild-card spot in the baseball playoffs. The city's professional soccer team, the Metrostars, a bust last year, has vaulted to the playoffs. Meanwhile, the regular hockey and basketball seasons are not yet under way, which means that it is too early to get depressed about the Knicks and the Rangers.

title: AT&T LATIN UNIT POSTPONES SHARE SALE
description: Citing low stock prices, the AT&T Latin America Corporation postponed a planned issuance of 35 million common shares just weeks after the company merged with the FirstCom Corporation, a broadband communications group that operates in Chile, Peru and Colombia. The company will instead rely on a $200 million finance package from its parent company, the AT&T Corporation, and long-term financing from vendors like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks to finance its expansion. Jennifer L. Rich

title: House Passes Republican Debt-Cutting Bill
description: The House voted overwhelmingly tonight to commit 90 percent of next year's federal surplus to reduce the national debt and to make it harder to use Medicare or Social Security surpluses for tax cuts or other programs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STINE, ESTHER K.
description: STINE-Esther K. Dearest mother, gone 30 years but always in our hearts. Your Childre

title: So Far, So Dominant: Americans' Regimen Is Paying Off
description: Ricardo Juarez, one of six American boxers to convincingly win his opening fight in the Olympic boxing tournament, has a catch phrase for how the United States team prepared in the last two months: train high, live low.

title: In His Own Words
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN

title: Buchanan Forcefully Strikes Familiar Notes in Speech at Bob Jones University
description: Patrick J. Buchanan roared back from his sickbed tonight to resume his fight for the country's soul, using the richly symbolic podium of Bob Jones University to declare his high-decibel presence as the Reform Party presidential candidate in the remaining weeks of the campaign.

title: A Deep U.S. Women's Team Beats Cuba and Looks Forward to Russia
description: Wherever she has played the past five years college, professional or pickup -- Katie Smith's job description was simple: go-to player.

title: U.N. Is Unsettled After 4 Recent Killings of Staff Workers
description: The killing of a fourth United Nations refugee worker in less than two weeks is prompting the United Nations high commissioner for refugees to reassess how best to safeguard staff members worldwide who come to the aid of refugees trapped in the vortex of war, violence and chaos.

title: Corzine Discloses Donations After Queries on Political Ties
description: After trying for months to avoid disclosing his charitable contributions, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic Senate candidate, revealed today that he had given more than $100,000 to groups whose leaders or sponsors later endorsed him.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HYMAN
description: MARCUS-Hyman. Age 86, On September 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Sydelle. Loving father of Beverly Chosak and Carol Baker. Devoted grandfather of Stephanie, Marjorie and Bonnie and great grandfather of Derek and Brian. Private services were held.

title: Technology Briefing
description: RESEARCH GOVERNMENT SITES LAGGING, SURVEY SAYS Most government Web sites do not offer search capabilities, technical help or citizen services, like the ability to register a vehicle online, according to an analysis by researchers at Brown University. The study of 1,813 state and federal government Web sites concluded that government at all levels was not making full and effective use of commonly available information technology. Specifically, the survey found that 78 percent of the sites surveyed offered no online services, only 15 percent allowed some form of disability access and just 4 percent had foreign-language translation features. The survey, completed at Brown's Taubman Center for Public Policy and American Institutions, found that the largest states had the most comprehensive presence online. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Genetics: Blind Spot in Medical Training
description: The explosion of knowledge about what role genetics plays in disease has altered the way medical care is being provided at the most basic levels, and many health professionals may not be up to the task.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, GEORGE E.
description: SANDS-George E. Died peacefully in his 100th year on September 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Marjorie U. Sands. Devoted stepfather of Charlotte Stadler and Julia Shubik. Grandfather to Claire Shubik, Daniel, Alex and David Stadler. Great-grandfather to Henry and Lily Stadler. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, September 19, 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Long Island Caddie Scholarship Fund C/O John Buckley, 15 Homestead Drive, Wheatley Heights, New York 11798, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Drug Warning for Seasick Scuba Divers
description: Some scuba divers are at ease under the water but mighty uncomfortable on the diving boat. For help, they turn to over-the-counter seasickness medicines.

title: New Star Points South Korean Archers to Olympic Gold Again
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- Seven years ago, Kim Soo-Nyung of South Korea decided to retire after a career as one of the greatest female archers ever, with three Olympic gold medals and one silver to her name. She was the queen of quivers in a country where a generation of archers was establishing Dream Team-like dominance in international competition.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Japan Planning Another Budget Move to Boost Its Economy
description: TOKYO, Sept. 19  The Japanese government is preparing yet another package of supplemental spending aimed at propping up the economy, which has failed to gain enough momentum on its own despite several previous injections of money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, WM. BRIAN
description: LITTLE-Wm. Brian. Loved husband, father, son, grandfather, father-in-law, friend of Judy, Jackie, Greg, Bill, Will, Megan, Jack, Henry and Alicia. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Colgate University or the Photography Department of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art or the Photography Department of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Ratings Come Up Short
description: The ratings picture for NBC's coverage of the Sydney Olympics grew much cloudier over the weekend as first Saturday's and then Sunday's numbers came up well short of what the network had scored for the past two foreign-based Olympics.

title: About That Receiver, The Jets Plead the Fifth
description: Is there a team in the National Football League with a more daunting task this week than the Jets? Take on perhaps the best team in the league. And try to ignore the loudest mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENDERGAST, KEVIN J.
description: PRENDERGAST-Kevin J. On September 9th, 2000, after a long illness. Tax attorney, specializing in executive compensation. For most of his career, practiced law with the firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, where he was described by a partner as a person of immense integrity and ability. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Donations in his memory may be made to Washington University in support of lung transplant research through Randy Farmer, Medical Alumni & Development Programs, Washington University, Campus Box 8509, 4444 Forest Park Ave., St. Louis, MO. 63108.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: What Local Control?
description: The presidential candidates are taking their parties to new places with their education proposals: Al Gore has called for higher standards for teachers as well as higher pay, while George W. Bush has emphasized closing the achievement gap between rich and poor and holding schools accountable for student performance. Yet no matter who wins in November, there is little reason to believe that any serious improvement is in the offing.

title: U.S. Women Run Their Softball Streak to 112
description: If the United States women's softball team is looking for a marketing label, they can credibly lay claim to ''The Invincibles.''

title: NIPPON TO RAISE FUNDS
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest telephone company, plans to sell as much as $3.5 billion in stock next month to finance the recent purchase of an Internet company in the United States, Nippon officials said. The sale would coincide with the Japanese government's sale of 1 million Nippon shares for as much as $12 billion.

title: Boats Forced to Lower Their Flags
description: SYDNEY Australia -- No more Stars and Stripes, Union Jack, Rising Sun or the tricolors of France and Italy billowing in the breeze at the Sydney Olympic regatta. Those country flag spinnakers gave the wild 49ers a snazzy look in their first two Olympic races in Sydney Harbor. But they'll have to be stowed, because it turns out that the chemical process used to emblazon the three-quarter-ounce silicon cloth reduced its strength.

title: It's Time For Rusch To Pass Big Test
description: There is no pregame pep talk planned, no advice he has been rehearsing for his star pupil. Al Leiter, the veteran left-hander who has been a mentor to Glendon Rusch this year, thinks Rusch is ready for the biggest start of his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, BARBARA S.
description: KARP-Barbara S. Of Palm Beach, FL. died Monday, September 18, 2000. Mother of Michael. Beloved grandmother of Matthew, Merrie and Meg Buchsbaum. Devoted aunt and stepmother.

title: THAILAND'S ECONOMY GROWS
description: Thailand's econ omy expanded at a faster-than-expected 6.6 percent in the second quarter, compared with a year earlier. The quarterly rise was its sixth consecutive one and was powered by exports, the government said. Exports of computers, air-conditioners, televisions and cars rose by about a third, helped by a decline in the baht. Even so, Thailand's growth lagged expansions in Korea, Malaysia and Singapore.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AVON PRODUCTS, New York, named Brian Connolly, senior vice president for United States sales and operations, to the post of president at its Avon U.S. division.

title: Auto Industry May Ease Safety-Ratings Stance
description: The high number of sport utility vehicles that have rolled over because of defective Firestone tires has splintered the auto industry's once-monolithic resistance to federal ratings of new models' tendency to roll over, increasing the odds that such ratings will be imposed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN-Gladys. 23 years have passed unbelievably and you are always in our hearts with the fondest of memories. Love, Irving Newman and Family

title: Saving the Heart Can Sometimes Mean Losing the Memory
description: James Haneman believes his surgeons sacrificed his mind in saving his heart.

title: Barnesandnoble.com and Yahoo Enter Marketing Pact
description: Article.@urlbody

title: Rocker Finishes the Job Started by Maddux
description: Maybe there really are no spells or hexes on the Mets, as they claim. Maybe when they play the Atlanta Braves, the Mets usually lose because they cannot hit the Braves' pitching. That is what happened tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, DR. WILLIAM BEAUREGARD III
description: YOUNG-Dr. William Beauregard III, 74, died on September 17, 2000. Services at 11 A.M., Tuesday at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church. Burial in Maplewood Cemetery. Survived by wife Ann, sons Thomas of NYC, William IV of Greenville, NC, and Vance of Wilmington, NC, and four grandchildren.

title: Mrs. Clinton Portrays Lazio as Bully and Derides His Tax Plan
description: At ease in a Manhattan hotel ballroom filled mostly with Democratic women, Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday made a broad appeal for women to support her Senate campaign, casting her Republican opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, as a bully in last week's debate and dismissing his tax plan as misleading and mathematically unsound.

title: Giants Look Like Prosperous Underdogs
description: Michael Strahan did not intend to sound in awe of the Washington Redskins. None of the Giants appeared to be today. Strahan's glowing review of Washington's roster was conditional and echoed what is being discussed around the National Football League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGEN, EUGENE DEBS
description: COGEN-Eugene Debs. On September 14, 2000. Cherished father of Alisha. Dear brother of Robbie. Benefactor of many. Life enhancer to multitudes. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Review/Fashion; Choosing a Destiny: Here-to-Stay or Here-to-Play
description: Conceptually, Sunday in New York resembles a giant playpen for the infantile ego. It is the one day, especially during Fashion Week, when all the arty kids come out in their homemade clothes, and there are not too many old people around to give them grief. Everyone is creative. Everyone is feeling -- how can one put it after seeing the Imitation of Christ show amid the rose-colored solemnity of the Peter Jarema Funeral Home on East Seventh Street? -- a oneness with Chloe Sevigny.

title: WEST'S GOVERNORS BACK CLINTON PLAN FOR FIGHTING FIRES
description: Governors from Western states that have been devastated by wildfires this summer strongly endorsed a Clinton administration firefighting plan today that would place a new emphasis on prevention and local decision-making.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN TO ACQUIRE ASSETS OF INVENSYS UNIT
description: Parker Hannifin, the world's largest maker of hydraulic equipment, agreed to buy the assets and stock of Invensys's pneumatics unit for $38 million. The unit of Invensys, based in London, makes equipment and controls for automated processes like material handling. It operates plants in France, Britain and the United States, and generates $50 million in annual revenue. Parker Hannafin, based in Cleveland, makes motion-control equipment and hydraulic systems used in jet engines, amusement park rides and movie sets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAND, WINIFRED R.
description: BOLAND-Winifred R. On September 17, 2000 of Manhattan. Daughter of the late John Boland and Katherine (nee Kilduff) Boland. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial mass will be celebrated at Immaculate Conception Church, 14th St and 1st Ave, NYC, with notice of time later.

title: Corrections
description: Pages 40 and 42 of Arts & Leisure, carrying arts listings, were omitted from some copies in the New York region on Sunday and replaced by pages from a special E-Commerce section scheduled for tomorrow. Readers wishing replacement pages may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: The Cost of Not Living On a $5.15 Minimum; Little Impact Seen in Raising Wage Now
description: Four years ago, the last time Congress agreed to raise the minimum wage, Lynn Martins was quick -- though far from eager -- to respond.

title: DEUTSCHE POSTE TO OPEN NETWORK
description: In a break for United Parcel Service Inc., postal regulators ordered Deutsche Poste, Europe's largest mail company, to immediately open part of its delivery network to United Parcel. The order means Deutsche Poste must now forward many United Parcel packages to their final address at a discount. The ruling is a setback for Deutsche Poste, which just a few days earlier strengthened its dominance in European delivery operations by purchasing a controlling stake in DHL International, a Brussels-based package delivery service. Suzanne Kapner

title: Exercise as Necessity
description: To the Editor:

title: Malchow Takes Gold in 200 Meter Butterfly
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 19 -- At 6 feet 7 inches, with a thin waist and cantilevered chest, Tom Malchow takes a 42 extra long in the new high-tech swimming bodysuits. He trains ferociously, even pulling a 10-gallon bucket through the water to increase drag, just as track sprinters trail parachutes during workouts.

title: Colon Fires a One-Hitter for Cleveland
description: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
