title: Inquiry Into Abuse by G.I.'s In Kosovo Faults Training
description: More than 800 soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division, one of the Army's elite fighting units, were sent to Kosovo last year with little training in the subtler arts of policing the streets and preventing violence between ethnic factions, according to an Army investigation into accusations that members of the unit beat and manhandled ethnic Albanians.

title: Man Held in Terrorist Plot Agreed to Talk, Agents Say
description: Two federal agents testified yesterday that a Brooklyn man arrested last December in a plot to smuggle explosives into the United States agreed to talk voluntarily in an interrogation lasting more than 10 hours.

title: Drug Accounts In the Spotlight
description: Drug accounts are coming and going at Bates Worldwide in New York, part of the Cordiant Communications Group.

title: Two Are Chosen For Creative Posts
description: Two freelancers have been named to share the top creative post at the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA unit of the Omnicom Group. They succeed David Page, who was dismissed last week after 18 months as chief creative officer.

title: C.I.A Says Chilean General in '76 Bombing Was Informer
description: The former chief of Chile's secret police, convicted of masterminding a lethal car bombing here in 1976, was an informer for the Central Intelligence Agency when the bombing occurred, a year after he had received a one-time payment for his cooperation, newly released documents show.

title: Romania Wins Team Gymnastics
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- The six sprite-sized Americans were sitting as tight as piano keys on the edge of the arena floor tonight, telepathically willing a misstep by the Chinese or Russian teams that were still competing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SOPHIE
description: DAVIS-Sophie. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health deeply mourn the passing of a most generous benefactress, Sophie Davis. Mrs. Davis and her husband Leonard were outstanding supporters of medical research and health care, and the School of Medicine shared in her generosity through its participation in the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at the City University of New York. The Leonard and Sophie Davis Foundation also provided ongoing support for research in endocrinology. Sophie Davis's conribution will be long remembered. We extend our sincere sympathy to her husband and the entire family. Helene L. Kaplan, Chairman, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stephen M. Peck, Chairman, Mount Sinai NYU Health Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh., Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. Freedman, Acting President, Mount Sinai NYU Health

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENTER, ALFRED MITCHELL
description: SENTER-Alfred Mitchell, age 86. Owner of the former Senter's Department Store in Brunswick, Maine died Saturday, September 16, 2000, Freeport, Maine. Mr. Senter was born in Brunswick, March 2, 1914, the son of Wilbur Fisk & Emma Thompson Senter. He attended Brunswick High School for two years and graduated from Kiskiminetas Spring School, Saltsburg, Pennsylvania in 1934. Mr. Senter then attended the University of New Hampshire for two years and graduated in 1939 from the Wharton School of Business and Finance of the University of Pennsylvania. Survived by 2 brothers, John Thompson, Sr. of Hampden, Maine and George Dyer of Brunswick; a sister, Jane Senter Lee of Westwood, New Jersey; fourteen nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M., Sunday, September 24, 2000 at First Parish Church, Maine Street, Brunswick. For information Brackett Funeral Home, 29 Federal Street, Brunswick, Maine 04011.

title: Local Officials Fear Effect Of Nassau's Budget Plan
description: The spending cuts and new revenues that Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau county executive, is counting on to help balance the county's troubled finances could instead wreak havoc on cities and towns here in the years to come, officials say.

title: Blair's Disenchanted Kingdom: Strike Takes a Toll
description: The truckers and farmers whose protest over fuel prices brought Britain to a virtual standstill last week have claimed another victim -- the eight-year-long lead in opinion polls that the Labor party has held over the Conservatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUPP, FRANKLIN O.
description: KAUPP-Franklin O. On September 18, 2000. Husband of Evelyn Gross. Father of Ruth (Mark) Hroncick and Evelyn C. Grandfather of Sarah and Benjamin Hroncick. Visiting Tuesday & Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, N.Y. (at RR Plaza). Mass of Christian burial on Thursday 10:30 A.M., at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: U.S. Asks Putin Not to Sell Iran A Laser System
description: The United States has been pressing Russia not to proceed with plans to sell Iran laser technology that Washington says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons, according to Administration officials.

title: ALLAIRE STOCK FALLS 40 PERCENT
description: Shares of Allaire, which makes software that lets companies tailor Web site content for electronic commerce, fell sharply yesterday after the company said sales of its core product would fall far short of expectations. For the third quarter ending Sept. 30, the company now expects revenue of $28 million to $32 million, compared with $33.3 million in the second quarter and $15.1 million in the third quarter of last year. The company expects a net loss of 5 cents to 20 cents a share in the third quarter, in contrast to net income of 6 cents a share in the second quarter and a net loss of a penny a share in the third quarter of 1999. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had predicted earnings of 7 cents a share for the third quarter. Allaire's stock closed down $7.06, or 40 percent, to $10.44, just off its 52-week low and well off the 52-week high of $94.12 it reached in March.

title: The Case He Can't Solve: A Detective's Delusions
description: WHEN WE WERE ORPHANS

title: Brain-Updating Machinery May Explain False Memories
description: Scientists may have found a biological reason to explain why two people who witness the same event will, years later, often have different memories of what happened.

title: Archdiocese Settles Sex Lawsuit Involving Former Nun and Boy
description: A 25-year-old man who was sexually molested as a seventh grader has agreed to a settlement of his lawsuit against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and his old parish school in the Bronx, which he said had failed to investigate signs that his homeroom teacher was carrying on a sexual relationship with him.

title: Sports of The Times; Johnson, Feeling Scorned, Responds by Flaunting It
description: Keyshawn Johnson can tell you about the first call and the last one he made to the Jets about his eventual trade, about conversations before it and after it with his former teammates, about contract fallout and about Wayne Chrebet and Al Groh and the lowdown on who said what and who did what and why.

title: Last-Minute Wisdom for a Condemned Man
description: As the title suggests, ''A Lesson Before Dying,'' the 1993 novel by Ernest J. Gaines, is a peculiar combination of potent drama and tear-jerker. The story of a self-loathing schoolteacher, sent by his grandmother to counsel an unjustly convicted young man on death row, it is rife with prosaic sentimentality. The human dignity that the teacher seeks to instill in the prisoner and the pride of purpose that the teacher himself needs to learn are grandiose pursuits set in a race against time.

title: Marks & Spencer, British Retailer, Shakes Up the Top Ranks
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., once the unchallenged flagship of British Main Street retailing, ousted its chief executive and other longtime managers today, pursuing its quest for an elusive formula to reverse declining sales and a plunging stock price.

title: Remedial Program Refuses to Die; Revamped SEEK Remains Path for Poor Into CUNY
description: Martha Bell remembers bursting into tears when the Board of Regents voted to allow the City University of New York to end remedial instruction for bachelor's degree students.

title: Movie Violence: Too Much Ado?
description: To the Editor:

title: Major Creditor Says Russia Media Mogul Backed Out of Secret Deal
description: The fight between the media mogul Vladimir V. Gusinsky, his creditors and the government took an unexpected turn today.

title: Public Interests; The Plus Spin of Pickiness
description: There is a strong feeling on the part of many political campaigns that reporters have way too much time on their hands. They write a story every time George W. Bush backward speaks the sentence written. Or they point out that Al Gore once mistranslated ''e pluribus unum.''

title: Paper Makers Settle Price-Fixing Lawsuit
description: Kimberly- Clark the maker of Kleenex facial tissue and Scott paper towels -- and other commercial tissue manufacturers have agreed to settle a price-fixing lawsuit for $56.2 million, lawyers said today.

title: The Right to Live
description: After generations in denial, doctors and lawmakers are paying attention to the importance of allowing sick people a dignified death, and to the value of helping patients and their families let go and say good-bye. Aggressive medical intervention in terminal cases is increasingly considered an avoidable cruelty, inflicted on a suffering patient by someone -- occasionally a doctor, but more often a family member -- unable to acknowledge the inevitable.

title: Armstrong Declares Himself Fit for Olympic Cycling
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- Lance Armstrong said today that he is largely recovered from a cracked neck vertebra he suffered when he was hit by a car three weeks ago while cycling in Nice and will race next week in the 148.4-mile Olympic road race and 29-mile individual time trial.

title: Ex-Executive of Bankers Trust Pleads Guilty to Falsifying Books
description: Bruce Kingdon, the former managing director of the Bankers Trust Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to making false entries in the bank's books to cover up millions of dollars in shortfalls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, VINCENT DEPAUL
description: JOYCE-Vincent DePaul, 87, of Toddy Hill Road, Newtown, formerly of Danbury and the Bronx, died Wednesday, August 23, 2000 at Ashlar of Newtown. He was the husband of the late Gertrude Joyce, (nee Kane). Born in the Bronx, N.Y. on July 8, 1913, he was the son of Christopher and Anna (Lyons) Joyce. He attended New York Catholic schools and worked for more than 32 years as a New York Times Lino-type Operator. He retired in 1975. He was a member of St. Peter's Church and the New York Typographical Union. Mr. Joyce is survived by his daughters, Maureen Consiglio of New Fairfield, CT, and Regina Joyce of New York City; and his son, Richard Joyce of Brunswick, OH; and 8 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Anne Burke of Jacksonville, Fla as well as several nieces and nephews. He was buried on Saturday, August 26, 2000 alongside his wife in Central Cemetery in Brookfield, Connecticut after the celebration of a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Peter's Church. Contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Connecticut, 20 Wooster Street, Waterbury, CT. 06708.

title: Absent Devils Take Patient Stance
description: Even though Lou Lamoriello stopped negotiations with Scott Niedermayer and Jason Arnott several days ago, the two players say they have not reached the stage of asking the president and a general manager of the Devils for a trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBAUM, MOLLY
description: APPLEBAUM-Molly. Age 90, died September 16, 2000. Wife of the late Jacob Applebaum, of Kew Gardens Hills, partner of the late William Goldman, of Tamarac, FL. Mother of James, Jane Barry and Amy Hutchings. Grandmother of David, Mimi, Julia, Jacob, Kenneth, Spencer and Peter, and great-grandmother of Lena, Lucy & Adam. Survived also by a sister Sarah Lieber. Memorial service at a later date. ''If music be the food of life play on''.

title: Foreign Affairs; Debate This!
description: Let's get crazy for a moment and imagine that the two presidential candidates are actually going to devote one of their debates to foreign policy -- what would they talk about? Would Al Gore, Rick Lazio-like, thrust upon George W. Bush a map of the world with the country names spelled out phonetically (RUSH-ah, ee-ROCK, Grease)? Would Mr. Bush ask Mr. Gore to give viewers his insights on Buddhist temples? Nah. Doubt it.

title: The Oldest Profession Seeks New Market in West Europe
description: Early this summer, Pavlika, a young Bulgarian woman, boarded a bus in Varna on the Black Sea coast and traveled westward to this town on the Czech-German border, where she now stands on the road in vampish boots and a skirt so short it leaves little to the imagination. ''Work,'' she says simply, a helpless smile spreading across her broad face. ''Work, that is why I came. In Bulgaria, there was no way to make money.''

title: National News Briefs; Suit Filed Over Death In Gene Therapy Test
description: The family of the 18-year-old whose death in a gene therapy experiment at the University of Pennsylvania started a debate about medical research filed a wrongful death lawsuit today against the university and five doctors, including a prominent medical ethicist.

title: Police Switching to a New Nightstick, Which Looks More Like the Old One
description: Just over a decade ago, the New York City Police Department replaced its conventional wooden nightsticks with a sleek, new tool: a side-handle baton fashioned out of hard plastic that required movements reminiscent of the martial arts.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Dominant U.S. Men Win Again, But Lose Fans
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 - Bill Gates paid the United States men's basketball team a visit in their locker room tonight, moments after another nettlesome competitor tried to toy with their global monopoly. The world's richest man did not commiserate with the American multi-millionaires over high tax brackets. But with all these uppity foreign opponents grabbing at their jerseys and making them come across as bullies when the superior Americans respond, the kinship is natural. ``These guys don't even ask for autographs anymore,'' Gary Payton lamented after Italy begrudgingly went down, 93-61. World domination is clearly beginning to wear on the United States men, who won the game but hardly failed to win over the crowd of 8,368 at the Dome in Olympic Park. Yes, Vince Carter threw down a tremendous, alley-oop dunk in the first half that had the building in a state of disbelief. And with 22 points off the fastbreak, they entertained everyone. But the masses jeered in the second half when Carter and the feisty Italian guard Allesandro Abbio grabbed and held each other until Carter planted a forearm in his throat and knocked him down. Miffed at Italy's defiance or not, coach Rudy Tomjanovich of the United States quickly sicced a full-court press on the Italians with less than 9 minutes left. The score at the time: 78-46. Team USA apparently feels it does not merely have to win; it must win so convincingly that not a single soul comes away with the notion that America was ever in trouble. ``There are good international players,'' Tomjanovich began matter-of-factly, ``but the other countries don't have 12 of them on the same team.'' There is an ornery resilience creeping into international play, though. You can see it with each game. Whether they have been watching Heat-Knicks playoff contests on tape is unclear, but somewhere Italy and the other nations are beginning to learn the art of the well-placed elbow in the small of the back. From the opening tip, when Italy's best player, Gregor Fucka, caught Alonzo Mourning with a open hand to the face, the Italians showed none of the great respect afforded other international teams comprised of N.B.A. players. Payton, Carter and Kevin Garnett took the physical challenge to heart, going at their opponents hard. It was not uncommon to see the 7-foot Garnett bodying up his man near halfcourt, trying any tactic to take away the ball. The Minnesota Timberwolves All-Star afterward bristled at one reporter's suggestion that the Americans should begin sending college players again to make it fair. ``It's like fighting,'' Garnett said. ``I get my five, you get your five from the neighborhood. I'm going to try and find the grimiest, dirtiest cats I can.'' And whether it plays or not back home, that is how the gold-medal pursuit is apparently going to go. With three preliminary games left, the U.S. men moved to 2-0 in Group A. Carter had 13 points, Mourning added 12 points and six blocked shots and Jason Kidd contributed 7 assists. In the first half, Carter rose for an alley-oop pass from Garnett on the left side of the rim. The ball was out of his grasp, so he waited for it to come off the backboard before slamming it through for the cameras. Even Abbio was impressed, despite the forearm in the throat. ``A wonderful personality,'' he said through a translator. ``He is a special player.'' Proof that the only incredible news the Americans can make is to somehow lose, the crowd cheered wildly for Italy as they held on for the most of the first half. The Italians came within 35-33 with less than 3 minutes remaining when Allan Houston, making his Olympic debut after jamming his right wrist and missing the first game, connected on two 3-pointers before the half ended.

title: For Gore, a Page From the Reagan Playbook
description: Even as his opponent shifts into a more aggressive gear, Vice President Al Gore is hewing to a front-runner's strategy that relies on discipline, stagecraft and control.

title: Harvard Finds 2 Poems, and a Latin Romance Reignites
description: One wintry December day three years ago, David Whitesell, a rare-book cataloger at Harvard University, walked from his windowless office into the seemingly endless stacks in Widener Library. What he found on one shelf made his heart race, and in recent months his discovery has become the talk of literary circles in Latin America and Spain.

title: Water Tanks
description: Q. Why doesn't the water in rooftop wooden tanks freeze in winter? How does the water get up there?

title: Technology Boom Too Tempting For Many Government Scientists
description: Throughout the high-tech era, government research laboratories have been seedbeds for some of the most important advances in computing, detecting nuclear weapons, robotics, gene sequencing and other fields. And for engineers and computer scientists, the laboratories have been havens of job permanence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SCHUYLER G., M.D., DRPH.
description: KOHL-Schuyler G., M.D., DrPH. SUNY-Downstate Medical Center's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology sorrowfully regrets the passing of Dr. Schuyler G. Kohl, a Distinguished Service Professor in the Department on September 14, 2000. Dr. Kohl was a member of the faculty for a period of fifty years. He was initially appointed to the faculty in the Department at SUNY-Downstate Medical Center in 1950 as a Research Associate. He was subsequently appointed to the level of an Assistant Professor and an Attending Physician at Kings County Hospital Center. In 1962, he was appointed to the level of Professor. During the period 1961-1971, he also served as the Associate Dean for the College of Medicine at SUNY Downstate Medical Center and as the Acting Dean in 1970. He was the Acting Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology during the period 1976-1978. In 1995, he was appointed to the faculty as a Distinguished Service Professor in the Department. Dr. Kohl participated in landmark efforts to provide family planning services at municipal hospitals in New York City and he trained hundreds of family planning instructors on a national and international level to provide family planning services. In concert with Brooklyn College, he was instrumental in developing a summer employment internship program in the laboratories at SUNY-Downstate for promising students who were interested in pursuing careers in medicine. He served for a period of fifteen years as a member of the Admission's Committee of the College of Medicine at SUNYDownstate Medical Center. He also served as the Chairman of the Admission's Committee for a period of ten years. Throughout Dr. Kohl's extraordinary productive career in medicine and public health, he was actively involved in research and is the author of several books as well as numerous publications. He was a participant on numerous committees, boards and bureaus on a local, national and international level. In 1995, Dr. Kohl retired from his full time faculty position as a Distinguished Service Professor and he continued to work in the Department as a part-time Professor until his death. The Department extends its deepest sympathy to the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEY, ELIZABETH (NEE BOIES)
description: SCHLEY-Elizabeth (nee Boies). Age 92. Of Whitehouse, N.J. On Saturday, September 16, 2000. Wife of the late Reeve Schley, Jr. Mother of Reeve Schley III and John P. Schley. Grandmother of Reeve T. Schley and Marie B. Schley. Also survived by her sister Mari B. Hitchcock. Services are private. Memorial gifts may be made to Bonnie Brae, P.O. Box 825, Liberty Corner, N.J. 07938. Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 176 Main St, Peapack, N.J.

title: The Big City; Let Candidates Do the Math On Education
description: WITH education supposed to be the crucial issue, both New York candidates for the Senate are busy visiting schools and promising large sums of money. The figures sound impressive, but it might be useful if the candidates paused at the schools' blackboards long enough to work on a few problems:

title: Crude Awakenings
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: A YEAR ago, Suzanne Richie embarked on her Internet adventure.

title: Driving Evil Spirits Away With Song and Pulsating Rhythm
description: ''The Mukishi,'' which Batoto Yetu has taken to the New Victory Theater, must surely be one of the most heartwarming shows in town. The audience on Saturday afternoon clapped and sang with the performers without any sense of self-consciousness.

title: Live From Big Ed's Roadhouse, Linking Up With a Beat
description: IN an old brick roadhouse on the fading edge of downtown Reno, Chris Smither poured out his soul on a small stage. The audience that had crammed into Big Ed's bar and restaurant sat rapt as Mr. Smither growled and sang country blues, picking polyphonic patterns on a steel-string guitar and stomping his feet on the wood floor to keep time.

title: For Mets in Atlanta, Rock Bottom Looks Closer
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 19  His fingers drummed the hardwood desktop to a forceful and ominous beat. Bobby Valentine was mad, and he was not going to take it anymore. There was no positive spin as Valentine, the Mets' manager, addressed reporters in his office at Turner Field after an awful 12-4 loss to the Atlanta Braves tonight. He was angry, and he had just told his players so, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, HANNAH C.
description: CARTER-Hannah C., 78. formerly of Short Hills, on August 22, 2000 in Hightstown, NJ. Wife of Dr. Ogden B., Jr. Memorial Service Friday Sept. 29, 2000 at 11 A.M. at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton, NJ. Contributions to The Morristown-Beard School, 70 Whippany Road, Morristown, NJ. 07960.

title: Ex-I.R.S. Lawyer Faces Tax-Evasion Charge in Stock Case
description: A former Internal Revenue Service lawyer and four other men were indicted yesterday on charges of tax evasion and other crimes stemming from what prosecutors described as a stock swindle in which the profits were funneled through offshore accounts.

title: U.S. Defends Freestyle Swimming Title With Record-setting Leg by Thompson
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- After three legs of the women's 4x200-meter freestyle relay tonight, the United States was in danger of not defending its Olympic title.

title: RUSSIA METALS COMPANY REORGANIZES
description: Norilsk Nickel, a metals producer, plans to reorganize in a move analysts said would hurt minority shareholders and erode the company's value. Norilsk is a major world producer of platinum and palladium. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Why This Consumer Giant Isn't About to Sell to Consumers
description: AS consumers gravitate to the Web, more and more are expecting retailers to deliver highly specialized packages -- books, clothing, compact discs, software -- to their doors.

title: Price Is Set For Electronic Book Reader
description: After months of speculation in the book publishing business, Thomson Multimedia has set the prices of its new hand-held devices for reading electronic books. Beginning at about $300, the prices are higher than publishers had hoped, at a level unlikely to speed the adoption of electronic books by the mass market.

title: Food Stuff: Through the Electronic Lion Gates to the Foods of Asia
description: The best Web sites that sell food products deliver solid information along with them, and the new site established by the Asia Society, www.asiafood.org, is a prime example. Among the products for sale are spice pastes, noodles, rice and condiments suitable for most Asian cuisines, as well as for Persian and Australian cooking. But even better, the site has recipes galore and links to resources like a fairly thorough glossary of Asian food terms, from Charlaine Solomon's Encyclopedia of Asian Food.

title: Fire Disrupts Penn Station and L.I. Trains
description: An electrical fire in a train tunnel under the East River caused a brief shutdown and extensive rush-hour delays on the Long Island Rail Road last night and sent smoke billowing into Pennsylvania Station, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEXNER, MILTON
description: HEXNER-Milton. On September 18, 2000. Beloved father of Leslee Penalver. Devoted brother of Julie, Helen Rosenman and Francine Velocci. Cherished grandfather of Sydney and Madison. Loving companion to Joann and son Peter. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. He will be sadly missed by many friends and associates. Religious services today 1PM at ''Parkside Chapels'', Queens Blvd at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: F.D.A. Wants Warnings on Overusing Antibiotics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration today proposed placing warnings on the labels of virtually all antibiotics to remind doctors that overuse is harming their effectiveness.

title: Over Their Dead Bodies: How Their Stores Will Go Online
description: SOMEDAY, the Web may indeed change everything. But for right now, more than 80 percent of small businesses are getting along without a Web site, and only 7 percent are selling goods online, according to a recent survey conducted by the National Federation of Independent Businesses in Washington. Owners of the 1,055 businesses surveyed cited concerns about cost, lack of technical expertise and losing the personal touch that they see as vital to their businesses. Our informal survey of small-business holdouts in the New York City area reflected the same concerns, phrased rather more colorfully. ED BOLAND JR.

title: Honda Warns the Owners Of Over 500,000 Vehicles
description: The Honda Motor Company today became the third major Japanese company in the last month to issue an extensive product recall, warning owners of 551,924 vehicles that they might have potential oil leaks or audio wiring flaws that could cause fires.

title: Despite Taint, Bulgaria Continues to Win Lifting Medals
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Two Olympic medals, two world records. Bulgaria's weightlifters will take this over a tarnished medal any day.

title: Lazio Says Debate Critics Are Sexist
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio today issued his strongest rebuke yet to critics of his debate tactics, saying it was ''sexist'' to suggest he should not have walked over to Hillary Rodham Clinton's lectern in a challenging manner.

title: An Unusual Commute Leads to a Different Kind of Partnership
description: THE drive from here to Tel Aviv is only 75 minutes, shorter than the ride from San Francisco to San Jose, in California. But Omar Salah is certainly the only Internet entrepreneur making it regularly.

title: They Ate Their Way Cross-Country
description: Allison and Margaret Engel, who are twins, have revised ''Food Finds,'' the most comprehensive guide to American regional foods and the people who produce them (Quill, $18). The 465-page book is better than ever, with all listings up to date and fortified with Web site information.

title: No Windups, Just Pitch After Pitch
description: THE scene could have been ripped right out of an ''Ally McBeal'' episode. Kevin Fong, a venture capitalist at the Mayfield Fund in Menlo Park, Calif., was driving through downtown San Francisco recently when, after slamming on his brakes to avoid hitting a cyclist, the driver of a green minivan scraped the rear bumper of his BMW 328 convertible.

title: FILE-SHARING HERE TO STAY?
description: Napster, the controversial start-up, says its file-sharing service lets Internet users swap music online. The record companies says it facilitates theft. But a report released yesterday by Forrester Research suggests the whole debate is moot, concluding that the one certainty about Napster, and services like it, is that they are here to stay. In the report, Forrester concludes that consumers will use any means necessary to gain access to content like music. The firm asserts that if the industry tries to combat file-sharing services like Napster by encrypting music files or by filing copyright infringement lawsuits, consumers will find other ways to trade files online. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. September 20, 1996. ''I remember you. You're the one who made my dreams come true.'' Yours, Nanc

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTWOOD, W. NORMAN
description: EASTWOOD-W. Norman. Died peacefully at age 94. He was born in Ashton-under-Lyme, England and came to Sand Key, Clearwater in 1974. He retired as Vice President of Merritt-Chapman & Scott of New York after a long construction management career. He was Assistant construction Superintendent of the Empire State Building and supervised construction projects in Iran, Turkey, the north of Canada, Niagara Falls and elsewhere around the world. He was an Associate member of Church of the Isles, Indian Rocks Beach and a member of Marble Collegiate Church, New York City, He was a member of Egypt Temple Shrine, Tampa and past President of Holiday Isles Shrine Club, and past Master Tabernacle Lodge and past President of the Men's League of Marble Collegiate Church, both of New York and past President of Sand Key Club Condominium Association. He is survived by his wife Alma of 46 years; a son, Norman of Palos Verde, Ca., a daughter, Diane Plotkin of Huntington Beach, Ca. several grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at 10 am, Saturday, September 23, 2000 at Church of the Isles, 2408 Bay Blvd., Indian Rocks Beach. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Shriners Hospitals for Children, 12502 North Pine Drive, Tampa, FL. 33612-9499.

title: Review/Fashion; Girly Looks From de la Renta and Jacobs
description: E. B. White, that great chronicler of life in New York, once said of the city's mood-altering powers, ''You always feel that either by shifting your location 10 blocks or by reducing your fortune by $5 you can experience rejuvenation.'' White probably wasn't thinking of models whisking themselves down a catwalk, but the line rings true for fashion, too.

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: More Deaths Are Attributed To Faulty Firestone Tires
description: Federal regulators announced this evening that since Aug. 31 they had received complaints of 15 more deaths attributed to Firestone tires on sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, raising to 103 the number of deaths under review.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in this section last Wednesday with an article about winemaking in Virginia referred incompletely to a house designed by Thomas Jefferson on the grounds of what is now Barboursville Vineyards. The picture showed the house when it was still standing; as the article noted, it is now a picturesque ruin.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about plans to unveil a sculpture by Lorenzo Pace in Foley Square commemorating an 18th-century cemetery for black New Yorkers misstated the location of the statue. The statue is in Foley Square, within the African Burial Ground and the Commons Historic District. The statue is not on the nearby site within the district where part of the burial ground was excavated in 1991 during construction of the Federal Building at 290 Broadway.

title: Beach Volleyballers Prepare for Action
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Four days off between their Olympic openers and second-round matches have seemed an eternity for the two U.S. women's beach volleyball teams. Now the real action begins.

title: Victory, Advancement, Luster For Donovan and U.S. Team
description: There is no such thing as a golden boy in sports. Too many bottles of peroxide have been dumped on too many athletes' heads.

title: Sound Strategy on Forest Fires
description: What President Clinton has called ''one of the worst fire seasons in memory'' has yielded at least one tangible benefit -- an ambitious new firefighting strategy aimed at protecting the nation's forests and grasslands from runaway fires like those that have scorched more than 6.7 million acres in the last two months. It has also produced a rare moment of bipartisan harmony in an otherwise rancorous election year. Meeting in Salt Lake City, six Western governors, five of them Republicans, joined with administration officials in urging Congress to approve Mr. Clinton's $2.8 billion request to get the plan under way. Congress should heed their plea, while resisting the temptation to reopen an unproductive debate over the administration's earlier proposals to protect millions of acres of federal forests from commercial logging.

title: Sophie Davis, Executive and Philanthropist, Is Dead at 74

She attended St. Mary's Hall before going to the University of Texas at Austin, after which she married her high school sweetheart, Sonny Collins. They began their married life together in New York City and had five children. She was a devoted wife, mother, sister and friend whose cheer, faith, creativity & sense of humor will be lovingly remembered and missed. She is survived by her husband, Edward Everett Collins III; her daughters Joan Wyatt, Stephanie McCarthy and Anna Collins; her sons Taylor and Harris Collins; her two sisters Ann Bahan and Joan Sharpe; her brother Michael Bahan; & her grandchildren Julia Collins and Henry Wyatt. A Memorial Mass will be held at 10 AM on Thursday, September 21 at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Highlands, New Jersey. title: Korean Is Fencing Champion by Razor-Thin Margin
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- Cliff Bayer will long remember the last touch of Young-Ho Kim's sword to his stomach today, the one that crushed his chance of advancing to fencing glory. Bayer came to the Summer Olympics trying to ignore the hopes of his team and his federation that come with winning two World Cup titles in the last year and of being the 12th-ranked foilist in the world. He wanted to prove that an American fencer was the equal of his foreign competition and that he was better than the anxious 19-year-old who lost his first bout at the 1996 Summer Olympics. Bayer had never faced Kim before but was wary of the resilience he had seen when Kim came back from an eight point deficit to win a world championship match. ``He was the one guy I really didn't want to face,'' Bayer said. ``When I saw him in my bracket, I was nervous. He's smart, really smart.'' In their match today, the second for each man, Bayer was cruising, up 11-7, 13-10, then 14-13. But Kim knotted the bout, then ducked under an attack by Bayer and countered with the final touch. ``I'll be seeing that for a long time,'' said Bayer, who works out of the New York Athletic Club and is on a sabbatical from attending the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business. ``I just missed. It's a heartbreaker.'' Kim, 29, inflicted heartache on three more opponents to win a gold medal, staging riveting, methodical comebacks against Dmitri Chevtchenko in the semifinal and Ralf Bissdorf of Germany in the final. Three of Kim's victories came by 15-14 scores. ``I didn't want it that way,'' Kim said through an interpreter. ``I want to win from the beginning.'' In fencing, the first to 15 points wins; if no one hits 15, the most touches after three three-minute rounds wins. Athletes are frequently better at executing a strategy rather than explaining it. Throughout his bout with Bissdorf, Kim stalled frequently, doing nothing, avoiding contact while pointing his foil at Bissdorf across the strip, measuring, or maybe, lulling the German. The ploy seemed to give each man a respite, but Kim could only describe it as a defense against a Bissdorf attack. Later, he said his ability to come back against Bayer, Chevtchenko and Bissdorf was by means of a ``a skill, where I have to stretch my arm if I'm not as tall as he is. I practiced it for three months. It's an attack. . .a stretch.'' Kim is 5-foot-11, Bissdorf stands 6-2. Whatever it was, it worked, and Bissdorf understood. ``He likes to attack and he attacks very well. I do, too,'' he said. ``But we didn't attack each other as much because our defenses were so good. Today we had a real good fight. At 14-14, my strategy was not enough. His was excellent.'' Kim may have succeeded because he adapted his style to suit his foe. Against Chevtchenko, he was a Joe Frazier-like plodder, a tough guy repelling the 6-foot-4-inch Russian's trademark running charge, like an irate bull, down the strip. Their bout had all the wondrous excitement of a late-in-the National Basketball Association game Hack-a-Shaq strategy. Against the lean Bissdorf, he seemed to mimick the German's style, as they stretched their scoring into early in the third period. Bissdorf seemed to be in command at 9-6, but Kim rallied with five unanswered touches and stretched the lead to 13-10, before Bissdorf tied Kim at 14. When Kim won the decisive point, his coach rushed onto the stage at the Sydney Exhibition Center and tackled him, while Bissdorf stood to the side, waiting to congratulate him. ``I didn't know if I was dreaming,'' Kim said. ``I didn't know if it was reality. I thought about my wife, my mother, my son. History was being made. This is the first gold for Korea in the men's individual foil.'' Kim, whose wife fenced until giving birth to their son, had one request to make of the Korean Fencing Association, now that he has a little leverage. Fencing is not widely popular in Korea, and Kim rarely had enough good partners to work with. He's had to travel around Korea from his home in Taejun to stay sharp. In victory, he said, ``I ask for more opponents.''

description: IN the beginning, images didn't matter. The Internet as first conceived was just a way for government agencies, universities and libraries to share information, and what they shared was fairly mundane: catalog entries, data files, e-mail messages. Animation and movement didn't enter into it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUECKEL, ALICE E.
description: LUECKEL-Alice E., 94. On September 19, 2000 at Seabury Village in Bloomfield, CT. She was the wife of the late William J. Lueckel Sr. and beloved friend of stepson William J. Lueckel Jr. and his family of Glastonbury, CT. In lieu of flowers a contribution in her memory to St. James Episcopal Church in the Bronx would be appreciated. A memorial service will be held at Seabury in November.

title: A Parent's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Beautiful to Be True
description: KYOCERA knives have all the cachet needed to persuade home cooks to plunk down $100: the endorsement of Ming Tsai, a celebrity chef; great press; a novel material (ceramic in the blades); and a beautiful design.

title: Suave Rival Has Words For the U.S.: 'En Garde'
description: Like the French satirical television show that twits the United States for being the ''World Company'' that invades people's lives around the globe, the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, expresses frustration, and perhaps a little envy, at America's dominion.

title: Some New Entries in Their Lists of Favorite Shopping Sites
description: Last September, we asked listed some shoppers' favorite sites, and profiled some new e-businesses. Some of them are revisted in this section.

title: Gore Maintaining Momentum, Post-Labor Day Polling Shows
description: Polls taken since Labor Day show Al Gore keeping the momentum he gained after his party's convention and continuing to hold an advantage over George W. Bush on issues like health care, prescription drugs and the environment.

title: The Buck Stops at Justice
description: The finger-pointing has begun in the failed case against Wen Ho Lee, and there is plenty of blame to go around.

title: ICG CHIEF STEPS ASIDE
description: ICG Communications Inc. said yesterday that its chief executive had quit, a day after the provider of telephone and Internet service warned of lower sales. Carl Vogel, ICG's chairman and chief executive, and two board members, Gary Howard and Thomas Hicks, resigned without giving a reason, ICG said. A spokeswoman declined to comment further.

title: U.S. Is Bruised in Its Victory, and China Is Bumped
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 20  China is gone. There will be no replay of the 1996 Summer Games final, no replay of the 1999 World Cup final. And the new American coach, April Heinrichs, will not exactly wax sentimental at not presiding over a rematch.

title: Rev. Ellwood Kieser, Priest And Film Producer, Dies at 71
description: The Rev. Ellwood Kieser, an Emmy Award-winning Roman Catholic priest who blended religious commitment with a passion for making socially aware film and television, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 71 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, EVA
description: BERKOWITZ-Eva. Born July 29, 1913. Died on September 18, 2000. Devoted wife of 53 years to Abraham, loving mother to Morrell, proud grandmother of Jake and Max, & who adored her daughterin-law Harriet. A good, kind, gentle and giving person whose likes are not often seen. Contributions can be sent in her name to Temple Israel, 112 East 75 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINS, JAMES, M.D.
description: CUMMINS-James, M.D. Of Bedminster, NJ died on September 16, 2000. Beloved ''Dr. Jim'', surgeon on hospital ship, Refuge; served in U.S. Navy during World War II and Korean War; rank of Commander. General and thoracic surgeon at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Graduate of Fordham University, Georgetown University School of Medicine & member of American College of Surgeons. Survived by wife, Dr. Ella Cummins, children, Densey Jovonen, Jim Cummins, Dr. Tom Cummins and Candace Riegelhaupt, grandchildren Erik, Justina, James, Ian, Loren, Rebecca and Alexandra, great-grandchildren, Camilla and Nickalas and brothers, Dr. Mitchell Cummins, Tom Cummins, Esq. and Dr. Edward Cummins. A memorial service will be held at St. John's on the Mountain in Bernardsville, New Jersey at 11 AM on Saturday, September 23. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Morristown Memorial Hospital.

title: Automated Advice Sites Turning Up the Heat on Planners
description: MOST of his peers look at the Internet and see a threat to their livelihood, but Frank Armstrong sees a medium for spreading the gospel of financial discipline to those he could not reach otherwise.

title: Speaking of Pinots, Exploring the Blanc
description: THE pinot family of grapes is a large and hospitable one. And like many families, it's also a bit unstable. We all know -- and a lot of us love -- pinot noir, the head of the clan. And a lot of us like the offspring, pinot gris, which in Italy goes by the name pinot grigio. Gris and grigio, in case you were wondering, both mean gray.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RABINOWICZ, RACHEL ANNE
description: RABINOWICZ-Rachel Anne ZL 20 Ellul 5747 14 September 1987 Love everlasting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYAN, JOAN GIBSON
description: BRYAN-Joan Gibson. On September 16 at Beth Israel Hospice. Born in Minnesota, she trained at the famed Mayo and became an RN. Later, she was for many years an associate at the Herbert Starr Art Gallery in New York. She will be deeply missed by all who cherish the rememberance of her loyal and compassion-giving friendship. A memorial service is planned. ''To live in hearts we leave behind is not to die.''

title: Before a Hollywood Crowd, Democrats Lower the Volume
description: Face to face with 300 of their most generous contributors, Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman muted their criticism of the entertainment industry on Monday night as they sought to reassure Hollywood that their calls for stricter marketing practices were not an effort to squelch creativity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, DR. ELKAN
description: SNYDER-Dr. Elkan. September 19th. Husband of Ellen and the late Bess Cheikin. Father of Fred and his wife Leslie Snyder and stepfather of Steven, Mark and Laura Zirinsky. Grandfather of Nicholas and Douglas Snyder. Brother of Leona Dick and Beulah Fishman. Service Wednesday September 20 at 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Two years today. Devoted mother and Nana. Her song has ended but the melody lingers on. Joyce, Jason, Greg and Jordana

title: Changes Are Made In Public Relations
description: Several agencies are making changes involving public relations operations.

title: Officials Puzzle Over American's Behavior : Hostages' Fate Unclear As Filipinos Hit Rebels
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines  The fate of the 19 hostages held by the militant Islamic group Abu Sayyaf remained unclear Tuesday as the Philippine military marched across Jolo, pounding the rebels with mortars and air attacks.

title: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND WILL SHUT 2 COTTONSEED PLANTS
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company, one of the world's largest processors of oilseed, corn and wheat, said yesterday that it would permanently close its cottonseed plants in Montgomery, Ala., and North Little Rock, Ark., because of poor market conditions in the cottonseed business. Archer Daniels said it would also indefinitely close its cottonseed processing operations at Levelland and Sweetwater, Tex. The company, based in Decatur, Ill., did not say how many employees would be affected by the moves.

title: A Guided Tour Through a Writer's Mazy Mind
description: QUARREL & QUANDARY

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the China Disabled People's Performing Arts Troupe and its chairman, Deng Pufang, who are touring the United States, misstated the year of the death of Mr. Deng's father, the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping. It was 1997, not 1987.

title: Whitewater-Chronology
description: Major events in the Clinton investigation:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Plan to Compensate Nuclear Workers Is Slowed
description: An administration plan to compensate private-sector workers who were made sick by exposure to hazardous chemicals or radiation while building nuclear weapons may fall victim to a jurisdictional dispute, administration officials say.

title: Metro Business; New Airport Bus Service
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun a new bus service from its George Washington Bridge Bus Station to Kennedy International and Newark International Airports.

title: Sports of The Times; Redskins Can't Buy A Winner
description: IN Washington, the Redskins are more than a professional sports team, they are also a passion, more valuable to the city than the politicians who run it. Only someone who was born and raised there might fully understand this. When the Redskins are doing well, the crime doesn't seem so bad and the potholes are not so numerous. When the Redskins aren't doing well, fans begin begging for presidential intervention.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Markets Fall, But Goldman Keeps Rolling
description: Anybody who has wondered why the world's biggest banks have been scrambling for a foothold on Wall Street need look no further than the Goldman Sachs Group's latest earnings report.

title: For the U.S., It's Another Abrupt Finish
description: What do you do to stand out when you are the eighth American Olympic boxer to climb into the ring and the previous seven boxers from your team have not only won but won convincingly?

title: Final Passage of Bill To Normalize U.S. Ties Is Approved, 83 to 15 : Senate Vote Introduces New Era in China Trade
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate, by a resounding 83-to-15 vote, gave final approval to legislation Tuesday to normalize trade relations with China permanently, a move expected to unleash a period of fierce competition and rocky change in the global economic system, but also to increase stability in the world's most populous country and nudge it toward greater political openness.

title: Redskins (1-2) Facing Paying a Heavy Price
description: The Giants, taking advantage of an obscure National Football League rule, sent scouts daily to the training camp practices of the Redskins this summer, accumulating dozens of pieces of useful information.

title: London-Frankfurt Merger: Deal Whose Time Had Passed
description: When the planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges collapsed last week, the participants were left to confront an odd reality: those markets, it turned out, could not beat the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUCKER, MARGARET
description: SCHUCKER-Margaret. The Board of Trustees, faculty, staff and students at The Institute of Design and Construction mourn the loss of Margaret (Maggie) Schucker, wife of the late Charles Schucker. Maggie was with the Institute for over thirty years and was a dear friend of The Institute. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Vincent C. Battista, R.A., Executive Director

title: Milosevic, Trailing in Polls, Rails Against NATO
description: In his race for re-election, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is running against NATO and the United States, not against his democratic opposition.

title: Business Travel; An apparent case of air rage on Southwest Airlines ends in what is later ruled homicide.
description: LAST Saturday, The Associated Press sent out a short report datelined Salt Lake City that began with this astounding sentence: ''A passenger who tried to break into the cockpit during a Southwest Airlines flight was killed by other passengers who restrained him, and not by a heart attack, an autopsy has concluded.''

title: SPECIAL TODAY/E-Commerce
description: Interactive television has been a World's Fair technology for years, but this fall it is arriving in living rooms across the country. Just how interactive do viewers want to be? Plus: Articles on the rest of the entertainment industry in the ever-changing online landscape, business-to-business e-commerce, personal finance and shopping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, WM. BRIAN
description: LITTLE-Wm. Brian. Loved husband, father, son, grandfather, father-in-law, friend of Judy, Jackie, Greg, Bill, Will, Megan, Jack, Henry and Alicia. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Colgate University or the Photography Department of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art or the Photography Department of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Oregon Immigration Official Resigns Amid Furor
description: After a wave of complaints about abusive treatment of foreigners by immigration agents that gave Oregon's largest city the unwanted nickname of ''Deportland'' in some Asian countries, the top immigration official in Portland said today that he was retiring.

title: DEVILS' PARTIAL SQUAD FALLS TO BRUINS
description: The Devils suffered a 2-1 preseason loss to the Boston Bruins last night in Albany, home of the New Jersey's top affiliate in the minor leagues.

title: L.L. Bean Beats the Current by Staying in Midstream
description: IT is 9:30 on a Sunday night in southern Maine, and it is fairly safe to say that nowhere else in this state is someone doing brisk trade in backpacks, sunglasses and hunting supplies.

title: PARTS MAKERS HIT
description: Pinched by a slowdown in automobile markets, the Michelin tire company and Valeo S.A., reported disappointing results. Michelin said first-half operating income fell 9.4 percent, to 540 million euros, or $469 million. Valeo said it would not meet a projected full-year operating profit of 7 percent of revenue. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: MORE ON THE GAMES
description: GYMNASTICS

title: Correction
description: An editorial last Saturday erred in saying that Gov. George W. Bush opposes the right to sue health maintenance organizations. The Bush campaign says that its candidate favors a patient's right to sue provided that the claim is first reviewed by an independent medical panel.

title: New Realism Wins the Day as Senate Passes Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Senate's overwhelming vote today to give permanent trade benefits to China ended a clash between America's global economic interests and the notion that the United States could use the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Beijing's behavior.

title: Tightening Controls on Media Worry Journalists in Angola
description: The microphone was burning, the telephone switchboard was flashing and this time it was Victor Correa on the line to Radio Ecclesia, 97.5 on the FM dial. And the three government officials taking calls in the studio braced themselves for yet another public whaling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRES, JULIO S.
description: TORRES-Julio S. On September 18, 2000. Survived by his devoted wife Maria. Loving children Martha, Julio H. and Omar. Beloved brother of Josefina, Maruja and Alfonso. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 9:30AM at Our Lady of Cenacle. For information call Walter B. Cooke, 718-823-6200.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNA, BARBARA
description: KENNA-Barbara. The Class of 1952 of The College of New Rochelle mourns the loss of our classmate Bobbie on September 11. We will remember her spirit, generosity, zest for living and loyalty to all. Alice Timothy Marcella Chodaczek

title: Swede Unseats Champion
description: Pia Hansen of Sweden outshot Kim Rhode, the defending Olympic double-trap champion, in the final and won the gold medal. Rhode, who won the event at age 17 at the Atlanta Games in 1996, claimed the bronze, while Deborah Gelisio of Italy took the silver medal.

description: To the Editor:

description: The ad is anything but subtle or subliminable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSESSON, ESTHER W.
description: MOSESSON-Esther W. Died on September 19th, 2000 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Mosesson, devoted mother of Michael and Shirley (McDowell) Mosesson, and Judy and Ira Dembrow, cherished grandmother of Matthew and Amber (Jost) Mosesson, Marni and William Kambol, Aimee Mosesson, Adam Dembrow and Beth Dembrow, adored great grandmother of Harper Mosesson, loving sister of the late Archie, Beatrice, Blanche, Helen, Herbert, Lille, and Norman, & caring aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Thursday 9:45 A.M. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Esther and Benjamin Mosesson Fund for Thrombosis Research, The Blood Research Institute, PO Box 2178, Milwaukee, WI. 53201-2178.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about people in the movie industry who were troubled by politicians' recent criticism of Hollywood misstated the sponsorship of a fund-raiser for Al Gore that day. Although the sponsors included Alan Horn, president and chief operating officer of Warner Brothers, the company itself was not a sponsor. The others were Rob Reiner, the writer and director; Haim Saban, a children's television executive; and Ron Burkle, a supermarket entrepreneur.

title: New Tally Confirms an Upset in Primary
description: Regina Seltzer, a political outsider who challenged Representative Michael P. Forbes after he switched from Republican to Democrat, will be the Democratic Congressional nominee for the East End of Long Island, a recount confirmed today.

title: National News Briefs
description: Restrictions Sought on Use of Acne Drug

title: As New Geeks Seek Chic, Gadgets Get Fashionable
description: LAUREL WELLS, a co-founder and the marketing director of Gurl.com, an Internet magazine for teenagers, is a study in bohemian chic.

title: Night of the Streaming B-Movies
description: WHILE Hollywood's moguls are trying to figure out the big budget future of online entertainment, Alan Miller is staking his claim to a modest, but tangible, piece of that future.

title: THAT OWNS HYATT HOTELS WILL BUY CHAIN OF INNS
description: The Hyatt Corporation's Pritzker family agreed to buy U.S. Franchise Systems Inc., the franchiser of Microtel Inns and Suites, for $99.8 million. The Pritzkers, owners of the Hyatt hotel chain, will pay $5 a share for all U.S. Franchise outstanding stock, 14 percent more than Monday's closing price of $4.38. The deal negates a June agreement for the family to invest $75 million to gain a controlling interest in U.S. Franchise, which is based in Atlanta. The family, from Chicago, is one of the wealthiest families in the nation.

title: Getting Good Teachers for Poor Schools
description: MANY urban teachers' unions have negotiated the right for senior members to pick the schools where they teach. Some have gone further. In Los Angeles, teachers can even choose which classes to teach. And in Boston, principals cannot rehire promising first-year teachers if senior instructors want the novices' jobs.

title: Metro Business; Print and Dot-Com Team
description: Primedia, the parent company of New York magazine, has selected MLX.com, an online real estate company, to power its Web site's database, which will include listings for hundreds of apartments for rent and sale each week, officials said yesterday.

title: Russia Sends Mixed Signals on Laser System Sale to Iran
description: The White House said yesterday that Russia had suspended a contract to sell Iran sophisticated laser technology that Washington says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons. But the Russian scientific institute involved says it still plans to make the sale.

title: The Buck Stops at Justice
description: The finger-pointing has begun in the failed case against Wen Ho Lee, and there is plenty of blame to go around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JACOB
description: GROSS-Jacob. Beloved husband of the late Ella. Devoted father of the late Jerry Gross. Cherished grandmother of Michelle and Elyse. Loving father-in-law of Esther. Service Thursday, 10:45AM. ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: Dutch and Cuban Win Judo Golds
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Mark Huizinga of the Netherlands defeated Carlos Honorato of Brazil to win the Olympic gold medal Wednesday in men's 90-kilogram judo.

title: THE BOSS; Solving the Puzzles of China
description: I remember looking at my wife asleep on the plane on my way to Shanghai two years ago and thinking that this woman must really love me to give up her job, her friends and her lifestyle to move to China with me. But this has turned out to be the best life experience that we have had. And unless we are truly blessed, it will be the best we will ever have.

title: She's Only Code and Pixels, but She Can Help You Shop
description: IF you are unsure about which of the 100 different flower arrangements at Proflowers.com is right for you, just ask Emily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, GEORGE E.
description: SANDS-George E. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and former President, George Sands. PastPresident of the Metropolitan Golf Association, honorary chairman of the Ike Tournament, founder and Chairman of the Long Island Caddy Scholarship Fund. An active member since 1920, he will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Marjorie and to his family. Jerome H. Grossman, President Enid Rosenthal, Secretary

title: The Web Makes Going Global Easy, Until You Try to Do It
description: WHEN First Net Card was started in 1999, it had a vision of using the Internet to provide credit for online transactions to anyone in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASH, HAROLD C.
description: CASH-Harold C. On Sept. 19, 2000. Born October 29, 1915 in Syracuse, NY. An Industrial Psychologist specializing in Marketing and Sales training. A graduate of Syracuse University with a Master's Degree from NYU. A former Marketing Professor at NYU. Beloved husband of Frances Elizabeth for 56 years. Loving father of James, Margaret, Mary and Sheila. Also survived by six grandchildren. Reposing Wednesday at Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, L.I. Interment Friday, St. Columbkille Cemetery, Seneca Falls, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Mineola Volunteer Ambulance Corps would be appreciated. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Wen Ho Lee, and Our Calls for Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges' Group Opposes Bill to Limit Seminar Participation
description: The judges who set policy for the federal court system voted today to oppose new limits on the ability of judges to attend privately sponsored seminars and educational programs.

title: Armstrong to Race After Injury
description: Lance Armstrong said today that he was largely recovered from a cracked neck vertebra he sustained when he was hit by a car three weeks ago while cycling in Nice, France, and would race next week in the 148.4-mile Olympic road race and 29-mile individual time trial.

title: Mary Colquhoun, 61, Casting Director
description: Mary Colquhoun, a versatile, award-winning casting director, died on Sept. 10 in Manhattan. She was 61 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dispatches From a Culinary Frontier
description: BETWEEN carrying on about Ian Thorpe, the young swimmer with feet almost as big as a kangaroo's, and marveling at Sydney's magnificent harbor and opera house, the writers and broadcasters covering the Olympic Games have somehow found time to rave about the food and wine they have discovered in Australia.

title: Speaking English Is My Business
description: I'm the official interpreter, translator and all-around spokesman to the English-speaking world for the medieval Czech town of Cesky Krumlov.

title: Overtime and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Peru's President, Cheered by Supporters, Vows to Stay in Office Until Next Summer
description: In his first public appearance since he called for new elections and the dismantling of the National Intelligence Service, President Alberto K. Fujimori entered the Palace of Government tonight to the cheers of supporters and assured the nation that he was in full control and would remain in office until his successor is sworn in next July.

title: Mrs. Clinton Against the Odds
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement last night.

title: Mighty Ducks Hire Neil Smith
description: Neil Smith, who was dismissed as president and general manager of the Rangers last March 28 along with Coach John Muckler, has joined the Anaheim Mighty Ducks as a consultant to Pierre Gauthier, the team president.

title: EMI Says It and Time Warner Make Deal Concessions
description: In an attempt to keep European regulators from blocking a $20 billion merger, Time Warner and the EMI Group today proposed what they called ''substantial'' concessions that might include selling some of their record labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, BELLA
description: WINSTON-Bella. On Sunday, September 17, we lost our center, our solace and our strength. Our mother's love sustained and comforted twenty-eight people; now the heart of a vast family is broken in ways that can not mend. At 72, our mother's soul was still trusting and sweet yet also wise and brave enough to withstand daily strife and terrible tragedy. Her death followed our father's by three short months, as if he could endure neither life nor death without her. We, her children, held a private funeral on Monday so that we might have a few last moments alone with her. Both our love and grief were too great to share.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts to control a fire near Boulder, Colo., gave an incorrect title in some editions for Joe Gang of the Boulder County Sheriff's Office. He is a sheriff's lieutenant, not the sheriff.

title: Atlantis Returns to Earth
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Space shuttle Atlantis and its crew of seven swooped through the pre-dawn darkness and landed Wednesday, ending a successful mission to outfit the international space station.

title: HEINZ CREATES NEW DIVISION TO OFFER SPECIALTY PET FOOD
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it had created Heinz Specialty Pet Food, a new unit that will focus on selling Nature's Recipe, Techni-Cal and other specialty brands to veterinarians and pet stores. The new business will be separated from Heinz's grocery and mass merchandising pet food unit, which the company said should help increase sales and profit of its specialty pet food. Specialty pet food has generated about $150 million in sales for Heinz, which is based in Pittsburgh. The market for specialty food has been rising 11 percent a year, while at grocery stores it has increased only 3 percent.

title: Pathmark Stores Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: Pathmark Stores said today that it had emerged from bankruptcy court protection after a judge approved its plan to reorganize and eliminate about $1 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, PATRICIA FAY
description: WOODS-Patricia Fay, on September 6, 2000 in San Francisco, CA of cancer after a short illness. She was the beloved mother of Wendy Luers, Ward, Cynthia and Susan Woods, loving grandmother of Kate and Alexandra Woods, Ramsay and Connor Turnbull, Max and Tatia Bauer & great-grandmother to Rowan and India, loved by her sons-in-law William Luers, Myron Sugarman and Johannes Bauer and her daughter-in-law Priscilla Woods. She will be remembered fondly by her caregivers: Rosa Sandoval, Annie Vega, Marcenita Villegas and Rosemary Massey. Patsy, a third generation San Franciscan, was generous and important in the lives of her many nieces and nephews, cousins, and friends of all generations whom she welcomed with ease and style in the many places she made her home. She will be sorely missed by all whose lives she brightened with her happy spirit and contagious optimism and energy. And above all, we will all remember her humor, kindness and wonderful sparkling smile. The family suggests contributions to St. Anthony's Foundation, 121 Golden Gate Avenue, San Francisco, Ca 94102 or Mount St. Joseph-St. Elizabeth, 100 Masonic Avenue, San Francisco, CA 94118. A memorial service will be held on October 20th at 3 PM at St. Dominic's Church, 2390 Bush Street, San Francisco followed by a reception.

title: Krayzelburg Favored; Thompson a Long Shot
description: Lenny Krayzelburg is swimming toward another Olympic gold medal. Jenny Thompson would settle for one individual one of her own.

title: Guilty Plea in Connecticut Fraud Case
description: A Michigan man has pleaded guilty to helping Martin Frankel, the former money manager, defraud the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, FRANCES E., M.D.
description: STEIN-Frances E., M.D. Died at home September 18, 2000. Mass of Resurrection to be held at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street, NYC at 10AM on Thursday, September 21, 2000.

title: Nevada Senate Race Tightening
description: Republican John Ensign's 20-point lead in Nevada's U.S. Senate race over Democratic challenger Ed Bernstein has been cut nearly in half, according to a new poll.

title: He Still Doesn't Sell Beans, But the Page Keeps Perking
description: DAVE WOLFF now has a computer (sort of), which puts him ahead of where he was a year ago, when we followed his first steps into the world of e-commerce. With help from me, a high school friend and an avid but amateur Webmaster, Dave put his small-town Main Street coffee shop, The Fine Grind, online. He hoped to sell coffee and coffee-related items on the Web, research sources for supplies, lure customers to the cafe with promotions and increase a sense of community in the rural area around Bel Air, Md., 45 miles northeast of Baltimore.

title: Israel Puts Peace Talks Off Again, On Again
description: Israel canceled a scheduled meeting with Palestinian negotiators today, raising concerns that the fragile peace effort had reached another potential breaking point. But by day's end, the Israelis had arranged another meeting for Wednesday.

title: Hold the Ads, ABC Decides
description: The world of network television is increasingly about creating events, and ABC, with its plan for ''Gideon's Crossing,'' a medical drama, has found a way to make one of its new shows stand out.

title: Food Chief Defends the $2.18 Lunch
description: The other day, Kevin F. Gill, the Board of Education's chief of food and transportation, made a genial host at a $2.18 lunch, the best the New York City school system has to offer.

title: U.S. Team Confident Following Two Losses
description: BLACKTOWN, Australia, Sept. 20  Invincible for so many years, the United States softball team let the world know that it can be beaten. Now, everybody wants in on the action.

title: Through the Electronic Lion Gates to the Foods of Asia
description: The best Web sites that sell food products deliver solid information along with them, and the new site established by the Asia Society, www.asiafood.org, is a prime example. Among the products for sale are spice pastes, noodles, rice and condiments suitable for most Asian cuisines, as well as for Persian and Australian cooking. But even better, the site has recipes galore and links to resources like a fairly thorough glossary of Asian food terms, from Charlaine Solomon's Encyclopedia of Asian Food.

description: EDUCATION COLUMN

title: As Election Nears, Yugoslav Rivals Lash Out
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 20  With Yugoslavia's presidential election only days away, the two main rivals held competing rallies here tonight, speaking as if to two separate nations, with President Slobodan Milosevic taking up the fight for his future in an extraordinarily personal fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, CYRELLA
description: LANGER-Cyrella. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our members Richard Langer upon the loss of his mother, and to Dr. Isaac Chavel upon the loss of his sister. May they and their families be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President
