title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, FRANCES
description: KANTOR-Frances. Died September 16, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Was joyous in life. Leaves daughters Dana, Elisabeth and Marjorie, four grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Graveside service today, 1PM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Valentines Words Serve as Reminder
description: ATLANTA -- Bobby Valentine was leaning back in his office chair with his feet crossed on the desk in front of him last night at Turner Field. A picture of Valentine would have shown a manager who seemingly looked relaxed, but that was not true. Valentine was still seething inside, the rage just not being shown outwardly anymore.

title: Report Says Evidence Lacking Against Clintons in Whitewater
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The independent counsel who has been investigating the tangled affair known as Whitewater said today that there is insufficient evidence to charge President Clinton and the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, with wrongdoing.

title: HEWLETT SETS WIRELESS INVESTMENT
description: Hewlett-Packard plans to invest $52 million in a wireless location network under construction by U.S. Wireless, a company that provides mobile-location and traffic-related information to communications companies. The network is expected to allow users access to traffic navigation services, in addition to allowing authorities to determine the location of cell phone users in 911 emergency situations. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, JEROME
description: NEWMAN-Jerome. Beloved husband of the late Roslyn. Devoted father of Nan Frankel and Charlie Newman. Loving grandfather of six, adored great grandfather of six. Services Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ Wednesday, 4 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUTEAU, MARGARET M. NEE REGAN
description: COUTEAU-Margaret M. nee Regan. Of Ridge, NY, on Monday, September 18, 2000. Beloved wife of Thomas. Loving mother of Robert, Thomas, and Mary Zaffarano. Devoted grandmother of Nicole, Jacqueline, Michael, Nicholas and John. Her love and spirit will always be with us.

title: Orwell in Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: HITACHI FIBER OPTIC VENTURE
description: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest electronics maker, said yesterday that it would transfer its fiber optic components business unit into a new company to be called OpNext Inc., a joint venture with Clarity Group. Clarity Group itself is a joint venture between the Los Angeles-based Clarity Partners, a new fund that invests in media and communications companies and the Marubeni Group of Japan. Clarity Group will invest up to $450 million in the new company. Laura M. Holson (NYT)

title: As Brazil's Market Grows, So Does the Free Access Dispute
description: WITH 170 million people and more than 10 million computers, five times the number in use five years ago, Brazil is the most promising Internet and e-commerce market in Latin America.

title: Adding Sniping to Bidding to Get the Goods
description: WHEN Eric Clayberg and Dan Riggs crossed paths on eBay a year ago, they were exuberant newcomers to online auctions. Mr. Clayberg, a software programmer in Middletown, Mass., had bought an old coin-operated arcade game from Mr. Riggs, the co-owner of an arcade-game shop in Tulsa, Okla. They never met or even talked on the phone, but they raved about the way the Internet had enabled them to find each other 1,400 miles away.

title: Atheists and Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Syrah's Northwest Passage
description: SYRAH is a coming grape in the United States, and Washington is one of its hotbeds: more than 1,500 acres are planted with syrah vines. That's almost triple the acreage of a year ago, though well behind the more than 10,000 acres planted in California, where acreage is also rapidly increasing. But while syrah in California may always be overshadowed by chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon and the other big boys, it has a chance to make a name for itself in Washington, where the wine industry is not as established.

title: Aging in America: The Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: The Naked Truth About Chestnuts
description: Chestnuts are not often seen in their well-armored husks, but the Eckerton Hill Farm stall at the Union Square Greenmarket has them on Mondays and Wednesdays. Chestnut trees mostly succumbed to blight early in the 20th century. Tim Stark, however, owner of the farm, which is in Pennsylvania, is one of the few who still have healthy trees. His fresh, unroasted chestnuts are $4 a pound. Alex Lee, the executive chef at Daniel, finds them sweeter than Italian chestnuts and says they can be frozen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDMUNDS, ROBERT, M.D.
description: EDMUNDS-Robert, M.D. Died peacefully September 18, 2000. Born September 14, 1924, Toledo, OH. Graduate Harvard College 1946 and Columbia Univ. College of Physicians and Surgeons 1951. He was a surgeon on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital for 25 years and served on the Faculty of Columbia P&S. He was a fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Member of the N. Y. Surgical Society and N. Y. Academy of Medicine and an Officer of the N. Y. Cancer Society. Subsequent to his private practice, he was a Medical Director for the U. S. Steel Corp. in Chicago and Cleveland. During WWII, he was an officer in the Navy and later served in the Army Medical Corps Reserve retiring as Colonel. He is survived by his five children Nancy Kalal, Priscilla Smith, Elizabeth Bennett, Cynthia Edmunds, Robert Edmunds and four grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 28 at 4PM at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center Chapel, 113 St. between Amsterdam Ave. and Morningside Dr, NYC. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, New York, 10019 Att: Donations.

title: Equatorial Guinea Swimmer Finds Celebrity
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- Eric Moussambani is a refreshing breath of air to an Olympic movement too often scandalized by drug cheats and pompous officials.

title: In Clinton's Words: 'An Outstretched Hand'
description: Following is President Clinton's statement today in the White House Briefing Room on the Senate vote on trade relations with China, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: Those Banner Ads Keep On Waving, But They're Singing a Different Tune
description: WAY back when, say in 1995, they were still something of a curiosity. That was the year that Yahoo first decided to put advertising on its site, a time when the words ''advertising banners'' still conjured images of cloth signs trailing from airplanes on hot summer days.

title: Safin, U.S. Open Victor, Loses Cool and Match
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20  "Some day he's going to crush me," Fabrice Santoro said. "It's just a matter of time."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Vladimir V. Putin's dedication of a Jewish community center in Moscow included an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for the rabbi shown. He was Mordechai Eliyahu, former chief Sephardic rabbi of Israel, not Meir Lau, the current chief Ashkenazic one.

title: New Home Construction Rises 0.3%
description: Construction of new homes increased in August for the first time in four months as lower mortgage rates renewed interest from buyers.

title: School Laptops Paid With Ads Called Feasible
description: The Board of Education is pushing ahead on a proposal to provide portable computers to most New York City students as well as Internet access over a new Web site that would include commercial advertising, all at a cost that has now been put at $900 million over the next 10 years.

title: Excite@Home Chief Executive Quits but Stays as Chairman
description: George Bell, one of the first executives to leave a traditional media company to seek his fortune on the Internet, said yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of Excite@Home.

title: From Switzerland, a Cheese to Yodel For
description: A new cheese in town has the ecru color and smooth texture of Appenzeller but an herbal twist. The rind is rubbed with herbes de Provence, infusing the cheese, which is fruity tasting, with the aroma of thyme. The cheese, an artisanal import from Switzerland, is called Le Marechal. It is made for a glass of sauvignon blanc. Zabar's, Broadway and 80th Street, is selling Le Marechal for $8.49 a pound. It is $14.95 a pound at Ideal Cheese, which moved this summer from Second Avenue and 63rd Street to 942 First Avenue (52nd Street).

title: Commercial Real Estate: For Skyscraper Museum, A Home at Ground Level; Space Donated in Battery Park City Tower
description: The Skyscraper Museum finally has a skyscraper to call its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONGIOVANNI, ANTHONY
description: BONGIOVANNI-Anthony. On September 18, 2000 of Lyndhurst, NJ. Beloved brother of Nancy Porro and Emil Bongiovanni. Funeral Saturday 9 A.M. from the IppolitoStellato Funeral Home, 425 Ridge Road, Lyndhurst, NJ. Funeral Mass 10 A.M. Sacred Heart R.C. Church, Lyndhurst, NJ. Entombment Holy Cross Chapel Mausoleum, N. Arlington, NJ. Friends will be received Friday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Donations may be made ''in memory of Anthony Bongiovanni'' to: Sacred Heart R.C. Church, 324 Ridge Rd, Lyndhurst, NJ 07071.

title: Richard Holman, 77, Founder Of The Wall Street Transcript
description: Richard A. Holman, an inventive publisher and editor who foresaw the market for specialized business information services and was involved in an important legal test case to distinguish true business journalism from tout sheets, died on Monday at New York University Hospital. He was 77.

title: If That's Me in the E-Dressing Room, Why Doesn't This Fit?
description: I HAVE never been the kind of person who has a shopping outfit, a special no-fuss ensemble that can be whipped off to try on clothes and reassembled in record time without leaving a hair out of place.

title: In Tales of Loss And Loneliness, A Singer Finally Finds Herself
description: Suddenly Emmylou Harris is a full-fledged songwriter. She has spent most of her 25-year career recording other people's music, occasionally placing a song of her own on an album. But for her new ''Red Dirt Girl'' (Nonesuch), she simply decided to write a whole album, then proceeded to come up with 11 of its 12 songs. That gave her a small problem with stage patter when she started a three-night stand on Monday night at Joe's Pub (425 Lafayette Street, East Village). ''I usually preface songs with who wrote them,'' she said ruefully. ''But I wrote them, so I don't know what to say.''

title: Marketing Tied to Increase In Prescription Drug Sales
description: Advertising to consumers has stimulated a major increase in retail spending on prescription drugs, the fastest-growing item in the nation's health care budget, a new study says.

title: Close Your Eyes, Punch and Judy. It's Too Scary!; A Dark Universe of Puppets Is Luring Adults With Tales Of the Bizarre and Profound
description: By any clock, it's not Howdy Doody time in the dank universe of puppets and cockroaches that inhabit the gloomy stage sets for ''Snuffhouse Dustlouse.''

title: Is It Theft, or Is It Freedom? 7 Views Of the Web's Impact on Culture Clashes
description: FILE sharing'' sounds innocent enough. But the practice of downloading files from the Internet is at the center of a battle between Internet-connected consumers and the entertainment industry. Today, file sharing refers mainly to songs that computer users download in the MP3 format from the hard drives of other users through services like Napster. The music industry calls this stealing. Those who swap files reply that it is the same as borrowing a CD from a friend. But while Congress and the courts wrestle with legalities of the music industry, file sharing is spreading to other creative works. As bandwidth expands, video games, movies and pay-per-view TV programs could be swapped as easily as songs. Already, multimedia file-sharing services like Gnutella and Scour Exchange provide a glimpse of this future.

title: The Fragile Nature of a Dream
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- First there was a twinge, then tightness, then a screaming, hot pain. Finally, Inger Miller had to face the moment of reckoning. She got down in the starting blocks last week and tried to explode. She couldn't.

title: The Gods Hovering in Times Square
description: The Times Square of legend takes a last loopy bow in Richard Sandler's engaging documentary ''The Gods of Times Square.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Increases Sharply In a Technology Rebound

title: Bus Driver Lost? Agitators Banned? 'No Worries' for an Anxious Nation
description: Doesn't anyone here worry? Ever?

title: Hollywood Agents' New Role: They're Silicon Valley Guys
description: FOR decades, Hollywood talent agents used the phone and a brash style to make deals for clients. Talent agencies focused their energies on signing up actors, writers and directors and finding jobs for them in films and television.

title: Rebates May Save Money, Just Maybe Not for You
description: WITH more merchants elbowing their way into the Internet bazaar, an old gimmick, the rebate, is increasingly being used to snare online customers.

title: U.S. Women Hoops Team Survives a Scare
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- Ruthie Bolton-Holyfield had just rushed two shots, long 3-point heaves that careened badly off the rim. Lacking rhythm and patience, she ran downcourt to witness something even more unsightly. Elena Pchkova, the Russian forward, beating most of Team USA downcourt, hitting a little runner from the left side, clutching her fist at the enormous possibility in front of her. The United States women trailed by seven points, their dominance threatened by the same nation that dealt them their last Olympic loss eight years ago. ``I don't if I would used the word 'scared,''' began Nikki McCray, the starting shooting guard, ``but we had to show our character at some point, or we were headed for real danger.'' It began with a McCray steal and 3-pointer with 17 minutes left, a shot that erased the first Olympic halftime deficit the women had known since 1992 in Barcelona. Their resolve kicked in again with less than 12 minutes remaining, when Bolton-Holyfield caught fire from the perimeter, knocking down two three-pointers and another jumper within two minutes of each other, baskets that helped turn a 1-point lead into a 10-point bulge. And their show of character ended with menacing defense, pressure that wore the Russian Federation down and gave the United States women a 88-77 victory, won on much more grit than skill before 8,383 at the Dome in Olympic Park. Asked if she saw the game as either a crack in the United States facade or show of perseverance after her team moved to 3-0 in preliminary play, the UNited States coach, Nell Fortner, replied, ``We were resilient. We came together when we had to against some very tough opposition.'' Lisa Leslie overcame early foul trouble to score 14 of her team-high 18 points in the second half, driving harder to her right than George W. Bush. Yolando Griffith and Sheryl Swoopes each added 16 points and Bolton-Holyfield contributed 12 clutch points off the bench. Russia was never out of the game, but the closest it came after the spurt was 68-63 with less than 8 minutes left. Yet for much of the first 20 minutes, the Russians sliced apart the vaunted defense of the Americans with the precision of a Teppan Yaki chef. The point guard, Anna Arkhipova, and the Connecticut forward, Svetlana Abrosimova, ran the pick-and-roll as well as any Hall of Fame tandem from Utah, popping out for jumpers or penetrating for short bankshots. The center tandem of Elen Chakirova and Maria Stepanova, a 6-foot-8, slender woman with golden blond hair and striking features whom the Australian press has nicknamed ``The Russian Barbie,'' were responsible for putting Leslie and Griffith in foul trouble. Taking it to the Americans like no other team in the tournament, the Russians matched the United States women in every facet until the comeback. They put, if not fear, at least major concern into the minds of Fortner and her players. The American women never trailed at halftime during any of their games en route to the gold medal four years ago in Atlanta. They had not lost in Olympic competition since the 1992 semifinals in Barcelona, when several of the same Russian players pulled off the upset. Their last loss in international competition came against Brazil in a Rio de Janeiro exhibition in March. ``We're not aggressive right now defensively,'' Griffith said. ``This is the third game we started slow. It was a great game, but we need to work on our communication a little harder.'' Russia seems headed for a semifinal showdown with Australia, who played Slovakia last night. The winner would most likely see the United States in the gold medal game. At the 1998 world championships, the Russians beat Australia by six points in the semis. As well as they played, the Russians were minus some key players. Their regular starting point guard, Irina Soumnikova, was sidelined for the tournament when she caught an elbow in the face from a Cuban player in the team's first game. Falling to the floor, she fractured her right wrist on the play and, the Russians said, had to undergo two hours of plastic surgery for a facial injury. The Russian coach, Evgeny Gomelskiy, was still blaming the Cubans tonight for leaving him short-handed, calling the act malicious. ``She forced one of our girls to end up in a hospital,'' he said. The Cuban player, Maria Leon, denied on Monday that she purposely hit Soumnikova. What's more, the center, Elena Baranova, one of the best players from Russia who stars in the WNBA, missed the Olympics with a knee injury. That left the arching 3-pointers of Arkhipova -- she made all four she attempted -- and the creative passing of her teammates to fill the void. Often, the Russian players over 6-feet tall dribbled the ball upcourt and picked up their defensive assignments in the backcourt. ``I look at Russia, and their post players can do so much,'' McCray said. ``Can you imagine Lisa Leslie picking up someone 64 feet from the basket? They're really talented in a lot of different areas of the game, where as we specialize a lot.'' Gomelskiy, the Russian coach, congratulated the Americans for their comeback and superiority on defense at the post-game press conference. He talked about the incredible individual skills of the Americans, almost inferring that his players played better together. He lamented a few mistakes by the Russians, ``but as far as the team effort, there are no tragedies today,'' he said. No, but for a few anxious moments, the United States came closer than they have in a while to going down. ``This really wasn't a scare,'' McCray said, again. ``It was a great challenge. Look, we're not going to beat the really good teams by 20 points, anymore. People just have to get used to that.''

title: Dot-Com? Nobody Here by That Name
description: SHE was once the belle of the ball, but now ''dot-com'' is finding it increasingly difficult to land a suitor. Worse, she's even getting dumped, unthinkable a year ago.

title: The 'Tequila Crisis': Take It With a Grain of Salt
description: For a while there, if you believed the rumors, the headlines and the desperate cries of some New York bartenders, you might have thought that the world's supply of tequila was about to dry up.

title: Nuts, Bolts and Bumps in the Road
description: A YEAR ago, W. W. Grainger Inc., which distributes manufacturing valves, maintenance products and replacement parts for industry, had established itself as a pioneer in electronic commerce.

title: Refugees in West Timor Camps Are Said to Be Low on Food
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 -- Government officials and aid workers in the divided island of Timor said today that they had run out of food for tens of thousands of East Timor refugees living in squalid camps on the West Timor border. Without quick intervention from the central government or the international community,the officials and workers said, the refugees face starvation by the end of the month.

title: Aetna Quitting 3 Ventures
description: Aetna said today that its international unit had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in three Mexican joint ventures to Grupo Financiero BBVA Bancomer for $693 million. The ventures are a general insurance company, Seguros Bancomer; a pension company, Afore Bancomer; and an annuity company, Pensiones Bancomer. Aetna is in the process of selling its international business to ING, the Dutch financial services company. Fred Laberge, an Aetna spokesman, said ING already had a large presence in Mexico.

title: Rookie Takes Scenic Route
description: Only a few years ago, Ron Dixon was out of football and pumping gas. While the days dragged on, he still maintained a belief that one day he would be in the National Football League, though he had little to back that up other than speed to burn and memories of being a hot prospect in high school.

title: QWEST MOVES TO OPEN SYSTEM
description: U S West, now part of Qwest Communications International Inc., announced a series of complicated technical initiatives yesterday meant to help new local phone companies connect to its network. Qwest said it would allow its competitors to put more of their equipment in Qwest's facilities and would withdraw 17 lawsuits it had filed against state regulators challenging their ability to force the company to open its systems. The announcements could begin a thaw between Qwest and the competitive local carriers, but Qwest will still remain by far the laggard among the Bells in opening its systems and in its prospects for winning entry to the long-distance market. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: A Queens Address
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the China Disabled People's Performing Arts Troupe and its chairman, Deng Pufang, who are touring the United States, misstated the year of the death of Mr. Deng's father, the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping. It was 1997, not 1987.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAYES, ABRAM
description: CHAYES-Abram. A memorial service for Harvard Law School professor Abram Chayes will be held on Wednesday, September 27 at 3PM at the Ames Courtroom of Austin Hall, Harvard law school 1515 Mass. Ave., Cambridge, MA.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil edged lower in advance of an inventory report that showed supplies of refined products were below year-earlier levels. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 37 cents, to $36.51 a barrel.

title: Miller, Top Threat to Jones, Drops Out of 100
description: Inger Miller, the only real sprinting threat to Marion Jones and her fastest teammate on the American 4x100-meter relay team, has withdrawn from the 100 and may not be able to run the 200 or the relay at the Olympics because of a hamstring injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDNA BARON
description: GOLDSTEIN-Edna Baron. Of Hollywood, FL, on September 18, 2000. Beloved wife of George Goldstein and the late Abraham Baron. Dear mother of Robert and Paul Baron, and stepmother of Robert & Gary Goldstein. Motherin-law of Ruth Baron, Susan Hill and Sandra Goldstein. Sister of Muriel Minsk and the late Ruth Grossfeld. Cherished grandmother of Raphael Baron, Cynthia Banister and Beth Goldstein. Services at Ballard Durand, White Plains, NY, Thursday, September 21, 10 AM.

title: Olympic Swimmers and Divers Finding the Water Down Under to Their Liking
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- With world and Olympic records rapidly dissolving in the Olympic swimming pool, can the deeper pool just a few feet away have the same effect for divers? The American diving coach, Jay Lerew, says it's possible, and his divers say they like the pool. ``This sort of water feels good to divers,'' said Lerew. ``It has a nice fluffy feel and you can see a lot better on entries.'' The pools at Sydney International Aquatic Centre use nearly identical circulation systems, producing remarkably clear water containing few of the harsh chemicals like chlorine that irritate divers. Water quality has been cited by competitors and swimming experts as one reason Olympic swimmers have excelled in the 50-meter swimming pool. The diving pool seems to elicit similar reviews from the American divers. ``I love this pool,'' said Michelle Davison, a 3-meter springboard diver. ``The water is great; the boards are great.'' Troy Dumais, another 3-meter springboard diver, said that he has enjoyed competing in the pool at several previous meets, but added that the facility is not perfect. He said that relatively minor drawbacks include fluctuating temperatures in the showers and in the whirlpool tubs, and a cool breeze in the locker room that sometimes chills athletes who are between dives. ``But if one person has to deal with it, we all have to deal with it,'' he said. ``It's a great pool.''

title: $55 Million Face Lift for Brooklyn Museum
description: Officials of the Brooklyn Museum of Art unveiled a $55 million plan yesterday to transform the institution's front entrance into a major civic plaza, with tiered seating, reflecting pools and programmable fountains flanking a modernistic new lobby of glass and steel.

title: A 'Tilt' Toward India
description: Two years ago, India's nuclear tests provoked worldwide condemnation and retaliatory sanctions by the United States. Yet in recent months, culminating in Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's visit to Washington last weekend, the United States has drawn closer to India diplomatically than at any time since the early 1960's. President Clinton has shaped a new foreign policy course in South Asia by embracing India and distancing the United States from Pakistan's military government. These steps have far-reaching ramifications for all of Asia, including China, as well as for the issue of nuclear proliferation. The shift is justified by India's growing importance. But it should be accompanied by more pressure on India to exercise nuclear restraint and defuse tensions with Pakistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLEY, ASTRID E.
description: VALLEY-Astrid E. Age 92, on Sept. 12, 2000 in Oakmont, PA. Daughter of the late Olaf and Hannah Westlund Valley. She was a teacher for 40 years in the New York City Public Schools. She authored the book ''Marching Bonnet'' that was published by MacMillan in 1948. She is predeceased by sister Alva Swenson. Surviving is nephew Rev. Bruce H. Swenson and his family in Pittsburgh, PA

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the release of the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee from prison misspelled the surname of one of his lawyers. The lawyer is John Cline, not Kline.

title: Heir Apparent Leaves Post at Big Insurer
description: After building the most powerful insurance company in America over three decades, Maurice R. Greenberg apparently wanted nothing more than to leave one of his sons in charge when he died.

title: Clicking Outside the Box
description: THE clock in the dimly lighted control room flashes 20:00. J. R. Gant, the director, nods, an assistant pushes some buttons and the image of Regis Philbin flashes on a bank of monitors on the wall as another episode of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' begins.

title: Nomination of Judge to European Bank Mires Dublin in Criticism
description: The details were sordid: A leading judge on the Irish Supreme Court, a 40-year veteran of the bench and a onetime candidate for chief justice, was accused of arranging the early parole hearing and eventual release of a family acquaintance who had been convicted of killing a young mother while driving drunk.

title: It's Hard to Be Funny When You Can't Hear Them Laugh
description: COMEDY isn't funny. Or, to put it another way, it's not always easy to make people laugh.

title: It's a TV. It's a Book. It's a Radio. It's a Heck of a Lot of Work.
description: WHEN I read Stephen King, I expect to be frightened, possibly sleep with the lights on, even believe I will be attacked by my blender. But I don't expect to pull a hamstring.

title: Marital Status Is Shaping Women's Leanings, Surveys Find
description: Perhaps David Letterman put it best. After Vice President Al Gore appeared on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' last week, talking up his marriage and his family life to millions of female viewers, Mr. Letterman joked: ''Al, you go, girl!''

title: The Catch of the Moment: White Salmon
description: FIVE years ago, white king salmon was a curiosity, if not a nuisance. When fishermen in the Pacific Northwest pulled it up, it went in the pile headed for the cannery or the smokehouse.

title: Movies Meet New Technology: The Sequel to the Sequel
description: WHAT in the world can you do about the Internet?

title: Australias Fairweather Wins Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- The Australia-United States rivalry that has become an untangling thread through the Olympic Games surfaced again today in the men's individual archery finals. But it was less a story of fervent nationalistic competition than the tale of two single-minded athletes who met for the ultimate prize.

title: Though Unsigned, Mottau Agrees to Join Rangers
description: On the first day of training camp, Rangers Coach Ron Low challenged his players to go out and win a job. Last night, Low was still waiting.

title: George Sands, 99, Golf Official; Co-Founded the Ike Tournament
description: George Sands, whose association with golf in the metropolitan area encompassed more than seven decades of service and leadership, died in his sleep last Saturday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Oreos and Hostess Cupcakes, Without the Cellophane
description: Aficionados might swear it is impossible to improve on an Oreo cookie or a Hostess cupcake. But two upscale bakers in New York may have done so. Dean & DeLuca is selling dark, dark chocolate sandwich cookies with a white cream filling, which are much richer than Oreos. The filling is softer and sweeter, and the cookie is not so salty, more like chocolate shortbread. They are made by Amy's Cookies (no relation to Amy's Bread), for Dean & DeLuca and Grace's Marketplace. Leslie Nelsson of Cafe St. Bart's in Manhattan and Sage American Kitchen in Queens, is baking excellent chocolate cupcakes with more texture than the packaged prototype and with a filling using cream cheese. They are definitely better than the original.

title: Review/Fashion; For Chalayan, the Past Is No Crutch
description: After listening to designers relay their contrived references season after season -- Julie Christie in ''Darling,'' Petula Clark in ''The Runaway Bus,'' Golda Meir meets ''Sabrina'' -- there's nothing quite as refreshing as handing the microphone over to Hussein Chalayan. A few days before he showed his spring 2001 line for Tse New York at the Roseland Ballroom on Monday, Mr. Chalayan offered these words: ''I don't refer to anything really, anything historical, anything about clothes from the 60's, anything at all. It's based on the idea of a circle, a square and a triangle.''

title: Economists Fret as Japan Readies One More Stimulus Budget
description: The Japanese government is preparing yet another package of supplemental spending aimed at propping up the economy, which has failed to gain enough momentum on its own despite several previous injections of money.

title: EXPANSION BY TELEVISA
description: The leading Spanish-language broadcasting network, Televisa, will form Mexico's largest radio company, increasing its national dominance and setting the stage for a possible expansion into the United States, Central America and Spain, said Televisa's chairman and chief executive, Emilio Azcarraga (above). Televisa will buy 27.8 percent of a Mexican radio company, Grupo Acir Communications, for $101 million, giving it a controlling stake in the new company, to be called Grupo Acir-Radiopolis. A United States broadcaster, Clear Channel Communications, will have a nearly 25 percent stake. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: GUCCI BENEFITS FROM LUXURY DEMAND
description: Lifted by recent acquisitions and strong sales of its luxury leather goods, the Gucci Group reported that revenue almost doubled in the second quarter, to $497 million, from $261 million in the period a year earlier. But net profit rose only 6 percent, to $80.9 million, largely because of restructuring costs. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Man Who Wanted 40 Winks Held in Sea Cruise
description: Flush with Coca-Cola, chocolate chip cookies and cigarettes, Christopher Rivera, 34, unfastened a 47-foot maintenance boat from its pier, revved up the engine and set off on a moonlight cruise from Staten Island on Monday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POOR, ARTHUR G., JR.
description: POOR-Arthur G., Jr. 1925-1990. This love of mine goes on and on. Love, Nance

title: Packing Asia Into a Menu and Taking It All Downtown
description: WALKING the narrow line between culinary authenticity and popular appeal, Brad Kelley has always managed to keep his balance. His restaurants, Kin Khao, Kelley & Ping, and Bop, each present an Asian cuisine in a seductive downtown environment, where unfamiliar foods are wrapped in a cushion of cocktails, sexy design or creature comforts. While he has won over young American crowds, the tradeoff has been toned-down food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBILOTTO, ELVIRA (VERA)
description: ROBILOTTO-Elvira (Vera). On September 19. Wife of the late John D. Both lifelong residents of Greenwich Village. Survived by a daughter Joan R. Gibson of Mountainside, New Jersey, 3 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Friends may visit at Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Ave (Corner Morris Ave), Summit, NJ between the hours of 2-4 and 79PM on Thursday, September 21.

title: Minority Admissions And Jeb Bush's Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Where, Oh Where Has My Shopping Bot Gone?
description: KATIE the audio technician and I were sitting in the Staples Center in Los Angeles, waiting patiently for our next assignment at the Democratic National Convention, when I asked her to participate in a little experiment.

title: Medical Marijuana and Free Speech
description: The Clinton administration's three-year battle to prevent the use of marijuana as medicine as allowed under California law got a well-deserved rebuke this month. A federal judge wisely ruled that the administration could not punish doctors who recommend the benefits of marijuana to their patients. Such a policy, wrote Judge William Alsup, raises ''severe First Amendment doubts.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SCHUYLER G., M.D.
description: KOHL-Schuyler G., M.D., Dr.Ph, The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Schuyler G. Kohl, M.D., Dr.Ph, distinguished service professor of obstetrics and gynecology. Dr. Kohl was an expert in maternal and fetal health and a leader in the field of midwifery education and family planning. He was active in the drive to decrease infant mortality, took part in landmark efforts to bring family planning to municipal hospitals, and helped ensure adequate length of stay for mothers and newborns. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his family, colleagues and friends. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean of the College of Medicine

title: On Pro Football; Dungy of the Buccaneers A Stickler for the Defense
description: He was a rookie and was ready to play in his first preseason game in 1977. Tony Dungy was a Pittsburgh defensive back and the Steelers were at New England, at Foxboro Stadium.

title: Article 2000092093325978213 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: The Chef: Eggplant Puree With Mixed Herbs
description: EVERYONE knows how beautiful deep purple eggplant can look in the market, but they are even more elegant in the field: row upon row of dark green plants with flawless, shiny purple ornaments suspended beneath the leaves.

title: HOTEL MERGER TALKS
description: The British conglomerate Granada Compass P.L.C. and the French hotel company Accor S.A. have held early talks that could lead to the sale of Granada Compass's hotel division to Accor. Granada said a deal was not imminent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACFARLANE, GEORGE F.
description: MacFARLANE-George F. On August 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Adele (nee Doretta); loving father of the late Robert; brother of Jean Charboneau and John. Memorial Mass at Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and Second Avenue, NYC, Saturday, September 23rd. 11 AM.

title: New Realism Wins the Day
description: The Senate's overwhelming vote today to give permanent trade benefits to China ended a clash between America's global economic interests and the notion that the United States could use the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Beijing's behavior.

title: Metro Business; Federated to Close Two Stern's Stores
description: Two Stern's stores -- at 33rd Street and the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan and at the Nanuet Mall in Rockland County -- will close in March, the parent company, Federated Department Stores, announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLEN, ANTHONY P.
description: MALLEN-Anthony P. On September 17, 2000. Beloved son of the late Bernard J. and Elizabeth Mallen. Cherished brother of Edward of Andover, MA, and the late Sr. Angela Mallen and the late Maria Mallen Hefele. Dearest uncle of Jessica, Noel, Lauren, Michael and Ian. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Center for Special Studies at New York Presbyterian Hospital, 526 East 68th St., Box 566, New York City, NY 10021, or D.I.F.F.A., 150 West 26th Street, Suite 602, New York City, NY 10001.

title: Teen Settles Stock Manipulation Case
description: By day, Jonathan G. Lebed was just another 15-year-old high school student in Cedar Grove, N.J., a suburb of New York. But after school, securities regulators say, Mr. Lebed masterminded a stock manipulation scheme on the Internet that earned him almost $273,000 in illegal gains.

title: Judge's Ruling Puts City AIDS Agency Under U.S. Monitor
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a New York City agency had failed to provide adequate services for thousands of people with AIDS and ordered the agency placed under federal oversight for three years.

title: For Marbury, a Model Is Born
description: Wishing to promote his image nationally, Stephon Marbury signed with Wilhelmina Sports, a division of Wilhelmina Models that plans to embark on an aggressive marketing campaign for the 23-year-old Nets guard. He is the only basketball star Wilhelmina represents.

title: Autumn of Teachers' Discontent Is Dawning
description: Minutes before the fourth-period bell rang, Kathy Aborn, a computer sciences teacher at East Boston High, laid into school district officials about their contract offer, saying the city's teachers were dead serious in threatening to go on strike next month.

title: Buck the System, Cosby Tells Teachers
description: Bill Cosby, in his trademark avuncular fashion, leaned on a pew in Riverside Church yesterday afternoon and addressed an audience of 2,000 as though he were standing in his yard chatting with a neighbor.

title: Sports of The Times; The Face of Australia Is Free to Be Herself
description: CATHY FREEMAN was wonderfully poetic yesterday afternoon as she described the feeling of the final tension-filled seconds before a big race, the feelings shooting through her mind and body as they became one.

title: Auctions Old and New: Truck Space, Pigs and Plastics
description: FOR the last decade, Jim Long, a second-generation hog farmer near London, Ontario, has sold his pigs through phone and fax orders sent to his company, Baconmaker.

title: Killer Toys and Wonder Woman: When a Soft Sell Is a Big Deal
description: HIS angular ivory face framed by the upturned collar of a black magician's cape, Gary Norcigian cut a monochromatic figure amid the technicolor of the convention floor. It was as if Grandpa from ''The Munsters'' somehow wandered onto the set of ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Immigrant Workers Tell of Being Lured and Beaten
description: From the start, the two Mexican immigrants who were attacked Sunday with a shovel, a crowbar and a knife had a bad feeling about the white men who had lured them to an abandoned building with the promise of work.

title: Sue, but Dont Prosecute
description: WASHINGTON - "There ought to be a law." That's what many people are saying as the Firestone-Ford tire debacle unfolds. But what kind of law would help?

title: Venus Williams Breezes On, and Off, the Court
description: ''Citius, altius, fortius,'' read the words over the players' entrance at the New South Wales tennis center, and even though Venus Williams was no faster, higher or stronger than usual in the first Olympic tennis match of her career, she was still too much for her first-round opponent Henrieta Nagyova of Slovakia.

title: Wen Ho Lee, and Our Calls for Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO AIR, AN AIRLINE SERVING DETROIT, SUSPENDS FLIGHTS
description: Pro Air Inc., a low-fare carrier that flies out of Detroit City Airport, suspended flights at midnight last night after the Federal Aviation Administration revoked its operating certificate. Pro Air failed to correct maintenance procedures and record-keeping problems cited in a June inspection and operated ''unairworthy aircraft,'' the F.A.A. said. Pro Air is appealing the F.A.A. action, which was based on ''incorrect and outdated'' information, the company said. Pro Air, formed in 1997, has tried to take on the Northwest Airlines Corporation, Detroit's dominant carrier.

title: A Teacher Shows Herself to Be a Thoughtful Student, Too
description: Good pianists face shrinking prospects on the concert circuit, but the wisest of the good put roots down in academe, travel and perform where the opportunities present themselves. Lori Sims played at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night in a thoughtfully conceived event. Ms. Sims gave us her thoughts on Schumann's ''Kreisleriana'' and the Beethoven ''Eroica'' Variations, played Sofia Gubaidulina's early Chaconne and chose 7 of Curtis Curtis-Smith's 12 Etudes for Piano. Mr. Curtis-Smith is Ms. Sims's colleague at Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Cleveland and Steubenville, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, PETER VINCENT
description: FOSTER-Peter Vincent, 62. Ipswich, MA & Jackson, NH suddenly Sept. 16, 2000. Yale Graduate 1960. A memorial service will be Sunday, Sept. 24 at noon at the New Highland Cemetery in Ipswich. A Separate service will be Saturday, Oct. 14, in Jackson, NH. Contributions may be made to either: S.A.F.E. Studio, 2 Essex Rd., Ipswich, MA. 01938 or to Tin Mountain Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 1170 Conway, NH 03818. For information Morris Funeral Home of Ipswich.

title: When Lemon Is Enough
description: I LOVE the taste of lemon, and sometimes finish grilled or broiled poultry with just the fresh juice. But when I wanted to take advantage of the complex flavor of lemon, rind and all, I came up with this crisp-skinned Cornish hen.

title: Web Opens Up a Whole New Game for Her
description: FOR many entrepreneurs in the traditional entertainment industry, the Internet is viewed with tenuous curiosity -- or dread. Not so with Julann Griffin, one of the creators of ''Jeopardy'' and the former wife of Merv Griffin, who successfully merged her television game show with the Internet to introduce a popular interactive online game Web site.

title: The Empire That Guacamole Built
description: EVERY Mexican restaurant above the taco-stand level must answer a fundamental question at the outset. Will it take the pledge and swear to serve fine food, with a respect for regional differences and prime ingredients, or will it saunter down the cash-strewn path to Margaritaville?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOOS, GEORGE
description: FOOS-George. The staff and Board of Directors of American Jewish World Service mourn the passing of one of our founding Board Members. A distinguished leader in all his communities, he cared tremendously, through his Judaism, for the needs of people around the world.

title: PSEUDO CLOSING ITS DOORS
description: Pseudo Programs, a pioneer in producing original entertainment for the Internet, this week became the latest in a string of companies to fail at that endeavor. Pseudo's 175 employees were laid off on Monday afternoon. Founded in 1994 by Josh Harris, above, the co-founder of the research firm Jupiter Communications, the SoHo-based Pseudo started as an online radio station and soon began streaming video programming that ranged from live chat about hip-hop music to short documentaries about New York City. Investors included Intel, Tribune Ventures and the French luxury goods retailer LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. But after several management shake-ups, Pseudo's shows still failed to attract enough viewers to build significant advertising revenues. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: A Makeover Works Wonders for the MetroStars
description: Mike Petke knew it could be this way. Petke, a defender for the MetroStars, last year felt the sting of seeing his team viewed as Major League Soccer's No. 1 embarrassment. Now, as the MetroStars stand a victory from reaching the league's playoff semifinals, Petke can especially savor the difference.

title: Aging in America: The Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: TESCO EARNINGS RISE
description: Strengthened by higher sales from overseas expansion, Tesco P.L.C., Britain's leading supermarket chain, said first-half pretax profit rose 10 percent to $:422 million, roughly $590 million. Overseas sales, mainly from stores in Asia and Continental Europe, rose 42 percent, but in Britain, where Tesco does the bulk of its business, sales rose 7.5 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; From an Alternate to a 'Miracle Kid' in a Flash
description: THE one thing a teenager can count on is change, abrupt and ongoing, but even by that hormonal standard, Tasha Schwikert-Warren's Olympics were extreme. She came to Sydney as an alternate, a dreamer, a 15-year-old with metal in her smile. By late last night, she was hailed as the foundation and future of the United States women's gymnastics team.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Full of Banter, Bush Goes On the 'Oprah' Circuit
description: The question came by way of an e-mail message to Oprah, the queen of confessional television, and Gov. George W. Bush took it head on: What is the public's biggest misconception of him?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RUTH
description: EPSTEIN-Ruth. AMIT is saddened by the passing of our former National Vice President, and Past President of the AMIT New Jersey Council. A true and gracious ''woman of valor'', Ruth Epstein lived a life devoted to Torah values, loving kindness, and helping the people of Israel. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Solving the Puzzles of China
description: Iremember looking at my wife asleep on the plane on my way to Shanghai two years ago and thinking that this woman must really love me to give up her job, her friends and her lifestyle to move to China with me. But this has turned out to be the best life experience that we have had. And unless we are truly blessed, it will be the best we will ever have.

title: Valentine's Words Serve As Reminder
description: Bobby Valentine was leaning back in his office chair with his feet crossed on the desk in front of him last night at Turner Field. A picture of Valentine would have shown a manager who seemingly looked relaxed, but that was not true. Valentine was still seething inside, the rage just not being shown outwardly anymore.

title: Clementes Plaque Corrected
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19  Roberto Clemente's plaque at the Baseball Hall of Fame is being changed to correct an inaccuracy in his name.

title: Defying Forecasts, Census Response Ends Declining Trend
description: A higher percentage of households completed and returned census forms this year than in 1990, reversing a three-decade trend away from participation in the national population count, census officials said today.

title: SYNOVUS FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE CAROLINA SOUTHERN BANK
description: The Synovus Financial Corporation agreed to buy Carolina Southern Bank for $61.4 million in stock to expand in South Carolina's fast-growing Spartanburg area. Each Carolina Southern share will be exchanged for 0.8514 of a Synovus share. That values Carolina Southern shares at $17.56 each, a 30 percent premium over yesterday's closing price of $13.50. Carolina Southern has $212.4 million in assets and has four branches in the Spartanburg area. Synovus, which is based in Columbus, Ga., and has $13.7 billion in assets, will merge Carolina Southern with its National Bank of South Carolina affiliate. Synovus operates 39 banks in the South.

title: WEST NILE SPRAYING SCHEDULE
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY, N.Y.

title: Hyman, in Surprise, Joins No. 1 van den Hoogenband
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20  There had never been a 100-meter freestyle like this. Three men had traded the world record in swimming's main event over the last five days, and the eight lanes of water churned so furiously today that they seemed to boil with expectation.

title: Gore Maintaining Momentum, Post-Labor Day Polling Shows
description: Polls taken since Labor Day show Al Gore keeping the momentum he gained after his party's convention and continuing to hold an advantage over George W. Bush on issues like health care, prescription drugs and the environment.

title: Gore Tables Gun Issue As He Courts Midwest
description: Last April, on the first anniversary of the shootings at Columbine High School, Vice President Al Gore castigated Gov. George W. Bush for offering only ''half a solution'' to the problem of gun violence.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Report on Prisoner Care Is Used to Pressure State
description: Trying to pressure New Jersey prison officials to disclose whether they are making promised reforms in caring for mentally ill prisoners, a prominent human rights group today released a long-suppressed 1998 report that said the state's treatment of those prisoners was cruel and neglectful.

title: Faulds Wins Double Trap Gold in Shootoff
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Richard Faulds of Britain won the men's double trap in a shootoff with defending gold medalist Russell Mark of Australia.

description: TECHNOLOGY

title: Black Minister Criticized for Taking Corzine's Money
description: The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson knows how to move an audience, whether it is the parishioners of his congregation in Orange, N.J., or a nation outraged by allegations of racial profiling on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, EMMA JANE
description: GOLDEN-Emma Jane. Age 77, of Ridgewood, died suddenly Sunday September 17, 2000. Em received her B.A. degree from Wellesley College and her Masters in Education from Columbia Teachers College. She taught at Brearley School in NYC and the Shady Hill School in Cambridge. She was a member and past President of the Wellesley Club of Ridgewood, a member of the College Club of Ridgewood and The Society of Valley Hospital. Em is survived and dearly missed by her husband Bal, sons Peter and Bob, daughter Betsy and grandchildren Casey, Nikki and Mandy. Sister and sisterin-law of Kenneth and Jane Krakauer. The family will receive visitors at home from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM Wednesday (9/20). There will be a memorial service at the Unitarian Society of Ridgewood (Cottage Place) on Thursday (9/21) at 11:00 AM.

description: WHO -- or what -- is AXA?

title: Whitman Urges Corzine to Disclose More of His Finances
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman weighed in on the United States Senate race in New Jersey today, urging Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate, to remove any lingering ''shadow of doubt'' about his finances and release his personal income tax returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADDOW, ROBERT D.
description: HADDOW-Robert D. Died September 17, 2000. He is survived by his parents Robert S. and Virginia Haddow of Greenwich, Ct., a sister Susan of NYC, his wife of eleven years Amy and two sons Tyler and Matthew all of Seward, AK. A memorial service is scheduled for 11AM on Saturday, September 23 at St. Stephens Episcopal Church in Armonk, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggest contributions to the Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714. www.lustgarten.org

title: Unheralded U.S. Baseball Team Keeps Victory String Intact
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 20 -- The United States Olympic baseball team, unheralded minor leaguers and major league castoffs, knows that they are nobody's idea of a Dream Team. Call them uncelebrated, they might call themselves Olympic baseball's little-known secret.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''A Lesson Before Dying,'' by Romulus Linney, at the Signature Theater Company, misstated the surname of the play's director. As noted in the credits, he is Kent Thompson, not Anderson.

title: HYUNDAI MIGHT BUY DAEWOO MOTOR
description: With few suitors remaining for the Daewoo Motor Company, its main creditor, the Korea Development Bank, will allow the Hyundai Motor Company, to bid for Daewoo on the condition that Hyundai bring in a foreign partner. Daewoo's future is in doubt because Ford Motor dropped its $6.9 billion bid last week. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Commissioner Builds Consensus at Home
description: IRIS WEINSHALL has worked in New York City government for almost 20 years. In conversation, she uses phrases like ''maintaining the momentum of the process,'' ''exciting new challenges'' and ''skills sets'' without so much as blinking an eye. She talks about computerizing municipal personnel forms with the kind of joy that most people reserve for talking about their vacations.

description: Accents From All Over

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCORDINO, PRUDENCE
description: SCORDINO-Prudence. NY/IABC mourns the passing of Prudence Scordino, loyal Chapter Administrator. Her gentle efficiency and caring ways will be deeply missed.

description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, MARC I.
description: WEISSMAN-Marc I. We, the members of Marc Weissman Associates Incorporated, acknowledge with sadness and sorrow the untimely passing of our founder on Sunday, September 17, 2000. His design genius will continue forever to be a guiding inspiration to our organization. We extend our deepest sympathy to the members of his family. MWA

description: To the Editor:

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLIS, ALBERT
description: JOLIS-Albert. September 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Mona. Devoted father of Paul, Jack, James and the late Alan. Loving brother of the late Bernard. Cherished grandfather of Jane, Annie, Oliver, Timothy, Lucy, Jacob & Jeremy. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. He was a decorated officer during WWII. Service Saturday, September 23, 2000, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: RELIEF FOR LAIDLAW
description: Laidlaw Inc., the operator of Greyhound Lines and North America's largest fleet of school buses, said it should be able to satisfy working capital needs with a new credit of up to $200 million that it is close to signing with its banking syndicate. Laidlaw, based in Burlington, Ontario, has not paid interest on $3.1 billion of debt since mid-May and has been negotiating an operating loan with 16 banks. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Burned Out but Not Down for the Count
description: The characters of the young director-playwright Richard Maxwell are not what you would call an excitable lot. Their voices are as uninflected as a refrigerator's drone, their postures those of exceptionally passive people who have been parked somewhere and told to wait. In Mr. Maxwell's breakthrough work of two years ago, ''House,'' a couple of them were murdered, and it was hard to distinguish the dead from the living.

title: U.S. Team's Streak Intact
description: The American light welterweight Ricardo Williams Jr. didn't want to become the first United States boxer to falter and lose his first-round fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SOPHIE
description: DAVIS-Sophie. The American Jewish Committee deeply mourns the death of Sophie Davis, beloved wife of Leonard, a member of our National Leadership Council, a founder of AJC's Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations, and generous supporter. Their kindness and vision have greatly benefited the Jewish community and all peoples. We send sincere condolences to Leonard, their sons, grandchildren and the rest of the grieving family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Excutive Director

title: Review/Fashion; Tough Girls and Cottontails
description: The fashion crowd gathers and regathers each day to inspect the emperors' new clothes, and as of yesterday morning, the midpoint of the spring 2001 collections, there were just two boss designers, Ralph Lauren and Daryl Kerrigan, and they had a lot to say about how women will be dressing.

title: OIL COMPANY SOLD
description: Russia sold a small oil company, Onako, for $1.1 billion, more than double its asking price, in the first major privatization since President Vladimir V. Putin was elected. The success of the competitive auction indicated the government is serious about improving the business climate. The buyer was Evro-Tek, a Russian energy concern that is a subsidiary of Tyumen Oil. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Space: Network TV's Commercial Frontier
description: Last week, when NBC signed a deal to hold a televised contest to send a civilian into space aboard a Russian-built rocket, the television networks seemed to have pushed their hunger for new forms of reality programming literally to new heights.

title: AIN'T WE GOT FUN
description: Even sending a postcard from Times Square has gone high-tech. The Burger King restaurant at 327 West 42nd Street in Manhattan has computers that are equipped with 3Com digital cameras so diners can send short streaming video clips of themselves to e-mail addresses of their choice. To use one of the 16 PC's in the restaurant, a customer has to purchase a Value Meal at the store to receive a password good for 20 minutes of free computing time over a high-speed digital connection.

title: CANADA SURPLUS GROWS
description: Canada's federal government reported a budget surplus of 12.3 billion Canadian dollars ($8.3 billion) for the fiscal year ended March 31. It all was used to reduce debt, and an even larger surplus is building in the current fiscal year. Federal debt has been reduced by 19 billion Canadian dollars over the last two years, to 553 billion at the end of July. Debt as a percentage of gross domestic product has dropped to 59 percent from 71 percent since 1996. A budget surplus of 11.4 billion Canadian dollars in the first four months of fiscal 2000-2001 was twice as high as a year ago. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Government Cleared in Deaths at Waco
description: A federal judge today dismissed the wrongful death civil lawsuit brought by Branch Davidians, clearing the government of any wrongdoing in the deaths of about 80 members of the religious sect during the disastrous 1993 standoff at the group's compound near Waco, Tex.

title: Less Than Universal
description: To The Editor:

title: Nassau Officials Told Not to Play 'Games' With Finances
description: The chairman of a state board overseeing Nassau County's efforts to solve its fiscal crisis issued a stern warning to county officials today: drop the partisan political games or face a state takeover.

title: Surrounded by Egypt, Inspired by the World
description: SOME people here call it ''taste slippage,'' the irrational craving that sometimes overtakes expatriates in Egypt to fill their homes with lamps made from papier-mache camels, recycled-glass pyramids, mirrors shaped like minarets and framed hieroglyphics on papyrus.

title: Australia Bans Blood Donors With British Links
description: CANBERRA, Sept. 21 -- Australia said on Thursday it would ban thousands of donors from giving blood if they have had extended visits to Britain, after research showed mad cow disease can be transmitted through blood transfusions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, DOROTHY
description: KOPPELMAN - Dorothy. The American Jewish Committee is profoundly saddened by the death of a treasured friend and generous benefactor, Dorothy Koppelman. Dorothy and her husband Julius have been longtime members of the AJC family, serving on our national Board of Governors, National Leadership Council, Horizon Society, and national Advisory Board of our Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations, for which they established an endowment in honor of their 50th wedding anniversary. Equally active in her local AJC chapter, she served as a Vice President and Trustee of AJC's Central New Jersey Chapter and was honored in 1995 with their Philip Forman Human Relations Award. A devoted wife to Julius for more than 56 years and a loving mother and grandmother, Dorothy was also an educator who made time to nurture her passion for the well-being of the Jewish people, emphasizing not only Holocaust remembrance but Jewish vitality and identity through learning. She supported, in word and deed, those causes nearest to her heart, and did so with a quiet elegance and grace that were her trademarks. Her legacy of goodness and compassion will long be remembered. We send our deepest condolences to Julius, their four daughters and their families, and all who grieve her passing. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Excutive Director Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: Wash Your Hands (Don't Forget the Soap)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Women Get Scare but Go On to Win
description: Ruthie Bolton-Holifield had just rushed two shots, long 3-point heaves that bounced off the rim. Then she turned to witness something even more unsightly.

title: Cruelties of Apartheid, Chronicled by a Child
description: Her delicate appearance notwithstanding, Pamela Gien, the gifted writer and performer of ''The Syringa Tree,'' has an unyielding spine as a storyteller. Her show, presented at Playhouse 91 on the Upper East Side, is an evocative and difficult monologue about a childhood, presumably her own, spent in South Africa in the darkest days of apartheid.

title: Module Turns Visor Into Pocket MP3 Player
description: The promise of Handspring's Visor is its ability to easily morph into something other than the standard Palm device. To utilize the Springboard slot on the back of the unit, a developer could create a module that could turn the Visor into anything from a cell phone to a game player.

title: Sit! Stay! Bark! Cut!
description: William Hill was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a resume, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new iMac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable iMac without video editing.

title: Preserve Aalto's Rooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Leiter Helps Lighten Mets Load
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21  For Al Leiter, it was just a matter of doing his job on Wednesday night, and that job was pitcher, not stopper.

title: Sovereign Abusers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Levy Signs Job Pact
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy signed a two-year contract with the Board of Education yesterday that allows him to quit at any time, technically a departure from previous practice. In another change, the contract allows the board to fire Mr. Levy without a long hearing process.

title: A Broker in South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil at $37.20; Demand, Diplomacy and Politics Intense
description: The price of crude oil climbed again yesterday amid increasing concern about the impact of the rising price on the world's economy.

title: It's a Word World, Or Is It?
description: HOW do you compete in a business where the next-largest company holds a market share hovering just under 100 percent? That's the quandary WordPerfect faces.

title: Battle on Prescription Drugs
description: The advertising war over prescription drugs escalated this week: the Republican National Committee broadcast a biting new commercial in 17 states, and the Gore campaign quickly responded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADOVANO, LOUIS, S.J., M.D.
description: PADOVANO-Louis, S.J., M.D. On September 20, 2000. Beloved son of the late John and Margaret Padovano. Loving brother of John Padovano, Jr. and Angela Alaimo. Dear brother-in-law of Consuelo Padovano and Joseph Anthony Alaimo. Cherished uncle of Lisa and Christopher Alaimo, John III, Margaret and Cathleen Padovano and Monica Buttagliola. Dear friend of Rev. Patrick J. Frawley. Dr. Padovano was a graduate of Georgetown University and the Georgetown University School of Medicine. He maintained a practice in OB/GYN before entering the Society of Jesus in 1964. He was ordained a priest on June 12, 1969. After ordination he completed an additional residency in psychiatry at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and maintained his practice in New York until his passing. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'' 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Thursday, September 21 and Friday, September 22, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 980 Park Ave at 84 Street, Saturday, September 23, at 11 AM. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hanover, New Jersey.

title: A Shoe That Will Give Runners And Walkers Instant Feedback
description: FOR even the most occasional walker who just wants to take a heart-friendly stroll in the park, as well as the most fanatical marathoner, a single question dogs their every step: How far have I gone?

title: JOB LOSS IN CHASE-MORGAN MERGER PUT AT 3,000
description: William B. Harrison, the chairman of Chase Manhattan, said yesterday that fewer than 3,000 jobs worldwide would be lost because of its $33 billion purchase of J. P. Morgan & Company. Mr. Harrison and the chief executive of J. P. Morgan, Douglas Warner III, said the overlap between the two banks was minimal. Less than 10 percent of the combined company's investment banking and asset management staff of about 32,000 would lose their jobs, they said. Integrating the two companies will not affect Chase's consumer banking business, which employs most of the combined bank's 95,000 workers, Mr. Harrison said.

title: NBC in Sydney: The Judges Frown
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Internet Utility Plans Move to Westchester
description: The New Power Company, an Internet utility, is planning to establish its headquarters in Purchase, N.Y., state and Westchester County officials said yesterday.

title: Heavyweight Showdown Looms for Cubas Savon and USAs Bennett
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21 -- For effect, or perhaps just because he can, fabled Cuban boxing champion Felix Savon enters a boxing ring not by dipping between the ropes, but by lifting one leg at a time over the top rope with the ease of someone stepping into a warm bath.

title: The Suavely Familiar vs. the Daring of the Internet Age
description: Plans for two new arts centers were announced this month in Los Angeles. The more prominent is a 150,000-square-foot reconstruction of the Dixon Arts Center at the University of California at Los Angeles by Richard Meier (rendering, right). Mr. Meier, who designed the Getty Center, is but the latest New York architect to build on that campus. His design weaves together studios and galleries, and will make a connection by terraces to a sculpture garden and academic buildings. It seems an elegant planning solution and a high-quality, if familiar, white modernist Meier building.

title: Las Vegas Company Accused of Fraud
description: The BryCar Financial Corporation of Las Vegas and its president have been accused of securities fraud involving the sale of millions of dollars of fake investment programs to hundreds of buyers, many by way of the Internet, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: Metro Business; Middle-Income Housing
description: A ceremony will be held today to mark the completion of the exterior of an 11-story cooperative apartment building in Harlem that is intended to test the area's appeal to middle-income buyers.

title: The U.S. Consumers Friend
description: WASHINGTON - First it was the Sprint- WorldCom merger. Now it is AOL's proposal to buy Time Warner. Two mergers between American companies, both stymied by the European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union.

title: How the Senate Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 14-19 with 1,611 adults throughout the state. Of those, 1,212 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: NBC in Sydney: The Judges Frown

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESEL, SARA
description: PESEL-Sara. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our devoted Trustee and benefactors Rose and Herman Schwimmer on the loss of Rose's beloved sister. May the family be comforted by their cherished memories. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: A Parting Embrace For a Lifetime's Quirks
description: I RATHER like the idea of a whole new phase of life, with fewer possessions,'' Christopher Gibbs said, somewhat unconvincingly. Mr. Gibbs, 62, was gazing wistfully at the handsome stone exterior of the Manor House at Clifton Hampden, a rambling three-story house in Oxfordshire, built for his family in the 1840's, which he reluctantly sold in July.

title: EBAY FORECASTS STRONG GROWTH
description: Aggressively projecting continued strong growth, eBay has set a revenue goal of $3 billion in 2005, the online auction company said yesterday. EBay executives told analysts the goal would imply revenue growth ''approaching 50 percent a year.'' It based the goal on its estimate of the size of its various markets, including collectibles, practical items, computers and used autos and parts. EBay estimated the size of its potential markets at about $1.6 trillion, increasing to about $2 trillion by 2005.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Sewickley and Bloomfield, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUOTOLO, ANDREW KEOGH JR.
description: RUOTOLO-Andrew Keogh Jr. November 5, 1952-September 21, 1995. ''For the chosen few, there is no disillusionment. They march on into life with a boyish grace, and their high noon keeps all the freshness of the morning''.

title: HIGH-SPEED WIRELESS SERVICES
description: Metricom, the highspeed wireless Internet company backed by WorldCom and the investor Paul Allen, will introduce its high-speed wireless Internet service, Ricochet, today in Manhattan, Baltimore, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, Phoenix and San Francisco. Customers of Ricochet, which costs $75 to $80 a month and is already available in San Diego, Atlanta, Seattle and Washington, get Internet access from laptop computers and some hand-held devices at higher speeds than are normally available on dial-up connections. ''This is the all-you-can-eat wireless experience, far beyond the mockery of Internet applications available on cell phones,'' Timothy Dreisbach, Metricom's chairman, said. Metricom plans to extend its network to 46 markets by next year. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Kert Lundell, 64, Broadway Set Designer
description: Kert Lundell, a set designer for more than 75 Broadway and Off Broadway productions who won three Drama Desk Awards, died on Sept. 11. He was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Krayzelburg Adds a Second Backstoke Title
description: SYDNEY, Sept. 21 -- Lenny Krayzelburg's body was tightening up and the pain was gripping him. He was still leading the 200-meter backstroke, but his only goal in the last half of the race today was to fend off his American teammate, Aaron Peirsol, and Matthew Welsh of Australia.

title: U.S. Is Bruised in Its Victory, and China Is Bumped
description: China is gone. There will be no replay of the 1996 Summer Games final, no replay of the 1999 World Cup final. And the new American coach, April Heinrichs, will not exactly wax sentimental at not presiding over a rematch.

title: Article 2000092192795989233 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEMER, JOHN R., JR.
description: SCHOEMER-John R., Jr. Sept. 20, 2000, of Somers, NY, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Partner in the former law firm of Townley Updike. Husband of Dorothy (nee Goett). Father of John, Jill Hunter and Carolyn Huyghe. Also survived by 7 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, NY, Saturday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Giants Measure Words As Redskins Struggle
description: Football players, with the notable exception of Keyshawn Johnson, tend to be incredibly reserved when discussing coming opponents. Giving the other team any extra incentive is their greatest fear so they usually opt for a dose of diplomacy over reality.

title: Craftswomen of the World
description: After the World Conference on Women in Beijing in 1995, Paola Gianturco wanted to document the craftswomen of developing countries. Ms. Gianturco, a San Francisco-based marketing consultant, enlisted Toby Tuttle, a financial manager, to help photograph and write about women in 12 countries. They documented, among others, women painting in Zalipie, Poland, and doing needlework in Pang Mai Dang, Thailand; Ndebele women making beadwork in South Africa and Shipibo potters in Peru. Their book, ''In Her Hands: Craftswomen Changing the World'' (Monicelli, $60), will be in stores next month. ''My hope is that it will help make some invisible and, I think, heroic women more visible,'' Ms. Gianturco said.

title: At the Garden, It's Lights Out For a Superstar
description: It was early last November when Patrick Ewing was sprawled on the floor of a locker room, flexing old knees that resembled stripped lug nuts, testing a slow-healing Achilles' tendon that left him in dark moods.

title: Candidate Restored to Ballot
description: U.S. Senator Edward M. Kennedy is seeking a record seventh term against a field of five little-known candidates. Mr. Kennedy is heavily favored to win.

title: Regulating Decorators
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life and Death Story Set in Comic Book Land
description: THE AMAZING ADVENTURES OF KAVALIER & CLAY

title: Sit! Stay! Bark! Cut!
description: William Hill was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a resume, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new iMac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable iMac without video editing.

title: Its a Word World, Or Is It?
description: HOW do you compete in a business where the next-largest company holds a market share hovering just under 100 percent? That's the quandary WordPerfect faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACWILLIAMS, JOHN J.
description: MacWILLIAMS-John J. Of Old Lyme, CT, died on September 20, 2000. He is formerly of Pebble Beach, CA and Philadelphia, PA. He was born in Syracuse, NY on April 30, 1929. He attended Phillips Academy, Andover, MA., and graduated from Hobart College. He was the former chairman and CEO of Colonial Penn Group of Philadelphia, PA. Mr. MacWilliams is survived by his wife Lee; sons John J. of Dover, MA; W. Brewster of Santa Monica, CA; P. Huntington of Redwood City, CA and his daughter Cameron Karr of San Francisco, CA. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 29, 2000, at 11AM, in the First Congregational Church, Lyme St., Old Lyme, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Phillips Academy, Andover, MA.

title: Lieberman Is Criticized On Violent Entertainment
description: William J. Bennett, who has often joined forces with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in assailing violence and vulgarity in popular culture, sharply attacked Mr. Lieberman today, accusing him of retreating from that cause.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I tell people we still got the natural beauty, but why aren't the tourists here? I remind them our trash is not unique and tourists aren't going to pay to come and view it.''
