title: Chase in $22 Million Credit Card Settlement
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation will pay at least $22.2 million to settle consumer lawsuits asserting that credit card customers were forced to pay extra interest and late fees even when monthly payments arrived on time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMUS, STANLEY
description: KALMUS-Stanley. Of Bronx, NY, on September 19, 2000, beloved husband of Sydell, devoted father of Michael and Andrew, cherished father in law of Meryl and Sherry. Dear brother of Milton, Judy, and the late twin brother Albert. Loving grandfather of Jason, Pamela, Jacob, and David. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner of Park and Passaic Street, Hackensack, NJ, on Thursday, September 21, 2000 at 11 A.M. Contributions to American Diabetes Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Fernandez Stays Tough in Face of Rough Loss
description: BLACKTOWN Australia -- She strung together 25 strikeouts and 12 2/3 innings of raw dominance, but it wasn't until after one fatal mistake, her nightmarish defeat, that Lisa Fernandez staged her most impressive show of uncommon strength.

title: Pilots at American Reject Early Extension of Contract
description: Pilots at American Airlines overwhelmingly rejected a one-year contract extension yesterday, dealing a blow to the airline's efforts to improve relations with one of its most critical employee groups.

title: Clinton Decision on Oil Reserves Near, Energy Secretary Announces
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 21 - Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said today that the White House is considering whether to release oil from the nation's emergency stockpile in order to reduce the price of home heating oil.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on Aug. 2 about diamond smuggling in Africa that finances guerrilla wars included an outdated account of the views of Robert R. Fowler, Canadian ambassador to the United Nations. It was in an interview last February that Ambassador Fowler, chairman of a committee investigating sanctions violations in Angola, said that a diamond embargo against the Unita rebel movement there was having little effect. At that time, he said it was a government military offensive that was crippling the rebel smuggling operation. But in a statement to The Times last week, the Ambassador said the international sanctions had since begun to have a significant effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, GERTRUDE
description: LERNER-Gertrude. On Sept. 19, 2000. Beloved wife of Harry. Devoted mother of Judith, Lee Berman, Alex and Saul. Dear mother-in-law of Richard Berman, Helena Wallenberg and Vivian Benci. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Lindsay, Russell, Elliot, Austin, Faryn, Seth, Francesca & Maxwell. A courageous, loving and giving woman, Mrs. Lerner taught second grade at Yeshiva Torah Temimah, Brooklyn for over 30 years. A woman of grace and valor, she was a shining light who lit up the lives of everyone she came in contact with. Her spirit will live on in all those who were lucky enough to be a part of her life. Services Thursday, 1 PM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Trade Deficit at Record in July, Pushed by Cost of Oil Imports
description: The United States trade deficit widened to a record in July as demand for autos, oil and Chinese toys and clothes pushed imports to their highest level ever, government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, CARYN, PHD.
description: CHU-Caryn, PhD. The Faculty and Staff of Mt. Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourn the sudden passing of Karen Chu. Ms. Chu joined Mt. Sinai in 1993 as a graduate student and subsequently became a post-doctoral fellow within the Department of Pathology. The world of science has lost a precious young mind. She will be deeply missed by her colleagues and friends. Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Terry A. Krulwich, PhD, Dean Graduate School of Biological Sciences

title: U.S. in Quarterfinals
description: With Chelsea Clinton among the several hundred Americans watching today at Bondi Beach, the United States team of Annett Davis and Jenny Johnson-Jordan defeated Cuba, 15-9, in the first of the final rounds of the women's beach volleyball competition.

title: Question for All Divers: Is the Secret in the Pool?
description: With world and Olympic records rapidly dissolving in the Olympic swimming pool, will there be a ripple effect for divers in the adjacent, deeper pool just a few feet away?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, LIBBY (NEE GOLDBERG)
description: EISEN-Libby (nee Goldberg). Wife of the late Irving, born and raised in the Tarrytowns, also lived in Miami Shores and Plantation, FL. Survived by son Gerald (Linda), of White Plains, daughter Nancy (Michael), of Rye, daughter Roberta (Michael), of Texas, grandchildren, Jennifer, Robert, David, Mark, Richard, Michelle, and Jason. Also survived by sister Muriel (Jules) Quittell, of New Rochelle. Services will be private. Donations may be made to Guiding Eyes For The Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, New York 10598.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, SEIBERT G.
description: ADAMS-Seibert G. Well known in the college textbook publishing industry, died on Wednesday September 20 in Sharon, Ct. He was 65. Born October 12, 1934 in New Haven, Ct., son of Seibert Gruber Adams and Norma M. Adams. He graduated from Yale University in 1957 and served as a lieutenant in the Air Force for three years. Shortly thereafter, he began his career of over thirty years in educational publishing. Mr. Adams was awarded the James Leisey Award by the higher education group of the Association of American Publishers in May of 1995 for his outstanding contribution to college publishing. He leaves his wife, Ruth Cahill Adams, two daughters, Sharon Adams Poore of Mass, Sheryl Adams of New York, four grandchildren and his four cats. His sense of humor will continue to inspire us. Memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Monday, September 25 at 6PM. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his name to The American Cancer Society.

Fowler, Canadian ambassador to the United Nations. It was in an interview last February that Ambassador Fowler, chairman of a committee investigating sanctions violations in Angola, said that a diamond embargo against the Unita rebel movement there was having little effect. At that time, he said it was a government military offensive that was crippling the rebel smuggling operation. title: Edward O. Miller Dies at 84; Rector Backed Liberal Causes
description: The Rev. Edward O. Miller, an outspoken liberal Episcopal minister who was the longtime rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in Manhattan, died on Saturday in Bangor, Me. He was 84 and lived in Castine, Me.

title: T.J. Maxx Stores Quits Holland Mark
description: T. J. Maxx, the discount retailer owned by the TJX Companies, and Holland Mark Edmund Ingalls in Boston are parting ways after 24 years. Spending was estimated at $20 million.

description: YOU know they've gotten a BlackBerry when they stop calling.

title: Judge to Rehear Case Despite Claim of Bias
description: A Columbia University graduate student who was convicted of kidnapping and raping a 20-year-old student he met on the Internet, and who then won a new trial in an appeal last year, is scheduled to be retried before the original trial judge, whom defense lawyers have accused of bias against their client.

title: Swede Wins 50-Meter Rifle
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Jonas Edman's near-perfect qualifying round got him to the finals. A solid performance there won him the gold.

title: Woes of telecommunications seem to be rolled up in Sprint.
description: FOR an industry that is supposed to be improving the lives of people around the world, or at least around the United States, the telecommunications business sure looks ugly these days. Shares in communications carriers -- large and small -- are in a mire. Growth rates are slowing. The downturn is so broad that it might even comfort AT&T, which is stuck in one of its own periodic funks.

title: Americans Advance in Beach Volleyball
description: SYDNEY Australia -- It wasn't easy and they did it differently, but both U.S. women's teams made it to the Olympic beach volleyball quarterfinals.

title: For Those Mad Mandarin Nights
description: A spiffy new bed-and-breakfast-scale hotel, Maison 140 (at 140 Lasky Drive), in Beverly Hills, has been created by the team that designed the nearby Avalon Hotel. Kelly Wearstler, of Kelly Wearstler Interior Design, has transformed a 1930's hotel with a spin on French chinoiserie. Black corridors, fire-engine red walls, patterned wallpapers and ornamental furnishings offer a surprising visual jolt. The lobby, above, has white lacquer tables and a banquette by Ms. Wearstler's company, along with red enamel plates decorating the wall. Reservations: (800) 432-5444; rates for small rooms (12 by 17 feet on average, including bathroom) start at $140 a night.

title: Ways to Keep Out Broadband Hackers
description: Q. I have heard that a speedy connection like a cable modem or a digital subscriber line leaves your computer very vulnerable to invasion by hackers. Is that true, and how can it be prevented?

title: Board Betting on Corporate Vision for Laptop Plan
description: On their face, the numbers released yesterday spelling out the Board of Education's plan to link students to the Internet are so astronomical as to appear preposterous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHEIM, LEONARD H., JR.
description: BERNHEIM-Leonard H., Jr. Died on Tuesday evening after a long battle with pancreatic cancer. Born May 24th, 1937 in New York City, he is survived by his devoted wife of 33 years, Stephanie Hammerschlag Bernheim; their loving children, Erica Bernheim, Claudia Bernheim and her husband, Leo Raphaely; loyal brother Charles Bernheim and his wife Rachel and her daughters Ashley & Samantha Haspel; brother and sister-in-law Paul & Margaret Hammerschlag and their daughter Zoe; mother-inlaw Belle Hammerschlag Trattler and her brother Herbert Stessin. The family will be at home 5:00 to 7:30 P.M. Thursday, September 21. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. & 65th Street at 11 AM Friday In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to JBFCS, 120 W. 57th St., NY, NY 10019; the Art Museum at Princeton University, McCormick Hall, Princeton, NJ 08544; or the Department of Arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 5th Avenue, NY, New York 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINSSER, BARBARA L. (MRS. HANS)
description: ZINSSER-Barbara L. (Mrs. Hans). The American Farm School of Thessaloniki, Greece's Trustees, staff, students and friends honor the life of Mrs. Barbara L. Zinsser. A major force on the Board of the School, her wit, care, loyalty and keen insight guided us for more than 30 years. To quote the Greek: ''May your memory be eternal!''

title: Cuban Crash Survivors Taken to U.S. Hospital
description: Eight Cuban survivors of a plane crash in the Gulf of Mexico were taken today to Key West for medical evaluation, a move that is likely to allow them to remain in the United States.

title: Sparring Begins on Oversight of AIDS Unit
description: When the city, with no warning, canceled the food stamps of a 39-year-old Bronx father with AIDS in the summer, a lawyer tried two techniques to get the benefits restored: she wrote a letter to a top official at the Division of AIDS Services and Income Support, and she made a legal demand for a hearing on behalf of the man and his teenage son.

description: This town of 15,000 people gives many mixed messages to the brown-skinned men -- welcomed as workers but shunned as neighbors -- who line up in front of the 7-Eleven at a central intersection looking for day work.

title: Economic Scene; A big factor in prescription drug pricing: Location, location, location.
description: PRESCRIPTION drugs have become politicized. Al Gore recently criticized the manufacturer of the arthritis drug Lodine for selling it for $108 a month when prescribed for humans and $38 when prescribed for dogs. It's not just the doggy divide that has politicians upset; international price differences for drugs are another flash point. The House and Senate recently approved a measure allowing pharmacists to import prescription drugs from countries where they sell for substantially less than in the United States.

title: Rookie Makes Bid For Islanders Spot
description: The rookie Raffi Torres was too busy concentrating on earning a spot on the Islanders to pay that much attention to the fellow across the ice wearing No. 23 for the New Jersey Devils. But for Torres, he was impossible to ignore.

title: Designers Find You Can't Live On Buzz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFLIES, MATILDA
description: GOLDFLIES-Matilda. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Eva Halpern, on the passing of her beloved sister, who was a caring, kind and loving woman. May Eva, daughter Claire Kahane, and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: Metro Business; Spanish Newscast Is Tops
description: The evening newscast of New York's most prominent Spanish-language television station, WPIX, beat WCBS, WABC and WNBC among 18- to 49-year-old viewers during the July sweeps, according to a recently released audience analysis. WPIX, a Univision affiliate that is broadcast on Channel 41, had an estimated 272,000 viewers between 18 and 49 years old for its ''Noticias Univision,'' which is broadcast from 6 to 6:30 p.m. weekdays.

title: Love Is Painful For One Singer And a Comic Foil For Another

It was an efficient marathon show: two 100-minute sets separated by a 5-minute band changeover.

title: Nathan Kroll, 88, Producer Of Films on Noted Musicians
description: Nathan Kroll, a film producer whose background as a Juilliard-trained violinist informed his award-winning television documentaries about the cellist Pablo Casals, the violinist Jascha Heifetz and the tenor Luciano Pavarotti, among other musical subjects, died last Thursday after a long illness. He was 88 and lived in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London and the Publicis Groupe S.A. in Paris have agreed to discuss forming a giant media company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDMUNDS, ROBERT, M.D.
description: EDMUNDS-Robert, M.D. Died peacefully September 18, 2000. Born September 14, 1924, Toledo, OH. Graduate Harvard College 1946 and Columbia Univ. College of Physicians and Surgeons 1951. He was a surgeon on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital for 25 years and served on the Faculty of Columbia P&S. He was a fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Member of the N. Y. Surgical Society and N. Y. Academy of Medicine and an Officer of the N. Y. Cancer Society. Subsequent to his private practice, he was a Medical Director for the U. S. Steel Corp. in Chicago and Cleveland. During WWII, he was an officer in the Navy and later served in the Army Medical Corps Reserve retiring as Colonel. He is survived by his five children Nancy Kalal, Priscilla Smith, Elizabeth Bennett, Cynthia Edmunds, Robert Edmunds and four grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 28 at 4PM at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center Chapel, 113 St. between Amsterdam Ave. and Morningside Dr, NYC. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, New York, 10019 Att: Donations.

title: Golden Business as Usual for South Korean Archers
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- After sweeping the individual medals, three South Korean women joined to easily win the team archery gold for the fourth consecutive Olympics on Thursday (Wedneday night EDT), setting another world record.

description: MOLISANI-Marianne A. On September 19, 2000. Wife of the late E. Howard Molisani. title: U.S. Team Makes It 3 Losses In a Row
description: Lisa Fernandez relived her worst softball nightmare here this afternoon, when she surrendered a two-out, two-run home run to Australia, sending the United States women to a demoralizing 2-1 defeat in 13 innings in the preliminary Olympic tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, ZANVYL
description: KRIEGER-Zanvyl. We mourn the loss of a true giant in the world of Jewish and general philanthropy. As a Diamond Founder of the Medical Center, his outstretched hand of kindness made an invaluable contribution to our Department of Ophthalmology and to many thousands of people in Jerusalem. Our sincerest condolences to his daughters, Betsy Kandel-Krieger and Jeanne Krieger Kahn and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: The Missing Cant Beat Marion, Michael and Maurice
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  Marion Jones no longer needs to worry about Inger Miller in the women's 100 meters, and Cathy Freeman no longer needs to worry about Marie-Jose Perec in the women's 400.

title: ADC AND BROADBAND IN $2.25 BILLION DEAL
description: ADC Telecommunications, a telephone equipment maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held Broadband Access Systems, a maker of software and hardware for high-speed Internet access, for stock valued at $2.25 billion. ADC will issue $2.25 billion worth of its common stock to pay for all outstanding equity in Broadband Access. ADC's shares fell $2.44, to $32.44.

title: Hayworth Set for Weightlifting Contest
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Yes, Cheryl Haworth says, speaking of weighty matters, she really picked up a classmate's car and moved it from one side of her school parking lot to another.

title: Congress Appears Ready to Tackle Vehicle Rollover Problem
description: The 103 deaths now attributed to defective Firestone tires, most of which occurred in Ford Explorers that flipped when their tires failed, have galvanized Congress to tackle a far larger traffic safety problem: vehicle rollovers.

title: Cyclist Ends Long Wait for Gold
description: Marty Nothstein won the United States' first gold medal in cycling since 1984, defeating Florian Rousseau of France in the men's sprint finals yesterday in Sydney, Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKINS, R. BRUCE
description: HAWKINS-R. Bruce. Of Glen Cove, LI and Boca Raton, FL, on September 20th, 2000, age 70. Husband of Marilyn P., three sons and six daughters. For information, Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Long Island.

title: Politicking for 2012
description: The mayors of several would-be Olympic cities have been making the rounds in Sydney -- cozying up to members of the International Olympic Committee, getting tips and taking in the sights.

title: Making Room Online for Young Olympics Fans
description: IT started optimistically enough: find Olympics Web sites that appeal to children and are as exciting as watching Marion Jones run the 100 meters. But Olympic endeavors can have many a slip. Like the Russian gymnast who went whirling off his pommel horse on Saturday during a preliminary competition, the online sites are often disjointed and perform below expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSESSON, ESTHER W.
description: MOSESSON-Esther W. Died on September 19th, 2000 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Mosesson, devoted mother of Michael and Shirley (McDowell) Mosesson, and Judy and Ira Dembrow, cherished grandmother of Matthew and Amber (Jost) Mosesson, Marni and William Kambol, Aimee Mosesson, Adam Dembrow and Beth Dembrow, adored great grandmother of Harper Mosesson, loving sister of the late Archie, Beatrice, Blanche, Helen, Herbert, Lille, and Norman, & caring aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Thursday 9:45 A.M. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Esther and Benjamin Mosesson Fund for Thrombosis Research, The Blood Research Institute, PO Box 2178, Milwaukee, WI. 53201-2178.

title: In America; The Wrong Message
description: George W. Bush has been trying mightily to present to the nation an image of a more diverse, more inclusive Republican Party. But it's not an easy sell because his is a party with more than its share of troglodytes.

title: What's in a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Renews Call for Arena, With Pataki's Backing
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he wanted to build a domed indoor-outdoor arena on the West Side of Manhattan that would seat up to 100,000 people for major concerts, conventions and sports events. His plans were supported for the first time by Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the agency that owns the land.

title: U.S. Outlook Is Dismal
description: Indoor volleyball has changed dramatically since the last Summer Olympics. Sets are now played to 25 instead of 15, and a team can score on every exchange, not just when it is serving. A specialist defensive player, called a libero, is now part of the action and wears a different-colored shirt from his teammates.

title: Teaching the Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Over Saddam's Barrel
description: Nervous Nellie is worried about the strike by gas-gouged truckers in France and the panic buying of petrol by drivers in Britain. Nellie's fears are compounded by the rising price of gasoline in the U.S.

title: CANARY WHARF POSTS PROFIT
description: Canary Wharf, once a bankrupt victim of the 1992 recession, made its first profit as rents soared in London's second financial district. Canary Wharf Finance P.L.C., developer of the 10-tower complex in the Docklands, said profit from operations, stripping out one-time items, was $:15 million ($21 million) in the year ended June 30, compared with a loss of $:42.8 million a year earlier. The shares rose 5.5 pence to close at 535.5, the highest since they started trading in March 1999.

title: Sports of The Times; Look Who's On Display In Brooklyn
description: IN the years Joe DiMaggio reigned as New York's best baseball player, if not as all of baseball's best player, some often wondered how many more home runs he would have hit if he played for the Brooklyn Dodgers in cozy Ebbets Field instead of in Yankee Stadium, even more cavernous then than now. When that question was being debated one day, a New York Journal-American baseball writer named Garry Schumacher shook his head.

title: Yankees' Free Fall Grows, and It's Also Growing Serious
description: They plead guilty to their manager's charge of lethargy, but now that the Yankees consider themselves rehabilitated, they need a break to regain their place on the straight and narrow path that leads to the playoffs. Somebody needs to get a big hit, somebody needs to pitch a good game.

title: Mets Receive No Favors Against Phils
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21  There was an ease in the Mets clubhouse before the game tonight, the relief from having escaped Atlanta with a victory Wednesday night. Players partook in the usual distractions of videos, pizza and cards, but boasted a bit in the wake of having pulled off a rare victory at Turner Field.

title: CISCO TO WORK WITH NEC
description: Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of Internet infrastructure equipment, said yesterday that it would work with the Japanese Internet technology company NEC to develop products to ease online voice transmissions. The companies said they would integrate NEC's voice-based network products with Cisco's data communications systems. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, SIDNEY H.
description: LEVIN-Sidney H. Age 94. Died on September 19, 2000. In Los Angeles, CA. He is survived by his wife Idelle, his brother Alfred, his son Robert and daughter-in-law Elizabeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNETT, ILSE BLUM
description: BERNETT-Ilse Blum. September 19,2000. Wife of the late Frederick, mother of Peter and Tim, grandmother of Jesse and Claudia , sister of Walter Blum. Her warmth, vibrancy and intellect-a bright star for her whole, long life. A remarkable woman in every way. Expressions of sympathy to: Peter Bernett, 50 Bow Road, Belmont, Ma. 02478 and Tim Bernett, 4440 Morse Av, Studio City, CA. 91604. Contributions in her memory may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Montgomery Street, Montgomery, AL. 36104. Services will be held at 1PM Sunday, September 24 at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Road, Hartsdale, NY.

title: Valentine Wants Do-Over
description: After a humbling loss Tuesday night, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine scolded his players for their lackluster play this month. Today, he put the responsibility on himself, suggesting for the second year in a row that he should not return as manager if the Mets somehow miss the playoffs.

title: What's in a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Declines to Prosecute in Case of Man Beaten to Death on Jet
description: Federal prosecutors in Salt Lake City have decided not to file any charges in the death of a 19-year-old man who was beaten by fellow passengers last month after he broke into the cockpit of a Southwest Airlines flight to Salt Lake City from Las Vegas.

title: The City Life; Fashion Inside and Out
description: Soon Fashion Week -- a nine-day week, by the way -- will have come to an end. The huge white tents in Bryant Park will be struck. Burly men driving forklifts and self-propelled cherry-pickers will dismantle the rigging, the wiring, the plywood underfloor that has turned the grass yellow. The self-refreshing web cameras will be taken down, and one will no longer be able to peer into an audience of empty chairs or watch the models slowly strobing down the catwalk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWAN, BRIAN T.
description: DWAN-Brian T., 52, of New York, NY, on Wednesday, Sept. 11, 2000. After a brief illness. Beloved son of Grace (Barrett) Dwan of Harwich, MA., and the late Leon Adams Dwan. Brother of Grace Valentino of Sarasota, FL, Stephen Dwan of Walpole, MA, and Marilyn Kline of Port Charlotte, FL. Also survived by his loving nephews. Services will be private.

title: How 60 Israeli Women Managed to Dump the Boss
description: At the edge of the largest crater in the Negev, this isolated town draws nature lovers, artists, spiritual seekers and immigrants with nowhere else to settle. ''The stars talk to you here,'' one sculptor said, ''and you are tempted to talk back.''

title: Agency Is Seeking to Limit Peak Flights at La Guardia
description: Saying that delays have increased to an "unacceptable level" at La Guardia Airport, the Port Authority has told airlines that they cannot add more flights during the airport's busiest and most popular flying times, in the morning and evening.

title: A Political Wallflower Has a Full Dance Card
description: As Gov. George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, toured a Chicago classroom earlier this week, a sixth grader asked him how he would feel if he were running for election against his wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEVEAR, KENNETH WHITE
description: ROSEVEAR-Kenneth White, 93. Died September 15, 2000. Husband of the late Leslie (nee Ferguson), he is survived by two daughters, Cora Rosevear and Linda Greenberg, and two grandchildren, Leslie and Paul. A longtime resident of New York and Roslyn, Long Island, he lived in Sykesville, Maryland, for the last decade. Memorial service at St. Barnabas Church, Sykesville, on October 14th, at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The New York Public Library, 42nd Street Branch, Division of Art and Architecture.

title: Shopping, Your Way
description: To the Editor:

title: For Lithuanians, Miracle Moment Ends With a Miss
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  Eurelijus Zukauskas, a man Alonzo Mourning had never heard of before tonight, stepped to the foul line with 1 minute 9 seconds remaining.

title: Cheney Attacks Clinton's Dealings With Iraq
description: Using the same language that some critics used against him and former President George Bush after the Persian Gulf war nearly 10 years ago, former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today accused the Clinton administration of letting Saddam Hussein ''slip off the hook'' by avoiding weapons inspections.

title: NBC's Ratings Rise as Gymnasts Tumble
description: NBC's ratings for the Sydney Summer Games, which in their first four days drew the Olympics' smallest nighttime audience in American television history, improved on Tuesday night.

title: As Valentine Speaks, Folks Start Scribbling
description: It took one question about himself to make Bobby Valentine's eyes bulge, to make words spew out of his mouth and to convince him to make the same curious move that he made last season. One question for Valentine to suddenly declare that he does not deserve a contract extension if the Mets do not make the postseason. There should have been an echo.

title: S.E.C. Says Teenager Had After-School Hobby: Online Stock Fraud
description: By day, Jonathan G. Lebed was just another 15-year-old high school student in Cedar Grove in northern New Jersey. But after school, securities regulators say, Mr. Lebed masterminded a stock manipulation scheme on the Internet that earned him almost $273,000 in illegal gains.

title: Two Firms Offer Compromise on S.E.C. Audit Rule
description: Two major accounting firms broke rank with other firms yesterday and offered a compromise proposal to impose significant restrictions on the consulting work that accountants can do for their audit clients.

title: A LACK OF EVIDENCE IS CITED IN CASE INVOLVING CLINTONS
description: An independent prosecutor today put an end to the six-year Whitewater investigation, saying he had concluded that there was insufficient evidence to show that either President Clinton or his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, had committed any crimes in connection with the Arkansas real estate venture that vexed his presidency through two terms.

title: Artists Say Museum's Works Are Really Theirs
description: In the early 1980's, when the art dealer Sidney Janis was promoting the work of young graffiti artists, Michael Tracy, an underground painter from the South Bronx, gave the Janis Gallery several pieces to sell on his behalf, Mr. Tracy recalled. He said he considered one of the pieces, a six-foot metal subway door taken off a train and spray painted with his graffiti tag, ''Tracy 168,'' one of his best works.

title: People
description: * Paula Beer, director of account management at the New York office of Mad Dogs and Englishmen, was named general manager of a new San Francisco office.

title: Sit! Stay! Bark! Cut!
description: WILLIAM HILL was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a resume, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new iMac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable iMac without video editing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, JANE F., MD.
description: FERBER-Jane F., MD. On September 19th. Peacefully at home after a long illness. Loving mother of Elizabeth and Joshua; beloved mother-in-law to Josh and Prasthano; devoted grandmother to Gideon and Tallulah; inspiring companion to Richard. Graduate of Barnard College, 1957, and Columbia Univ. College of Physicians and Surgeons, 1961. Most recently Associate Residency director at Creedmore Psychiatric Center and Asst. Clinical Prof. of Psychiatry at Columbia University. She maintained a private psychiatry practice in New Rochelle, NY. she enlarged the life of everyone she knew. In addition to her family, she leaves a wide circle of grieving friends who will cherish her memory always.

title: Worker at Hospital Dies; Gas Leak Suspected
description: A man who was installing an M.R.I. machine at New York-Presbyterian Hospital was killed yesterday, apparently after nitrogen he was using leaked from its tank, officials said. Six other people were injured in the incident.

title: Time for Landmarking
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 French Journalists Tell of Escape From Jolo Rebels
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines  After 10 weeks of captivity in the mosquito-invested hills of a remote southern Philippine island, freedom for two French journalists came during a moment of confusion.

title: Agency Projects Costs of Earthquakes in U.S.
description: While California suffers the most economic harm from earthquakes, cities in other parts of the country, like Seattle, New York, Salt Lake City and St. Louis, are also at risk of heavy damage and should be doing more to prevent such harm, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said yesterday.

title: Safin, U.S. Open Victor, Loses Cool and Match
description: ''Some day he's going to crush me,'' Fabrice Santoro said. ''It's just a matter of time.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about interest shown by foreign automakers in South Korea's automotive industry misstated the year the Ford Motor Company sought to buy Kia Motors. It was 1998, not 1988. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the site of an interview with Peter A. Underwood, a consultant who advises foreign companies about doing business in South Korea. He was reached in Seoul by telephone from Tokyo, not interviewed in Seoul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUART, MAURICE
description: STUART-Maurice. Dear companion of Lloyd Altschul. Fond friend of many. Visitation Thursday 7 PM to 9 PM at The Piser Chapel, 5206 North Broadway Avenue, Chicago. For information call 773-561-4740.

title: Place Mats to Wake Up the Table
description: A TECHNOGEL place mat made with fabric scraps and a bright chartreuse straw mat are a far cry from their plain-Jane cousins. This fall, designers are using new materials and reworking old standbys to create interesting ways to protect, as well as decorate, the dinner table.

title: Thompson Settles for Bronze in Final Individual Event
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  Jenny Thompson was last out of the pool after tonight's 100-meter freestyle. This was her final individual event in her third Olympic Games. Soon she will retire at 27 and enter medical school at Columbia University. She checked the giant television screen and the scoreboard to see her name in third place, tied with her teammate Dara Torres in 54.43 seconds, behind another gold-medal effort by Inge de Bruijn. Thompson swam slowly toward the edge of the pool, as if she did not want to leave.

title: The Whitewater Verdict
description: In a brief and businesslike statement, the independent counsel Robert Ray said yesterday that the six-year investigation into Whitewater had produced ''insufficient'' evidence to justify criminal charges against President and Hillary Rodham Clinton. But while the statement came as a great relief to the White House, Mr. Ray's terse legal judgment does not excuse the White House's long record of obfuscation in the Whitewater matter, including its clumsy meddling with official inquiries and its failure to produce relevant records in a timely manner.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Settles Fraud Case With 15-Year-Old Student

title: Irans Well-Covered Women Remodel a Part That Shows
description: TEHRAN, Iran  The law in Iran requires women to cover their hair and to conceal the shape of their bodies in loose clothing.

title: Lazio Issues New Challenge On Soft Money
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, trying to put Hillary Rodham Clinton on the defensive over her campaign finance practices, declared today that he had obtained pledges from 14 political groups to stay out of the New York Senate race if Mrs. Clinton renounces soft money.

title: Mixing OS X and Microsoft
description: To the Editor:

title: Dueling Scholars Join Fray Over a Constitutional Challenge to Gun Control Laws
description: A federal appeals court case that offers the strongest constitutional challenge to gun control laws in decades has provoked a bitter academic dispute that could help shape rulings on whether Americans have an unfettered right ''to keep and bear arms.''

title: Suspensions Lead to American Weightlifting Gold
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Two Bulgarian weightlifters were stripped of their medals and thrown out of the Olympics on Friday after they tested positive for a banned weight-losing substance, giving the United States its first weightlifting gold medal since 1960.

title: A Question on Music Piracy
description: A1992 federal law, the Audio Home Recording Act, makes crystal clear that consumers may use digital audio tape players or similar audio recording gadgets to make copies of digital music for their personal, noncommercial use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEVY, JACK
description: KEVY-Jack. Of Fort Lee, NJ. On September 19. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Audrey Wilner and Larry Kevy. Cherished father-in-law of Alfred Wilner and the late Marlene Kevy. Loving grandfather of Matthew Kevy, Stewart Wilner and Michael and Jane Wilner, and great grandfather of Maddie and Katy Wilner. Services ''Wien & Wien'' corner Park and Passaic Sts, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday, September 21 at 10AM. Should friends desire, contrbutions to Temple Sinai, Tenafly, Temple Beth Shalom of Hastingson-Hudson, NY, or Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Barbara Walters To Stay at ABC

title: South Korean Aide Resigns Over Bank Loan Accusations
description: In the latest scandal involving high-ranking members of the South Korean government, a close aide to President Kim Dae Jung who was a key player in the government's reconciliation efforts with North Korea resigned today after being accused of using his position to help businessmen obtain substantial bank loans.

title: Trying to Skate Past A Hazing Scandal
description: At first glance, it seems like a typical first month of school in this bustling college town alongside a lovely lake. The sign on the diner says ''Welcome Back, Students.'' The bookstore hours are posted. Students stroll under trees that show hints of colorful foliage. At the athletic complex, hockey players work out informally in anticipation of official practice, which begins late next week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HATAB, LILA M.
description: HATAB-Lila M. Died September 21, 1979. It's been twenty-one years since you've left us. We still miss you and love you very much. George, Larry, Helen, Anne, Paul, and John

title: Article 2000092191069726695 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: SCHOLASTIC TO SET UP SHOP IN TOYS 'R' US
description: The Scholastic Corporation said yesterday that it would set up boutiques in 1,215 Toys ''R'' Us Inc. stores worldwide to sell Scholastic-branded crafts, games and toys. Financial terms were not disclosed. The products are expected to be available in the third quarter of 2001. Scholastic, based in New York, hopes to build on its reputation for educational products. The company posted better than expected results for the first quarter of its fiscal year late Tuesday and raised its profit forecast for 2001 because of the success of the Harry Potter books. Shares of Scholastic rose $7.38, or 12 percent, to $71.13.

title: Mullin and Nets Don't Seem a Fit
description: The Nets will not be signing the free agent Chris Mullin, the 37-year-old small forward and former St. John's star from Brooklyn whom the Indiana Pacers chose not to re-sign.

title: Rich? No, Frugal
description: After my mother-in-law died nine months ago, my family found itself among the 2 percent of Americans required to pay an estate tax. Suddenly we are among those whom President Clinton and Al Gore tag as ''very rich.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVAR, JOAN
description: KOVAR-Joan. We mourn the death of our longtime member, Joan Kovar. Our heartfelt condolences to Leon and her entire family. B. M. P. Family Circle Andrew Friedman, President

title: Law Firm Charged In Aiding Smugglers Of Chinese to U.S.
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday accused one of the city's busiest immigration law firms of working hand in hand with the smugglers who bring illegal immigrants from China and then keep them as virtual indentured servants in the United States until the price of their passage is repaid.

title: Examining Differences in Drug Prices
description: PRESCRIPTION drugs have become politicized. Al Gore recently criticized the manufacturer of the arthritis drug Lodine for selling it for $108 a month when prescribed for humans and $38 when prescribed for dogs. It's not just the doggy divide that has politicians upset; international price differences for drugs are another flash point. The House and Senate recently approved a measure allowing pharmacists to import prescription drugs from countries where they sell for substantially less than in the United States.

title: Peter Pinchbeck, Abstract Painter And Teacher, 69
description: Peter Pinchbeck, an English-born painter who worked in an Abstract Expressionist vein, was found dead in his loft in SoHo on Sept. 10. He was 69.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Wash Your Hands (Don't Forget the Soap)
description: To the Editor:

title: A summer slowdown in sales spurs additional efforts by archrivals Pizza Hut and Domino's.
description: THE nation's pizza peddlers, stung by a recent sluggishness in sales, are stepping up their already frenetic advertising, marketing and promotional efforts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of deletions during editing, an article on Sunday about growing resistance to mandatory overtime work omitted a reference to a new book that directed The Times to some of those interviewed. The book, a history of efforts to regulate the workweek, is ''Moments Are the Elements of Profit,'' by Prof. Marc Linder of the University of Iowa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARGENT, JAMES O'HARA
description: SARGENT-James O'Hara. Born August 3, 1962, died September 15, 2000. Beloved son of Clement Denny Sargent and Anne Sargent. Beloved brother and dear friend. He will be missed by all.

title: Advancing Without Abandoning The Past
description: Henry Threadgill is a powerful composer and uses the brute force of instrumentation to turn his music in different directions. And each time he changes direction, he retains the best ideas of his last band.

title: Bill Gates Senator Confronts Upstart Internet Challenger
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 21  Just as Henry M. Jackson was once known as the Senator from Boeing, Washington State's Slade Gorton is delighted to call himself the Senator from Microsoft , a man whose pit-bull advocacy for the software giant in the nation's capital has earned him the corporation's gratitude and campaign contributions from William H. Gates and other company officials.

title: Concert Review; Te Kanawa Opens Philharmonic Season
description: Rarely has the New York Philharmonic opened a season with so many loose ends dangling. The search for a new conductor is still frustrated. A deeply unsatisfactory hall awaits total overhaul. And an existing music director, Kurt Masur, lingers somewhere between his bruised relationship with a former Philharmonic management and some kind of part-time status in the future. The only encouraging certainty is Zarin Mehta, a newly installed executive director who just might make order out of existing chaos.

title: CHINESE SEE PAIN AS WELL AS PROFIT IN NEW TRADE ERA
description: China greeted its new prospects as a permanent American trade partner with official applause today, but there is growing trepidation as the country now shifts its focus to its future membership in the World Trade Organization.

title: U.S. Four - Man Rowers Advance
description: PENRITH Australia -- Selfish. Cocky. That's how Mike Wherley describes his decision to move from the U.S. men's eight crew to the four-man boat.

title: Coca-Cola Office in Spain Raided in Inquiry Into Business Practices
description: In an early morning raid yesterday, the Spanish authorities seized documents from the offices of Coca-Cola and its bottlers, investigating complaints that the companies had used illegal business tactics to keep rival soft drinks off the country's shelves.

title: Q & A / Peter Gottfried, secretary for integration : Hungary Vows to Meet EU Criteria by 2003
description: Hungary is one of six countries expected to be in the "first wave" of European Union expansion. For many, its strong economy makes it the front-runner: Gross domestic product is expected to grow 5.5 percent or 6 percent this year, inflationary and budgetary pressures are under control, and privatization and restructuring are almost complete.

title: Ford Tested Firestone Tires On Pickup, Not on Explorer
description: The Ford Motor Company acknowledged today that it had used a pickup truck, and not an Explorer sports utility vehicle, to test Bridgestone/Firestone tires at low air pressure, despite submitting an affidavit of a retired worker that implied that an Explorer was used.

title: No Headline
Priorities for Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleanup Fights Hillbilly Stereotype
description: Harvey Parrott, who hunts wild turkeys in his breathtaking native countryside hereabouts, could not believe his eyes and slammed on the brakes of his vehicle on the narrow forest road.

title: An American Finds Himself A Touch Short
description: Cliff Bayer will long remember the last touch of Kim Young Ho's sword to his stomach today, the one that crushed his chance of advancing to fencing glory. Bayer came to the Summer Olympics trying to ignore the hopes of his team and his federation that come with winning two World Cup fencing titles in the last year and being 12th-ranked in foil in the world.

title: Valentine Lets Wilpon Off the Hook
description: ATLANTA -- It took one question about himself to make Bobby Valentine's eyes bulge, to make words spew out of his mouth and to convince him to make the same curious move that he made last season. One question for Valentine to suddenly declare that he does not deserve a contract extension if the Mets do not make the postseason. There should have been an echo.

title: Panel Opposes UAL-US Airways Deal
description: The Senate Commerce Committee passed a resolution today opposing the $11.6 billion plan by the UAL Corporation to buy the US Airways Group because of concern that it could prompt more acquisitions among airlines.

title: Mind Games New Strategy In Savn Bout
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  For effect, or perhaps just because he can, the fabled Cuban boxing champion Felix Savon enters a boxing ring not by dipping between the ropes, but by lifting one leg at a time over the top rope with the ease of someone stepping into a warm bath.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIALIMIT REMOVED ON STEEL MAKER SHARES Hoping to increase the declining share price of the Pohang Iron and Steel Company, the world's largest steel maker, the South Korean government will eliminate the 30 percent foreign stock ownership and 3 percent individual share-holding limit in the company this month instead of next year, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said. Pohang's share price gained 3.2 percent. The shares had fallen 11 percent over the previous three days to the lowest level this year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Shopping, Your Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Vault Set Below Height, and a Favorite Is Undone
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  An inexplicable error made in the measurement of the vault apparatus during the women's Olympic all-around final tonight cast doubt on the validity of the outcome and may have cost the former world champion Svetlana Khorkina a chance to win a medal.

title: Effort Ends on Taittinger Control of Group
description: PARIS, Sept. 20  A pact involving Asher B. Edelman, the American corporate raider, that aimed to crack the Taittinger family's hold on the French luxury group Societe du Louvre has dissolved, leaving Mr. Edelman with a smaller stake.

title: LIMIT REMOVED ON STEEL MAKER SHARES
description: Hoping to increase the declining share price of the Pohang Iron and Steel Company, the world's largest steel maker, the South Korean government will eliminate the 30 percent foreign stock ownership and 3 percent individual share-holding limit in the company this month instead of next year, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said. Pohang's share price gained 3.2 percent. The shares had fallen 11 percent over the previous three days to the lowest level this year. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Trying to Move Beyond Prisons; Ogdensburg Hires a Go-Getter to Help It Diversify
description: Ask people in this lonely little city, so far north that it is practically part of Canada, and they will tell you that the one thing their town needs is a highway.

title: California in All Its Many-Sided Glory
description: ''Made in California,'' an exhibition opening next month at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, developed from three years of discussion and debate over what represents 20th-century California by curators from the museum, exhibition designers, historians and art and architecture critics. The show, meant to celebrate the turn of the millennium and the 150th anniversary of statehood, examines California's image in the popular and fine arts, architecture, decorative arts and ephemera. Included will be Ray Eames's cover for the May 1945 issue of Arts & Architecture (left) and a 1936 chair and ottoman (inset), designed by R. M. Schindler for the never-built Shep House. Information: (323) 857-6000.

title: Wash Your Hands (Dont Forget the Soap)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Displays Make a Big Deal Out of Tiny Details
description: FOR several years, the military has created its maps using computers rather than drawing boards. But when it comes time to use them in battle, things become decidedly low tech. ''They take a paper map and staple it to a 4-by-8 piece of plywood,'' said Jim Birch, business development director for microsystems and displays at the Sarnoff Corporation. ''That's the army we have today.''

title: Places to Close In on Ragweed, but From a Distance
description: PATTON'S first rule of war -- get the other poor blankety-blank before he gets you -- doesn't work with ragweed. It's too prolific, and a single plant's lightweight, allergenic spores, as many as one million a day, blow too far in the wind to let you solve your watering, itching and sneezing problems in your own backyard. Samples of ragweed pollen have been collected 400 miles at sea and 2 miles high, the National Institutes of Health says.

title: Residential sales
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTIVAL, DENISE HENRIETTE SUZANNE
description: ROTIVAL-Denise Henriette Suzanne. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Holt Rotival, their children and grandchildren, The Reverend Denise Rotival Huffman and her children, are saddened to announce the death of their aunt, Madame Denise Rotival. Chevalier du la Legion d'Honneur, Medaille des Forces Francaises Libres, Chevalier de la Sante Publique. Madame Rotival lived a memorable life. Born in Paris April 28th, 1900 she recently celebrated, in Paris, her 100th birthday surrounded by family and friends from both sides of the Atlantic. She came to the United States in 1914 to study at Smith College in North Hampton, Massachusetts, where she received both her Undergraduate and Masters Degrees. Madame Rotival developed life-long family ties with Dr. and Mrs. Hamilton Holt, of Woodstock, Connecticut, including becoming sister-in-law to their daughter Leila Stuart Holt Rotival. During the Second World War, Madame Rotival was the principal advocate and fundraiser in North America for the Free French. A portion of these funds were used for the reconstruction of the hospital in Saint Lo in Normandy. The religious ceremony was Wednesday, September 20th in the Eglise Reformee de Pentemont, 106 Rue de Grenelle, Paris, France.

title: CNF 3RD-QUARTER PROFITS MAY MISS ESTIMATES BY 24%
description: CNF Inc., the owner of Emery Worldwide, said its third-quarter earnings could be as much as 24 percent below analysts' estimates. CNF's stock price fell $1.44, to $23.63. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said late Tuesday that its profit would miss estimates because of a lower demand and higher costs at Emery, the air-freight company. CNF said it expects to earn 61 cents to 66 cents a share in the quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had been 80 cents a share.

title: NBC in Sydney: The Judges Frown
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Soon: Paperbacks That Sound Like Hip-Hop
description: Life is good for Jerome Usher, who drinks Dom P and lives in an enormous apartment with three bedrooms and a walk-in closet with rows of Versace, Armani, Valentino and Gucci suits, a $15,000 billiard table, an 80-inch Mission armoire and 10 universal remotes with which he can flip on Mobb Deep's ''Hell on Earth'' or just about anything else. Jerome also has a collection of watches, from Cartiers to Patek Philippes, and a six-foot Mosler safe that holds an assortment of handguns and silencers and an AR-15 sniper rifle. They are his professional tools. Usher is a black hit man.

title: Superhero Spider-Man Makes a Comeback
description: THE superhero sits brooding and unshaven in a musty armchair, his costume in tatters, his great muscles sagging, his spirit lost to despair. Many a time he has been recruited for computer and video games. And on many of those occasions, the game in which he was to appear vanished before the curtain rose. It is his history. It is his curse.

title: Nothstein Finds Himself Blocked From 2nd Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 21  It was not quite the daily double at the Meadowlands, but today's running of the Keirin cycling race was a reminder that not all Olympic sports have the heroic pedigree of the decathlon.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AVANEX, Fremont, Calif., named Paul Engle president and chief operating officer. As president, he succeeds Walter Alessandrini, chairman and chief executive. Mr. Engle was formerly vice president and general manager at the fiber optic communications division of Agilent Technologies.

title: From Theory to Practice; Capturing Every Moment of That Saturday Soccer Match
description: IS it as easy as computer and video camera makers would have you think to edit a home movie on a computer?

title: Real Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain's Battle Against Terrorism
description: In a series of raids conducted in both Spain and France in the past week, authorities arrested more than 36 alleged separatist Basque E.T.A. terrorists, including the man presumed to be their top leader. This is a victory not only for Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain, but for the Basque people themselves. They have had to bear the burden of the E.T.A.'s senseless terror.

title: VODAFONE'S SPANISH STAKE
description: In a move aimed at increasing its presence in the booming Spanish market, Vodafone S.A. plans to purchase another 8.5 percent of Airtel S.A., which will bring its stake in Spain's No. 2 wireless company to more than 30 percent. Vodaphone will pay three Spanish shareholders up to 570 million shares, or about 1 percent of the company's capital, worth about $2.1 billion. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Knicks Have a Hole in the Middle
description: Greetings from the Sydney Games, where the Knicks' new starting center was outplayed by Canada's Todd MacCulloch the other night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AETHER SYSTEMS INC., Owings Mills, Md., said it plans to buy the transportation unit of Motient Corp., Reston, Va., for $45 million.

title: In an MTV World, an Ancient Art Courts Followers
description: A familiar cacophony echoes in the school's peeling cement halls, just regular youngsters letting off steam during a break between classes. The boys are in tracksuits and Nikes, the giggly preteenage girls in Hello Kitty T-shirts and platform shoes.

title: National News Briefs
description: Air Traffic Controllers Accused of Slowdown

title: E-Mail You Can't Outrun
description: YOU know they've gotten a BlackBerry when they stop calling.

title: To Market, With a Digital Movie and a Dream
description: ''I think of us as the garage bands of the year 2000,'' Eva Ilona Brzeski said over a cup of coffee. Across the street at the Angelika Film Center, other young directors like Ms. Brzeski were screening their films at the IFP Market, a combination film festival and workshop this week in Lower Manhattan. Like Ms. Brzeski's ''Last Seen,'' an 87-minute feature about the disappearance of a high school volleyball player, many of the films have been shot, wholly or partly, on digital video.

title: Metro Matters; The X Factor (And the Y) In Politicking
description: ANN RICHARDS, the former governor of Texas, tells a revealing story about running for re-election against George W. Bush in 1994. He had accused her of being soft on crime because she supported probation for nonviolent small-time offenders (to make room in prisons for violent felons). So she worked hard to prove her toughness.

title: Dow Declines on Oil Worries; Nasdaq Has Technology Rally
description: A flurry of afternoon buying of technology stocks rescued the Nasdaq composite index from an early slide yesterday, but other major gauges slumped.

title: Thompson Delivers Another Victory
description: After three legs of the women's 4x200-meter freestyle relay tonight, the United States was in danger of not defending its Olympic title.

title: OPTIMARK TO CUT JOBS AND OPERATIONS
description: The electronic stock trading company Optimark Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 110 jobs and suspend its equity trading operations on the Pacific Exchange and the Nasdaq to save money. The closely held company, based in Jersey City, N.J., also said Philip Riese, its chief executive, would step down but remain as a director. He will be replaced by David Johnson and Robert Warshaw, who were named co-chief executives and appointed to the board. The company, whose investors include General Atlantic Partners L.L.C., Dow Jones & Company, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company, contemplated exiting the stock trading business last month.

title: Romanian Wins Sabre Gold Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Mihai Claudiu Covaliu of Romania won the Olympic gold medal in men's sabre Thursday, defeating Mathieu Gourdain of France.

title: Military Backs Ex-Guard Pilot Over Pvt. Gore
description: Al Gore enlisted in the Army and went to Vietnam. George W. Bush joined the Texas National Guard and did not. But for many people in uniform, that makes little difference. It is Mr. Bush, not Mr. Gore, who seems to enjoy some automatic credibility with the military because of his party affiliation, his policy positions, his running mate, his advisers -- and his father.

title: Under Attack, Gore Reshapes Censure of Drug Industry
description: Vice President Al Gore accused pharmaceutical companies today of gouging the elderly, pointing to the examples of several people he said were having problems paying for their medicine. But he did not repeat a personal anecdote about prescription drugs that Republicans have sharply ridiculed: the one about his mother-in-law, who, he said last month, paid three times as much for her arthritis medication as he did for the same drug for his dog.

title: Hartmann Takes Met PGA in Playoff
description: Rick Hartmann, despite shooting a bogey 5 on the first extra hole, won his first Izod/Cadillac Met PGA Championship yesterday in a three-way playoff with Heath Wassem and Carl Alexander at the Hudson National Club in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Prince of Central Park: A Musical Stripped of Its Score
description: Prince of Central Park

title: MCCAW STAKE IN SATELLITE VENTURE
description: If all goes as planned in a complex series of mergers in the last quarter of this year, Craig O. McCaw will control just over 60 percent of the stock of the new satellite company to be created from the merger of the formerly bankrupt ICO Global Communications and Mr. McCaw's Teledesic, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. McCaw will have to raise at least $2.8 billion in new investments for the London-based company to begin offering voice and data services for mobile phone and computer users in mid-2003, the filing said. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: It's All Archery All the Time For Gold and Silver Medalists
description: The Australia-United States rivalry that has become a thread through the Olympic Games surfaced again today in the men's individual archery finals. But it was less a story of fervent nationalistic competition than the tale of two single-minded athletes who met for the ultimate prize.

title: For a King Memorial, Metaphors Set in Stone
description: As an orator, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. made rich use of metaphor, often alluding to landscape -- mountains, valleys and water, shade and sunlight -- to convey emotion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODYEAR, MARY
description: GOODYEAR-Mary. The volunteers and staff of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society wish to express deep sorrow on the passing of Mary Thompson Goodyear, 88, of New Orleans, LA, who died on September 8. Mary Goodyear served as a volunteer for numerous philanthropic and community service groups in New Orleans. Her work with the National MS Society began in 1971 as a member of the National Board of Directors. In 1973, as one of the local founders, she initiated the charter for the Louisiana Chapter of the Society and for 28 years continued to help the Chapter flourish; she was the Chapter's first ever Dinner of Champions honoree last November. She remained steadfastly dedicated to the National MS Society and its work. Her son Charles is presently a member of the National Board of Directors. Mrs. Goodyear is survived by her daughter, Mary Goodyear Glenn; three sons, Charles, David and Andrew; sixteen grandchildren and eighteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on September 30th at 10AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, 1329 Jackson Avenue, New Orleans, LA. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Louisiana Chapter of NMSS. National Multiple Sclerosis Society Richard B. Slifka Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan, General, USAF (Ret) President and CEO

title: Study Says California Plan Would Aid Affluent
description: A school voucher initiative on the California ballot this fall would, once fully implemented, give at least $2.6 billion in taxpayer money to families -- most of them affluent -- whose children already attend private schools, according to an academic study released today.

title: Article 2000092193567235692 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: Speedier Trains
description: On days when gridlock paralyzed Newark International Airport this year, Continental Airlines resorted to putting some of its short-flight passengers on Amtrak trains. Such pragmatic improvisation made sense, but also raises the question why anyone would choose to fly from Newark to Baltimore or Providence in the first place. At a time when the nation's air traffic system is strained to its very limits, it is a question gaining added urgency.

title: In Poll, Mrs. Clinton Makes Gain Among Women From the Suburbs
description: Voter attitudes toward Rick A. Lazio have turned markedly more negative since June, with suburban women now moving solidly toward Hillary Rodham Clinton and many New Yorkers saying Mr. Lazio came across as harsh and inexperienced in his debate with Mrs. Clinton last week, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Raw Rap and Film May Stir a Fuss, but Hist'ry Shows 'Twas Ever Thus
description: The first English novels, by Henry Fielding and Samuel Richardson in the 18th century, were filled with debauchery, and the London establishment was convinced that this new form of literature was debasing the country's youth.

title: Advertising Group Selects Honorees
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives 40 and younger.

title: HYUNDAI LEAVING DAEWOO ALONE
description: The Hyundai Motor Company said it had no plans to make a solo bid to acquire the Daewoo Motor Company, even though regulators might seek one. Its partner in the first round of bidding, DaimlerChrysler, said it might be interested in part of Daewoo. The chairman of Hyundai Motor, Chung Mong Koo, said he had never considered making a bid without participation by DaimlerChrysler because the company already had overlapping product models with Daewoo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOELSON, LYNN
description: JOELSON-Lynn. Died peacefully on September 20, 2000 at Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, Florida. Loving mother of Chuck, Robert, and Paul. Dear mother-in-law of Manon and Wynne. Adoring and proud grandmother of Marlon, Kai, and Gina. Devoted sister, aunt, and friend. Her admirable spirit and resilience will be missed. Keep on dancing! A memorial service is planned.

title: Lessons on Shopping In a Confusing Market
description: FOR once, real estate experts are speechless.

title: Study Finds Monitors May Pose Health Risks
description: For people who sit in front of computer monitors all day, the old joke about being allergic to work may have some scientific validity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, FRANCES E., M.D.
description: STEIN-Frances E., M.D. Died at home September 18, 2000. Mass of Resurrection to be held at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street, NYC at 10AM on Thursday, September 21, 2000.

title: Valentine Wants a Do-Over
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20  After a humbling loss Tuesday night, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine scolded his players for their lackluster play this month. Today, he put the responsibility on himself, suggesting for the second year in a row that he should not return as manager if the Mets somehow miss the playoffs.

title: Impressive New Video Displays
description: FOR several years, the military has created its maps using computers rather than drawing boards. But when it comes time to use them in battle, things become decidedly low tech. "They take a paper map and staple it to a 4-by-8 piece of plywood," said Jim Birch, business development director for microsystems and displays at the Sarnoff Corporation. "That's the army we have today."

title: Surprise! Before He's Even Gone, Fujimori May Be Planning His Comeback
description: From the moment Alberto K. Fujimori entered politics little more than a decade ago, his most powerful weapon at times of crisis has been the element of surprise. Now, as he faces the most serious challenge to his hold on power, he appears to be counting once again on guile, agility and sleight of hand to save the day.

title: Hyman, in Surprise, Joins No. 1 van den Hoogenband
description: There had never been a 100-meter freestyle like this. Three men had traded the world record in swimming's main event over the last five days, and the eight lanes of water churned so furiously today that they seemed to boil with expectation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODESSEY, PAUL HERMAN
description: ODESSEY-Paul Herman. Died at his home in Great Neck, NY, on Tuesday, September 19, 2000. Mr. Odessey was President of Polarad Electronics Corporation from 1949 -1965. Mr. Odessey was the holder of many patents; notably one of the earliest translating devices developed for the U.N. From 1965 to 1990 he was President of Sterling Transformer Corporation. He is survived by his 4 children: Richard, Phyllis, Sheila, and Gail; and his six grandchildren: Eric, Rebecca, Ben, Sophie, Louis and Lola.

title: Los Angeles Agrees to Changes for Police
description: Bowing to the inevitable, Los Angeles city officials have agreed to accept a federal court agreement that would require a series of long-sought changes in police management and training to head off a threatened civil rights lawsuit over what the Justice Department has called a systemic pattern of abusive conduct by officers here.

title: Article 2000092192007605803 -- No Title
description: EDUCATION COLUMN

title: Finding A Purpose After a Loss
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Every athlete at these Olympics has a story. Few have a story like the Olympic boxer Jermain Taylor's. A number of stories all in one: triumph and tragedy, life and loss, coming face to face with the unfairness of it all and, ultimately, claiming victory.

title: RANGERS RETURN NOVAK
description: The Rangers got down to 33 players yesterday by reassigning defenseman Filip Novak to his junior team, the Regina Pats of the Western Hockey League.

title: The U.S. Consumer's Friend
description: First it was the Sprint-WorldCom merger. Now it is AOL's proposal to buy Time Warner. Two mergers between American companies, both stymied by the European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKARULIS, DR. JOHN A.
description: SKARULIS-Dr. John A. Graduate of and taught at St. Johns University and Professor of Chemistry for over 35 years, accomplished pianist and organist. Survived by two sons, John and Greg, MD, and nine grandchildren.

title: Stress Tests Help Predict Hidden Ills of the Heart
description: Apparently healthy men whose heartbeats are frequent out-of-sync during stress tests run more than twice the usual risk for dying of heart disease or stroke, a study has found.

title: The Right to Die With Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: CYTOCLONAL GETS PATENT RELATED TO CANCER DRUG
description: Cytoclonal Pharmaceutics Inc. said it received a patent for a gene that codes an enzyme used in producing the key ingredient in the cancer drug Taxol. The company, based in Dallas, said the patent covers the gene that makes an enzyme needed to produce paclitaxel, the active ingredient in Taxol, a cancer drug sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb, with $1.5 billion in annual sales. The patent also covers the enzyme produced by the gene, and the method used to isolate the gene. The company is working with Bristol-Myers to develop a cost-effective way to produce paclitaxel using genetic engineering, said Arthur Bollon, chief executive of Cytoclonal. Cytoclonal's shares were up $1, to $8.88.

title: Need for Food By Refugees In West Timor Is Worsening
description: Tens of thousands of East Timor refugees living in squalid camps on the West Timor border face starvation by the end of the month, government officials and aid workers on the divided island said today.

title: Suffolk Police Investigating Retired Officer's Death in Amityville House Fire
description: The Suffolk County police are investigating the death of a 62-year-old gunsmith who was also a retired New York City police officer in a fire that ravaged his home here on Tuesday night.

title: The Vintage Dress: 92,400 Places to Start
description: I AM a big defender of the dress. Suffering from three children, a dog, two cats and a suicidal streak that prompted me to agree last week to become a class mother, I am grateful to any single article of clothing that takes less than 30 seconds to put on but is efficient enough to function as an entire outfit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARG, HAROLD
description: BARG-Harold. Died on Monday, September 18, 2000. Survived by wife Phyllis; children Marcy, Jane and Steven; and 5 grandchildren. Services will be held at Bernheim, Apter, Goldsticker, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey at 1:00 PM, Friday, September 22.

title: Article 2000092193041637192 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, PROFESSOR LEON
description: WEIN - Professor Leon. The Brooklyn Law School Community mourns the loss of a beloved colleague and esteemed teacher. Over the past three decades he has touched the lives of thousands of students, lawyers and friends. Although his presence will be missed, his legacy will be enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Chaya, his children, Baruch, Simcha, Chaim and Rifka, and his entire family. Paul Windels, Jr., Chairman of the Bd. of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

title: As Election Nears, Yugoslavia's Main Rivals Lash Out
description: With Yugoslavia's presidential election only days away, the two main rivals held competing rallies here tonight, speaking as if to two separate nations, with President Slobodan Milosevic taking up the fight for his future in an extraordinarily personal fashion.

title: A Bed Murphy's Law Can't Touch
description: An update on the Murphy bed: the Vanja Container bed, by the Italian designer Vico Magistretti, is aimed at apartment dwellers who want style and storage space. The Vanja Container is an ingenious marriage of a Shaker-style cherry-wood base and headboard and a high-tech lifting device derived from Mercedes automobile mechanics. The bed (priced at a king-size $3,200) was introduced at the Milan furniture fair this year, and is available at Dormire, 1345 Fourth Street in Santa Monica, (310) 393-9288.

title: Digital Information For the Tragically Hip
description: A debate may rage over whether leather pants will really be this fall's fashion fetish, but there is one accessory that urban hipsters should not be seen without: Modo. At least that is what Modo's developers will tell you.

title: NBC in Sydney: The Judges Frown
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, WM. BRIAN
description: LITTLE-Wm. Brian. Loved husband, father, son, grandfather, father-in-law, friend of Judy, Jackie, Greg, Bill, Will, Megan, Jack, Henry and Alicia. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Colgate University or the Photography Department of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art or the Photography Department of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Aid to the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, director of the Black Ministers Council in New Jersey, which has campaigned against racial profiling by the state police, misstated the number of black and Hispanic men shot and wounded by state troopers during a traffic stop on the New Jersey Turnpike in April 1998. It was three, not four.

title: Bush Attacks Proposal
description: HOLLYWOOD, Md., Sept. 21  Vice President Al Gore said today that the White House should release a modest amount of oil from government stockpiles to try to stabilize oil prices, a move that Gov. George W. Bush immediately denounced as a political ploy that could endanger national security.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE ISSUES

title: LAURA ASHLEY REPORTS A PROFIT
description: After years of losses that brought it to the brink of insolvency, Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C., the British chain best known for floral prints, said it returned to a first-half profit following a shift toward home furnishings. The company, which sold off its money-losing business in the United States last year, said first-half net income rose to $:1.1 million or $1.54 million, compared with a loss of $:7.2 million one year earlier. Home furnishings accounted for 60 percent of its $:118 million sales. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Bush Adviser Tied to Companies
description: A principal author of Gov. George W. Bush's Medicare plan, Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, serves on the boards of eight health care companies whose fortunes could be affected by the Bush proposal.

title: BRITISH RATES MAY RISE
description: The Bank of England acknowledged that its Monetary Policy Committee had been narrowly divided this month on holding the benchmark interest rate at 6 percent. The bank said committee members voted 5 to 4 for the second successive month to leave rates unchanged. The closeness of the ballot suggested that the committee could be close to a rate increase if inflation was fueled by the sterling's weakness and high oil prices. The prospect helped to strengthen the pound to $1.4124 from $1.4016 and to 59.92 pence against the euro from 60.38 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Satellite Web Links Let Indian Tribes Take a Technological Jump
description: THE reach of the Internet has now made it to the floor of the Grand Canyon and several other remote places on American Indian reservations in the Southwest.

title: Mathis Gets Hot As MetroStars Finish Off Burn
description: When it was over, midfielder Tab Ramos, an original member of the MetroStars, sat at his stall in the team's Cotton Bowl locker room and just relaxed. Ramos did not seem all that excited about the team's qualifying for the Major League Soccer semifinals for the first time with tonight's 2-1 victory over the Dallas Burn.

title: CABARET IN REVIEW
description: A Broadway Romantic

title: Bertelsmann Sets Investment Fund
description: Bertelsmann A.G., Europe's largest media company, said today that it would invest up to $1 billion in a new private equity fund aimed at technology companies in the media industry.

title: The Right to Die With Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitis Presidential Campaign Officially Opens
description: PORT Haiti, Sept. 20  The campaign for Haiti's presidency and nine Senate seats began today in an election expected to return Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power.

title: American Sailor Loses Lead
description: SYDNEY Australia -- J.J. Isler thought the women's 470 Olympic sailing competition was going to be wide open, and she was right.

title: German Utility Expected to Buy Thames Water of Britain
description: In what is expected to spur further consolidation among European utilities, RWE A.G., a German energy and environmental concern, is nearing an agreement to acquire Thames Water P.L.C., of Britain for $:4.3 billion or about $6 billion, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Another Game, Another Pleasant U.S. Surprise
description: The United States Olympic baseball team, many of them unheralded minor leaguers and major league castoffs, knows that they are nobody's idea of a Dream Team. They might call themselves Olympic baseball's little-known secret.

title: Chinese Win Mixed Badminton Doubles
description: SYDNEY Australia -- The Chinese team of Zhang Jun and Gao Ling won the Olympic gold medal Thursday in mixed doubles badminton, defeating Tri Kusharyanto and Minarti Timur of Indonesia in three games.

title: Boring 50 Percent of the People 80 Percent of the Time, or Vice Versa
description: PERHAPS it would interest you to know that during the first quarter of this year, 50.4 percent of Internet users were women. You might be intrigued by the recent news that the number of people who visited Gov. George W. Bush's official Web site, www.georgewbush.com, soared 522 percent after a new version opened last month.
