Or maybe you will find it fascinating to learn that the money spent on business-to-business online advertising is expected to reach $3 billion by 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JAY A.
description: MILLER-Jay A. Formerly of New York died in Los Angeles, CA on September 19, 2000. Loved husband of Robin. Cherished father of Amy, Lauren & Lili. Grandfather of Jillian. Dear brother of Howard and Robert. Adored uncle. Your love, sense of humor and spirit will always be with us. We are grateful you are at peace.

title: Moonlighting With Clients at Siesta Time
description: It keeps Spanish hours, lures patrons from the restaurant next door and offers modern and refinished vintage furnishings. Homework, right, a new store opened by Laser Rosenberg, an interior designer, is next to a restaurant named Ammo. Mr. Rosenberg opens his store at 11 a.m., then closes it at 3 p.m. to see clients. Come 7 p.m., and the rush to dine at Ammo, Mr. Rosenberg opens again, and stays open until 11. In addition to his own work, like two pillows covered with 1970's fabrics, left ($78 for small and $98 for large pillows), Homework sells products by other American and European designers. At right are, foreground, an Ultrasuede pillow by Angela Adams ($375)and a white lacquered wood table by Siegel Arts of Brooklyn ($600). Homework is at 1153 North Highland Avenue (Lexington Avenue); (323) 466-1153.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, DONALD
description: WHYTE-Donald. A memorial service celebrating the life of Donald Whyte will be held in the auditorium of the New York Society of Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, Friday, Sept. 22, 2000 at 5 PM. Contributions can be made in the memory of Donald Whyte to Music Assistance Fund, c/o American Symphony Orchestra League, 33 W. 60th St, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10023 or A Gift Of Life For Heart Transplant Program, P.O. Box 49, Madison Square Station, NYC 10159.

title: Official at Pension Agency Faces Scrutiny
description: A top executive of the federal agency that guarantees pensions improperly steered $40 million worth of contracts to a minority-owned company, Congressional investigators are set to testify this morning before a joint meeting of two Senate committees. The allegations, they said, are being forwarded to the Justice Department.

title: In Heat of Campaign, Trial Is Just Distraction
description: SOME might be scandalized to hear that a fellow could win an election with a criminal indictment hanging over his head, but to hear Pedro Espada Jr., a Democratic candidate for the State Senate from the Bronx, tell it, his victory in the primary last week was a beautiful thing.

title: UN Skeptical Of Indonesia's Plan to Disarm Timor Militias
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesia has for the first time set out a timetable for disarming militia gangs terrorizing East Timorese refugees and foreign aid workers in West Timor, and threatening United Nations peacekeepers across the border in East Timor.

title: How the Senate Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 14-19 with 1,611 adults throughout the state. Of those, 1,212 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: Hard Words and Harder Play Help Mets Snap Out of It
description: Twenty-four hours earlier, in the same clubhouse, there had been a fiery monologue, stern words from their manager about how they were too good to be playing so badly.

title: Industrial Nations to Confront the Sagging Euro and Costly Oil
description: The slumping euro and fuel price inflation quickly took over as the dominant themes today in advance of a meeting of some of the world's top finance officials, with the European currency weakening to a record low and oil prices reaching another 10-year high.

title: Letter Asks Goldman Sachs To Allow Corzine Disclosure
description: In the latest attempt by Republicans to force Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, to release his personal tax returns, a former federal judge called today on Goldman Sachs Group, Mr. Corzine's former employer, to free him from a confidentiality pact that Mr. Corzine says prevents him from doing so.

title: Sometimes A Player Must Take His Time
description: Few slow-play penalties were imposed at the world team championship in Maastricht, the Netherlands, this month. When play was slow, there were several possible reasons: a particularly close match, complex conventions requiring much study of defensive methods, naturally slow players and difficult hands. South was certainly entitled to take his time in playing the diagramed deal from the quarterfinal stage.

title: CYBERWORKS STAKE SOLD
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the No. 2 British phone company, is selling a 4.9 percent stake in Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., an Asian Internet investment company, for as much as 10.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.3 billion). Cable and Wireless received cash and about a fifth of CyberWorks on Aug. 17 in return for holdings in Hong Kong's No. 1 phone company, Cable and Wireless HKT Ltd.

title: Anti-Euro Britons Feeling Vindicated; But Nation's Currency Isolation Is Still Seen as Threat by Many
description: When Europe's single currency was introduced in 11 countries last year Britain stood aloof, refusing to abandon its venerable pound. It brushed aside domestic critics and business leaders who said their land might be setting misplaced nationalism ahead of the opportunity to participate in the Continent's greatest financial revolution.

title: Knicks Send Ewing to Sonics As 4-Team Deal Ends an Era
description: After one embarrassingly botched trade attempt and several other false starts, the Knicks last night finally parted with Patrick Ewing, the cornerstone of the franchise for the past 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAKIM, EDWARD
description: HAKIM-Edward. Happy Birthday, Edward. I am lost without you. Love, Kay

title: The Tower Of Flowers
description: A joyful tower at 9865 Olympic Boulevard in Beverly Hills is the result of an ambitious art therapy project. The California Tower of Hope is actually a defunct oil drill that is clad in 220 polyvinyl-coated fiberglass panels painted in a flower design by 4,000 children in hospitals throughout California (helped by 35,000 California schoolchildren, who primed the panels). The project, soon to be illuminated at night, was conceived in 1995 by Ed Massey of Portraits of Hope, a public art and art therapy program.

title: Accounts
description: * Surgency, Cambridge, Mass., and San Jose, Calif., an Internet consulting firm formerly named Benchmarking Partners, to Frankfurt Balkind Partners, New York, as the first agency of record to handle its account. Spending was estimated at $6 million.

title: CITIBANK TO OPEN RETAIL BRANCHES IN ISRAEL
description: Citibank will open retail branches in Israel by July and may invest in or buy an Israeli bank in a bid to tap the wealth created by a growing technology industry, William R. Rhodes, the bank's vice chairman, said. Citibank, a unit of Citigroup Inc., also plans to increase investment in Israeli venture capital funds and issue credit cards in Israel, offering competition to domestic card companies owned by Bank Hapoalim Ltd. and Bank Leumi Le-Israel Ltd. The company opened its first commercial bank branch in Israel yesterday. Opening retail branches shows a commitment that Citibank hopes will attract more corporate business.

title: Taliban Open A Campaign To Gain Status At the U.N.
description: Four years after taking control of most of Afghanistan, the Islamic Taliban movement sent a high-level team to New York this week to lobby for the Afghan United Nations seat.

title: Fashion Week Diary; An Atypical Beauty Throws Pie at the Conventional Face
description: When Erin O'Connor suggested last week that beauty is boring, the actual term she used was unprintable French gutter slang. If hers was a remark unexpected from a model, it should be noted that Ms. O'Connor in no way typifies the breed.

title: American Rider Leads After Accident-Marred Day
description: SYDNEY Australia -- American David O'Connor of the United States conquered the cross-country course with a perfect ride Thursday to lead the Olympic individual three-day event on a day that was marred by a horse's death and spectacular spills.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about efforts by pagans to increase public understanding omitted the full name of a member of a pagan organization in Indiana who said there had been no protests over his group's rituals. He is C. L. Hankins II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, LAURIE D. (DI BELLA)
description: MAHER-Laurie D. (Di Bella) on September 19, 2000 of Ramsey, NJ. Beloved wife of John Maher. Devoted mother of Stephen, Dana and her fiance Michael Rollison. Loving daughter of Irma & Louis Di Bella of Wyckoff, NJ. Dear sister of Thomas of Oakland, NJ, Louis of Fairlawn, NJ & Katherine Seluja of Santa Fe, NM. Aunt of Brian Marotta, Chiara Di Bella, Serefina and Camila Seluja. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Friday, September 22, 2000 at St. Paul's R.C. Church in Ramsey, NJ at 10A.M. Visitation Thursday from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey. Interment Maryrest Cemetery in Mahwah, NJ. Donations to the New York Hospital Laurie Maher Cancer Pain Fund, C/O John Maher, 109 Darlington Avenue, P.O. Box 908, Ramsey, NJ 07446 would be appreciated. For further information or directions, please call 201-327-0030 or visit us at www.vanemburghsneider.com

title: Johnson Told to Curb Taunts
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers' general manager and the communications director yesterday asked Keyshawn Johnson to tone down his six-month tirade against the Jets. So yesterday, in the second of three news conferences Johnson is holding before the unbeaten Jets and the unbeaten Buccaneers in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday, the receiver seemed to go out of his way to say very little.

title: Testaverde Is Returning, Better for Wear and Tear
description: His is the other reunion, the silent sideshow to Keyshawn Johnson's full-color, surround-sound carnival of trash talk and bruised ego.

title: The Right to Die With Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Urges Clinton to Fight Oil Prices by Using Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Vice President Al Gore recommended today that President Clinton release oil from the country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to keep heating-oil prices from rising even higher this winter.

title: With Push From Wells, Yanks Slide Continues
description: TORONTO, Sept. 21  David Wells was once part of the solution for the Yankees. Now he is a big part of a growing problem.

title: Stumbling Into the Gap Between Analog and Digital TV
description: TEENAGE angst is nothing. To understand real pain, consider the grown man trying to buy a big-screen television in the year 2000.

title: Article 2000092192952818468 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: A New Father Is Also a New Champion
description: Aleksei Nemov hadn't seen his newborn son, not even a picture in the 18 days since his birth, but the idea of being a father took up every spare inch of his thoughts.

title: One More Lap, With Feeling, For American
description: Who doesn't dream of a Dan Jansen Olympic moment? For four years, for more hours in the gym and on the cycling track than he could remember, Marty Nothstein thought of little else.

title: Views of Nature Before Darwin Jumped Into the Debate
description: A Romantic Natural History, maintained by Dr. Ashton Nichols, a professor of English at Dickinson College, examines the way artists, writers and scientists viewed nature in the century before Charles Darwin published ''On the Origin of Species'' in 1859 (www.dickinson .edu/nicholsa/Romnat/romnat1.htm).

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Sept. 8 about the Wyclef Jean Foundation's new prize for outstanding students misspelled the names of the award and of the fur designer for whom it is named. It is the Battle Award, not the Brattle Award. The designer, who died this year at 37, was Nija Battle, not Naji Brattle.

title: INSIDE
description: Explosion in London

title: Pesticide Spraying in City Is Illegal, Lawyer Argues
description: In a lawsuit over New York City's use of pesticides to control West Nile virus, a lawyer for a coalition of environmental groups argued yesterday that using the chemicals in heavily populated areas violated federal and state environmental laws.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Lessons on the Fragile Nature of a Dream
description: FIRST there was a twinge, then tightness, then a screaming, hot pain. Finally, Inger Miller had to face the moment of reckoning. She got down in the starting blocks last week and tried to burst out of them. She couldn't.

title: Singapore Journal; A Fastidious City-State Has an Answer for Crows
description: The men with shotguns gathered in the park at dusk, loaded their weapons and fanned out along the shoreline between the palm trees and the concrete path with its signs warning joggers: ''Beware of falling coconuts.''

title: Once Upon a Time
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corzine Stumbles Over Question on Timing of Donation
description: Just when Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate, seemed to have put questions about his charitable giving behind him, a botched answer in a relatively pressure-free forum tonight set off a new wave of questions.

title: A Passion For Food And Other Delicacies
description: The soothing lilt of bossa nova floats over the malnourished but sometimes entrancing romantic comedy ''Woman on Top,'' which starts in Bahia, where the delectable Penelope Cruz plays Isabella, a chef. Isabella cooks magnificent meals, and epicures from around the globe fall in love with her culinary talents. In the dining room of the restaurant her husband, Toninho (Murilo Benicio), the restaurant's owner, flirts with female customers and fronts a band whose tempos dance above the diners' heads like aromas from the kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, JOHN RUPERT
description: MARTIN-John Rupert. Princeton University mourns the loss of its colleague, John Rupert Martin, Marquand Professor of Art and Archaeology, emeritus, who died on July 26, 2000. A memorial service will be held in The Chapel, Princeton University, Thursday, September 28, at 5 P.M.

title: Questions Facing the Knicks
description: New York now begins life without Patrick Ewing, but with Glen Rice, Luc Longley and Travis Knight. It may prove to be problematical. CHRIS BROUSSARD

title: Behavior at a Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Games, Five Medals for a Determined Briton
description: PENRITH, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 23  Don't shoot the old man. On the other hand, don't necessarily believe a word he says.

title: GORE ASKS RELEASE OF U.S.-STORED OIL TO STABILIZE PRICE
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that the White House should release a modest amount of oil from government stockpiles to try to stabilize oil prices, a move that Gov. George W. Bush immediately denounced as a political ploy that could endanger national security.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell after Vice President Al Gore urged President Clinton to tap the nation's emergency oil reserves. In New York, crude oil for November delivery fell $1.24, or 3.5 percent, to $34 a barrel.

title: Environmental Tests 'Falsified,' U.S. Says
description: The federal authorities said today that thousands of environmental safety tests conducted at Superfund locations, landfills and other hazardous waste sites from 1994 to 1997 will have to be repeated because the company that performed the tests falsified the results.

title: 'Trust' Theme Turns to Taxes
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, began broadcasting two 15-second television advertisements statewide yesterday. This one, ''Taxes,'' criticizes his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, accusing her of supporting tax increases over the years. The other, ''Scores,'' paints a negative picture of her record on education as the first lady of Arkansas.

title: Attack on MI6 Snarls Central London : Missile Hits the Home Of British Intelligence
description: LONDON  A small missile smashed into the eighth floor of the headquarters of MI6, Britain's foreign intelligence service, and the London Metropolitan Police warned Thursday of a "genuine threat of terrorism" in London.

title: Mutilation Victims Aided By Swiss Surgical Team
description: A little-known operation developed by a German Army surgeon during World War I has been used to restore some grasping ability to people whose hands were chopped off with machetes in terrorist attacks during the civil war in Sierra Leone, doctors are reporting today.

title: In Testimony, Firestone Puts Onus on Ford
description: Firestone began an unusually explicit attack on the safety of Ford Explorers in testimony before a House subcommittee today as the two companies criticized each other's products and executives from both companies tried to explain internal documents that committee members found incriminating.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 'In the Eye of the Beholder'
description: Kaikodo

title: Another Drama Beneath the Sea
description: Topicality isn't what Kathryn Bigelow had in mind when she began development on ''K-19'' four years ago. The plot outline of the film, about a Russian submarine trapped at the bottom of the sea, sounds alarmingly similar to the plight of the Russian sub Kursk, which held the world breathless last month.

title: Plan to Cut Nassau Budget Puts Long Island Bus Service at Risk, Transit Group Says
description: Plans by the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, to cut aid to Long Island Bus would risk destroying a public transportation network that serves more than 100,000 riders a day, a coalition of transportation groups said today.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Fernandez Stays Tough in Face of Rough Loss
description: SHE strung together 25 strikeouts and 12 2/3 innings of raw dominance, but it wasn't until after one fatal mistake, her nightmarish defeat, that Lisa Fernandez staged her most impressive show of uncommon strength.

title: Peru's Military Backs Fujimori in His Call for New Elections
description: Peru's military leaders publicly backed President Alberto K. Fujimori early today, ending five days of silence during which there were widespread fears that the armed forces might move to oust the president.

title: Bulgarian Lifters May Quit Games
description: Bulgaria's weight-lifting team said today that it may pull out of the Sydney Olympics after traces of banned substances were found in doping tests on two more of its medalists.

title: An Inquiry Begins, But Lack of Demand Is the Frustration
description: Chris Miller, a professional ticket scalper from Chicago, says he likes to think of himself as an Olympic entrepreneur.

title: Piazza and Jones Lead Mets to Win
description: PHILADELPHIA -- Slumping Mike Piazza homered twice and Bobby J. Jones pitched seven strong innings as the New York Mets beat the Philadelphia Phillies 9-6 Friday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, SHELDON M.
description: NEUMAN-Sheldon M. Age 65. On September 21, 2000 in Miami, FL. after a brief illness. Devoted lifetime partner of Cami Green. Beloved father of Rachel & Jonah. Father-in-law of Richard. Proud grandfather of Olivia. Wonderful and caring brother of Herbert and Marvin and brother-in-law of Stephanie. We will remember him for his wisdom, strength of character and generous and loving spirit. Services on Sunday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN COTT, MARJORIE PIERSON
description: Van COTT-Marjorie Pierson. Of Bridgehampton, NY on Sept. 20, 2000 at age 90. Predeceased by her husband, Clifford Van Cott; sister Gwendolyn Griffing, and stepdaughter, Leona Allen. Survived by several step grandchildren. A memorial service at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church at a future date will be anounced. In lieu of flowers, please contact Brockett Funeral Home, Inc. at (631) 283-0822 for Mrs. Van Cott's requests.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Article 2000092290209615021 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Nothstein Finds Himself Blocked From 2nd Medal
description: It was not quite the daily double at the Meadowlands, but today's running of the Keirin cycling race was a reminder that not all Olympic sports have the heroic pedigree of the decathlon.

title: 50 Rarities, No Hollywood
description: There may well be no other project quite like it, not only in the history of home video but also in the annals of the motion picture. One eases into such a claim with a deep breath and fingers crossed, but judge by the facts.

title: MARCONI IN DEAL FOR MARIPOSA
description: Marconi P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire Mariposa Technology Inc., a maker of tools used to integrate voice, data and video signals on communications networks for $268 million. Matt Richtel

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Just Published

title: In the Spirit of the Games: In Your Face
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Congratulations are in order to us, the good old U.S. of A., master of the sporting universe. Americans are not only pulling away from our Olympic hosts, the upstart Australians, in the overall medal race here at the 2000 Summer Games.

title: POSSIBLE LAYOFFS AT TITANIC BUILDER
description: Union leaders at the struggling Belfast shipbuilder Harland & Wolff said the company planned to lay off 600 of its 1,200 employees. The company has had a nearly empty order book since early this year. Harland & Wolff, which built the Titanic and once employed 20,000 people, made no statement about the job cuts. Brian Lavery

title: Clinton Focuses on Access Of Disabled to Computers
description: President Clinton gazed at a computer screen today at a community center for the disabled and -- using only the movement of his eyeballs -- haltingly typed out a two-word message: ''Good morning.''

title: Nothing Is What It Seems. Or Is It?
description: A movie featuring Gene Hackman and Morgan Freeman promises a battle of the aging titans, two men who still have enough fight in them to square off and throw the right punches when the clinch demands it of them. ''Under Suspicion,'' an update of the 1981 French psychological thriller ''Garde a Vue'' that has been moved to Puerto Rico, pits them against each other. Mr. Freeman is Benezet, a police detective with a complicated relationship with Henry Hearst (Mr. Hackman), a lawyer accused of the murder of two young girls.

title: Romania Sweeps as Controversy Swirls
description: An inexplicable error made in the measurement of the vault apparatus during the women's Olympic all-around final tonight cast doubt on the validity of the outcome and may have cost the former world champion Svetlana Khorkina a chance to win a medal.

title: NEWELL WARNS PROFIT WILL FALL BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., the maker of Levolor blinds and Calphalon cookware, said yesterday that its second-half profit would fall below expectations because of lower sales and higher costs. Third-quarter profit from operations will be 47 cents to 49 cents a share, compared with 44 cents in the year-ago quarter, the company said. Fourth-quarter profit will be 55 cents to 58 cents a share, compared with 54 cents last year. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected the company to earn 53 cents and 62 cents in the two periods.

title: Wave of the Future?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadly Statistics: A Survey Of Crime and Punishment
description: In its analysis, The New York Times examined homicide rates in two groups of states: the 12 states without the death penalty and the 36 states that passed laws within 10 years of the Supreme Court's 1972 Furman v. Georgia decision, which overturned all existing death penalty statutes. (New York and Kansas did not adopt the death penalty until the 1990's.)

title: A Pill to Extend Life? Don't Dismiss the Notion Too Quickly
description: Offering a sharp insight into the nature of aging, biologists report today that they have shown precisely why a calorically restricted diet prolongs life span, at least in a lower organism. The finding, should it prove true of people too, would open the possibility of developing drugs to mimic the effects and gain the remarkable benefits of the draconian low-calorie diet.

title: Port Authority Seeks to Limit Peak Flights at La Guardia
description: Saying that delays have increased to an ''unacceptable level'' at La Guardia Airport, the Port Authority has told airlines that they cannot add more flights during the airport's busiest and most popular flying times, in the morning and evening.

title: Knicks Still Have Heart, but Soul of Team Is Gone
description: From Down Under to Midtown, Knicks players weighed in on the Patrick Ewing trade.

title: The Gift of Life, Even at the End
description: To the Editor:

title: Vital in Washington, Less Visible at Home
description: More than 100 voters jammed a tiny community center Tuesday evening to hear two Congressional candidates argue about who could do more for the military, the central question in Virginia's Second District, with five major bases and 200,000 veterans and their families.

title: Lightly Regarded U.S. Team Reaches Water Polo Finals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22  Six months ago the United States team just scraped into the Olympic debut of women s water polo.

title: Man Charged in Stabbing Attack Days After Release From Prison
description: A homeless man who had been released this week from Rikers Island was arrested yesterday after he asked a woman for directions on the Upper East Side, then stabbed her, knocked her on the head and took her purse, the police said.

title: Amichai, Israels Most Important and Influential Poet, Dies at 76
description: Yehuda Amichai, Israel's most important and influential poet, whose verse, written in Hebrew and translated into 22 languages, including Chinese and Japanese, made him a major figure in his own country and in world literature, died today of cancer. He was 76.

title: Snack Foods Become Stars of Books for Children
description: As the host of the ''Bring Your Own Baby'' reading group at the Enchanted Forest bookstore in Dallas, Susan Minshall meets plenty of parents anxious to start their toddlers reading -- and to make them sit still. So she recommends the newly published ''Kellogg's Froot Loops! Counting Fun Book,'' which invites toddlers to insert the sugary cereal in cut-out holes in its cardboard pages.

title: An Art Made of Quicksilver
description: Hip-hop wasn't meant to stand still, not even for a museum show. In a little more than two decades it has transformed itself from block-party entertainment in the South Bronx to an international sonic and visual language. It mutates faster than any other cultural form, going through a generation within months; it has sent tendrils into film, fashion, television and advertising while transforming the English language. Hip-hop defines a generation gap in popular culture and creates entertainingly contentious misunderstandings from all quarters. And it eludes any attempts at prediction or control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOBIN, GENEVIEVE
description: JOBIN-Genevieve, 81. At home in Mt. Vernon, September 16, 2000. Gen was a retired legal secretary who never heard a word she couldn't spell or define. Dear mother of Dennis, Judith and Kathleen. Mother-in-law of Barbara. Aunt of Sue and Joan. Grandmother of Amanda, Denise, Christopher, Deirdre and Marc. Great-grandmother of Elspeth, Lara and Alexander. Adored companion of Missy, Meggy and Billy. Donations may be made to charites that feed the hungry or no-kill animal shelters.

title: Metro Business
description: MGM Mirage Inc. and Boyd Gaming Corporation broke ground yesterday on the first new casino in Atlantic City in a decade.

title: 'Alma'
description: Directed by Ruth Leitman

title: Intel Expects Its Revenue To Be Below Expectations
description: The Intel Corporation warned today that its third-quarter revenues were likely to be below the company's previous expectations, primarily because of weaker demand for the company's microprocessing chips in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, BERNICE P.
description: GOLD-Bernice P. On September 19, 2000. A community leader in Essex County, NJ, serving on the South Orange-Maplewood Board of Education and Chairman of Essex County UJA. She also lectured for Brandeis University. Survived by daughters, Barbara Zingman and Bette Rosen, 7 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, MICHAEL J., PHD.
description: DUFFY-Michael J., PhD. Of Bronxville, NY, and Mattituck, NY, on September 21, 2000. Husband of Judith Crabtree Duffy, father of Maura, Justine and Myles. Calling hours at Fred H. Mc Grath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hrs of 7-9PM, Saturday, 1-5PM Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, September 25 at 10 AM. Interment Cutchogue, NY.

title: Five Games, Five Medals for Determined Briton
description: PENRITH, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 23  Don't shoot the old man. On the other hand, don't necessarily believe a word he says.

title: Bill Gates's Senator Confronts Upstart Internet Challenger
description: Just as Henry M. Jackson was once known as the Senator from Boeing, Washington State's Slade Gorton is delighted to call himself the Senator from Microsoft, a man whose pit-bull advocacy for the software giant in the nation's capital has earned him the corporation's gratitude and campaign contributions from William H. Gates and other company officials.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mets Receive No Favors From Phillies
description: There was an ease in the Mets clubhouse before the game here tonight, a relief from having escaped Atlanta with a victory at Turner Field on Wednesday night.

title: The Gift of Life, Even at the End
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Colleagues Have Praise For Patrick
description: ON the way over to the game, Vin Baker and Gary Payton were giving each other ostentatious high-fives. The two teammates from Seattle sat in the back of the bus and yakked it up about how the order of the National Basketball Association had just done a major flip.

title: Time Warp of Two Asias in One Place
description: THUNDER FROM THE EAST

title: In Japan Banker's Suicide, Hints of Debt Burden's Human Toll
description: The suicide of the new president of Nippon Credit Bank, which was saved from insolvency earlier this month by a group of investors led by the Softbank Corporation, has stunned Japan's banking industry. And it has underscored the human misery caused by the burden of bad debt that continues to vex the Japanese financial system.

title: With Push From Wells, Yanks' Slide Continues
description: David Wells is the relentless suitor and the Yankees are the first love who broke his heart, and when he struck out Glenallen Hill tonight to complete his 20th victory and drive the Yankees deeper into their ominous late-season slump, he lived in the moment.

title: Album of the Week
description: TOM TOM CLUB: "The Good, the Bad and the Funky" (Rykodisc). The female bass player is a fixture in countless punk and indie bands. But the stereotypical role owes its existence to real pioneers, especially Tina Weymouth of the Talking Heads and the Tom Tom Club.

title: Governors Hit the Trail For One of Their Own
description: Just in case voters needed clarification of Gov. George W. Bush's education proposals, here was Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado on Tuesday, playing host to reporters from local and national news organizations on a telephone conference call.

title: Fallon and Ogilvy Share Top Award
description: The New York offices of Fallon Worldwide and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide each took top honors at the Athena Awards ceremony last night in New York, sponsored by the Newspaper Association of America for creative advertising.

title: Article 2000092290918201677 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Jeffrey Saldinger
description: CRG Art

title: Pentagon Says North Korea Is Still a Dangerous Military Threat
description: Despite recent signs of a diplomatic warming on the Korean peninsula, a new Pentagon report has concluded that North Korea remains a dangerous military threat, pouring its limited resources into a buildup of conventional forces and the development of short- and long-range missiles.

title: ELECTION.COM TO RUN ICANN VOTING
description: The nonprofit agency charged with administering Internet domain names and technical functions said yesterday that online balloting for its board members would be handled by Election.com. More than 76,000 Internet users worldwide have registered to participate in the vote for five board members of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. The election, to be held from Oct. 1 to Oct. 10, will seat 5 of the group's 19 board members. Nine are named by advisory committees and four more will be elected by Internet users in the future. Rebecca Fairley Raney

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO REBOUNDS. The euro rose against the dollar on speculation that major central banks may buy euros to support the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 85.82 cents, up from 84.72 cents on Wednesday.

title: Flex-Time for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Queen Emerges Amid American Women Swimmers
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- As an 8-year-old, Brooke Bennett watched on television as Janet Evans won the 400-meter and 800-meter freestyle swimming events at the 1988 Seoul Olympics.

title: Cooper Tire May Become Focus of a Safety Investigation
description: Six weeks after it pressed Bridgestone/Firestone to recall 6.5 million tires, the nation's traffic safety agency said yesterday that it was considering opening an investigation of a second tire maker -- the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NISSAN MOTOR CO., Japan, said it would sell part of its equity stake in the Japanese auto parts maker Yorozu Corp. to Minneapolis-based Tower Automotive Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Nissan added that Tower would replace Nissan as Yorozu's top shareholder in acquiring a 17 percent stake.

title: Atlanta Mayor Denounces F.B.I. Inquiry
description: A simmering federal investigation into possible corruption in local government contracts became a racial issue this week when Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta denounced federal law enforcement authorities as ''forces of evil'' for looking into his private life.

title: Haworth Takes Womens Weightlifting Bronze
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- From the far reaches of the grandstand, they called out to Cheryl Haworth, screeching her nickname, "Fun."

title: Block by Block, That Paradise for Browsers Takes to the Streets
description: Activities related to literature, from readings of printed novels to panel discussions on computer-generated texts, are to be offered over the next three days during the 22nd New York Is Book Country festival.

title: White House Guests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The following is a list of guests at the White House and Camp David between July 1, 1999 and August 31, 2000, provided by the White House. The list does not include staff members, their families, and Camp David guests during the 2000 Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Article 2000092293362678296 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Read On, All You Book Lovers, Read On
description: A variety of book-related activities, including screenings, readings and panel discussions, are planned at museums, libraries and elsewhere in New York City this weekend in conjunction with the New York Is Book Country fair, which is to be held on Sunday on Fifth Avenue (www.nyisbookcountry.com). Unless otherwise noted, events are free; programs are subject to change.

title: Ozone Hole Could Be Deepest on Record, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA, Sept 22 - The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica is growing at an unprecedented rate and could reach a record depth this year, United Nations meteorologists said on Friday.

title: British Court Says Doctors Can Separate Joined Twins
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Ruling in a case that confronted the law with stark life and death choices, England's Court of Appeals said today that doctors can proceed with an operation separating joined twins that will sacrifice one in an effort to save the other.

title: British Airways and KLM End Merger Talks
description: British Airways and KLM abandoned their merger talks today after months of discussions failed to produce a workable blueprint for what would have been one of the most ambitious airline combinations.

title: BEAR STEARNS LOSES FIGHT TO PREVENT CLASS-ACTION SUIT
description: The Bear Stearns Companies and its former senior managing director, Richard Harriton, have lost a bid to stop a judge from certifying a case against them as a class action. Judge John Sprizzo of Federal District Court in New York certified as a class action yesterday a lawsuit brought on behalf of investors who bought stock in companies through the brokerage firm A. R. Baron, which is now defunct. Bear Stearns acted as A. R. Baron's clearing broker from July 1995 to June 1996, when Baron went out of business, the lawsuit states. The suit, which was filed in 1997, asserts that Mr. Harriton and A. R. Baron artificially inflated the price of 10 securities.

title: No One Won the Whitewater Case
description: After six years and nearly $60 million of taxpayer money, the Whitewater investigation, for all practical purposes, is over. To the extent that they will face no criminal charges, Bill and Hillary Clinton have been exonerated. But what, for all the anguish, time and money, have we learned?

title: Pataki Vows to Fight Any Plan to Move Yankees to West Side
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would strongly oppose a stadium for the New York Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan. Although Mr. Pataki has long been skeptical of moving the team from the Bronx to a new home on the Hudson River, his comments were his most emphatic to date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHEIM, LEONARD H., JR.
description: BERNHEIM-Leonard H., Jr. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services note with great sorrow the passing of Leonard Bernheim, Jr., a vice president of JBFCS. For more than 30 years Leonard had been a devoted trustee and leader of JBFCS and for many years a chair of its Investment Committee. Leonard's dedication to community service followed in the footsteps of his parents, Leonard and Elinor, who were leaders of the Jewish Family Service, a predecessor agency of JBFCS, and the New York community. His commitment to helping troubled adolescents, most recently as co-chair of our Youth Counseling League Divisional Committee, and his earlier chairmanship of the Westside School, has been critical to the agency's expansion and enhancement of services. His diligence as vice chair of the Budget and Finance Committee has ensured a level of fiscal responsibility and foresight that keeps the agency at the forefront of the mental health profession. His co-chairmanship of the Capital Campaign protects the agency's financial strength and sustains its ability to provide the highest quality of services. Leonard's gentle manner, strong commitment, generosity and firm belief in the agency's responsibility to serve all those who need our help was respected by board and staff alike. His legacy will continue to inspire us and he will be missed. Leonard loved his family dearly and we offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Stephanie, his daughters, Erica and Claudia, and her husband, Leo Raphaely, his brother, Charles, and his entire family. Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President

description: The police have made the first arrest in the scare over the possible tampering of bottled water in the New York region. But rather than arrest someone for tampering, officials said, they charged the suspect with falsely reporting a police incident after he tainted his own water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, CARYN, PH.D.
description: CHU-Caryn, Ph.D. The students, staff and faculty of the Pathology Department of Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourn the untimely loss of our friend and colleague, Dr. Caryn Chu. Dr. Chu's tireless and dedicated research in cell and molecular pathobiology has yielded important clues to the function of cells in heart muscle, the nervous system and in cancers. Her recent breakthroughs have opened up new areas of research which will stimulate important new findings for years to come, and will surely lead to better lives for patients with cancer, heart and neurologic diseases. A Ph.D. graduate of Mount Sinai's Graduate School of Biological Sciences, Caryn touched the lives of everyone with her cheerful, friendly and consumately unselfish ways. She will be truly missed.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIABOND TRADING ALLIANCE In a move that could make it easier for foreign investors to buy and sell Japanese bonds, the Instinet Corporation, an electronic trading network, will forge an alliance with the Japan Bond Trading Company, which runs the biggest bond trading system in Japan. The link will help Japan Bond Trading expand its reach overseas while providing Instinet, a subsidiary of the Reuters Group, with a toehold to push its way into Japan, with a looming potential for electronic trading. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

But like parrots, these mostly sympathetic people have an unfortunate way of repeating themselves. Things that only need to be said once are frequently restated two or three times, and after a while you want to shout: ''We get it! We get it!''

title: Russian Gunmen Surrender, Release "Hostages"
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Gunmen surrendered to Russian police on Friday after a day-long hostage drama in a Black Sea resort, but officials said the entire incident may have been staged. German Ugryumov, deputy head of the FSB domestic security police, told Interfax news agency that all hostage-takers and people said to be their victims walked out of the small hotel, scene of the incident, at 11:15 Moscow time (0715 GMT). First Deputy Interior Minister Vladimir Kozlov told Interfax that police suspected the captors and their victims may have been partners in crime. ``There are serious suspicions that there were never any hostages, and that this was a staged situation with phoney hostages,'' Kozlov said. Earlier, Ugryumov had said the captors had launched the incident spontaneously, ``after a boisterous night and a big drunken binge.'' Officials first voiced suspicion that at least one of the presumed hostages, a woman, was an accomplice late on Thursday. Early on Friday the woman walked out of the building and officials said she was handed over to investigators to establish her role in the incident. Since Thursday, two other people have left the building, one jumping out of the window on the first (second U.S.) floor and breaking both his legs. The gunmen, who seized their hostages on Thursday, initially demanded $30 million and the release of all Chechen prisoners held in Russian prisons. But officials have played down suggestions of a political motive, saying the request to free Chechens looked like a smoke screen. ``The terrorists have no consistent demands. Various options have been discussed involving sums of money and means of escape from the scene,'' Ugryumov said shortly before the gunmen surrendered. Kremlin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky was quoted by Interfax as saying President Vladimir Putin was pleased with the outcome. POLICE WERE READY TO STORM HOTEL Ugryumov earlier said his officers were prepared to storm the building if negotiations failed. Itar-Tass had reported that crack commando units were in place around the hotel and trucks had brought floodlights and ladders. The FSB said on Thursday that the hostage-takers had thrown a video cassette from a window of the building showing three men and one woman handcuffed to a pipe. A jerry-can, said to contain petrol, and a grenade were also shown. The hotel is around 50 km (30 miles) from the main Black Sea resort centre of Sochi, in a region lying some 450 km (300 miles) west of Chechnya, where Russian troops have waged war against pro-independence rebels for a year. The FSB earlier named three hostage-takers as Igor Savchenko, and Soslan and Aslan Khugayev. The Khugayevs were described as being from the North Caucasus town of Vladikavkaz in a region neighbouring Chechnya. The hostage-takers fired a round from an automatic rifle through the window and threw three grenades onto the lawn outside on Thursday ``to put pressure on the negotiators,'' the FSB said. It said nobody had been injured.

The store, which sells out-of-print movie soundtracks, among other goodies, has had its ups and downs, but in 1998, as Internet music distributors like CDNow and MP3.com exploded in popularity, Mr. Wilber began to worry that the Web would be his Waterloo.

title: Islander Once, Now Voyager
description: Until I was 19 years old and, by then, living in New York (which once again celebrates itself as book country this weekend), I had never read a book of serious literature written in the 20th century and I had never read a book of serious literature written by someone who was not English and by that I do not mean someone from Britain. I mean literature written by someone from that place known as England. This wasn't the fault of anyone in particular. No one made a special effort to keep me from Virginia Woolf or E. M. Forster. It is just that I spent the first 16 years of my life on an island in the Caribbean Sea that was a British colony. To us the British Empire was the entire alphabet and in it we were not more than the dot over the common letter i.

title: Teen Sentenced to 6 months for Hacking NASA, Pentagon
description: MIAMI -- A teen-ager who admitted hacking into NASA computers that support the international space station has been sentenced to six months in jail. The teen, now 16, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal charges, and also admitted he had illegally entered a Pentagon computer system, intercepted 3,300 e-mail transmissions and stolen passwords. The young man's name was withheld because of his age. The Justice Department said he was the first juvenile hacker to be incarcerated for computer crimes. The teen was known on the Internet as ``cOmrade'' and will serve his sentence in a Florida detention center. He was 15 when the crimes occurred. ``Breaking into someone else's property, whether it's a robbery or a computer intrusion, is a serious crime,'' Attorney General Janet Reno said. Meanwhile, in California a 20-year-old man was arrested and charged Thursday by federal authorities who said he also hacked into computers operated by NASA, as well as several universities, including Harvard, Stanford and Cornell. Among the computer systems Jason Diekman of Mission Viejo, Calif., allegedly hacked into were those used by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena. In August and October 1999, ``c0mrade'' entered the computer network run by the Defense Threat Reduction Agency, which monitors the threat from nuclear, biological, chemical, conventional and special weapons. In a plea bargain, the young Florida hacker admitted to entering 13 computers at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., for two days in June 1999 and downloading $1.7 million in NASA proprietary software that supports the space station's environmental systems. NASA said it cost $41,000 to check and repair the system during the three-week shutdown after the illegal entry was discovered. Chris Rouland, who monitors computer attacks for Internet Security Systems Inc. in Atlanta, said the case was unusual in that the youngster was caught -- not that he managed to break into the computers. Rouland said the case reflects growing technical sophistication among hackers: ``This is a great bellwether as to the state of security where juveniles can traipse across computer systems with little or no fear.'' Had the hacker been an adult, he could have been charged with wiretapping and computer abuse crimes. As part of his sentence, he must write letters apologizing to the secretary of defense and the administrator of NASA.

title: Drug Scandal Goes On: Bulgarian Team Is Ousted From Games
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- The entire Bulgarian weight-lifting team was expelled from the Olympics today in a drug scandal, paving the way for the United States to win its first gold medal in the sport in 40 years.

title: At the Film Festival
description: The 38th New York Film Festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, opens tonight and closes on Oct. 9. All films are shown at Alice Tully Hall with the exception of the late show tonight, the closing night film and the screenings on Sunday night of ''Body and Soul,'' at Avery Fisher Hall. Several events are planned at the Walter Reade at Lincoln Center. ''Passion and Defiance: Silent Divas of the Italian Cinema,'' a retrospective of 15 films, begins on Sunday and runs through Oct. 6. ''Views From the Avant-Garde,'' a four-part series, is to be shown on Oct. 7 and 8. Tickets are $20 to $55 for ''Body and Soul.'' Tickets to ''Silent Divas'' and ''Avant-Garde'' are $9; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees. Box office: (212) 875-5600. Many festival screenings are sold out. (Returns may be available.) Tickets: $10 to $55; available at the Tully Hall box office, (212) 875-5050. Unless otherwise noted, the films shown were made this year. Some are scheduled to be released commercially in New York; release dates are noted in this schedule.

The other part is his track record: if he's implanted radioactive seeds once, he's done it a thousand times.

But in Russia and in the West, I have been called an oligarch, someone who wielded unknown power in the Yeltsin years and who does not believe in democracy. This was an unfair portrayal, but I never felt seriously compelled to refute it until recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADOVANO, LOUIS, S.J., M.D.
description: PADOVANO-Louis, S.J., M.D. On September 20, 2000. Beloved son of the late John and Margaret Padovano. Loving brother of John Padovano, Jr. and Angela Alaimo. Dear brother-in-law of Consuelo Padovano and Joseph Anthony Alaimo. Cherished uncle of Lisa and Christopher Alaimo, John III, Margaret and Cathleen Padovano and Monica Buttagliola. Dear friend of Rev. Patrick J. Frawley. Dr. Padovano was a graduate of Georgetown University and the Georgetown University School of Medicine. He maintained a practice in OB/GYN before entering the Society of Jesus in 1964. He was ordained a priest on June 12, 1969. After ordination he completed an additional residency in psychiatry at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and maintained his practice in New York until his passing. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'' 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Thursday, September 21 and Friday, September 22, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 980 Park Ave at 84 Street, Saturday, September 23, at 11 AM. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hanover, New Jersey. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOOS, GEORGE
description: FOOS-George. Passed peacefully in San Francisco on September 18th. He was preceded by is loving wife Helen in 1994. He is survived by his sons Richard, David, and Garson, his daughters-in-law Shari, Susana, and Nicole, and his five grandchildren, Harley, Miguel, Santiago, Sydney and Zachary. He is also survived by his beloved Helga Justman. George was born on October 30, 1920 in Camden, New Jersey. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Rutgers University in 1940 and enlisted in the Army in 1941 where he served as a cryptoanalyst in the intelligence corps in the Pacific. He was instrumental in breaking enemy codes. Upon returning from the service, he began a career in retailing, working for department stores in New York, New Jersey, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, and Los Angeles. In L.A. he was Chief Executive Officer of the May Company from 1970 to 1977. In 1977 he moved to S.F. where he served as Chairman of the Board of Emporium/Capwell Department Stores until his retirement. Since retirement he has served as a consultant and was on the board of directors of Clothestime, Abercrombie and Fitch and other corporations. He was also a longstanding member of Hillcrest and Lake Merced Golf and Country Clubs. His greatest passion was his strong belief in community responsibility and giving back to the less fortunate. Throughout his life he dedicated himself to a myriad of causes. In the late sixties, he and his wife Helen founded a scholarship program for minority youths entitled HELM (Higher Education for Los Angeles Minorities). In L.A. he was also Chairman of the American Jewish Committee and a Board member of the NAACP. In San Francisco he served on the board of the Fine Arts Museum, was President of The American Jewish Committee and was a founding board member of The American Jewish World Service. In addition, he served on the Board and was Campaign Chairman of the Jewish Community Federation. Also, he was on SF's Mayor Brown's committee for welfare reform. Throughout his entire life he was a staunch supporter of liberal causes and the Democratic Party. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations be sent to the American Jewish World Service, 989 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10018 or the American Jewish Committee, 121 Stewart Street, #

title: Article 2000092291576079582 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Animal Obstacles Plague Mountain Bikers
description: SYDNEY Australia, Sept. 22 -- Mountain bikers endure hazards unlike those faced by other Olympic athletes, including thorny plants and head-over-heels collisions with boulders. But attacks from magpies?

title: Goodyear Is Unlikely to Post Any Profit for Third Quarter
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, wrestling with high raw material costs, a weak euro and lower-than-expected sales, said yesterday that it was unlikely to post any profit for the third quarter and that it might even lose money. And, assuming conditions do not change, it held out little hope for much better news for the fourth quarter. Until yesterday, analysts had predicted that Goodyear would earn 29 cents a share in the third quarter and 35 cents a share in the fourth.

title: Greene, Johnson and Jones Advance Easily
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- The men's shot-put was in its final stages on the first night of Olympic track and field competition, and as the mammoth, barrel-chested men lumbered intensely about the infield, the 110,000 fans in the Olympic Stadium were beside themselves.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about the Olympics swimming competition misidentified the relay won by the Australian men's team. As the article reported, it was the 4x200-meter relay, not the 4x50-meter race.

title: American Sailor Takes Advantage of Shifts
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Whether it's a Texas lake or Sydney Harbor in the Olympics, Paul Foerster has a knack for picking wind shifts.

title: Reckless Campaign Spending; Soft Money in New York
description: For months now, Rick Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton have insisted that they are perfectly willing to keep ''soft money'' out of the New York Senate race provided that the other makes the first move. It is time for both candidates to stop their maneuvering and reach an agreement to ban campaign fund-raising and spending practices that destroy the integrity of the electoral system.

title: BOND TRADING ALLIANCE
description: In a move that could make it easier for foreign investors to buy and sell Japanese bonds, the Instinet Corporation, an electronic trading network, will forge an alliance with the Japan Bond Trading Company, which runs the biggest bond trading system in Japan. The link will help Japan Bond Trading expand its reach overseas while providing Instinet, a subsidiary of the Reuters Group, with a toehold to push its way into Japan, with a looming potential for electronic trading. Miki Tanikawa

title: Napoleon's Style Also Took Europe
description: Napoleon Bonaparte practically invented public relations. That's the message you get in the sumptuous exhibition that the dealer Ariane Dandois has organized here, ''The Empire Style and Its Conquest of Europe: 1800-1850'' (through Oct. 30). She decorated 11 rooms in her Place Beauvau gallery with antique Empire furniture, chandeliers and porcelains from France, Italy, Spain, Sweden and Russia.

title: The Space Race for Satellite Radio Is Picking Up Speed
description: OFFICIALS of XM Satellite Radio took a step into the future last week with a small demonstration in a refurbished 100-year-old printing building in Washington. They turned on a radio and received music.

title: No Basis to Probe Gore Over Trial Lawyer Donations
description: WASHINGTON -- Attorney General Janet Reno said Friday that Justice Department investigators found no basis for investigating Vice President Al Gore's relationship to donations from trial lawyers interested in a presidential veto.

title: It's Only Sex (Sanitized), Drugs and Rock 'n' Roll
description: Almost Famous

title: TIME WARNER TO BUY GST FOR $690 MILLION
description: Time Warner Telecom said yesterday that it had received bankruptcy court approval to buy a rival, GST Telecommunications, for $690 million. The acquisition of GST, which is based in Vancouver, Wash., will allow Time Warner Telecom to expand its presence in the western United States, effectively doubling to 44 the number of markets where it provides business communications services. Time Warner Telecom said it had also received commitments from its banks for $1.2 billion of additional financing to buy GST, which operates a national Internet system that includes 4,200 miles of fiber optic lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GERTRUDE S., M.D.
description: STERN-Gertrude S., M.D. On September 21, 2000. Wife of the late Dr. Seymour H. Stern, mother of Kenneth S. Stern and Alice F. Stern, mother-in-law of Marjorie Slome, aunt of Eloise Malek, grandmother of Daniel Slome Stern and Emily Slome Stern. Contributions in her memory may be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation of America, 3550 North Central Ave., Ste 300, Phoenix, AZ 85012. Services today 1:00 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Donors to Clinton Senate Race on List of White House Guests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have had more than 400 overnight guests at the White House and Camp David since Mrs. Clinton began campaigning for the New York Senate seat in July 1999, including a substantial number of donors to Mrs. Clinton's campaign and several of her campaign's top fund-raisers.

title: Judge's Ethical Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: In another sign that Brazil's economic expansion is gaining momentum, the unemployment rate decreased in August for a fifth consecutive month. Data from the National Statistics showed the rate fell to 7.1 percent from 7.2 percent in July and 7.7 percent in August 1999, reflecting stepped-up investment by industries in anticipation of stronger demand. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLIN, HAROLD SHELDON
description: CAPLIN-Harold Sheldon (76) passed away on September 21, 2000 in Newport Beach, CA. Beloved father of Barbara Eliran, Diane Leeder, Laura Ripston and William Caplin. Loving brother of Joseph Caplin and Rusty Meshel. Loving grandfather of Asher, Shira, Akiva, Shoshana, Nicholas, Ben and Sam. Funeral services 11:15 AM Sunday, September 24, 2000 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, 212-362-6600. Interment Westchester Hill Cemetery, Hastings-on Hudson, New York on Sunday September 24, 2000. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to IWMF Waldenstrom's Foundation 2300 Bee Ridge Road #

title: 200 Hoping for a Good Job and Easier Life Are Stranded
description: Ten weeks ago Damir Arbanas hopped a plane from Croatia to New York to begin what he thought would be a better life, waiting tables aboard a cruise ship, the Big Red Boat II. He dreamed of seeing the world and racking up fat tips from wealthy Americans.

title: Icahn Sells Entire General Motors Stake a Month After Purchase
description: Just a month after notifying General Motors that he might buy as much as 15 percent of its shares, the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has sold his stake in the automaker.

title: Edward S. Gordon, 65, Is Dead; Founded Real Estate Firm
description: Edward S. Gordon, a commercial real estate broker who built one of the largest real estate service companies in the New York metropolitan region, died yesterday at his home in Water Mill, N.Y. He was 65 and lived on Long Island and in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, HANS E.
description: GRUEN-Hans E. Age 74. Retired University of Saskatchewan, Professor of Biology, died suddenly and unexpectedly on September 7, 2000 at home in Saskatoon Canada. Survived by his sister Edith and brother Peter, both of New York City.

title: 'Urban Legends' Final Cut
description: Directed by John Ottman

title: The Big City; Fascination With Models Not About Sex
description: THE Anna Sui show in Bryant Park on Wednesday evening was a dissonant experience for at least one heterosexual male. Led by Gisele, the supermodels sashayed down the runway in tight dresses, low-cut tops, bikinis, slit skirts, fishnet stockings, spiked patent-leather boots, towering stiletto heels -- your basic wardrobe for making men drool.

title: Venus Williams Extends Winning Streak
description: SYDNEY Australia -- Serena Williams led chants as Venus Williams won her match, and Chelsea Clinton applauded them both.

title: New F.C.C. Rules Could Smooth Way for Low-Power Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission, seeking to win political support for its proposal to issue licenses for hundreds of new low-power FM radio stations, has completed new regulations that permit larger stations to raise complaints about any signal interference from the start-ups, agency officials said today.

title: Universe Without Happy Endings
description: ''I'VE seen it all; there's nothing left to see.'' These words are sung, with keening defiance, by Selma, a Czech emigre working in a factory and raising her son alone somewhere in Eisenhower-era America, who is going blind from a hereditary disease. Her response to the impending loss of her sight is a joyful shrug: ''To be perfectly honest, I really don't care.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, GEORGE CRAWFORD
description: BRADLEY-George Crawford, 87. beloved father, died on September 20 in Southampton, NY. Educated at Exeter and Yale, he served in WWII aboard the USS Pollux and the USS Montpelier. He later became Executive Vice President of Evans & Co., a brokerage house in NYC. Predeceased by his wife Lucy Glazebrook, he is survived by children (George Bradley, Jr., Anne Bradley, Ciaran Mercier and Christine Wooding) & grandchildren (Martha Mercier and Beatrice Bradley), as well as several nieces and a nephew. Memorial service at 1 PM, Saturday, September 23, St. Ann's Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Donations may be made to the National MS Society, 733 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017-3288.

title: Sprinkling Stardust and a Dollop of Magic Over a Pair of Lovebirds
description: ''Perhaps 'The Fantasticks' is by nature the sort of thing that loses magic the longer it endures,'' Brooks Atkinson wrote in The New York Times more than 40 years ago. Of course Atkinson meant simply that this two-act musical trifle went on for too long to sustain its air of lighthearted romanticism. But the New York stage production of ''The Fantasticks'' has endured for something like a geologic age; next to it, even the extinct ''Cats'' occupies but a whisker's breadth on the timeline.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Finding A Purpose After a Loss
description: EVERY athlete at these Olympics has a story. Few have a story like the Olympic boxer Jermain Taylor's. A number of stories all in one: triumph and tragedy, life and loss, coming face to face with the unfairness of it all and, ultimately, claiming victory.

title: The Gift of Life, Even at the End
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DISPEKER, THEA
description: DISPEKER-Thea. A Memorial Concert celebrating Thea's extraordinary life will be held September 25, 2000, at 5:30 PM, at Mannes College of Music, 150 W. 85th St, New York, N.Y. 10024. Contributions can be made to the Thea Dispeker Memorial Voice Scholarship Fund at Mannes College.

title: With Deal Done, the Knicks Now Have to Live With It
description: One day after putting an unceremonious end to the Patrick Ewing era in New York, Scott Layden stood at a lectern in Madison Square Garden and praised the future Hall of Fame center and the team's newest star acquisition, Glen Rice. Accompanied by the Garden president Dave Checketts, Coach Jeff Van Gundy and Rice, Layden then made an unsolicited and telling comment about the Knicks' new roster.

title: A Rare Stroll In the Garden
description: When Sotheby's and Christie's are finishing their plans for the annual November evening sales of Impressionist and Modern art, it always adds an air of mystery to have an important painting the public has not seen for decades. That's the case this year for Sotheby's, which will be offering Manet's ''Woman in a Garden,'' a luscious Impressionist landscape that was last shown 47 years ago, in an exhibition in Minnesota.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special E-Commerce section on Wednesday about companies that have dropped ''.com'' from their names misstated the surname of the chief executive of J2 Global Communications, which was formerly JFax.com. He is Steve Hamerslag, not Hamberg.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury-Rental Project on East Side Is Converted to Condos
description: A Manhattan development team that has made its mark on the Upper East Side with luxury rentals is hoping for similar success with condominiums.

title: Supporters of U.S. Weightlifting Medalist Haworth Revel in Fun
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- From the far reaches of the grandstand, they called out to Cheryl Haworth, screeching her nickname: Fun.

title: 3 Missed Field Goals A Bad Sign For Giants
description: Brad Daluiso, the Giants' place-kicker, doesn't want to dwell on the three field-goal attempts the team botched on Sunday. Those misses turned what should have been an easy victory over the Bears into a last-minute stand by the defense.

title: Asian Countries Urged to Tackle Corruption Issue
description: PRAGUE  The president of the World Bank urged Asian countries, particularly South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia, to take steps to eliminate rampant corruption and cronyism, saying Thursday he was "deeply concerned" that the region's economic recovery had removed the incentive to tackle the problem.

title: Pegasus To Return At Jerome
description: The great comeback became official yesterday when Fusaichi Pegasus, winner of the Kentucky Derby and already valued at $60 million, was entered in tomorrow's Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park with high weight of 124 pounds, the inside post position and six rivals eager to knock off racing's wonder horse after a four-month absence.

title: Forests on Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Court, Citing Its Kindness, Cuts Sentences for 10 Jews
description: An appeals court in Iran today reduced the sentences of 10 Iranian Jews who had been convicted of cooperating with Israel in a trial that drew relentless international scrutiny and widespread criticism.

title: Calligraphy in Harmony With Poetry and Painting
description: In China, painting, poetry and calligraphy were the dream team of art: the ''three perfections,'' they were called. Any truly evolved person was adept at each. And discussion about any of them was framed in the same terms: rhythm, touch, tone, spiritual energy.

title: Congress Has Made Little Progress on 11 Spending Bills
description: With nine days to go before the end of the fiscal year, Congress has made little progress on approving any of the 11 spending bills it must pass to prevent the government from shutting down.

description: To the Editor:

description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that Jerry Bailey, its chief financial officer, was resigning for ''unspecified family reasons.''

title: More Antibiotics Ineffective Against Gonorrhea
description: New evidence from Hawaii and Missouri indicates that gonorrhea is becoming resistant to a wider variety of antibiotics, federal health officials said yesterday.

description: By DAVID STOUT

title: California Proposal Aims To Improve College Diversity
description: In an effort that could help reverse the impact of the state's ban on affirmative action, the president of the University of California proposed yesterday that the university guarantee provisional admission to the top 12.5 percent of students at every high school.

title: A Gold Medal in Maturity
description: As the Romanian, Russian and Chinese gymnasts waved their flowers at the crowd in Sydney this week, celebrating team victories in the Olympics, the American female gymnasts watched from the sideline. They had bobbled and wavered enough to finish fourth, dramatically short of their gold-medal showing in Atlanta four years ago.

title: 'Opening Exhibition'
description: Scholten Japanese Art

title: Plan to Tap Oil Reserve Strikes Some Experts As Temporary Answer
description: When the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was created in the 1970's, it was seen as a defense against supply disruptions that threatened national security -- not as a political tool to manage price disruptions.

title: Philharmonic Resumes With Te Kanawa
description: Rarely has the New York Philharmonic opened a season with so many loose ends dangling. The search for a new conductor is still frustrated. A deeply unsatisfactory hall awaits total overhaul. And an existing music director, Kurt Masur, lingers somewhere between his bruised relationship with a former Philharmonic management and some kind of part-time status in the future. The only encouraging certainty is Zarin Mehta, a newly installed executive director who just might make order out of chaos.

title: MICROSOFT EXPANDS IN IRELAND
description: Underscoring Ireland's growing attractiveness as a high-technology center in Europe, Microsoft said it would establish an Internet data operation in Dublin to distribute software products and to handle sales for Europe, the Middle East and Africa. The company said that the data center would purchase bandwidth from the Irish government's joint venture with the telecommunications giant Global Crossing. Brian Lavery

title: A Charity Wins Its Argument With a Trust, but Is Still Denied the Money
description: In a bitter fight between two old-line New York charities, a state appeals court yesterday ruled that a foundation that administers charitable gifts from hundreds of trust funds wrongly redirected money designated for a society that aids the poor -- but the court also said the challenge came so late that the claims were barred.

title: Putin Reins in Russia, at a Price
description: If asked to describe myself, I say, rightly, that I am a businessman who turned to politics, an entrepreneur, a communications executive. But in Russia and in the West, I have been called an oligarch, someone who wielded unknown power in the Yeltsin years and who does not believe in democracy. This was an unfair portrayal, but I never felt seriously compelled to refute it until recently.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ETA Claims Responsibility for Recent Attacks in Spain
description: MADRID, Sept. 22 -- The Basque separatist group ETA claimed responsibility on Friday for a series of recent attacks in Spain, including the killing of a politician late last month, a failed assassination attempt and five bombings. ETA, in a communique published in the radical separatist newspaper Gara, said it bombed a Basque discotheque earlier this month because it considered the nightclub a centre of drug trafficking. ETA accused police of turning a blind eye to the illegal drug trade that it said ``hurts Basque youth and goes against the process of liberating the Basque Country.'' The communique was released just a day after the killing of a town councillor in a Barcelona suburb, the latest attack blamed on the guerrillas. ETA did not immediately claim responsibility for Thursday's assassination -- it rarely does until weeks later. But with Friday's communique, ETA has now admitted to 12 of the 13 killings tied to ETA this year since it called off its 14-month-long ceasefire last December. The guerrillas have been blamed for about 800 deaths in their 32-year fight for an independent state in northern Spain and southern France.

title: Major Central Banks Step In to Shore Up the Ailing Euro
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 22  Shaken by the relentless decline of Europe's single currency, the euro, the European, American and Japanese central banks launched a surprise rescue attempt today to fight what they called a threat to the world economy by purchasing billions of euros on the global foreign exchange market.

title: A Question on Music Piracy
description: A1992 federal law, the Audio Home Recording Act, makes crystal clear that consumers may use digital audio tape players or similar audio recording gadgets to make copies of digital music for their personal, noncommercial use.

title: Thompson Settles for Bronze In Her Final Individual Event
description: Jenny Thompson was last out of the pool after tonight's 100-meter freestyle. This was her final individual event in her third Olympic Games. Soon she will retire at 27 and enter medical school at Columbia University. She checked the giant television screen and the scoreboard to see her name in third place, tied with her teammate Dara Torres in 54.43 seconds, behind another gold-medal effort by Inge de Bruijn. Thompson swam slowly toward the edge of the pool, as if she did not want to leave.

title: Reckless Campaign Spending; Mr. Corzine's Gifts in New Jersey
description: After months of dodging, Jon Corzine, New Jersey's Democratic Senate candidate, has finally made public his recent charitable contributions. It was immediately apparent why he might have preferred to avoid disclosure. It turns out that Mr. Corzine, a multimillionaire who spent a record $35 million in winning the Democratic primary, gave more than $100,000 to politically active groups whose leaders or sponsors later endorsed him.

title: Metro Business; Atlantic City Casino Has Groundbreaking
description: MGM Mirage Inc. and Boyd Gaming Corporation broke ground yesterday on the first new casino in Atlantic City in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUSZKA, JOSEPH
description: KRUSZKA-Joseph. The employees of The Bear Stearns Companies Inc. mourn the passing of their esteemed colleague and friend. He inspired all who had the good fortune to know and work with him. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Our heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends.

title: ABSENCE OF EXECUTIONS: A special report.; States With No Death Penalty Share Lower Homicide Rates
description: The dozen states that have chosen not to enact the death penalty since the Supreme Court ruled in 1976 that it was constitutionally permissible have not had higher homicide rates than states with the death penalty, government statistics and a new survey by The New York Times show.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Only a small percentage of women want body work because there are so few opportunities in Iran to see women's bodies. No seashore, no swimming pools -- except for women.''

title: Named a Market Swindler at 15; Likes Wrestling, the Mets and Penny Stocks
description: Jonathan G. Lebed was not shy about telling people that he found his suburban New Jersey hometown a singularly uninteresting place.

title: The Missing Can't Beat Marion, Michael and Maurice
description: Marion Jones no longer needs to worry about Inger Miller in the women's 100 meters, and Cathy Freeman no longer needs to worry about Marie-Jose Perec in the women's 400.

title: Krayzelburg Powers To Second Gold Medal
description: Lenny Krayzelburg's body was tightening up and the pain was gripping him. He was still leading the 200-meter backstroke, but his only goal in the last half of the race today was to fend off his American teammate, Aaron Peirsol, and Matthew Welsh of Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEBEL, ERIC
description: STIEBEL-Eric. On September 21, 2000 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Irene. Loving father of Gerald and his wife, Penelope. Adoring grandfather of Catherine Fiebach, Daniel & Hunter Stiebel. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Friday, September 22nd, 1:30PM. Interment is to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the UJA/Federation.
