description: One day last June, lawyers for the tobacco industry received an unsolicited e-mail message in their offices in New York and elsewhere around the country offering a trove of secret information in return for millions of dollars.

title: Acting Early, Deutsche Bank Picks Successor to Its Criticized Chief
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., the largest bank in Germany, appointed a Swiss investment banker today to succeed its chief executive, Rolf-Ernst Breuer, who is scheduled to retire in 2002.

description: CIRCUITS

title: Metro Business; Broadway Building Is Sold
description: SL Green Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust specializing in Manhattan office buildings, said it had agreed to buy an office building in Midtown for $50.5 million.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Hitting Showers, U.S. Team Finds Way to Win Again
description: The voodoo curse, the hex on the American softball team, had to be exorcised. So on Thursday night, after the once-dominant team's third straight loss in the Olympic tournament, Lisa Fernandez suggested a joint cleansing. In their white uniforms, the United States' players jumped in a shower in the athletes' village, stomping around, flooding the floor, in hopes of regaining the form that sustained them through a 112-game winning streak.

title: Article 2000092293998173533 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: U.S. Rider Cant Find His Way, but Can Find a Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- In front of a hushed crowd spellbound by the tension, the American David O'Connor had just guided the silky black Custom Made gracefully over a tricky fence, and appeared halfway to the gold medal stand. Until he hesitated.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Saturday described the life of textile workers in Nicaragua. It quoted Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee, an international group that is trying to organize the workers for better wages and conditions. The article was illustrated with a photograph of dozens of women walking across a field, presumably on the way to work at a Nicaraguan textile plant. The credit line attributed the picture to Mr. Kernaghan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRALEY, ROBERT
description: FRALEY-Robert. The Diller-Quaile School of Music mourns the passing of Robert Fraley, Executive Director of the School from 1972-1976. Beloved by his piano students, Mr. Fraley started many new programs at the School. He initiated the first Suzuki piano program in the City, and, with the collaboration of Brick Church, began the Summer Outreach Program for children from day care centers in Harlem and East Harlem. The School extends its warmest condolences to the family.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Morgan Stanley Misses Forecast and Its Stock Tumbles
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the nation's second-largest securities firm and a darling of the investment industry, stumbled a bit on Wall Street yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Wednesday about a concert at 7:30 tonight to raise money for breast cancer research at Weill Medical College of Cornell University in New York omitted the site for the event. It is Carnegie Hall.

description: Directed by John Leekley

title: Police Say Ex-Employee Shoots Lawyer
description: A 72-year-old retired paralegal who is suffering from multiple sclerosis and uses a wheelchair yesterday shot and wounded a 67-year-old lawyer for whom he once worked, the police said, calling the incident a dispute over money.

title: Donors to Clinton Senate Race on List of White House Guests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have had more than 400 overnight guests at the White House and Camp David since Mrs. Clinton began campaigning for the New York Senate seat in July 1999, including a substantial number of donors to Mrs. Clinton's campaign and several of her campaign's top fund-raisers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIATT, NEAL
description: GILLIATT-Neal. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc. deeply mourns the passing of Neal Gilliatt, a member of the New York Philharmonic's Board of Directors and a tireless supporter of the Orchestra since 1978. A leader in the advertising and marketing industry and President and Marketing Consultant of Neal Gilliatt/Stuart Watson, Inc., Mr. Gilliatt was an enthusiatic participant in all Philharmonic activities and served on many Philharmonic committees, including a long tenure as Chairman of the Marketing Committee. In recognition of his many efforts on behalf of the Orchestra, he was elected an Honorary Board Member in December, 1998. His devotion and generosity to the New York Philharmonic will long continue to enrich our lives. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Mary, and to his entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Executive Director

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Masur Withdraws From Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that Kurt Masur is withdrawing from two weeks of subscription concerts he was to have conducted in November and from a special concert being added in October. Mr. Masur has to undergo an unspecified minor surgical procedure, and will need time to recover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HENRY
description: WEINSTEIN-Henry. Died on September 17, 2000. Friends celebrate Henry Weinstein's distinguished contribution to the University Playhouse, the Theatre Guild, the Westport Country Playhouse, Play of the Week, The American Film Theatre, MGM and 20th CenturyFox. Above all we celebarte the unique good nature of the man.

title: Major Auction Houses Will Pay $512 Million to Settle Price-Fixing Case
description: Sotheby's and Christie's tentatively agreed today to pay $512 million to settle claims that the world's most powerful auction houses cheated buyers and sellers in a price-fixing scheme that dates back to 1992.

title: Technology Briefings
description: INTERNET ELECTION.COM TO RUN ICANN VOTING The nonprofit agency charged with administering Internet domain names and technical functions said yesterday that online balloting for its board members would be handled by Election.com . More than 76,000 Internet users worldwide have registered to participate in the vote for five board members of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. The election, to be held from Oct. 1 to Oct. 10, will seat 5 of the group's 19 board members. Nine are named by advisory committees and four more will be elected by Internet users in the future.

title: On the 7 Train, Living the Multicultural Ideal
description: The fringe on Willa Bronce's red silk shawl follows her lead as she twirls, stamps her feet and raises her arms to the flamenco rhythms of Reynaldo Rincon's guitar. ''I asked the wind if he had seen you,'' Mr. Rincon sings intensely in Spanish, ''and I asked myself if you still loved me.'' She replies with vigorous but graceful movements, and her passion fills the dining room and bar of Meson Asturias in Elmhurst, Queens. With artistry, the Romanian-Irish New Yorker dances on a stage narrower than the platform of the nearby No. 7 train.

title: AXA RESULTS DISAPPOINT
description: Shares in one of Europe's biggest insurance groups, AXA S.A. of France, fell sharply after it reported a 3.3 percent first-half rise in net income, lower than many analysts had expected. AXA, which has agreed to sell the United States investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to Credit Suisse, said that net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros, or $1 billion, but that property and casualty insurance income dropped 14 percent, largely because of weak results in Belgium and Britain. John Tagliabue

title: You Insecure, Back-Stabbing Superhero You
description: If you've ever fretted that cartoon and video game action heroes and the toys they inspire might be having more fun than the rest of us, ''The Specials'' is here to reassure you that these wondrous saviors of humanity are just as insecure, envious, spiteful, dirty minded and power hungry as everybody else. Maybe more so. No, it ain't easy being a superhero. The strain of maintaining a squeaky-clean altruistic image 24 hours a day can be deadly.

title: Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Disagree on Upstate Economy
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton turned her attention back to upstate New York today, flying here to attack Representative Rick A. Lazio for asserting that the region's beleaguered economy had ''turned a corner.'' Mrs. Clinton said that Mr. Lazio's remark demonstrated that he was ''out of touch'' with a part of New York that should be the foundation of his political base.

title: Talk of a Town Is Mrs. Clinton, And the Votes May Soon Follow
description: The Lemon Tree hair salon, clean and efficient but no frills at $12 for a wash and cut, is probably not the kind of place where the first lady of the United States would get her hair done.

title: And Baby Makes Two, For Now
description: Hollywood could learn a thing or two about how to be truthful and lighthearted at the same time from Nisha Ganatra's perky little comedy ''Chutney Popcorn.''

title: Coalition Partner of Milosevic Attacks Him Over Elections
description: The leader of the Serbian Radical Party, Vojislav Seselj, made a bitter attack today on ''the undemocratic propaganda methods'' of the political coalition of President Slobodan Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic -- a coalition Mr. Seselj has supported in both the federal and Serbian parliaments.

title: Questions on Spending
description: The New York State Democratic Committee began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement yesterday.

title: LAS VEGAS SELECTS BOMBARDIER
description: Bombardier Inc. of Montreal has won a $200 million contract to design and build an elevated monorail in Las Vegas, linking eight hotels and casinos along a four-mile section of Las Vegas Boulevard. Bombardier will be paid an additional $56 million to operate and maintain the four driverless, nine-car trains on the line for five years after service begins in 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLIS, ALBERT
description: JOLIS-Albert. September 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Mona. Devoted father of Paul, Jack, James and the late Alan. Loving brother of the late Bernard. Cherished grandfather of Jane, Annie, Oliver, Timothy, Lucy, Jacob & Jeremy. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. He was a decorated officer during WWII. Service Saturday, September 23, 2000, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: COVANCE TO SELL DRUG-PACKAGING AND BIOTECH UNITS
description: Covance Inc., a leading manager of clinical drug studies, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would probably fall below analysts' estimates and that it planned to sell its drug-packaging and biotechnology units. Covance expects third-quarter earnings of 1 cent to 3 cents a share. The company had been expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial to earn 13 cents in the quarter. The company, based in Princeton, N.J., said the weaker performance was a result of losses in its business of managing late-stage drug tests and in a unit that makes biotechnology products.

title: Free Lori Berenson
description: Lori Berenson, the American serving a life sentence in Peru for treason, has always been at the mercy of Peru's stormy politics. President Alberto Fujimori has repeatedly used her case to prove he is tough on terrorism and to paint his opponents as squishy. The current turmoil in Peru now threatens to prolong Ms. Berenson's imprisonment. Last month Peru's highest military court -- no doubt directed by a president eager to improve relations with Washington -- granted her a new trial on a lesser charge. The court acknowledged that Ms. Berenson was not a guerrilla leader, the original justification used in charging her with treason.

title: Planting New Forests Can't Match Saving Old Ones in Cutting Greenhouse Gases, Study Finds
description: A new study has cast doubts on an important element of a proposed treaty to fight global warming: the planting of new forests in an effort to sop up carbon dioxide, a heat-trapping gas.

title: It's Where the Bodies Are
description: Bodies, Bulgers and bagmen are not likely to be issues when the first presidential debate of the season is held here on Oct. 3, but they may lurk in the background.

title: Hip-Hop As a Raw Hybrid
description: You can almost hear the eyebrows knitting and the nostrils flaring. The Brooklyn Museum of Art, the object of all kinds of opportunistic and misguided moralizing during its ''Sensation'' exhibition last year, has now mounted an exhibition titled ''Hip-Hop Nation: Roots, Rhymes and Rage.'' The show, which was organized by Kevin Powell, a music critic and historian, for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, has been tweaked and expanded for Brooklyn with help from Kevin Stayton, chairman of the museum's decorative arts department.

title: Review/Fashion; Those Who Defy, and Those Who Don't
description: Orfi, the label produced by Ana Gonzalez, a designer, and Donald Hearn, an architect, is an acronym for Organization for Returning Fashion Interest to the People. It's an odd name, in part because the clothes are sold at places like Barneys New York and Louis Boston, not generally considered the premiere shopping destinations of ''the people,'' and also because regular men and women -- the vast majority who have no answer to the question, ''What's your favorite issue of Visionaire?'' -- probably wouldn't have much use for the team's particular brand of subversion.

title: Gherman Titov, 65, Second In Quest to Be First in Space
description: Gen. Gherman Stepanovich Titov, a fighter pilot who in 1961 became the second Russian to fly in space and the first man to sleep there, died on Wednesday while taking a sauna in his apartment here, officials said today.

title: Report Faults Schools' Inaction in Attacks
description: On two days in June, groups of teenage boys sexually assaulted girls in two New York City schoolyards during school hours, but the safety officers and administrators on duty failed to take action or notify the police, according to a report issued yesterday by the special investigator for the city school system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKOFF, EVA
description: WOLKOFF-Eva. Age 96, on September 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Rubin. Devoted mother of Helen Mann and the late Morris and Norma Lerner and Alfred. Cherished grandmother of Robert and Ronald Mann, Nancy Beck and Randolph Lerner. Loving great-grandmother of thirteen. Graveside services are on Friday, at 3:00 P.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: UNION PLANTERS TO ACQUIRE JEFFERSON SAVINGS BANCORP
description: The Union Planters Corporation, Tennessee's largest bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Jefferson Savings Bancorp Inc. for about $140 million in stock to increase business in the St. Louis area. Under the agreement, Jefferson Savings shareholders will receive 0.433 share of Union Planters stock for each Jefferson Savings share held, Union Planters said. That price represents a 23 percent premium for Jefferson Savings shareholders, based on Wednesday's closing prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SOPHIE
description: DAVIS-Sophie. Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel, its Board of Directors and staff of MDI, Inc., are deeply saddened by the death of a friend and supporter, Sophie Davis. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, Leonard, her sons and their families. H. Irwin Levy, Chmn of the Board Arnold Forster, President Dr. Itamar Shalit, Dir, SCMCI Shlomit Manson, Nat'l Exec Dir

title: A Test for Milosevic
description: For the first time since 1992, Slobodan Milosevic is running for direct election in Sunday's balloting for president, and even the opposition expects him to be declared the victor. He called the election early, apparently determined to cement his hold on power. And he has the support of many Serbs who accept his unceasing message that he is better than the foreign-financed opposition that would oust him.

title: Fashion Week Diary; A Debut for a Calm Place Where Tasteful Millionaires Can Buy Adult Toys
description: Down came the white-coated servers with trays of miniature skewered fruit. Down came the honeydew melon juiced into iced tumblers. Down, too, came the coffee in Safari-pattern demitasses, the Champagne in crystal flutes, tray after tray of enticements descending a spiral stair, as Hermes opened its long-awaited store at 691 Madison Avenue on Wednesday.

title: Americans Share Freestyle Gold Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 22 -- They did the same unorthodox training every day in Phoenix. They performed with the same cartoonish brashness. They both ate a diet similar to the winner of the Kentucky Derby. And tonight they stood together on the top rung of the Olympic medal podium, each draped with an identical gold medal around his neck.

title: Grosse Pointe 48236, the Melrose Place of the Midwest
description: The three young women carrying their books to class don't look as if they belong in any high school on earth, which is good. They fit perfectly in the fun house world of a soap opera, which is exactly what we are watching them film. As the camera rolls on the fictional soap ''Grosse Pointe'' -- the show within a show on the amusing WB comedy also called ''Grosse Pointe'' -- the actresses walk side by side down a corridor.

title: NASA Says It Won't Cooperate Now on Reality-Based Show
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration found itself in the odd position yesterday of having to emphasize that it would not cooperate in a proposed, prime-time reality television program in which contestants would vie for a televised trip to the International Space Station.

title: Margeotes/Fertitta In Latest Acquisition
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York said yesterday that it had acquired Bratskeir & Company in New York, a public relations agency, for undisclosed terms.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Knickerbocker's Knickknacks
description: THE Met's ''Art and the Empire City'' is what Cecil B. De Mille would have come up with if he were making an epic about ''Antiques Roadshow.''

title: INSIDE
description: Iran Cuts Jews' Jail Terms

title: Navy Selects Agency For Recruiting Effort
description: The United States Navy has named Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle advertising to support efforts to recruit and retain personnel. The Navy plans to spend $40 million to $50 million in the next year.

title: Hate Trade, Love Trade: For Fans, a Split Verdict
description: Melvin Hammonds, who lives in Long Island City and works for a janitorial service at Penn Station, propped his chin in his hand and looked across an ocean of late-afternoon commuters rushing to the Long Island Rail Road. Hammonds, a big Knicks fan, was pondering the significance of Patrick Ewing's departure.

title: Sanctions on Belgrade
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, EDWARD J.
description: RAUCH-Edward J. On September 20, 2000 of Bergenfield, NJ. Brother of Marie DuLaney, Blanche Landman, Eleanor Staub, Dorothy Schaffner, Grace Rauch-Dincin, the late Margaret Schaffner, Julia Perrine and Anna Farrar. Uncle of 13 nephews and nieces and 22 grand-nieces & nephews. Funeral liturgy at Saint John's RC Church, Bergenfield, New Jersey, on Saturday, 10:00 AM. Cremation, Laurel Grove Crematory, Totowa, N.J. Visiting Friday, 2:00-4:00 and 7:009:00 PM at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 South Washington Avenue, Bergenfield, NJ. Donations may be made to Bergenfield/ Dumont Rotary Club.

title: The Prosecutor's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: STRONG GAIN AT FRENCH BANK
description: The largest French bank by assets, Credit Agricole, reported a 12 percent increase in first-half operating income, to 3 billion euros, or $2.5 billion, buoyed by its investment banking and asset management businesses. Credit Agricole, which is owned by and serves regional French savings banks, said net income rose almost 22 percent, to 1.4 billion euros. Big, publicly traded banks in France have reported similarly strong results. Credit Agricole has said it intends to apply for a stock market listing. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNER, KENNETH
description: BROWNER-Kenneth. Of Delray Beach, Florida. Passed away on September 19th, 2000. Beloved husband of Elaine; loving father of Cliford (Eileen) & Kevin Browner; cherished grandfather of Cayla and Jessy. Services on Sunday, September 24, 2000, 1 PM at King Solomon Cemetery in Clifton, NJ. For further information call ''Gutterman's'', 1-800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINMEL, SIDNEY
description: FEINMEL-Sidney. 9/22/97. Brother and mentor. Missing your counsel more and more. Mychal

title: Sports of The Times; Disapperance Of Mysterious Champion
description: THERE are tremors in Sydney and Paris this morning, as the world prepares for the Olympics' greatest days: the track and field competition.

title: GERMAN PRODUCER PRICE INDEX RISES
description: German factories raised prices for a fifth consecutive month in August, while consumer prices climbed in five German states this month, as companies passed along higher costs of raw materials. The producer price index rose 0.3 percent from July and 3.5 percent from a year earlier, the largest annual increase since April 1989. Led by heating oil, prices in the states of Brandenburg, North-Rhine Westphalia, Saxony, Bavaria and Hesse rose 0.2 percent to 0.5 percent in the four weeks to mid-September. The IFO research institute of Germany said that business confidence in the nation, Europe's largest economy, fell for a third month in August. The German inflation rate is expected to breach the 2 percent level for the first time in almost three years in September.

title: U.S. Takes Circuitous Route To Reach Gold Medal Game
description: Six months ago, the United States team just scraped into the Olympic debut of women's water polo.

title: AMSOUTH EXPECTS PROFIT TO FALL BY 26% NEXT YEAR
description: AmSouth Bancorp warned that profit next year might be as much as 26 percent below analysts' expectations, as the bank, Alabama's third-largest, struggles to make money on loans. The Birmingham-based bank said in a statement that it would try to stem earnings declines by selling $5 billion of low-yielding auto loans and securities and take a third-quarter pretax charge of $280 million. The asset sales will lower the bank's profit over the next year and a half. The company warned that operating earnings in 2001 would now be in the range of $1.45 to $1.55 a share.

title: Washington Post to Get New Publisher
description: Donald E. Graham announced yesterday that he was stepping down after 21 years as publisher of The Washington Post to concentrate on steering its parent company, of which he is chairman and chief executive, as it continues to expand its new-media ventures.

title: Diamond Nine, a Best Friend To Zia, a Resourceful Expert
description: Those who say that ''there is nothing new under the sun'' are clearly wrong, in both the microcosm of the bridge world and the wider world. In the diagramed deal, consider the North-South diamonds, which declarer is aiming to establish in a four-spade contract.

title: Few Believe the Knicks Are Finished Dealing
description: Scott Layden is viewed throughout the National Basketball Association as an honest and straightforward general manager who rarely, if ever, misleads. Even so, few executives around the league believed him Thursday when he said that the Knicks would not make another trade before the start of training camp on Oct. 3.

title: U.S. Envoy to Israel Relieved of Post Over Security Issues
description: Martin S. Indyk, the American ambassador to Israel and an architect of American policy in the Middle East, has been temporarily relieved of his post and has had his security clearance lifted, pending an investigation into whether he mishandled classified materials, State Department officials said today.

title: Yankees Snap Losing Streak
description: NEW YORK -- David Justice homered twice to overcome a poor start by Roger Clemens and Derek Jeter hit a three-run homer Saturday to rally the Yankees to a 13-8 victory over the Detroit Tigers, snapping New York's season-high, six-game losing streak.

title: Come to Bryant Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Williamses Reach Tennis Quarterfinals
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Venus and Serena Williams overcame a slow start Saturday to reach the quarterfinals in doubles at the Olympics, beating Elena Likhovtseva and Anastasia Myskina of Russia 4-6, 6-2, 6-3.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 11 about rules of decorum established by the City Commission of Coral Gables, Fla., for its meetings included an erroneous account from a resident about a warning given her by Mayor Raul Valdes-Fauli. The mayor warned that the resident, Roxcy Bolton, who spoke passionately at a meeting, would be removed if she offended commission members or cast aspersions on their honesty. He did not say he would have her arrested.

title: MERIDIAN INSURANCE REJECTS BID FROM AMERICAN UNION
description: The property and casualty insurer Meridian Insurance Group said yesterday that it had rejected a sweetened unsolicited $195 million bid from the closely held American Union Insurance Company. American Union, based in Bloomington, Ill., raised its offer to $25 a share from $20 a share, or $158 million, last Monday in the latest move in a takeover effort that began in April. Meridian, based in Indianapolis, said shareholders of the Meridian Mutual Insurance Company and the Meridian board, who together own more than half of Meridian's approximately 7.8 million shares outstanding, would not tender their shares to the latest bid. Based on Thursday's closing share price of $16.13, down 69 cents, or 4.1 percent, the offer represented a 35 percent premium to Meridian shareholders.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Lobbies Yugoslavs

title: Neighbors' Gentler View Of Man Killed on Plane
description: In his upscale neighborhood of ranch-style houses in Las Vegas, Jonathan Burton was known as a model citizen. He helped young children learn to ride bicycles and play video games. He carried groceries for elderly people. ''I wish he was my son,'' said Mary Mahoney, who lives next door to the Burton family.

title: A Laptop in the Backpack of Every Child?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Hoping to Keep A Division Rival Down
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel has not denied the importance of Sunday's game with the Redskins, calling it his team's biggest game of the first half of the season. It may also be the most anticipated game the Giants have played since Fassel's first year as coach in 1997.

title: Approval for RU-486
description: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to announce a decision next week on the fate of RU-486, the abortion pill that can offer women a safe, non-invasive alternative to surgical abortion. The agency faces a Sept. 30 deadline on whether to give final marketing approval for the drug, call for a delay of action or deny approval.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the Indian fondness for chewing a substance called paan misstated the location of the Jama mosque, where a vendor was selling it. The mosque is in Old Delhi, not New Delhi. The picture also carried an incorrect credit; it was from Drison Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHOLZ, EV
description: TEICHOLZ-Ev. On September 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bruce. Loving mother of Debbie and Tom. Adoring and cherished grandmother of Yasmine, Shira and Natasha. Loved and beloved, she will stay in our hearts forever. Service Sun., 11:30 AM.at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterda

title: Bans in Brawl Are Reduced
description: TORONTO, Sept. 22  Major League Baseball has reduced the suspensions of three Tampa Bay players who were involved in a brawl with Pedro Martinez and the Boston Red Sox on Aug. 29.

title: With Godsey at Quarterback, Notre Dame Mystery Is Solved
description: The first act of ''The Gary Godsey Story'' was promising: the credits rolled 13 days ago at O'Neill Hall on the Notre Dame campus. Godsey, the 6-foot-7-inch tight end turned quarterback, is sleeping. In walks quarterback Arnaz Battle, who nearly led the Fighting Irish to an upset of Nebraska, the top-ranked team in the country, the day before. Battle has six teammates with him, as well as a broken left wrist.

title: A Small Plea For Sanity In a Campaign
description: THE New York Senate candidates are bopping each other over an issue that has no doubt cost you many a sleepless night: a ban on soft-money donations to their campaigns. They talk about taking the pledge to stay far from that demon cash.

title: Nassau Police Contracts May Cost $200 Million
description: Proposed labor contracts that Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has negotiated with three county law enforcement unions would cost the county up to $200 million over the next five years, the comptroller said today.

title: Fugard's Wrenching Tale Of Lost Hope and Youth
description: A stage direction in Athol Fugard's play ''Boesman and Lena'' says of its main characters, a mixed-race (or ''colored'') couple making their way across the cruel landscape of apartheid-era South Africa, that ''a life of hardship and dissipation obscures their ages, but they are most probably in their 50's.'' In John Berry's film adaptation of the play, which will be shown tonight and tomorrow in the New York Film Festival, Boesman and Lena are played by Danny Glover and Angela Bassett, two actors so charismatic that it is shocking to see them so bruised and ragged.

title: Monarchs Sent Off to Mariachi Beat
description: The dozens of black-and-orange butterflies being held captive at Monarch Watch 2000 in Central Park fluttered wildly against the net walls of their cage yesterday afternoon when a six-piece mariachi band behind them began blaring the Mexican Hat Dance.

title: Prague Journal; Protesters Assemble, Hoping for a Rerun of Seattle's Show
description: Woodstock was once the Valhalla for aspiring hippies everywhere -- a name that invoked the ideals of a generation of make-love-not-war activists. For today's dreadlocked wannabes, there cannot be much doubt that the word is Seattle.

title: The Right Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: J. C. Penney Names Chief of Drugstore Unit
description: The J. C. Penney Company said today that it had named J. Wayne Harris, a longtime executive of the supermarket industry, to be the chairman and chief executive of its Eckerd drugstore chain, which is struggling to cut costs and increase the sales of high-profit products.

title: U.S. Agency Says Allstate Illegally Coerced Agents
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission determined this week that when the Allstate Insurance Company forced more than 6,000 agents to sign away their rights to sue the company in order to keep their jobs, it violated federal law.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about reassignments at the Vatican misspelled the given name of one co- author of an article in the Jesuit magazine America that suggested that the Vatican was growing more tolerant about the use of condoms to combat the spread of AIDS, and misspelled the surname of the other. The authors are the Rev. Jon D. Fuller (not John) and the Rev. James F. Keenan (not Keegan).

title: Live Blues Speak for a Hoary Silent
description: Wycliffe Gordon's original score for Oscar Micheaux's ''Body and Soul'' -- as it was performed in a slightly abridged version in a preview performance earlier this week -- is a first long work and a first film score for Mr. Gordon, the brilliant trombonist of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra. It sounds like it. Though the band played the piece beautifully, the writing was functional, with some inventive touches that lay within the compositional style of the orchestra's leader, Wynton Marsalis.

title: Chief Operating Officer at Sears Resigns
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that its chief operating officer, Julian Day, would resign after Alan Lacy, who will become chief executive on Oct. 1, decided to eliminate the ''office of the chief executive.'' The two men shared the advisory post with Arthur Martinez, the chairman, who is retiring.

title: Atlanta Forgotten, Greene and Jones Win Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  Four years ago, the Atlanta Games played on with them in the audience, not on the track. Marion Jones was recovering from a broken foot, Maurice Greene from a bruised ego, having failed to qualify for the 100 meters at the United States track and field trials. Sitting in tears as Donovan Bailey of Canada won the gold medal, Greene told himself, "This will never happen again without me."

title: The Many Lessons of Whitewater
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT TO ADD TITLE OF CHAIRWOMAN
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that Carly Fiorina, the president and chief executive, would add the title of chairwoman, and that the company, the world's No. 2 computer maker, would buy back as much as $1 billion of its shares. The stock rose $5, to $104.25. Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it was confident that it would meet its 15 percent revenue growth target and the average analyst earnings estimate of $1.03 a share for the current quarter. The company said it would continue a share repurchase program and buy back as much as $1 billion worth of stock to offset the dilution of its share price associated with employee stock plans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the second trial of Oliver Jovanovic, a Columbia University graduate student, on charges that he attacked a woman he met on the Internet in 1996, misstated one conviction that was overturned. At his first trial, Mr. Jovanovic was convicted of having kidnapped, sexually abused and assaulted the woman. He was not convicted of rape.

title: Reno Orders Internal Inquiry Into Handling of Secrets Case
description: Attorney General Janet Reno told President Clinton today that she has ordered an internal review of prosecutors' handling of the case of Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos nuclear scientist who was released from jail this month after the federal government's case against him largely collapsed, officials said.

title: Night Belongs to Greene; Future Belongs to Jones
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  Off the track and into his new and long-awaited life as an Olympic gold medalist, Maurice Greene made the rounds, hammed it up with the men who had finished in his dust and then happened to glance at the television, mounted high on the back stage wall. There, was a scene that is likely to be repeated several times over the following week. There, was a face that Madison Avenue will undoubtedly soon come to love.

title: S.E.C. Files Fraud Complaint Against a Financier
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had filed a fraud complaint against Martin R. Frankel, the financier who is already facing federal criminal charges in a huge insurance scandal.

title: Article 2000092391512128114 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Sleepovers and Soft Money
description: Just when Hillary Rodham Clinton has been making headway among voters in New York, her campaign for Senate has hit a familiar political problem. Yesterday the White House released a list of more guests who have stayed overnight there or at Camp David since July. About a quarter of them have contributed to Mrs. Clinton's campaign. At the same time, the first lady's proposal to Representative Rick Lazio that both candidates forgo all broadcast ads paid for with unregulated soft money was rejected by Mr. Lazio on the grounds that it was one-sided. The collection of soft money, of course, is at the center of the reckless fund-raising system that has led to excesses like the White House sleepovers.

title: Germany Denies U.S. Fencing Medals
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- It was a tough way for the U.S. women's fencers to again be denied a medal.

title: CLINTON APPROVES RELEASING SOME OIL FROM U.S. RESERVE
description: President Clinton ordered the release today of 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's emergency reserve over the next month, only a day after Vice President Al Gore injected the issue into the presidential campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 9 about a lawsuit filed by Anne Steinberg against her son, the financier Saul Steinberg of Reliance Group Holdings, gave a misspelled name in some copies for the company he founded early in his career. It was Leasco, not Leaseco.

title: DEBIS AIRFINANCE BUYS AERFI
description: The aircraft leasing company Debis AirFinance, a unit of DaimlerChrysler based in Amsterdam, agreed to acquire the privately owned AerFi Group of Ireland for $750 million in cash. The move would give the merged company, to be called AirFinance, 46 new clients. The deal, in which $3.90 would be paid for each share of AerFi, is subject to approval by AerFi shareholders.

title: F.A.A. Says Delays Have Grown at La Guardia
description: The Federal Aviation Administration reported yesterday that delays at La Guardia Airport had grown so sharply that they contributed to a 60 percent national increase in August in the type of delays caused when too many planes were scheduled to take off at the same time.

title: U.S. Rallying Cry Isnt Enough to Beat Cuba
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  Manager Tommy Lasorda insists he was not playing politics when he said he wanted his United States baseball team to win its preliminary game tonight against Cuba for Cuban exiles in Miami. He was not rattling sabers, he said; he was making a baseball pledge to friends.

title: Juarez Set to Meet Defending Olympic Champ
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Rocky Juarez helped set up an Olympic quarterfinals match between featherweight champions with a narrow victory in a second-round bout Saturday night.

title: LATE-NIGHT POLITICS
description: Al Gore and George W. Bush may both be lampooned by the likes of Leno and Letterman, but the satire isn't impartial. And now a political joke can reverberate all the way to the voting booth. A report by Marshall Sella in The Times Magazine.

title: Florida Challenge By Gore Campaign Upsets Bush Camp
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23  As Gov. George W. Bush today devoted a second day to stumping a state he never expected to be fiercely competitive, many of his supporters say his campaign neglected to see signs of Vice President Al Gore's potential to win Florida and did not move quickly to thwart him from gaining ground.

title: From British Cousins, an R-Rated Ballet
description: It's not often that publicity announcements warn that a ballet is not family entertainment. Yet some of those heralding David Bintley's ''Edward II'' did note that this production ''presents graphic sexual images and is not appropriate for children.''

title: At News Conference, Gore Defends Use of Oil Stockpile
description: VANPORT, Pa., Sept. 22  Vice President Al Gore held his first news conference in 67 days today, defending his call for the release of oil from the government's stockpiles and vowing that he would "confront friend and foe alike" over the marketing of violent entertainment to children, despite the millions in donations he receives from Hollywood.

title: Last-Second Shot Wins Water Polo Gold for Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Maureen O'Toole's dreams of Olympic gold will have to pass into history.

title: AIR CANADA WILL TRIM 2,000 JOBS
description: The Air Canada Corporation will eliminate about 2,000 jobs once it completes its acquisition of Canadian Airlines International Ltd., The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported, citing Robert Peterson, the chief financial officer of Air Canada. Mr. Peterson said the airline had set aside 90 million Canadian dollars, or $60.4 million, for separation packages. There will be no involuntary layoffs, the paper said. Since it began the acquisition, Air Canada has hired about 2,000 full-time flight attendants, mechanics and service agents to deal with public complaints about poor customer service and long lines. Mr. Peterson said he expected to reduce the staff to the level before the merger once the two airlines are fully combined, the paper said.

title: Finns Win Gold in 49er Class
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- A couple of fast Finns on a fast skiff took the 49er gold medal that brothers Jonathan and Charlie McKee of Seattle hoped would be theirs.

title: President of Princeton To Step Down Next Year
description: With the completion of a $1.1 billion fund-raising campaign and a plan to expand undergraduate enrollment by 10 percent, Dr. Harold T. Shapiro, the president of Princeton University for 13 years, said yesterday that he would step down next summer.

title: Controversy Over Judging, and a Surprise U.S. Loss
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  In the Olympics, there is the quaint notion that the fight game can be domesticated  headgear is worn, fights are short and savage knockouts are few  but it is still boxing. And that means that sooner or later there will be a judging controversy and intrigue over scoring decisions.

title: Worlds Fastest Woman Still Has More Work to Do
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  By 8:25 tonight, you could virtually hear the moths breathing at Olympic Stadium.

title: The New Prophet Of a Techno Faith Rich in Profits
description: It is best to begin with a confession. I am a Gilderite. Each month, along with some 65,000 stock traders, technophiles, computer scientists and optical engineers, I await the arrival of an eight-page newsletter in which George Gilder -- a former speechwriter for Ronald Reagan, a former Male Chauvinist of the Year (as proclaimed by NOW) and currently a widely applauded (and occasionally derided) ''technological guru'' -- celebrates the dawn of a new age. As Mr. Gilder proclaimed in one recent issue, ''Weirder and weirder becomes the world.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about reassignments at the Vatican misspelled the given name of one co-author of an article in the Jesuit magazine America that suggested that the Vatican was growing more tolerant about the use of condoms to combat the spread of AIDS, and misspelled the surname of the other. The authors are the Rev. Jon D. Fuller (not John) and the Rev. James F. Keenan (not Keegan).

title: City Short of Police Recruits as Job Loses Luster
description: In a striking illustration of the eroding interest in police careers, New York City has fallen far short of finding enough recruits to fill its next Police Academy class, which is scheduled to begin training in just a few days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, HANS E.
description: GRUEN-Hans E. Age 74. Retired University of Saskatchewan, Professor of Biology, died suddenly and unexpectedly on September 7, 2000 at home in Saskatoon Canada. Survived by his sister Edith and brother Peter, both of New York City.

title: Art Auction Houses Agree to Pay $512 Million in Price-Fixing Case
description: The world's largest auction houses, Sotheby's and Christie's, agreed yesterday to pay $512 million to settle claims that they cheated buyers and sellers in a price-fixing scheme dating back to 1992.

title: 40 States Forfeit Health Care Funds for Poor Children
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Forty states will soon lose hundreds of millions of dollars of federal money that was supposed to provide health insurance to children in low-income families, federal and state officials say.

description: They are stories of the heart, unscripted Olympic moments of poignancy, tenderness and sportsmanship that live for the ages.

title: Democrats Lash Back at Cheney on Oil
description: As the Republicans renewed their attacks on Vice President Al Gore over his plan to tap the nation's oil reserves, Mr. Gore's aides fought petroleum with petroleum today. They released news accounts from last year that they said showed Dick Cheney, who was then the chief executive of an energy-services company, praising the global oil cartel for driving up worldwide oil prices.

title: Fears Deepen Milosevic Will Rig Vote
description: With Yugoslavs preparing to vote on Sunday, final opinion polls show that President Slobodan Milosevic continues to trail his main challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, but by a margin that the opposition worries may be overcome by fraud.

title: Reverend's Wrongs Unrighted
description: Late in Oscar Micheaux's 1925 silent film classic ''Body and Soul,'' there is a scene in which Paul Robeson, playing an escaped convict posing as the minister of a Southern black church, rouses his adoring congregation with a sermon that sparks tumultuous jubilance. Gesticulating wildly while sneaking swigs from a flask under the pulpit, this cunning clerical impostor who goes by the name the Rt. Rev. Isaiah Jenkins becomes so carried away with his own charisma that he accidentally knocks one of the deacons to the floor.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

description: Nicolas Ghesquiere did a Peter Pan yesterday after his season-defining Callaghan show, flying from the kisses of editors before they could tell him what is already old news. That he is changing fashion.

description: Vice President Al Gore held his first news conference in 67 days today, defending his call for the release of oil from the government's stockpiles and vowing that he would ''confront friend and foe alike'' over the marketing of violent entertainment to children, despite the millions in donations he receives from Hollywood.

description: Clinton Orders Oil Released From Emergency Reserve

title: U.S. and Allies Meet to Debate Global Economic Goals
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 23  The top United States financial officials, fresh from parallel plunges into world oil and currency markets, sought to rally allies in the Group of 7 industrialized nations today to fight what they labeled twin threats to the record- breaking American economic expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSKY, ALBERT
description: LEVINSKY-Albert. We mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our friend and client of more than forty years, and send our condolences to his bereaved family. Allen and Gail Weiss

title: Vallone Seeks Park Records On Donations
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone charged yesterday that the Parks Department's requests for donations from nonprofit groups that use the city's parks are heavyhanded and possibly illegal. He also threatened to subpoena financial records of the department to determine how much had been raised through such donations and how the money had been spent.

title: Slovenian Wins Shooting Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia (AP) -- Slovenia's top gun shot his way to a gold and two records.

title: Talks Collapse for Soft-Money Ban in Clinton-Lazio Race
description: Negotiations over an agreement to ban soft money in the New York Senate race collapsed yesterday after Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a plan that was initially embraced by Representative Rick A. Lazio -- until he learned that it contained more restrictions on him than on her.

title: NIPPON TELEGRAPH TO CUT 6,500 JOBS
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's third-largest private employer, plans to cut up to 6,500 jobs using early retirement incentives, extending plans to trim staff through attrition as competition stiffens. N.T.T. wants to shed the jobs at its regional units over two years, the company said, confirming a report in the newspaper Nihon Keizai. The plan is aimed at saving 60 billion yen, or $560 million, at the two units, which had a combined work force of 120,000 employees as of March 31. It would be N.T.T.'s second early retirement offer since 1993.

title: Bringing People Down to Earth With Just a Laugh
description: Winning a Nobel Prize in Literature can be an albatross, making it more difficult for a writer to create work after he has been anointed by the Swedish Academy. Not so with Dario Fo, whose Nobel in 1997 -- the first, as the playwright and comic actor says, for a buffoon -- has increased his productivity and improved his standing as an artist.

title: The Wounded Euro
description: Yesterday's surprising decision by the United States to join with Japan and Europe in propping up the euro will not heal the ailing new currency, but it was a gesture worth making.

title: Gridlock at La Guardia
description: New York City's airports are already strained beyond their limits and crying out for more flights to enhance competition. That is the conundrum now facing regional and federal transportation authorities.

title: Central Banks Move to Rescue An Ailing Euro
description: Shaken by the relentless decline of Europe's unified currency, the euro, the European, American and Japanese central banks undertook a surprise rescue attempt today to fight what they called a threat to the world economy.

description: Remarks yesterday to members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers in Vanport, Pa.:

title: House Arrest Said to Fail in Murder Case
description: Gerald A. Jones was an 18-year-old with a robbery conviction. He stuck a gun in a woman's face and stole her watch. That was last summer. This summer, he was released from jail under a special program that gives young first offenders a second chance. He was placed under the most stringent form of probation, house arrest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Anne E. Pediatrician and philanthropist, died Thursday, September 21, 2000, at the age of 52 after a year long battle with breast cancer. Since 1979, Anne E. Dyson had served as the President and Director of the Dyson Foundation, a family philanthropy founded in 1957 by her late parents, Margaret and Charles Dyson. Under her leadership, the Dyson Foundation has extensively funded many programs in the Mid-Hudson Valley of New York State, and has focused on improving the life opportunities and health of young children across the country. Dr. Dyson was a board-certified pediatrician, and held academic appointments at Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University, where she was a Clinical Assistant Professor of Pediatrics and at the University of Illinois College of Medicine. Dr. Dyson was a Director of the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, an international multi-industry holding company headquartered in New York City that was founded by her father in 1954. She served as the Chair of the Board of Directors of the Hole in the Wall Gang Fund, Inc., a camp for children with life-threatening illnesses. She was a Vice Chair of the Board of Overseers of the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University and was the Co-Chair of the Partnership for Children of the American Academy of Pediatrics. She was a member of the Board of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, and served as a member of the Board of Health of Dutchess County, New York. Dr. Dyson was educated at New York University and received her M.D. degree from New York Medical College in 1977. Her post-doctoral training included an internship at St. Christopher's Hospital in Philadelphia, residency training at Cornell Medical CenterNew York Hospital, a research fellowship at Rockefeller University and an infectious disease fellowship at Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, NY. She was a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Dr. Dyson is survived by her husband Michael S. Kramer, journalist and political commentator her sons Roberto Hull and Mac Hull, her stepson Ben Kramer, three brothers, Robert R. Dyson and his wife Emilie, John S. Dyson and his wife Kathe, and Peter L. Dyson and his wife Barbara, and their families, which include her nieces and nephews Leigh, Eliza, Christopher, Molly, Karen, Lisa, Brian and John. Dr. Dyson and her family lived in Millbrook, NY. Services and burial will be held at Grace Church, Franklin Avenue in Millbrook, New York on Tuesday, September 26, 2000 at 11:00 a.m. A memorial service will also be held in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp in New Haven, Connecticut or the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Yehuda Amichai, Poet Who Turned Israel's Experience Into Verse, Dies at 76
description: Yehuda Amichai, the Israeli poet who distilled his experience -- and his nation's -- into highly metaphorical verse written in Hebrew and translated into more than 25 languages, died yesterday in Jerusalem. He was 76.

title: The Sideshow Is Over; Let the Feature Begin
description: Jets Coach Al Groh looked relieved when he walked into a nearly deserted news media room today, after encountering a packed house all week overflowing with reporters who peppered him with questions about Keyshawn Johnson. Groh spoke to the team early in the week about trying to avoid becoming entangled in the Johnson sideshow; the players were told to be careful what they said about Johnson. Still, Groh said he did not dread weeks like this.

title: Sports of The Times; In the Spirit Of the Games: In Your Face
description: CONGRATULATIONS are in order to us, the good old U.S. of A., master of the sporting universe. Americans are not only pulling away from our Olympic hosts, the upstart Australians, in the overall medal race here at the 2000 Summer Games.

title: A Bishop Works to Bridge Faiths in the Cause of Peace
description: CONVERSION is an individual experience, but those who have undergone it share in a basic story of how something unexpected worked a great change in their lives, either on the spot or over time.

title: Sprint Ends Suit Over Limits On Car Phones
description: A month after officials in Marlboro Township, N.J., approved the state's first ban on the use of handheld cellular phones while driving, Sprint PCS sued to challenge the ban -- and then withdrew the suit yesterday.

title: British Court Orders Surgery That Will Kill One Siamese Twin
description: Ruling in a case that confronted the law with stark life-and-death choices, the Court of Appeal said today that doctors can proceed with an operation to separate joined twins that would sacrifice one in an effort to save the other.

title: Nordstrom Chicago Debut
description: Nordstrom Inc. opened its first department store in Chicago today, competing with rivals along the city's Magnificent Mile while seeking to draw younger customers and improve stagnant earnings. The four-story, 271,000-square-foot store on Michigan Avenue is the biggest Nordstrom in the Midwest and one of the biggest in the United States, Blake Nordstrom, the retailer's new president, said at a ceremony. The largest Nordstrom store is in Seattle, where the chain is based.

title: No Wings, No Worry, 'Cause She Sings a Lot in a Hurry
description: ''Beauty's truth; truth is beauty./ Gabriel, blow your rooty-tooty!''

title: New Judge for Defendant Tied to Threat
description: A stock-fraud defendant charged with plotting to kill the judge assigned to his fraud case will be tried before another judge.

title: Five Games, Five Medals For a Determined Briton
description: Don't shoot the old man. On the other hand, don't necessarily believe a word he says.

title: Critical Words Sting the I.O.C. A British Author Revels In Uncovering Scandals
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Well before the International Olympic Committee became easy to mock for its excesses and before the investigation of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal uncovered internal corruption, Andrew Jennings symbolized a one-man, cheeky and obsessive opposition. Other reporters were critical, but through three freewheeling books written during the past decade, Jennings, a shaggy, gray-haired British journalist in the sleeveless photographer's vest, has made sport of detailing malfeasance within the I.O.C. His reporting led to a lawsuit against him by the I.O.C. in 1994 and a conviction by a court in Lausanne, Switzerland, for his "distasteful" portrait of his constant target.

title: ISRAEL IS STUDYING NEGOTIATING IDEAS ONCE UNTHINKABLE
description: It would have been unthinkable just several years ago for Israel to contemplate entrusting anything to the United Nations, much less control of the most holy site in Judaism.

title: If It's Goodbye Books, Then Hello . . . What?
description: Has reading become old-fashioned? Are computers dragging literacy down? Are Americans going to cultural hell in a technological handbasket? Ruminations on these and related questions appeared in the summer 2000 issue of Dissent magazine in an article titled ''Goodbye to All That?: Elegies for the Book.'' The author is Steven J. Zipperstein, the David E. Koshland Professor in Jewish Culture and History at Stanford University. Excerpts follow.

description: When the central banks of the world's leading industrial nations intervene in the currency market, there are winners and losers.

description: ''If we don't make this class, and we have no one signing up to take the tests, we will eventually reach a point where we will have no one to make up the shortages, and the department will have to shrink.''

title: Sports of The Times; In Sports, Dysfunction Has Its Uses
description: IT was not long after his autobiography had been published that Keyshawn Johnson, the author, had one of his first run-ins with Wayne Chrebet, the target. The incident happened outside a dormitory, where Jets players were staying at training camp. Chrebet, according to a number of Jets players, was so angry at Johnson's calling him the ''team mascot'' in his book that he wanted to physically confront his teammate.

Schools like Minnesota, Northwestern, Michigan and Rutgers, and Ivy League programs like Cornell and Columbia were all in pursuit of Bennett, then a senior.

title: Online Grocer To Postpone An Expansion
description: The online grocer that was scheduled to open two large warehouses in the South Bronx and Bergen County, N.J., bringing more than 1,900 jobs to the region, said yesterday that it would delay its most immediate expansion plans, including the New Jersey warehouse.

title: CENDANT EXPECTS EARNINGS TO BE IN LINE WITH ESTIMATES
description: The Cendant Corporation, the owner of the Days Inn hotel chain and Century 21 real estate brokers, said it expected third-quarter earnings to be in line with analysts' estimates. The stock has dropped 23 percent this quarter. The company, based in New York, is expected to earn 29 cents a share before extraordinary items and results for its Move.com Internet business, according to a survey of analysts. The results will be released Oct. 18, Cendant said in a statement. Cendant shares fell 25 cents, to $10.75.

title: Student Dies And Levy Faults School Medical Dept.
description: A 16-year-old student at Samuel Gompers High School in the Bronx whose medical condition was apparently ignored by school nurses died yesterday morning after collapsing while climbing stairs, Board of Education officials said.

title: Europe Reviewing Revisions On AOL-Time Warner Deal
description: Time Warner and America Online have proposed remedies to allay concerns of European antitrust regulators about their proposed $165 billion merger. But the remedies have failed to sway opponents of the deal in the music and Internet industries and among consumer organizations, making it unlikely the regulators will accept them without substantive change.

description: Following is the text of the statement of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt as it announced the joint action with other central banks yesterday:

title: Abroad at Home; Correcting A Mistake
description: Hardly anyone noticed, but the House of Representatives did something rare and admirable the other day. It voted to correct a legislative mistake that has had cruel consequences for thousands of legally admitted aliens: the retroactive deportation feature of the 1996 Immigration Act.

title: Costco Sees Higher Sales
description: The Costco Wholesale Corporation expects same-store sales to rise 7 percent to 8 percent in fiscal 2001, said Richard Galanti, the chief financial officer. Adding new operations like gas stations, pharmacies and optical departments will help bolster sales for the company, Mr. Galanti said. Costco's estimate is more optimistic than forecasts for the nation's retail industry. Shares in Costco, which is based in Issaquah, Wash., fell 44 cents to $34.94.

description: Retrieved e-mail messages turned over to investigators show that in early 1996, Vice President Al Gore's senior aides routinely characterized White House coffee sessions as fund-raisers, a description seemingly at odds with Mr. Gore's accounts.

description: For 35 mostly successful seasons, the mountains of Central Pennsylvania seemed to surround and protect Joe Paterno's football program like so many big blockers forming a pass pocket. But this year, Paterno's team may be standing on a precipice.

description: In front of a hushed crowd spellbound by the tension, the American David O'Connor had just guided the silky black Custom Made gracefully over a tricky fence, and appeared halfway to the gold medal stand. Until he hesitated.

But despite recent signs of decline -- in 1990, the National Jewish Population Survey found a 52 percent intermarriage rate, shocking much of the Jewish world -- the rumors of its death have been greatly exaggerated.

title: French Flight Tests Ban Against Iraq
description: Insisting that it has never recognized an embargo on civilian air travel to Iraq, France today let a group fly from Paris to Baghdad.

Sinai Hospital or Southampton Hospital Emergency Room, c/o Dr. Howard Sklarek.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a health care policy adviser to Gov. George W. Bush who has financial ties to eight health care companies referred incorrectly to her ownership of 16,000 options on shares in United Health Care, of which she is a director. The adviser, Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, sold the shares in May at a profit of $328,144; she does not still hold them.

title: Stocks Rattled By Bad News From Intel
description: A steep tumble in shares of Intel dragged the stock market lower yesterday, after the company's warning late on Thursday that its sales in the third quarter would grow much less than had been expected. Trading in Intel set a daily record of more than 300 million shares.

description: To people familiar with the multibillion-dollar trafficking of human lives and dreams, the operation described by federal prosecutors in Wednesday's indictment of a Manhattan immigration lawyer sounded all too commonplace.

description: SYDNEY, Australia -- This is Mitt Romney's first Olympic experience, and he is having a great time, donning an official Salt Lake Organizing Committee outfit and joining the staff for a jog up the Sydney Harbor Bridge.

description: SYDNEY, Australia -- The Americans dominated the Olympic swimming competition. At the other end of the Sydney International Aquatic Center, they were out of sync.

title: Kraft Recalls Taco Shells With Bioengineered Corn
description: Kraft Foods announced a nationwide recall of taco shells yesterday after confirming that they contained a genetically engineered corn not approved for human consumption.

description: Stocks swooned around the world Friday after Intel Corp. warned of slower-than-expected European sales, focusing investor attention on fundamental problems they had been willing to overlook.

title: Eric Stiebel, 89, Gallery Dealer Focusing on Old Master Works
description: Eric Stiebel, chairman of Rosenberg & Stiebel, an internationally known art gallery that specialized in European old master paintings and decorative arts, died on Thursday, his family said. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Thursday about a victory celebration at City Hall for the Staten Island Yankees misstated the reason that Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, wore a button expressing support for William J. Bratton, the former police commissioner, who is considering a 2001 run for mayor. Mr. Molinari, who was dressed as Scooter, the team's mascot, wore it in jest; he is not supporting Mr. Bratton's candidacy.

title: U.S. Makes Biggest, and the Final, Waves
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  Between the body suits and the 15 new world records and the routine brilliance of two Dutch swimmers named Inge de Bruijn and Pieter van den Hoogenband, it was an unusual Olympic meet. But when it came down to the final two events of the final day, it ended as Olympic meets almost always end: with the Americans dominating the medley relays.

title: I Think, Therefore Ill Garden
description: FALL has always felt like the beginning of the garden. That first crisp day, when the sumac leaves start to redden, I walk around the farm in Maryland looking at what worked and didn't work and my head starts filling with pictures again. Anything seems possible.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Diary column yesterday about Fashionlab 2000, a multimedia collaboration between artists and clothing designers at Eyebeam Atelier, 540-48 West 21st Street in Manhattan, misstated the date. It is today at 6 p.m.; it was not held on Thursday.

title: Article 2000092392108842881 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Youth Sentenced in Government Hacking Case
description: A 16-year-old from Miami who repeatedly penetrated computer systems of the Defense Department and the space agency has been sentenced to six months in juvenile detention. The Justice Department said he is the first juvenile hacker to be sentenced to serve time.

title: Senate Donors Among Guests At White House
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have had 404 overnight guests at the White House and Camp David since Mrs. Clinton began campaigning for the New York Senate seat in July 1999, including scores of donors to Mrs. Clinton's campaign and several of the Democratic Party's most prominent fund-raisers.

title: For Alaia, a Retrospective and a New Deal
description: If anyone is the man of the moment, it is Azzedine Alaia, the Tunisian-born designer whose name was whispered throughout the Helmut Lang show and who is the subject of a retrospective that opened last night at the SoHo branch of the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Pratfalls of Old Age Confronted by a Lost Self of Youth
description: ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' Atom Egoyan's loving and scrupulous adaptation of Samuel Beckett's 1958 play, opens with a bit of melancholy slapstick that offers an elegant reminder of the playwright's affinities with the great clowns of silent cinema, Buster Keaton in particular. Krapp, a mournful old man who lives surrounded by the detritus of his once-heroic intellectual ambitions -- books, papers and boxes of reel-to-reel tape -- reaches into a drawer of his metal desk and extracts a banana. He removes the peel in four sections, which he lets fall to the floor, and then, with languorous relish, eats the banana, whereupon he circumnavigates the desk and promply slips, disappearing from the frame with a poignant and hilarious crash.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK
description: The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as 30 million more shares, or 7.5 percent of those outstanding, in a move that could help the company, the No. 2 United States railroad, bolster its share price. The buyback would cost $622.5 million at Thursday's closing price of $20.75. The company, based in Fort Worth, has repurchased almost all of the 90 million shares it decided to buy in three earlier programs authorized in July 1997, December 1999 and April, a spokesman, Patrick Hiatte, said. Burlington Northern's share price, as high as $27.94 last year, has fallen 27 percent since it announced a plan to merge with the Montreal-based Canadian National Railway Company on Dec. 20.

title: KLM SHARES SINK
description: In a show of uncertainty over the future of KLM, the Dutch airline, its shares tumbled 21 percent, to 21.5 euros, or $18.89, their biggest one-day decline ever, after the collapse of merger talks with British Airways. The British airline's shares fell less than 1 percent, to 295.25 pence, or $4.14, after having risen as much as 5.8 percent in intraday trading. Most analysts agree that KLM is too small to survive on its own, but the list of possible partners is dwindling. Earlier this year, KLM abandoned merger talks with Alitalia of Italy. Suzanne Kapner

title: Tape Details Kickbacks To an Aide Of Chirac
description: More details were made public today from the videotaped confession of a former aide to President Jacques Chirac, who described how he collected kickbacks from contractors installing elevators and painting hallways in city housing projects.

title: Bush Says Gore Is Waffling on Oil Release to Win Votes
description: A day after Vice President Al Gore called for tapping federal oil reserves, Gov. George W. Bush sought to turn the proposal into a test of character. He accused his opponent of turning ''political somersaults'' and proclaimed that voters ''don't want flip-floppers as president of the United States.''

title: Article 2000092392211171269 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: MACK-CALI ENDS BID FOR PRENTISS PROPERTIES TRUST
description: The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation ended an agreement to buy the rival commercial property developer Prentiss Properties Trust for $2.2 billion in stock and assumed debt, bowing to shareholder opposition. The purchase would have created the fourth-largest real estate investment trust, increasing Mack-Cali's real estate holdings by 68 percent, to 47.7 million square feet of mostly suburban space nationwide. When the purchase was announced in June, shareholders of Mack-Cali expressed concern that it would reduce earnings until 2002 and alter the company's focus on the Northeast, where rents are rising at some of the fastest paces in the United States. Mack-Cali is based in Cranford, N.J.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WORLD WRESTLING FEDERATION ENTERTAINMENT INC., -- Stamford, Conn., said it intended to list its common shares on the New York Stock Exchange on Oct. 25 under the symbol WWF. The company's shares were first quoted on the Nasdaq stock market after it completed its public offering on Oct. 19, 1999.

title: Sect Leader Wanted by China Can Stay in U.S., but in Custody
description: A federal immigration court in Hawaii has ruled that the leader of a banned Chinese meditation group may remain in the United States, defying Beijing's demands that he be returned to face rape charges, a rights group said yesterday.

title: A Cheer for the Bronx

title: Pezzo Successfully Defends Mountain Biking Title
description: FAIRFIELD, Australia -- Two in row for Paola Pezzo of Italy.

title: Yanks' Playoff Drive Has Hit the Skids
description: Joe Torre insists there is no uneasiness surrounding the Yankees. Sure, they want to win and they expect to win, but they are not tight about losing games in September as if they are suddenly imitating the Mets. Walk around the clubhouse, Torre politely advised. Do the Yankees look nervous?

title: Coulthard Records Fastest Practice Lap
description: The McLaren driver David Coulthard recorded the fastest lap time in yesterday's two practice sessions for tomorrow's United States Formula One Grand Prix in Indianapolis.

title: The Not So Discreet Evil Of the 1905 Upper Crust
description: Terence Davies's starched, funereally gloomy screen adaptation of Edith Wharton's novel ''The House of Mirth'' arrives at a timely moment in New York City's social history. The post-Victorian Fifth Avenue milieu in which Lily Bart (Gillian Anderson), the heroine of Wharton's great, sad novel, is ruthlessly torn apart by the jackals of high society obliquely anticipates today's post-feminist climate of ''Sex and the City,'' prenuptial agreements and trophy wives. Money rules, and anyone who doesn't catch on to that fact is a fool who deserves to learn the hard way. However amorous a high-powered match might be, there is also likely to be a business arrangement lurking under the bed covers. The English director's vision of New York City in 1905 is infinitely bleaker and more sterile, of course, than the glittering Versace and Gucci-clad present. The characters are too constricted by a punishing puritanical code of behavior to have much fun; hardly a smile is cracked throughout the film's glum 140 minutes.

title: A Young American Fulfills Her Modest Goal: Bronze
description: From the far reaches of the grandstand, they called out to Cheryl Haworth, screeching her nickname, ''Fun.''

description: Former President George Bush may have a mannerly reputation, but shortly after the Republican National Convention opened in Philadelphia, he was burning to mix it up with President Clinton for saying not-so-nice things about his eldest son.

title: A Wide-Eyed First-Time Olympian Sailor
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23  When the burly captain of the United States sailing team marched into Olympic Stadium for the opening ceremony of the Sydney Games, it was another milestone in an unlikely journey. For at the not-so-tender age of 46, in many ways Magnus Liljedahl was far removed from Goteborg, Sweden, the coastal city of his birth.

title: PANTRY AGREES TO PURCHASE 26 FAST LANE STORES
description: Pantry Inc., a convenience-store operator in the southeastern United States, has agreed to buy 26 Fast Lane stores in Mississippi and Louisiana from the closely held R. R. Morrison & Son Inc. for an undisclosed price. Pantry, based in Sanford, N.C., said the deal would give it its first stores in Louisiana and add to the 36 stores it has in Mississippi. It has acquired 140 convenience stores in fiscal 2000. In May, Pantry agreed to buy 19 Big K convenience stores in Mississippi from the closely held Tip Top Convenience Stores Inc.

By game's end in the Bronx, most of the Yankees realized that lowly Tampa Bay had beaten the Blue Jays and reduced the Yankees' number for clinching the American League East to six.

description: Dr. Anne E. Dyson, a pediatrician known for her philanthropy in the field of children's welfare, died yesterday at her home in Millbrook, N.Y. She was 52.

title: South Korea to Spend $44 Billion More to Support Banks
description: South Korea will have to spend another 50 trillion won, or about $44 billion, to prop up domestic banks, which were hit hard by the collapse of efforts last week to sell off the nearly bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company, the nation's finance minister, Jin Nyum, said today.

title: News Analysis: Politics or Policy?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Did President Clinton decide to dip into the Strategic Petroleum Reserve today to protect Vice President Al Gore? Or does he truly believe it will reverse a jump in oil prices that could hurt millions of Americans and threaten the country's remarkable prosperity?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, GEORGE CRAWFORD
description: BRADLEY-George Crawford, 87. beloved father, died on September 20 in Southampton, NY. Educated at Exeter and Yale, he served in WWII aboard the USS Pollux and the USS Montpelier. He later became Executive Vice President of Evans & Co., a brokerage house in NYC. Predeceased by his wife Lucy Glazebrook, he is survived by children (George Bradley, Jr., Anne Bradley, Ciaran Mercier and Christine Wooding) & grandchildren (Martha Mercier and Beatrice Bradley), as well as several nieces and a nephew. Memorial service at 1 PM, Saturday, September 23, St. Ann's Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Donations may be made to the National MS Society, 733 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017-3288.

title: How a Korean Folk Form Freshens a Fairy Tale Love
description: Parts of Im Kwon Taek's ''Chunhyang'' have the enormous and verdant sweep of a fairy tale, complete with the horrific turns of plot that pound at the heart of unexpurgated versions of folk stories. This master Korean director, who has made more than 90 films, uses the blush of ardor to warm the tale's familiarity.

description: The earliest days of the 2000 Olympic boxing tournament were full of success and ever-escalating medal predictions for the United States boxing team. Today was a sobering day of defeat and default.

description: Phillip Glasier, who helped revive the ancient sport of falconry, writing what some consider its bible and starting the National Birds of Prey Center in Britain, died at his home in Gloucestershire on Sept. 11. He was 84.

And tonight they stood together on the top rung of the Olympic medal podium, each draped with an identical gold medal around his neck.

description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, HERBERT
description: CANTOR-Herbert. 87, of Levittown, N.Y., died September 21, 2000 after a brief illness. A good, kind man, smart and funny, he was much loved by Millie, his wife of 54 years, children Phil, Mady and Dan, children-in-law Carrie, Arthur and Laura, and grandchildren Max, Nate, Tess, Eli, Ethan and Alice. A WWII veteran and lifelong Democrat, he owned Valley Stream Auto Parts for 30 years, and was a member of the Israel Cantor Family Society which was founded at his birth. A passionate follower of the events of the day and a partisan of fairness and decency throughout his life, he leaves a legacy of devotion to family and friends, of generosity without strings, and a marvelous sense of humor. He will be missed. Funeral Sunday, September 24, 12 noon, I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead. Visit www.cantorfamily.org

description: The men's shot-put was in its final stages on the first night of Olympic track and field competition, and as the mammoth, barrel-chested men lumbered intensely about the infield, the 110,000 fans in the Olympic Stadium were beside themselves.
