Proud grandfather of Olivia. Wonderful and caring brother of Herbert and Marvin and brother-in-law of Stephanie. We will remember him for his wisdom, strength of character and generous and loving spirit. Services on Sunday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Journal; No Business Like Show Business
description: Not since Richard Nixon tried to prove his 60's hip bona fides by delivering a ''Sock it to me'' gag on ''Laugh-In'' has there been a shotgun marriage of show biz and politics more awkward than George W. Bush's Thursday appearance on ''Live With Regis.'' But male candidates desperately seeking undecided female voters will do desperate things. In this case, Mr. Bush -- whose co-stars on the show were a man who breaks boards over his head and the singer Sarah Brightman -- donned a dark shirt and matching tie from the ''Regis collection'' and suffered gladly the morning's Kathie Lee wannabe, the persistently dim Susan Hawk of ''Survivor.'' He at least knew better than to give her a smooch, as he had Oprah two days before in his continuing if doomed quest to make up the ground he lost after Al's Excellent Kiss.

title: Drug Scandal Goes On: Bulgarian Team Is Ousted From Games
description: The entire Bulgarian weight-lifting team was expelled from the Olympics today in a drug scandal, paving the way for the United States to win its first gold medal in the sport in 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKES, STASIA
description: MENKES-Stasia. Age 94, died at her home on August 30, 2000. She was born in Stryj, Poland. Before WW II Stasia Menkes studied at at the Sorbonne in Paris. While in Paris she befriended and became a part of the circle of the avant guard painters and sculptors such as Chagall, Lipchitz, Soutine, Pasein, Zadkin and Sigmund Menkes. She fell in love with the painter Sigmund Menkes whom she marrried. She and her husband Sigmund Menkes escaped the Nazis and immigrated to the USA. Stasia Menkes was a striking beauty. She became the model for many of her husband's paintings. She was a talented fashion designer. She was a generous hostess. To her last days she displayed her sharpness, intelligence, and awareness over her circumstances. She is survived by her nephew Prof. Michele Jamiolkowski, his wife, Jadzia and their two daughters, Caterina and Maddalena. A private memorial service by the surviving family members and friends to follow.

title: Ford Raises Recommended Tire Pressure
description: The Ford Motor Company recommended tonight that owners of Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles inflate their tires to 30 pounds per square inch, instead of the 26 pounds that the automaker has recommended for the last 10 years.

title: That's More Like It: Piazza and Benitez Lead Mets to Victory
description: It was the kind of hit Mike Piazza has made famous, the laser over the right-field wall. It is a product of his superior strength and a simple swing. He stands still and upright in the batter's box, then with a jolt, the ball is gone. Nobody, perhaps, can hit a ball that hard the opposite way.

title: Republican Crusader on Shifting Ground
description: ''It's not about chasing headlines,'' say the television and billboard advertisements on which Roger Kahn has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars, and around the suburbs and farms of northwest Georgia there is nothing cryptic about the meaning of his campaign slogan.

title: Liebermans' Tax Returns, Made Public, Show Senator's Pay as Main Source of Income
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and his wife, Hadassah, yesterday released their federal income tax returns for the last 10 years, revealing that they depended almost entirely on his Senate salary, supplemented in some years by his wife's earnings as a women's health organizer, and, since 1996, by fees for administering two family trusts.

title: Drawn to the Faces Others Avoid; For Some, Foster Care System Fulfills a Longing to Adopt
description: In a windowless room on the eighth floor of a Lower Manhattan office building, a pair of photo albums are passed around one recent evening. On page after page, artful portraits of boys and girls stare up, some smiling solo at the camera, some draping their arms around a brother, a sister.

title: Coffees at White House Were Called Fund-Raisers
description: Retrieved White House e-mail messages turned over today to federal and Congressional investigators show that Vice President Al Gore's senior aides routinely characterized White House coffee sessions as fund-raising events in early 1996.

title: Longer Sentences for Ex-Archer Officers
description: A federal judge has increased the sentences of two former executives of the Archer Daniels Midland Company for their roles in a global conspiracy to fix the price of the animal-feed additive lysine.

title: Drunken Driving: Drawing the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDE, MARTIN
description: LANDE-Martin. Passed away September 21, 2000. Dearest beloved husband of Corinne for 53 years. Adored father of Jane Scrobola (Robert) and the late Melinda Rosenblatt (Lief). Devoted and loved Grandpa of Andre. He waged the last battle with the same courage and dignity with which he lived his life. He will be greatly missed by those who knew him and loved him. Services Sunday 11:45 at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: TOYOTA EXPECTS STRONGER RESULTS
description: Japan's leading automaker, the Toyota Motor Corporation, said yesterday that it was likely to report higher earnings for the first half of its fiscal year than it had anticipated as sales were stronger than expected in North America and Europe. Toyota raised its profit forecast by 43 percent, to 100 billion yen, or nearly $1 billion, for the six months ending in September. It will probably sell 10,000 more cars domestically and 60,000 more for export to North America and Europe than it originally expected.

title: Judge Orders Pilots' Union To Make Payment to Airline
description: The pilots' union at American Airlines and its leaders must pay the airline $45.5 million in damages for ignoring a judge's order to end a 1999 work stoppage, a federal court has ruled.

title: Trying to Deflect Criticism, Corzine Goes on the Attack
description: Battered by weeks of criticism and his own missteps, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic multimillionaire running for Senate from New Jersey, moved sharply today to change the subject with a barrage of new attack advertisements aimed at his little-known Republican rival, Representative Bob Franks.

title: As Season Ends, Some Managers Are in Danger of Losing Their Jobs
description: Larry Dierker managed Houston to division championships in each of his first three seasons with the Astros. In this, his fourth season, the Astros have played badly, and Dierker is said in baseball circles to be in danger of losing his job.

title: Estate of the Nation
description: Do heirs deserve their parents' wealth? Probably not, but neither does the government. The proper question is whether people deserve to see their property go where they want it to go, or whether they should see it seized by others. In a fair society, there is only one answer to that question.

title: Armstead Leads Revitalized Defense
description: Jessie Armstead and Giants Coach Jim Fassel agreed to leave Armstead's outburst last November behind them by the time Armstead reported for the team's off-season conditioning program in March. He was there as much to rehabilitate his surgically repaired left knee as to prove he was still a leader.

title: Christina Ha and Marcus Solis
description: WHEN Christina Ha started dating Marcus Solis in the fall of 1996, she was so weary of living in New York that nothing could cheer her up about the city -- not even getting invited to a glamorous movie premiere or taking a cab up Madison Avenue and having every traffic light turn green for her.

title: Elisabeth Thorington, Stephen Mongillo III
description: Elisabeth Gindrat Thorington, a daughter of Winifred Ann Pilcher Thorington and Robert D. Thorington of Montgomery, Ala., was married yesterday to Stephen Arthur Mongillo III, a son of Mary Gail Scanlon Mongillo and Mr. Mongillo of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Craig Townsend performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: The Nation; Violence on the Screen: Unlovely and Invulnerable
description: THIS is the logic of politicians when they think about popular culture: Many of today's films and music and video games are vile, not like the John Wayne movies or Elvis records they enjoyed when they were young.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Watch column last Sunday, about a Nasdaq proposal for a new system of handling trades, misstated the name of a money and mutual fund management company whose Nasdaq trades on electronic communications networks, known as E.C.N.'s, cost far less than those made through Wall Street brokerage firms. It is American Century Investments; a subsidiary is American Century Ventures.

title: Ask a Child to Create a Friend? That's a Ni Ni
description: When Kenn Viselman polled preschoolers about the qualities they'd most like to find in a playmate, the result was neither fish nor fowl - or even boy or girl.

title: Navarro May Fulfill a Brothers Failed Quest
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 24  A soundtrack came with the American flyweight Jose Navarro's second- round victory today in the Olympic boxing tournament. It was loud, passionate and mostly in Spanish, and it came from Navarro's older brother, Carlos, who stood ringside yelling instructions and encouragement that filled the small converted hall that serves as Sydney's boxing arena.

title: Handling Stars Who Respond to Affection
description: CHRISTOPHER GUEST will tell you that his new movie is not about dogs. His mock documentary ''Best in Show,'' which opens on Friday, is set at a Westminster-like national dog competition in Philadelphia, and its characters do include Winky the Norwich terrier, Miss Agnes the Shih Tzu and Beatrice the Weimaraner. But, Mr. Guest says, the story is about the owners, not the animals, and he could have found the same humor making a film about hospital workers or art dealers.

title: A Nod, a Smile, Trying to Decipher Iran's Message on Jailed Jews
description: The reports flowed steadily into the White House and State Department in recent days: Iran's foreign minister, Kamal Kharazi, was telling foreign officials, members of the Jewish and Iranian-American communities and human rights leaders that some of the 10 Iranian Jews convicted of cooperating with Israel would go free, and that the rest would have their sentences reduced sharply.

title: Volunteer Duty Leads U.S. Soccer Team to Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 24 -- Peter Vagenas volunteers for penalty kicks. Not everybody does. Some of the most prolific scorers in soccer history would just as soon inspect the light stanchions or the clumps of grass when the call goes out for volunteers. But Vagenas wants the ball.

title: China Clerics Deny Reports That Churches Are Bullied
description: Leaders of the official Protestant church defended China's policies on religious freedom this week, asserting that a record 15 million Chinese now worship in approved Protestant churches and that persecution of so-called underground Christians is rare.

title: Suzanne Reitano, Mark Burchill
description: Suzanne Marie Reitano, the daughter of Virginia and Arthur Reitano of Pawleys Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Mark Andrew Burchill, a son of Cathryn Burchill and Thomas F. Burchill II, both of New York. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island in Rhode Island.

title: Automotive Ecosystem Proves Fragile
description: THE fallout from the Firestone tire recall is rattling many of the biggest automotive parts suppliers, who are already dealing with weaker sales, cost-cutting demands and other pressures.

title: Pure Gold
description: To the Editor:

title: The 60's Return, Upswept and Glued Down
description: YOU had to look twice, so transformed were her features, but yes, that was Maggie Rizer gliding down the runway at Oscar de la Renta's spring 2001 fashion show on Tuesday. Her eyes, just visible between layers of bright paint, seemed to be spearing onlookers with their gimlet stare.

title: Suing Seller Who Reneged
description: Q What practical recourse does a buyer have when a seller who has already signed a contract of sale nevertheless sells the property to someone else for a higher price? Is it true that trying to enforce a contract on a property that has already been sold is an exercise in futility? Would recording the contract at the county clerk's office have prevented this problem? . . . Julie Tara-Slater, East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Fusaichi Pegasus Sharp In His Return to Racing
description: Fusaichi Pegasus made a triumphant return to racing yesterday after a four-month absence, and he did it regally and professionally, sweeping into the lead in the homestretch and winning the Jerome Handicap over El Corredor and Albert the Great.

title: Nader Fades in Polls but Draws Crowds
description: The main act came dressed in a wrinkled blue suit, file folders tucked under his arms. As he stepped onto the stage, squinting into the klieg lights, he looked more like an accountant than a performer. Yet the 12,000 boisterous fans who paid $7 each to get inside the Target Center erupted like teenagers at a Smashmouth concert, chanting his name and waving signs that read, ''Let Ralph Debate.''

title: Sarah Fortune, Christopher Langhart
description: Sarah Cain Fortune, a daughter of Sheila and Philip J. Fortune of Morristown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher Bernhard Langhart, a son of Marlene and Bernhard Langhart of East Northport, N.Y. Msgr. Martin Rauscher performed the ceremony at the Church of the Assumption.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is 19 years of believing and dreaming about this.''

title: A Gymnastics Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sept. 17-23; Trading in Human Lives
description: Federal prosecutors accused Robert E. Porges, a Manhattan lawyer whose Chinatown firm has represented thousands of Chinese immigrants seeking political asylum in the United States, of participating in the smuggling of illegal immigrants into the country from China.

title: Chateau du Basement: The '00 Vintage
description: HOME winemaking is a well-worn first step toward a commercial career, as Kip Bedell, the North Fork merlot master on Long Island, can attest. The hobby that began in his Garden City basement in 1970, when he made five gallons from riesling grape concentrate, culminated in February in the $5 million sale of Bedell Cellars. Not a bad return.

title: To Dance Vivaldi, Just Ask Vivaldi
description: CHRISTOPHER WHEELDON had no intention of making a ballet of Antonio Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' even though he thinks the music is wonderful. When he saw James Kudelka's ballet to the same score, he recalls, he thought: ''Wow, this is long. I love the music but I would never do this.'' He couldn't see how to stretch enough inventive steps over the length of such a familiar work.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Gain Hope In Pennsylvania Race
description: Democrats are taking heart from a Pennsylvania poll that shows Representative Ron Klink gaining in his effort to unseat Senator Rick Santorum, a freshman Republican.

title: Estee Levine, David Little
description: Estee Sherry Levine, a daughter of Gale and Lawrence Levine of Rockville Centre, N.Y., was married last evening to David Dunlap Little, a son of Margaret and Thomas Little of Lyme, N.H. Judge Ruth Balkin of Nassau County Family Court officiated at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

title: All in the Family
description: Sullivan omits reference to the Harrisons (William Henry, the grandfather, and Benjamin, the grandson) who also served in the presidency. Furthermore, the history of dynastic succession that he laments (at least with reference to the office of the president) does not support his contentions. The Adamses as well as Benjamin Harrison were all defeated for re-election. And Robert Taft, the son of William Howard Taft, while serving long in the Senate, was never able to translate his family connections into even a nomination for president, although he sought it more than once. It would seem that the American electorate is quite capable of deciding on electoral outcomes based on factors other than nepotism.

title: Sept. 17-23; Gone, but Not Forgotten
description: Robert W. Ray, the independent prosecutor, ended a six-year, almost $60 million investigation by delivering a report that cleared both President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, of criminal wrongdoing in connection with the Whitewater real estate deal.

title: Jets Gird For Battle With Bucs' Defence
description: It was facetiously suggested at some point during the cacophonous past week that the real fun would be if Keyshawn Johnson played defense, too, so that he could spend today trying to jam Wayne Chrebet all the way into the grass of Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla.

title: Indonesian Police Report Arresting 25 Suspects in Jakarta Bombings
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -- The Indonesian police said today that they have arrested 25 people in connection with a recent series of bombings in Jakarta, including one that killed 15 people at the stock exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, HERBERT I.
description: PRINCE-Herbert I. Formerly of NYC and Boca Raton, FL, passed away gently in his sleep September 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Marian for 41 years. Father of Robert J. Prince, Sarabelle, Laurie Ann. Dear grandfather to Molly, Abigail, Benjamin, Danny, Julie and Jennifer. Served as an officer in the U.S. Air Force during WWII. Founded Serascreen Corp. in 1951. Retired in 1985 after a successful career as a respected leader in the screen printing industry. A kind, loving, gentle man with a warm sense of humor, you will always be in our hearts. We are grateful you are at peace. We knew you as a true ''prince.''

title: Vamps and Martyrs, Enraptured and Anguished
description: IN film after film, the diva's role is not an easy one. She may portray a countess or a woman of the people, be lodged in a chateau or a fisherman's shack, appear covered in furs, a Neapolitan shawl or a nun's habit; but her characters are always haunted by terrible secrets and fearful of ghosts from the past. With her arabesque gestures and her gaze turned toward heaven, she recalls the dark-eyed heroines of 19th-century melodrama; yet she also plays the New Woman, who smokes cigarettes, wears pants, flirts with men and rides in hot-air balloons. The camera loves her beauty, but on screen her charms may draw unwanted attentions, perpetual suspicions and even a jealous lover's knife.

title: Hannan's Two-Way Effort Leads Way for Garden City
description: Bill Hannan rushed for three touchdowns and returned an interception 55 yards for another score to help Garden City defeat Hewlett, 24-12.

title: The Real Thing
description: Jonathan Reynolds's article on heirloom tomatoes (Food, Aug. 27) was clever and informative and managed to plug organic farming and thumb its nose at Monsanto at the same time. I had just polished off a wonderful salad Caprese of organic heirlooms, fresh basil and fresh mozzarella before reading it. It was like finding the perfect after-dinner drink.

title: Channel Islands
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's article ''A Foot in Two Countries,'' (Aug. 27), about the Channel Islands, was much needed for American travelers but missed some attractive and important sites. A few years ago I took a garden tour that included Guernsey and Sark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, ADAM S.
description: LIPTON-Adam S. Suddenly, on September 21, age 36. Husband of Margaret. Son of Jerome and Caroline Lipton. Services Sunday at Noon, Congregation Beth El, Bethesda, MD. Donations in Adam's name to NFTY or the Adam S. Lipton Fund for Social Justice at Hebrew Union College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROBERT B.
description: STERN-Robert B. Age 71. Died Sept. 19, 2000, in Miami, FL, after a valiant battle with cancer. He was predeceased by his daughter Erica Ann in 1992. Survived by his cherished wife Rhoda; Beloved daughters Claudia and Lydia Stern; His extended family, daughters Toby and Terry and son Jeffrey; Granddaughters, Christina and Ryelee; Sister Carole Selig; Nephew Gregory; Brother-in-law Allan; and his many adoring friends. His wit and charm and extraordinary personality melted the hearts of all who knew him. He is loved forever and will never be forgotten. Memorial service was performed at Eternal Light Funeral Chapel in Miami. New York memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, SHELDON M.
description: NEUMAN-Sheldon M. Age 65. On September 21, 2000 in Miami, FL. after a brief illness. Devoted lifetime partner of Cami Green. Beloved father of Rachel & Jonah. Father-in-law of Richard. Proud grandfather of Olivia. Wonderful and caring brother of Herbert and Marvin and brother-in-law of Stephanie. We will remember him for his wisdom, strength of character and generous and loving spirit. Services on Sunday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: How Rembrandt Made His Name Painting Himself
description: IN 1629 Rembrandt was 23. He had tousled, curly hair, a bulbous nose, a small mouth and round, staring eyes. He shared a studio in his birthplace, Leiden, with Jan Lievens. Two years later, having achieved fame and some fortune, to a large extent from experimenting with images of his own face, he moved to Amsterdam, the commercial and artistic center of the Netherlands.

title: Canada Calls for Moratorium on Debt Repayments From Poor Countries
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 24 -- Canada on Sunday called for a moratorium on debt repayments for poor countries that commit themselves to effective, corruption-free governance. Canadian Finance Minister Paul Martin, in a speech prepared for delivery here, told International Monetary Fund policymakers that a debt relief scheme they launched four years ago with the World Bank was moving too slowly. He recalled that the IMF last year had made a commitment to stepping up the pace of the heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC), which offers relief to impoverished nations that adhere to IMF economic reforms and draft action plans to eliminate poverty. "We made a commitment last year to faster action and we must make good on this commitment," Martin told a meeting of the IMF's International Monetary and Financial Committee. "Too many heavily indebted countries have still not benefited from the faster, deeper and broader debt relief promised under the enhanced HIPC initiative ...We must ask ourselves whether we cannot do more. For example, why should we not consider an immediate moratorium on debt payments from eligible reforming HIPC countries?" He said the moratorium could be extended to countries "committed to principles of good governance and are not in conflict." But the actual cancellation of the debt would not take place until countries have been deemed finally eligible for relief under HIPC. Such an approach, according to Martin, would "create an incentive for countries to continue to implement good policies." Of some 40 countries that are in principle eligible for HIPC treatment, only 10 -- Benin, Bolivia, Burkina Faso, Honduras, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Senegal, Tanzania and Uganda -- have actually been approved for debt relief. Canada is currently owed $1 billion from 17 countries.

title: Sara Duffy, Nathanael Greene
description: Sara Duffy, the daughter of Michaela Minden Duffy of Manhattan and Paul Duffy of Falmouth, Mass., was married on Nantucket yesterday to Nathanael Wade Greene, the son of Susanne and Wade Greene of New York and Nantucket. The Rev. Georgia Anne Snell, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Wade Cottages, a bed-and-breakfast owned by the bridegroom's parents in Siasconset, Mass.

title: The World: Movement; Growing Up and Getting Practical Since Seattle
description: WITH her Danish mother, her Syrian father, her French passport and her Oxford education, Annie-Christine Habbard, 31, seems every inch the global citizen equipped to succeed in a shrinking world. Yet here she is, chic in black, articulate in several tongues, at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, protesting the state of the globe. What she wants is more social justice, respect for human rights, a ''counterpower'' to high finance and, for good measure, a more equitable distribution of the spoils from a new Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline.

title: 'Best Wishes, George Allen's Daughter'
description: At my father's funeral in January 1991, several men told me, ''Your father died a winner.'' His fatal heart attack came just after he had completed a season as head coach of the Long Beach State 49ers, a Division IA squad he adopted a year earlier because the university was threatening to cancel its failing football program. According to his doctor, my father's health probably started to deteriorate seconds after the final game of the 1990 season -- a victory that gave the team its first winning record in four years -- when the players doused him with a bucket of ice water. After the game, sitting in his wet clothes, my father answered reporters' questions. They wanted to know why George Allen, the legendary National Football League coach, had accepted such a small-time coaching job.

title: INVESTING WITH: Alfred Harrison; Alliance Premier Growth Fund
description: THESE days, Alfred Harrison lives in Minneapolis and presides over about $80 billion of investments for Alliance Capital Management. But he developed a horse sense for arbitrage during his youth, when his father took him on trips from their home in Nottingham, England, to the Newmarket racetrack.

title: Sports of The Times; The Night Belongs to Greene, but the Future Belongs to Jones
description: Off the track and into his new and long-awaited life as an Olympic gold medalist, Maurice Greene made the rounds, hammed it up with the men who had finished in his dust and then happened to glance at the television, mounted high on the back stage wall. There, was a scene that is likely to be repeated several times over the following week. There, was a face that Madison Avenue will undoubtedly soon come to love.

title: The Sommelier
description: Olympic athletes in second-skin swimsuits are not the only ones coming out of Australia sporting racy styles. Ned Goodwin, a sommelier from Sydney who moved to New York four years ago, has his own full-bodied style. When working at Veritas, a restaurant in the Flatiron district known for its extensive wine list, he sticks to an all-business look, but after hours he uncorks his wild-and-crazy fashion sensibility. ''I was brought up in a city that's very body-conscious,'' said Mr. Goodwin, 31, who grew up surfing at Bondi Beach, where the Olympic volleyball games are being held. ''I like clothes that are bright, flamboyant and bawdy.''

title: The World: Putin and the Press; An Invitation You Can't Refuse: Be on My Team
description: IN Russia, rulers don't just fight to take or keep power. They also fight to make sure they don't have to share it. This was true for the czars, it was true for the Communist Party and, so far, it seems to be true for President Vladimir V. Putin, who came to the Kremlin by way of the K.G.B. and its successor agency, the F.S.B., where he learned to look on people as either patriots or traitors.

title: Toward Universal Coverage
description: The national debate over health policy, which first occupied the top rungs of the political agenda in the 1992 presidential campaign, shifts focus as the nature of problems shifts. In the mid 1990's, the focus was on the soaring cost of health insurance. Toward the end of the 90's, attention shifted to alleged excesses of managed care plans. But one problem never fades away. That is the shameful fact that the United States is the only industrialized power that does not provide some form of universal health coverage for its people. Some 45 million Americans still lack health insurance, and despite a decade of prosperity, the number is growing.

title: Oil Price Rise Heightens Dismay Over the Euro
description: TWO years ago, Americans arriving in Paris or Brussels or Frankfurt would routinely be shocked at the high cost of nearly everything: dreary hotels that cost nearly $200 a night; $10 to develop a roll of film; and clothes that often cost 50 percent more than in the United States.

title: From Magic Acts To Drums: Hiring The Life of the Party

Whether it's a wedding, bar mitzvah, anniversary, corporate or school event, the entertainment choices are limitless. And the wackier the better. Magicians, prancing drummers, impersonators, belly dancers, face painters, ventriloquists, sword swallowers, male strippers, puppeteers and multi-talented performers who walk on stilts, ride unicycles and play with yo-yos are only a fee away. Here are some of the possibilities.

title: Runways; Flying Close to the Sun
description: Five hours into crossing the Atlantic in his wooden, single-engine plane, Andrea Tremolada began to have serious doubts whether he'd live to see the coast of Brazil. The steady drizzle that had followed his red Falco F.8L from Sal Island, off the coast of Senegal, suddenly turned into a convulsive thunderstorm. In seconds, his 22-foot plane shot from 8,000 feet to 15,000 feet and slammed back down. ''Those accelerations were breaking the plane,'' he said. ''And the cockpit was full of water. I looked at my watch, and it was 11:23, and I said, 'This is the time I am going down.'''

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00; Fly the Angry Skies
description: It wasn't supposed to be this way. We were told to expect medium-rare chateaubriand and exotic fondues and white linen antimacassars gentling our dreamy heads and fancy French wine all around and the bell ring of sterling flatware. These I was promised. Knifing through the jet stream at 50,000 feet, I would put up my stockinged feet, take my good wife's gloved hand, beam at our Cleaver-perfect children across the wide aisle and doze as we rocketed safely into our future at 600 miles per hour. This is what we were sold. Promises were made, the ancient newsreel promises of commercial jet travel, circa 1960. The new magic carpet for the new American leisure class.

title: A Life Coach to Hold in Your Hand
description: MODO looks like a clam or a walnut or a beetle. It sits nicely in your hand, and its rubber ''tongue'' untoggles from its hooked carapace to reveal a little screen. Each Modo comes packaged in a vacuum-sealed hard plastic and silver paper wrapper, and when you open it, you can hear a whoosh. ''Like it's sealed for freshness,'' explained William Lynch, a Modo promoter. ''Like a pill, a vitamin,'' he continued, encouragingly. ''Take your Modo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SOPHIE
description: DAVIS-Sophie. The arts have lost a great friend and remarkable lady. Sophie Davis had a long history of cultivating and providing the finest in the performing arts-and providing communities with the knowledge of what the finest is. She brought an enormous sense of good taste, practicality and good old-fashioned show business timing to any project. The Kravis Center had the good fortune to have her ear, heart, and wisdom for so many years. Our heartfelt condolences to Leonard, Alan, Michael and their families. Judith Shepherd Mitchell Chief Executive Officer Alexander W. Dreyfoos, Jr., Board Chairman Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, West Palm Beach, Florida

title: Bus Driver Shortage Leaving Students At the Curb
description: THE shortage of school bus drivers resulting from the expanding economy and the state's low unemployment rate has made the first few weeks of the school year chaotic ones. Buses in many towns are regularly late, routes have been expanded so students have to leave for school earlier and get home later, and in some cases, most notably in Stamford where the shortage has been acute, buses haven't come at all.

title: Prolonging the Buzz
description: Attract bees and butterflies well into fall with clumps of familiar perennials like asters, butterfly weed and hyssop and underused ones like mountain mint (Pycnanthemum muticum), ironweed (Vernonia noveboracensis) and leadwort (Ceratostigma plumbaginoides). Seven-son flower (Heptacodium miconioides) is an underused small tree whose many virtues include panicles of small, white flowers that smell of nutmeg and tuberose and are alive with blissful bees and butterflies through September.

title: Don't Mar the Mall
description: Before he leaves office, President Clinton hopes to break ground for a suitable memorial to the veterans of World War II, who are dwindling in number with each passing day. The veterans of that brutal and pivotal conflict, so important to the protection of democratic freedoms everywhere, richly deserve such a memorial. But neither their memory nor Mr. Clinton's legacy will be well served by the proposed memorial approved Thursday by the National Capital Planning Commission.

But Fernandes Herlander Coimbra, his left hand holding a duffel bag on his shoulder, laughed when that name was brought up.

title: For Gardeners, Learning Season
description: DAVID gardeners know that fall is a time to get back out into the beds and borders after the dog days of summer. The weeds grow, rain or shine, and all those garden center bargains have to be planted before the nights begin to get frosty. Then there are the bulbs. If you ordered in bulk in July, you can count on spending September and October digging holes. And even after the bulbs and the perennials have been safely put to bed, there is the fall cleanup to be done.

title: Rescue Attempt for the Euro Falls Short of Bankers' Hopes
description: One day after the world's major central banks announced a startling rescue attempt for the euro, Europe's struggling currency, the effort showed signs today of being more modest and tentative than it first appeared.

title: Melissa Felsher, Mark Jaffe
description: Melissa Amy Felsher and Mark Jaffe, lawyers in the abuse and neglect division of the New York City Administration for Children's Services, were married last evening by Cantor Richard Botton at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: As Raw As They Dare to Be
description: THIS year's Toronto Film Festival, which ended last weekend, highlighted at least one trend worth noting: women directing women in movies that are openly about sex -- not lyrical playhouse lovemaking, but extreme behavior that makes the participants come to grips with the way that sex can ruin lives.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00: The Ethicist; Conference Call
description: A drug company invited me, a physician, to a weekend conference on one of their expensive new products. They flew my wife and me to a lovely resort where they fed and entertained us lavishly. I attended scientific meetings for a few hours; the rest of the time we were free to amuse ourselves. No quid pro quo was requested. To circumvent government regulations that limit such gifts, they made us doctors nominal ''consultants'' and paid us each $1,000. Everyone I spoke with felt a bit guilty about it (including me), but the inducements were too good to pass up. Do you see an ethical problem here? -- Anonymous, Kansas

title: Mary Ellen Glynn, Dwight Holton
description: Mary Ellen Glynn and Dwight Carter Holton were married on Friday in La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Robert L. Kealy, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Mary, Star of the Sea, with the Rev. Samuel Kirk, a Methodist minister, taking part.

title: Where Low Tech Gets a High-Five
description: ADULTS impressed by space-age gadgetry might expect the most popular draw at a children's museum to be the computer-based attractions. But for children, low-tech can be way cool.

title: Measuring That Whirring Sound Just Above
description: For years, New Yorkers have complained about helicopter noise to just about anyone who would listen. Right now, they have the attention of the federal government, and rattled residents living near helicopter routes are giving officials an earful.

title: Home Care
description: At a time when managed-care companies offer quality health care for senior citizens and then pull out of an area, leaving many scrambling, it is refreshing to read of the unselfish Chyd Denny and her family.

title: Appearances; Warm and Fuzzy
description: I guess I should be flattered. A lady I hadn't seen in several years kissed me on the cheek at a funeral recently, and exclaimed: ''You haven't aged! It's because you shave. I should start shaving.''

title: U.S. and Others Press for Cuts In Price of Oil
description: The top financial officials of the United States, fresh from an unprecedented synchronized plunge into world oil and currency markets, joined other rich nations today in vowing to fight what they described as double jeopardy for the global economy.

title: Golden Redemption for Jones and Greene
description: Four years ago, the Atlanta Games played on with them in the audience, not on the track. Marion Jones was recovering from a broken foot, Maurice Greene from a bruised ego, having failed to qualify for the 100 meters at the United States track and field trials. Sitting in tears as Donovan Bailey of Canada won the gold medal, Greene told himself, ''This will never happen again without me.''

title: Clinton Enlists Internet to Stop Illicit Gun Sales

Four women at last week's spring fashion collections in the tents in Bryant Park and other sites around New York City captured this style and stood out among the thousands of guests.

title: Some New Touches At Shelburne Museum

The John Slade Ely House, where the club has been exhibiting regularly since 1961, has been spruced up for the occasion. The art is all from club's collection and many objects have also just been cleaned.

title: Yoga Teacher to Stars Tries Becoming One
description: DANNY PARADISE -- yogi, minstrel, world citizen -- has no phone number, no post office box, no residence he calls home. He roams the planet with a bag or two, leaving luggage under beds in his wake. The only way to reach him directly is through a carefully guarded e-mail address. ''People generally get to me by contacting someone who already knows me, and when I'm in their area, I'll call that person to say I've arrived,'' he said.

For the equivalent of about 5 cents, she offered a huge green mango leaf filled with rice, fish paste and fried beetles. It was a hearty breakfast, if one didn't mind the odd antenna left sticking in one's teeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Anne E. Pediatrician and philanthropist, died Thursday, September 21, 2000, at the age of 52 after a year long battle with breast cancer. Since 1979, Anne E. Dyson had served as the President and Director of the Dyson Foundation, a family philanthropy founded in 1957 by her late parents, Margaret and Charles Dyson. Under her leadership, the Dyson Foundation has extensively funded many programs in the Mid-Hudson Valley of New York State, and has focused on improving the life opportunities and health of young children across the country. Dr. Dyson was a board-certified pediatrician, and held academic appointments at Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University, where she was a Clinical Assistant Professor of Pediatrics and at the University of Illinois College of Medicine. Dr. Dyson was a Director of the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, an international multi-industry holding company headquartered in New York City that was founded by her father in 1954. She served as the Chair of the Board of Directors of the Hole in the Wall Gang Fund, Inc., a camp for children with life-threatening illnesses. She was a Vice Chair of the Board of Overseers of the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University and was the Co-Chair of the Partnership for Children of the American Academy of Pediatrics. She was a member of the Board of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, and served as a member of the Board of Health of Dutchess County, New York. Dr. Dyson was educated at New York University and received her M.D. degree from New York Medical College in 1977. Her post-doctoral training included an internship at St. Christopher's Hospital in Philadelphia, residency training at Cornell Medical CenterNew York Hospital, a research fellowship at Rockefeller University and an infectious disease fellowship at Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, NY. She was a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Dr. Dyson is survived by her husband Michael S. Kramer, journalist and political commentator her sons Roberto Hull and Mac Hull, her stepson Ben Kramer, three brothers, Robert R. Dyson and his wife Emilie, John S. Dyson and his wife Kathe, and Peter L. Dyson and his wife Barbara, and their families, which include her nieces and nephews Leigh, Eliza, Christopher, Molly, Karen, Lisa, Brian and John. Dr. Dyson and her family lived in Millbrook, NY. Services and burial will be held at Grace Church, Franklin Avenue in Millbrook, New York on Tuesday, September 26, 2000 at 11:00 a.m. A memorial service will also be held in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp in New Haven, Connecticut or the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: The Virtual Museum, Imperfect But Promising
description: I FIRST entered an art museum by mistake, at age 11, to get out of the rain. I lost my cool right away when I bumped into a John Marin watercolor daubed in wild, fiery hues. It stood framed, marvelous and alone, in the lobby of the venerable Phillips Collection in Washington. While I gawked, my impatient mother tried to pull me away. She failed.

description: THE MILE HIGH CLUB

title: For Orthodox Jews, a Gathering Place on the Air
description: SEVERAL years ago, a prominent Orthodox rabbi was a guest on a Jewish music and talk show on the noncommercial radio station WFMU-FM. The rabbi, Haskel Lookstein, was so impressed with the knowledge and easy manner of the host, Nachum Segal, that he told him after the show: ''Nachum, you could do such a great job in the rabbinate.''

title: Bridging the Gap Between Arab and Jew
description: THE collapse of the Camp David summit in July has landed Arab-Israeli relations in a brand new state of flux.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Sarah Montague Mason and Terrence Michael Burgess misstated the couple's married name. They are Mr. and Mrs. Burgess, not Mason. The report also misstated the surname of the bridegroom's mother at one point. As noted elsewhere, she is Nancy Burgess, not Mason.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Michael Kors; Charm by Design
description: WHEN Martha Stewart strode into the opening party for Michael Kors's new store on upper Madison Avenue on Thursday, she flashed her calm, confident smile for the cameras. Then she saw Mr. Kors, and suddenly became girlish. ''I just threw these on,'' she said demurely, fingering the multiple strands of pearls she was wearing with a brown leather shirt. She even kicked one leg up and giggled as she pointed to her beige Shantung pants.

title: Sept. 17-23; Athletic Oddities in Sydney
description: The Olympics began to look a little like a soap opera, which could only boost NBC's anemic ratings.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Imagining Wyoming
description: Film critics were jolted last year when David Lynch, who directed a version of Barry Gifford's novel ''Wild at Heart,'' released ''The Straight Story,'' a G-rated road movie with a fuzzy sheath of atypical sentiment. Now it's Gifford's turn to surprise: his new novel, WYOMING (Arcade, $19.95), is a tender and understated story that has none of the gleeful sadism or frenzied grotesqueries that have defined his earlier work. Not all of Gifford's trademarks have disappeared: The narrative is elliptical, the dialogue zigzags and Gifford's preoccupation with highway-bound drifters stands front and center. But instead of the dissipated losers and bug-eyed maniacs who've peopled Gifford's previous novels, the drifters here are a sweetly indulgent single mother and her young son, Roy; their travels through 1950's America are the novel's backbone. Just where they're headed, or why, is rarely revealed, but that's not the point, as even young Roy understands: ''Maybe sometimes it's better to imagine how something or someplace is rather than to have it or be there.'' For this pair, Wyoming is just such an imaginary place, a dream locale where Roy and his mother can always escape. ''It's really big there, with lots of room to run,'' Roy says. ''I looked on a map. Wyoming's probably a good place to have a dog.'' When anything bad happens, Roy tells her he's going to ''think about Wyoming.'' ''It's a good thing, baby,'' she replies. ''Everybody needs Wyoming.'' That Gifford forges these characters almost entirely out of dialogue makes their affecting humanity doubly impressive; by the novel's end, Roy and his mother are likely to live as vividly in the reader's mind as their unseen Wyoming lives in theirs. Jonathan Miles

title: You've Got Ordnance
description: Marketers are always looking for a gimmick to cut through the clutter. A popular line of attack is to send a select list of prospective customers something attractive and memorable in the mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGHAM, LEWIS E.
description: BINGHAM-Lewis E. The Committee of Methadone Program Administrators Inc. (COMPA) of New York State extends heartfelt condolences to the family and colleagues of Lewis E. Bingham, late Senior Executive Vice President of the Addiction Research and Treatment Corporation (ARTC) of Brooklyn, NY, where he worked for 27 years. Lewis was a longstanding member of the COMPA Executive Committee, a consummate professional and an extraordinary person. We will miss his wisdom and good nature. We share the sorrow of his passing with his wife and children, his friends and staff of ARTC. His spirit remains forever in our memories. Peter Coleman, Chairperson Martin Livenstein, Exec. Director

title: Sept. 17-23; A Kiss for the Ages
description: First Al Gore planted a big one on his wife, Tipper, at the Democratic Convention, and the pollsters said it worked wonders with women. So after Oprah Winfrey jokingly complained that Mr. Gore failed to kiss her in a cheery appearance on her talk show, Mr. Bush delivered a strategic smooch to her cheek last week and declared that his favorite gift to his wife, Laura, was a kiss.

title: It's Always About Me.
description: Jesse Bradford at the Chateau Marmont:

title: Plans for World War II Memorial Lurch Forward
description: ''It has taken twice as long to build this monument than it took to fight the war,'' Representative Marcy Kaptur said the other day as the National Capital Planning Commission prepared to approve the National World War II Memorial, which would be built on the Washington Mall.

title: Sept. 17-23; Now Comes the Real Revolution
description: On the annual Woman's Day in Iran last week, a conservative bureaucrat named Farah Khosravi announced that she wanted to run for president in next year's election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, TERRENCE P.
description: COSTELLO-Terrence P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Terrence P. Costello, associated with The Times from 1959 until 1995.

title: High-Profile Partners Pitch Tents in Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia Sept. 25 -- Samsung Electronics believes in the Olympics, in the brand, the logo and the prestige it expects to receive from investing heavily in them. The Korean company is paying $55 million as one of the International Olympic Committee's 11 worldwide sponsors, and is persuaded that the connection will further propel its cellular phone business into world leadership.

title: All in the Family
description: I agree with Andrew Sullivan (Counter Culture, Sept. 3). It is unfortunate that our choice for president this year is between two candidates who come from political families. But to me, this is a coincidence and nothing especially portentous. In my lifetime, there have been 11 presidents: Roosevelt, Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter, Reagan, Bush and Clinton. Only Roosevelt, Kennedy and Bush came from political families. The others were all self-made men; indeed, most came from humble origins -- most notably, Bill Clinton.

title: New Rochelle Studying Report on Ikea Impact
description: FOR more than a year now, while factory owners, residents and parishioners of two churches wondered if they would lose their property to make way for an Ikea furniture store, city leaders here have kept their opinions on the project to themselves.

title: On The Ropes; And in This Corner Office . . .
description: Boxing is pain, and that's even before anybody starts punching you. I knew that before I started. But I was tired of being who I was, all soft and gooey and runny both inside and out. At first, it was really hard. I thought I was going to pass a lung through my nose. The only question was whether I should throw up before or after I fainted. Now it's different. One hour. No rest. As I stand there at the end of each class, heaving and trembling, little red lights dancing before my eyes, I know I'm going to make it all the way to the top of this lousy game called life. If it kills me, the hell with it. I'll go out a man.

title: Using Music to Topple Walls for Jailed Youths
description: PAUL THOMPSON does not envision himself as a hip-hop version of a catcher in the rye. Rather, he just hopes to help create the epiphanies and sense of possibilities that saved his own skin, when he was a troubled boy running the streets of Harlem and the pregentrified Upper West Side.

title: Listeners Help Keep Public Radio Alive
description: WHATEVER the vagaries of Congressional financing, public radio stations on Long Island are thriving, thanks to support from universities and listeners attracted to their niche programming.

title: Virginia Cornish, Donald Rollock
description: Virginia Wood Cornish, an assistant professor, and Donald Terrence Rollock, an assistant district attorney, were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert C. Wright, an Episcopal priest, at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: Sept. 17-23; Quitting While He's Ahead
description: When he was appointed the top antitrust cop at the Justice Department, Joel Klein was sharply criticized for being too soft, particularly on telecommunications mergers.

title: Gore Takes an Approach Both Risky and Calculated
description: They are bad. Really bad. Malevolent even. And not just bad. They are big. Big and bad, like those nightmarish, saw-toothed meanies that lurk beneath the bed.

title: From the Metropolitan, Truly Rare Recordings: Historic, Live and Legal
description: IT used to be hard for opera fans to find recordings of historic live performances on commercial labels. No longer. As record companies continue to flood the market, live opera recordings from the past turn up in all the larger record stores. Some hold historical interest for more than musical reasons: a recently issued recording of Wilhelm Furtwangler conducting Wagner's ''Meistersinger von Nurnberg'' at the Bayreuth Festival in 1943 on the Arkadia label, for example, a fascinating relic of Nazi Germany. Others are nothing special, just routine nights at important opera houses that record companies stumble on and release, hoping that susceptible buffs will buy them anyway.

title: Neighbors and Kin Join as Cast
description: FOR a community theater, the Bergen County Players, who perform in the Little Firehouse Theater in Oradell, have an unusually close-knit membership. The group has become a second home to many of the 350 members and long-lasting personal, and professional relationships are common. In some cases entire families participate in productions.

title: 1936, Stored in Stone, Is Relived at Brooklyn College
description: The year was 1936, and President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, along with 7,500 guests, had turned out to lay a cornerstone at Brooklyn College, a W.P.A. project that was under construction on a graceful ivy-covered campus in the heart of Midwood.

title: Parents and Children Wait, But Not Exactly Patiently
description: THE bus had been late before, and Millie Ho of Stamford expected the problems to continue. So instead of her son, Norman, 8, standing around waiting every morning, she began driving him to Davenport Ridge Elementary School.

title: A Path to Defusing Anger Relies on Twists and Turns
description: Ariane Burgess is a labyrintista, she says, an artist who builds labyrinths according to ancient tradition. On a recent afternoon, she sat in the center of her latest creation, a labyrinth she and neighborhood children are building out of tree stumps and twigs in a vacant lot on 136th Street, and watched a bright green grasshopper jump across its wood chip floor.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture listing in the New Season issue on Sept. 10 misstated the dates of the exhibition ''Mies in America'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art. They are June 21 to Oct. 14, 2001.

title: Simcha Dancing: Beyond Hava Nagila. Way Beyond.
description: THE students march into Atara Serle's weekly dance class with their bodies itching to groove and their feet laced up in gym shoes. But for all their energy and grace, these dance students are not part of the nightclub set. For starters, there are no men allowed here; this mostly Orthodox Jewish troupe frowns upon men and women dancing together. Then there is the unusually modest attire: long skirts, loose fitting blouses, and wigs or hats, in accordance with Orthodox custom. To top it off, the music blaring from the stereo is not on any top hits list, except perhaps that of Hasidic rockers who croon Hebrew or Yiddish numbers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTTEL, BERTHA
description: MOTTEL-Bertha. Ten years. Still remembered. Love Geri

description: STIEBEL-Eric. On September 21, 2000 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Irene. Loving father of Gerald and his wife, Penelope. Adoring grandfather of Catherine Fiebach, Daniel & Hunter Stiebel. Services were held. Contributions in his memory may be made to UJA/Federation.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00: Encounter; Portrayal of the Artist
description: Our subject today is artistic suffering, and Malibu -- so bronze and sandy, so L.A. -- might seem like an odd place to muse on it. Yet as I sit in Ed Harris's lushly planted yard listening to him talk about Jackson Pollock, it seems quite logical that the story of New York bohemia would gravitate toward sunny California. As we know, there are no second acts in American lives. But for those whose first acts are artfully tormented, there is always a movie.

title: Restaurants Offer Music as an Entree
description: GUACAMOLE has more zip and a margarita more tang when accompanied by a mariachi band; veal Marsala and spaghetti Arabiata more savor when they are enjoyed in tandem with a Verdi aria; swordfish kebab and shrimp Marmaris seem more exotic when a belly dancer is also working her magic; even a quiet dinner takes on a new identity when there is more to come: a movie or show as part of the price.

title: For $28,000, You'll Get . . .
description: MICHELE HERNANDEZ sent a shock wave through college admissions offices across the country a few months ago when she announced her top price for advising a high school student through the college admission process: $28,000.

title: Dallas
description: After the sweltering summer (and this year's, with record-breaking heat, was no exception), Dallas comes alive in the fall when cooler temperatures and the State Fair of Texas arrive. The first state fair, in 1886, dazzled visitors with livestock shows, displays of fancy needlework and rides on flying-jennies (primitive carousels). More than 100 years later, Texas' rural roots will still be evident, with blue ribbons awarded for champion bulls, the finest handmade quilts and the best apple pie.

title: Nations Claim Breakthrough in Battle Against High Oil Prices
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 24  Rich nations claimed a breakthrough today in their battle against high oil prices after persuading several oil producing countries to join them in calling for cheaper crude. But their intensive campaign to stabilize commodity and currency markets awaited the verdict of traders Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the death of a Bronx high school student who had a heart ailment referred incorrectly in some editions to the semester in which Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said the boy was wrongly assigned to a physical education class. It was last spring, not this fall.

title: Move Over, Shecky
description: A WELL-MUSCLED young man, carried by guide wires, does five flips 10 feet up in the air before landing on the stage as fireworks spurt off around him. Stage left and right at the Trump Taj Mahal' s Mark Etess Arena, hard-bodied dancers of both sexes slither to the center in orange pod suits, reminiscent of characters in alien movies.

title: Driving, and Thriving, in the Dirt
description: BILLY PAUCH cringes in the passenger's seat. He is a cautious rider, and as another car approaches about 100 yards down the road in this rural Hunterdon County town, he says ''Oh, oh.''

title: The Nation; A Grunt as President? History Salutes a Few Good Men
description: MUCH has been made in the presidential campaign about Vice President Al Gore's stint with the Army in Vietnam, but one striking fact has gone largely unnoted: If elected, Mr. Gore would be the first president in a century to have served as an enlisted man and one of only four ever.

title: By Their Lycra You'll Know Them
description: THIS is a popular time of year to hit the road for long bike rides held to raise money for good causes or just to get cyclists together for a 100-mile spin. It's also a great time of year for a shorter bike trip, around the park or around the block. But the masses pass by on two wheels, don't believe they are all alike. There are several classes of bike rider. For those who care -- and there are people who spend their lives classifying birds or ferns, after all, so why not bicyclists? -- here is a field guide to the bicyclist.

title: WHITE PLAINS: DELAY FOR CENTER
description: Construction of a $125 million movie and retail project in White Plains has stalled because of financial problems in the movie theater industry. Loew's Cineplex has reported losses, and Tishman Speyer Properties, the developer, reported that it was encountering difficulties getting the project, called the Town Center, financed, Mayor Joseph M. Delfino told the Common Council on Monday. Tishman Speyer bought the 7.2-acre site in 1998 for $12.2 million. Elsa Brenner

title: Liberties; Tin Cup Couple
description: An opulent mansion drenched in sex and money, where business and bedroom adventures abound, the over-the-top saga of a twisted, dysfunctional family.

title: Streetscapes/Brian Merlis; An Amateur Historian With a Passion for Brooklyn
description: I'M kind of a renegade,'' the Brooklyn-born Brian Merlis says about his obsession -- an obsession with collecting that in the last 20 years has cost him $250,000 -- and his marriage. Mr. Merlis doesn't gamble, scuba dive or fly fighter planes. He is an amateur historian and a collector of photographs and artifacts who has apparently published more books on the history of his native borough than anyone else.

title: Joness Husband Named in Steroid Allegation
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Sept. 25 -- Marion Jones, trying to win five gold medals in track and field, ran into a major distraction today when her husband, the shot-putter C. J. Hunter, was identified by track and field's international governing body as having tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

title: French Mountain Biker Adds Gold to Resume
description: FAIRFIELD, Australia -- Miguel Martinez of France added a gold medal at the Olympics to the one he claimed three months ago at the mountain bike world championships.

title: No Fun Allowed, Experts Say; Obsessive Worry Chases a Fad on Wheels
description: There seems to be a law of contemporary life that goes something like this: any time too many people start having too much fun, they must be in danger of something. Especially if they include the kind of people who like Buzz Lightyear Band-Aids and toothpaste the flavor of bubble gum.

title: No Left Turn
description: The Right Moment

title: Rison Returns to Face Criminal Charges
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 23  Receiver Andre Rison, now with the Oakland Raiders after three seasons with the Kansas City Chiefs, returned to town Friday to take care of criminal charges against him.

title: Behind the Drama Lies Even More Drama
description: THE Sleep-Tite Pajama Factory is all aflutter. Besides union trouble (workers want a seven-and-a-half cent raise), there are a few romances brewing.

title: POSTINGS: Maps Pinpoint Problem Areas; Web Site on Environment
description: Prospective home buyers -- or anyone concerned about a neighborhood -- can now gain access through the Internet to government maps and documents pinpointing environmental problems and offering information about communities across the country.

title: Cone and Gooden Switching Spots Once Again
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre yesterday sent his beleaguered and aching veteran, David Cone, to the bullpen for the second time this season, likely ensuring that the pitcher would stay there for the rest of his devastating 2000 season.

title: 'Ghosts of the Titanic'

title: A Reunion of Playwrights Shaped in One Crucible
description: FOR the past 10 years, the Signature Theater Company, which devotes each of its seasons to the work of a single writer, has been home to many of the nation's leading playwrights, including Edward Albee, Arthur Miller and Maria Irene Fornes. This season, however, is something of a departure for the company; instead of featuring a single playwright, it has invited each of its past nine resident writers to submit a new play, with the goal of producing nine New York premieres over the next 20 months. Overseen by the artistic director James Houghton, the series officially began on Sept. 17, with the opening of ''A Lesson Before Dying'' by Romulus Linney (a related article is on Page 18). The next production, ''The Last of Thorntons,'' by Horton Foote, is to open in early December.

title: LOWER RATINGS
description: A lesson learned by NBC from lower-than-expected ratings for the Summer Olympics: five hours a day is too much. In four years, when NBC carries the Summer Games from Athens, a half-hour is likely to be cut, said Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports.

title: Andrea Stock, Richard Spaar
description: Andrea Lynn Stock, a daughter of Evelyn M. Stock and Dr. Howard F. Stock of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening in New Rochelle, N.Y., to Richard Thomas Spaar, the son of Carol Spaar and Ronald J. Spaar of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Sarah Brown, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Fountainhead, a caterer, with Rabbi Jerry Heller taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFER, MAX C.
description: KUPFER-Max C. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Sherman and Adele, Joan and Paul Ross. Cherished grandfather and great-gandfather. Services today, 2 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Sailing Captain, First-Time Olympian
description: When the burly captain of the United States sailing team marched into Olympic Stadium for the opening ceremony of the Sydney Games, it was another milestone in an unlikely journey. For at the not-so-tender age of 46, Magnus Liljedahl was in many ways far removed from Goteborg, Sweden, the coastal city where he was born.

title: Alone at the Top
description: Sanford I. Weill is alone at the top because he is ruthless, manipulative and unsentimental (Roger Lowenstein, Aug. 27). He gets the prize because, like Richard in ''Survivor,'' he believes it is all a game of strategy and alliances.

title: Whitewater Course Powered by ITT Pumps
description: ALL week, Olympic kayakers and canoeists have been barreling through churning waters, pitching into Class 5 and 6 rapids, avoiding boulders and other hazards as they race through whitewater. But while the challenges the athletes face are very real, the river is not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAY, MORRIS L.
description: RAY-Morris L. Age 87. Died September 11, 2000. Attorney and retailer for many years. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Diane and Linda; proud grandfather of Maya, Naomi, Justin and Nicholas. Appreciative father-in-law to Patrick Keeffe and Paul Schoenfeld. His strong spirit will live in our hearts forever-The Family. Donations to American Parkinson Disease Foundation.

title: Bargain Flights
description: To the Editor: To your recent list of low-cost European airlines (''Bargain Flights Within Europe'' Sept. 3), may I add the Spanish carrier Air Europa?

title: The Container Store Opens Its First New York Site
description: The Container Store will open its first store in the New York region next month at Westchester Avenue and Bloomingdale Road in White Plains.

title: Deported to Italy After a Guilty Plea
description: A FEW years ago, Romano Denaro was a corporate executive in Manhattan. Each evening he was driven home to Harrison, where he and his wife had three sons in private school and many friends. He liked playing golf and had season tickets to the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Edifice Rex
description: When it's time to put on a suit, a man with grown-up tastes wants impeccable architecture. Something new by Frank Gehry, perhaps?

title: Embracing Death With Full Dignity
description: FOR the playwright Romulus Linney, ''A Lesson Before Dying,'' his adaptation of Ernest J. Gaines's award-winning novel, is not just about racism. Set in Louisiana in 1948, the play tells the story of a guileless young black laborer who is wrongly convicted of murdering a white liquor store owner and sentenced to the electric chair. A black school teacher answers the pleas of the young man's godmother and shows him how to die with dignity.

title: Article 2000092493806945556 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: How Country Fields Offer Inspiration
description: If your fall garden seemed uninspiring this year, think about organizing its colors the way Mother Nature does. In the fall, country fields are full of Queen Anne's lace, wild asters and blue chicory, all sprouting cheek by jowl with brilliant yellow goldenrod. Waves of gold make a wondrous backdrop for the starry clumps of blue and white.

title: Political Briefing; Choosing a Legend, Of the Opposing Party
description: Among the races that could be especially important in determining control of the House of Representatives is the race in Florida's 22nd Congressional District. This is the Gold Coast district, stretching from Miami Beach to Palm Beach and chock full of retirees.

title: Peru's Deep-Rooted Spy System Could Outlast Promised Purge by Fujimori
description: Hoping to blunt the crisis that threatens to drive him from office, President Alberto K. Fujimori has promised to dismantle the powerful National Intelligence Service. But the spy agency has so thoroughly penetrated Peruvian government and society, experts and diplomats say, that a complete purge of the security system will be hard to carry out even if Mr. Fujimori really means what he says.

title: A Shortage of Parking Spaces Plagues the County's High Schools
description: FOR Evan Dunn, the morning commute is a pain. ''I wake up earlier and earlier to get a parking spot,'' he said.

title: INTERVIEW; Michael Chabon: Comics Came First
description: Michael CHABON claims to read comics only for ''research'' these days, but he talks with a revealing passion about his favorite comic book artist, Jack Kirby, the creator of Captain America and the Incredible Hulk -- superheroes with notably human characteristics and frailties. ''He's truly the Shakespeare or Cervantes of comic books,'' Chabon says. Chabon, who is 37, had hoped to interview Kirby while he was preparing to write about the golden age of comic books in his third novel, ''The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay,'' but Kirby died just as Chabon was starting work.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00: Salient facts: School Lunches; Hamburger Helper
description: NO MORE MYSTERY MEAT

title: The Right Stuffers
description: Last year, Jimmy Choo came out with million-dollar diamond-studded shoes, and now shoe fanciers can buy equally extravagant shoe stuffers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Open House By Elizabeth Berg. Random House, $23.95.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WAITING, by Ha Jin. (Vintage International, $13.) This novel, which won a National Book Award in 1999, is about a Chinese Army doctor and a nurse who are forced to postpone their marriage for 18 years, the legal time period required before he can divorce without his spouse's consent. Ha Jin ''generously provides a dual education: a crash course in Chinese society during and since the Cultural Revolution, and a more leisurely but nonetheless compelling exploration of the less exotic terrain that is the human heart,'' Francine Prose said here.

title: All in the Family
description: When you boil down all the ersatz news commentary and talking-head punditry, what remains is Sullivan's revealing, embarrassing and downright accurate analysis of this year's campaign season. However, he ought to have mentioned Bill Clinton, who could beat either of the two pampered pretenders to the throne in a landslide.

title: Show and Tell; Double Shift Times Six
description: ''Baby, the wheel turns slowly,'' my grandmother used to say, ''but it does turn.'' Which is why I'm here, spending a particularly gloomy and humid August day in 20-below conditions in downtown Detroit. That is no misprint -- 20 degrees below 0 -- because I'm working in the freezer of the Melody Farms dairy.

title: Lives; Clean Start
description: BeforeSince I was 15, I've saved all kinds of stuff: bureau handles, small bottles, marbles, mirrors, nuts, screws, wire, cord, bathtub stoppers, mothballs, empty cigarette packs, frying pans, pencils that say different things on them, trusses, parking tickets. In 1997, my brother Harry, with whom I lived, slipped on some of my papers and got brought to a nursing home. The social worker wouldn't let him come back unless I got rid of my collections. So I bought a bus pass and visited him once a week. He died last year at 85. If he'd had a hobby like me, he might have lived longer. I liked living in my junk, and I always knew where everything was. In the living room, the junk came up to about my chest. In the bedroom, it wasn't too bad; it just came up to my knees. I made paths to get around. It made me feel important. But I guess I overdid it. The landlord wanted me to get rid of my junk. A third of my neighbors wouldn't talk to me. I suspected I might get evicted. So this summer I had to let my junk go.

title: Fashionable Tune
description: An ear for music and an eye for clothes made the week move along quickly.

title: Polly Pratt, Stephen Boeschenstein
description: Parnell Anne Pratt, the daughter of Nancy and Keith Pratt of Duxbury, Mass., was married yesterday at the Pilgrim Church there to Stephen Scott Boeschenstein, a son of Josephine and William Boeschenstein of Perrysburg, Ohio. The Rev. Kenneth C. Landall, a Congregational minister, officiated at the ceremony, with the Rev. Joseph F. Mozer Jr., a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Erica Youngren, Craig Abruzzo
description: Erica Leslie Youngren, a daughter of Dr. Virginia Rotan Youngren and Dr. William T. H. Youngren of West Newton, Mass., was married yesterday to Craig Thomas Abruzzo, a son of Rose Abruzzo of Farmington, Conn., and Anthony Abruzzo of Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Edward Anderson performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, WILLIAM CLARKSON
description: IRVING-William Clarkson, 63. On September 9, 2000. Devoted high school teacher. Husband of Claire Hodupp Irving. Son of the late James E. and Cecile M. Irving. title: Estate of the Nation
description: While not all fortunes are the result of thrift and industry, a lack of these two virtues most surely destroys them (The Way We Live Now: Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., Sept. 3). If it is equality of opportunity that Aldrich desires, he need look no further than his family's fortune, which was diminished by human nature rather than by the strong arm of the government. If he believes that it would be better for the American public to inherit every fortune, he lacks both understanding and a sense of humor. For while the American public's voracious appetite for unearned goods and services could make quick work of the largest of fortunes, the result is far less entertaining than hearing that a lady blew it all for a Hungarian count or that a man was disowned by his own mother.

title: Diary: Seeing the Future in a Surge in Patents?
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has been bursting at the seams with ideas for products and innovations, in a way that is reminiscent of the early part of the last century, according to a Merrill Lynch study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACOVELLI, PEARL
description: IACOVELLI-Pearl. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Pearl Iacovelli, associated with The Times from 1981 until 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, RALPH W.
description: TUCKER-Ralph W., 56. Died on Feb. 26, 2000, at Mt. Sinai Hospital of complications of multiple myeloma. A free-lance writer, director and producer of industrial films, he learned film-making at the Army Pictorial Center in Astoria after a year's tour of duty in Vietnam. He was born in Bradenton, Fla, graduated from Maryville College in Tennessee, and lived all over the U.S. and in Europe and Asia before settling in New York in 1967. Tucker worked in New York and the U.S. on hundreds of sponsored theatrical films, prizewinning corporate videos, multimedia shows & business theater. Abroad he worked for the Truk Red Cross in Chuuk, Micronesia, and for the Association Internationale des Etudiants en Sciences Economiques et Commerciales. Among his personal works in progress when he fell ill were a play based on Huckleberry Finn, a science-fiction novel and a photojournalism book about the great harbor explosion in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He had planned to begin a book called ''Spine'' about his adventures as a multiple-myeloma patient. The New York Women in Film and Television screenplay reading committee staged a reading, on February 28 at the Cherry Lane Theatre, of ''The History of an Unremarkable Life.'' The play, based on the novel ''Ships That Pass in the Night'' by Beatrice Harraden, was written by Tucker and Heather M. Winters and directed by John Steber. Tucker is survived by his wife, Helen Anne Easterly, and son, Guy, both of New York; his parents, LTC (Ret.) Walter F. and Roberta P. Tucker of St. Petersburg; a sister, BethAnn of Atlanta; and two brothers, Kenneth of St. Petersburg and Robert of Anchorage.

description: The people of Yugoslavia will vote on Sunday in what everyone agrees is a watershed election for the future of President Slobodan Milosevic, who trails his main challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, in the opinion polls.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23  Barring an incredible comeback in the next week, the Los Angeles Dodgers' streak without a postseason victory is about to reach 12 years.

title: The Harley Culture, Reshaped
description: AS most every marketing student knows, Harley-Davidson sets the standard in consumer loyalty. Its devoted customers tattoo Harley's logo on their flesh. Has anyone ever seen a bicep embossed with Coca-Cola's logo?

description: Louise Ramona Kuo and Ronald Joseph Habakus are to be married today by the Rev. David Henderson at the Woodside Village Church in Woodside, Calif.

title: How Black Comedy Got the Last Laugh
description: I enjoyed Lynn Hirschberg's profile of Chris Tucker. Here's a guy who tries to define himself without referring to his skin color, but your writer wouldn't let him. Had Jim Carrey or Greg Kinnear decided to take the same career track (no agent, picky about parts), he would be described as daring and revolutionary, not ''nave and lucky.''

title: Watch Emeril, but Learn to Cook in a Class
description: VICKI CAPARULO, a petite chef with close-cropped hair and the images of a fried egg and slice of bacon painted on the tips of her clogs, stood at the counter, ready to begin. She was about to make a meal for an audience of 18, including me, expounding on the theme ''No-Cook Summer Sauces for Pasta.'' Before the night was over, students in the cooking class would learn seven different sauces, from a puttanesca to a citrusy lemon-pepper shrimp sauce.

title: The Gender Gap; A Lingerie Buyer's Guide
description: 1. If you don't know the size of her bra cup, think of a comparable fruit. One New York lingerie-shop owner equates lemons with A, oranges with B, grapefruit with C and melons with D or DD.

description: It looked dicey this summer for a towering 205-year-old tulip tree at 11 Oceanview Place that a builder planned to remove to make way for two new homes. But then D. J. Donnelly, a 40-year-old caterer who lives on the block, started a campaign to save the tree, one of the largest on Staten Island.

title: Estate of the Nation
description: After extracting the essence of an upper-crust upbringing (Harvard, sailboats), Aldrich cheers the estate tax as a pillar of equal opportunity. Clouding his personal finances in obscurity, however (''I am very far from poor''), he would be more convincing if he denied his own use of tax loopholes like real estate and family corporate trusts.

title: Clemens Limps Off, But Yanks Finally Win
description: When Roger Clemens limped off the field at the end of the fifth inning, the back of his bruised right thigh pounding from the ground ball he absorbed there in the third, he had given up seven runs and lost a 5-1 lead. The crushing blow was an upper-deck grand slam that he yielded to Billy McMillon, the Detroit Tigers' best minor-league player this year.

description: The County Department of Health has identified a gasoline discharge from the ground near Town Dock Road in New Rochelle, which is leaching into Long Island Sound from an undetermined source. The department said that the incident posed no public health threat but urged water users in the vicinity to avoid unnecessary contact with the water while gasoline is present. Elsa Brenner
