title: Style; Mr. Bubble
description: 'I have been one of the most misquoted, misinterpreted photographers,'' Melvin Sokolsky sighs, as he tells me the rather heartbreaking story of his career. As if to prove a point, he recalls, ''About six months ago someone told me that I had been fired from Brides magazine because I took a beautiful guy and shot him in bride's clothes for the cover, when I never even worked for Brides!'' (Too bad -- maybe that's just what Brides needed.) He did, however, shoot a lot for Harper's Bazaar in the 60's, creating unforgettable on-the-money images that are once again finding an audience. A New York show of his work can be seen through Sept. 30 at the Staley-Wise Gallery, and Melvin Sokolsky's ''Seeing Fashion'' was recently published by Arena Editions.

title: Introduction
description: The very different styles of two hot comedians, Chris Tucker and Chris Rock, sparked debate on ''blackness'' and audience appeal. Many readers connected Sandy Weill's deft elimination of competition to TV's ''Survivor.'' And Nelson Aldrich's airing of family laundry drew comment.

title: Area Dress Code
description: As New Yorkers grapple with area code angst, worrying about who is worthy of (212) and who gets stuck with (646), Brooklynites are defiantly wearing their area code (718) on their chests. In recent weeks, borough pride T-shirts have become fashionable in Brooklyn's Cobble Hill, and ''718'' T-shirts, shown on models ($16, from Refinery, at 254 Smith Street), are now as much a part of the local landscape as Razor scooters and Mr. Softee. As temperatures creep downward, the store's owners, Suzanne Bagdade and Andrew Raible, are adding long-sleeved T's ($20), and next month they hope to have sweat shirts, too.

title: A Life in Music, From Bond Films to 'Dances With Wolves'
description: THE man sitting in the comfortable, plush chair was dressed in black. His graying hair was longish, and when he smiled there was a knowing twinkle in his eyes. Behind him in the large room was a complete view of the bay and a table overflowing with framed photos spanning numerous decades. Though British, he has made his home in Oyster Bay for some 20 years.

title: The Widow Peaks
description: There comes a moment during the concert when Yoko Ono throws the audience an appraising look over her jumbo blue rimless glasses. She's a woman of 67 -- hard to believe as she strips off a tailored jacket to reveal arms absent of extra flesh and thighs wrapped in tight denim. This is not her crowd. It's not even a crowd that belongs to DJ Spooky or Thurston Moore, Sonic Youth's Pied Piper of experimental rock, up there on stage to give her context. A frumpled dot-com type is reaching for his P.D.A. and muttering, ''I don't think I've ever met a Yoko Ono fan.'' They've come for Stereolab, which is next on the jazz festival bill at Battery Park this summer night.

It is about a royal hero's very long, spooky and supernatural voyage home. It takes 10 years but he's been away for 20, having served with glory as a warrior and a general for the first 10.

title: Alone at the Top
description: Sandy Weill follows in the footsteps of great American entrepreneurs like Carnegie, Mellon and Rockefeller. The Sandy Weill you depicted is not the man I know and have collaborated with on numerous business projects and not-for-profit undertakings for 25 years. He is a talented and creative business partner of great integrity and a committed philanthropist.

title: CANDIDATES BACK 'SOFT MONEY' BAN IN NEW YORK RACE

Lazio reached a tentative agreement yesterday to forgo the use of millions of dollars in soft money for advertising in the New York Senate race. But the deal included several conditions and provisions that could derail it and came just a day after talks on a similar proposal collapsed.

title: PULSE; Wit, at No Extra Charge
description: At A Girl's Habit, a vintage clothing store, designer togs come with price tags that make customers chortle. It's not that the fashions bear ridiculously high prices -- a gray Hermes blouse from the 70's sells for $275 -- but that the prices are paired with quips. ''It's Courreges so it has to be expensive, $145,'' reads the tag on a mod dress from the late 60's. On a couple of vintage T-shirts emblazoned with a Barbie doll's face, the tags exclaim: ''Can you believe I found two Barbie shirts?'' Ellen Koenigsberg opened A Girl's Habit (17 Bleeker Street) in July and started embellishing her price tags to entertain herself during the rainy summer days when business was barely a drizzle. More recently, fashionistas have made her store a destination, not for the sartorial wisecracks but for retro classics whose provenance spans suburban Kmarts and designer ateliers. Seen browsing were Sally Singer, a Vogue editor; the pop star Natalie Merchant; and the designers Jill Stuart and Marc Jacobs, whose new secondary line, Marc, includes a well-worn denim vest and skirt not unlike the 70's pieces in Ms. Koenigsberg's shop. DANA DICKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSYTH, BENJAMIN
description: FORSYTH-Benjamin, 94. Died peacefully at home September 22, 2000. He came from revolutionary Russia and led a fruitful life in Brooklyn with his soulmate and wife of 60 years, the late Emma Forsyth. He was gentle, compassionate, generous and eloquent in word and deed. He was a civil engineer for 40 years with Ammann & Whitney and published books on reinforced concrete design. His exemplary soul will be sorely missed by his three children, their spouses and children: Barbara, Michael, Daniel, Jeremy and wife Michelle Haas; Louise Forsyth and Howard, Leonora and Micaela Stein; David, Stephanie and Joshua Forsyth; by his devoted niece Dolora Lazko and his dear sisters and brothersin-law, nieces and nephews, and friends. Contributions in his honor may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union. The family will sit shiva Sunday evening, all day Monday and Tuesday, at 184 Terrace Place, Brooklyn.

description: What do a rock star, a Treasury secretary and the pope have in common? Well, not their wardrobes. But even in his black garb and dark glasses, Bono, the singer of the Irish band U2, fit in philosophically with Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and a bevy of legislators as they pushed for foreign debt relief last week.

title: Alone at the Top
description: If Sandy Weill were cast on ''Survivor,'' he would win not only the million dollars but also CBS and all the affiliates.

title: PULSE; Spin to Spin
description: For fashion publicists and other spin masters, the latest hit promotional device is the custom-produced CD. Hugo Boss sent out house and jungle dance remixes to commemorate its fall-winter 2000 runway show, and Fashion Targets Breast Cancer raises money from sales of a disc inspired by music heard on European runways. The Boutique Hotel Group, which owns the Shoreham, the Roger Williams and other properties popular with trendsetters, gives away ''Salute to a Century of Jazz.'' The TriBeCa Grand Hotel offers guests ''Fresh Sounds From TriBeCa,'' with DJ Spooky and Sex Mob.

title: Listings; Must-Wear TV
description: ''Why?'' you might be asking yourself, in between bites of your bagel with low-fat cream cheese. ''Why is a television writer being asked to comment on the new fall fashion trends?'' My thoughts exactly. But rather than pass on the chance of having my name in The New York Times, I got to thinking: fashion and television -- are they really that different? They both start their new season in the fall, and then, a year later, the once-promising ideas just look silly. Aren't those midcalf pants I wore last summer in the Hamptons exactly the same as those in that ''Shasta McNasty'' I saw last season on UPN? With two such huge businesses that both chase money and trends, how long till they find each other and actually merge? If Tom Ford can create for the House of Gucci, it's not terribly far-fetched that he could create for the House of Disney. Isn't it just a matter of time till the new fall line and the new fall lineup merge into one big moneymaking, trendsetting fall season?

title: Ivy League Fever

It was early on a September morning, and Ms. Gill, seated at the desk in her spacious Dobbs Ferry office and clad in a dark business suit, could have been mistaken for a high-powered lawyer or consultant besieged with clients.

title: Williamsburg Rethinks History
description: TO begin, a confession: Mobcaps embarrass me. When I visit a restored house, an interpreter in historical costume makes my heart sink. The hair and makeup are modern, the shoes are usually all wrong; the interpreter looks uncomfortable and I feel doubly so. On the other hand, an old building furnished as it was originally is one of the best windows into the past that I know.

title: Penn State Demolished As Ohio State Rumbles
description: In terms of point differential, today's loss to Ohio State was the worst defeat in Joe Paterno's 35 years as head coach of Penn State. In terms of overall record, the Nittany Lions' mark of 1-4 represents the worst start of any Penn State season since Paterno took over from Rip Engle in 1966.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHEIM, LEONARD H., JR.
description: BERNHEIM-Leonard H., Jr. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services note with great sorrow the passing of Leonard Bernheim, Jr., a vice president of JBFCS. For more than 30 years Leonard had been a devoted trustee and leader of JBFCS and for many years a chair of its Investment Committee. Leonard's dedication to community service followed in the footsteps of his parents, Leonard and Elinor, who were leaders of the Jewish Family Service, a predecessor agency of JBFCS, and the New York community. His commitment to helping troubled adolescents, most recently as co-chair of our Youth Counseling League Divisional Committee, and his earlier chairmanship of the Westside School, has been critical to the agency's expansion and enhancement of services. His diligence as vice chair of the Budget and Finance Committee has ensured a level of fiscal responsibility and foresight that keeps the agency at the forefront of the mental health profession. His co-chairmanship of the Capital Campaign protects the agency's financial strength and sustains its ability to provide the highest quality of services. Leonard's gentle manner, strong commitment, generosity and firm belief in the agency's responsibility to serve all those who need our help was respected by board and staff alike. His legacy will continue to inspire us and he will be missed. Leonard loved his family dearly and we offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Stephanie, his daughters, Erica and Claudia, and her husband, Leo Raphaely, his brother, Charles, and his entire family. Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President

title: The View From/Mystic; For Historical Society, Good Old Days Are Now
description: IN Mystic in the 1840's, the general store carried all sorts of things, including flour (3 cents a pound), gin (6 cents a pint), green paint (17 cents a pound) and red flannel (40 cents a yard). Sometimes people paid cash, but often they bartered goods and services. They could get a penny in credit for each egg they brought in, or tar some sled runners for 12 cents.

title: Kristina Skeffington, Khalil Shalabi

Victor P. Kennedy performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Personal Approach in Paris
description: The news of Alain Ducasse's stumbling entrance in the New York restaurant business has been arriving by e-mail and fax to no slight amusement at the leading restaurants back in Paris, his base. Chefs and restaurant owners there are fully familiar with how, at the restaurant bearing his name, Mr. Ducasse has presumed to charge proud New Yorkers far more ($700-plus for two) than any other place in town while seldom making an appearance himself.

title: The Case of the Phantom Sales Logged by Mitsubishi Managers
description: IN recent years, it has sometimes seemed that if it wasn't for bad news, there would be little news at all for Mitsubishi. For several years, the company was dogged by complaints of sexual harassment in its Normal, Ill., assembly plant. In 1998, the president of the Japanese parent company resigned over illegal payments to gangsters. His successor, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, announced his resignation this month after the company was embarrassed by reports that it had concealed customer complaints for two decades.

title: South Korea Starts Work on Rail Link to the North
description: IMJINGAK South Korea, Monday, Sept. 18  In the latest sign of improving relations between North and South Korea, workers began rebuilding a railway line across the two nations' border today to connect the Korean capitals for the first time in more than 50 years.

description: And here are some responses from , a New York Times online knowledge network, to Lynn Hirschberg's article on the new generation of black comedians.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Decision Nears on Much-Debated Mall at Oyster Bay
description: WHEN the last speaker sat down sometime after 4 a.m. on Sept. 8, ending one of the longest public hearings ever in the town of Oyster Bay, there was agreement on only this: the former Cerro Wire and Cable Company plant near Syosset was a blight and had to go.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; For Newark's South Ward, Homes on Vacant Lots
description: THEY number in the hundreds, the scattered vacant lots that like ugly bruises mar the streets of this city's South Ward, which sits in the shadow of Newark International Airport. But that situation may soon change.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYER, MURRAY P.
description: MEYER-Murray P. Sept. 21, 1986. Always in our hearts. Sadly missed. Lucille Ruby, Phyllis & Laurence

title: Often Revised
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case of the Missing Childhood
description: WHEN WE WERE ORPHANS

title: Management From the Sandbox
description: While negotiating the perilous rapids of the modern workplace, businesspeople have often turned for wisdom to venerable barbarians and connivers like Attila the Hun and Machiavelli. But all the while, it seems, trenchant job analysis, perceptive career guidance and sage financial advice have been available no farther away than the nearest child.

title: Hard Edges Veiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilmington Adapts After a Mainstay Cuts Back
description: WHEN the DuPont Company said in early 1999 that it was selling three of its buildings, about 10 percent of the city's office space, the announcement shook the community to its industrial foundations. But a vibrant economy has helped smooth the transition.

title: Give the Guests a Chef's Apron and Let the Cooking Begin
description: THERE are two ways to give a dinner party and do very little work. Catering is easy, if not always interesting. A more entertaining approach is to invite guests to come over and do the cooking themselves.

title: Look to Joint Tax Returns To Find Hidden Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Bureaucracy and Bitterness
description: One morning last week in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, a clamorous, winding line of more than a dozen people waited to use the telephone inside one of the city offices set up to serve poor people with AIDS.

title: Rebecca Bernstein, Eric Rubenstein
description: Rebecca Elyse Bernstein and Eric Michael Rubenstein are to be married today by Rabbi Henry M. Weiner at Metronome, a restaurant in New York.

title: Reviewing the Economy's Star Performer
description: After a rocky week of earnings warnings, spikes in the price of oil and a euro in intensive care, the economic data this week may focus the market's thinking on the juggernaut underpinning what has been an unsinkable economy: the consumer.

title: Bridging the Worlds Of Broadway and Jazz, Outside the Limelight
description: ORCHESTRATORS rarely receive marquee billing. Luther Henderson knows this as well as anyone. More than 25 Broadway musicals, a good many more television shows and untold numbers of club acts and recording sessions have used his distinctive talents for more than 50 years. Few ever acknowledged his name prominently. But that is the lot of the orchestrator-arranger who labors behind the scenes to construct instrumental settings that animate the music of others.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE HORSE FAIR

title: The Romance of Remorse
description: Country music, which has long coddled its elderly, now has in Emmylou Harris a better example of how to grow old gracefully (Daniel Menaker, Sept. 3). Compared with the thick paint, toupees and wobbly voices that have populated the Opry, Harris retains not only a dignified (and attractive) physical presence but also continues to experiment with her sound. She may not post big sales numbers, but she will remain an artistic force long after Shania's navel and Garth's hat are distant memories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JABLONSKY, SANDRA HYLE (NEE OSTFELD)
description: JABLONSKY-Sandra Hyle (nee Ostfeld). On September 20, 2000. Survived and always remembered for her strength, her beauty and her heart by husband Arnold, her cherished children Lisa and Gregg, her brother Michael and many loving friends.

title: Buying the Bank, Not Just the Banker
description: The $11 billion banker?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-23

title: Changing the Philanthropic Model
description: PHILADELPHIA elementary school students are learning grammar with software that listens and talks back. North Carolina parents are holding confidential chats with teachers about high school seniors online. And Texas school administrators are planning curriculums with the click of a mouse.

title: Dawn Langley Simmons, Flamboyant Writer, Dies at 77
description: Dawn Langley Simmons, an author whose tumultuous life included a sex change operation and an interracial marriage that scandalized her adopted hometown, Charleston, S.C., died on Sept. 18 at her daughter's home there. She was 77.

title: U.S. Makes Biggest, and the Final, Waves
description: Between the bodysuits and the 15 world records and the routine brilliance of two Dutch swimmers named Inge de Bruijn and Pieter van den Hoogenband, it was an unusual Olympic meet. But when it came down to the final two events of the final day, it ended as Olympic meets almost always end: with the Americans dominating the medley relays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHOLZ, EVA
description: TEICHOLZ-Eva. On September 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bruce. Loving mother of Debbie and Tom. Adoring and cherished grandmother of Yasmine, Shira and Natasha. Loved and beloved, she will stay in our hearts forever. Service Sun., 11:30 AM.at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam

title: Bronx Museum Plans to Renovate Old Space and Create a New One
description: A $55 million renovation plan for the Brooklyn Museum of Art was unveiled this week, but a much more modest museum in another borough is looking forward to an ambitious face-lift of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, IRVING
description: SILVERMAN-Irving. 78, passed away Sept 21,2000. He is survived by his loving wife Bunny and his son Andrew and daughter Ronnie.

title: Girl Talk
description: I KNOW JUST WHAT YOU MEAN The Power of Friendship in Women's Lives. By Ellen Goodman and Patricia O'Brien. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Allison Lister, Henry Boeckmann III
description: Allison Reeve Lister, the daughter of Joan Gibson Lister of New Canaan, Conn., and Stephen A. Lister of New York, was married yesterday to Henry Boeckmann III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Boeckmann Jr. of West Islip, N.Y. The Rev. Lidabell Lunt Pollard performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: Rookie Kicker Learning to Adjust
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 23  Sebastian Janikowski is a lone figure on the Oakland Raiders' practice field, well before the start of the afternoon workout.

title: Where All the Town's a Stage
description: AT Strawbery Banke in Portsmouth, N.H., costumed role players and interpreters encourage visitors to eavesdrop on three centuries of daily life, from the first settlement here in 1630 to the museum's foundation in 1958. The 1630 settlement took its name from the wild berries that grew along the banks of the Piscataqua River, but the settlers were less interested in the site's sylvan pleasures than in its economic possibilities. In 1653 Strawbery Banke changed its name to Portsmouth, trumpeting that ''We are at the river's mouth and our port is as good as any in the land.'' Today's Strawbery Banke, which calls itself an outdoor history museum, preserves the original spelling of the first settlement's name.

title: Don't Ask the Critics. Ask Wallace Roney's Peers.
description: THOSE who hear the trumpeter Wallace Roney at Birdland in Manhattan this week will experience the art of one of the musicians most responsible for the jazz renaissance that took off in the early 1980's. They will also hear one of the best band leaders in the music, for Mr. Roney has found a personal way of fusing his three major influences on composition, arranging and group playing -- Miles Davis, John Coltrane and Herbie Hancock, informed by the studying and the playing that he did with Ornette Coleman.

title: Sports of The Times; The New Face in the Yankees' Dugout
description: WHENEVER a television camera peeks into the Yankees' dugout now, there's a different pitching coach next to Joe Torre. While Mel Stottlemyre is on medical leave to receive stem-cell treatments for bone-marrow cancer, Billy Connors is sitting in the dugout next to the manager, staring out at whichever Yankee is on the mound.

title: Humbling Days for Top New Hampshire Court
description: The court clerk choked up as he recalled his agony of conscience. One justice called the last six months a nightmare. Another said the court was made up of five prima donnas. And today, a former justice who resigned amid scandal discussed the humiliation of his publicly torturous divorce.

title: Home Care
description: Thank you for the beautiful photo essay by Naomi Harris and Catherine Saint Louis (Lives, Aug. 27). The love and kindness -- even the sense of play -- between Chyd Denny and Sam Klein touched me deeply.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Preserving the Perishable Art of the Digital Age
description: MY films are in effect a kind of sculpture,'' says the artist and filmmaker Anthony McCall. ''They have everything to do with the cinematic apparatus, and are almost impossible to re-purpose.'' Thus Mr. McCall challenges art museums collecting his works: to preserve them for more than a few decades, we will have to do the impossible. Mr. McCall, who makes art on the Internet, was speaking about his 1973 ''A Line Describing a Cone,'' which was recently purchased by the Whitney Museum.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Not many men would turn down the chance to ford glacial rivers in hardy vehicles, explore vast lava fields, trek amid 100-foot waterfalls, angle for prize salmon and then sit nearly naked next to a beautiful blond ice princess in a steaming, mineral-rich geothermal pool. The collaborative artists Nicholas Kahn (right) and Richard Selesnick were no exception -- they had been eager to visit Iceland for some time. Although they had never done a fashion shoot before, the synergy was perfect: their work involves the construction of narratives in which they transform themselves and close friends into fictional characters to create pseudohistorical scenarios. The idea of two grown men playing dress-up and taking photographs for a fashion issue that deals with growing up seemed, well, ideal.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DON'T you just hate George Bush (pere) for turning ''a kinder, gentler America'' into a political joke? Henry Koster's HARVEY (1950) couldn't be kinder or gentler, even though it's about an alcoholic with mental problems James Stewart plays Elwood P. Dowd, of course, best friend of the title character, an invisible, martini-drinking 6-foot-3 1/2-inch-tall rabbit. (Harvey is seen by audiences only once, with is arm draped around Stewart in an oil portrait over the fireplace.) Josephine Hull won the best supporting actress Oscar for her role as Veta, Elwood's nervous older sister who tries to have him committed. Anyone who can sit through Stewart's alley-behind-the-bar speech and not feel a surge of warmth toward human kind in general is too cynical to live - Wednesday at 10:15 p.m. and Wednesday/Early Thursday at 4:45 a.m. on AMC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERWIN, LEE
description: ERWIN-Lee. On September 21, 2000. Born July 15, 1908. Originally from Huntsville, AL. Was famous for the Moon River program which originated at WLW Cincinnati and was on NBC Radio Network. In 1945 Mr. Erwin joined the CBS Music Department in New York, where he became organist, composer and arranger for the various Arthur Godfrey shows and played periodic stints on virtually every soap opera originating in New York. To thousands of movie fans, Lee Erwin is known for his extraordinary musical presentations accompanying silent films on the theater organ. He has composed new scores for more than 70 films: all of Keaton and Chaplin films, the D.W. Griffith masterpieces, the Valentino classics, many early Hitchcock silents, the Langdon and Lloyd comedies, all of the films of Douglas Fairbanks, Eric Von Stroheim, Mary Pickford, Greta Garbo, Lillian Gish and many others. He is survived by companion and partner Donald T. Schwing, brother Joseph Erwin, and sisters. He died on Thursday. Viewing to be held Tuesday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 141st and Convent Ave., New York City, 3-8 PM. Funeral services Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Hearing Is Scheduled On Rising Fuel Costs
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano will hold a public hearing Oct. 23 on the rising cost of fuel.

title: How Black Comedy Got the Last Laugh
description: Lynn Hirschberg's cover article (Sept. 3) was missing something: Chris Rock. (There was only a brief interview with Rock, one of the most politically astute and provocative comedians of his generation.) Chris Tucker may demonstrate how to get ahead in show business, but Chris Rock's humor and insight about relationships among and within the races places him solidly in the pantheon of black comedians.

title: Course in Water Safety
description: The Cross County chapter of the United States Power Squadron, an organization of boat owners that promotes safe boating, will offer a free eight-week course on water safety and basic sailing skills beginning on Oct. 4 at 7:30 p.m. at Mamaroneck High School. Topics will include how to read buoys and charts, how to use a depth sounder and which safety devices to have on board. Course information is available from Virginia Moore at (914) 963-9409.

title: There Are Some Answers To Family Court Quagmire
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MOTT HAVEN

title: Verona as Philadelphia, Shakespeare as an M.C.
description: ASK anyone to name the progenitors of hip-hop, and the name William Shakespeare isn't likely to spring to mind. But that may change on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where the choreographer and director Rennie Harris will unmask the Bard of Avon as a hip-hop M.C. steeped in street jive and well-versed in gang warfare and gangsta psychology.

title: With Election Fraud Feared, Kosovo Could Be the Key
description: With its Serbian population largely departed, and an Albanian population refusing to take part in Sunday's Yugoslav elections, Kosovo would seem unimportant in the battle for votes. Yet, in one of the Balkans' many ironies, the one part of Yugoslavia that the West controls may supply the swing that brings victory for the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Crime
description: When times are hard, people tell stories. Heads huddled on the sleeping porch, at the barber shop, around the kitchen table, they spin tall tales about the panther that chased a woman and her baby in a buckboard, the tornado that swept up Old Man Chandler in his outhouse, the Goat Man who snatches children who try to cross the Swinging Bridge -- wondrous yarns like the ones in THE BOTTOMS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $24.95), a pungent period mystery by Joe R. Lansdale that draws on the idiom of regional folk legend to filter the horror of race violence and serial murder in a small East Texas town during the Depression.

title: Giants at Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: What Else Is New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: In Praise of Public Life

title: Festival Draws Bards, Sonneteers and a Laureate
description: The attire ranged from athletic-coach casual to the flowing-skirts-with-hiking-boots look, with an occasional beret and silk scarf sighted. Grandmothers and pierced eyebrows were in equal abundance. There were blind poets with guide dogs, slouching young poets with infants asleep on their breasts, and everywhere, under almost every tree, someone writing in a hard-bound notebook -- poets in their natural habitat.

title: Playing Bumper Cars, With Real Cars
description: FOR the last nine years, Joe Reilly fixed cars instead of crashing them. And then, last month, his son, Joe Jr., found the car, a 1978 Cadillac Seville in slightly less than mint condition.

title: Where American Politics Becomes a Televised Sport
description: IN the second debate of his 1984 re-election campaign, Ronald Reagan was reminded by Henry Trewhitt, then the diplomatic correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, that he was ''already the oldest president in history.'' Mr. Trewhitt asked whether he had any doubts about his capacity to function effectively on little sleep during a national emergency like the Cuban missile crisis.

title: Latin American Bank Breaks New Ground With Technology Fund
description: LATIN AMERICA has never been known for homegrown mutual funds.

title: Food; A Taste for Seduction
description: My first writing jobs were for the David Frost and Dick Cavett talk shows -- which were extremely exciting because whatever I wrote was usually seen the very night I wrote it on national television. This instant gratification spoiled me. When I was, ahem, excused from the Cavett show and began to write plays and movies, there was either no feedback at all or it would dribble in months after the work was completed.

title: Australia Stuns U.S. With a Last-Second Score
description: Under the mirror-ball effect from the sudden flurry of flashbulbs in the aquatic center, beneath the thundering sound of the foot-stomping Australians erupting at the buzzer, the American Maureen O'Toole finally pulled herself out of the pool.

title: Thriving Despite AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Controversy Over Judging, and a Surprise U.S. Loss
description: In the Olympics, there is the quaint notion that the fight game can be domesticated -- headgear is worn, fights are short and savage knockouts are few -- but it is still boxing. And that means that sooner or later there will be a judging controversy and intrigue over scoring decisions.

title: A Night at the Movies, Day After Day
description: THERE is nothing quite like the feeling of walking into a dark movie theater enveloped by the scent of fresh popcorn, sitting in a plush chair and losing yourself in a film.

title: In Washington, More Than the Postcard View
description: EVERYBODY, smile. Hey, no funny faces, O.K.?'' The weary-looking dad raised a camera and struggled to get his shot: three squirmy grade schoolers in the foreground, the White House in the background.

title: REFERENDUM: NEW JAIL
description: The Board of Legislators has decided that the 84-year-old county jail in Valhalla should be replaced, and voters will be asked in November to approve a $59.5 million four-story penitentiary. The state has found the existing structure unfit and could force Westchester to improve it. The project would be financed through municipal bonds, but under the County Charter a bond issue exceeding $10 million must go before voters. The Board voted 16 to 1 in favor of the project, with James Maisano of New Rochelle the only dissenter. Mr. Maisano argued for more study of the project.

title: Tutor in Two-Wheel Independence
description: FIVE-YEAR-OLD Jake Vitale, balanced confidently on a two-wheeler, careened around a parking lot at the Greenville Elementary School here, nearly clipping his two older brothers as he raced by them.

title: Pamela Thurschwell, James Endersby
description: Dr. Pamela Nina Beth Thurschwell, the daughter of Charlotte and Hubert Thurschwell of Wynnewood, Pa., is to be married today to James John Endersby, a son of Elisabeth B. Escher of Hook Norton, England, and John C. Endersby of Sibford Gower, England. Adrian Wright, a superintendent registrar for the Cambridge District, is to officiate at the Royal Cambridge Hotel in Cambridge, England.

title: Quality-of-Life Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lineman at Harvard Finds Niche
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21  Mike Clare remembers when he was not allowed to play football.

title: Diversity and G.E.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAET, MIMI H.
description: SPAET-Mimi H. Regretfully passed away Thursday, September 21. Mother of Jonathan and Dorothy. Grandmother of L.J., Peter and Joshua. Loving sister of Helene. Service to be held at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Sunday, September 24 at 2 PM.

title: Habitats/Seventh Avenue and 24th Street; Giving Up an Empty Nest For a Perch in Manhattan
description: MORE often than not, people complain about real estate. Everything is too expensive or not good enough; brokers are duplicitous or uncaring. It's so common for even privileged New Yorkers to make whiny, ironic or cynical comments that it's surprising to hear Bill and Georgia Levis talk about their new place in Chelsea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACK, KATHERINE
description: BACK-Katherine, 88. Of Bronx, NY, on August 10, 2000. Former teacher, Board of Directors at Fordham Hill Oval Association. Survived by her nephew Robert Wald of Naples, FL. We will miss her enthusiasm for life and her wonderful sense of humor.

title: Metro-North Adds More Service
description: IN one of its largest service expansions in recent history, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's new fall schedule will add more than a dozen trains between Connecticut and New York in response to increased ridership throughout the New Haven line.

title: Torn Asunder
description: This House

title: Makeover; From Player to Prayer
description: The photojournalist Lisa Eisner, a fashion muse to everyone from Madonna to Tom Ford, specializes in capturing people with a strong individual look; people like Bishop Don Magic Juan. A pimp-turned-preacher who was featured in the Hughes brothers' documentary, ''American Pimp,'' the Bishop is the last word when it comes to what he calls ''pimp style'' -- highly coordinated ensembles of vibrant colors and satiny textures that have had an influence on fashion houses like Versace and Gucci.

title: As Indexes Fall, Some Musings on the Downside
description: AS the last week of the third quarter begins, the three major stock indexes are down for the year. And if they finish the quarter this way, it will be the first time since 1990 that all three have been down at this time of the year. So let's think some bearish thoughts.

title: President Offers His Take On Impeachment Reading
description: President Clinton said today during a visit to a bookstore that he had read books about his impeachment but did not plan to write one of his own.

title: Deborah Brown, Jefrey Pollock
description: Deborah Alyse Brown, the daughter of Gloria Brown and Dr. Ashley Brown of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Jefrey Ian Pollock, the son of Joy and Jay Pollock of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Tamara Miller officiated at the Daughters of the American Revolution Genealogical Library in Washington.

title: How Black Comedy Got the Last Laugh
description: These new comedians like Chris Tucker and Chris Rock are good and getting better, so good in fact that studio heads and network executives no longer see black -- they see green.

title: The Stiff Guy vs. the Dumb Guy
description: Alexis Boehmler is a junior studying English at Davidson College. At 20, she is bright and well versed, with strong views on the abortion issue and other political matters. Occasionally, friends tease her about her passion for literature; she recalls with some embarrassment speaking in class once about Don DeLillo's novel ''White Noise'' and being moved nearly to tears. Her opinions do not betray a hint of apathy or intellectual lethargy, and she has every intention of voting in November. And her primary news source -- often, her only news source -- is ''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,'' a parody.

title: Michael Parfit replies:
description: Charles Pellegrino wrote in ''Ghosts of the Titanic'' that life is one of the ''dominant conditions'' of the abyssal plains. I disagreed with that description. Now he argues that he was referring to life smaller than an aspirin. However, microbial life is present almost everywhere, including many deserts. In those places, as on the abyssal plains, life is not a dominant condition.

title: Campaign Memo; With the Soft-Money Issue, Lazio Becomes a Player
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio made no mention of campaign finance reform in his speech accepting the nomination as the Republican Senate candidate on May 30. In eight years in Congress, he was never closely identified with the issue, although he did vote on House bills advocating it. And he barely mentioned the subject until August, after two months of aggressive and fruitful fund-raising showed him catching up to his rival.

title: Preserving the Forest By Leasing the Trees
description: IT'S a hard sell.

title: Gillian Segal, Peter Lattman
description: Gillian Zoe Segal, the daughter of Leanor Segal and the stepdaughter of Alvin Segal of Montreal, was married there last evening to Peter Todd Lattman, a son of Ellen and Stanley Lattman of Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Barbara Borts officiated at the Chalet in Mont-Royal Park.

title: Mary Ellen Strawbridge, Francis Partel Jr.
description: Mary Ellen Burke Strawbridge and Francis Joseph Partel Jr. were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Ann W. Stevenson officiated.

title: N.R.A.'s Ads on Teams' Broadcasts Irk League
description: Listeners to the Washington Redskins' radio broadcasts this season on the flagship station WJFK-FM have heard a former Redskins great, defensive lineman Dave Butz, speaking on behalf of the National Rifle Association.

title: Homing In on a City Before You Go
description: A new Web site sponsored by the International Association of Convention and Visitor Bureaus provides links to the official Web sites of visitors bureaus and tourist boards of more than 1,000 cities in 27 countries.

title: An Invitation: 'Do Touch, Please'
description: BEFORE you enter the Garden State Discovery Museum in Cherry Hill, there is no need to give a stern lecture about how this building is full of items that are just to look at and not to touch. Here, you are invited and encouraged to look, touch, pick up and play.

title: One Government Site Has All the Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Those who want apply for a federal student loan, find the nearest veterans hospital, or reserve a campsite at a national park can find answers at a new one-stop government Web site.

title: Olympic Talk Show
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCUDI, RUTH
description: SCUDI-Ruth. Adored wife of the late Michael. Loving mother of Jane Dell and the late Gail Chadwick, and grandmother of Michael Chadwick. Passed on peacefully September 23. Rest in peace, Mommy. Jane

title: The Gender Gap; Getting Her Knickers in a Twist
description: When I first moved to New York I went out only with older women. My reasons were practical; everyone my age was wisely beginning college, so there weren't many peers to play with. The only women left on this campus of life were young divorcees or the hostesses at whatever restaurant that was about to fire me. Unfortunately, I never had enough money to take those few candidates to romantic dinners or to buy them little nothings. When I would pass Cafe des Artistes, I would feel nothing but shame. Pretty soon I stopped walking down West 67th Street altogether; a peripatetic waiter has no business being near such a place unless he's also a gigolo. I was an actor, with too much pride and not enough work, so my dates and I usually went Dutch at Beefsteak Charlie's.

title: So You Think You're the Hero Of Your Own Drama. They Do, Too.
description: When asked to describe ''Lifegame,'' the newest import from the Improbable Theater in London, the show's creators tend to use words like unfinished, imperfect and, most commonly, scary.

title: NEW FOOD INSPECTION PROGRAM
description: Responding to an increase in food-borne illnesses and the importation of food from abroad, the state has increased its safety efforts. A new law increases inspections and strengthens retail standards. As a result, supermarkets and other outlets will be subject to more rigorous inspection schedules and will be required to post their most recent inspection for the public to see. The law also requires each food store to post the results of its last inspection near each public entrance and to make these results available to the public upon request. Elsa Brenner

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROBERT L. CRANDALL; A Giver of Miles Wants Some Back
description: THE man who by many accounts was the most innovative, respected and controversial executive in modern aviation until his retirement in 1998 -- Robert L. Crandall -- is now re-entering the business from a new angle, tackling the fallout from one of his best-known brainchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUNE, GILBERT CHARLES
description: JUNE-Gilbert Charles. Passed away on September 20. Beloved husband of Joan and loving father of Athena. Services on Tuesday, September 26, at 10 AM, at McCall's Funeral Home, Bronx, NY.

title: Appeals Continue for 2 Convicted in 1991 Unrest
description: The violent images, the headlines and the public recriminations have faded, but the legal battles quietly continue long after the disturbances that rocked Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and took the life of a Hasidic scholar nine years ago.

title: Taking Care Working With Stone
description: WORKING with natural stone can be a rewarding experience because a project finished in stone has a rustic charm that is unmatched in any other building material. Stone is easy to work with because it requires minimal dressing and shaping, although gathering and positioning stones calls for a lot of muscle and sweat.

title: Road to Politics Ran Through a Texas Ballpark
description: For those who mock George W. Bush as a daddy's boy who slouched through life reaping the dividends of his name, the lovely Texas Rangers baseball stadium here is a useful rebuttal.

title: Parks Commissioner Takes Early Retirement
description: AFTER 35 years in public service, Salvatore A. DeSantis, who led efforts to protect the biodiversity of Westchester's nature preserves, is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOOS, GEORGE
description: FOOS-George. The family of Abercrombie & Fitch is deeply saddened at the loss of our friend and director. George was a truly unique and kind human being. He spent a great deal of his life helping others. His help to us was enormous and many of his values have become the values of A&F.

title: Eight Ways to Better Buying
description: With the autumn and winter wine buying season here, savvy New Yorkers can drink and entertain rewardingly every day for $20 a bottle and under. No city, foreign or domestic, matches the cosmos of wines found here. Though state law prevents New Yorkers from buying wine inexpensively in supermarkets, as Californians can, acute competition and widespread discounting can yield substantial savings.

title: The Rock That Gives New York Its Face
description: ON a quiet street in Morningside Heights lies one of the city's most amazing natural wonders: a rock as big as a whale pressed between the sides of two apartment buildings. Its bulk seems misplaced, as if an alien form had dropped into the tidy neighborhood between Broadway and Riverside Drive. But the rock has been there for hundreds of millions of years. If anything, the buildings are the interlopers.

title: Big Advance? No, Thanks, He'll Publish It Himself
description: BIG publishers dream about first-time authors like Benjamin R. Kaplan.

title: Tick-Borne Illnesses in West Nile's Shadow
description: EVERY year from May to October, thousands of state residents are infected with debilitating, potentially fatal tick-associated diseases. And although Lyme disease is the most well-known, there are other illnesses that have made a relatively new appearance in the state.

title: OFFICER WINS SEX BIAS CASE
description: A federal jury has awarded $2.3 million to a former police officer who sued Sleepy Hollow for sexual harassment, gender discrimination and retaliation. The former officer, Nancy Paolantonio, who joined the force in 1998, said she was subjected to lewd comments and forced to endure a different set of working conditions than her male counterparts. She was fired by the Village Board of Trustees a year later after her supervisors said she showed up drunk for work, a claim she denied. Mayor Philip Zegarelli said the village will appeal the ruling. Elsa Brenner

title: Decomposition 101
description: TIDELAND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCH, ROSE
description: BOCH-Rose. On September 21, 2000 peacefully at home. Beloved wife of the late Armand Boch. She is survived by her loving son Richard Boch of Manhattan, her sister Olga Brancard and her brother Andrew Krische. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, New York.

title: Back on Their Feet
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Murphy, Peter Shimamoto
description: Jane Owen Murphy, the daughter of Margaret Murphy of Manhattan and Eugene Murphy of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Peter Michael Shimamoto, a son of Alice and William Shimamoto of El Cerrito, Calif. Judge Betty E. Staton of Family Court in Brooklyn officiated with Judge Robert Merhige Jr., who is retired from the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.

title: Indonesian Police Report Arresting 25 Suspects in Jakarta Bombings
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -- The Indonesian police said today that they have arrested 25 people in connection with a recent series of bombings in Jakarta, including one that killed 15 people at the stock exchange.

title: If It's Off to Cheshire, Take a Hearty Appetite
description: BRIX in Cheshire inhabits the space (with the same ownership and chef) that once housed the Pavilion, but the proprietors Onella and Bernard Gayraud (he is also the chef) have changed the cuisine, menu and decor dramatically, evoking a more casual Mediterranean image, which seems to have taken hold very nicely. With good reason. The bright, stylishly mustard walls, parquet floor, Windsor-style chairs, banquettes and booths are a simple backdrop for some delicious, fresh-tasting food on a menu that also features a few pastas and pizzas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with a brief article about the use of recorded bird sounds in televised golf tournaments was published in error. It showed a house sparrow; the birds heard on the telecasts included white-throated sparrows and hermit thrushes.

title: Bogong Moths Set Upon Olympic Park
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 24 -- As television cameras high above Olympic Stadium pull back to reveal the magnificent panorama below, the first things viewers may notice is not athletes but moths. Millions of them, jammed almost wing-to-wing around the huge stadium lights, appearing to TV cameras like shimmering stars. They are Bogong moths, distracted from their southward migration through New South Wales to the Bogong region of Alpine National Park, near the Murray River in northern Victoria state. Along the way the moths will be guests of honor at the annual Mungabareena Ngan-Girra Festival, formerly known as the Bogong Moth Festival, where aboriginal Australians will fete their return and eat quite a few. There is even a Bogong Moth Hotel (for people) in Mount Beauty. Sydney's Olympic organizers consider the moths a pest -- plagues of Bogong months occasionally infest Sydney and Canberra -- and they find it necessary to announce at night baseball games that the huge moths are harmless. The massive lights at the Olympic Stadium are an even bigger temptation, and stadium managers will dim the field lights and turn off the external stadium lights at midnight rather than 3 a.m. to encourage the moths' departure. Jayne Pearce, a spokeswoman for the track and field events, said that no athletes had complained, but that the cleaning staff has been instructed to pay special attention to moth carcasses. "If they die they tend to create a bit of a mess," she said. Grown Bogong moths have two-inch wingspans, and they swoop down on startled fans, then rest on pant legs or shirts. Aborigines found the moths to be a reliable source of food, and they regularly gathered moths from the mountain caves southwest of here. The most common Bogong moth recipe includes roasting in heated sand and hot ashes, then sometimes grinding the bodies into a powder and making it into cakes. The walnut-flavored delicacy is available at the moth festival and at other aboriginal reunions. Variations include Bogong and popcorn (just what it sounds like). A Web page devoted to the moth festival includes this advice to backyard chefs: "A simpler way to roast Bogongs is on your barbie. Just put them on sticks...they do get a bit black, but they taste about the same."

title: Ewing Finally Takes Himself Out of the Blame Game
description: An open letter to a former Knick:

title: Rock Dreams, as Latte Steams
description: SOMETIMES, the true rebels are the quiet rebels.

title: Prime Times
description: Jamie Foxx, now starring in the film ''Bait,'' remembers it all, from his first set of wheels to the girl who made him a man.

title: A Model Festival for London. But for New York?
description: IT is the very model of a modern music festival,'' the conductor Andrew Davis pattered during the 72nd and last concert of the BBC Proms festival at the Royal Albert Hall here this month, offering no apologies to Gilbert and Sullivan and filling out the famous song with more doggerel celebrating the Proms. It was a parting tribute, for Sir Andrew was relinquishing the post he had held for 11 years, as chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the mainstay of the festival, to become music director of the Lyric Opera of Chicago. (Leonard Slatkin succeeds him at the BBC.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSEL, RALPH
description: CORSEL-Ralph. Passed away on Sunday, September 17, 2000. Surviving are his daughter Candy and his grandchildren Elise and Paul. Ralph's love of life was infectious and touched all that knew him. He will be greatly missed and his spirit lives on.

title: The New Might of Money Funds
description: One way for mutual fund investors to keep their heads above water this year has been to own a money market fund.

title: Pauline Golbin, Stefan Reyniak
description: Pauline Valerie Golbin, a dancer in the New York City Ballet, and Stefan Victor Reyniak, a venture capitalist, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan. The Rev. Alfredo Balinong performed the ceremony, at which Wynton Marsalis, a friend of the bride's, played the trumpet.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Our Towns; After Confinement in Two Kinds of Prisons, a Plea for Clemency
description: MUSCULAR dystrophy slowly makes its way through Terrence Stevens's body, shutting down muscle after muscle. But his continued imprisonment is equally contorting.

title: The World; A Man With Big Ideas, a Small Country . . . and Oil
description: HUGO CHAVEZ spent his first 18 months as president of Venezuela consolidating his power on the domestic front. Now, with the price of oil nearing $40 a barrel and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries scheduled to gather here this week for a conference of its heads of state, he is about to step out onto the world stage in a big way.

title: Abstracting The Meaning
description: IN the late 1950's, the Abstract Expressionist Adolph Gottlieb said, ''We are going to have perhaps a thousand years of nonrepresentational painting. . . . Abstraction is not a limitation but a liberation.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURACK, ABRAHAM W.
description: BURACK-Abraham W. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Bronxville, NY, passed away in New York City on September 22, 2000. Cherished and beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father to Herb and Donna. Father-in-law of Jodi. Future father-in-law of Sandy. Beloved grandfather to Ross and Jeffrey. Brother of Dorothy Jaffe. Loving friend to all. He will be missed for his guidance, wisdom, strength of character and diplomacy. Services on Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Shorter Term For President? The French Say Ho-Hum
description: At a rally for his own local party leaders this week, Frances Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, tried to whip up some enthusiasm for the referendum France is holding on Sunday to de- cide whether to cut the presidents term from seven to five years.

title: Gore's Surge Helps Raise Millions for Democratic Committee
description: Call him the $60 million man.

title: Sept. 17-23; A Billion Consumers Live In China -- Next Question?
description: In a major triumph for the Clinton administration and American business, the Senate cast a bipartisan vote to remove trade restraints and expand commerce with China, the world's most populous nation.

title: Health Insurance Program Comes to the County
description: Healthpass, an insurance program for small businesses that lets workers choose from 20 different health plans, will expand from New York City to Westchester on Oct. 1.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Drawn on Deadline
description: When Bill Gallo was recently asked how long it took him to draw a cartoon, he replied, ''Two hours and 40 years.'' DRAWING A CROWD: Bill Gallo's Greatest Sports Moments (Jonathan David, $35), written with Phil Cornell, a copy editor at The Daily News, is a celebration of those four decades, and Gallo's uncanny ability to render sports stories into insightful, single-frame drawings. Gallo's stylized truth-telling even got through to Muhammad Ali, who used a Gallo cartoon, depicting a corpulent Ali pushing his own stomach around in a wheelbarrow, as motivation to get back into shape. Because most of these cartoons were drawn as commentary on breaking news, the book has a vitality and anticipatory quality that makes each turn of page into something of a surprise: Who will break the single-season home run record, Mantle or Maris? In which round will Sonny Liston knock out Cassius Clay? Isn't the newly constructed Astrodome a wonder that rivals the Taj Mahal? Early in Gallo's career at The Daily News, the managing editor tried to make the young cartoonist conform to a precise, draftsman-like drawing style, which was totally out of character. A despondent Gallo soon asked to be taken off cartooning, but not before drawing one final piece, done in what would become his loose-lined, whimsical style. Gallo's superior saw it, and said, ''From now on, do it your way.'' The sports world is richer for it. Mark Levy

title: Letters
description: KANE AND WELLES

title: Joanne Baker, Andrew Jaffe
description: Dr. Joanne Clare Baker, a daughter of Susan and Peter H. Baker of Brixham, England, was married on Friday to Dr. Andrew Howard Jaffe, the son of Lynne and B. Edward Jaffe of Fort Lee, N.J. The couple, both astronomers at the University of California at Berkeley, were married by Freed Toor, a Universal Life minister, at the City Club in San Francisco.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Real Life, N.Y.P.D. Blue Has Soft Side
description: As a member of the F.B.I.'s Joint Terrorist Task Force for more than 15 years, Detective Thomas Corrigan of the New York City Police has interviewed many suspects in terrorism investigations.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. The Experience Music Project, or E.M.P., which opened last June, is a $240 million, 140,000-square-foot museum designed by Frank Gehry and conceived by Jody Allen Patton and her brother, Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen, who financed the project. Originally intended as a gallery dedicated to Jimi Hendrix, E.M.P. grew to include 80,000 artifacts, from rock memorabilia to a 30-foot sculpture made of over 500 guitars. It also contains interpretive and interactive exhibits that trace the history of rock and allow visitors to play instruments and mix their own music. As you might expect from a museum located in the heart of Microsoft country, its state-of-the-art computer wizardry required enough cable to wrap around the earth, according to the museum's Web site, www.emplive.com.

title: Clinton Makes Further Moves To Lower Cost Of Heating Oil
description: The Clinton administration took several additional steps today to cushion the oil market against shortages this winter and to soften the shock of higher prices on consumers. Like the temporary release of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, announced on Friday, the new measures are intended mainly to ease tight supplies of heating oil, President Clinton said.

title: The Nation: Crisis Management; There's No Shortage of Repositioning on Oil
description: WHEN the idea of tapping the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve was floated last winter, in the face of high home heating prices in the Northeast, no one was more skeptical than Vice President Al Gore. Oil-producing nations, he explained to a Massachusetts audience in February, could easily counter the move. ''All they would have to do is cut back a little bit on supply and they'd wipe out any impact from releasing oil from that reserve,'' Mr. Gore said.

title: Further Steps Taken To Lower Oil Prices
description: The administration took several more steps to cushion the oil market against shortages and to soften the shock of higher prices on consumers. President Clinton also directed the Department of Health and Human Services to release $400 million to help poor families buy fuel, a record allocation for the program.

title: Staying Connected, Even Aloft
description: BY the end of next year, airline passengers may be able to send and receive e-mail, trade stocks, surf the Internet and watch television -- using just one screen -- at 40,000 feet and 500 miles an hour.

title: Travails of the Tape
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Spotlight Magazine Bought by Martinelli Family
description: Spotlight magazine, which has a circulation of 64,000, will shift its focus from the broader metropolitan region to Westchester County and vicinity under new owners, the Martinelli family, who bought it last month from its founder, Susan Meadow Engel, for an undisclosed price.

title: Bookend; Prescribing 'Arrowsmith'
description: YOU can't pick up a newspaper today without feeling deluged by reports on miraculous medical discoveries. The authority of science is as much a part of our worldview as an even higher authority was for our grandparents. So intense is the belief in the medical profession's ability to cure our ills that it is striking to note it was only 75 years ago that a medical scientist first entered American literary consciousness in the exalted role of hero. Sinclair Lewis's 1925 novel, ''Arrowsmith,'' is the story of a physician's relentless search for truth. Unlike in other novels of this period or before it, the main character is no cleric, writer or philosopher. He is not even a particularly great doctor. Lewis, aware of the wide public interest in medical progress (not unlike our current fascination with all things genetic), introduced millions of readers to a young man who dedicates himself to the hottest field of his day: bacteriology.

title: Airport Amenity: DVD Rentals
description: AIR travelers, faced with a flight where the entertainment options consist of miniature pretzel packets and edited versions of movies that were bad to begin with, can now literally take matters into their own hands at some airports. InMotion Pictures offers rentals of portable DVD (digital video disk) players and movies to airline passengers.

title: Sticking to It, One Way or Another
description: BEAUTIFUL'' may be the title of the new movie that marks her debut as a film director, but it's not an adjective Sally Field has heard much during her 36-year career in Hollywood.

title: Born in Fame, Guitarist Finds His Own Career and His Own Sound
description: AS an infant, Murali Coryell lay in his baby basket, looking up wide-eyed as Jimi Hendrix peered down at him. A few months later Carlos Santana was bouncing the little boy on his lap, and on his 10th birthday Miles Davis gave him a $100 bill.

title: The Smith in the Shadow at G.M.
description: IT is an early September morning at the Four Seasons Hotel, and Manhattan's power brokers are back from their summer vacations, posturing over caffe lattes and toast in the hotel restaurant, bragging about their latest deals. Among them, in this cavernous I. M. Pei room, Michael T. Smith sits quietly, picking at an egg-white omelet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FAIRBANKS, DOUGLAS, JR.
description: FAIRBANKS-Douglas, Jr. A memorial service for Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. will be held Tuesday, September 26 at 2:00 pm at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St., NYC

title: Seeing the Future In a Surge in Patents?
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has been bursting at the seams with ideas for products and innovations, in a way that is reminiscent of the early part of the last century, according to a Merrill Lynch study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, HANS E.
description: GRUEN-Hans E. Age 74. Retired University of Saskatchewan, Professor of Biology, died suddenly and unexpectedly on September 7, 2000 at home in Saskatoon Canada. Survived by his sister Edith and brother Peter, both of New York City.

title: 'The Rocky Horror Picture Show,' With Dirndls
description: THE SETTING -- At the Ziegfeld Theater on Tuesday, girls in blue satin sashes tripped about, as if they were part of Fashion Week. There was a multitude of nuns, one in black cargo pants. A contingent from the Village Light Opera Group, a community troupe, had paper snowflakes stuck to their noses and eyelashes. Men tucked plastic sprigs of edelweiss (provided in a goody bag along with one of those confetti-spewing poppers) behind their ears.

title: Trips Halted as Ships Are Seized by Creditors
description: Six ships from Premier Cruise Lines abruptly halted service on Sept. 14 after they were seized by creditors, cutting short the vacations of about 2,800 passengers in ports from Halifax, Nova Scotia, to Nassau, the Bahamas, to Cozumel, Mexico.

title: Musing; The Seventh-Decade Stretch
description: After reaching 50, I was once told, a man loses an additional inch of his height for each succeeding decade of his life. The bearer of this nugglet of information was Carl Reiner, the protean actor and celebrated factoidologist.

title: Platinum to Rehab and Back
description: THERE'S a new stop on the standard rock career path. It comes after the lean years of barnstorming or singing at talent shows, after the big break, after the hit singles and platinum discs. It comes after the arena tours, the ballooming egos, the groupies and booze and drugs, after the affairs and bickering that shatter lifelong friendships, after the spectacular mishaps. It comes after the failed solo albums, after the lawsuits with ex-managers and ex-wives, after the stint in rehab.

title: Bush Courts Florida
description: A dead heat in Florida has the Bush camp being criticized as having taken winning for granted.

title: Fourth Hilton in China Opens in Dalian
description: Hilton has opened its fourth hotel in China, what will be a 372-room establishment in Dalian, the major northeastern port city 300 miles east of Beijing on Korea Bay. The 36-story hotel is in the Chang Jiang Commercial Complex, which includes an apartment building and an office tower, on the harbor.

title: At a Mall, Digging Dinosaur Facts
description: OUR 2-year-old daughter, Una, has been to malls and to museums, and she thinks she knows the difference. So she was puzzled when we pulled into the parking lot of the South Hills Mall in Poughkeepsie. ''That not a mooseeum,'' she insisted.

title: A Double Identity For Bucs
description: If you locked Keyshawn Johnson and Warren Sapp in a room together with only one microphone, who would get the first word and who would have the last one? When both are in the same locker room, both as Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Johnson holds court on one side, Sapp on the other. They often meet in the center, offering playful jabs, pushing buttons, creating a fun ruckus.

title: Indonesian Is Under Fire For Comments About Timor
description: The appointment of a little-known academic as Indonesia's new defense minister has raised widespread concerns both here and abroad not only because he has no experience in military affairs but also because of the statements he has made about East Timor.

title: 40 STATES FORFEIT HEALTH CARE FUNDS FOR POOR CHILDREN
description: Forty states will soon lose hundreds of millions of dollars of federal money that was supposed to provide health insurance to children in low-income families, federal and state officials say.

title: Off the Second-Home Bandwagon
description: ONE thing you can say about us baby boomers is that there sure are a lot of us. Some people say that's the only thing that makes us special, but I suspect that they are just sick of hearing about us. Still, when we lock onto a trend, we make it ours, whether it was having the children who are now packing our schools to bursting or, eventually, when we begin dying in droves. In life or death, we make an impact.

title: Saying Adieu, Finally, To a Few 'Monsters'
description: Two dozen ''green monsters,'' nearly half of which have been occupying sidewalk space in a landmark neighborhood for nearly two years, will soon be removed, some possibly within a month. The boxes house electronic and fiber optic equipment for Time Warner Cable.

title: What's Entertainment? That Depends...
description: REMEMBER what fun it was rushing Snowball to the vet after he gulped down a badminton birdie? Hey, you protest, that was not fun. Nevertheless, that's entertainment, according to the United States government.

title: Broadening the Base of Decision-Making
description: LEE OZLEY, co-author of ''More Than a Motorcycle,'' is an organizational consultant who has worked with Harley-Davidson since 1987.

title: Retail Therapy; All the King's Men
description: It's not always good to be king. Of course there are perks -- laurels, deference and a pretty nifty title. However, along with such high honors comes the grief -- eternal unrest among the subjects, challenges from the pretenders and endless acts of noblesse oblige. (In this case the royal labors include cleaning up fouled carpets, ministering to skittish princelings and mediating the generational squabbling that invariably attends the robing ceremony.) Yes, uneasy lies the crown upon the regal noggin of Gene Lubin, King of the Bar Mitzvah Suit.

title: A Pet Vacation Without Growls
description: THE classic image of a dog on a road trip, head out the car window, tongue lolling in the breeze, is due for a revision.

title: Buccaneer, or the Shareholder's Best Friend?
description: CARL C. ICAHN has been called a lot of names in his life.

title: Johnson Taunts, but Chrebet Has Final Word
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 24  One hour before today's game, Keyshawn Johnson and Wayne Chrebet stood little more than 10 yards apart, warming up side by side in silence, refusing even to meet each other's gaze. Chrebet wore headphones as he caught passes, the better to insulate himself from the final moments of a week of noise and needling he had taken from Johnson.

title: Here Comes The Bride, And Her Sponsors
description: WHEN Natasha Allen recalls her wedding, in a historic village outside Cincinnati last fall, she breathlessly describes arriving in a horse-drawn carriage, the way her satin gown trailed through the autumn leaves -- and the table at the reception with her sponsors' brochures laid out.

title: Alone at the Top
description: I am disappointed that you would choose to focus on a neurotic workaholic whose claim to fame is that he makes a lot of money and fires his close friends.

title: She Brings a Succulent Taste Of Jamaica to the Courthouse
description: Eric Warner, the lead prosecutor at the trial of Amadou Diallo, will be leaving the Bronx district attorney's office next month to become a partner at a Midtown Manhattan law firm. Last week, a friend sardonically asked him if he was going to miss Bronx cuisine.

title: Tough-minded Australian Pair Wins
description: BONDI BEACH, Australia, Sept. 25 -- Australia's Kerri Pottharst -- Potsy to her friends -- became a beach volleyball player for the most obvious reason of all. ``I loved to hang out at the beach,'' she said. Pottharst turned her cap backward, and played on, even through four knee surgeries. Natalie Cook, Pottharst's playing partner, tread an exacting path of a different sort -- occasionally across broken glass and 600-degree burning coals. Seeking a competitive edge, Cook recently sought out a ``success coach.'' It's the specialty of Kurek Ashley, an American who tutored Cook in various acts of daring-do, like walking on shattered glass and hot coals. ``It makes you believe the impossible isn't impossible,'' Cook said. And yet, for all their enterprise and empiricism, Pottharst and Cook were never more than second to the top-rated Brazilian beach volleyball combination of Shelda Bede and Adriana Behar. Pottsharst and Cook worked at the karma of the matchup, filling their team lodgings in the last month with dozens of things colored gold -- replica medals, goldfish, goblets, volleyballs and wall hangings. They bought gold toothpaste and gold shampoo. ``Our plan was to have this tidal wave of emotion and thought,'' Cook said. ``And to have it wash over the Brazilians.'' Today, surfers cruising Pacific Ocean whitecaps were visible through the portals of the makeshift Olympic beach volleyball grandstand that rises above shimmering Bondi Beach. On the sand below, Pottharst and Cook were riding a swell of their own. In a setting that could not have been more fitting of the 2000 Sydney Games -- as carefree as a day at the beach -- Australia hosted another perfect Olympic moment for itself. Before 10,000 fans, many waving Australian flags and wearing green and gold, Pottharst and Cook defeated Bede and Behar in the beach volleyball gold medal match. And the Australians did so in stunning fashion, winning the first two games of a planned best-of-three with late, startling rallies that left the home crowd delirious. When it was over, Pottharst lay face down in the sand for half a minute with Cook kneeling over her. ``I just lost it,'' said Pottharst, who at 35 years old is 10 years Cook's senior. ``I could not believe we had won. You dream of something forever and when it happens, sometimes it's too amazing to comprehend.'' Behar and a tearful Bede, who would later apologize to Brazilian fans for the loss, were also embracing at their end of the court. ``It was a great scene today, a great party,'' Behar, who won a beach volleyball gold medal with a different partner four years ago, later said. ``But you have to know the disappointment for us, too.'' For Pottharst and Cook, it was the culmination of an odd, four-year journey. Now the ``best of mates,'' according to Cook, they had split as playing partners after the 1996 Atlanta Olympics when they teamed to win a bronze medal. ``We're 10 years apart and it had become too much like big sister and little sister,'' Cook said. ``I needed to learn some things for myself.'' Reunited last year, they agreed to come together as equals. ``Though we still get on each other's nerves,'' Cook said. Pottharst brought her powerful serve, Cook a consistency in all areas and some fresher, younger legs. They needed both today, especially when the Brazilians took 10-6 leads in both games. The first team to 12 points wins. They won the first game, also called a set, when Cook's serve hit the top of the net and fell straight down. So a lucky break brought the first big ovation. Bede and Behar looked stunned, but took the same commanding 10-6 lead in the next game. Consecutive spikes by Cook cut Brazil's lead in half, and then with Pottharst serving, the Australians tied the game, 10-10. Pottharst was again serving at 11-10 when an awkward return by Bede shockingly fell wide of the sideline. Pottharst fell to her knees and buried her head. Earlier in the week, she had called the crowd of 10,000 distracting. ``I wasn't used to it,'' she said. ``We don't play before crowds like that. I wanted to say, `Would you all just shut up.''' But Pottharst and Cook came to embrace the crowd and its advantage. They included the fans as partners in their pursuit of the gold medal, a movement they called, ``The Dreamachine.'' As Pottharst lay in the sand in victory, Cook beside her, the ovation reverberated around the natural rock formation that protects Bondi Beach's radiant sandy shore. Suddenly, Pottharst jumped to her feet, never more at home, and threw handfuls of sand in the air. A few minutes later, hat still on backward, she addressed the crowd. ``I know it's a dream,'' Potsy said, ``but I'll remember this day for the rest of my life.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, SANDY
description: DAVIS-Sandy. Three years since you're gone. Miss you, love you. Always in our hearts. Mom, Dad and Family

title: Q & A
description: London's Fall Gardens

title: Commercial Property; An Up Cycle Just Keeps Rolling
description: OFFICE vacancies are approaching record lows and rental rates reaching record highs in Manhattan. Despite the demand, there is no speculative construction in the city, with the few buildings that are being constructed substantially preleased before a shovel went into the ground.

title: When Baby Makes Three, It Begins. When Does It End?
description: When I was a child I did not know that the circus had an intermission. The moment the break came in the show, my mother would stand up and say, ''Well, wasn't that wonderful?'' and sweep us toward the exit of Madison Square Garden faster than you could say ''Ringling, Barnum and Bailey.''

title: Teach the Children: Who Decides?
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Community Board Opposes Adding to Height; A Plan to Renovate an East Side Landmark
description: One of the last mansions built in Manhattan -- the 22-bedroom Loew House at 56 East 93rd Street, constructed in 1932 -- would receive an expanded fifth floor, a new sixth floor and a below-ground gymnasium under a renovation plan proposed by its new owner, the Spence School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILNER, JOSEPH H.
description: FILNER-Joseph H. Died June 28, in Columbia, MD. He is survived by his wife Doris Filner of Columbia, sons from his first marriage to Sarah Filner, Representative Bob Filner, (D) California, and Dr. Bernard Filner, step-daughter Nancy Stein and five grandchildren. He pioneered the stainless scrap industry. He was active in numerous progressive organizations, was an early supporter of M.L. King, Jr. and helped launch the SCLC. Donations may be made to the SCLC in Atlanta, GA.

title: Stamp Collectors' New Focus
description: AS the summer fades into fall, indoor activities become more important. And in this age of electronic addictions, many parents cast about for something to keep young fingers (and minds) occupied with something other than dot.coms and sitcoms.

title: The World; Rethinking Their Tired and Poor: A Swiss Proposal
description: SWISS voters will roll out the apparatus of direct democracy today and consider, alongside proposals on fuel taxes and voting procedures, whether to limit the resident foreign population to 18 percent. Sponsors of the bill point out that the current level is over 19 percent a 25 percent increase over the last 10 years. But opponents of the initiative, who appear to be in the majority, argue that it would undermine the Swiss economy and tarnish the countrys image abroad. Six similar initiatives have found their way to the bal-lot box since 1970. Each one has failed. But the 18 percent initiative, as it has come to be known, is particularly contentious because it would provide exceptions for highly educated foreigners involved in technological and scientific pursuits, leaving asylum seekers and poorer immigrants at the mercy of the new quota. Switzerland has one of the highest proportions of foreign residents in Europe. Here is a look at how the country compares with its neighbors, and where most of the new arrivals are coming from. TOM ZELLER

title: End-of-the-Season Dishes Made Easy With Corn and Tomatoes
description: THE calendar may say autumn, but summer lingers at produce stands. There's still time to enjoy fresh sweet corn and ripe tomatoes. And with them, the pungent seasoning provided by fresh cilantro is always welcome.

title: Reckonings; Wag the Dog
description: George W. Bush is still using the four-dollar routine in his public appearances -- the one where he pulls out four dollar bills to represent the projected budget surplus, then says that he plans to use only one of those bills, one-quarter of the surplus, for tax cuts. Anyone who has looked at his campaign's own numbers (or who read this column a week and a half ago) knows that this isn't right -- that the tax cut would actually use up more than a third of the surplus. But most commentators seem to think that this is a minor detail -- a quarter, a third, what's the difference? (About $450 billion, but who's counting?)
