title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, SEIBERT G.
description: ADAMS-Seibert G. Well known in the college textbook publishing industry, died on Wednesday September 20 in Sharon, Ct. He was 65. Born October 12, 1934 in New Haven, Ct., son of Seibert Gruber Adams and Norma M. Adams. He graduated from Yale University in 1957 and served as a lieutenant in the Air Force for three years. Shortly thereafter, he began his career of over thirty years in educational publishing. Mr. Adams was awarded the James Leisey Award by the higher education group of the Association of American Publishers in May of 1995 for his outstanding contribution to college publishing. He leaves his wife, Ruth Cahill Adams, two daughters, Sharon Adams Poore of Mass, Sheryl Adams of New York, four grandchildren and his four cats. His sense of humor will continue to inspire us. Memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Monday, September 25 at 6PM. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his name to The American Cancer Society.

title: Corrections

title: From a Broken Dream to a Gold Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 24  Six months ago, the platform diver Laura Wilkinson broke three toes on her right foot while training. With Olympic trials looming, she figured her dreams of Sydney fractured as well that day.

title: Basilicata
description: To the Editor: I have long awaited the time when travel writers would find the rugged beauty of the Basilicata region as the last of ''undiscovered'' Italy, and read with pleasure ''Basilicata, Rock Hard and Still Untamed,'' by Frederika Randall (Sept. 3). It is an area I have visited many times, as my parents migrated from there in 1930.

description: Kimberley Rose Izzo was married yesterday to Bradford Corcoran Emmet. The Rev. Nicholas G. Lang performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on the Green in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Taiwan and the Philippines Settle Yearlong Air Dispute
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Taiwan and the Philippines have settled an aviation dispute that had severed air links between them for nearly a year and agreed to resume flights by October, a Philippine official said Sunday. Rodolfo Reyes, executive director of Manila's de facto embassy in Taiwan, said both sides will sign a memorandum of understanding Monday allowing Taiwanese air carriers to fly passengers and cargo from Manila to third destinations. ``Our prayers have been answered. We just have to finalize the details, but everything has been resolved,'' Reyes said. Normally cordial relations between the countries turned sour when Manila scrapped the 1996 air pact with Taiwan, accusing Taiwanese carriers of unfair competition by flying passengers to third countries. Taiwan complained that by canceling the agreement, Manila ignored international procedures that call for a one-year warning before an air pact is terminated. The squabble has proved costly for the Philippines, where Taiwanese investment has dropped by 72 percent to $390,000 in the first quarter of the year, compared to the same time last year, Taiwan's Economy Ministry said. Both Taiwan's EVA Airways and Philippine Airlines will be able to resume flights by Oct. 10, but China Airlines will start flying only by the beginning of November, Reyes said. As part of the deal, each side will fly a maximum of 9,600 passengers weekly, a number stipulated under a 1996 air services agreement. The Philippines said the number was too high and unilaterally scrapped the agreement last October. ``In effect, we will be going back to the 1996 agreement, Reyes said.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Sept. 3, about bargain flights within Europe, misstated the location of Charleroi, Belgium. It is south of Brussels, not to the north.

title: Italian Cuisine in New Millwood Setting
description: PATRONS of the old Spaccarelli's, a shabby place in the A.&P. shopping strip here, have probably seen its brand new structure just around the corner. The restaurant has been reinvented as a contemporary spot, with gauzy curtains covering a sweep of glass on one wall and a honeycomb stacked with wine bottles on another. Subtle lighting and dusty rose walls make the room glow. Although still a neighborhood eatery, it's not the Spaccarelli's we remember, and hooray for that.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 10 about film adaptations of Henry James novels misattributed a quotation from ''The Portrait of a Lady.'' It is the character Madame Merle, not Isabel Archer, who says: ''I've a great respect for things! One's self -- for other people -- is one's expression of one's self; and one's house, one's furniture, one's garments, the books one reads, the company one keeps -- these are all expressive.''

title: Alfonzo Ignores Pain and Powers Mets' Drive
description: Edgardo Alfonzo was worn down by the end of last season. Alfonzo, the Mets' second baseman, had taken only five games off, and after the playoffs he sat out the winter ball season at home in Venezuela. He resolved to ask for a few more days off this season, and he has gotten them -- 12, in all.

title: Venerable Houses Live Again
description: ONE of the fine old dwellings that have been demolished on Staten Island was the Edward J. Bonner house, a shingle-style home with Queen Anne elements. The structure was on Bard Avenue near Livingston Court in Livingston.

title: From the Hands Of Shipbuilders
description: WHAT first catches the visitor's eye on entering the Connecticut River Museum in Essex is a group of architectural models, the heart of the exhibition ''Framing the Past.'' Graceful, lean skeletons of historic barns and houses, crafted of vintage wood at a scale of one inch to one foot, they complement the spare beauty of the exhibition space and allow glimpses of the river sparkling outside the windows.

title: In Bologna, A Grand Plaza Defines the City
description: FEW Italian cities still live in their main squares as intensely as Bologna does. Since the 13th century, the Piazza Maggiore has served as the city's social, administrative, political and commercial heart. Milestone events that have marked Bologna's history -- from the celebrations for the coronation of Charles V as Holy Roman Emperor in 1530, to the city's collective rage after a bomb killed 85 people at the train station in 1980 -- have been commemorated there.

title: At a Mall, Digging Dinosaur Facts
description: OUR 2-year-old daughter, Una, has been to malls and to museums, and she thinks she knows the difference. So she was puzzled when we pulled into the parking lot of the South Hills Mall in Poughkeepsie. ''That not a mooseeum,'' she insisted.

title: The New Entrepreneurs of Silicon Heights
description: APROSYS COMPUTER, a tiny business above the Amir Barber Shop on West 181st Street in Washington Heights, is easy to miss in this neighborhood where beauty salons and discount stores with bins of $10 jeans are more common than computer shops.

title: Good Grief and Bad
description: As a professional counselor, I felt compelled to write after reading and rereading the article by Lorenzo Albacete (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 27). It seems to me that he has largely missed the boat on the purpose of grief counseling. Any good bereavement counselor knows that it is impossible to lessen the pain or to truly console the bereaved. The counselor simply provides a shoulder to lean on. This function (profession, if you will) developed out of the needs of a largely death- and grief-denying society, in which workers are typically allowed three days (five if the employer is generous) to grieve the death of a significant family member. After that, they are expected to ''be over it'' and to function at full capacity at their jobs.

title: An Audience With Dolly
description: Recently, I marked the dawn of the new millennium by making a peculiarly postmodern pilgrimage. I journeyed across the Atlantic to the little town of Roslin, Scotland, to see Dolly, the world-renowned clone, the most photographed, fretted over and philosophized about farm animal in the history of civilization. Two thousand years ago, as the New Testament tells it, wise men traveled great distances to see the Christ Child in his manger outside Bethlehem. Now we come from all corners of the globe to visit with a distant relative of one of that manger's bit players.

title: Family's Choices Can Blunt The Effect of Video Violence
description: In their home in Yellow Springs, Ohio, Will Lapedes and his parents were negotiating a conflict over electronic turf. Will, 14, wanted a computer in his room. For his parents, this raised a red flag. ''We wanted to be able to see the screen,'' his mother, Maureen Lynch, said. So they compromised, putting the machine in the hallway outside his room. From this roost, he chats online, looks at sports Web sites and plays an array of video games. Most of them, he said, are ''pretty gory.''

title: High-Speed Web Access Creeping Along

The company designs Web pages that often include streaming video and animated graphics. But its dial-up modems, which received data over regular telephone lines, were so slow that it often took minutes to get online access to some of the Web pages his employees had created.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, DR. ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Board of Directors, performers and staff of the Big Apple Circus mourn the passing of Dr. Anne E. Dyson, friend, colleague and inspiration. Over the last decade the Big Apple Circus and the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit (CCU) Program have been the beneficiaries of her wisdom and commitment. As a member of the CCU Advisory Committee, Dr. Dyson's counsel guided the implementation of a strategic plan for national expansion of the CCU, enabling its clown doctors to bring joy, laughter and wonder to bedsides of ever greater numbers of hospitalized children. That plan continues and has resulted in the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit making nearly 180,000 annual bedside visits in 14 leading pediatric facilities across the nation. Dr. Dyson was a visionary leader, a powerful force for the care of children, and a good friend. We were inspired by her life's work for children and in her memory rededicate ourselves to our shared commitment to children and their families. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and her colleagues. Paul Binder, Founder Michael Christensen, Co-Founder Gary Dunning, Executive Director

description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 25  The opposition candidate in the Yugoslav presidential election claimed victory today over Slobodan Milosevic in elections on Sunday. But with official vote counting suspended, there were concerns about whether Mr. Milosevic is willing to acknowledge defeat.

title: University Shows Black in Sea Of Whites, Except He Wasnt

description: MALLER-Jane. Her outer beauty was a reflection of the beauty inside her. Jane was such a good friend to so many people who prized her. Beloved and devoted wife of Arthur, cherished mother of Robin and Lisa, dearest sonin-law Zelik, adored grandmother to Robert, Lauren, David, Alexandra and Michael. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, EDWARD PHILIP
description: SNYDER-Edward Philip. Of Southport, CT, died September 23, 2000, in his home. Born in 1919, he graduated from the Taft School where he long served as a Trustee. He was in the Class of '42 at Yale and served with distinction during WW II in the U.S. Navy in both the North and South Pacific Theaters, attaining the rank of Lt. Commander. Mr. Snyder was a retired Senior Partner with Moore & Munger in New York City. He founded the Carlos Otis Medical Clinic at Stratton Mountain where he served as a Director. A lifelong sailor, he was a member of the New York Yacht Club and Cruising Club of America in addition to being a member and past Commodore of both the Storm Trysail and Pequot Yacht Clubs. Survivors include his wife, Frances, three children, seven grandchildren; his brothers Peter and Frank and their children. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, September 26, 2000, at 11 AM at the Southport Congregational Church, 524 Pequot Ave., Southport, CT. The family requests in lieu of flowers that contributions be made to the Southport Congregational Church, the Carlos Otis Medical Clinic, Stratton Mountain, VT, or Norwalk Hospital, Maple St., Norwalk, CT.

title: Development for New York City; Dithering Over Governors Island
description: For five long years, New York's political leaders have been at odds over how to take advantage of one of the best real estate deals ever offered. On a helicopter ride over New York Harbor in 1995, President Clinton spotted Governors Island, asked Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan about its history and then offered to return the 172-acre plot to New York State for the tidy sum of $1. The one catch, which turned out to be bigger than even the skeptics could have imagined at the time, was that New York City and New York State had to agree on a suitable way to use the island and protect its historic sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, PHILLIP L.
description: JACKSON-Phillip L. 49, died September 22 after a long and courageous struggle with AIDS. Phil, a partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was a leading international corporate and securities lawyer with a distinguished and devoted clientele. His practice was characterized by the highest standards of integrity, intellect, and devotion to his clients. Phil was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, and graduated first in his class at the University of Oklahoma. Upon graduation he took up a Rhodes Scholarship to Merton College, Oxford, where he read Classics and Philosophy. He took his law degree from the University of Chicago in 1979, and thereafter commenced practice at Shearman & Sterling, where he spent his entire legal career. A devoted friend, author, classicist, musician, photographer and traveler, Phil is survived by his loving partner, Dat Chi Luong; by his beloved parents, George H. and Frances M. Jackson; his brothers George H. and R. Kern Jackson; and by six nieces and nephews. A memorial service in celebration of Phil's life will be held on Wednesday, September 27, 2000, at 3:30 PM at St. Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends are invited to make contributions in Phillip's memory to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Yugoslav Opposition Declares Victory as Votes Still Counted
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Claiming victory in an election marked by fraud allegations, Slobodan Milosevic's opponents warned that the Yugoslav president may try to rig the vote in a desperate attempt to keep the power he has wielded for 13 years. ``This is the dawn of our freedom,'' law professor and opposition candidate Vojislav Kostunica said early Monday as Yugoslavians poured onto the streets of Belgrade and other cities. By midmorning Monday, election officials had still not released any official numbers from Sunday's elections, nor had they resumed work suspended the night of the vote. An estimated 74 percent of the country's 7.6 million voters cast ballots for president, parliament and local officials. However, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia party claimed its candidate, 56-year-old Kostunica, had won the presidency, saying its poll watchers reported that he had an absolute majority, defeating Milosevic and three other contenders. ``Votes can be rigged when there is a slim difference between two groups, but when the difference is this big there is no way anyone can falsify the results,'' said Vladan Batic of the opposition alliance. No one in Milosevic's Socialist Party was willing to go on the record, but a senior official requesting anonymity told The Associated Press that the party's ``top people were debating all night ... We don't exactly know what we'll do.'' If no candidate ends up with an absolute majority, a runoff will be held Oct. 8. However, Milosevic was showing no signs of conceding defeat, and Western governments held late night consultations to determine how to respond. The European Union on Monday issued a statement criticizing Milosevic for intimidating voters and manipulating the presidential ballot, declaring that any effort by the Yugoslav leader to declare victory would be ``fraudulent.'' In Vienna, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, the chairwoman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said in a statement, ``All available information points to a clear lead by the Democratic Opposition of Serbia's Vojislav Kostunica in the first round.'' British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on Monday said ``all the reliable evidence'' shows Milosevic had lost and urged the president to step aside. ``Be honest with your people, don't cheat them, get out of the way and let Serbia get out of the prison into which you have turned it,'' he told a Labor Party conference in London, referring to Yugoslavia's main province. Early in the vote-counting, White House spokeswoman Nanda Chitre said questions about irregularities brought into question ``the integrity of the whole process.'' Hours later, as reports came out that the opposition -- which the United States backs -- was in the lead, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher in Washington took a softer tone, warning simply that ``the world is watching.'' Believing that there can be no stability in the Balkans as long as Milosevic remains in power, the United States has invested millions in an attempt to organize the traditionally fractured Serbian opposition and defeat Milosevic. Milosevic spokesman Nikola Sainovic, however, claimed that with 20 percent of the votes counted, Milosevic was leading by 44 percent while Kostunica had 41 percent. Kostunica's group, an alliance of 18 parties, claimed returns from 51 percent of 10,000 polling stations showed him leading with 53 percent to 36 percent for Milosevic. The ultranationalist Serbian Radical Party, which ran its own unsuccessful presidential candidate, said Kostunica was leading Milosevic by 53.5 percent to 37.9 percent with 20 percent of the votes counted. Confident of victory by an opposition that seemed hopelessly fragmented only months ago, huge crowds streamed into the streets of downtown Belgrade late Sunday to await official results. Helmeted riot police carrying shields and armed with tear gas cordoned off the group but later withdrew as the mood became more festive than confrontational. Similar gatherings were reported in Nis, Novi Sad, Cacak and several other towns in Serbia. There were no immediate reports of clashes, and the crowds dispersed early Monday. Despite the public euphoria, opposition leaders said they were concerned that Milosevic would try to claim victory -- or ensure a place in the runoff. ``Milosevic has to seriously understand the judgment of history, and he shouldn't gamble any longer,'' said Kostunica's campaign manager, Zoran Djindjic. Montenegro, the smaller republic that along with Serbia forms present-day Yugoslavia, said it would hold an independence referendum if Milosevic wins. If he loses, the European Union has promised Yugoslavia massive aid. Kostunica had been leading in opinion polls -- despite a campaign marred by a crackdown against opposition supporters. The Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a private group including human rights workers, lawyers and other volunteers, reported a turnout of 74.6 percent in Serbia. In Montenegro -- where the pro-Western government boycotted the vote -- the turnout was 24 percent, the opposition said. The center also reported major voting irregularities, including officials kicking opposition representatives out of polling stations or not allowing them to inspect voters' lists, voting boxes and ballots. The government's electoral commission said the vote passed without irregularities, ``despite Western propaganda.''

title: In Underwhelming Turnout, French Voters Cut Presidential Term
description: A referendum to cut the French president's term of office from seven to five years was overwhelmingly approved today though a record number of voters did not bother to cast a ballot.

Fatso is a stuffed wombat with an oversized posterior who is the mascot and inanimate co-star of "The Dream," a bawdy and disrespectful Olympic wrapup program carried nightly by the Seven Network, which is broadcasting the Summer Games to Australia.

title: A Night Full of Magic, Under the Cast of a Shadow
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 25  On the most anticipated night of track and field at the Sydney Games, Michael Johnson won his second gold medal in the men's 400 meters and Cathy Freeman stopped a nation in the women's 400. Stacy Dragila won the inaugural women's pole vault and tossed a bouquet of flowers over her shoulder like a bride at her reception. Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia ran 6.2 miles and had to lean like a sprinter at the tape to defeat his nemesis, Paul Tergat of Kenya.

title: A Storyteller Stands Where Justice Confronts Basic Human Needs
description: Some months ago I had a letter from a reader who was so furious she covered four pages by hand, demanding to know why my books were "infested" with political issues. "When I buy a mystery, I expect to be entertained," she wrote, "and when you bring in all that stuff about homeless people, you aren't entertaining me."

title: Development for New York City; The West Side Jets
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposal to build a football stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, perhaps for the New York Jets, has suddenly taken on new life. It has also generated understandable skepticism from New Yorkers. Nevertheless, the idea is more promising than it might seem at first. The Jets are said to be extremely interested. The earlier idea of moving Yankee Stadium to the West Side is effectively dead, especially now that Gov. George Pataki has come out against it. More important, City Hall and the governor's office are mulling some financial arrangements that might work and also speed the redevelopment of a poorly served and underutilized area of Manhattan.

The spot, intended as a spoof of so-called slasher movies, was widely castigated as making light of violence toward women and was soon pulled off the air by NBC.

title: Better Nursing Home Care
description: When President Clinton walked into a room filled with the old people who live at the Washington Home, in the District of Columbia, on a recent Saturday, Alice Gavin, who is 105, stood up. It was, she thought, the respectful thing to do, and Mr. Clinton was about to deliver his weekly radio address, proposing a package of federal grants, punishments and rewards to try to improve the quality of care in the nation's nursing homes. He called for a billion dollars in new federal grants to hire more health care workers and better train them so each resident would have at least two hours of individual care each day.

title: No Wealth of Opportunity
description: Politicians have been talking a lot about the prosperity that has transformed the country, and though I see it all around me, I have yet to feel it. My husband, a science professor, and I couldn't afford to have children for years. We waited until we could wait no longer. We lived 12 years in a neighborhood we were not wild about before we moved into our present house in a picturesque neighborhood in an excellent school district. It takes our two incomes to live where we do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSENFELD, HAROLD IRWIN
description: HASSENFELD-Harold Irwin. Of Palm Beach, FL, and Nashville, TN. Died peacefully on September 22, at the age of 84, following a long illness. Mr. Hassenfeld was born January 13, 1916, in Providence, RI, was the oldest son of the late Henry and Marion Hassenfeld. He attended Hope High School in Providence, RI, and graduated from Brown University. Mr. Hassenfeld served in the Army during WWII in Europe. Following his military service Mr. Hassenfeld returned to Providence, RI, becoming President and Chairman of the Board of Hassenfeld Brothers, Inc., now known as Hasbro Industry. In 1946, in a move to expand the ongoing operations and business interests of the family business, Mr. Hassenfeld moved to Nashville, TN, to personally head up the Empire Pencil Company. Mr. Hassenfeld continued as Chairman of the Board of Empire/Berol Corporation until he retired in 1988. Among his many lifetime achievements is included the development of the Epcon process of manufacturing wood-like pencils using resins in place of natural cedar wood. This process revolutionized the writing industry and contributed greatly to the preservation and regeneration of cedar trees commonly used in pencils. Mr. Hassenfeld was involved with many philanthropic interests throughout his lifetime. He was a Fellow at Brandeis University. He also served on the Board of Directors of Temple Emanu-El in Palm Beach, West End Synagogue in Nashville and the American Cancer Society. Both he and his wife, Rita Dee, have been honored by the American Jewish Committee and Jewish Theological Seminary. Mr. Hassenfeld devoted much time and effort to numerous local and national religious and civic organizations thoughout his lifetime. Mr. Hassenfeld was a member of the Paul Harris Fellow Society of Rotary, Masons, Kiwanis and Shriners. Mr. Hassenfeld is survived by his wife Rita Dee Greenberg Hassenfeld, his children Pamela and Anthony Iannacio of Tampa, FL, Elizabeth and Stanley Litchman of Framingham, MA, and John and Heide Hassenfeld of Nashville, TN, four grandchildren, Patricia and Ethan Hassenfeld, and Alexander and Addison Iannacio. Funeral services were held in Nashville, TN, on Monday.

title: Barak and Arafat Plan Middle East Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM -- Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat plan to meet Monday evening for the first time since the Camp David summit to try to break the deadlock in peace talks, Palestinian officials said. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the meeting would likely take place at the Erez crossing between Israel and the Palestinian-controlled Gaza Strip. The two leaders -- who have a history of icy relations - last met in the U.S.-hosted peace summit at Camp David in July. The talks collapsed over the future of Jerusalem and have yet to resume at full speed. In another sign that peace efforts may be moving into high gear after two months of stagnation, negotiating teams from both sides were to leave for Washington on Monday night for separate talks with the Americans, the Palestinian officials said. The negotiators are under growing time pressure. Barak faces an increasingly hostile parliament which has threatened to topple him over his peace policies when it reconvenes in late October. Palestinian Information Minister Yasser Abed Rabbo said Arafat was not meeting Barak in order to announce any softening in the Palestinian position. ``By agreeing to the meeting, we are giving the peace process a new chance, we are extending our hand to the other side to tackle the differences on the negotiating table,'' Abed Rabbo said. ``We are not going to make concessions.'' The talks are locked over rival Palestinian and Israeli claims to east Jerusalem, in particular the Al Aqsa mosque compound, the third holiest site in Islam and also the site of the former Jewish Temple, the holiest shrine of Judaism. Barak has said Israel would never hand sovereignty over the area to the Palestinians or any Muslim body. Palestinian negotiator Hanan Asfour, meanwhile, rejected Barak's suggestion to sign a partial agreement if a comprehensive deal cannot be reached. ``A partial or transitional agreement has no place in our political dictionary,'' Asfour said. Shlomo Ben-Ami, Israel's acting foreign minister and a senior negotiator, confirmed that the two leaders would meet, but did not say when. ``It is important to build trust between the prime minister and Yasser Arafat,'' Ben-Ami told Israel radio. According to the Palestinian sources, American-Jewish businessman S. Daniel Abraham, former head of the weight loss business Slim-Fast Foods, helped set up the meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTMAN, JOHN MERRITT
description: EASTMAN-John Merritt. John Merritt Eastman of Rye, NY, died on September 21, 2000, after a struggle with cancer. He and his family lived in Rye for 44 years where he was a committed member of the Manursing Island Club. A lifelong devotee of sailing and racing, he was also a member of the Storm Trysail Club and a Corinthian Yachtsman. Mr. Eastman was born in Westbury, NY, and graduated from Friends Academy in Locust Valley. He attended Columbia College where he was selected to work on the Manhattan Project. He spent his career as a senior marketing and advertising executive in New York, most notably with the firms Jack Tinker and Partners and Doyle Dane Bernbach. Mr. Eastman is survived by his wife, Juliette, of Rye, NY; daughter Sarah Eastman and husband Kevin Pinto of Manhattan; daughter Polly Scott and husband Eugene of Manhattan; son Kim Eastman of Rochester, NY; brother Dr. Gerard Lester Eastman of Huntington, NY; and four adoring grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church, Rye, Saturday, September 30, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Christ's Church, Rye.

title: LAPORTE TO SELL UNITS
description: A British chemicals maker, Laporte P.L.C., said it would sell about 60 percent of its business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the United States buyout firm, for $1.2 billion in cash. The disposals are the latest in a line of restructuring efforts dating back to 1996, and will leave Laporte focused on its fine and performance chemicals business. Among the businesses being sold are pigments, additives, compounds, water technology, timber treatment and electronics, which had operating profit before exceptional items of $:83 million, or $120.7 million, last year, on sales of $:494 million. Laporte also said its chief executive, Jim Leng, would succeed George Duncan, who is retiring, as chairman. Suzanne Kapner

title: ARMSTRONG, A TILE COMPANY, WILL LAY OFF 300 IN EUROPE
description: Armstrong Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it planned to eliminate about 300 jobs, or 17 percent of the company's European work force, as part of a reorganization there. Armstrong added that it expected to record a related after-tax charge of up to $31 million for the third quarter. The company said that under the restructuring plan, it would close unprofitable sales offices, combine residential and commercial sales offices, close the British-based Team Valley commercial tile plant and discontinue unprofitable product lines. Armstrong, based in Lancaster, Pa., makes tile and sheet floor coverings, ceiling materials for homes and businesses and specialty products that include gasket materials and pipe insulation. Shares of the company were down 19 cents, at $12.63, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HOPING TO HELP STOCK PRICE, ALCOA WILL BUY BACK SHARES
description: Succumbing to shareholder pressure and worries that share values may tumble even further, the aluminum giant Alcoa Inc. said yesterday that it would immediately begin buying back stock under a previously authorized stock repurchase program. The aluminum producer, which has about 868 million shares outstanding, is authorized to purchase 29.5 million shares, according to a company spokeswoman. Alcoa, whose shares have declined 42 percent so far this year, has come under pressure from shareholders to resume the share repurchase program to buoy the company's share price. Alcoa's shares rose 13 cents to end at $23.88 on the New York Stock Exchange.
