Memorial contributions may be made Hospice of Washington, 3720 Upton Street, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Mrs. Clinton Will Still Raise Soft Money for Democrats
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that she would continue to help raise soft money for the Democratic Party even though she had agreed with Representative Rick A. Lazio not to allow advertisements in their New York Senate race paid for with the largely unregulated money.

title: CIENA SHARES LEAP AFTER COMPANY WINS KOREA CONTRACT
description: Shares of Ciena, a maker of telecommunications equipment, soared yesterday to an all-time high after the company announced it had won a contract to supply Korea Telecom. The state-run company will use Ciena's systems in seven South Korean cities, including Seoul, the company said. Ciena did not disclose financial terms of the deal. Its shares gained $6.81, to $127.56, after hitting a high of $136.25 earlier in the day. Ciena, which develops and manufactures products to increase the capacity of telephone and data networks, said the deal positioned it for additional expansion in Asia.

title: Trip South in '63 Gave Lieberman a Footnote, and Hold, in History
description: Thirty-seven years ago, in the autumn of another political season, Joseph I. Lieberman and a carload of other Yale students headed south from New Haven on a trip of nearly 1,300 miles, stopping only for gas and a quick dinner in the Washington suburbs. They were eager to get to Mississippi, where they hoped to make a little history.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Stress and Fat, Linked at the Waist
description: A new study suggests that for women, stress and fat are linked -- but at the waist, not the hips.

title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: The Crumbling of the Milosevic Fortress
description: As Yugoslavia voted on Sunday, one friend's e-mail message from Belgrade summed it all up: ''We're all in election fever, hope and horror at the same time. Wish us luck!'' No amount of analysis and informed guesswork could have caught the mood better.

title: Interferon Treatment Found To Delay Multiple Sclerosis
description: Researchers have shown for the first time that the onset of multiple sclerosis can be delayed, and its severity reduced, by drug treatment for neurological problems thought to be very early signs of the disease.

title: W.N.B.A. Awaits Australias Jackson
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Lauren Jackson ran upcourt after a brief altercation under the basket with the frustrated United States player.

title: U.S. Says Asylum in Panama Helped Avert a Coup in Peru
description: American officials today defended their role in pressing Panama to give refuge to the ousted intelligence chief of Peru, asserting that his departure was necessary to avoid a coup by officers loyal to him.

title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Labeling Genetically Altered Food Is Thorny Issue
description: The discovery of an unapproved variety of genetically engineered corn in a brand of store-bought taco shells is prompting new calls for the labeling of bioengineered foods.

title: INSIDE
description: Barak and Arafat Meet

title: DEAL FOR THAMES WATER
description: The German utility company RWE A.G. will buy Thames Water P.L.C., of Britain for 6.7 billion [pounds] in cash and assumed debt, about $9.4 billion. The deal values each Thames Water share at $:12.15, or $17.66, a 50 percent premium to their trading average in the last 12 months. The combined company, to be called Thames Water, will be the world's third largest in water and wastewater management, with 34 million customers. Thames Water's chief executive, Bill Alexander, will head the new company. Suzanne Kapner

title: Public Interests; A Hot-Button Issue
description: The presidential campaign has stopped talking about nuclear defense because married women, the critical swing voters, aren't supposed to be interested. (Our motto: If it hasn't come up on Regis it can't be all that important.)

title: French Scandal Turns Bipartisan as Socialist Is Accused
description: A whiff of scandal crossed the political aisle here today when a former Socialist cabinet official acknowledged that he was given a copy of a videotape that accuses President Jacques Chirac of illegal activities, but did not notify the authorities during the two years he had the tape.

title: MICROSOFT REPORT
description: As the Supreme Court prepares to say whether it will take the Microsoft antitrust case, the public relations war is accelerating. Yesterday, the pro-Microsoft Association for Competitive Technology released a study by a University of Texas economist that asserts that the government's proposed remedy of splitting Microsoft into two companies will cost consumers worldwide $125 billion to $310 billion in higher software costs over three years. The study, written by Stan J. Liebowitz, suggests that after a split of Microsoft, the resulting two new competitors will ''depart from Microsoft's traditionally low pricing practices.'' John Markoff

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; Garlic to Cut Cholesterol? Don't Bother
description: Garlic consumption can indeed lower cholesterol levels, but not by enough to constitute an effective treatment, researchers have found.

title: Metro Business; Schumer Urges Steps To Aid Technology
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer told members of one of Silicon Alley's largest trade groups yesterday that if the city is to remain competitive in the technology industry it must create more options for less-expensive commercial space, force competition into the high-speed Internet field and train more skilled workers.

title: Germany Set To Overhaul Its Program On Pensions
description: FRANKFURT  The German government will unveil a long-awaited overhaul of the state-run retirement system Tuesday in the latest reform of its once-sacrosanct welfare state.

title: Redskins' Trick Catches Rookie By Surprise
description: The Giants still held a slim hope of salvaging the game when the Redskins lined up to punt with two minutes remaining on Sunday night. On fourth-and-4 from the Giants' 34-yard line, the Giants' rookie Brandon Short jumped offside. The 5-yard penalty gave the Redskins a first down and essentially ended the game. The Giants did not get the ball back and lost, 16-6.

title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, HERBERT
description: HONIG-Herbert. Beloved brother of Ruth and George Sadowsky. Devoted cousin of Ruth and Helen Siegel. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: DOUBLECLICK TO BUY ATPLAN
description: The online advertising company DoubleClick said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase AtPlan, an online market research company, for $120 million in stock and cash. AtPlan stockholders are to receive the equivalent of $9.25 for each share of AtPlan common stock -- 20 percent of which will be given as cash, the rest in DoubleClick common stock. AtPlan's shares closed yesterday at $8.75, up $1.50, or 21 percent. Bob Tedeschi

title: Verizon Wireless Offers Free Phones
description: Verizon Wireless Inc., the largest United States mobile-phone company, said yesterday that it would give customers who choose two-year contracts for digital cellular service new phones at no cost when they renew their service agreements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSINSKY, AARON
description: SOSINSKY-Aaron. On September 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Debra. Services were held Monday, September 25

title: Article 2000092691016254723 -- No Title
description: E-COMMERCE REPORT

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Kardanov Defeats Lindland to Win Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Matt Lindland's circuitous route to the Olympic wrestling mat took him from the trials to the rulings of arbitrators and into federal courtrooms. Back and forth the tussle went over whether he or Keith Sieracki would be placed on the United States Greco-Roman team. One day, Sieracki was the 167 1/2-pound representative. The next, it was Lindland.

title: Hunter, Jones's Husband, Denies Drug Charge
description: The husband of Marion Jones denied today that he had taken steroids and said that a mislabeled nutritional supplement was responsible for elevated levels of the performance-enhancing drug nandrolone in his system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBSTMAN, MANDY
description: HERBSTMAN-Mandy. A journalist, publicist, raconteur, generous and staunch friend. H. Singer

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages last Tuesday with an article about five siblings who attend the Juilliard School referred incorrectly to the image of one, Gregory Brown, who was shown playing table tennis. It was a direct image, not a reflection in a mirror.

title: Prague Protesters Fail to Stop Meeting of World Bank, I.M.F
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 26  Black-masked protesters hurled cobblestones ripped from Prague's medieval streets and attacked police with homemade gasoline bombs, trying desperately, and ultimately unsuccessfully, to shut down a global finance meeting here today.

title: Sotheby's Shares Jump on News of Price-Fixing Settlement
description: Shares of Sotheby's Holdings rose more than 15 percent yesterday after the board of the beleaguered auction house agreed to pay $256 million to settle a class-action claim that it colluded with Christie's to fix commissions charged to buyers and sellers.

title: ETHERNET SERVICE EXPANDING
description: Continuing the expansion of Ethernet, the local area networking technology, from offices into large communications networks, Level 3 Communications, the big telecommunications upstart, plans to announce today that it is offering high-speed Internet service over Ethernet. Long thought robust enough only for office networks, Ethernet this year has emerged as a way to provide high-speed data links outside of buildings at costs far below those of traditional communications systems and with little, if any, loss of reliability. Seth Schiesel

title: 2 Korea Defense Chiefs Agree On Small Steps at Initial Talks
description: In the most important meeting between North and South Korea since their leaders met in June, the defense ministers from both countries traveled here on Monday to discuss lowering tensions across their border, the most heavily armed in the world.

title: Teachers Question Critical Study of Classroom Computers
description: Elementary school teachers using technology in the field are questioning a recent study that calls for a "time-out" for computers in classrooms with young children, saying that the new technology make their students more eager to learn.

title: Moths Have an Even, Too
description: As television cameras high above Olympic Stadium pull back to reveal the magnificent panorama below, the first thing a viewer notices may be the moths. Hundreds of thousands of them, jammed almost wing to wing around the stadium lights, appear on television like shimmering stars.

title: Unlikely Debate Topics
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO NETWORKING CONCERNS TO MERGE
description: Predictive Systems, a leading networking consulting firm, plans to announce today that it is acquiring one of its small private competitors, Synet Service. Predictive, based in New York, will pay $9 million in cash and 2.2 million of its own shares for Synet. Predictive's shares closed yesterday at $15.12, down $1.88, giving the deal a value of about $42 million. ''What was attractive about Synet was that in addition to having very strong technical people who are up on the latest technology, they, like we, had a very business-oriented approach,'' Robert L. Belau, Predictive's president, said in an interview yesterday. Seth Schiesel

title: A Briton Is Chosen as Director of the Cooper-Hewitt
description: In a sure sign that design credentials flow freely beyond borders, the Smithsonian Institution announced yesterday that the new director for its Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum is British.

title: A Great Hope of Physics Falls on Hard Times
description: Two years ago at a scientific conference in Madison, Wis., a physicist named E. Michael Campbell gave a triumphant progress report on a project to build a stadium-size laser at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCASTOR, FRANCES MOORE
description: McCASTOR-Frances Moore. On September 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joseph S. Moore, and the late Dr. Joseph McCastor. Cherished mother of Joseph, Roberta, Rosemary, Therese, and the late Lorana. Mother-in-law of Litza, Reini, and Thomas. Devoted and fun grandmother to Christopher, Larisa, Stephen, Michael, Caitlin, and Zachary. Loving great grandmother to Spencer. Dear sister to Dorothy. Frances will be terribly missed by all who knew her. Her charm, wit, intelligence, warmth, and love, lightened our days. Dear mom, wear your high heels in heaven. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell,1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at Saint John The Evangelist Church, First Avenue at 55th Street, Tuesday October 3, 2000, at 11 A.M.

title: World War II Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; Those Roomy Sleeves Say '80's Redux'
description: The conclusion of the Spring 2001 collections in New York brought with it these questions: Is there time between now and March for stores to figure out how to control the masses of women, many possibly wearing side ponytails and scrunchies, who will storm the gates demanding to look as they did the first time they heard a Human League song? Will Barneys and Bergdorf's start to resemble the meat counter at Balducci's, with numbers handed out for handkerchief skirts rather than pork chops?

title: G-Rated Songs of the 60's Join the X-Rated Successors
description: Back in the 1960's Rudy Ray Moore was content to sing jovial rhythm-and-blues. He recorded songs about finding and losing love; he declared that women were ''Angels on Earth'' and called himself a ''Hully Gully Papa'' who loved to ''coffee grind real slow.'' He sang those songs again, for what was said to be the first time in more than 30 years, at Wetlands on Saturday night, celebrating their recent rerelease on ''Hully Gully Fever'' (Norton).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, CECIL JOY
description: ROBBINS-Cecil Joy, former ballerina, protege of Harriet Hoctor, featured dancer at Billy Rose's Diamond Horseshoe, Lou Walters Latin Quarter, and niteclubs and theaters throughout the country passed away peacefully at home on September 25, 2000. She loved life with a vivacious and energetic passion which she passed on to all in her family and her many friends. She is survived by her lovng husband Jules, daughter Linda, sons Steven and David, brother Harold, sister Myrna and grandchildren Skyler, Alex, Marc and Mick. Viewings are from 6:00 to 9:00 PM on Tuesday and Wednesday at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Services on Thursday, September 28, 2000 at 12:45 PM

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile last Tuesday about John R. Gambling, whose longtime radio program ''Rambling With Gambling'' on WOR-AM was recently canceled, misstated the title of the poem by Clement Clarke Moore that Mr. Gambling helped to recite on the program at age 5 when his father was the host. It is ''A Visit From St. Nicholas''; it is popularly known as ''The Night Before Christmas.''

title: Fox Bids $2.5 Billion for Baseball TV Rights
description: Fox Sports is bidding an estimated $2.5 billion for the entire Major League Baseball network television package for six years, ending a split of rights with NBC, industry executives said. Fox wants to merge everything it has broadcast since the 1996 season with NBC's package and add the division series playoff games that ESPN has carried.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Concern About Earnings Continues to Hobble Stocks

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Talk of Euro's Revival May Be Premature
description: As a show of market power, the joint intervention to rescue the euro seems not to have much impressed its audience.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The Analyst as Bomb Thrower; Thomas Brown Has an Attitude, One He Likes to Share
description: For years, Thomas K. Brown threw verbal darts in a profession known for cozy collegiality. A top-rated stock analyst, he frequently blasted top bankers who were stringing together mergers at prices he believed were too high.

title: For Gooden and Cone, a Struggle From the Start
description: Dwight Gooden's four-month metamorphosis from out-of-work pitcher pondering retirement to Yankees fill-in starter might have qualified as a near-miracle, until he revealed again last night that he is very mortal.

title: Gymnast Tests Positive and Loses Gold
description: Less than a week after the charismatic Romanian Andreea Raducan won the prestigious Olympic all-around gold medal with a style some compared to Nadia Comaneci, she was stripped of her medal today after testing positive for a banned drug.

title: Giuliani Describes City Plans For Staten Island and Its Ferry
description: Construction is under way on a $180 million Staten Island Ferry terminal in Lower Manhattan, one piece of a city government building boom of sorts that would benefit a borough that has traditionally been shortchanged, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, JAMES
description: KEEGAN-James. The entire staff of the Hebrew Home for The Aged at Riverdale mourns with great sorrow the untimely death of James Keegan, a devoted member of the Hebrew Home family for 32 years. Jim's wholehearted dedication to our residents and to the development and maintenance of the Hebrew Home plant and facilities was unequaled. A friend, mentor and colleague to us all, Jim shall be dearly missed. Our hearfelt condolences to his daughter Laura, his sonin-law Edmond, his grandchildren Kristen, Edmond, Jr., and Caitlin, his brother John, and his friend and former wife Sandy. He shall be long remembered by all who knew him. For information Riverdale-on-Hudson 718-884-6100. Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Article 2000092691353936723 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Bennett Loses to Savon on Points
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- First, a partition was raised, expanding the grandstand at the Olympic boxing site by 2,000 seats. Then the arena lights darkened. The sound system played louder and faster-paced music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKMAN, DORIS
description: BLACKMAN-Doris (Weinstein) formerly of River Vale, NJ. Died Saturday in Boca Raton, Fl. Survived by her husband Stanley; daughters Betsy (Chris) Wahmann and Susan (Michael) Terven and sister Leila Schuman. Service in Boca Raton. Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel.

title: Sun Names 2 Agencies To Share Its Work
description: Sun Microsystems in Palo Alto, Calif., has named two agencies to share its account, with billings estimated at $100 million. The two shops, which will work as a team, are the New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, and Tonic 360 in San Francisco, which has handled the Sun interactive assignment for the last two years.

title: From The Editors; The Times and Wen Ho Lee
description: On March 6, 1999, The New York Times reported that Government investigators believed China had accelerated its nuclear weapons program with the aid of stolen American secrets. The article said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had focused its suspicions on a Chinese-American scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. Two days later, the government announced that it had fired a Los Alamos scientist for ''serious security violations.'' Officials identified the man as Wen Ho Lee.

title: Estate Tax Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000092692494770090 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Scooter Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Fates of Wolf and Aspen

title: U.S. Takes Tribes' Side On Bones
description: Moving to resolve a custody battle over one of the oldest and most significant set of human remains ever found in North America, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt announced today that the bones of Kennewick Man belong to five American Indian tribes that claim him as an ancestor and wish to bury him.

title: Executives Promoted At New York Times
description: Promotions of three executives in the circulation department of The New York Times were announced yesterday by Scott Heekin-Canedy, the newspaper's senior vice president for circulation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CHARLES ROBERT
description: THOMAS-Charles Robert. 83, on September 24, 2000, in Cambridge, NY, formerly of Brooklyn. Beloved husband of Winifred A. (nee Taylor), and loving father of Bob, Liz, John, Mary Ann, Stephen, David, and Brian. Devoted grandfather and great grandfather. Also survived by a sister, Virginia Thomas, of Fort Walton Beach, FL.

title: Rocker Is Back, As Is Barricade
description: John Rocker will be in New York with the Braves again for a three-game series starting tonight, and the Mets will use most of the same security measures that were in place when Rocker visited Shea Stadium for the first time this season in June.

title: Crash Leads to Explosion at Gas Station on Long Island
description: EAST ISLIP, N.Y. -- A woman was killed when her minivan smashed into a gas tanker outside a Long Island gas station Monday night, police said. The crash triggered an explosion that shook houses several blocks away and shot flames more than 100 feet in the air.

title: TOYOTA RESEARCH COMPANY
description: Japan's largest car manufacturer, Toyota Motor, will set up a research company together with some of its affiliated companies to help them scout for new businesses in the realm of information technology and develop them. Toyota, which has large cash reserves, has long focused on information technology as part of its effort to develop ''smart'' cars. The Kyocera Corporation, the world's largest maker of ceramic packages for computers, and the Denso Corporation, Toyota's main parts supplier, will also take a stake in the new company. Stephanie Strom

title: A Night Full of Magic, Under the Cast of a Shadow
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 25  On the most anticipated night of track and field at the Sydney Games, Michael Johnson won his second gold medal in the men's 400 meters and Cathy Freeman stopped a nation in the women's 400. Stacy Dragila won the inaugural women's pole vault and tossed a bouquet of flowers over her shoulder like a bride at her reception. Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia ran 6.2 miles and had to lean like a sprinter at the tape to defeat his nemesis, Paul Tergat of Kenya.

title: Lawyers Allege Coercion of Witnesses in Terrorism Case
description: Lawyers for a suspect in a terrorism case involving the bombing of two United States embassies have accused federal prosecutors of employing a ''pattern of coercion and intimidation'' against at least eight potential defense witnesses through improper use of the grand jury and other tactics.

title: Repudiating Mr. Milosevic
description: During his 13 years in power, Slobodan Milosevic has lost piece after piece of his country. His Serbian nationalism and demagoguery ended in the independence of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia, their borders drawn in blood. Today Macedonia is independent, Kosovo is under United Nations control and Serbia's sister republic, Montenegro, has seceded in all but name. Mr. Milosevic is left with only Serbia, and after Sunday's elections, Serbia is no longer his.

title: ANCHOR GAMING WILL BUY SHARES FROM CHAIRMAN'S FAMILY
description: Anchor Gaming said yesterday that it would buy about 4.6 million of its shares from its chairman, Stanley Fulton, and members of his family. At $66.60 a share, the deal is valued at $306 million. Stanley Fulton; his son, Michael; and his daughter, Elizabeth Jones, have agreed to resign from their positions on Anchor's board. After the transaction is finished, Mr. Fulton and his family members will retain ownership of about 539,600 Anchor shares. Under the agreement, Stanley Fulton is to acquire from Anchor ''substantially all the assets'' of its Sunland Park Racetrack and Casino in New Mexico, and its 25 percent interest in a Massachusetts horse racing operation. Anchor Gaming, based in Las Vegas, makes video gaming equipment for casinos.

title: Old Is New as Sonics Introduce Ewing
description: A highlight film preceded his entrance, offering archival evidence of Patrick Ewing in his prime, back when he could finish a fast break with an inspiring dunk and an emphatic scowl, or spin swiftly past an opponent and drop a baby-finger roll into the bucket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, LOUIS H.
description: EPSTEIN-Louis H. Of Plantation, FL. Died peacefully on Monday, September 25, 2000 at the age of 93. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Jacobs. Loving father of Myrna Algus and son-in-law Dr. Seymour Algus of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Loving grandfather of Dr. Jane Algus, and Dr. Mitchell Algus and wife Dyanne Maue. Anavid sportsman, Mr. Epstein continued to play racquetball well intohis 93rd year. He was much loved and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Center, N.Y., Wednesday, September 27th, 12 Noon. The family will observe shiva at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Algus, 39 Milburn St, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Sunday and Monday.

title: POINT, CLICK, WIN (MAYBE)
description: In another experiment by advertisers using new technology to deliver sales pitches, AT&T and Ericsson are co-sponsoring an interactive wireless promotion tied to the ABC quiz show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.'' AT&T and Ericsson will mail out 100,000 electronic devices shaped like Ericsson cellular phones to consumers, who will be asked to watch the show in late October for special encoded commercials. When pointed at a TV screen, the devices can read light patterns, telling viewers whether they have won prizes. Stuart Elliott

title: California Makes College an Entitlement
description: California's legislature has created a new educational entitlement: lots of kids will be going to college free of charge. Sound good? It isn't. It's likely to harm the great public universities of the state, as well as undermine California's drive for standards in elementary and secondary education. And it won't address the real problem: the inadequate academic preparation of too many high school graduates, particularly those from low-income families.

title: Article 2000092690482492836 -- No Title
description: CIRCUITS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, PHILLIP L.
description: JACKSON-Phillip L. 49, died September 22 after a long and courageous struggle with AIDS. Phil, a partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was a leading international corporate and securities lawyer with a distinguished and devoted clientele. His practice was characterized by the highest standards of integrity, intellect, and devotion to his clients. Phil was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, and graduated first in his class at the University of Oklahoma. Upon graduation he took up a Rhodes Scholarship to Merton College, Oxford, where he read Classics and Philosophy. He took his law degree from the University of Chicago in 1979, and thereafter commenced practice at Shearman & Sterling, where he spent his entire legal career. A devoted friend, author, classicist, musician, photographer and traveler, Phil is survived by his loving partner, Dat Chi Luong; by his beloved parents, George H. and Frances M. Jackson; his brothers George H. and R. Kern Jackson; and by six nieces and nephews. A memorial service in celebration of Phil's life will be held on Wednesday, September 27, 2000, at 3:30 PM at St. Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends are invited to make contributions in Phillip's memory to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: A New School Rule: Play With Your Food!
description: To the Editor:

title: A Religious Revival Near an Israeli Jail
description: Calling a young man up to the stage, Rabbi Yehuda Deri beamed as the youth was draped in a prayer shawl and vowed to become an observant Jew.

title: Foreign Affairs; Candidate In the Balance
description: It's interesting watching the American oil crisis/debate from here in Tokyo. The Japanese are cool as cucumbers today -- no oil protests, no gas lines, no politicians making crazy promises. That's because Japan has been preparing for this day since the 1973 oil crisis by steadily introducing natural gas, nuclear power, high-speed mass transit and conservation, and thereby steadily reducing its dependence on foreign oil. And unlike the U.S., the Japanese never wavered from that goal by falling off the wagon and becoming addicted to S.U.V.'s -- those they just make for the Americans.

title: Testaverde Bristles At Being Blindsided By Short Benching
description: Wayne Chrebet was at the center of one circle of reporters today, joking about the 100 electronic messages he had received on his Web site after Sunday's shocking 21-17 victory over Tampa Bay, including the one that suggested a new moniker for him: the Green Lantern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, CLARA
description: ORKIN-Clara. On September 25, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Teitelbaum, and William Orkin, loving mother of Adina Gordon, Yerucham Teitelbaum, and the late Shimon Yehuda Teitelbaum, and mother-in-law of Yitz Gordon, and Elsie Teitelbaum, cherished grandmother to Mark Gordon, Miriam Gordon Medoff, David Tausik, Rivka, Hinde, Shimon Yehuda, Menachem Mendel Teitelbaum, and great grandmother to Joshua and Jena Gordon, Adam and David Medoff, and Shimon Nathan August Tausik. Services Tuesday 9:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. Interment will take place in Jerusalem.

title: Harold Barg, 75; Dealt in Burgundy Wines
description: Harold B. Barg, a sales and marketing agent in the United States for owners of well-known vineyards and wineries in the Burgundy region of France, died on Sept. 18 in Dijon, France. He was 75, lived in Roseland, N.J., and was on a business trip.

title: Chinese Player Salutes Swede He Defeated
description: When Sweden's Jan-Ove Waldner travels to China to play table tennis, he is mobbed when he leaves his hotel, as if he were a rock star walking around Manhattan or a soccer star walking around Europe.

title: Article 2000092691731182817 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Cruise Ship Bill Draws Environmental Critics
description: Congress is close to passing legislation that the Justice Department says would legalize cruise ships' dumping of toxic chemicals from their dry cleaning and photo processing operations, offenses for which a major cruise line, Royal Caribbean, pleaded guilty last year.

title: Insiders Squirm as Corruption Case Slowly Unfolds
description: A year after Paul J. Silvester, the former Connecticut treasurer, pleaded guilty to taking bribes while in office, political insiders throughout the state are nervously waiting for the next shoe to drop in a case with the potential to tarnish both political parties.

title: LONDON EXCHANGE FIGHTS TAKEOVER
description: The London Stock Exchange argued in its official defense document that the takeover bid from OM Gruppen, the Swedish company that runs the Stockholm exchange, would represent a loss of influence, inadequate value and an unattractive business proposition, and it urged shareholders to reject the hostile bid. London exchange shareholders, the document asserted, would own just 18.5 percent of the merged entity, even though the exchange would contribute nearly half of the new group's profits. In the wake of its failed plan to merge with the Deutsche Borse, the London exchange has been the subject of merger speculation. Suzanne Kapner

title: ASIA SHIFTS SEEN ON STOCK INDEXES
description: The investment banking arm of ING Groep N.V., ING Barings, predicted that investors might pull $122 billion out of the Japanese stock market as a result of changes that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, The Financial Times and Dow Jones Inc. are making in the way they compile their indexes. Elliott Flynn, a senior analyst in ING's London office, said $155 billion might flow out of Asian equity markets as a result of the changes, which assign new weights to index components based on how freely their shares trade. Thus, companies that are partly owned by governments or by other companies, of which Japan has many, will be assigned less importance in the indexes. Stephanie Strom

title: INSURER TO ACQUIRE U.S. OPERATIONS OF BRITISH COMPANY
description: The White Mountains Insurance Group, headed by the longtime insurance executive John J. Byrne, said yesterday that it would buy the United States property-casualty insurance operations of the British insurer CGNU for $2.1 billion. Mr. Byrne previously ran the auto insurer Geico Inc., now a unit of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Warren Buffett's company. White Mountains said Berkshire Hathaway would invest up to $300 million in the company as part of the deal. Shares of White Mountains, which is based in Hanover, N.H., surged $37.63, to $212.13, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, SHIRLEY
description: GOLDSMITH - Shirley. Adored wife of the late Arthur (Lofty). Loving mother of Karen MartinEliezer (Jay), Susan Roden (Peter). Cherished grandmother of Greg, Suzanne, Bruce, Electra, Casey and Andrew. Great grandmother of Sophia and Georgianna. Services Wednesday, 11:00 am, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva at Purchase residence.

title: Nightclub Incident Leaves Celtic Recovering From Stab Wounds
description: Paul Pierce, considered one of the Boston Celtics' rising stars, was stabbed more than five times during an altercation early yesterday inside a Boston nightclub, according to the police.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The numbers speak for us. We will fight in democratic ways. The truth is our strongest weapon. We don't want to provoke internal tensions and foreign intervention.''

title: Household Income Rises to Record Level in 1999
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Average household income rose to a record level in 1999 as more and more Americans were lifted out of poverty in this era of prosperity, the government said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALEXION PHARMACEUTICALS INC., New Haven, a biopharmaceutical company, bought the closely held Prolifaron Inc., San Diego, for $41 million in stock to speed development of its antibody drugs.

title: Power to Erase Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Are the Hardy-Har-Hars of Yesteryear?
description: Whatever the deficiencies of the new Broadway production of ''The Best Man,'' Gore Vidal's 1960 take on presidential politics, it draws attention to the rhetorical flatness and general humorlessness of the current political contests. Viewers looking for some semblance of wit or cleverness find a crop of stock phrases and standard gestures. Epigrams are outlawed and the language is as strictly restricted as immigration law lest some intended drollery slip in. Perhaps the candidates have learned from Mr. Vidal's shaky political career that being clever is not a route to electoral popularity.

title: Giants See Error of Their Ways, but Take It Lightly
description: The mistakes had seemed minor in the past, hidden behind winning scores and masked by inferior opponents. The Giants realized they had eluded perfection each week and yet they entered their game Sunday night against the Washington Redskins undefeated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, HERBERT JOHN
description: GOLDFRANK-Herbert John. Died at his home in Thornwood, N.Y. on September 9, 2000. He would have celebrated 93 years on September 11th. He is survived by his wife Helen, his son Lewis and daughter-in-law Susan, his daughter Joan and son-in-law Michael, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, Ossining, N.Y. 10562.

title: Sob Stories for Sydney
description: Tom Greenwald is an advertising copywriter. Designed by Will Pflaum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFTER, RITA
description: GEFTER-Rita, died at age 50 on September 25, 2000. Beloved wife of Larry, loving mother of Jodi and Dana, devoted daughter of Rose and Henry Zukor, sister of Susan (Arie) Bauer, cherisheddaughter-in-law of Marilyn and Michael Gefter. Services at 12 Noon on Wednesday, September 27, 2000, at Riverdale Temple at W. 246 St and Independence Ave in Riverdale, NY.

title: U.S. Mens Soccer Team Succumbs to Spain
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- The unimagined has now become almost a necessity. Having lost to Spain, 3-1, in the semifinals tonight, the United States wants to bring back a medal from the Olympic soccer competition.

title: Searching for Genes to Slow The Hands of Biological Time
description: ''Research is a very circuitous road. It requires tremendous patience and tolerance for failure. That's something you don't find out about yourself till you actually do it. It's depressing to put so much time and effort into something and have nothing to show for it.''

title: Technology Briefings
description: DEALS

title: The Rural Life; The Towner Tragedy
description: I was in Eads, Colo., recently, just passing through, which is true of nearly everyone who has ever come to Eads. The town lies on a major truck route across southeastern Colorado.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Decides Not to Hear Microsoft Case
description: The Supreme Court, granting a Microsoft request Tuesday, refused to hear the massive antitrust case that threatens to break the computer software giant in two. The justices said the case first should be heard by a federal appeals court.

title: Air France Adds To U.S. Flights
description: Air France S.A., Europe's No. 3 airline, said today that it would increase service to the United States this winter by 14 percent from last year, adding 17 flights a day on North Atlantic routes, where airline profits are being squeezed by excess capacity.

title: Senator and Delegate Back Plan to Reopen Pennsylvania Avenue
description: Mayor Anthony A. Williams, backed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Eleanor Holmes Norton, this city's nonvoting Congressional delegate, today urged the reopening of Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House, calling it a ''visual blight'' to ''America's Main Street.''

title: POVERTY TOUR REVISITED/American Voices; Forget Washington. The Poor Cope Alone.
description: In Eastern Kentucky, a 15-year-old boy dreams of quitting school to make real money working at a pizza parlor. Here in Clarksdale, a 68-year-old widow thanks God that she can manage the $200-a-month rent on a house one good rain could wash away. In East St. Louis, Ill., a 20-year-old mother of six wishes she could find a public housing project where the broken glass on the stoop is swept away.

title: NTT DoCoMo Confirms Talks With AOL
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., the largest mobile communications company in Japan, confirmed today that it was in advanced talks about an alliance with America Online. A deal could greatly expand the AOL presence in Japan, where it has made little headway since introducing its services here three years ago.

title: In Lieberman's Own Party, Pressure to Exit Senate Race
description: With Democrats growing more confident about their chances of regaining control of the Senate this fall, several colleagues of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman are pressuring him to let another Connecticut Democrat seek his seat so that the party will not lose it if he becomes vice president.

title: Mientkiewiczs Home Run Propels U.S. to Gold-Medal Game Against Cuba
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Moments after he was cut last spring, a stunned Doug Mientkiewicz had to make a torturous 500-yard walk across the parking lot, from the Twins' glamorous major league facility to its minor league outpost, from the big time to Mayberry.

title: More Companies Offering Same-Sex-Partner Benefits
description: More companies are offering health insurance benefits to partners of gay and lesbian employees than ever before, including more than 100 of the Fortune 500 companies, a new study has found.

title: The High Cost of Making Headlines
description: SYDNEY , Australia -- They entered the room holding hands. Marion Jones, one of the world's greatest sprinters, and her husband, C. J. Hunter, who was coming off as one of the world's biggest head cases.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELLIN, SAMUEL
description: GELLIN-Samuel 9/25/'90 In loving memory. Ine

title: Junk Food and Obese Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, NORMA B.
description: GOLDSMITH-Norma B. Beloved wife of Sandy. Devoted mother of Lauren and John Saverino, Bruce and Lorraine, Barry and Flo, Jennifer and Lewis Biblowitz. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Dylan, Kathleen, Joshua, Alexa, Bryan and Jonah. Dear sister of Sheldon and Lucille Gruber. Services Tuesday, 10:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENT; Doctors Try Cooling as Stroke Therapy
description: A small experiment in Copenhagen that involved efforts to limit a stroke's damage by cooling patients down generated enough evidence of a benefit to warrant larger-scale testing, according to an article in the September issue of the journal Stroke.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the start of the Summer Olympics misstated the precedents faced by the rower Steven Redgrave in his effort to win a gold medal in each of five Olympics. He would be the third athlete, not the first, to accomplish that. The Hungarian fencer Aladar Gerevich won gold medals in six Olympics, and his teammate Pal Kovacs won gold in five.

title: Sports of The Times; Facing Backlash Head-On
description: KEYSHAWN JOHNSON flipped through the clippings of New York newspaper articles about his new team's 21-17 loss to his old team on Sunday. He expected what he saw: ''This Flashlight Leaves Key in the Dark.'' ''Keyshawn Looks Like Invisible Star.'' ''Keyshawn's a Mascot for All Loudmouths.''

title: Little Hope for Police Pacts As Nassau Budget Is Studied
description: Lawmakers who spent most of today examining the high costs of policing in Nassau County came away with one overriding sentiment: the proposed labor contracts that County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has negotiated with two police unions are all but dead.

title: Sports of The Times; A Gold Medal In One Race Is Big Enough For 2 Nations
description: We often talk about people carrying the weight of the world on their shoulders, but never really mean it as much more than a metaphor.

title: The Carefully Examined American Life, Continued
description: CHERRY

title: DISCORD AT CHINA TRADE TALKS
description: The World Trade Organization's top diplomat in charge of talks on China's entry, Pierre-Louis Girard, stormed out of a negotiating session and threatened to resign after a shouting match with China's top trade negotiator, Long Yongtu, left. The dispute, which was subsequently resolved, reflected China's frustration over what it views as new demands by future trading partners. Elizabeth Olson

title: Bid to Toughen Drinking Law Holds Up Transportation Bill
description: A major fight has erupted in Congress over a proposal to compel states to adopt a more stringent standard for drunken driving, under the threat of losing millions of dollars in federal highway aid.

title: Article 2000092692205885722 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Truth About Bob Jones
description: To the Editor:

title: The Times and Wen Ho Lee
description: On March 6, 1999, The New York Times reported that Government investigators believed China had accelerated its nuclear weapons program with the aid of stolen American secrets. The article said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had focused its suspicions on a Chinese-American scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. Two days later, the government announced that it had fired a Los Alamos scientist for ''serious security violations.'' Officials identified the man as Wen Ho Lee.

title: Controversial Drug Makes a Comeback
description: In 1983, the morning sickness drug Bendectin was removed from the market amid a barrage of lawsuits claiming that it caused birth defects. Now, in what medical and legal experts say is a highly unusual reversal of fortune, it may well be brought back.

title: Forecasters at a Loss With Absence of El Nino
description: For many parts of the Americas and Asia, the occasional warming and cooling cycles in the tropical Pacific Ocean known as El Nino and La Nina are unwelcome visitors -- barging in, usually with little warning, then staying for months or sometimes a year or two, bringing all kinds of baggage in the form of distorted patterns of storms and droughts, heat and cold.

title: Rescheduling Not Ordered, Ebersol Says
description: With each successive day bringing more disappointing ratings for his taped Summer Olympic production, Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, said he had not demanded that schedules be altered to let the network carry track and field live in prime time.

title: W.N.B.A. Awaits Australias Jackson
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Lauren Jackson, her brown ponytail wagging behind, ran upcourt after a brief altercation under the basket with the frustrated United States player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, DONALD
description: BERGER-Donald. On September 24, 2000. Cherished father of Allen and Rebecca, Richard, and Rebecca, Helen and Bruce Kronman, and Ruth and Michael Sigal, devoted grandfather of Joshua, Moriah, Rachel, Sara, Michael, Marsha, Eric, Marc, Amy, and Stacey. Dear brother of June Honig, and Sherwin Berger. Beloved friend of Judy Rosenblatt. Fond uncle and cousin. Services today 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his name to The Sierra Club.

title: HONG KONG STOCKS GAIN
description: Hong Kong's leading stock index, the Hang Seng index, staged its biggest one-day gain in points and percentage this year, but volume was thin, indicating that many investors remained cautious. The Hang Seng closed up 5.58 percent, or 816.07 points, at 15,428.95. Blue chips that were sold heavily in Friday's technology sell-off were the focus of buying interest as traders covered short positions.

title: Lieberman's Civil Rights Trip
description: In 1963, Joseph I. Lieberman and a carload of other Yale students embarked on a different campaign, in Mississippi for civil rights. Page A21.

title: International Lenders' New Image: A Human Face
description: Deepa Narayan, a Indian woman with a steely gaze who spends much of her time in the poorest villages on earth, speaks of power, voice and equality as the keys to ending poverty. Keeping men from beating women does far more to raise living standards than any dam project ever did, she argues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALKIN, ROBERT
description: BIALKIN-Robert. Passed away September 24, 2000 at home in Amherst, New Hampshire. Son of Samuel and Lillian Bialkin. Husband of Harriet. Father of Deborah Eisenberg, Rachel Behrens, Jesse and Rodney, brother of Kenneth and the late Edith Barth. Also survived by five grandchildren. Services at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, 11:30AM Tues., September26. N Y City, NY. No flowers, please.

title: Champions Of 400
description: Cathy Freeman, running for Australia and its Aborigines, won the 400-meter race, and Michael Johnson repeated as the men's champion.

description: BYRNES-Mary Elizabeth formerly of Larchmont, NY. Beloved wife of the late Frank A. Byrnes. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Watt. Cherished grandmother of William Edward Watt, Mary Catherine Watt and Kerry Anne Watt. Great grandmother of Anna Elizabeth. Loving mother-in-law of William Anthony Watt. Inquiries Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Funeral Home, Inc.
