Professor Lay was an educator at City College and helped establish the ESL Department. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St,. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121 St., Friday, 10 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Breast Center of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Better Off Than Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleuths Solve Case of Bubble Mistaken for a Snapping Shrimp
description: How does a snapping shrimp snap?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ALICE
description: LEVY-Alice. On September 23, 2000 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Irving Levy. Cherished mother of Linda Grabel, Paul Levy and Karen Meshnick and mother-in-law of William Grabel, Nancy Levy and Michael Meshnick. Loving grandmother of Naomi, Cara, Jonathan, Glen, Cheryl, Jason, Jennifer and Jillian and great-grandmother of Zachary, Benjamin and Maxwell. Devoted grandmother-in-law to the Case, Harris and Sachs families. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Her family meant everything to her and she meant everything to them. Contributions to Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, NY would be appreciated.

title: Colleges Now Courting Their Black Alumni
description: In the 13 years since she graduated, Cheryl Jenkins Haywood has viewed calls from Harvard Law School as an intrusion. When it asked for her help in recruiting others like her -- young, talented and black -- she refused.

title: Hunter, Joness Husband, Denies Drug Charge
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 26  The husband of Marion Jones denied today that he had taken steroids and said that a mislabeled nutritional supplement was responsible for elevated levels of the performance-enhancing drug nandrolone in his system.

title: Supreme Court Adds a Dozen New Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  While the Supreme Court's decision not to hear the Microsoft case grabbed the headlines today, the justices were also busy on another front, adding a dozen new cases to their docket for the new term that opens next Monday.

title: Going, Going, Gone? U.S. Now Going Strong
description: Ask the players on the United States softball team to describe their first week at the Olympics, and they use the same word: nightmare. After winning their first two games, the team lost three in a row, shattering a 112-game winning streak and putting a gold medal seemingly out of reach.

title: State G.O.P. Pushing Issues Unlike Bush's
description: New York Republicans, faced with a set of pivotal legislative races in November, are running campaigns that are increasingly at odds with the policies of their party's presidential nominee, George W. Bush.

title: Jury in New York Orders Bosnian Serb to Pay Billions
description: A jury in federal court in Manhattan yesterday ordered Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb wartime leader, to pay $4.5 billion in damages to victims of rape, torture and genocide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ADENA
description: RUBIN-Adena (Lipschitz). On September 24th, 2000 at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Eli H. Rubin. Loving mother of Zick, Leonard, and Susan Gesner Danziger. Devoted grandmother of Larry, Matthew, Mark, Elihu, and Noam, and great-grandmother of Meg and Burt. Dear sister of Sarah Novogrodsky, Maish Lippman, and the late Sadie Zide, Leah Rubin, Deb Slater, and Ralph Lippman. Caring aunt and great-aunt. Outstanding teacher and Hadassah leader. Burial was on Monday. Contributions may be made to the Solomon Schechter Day School of Greater Boston, 125 Wells Ave., Newton, MA 02459.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Another Executive Leaves Janus Funds
description: Another executive has departed Janus Capital, the Denver company that is the nation's fifth-largest manager of mutual funds. Last month, James Craig, the respected chief investment officer, said he would leave to manage money for a charitable foundation. Yesterday, a federal filing disclosed that the chief financial officer was also leaving.

title: Nominees Tangle in Back-to-Back Debates
description: Probably no Senate Democrat has a tougher re-election fight than Charles S. Robb of Virginia, who trails his Republican challenger, former Gov. George Allen, by up to 10 percentage points in some polls.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; Something Special in That Glass of Wine
description: Ever since the evidence began to accumulate that moderate wine consumption can reduce the risk of heart disease, researchers have sought to discover whether the benefit lay simply in the alcohol consumed, or whether wine offered additional protection.

title: A Violetta, No Languishing Consumptive She, Leaves Scenery Intact
description: Of the many modes in which the enterprising New York City Opera functions these days, an opera from the heart of the repertory in a fully conventional production may soon be the rarest. But there was Verdi's ''Traviata'' on Friday evening, returning to the New York State Theater in Renata Scotto's 1995 staging.

title: Some See Hope in Biofeedback for Attention Disorder
description: If a child at the Enrico Fermi School in Yonkers is found to have attention deficit disorder, parents can choose an unusual alternative to medication: neurofeedback, a computerized biofeedback system that some say strengthens the brain.

title: A New School Rule: Play With Your Food!
description: To the Editor:

title: So Which One is Mommy Dearest?
description: At the center of ''The Comedy of Innocence'' is a round-faced, apple-cheeked moppet named Camille (Nils Hugon) who lives in serene haut-bourgeois elegance in an old house in Paris. Shortly after his ninth birthday, Camille, whose closest companions are a possibly imaginary friend named Alexandre and a video camera, starts behaving strangely. He insists that his name is Paul and starts addressing his mother (Isabelle Huppert), with cold formality, by her first name, which is Ariane. Soon he has dragged her halfway across the city to the chic bohemian apartment of the woman he claims is his real mother, a flighty violin teacher named Isabella (Jeanne Balibar), whose son drowned two years earlier.

title: A Reminder to Wash
description: To the Editor:

title: A Composer May Age, but the Compositions Are Ever Young
description: Things both change and do not change. That is perhaps the central lesson of Steve Reich's music, and through matching concerts he gave with his regular musicians at Miller Theater on Thursday and Saturday evenings, the lesson zigzagged through many dimensions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Writers on Writing series yesterday, by Sara Paretsky, misidentified the creator of the mystery novel character Brigid O'Shaughnessy. He was Dashiell Hammett, not Raymond Chandler.

title: Great Britains Percy Maintain Lead
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- It has been said that into everyone's life a little rain must fall. Today, under bleak skies in Sydney Harbor, it descended on the United States skipper Russ Silvestri and his two dozen opponents in the Finn single-handed dinghy class as the second week of the Olympic sailing competition continued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, ANNE
description: DYSON-Anne, Dr. The Advisory Board and staff of the Children's Defense Fund-New York notes with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Anne Dyson. Dr. Dyson's commitment to and direct work with the Children's Defense Fund, both on a national and state level, was unparalleled. The legacy of Dr. Dyson's vision will continue on through the many children whose lives were improved as a result of her generosity and dedication. Our thoughts and prayers are with her husband Michael, her children Roberto and Mac and her family. Maureen Cogan, Vice Chair, CDF Donna A. Lawrence, Executive Director, CDF-NY

title: A UNIT OF SHELL OIL WILL SELL ITS GAS PIPELINES IN LOUISIANA
description: A unit of the Shell Oil Company, the United States arm of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, agreed yesterday to sell a 1,000-mile natural gas pipeline system in southern Louisiana to Enterprise Products Partners L.P. for $226 million. Acadian Gas L.L.C., now owned by Shell's Coral Energy unit, can handle 1 billion cubic feet of gas a day. The system's three pipelines -- the Acadian, Evangeline and Cypress lines -- link gas wells to electric companies and industrial gas consumers and to major interstate pipelines.

title: Sand and Hot Coals Line Path to Gold for Australians
description: Australia's Kerri Pottharst Potsy to her friends -- became a beach volleyball player for the most obvious reason of all.

title: A Happier Second Act; After a Slow Season and a Community Protest, Manhattan Theater Club Savors Its Comeback
description: Nineteen ninety-eight was not a good year for the Manhattan Theater Club. In the spring the playwrights Jon Robin Baitz and Richard Greenberg said they would no longer bring their work to the theater club because they felt that its aging audiences were unresponsive. Then the theater club, a 30-year-old nonprofit institution that produces plays off Broadway at City Center, became front-page news for caving in to bomb threats and canceling its production of Terrence McNally's ''Corpus Christi,'' a decision it later reversed after protests from writers, actors and civil liberties groups.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILLIATT, NEAL
description: GILLIATT-Neal. There will be a memorial service on Thursday, September 28, at 4:00 PM at the Second Congregational Church, 139 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT (for directions call 203869-9311). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Neal Gilliatt Chair in Marketing in care of the Indiana University Foundation, Kelley School of Business, PO Box 500, Bloomington, IN 47401

title: Turks Protest U.S. Bill Calling Armenian Deaths "Genocide"
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 26  Angry over a bill in the United States Congress labeling the 1915 killing of Armenians genocide, Turks demonstrated outside the American consulate here today, and political leaders warned that the legislation could damage Turkish-United States relations.

title: A Composer Who Freed Performers
description: One of the great things about the music of John Dowland is the degree to which it gives performers control of matters that eventually became a composer's prerogative. In Dowland's songbooks lush vocal harmonies are offered, but the music's flexibility is such that if four or five singers are not available a single singer (or two, or three) could perform the song with the additional harmonies played on the lute, or on viols or even recorders.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about feuds among Labor Party members of Britain's government, who were told by Prime Minister Tony Blair to quit bickering so that their party would survive, misstated the title of CBS's summer game show about ruthless competitors on a desert island. It was ''Survivor,'' not ''Survival.''

title: Debate Over Milk: Time to Look at Facts
description: ''Got milk?'' cries the National Dairy Council, seeking to reverse or at least stem a half-century decline in per capita consumption of this nutrient-packed beverage.

title: How to Dance Balanchine? 6 Troupes Count the Ways
description: George Balanchine the abstractionist. Balanchine the storyteller. Balanchine the prankster. Those facets of Balanchine's choreographic personality were beautifully displayed when the San Francisco Ballet and the Pennsylvania Ballet shared a program this afternoon as part of the Balanchine Celebration at the Kennedy Center here.

title: Protecting Coral
description: To the Editor:

title: Savon Is Easy Winner Over Benett
description: To upset Cuba's famed two-time Olympic boxing champion Felix Savon, the United States heavyweight Michael Bennett knew he had to avoid Savon's mighty right hand at any cost. That was the American plan, but Bennett, giving away 6 1/2 inches in height to Savon, couldn't stay out of Savon's range.

title: Lee Erwin, 92, Organist and Composer, Dies
description: Lee Erwin, a theater organist who composed scores for more than 70 silent films and whose performances helped create a revival of interest in silent films during the 1970's, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 92.

title: Sports of The Times; Marion Jones Needs a Quiet Understanding
description: The Olympics continued here tonight, despite the revelation that Marion Jones's husband had joined a thousand Bulgarian weight lifters in the holding pen for drug cheats who claim the laboratory lied.

title: WEBVAN FOUNDER STEPS ASIDE
description: The Webvan Group, which sells food and other goods over the Internet, named its chief executive, George Shaheen, as chairman to replace its founder, Louis Borders. Mr. Borders, who also founded the Borders bookstore chain, will remain a director. Mr. Shaheen was chief executive at Andersen Consulting, the world's largest management-consulting company, before joining Webvan in September 1999.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Decides Not to Hear Microsoft Case
description: The Supreme Court, granting a Microsoft request Tuesday, refused to hear the massive antitrust case that threatens to break the computer software giant in two. The justices said the case first should be heard by a federal appeals court.

title: For Escalators and Elevators, Newer Isn't Better, Report Says
description: Dozens of new subway elevators and escalators installed during the last six years at a cost of more than $500 million have been breaking down more often than the system's older elevators and escalators, an examination by the public advocate's office has found.

title: A Place to Turn When Breast Cancer Strikes
description: ''Breast Cancer: The Complete Guide'' (third edition), by Dr. Yashar Hirshaut and Dr. Peter I. Pressman (Bantam Books, $15.95).

title: Ups and Downs for Diet Guinea Pigs
description: Like many people discussing the rigors of being on a diet, Jeffrey A. Behrendt, a lawyer in Ottawa, sounds both plaintive and hopeful.

title: The Big City; To Our Guests
description: WELCOME to the Lincoln Bedroom! This room has a special place in the history of the nation; and, more important, in the history of the Clinton family. It's where our best friends stay. We can't always be here to welcome you personally, but whether you're spending the night or taking a Junior Donor Nap, you'll always find clean towels and warm hospitality. So relax! You're family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINCHESTER, MADELINE K.
description: WINCHESTER-Madeline K. On September 24, 2000 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late William Winchester, loving mother of Dr. Robert Winchester and grandmother of Alan and Priscilla Winchester. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at St Monica's Church, 413 E 79 St, Thursday 10am. Interment to follow at Gate of Heavan Cemetery.

title: AT&T EXPANSION IN ARGENTINA
description: The Latin American unit of the AT&T Corporation will build a 1,000-mile fiber optic network in Argentina to link the nation's major cities. The network is part of AT&T's effort to provide high-speed data services to Buenos Aires, Rosario, Santa Fe, La Plata, Cordoba and Mendoza. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAIDORF, BLANCHE
description: NAIDORF-Blanche,on September 24th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Irving. Devoted mother of Michael and the late Dr. Kenneth. Adored grandmother of Meredith and Matthew. Cherished motherin-law of Kelly Naidorf and Dr. Ellen Naidorf. Dear sister of Pearl Lipper and Beatrice Kaplan. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 12:30 PM, Tuesday.

title: Plan by Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., a maker of computer servers that power Internet sites and run corporate networks, will invest $50 million in Asia-Pacific companies to expand markets for its products and support its technology-development efforts. Sun plans to focus first on start-up Internet and communications companies in Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Australia. With investments from local venture capital partners, the Sun Asia Pacific Venture Investment Program is expected to provide $250 million for companies in the region, Sun said.

title: MCI to Begin Review Of an Account
description: MCI WorldCom, the consumer unit of WorldCom, said yesterday that it had begun a review of its long-distance subscription advertising account, with billings estimated at $70 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELOVE, BERTHA
description: ABELOVE-Bertha. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Dr. Laurence Abelove. Cherished grandmother of Jason. Dear sister of Anna Krakower. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the East Midwood Jewish Center, Ocean Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11230 would be appreciated.

title: High Court Says Appeals Court Should Review Microsoft Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - In a disappointment for the Justice Department, the Supreme Court declined today to hear the Microsoft case at this time, declaring that a lower federal appeals court should take up the matter first.

title: Morgan Stanley Makes Executive Changes
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company named new managers yesterday for its trading, research, investment banking and asset management units in the biggest executive changes since the firm's creation in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, EDWARD S.
description: GORDON-Edward S. The Directors, Trustees and Staff of National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver, CO, express their sincerest condolences to the Gordon Family and the many friends of Edward S. Gordon. Mr. Gordon was a 1991 recipient of The National Jewish Medical and Research Center Humanitarian Award. In addition, he established The Paula Gordon Memorial Research Fund in allergies at National Jewish. Mr. Gordon enriched the lives of those near him and did so for patients at National Jewish, as well, through the establishment of The Allergy Research Fund. Family, friends, and business associates will truly miss his leadership and friendship. Larry Silverstein, Treasurer National Jewish Medical and Research Center Lynn M. Tauffig, MD, President and CEO National Jewish Medical and Research Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, DR. ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Board and the Staff of the Hole in the Wall Gang Fund are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Anne Dyson. She served our organization from its earliest stage with skill, generosity and commitment. Most especially, however, we will remember her compassion and humanity on behalf of the seriously ill children in our care. Each person affiliated with the Hole in the Wall Gang says ''God Bless You'' on behalf of the thousands of children whose lives were made better in so many ways by Anne Dyson. Our sincere sympathy goes out to each member of her family, to whom she meant so much.

title: Drug Testing in U.S. Comes Under Fire From Olympic Officials
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- As the husband of Marion Jones seeks to clear his name, the entire system of drug testing in the United States has come under fire from international Olympic officials who considered the Americans hypocritical, laggard and deceptive in their handling of doping cases.

title: Shares Fall as Investors Worry About Earnings Reports
description: Stock prices slipped again yesterday, pulled down by continued worries about coming earnings reports from big technology companies.

title: Bush Expands on Education Theme, Saying a Reading Crisis Endangers the Economy
description: Sounding his new slogan intended to raise anxieties about the nation's well-being, Gov. George W. Bush accused the Clinton administration today of helping create an ''education recession'' in which minority and low-income students were routinely allowed to fail.

title: F.D.A. Rejection Sends Cell Pathways Plummeting
description: It is a fabled story in the biotechnology industry. Floyd Nichols, a computer salesman and entrepreneur who had a rare disease that leads to colon cancer, heard of a drug that might save his life. When he could not interest a pharmaceutical company in developing the drug, he formed his own company. And although it was too late for Mr. Nichols -- he died of cancer in 1996 at age 43 -- the drug is now being used experimentally to treat his son, Eric, who also has the disease.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about presidential candidates in Zambia who are testing their political messages on voters in the Copperbelt, the country's industrial section, misspelled the surname of the incumbent president. He is Frederick Chiluba, not Chibila.

title: DIPIETRO RECOVERING
description: The Islanders' No. 1 draft pick, Rick DiPietro, practiced yesterday in Syosset, N.Y., for the first time in full pads since pulling a groin muscle Wednesday, but Coach Butch Goring said it was unlikely he would start in goal against either the Rangers on Sunday or the Devils on Monday, in the final preseason game.

title: Rangers Have Familiar Cast, and That's Not Good
description: The faces in the Rangers' front office are very different this fall. On the ice, however, many of the faces on the Rangers' top three lines will be the same, with a few exceptions.

title: 'Positive Spirit' as Arafat and Barak Meet
description: In an effort to improve a strained relationship, Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, met tonight for the first time since the Camp David peace talks ended two months ago.

title: Penn State Player Has Spinal Surgery
description: Adam Taliaferro, the Penn State freshman cornerback who suffered a spinal injury during a loss to Ohio State on Saturday, underwent successful surgery yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, the school's sports information department announced.

title: A Mediocre Victory Punctuated By Carter
description: Sometime between last May and tonight, Vince Carter developed a serrated edge on the court. Gone is the cuddly Toronto Raptors acrobat with the postgame disposition of a koala and the ''Inside Stuff'' smile.

title: Sugar in Disguise
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CALIBER LEARNING NETWORK, Baltimore, named Mark F. Yanson chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer at the iSky Corporation.

title: SENATE APPROVES $7.8  BILLION  PLAN TO AID EVERGLADES
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to approve a $7.8 billion plan intended to restore the Everglades and its ecosystem, a project supporters say is the most ambitious environmental restoration effort ever.

title: Judge Dismisses State Suit Over Pollution of Hudson
description: A lawsuit filed by New York State's attorney general against General Electric last year arguing that the company should be held liable for the economic costs of pollution in the Hudson River has been dismissed by an Albany judge, who called it ''premature'' and ''meritless.''

title: Sixth Duke of Sutherland, 85, Art Collector
description: The sixth Duke of Sutherland, a Scottish landowner who held one of the largest private collections of old master paintings in the world, died on Thursday. He was 85 and lived on the family estate near St. Boswells, Scotland.

title: Front Row
description: With Fashion Week behind us, it is time now to revisit some of the ideas and philosophies behind the clothes. These may not always be legible in the garments themselves, or for that matter, in the designers' often loopy press notes. Do these explain what the viewer has just seen or obscure it? The answer is not always clear. And that may be the point. Nobody is looking to Marc Jacobs for a sequel to the ''Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.'' And let's face it: Ludwig Wittgenstein probably couldn't baste a hem.

title: Americans Win Beach Volleyball
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26  Dain Blanton and Eric Fonoimoana are leaving this Olympic city with "some Australian sand in our ears"  and perhaps the most surprising of gold medals gained by American athletes here.

title: School Board to Turn to Outside Advisers
description: In a concession to the complexity of running a 21st-century school board, the New York City Board of Education is planning to add outside experts from the corporate world, government and community organizations to its committees that deal with everything from finance to education policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, CATHERINE T.
description: COLEMAN-Catherine T. On September 24, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Patrick. Loving daughter of Clara and the late James V. Cole. Loving mother of James, Maureen Stamos, Patrick, Kathleen, Michael, John and the late Frances. Dear sister of Mary Corcoran, Frances Fordeliso, Dorothy Maier, Patricia Shipley, James E. Cole and the late Rev. William J. Cole. Also survived by eleven grandchildren. Visitation, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 3rd Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: Blair Takes Blame for Labors Low Poll Ratings
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 26  Prime Minister Tony Blair took personal blame today for government actions that have sent Labor's resilient poll ratings plummeting this month. But he urged the party to have confidence that it would defeat the Conservatives and win a second term in the election expected this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, FRANK B.
description: CLANCY-Frank B. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Frank B. Clancy, a Veteran Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: OIL REFINER PLANS OFFERING
description: China's largest oil refiner, Sinopec, plans to raise as much as $3.85 billion by selling 20 percent of its shares in New York and Hong Kong next month. The company was carved out of the larger state-owned Sinopec Group to raise capital for the expansion of the country's energy industry. Exxon Mobil Corporation, BP Amoco P.L.C., Royal Dutch/Shell Group and ABB Ltd. of Sweden have already agreed to buy more than half of the shares offered. Craig S. Smith

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A4-12

title: Older, Wiser and Still Reaching Out to Help
description: IF you wanted a house fit for a children's picture book, you could do no better than Mia Farrow's home in Connecticut.

title: For Asian Satellite Network, Simplicity Is Simply Better
description: After months of gloomy news in the satellite communications sector, analysts are looking forward to the commercial debut tomorrow of an Indonesian satellite phone venture focused strictly on Asia.

title: I.R.S. Issues Revised Memo On Kidnapping
description: The Internal Revenue Service, which came under fire in Congress three weeks ago over a legal memorandum that said the parents of a kidnapped child could not receive a tax break for the missing child in the years after the abduction, reversed itself yesterday.

title: Birth and Death of Stars
description: Q.: Are stars all burning out, or are new ones forming?

title: Credit Card Company Settles Over Ads
description: The MBNA Corporation agreed today to pay as much as $7.8 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing the company, the world's No. 3 credit card issuer, of luring consumers with misleading advertisements about low-rate cards.

title: Braves and Division Titles Are the Norm
description: The stands were speckled by the eighth inning, more empty than filled. There was no reason to stay on a raw night when the Mets played dead and their rival, the Atlanta Braves, buried their hopes for a division championship.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- St. Louis and Fayette, Mo.

title: Bush, Baseball Owner
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate on Need for New Power Plants Ignores Conservation
description: New Yorkers heard a lot this summer about why their electricity bills were going up and why a new generation of power plants was needed, and the message centered on one word: demand.

title: Yugoslavia's Opposition Leader Claims Victory Over Milosevic
description: The opposition candidate in the Yugoslav presidential election claimed victory today over Slobodan Milosevic in elections on Sunday. But with official vote counting suspended, there were concerns about whether Mr. Milosevic is willing to acknowledge defeat.

title: The White Sox Are Showing That Sometimes Less Can Be More
description: No greater irony could impose itself on the playoffs than the presence of the Chicago White Sox. No. 26 in the Major League Baseball payroll standing for most of the season, the White Sox have the majors' best won-lost record and are the newly crowned champions of the American League Central.

title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROCHOWSKY, JOAN CAROL
description: GROCHOWSKY-Joan Carol. On September 24, 2000 at age 53. Survived by her devoted husband Gerald, Deputy District Director, Management, of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York City, her devoted daughter Jennifer Alison, her loving father William Fliegelman, Retired Chief Judge U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service, her loving mother Shirley, her dear sister Susan Oseroff and beloved nephew Marc. She was an outstanding public school teacher who received many accolades. She will not be forgotten. Funeral services Wednesday, 12 noon at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Exp, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: High Court Says Appeals Court Should Review Microsoft Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Supreme Court handed a victory to the Microsoft Corporation today when it summarily rejected the government's plea to immediately hear the appeal of its landmark antitrust case and instead returned the proceeding to an intermediate appeals court, in effect prolonging the legal battle by at least a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, ROBERT
description: MAHONEY-Robert, of Bridgehampton, N.Y. On September 10, 2000 in his 69th year. Survived by his loving wife Helene, and several nieces and nephews. He was the Superintendent of Manhattan Sites for the Dept. of the Interior and received the Founders Award for development of the Gateway National Recreation Area. Memorial services will be held on Oct. 7, at the Queen of The Most Holy Rosary Church, 2350 Montauk Highway Bridgehampton at 1:00 p.m. and on Nov. 2, at 5:30 p.m. at Federal Hall, 26 Wall Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Robert Mahoney Memorial Fund, C/O Queen of The Most Holy Rosary Church, P.O. Box 3035, Bridgehampton, N.Y. 11932 or the Dominican Sisters Family Health Services, P.O. Box 1028, Hampton Bays, N.Y. 11946

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGIDSON, EUGENE
description: MAGIDSON-Eugene. On September 23, 2000, of Merrick, LI. Beloved husband of the late Thelma. Devoted father of Harry. Dear brother of Anne Stone and Sam. Cherished friend of Marjorie Gray. Graveside services Wednesday, 11:00 AM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Plan by Russian Metals Producer Outrages Shareholders
description: Norilsk Nickel of Russia, the world's biggest palladium producer, sought today to allay growing investor anger over a reorganization plan that minority shareholders call a brazen move to dilute their stakes.

title: Rome Journal; In This Gladiators' Arena, Even Nero Is Bloodless
description: The first lesson at the gladiator school of the Roman Historical Society stressed discipline. ''You are slaves, and that is how I will treat you,'' Giuseppe Coluzzi, 32, barked at eight adults fidgeting in short white togas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLER, JANE
description: MALLER-Jane. A dear and true friend for 40 years, who enriched our lives with her kindness, dignity and insight. We extend sympathy to her devoted family. Carol and Emil Pomerantz

title: INSTINET OFFERING PLANNED
description: The British news service Reuters has decided to sell shares in Instinet, its electronic trading platform, in an initial offering, according to a person close to the company's planning. In February, Reuters said it had appointed Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to underwrite a public offering of its Greenhouse Fund, which invests in technology and Internet businesses. And last year, Reuters floated shares in its software subsidiary, Tibco. Reuters executives declined to comment. Suzanne Kapner

title: U.S. Softball Team Reaffirms Its Dominance
description: BLACKTOWN, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Laura Berg saw the ball sailing, and the Japanese left fielder, Shiori Koseki, straining. Halfway down the first-base line, Berg realized Koseki would be there, in position. She watched the glove go up, and the catch being made. And then Koseki was falling, the ball dislodging, with Koseki landing on her back.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Sept. 15 about visiting the Hudson Valley misidentified the operator of the Cascade Mountain Winery restaurant in Amenia, N.Y. It is run by the winery, not affiliated with the Culinary Institute of America.

title: North and South Korea Agree to Repair Rail Link in DMZ
description: CHEJU, Korea, Sept. 26  North and South Korea reached agreement today on the limited reopening of the demilitarized zone dividing the two countries to allow repair work on a railway link that has been severed for more than 50 years.

title: Bush Would Use Medicare For Tax Cuts, Gore Says
description: Campaigning in Florida, where as many as 40 percent of this November's voters may be 60 or older, Vice President Al Gore promised today to strengthen sanctions against health maintenance organizations that pull out of the Medicare market and to eliminate Medicare copayments and deductibles for a variety of preventive tests.

title: As Nassau Sinks, Suffolk Gloats; A County's Misfortunes Have a Neighbor Snickering
description: Robert S. Wilson, a firefighter here, got right to the point when asked what he liked about living in Suffolk County: ''Our budget isn't going down the tubes.''

title: Biotech Corn Isn't Serious Threat to Monarchs, Draft U.S. Report Finds
description: In a finding that is being hailed by the biotechnology industry and denounced by environmentalists, the Environmental Protection Agency has issued a preliminary report concluding that genetically modified corn is unlikely to pose a serious threat to monarch butterflies.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Going Against Summer Traffic

title: The Doctor Is So Dedicated. So Are His Opponents.
description: Marion Lipschutz and Rose Rosenblatt clearly state their purpose at the beginning of their film ''Live Free or Die,'' which PBS is showing tonight as part of the series ''P.O.V.'' These filmmakers wanted to produce a documentary about what they call ''the abortion provider crisis.'' What they needed, they say, was a hero: a doctor who endured protests and risked violence by performing abortions and was willing to be tailed by a film crew.

title: MONTREAL EXCHANGE PLANS CHANGES
description: Following the lead of some larger markets, the Montreal Exchange will change its ownership structure on Sunday, with member brokerage firms becoming shareholders in a profit-making company called Montreal Exchange Inc. The Toronto Stock Exchange, Canada largest securities market, became a for-profit company called TSE Inc. in April. The new corporate structures permit capital to be raised from additional sources, including public share offerings. Timothy Pritchard

title: Terfel, as Don Giovanni, Opens Met Opera Season
description: Opera has known its fleeting fames and forgotten masterpieces, but ''Don Giovanni'' is not among them. Since its debut at the Prague National Opera in 1787, Mozart's great work, subtitled ''The Libertine Punished,'' has never been out of the international repertory. Presented with a difficult piece fueled by intricate ensembles and a swiftly moving libretto by Lorenzo da Ponte, companies large and small have had their go at it. In the ''large'' category is the Metropolitan Opera, which opened its season with ''Don Giovanni'' last night.

title: A Parade Of Youth And Stars For Stern
description: Deciding evidently that one evening would not do, Carnegie Hall took a weekend to celebrate Isaac Stern's 80th birthday. On Saturday there were films. Sunday was packed with family concerts. The Miro and Aviv String Quartets played at Weill Recital Hall. Distinguished soloists, singers and members of the New York Philharmonic were everywhere. And a long tribute -- a parade of youth and celebrity -- serenaded Mr. Stern on Sunday evening. Two of his sons conducted; a daughter spoke.

title: World Business Briefings
description: EUROPE

title: Mets-Braves Series Looms As Vital, or Perhaps Not
description: The pressure is off the Mets for the three-game series that begins tonight against Atlanta, but it is not. The first- and second-place teams in the National League East will play games that are not that important, but they are very important. The Mets are so close to advancing to the postseason that they can feel October, but they are not officially excited about anything just yet.

title: DELL ADDS MORE COLOR TO NOTEBOOKS
description: Dell Computer said yesterday it would sell a new notebook computer with a stylized design and snap-on accent panels in a choice of five colors. The model Inspiron 4000 notebook will have processors ranging from a 600 megahertz Celeron to an 850 megahertz Pentium III; prices will start at $1,699. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Republican Group Buys Radio Ad on Behalf of Bob Franks
description: For the last month, New Jerseyans have hardly been able to avoid hearing about the virtues of Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic multimillionaire who has spent more than $1 million a week on television advertising for his Senate campaign. With only six weeks to go before the November election, his underfinanced Republican opponent, Representative Bob Franks, has yet to broadcast a single commercial.

title: Article 2000092691007868077 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Exploring Antibiotics for Gastric Distress
description: Using antibiotics to wipe out the bacteria that cause ulcers can cure some cases of chronic gastrointestinal distress -- far from every case, but enough to make the treatment worth trying, according to an article and editorial in The British Journal of Medicine.

title: 2 Pension Funds Seek Meeting With AT&T Over Stock Slide
description: The comptrollers of the State and City of New York, representing pension funds for public employees that are among the largest shareholders in AT&T, have requested a meeting with its chairman to discuss the company's long-term prospects.

title: Gebrselassie Finishes Like a Sprinter to Beat Tergat in 10,000
description: He finished second to Haile Gebrselassie in the last Summer Olympics; finished second again in the 1997 world championships and the 1999 world championships. But this major race felt different to Paul Tergat of Kenya as he sprinted into the lead with the finish line in sight.

title: Court Holds Hearing on Parole For Killer of 2 Police Officers
description: For the third time since the early 1980's, the New Jersey Supreme Court today took up the politically charged issue of parole for a 62-year-old prisoner who pistol-whipped and murdered two police officers in a nightclub in Lodi, N.J., in August 1963.

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: Sun Names 2 Agencies to Share Its Work

title: Athletes' Injuries Go Beyond the Physical
description: A month after badly breaking her left leg and blowing out her right knee in a skiing crash in Switzerland, Picabo Street, the fearless, spunky media darling of the 1998 Nagano Olympics, shut herself in the bedroom of her parents' house and closed the blinds. She would not let family or friends in, she took no phone calls, did not watch television, did nothing for weeks but lie there in the darkened room thinking miserable thoughts.

title: The Taboos And Panic For Women of Iran
description: Jafar Panahi's first feature, ''The White Balloon,'' released in the United States in 1995 after its debut at the New York Film Festival, was among the first products of the Iranian new wave to reach a wide and enthusiastic audience in the West. That film, the delicate, charming tale of a 7-year-old girl's search, through the workaday bustle of Tehran, for the perfect pet goldfish, showcased what have come to be seen as the hallmarks of contemporary Iranian cinema: a sensitive, unsentimental interest in childhood, extensive use of the outdoors and nonprofessional actors, and an approach to storytelling at once straightforward and elliptical.

title: The Times and Wen Ho Lee
description: On March 6, 1999, The New York Times reported that Government investigators believed China had accelerated its nuclear weapons program with the aid of stolen American secrets. The article said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had focused its suspicions on a Chinese-American scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. Two days later, the government announced that it had fired a Los Alamos scientist for "serious security violations." Officials identified the man as Wen Ho Lee.

title: Music of a Different Sort From Met Opera Protesters
description: As opera lovers arrived at Lincoln Center for last night's opening, they were greeted by hundreds of cacophonous demonstrators backing an effort to unionize 95 restaurant workers at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: In a surprise, Kmart gives a $100 million account to the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day.
description: AN agency that had not initially been identified as a participant in one of the year's biggest reviews landed the assignment yesterday.

title: The Death Penalty Is Beyond Repair
description: To the Editor:

title: Xiong Claims Gold in Diving
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- For five rounds of diving, Xiong Ni had watched Dmitri Sautin whirl through the air in tightly wrapped spins and somersaults, building a lead that neither Xiong nor Sautin's 10 other rivals appeared ready to match. Xiong had come out of retirement specifically to help the Chinese team counter Sautin's pre-eminence, and now he was waiting and hoping for the Russian to give him an opening in the 3-meter springboard final.

title: Letters: Power to Erase Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Folk Remedies, Off the Shelf and Off the Wall
description: ''More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies,'' by Joan Wilen and Lydia Wilen (Ballantine Books, $14).

title: Oil Prices Ebb On Release From Reserve
description: The prices of crude and home heating oil fell yesterday in the wake of the Clinton administration's decision last week to release 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's emergency reserve. But it still appears that this will be a difficult winter for consumers, as home heating oil and gasoline prices remain near 10-year highs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ESTHER
description: SOLOMON-Esther (nee Seltzer). On September 24, 2000. Age 86. Loving wife of the late Milton, dear mother and mother-in-law of Leonard and (Barbara), Allen and (Syril), and Roslyn and (Michael) Tannenbaum. Dear sister of the late Sidney Seltzer. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. An independent, intelligent and caring human being. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory can be made to the American Cancer Society. Services 2 PM today, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn (corner Ave M).

title: A Night Full of Magic, Under the Cast of a Shadow
description: On the most anticipated night of track and field at the Sydney Games, Michael Johnson won his second gold medal in the men's 400 meters and Cathy Freeman stopped a nation in the women's 400. Stacy Dragila won the inaugural women's pole vault and tossed a bouquet of flowers over her shoulder like a bride at her reception. Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia ran 6.2 miles and had to lean like a sprinter at the tape to defeat his nemesis, Paul Tergat of Kenya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTERMAN, SHIRA
description: SCHUSTERMAN-Shira. Hillel: The Foundation For Jewish Campus Life mourns the passing of Shira Schusterman, age 4, after a long illness. She was the beloved daughter of Hal and Ruth Schusterman, cherished sister of Meital and treasured granddaughter of Lynn and Charles Schusterman. May the Schusterman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Hillel International Board of Governors Edgar M. Bronfman Chairman Michael Steinhardt Co-Chair Richard M. Joel, President and Internat'l Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISZ, ARTHUR
description: WEISZ-Arthur, M.D., FACC. On September 25, at age 95. Beloved husband of Edith B. Weisz. Devoted father of George Weisz and cherished grandfather of Jessica Weisz. Interment private.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: A World Torn by Drugs
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Our Towns; In Nassau, Hard to Leave A Gilded Past
description: THE good news is that Nassau County's long-running financial nightmare is reaching a climax. Within weeks, the bumbling band of county officials will take their weed whackers to their beloved bureaucracy, and then they will likely raise taxes (by $100 a household, at most). If not, state officials will take over and do it. And just like that, the greatest municipal finance crisis in one of the state's richest counties will be on the mend.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; If Register.com, the domain name company, has hit bottom, the only way to go is up, right?
description: THINGS have not been working out so well lately for Register.com.

title: At Penn State, Prayers For Freshman to Walk
description: A spinal cord injury is especially cruel. It imprisons a person inside his own, immobile body. The sentence might be temporary or it might be for life. When the victim is a young athlete, his paralysis mocks the fit physique and well-toned muscles that lie so still in a hospital bed.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Business column on Thursday about the high ratings of Univision's Spanish-language newscast among viewers 18 to 49 years old misidentified the network's New York affiliate. It is WXTV, not WPIX.

title: At Microsoft, Still Business According to Strategy and Plans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26  Microsoft has long maintained that the government antitrust case would do nothing to alter its business practices or long-term strategy. And today, as it won at least a procedural victory in the case, the company had another opportunity to make its point.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Lieberman's Two Races
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman has only a month to end his safety-net campaign in Connecticut, where he is running for a third term in the Senate as well as for vice president on Al Gore's ticket. His Democratic colleagues in the Senate are pressing him to drop the Senate re-election bid lest his seat be lost if the national ticket wins. Even his own constituents oppose his dual candidacy by a narrow margin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLISKIN, ROBERT
description: PLISKIN-Robert. On September 26, 2000. Died peacefully at home surrounded by a loving family. Beloved husband to Caroline. Devoted father to Arlene, Patricia and the late Pamela. Adored grandfather to Stephanie, Mindy, Tracy, Joshua, Jamie, Alysha, Jason and Melissa. Dear brother to Irving and Mort. We mourn the loss of a committed, energetic, generous human being & a friend to many. He fought a long & courageous battle. He will be sorely missed and affectionately remembered. Service Thursday, September 28th, 1:15PM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: A Triumph for 'Today'
description: The ratings for its prime-time Olympics coverage may be disappointing to NBC, but the ratings are doing well for the network in the morning.

title: JUSTICES DECLINE A DIRECT APPEAL IN MICROSOFT CASE
description: The Supreme Court handed a major tactical victory to the Microsoft Corporation today when it rejected the government's plea to hear the appeal of its landmark antitrust case immediately and instead returned the proceeding to a lower court.

title: On MTV, Gore Hits Hip Buttons and Dreams of Air Force One
description: He did not have to choose between boxers or briefs. But in a lengthy MTV forum today, broadcast tonight, Vice President Al Gore did reveal that he had a compact disc by the alternative rock band Sister Hazel in his CD player right then, that he would probably write for a living if he were not otherwise employed next year, and that he coveted Air Force One more than any other White House perquisite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAY, DR. NANCY DUKE S.
description: LAY-Dr. Nancy Duke S. On September 24th, 2000 at age 62. Beloved sister of Manuel, Manchiu, Manhoo, Addellia and Eva Lay and Rose Gonzales. Professor Lay was an educator at City College and helped establish the ESL Department. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St,. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121 St., Friday, 10 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Breast Center of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Texas Execution Reset After DNA Report
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 26 (AP)  A man who was 10 minutes and about 10 steps from the Texas death chamber on June 1 when he got word of a temporary reprieve, is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday for the 1993 rape and murder of his 12-year-old stepdaughter.

title: The New Kings of Soft Money
description: Republicans and conservatives around the country desperately want Rick Lazio to beat Hillary Rodham Clinton in the New York Senate race. Yet the Lazio campaign is forcing them to rethink two of their most cherished dogmas: Republican faith in soft money, the unrestricted donations to political parties and outside groups that are used to help campaigns, and conservative aversion to campaign finance reform.

title: Bush Is Pointing to the Cloud in the Silver Lining
description: For decades, political scientists have considered the economy the single best predictor of the electorate's mood. Good times favor incumbents, bad times insurgents. And so for Gov. George W. Bush, one challenge has loomed high above the others in his quest for the White House: how to defeat a sitting vice president during these roaring good times.

title: When the Children Spend Hours Online
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Learning the Value of Corporate Public Relations
description: The Tokyo Chamber of Commerce and Industry thought it might be a good idea to prepare a handbook for member companies interested in learning how to cope more effectively with the media during a crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the sound made by snapping shrimp misidentified the journal that published the research. It was Science, not Nature.

title: YESTERDAY
description: BASEBALL

title: Business Travel; The Acela Express may not be as competitive with airlines as was first thought by many.
description: BUSINESS travelers, still toting up the fiscal and psychological costs of the summer's air-travel gridlock, are soon going to be hearing a lot more about the future promise of ''high-speed rail.''

title: For Venezuela's President, Steep Oil Prices Are Just
description: With oil prices at their highest level in a decade and the United States and other industrial countries calling for relief, heads of state and oil ministers from the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are to begin a two-day summit meeting here on Wednesday.

title: Insiders Get A Sturdy Tool To Rake In Stock Gains
description: The crests and troughs in the AVT Corporation's stock price are enough to bring on a bad case of sea sickness.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BALL CORP., Broomfield, Colo., named R. David Hoover, vice chairman, president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive. He succeeds George A. Sissel, who remains chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITZLING, MORTON
description: WITZLING-Morton. The partners, associates and staff of Goldfarb & Fleece are deeply saddened by the passing of retired partner, Morton Witzling, a wonderful person, attorney, teacher and student of the law. Our thoughts, love and prayers are with his wife, Renee, his daughters, Mara & Catherine, his beloved grandsons, Benjamin, Ethan and Jacob, his beloved granddaughter Sophia, his son-inlaw, Stephen Wilson, Mara's partner, Peter Cass, his sisters, Estelle Witzling Moskowitz and Mildred Adler, and his brother-in-law, Norman Adler. A memorial ceremony will be arranged at a later date. Partners of Goldfarb & Fleece

title: Punching Around-the-Clock Time Clocks
description: In May, federal highway safety officials proposed that all commercial trucks be equipped with electronic tracking devices to record when they are rolling and when they are standing still. The idea was to make sure drivers have enough rest, thereby reducing accidents. But so far, the proposal's main impact has been to bring a new dimension to the debate about Big Brother in the workplace.

title: Libyan Double Agent Testifies in Lockerbie Bomb Trial
description: The Libyan double agent considered the most crucial witness in the Lockerbie trial testified today that the two defendants brought a brown Samsonite suitcase to Malta like the one believed to contain the bomb that destroyed Pan Am Flight 103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, URSULA
description: STERNBERG-Ursula (nee Hertz). Of Chestnut Hill-Philadelphia, Pa., on Friday, September 22, 2000. Born in Germany, Mrs. Sternberg was a well respected painter who exhibited extensively throughout Europe and the U.S. Surviving are her husband of 43 years, symphony conductor Jonathan Sternberg, daughter Tanya Pushkine Rojas of New York, grandchildren Luca and Lara-Sophia Rojas, son Peter Raphael Sternberg of Paris and sister Renee Haferkamp of Brussels. Private celebrations of her life will be held in Philadelphia and Paris.

title: KANEB TO BUY SHORE TERMINALS FOR $160 MILLION
description: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners L.P., a transporter of fuels refined from petroleum, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Shore Terminals L.L.C. for $160.75 million in cash and shares of the partnership to expand its West Coast terminal business. Kaneb offered $106 million in cash and two million of its partnership units, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange. The units are valued at $54.75 million, based on Monday's closing price. The acquisition will give Kaneb seven petroleum products terminals with a total capacity of 7.8 million barrels, the company said.

title: When a Career Isn't Paramount
description: JUST a few years ago, Dan Gross would have said he had this work-life thing all figured out. Simply put, his work was his life.

title: Red Sky Acquires 2 Media Companies
description: Red Sky in San Francisco, a specialist in interactive communications, has acquired Olive Jar Studios, an animation and film production company based in Boston and Los Angeles, and White Noise Productions, a multimedia agency in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Dream of Zinfandel, Delivered to the Door
description: EVERY year around this time, the mail brings a raft of notices from California's small exclusive wineries offering their latest vintage. The wines are listed with prices, and an address to which I should send my check.

title: INTEL SAYS INVESTIGATION DROPPED
description: Intel said today that it had been notified by the Federal Trade Commission that its investigation into the company's business practices had been closed. The investigation began in September 1997 in response to complaints that Intel had used anticompetitive practices to cement its near monopoly in microprocessors for personal computers. In a letter addressed to Craig Barrett, Intel's president and chief executive, Richard Parker, director of the F.T.C.'s Competition Bureau, wrote, ''It now appears that no further action is warranted by the commission at this time.'' The F.T.C. has also closed its investigation into whether Intel's acquisition of Chips and Technologies and equity in Real3D had any anticompetitive effect on any markets for graphics components or other computer hardware. ''The closure of the investigation reflects our view that Intel conducts its business in an ethical and lawful manner,'' Mr. Barrett said in a statement. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: White Salmon and Guess What?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Skipper Needs a Breeze To Catch Bronze or a Silver
description: It has been said that into everyone's life a little rain must fall. Today, under bleak skies in Sydney Harbor, it descended on the United States skipper Russ Silvestri and his two dozen opponents in the Finn single-handed dinghy class as the second week of the Olympic sailing competition continued.

title: Spice-Crusted Rack of Lamb: This Is Kosher?
description: CHEFS who are finding new ways to make kosher food stylish are not pushing the limits of dietary laws but instead are simply rethinking their approach.

title: DISAPPROVAL RATINGS -- A special report.; Fame a Two-Edged Sword For the Candidate Clinton
description: Being first lady isn't a job, Hillary Rodham Clinton said early this year in Manhattan, ''it's a role.''

title: Stars Come to Aid Spinal Cord Research
description: Charles Barkley, Dan Marino, Mary Jo Fernandez and Mike Schmidt arrived first, followed by Mario Lemieux, Dick Vermeil and Cale Yarborough. Michael Jordan bypassed the reception in the west foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and went straight to the dais, taking his place among the eight athletes honored last night at the 15th annual Great Sports Legends dinner.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Researchers Find Gene for Type 2 Diabetes
description: A novel gene associated with development of Type 2, or adult-onset, diabetes, a major and growing public health problem, has been identified from study of Mexican-Americans in Starr County, Tex., a population with an unusually heavy burden of the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, EDWARD S.
description: GORDON-Edward S. The Real Estate Institute of New York University's School of Continuing and Professional Studies, mourns the passing of our friend, colleague and supporter Edward S. Gordon. Ed has been a member of our Advisory Board for many years and we have benefitted greatly from his wisdom and advice; he will be missed. Our members extend their condolences to his family and colleagues. D. K. Patton, Director, Real Estate Institute Joseph A. DeLuca, Chairman, Advisory Board

title: Largest Trash Hauler Drops 10 Percent of City Clients
description: The nation's largest trash disposal company, which made a much-heralded entry into New York City four years ago as part of the Giuliani administration's effort to combat organized crime, is dropping 10 percent of its city customers, saying that hauling trash in parts of Queens, Staten Island and Manhattan is not profitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, PHILLIP L.
description: JACKSON-Phillip L. 49, died September 22 after a long and courageous struggle with AIDS. Phil, a partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was a leading international corporate and securities lawyer with a distinguished and devoted clientele. His practice was characterized by the highest standards of integrity, intellect, and devotion to his clients. Phil was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, and graduated first in his class at the University of Oklahoma. Upon graduation he took up a Rhodes Scholarship to Merton College, Oxford, where he read Classics and Philosophy. He took his law degree from the University of Chicago in 1979, and thereafter commenced practice at Shearman & Sterling, where he spent his entire legal career. A devoted friend, author, classicist, musician, photographer and traveler, Phil is survived by his loving partner, Dat Chi Luong; by his beloved parents, George H. and Frances M. Jackson; his brothers George H. and R. Kern Jackson; and by six nieces and nephews. A memorial service in celebration of Phil's life will be held on Wednesday, September 27, 2000, at 3:30 PM at St. Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends are invited to make contributions in Phillip's memory to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Call Off All Bets
description: Casinos are dotted across America, but there is only one state where customers can bet legally on college sports events. When gambling on amateur sporting events was banned by a 1992 federal law, an exemption was given to Nevada.

title: F.T.C. Approves Acquisition Of Hughes Space by Boeing
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved Boeing's $3.75 billion acquisition of Hughes Space and Communications yesterday after Boeing agreed to some conditions.

title: With a Little Luck, U.S. Keeps Its Hold on the Gold Medal
description: Laura Berg saw the ball sailing, and the Japanese left fielder, Shiori Koseki, straining. Halfway down the first-base line, Berg realized Koseki would be there, in position. She watched the glove go up, and the catch being made. And then Koseki was falling, the ball dislodging, with Koseki landing on her back.

title: Boxers From Former Soviet Union Dominate
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 27  They come from Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, the Ukraine and Russia, burly, hard looking men who fight with a relentless, intractable boxing style. On the 12th day of the 2000 Olympic boxing tournament, in a headstrong, straight-ahead march through the quarterfinals, it was the fighters from the countries formed by the breakup of the Soviet Union that imposed a new pecking order on the competition.

title: Accord Likely on Measure Allowing Drug Imports
description: A proposal to allow imports of low-priced prescription drugs won support from House Republican leaders today, making it all but certain that Congress and President Clinton could eventually agree on the legislation.

title: Reckonings; A Drop in the Barrel?
description: The decision to release part of our Strategic Petroleum Reserve has been widely criticized. Even many commentators with no ax to grind seem convinced that there is something irresponsible about the move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBART, ALFRED
description: LUBART-Alfred. A loving friend and a wonderful traveling companion. He will be missed. Fredda and Sheldon Leitner

title: A Thank You to Medicine From Spunky Survivors
description: Last summer, just hours before she was to make her Tanglewood debut as soloist in the Brahms Violin Concerto, Joan Kwuon, a Los Angeles-born violinist, discovered a lump in her breast. Subsequent consultations confirmed that Ms. Kwuon had cancer. She was only 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIN, SELMA
description: HAIN-Selma. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Cherished mother of the late Dr. David D. Hain. Loving mother-in-law of Marcia Hain and Morty Engle. Devoted grandmother of Pamela and Neil, Andrew, Joseph and great-grandmother of David. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30PM, Wednesday.

description: The court that will next hear the appeal of the government's antitrust case against Microsoft has dealt with some of the company's legal arguments in the past, handing the company its most significant victory before today.

title: Boy's Death Leads to Calls For Helmets With Scooters
description: The police say a helmet would probably not have saved a 6-year-old boy who was fatally struck by a car last Thursday afternoon while crossing the street on a foot-powered scooter in Elizabeth, N.J. But helmets may soon be required for young scooter riders in the state.

title: Case on Use Of Carts Goes to High Court
description: Taking up its first case on the relationship between disability law and professional sports, the Supreme Court announced today that it would decide whether the golfer Casey Martin has a legal right to use a cart rather than walk the course during PGA Tour events.

title: A Finale for the Woodies, Tennis Dynamic Duo
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- They have been known as the Woodies, the Australian doubles of doubles, though they look nothing alike, hardly play alike and have based themselves on opposite coasts of the United States. They formed a partnership 10 years ago, when Mark Woodforde was 25 and Todd Woodbridge was turning 20. Sixty-one tournament titles, 11 of them Grand Slams, and 1 Olympic gold medal later, they walked on court here yesterday afternoon to thunderous applause, the final chapter to a storybook all but set in print.

title: HIGH-SPEED ACCESS VENTURE
description: The Softbank Corporation, one of the world's largest investors in Internet-related businesses, is starting a third venture aimed at increasing access to the Internet at high speeds. IP Revolution, the new unit, plans to offer the service over fiber optic cables sometime next year, according to an application filed with regulators in Tokyo. Two other efforts by Softbank to provide high-speed Internet services have faltered, in part because of technical complications. Stephanie Strom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOING, MARY ANN
description: GOING-Mary Ann. Beloved sister of the late Patricia Going Plante, James, Robert and Eileen Going Foy. Also survived by 13 nephews and nieces. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 7 to 9 PM and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campaign Briefing column yesterday about gift packages sent to reporters by Marcia Lieberman, the mother of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, misspelled the brand of bagel chips she included. It is Manischewitz, not Manishewitz.

title: A Giant, Made Small, Craves Redemption
description: Shaun Williams, a first-round draft pick now in his first year as a starter for the Giants, failed an important test Sunday night against the Washington Redskins. He knows that another test will come this Sunday against the Tennessee Titans, and he says he embraces the chances.

title: Fox Decides Against Debates
description: The Fox network's decision not to cover next month's presidential debates and to supplant them on two nights with offerings like ''Dark Angel'' and ''That 70's Show'' marks the first time that a full-fledged broadcast network will use entertainment shows to counterprogram the debates.

description: With ''Twilight: Los Angeles,'' the documentary and video maker Marc Levin has transformed Anna Deavere Smith's much-honored performance piece ''Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992'' into something both more and less than itself.

title: Baden Powell, 63, Guitarist Who Pioneered Bossa Nova
description: Roberto Baden Powell de Aquino, the musician whose blend of African, jazz and classical influences gained him renown as one of Brazil's greatest guitarists, died yesterday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 63.

Survivors include her daughter, Wendy Walden of Guilford, CT; her son, Allen Hoyt of Boise, ID; a brother, George Reeve of Manhasset, New York; a brother-in-law, Willis Bradford Hoyt of Forest Hills, New York, and six grandchildren.

title: Jerry Claiborne, 72, Dies; Coach of All-Star Scholars
description: Jerry Claiborne, who turned out good teams but even better classroom stars in 28 years as the head football coach at Virginia Tech, Maryland and Kentucky, died Sunday at a hospital in Nashville. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISCHY, BENJAMIN
description: SISCHY-Benjamin, MD. Beloved and gifted physician died in Sarasota, Florida on September 23, 2000 at the age of 82. He was born in South Africa in 1918. He practiced medicine there and also subsquently in Edinburgh and London in the UK before emigrating to the USA in 1967. In Rochester, NY, he established the department of Radiation Oncology at the Highland Hospital where he remained as Chief until his retirement in 1990. In recognition of his research and contribution to the advancement of cancer treatment, he was appointed Clinical Professor of Radiation Oncology at the University of Rochester and upon his retirement, was named Professor Emeritus. A widely published author of papers and texts in his field, Ben Sischy was also a dedicated healer whose first consideration was always the well-being of this patients. They, in return, both loved and respected him. As a lasting testimonial to this extraordinary human being, an endowed fund was established in the early 1990s which supports the Ben Sischy, MD Visiting Scholor in Humane Medicine. His years of retirement in Sarasota, since 1990, have been devoted to community work. Included amongst the offices he has held he served as President of the American Jewish Committee and membership of the Board of the Jewish Federation, the Jewish Housing Council, and the Center for Catholic Jewish Studies. He was an active congregant of Temple Beth Israel where he was a Board member and sat on many committees. Survivors include his most beloved wife of 56 years, Claire; his sons, Mark of Edinburgh, Scotland and David of Rochester, NY; his daughter Ingrid of New York City; his daughtersin-law Judith and Linda; his grandchildren, Deborah, Adam, and Ilana, and his sister, Clarice, of London, England. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday at 3:00 P.M. at Temple Beth Israel, Longboat Key, FL, followed by interment in Palms Memorial Park in Sarasota. Donations may be made to the Ben Sischy, MD Visiting Scholar in Humane Medicine C/O Dr. Richard Frankel, Primary Care Institute, Highland Hospital, 1000 South Avenue, Rochester, NY 14620 or alternately to a charity of one's choice. For information call, Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Colonial Chapel, 941 955-4171.

title: Buying the Rings for Leverage
description: Samsung Electronics believes in the Olympics, in the brand, the logo and the prestige it expects to receive from investing heavily in them. The South Korean company is paying $55 million as one of the International Olympic Committee's 11 worldwide sponsors and is convinced that the connection will help propel its cellular phone business into world leadership.

description: The polite, if strained, cooperation that has long marked the relationship between France's two leaders -- President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin -- came apart today as their supporters hurled accusations of corruption and political manipulation at each other.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Excessive? Exasperating? Don't Tell the Millions; Streisand May Be Too Much, but She's Just Enough to Succeed on Her Own Terms
description: In his recent memoir the writer and director Arthur Laurents offers a revealing account of working with Barbra Streisand in 1962 on her breakthrough supporting role in the Harold Rome musical ''I Can Get It For You Wholesale,'' a show about the cutthroat world of the New York garment district during the 1930's. Ms. Streisand, then 19, played Miss Marmelstein, a harried, put-upon 50-ish secretary. Her one solo song, ''Miss Marmelstein,'' was an ambling lament of a feisty spinster who wants to be more than the frumpy nobody that everyone in the office takes for granted.

title: NOVARTIS PHARMA AND BIOTRANSPLANT IN ALLIANCE
description: Novartis Pharma A.G. and BioTransplant Inc. said yesterday that they had formed an alliance to develop their technology bases in xenotransplantation, which involves animal-to-human organ transplants. Under the agreement, an independent company focusing on xenotransplants will be formed. Novartis said it would own 67 percent of the new company, while BioTransplant would own 33 percent. A spokesman for BioTransplant said Novartis would invest $30 million in the venture over the next three years. Novartis will retain the rights to commercialization of research from the new company, in return for contributing technology and financial support. BioTransplant will receive unspecified royalty payments from Novartis's sales. Novartis Pharma is a part of the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant Novartis A.G.

description: Saying new technology can make more students eager to learn, elementary school teachers using the new tools in the classroom are questioning a recent study that calls for young children to take a "time-out" from computers.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Congressional Democrats cleared the way today for approval of a major influx of foreign technology workers as the lawmakers shifted their strategy to help illegal migrants.

title: Peru's Spy Chief in Exile
description: Vladimiro Montesinos, Peru's Rasputin, is now in Panama City awaiting a decision on whether he will get political asylum there. Mr. Montesinos, the intelligence chief and all-around fixer for Peru's president, Alberto Fujimori, fled the country after a videotape was televised that showed him apparently bribing a congressman. His departure on Sunday from Peru was, perhaps, the only way to break his hold on power there. But Mr. Montesinos must ultimately be brought to justice. He is accused of serious human rights abuses, and granting him asylum would be an insult to genuine victims.
