title: With Memorial, a Monumental Predicament
description: THIS is a portrait of the artist as an angry middle-aged man (except when he's laughing at the irony of his predicament). After a career spent scraping by in near-anonymity, he is selected from 400 applicants to design a city monument at Foley Square in Lower Manhattan that pays homage to African-American slaves like his great-great-grandfather, Steve Pace.

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Building Is Leased Before the Work Starts
description: Earth-moving equipment has just begun digging the hole that will be the basement of a 25-story office building at 222 East 41st Street, but the building is already full, in a manner of speaking.

title: Russian's Mistake Costs Him First
description: For five rounds of diving, Xiong Ni had watched Dmitri Sautin whirl through the air in tightly wrapped spins and somersaults, building a lead that neither Xiong nor Sautin's 10 other rivals appeared ready to match. Xiong had come out of retirement specifically to help the Chinese team counter Sautin's pre-eminence, and now he was waiting and hoping for the Russian to give him an opening in the 3-meter springboard final.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Simple Exchange, Complex Memories

title: Peru Closing Bribery Case Of Top Aide Now an Exile
description: As Panamanians denounced the arrival of Peru's disgraced intelligence chief to seek asylum, a prosecutor announced in Peru today that she was closing the bribery case against him.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB TO BUY GERMAN CONTACT LENS MAKER
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., a maker of contact lenses, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Woehlk Contact Lens G.m.b.H., a unit of the closely held optical-products maker Carl Zeiss Inc., for $26.2 million in cash to expand sales in Germany. The purchase, which is expected to be completed in mid-October, will slightly add to Bausch & Lomb's earnings in 2001, a spokeswoman said. Bausch & Lomb, which makes ReNu and Sensitive Eyes contact-lens solutions, said the purchase would help it become No. 2 in Germany's contact lens and lens-care products market.

title: Finding Freedom in Lightness After the Brahms and Bartok
description: Leonidas Kavakos, a Greek violinist in his 30's, made a striking impression at his first American concerts in the late 1980's and since then has made a handful of recordings that affirm his place on the list of young fiddlers to watch.

title: Numbers Are Crunched for Playoff Roster
description: The Mets had clinched nothing more than a tie for a postseason spot before last night's loss to the Atlanta Braves. For that reason, they treaded lightly around questions about the playoffs, which will begin next Wednesday at San Francisco or St. Louis -- whichever has the better record -- should the Mets hold their wild-card spot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGANELLA, CARMEN KELLY
description: MANGANELLA-Carmen Kelly. On September 25, 2000. Treasured spouse of Richard, loving mother of JoAnna, adoring grandmother of Thomas and Timothy, beloved sister of Beverly, Mary and Sylvia, devoted daughter of Doris. Our hearts are breaking with the suddenness and shock of losing you. We will always hear your voice, see your face and cherish the love we shared. Reposing at HorneDanneker Funeral Home, 336 W. 23 St 212-242-5250 on Wednesday and Thursday. Funeral Mass on Friday morning.

title: Let's Try Again on Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A new campaign tries to persuade gun owners to lock up their weapons to save children's lives.
description: THE commercial opens on crayon drawings and the tiny voice of a child talking lovingly about her little sister. Then the camera zooms in on a stick figure lying on the ground, part of its body covered in red marker. The next frame shows the speaker's self-portrait, her face violently scribbled out in black.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Corporate Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: American to Add Overseas Flights
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said today that it would add international flights from San Jose, Calif., a city it once abandoned as a hub, to compete for increased business travel by computer-related companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special E-Commerce section last Wednesday about the broadcasting of live music performances over the Web misidentified the company that employs Idil Cakim, a media analyst who commented on the increasing popularity of live events online. It is Cyber Dialogue, not Cyber Quest.

title: VODAFONE BOARD MEMBER RESIGNS
description: Klaus Esser, the former chairman of Mannesmann A.G., resigned from the board of the Vodafone Group, the world's largest mobile telephone operator. Mr. Esser had joined the board on an interim basis after Mannesmann was acquired by Vodafone for $183 billion in the largest takeover ever. Mr. Esser was paid $27 million in severance pay. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: RealNetworks Pact On Server Software
description: RealNetworks Inc., the maker of the most popular software for playing Internet audio and video files, said today that it would work with Hewlett-Packard to produce and sell servers that can be used to distribute media files.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, SEENA
description: FISH-Seena (nee Israel), of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., died September 26 after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of Charles Fish, cherished sister of Arline Gardner, devoted mother of Melissa Darrow (Paul) of Atlanta, GA, Jason Fish (Courtney) of San Francisco, CA, and Nora Fish of Brooklyn, N.Y., loving grandmother of Susannah, Genevieve, Sarah, Grace & Alexander. Memorial services will be held at 11 A.M., September 27, at the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITFORD, JOSEPHINE C.
description: WHITFORD-Josephine C. The Manhattan School of Music is saddened by the loss of longtime friend and beloved dean for more than 40 years, Josephine Whitford. Ms. Whitford came to the school in 1931 and remained active as part of the administration until 1984 when she was awarded an honorary doctoral degree for her years of dedication and service. Her strong-willed personality, intellect, compassion and generosity enriched the lives of generations of students. She leaves an enduring legacy and will be missed by all who knew her. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: Paxil Found to Ease Depression in Older Patients
description: CHICAGO -- The antidepressant Paxil appears to ease mild forms of depression in older patients, a study found.

title: Ebbets Lights Dimmed Again; In City Prizing Relics, Link to Dodgers Needs a Home
description: The lights of Ebbets Field, which gazed down on a golden past of Robinsons and Reeses and Walkers and Furillos, found a home in Downing Stadium when the wrecking ball tore into the home of the Dodgers and stilled the heart of Brooklyn.

title: Gore and Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocker's Arm, Not Mouth, Is Doing the Talking Now
description: John Rocker paused for a moment after the question was asked. Now right there was a sign of maturity, thinking before opening mouth.

title: Track Alibi: The Dog Ate My Drug Test Results
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Regarding that form of drug known as "performance enhancing," there is only one claim I would definitely believe from any athlete:

title: Go On. Turn His Head. He Can Take It.
description: On tonight's ''American Masters,'' Clint Eastwood's mother explains everything. ''He was the biggest baby born in St. Francis Hospital in San Francisco,'' she brags with fond good humor. ''They took him all around to show the other ladies what they might have done.''

title: Studios to Curb Marketing Of R-Rated Films to Youth
description: As executives of movie studios prepared for sharp questioning at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, the industry announced new steps today to limit the marketing of adult-rated movies to children.

title: LIMITS ON SALE OF CUSTOMER NAMES
description: Living.com, a bankrupt Internet furniture retailer, will not be allowed to sell customer lists without customer consent under a settlement proposed by the office of the Texas attorney general, John Cornyn. He proposed the settlement in a federal bankruptcy court in Austin amid general concerns from privacy advocates that defunct dot-com companies will seek to sell, as assets, names and other data from their customer lists. In the most widely publicized such case, the Federal Trade Commission sued earlier this year to stop ToySmart.com, a bankrupt toy retailer, from selling such lists as part of its liquidation. For its part, Living.com's privacy policy promised customers their names would not be sold if they registered their objections via e-mail. Under the proposed settlement, customer lists can be sold, but only if those on the lists are informed and given a chance to object. Matt Richtel

title: More Disappointment for Devers
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 27 -- The former Olympic track coach Mel Rosen says there is only one good place to run a long sprint from Lane 1: the moon.

title: SIEMENS PLANS BRAZIL INVESTMENT
description: Siemens A.G. will invest more than $700 million during the next three years in Brazil's mobile phone network to take advantage of the country's growing market, the company said in a statement. Siemens, based in Germany, expects Brazil, with more than 170 million inhabitants, to become Latin America's largest mobile phone market. Currently, about 11 percent of its population uses mobile phones. The money will be invested in network infrastructure and marketing over the next three years. ''In comparison to average penetration rates of 45 percent in Europe, we see excellent growth potential for the Latin American market,'' said Rudi Lamprecht, president of the Siemens mobile group.

title: Whole Grains Cut Stroke Risk, Study Finds
description: CHICAGO -- Women who eat lots of whole-grain foods can significantly reduce their risk of strokes, researchers say in another study suggesting that healthy eating leads to healthy living.

title: PROFIT FALLS AT IRISH AIRLINE
description: The Irish national airline Aer Lingus P.L.C. reported net profits of 51.9 million euros in 1999, down 30 percent from 74.6 million euros in 1998, despite a 12 percent increase in revenue to 1.134 billion euros. The company carried 6.5 million passengers in 1999, an increase of 13 percent. The Irish government is expected to sell the airline in a public offering early next year. Brian Lavery

title: Excerpts From Testimony at Congressional Hearing on Wen Ho Lee Case
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Attorney General Janet Reno and Louis J. Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, yesterday at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the case of Wen Ho Lee, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHOSSN, EDWARD
description: GHOSSN-Edward C.D. On September 26, 2000. Cherished son of the late Marie Ghossn, devoted son of Edward Ghossn, loving brother of George Ghossn and the late Keith Ghossn, beloved partner of Richard Weissman and caring and treasured friend. No services, time of memorial will be announced. We will miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAHARY, SHAUL S.
description: BAHARY-Shaul S. Age 97 of New York passed away September 25, 2000. Beloved husband of Victoria, devoted father of Kamel, Emil, Gladys & William. Loving brother of Norman, Khatoun, and Violet. Father-in-law of Kamal and Susan. Cherished grandfather of two and great-grandfather of two. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, September 27 at 11 AM.

title: Congress Weighs Limiting State Food-Safety Measures
description: BEFORE Congress adjourns next month it may vote on a bill that would prohibit state and local governments from passing food safety laws that are tougher than federal laws, as well as void any such laws that already exist. The food industry has tried since 1986 to persuade Congress to pass this legislation, and this year it may succeed through legislative maneuvering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, JAMES
description: KEEGAN-James. The entire staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourns with great sorrow the untimely death of James Keegan, a devoted member of the Hebrew Home family for 32 years. Jim's wholehearted dedication to our residents and to the development and maintenance of the Hebrew Home plant and facilities was unequaled. A friend, mentor and colleague to us all, Jim shall be dearly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his daughter Laura, his sonin-law Edmond, his grandchildren Kristen, Edmond, Jr., and Caitlin, his brother John, and his friend and former wife Sandy. He shall be long remembered by all who knew him. For information Riverdale-on-Hudson 718-884-6100. Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: People
description: * A. J. Wright, Framingham, Mass., part of the TJX Companies, to the Link Agency, Providence, R.I., to handle the account of the discount retailer, which had been at Holland Mark Edmund Ingalls, Boston. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Promotions Curbed
description: After NBC's disappointing ratings during the first week of its Olympic coverage, it was expected that extra commercials owed to advertisers would swamp the second week, as has happened in previous Olympics.

title: Only Memories Remain of Fierce U.S.-Russia Basketball Rivalry
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 27 -- The game was over, and the aging man quickly made his way through the emptying stands and down to the floor until he finally reached his old friend at courtside.

title: Anti-Capitalist Protests Diminish in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 27 -- Anti-capitalist protests diminished sharply in Prague today, as financial officials and many demonstrators condemned the outbreak of violence and vandalism that turned a conference of aid officials into a street battle.

title: Nations Reach Deal on Iraq Compensation Funds
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27  In a concession to nations seeking to soften rigid restrictions on Iraq, the Clinton administration agreed today to reduce the money set aside to compensate victims of Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. In return, Russia and France will allow a disputed reparations claim of $15.9 billion to be paid to the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: Oppressed by the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Won't Celebrate Wild Card
description: THE Mets had a Hamlet dilemma last night: to be or not to be celebrating.

title: Mr. September's Blast Sends U.S. Into Final Against Cuba
description: Moments after he was cut last spring, a stunned Doug Mientkiewicz had to make a torturous 500-yard walk across the parking lot, from the Twins' glamorous major league facility to its minor league outpost, from the big time to Mayberry.

title: Mr. Liebermans Two Races
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman has only a month to end his safety-net campaign in Connecticut, where he is running for a third term in the Senate as well as for vice president on Al Gore's ticket. His Democratic colleagues in the Senate are pressing him to drop the Senate re- election bid lest his seat be lost if the national ticket wins. Even his own constituents oppose his dual candidacy by a narrow margin.

title: U.S. Wins First-Ever Baseball Gold Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 27 -- As the United States closed in on a remarkable victory over Cuba Wednesday, Bob Watson, the man who helped put the team together, rose from his seat behind home plate and began to accept congratulations. When Mike Neill made a sliding catch of Yasser Gomez's fly ball to left to seal Ben Sheets's three-hit shutout, the emotion that had been building since the middle of the third inning exploded in chants and cheers. Watson and his wife, Carol, were right there in the middle of it all.

title: Timeout, Jets: Testaverde and Groh Have a Score to Settle
description: It should come as no surprise that Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde rather uncharacteristically spoke out about his benching by Coach Al Groh in the game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Because for months now, rather quietly, the relationship between the two men has become quite chilly.

title: Blair Says Blame Is His for Party's Plummeting Ratings
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair took personal blame today for government actions that have sent the Labor Party's resilient poll ratings plummeting this month, but he urged the party to have confidence that it would defeat the Conservatives and win a second term in the election expected in the next year.

title: ADATOM ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND CHANGES
description: Adatom.com, an electronic commerce business, will cut its 55-person work force by 45 percent and reduce spending as part of a restructuring effort aimed at focusing on partnerships in China. Adatom of Milpitas, Calif., gets most of its revenue from operating an Internet superstore and helping other companies to set up electronic marketplaces. In the new arrangement, announced Monday, the company will license the operation of those businesses to other companies and focus on helping trade between companies in the United States and China. The company reported a net loss of $2.03 million, or 13 cents a share, in the second quarter. Laurie J. Flynn

title: American's Legal Saga Finally Ends on Mat, Just Shy of Gold
description: Matt Lindland's circuitous route to the Olympic wrestling mat took him from the trials to the rulings of arbitrators and into federal courtrooms. Back and forth the tussle went over whether he or Keith Sieracki would be placed on the United States Greco-Roman team. One day, Sieracki was the 167 1/2-pound representative. The next, it was Lindland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LILLIAN
description: SCHNEIDER-Lillian. Died peacefully on September 26, 2000 at the age of 100. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Leonard and Donna Schneider, and Ruth and Mike Pomerantz. Devoted grandmother of Susan and Robert Giglio, Drucie and Gerald Isenberg, Newell and Ron Carapezzi, and David Schneider. Great grandmother of Halie, Jennifer, Matthew, Stephen, Lindsey, Benjamin and Grace. ''Goodbye my lady love, goodbye.''

title: Reno and Freeh, in Hearing, Defend Case Against Scientist
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. defended their handling of the Wen Ho Lee case today, asserting in a Senate hearing that Dr. Lee had committed a serious crime when he removed what they called a portable library of atomic secrets from the weapons laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: Three Candidates Vie for Seat in Minnesota
description: The Democratic candidate is a heavy-spending department store heir who drew fire from his opponent for drug company investments. The Republican incumbent has had personal problems that appeared to undercut his family values message. And along with them, a third party candidate carries the banner of Gov. Jesse Venturas Independence Party.

title: Discretion and the I.N.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Delight for All but Dagwood
description: FOR such ordinary things, sandwiches are awfully hard to get right. Chief among the sandwich-making sins is the impulse that drives chefs to pile on more and different ingredients in an effort to create their own masterpieces. But sandwiches rarely work as Jackson Pollocks; the simplicity of a Mark Rothko is far more often the ideal.

title: THE BOSS; Staying in the Games
description: I grew up playing Strat-O-Matic baseball, and I actually created my first fantasy baseball game on an old Prime mainframe when I was in middle school. In high school, I was all-county basketball and baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, THOMAS J.
description: WALSH-Thomas J., Sr. In Bowdoin, ME, age 85, died Monday, September 25, 2000 at his home. Former resident of Scarsdale, NY and CPA with Kennedy Enerprises and Director of Emigrant Savings Bank. Husband of Irene Walsh.

title: This Time It's Small Farms To the Rescue
description: TO most outsiders, the southeastern coast of New England is a stretch of tranquil countryside, a blur of old stone fences and shady country roads on the way to Cape Cod. A place where ospreys nest along the tidal Westport River, and where black and white cows graze in pastures all the way down to the shoreline.

title: The Big D Is in New Jersey
description: The Jets' defense has had a remarkable impact in the first four games of the N.F.L. season. Consider that the Jets:

title: Venus Williams Has Golden Streak
description: Increasing her winning streak to 32 matches, Venus Williams won the tennis gold medal in singles with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Elena Dementieva of Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISZ, ARTHUR
description: WEISZ-Arthur, M.D., FACC. On September 25, at age 95. Beloved husband of Edith B. Weisz. Devoted father of George Weisz and cherished grandfather of Jessica Weisz. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: The ''His Own Words'' feature yesterday with the campaign coverage, quoting from remarks by George W. Bush at Bethany Elementary School in Beaverton, Ore., misstated the day he spoke. It was Monday, not yesterday.

title: AT&T-Panasonic Deal
description: AT&T, the biggest United States cable television company, has ordered one million digital set-top boxes from Panasonic, a unit of Matsushita Electric Industrial Company in Japan, so that it can offer more services. Terms were not disclosed. Panasonic will deliver the boxes over three years, the companies said in a statement. The boxes will let customers shop and bank online and send e-mail using their TV sets. The companies hope to benefit from an expected surge in the services, like phone calls, delivered on the TV set.

title: Metro Business; Newsstand Union Vote
description: Newsstand employees at the Hudson News Company voted last week to become members of the Newspaper Guild of New York, a division of the Communications Workers of America. The employees, most of them immigrants from India or Pakistan, voted 197 to 121 to join.

title: Australian Poised to Give U.S. Dose of Its Own Medicine
description: Lauren Jackson ran upcourt after a brief altercation under the basket with the frustrated United States player.

title: Article 2000092791316782108 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Taking a Hip-Hop Route to Teaching a Love of Language
description: A green and white circus tent at the edge of a country pond was pulsing with a bass beat last week, as Toni Blackman and FreeStyle Union, a group of rap artists, weaved back and forth on stage, microphones pressed to their lips.

title: Un-Safir Races The Clock
description: NEW YORK CITY'S new police commissioner shook his head as he heard himself introduced yesterday as ''suddenly one of the most famous, well-known and recognized people'' in town.

title: U.S., Losing to Spain, Still Dreams of Medal
description: The unimagined has now become almost a necessity. Having lost to Spain, 3-1, in the semifinals tonight, the United States wants to bring back a medal from the Olympic soccer competition.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Irreverent Take on the Games
description: The day's competition ends, and Fatso lives another day. Fatso is a stuffed wombat with an oversized posterior who is the mascot and inanimate co-star of ''The Dream,'' a bawdy and disrespectful Olympic wrap-up program carried nightly by the Seven Network, which is broadcasting the Summer Games to Australia.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Springfield, Mo.

title: Companies Act to Keep Bioengineered Corn Out of Food
description: Moving to address safety concerns, agribusiness companies took steps yesterday to limit the chances that a strain of bioengineered corn not approved for human consumption could end up in food products.

title: BECTON DICKINSON SHARES FALL ON WARNING
description: Shares of Becton Dickinson & Company, the country's largest maker of syringes, plunged yesterday after the company announced it would eliminate 1,000 jobs over the next year and would miss Wall Street's earnings estimates for its fiscal fourth quarter. The company, based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., said it would cut the jobs and stop some incentive programs for its distributors in an effort to reduce costs and improve its sagging stock price. Becton Dickinson also said it would earn 39 cents a share for its fiscal fourth quarter, which ends this month. Analysts expected the company to make 46 cents a share for the period. Shares of Becton Dickinson fell $3.25, to $21.75.

title: Movie Marketing Methods
description: Following are excerpts from documents of the National Research Group, the dominant market research organization for major studios about its work on the movie, "I Know What You Did Last Summer."

title: COPYRIGHT MEASURE INTRODUCED
description: Declaring that the letter of United States copyright law should not limit the use of new technology that remains true to its spirit, Representative Rick Boucher, a Virginia Democrat, has introduced a bill that would legalize the controversial MyMP3.com service. Earlier this year, a federal judge ruled that the service infringed the copyrights of the major recording labels. But Mr. Boucher said MyMP3.com, which enables consumers to listen to CD's by logging on to the MP3.com site, was analogous to consumers carrying CD's with them without the inconvenience of doing so. Action on the legislation is not expected before the end of the current session of Congress, but Mr. Boucher said it would be reintroduced in the next session. Trade groups representing the music industry circulated a letter among members of Congress on Monday calling the legislation misguided. Amy Harmon

title: Topics of The Times; Debate Time for the Networks
description: The tightening presidential race makes it all the more important for Americans to take a close look at Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore at their first debate next Tuesday night. For the NBC and Fox networks, however, baseball and commercial interests appear to be more important than the presidential debates.

title: Senators Hear Testimony on Children and Movie Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  A top entertainment executive told the Senate today that it was a "judgment lapse" for his movie company to try to advertise a film with violent scenes on a children's television network.

title: 3Com Posts Smaller-Than-Expected Quarterly Loss
description: The 3Com Corporation reported a smaller-than-expected first-quarter loss today, citing a reorganization that included its exit from the analog modem and network router businesses in the previous quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERBER, STEVEN
description: FERBER-Steven. In our hearts you hold a place no one can ever fill. You knew what it meant to live life to the fullest and be the best you could be. You left heart prints with all of us. Love, Mom, family and friends

title: Believers Crowd a Street, Seeking the Face of Mary
description: Not every pedestrian on Washington Street here sees an apparition of the Virgin Mary in the smudgy colored streaks of the thermal pane window.

title: Commanders Ask Congress for Increase in Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The nation's senior military commanders told Congress today that the armed services needed an increase in defense spending that would exceed what has been proposed by either major presidential candidate and would consume a large part of the budget surplus.

title: A Metamorphosis on the Upper East Side
description: THE Mortimer's era is officially over. And Orsay has put the period on the sentence. Glenn Bernbaum, Mortimer's notoriously highhanded and cranky owner, made sure the restaurant would not survive him. He arranged to have the name retired at his death, two years ago, and barred his former employees from operating a restaurant on the premises. Undeterred, they moved two blocks south and created Swifty's, where the spirit of Mortimer's has migrated with surprising ease, along with the Mortimer's ''in'' crowd. In the meantime, the partners who run La Goulue bought Mr. Bernbaum's building, transformed it into a French brasserie and, in a final dismantling of the Mortimer's legacy, are serving very good food. Mr. Bernbaum must be wincing at the very thought of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, NED
description: FISCHMAN-Ned. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. formerly of Hillside on Monday. September 25th. Beloved husband of Gertrude (nee Bauer). Devoted father of Michael Eric Fischman (wife Elyse) of Chappaqua, NY, Herbert William Fischman (wife Jennifer) of Mamaroneck, NY and Jacob Fredrick Fischman of Santa Monica, Ca. Dear brother of Ella Taufield of Stamford, CT. and brother-in-law of Audrey Fischman of West Orange, NJ. Loving grandfather of Brian, Jeremy, James, Lauren & Sophie. Graveside services King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, N.J. today at 11 AM. For information Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton.

title: Nike Officers Joining P.B.A.
description: Already backed by high-tech money, the Professional Bowlers Association added old-fashioned marketing savvy today with the hiring of two former Nike executives. Ian Hamilton was named commissioner and Steve Miller will be president of a P.B.A. that hopes to use the Internet and television to reinvent itself as a multimedia experience.

title: Scallops With Snap
description: A CRISP edge on scallops really brings out their sweetness. It's easy to achieve when you saute them: dredge them in flour, cornmeal or bread crumbs before adding them to the hot pan. But if you give the crunchy crust an intense flavor, they're even better.

title: Corrections
description: The "His Own Words" feature yesterday with the campaign coverage, quoting from remarks by George W. Bush at Bethany Elementary School in Beaverton, Ore., misstated the day he spoke. It was Monday, not yesterday.

title: MOOG TO ACQUIRE ELECTRIC MOTOR UNIT OF EATON
description: Moog Inc., a maker of control systems for missiles and commercial aircraft, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an electric-motor division from the Eaton Corporation for an undisclosed amount to broaden its product line. The Vickers Electrics division, located in Casella, Italy, has 162 workers and annual sales of $20 million, the companies said in a statement. Eaton, which is based in Cleveland, has been selling businesses to focus on drivetrains, engines and specialized sensors. Moog had sales of $630 million in its fiscal year ended September 1999.

title: Business Briefings
description: Yale Robbins Inc., a leading real estate publisher, will introduce a Web site today that is intended to help commercial tenants track down office space in New York's increasingly tight market, company officials said yesterday.

title: Nation's Largest Hauler Cuts Back on City Trash
description: Saying that collecting trash in parts of Queens, Staten Island and Manhattan is not profitable, Waste Management is dropping 10 percent of its commercial customers in New York City. The move comes as prices for trash hauling are rising and as locally owned, independent companies are regaining some of the market share lost to national haulers, which moved into the city as part of the Giuliani administration's effort to combat organized crime.

title: A Thousand Recipes (But Who's Counting?)
description: IT'S not a stretch to call Faye Levy's 625-page volume, ''1,000 Jewish Recipes,'' a culinary bible. It may be the only Jewish cookbook you'll ever need.

title: New Images Offer Clues To Hot Halo Around Sun
description: The sharpest and most detailed pictures ever made of the surging gases above the sun's surface, captured by a NASA satellite, may reveal the source of one of astronomy's most enduring mysteries: what makes the sun's extended atmosphere, or corona, hundreds of times hotter than its surface, the only apparent source of heat?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, CECIL
description: ROBBINS-Cecil. We are truly saddened by the passing of our very dear friend, Cecil Robbins. She was the epitome of warmth, wit and charm. A ray of sunshine to all of those she touched. For all of us fortunate enough to have known and loved Cecil, we grieve her loss and extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Jules, daughter Linda and sons Steven and David. Jane and Larry David

title: 'Ambitious' Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The High Cost of Making Headlines
description: THEY entered the room holding hands. Marion Jones, one of the world's greatest sprinters, and her husband, C. J. Hunter, who was coming off as one of the world's biggest head cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIATT, NEAL
description: GILLIATT-Neal. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City and the UCP Research and Education Foundation acknowledge the passing of a devoted and generous friend, and Board member. He was a staunch supporter of the needs of children and adults with Cerebral Palsy for many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Mary and the Gilliatt family. Leo Hausman, Chairman

title: COSINE I.P.O. TAKES OFF
description: The shares of CoSine Communications almost tripled after the maker of equipment to protect corporate telecommunications networks from hackers and unwanted traffic raised $230 million in its initial public offering. The initial price was $23, but CoSine closed at $63.06 on Nasdaq yesterday, having been as high as $71. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., received enough demand before the I.P.O. to twice increase its asking price and wound up selling 10 million shares in the sale managed by Goldman Sachs Group. CoSine, backed by one if its key customers, Qwest Communications International, sells its switches and software to telephone and Internet companies that are increasingly seeking new security products and features for business customers. CoSine's products make a so-called firewall to protect networks. The company began shipping products in the first quarter. By running Cosine services from network hubs, telecommunications companies do not need to send workers out to customers whenever they want a feature installed, fixed or upgraded.

title: RODAMCO AND URBAN SHOPPING CENTERS IN $3 BILLION DEAL
description: Rodamco North America N.V., a Dutch owner of shopping malls in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Urban Shopping Centers Inc. for $3.4 billion in cash and assumed debt to more than double in size and gain expertise in property services. Rodamco will pay $48 a share, or $1.6 billion, for Urban, which is based in Chicago, 39 percent more than Monday's closing price. It will also assume about $1.6 billion in debt and $400 million in preferred securities. The purchase will more than double Rodamco holdings, to 36 malls with 40 million square feet in 15 states, making it the third-largest mall owner in the United States. Rodamco's Amsterdam-listed shares fell 4.4 euros, to 41 euros. Urban's shares rose $12.88, to $47.31.

title: G.O.P. Senator's Challenger Has a Recognition Problem
description: The Democrats' high-priority targeting of Senator Rick Santorum for defeat this year is proving to be an uphill struggle so far for his challenger, Representative Ron Klink.

title: U.S. Says 2 Russia Advisers Misused Positions for Gain
description: Federal prosecutors today filed a civil suit contending that two Harvard University advisers who helped mold Russia's economic reforms in the mid-1990's misused their government-financed positions in pursuit of personal gain for themselves and their wives.

title: Let's Try Again on Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000092792987908038 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Excerpts From Testimony at Hearing on the Wen Ho Lee Case
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Attorney General Janet Reno and Louis J. Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, yesterday at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the case of Wen Ho Lee, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: How the Studios Used Children To Test-Market Violent Films
description: Before the Hollywood Pictures unit of Disney released the R-rated Sylvester Stallone movie ''Judge Dredd,'' about urban anarchy and street war, the studio tested the film before a focus group that included more than 100 youths ages 13 to 16.

title: 2 Photography Centers Join To Form a Vast Collection
description: Two major photography institutions -- the George Eastman House in Rochester and the International Center of Photography in New York City -- have entered an alliance that will give New Yorkers more access to one of the world's greatest collections of photographs and motion pictures.

title: Mrs. Clinton Proposes Ban On Ads for Young Children
description: Declaring that advertisers were directing a ''barrage of materialistic marketing'' at young children, Hillary Rodham Clinton today called on the federal government to ban commercials aimed at preschool children, and to prohibit advertising inside public elementary schools.

title: In Election Confusion, U.S. Sees Serb's Demise
description: Surprised by the sweep of the vote for the opposition presidential candidate in Yugoslavia, but cautious about gloating, President Clinton praised the ''brave people'' there today for choosing change and sought to embolden them by offering to lift economic sanctions if they prevail.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: BP Will Invest In Exploration
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., the world's third-largest publicly traded oil company, said today that it would spend $4.5 billion over the next three years to look for natural gas in North America, where supplies are down and prices are at record highs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about using the drug Avonex (also called interferon beta-1a) to delay the onset of multiple sclerosis omitted the source of the research report. It is scheduled for publication tomorrow in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Radio Station to Broadcast All News All the Time in Spanish Starting Today
description: When WNNY-AM (1380) turns on its microphones today at noon, it will become the New York region's first all-news, all-the-time Spanish-language radio station. To many industry analysts, that is a sign of advertiser interest in the growing buying power of the nation's Hispanic listeners.

title: U.S. Goes On Offensive Over Tests For Drugs
description: As the shot-putter C. J. Hunter, husband of Marion Jones, denies that he knowingly took banned substances, the entire system of drug testing in the United States has come under fire from the international Olympic hierarchy. These international officials consider the Americans hypocritical, laggard and deceptive in their handling of doping cases.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEBATES

title: Victim of Subway Push Faces His Attacker
description: The vigorous, once athletic man who was pushed into the path of an oncoming subway train faced his attacker yesterday in a Manhattan courtroom, and in a clear voice recounted how he had awoken in a hospital to find that his legs had been severed.

title: Chinese Airline Crew Overpower Hijacker
description: BEIJING, Sept. 27 -- The crew of a Chinese domestic airliner Wednesday foiled a mid-air hijack attempt which left one hijacker dead and the captain of the plane fighting for his life, state media reported. Two passengers attempted to hijack Xinhua Airlines flight LW126, which took off from the city of Baotou in Inner Mongolia at 7:20 a.m. (2320 GMT) bound for Beijing, said CCTV.com, a website run by state television. The report said members of the crew on board the Boeing 737-300 overpowered the assailants, but that two crew members were injured in the scuffle, including the captain who was seriously hurt. The plane, carrying 143 passengers, was forced to divert from its original route and landed in Jinan, capital of eastern Shandong province at 9:36 a.m. (0136 GMT), said CCTV.com. The website said one of the hijackers was shot dead by police at Jinan airport and the other was arrested, although it gave no further details. The official Xinhua news agency said there was only one hijacker. It gave no details of any casualties but said all the passengers were safe. An official at Jinan airport confirmed all the passengers were safe, but he declined to give further details. A spokesman for Xinhua Airlines also declined to comment. The reports gave no details of the motive for the hijacking or any indication of any weapons the assailants may have been carrying. Early this year, a passenger tried to hijack a China Southwest Airline plane bound for the southeastern city of Fuzhou, wielding a knife, but he was also overpowered by the crew. In 1993 and 1994 there was a spate of hijackings of Chinese aircraft by people trying to flee to the island of Taiwan, which has been ruled separately from the mainland since 1949.

title: Manhattan School District Withdraws Support for Scouts, Citing Bias
description: In a move that was largely symbolic, Manhattan's Community School District 2 joined a handful of other groups across the nation last night in withdrawing support for the Boy Scouts of America, citing the organization's exclusion of gays. The board urged the city's other districts and the Board of Education to follow its lead.

title: Gasoline Truck Fire Kills Woman and Disrupts Neighborhood
description: A Suffolk County woman died when her vehicle collided with a gasoline tanker outside a service station here Monday night, setting off a fiery explosion that shook nearby homes, forced the evacuation of 100 people and caused power failures that continued today.

title: China Protests Planned Canonization of 120
description: China stepped up its attacks on the Vatican today for its plans to canonize 120 Catholics who were killed in China between 1648 and 1930.

title: High Camp And the Games' Cookie Cutter
description: To much of the television audience -- especially the women and other casual sports followers NBC claims to be eager to court -- the Olympics is not an athletic event but an entertainment event that happens to be about sports. You wouldn't want to go to a cocktail party and not know who Tiger Woods is. In theory, the Olympics should produce the same need-to-know buzz. You wouldn't want to go to a party and not know what was going on in Sydney.

title: Move Toward Schools Open Year-Round
description: Aiming to ease overcrowding, a City Board of Education task force has decided to recommend that newly constructed high schools that are opened over the next few years operate on a year-round schedule, with student vacations scattered throughout the year instead of being confined to the summer months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMART, WILLIAM S.
description: SMART-William S., 70, of Spring Hill, FL, September 23. A native of Bronx, NY and Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, he retired to Florida in 1998. Mr. Smart was in the insurance/investment business. Served in U.S. Army in Korea. Graduated N Y U in 1951 & attended N Y U Law School. Memorial service will be held Sun., Oct. 8 at 1:00 P.M. at HoHo-Kus (NJ) Community Church.

title: Ullrich Wins Olympic Road Race
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 27 -- Everything went according to plan for Lance Armstrong and his United States teammates in the Olympic cycling road race today. The problem was that things went even better for the Germans.

title: New York Polls Vary, But Mrs. Clinton Has Slight Edge
description: Several statewide polls of New York have been taken in the last two weeks since Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio met in Buffalo for their first debate. The results have been varied  ranging from showing the race to be tied to a margin of nine percentage points between the candidates. When the results of the latest four polls are averaged, Mrs. Clinton leads by six points, 49 percent to 43 percent.

title: NBC Ends Bid, So Fox Will Get Contract
description: NBC and baseball are parting ways. The network told officials of Major League Baseball yesterday that it would not agree to pay at least double its current $80 million-a-year rights fee, ceding all the broadcast rights to Fox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, SHIRLEY
description: GOLDSMITH - Shirley. Adored wife of the late Arthur (Lofty). Loving mother of Karen MartinEliezer (Jay), Susan Roden (Peter). Cherished grandmother of Greg, Suzanne, Bruce, Electra, Casey and Andrew. Great grandmother of Sophia and Georgianna. Services Wednesday, 11:00 am, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva at Purchase residence.

title: Pinstripe Potholes
description: The Yankees' pitching staff has been erratic down the stretch, and as Manager Joe Torre sets up his rotation and bullpen, he's got some question marks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTER, HARRY
description: PASTER-Harry. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: INSIDE
description: Crucial Lockerbie Testimony

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a successful turnaround for the Manhattan Theater Club misspelled the given name of its artistic director. As noted in the article, she is Lynne Meadow, not Lynn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MILDRED E.
description: SHAPIRO-Mildred E. Beloved wife of the late Murray A. Devoted mother of Fredda Lynn and Joan Weiner. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside service today 11AM, at Beth Moses cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: Bold Themes in a Lynne Cheney Novel
description: Elaine Showalter, an English professor at Princeton University, was browsing a used-book stall in Paris in the early 1990's when she came upon an astonishing find: an Old West romance, replete with whorehouses, lesbian affairs and attempted rapes, written by an author whose name was all too familiar to academics in the humanities.

title: Spam University
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: MTV CUTTING ONLINE JOBS
description: Viacom said yesterday that it would cut the staff at MTVi Group, the Internet division of MTV Networks, by 105 positions, or 25 percent. The company also postponed plans for a spinoff of the year-old MTVi, whose 22 Web sites include MTV.com, VH1.com and Sonicnet.com. A spokesman said that the 105 layoffs were part of a move to consolidate the music sites and that MTVi's revenue is expected to nearly double this year from $19.9 million in 1999. But some analysts saw the move as a product of the market's cooling toward Web companies that focus on digital entertainment. ''This makes you notice how even major entertainment companies are struggling to create successful online entities,'' said Stacey Herron, an analyst at Jupiter Communications. Catherine Greenman

title: Mexican Truck Maker May Lose Order
description: Consorcio G Grupo Dina S.A., a troubled Mexican bus and truck maker, faces the loss of a three-year agreement to make 9,000 trucks for Western Star Truck Holdings now that Western Star has been bought by DaimlerChrysler A.G.

title: CueCat Links Printed Ads to Web, but Skeptics Are Wary
description: TRY this: Go to your local Radio Shack and ask for a CueCat. The sales representative behind the counter will nod, reach into a box, pull out a plastic off-white object that looks like a McDonald's Happy Meal toy and hand it to you, at no charge.

title: Scooters and Helmets
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER T-ONLINE EXECUTIVE LEAVES
description: T-Online International of Germany, Europe's biggest Internet service provider, lost its third senior manager in a month, heightening concerns about management upheaval and sending the stock down 5 percent. The manager, Christian Honing, chief financial officer, is leaving for personal reasons, said Deutsche Telekom, which controls T-Online. The chief executive quit on Aug. 25, and the marketing chief left last week. The departures leave just two members of the original management team on the board of the company.

title: Nonstars All, Americans Dethrone Cuba
description: As the United States closed in on a remarkable victory over Cuba tonight, Bob Watson, the man who helped put the team together, rose from his seat behind home plate and began to accept congratulations. When Mike Neill made a sliding catch of Yasser Gomez's fly ball to left to seal Ben Sheets's three-hit shutout, the emotion that had been building since the middle of the third inning exploded in chants and cheers. Watson and his wife, Carol, were right there in the middle of it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONO, MARYANN, RN, BSN, MA, GOING, MARY ANN, RN, BSN, MA, MOLLICK, KATHLEEN, BSN WALSH, JOAN E., RN.C, BA, MA.
description: DONO-Maryann, RN, BSN, MA, GOING-Mary Ann, RN, BSN, MA, MOLLICK - Kathleen, BSN WALSH-Joan E., RN.C, BA, MA. The Board of Directors of Saint Vincents Catholic Medical Centers, and the Sisters of Charity, Hospital Auxiliary, Administration, Medical Staff and Hospital Staff of Saint Vincents Catholic Medical Centers-Saint Vincent's Manhattan, mourn the passing of our beloved colleagues and dear friendsMaryann Dono, Mary Ann Going, Kathleen Mollick and Joan Ellen Walsh. These dedicated women, all graduates of our St. Vincent's School of Nursing, spent their entire careers serving patients at St. Vincent's Hospital. They were the very essence of our mission. Together, these four nurses served the Hospital for 160 years. Their common bond in caring for sick children brought them together, as they all served in our Pediatric and Neonatal Intensive Care Services. The entire Saint Vincents' family extends its deepest condolences to the family members of each of these outstanding women. Their loss will be deeply felt by grateful patients and their families, and the countless number of colleagues that they have mentored for more than 40 years. We will miss them deeply. David J. Campbell, President & CEO Saint Vincents Catholic Medical Centers Jane Connorton, President, St. Vincent's Manhattan

title: Essay; The Wild Poll Pendulum
description: Are you getting the feeling, as I am, that we are being jerked around by wildly swinging poll numbers?

title: A BIG PUSH IS ON FOR NATURAL GAS UNDER THE ARCTIC
description: For three decades, geologists probing beneath the Arctic Ocean near here and offshore Alaska have mapped the largest known untapped reserves of natural gas in North America: 165 trillion cubic feet, seven times what the United States will consume this year.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the benefits of drinking milk, misstated the sponsorship of an advertising campaign against milk. It was produced by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, not by the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.

title: Heberto Padilla, 68, Cuban Poet, Is Dead
description: Heberto Padilla, an acclaimed Cuban poet whose criticism of Fidel Castro's rule landed him first in jail and later in exile, died on Monday in Auburn, Ala., where he had recently become a writer in residence at Auburn University. He was 68.

title: 4-Star Kitchens Delivered on a Takeout Budget
description: IN New York City, remodeling an entire kitchen for less than $20,000 -- with new appliances in better locations, new countertops, cabinets, floor and labor -- is the equivalent of finding a two-bedroom apartment for $1,000 a month. It's possible, but not very likely.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday tracing Hillary Rodham Clinton's approval ratings in opinion polls over the last eight years referred incorrectly in some copies to the sources of the data. They were 40 national and 6 statewide polls, not 46 national and 6 statewide.

title: Danes to Vote on Adopting the Euro
description: Denmark, pursuing an odd calling as the barometer of Europe's mood, holds its fourth referendum in less than a decade on Thursday on what degree of integration with the European Union the country desires.

title: Apple Issues Earnings Warning
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Apple Computer Inc. said today that its fourth quarter earnings will fall far below analysts' estimates because of weak September sales, an announcement that sent the company's shares plunging in after-hours trading.

title: About to Hatch Their Third Republic
description: ZEN is an upfront influence at the office of ZoZa, a new fashion company set for its Web debut in mid-October. Shoes are to be removed at the entrance and placed in cabinets. A hefty Chinese gong stands ready to call meetings, and there's a large empty swath of carpet for the staff's morning yoga classes.

title: Mix of Drugs Slows Cancer of the Colon
description: Researchers have found that combining a new drug with the standard ones can more effectively slow end- stage colorectal cancer and slightly prolong victims' lives.

title: Merging TV With the Internet
description: AT first glance, the scene at MTV's Times Square studio last week was familiar to anyone who has ever watched even a few minutes of the channel. There was music, dancers, D.J.'s, guest appearances and, of course, music videos. But the show that was being rehearsed, a live, hourlong hip-hop music show called ''Direct Effect,'' may be anything but typical. Its producers say that it offers a glimpse into the near future of television for all viewers, even those who can't hold a beat in a basket.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Nagada, a textile and housewares shop in Cairo noted for multicultural designs, omitted a letter in an American e-mail address with information about its products. It is sxs99@po.cwru.edu.

title: The College Search Game, Spam Included
description: THOMAS LIPSMEYER, a high-school senior with a talent for the tenor sax, plays in every instrumental ensemble in his school and practices nearly five hours a day. So when he decided that he wanted to go to a college with a strong music program, he applied the same discipline to the college-search process.

title: Rooting for WordPerfect
description: To the Editor:

title: An Artist the Web Was Made For
description: YOU would think that art and the Internet were made for each other. But all artists are not equal on the Web. There are reproductions, to be sure, but what about ''appreciation''? Some renowned artists are represented by little more than a few capsule biographies and a lot of dealers, with precious little commentary or insight, even from museums.

title: The Museum-Class House That Post Toasties Built
description: WHY, you live like a queen, don't you?'' was the comment of Queen Maude of Norway to Marjorie Merriweather Post. Mrs. Post did indeed, and she filled Hillwood, her home-museum at 4155 Linnean Avenue NW, which has just reopened, with a battalion of royal objects. Her collection of imperial Russian art from the 18th and 19th centuries is the greatest in the world outside Russia, and she had one of the leading United States collections of Sevres porcelain, much of it commissioned by Catherine the Great.

title: FIRST DATA TO DROP ANOTHER 1,000 EMPLOYEES
description: The First Data Corporation, which earlier this year said it would cut 1,940 jobs, will lay off another 1,000 employees to try to increase profits. The company, based in Atlanta, processes credit card payments and does the billing for credit card issuers. It said 725 of the new cuts will come at FDRLimited, a subsidiary in Britain. The company will cut 280 jobs in the United States.

title: Creative Sparks
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Canadian Prime Minister, Dies at 80
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the long-serving Prime Minister of Canada who successfully defended his vision of federalism and a unified nation against the aroused forces of Quebec separatism, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: Metro Business; Guilty Pleas in Stock Scam
description: The New York attorney general's office said yesterday that the employees of a Long Island investment company accused of defrauding nearly 90 people out of $3.2 million have pleaded guilty to several charges and will all be sentenced by the end of the month.

title: Congressional Leaders Approve a Deal to Allow Food Sales to Cuba
description: The House and Senate leadership today approved a deal to allow the sale of American food products to Cuba, clearing the way for the most significant rollback of United States sanctions against the island in four decades.

title: MICROSOFT TO OFFER HIGH-SPEED ACCESS
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would begin selling a high-speed online service at RadioShack stores. The MSN HighSpeed service will be available on telephone lines from the NorthPoint Communications Group and by satellite from a unit of Gilat Satellite Networks, beginning in November. It will cost $39.95 a month for a phone connection and $59.95 for a satellite link.

title: Shelf Life and Pillow Talk
description: From 1952 to 1973, Alexander Girard designed more than 300 fabrics for the Herman Miller Furniture Company in Zeeland, Mich. Ten of those samples, from the 1960's, are now available as 20-inch-square pillows, right, $75 each at Regeneration in SoHo.

title: Bending Bamboo Until It's Elegant
description: Bamboo may be today's dream material, abundant for flooring and surfboards alike. But can it be made as chic as wenge? ''It's hard to manipulate,'' said John Birch, the owner of Wyeth, 315 Spring Street (Greenwich Street), who has coaxed the resinous poles into wide sheets of rich veneer topping white oak. The result is ''as elegant as straw marquetry, and more durable,'' he said. Sleek tables run $8,500 to $16,000 (nine-foot size). DAVID COLMAN

title: Avon Wants to Sell at Penney and Sears
description: Avon Products Inc., the world's largest direct seller of cosmetics and fragrances, said it was in talks to sell a new cosmetics line in 150 to 200 J. C. Penney Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company stores.

title: Another Look at Gore the Man
description: The Gore-Lieberman campaign began broadcasting a new commercial, titled ''Veteran,'' this week that highlights stands on several issues, including tax cuts, welfare, child support and Internet pornography, that are the kinds Republicans have used in the past against Democrats. It is being broadcast in 17 swing states, although the Gore campaign would not identify them.

title: Rio Journal; Scandal Rocks Soccer, Sending Brazil Into Shock
description: Even in their worst moments, Brazilians had their prowess in soccer to sustain them, as celebrated in four World Cups. But the passion has suddenly become a sorry symbol, with the coach of the World Cup team accused of corruption and several star players under investigation for tax evasion.

title: F.D.A. Approves Abortion Pill
description: In what abortion rights supporters hailed as a major victory, the Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had approved the marketing of an abortion-inducing pill, the first alternative to surgical abortion approved in the United States.

title: Making It in This New Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Kazakhstans Boxers Fight in One Direction -- Forward
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  During the 1950's and 1960's, citizens of the Soviet Union were urged to help settle the "New Lands" of the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic, a landlocked area roughly four times the size of Texas just northwest of China. For the athletes of this region, the immigrants, who were mostly Russians, brought with them the lessons of a centralized sports system, and in the sport of boxing, a specific technique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, IDA
description: ROTH-Ida, age 90, of New York City. Passed away September 26, 2000. Beloved mother of Diane (Lawrence) and Florence (Arthur). Adored sister of Benjamin and the late Simon. Cherished grandmother to Jill, Mark, Randi (Ira) and Larry. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Friday, September 29th, 9:30 A.M.

title: Plane or Train? The Joys and the Burdens
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Lauds NBC Olympic Performance
description: Bob Wright, the president of NBC, has heard all the criticism of the network's coverage of the Sydney Olympics and has seen the ratings fall below NBC's expectations.

title: Bush Welcomes Vouchers, But the Word Eludes Him
description: Gov. George W. Bush concluded three days of education events today with a visit to a parochial school in this city's heavily Hispanic South-Central section, talking about reading, character education and discipline. But there was one issue Mr. Bush did not so much as mention: school vouchers.

title: Number of Americans Without Health Insurance Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  After rising relentlessly for 12 years, the number of Americans without health insurance finally declined last year, to 42.6 million, a reduction of 1.7 million from 1998, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS TO START VENTURE CAPITAL BUSINESS
description: The Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said it was starting a venture-capital business with $250 million of the firm's capital to invest in fledgling financial-services companies. The new company, GSVentures, will be run by Michael P. Mortara, Goldman's former co-head of fixed-income, currency and commodities.

title: WHAT'S NEXT; Mega-network: Strength in Numbers
description: WHO makes the greatest demands on computer networks? Napster fans, real-time gamers, corporate video conferencers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAIDORF, BLANCHE
description: NAIDORF-Blanche. On September 24th, 2000. The Chairman, Faculty and Staff of the Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons note with deep sorrow the passing of Blanche Naidorf. Mrs. Naidorf's kindness and generosity will long be remembered in our department. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Michael, Kelly, Ellen, Pearl Lipper, Beatrice Kaplan and grandchildren, Meredith and Matthew. Michael D. Gershon, M.D., Professor and Chairman

title: BRICKS AND CLICKS CONVERGENCE?
description: In another effort to bring together Internet and traditional retailing, a company named in Los Angeles is introducing a series of prepaid cards to be sold in retail stores that enable the card holders to buy merchandise on the Web sites of e-commerce companies. J. Michael Boh, chief executive at Prepay.com, described the cards as a cost-effective method for dot-coms to acquire customers as they ''search for ways offline to drive people online.'' The cards can be used like gift certificates, entitling the users to buy merchandise on the Web sites of dot-coms like Aboutgolf.com, Beautyscene.com and Cigar.com. Mr. Boh said Prepay.com would begin national sales of the cards through large retail chains in late October. Stuart Elliott

title: Haggling on the Web Interface to Interface
description: IF you have spent an extended period of time in the company of children (five minutes should suffice), you will understand the full scope of the tactical error I made soon after the foot-powered-scooter craze reached my neighborhood: I bought one for my family to share.

title: Air France Sues Continental Over Crash of the Concorde
description: Air France said today that it had filed a lawsuit against Continental Airlines because it believed a metal strip from a Continental DC-10 led to the crash of its Concorde jet in July.

title: The Armenian Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; New Jersey Is First For 2-Bedroom Cost
description: New Jersey has the highest rents in the nation for two-bedroom apartments this year, surpassing Hawaii, according to a private study based on figures from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: P.D.A.s That Go Online
description: Owners of Palm Inc.'s VII and VIIx models can subscribe to Palm.Net, a wireless service operated by the company, under plans that range from $9.99 a month plus additional-use charges to $44.99 a month for unlimited use. Palm's system, unlike those for cell phones, uses conventional Internet page language and offers about 400 sites that have been revised using what Palm calls Web clipping. To speed up downloading, that technology strips away graphics and links from Web pages. Palm.Net also offers services that will clip any page on the Web on demand, although the results can often be disappointing. Other wireless service providers also offer Web services that work with Palm, Windows CE and Pocket PC devices.

title: Hotel Group Wins Bidding To Purchase Rihga Royal
description: The heated auction of the Rihga Royal Hotel has come to an end, with Strategic Hotel Capital emerging as the victorious buyer of the 54-story tower on West 54th Street, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, according to hotel and real estate executives.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; News Corporation and Liberty Media complete an asset swap.
description: THE News Corporation and Liberty Media Group confirmed yesterday that they had agreed to a complex stock and asset swap in which Liberty Media would increase its stake in the News Corporation and the News Corporation would pick up Liberty's Gemstar-TV Guide International holdings.

title: Pagers That Surf
description: Pagers with tiny keyboards from Motorola and Research in Motion are primarily used to send and receive e-mail. But Research in Motion recently introduced a larger- screen model as a step toward linking its users to the Web as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, RICHARD MAYER
description: HABER-Richard Mayer. On September 26, 2000. Cleveland born attorney, writer and philanthropist at age 81. Beloved long-time companion of Raoul Abdul. Also survived by a cousin Lois Haber Siegel of Miami Beach, Florida. There will be no services.

title: Judge Tells Firestone to Release Technical Data on Tires
description: A federal district court judge here ruled today that the public should have access to extensive information on tire technology that Firestone was compelled to turn over during a lawsuit over a fatal accident. The company said that releasing the documents would amount to giving up trade secrets.

title: Mrs. Clinton Offers Debt-Reduction Plan; Lazio Questions Its Value
description: Supported by Robert E. Rubin, the former secretary of the Treasury Department, and Warren Buffet, the billionaire investor, Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged yesterday to protect the federal budget surplus from Republican ''tax schemes'' by proposing legislation to limit tax cuts and new spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, CECIL JOY
description: ROBBINS-Cecil Joy, former ballerina, protege of Harriet Hoctor, featured dancer at Billy Rose's Diamond Horseshoe, Lou Walters Latin Quarter, and niteclubs and theaters throughout the country passed away peacefully at home on September 25, 2000. She loved life with a vivacious and energetic passion which she passed on to all in her family and her many friends. She is survived by her lovng husband Jules, daughter Linda, sons Steven and David, brother Harold, sister Myrna and grandchildren Skyler, Alex, Marc and Mick. Services on Thursday, September 28, 2000 at 12:45 PM at The Riverside Chapel, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Matters; Back When A Water Scare Was a Crisis
description: SO the great water scare is over. There was no bad stuff in bottled water, just a guy pulling a scam, and maybe some wayward Palmolive.

title: MUSIC SITES DRAW AD SPENDING
description: In what may be seen as a silver lining to the legal clouds hovering over Internet music sites, data gathered by the advertising measurement service AdRelevance suggests that the sites have benefited from increased ad revenue in the wake of publicity surrounding this sector. During the two weeks after the July 26 injunction against the music file-sharing service Napster, advertising revenue at about 23 music sites monitored by AdRelevance jumped 39 percent. Although for most music sites, the spike was short-lived, a few, like Spinner.com and Sonic.Net, had sustained increases in advertising revenue through early September. But Napster itself does not stand to benefit from the effect, since its Web site does not carry advertisements. Susan Stellin

title: Summit Bancorp Said to Discuss Acquisition by FleetBoston
description: Summit Bancorp, the largest bank in New Jersey, is in talks to be acquired by the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This school and these children, they may take everything I have. But there's a really deep well in me, and it's time to draw on it.''

title: Techno Fabrics Suffer Red Wine Stylishly
description: THINK the withdrawal of Scotchgard from the market means being forever careful eating that bowl of cereal in the den? Don't worry. Spill whatever you want -- coffee, ice cream, mustard. We did it on these techno fabrics, all of man-made materials like polyester and plastic, and found that a cloth and hot soapy water removed everything. Techno fabrics are washable, scrubbable, even water-repellant. And they have a cachet borrowed from the world of fashion, where designers like Helmut Lang and Jil Sander have used them. ''It's all about cross-marketing,'' said Michael Maharam, an owner of Maharam, a textile company in the forefront of innovative materials. ''But plastic fabric is definitely fashionable.''

title: SIEMENS WILL PURCHASE ACUSON FOR $700 MILLION
description: Siemens A.G., Germany's largest electronics manufacturer, agreed to buy the Acuson Corporation, a maker of ultrasound radiology devices, for about $700 million to expand overseas. Siemens said it offered $23 a share, 47 percent more than Tuesday's closing price. Acuson shares rose $6.94, or 44 percent, to $22.63, yesterday. Acuson is the latest of three major acquisitions Siemens has made this year to focus on technology and communications. Acuson, based in Mountain View, Calif., had annual sales of $475.9 million in 1999 and employs 1,900 people worldwide.

title: AIRLINE EXPANDING CARGO UNIT
description: Varig, Brazil's leading airline, said yesterday that it would spend $100 million expand its cargo unit into a logistics company that will include distribution, delivery, packaging and storage services. The new company, to be called Varig Logistica, or Varilog for short, is expected to account for 30 percent of Varig's revenue, or about $500 million this year. The company is expected to compete with FedEx and DHL, which have stepped up investments in Latin America in recent years. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Defense in Lockerbie Trial Undermines a Key Witness
description: In an atmosphere so hostile that the witness's fear could be heard even in the voices of his translators, the testimony of the most important witness in the Lockerbie trial was systematically torn to pieces by defense lawyers today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSKY, ALBERT
description: LEVINSKY-Albert. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Albert Levinsky, beloved brother of our dedicated members Harold and Betsy Levinsky. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Engineers' Marvels, Solved in Pictures
description: AN automobile piston, as anyone who has read David Macaulay's 1988 best seller, ''The Way Things Work,'' can tell you, is a simple reciprocating pump that operates on the principle of . . . well, it would be a lot easier to explain using one of the witty illustrations that fill Mr. Macaulay's books and television programs. You could blow a gasket trying to explain some of the principles that Mr. Macaulay, an author and illustrator, distills into simple, illuminating images.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the redesign of an art center at the University of California at Los Angeles misspelled the center's name. It is the Dickson Art Center, not Dixon.

title: Sony Says It Will Far Short On Delivery of Playstation 2
description: By BARNABY J. FEDER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOFF, GRACE G.
description: KOFF-Grace G. On September 26, 2000 in Sunbury, PA. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Susan and Tom Travis of Lewisburg, PA, Barry and Nancy Koff, Robert and Denise Koff, Chuck Gormley and the late Aileen Gormley. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Services Friday 10:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. Donations in her memory to Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

title: Last-Second Shot Lifts Brazil Into Semifinals
description: Hortencia, their greatest player ever, was at home, retired. Janeth Arcain, the best player they have here, had fouled out. What remained of the Brazilians' storied women's basketball tradition and team limped out on the court with less than two minutes left in tonight's game, trailing Russia by 3 points.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: The Mets vs. the Thing (A Nonmusical Sequel)
description: When a character in the musical ''Phantom of the Opera'' tries to explain away mysterious mishaps by saying ''these things happen,'' another character says emphatically, ''These things do not happen.''

title: SENATORS RAISE AOL CONCERNS
description: A Senate committee on telecommunications, trade and consumer protection convened yesterday to discuss interactive television. But with Stephen M. Case, chairman of America Online, present, questions turned to issues standing in the way of the proposed AOL-Time Warner merger. Members of the committee tried to tackle thorny topics like whether Time Warner should be required to open its cable network to all Internet service providers as a condition of the merger and whether AOL would share its popular instant messaging services. Mr. Case sought to assuage concerns, noting that many Internet service providers are waiting until after the merger to negotiate for access to Time Warner's cable systems and saying the messaging technology could be compatible with other systems.

title: After an Intense Match, Norway Knocks Off U.S.
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  No matter how many international tournaments the United States has won, Norway has always played the role of asterisk in the American domination of women's soccer.

title: Calling an Ambulance
description: To the Editor:

title: Stray Bullet From Street Fight Kills a Neighborhood Fixture
description: Enrique Miravala, known to all as Flaco, was a fixture at the corner of Wilson Avenue and Palmetto Street in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. A gentle, sometimes homeless alcoholic, 54 years old, he repaired cars expertly, swept storefronts and ran errands, earning beer money and the affection of his neighbors.

title: Report Says Global Accounting Firm Overlooks Factory Abuses
description: In a rare inside look at the auditing firms that inspect overseas factories to see whether they are sweatshops, an M.I.T. professor contends that the world's largest factory-monitoring firm does a shoddy job and overlooks many safety and wage violations.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO IS LITTLE CHANGED. The euro edged up slightly ahead of a vote today in Denmark on a proposal to adopt the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 88.30 cents, up from 88.27 cents on Tuesday.

title: For a West Side Stadium
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Relax Requirements For Recruits
description: Faced with a dwindling number of applicants for the city's Police Academy, the Police Department relaxed its eligibility requirements yesterday to allow younger recruits to join the department and to admit more officers without two years of college.

title: Cable's Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Many in Belgrade Say It Is Time for a Change
description: In the crumbling streets of a faded Belgrade, tired and worn from 10 years of international sanctions and isolation, most people have simply had enough of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: This Net Is Built For Play
description: IT was a lovely September afternoon and I was doing what many like-minded souls do on weekends in autumn: playing football with friends. But instead of running around and possibly damaging valuable body parts, I was sitting in a comfortable chair at my friend Jenn Sturm's apartment.

title: Torre Says Players Won't Get Extra Rest
description: The Yankees whipped the Red Sox in three games at Fenway Park earlier this month, and it appeared that Manager Joe Torre would be able to use the last two weeks of the regular season to preen and tweak and prepare for the postseason.

title: A Welcome to America That Touches All Bases
description: A deeply satisfying new musical, with much on its mind about history, humanity, man and God and the American Dream, is beckoning to theatergoers with a taste for rich characters in a tale that touches the heart, glows with humor and soothes the ear.

title: Priceline Shares Fall on Word Sales Won't Meet Forecasts
description: Shares in the online retailer Priceline.com fell more than 40 percent yesterday after the company said its sales in the third quarter would be as much as 11 percent below analysts' forecasts.

title: Eye on Lasorda From Flushing
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine followed the United States Olympic baseball team's gold medal victory in Australia on television and the Internet yesterday, but he was unable to reach Tommy Lasorda despite having an in.

title: A Thawing Of Cold War Memories
description: The game was over, and the aging man quickly made his way through the emptying stands and down to the floor until he finally reached his old friend at courtside.

title: Economic Scene; Don't underestimate the government's role in building the economy.
description: GEORGE W. BUSH has finally made government the issue of the presidential campaign. After wasting months focusing on Al Gore's character, he returned to what was always the Republicans' meat and potatoes. As president, Vice President Gore would give you big government, Governor Bush now emphasizes. But if voters elect him instead, Mr. Bush says, he would continue to tame Washington.

title: Ads on Cell Phones (And You Thought You Had Escaped)
description: IT'S a Saturday night and all the tables at the hot new restaurant in town are reserved. But you're in the neighborhood when suddenly your cell phone chirps, alerting you of a table that is available at the last minute along with a coupon for a free drink. A few minutes later, you are being seated.

description: Koch Digs Deep For His Candidates
