title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, SHIRLEY
description: COOPERMAN-Shirley. On September 25, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Ellen Abrams, Stephen Cooperman and Lisa Riffkin. Loving sister of Anita Fenson. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Mitchell, Ivy and Jay. Adored great-grandmother of Lauren. Services Thursday 1PM, ''Gutterman's''. 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Interment at the Beth David Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations in her memory to your favorite charity.

title: Interpublic Group names a coordinator of its increasingly diversified units.
description: A SEASONED executive with experience in the account, creative and strategic realms of agency operations is being named to a new top post at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York. The executive, Bruce S. Nelson, will coordinate efforts to manage the increasingly diversified Interpublic units specializing in interactive and direct marketing, public relations, media services, research, programming and consulting as well as traditional advertising.

title: Plea Deal Protected Weapons Data, U.S. Prosecutor Says
description: A federal prosecutor in the Wen Ho Lee case told a Senate subcommittee today that a defense lawyer's threat to turn a trial into a ''long, slow death march'' that would force the government to reveal highly classified nuclear weapons data made the government more willing to reach a plea agreement.

title: In Brooklyn, a Vision Of a Cultural Haven; Academy Plan Generates Buzz and Backlash
description: The three desolate lots that encircle the Brooklyn Academy of Music have gnawed at Harvey Lichtenstein for decades.

title: F.D.A.'s Decision on Whether to Permit Sale of Abortion Pill Is Expected Soon
description: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to decide by Saturday whether it will approve the abortion pill, known as mifepristone or RU-486, for sale in the United States. It would be the first alternative to surgical abortion approved here.

title: Art Patrons With a Trans-Atlantic Reach; British Institutions Find Their Donor Walls Reinforced by Americans
description: Fifteen years ago J. Paul Getty 2nd gave the National Gallery in London a $62.5 million grant, the largest since its founding in 1824. That any individual, let alone an American, would give so generously to a British museum was unheard of. In those years few rich Britons ever wrote a substantial check to a cultural institution. They didn't have to; the government provided ample support. Besides, for British citizens, giving never had the tax advantages that it does in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAY, DR. NANCY DUKE S.
description: LAY-Dr. Nancy Duke S. On September 24th, 2000 at age 62. Beloved sister of Manuel, Manchiu, Manhoo, Addellia and Eva Lay and Rose Gonzales. Professor Lay was an educator at City College and helped establish the ESL Department. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St,. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121 St., Friday, 10 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Breast Center of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Raoul Berger, 99, an Expert On Constitution in 2nd Career
description: Raoul Berger, a widely read and widely debated authority on the United States Constitution, died on Saturday at his home in Concord, Mass., his wife, Patricia, said. He was 99.

title: An Overview; The Wen Ho Lee Case
description: With the public testimony of Attorney General Janet Reno and Louis Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on Tuesday, the Wen Ho Lee case entered a new phase. It is now possible to see for the first time in a full public accounting the outlines of the government's case against Dr. Lee, the former government scientist who pleaded guilty to mishandling classified materials. That case is sobering in its account of Dr. Lee's pattern of suspicious and ultimately illegal activities, though not conclusive on the question of how the Chinese government made its undisputed gains in nuclear weapons technology. But in the wake of Tuesday's joint session of the Senate Judiciary and Intelligence committees, any assessment of the national security and civil liberties aspects of the case -- and the continuing journalistic debate about coverage of the case -- can begin by evaluating Mr. Freeh's presentation.

title: Two Enemies Make Music by Playing So Hard
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Back in Norway, they heard about the victory tour, the commercials, the sponsorships, when the United States won the Women's World Cup in 1999.

title: A U.N. Compromise on Iraqi Money Matters
description: In a concession to nations seeking to soften restrictions on Iraq, the Clinton administration agreed today to reduce the amount of money being set aside to compensate victims of Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. The money saved from the compensation fund would be used for relief projects for Iraqis.

title: POSSIBLE SPANISH UTILITY MERGER
description: Endesa, the leading Spanish power company is in talks about a possible merger with the country's second-largest electricity producer, Iberdrola, which would create one of the biggest utilities in Europe and be among the top 10 in the world. Spanish government regulators are expected to examine the details closely to ensure that it does not violate competition rules. Earlier this year, the government blocked a merger of the power companies Unin Fenosa and Hidroelectrica del Cantabrico over antitrust concerns. Endesa and Iberdrola control more than 80 percent of the electrical power market and have a combined value of more than $31 billion. Benjamin Jones

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONO, MARYANN, RN, BSN, MA. THE ALUMNI ASSOCIATION OF ST. VINCENT'S HOSPITAL SCHOOL OF NURSING NOTES WITH DEEP SADNESS THE TRAGIC DEATH OF OUR FRIENDS AND ALUMNI IN THE MATERNAL CHILD HEALTH DIVISION: MARYANN DONO '60 (SECRETARY, TREASURER); MARY ANN GOING '61; KATHLEEN MOLLICK '57; AND JOAN ELLEN WALSH '64. THEY WERE PROUD TO CALL THEMSELVES ST. VINCENT'S NURSES, AND WE ARE PROUD TO CALL THEM COLLEAGUES. CONTRIBUTIONS MAY BE MADE TO THE ST. VINCENT'S NURSES MEMORIAL FUND, C
description: DONO-Maryann, RN, BSN, MA. The Alumni Association of St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing notes with deep sadness the tragic death of our friends and alumni in the Maternal Child Health Division: Maryann Dono '60 (Secretary-Treasurer); Mary Ann Going '61; Kathleen Mollick '57; and Joan Ellen Walsh '64. They were proud to call themselves St. Vincent's nurses, and we are proud to call them colleagues. Contributions may be made to the St. Vincent's Nurses Memorial Fund, C Development, St. Vincent's HospitalManhattan, 153 West 11th Street, New York, New York 10011. Joan J. Caruana '61, President & the Board of Directors

title: Concert Review; Color Me Saying Adieu: Streisand at the Garden
description: Leave it to Barbra Streisand to turn her own life into a musical fairy tale, one with a resoundingly happy ending. That is the essence of the farewell show she brought to Madison Square Garden for two sold-out performances last night and this evening. The personal story she tells in songs and anecdotes is a variation on any number of myths in which a lonely, gifted child who never knew her father finds and marries a handsome prince and lives happily ever after. On the way, she also becomes queen of the Hollywood dream factory with her spellbinding voice.

title: Gore Challenging Bush To Bar Soft Money for Ads
description: Vice President Al Gore challenged Gov. George W. Bush today to agree to ban the use of unregulated party money on television and radio advertising for the rest of the presidential campaign.

title: Objection to Time Warner-EMI Deal, but Europeans Favor Merger with AOL
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 28  European antitrust regulators plan to block Time Warner's joint venture with the British music conglomerate EMI Group but are close to approving Time Warner's $135 billion merger with America Online, people close to the talks said today.

title: Russians End the Upstart Americans Run
description: SYDNEY, Sept. 28  A United States women's volleyball team that arrived here little known and lowly rated took Russia to a fifth game tonight for the right to play for the Olympic gold medal. But the American squad, seeded 10th in a 12-nation field, finally lost to the second-seeded Russians in a tough 90-minute semifinal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, HARRY G.
description: HILL-Harry G. Age 99, on September 26, 2000 of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of the late Grace M. (Byrne). Loving father of Harry G., Jr., David B. and Sister Elizabeth A., C.S.J. Cherished grandfather of seven grandchildren. Member of the firm of Cullen and Dykman for over 50 years. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, NY 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, NY, 11 AM Friday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKOW, ROBIN M.
description: RANKOW-Robin M. On Sept. 22, 2000. Professor Emeritus and Attending Surgeon, Head and Neck Surgery, Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. Attending Surgeon, Yale University, New Haven Medical Center, 1979-1985. Authored surgical atlas, medical texts, numerous articles. Past President, American Society of Maxillofacial Surgeons; New York Chapter, Association of Military Surgeons. Colonel, U.S. Army Reserve, served in World War II with military commendations. Predeceased by his first wife, Elaine. Survived by his daughter, Leslie, of New York and by Jane Whitman, of Tuscon, Arizona. Private interment at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Columbia University, C/O The Association of Alumni.

title: Actors' Strike Dragging On As Talks Break Down
description: Thirteen days of negotiations between representatives of advertisers and actors on strike broke down yesterday as the strike approached the end of its fifth month.

title: Metro Business; Sally Ride Leaves Dot-Com
description: Sally Ride, the first woman who was an American astronaut, resigned on Tuesday as president of Space.com, a year after she joined the company, a Manhattan multimedia publishing firm that bundles space-related Web sites and services.

title: Contractors to Go
description: IN Manhattan, it's easy to find cabinets and appliances, but hard to find a contractor who is professional and willing to work on a kitchen for $20,000 or less including labor. Here are seven contractors, carpenters and cabinetmakers who will work within those restraints, and who are recommended by the designers of the seven kitchens.

title: Drug-Cost Bill May Not Dent Industry Profit
description: If a bill allowing imports of low-priced prescription drugs becomes law, drug companies will be able to use many tactics to protect their profits, Wall Street analysts said yesterday, and keep the amount of reimported drugs to a minimum.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about viewers' responses to the ''Hip-Hop Nation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art referred incorrectly to materials used by the artist Chris Ofili for his collage of the Virgin Mary in the museum's recent show ''Sensation.'' Along with paper, oil paint, glitter and resin, the artist used elephant dung, not cow dung.

title: U.S. Takes Silver in Regatta, but Australia Wins the Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  In sight of the famous waterside Opera House and the Olympic rings emblazoned across the Sydney Harbor Bridge, the American crews of J.J. Isler and Pease Glaser, and Paul Foerster and Bob Merrick, raced to silver medals this afternoon in the Olympic regatta.

title: Giants Aim For Silent Treatment
description: The loudspeakers stood like black monoliths on the sidelines of the Giants' practice field today, substitutes for the harsh atmosphere the team expects to face Sunday against the Titans at Tennessee.

title: Sexy Styles, Short Skirts and an 80s Attitude
description: At New York Fashion Week for spring 2001, which ended last Friday, visions for designer collections ran the gamut. Randolph Duke showed evening wear inspired by the flowing togas and gowns of Greek and Roman goddesses while Betsey Johnson's playful runway show featured Playboy bunnies in brightly colored sundresses and naughty nighties.

title: Parties Playing A Larger Role In Election Ads
description: Both the Republican and Democratic Party organizations, using soft money, are outspending special interest groups and the Bush and Gore campaigns on television in the presidential elections, say researchers monitoring paid political advertising.

title: Tale Told by an Ingenue: Theater Showcase Returns
description: An Eisenhower-era mother with a penchant for eating cat food. Her daughter, who is so obsessed with getting a puppy that she simply barks as an introduction. And the mysterious Dr. Phallus, an erudite quipster whose sole mission in life is to educate the hero about his true sexual desires (as if the Judy Garland poster was not signal enough).

title: Despite Ups And Downs, Surveys Show Race Is Tied
description: After watching his opponent's popularity rise in the polls over the last month, Gov. George W. Bush got a dose of good news over the last few days. The momentum is now his, with three new nationwide polls showing that he has regained some of the ground he lost to Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Bush seems to have the edge in at least two of the polls. But is it real?

title: BANK LAYOFFS EXPECTED
description: Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival may lay off as many as 3,000 people, or about 10 percent of its work force, to cut costs in coming months, a bank official said yesterday. These are ''adjustments to make the bank more practical, efficient and to improve operations,'' said Jose Ortiz Izquierdo, director of media relations at the bank, the second largest in Mexico. He said the adjustments would involve job cuts and would affect all areas of the bank, though top management would remain in place. An official announcement will be made within two weeks.

title: British Open Will Be 4th L.P.G.A. Major
description: The Weetabix Women's British Open will become a major championship next year, allowing the L.P.G.A. to continue having four majors on its schedule, L.P.G.A. officials said yesterday.

title: China Dives for More Gold Medals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  Two systems for developing divers were on display at the Olympic Park Aquatic Center tonight, and the results were as defining as Fu Mingxia's nearly flawless technique.

description: Two agencies are making acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: The First Lady Heads West to Raise Money, Both Hard and Soft
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton began a three-day fund-raising trip outside New York yesterday with a visit to Oklahoma City, where her host was a former state attorney general who came under scrutiny in one of the fund-raising investigations involving her husband's re-election.

title: A Call to Put the Budget Surplus to Use for the Military
description: The nation's senior military commanders told Congress today that the armed services needed a significant increase in spending in the years ahead, suggesting amounts that would exceed what has been proposed by either major presidential candidate and consume a large part of the projected budget surplus.

title: Gaze, Now 35, Puts On a Show TV Could Love
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  The young, brooding guard from Italy was shaken, his words tumbling over each other after the wrenching, last-second loss to Australia.

title: Internet Appliance Eliminates Hard Drive
description: Imagine upgrading your computer's operating system by simply popping out a CD-ROM and replacing it with a new one: No muss, no fuss, no scrambled software drivers and bald spots from pulling out hair.

title: Homeless Shelter Proposal Is Questioned
description: A foundation controlled by a real estate speculator convicted last year in a Brooklyn bid-rigging scheme stands to earn $700,000 from a complex real estate deal backed by the Giuliani administration.

title: Suit Considers Computer Files
description: When the public schools in Exeter, N.H., gave Internet access to students in 1998, they chose not to use filtering or blocking software on classroom terminals, opting instead for a less restrictive combination of supervision and spot-checks.

title: In America; Focus on Women
description: The most extensive analysis of women's views in this campaign season has shown that as the economy has improved, American women have been taking a much closer look at the quality of their lives, and not liking a great deal that they see.

title: Party for a Division Title Is Postponed Again
description: The Champagne will be flat by the time the Yankees get around to clinching the American League East. Heck, if they drag it out any longer, George Steinbrenner might disgustedly tell his players to split a six-pack of beer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIBERTY CORP., Greenville, S.C., which owns Liberty Life Insurance and Cosmos Broadcasting, said it would buy up to three million more of its shares, in addition to the one million already authorized for repurchase.

title: Meet the New Web. Same as the Old Web.
description: ONE night this summer, Robert Smith was in a bar debating the name of an obscure supporting actress in an equally obscure John Wayne film. It was his telephone that finally settled the discussion.

title: Rangers Leave Two Unprotected
description: The Rangers, in Coach Ron Low's words, hedged their bets yesterday by leaving two highly paid veterans, John MacLean and Rich Pilon, available among their unprotected players for tomorrow's National Hockey League waiver draft.

title: After Yugoslavs Celebrate, Belgrade Orders a Runoff
description: About 2 a.m. today, just hours after more than 200,000 people claiming victory for the opposition candidate in last Sunday's presidential election had gone home, the government of President Slobodan Milosevic pressed through a final ruling that both candidates would have to meet in a second round on Oct. 8.

title: Olympic Arbitrators Reaction to Gymnasts Appeal: Too Bad
description: Sydney, Australia -- If you had put it to a vote, polled the Olympic community, I suspect it would have been a landslide Slobodan Milosevic couldn't ignore. By the time it was announced today that Andreea Raducan wasn't getting her gold medal back, people just wished the cute little gymnast could wipe away the tears, go home happily to Romania to claim her $30,000 victory prize.

title: A Favorite Winning Hand In a 3-Decade Quest for a Title

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDLER, FAY R.
description: HENDLER-Fay R. On September 26, 2000, at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Aaron T. Hendler, and beloved sister of Jack Rosenstock. Cherished mother of Susan and Ronald Cohen, Merry and Martin Lapidus, and Hilary Hendler. Adored grandmother of Beth and Ted Snyder, Adrienne Cohen, Heather Lapidus, and Richard Lapidus. Services September 28, 2000, 1:30 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Fay's memory may be made to The American Parkinson Foundation or the charity of your choice.

description: On her fourth day as a teacher, Donna Moffett would not -- could not -- stop smiling.

title: States Prove Unpredictable in Aiding Uninsured Children
description: In Alaska, health care officials found that the best way to get children enrolled in a federal health insurance program was to give their parents information encased in an imitation caribou-skin tote bag. Louisiana had a tireless advocate for the program, and made things easy for parents by giving them stamped self-addressed envelopes to return their applications.

title: Book Seeks to Indict Anthropologists Who Studied Brazil Indians
description: A new book about anthropologists who worked with isolated Indians in the Amazon Basin has set off a storm in the profession, reviving scholarly animosities, endangering personal reputations and, some parties say, threatening to undermine confidence in legitimate practices of anthropology.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Woodies Lose, But Are First In Fans' Hearts
description: THEY have been known as the Woodies, the Australian doubles of doubles, though they look nothing alike, hardly play alike and have based themselves on opposite coasts of the United States. They formed a partnership 10 years ago, when Mark Woodforde was 25 and Todd Woodbridge was turning 20. Sixty-one tournament titles, 11 of them Grand Slams, and 1 Olympic gold medal later, they walked on court here yesterday afternoon to thunderous applause, the final chapter to a storybook all but set in print.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ARTHUR L.
description: DAVIS-Arthur L. Loving and devoted husband of Lenore for 59 years, father of Nan, Ruth and Rob, father-in-law of Nina Davis and Bill Drew, grandfather of Jonathan and Jesse Davis, David and Mark Drew. Died peacefully surrounded by his family Tuesday, September 26. He was 81 years old. He was a founding member of Temple Sinai, Tenafly, NJ. Past president of the New Jersey American Institute of Architects, contributor to many charities and organizations throughout his long and healthy life. He was a man of great humor and a great lover of all things cultural. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers a donation to your charity of choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSER, SUZY CHADWICK, PHD, 56.
description: KUSER-Suzy Chadwick, PhD, 56. Of Mesa, Arizona, died on Sunday, Sept. 24, 2000. She was born in NYC, NY and was a psychologist. She is survived by her husband, William H. Kuser, sons, Greg, Mike, & Pete Chadwick, and five grandchildren. A chapel service will be held Saturday, September 30, 2000, at 10:00 A.M., at the Lakeshore Mortuary, 1815 South Dobson Road, Mesa, Arizona, (480) 838-5639.

title: Netanyahu, In Atlanta, Is All Smiles
description: Benjamin Netanyahu was among a crowd of oblivious techies here today, trying his best to pitch the merits of an Israeli telecommunications company while being repeatedly interrupted by calls on his cellular telephone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANBAZIAN, REV. MOVSES B.
description: JANBAZIAN-Rev. Movses B., Executive Director of Armenian Missionary Association of America, Inc., Paramus, NJ on September 25, 2000. Husband of Louisa (nee Youmoushakian). Father of Vahak Boghos and Ani Agnes Janbazian. Son of Agnes (nee Andonian) and the late Boghos Janbazian. Brother of Marie Sarmazian, Vehanoush Sood, Sona Koujanian, Ani Hasserjian and Jack Janbazian. Religious service Saturday 11:00 AM, Armenian Presbyterian Church, 140 Forest Avenue, Paramus. For information, call Frank A. Patti & Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Directors, Fort Lee, (201) 944-0100.

title: Arafat Hails Big Gas Find Off the Coast Of Gaza Strip
description: Yasir Arafat traveled 19 miles off the Gaza coast today to light the first flare stack over a major offshore deposit of natural gas, proclaiming it ''a gift from our God to our people.''

title: Article 2000092893581067318 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: In Australia Hinterland, A Ton of Native Pride
description: The teacups clinked daintily as the ladies of the Lithgow Valley Lawn Bowling Club sat down to lunch. But the talk was of male Olympic swimmers and their rippling muscles.

title: Fashion Marketers Plan Changes
description: Two fashion and beauty marketers are making agency changes.

title: Under Pressure, Putin Postpones Military Cuts
description: Facing opposition from his military commanders, President Vladimir V. Putin postponed plans today to cut the armed forces by a third and said ''there will be no wholesale, massive reductions of the Russian armed forces.''

title: Owens Corning Unifies With Doner
description: Owens Corning, the home improvement and building materials company, said yesterday that it would consolidate its account by naming Doner in Southfield, Mich., to handle duties ranging from advertising to media services to interactive assignments. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: A Video Game With Cinematic Aspirations
description: IT could happen to any developer. You spend years working on a game, creating an elaborate story, detailed characters and beautiful snow scenes carefully lit to reflect the time of day. Then, just as you think you're finished, you realize that you have completely forgotten one thing: giving people something they can actually play. With no time left, you quickly toss in a little mindless action and release the game.

title: Color Choices for Headphones Make Them iMacs for the Ears
description: Just how far is all this Macintosh-inspired translucence going to go? Apparently, the design folks at Sony believe that the iMac look should be extended to their latest offering in lightweight headphones.

The Right Move on Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEANS DELIBERATE ON DEALS
description: European antitrust regulators met in Brussels yesterday to decide whether concessions submitted by Time Warner and its proposed partners, America Online and the EMI Music Group, were sufficient to allay European concerns that the planned deals would choke competition in the Internet distribution of music. The regulators, from the national antitrust agencies of the 15 European Union member states, were expected to issue a recommendation whether to accept or reject the concessions, or possibly to seek further clarification from the companies. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HARVEY S.
description: GREENBERG-Harvey S. On September 27, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Minerva. Devoted father of Cynthia and Jerry Kassman, & the late Stuart. Brother of Irving Greenberg and Claire Abramson. Dear grandfather of Myles and Amy, Howard and Kirsten, Shawn, Jason and Jillian. Adored greatgrandfather of Marra & Marshall. Services today 12 Noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Long Island.

title: Suharto Said Unfit to Stand Trial
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia -- An independent medical team said Thursday that ex-dictator Suharto is too sick to stand trial, a finding that means the former president may not face charges he embezzled hundreds of millions in government money.

title: In City Canyons, Slivers of Public Space Erode
description: Most privately owned public spaces in New York City, created in a tradeoff that was meant to give pedestrians a little extra breathing room as developers got extra-large buildings, have failed in some way, large or small, a new study has found.

title: Rooting for WordPerfect
description: To the Editor:

title: City Sending Old Rape Evidence for DNA Testing
description: After years of stockpiling biological evidence from unsolved rape cases, the city is sending the evidence to private laboratories to try to identify the rapists through any DNA they left behind.

description: Percent

title: It's the Icon Challenge
description: DURING every Olympics, in a tradition as hallowed as the torch, viewers encounter a new set of pictograms: that menu of symbols representing the events of the Games. These abstract figures are meant to be legible to athletes and fans of any nation -- a visual Esperanto.

title: No Prosecution For Netanyahu In Graft Inquiry
description: After deliberating for six months, Israel's attorney general said he had found insufficient evidence to prosecute former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on corruption charges, clearing the way for a possible political comeback by the conservative leader.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Rivalry Brings Out The Best In Braves
description: Several Mets sliced or peeled away the splashy green posters that adorned the strips of plastic covering their lockers in the Champagne-soaked clubhouse. The posters declared the Mets as the wild-card entrant from the National League, and some players obviously wanted to bring these posters home. They had earned it.

title: Buildings Official Charged With Accepting Gifts
description: A deputy commissioner for the city's Buildings Department has been indicted on charges that he accepted gifts, including wine and Rangers tickets, and did not report them on official government disclosure forms, a lawyer familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Parent Says Chrysler Unit Will Post a Third-Quarter Loss
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that its Chrysler car group would report a loss in the third quarter -- the first such loss since a recession in the United States nine years ago -- and that Chrysler's highly respected design chief, Thomas C. Gale, would retire at the end of this year.

title: Ruling May Revive a Luxury Goods Battle
description: Reviving a battle between two of Europe's biggest luxury goods groups that had seemed resolved, a Dutch court today ordered a review of a decision last year that had allowed the sale of a $3 billion controlling stake in the Gucci Group to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute of France.

title: Mega-network: Strength in Numbers
description: WHO makes the greatest demands on computer networks? Napster fans, real-time gamers, corporate video conferencers?

title: Don't Like Today's Candidates? Step Back in Time
description: A new Web feature lets you compare TV commercials and pick a candidate: Ike or Adlai. The Living Room Candidate, an online version of a 1992 exhibition at the American Museum of the Moving Image (ammi.org), has compiled television campaign ads for presidential elections from 1952 to the present. The highlights include campy cartoons from the 1952 Eisenhower-Stevenson race and infamous attack ads from the campaigns of Lyndon B. Johnson (the ad that showed a little girl picking the petals of a daisy -- until a nuclear bomb exploded) and George Bush (the Willie Horton ad). The Desktop Candidate area links to sites with TV ads from the 2000 race and archives with the 1996 campaigns' online efforts. Carl Goodman, the museum's curator of digital media, said visitors could examine ''parallels between how politicians started to use the then-new medium of television and the kind of baby steps that are being taken now on the Internet.'' MATTHEW MIRAPAUL

title: Arbitrators Reject Appeal by Romanian Gymnast
description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport today denied the Romanian gymnast Andreea Raducan's appeal to regain the gold medal stripped from her by the International Olympic Committee because she tested positive for a banned substance.

description: A former manager of the Luxottica Group of Italy and 14 other people and companies were accused today of trading on inside information in the company's 1995 acquisition of the U.S. Shoe Corporation.

description: In this overwhelmingly Republican state, Democrats have to tread carefully.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Microsoft antitrust case were reversed and carried incorrect or incomplete credits. Judge Harry T. Edwards was at the left (photo by Craig Herndon of The Washington Post) and Judge David B. Sentelle at the right (photo by Ray Lustig of The Washington Post).

title: McSorley Says He Wanted to Fight, Not Injure
description: Offering more reasons than remorse, Marty McSorley testified today that his stick-swinging against Donald Brashear in a game last year was little more than an unfortunate accident between National Hockey League enforcers.

title: RANK GROUP SELLING UNIT
description: The British conglomerate the Rank Group said that it would sell its holidays division, which includes hotels and camping parks, to the Bourne Leisure Group for as much as $:700 million, or about $980 million. The privately held Bourne Leisure, which runs parks throughout Britain, said it would pay $:650 million up front and an additional $:50 million in two years if Rank's Butlin's resorts unit meets profit targets. Rank's shares rose 5.9 percent, to 161 pence, or about $2.24. Rank has been shedding businesses, like Odeon cinema and a stake in Universal Studios Escape, to pay down debt. Suzanne Kapner

title: With Rents as High as the Skyline, Designers Seek a New Home
description: If you are a designer working at home, have a thriving business and are thinking of expanding into commercial Midtown Manhattan, think again. The severe shortage of office space and record rents (up nearly 30 percent over the last year) are driving longtime New Yorkers out. One of the most prominent teams to go, Massimo and Lella Vignelli, above -- designers of elegant graphics, furniture and exhibitions, including the Venetian glass show at the American Craft Museum -- made a painful decision to close their celebrated minimalist office at 475 10th Avenue (37th Street) when their 15-year lease expires next month. Rent on the 12,000-square-foot space rose sixfold, to $62.50 a square foot.

title: VIACOM SETTLES WITH SHAREHOLDERS IN SPELLING BUYOUT
description: Viacom Inc. has agreed to pay more than $18.4 million to settle shareholder suits over its buyout of Spelling Entertainment Group Inc., court papers say. In March 1999, Viacom, based in New York, offered $9 a share, or $167 million, for the 20 percent of Spelling it did not own. The acquired company is the creator of television shows like ''Beverly Hills 90210'' and ''7th Heaven.'' A group of Spelling shareholders sued in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington, asserting that they were being shortchanged in the buyout. After negotiations, Viacom officials agreed to add 75 cents a share, or $17.9 million, to their offer. Viacom officials weren't immediately available for comment. Viacom also agreed to pay as much as $575,000 to cover the shareholders' legal fees, court papers show. The agreement needs the approval of Chief Judge William B. Chandler III of Chancery Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLICK, KATHLEEN
description: MOLLICK-Kathleen. 29+, daughter of the late Frank and Mary Mollick, sister of the late Johanna Corcoran. Devoted aunt of Jacqueline Corcoran, Jennifer Corcoran, and Joan Corcoran Green, and her husband, Richard. Adored great aunt of Hannah, and Megan Green. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 A.M. Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at 50th Street. Friends may call Thursday evening 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Saint Vincent's Hospital.

title: Republicans Call Gore Solicitation Misleading
description: The Gore-Lieberman campaign is raising millions of dollars for an obscure fund that is supposed to pay only for legal and accounting costs and not television advertisements or other political costs.

title: Overcoming Fear of Lane 1, Taylor Hurdles to Victory
description: The former Olympic track coach Mel Rosen says there is only one good place to run a long sprint from Lane 1: the moon.

title: Romeo Is on the Streets. But Where's Juliet?
description: Ever since Shakespeare wrote his play about them, Romeo and Juliet have gone through innumerable artistic reincarnations. Their tragedy has inspired many ballets, operas and movies and, as Leonard Bernstein's classic musical ''West Side Story'' and Baz Luhrmann's 1996 film adaptation demonstrate, the people who portray these lovers can look as believable in modern dress as they do in Renaissance attire.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the E-Commerce Report column in Business Day on Monday referred imprecisely to the relationship between ABC News and an Internet company, ScreamingMedia. The ABC Web site, ABCNews.com, provides the text of its online reports to ScreamingMedia, which then distributes them to other Web sites. It does not currently provide video images with the reports.

title: Adm. Horacio Rivero Jr., 90, Vice Chief of Naval Operations
description: Adm. Horacio Rivero Jr., a former vice chief of naval operations and ambassador to Spain, died on Sunday at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUNZIATA, VIVIAN C.
description: NUNZIATA-Vivian C. Peacefully died on September 27, 2000 at the young age of 80. Beloved wife of the late Anthony J., loving mother of Jo N. and Gregory Rossicone of Staten Island and Joseph and Fran Nunziata of Pelham Manor, NY. World-renowned for her unparalleled legacy as ''Grandmother of the Century'' to her five grandchildren, Robert and Michael Rossicone, Anthony, Will and Anne Nunziata. Her unwavering love and devotion will live on in everyone she has touched. Friends may call at Matthew Funeral Home, 2508 Victory Blvd, S.I. on Thursday 7 to 9 PM and Friday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral mass will be celebrated on Sat., 9:30 AM, St. Rita Catholic Church, S.I. Interment to follow Moravian Cemetery.

title: NATURAL GAS PRICES COULD HURT MEXICO
description: A leading Mexican industrial group warned yesterday that at least 500 Mexican glass, steel and ceramic plants might be forced to lay off 250,000 workers this winter because of rising natural gas prices. The trade group, known as Canacintra, blamed the state-run oil monopoly, Pemex, for raising natural gas prices in the absence of competition. Pemex, which is expected to earn a windfall from Mexican oil and gas production this year, said increased demand had forced it to raise prices. Graham Gori

title: Brawlers From the Old Soviet Are Making the Biggest Strides
description: They come from Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Ukraine and Russia, burly, hard-looking men who fight with a relentless, intractable boxing style. On the 12th day of the 2000 Olympic boxing tournament, in a headstrong, straight-ahead march through the quarterfinals, it was the fighters from the countries formed by the breakup of the Soviet Union that imposed a new pecking order on the competition.

title: Joness Second Task Is Surprisingly Easy
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  For nearly every first-time Olympian, even one with lofty goals and an abundance of talent, tonight's achievement would have been more than enough. For Marion Jones, it was merely the end of Phase 2.

title: The Washington Crowd, Graying Now, Is Revisited
description: THE GOLDEN AGE

title: Who Could Ask for Anything More?
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  Ten days ago, Venus and Serena Williams arrived as two players in the Olympic medal mix but they left today after overwhelming the scene like a dye drop in a pool.

title: Voila, and More: Black Readers
description: Among the epiphanies that have smitten book publishing lately, the most interesting is not the future of the e-book or print-on-demand or online publishing. Rather it is that there is a large and growing citizenry of black people who buy books and are greedy for reading material relevant to them.

title: Even 286-Pound Legends Lose Eventually
description: The wrestling behemoths stood side by side during introductions, displaying two distinct versions of 286-pound physiques. On the left was the lean and sculptured Siberian with the Ray Nitschke snarl and a seat in the Russian parliament. On the right, with his hands clasped before him, was a hefty slab of prime Wyoming beef who looked like a shy kid with too much baby fat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, SY
description: UNGER-Sy. Brave, beloved husband of Valerie Unger, father of Melissa and Rusty, grandfather of Amanda Guinzburg. Mourned by loving in-laws, the Houles family; survived also by Robert Unger. May his memory be honored as he rests in peace. Donations to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society are welcomed.

title: Web-Enabled Cell Phones
description: To reach the Web with a cell phone, users must first open a minibrowser that establishes a wireless connection with the Internet, usually through a special server. To save users the frustration of entering a Web address using the buttons on the telephone's numeric keypad, service providers usually present choices of text prompts on each phone's display.

title: Contentious MetroStars Limp Home After Loss
description: Tab Ramos sat on the floor, not moving, his eyes ringed with red, his uniform still on well after the end of the match. Clint Mathis simply stared into space, not responding to questions from reporters. Coach Octavio Zambrano sat, head down, quiet, finally saying, ''I just don't know what happened.''

title: Global Crossing's Web Host May Be Sold to Rival Exodus
description: In a move that would advance its lead in the business of storage and maintenance facilities for company's Web sites, Exodus Communications is close to acquiring the Web host division of Global Crossing for about $6.5 billion in stock, people close to the companies said yesterday.

description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTER, HARRY
description: PASTER-Harry. The entire membership and staff of the American Association of Advertising Agencies mourns the loss of Harry Paster, who died Tuesday September 26 at the age of 74 after a prolonged illness. A former AAAA executive vice president, Harry was one of the most influential and colorful figures in the United States advertising agency industry. He spent his entire professional career at the AAAA, where for five decades he met and advised some of the biggest, most famous names in the American ad industry. Harry joined us in 1948 and was named vice president in 1966, senior VP in 1978, and executive VP in 1980. He provided valuable counsel to AAAA member agencies on management issues including costs and profits, benefit plans, compensation arrangements, contracts, succession plans, and mergers and acquisitions from 1980 until his 1995 retirement. The AAAA extends its deepest sympathies to his entire family. Services will be held Thursday at 10 A.M. at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck, NY. A funeral will follow immediately at Beth Moses Cemetery on Pine Lawn Avenue in Farmingdale, New York. We'll miss you, Harry.

title: WIRELESS FINANCIAL SERVICE
description: Extending its Internet information service to wireless distribution in Japan and Europe, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said yesterday that it planned to give its institutional customers access to research, stock recommendations and financial news over mobile telephones. Called Radar, the service is expected to become more sophisticated and wide-reaching over time, so that a customer might, for instance, be able to order her phone to alert her to sudden movements in stocks. Stephanie Strom

title: Coal Mine Blast Kills 118 in China
description: SHANGHAI, China -- A gas explosion in a coal mine in southern China killed 118 miners, a mine official said Thursday.

title: Media, New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Say Censoring Films Is Their Job, Not Politicians'
description: Overwhelmed by the competing proposals in a tight presidential race, Michael Horst grabbed a sheet of paper during the evening news the other night and drew a line down the middle. He wrote ''Gore'' on the left, ''Bush'' on the right, and then rated the candidates' positions, drawing a plus sign in the Bush column next to capital punishment and a minus sign next to the Texas governor's education record.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL GAINS. Heating oil rose after a report showed that refiners were making little headway in storing the fuel for the winter. In New York, heating oil for October delivery rose 1.81 cents, or 2 percent, to 94.8 cents a gallon.

title: Honor and Beautify
description: To the Editor:

title: Making It in This New Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For Ewing, A Last Shot At Changing
description: AND so, as the late autumn, if not the hoary winter, of his career is upon him, Patrick Ewing, at age 38, with his 7-foot body battered but still willing after 15 bruising seasons with the Knicks, looked back on his professional basketball life. ''Athletically,'' he said, ''I'm not where I was back in my prime, but mentally I'm much better. When I think about what I knew back then and what I know now, I realize how great I could have been.''

title: Hollywood Executives Go to Washington
description: With eight Hollywood executives appearing as witnesses before a Senate committee, politicians from both parties today stepped up their criticism of the way violent movies are marketed to children.

title: U.S. Adjusts Inflation Rate Upward for A Small Error
description: The government said yesterday that inflation rose a bit faster in the first eight months of this year than it had previously reported, a mistake whose correction means slightly higher payments for recipients of Social Security and other federal benefits.

title: A Parting Gift From the Boss Who Cared
description: Much has been made of the fringe benefits of working for a dot-com company -- the free cappuccino, the concierge services and the lucrative stock options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, ROBERT (TAB), 83
description: FINE-Robert (Tab), 83. Of Brooklyn and Boca Raton, FL. passed away September 23, 2000. Beloved husband of 60 years to Mildred (Rosenblatt). Devoted father to Arline Kirschner and Steven. Father-in-law to Larry and Arlene. Loving grandfather of five. Greatgrandfather of four. He shall be remembered forever by those who loved him.

title: MGM MIRAGE WILL SELL ASSETS TO REDUCE ITS DEBT
description: MGM Mirage Inc., the casino operator controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, said yesterday that it would use $66 million from the sale of assets that include land, a golf course and artwork to reduce debt. MGM Mirage agreed to sell about 5.5 acres of undeveloped land along the Boardwalk in Atlantic City, and the Cascata Golf Course in Boulder City, Nev., to the Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the company said. Both companies are based in Las Vegas. MGM Mirage said it would sell four paintings, one by Renoir, one by Morissot and two by Modigliani. They will be auctioned Nov. 9 by Sotheby's Holdings Inc. in New York.

title: Shifting Gears: 4 Cubans Battle to Finals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  Things did not start out well for the celebrated Cuban boxing team tonight when their light flyweight Maikro Romero lost a controversial decision to Brahim Asloum of France. It was the fifth consecutive defeat for a Cuban boxer in the Olympic tournament going back to Wednesday night.

title: DOCOMO-AOL PARTNERSHIP
description: Japan's leading cellular phone company, NTT DoCoMo, and America Online announced a widely expected strategic partnership yesterday that they said would propel the two companies into the forefront of global wireless Internet services. DoCoMo will take a 42.3 percent stake in AOL Japan and will feature AOL mail and Instant Messenger on DoCoMo's i-mode service, the largest wireless Internet service in the world, with more than 12 million subscribers. The partnership will catapult AOL Japan, a laggard among Japanese fixed-line Internet access providers, into a leading position in the Japanese market and give AOL's content to wireless users with a DoCoMo phone. Kiyoyuki Tsujimura, managing director of global business development at DoCoMo, said the partners would collaborate on new ways to integrate wireless and fixed-line Internet services, so that, for example, a bidder in an online auction could participate via mobile phone. Miki Tanikawa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITZLING, MORTON
description: WITZLING-Morton. The partners and staff of Milton N. Hoffman Co. are deeply saddened by the passing of a wonderful, kind and caring friend, Morton Witzling. His counsel and wisdom will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife and family.

title: Effect of Prison Building on Crime Is Weighed
description: The first studies to look at the link between the enormous growth of incarceration and the significant drop in crime in the 1990's show that the nation's prison-building boom has accounted for 5 percent to 25 percent of the eight-year decline. In light of those findings, some of the researchers questioned whether the benefits from the growth of incarceration were worth the cost to taxpayers.

title: At 99, Man of Fashion Finds Life a Good Fit
description: CLOTHES make the man, goes the old saw. You would not get an argument from Abe Schrader.

title: Lampooning Confidence, in 12 Tones
description: The composer Ernst Krenek wrote his one-act chamber opera ''What Price Confidence?'' in 1945 for four singers from the Metropolitan Opera who wanted an adventurous work that could be performed with piano in concert settings. At the time Krenek, who was born in Vienna in 1900 and fled Nazi Germany for the United States in 1938, was still the famous composer of the 1927 opera ''Jonny Spielt Auf.'' With its jazz-influenced score and daring plot about a black musician and his white girlfriend, that genre-blurring work had been acclaimed, debated and denounced in productions around the world. So there should have been considerable interest in ''What Price Confidence?''

title: WEAK RESULTS AT BANK OF SCOTLAND
description: Restructuring costs and provisions for bad debt contributed to weaker-than-expected first-half earnings at the Bank of Scotland, which recently lost to the Royal Bank of Scotland in a bidding war for National Westminster Bank. Bank of Scotland shares fell 4.9 percent yesterday, to 580 pence, or about $8.12, after the bank said it had earned $:469 million, or about $657 million, in the first half of the year, compared with $:471 million a year earlier. The bank is facing pressure on its profit margins as competition grows, and it has been the rumored target in takeover speculation recently. Suzanne Kapner

title: Accounts
description: * Environmental Protection Agency to the Danvers, Mass., office of Bozell Kamstra, part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, to handle its national Energy Star account along with the Cadmus Group, Waltham, Mass., an energy and environmental consulting company. Spending for Energy Star, which encourages consumers to buy energy-efficient appliances, was estimated at $35 million for a five-year contract. The previous agency was the Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Oppenheimer Takes Stake in Folio Fund
description: The Oppenheimer Funds has made a small investment in a new company that is creating an alternative to mutual funds.

title: A Summer to Remember Becomes More Memorable
description: The way Venus Williams dominated Elena Dementieva with her sling-blade strokes was expected, as was her customary parade queen's wave to the crowd upon match point, as was her giddy acceptance of the gold medal.

title: New Jersey Man, 82, Is First Known West Nile Fatality in U.S. This Year
description: New Jersey officials announced yesterday that an 82-year-old Passaic County man died of the West Nile virus two weeks ago, the first person known to die of the disease in the United States this year.

title: A Large Government Surplus Offers More to Fight Over
description: President Clinton bragged today that the government had a bigger budget surplus than ever before and then accused Congressional Republicans of trying to devote much of the money to special interests.

title: A Pen That Could Let You Scribble Your Way Across the Internet
description: ONLY a few years ago, if you wanted to send e-mail across the Internet, you needed a computer and a modem. In the relentless move to simplify technology and make it more accessible, a waveof more familiar Internet devices followed, startingwith WebTV, which turned your television into a PCscreen, and including cellular phones and dedicated e-mail stations that you plug into a phone line.

title: A Showcase for a Busy Young Baritone
description: Brian Leerhuber, a gifted 27-year-old baritone, inaugurated this season's On Wings of Song voice recital series at the Kosciuszko Foundation on Sunday afternoon, accompanied by the pianist Michael Baitzer, a member of the vocal arts faculty at the Juilliard School. These noteworthy events are sponsored by the Marilyn Horne Foundation, whose mission is to present young singers in recitals across the United States.

title: National News Briefs
description: Once Spared by Bush, Texas Inmate Is Executed

title: Illegal Operations And Computer Ports
description: Q. What is an A.G.P. port, and what are P.C.I. slots used for in a computer?

title: A Report Harshly Criticizes The Federal Policy on AIDS
description: Saying that more effective AIDS prevention could avert thousands of new infections each year in this country, the nation's leading science organization sharply criticized the Clinton administration today for what it said was a failure to develop a comprehensive and effective plan to combat the disease.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the first all-news Spanish-language radio station in the New York region misstated the transmitter power of the station, WNNY-AM (1380), and others in the region. WNNY has a signal of 5,000 watts, not megawatts. The much larger WCBS-AM (880), WINS (1010), and WADO-AM (1280) have signals of 50,000 watts, not megawatts.

title: A Night of Competing Aspirations
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Some Olympic days are more defining than others. Yesterday was one of those days  and one of those nights  of clarity that brings fleeting insight into the essence of the Olympic spirit.

title: Making It in This New Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Study of the Wired World Finds Dropouts and No-Shows
description: If the Internet is the information superhighway, a substantial number of American adults are avoiding the on-ramp, according to a recent survey sponsored by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MORTON
description: GOLDSTEIN - Morton. Renais sance man available to all. We will sorely miss his wisdom, warmth, wit, humanity & humor. Survived by his wife of 53 years, Sonia, five children, five siblings, 5 wonderful grandchildren and two computers. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue, Thursday, September 28 at 3:00 PM.

title: At Shea, October Still Holds Promise
description: The Mets are not the best team now, but they remember when they were. Their commemorative caps are not as brash, but they were still soaked in Champagne. The Mets missed their first goal, the National League East championship, but will be in the playoffs.

title: Rooting for WordPerfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Perfectionism
description: Far from an absence of detail, minimalism seems to hinge on an excess of it. How else to explain John Pawson's determination to bore a hole into the bedrock under his London town house, left, to produce geo-thermal heat? ''John Pawson: Works'' (Phaidon, $59.95) is not your ordinary monograph, thanks to lively prose by Deyan Sudjik, the editor of Domus, the Italian design magazine. Chapters on the Calvin Klein showroom and Martha Stewart's stalled makeover of the Bunshaft house in East Hampton, N.Y., frankly reveal an architect striving to cope with perfectionists even more insistent than he. One quibble: arty gray type on white pages shows a lack of respect for the all-too-cruel realities of human sight. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: SYDNEY 2000: CYCLING; Armstrong's Plan Is Good, But Ullrich's Is Even Better
description: Everything went according to plan for Lance Armstrong and his United States teammates in the Olympic cycling road race today. The problem was that things went even better for the Germans.

title: Article 2000092892789851570 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: UTILITY SAYS PROFITS WILL BEAT ESTIMATES IN 3RD QUARTER
description: Reliant Energy Inc., owner of the second-largest utility in Texas, said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter profit to exceed analysts' estimates, led by wholesale power sales in the California region and its utility in Houston. Profit in the third quarter will be 25 percent to 30 percent higher than the $1.07 a share average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, Reliant said. The company also benefited from its trading and marketing business and from growth in the number of customers at Reliant Energy HL&P, which has 1.7 million customers in the Houston area, which had record heat this month. Reliant's shares rose $2.96, to $44.33.

title: Rooting for WordPerfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the last two words of a film review yesterday about Anna Deavere Smith's ''Twilight: Los Angeles'' were omitted. The concluding paragraph should have read: ''The resulting compromise does not produce a perfect film, but it is a fine record of a classic production and an important reminder of an event that has not stopped echoing in American culture.''

title: Making It in This New Economy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBIERI, JOSEPH J.

Retired 1981 after a 35-year career as Treasurer with the Mamaroneck Board of Education. Graduate Fordham College School of Business 1941. Member of American Legion and Mamaroneck Old Timers Club. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY, Friday, 2-4 PM, 79 PM. Mass St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, New York, Saturday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Rosary Hill, Hawthorne, New York, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, or the charity of your choice.

title: U.S. Mens Soccer Team Wins Respect
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28  Even if the United States men's soccer team returns home without a bronze medal, their head coach says they have already earned something sought after even longer  the respect of the world's soccer powers.

title: Texan Beats Korean in Taekwondo With a Counter-Kick Worth Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28 -- Patience and a penalty point helped propel Steven Lopez of Sugar Land, Tex., to a gold medal tonight in the Korean martial art of taekwondo, 1-0.

title: Police Search the Cash Boxes of Belmont Betting Clerks for Evidence of Money Laundering
description: The State Police were going through the cash boxes of scores of betting clerks at Belmont Park racecourse yesterday as part of an investigation into allegations that clerks at New York tracks laundered money for a criminal organization, law enforcement and racing officials said.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: A Time for Loincloths, Long Locks And Lust
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 1998 production of Saint-Saens's ''Samson et Dalila'' returned to the house on Tuesday night, having already acquired the feel of a dusty and familiar old show.

title: Protests Diminish at Conference in Prague on Worldwide Aid
description: Protests diminished sharply today as financial officials and many demonstrators condemned an outbreak of violence and vandalism on Tuesday that turned a conference on aid into a street battle.

title: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE WARNING
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, a speech-recognition software maker, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings and revenue would fall short of analysts' expectations, citing ''distractions,'' management changes and other factors. The Securities and Exchange Commission opened an investigation last week into the Belgian company's financial statements. The company also commissioned an independent audit of its sales information in August. Shortly after the audit was announced, its chief executive, Gaston Bastiaens, was replaced by John Duerden, above.

title: Neighbors Stunned by the Murder-Suicide of a Devoted Couple
description: After more than 30 years of marriage, Harriet Racenstein would still run to the phone when her husband, Martin, called to find out about her day as a high school guidance counselor. He would pin up photos of his wife at the office, and spoke often of her to his employees at a Manhattan window-cleaning supply company.

title: An Unjust Sacrifice
description: An appeals court in London has made a Solomonic ruling, deciding that 8-week-old twins joined at the pelvis must be separated. In effect, one twin, known as Mary, is to be sacrificed to save the other, known as Jodie, in an operation the babies' parents oppose.

title: Courage on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Court Says Suharto Too Ill to Face Corruption Trial
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 28  An Indonesian court dismissed the Government's landmark corruption case against former President Suharto today, after an independent team of doctors declared him medically unfit to stand trial.

description: GOING-Mary Ann. Beloved sister of the late Patricia Going Plante, James, Robert and Eileen Going Foy. Also survived by 13 nephews and nieces. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, NYC. He will be missed and remembered by all.

title: Arrest at Shea May Put Killer of Infant Son Back in Jail
description: WYCKOFF, N.J., Sept. 27  Since returning here in January after a prison term for discarding the body of his newborn son in a motel trash bin, Brian C. Peterson had compiled a spotless probation record. But on Tuesday night, he and a friend from high school went to Shea Stadium for a Mets game. Mr. Peterson left in handcuffs, his eight months of good behavior tarnished and his future at risk.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: EVERAD, New York, named Angela Pumo chief executive. She was most recently executive vice president at CNX Media Networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONHARDT, WILLIAM STROUP
description: LEONHARDT-William Stroup. On September 26, 2000 of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Cranford and Westfield, NJ. Husband of the late Evelyn F. Leonhardt (1993), and father of the late William S. Leonhardt Jr. (1993). Cherished father of Lynne Toth, Geraldine Leonhardt, and Janet L. Small. Brother of Mary Moore, and Elizabeth Hutchinson. Grandfather of six and great-grandfather of two. Uncle of several nieces and nephews. Visitation Thursday from 24, 7-9 PM at The Gray Funeral Home, 318 East Broad Street, Westfield, NJ. Funeral Friday 11 AM at the funeral home with burial at Fairview Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations woulld be appreciated to any local hospice program.

title: From Brooklyn To Manhattan, a Look At the 21st Century
description: Suffering from midcentury-modern fatigue? Nightmares of being chased through the Seagram Building by a giant Egg chair? Go to Brooklyn, or rather, Breukelen. After four years of selling cutting-edge contemporary home furnishings on Atlantic Avenue, John Erik and his partner, Thomas Gibson, opened a second Breukelen, at 68 Gansevoort Street in Manhattan. Same stuff, but closer to customers who covet names like Bodo Sperlein and Burning Relic as if they were Eames and Nelson. ''To me it seemed more of a challenge to go out and chose from all-current product and pick out things that don't have a pedigree,'' said Mr. Erik, above, in front of a panel of flannel from the 40's. He is too diplomatic to suggest that purveyors of old-modern -- as opposed to modern-modern -- are passe. After all, they're his friends, and he digs Verner Panton as much as the next Parsons industrial-design grad. But he'd rather seek out New Zealand shag rugs that look like sea anemones (bottom far right, $55 a square foot), a floor lamp made from globes of Venini glass (below center, $2,200) or sconces from the German-born, London-based Mr. Sperlein (right, $950 each) fabricated from a porcelain used in the medical industry. ''We're crazy about porcelain,'' Mr. Erik said.

title: Scout Councils Urged to Defy Policy on Gays
description: A day after a Manhattan school district withdrew its support for the Boy Scouts of America over its exclusion of gays, officials in New York City and at a major charity in Westchester and Putnam Counties intensified the pressure on scout officials to defy the parent organization.

title: From Europe, Creative Taxation; Hungry for Revenue and Seeing Web Sales as a Banquet
description: Europe is rushing to tear down borders, but the Internet is toppling some of them even faster, making life distinctly uncomfortable for European policy makers.

title: Judge Narrows Governments Case Against Tobacco Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A federal judge threw out part of the government's suit against the tobacco industry today, narrowing the avenues by which the Justice Department can seek billions of dollars in damages.

title: O Profligate Youth of Rome, Ye #*!, Ye @#! (See Footnote)
description: The publisher of the Loeb Classical Library, the very proper series of Greek and Roman literature for English-speaking readers, has been gradually putting back the naughty bits it had been editing out of the books.

title: Making It in This New Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Reimagining A Design Museum
description: AS an Englishman about to move to New York, Paul W. Thompson has a lot to think about. Where should he and his family live? Is it too late for his daughters to get into Spence? Oh, and what's to be done about reinventing the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum?

title: Nashville's Country Music (Old, European Country)
description: As pre-eminent as it is in the world of country music, Nashville has barely registered on the radar of classical music listeners. But since 1983 Kenneth Schermerhorn has been building the Nashville Symphony into a solid, disciplined ensemble, and when the orchestra made its Carnegie Hall debut on Monday evening it gave a performance that was mostly a knockout. And now that it has undertaken an ambitious American music series for Naxos, it is likely to have a higher profile.

title: Jets Talk Out a Problem, and Say It Wasn't One
description: Vinny Testaverde said he was misunderstood, though he did not regret what he said on Monday. Al Groh blamed the news media. The spin controlling was at full whirl today as Testaverde, the Jets' quarterback, and Groh, the head coach, hurried to quell speculation that their relationship was anything but splendid.

title: Making Sense of Censorship
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Firestone Uneasy Over Threatened Changes
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., which is struggling to cope with the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires, can chalk up one more problem: growing uncertainty about who will be running the company in the days ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELLER, ROBERT G.
description: SHELLER-Robert G., Esq. Died peacefully on September 26, 2000 at the age of 93. Husband of the late Helen Reiser Sheller. Father of Elly Sheller Rufer and the late Ed Sheller. Grandfather of Alexandra and Christopher Sheller, Daniel and Kate Rufer. Brother of the late Frances Snyder and uncle of Joan Steiner and Martin Snyder. Father-in-law to John Rufer. Brother-in-law to the late Florence Reiser Shultz. Litigator extraordinaire! He was a force in the courtroom for over 60 years. Avid card player: from casino with his grandchildren, to weekly bridge games with the ladies. We will always miss his amazing intellect, his incredible wit and his pragmatic approach to life. As requested, no services will be held. Donations may be made in his memory to the Summit School, 187-30 Grand Central Parkway, Jamaica Estates, New York 11432.

title: Two Sides in Race Are Seeking an Edge in a State Mirroring the U.S.
description: Last Feb. 22, Gov. George W. Bush lost the Michigan Republican primary to Senator John McCain of Arizona, thanks to a notably poor showing among independents, moderates and women.

title: Danish Voters Say No to Euro; A Blow to Unity
description: Denmark voted today not to join Europe's common currency, the euro, undermining an already fragile monetary experiment, and turning its back on the rapid European political integration championed by France and Germany.

title: German Upper House Finishes Move to Berlin
description: BERLIN, Sept. 28  Just in time for the 10th anniversary of German reunification, the upper house of Parliament reopened today in a renovated Baroque palace to complete the government's return to the prewar capital.

title: VERMONT TEDDY BEAR PLANS TO INCREASE PRODUCTION
description: The Vermont Teddy Bear Company said yesterday that it planned to increase production at a Newport, Vt., plant by 50 percent to meet growing demand. The company's Newport unit, which opened last November, employs 74 workers and produces about 20,000 bears a month. Production will increase to at least 30,000 bears a month by June 2001, the company said. Vermont Teddy Bear, based in Shelburne, Vt., makes more than 425,000 bears a year. The company had sales of $33.3 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: Use of Mifepristone in Abortion Is a 3-Step Procedure
description: An abortion using mifepristone, or RU-486, takes place in three steps.

title: EXODUS TO BUY GLOBAL CROSSING UNIT
description: Exodus Communications confirmed yesterday that it would buy Global Crossing's Web-operating unit for about $6.53 billion in stock. The deal shows the increased emphasis in the telecommunications industry on running Web sites, a business that is growing faster than traditional telecommunications services. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Ammann Will Start in Goal for MetroStars
description: Three broken ribs and a punctured lung sustained 42 days ago were supposed to end Mike Ammann's season. But he has recovered so well in such a short time that he will be the starting goalkeeper when the MetroStars play the Chicago Fire on Saturday night at Giants Stadium in Game 2 of the Major League Soccer semifinals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, SYLVIA ADLER
description: RODGERS-Sylvia Adler. Devoted mother to Marc, Kenneth and Rand. Adored grandniece to Minnie Cohan. Loving sister to Abner and Howard. Childhood and lifelong friend to Margery Aronstein.

title: Fiberglass Herd Is Sent to Market
description: They were rustled in the dead of night and sprayed with graffiti, saddled by children and derided by critics. And last night the cows of the city's CowParade New York 2000 did yeoman's service one more time, raising $1.35 million for charity.

title: Can a Driven Baton Twirler Become Miss Congeniality?
description: ''Beauty may be only skin deep, but ugly is to the bone,'' the queen of the thunderously intoned wisecrack, Tallulah Bankhead, is reputed to have said on the subject of appearances. But if we are to believe ''Beautiful,'' a clumsy satire of the world of beauty pageants, most of those involved in that world are spiritually ugly to the bone.

title: Needing Momentum, the Yanks Don't Come Close
description: If anyone bothered to turn on one of the four television sets hanging from the ceiling in the visitors' clubhouse here tonight, the Yankees would have known whether they were about to clinch the American League East. They would have known whether Chicago eliminated Boston, once and for all.

title: Richard Mulligan, 67, Actor On 'Soap' and 'Empty Nest'
description: Richard Mulligan, who won Emmy Awards for his portrayal of fathers on the situation comedies ''Soap'' and ''Empty Nest,'' died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 67.

title: Blacking Out The Body Parts
description: It may not be down in writing but censorious fig leaves placed over genitals probably weren't what the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier had in mind five years ago when he formulated his so-called Vow of Chastity, the set of stringent movie-making rules known as Dogma 95.

Great-grandfather of Erica and Allison. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Friday, at 10:30 A.M., at Goldsteins Rosenbergs Raphael-Sacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, Penn. Interment Montefiore Cemetery, Fox Chase, Penn.

title: SOUTH KOREAN INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION
description: South Korea's factories increased output in August as they produced more memory chips, computers and mobile phones for overseas customers. Factory output rose 3.3 percent from a month earlier, seasonally adjusted, compared with July's 3.5 percent gain, the National Statistical Office said. From a year earlier, output rose 24.1 percent, the biggest jump since February. Factories used 82.1 percent of their capacity, the highest rate since May 1996.

title: NEW WRINKLES IN CHINA-W.T.O. APPLICATION
description: China's effort to gain admission to the World Trade Organization has encountered new problems, undercutting the chances that the country can join by the end of the year. China's top negotiator, Long Yongtu, denied speculation of a deadlock, but the W.T.O. negotiating group chairman issued a statement calling for a ''fundamental re-examination of negotiating positions in capitals'' before any new session takes place. Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, has asked for a meeting with China's premier, Zhu Rongji, but no date has been set, Mr. Long said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Conjuring a Genre From Light and Air
description: There are a few big-name artists in the Gere collection of landscape oil sketches -- Bocklin, Boldini, Corot, Degas, Leighton and Salvator Rosa -- but they are not the rule. Most of these small landscapes, notable for their freshness and immediacy, were done in Italy by all but unknown 17th, 18th and 19th-century talents: Edouard Bertin, Jean-Joseph-Xavier Bildaud, Heinrich Burkel, Giovanni Costa, Louis Gauffier, Josephus Augustus Knip, George Heming Mason, Achille-Etna Michallon and Goffredo Wals, to name a few.

title: 'The Great Dance'
description: 'A Hunter's Story'

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: In an Old Man's Reveries, The Past Lives On as Pain
description: Here's an unsettling thought: The hardest lessons we learn in life (and maybe the only lessons we truly absorb) are those learned too late. It is precisely this sense of nagging regret and the compulsion to comb obsessively through decisions that can't be undone that haunts the characters in Liv Ullmann's morose and profound film, ''Faithless.'' For in looking back, there is usually a point at which past events lose their fluidity. That lingering question of what-if? evaporates, and the past becomes frozen, at once accessible and out of reach.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about American philanthropists' donations to British art institutions misstated the surname of the director of the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London. He is Desmond Shawe-Taylor, not Shore-Taylor.

title: For Some, the Boys of Summer Never Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Floating Like a Butterfly, Stinging Like a Bee
description: We first see Diana Guzman, the heroine of ''Girlfight,'' Karyn Kusama's sweet and fierce directorial debut, through a crowd of teenagers stampeding through the halls of a Brooklyn high school. She's leaning against a locker, head down, her black hair in cornrows along her scalp. Then she slowly raises her eyes, throwing out a glower as fearsome as Robert De Niro's in ''Raging Bull.'' It's a riveting, iconic moment, a glimpse into the soul of an angry, proud young woman. The shot also introduces a powerful, extraordinarily gifted young actress: Michelle Rodriguez. Remember the name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, ARTHUR J.
description: FLYNN-Arthur J. Sr. Died peacefully in his sleep on September 24, 2000. Loving husband of the late Helen. Cherished father of Thomas and wife Liz, Billy and wife Rosann, Rosemarie, Michael, Ricia and husband Gary, Arthur Jr. and wife Karen, James and wife Darlene, Fran and husband James, and Helen. Adored grandfather of Colleen, Kerry, Thomas, Christopher, Sara, Kelly, Timothy, Sean, Owen, Kyle, Keira, Mathew, Marc, Megan, and Liam. Devoted great-grandfather of Nicholas and Emily. Daddy, may your memory be honored as you rest in peace.

Greene, the federal prosecutor who is leading a separate criminal antitrust investigation in New York. He is not the head of the Justice Department's New York antitrust office; the head is Ralph T. Giordano.

description: SACHS-Belle (Billie). Of Aventura, FL., on Monday, September 25, 2000. Widow of Aaron Sachs, devoted mother of Merrily and Frank Lewis, Sue and Larry Cholden, cherished sister of Tiny Gingold, and adoring grandmother of four. Interment services were held in Miami, FL.

title: Abortion Changes, But How Much?
description: The RU-486 announcement yesterday arrived with a lot of emphatic declarations attached: ''historic moment,'' ''milestone,'' ''most significant technological advance in women's reproductive health care since the birth control pill.'' That last characterization was from Gloria Feldt, president of Planned Parenthood, responding to the news that the Food and Drug Administration had finally approved the marketing of what's come to be known as the abortion pill.

title: The Big City; A Conqueror In and Out Of the Ring
description: THE Olympic television ratings may be low, but there was clear evidence yesterday that Americans still appreciate the glories of classic athletic competition. They stood in line for six hours in Times Square just to get Chyna's autograph.

title: EXCUTIVE CHANGES
description: ABN AMRO INC., -- Chicago, has named John K. Martin Jr., vice president of investor relations for Time Warner, as director of ABN AMRO's equity research team in New York.

title: Try Hard Not to Remember The Lowlights of September
description: The custodian started cleaning and replacing the Champagne-soaked ceiling boards in the Mets' clubhouse before the last player had finished showering on Wednesday night. The giddy and relieved Mets had treated the clubhouse like a frat house after clinching a wild-card playoff berth, so the tidying was necessary.

title: E.P.A. Says Lead-Paint Law May Increase Risks to Children
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has notified New York City officials that it believes changes made in the city's lead-paint law last year are critically flawed. It said the law is now likely to result in more lead poisoning of children and called on the city to close the loopholes.

title: Pollution Standards Tightened for Dumping Off Shore
description: Federal regulators announced yesterday that they had tightened pollution standards for some dredge materials to be dumped off the New Jersey shore.

title: Senators Doubt Progress on Global Warming Plan
description: Several Republican senators today expressed strong concerns that talks to flesh out details of a global-warming treaty signed by the administration in 1998 would never produce a document that the Senate would approve.

title: After Five Sets, the Russians End the Upstart Americans' Run
description: A United States women's volleyball team that arrived here little known and lowly rated took Russia to a fifth game tonight for the right to play for the Olympic gold medal.
