But the American squad, seeded 10th in a 12-nation field, finally lost to the second-seeded Russians in a tough 90-minute semifinal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELOWITZ, BEATRICE
description: MENDELOWITZ - Beatrice. On September 28, 2000, of Jackson Heights, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted mother of Paul C., M.D., and Lisa. Dear sister of Anne Gilbert. Cherished grandmother of Lee and Neil. Services Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''Gutterman's'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., Rego Park, NY.

title: Union Balks at Possibility Of Makeup Game for Yanks
description: The Yankees will play the Florida Marlins at Yankee Stadium on Monday to make up the game that was rained out July 15. Or will they?

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: East-West

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, FRANCES L.
description: MILLER-Frances L. On September 27, 2000. Loving mother of Susan Barocas and her husband Michael. Cherished grandmother of Alex and Evan. Dear sister of Stanley Linder and his partner Ray Baker. Contributions in her name to Cabrini Hospice.

title: Anticipated Resignation Occurs at 3Com
description: The 3Com Corporation said today that Eric Benhamou had resigned as chief executive, but would remain chairman.

title: Your Story, Transformed On the Spot Into Theater
description: The odds are you have never heard of the star of ''Lifegame,'' the piquant, oddly touching new offering from the ever-resourceful Improbable Theater. Certainly, I had never heard of one Nancy Rosenthal, who on the night I caught the show held the stage of the Jane Street Theater with a commanding, radiant centeredness. I would recommend that you go see the charismatic Ms. Rosenthal, a self-described ''stay-at-home Mom'' of 45, except that her run ended the night it began. The stars of ''Lifegame'' are stars for only two hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, HELEN J.
description: BENNETT-Helen J., 63 years, Sante Fe, New Mexico. Died September 25. She had formerly resided in New York City, Crystal Lake, PA., and Scranton, PA. Beloved mother of Gerald Bennett, Edgartown, MA. Sister of Barbara J. Munley, Rio Rancho, NM; Cynthia Wetherill, Scranton, PA and Laurence C. Tillman, Narragansett, RI. One grandaughter, one grandson, nieces, nephews and cousins also survive. Memorial services will be conducted Tuesday, October 3 at 4:00 PM in the Snowdon Funeral Home, 1810 Sanderson Avenue, Scranton, PA. Friends will be received from 3:00 PM to service time. Preferred memorials to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Day Later, a Close Bunch Shares the Pain
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Nobody on the Dream Team ever wailed, "Oh, God, stop this," the way Mia Hamm did to inject a note of levity during her team's cry-a-thon yesterday.

title: PILGRIM'S PRIDE IN $240 MILLION DEAL FOR WLR FOODS
description: The Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, a leading chicken producer, has agreed to acquire WLR Foods Inc. for $240 million. In a statement released late Wednesday, Pilgrim's Pride said it would also assume $60 million in debt in the deal. The company agreed to pay $14.25 for each outstanding WLR share, more than double WLR's closing price of $6.88 on Wednesday. Pilgrim's Pride, based in Pittsburg, Tex., said the acquisition would help it expand into the mid-Atlantic region. WLR Foods, based in Broadway, Va., has about 7,000 employees in Virginia, North Carolina, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. (Bloomberg News)

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: A New Home For Old Masters
description: A major gift has transformed the University of Oklahoma into a repository of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Clash Over Religion and Rules Sidelines Soccer Players, but Keeps the Lawyers Busy
description: The 10-year-old boys of the Avon Soccer Club will not be playing the lads of Fairfield United in the Connecticut state soccer tournament this Saturday. Whether this is due to religious intolerance, as Avon's coach believes, or the inability of some suburban parents to follow the rules, as the Fairfield coach thinks, is for the lawyers to decide.

title: National News Briefs
description: California Regulators Mandate Diesel Filters

title: Building a Theatrical Season, Month by Month
description: IT is late morning on a muggy day in August. Most of New York City seems to be rushing to appointments or toiling in air-conditioned offices. But in a cramped, dusty East Village space on 13th Street, four people who make their lives working in the theater are talking about a hat.

title: Italians, Once Again, Miss Volleyball Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 -- As Vladimir Grbic drove the final spike into their Olympic obsession tonight, the Italians did not even wait for the ball to hit the floor before turning to trudge to the net for the ritual handshakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, CHRISTOPHER
description: BLAKE-Christopher. Painter and sculptor passed away in the darkened hours of September 27 at the age of 51. The art-world has lost a sensitive and creative talent. His original and provocative work took on a whimsical surreal magic that reflected his entire life. Chris graduated from Cooper Union Art School, NY in 1971. He is survived by his mother Grace, and two brothers, Charles and Robert. He lived his life his way. We will miss him dearly. Services today at Bartholomew Funeral Home, 2:005:00, 7:00-9:30 PM, Bellmore, LI.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: FREESERVE POSTS LOSS
description: Shares of Freeserve, the leading provider of Internet access in Britain, fell 3 percent to 235 pence, or about $3.31, after it said first-quarter losses had nearly doubled to $:15.5 million, or about $19 million, as spending on advertising and new services increased. Revenue grew more than threefold to $:14.6 million, and the number of registered users grew to 2 million, compared with 1.4 million a year ago. Freeserve, which is 80 percent owned by Dixons, the British consumer electronics retailer, has been unsuccessful in efforts to find a buyer even as other Internet service providers have rushed to consolidate. Tiscali of Italy and T-Online International of Germany, which have made acquisitions to expand and cut costs, now have more than six million users each. Freeserve also is facing stiff competition from the American Internet companies Yahoo and America Online.

title: Sports of The Times; Mad Dog Is Still Top Dog
description: HE is called Mad Dog the way bald guys are called Curly, or penny-pinchers are called Big Spenders. It is the flip side of what is. If he were, in fact, a canine, he might be the ultimate thinking man's pooch, a bloodhound, say, or one of those Labrador retrievers who remarkably leads the cops to the packet where the coke is stashed.

title: NORTEL WINS CHINA AND TAIWAN DEALS
description: Nortel Networks of Canada has won two contracts worth $525 million to build wireless telephone systems in China and Taiwan. One contract, worth $250 million, is for 1,900 new base stations for cellular phone and Internet transmission for Chunghwa Telecom in Taiwan. Chunghwa has given Nortel, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, $900 million worth of orders since 1994. The second, $275 million, contract is with Zhejiang Unicom in China to install infrastructure and software for wireless Internet services.

title: Stopgap Budget Measure Approved by Senate
description: The Senate today passed a stopgap spending measure that will allow the federal government to function through Oct. 6, seven days after the end of its fiscal year.

title: DRUG OFFERS MORE PRIVACY, AND COULD RESHAPE DEBATE
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it had approved the marketing of an abortion-inducing pill, the first alternative to surgical abortion approved in the United States.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: What Rhymes With Tweak?
description: Confirming rumors that first emerged online, the producers of ''Seussical'' said yesterday that the director and choreographer Rob Marshall will be brought in to help doctor the highly anticipated musical.

title: Home Video: Blacking Out the Body Parts
description: It may not be down in writing but censorious fig leaves placed over genitals probably weren't what the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier had in mind five years ago when he formulated his so-called Vow of Chastity, the set of stringent movie- making rules known as Dogma 95.

title: A Devotion To Japanese Art Is Requited
description: Rene Scholten came to love Japanese art through a circuitous route. On a trip to Japan while working as a software consultant, Mr. Scholten, who is Dutch, purchased an inexpensive woodblock print. Then he saw a fine 1929 print by Torii Kotondo of a beautiful woman applying powder. Completely seduced, he bought it.

title: Fairy Tales Can Come True if You're a Star
description: Leave it to Barbra Streisand to turn her own life into a musical fairy tale, one with a resoundingly happy ending. That is the essence of the farewell show Ms. Streisand brought to Madison Square Garden for two sold-out performances on Wednesday evening and last night.

title: Some Say State Takeover May Be Just What Nassau Needs
description: In a county with more than its share of fiscal nightmares, it is what politicians in both parties fear the most. Yet others say it is exactly what Nassau County needs: a state takeover of the county's finances.

title: Migrant Worker Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton's Surprise: She Supports Some Tax Cuts
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement in downstate New York yesterday. A similar ad, the campaign said, will be shown upstate.

title: Judge Dismisses Part of U.S. Tobacco Suit
description: A federal judge threw out part of the government's suit against the tobacco industry today, narrowing the avenues by which the Justice Department can seek billions of dollars in damages.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 5
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULDER, MARGARET M.
description: SCHULDER-Margaret M. Age 97, on Sept. 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Jack Schulder; mother of Peggy S. Blitz and Daniel Schulder; grandmother of Joseph, Rachel, David, Zoe and Malcolm Schulder, and great-grandmother of Julian and Katherine. Her family and friends mourn the passing of this strong and cheerful member of the Sunnyside community. Viewing 2 to 5 PM and 7 to 9:30 PM, September 29. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside. Funeral Mass, September 30, 9:45AM, Queen of Angels Church, Skillman Avenue and 44th Street, Sunnyside.

title: Saul Fletcher
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, CHARLES S.
description: McVEIGH-Charles S., Jr. Charles S. McVeigh, Jr. died suddenly at his home in Syosset on September 27. He is survived by a daughter, Lynne McVeigh, two sons, Charles S. McVeigh III and Johnson B. McVeigh, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: Closer, Maybe, but Still Short of a Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 -- Ivan Zamorano, the type of world-class scorer the Americans need to develop if they are ever to threaten soccer's traditional powers, scored both goals in the United States' 2-0 loss to Chile in tonight's bronze medal game. The medal was Chile's first in the Olympics since 1988, and its first ever in Olympic soccer.

title: A Man Gets Mad, and Two Golds May Follow
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29  From his corner ringside perch tonight, the United States boxing coach, Tom Mustin, watched the first round unfold between his fighter, Ricardo Williams Jr., and Cuba's powerful Diogenes Luna and had just one thought: we're in trouble.

title: Claude Wampler
description: 'Painting, the Movie'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 17 about the Oakland Table, a program of intellectual seminars organized by Mayor Jerry Brown of Oakland, Calif., referred imprecisely to some criticisms of the series. The terms "Jerrification" and "pointy-headed table talk"were the article's paraphrase of local critics, not the words of Wilda White, president of the Jack London Neighborhood Association and an Oakland school board member. Ms. White said academic discussions should not take precedence over the city's problems with crime, education and the lack of affordable housing.

title: Three Palestinians Reported Dead in Clash at Jerusalem Shrine
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 -- Complete mayhem erupted in the sacred, contested center of Jerusalem's Old City today as stones and bullets interrupted a day of prayer for Muslims and Jews, turning it bloody.

title: Sampling Life Where Many Want to Live
description: Vancouver, British Columbia, is nearly 3,000 miles northwest of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information, with prices in United States dollars ($1 equals $1.49 Canadian):

title: Article 2000092993839452001 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA WEINER

title: Article 2000092993367717871 -- No Title
description: The College Search Game, Spam Included

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA BANK EXPANDS SOUTH
description: Canada's largest bank, Royal Bank of Canada, has agreed to buy the Dain Rauscher Corporation of Minneapolis, a retail brokerage firm and investment banker, for $1.456 billion. At $95 a share, the offer is 19 percent above Dain Rauscher's trading price Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. The chairman of Royal Bank, John Cleghorn, said the acquisition would provide ''an established U.S. presence and a platform for growth.'' In June, the bank bought the insurance businesses of the Liberty Corporation of Greenville, S.C., and indicated that it wanted to develop cross-marketing of banking, insurance and brokerage services that are not yet permitted in Canada. The latest transaction requires approval from regulatory agencies and shareholders. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Mexico's New Chief Wants the Truth
description: If history is written by the winners, Mexico may be in for a major rewrite.

title: FORD SAYS 78% OF DEALERS ARE BACKING ONLINE VENTURE
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that 78 percent of its eligible member dealers had agreed to participate in FordDirect.com, which will sell cars and trucks on the Internet at the prices dealers pay. The Ford dealers council said 3,194 of the 4,080 eligible dealers in the United States, who account for 90 percent of Ford sales, had committed themselves to participating in FordDirect.com. The first online site is expected to be running in California next month. Automakers are trying to compete with online car-buying Web sites like Autobytel.com, Autoweb.com, CarsDirect.com and Greenlight.com, while trying not to threaten their traditional dealers.

title: Advice From a Prince: Milosevic Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifting Gears: 4 Cubans Battle to Finals
description: Things did not start out well for the celebrated Cuban boxing team tonight when their light flyweight Maikro Romero lost a controversial decision to Brahim Asloum of France. It was the fifth consecutive defeat for a Cuban boxer in the Olympic tournament going back to Wednesday night.

title: Stock of Merged Japanese Bank Is Up on First Trading Day
description: Shares of Mizuho Holdings Inc., the large bank holding company formed from the merger of three Japanese banks -- Fuji Bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan -- rose 6.5 percent today in their first day of trading, despite increasing skepticism about the new institution's prospects.

title: Frank Wills, 52; Watchman Foiled Watergate Break-In
description: Frank Wills, the night watchman who discovered the 1972 Watergate burglary, which ultimately led to President Richard M. Nixon's resignation, died on Wednesday. He was 52 and lived in North Augusta, S.C.

title: I'll Take the Red One: Do Computers Now Sell Like Cars?
description: COMPUTERS have driven this economy to the longest expansion ever. Computer stocks have racked up some of the biggest gains of the bull market.

title: Near Nightmare for Dream Team
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 -- The shot left his hands an instant before the final horn blared, an arching rainbow from 22 feet.

title: Despite Losing Appeal, Romanian Says Her Heart Is at Peace
description: Andreea Raducan still can't believe that her gold medal for winning the gymnastics individual all-around competition was stripped from her for taking a cold medication that contained a substance banned by the International Olympic Committee.

title: McSorley Awaits Judge's Decision
description: Testimony concluded yesterday in Marty McSorley's assault trial in Vancouver, British Columbia, with the player set to learn the judge's verdict next Friday.

title: Everything's New but the Mountains and the Sea
description: Conspire to arrive by ship. Like Naples, like New York and Cape Town, Vancouver looks its best from the water, its shiny glass towers rising like Xanadu against a backdrop of indigo peaks whose foothills dip their toes in the harbor.

title: Singapore Airlines to Choose Between Boeing and Airbus
description: The battle between Boeing and Airbus Industrie for the future of large-scale jetliners could reach a decisive point on Friday when Singapore Airlines, the profitable and prestigious Asian carrier more famous for flight attendants than financial muscle, announces its latest plans to buy new aircraft.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; A Night Of Competing Aspirations
description: SOME Olympic days are more defining than others. Yesterday was one of those days -- and one of those nights -- of clarity that brings fleeting insight into the essence of the Olympic spirit.

title: Northwestern Business Dean Plans to Step Down Next Year
description: Donald P. Jacobs, one of the most influential people in management education, will step down next spring after a quarter-century as the dean of Northwestern University's business school, the university announced yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; In Olympic Doping Sagas, Only Names Change
description: If you had put it to a vote, polled the Olympic community, I suspect it would have been a landslide Slobodan Milosevic couldn't ignore. By the time it was announced today that Andreea Raducan wasn't getting her gold medal back, people just wished the little gymnast could wipe away the tears and go home happily to Romania to claim her $30,000 prize.

title: Giving Praise to Clinton, Bush Says Gore Is Flawed
description: After more than a year of trying to hang President Clinton around Vice President Al Gore's neck, Gov. George W. Bush took the opposite tack today, saying the main problem with Mr. Gore was that he was not enough like his boss.

title: Aussies, Jackson Win Wish: Basketball Final Against USA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 -- The kid from Adelaide finally caved in three weeks ago. Between interview requests, slippage in her game and the mounting expectations of a nation, Lauren Jackson no longer felt like the star of the Australian national team.

title: Hockeyroos Live Up to Reputation
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29  The train that winds into Olympic Park was slowly easing by the hockey stadium earlier this week when a boy sprung from his seat like a trick snake out of a can. Sticking his painted face against the window, he was searching the empty field in the distance.

title: Eating Out
description: Food That Travels Well

title: Gore's Debate 'Advisers' Include Voices From the Campaign Trail
description: When Vice President Al Gore travels to his debate preparation camp in Sarasota, Fla., on Saturday, he will be accompanied by many of the usual campaign suspects: his chairman, his media consultant and his message guru. But he will also bring along some unusual -- and unsuspecting -- advisers he picked up on the campaign trail, like Erin K. Conner, a 14-year-old freshman at Belleville West High School in Belleville, Ill., and Joyce E. Martin, a 76-year-old retiree from Clearwater, Fla.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple Warns on Earnings, And Stock Falls After Hours

title: STRONG RESULTS AT FRENCH CONGLOMERATE
description: The French media company Lagardere, best known for its publishing division and magazines, reported a 36.4 percent increase in first-half operating income, to 263 million euros, or $232 million, as revenue increased to 5.9 billion euros from 5.8 billion a year earlier. Net profit soared almost sixfold, to 788 million euros largely on a one-time exceptional gain of 1.1 billion euros related to the sale this year of an Internet service provider, Club Internet, to Deutsche Telekom, and of the publisher Grolier Inc. to the Scholastic Corporation. To focus on the media, Lagardere this year also entered an alliance with Canal Plus, a European pay-for-view television company.

title: Second Task on Jones's To-Do List Is Surprisingly Easy
description: For nearly every first-time Olympian, even one with lofty goals and an abundance of talent, tonight's achievement would have been more than enough. For Marion Jones, it was merely the end of Phase 2.

title: NETS INVITE 18
description: The Nets announced yesterday that they would take 18 players to preseason training camp next Tuesday.

title: Fujimori in Surprise Visit to Washington
description: As tensions deepen for him at home, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru flew to Washington today to seek support from the United States and inter-American countries and organizations for his plan to transfer power to an elected successor, officials said.

title: Tokyo Journal; A Demimonde Scrutinized After a Disappearance
description: Although she's still only 22, Veronica Solano thinks that she has got the world pretty much figured out.

title: COMPAQ CHAIRMAN STEPS DOWN
description: Benjamin M. Rosen, a pioneering figure in the personal computer industry and a founding investor in both Compaq Computer and Lotus Development, resigned yesterday as chairman of Compaq. Mr. Rosen, 67, who was a Wall Street analyst during the 1960's and 1970's, is credited with being one of the first analysts to spot the rise of the PC industry. He founded The Rosen Electronics Letter as president of Rosen Research, a technology consulting and publishing firm that he formed in 1980 and later sold to Esther Dyson. Mr. Rosen had stepped in several times to help reorganize Compaq and redirect the company's strategy, most recently last year. Compaq's chief executive, Michael Capellas, above, will now serve as chairman. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, GRACE
description: HARRIS-Grace. (Goldie.) Of Jersey City. Beloved wife of Paul. Devoted mother of Mark and Alan. Dear sister of Florence Stillman. Services Friday 11:00 AM, Mt. Moriah Chapel. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-378-1892.

title: A Strike No One Can Win
description: I am a scab, a nonunion actor who crossed the Screen Actors Guild picket line to audition for and act in a commercial. This may be the first issue on which Susan Sarandon and I disagree.

title: The Yugoslav Who Could Be Leader Sketches the Nation He Envisions
description: Should Vojislav Kostunica take office as Yugoslavia's new president, he wants, he says, to help shape a country with a different sense of itself and its place in the world, less isolated and neurotic, a normal European nation with a good dose of skepticism toward American foreign-policy goals.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hitmen Name Tillman Coach
description: The movie screen lifted dramatically yesterday, and there was the first head coach of the New York/New Jersey Hitmen, Rusty Tillman, hunkered on a bar stool, hair shorn almost to the scalp, dressed in a tough-guy black suit with a black shirt.

title: LOPEZ TAKES GOLD
description: Patience and a penalty point helped propel Steven Lopez of Sugarland, Tex., to a taekwondo gold medal last night, 1-0. Lopez faced Sin Joon Sik of South Korea for the gold medal in the 68-kilogram (150-pound) class, after defeating three opponents by a combined 10 points to 1. The 6-foot-2-inch Lopez used a six-inch height advantage to keep Sin backing away and risking penalties for lack of aggression.

title: Voter-Friendly Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: About the Tables
description: Beginning next week and continuing through Dec. 29, Business Day will include a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays. That section will consist of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: China's Dominance Continues in Diving
description: Two systems for developing divers were on display at the Olympic Park Aquatic Center in Sydney, Australia, last night, and the results were as defining as Fu Mingxia's nearly flawless technique.

title: Tempering Rosy View, Lazio Revisits Economics Upstate
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio today sought to rebut the perception that he has been too upbeat in the face of economic suffering upstate, asserting before the Rotary Club here that new jobs are being created while acknowledging that ''the recovery here has not reached every single family.''

title: WEBMD TO CUT JOBS IN REVAMPING
description: The WebMD Corporation, an Internet company that links insurers, doctors and patients, will cut 1,100 jobs as it eliminates overlap from acquisitions. The job cuts, equaling about 20 percent of WebMD's work force, will be completed by the end of next year. WebMD will take a pretax charge of $35 million to $45 million in the third quarter, the company said in a statement. Shares of WebMD rose $2.75, or 24 percent, to $14 on the news. Separately, Garden.com Inc., which sells gardening products on the Internet, said it would lay off 93 workers, or 30 percent of its full-time staff. It said it had about $11 million in cash on hand, enough to last through the end of the year. Garden.com said it had hired Robertson Stephens to help it evaluate its alternatives after failing to raise more cash.

title: Gaze, Now 35, Puts On a Show TV Could Love
description: The young, brooding guard from Italy was shaken, his words tumbling over each other after the wrenching, last-second loss to Australia.

title: School Contracts Investigation Focuses on Ex-Superintendent
description: Investigators are looking into whether a former Queens school superintendent received kickbacks of $100,000 and favorable financing terms on real estate investments in exchange for steering more than $6 million in school computer contracts to a Long Island technology company, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Key College Football Matchups for September 30th
description: SATURDAY'S KEY GAMES

title: New Voluntary Standards Are Proposed for Experiments on People
description: The new head of the federal office that oversees research on people said yesterday that the system was flawed and would be revised to increase protection for human subjects.

title: INSIDE
description: Saudis to Pump More Oil

title: For White, Footwork A Problem
description: Rick White, the Mets' right-hander who has struggled lately, studied videotape Wednesday, searching for flaws. He and the pitching coach Dave Wallace went down the checklist of typical mechanical problems, but they could find nothing wrong. White was not tipping his pitches, not drifting forward in his delivery and nothing was wrong with his leg kick.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about accusations by the Bush campaign that the Gore campaign sent out misleading solicitation letters for a fund for legal and accounting expenses misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission, who declined to say whether the agency was examining the solicitations. He is Ian Stirton, not Striton.

title: Incomplete Breast Cancer Care Found
description: A third of American women who had lumpectomies or other breast-conserving operations for early-stage breast cancer from 1990 to 1995 did not receive other needed treatments, a new study says.

title: Metro Business; Electric Utilities Ask U.S. Agency for Help
description: Consolidated Edison and Orange and Rockland Utilities urged federal energy regulators yesterday to reform New York State's wholesale electricity market to reduce energy prices.

title: Number of Insured Americans Is Up for First Time Since '87
description: After rising relentlessly for 11 years, the number of Americans without health insurance declined last year, to 42.6 million, a reduction of 1.7 million from 1998, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Foreign Affairs; Under the Volcano
description: So you get home tonight and you get on AOL and you have a question about your bill or a technical glitch. You go to the AOL help section and get online with an AOL helper, who walks you through your problem, using e-mail back and forth. Do you know whom you're talking to? You're talking to a Filipino techie working in AOL's back office, which, thanks to a fiber-optic cable under the Pacific, is now located here at the former Clark Air Base outside Manila, beneath the Mount Pinatubo volcano.

title: Saluting a Pure Form of Abstraction, Long May It Wave
description: The exhibitions of Bridget Riley's work at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea and at PaceWildenstein on East 57th Street may be a case of perfect timing. At a point when contemporary art can seem bogged down with narrative, language and representation, when photographic images and video maintain an around-the-clock bombardment, and when realism is one of the few connecting links between mediums and styles, Ms. Riley's bracingly pure abstractions, sustained for four decades, seem literally to clear the air. They are a sight for sore eyes, even if they sometimes cause them, too.

title: Mets Hammer Maddux, Just for Fun
description: The Mets are not used to relaxing. Sometimes they press, sometimes they focus, but not since the end of the 1997 season had the Mets been able to kick back and play ball for the heck of it. With nothing on the line last night, the Mets had no trouble beating the best pitcher of this generation.

title: Courting Michigan, A Mirror of the U.S.
description: In February, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas lost the Michigan Republican primary to Senator John McCain of Arizona, thanks to a notably poor showing among independents, moderates and women.

title: A Scare for the Big, Bad U.S.A.? Good
description: Sydney, Australia  There should be no complaining now about the result, the near shocking upset. No windging (whining), as they like to say here. We wanted competition, didn't we? We've been crying out for actual basketball contests of shooting and strength and will, and not the dunk and pony shows that became so tedious the minute Michael, Magic and Larry departed their grand Olympic stage.

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLIER, MILTON R.
description: FLIER-Milton R. Five years since you left us, but our memories and love are constant. Dorothy, Jeff, Terry, Steve, Carol, Sarah, Dana, Emily and Lydi

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Sept. 21 about Word Perfect software referred incorrectly to the program used in the New York attorney general's office. It is WordPerfect; the office used Microsoft Word in 1998, when the states' antitrust suit against Microsoft was written there.

title: ALLEN LEAVES MICROSOFT BOARD
description: Microsoft said yesterday that its co-founder Paul G. Allen and the former Hewlett-Packard executive Richard Hackborne were resigning from the board. Mr. Allen and William H. Gates founded Microsoft 25 years ago to market the BASIC computer language to hobbyist computer users. Later, on the strength of a contract from I.B.M. to development MS-DOS, a simple personal computer operating system, Microsoft grew into the world's dominant independent software publisher. Mr. Allen, through his Vulcan Ventures, is a powerful force in new media and other technology companies. He left Microsoft in 1982 when he contracted Hodgkin's lymphoma, but had remained a board member. He owns 3.5 percent of Microsoft's stock. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Kazakhs' Motto: 'Fight to the End'
description: During the 1950's and 1960's, the Soviet Union sent settlers to the ''virgin lands'' of the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic, a landlocked area roughly four times the size of Texas just northwest of China. The newcomers, who were mostly Russians, brought with them the lessons of a centralized sports system, and in the sport of boxing, a specific technique.

title: Nat Fein, 86, Pulitzer Winner For Picture of Ruth's Final Bow
description: Nat Fein, who won a Pulitzer Prize for capturing one of the sports world's most poignant images, a rear-view photograph of a dying Babe Ruth receiving his final accolade at Yankee Stadium in June 1948, died Tuesday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 86 and lived in Tappan, N.Y.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Fighting Marketing Pirates; Sponsors Guard Their Investments at Olympics
description: It has become an urban legend at these Olympic Games. Security guards are supposedly confiscating bottles of Pepsi-Cola from visitors at the gates of the Olympic Park. Pepsi, The Sydney Morning Herald wrote, is on the forbidden list -- along with guns, knives and explosives.

title: Giants Feel The Wrath As Fassel Lets Loose
description: The head coach stalked off the practice field after a heated address to his players. A top receiver carefully worded his frustrations over the sputtering passing game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVITT, CEIL
description: CRAVITT-Ceil. Scarsdale Synagogue - Tremont Temple, Scarsdale, N.Y. mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Stephen A. Klein, Rabbi Andrew J. Goodman, President

title: Of Frogs And Philosophy
description: In a typical fairy tale, a frog is an enchanted creature just waiting for his true self to be revealed. In ''Boonah, Come Down,'' the frog is also on a quest, but his transformation is achieved through meditation, -- no princess's kiss required.

title: Fidelity Sells Newspapers To Boston Herald Owner
description: The owner of The Boston Herald is purchasing the Community Newspaper Company, a group of four daily and 88 weekly newspapers in the Boston suburbs, from Fidelity Capital, the new business and venture capital arm of Fidelity Investments.

title: Article 2000092991926704688 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: $12 Billion Set Aside for Conservation Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  White House and Congressional negotiators today agreed to set aside $12 billion over six years in the largest conservation fund in the country's history.

title: Berlin to Give Brandenburg Gate a Scrub
description: BERLIN, Sept. 28  Decades of grime will soon be stripped from the Brandenburg Gate, the first cleanup for Berlin's best-known emblem since before World War II.

title: REMEC OFFERS $428 MILLION FOR ALLGON
description: The wireless technology company Remec Inc. offered to buy Allgon A.B., a Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, for 15.75 million of its shares. The offer, worth about $428.2 million at yesterday's closing price for Remec, topped an unsolicited bid from LGP Telecom Holding.

title: An Olympic Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Is Facing Big Delays For Its Playstation 2 System
description: The North American debut of Sony's new Playstation 2 video system appears to have become a marketing nightmare.

title: Los Alamos Workers Face Disciplinary Action
description: Workers at the Los Alamos weapons laboratory have been notified that disciplinary actions, possibly including one dismissal, are imminent in the case of computer hard drives that vanished from a safe and then were found behind a copying machine.

title: For Edgemont, Thursday Is Fine Night for Football
description: Because of Rosh Hashana this weekend, several public high school football games in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were played yesterday rather than on Saturday.

title: A Gold Quest Now Includes a Little Bronze
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Fun is winning.

title: Suit Considers Computer Files
description: When the public schools in Exeter, N.H., gave Internet access to students in 1998, they chose not to use filtering or blocking software on classroom terminals, opting instead for a less restrictive combination of supervision and spot-checks.

title: The Writing Life: Never Unexamined, Often Nasty
description: MARTIN BAUMAN

title: Judge Criticizes Police Agency In Bias Case Brought by Officer
description: A federal judge sharply criticized the New York Police Department yesterday for apparently failing to adequately investigate an officer's claims that she was discriminated against for being gay.

title: The Evolution of Bush the Debater
description: In the first debates of the Republican primaries, Gov. George W. Bush did not have to do much. With six candidates dividing an hour and a half, no one got more than 15 minutes.

title: Morgan Stanley Creates Fund Tied to Internet Index
description: Beginning today, investors will be able to tie their money to picks made in part by one of the most influential Wall Street analysts following the Internet.

title: Public Interests; The Fall Lineup
description: Americans are very sophisticated about the relationship between politics and entertainment. Anybody can tell you that Richard Nixon blazed the trail in 1968 when he appeared on ''Laugh-In'' and muttered the show's catch phrase, ''Sock it to me.'' It was one of the first glimpses of the ''fun'' Nixon the nation would later come to love.

title: CISCO BUYS 2 SOFTWARE CONCERNS
description: Cisco Systems said yesterday that it had acquired two privately held communications companies to expedite its efforts to deliver voice over data networks. Vovida Networks is a supplier of networking protocols and communications software. IPCell Technologies provides software for broadband networks. By enabling it to combine voice, video and data services over packet networks, the acquisitions will help decrease network costs and generate new revenue for network service providers, Cisco said. The two deals were valued at $369 million in Cisco common stock.

title: Was He a Fastidious Romantic Or an Impassioned Classicist?
description: Mendelssohn, the present subject of celebration at the New York Philharmonic, has not played the posterity game with any great success. History often prefers engines of change. Some people may not like Schoenberg's music, but they will never forget the name. Everyone likes Beethoven and Mozart, but their names, like Schoenberg's, are writ particularly large by virtue of movements they represent. We keep track of the past by dividing it into eras, and all three of these men are prominent hinges joining one period to the next.

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: City Will Test Blood for Virus, Door to Door on Staten Island
description: City health officials are urging Staten Island residents to give blood for tests to determine how many people in the borough have been infected by the West Nile virus.

title: Civil Disobedience Is Planned To Try to Force Milosevic Out
description: Serbia's democratic opposition thinks it has a president in Vojislav Kostunica. But it also has a problem: how to get the incumbent, President Slobodan Milosevic, out of power.

title: Slowing the Pace Until Chatter Can Be Revelation
description: ''I like to go to beautiful places, places that are nice and calm and quiet,'' says Nasia (Candace Evanofski) in ''George Washington.'' This dream of a movie is set in such a place; with its delicate shifts of tone, it could be a fairy tale by Faulkner. The picture is also bursting with talent, from its very young cast -- most of the actors are preteens to 14-year-olds -- to its first-time feature writer and director, David Gordon Green, who puts his trust in his ensemble. It comes through for him.

title: Metro Business; Theme Restaurant Swap
description: The Official All Star Cafe, a five-year-old theme restaurant that helped to transform Times Square into a tourist destination, closed Tuesday night to make way for another theme restaurant owned by the same company.

title: People
description: Gerry Graf rejoined BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, as a fifth executive creative director. He left BBDO in 1997 to join Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, as an associate creative director.

title: Everythings New but the Mountains and the Sea
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Conspire to arrive by ship. Like Naples, like New York and Cape Town, Vancouver looks its best from the water, its shiny glass towers rising like Xanadu against a backdrop of indigo peaks whose foothills dip their toes in the harbor.

title: Who Could Ask for Anything More?
description: Ten days ago, Venus and Serena Williams arrived as two players in the Olympic medal mix, but they left today after overwhelming the scene like a dye drop in a pool.

title: Workers Sue, Invoking Law Used to Fight Racketeering
description: A dozen current and former workers at one of Chinatown's largest restaurants have taken the novel step of suing its management under a federal anti-racketeering law for what they call extortionate practices that they say deprived employees of their pay and sought to break their union.

title: Apple Says Quarterly Profit Won't Meet Expectations
description: Apple Computer said today that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall far below analysts' estimates because of weak September sales, an announcement that sent the company's shares plunging in after-hours trading.

title: In Suburbs, the Batman Meets His Villain; As Awareness About Rabies Grows, More Business for This Crusader
description: When the furry winged creature, its teeth as small and sharp as needles, swooped through her bedroom here in the middle of the night, Gina Grieco shrieked, pulled the sheets over her head and told her husband to call 911.

title: PACKAGING CORP. TO SELL 385,000 ACRES OF TIMBERLAND
description: The Packaging Corporation of America said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 385,000 acres of timberland to Southern Timber Ventures for $250 million in cash and a one-third ownership stake in the company. Packaging, a maker of containerboards, will use the proceeds to pay off debt, the company said. The company wants to cut $1.2 billion in debt by the end of next year. Taking a stake in the closely held Southern will allow Packaging to benefit from a rise in the value of the timberlands in the future, the company said. Shares of Packaging rose 81 cents, to $11.31.

title: Outcome Expected to Increase Pressure on Single Currency : Danes Vote 'No' On Joining Euro By Solid Margin
description: COPENHAGEN  Danish voters rejected Thursday the country's entry into the European common currency by a convincing margin.

title: Defense and F.B.I. Agent Spar At Lockerbie Bombing Trial
description: The testimony of a Libyan double-agent once expected to be the star witness in the Lockerbie trial ended today after defense lawyers accused him of being not only a liar but also a black market currency dealer and an opportunist hoping for the $4 million reward offered by the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, SY.
description: UNGER-Sy. Brave, beloved husband of Valerie Unger, father of Melissa and Rusty, grandfather of Amanda Guinzburg. Mourned by loving in-laws, the Houles family; survived also by Robert Unger. May his memory be honored as he rests in peace. Donations to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society are welcomed.

title: Bush, Gore Fight Over Energy Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Gov. George W. Bush went after Vice President Al Gore on energy issues today, laying out a plan that he said would improve the country's security while safeguarding its environment and accusing the Clinton administration of being caught unprepared.

title: R. S. Thomas, 87, Clergyman Poet Drawn by the Welsh Countryside
description: R. S. Thomas, a Welsh clergyman and poet whose spare, often bleak verse reflected the rugged people and landscape of his native land, died on Monday at his home in Llanfairynghornwy, Anglesey, Wales. He was 87.

title: Article 2000092991794683430 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Kayaker Keeps Dream Alive
description: PENRITH, Australia, Sept. 30 - The burly man with the powerful forearms and the peach-fuzz hair steered his kayak by the side of the dock, and came to rest. His chest swelled as he inhaled, before releasing the tension of another hurdle passed, another heat survived, and a doubling of the chances of living his dream.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL, -- Bethesda, Md., which manages and franchises hotel properties, said it would sell four hotels to Capital Hotel Investments, a new joint venture between Marriott and affiliates of Blackacre Capital Management, for about $274 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, DR. ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely passing of Anne Dyson, a member of the board since 1990. We extend our sincerest sympathy to the members of the Dyson family, who have been generous friends of The Metropolitan Opera for so many years. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Paul M. Montrone, President

title: Do-Ho Suh
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: 2 Senate Rivals Still in the Hunt For Soft Money
description: It promises to be the political fund-raising event of the fall season in New York. The cost to attend is as much as $100,000 for an evening of cocktails and dinner at a Manhattan hotel, alongside some of the most powerful Republicans in the state.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIANEW WRINKLES IN CHINA-W.T.O. APPLICATION China's effort to gain admission to the World Trade Organization has encountered new problems, undercutting the chances that the country can join by the end of the year. China's top negotiator, Long Yongtu, denied speculation of a deadlock, but the W.T.O. negotiating group chairman issued a statement calling for a "fundamental re-examination of negotiating positions in capitals" before any new session takes place. Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, has asked for a meeting with China's premier, Zhu Rongji, but no date has been set, Mr. Long said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Jakarta Court Drops Charges Against Ailing Suharto
description: An Indonesian court dismissed the government's corruption case against former President Suharto today after court-appointed doctors declared him medically unfit to stand trial.

title: Importing Cheaper Drugs
description: Now that the Republican leadership has joined forces with President Clinton, Congress is almost certain to pass a bill that would permit imports of American-made pharmaceutical drugs that are sold at low prices abroad. The Republican leaders may have come around to the idea to insulate themselves from charges that they have failed to protect Medicare and other patients from soaring drug prices. To be sure, a proposal designed to lower price is by no means a sufficient answer to the problem that millions of the elderly have no coverage for prescription drugs. Yet it is worth trying in an effort to curb prices and instill more evenness in global pricing.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Residential Real Estate; A Community Created By a Builder's Tenacity
description: John Ciardullo is planning to build himself a new home on Rock Shelter Road in the northern Westchester hamlet of Waccabuc, and why not? He carved the road itself out of rocky wooded terrain, designed, engineered and built all the 7 houses on it, and will do the 14 yet to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, THOMAS A.
description: SILLS-Thomas A. On September 26 at age 86. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne Reynal, a mosaicist. Devoted father of Kenneth and Michael, grandfather of Arvis and Dawn and brother of Anne McMurray. A gifted artist, who was a member of the New York Abstract Expressionist movement and then later in life turned to collage as a medium to create surreal works of unusual power and beauty. Lawrence Campbell wrote in Art News, ''There is a novel and unique strangeness to his work. He flirts with a language which has taken thousands of years to evolve.'' Memorial services Monday evening, 6 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: 20 Years From Lab to U.S. Consumer
description: ACloser Look

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlesimo Receives A Seton Hall Salute
description: A rubber track surrounds it, and steel beams criss-cross the ceiling. Seton Hall's fieldhouse is nothing special, but for P.J. Carlesimo it contains the fondest memory of his 12-season reign as a coach.

title: Australian Duos Capture Gold Over U.S. Crews
description: In sight of the famous waterside Opera House and the Olympic rings emblazoned across the Sydney Harbor Bridge, the United States crews of J. J. Isler and Pease Glaser, and Paul Foerster and Bob Merrick, raced to silver medals this afternoon in the waning days of the Olympic regatta.

title: Mosley Back in Ring At Garden vs. Diaz
description: Since June 17, when Shane Mosley dethroned Oscar De La Hoya and seized the World Boxing Council welterweight title by a decision, Mosley has played some basketball, taken a Caribbean cruise and basked in the accolades. But he has not been in the ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIS, SUSAN
description: BAILIS-Susan. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the loss of Susan Bailis, a dear friend who shared an enduring commitment to the Jewish community with her beloved father, Sanford Solender, and her cherished brother, Stephen D. Solender. Through her own heartfelt efforts, she embraced the legacy of her father, who served as executive vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for 11 years, a predecessor to UJA-Federation. And like her brother, who served as executive vice president of UJA-Federation for 13 years, Mrs. Bailis combined a deep concern for humanitarian causes with love for the Jewish people. A social worker who rose to the ranks of top hospital administrator, and eventually built New England's largest nursing home company, Mrs. Bailis was a tireless crusader, dedicated to improving health care for the elderly and promoting research leading to advanced treatments and cures for breast cancer. A devoted leader respected by her colleagues, friends, and family for her generosity and vision, Mrs. Bailis served as chair of the board at the Heller School at Brandeis University and at the Simmons College School of Social Work. She was a dedicated member of the boards of Brandeis University, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Boston, and Americans for Peace Now. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mrs. Bailis' beloved husband, Lawrence; her children, Kathryn and David; her father, Sanford, and brother, Stephen; her sister-in-law, Elsa; and her entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Udomsak Krisanamis
description: Gavin Brown's Enterprise

title: Brodeur Is Matched By a Rookie
description: Rangers Coach Ron Low and the rookie goaltender Jason LaBarbera were both asked tonight to name LaBarbera's strengths after he matched the Devils' Martin Brodeur save for save in a preseason game that ended in a 2-2 tie.

title: High Priest of a Boundless Era
description: Much has been made of John Ruskin (1819-1900) this year, and not without a reason. It is the centenary of the death of this artist, art and architectural critic extraordinaire, social reformer, polymath lecturer, first official professor of art in England (at Oxford University) and an admirer of little girls whose mismarriage to a full-grown woman ended in disaster.

title: 'The Price of Air'
description: Directed by Josh Evans

title: Mr. Milosevic's Trickery
description: Slobodan Milosevic's resounding defeat in Yugoslavia's presidential elections is being celebrated by large and joyous crowds around the country. Yesterday Serbia's Orthodox Church joined most of Yugoslavia's political parties, President Clinton and leaders across Europe in recognizing the election of the opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica. Regrettably, Mr. Milosevic himself does not yet seem to have gotten the message. His allies in the government-controlled election commission have brazenly shaved just enough votes off Mr. Kostunica's winning margin to call for a runoff vote next month. That insults democracy and invites political turmoil. The international community, including Russia, must firmly insist that Mr. Milosevic step aside now.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He can do nothing to us. He is broken.''

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Diners with a long memory may recall that there was a Sandro's near the Queensboro Bridge that closed in 1992. It won respect for its Roman-style cuisine, but it never overcame its awkward location. Sandro Fioriti, the chef, went on to cook at Nello and many other restaurants.

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Two 'Enemies' Who Make Music By Playing Each Other So Hard
description: BACK in Norway, they heard about the victory tour, the commercials, the sponsorships, when the United States won the Women's World Cup in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, HERMAN
description: STRAUSS-Herman. Beloved husband of Irma, devoted father of Donald, Beatrice Roth and Ellen Koval and loving grandfather of seven grandchildren. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J., Friday 12 noon (1-800-378-1892).

title: Chairman of S.E.C. Briefs Panel on Audits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Arthur Levitt, offered a private briefing to a Senate subcommittee today on what he called credible evidence that consulting for audit clients can taint accountants' financial reports on those clients.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about the publishing industry's increasing attention to black readers, misspelled the given name of the television host whose book club has stimulated sales by and to blacks along with whites. She is Oprah Winfrey, not Opra.

title: PARTNERSHIP ON WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS
description: In a deal to help speed the development of in-car electronic services, the Ford Motor Company and Peugeot Citroen of France announced that they would form an alliance to cooperate in automotive design and the development of wireless services like cell phone and Internet access and entertainment channels. The companies expect to formally seal the deal by the end of the year. In August, Ford formed a joint venture with Qualcomm Inc., called Wingcast, to equip its cars for wireless services. The deal is the latest example of a spreading web of cooperation agreements in the car industry. Ford and Citroen recently announced an agreement to cooperate in the development of diesel engines.

title: Editorial Observer; The Senator and the Talmud: A Case Study
description: When Vice President Al Gore chose Senator Joseph Lieberman as his running mate, even many Jews wondered how an Orthodox Jew would reconcile his religious obligations with the demands of the job he was seeking. Would Mr. Lieberman take an official phone call on the Sabbath? Would he fly to Washington for a tie-breaking vote in the Senate?

title: Ebersol Has Few Regrets About Olympic Coverage
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29  You must understand, Dick Ebersol said, he loves the Olympics. He relishes controlling the production, is riveted by athletic sacrifice and adores his staff. He has worked 20- hour days, rarely seen his wife and his youngest son, and looks as if he needs a vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDER, BERTHA
description: PENDER-Bertha. The Trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services regret the passing of Bertha Pender, mother of Mary Pender Greene, ACSW, Chief of Social Work Services and Director of Group Treatment. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mary and her family. Joseph S. Kaplan, Pres. Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Exec VP Paul Levine, CSW, Assoc Exec VP

title: How the Goal Line Came To Replace the Color Line
description: It's striking how many of the images that capture America's struggle to overcome its legacy of racism come from the world of sports. Think of Jesse Owens at the 1936 Olympics, Jackie Robinson stealing home, Arthur Ashe triumphing at Wimbledon, Tiger Woods winning his first major tournament.

title: UNILEVER-BESTFOODS DEAL APPROVED
description: The European Commission said it had approved the $24.3 billion acquisition of the United States food company Bestfoods by Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch food and consumer goods conglomerate. Under the European Commission's condition for approval, Unilever must shed brands and businesses worth $440 million in annual sales. Unilever said it had agreed to shed overlapping businesses like its Oxo bouillon cubes and Bestfood's Lesieur mayonnaise products in France. The Federal Trade Commission in the United States has approved the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, HELEN K.
description: HOROWITZ-Helen K. Wife of Jacob L. for 66 years. Mother of Bertha (Henry) Kressel & Avram (Esther) Horowitz. Grandmother of Aron and Lois Kressel, Kim and Ze'ev Ephrat of Israel, Judy and Avrumy Safrin, Benjy and Amy Horowitz. Great grandmother of Ariel, Yonatan, Dalia and Noam Ephrat; Melanie, Daniel and Perri Kressel; Meir, Ayelet and Atara Safrin. Services were Thursday, September 28, 2000.

title: Track Group Proposes Compromise on Testing
description: USA Track and Field, under fire for allegedly suppressing positive drug tests, proposed today that its entire doping control program be handed over to an independent world body.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Singaporean Tells of Khmer Rouge Aid
description: SINGAPORE  China, the United States, Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand spent more than $1.3 billion in a largely secret program in the 1980s to support Khmer Rouge and non-Communist guerrillas in Cambodia fighting Vietnamese troops and allied Cambodian forces, the Singaporean senior minister, Lee Kuan Yew, has disclosed in his memoirs.

title: Article 2000092992664197521 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Economy Grew At 5.6% Rate In 2nd Quarter
description: The economy grew faster in the second quarter than previously estimated without causing inflation to pick up, government figures showed today.

title: JOY AND OUTRAGE
description: Abortion rights supporters celebrated a long-sought victory today, with the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the abortion pill RU-486, but acknowledged that it could be an exceedingly fragile one.

title: Hughie Lee-Smith
description: June Kelly

title: West Nile Victim Recalled As a Hale and Hearty Man
description: Before he died of complications from West Nile virus two weeks ago -- becoming the first fatality of the outbreak in the United States this year -- Anthony Opalka projected an image of vigorous good health.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Business Briefs
description: Electric Utilities Ask U.S. Agency for Help

title: A.F.C., And Jets, Credit Martin
description: After Keyshawn Johnson was traded, Vinny Testaverde tweaked his former teammate by saying that Curtis Martin, not Johnson, was the team's most valuable player. Here's more proof:

title: Europe Reported Ready to Block Time Warner's Deal With EMI
description: European antitrust regulators plan to block Time Warner's joint venture with the British music conglomerate EMI Group but are much closer to approving Time Warner's $135 billion merger with America Online, people close to the talks said today.

title: In Damien Hirst's Big, Shiny Universe, Glass and Steel Meet Pills and Pain
description: Contrary to rumors that the young British artist Damien Hirst has forsaken art for the business of advertising or restaurant running, he seems to have gone into overproduction. His third solo show in New York, which inaugurates the palatial redesign of the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, is an extravaganza of paintings and room-size vitrine sculptures, including two that have been outfitted as gynecological examination rooms and then filled with water and fish, to great Surrealistic effect.

title: Nina Sten-Knudsen
description: 'The Landscape, Later'

title: Chicago Agency Plans A Reorganization
description: The B Com3 Group in Chicago said yesterday that it would reorganize management of its largest agency networks, Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Worldwide in New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: After a Wild, Intense Match, Norway Steals One From U.S.
description: No matter how many international tournaments the United States has won, Norway has always played the role of asterisk in the American domination of women's soccer.

title: Article 2000092992983409446 -- No Title
description: He can do nothing to us. He is broken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, JOHN
description: MARTIN-John. On September 26, 2000. Retired partner and head of Aviation Department of Bigham, Englar, Jones & Houston. Husband of Gilda Tedesco, predeceased Rita Cordts, father of John, Paul, Gerard, Ann and Rita. Grandfather of six and one greatgrandchild. In repose at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, East Meadow, New York.

title: Nice Is Not Enough
description: Watching ''Big Brother'' has been as exciting as watching vegetables grow. More precisely, it has been as exciting as watching people put together a jigsaw puzzle, one of the many inane tasks assigned to the 10 contestants who agreed to live in a house for three months with cameras on them 24 hours a day. You may be wondering why producers would even imagine that seeing people set up dominoes or ride a stationary bike would create dynamic television, but it turns out that such stupid human tricks are not to blame for the show's failure.

title: Metro Business; Staples Plans Warehouse
description: Staples Inc., the office-supply company, will open a Northeastern distribution center in the Orange County town of Montgomery, investing $40 million to buy and renovate a building formerly occupied by a company that is now bankrupt. The new warehouse is expected to employ 300 people by the end of next year, and 450 within five years, Staples said.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SAYS IT WILL MEET PROFIT FORECASTS
description: Procter & Gamble, maker of Tide detergent and Crest toothpaste, said yesterday that it expected to meet profit estimates for its fiscal first and second quarters, sending its shares up 8.3 percent. The company's chief executive, Alan G. Lafley, said Procter & Gamble planned to cut costs, raise prices on some products and revive brands like Pampers diapers. Shares of the company rose $5.13, to $67. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial expect Procter & Gamble to earn 88 cents a share in the quarter ending Sept. 30, and 93 cents in the quarter ending Dec. 31. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, expects sales to increase 2 percent to 3 percent this year.

title: A Postwar Survey, Semi-Wild at Heart
description: THE Museum of Modern Art has got to be in an enough-already frame of mind. The staff has just come through a grueling strike. Construction of a new wing has reduced the sculpture garden to rubble. Now all hands are on deck for ''Open Ends,'' the third and final leg of ''MOMA 2000,'' the millennium-marking group show that has taken up every inch of the museum's gallery space for the last year.

title: Deconstructing Deneuve
description: Catherine Deneuve is a little tired. It's been a long day, interview after interview. So much talking. She reaches into her purse, pulls out a sweetener pellet and drops it with a plink into the fresh cappuccino that has just been delivered to her hotel suite, the dregs of an ice-cold espresso pushed aside. She makes eye contact, that breathtakingly perfect, porcelain face leaning forward to take a good, solid pull on a thin, elegant cigarette.

title: Sauce Is Boycotted, and Slavery Is the Issue
description: The sauce itself is an act of defiance: a thick, yellow mustardy glaze that dares to call itself a barbecue sauce despite its utter lack of tomatoes. South Carolinians are among the only humans known to allow it upon their meat.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Phil Swaps Roles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWINBURNE, JOHN KNOWLES
description: SWINBURNE - John Knowles, M.D., of Sea Cliff, New York, on September 26th, 2000. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Ben, David and Nathaniel. Dear brother of William Swinburne. A Memorial Service will be held on October 1, 2000, at 2 P.M., at the Unitarian Universalist Church, 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset, NY. Contributions may be made to the Don Monti Foundation, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030 in John's memory. Further information, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY.

title: Golden Dreams End for Jones
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29  Marion Jones stood on the runway, blew air from her cheeks and shook her arms as if she were shivering on this hot, windy night at the Olympics. This was her sixth and final long jump. She crouched and swung her arms, then she leaned back and hopped slightly and began her final, urgent sprint toward history.

title: Nasdaq Amends Proposal For a New Trading System
description: Responding to criticism that their plan for a more centralized system for executing stock trades treated some investors' orders unfairly, Nasdaq Stock Market officials revised the proposal yesterday.

title: Gymnastics Rates Highly Before and Behind the Camera
description: SYDNEY, Sept. 29 -- On Monday, the final day of Olympic gymnastics, David Michaels was reflecting on how much he enjoys producing the sport. He's produced major sports like National Football League conference championships, but gymnastics stirs him, body and soul.

title: Metro Business; Bank Takeover Bid Ending
description: North Fork Bancorporation announced yesterday that it would not extend its exchange offer for Dime Bancorp stock, which is scheduled to expire today. The expiration effectively ends North Fork's seven-month-long hostile bid for Dime, a New York savings and loan.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS PLANS TO STOP MAKING FLU VACCINE
description: King Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that it would stop manufacturing its influenza vaccine after the Food and Drug Administration told the company it could not distribute the vaccine this year. The company will take $90 million in pretax charges in the third quarter, half related to the decision to discontinue the vaccine, Fluogen, and half related to its purchase of a rival, Jones Pharma, the company said. In March, the F.D.A. ordered King, based in Bristol, Tenn., to halt production of Fluogen because of manufacturing flaws. King's shares rose $2.13, to $31.13.

title: Pierre Trudeau Is Dead at 80; Dashing Fighter for Canada
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the long-serving prime minister of Canada who successfully defended his vision of federalism and a unified nation against the aroused forces of Quebec separatism, died yesterday in Montreal. He was 80.

title: Marcel Dzama and Jockum Nordstrom
description: David Zwirner Gallery

title: Bristol-Myers Planning to Sell Two Units, Including Clairol
description: After a year filled with setbacks, Bristol-Myers Squibb announced yesterday that it would sell its Clairol beauty care business and another unit that sells medical equipment so that it could focus more on the highly profitable business of prescription drugs.

title: Giuliani Has a New Formula For the Financing of Stadiums
description: Efforts by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to champion grand new ballparks for the Yankees and the Mets took a fresh turn yesterday, with the mayor proposing a financing formula in which each team would pay one-third of the costs of new stadiums. He said the city and state should divide the remaining costs down the middle, resulting in an even three-way split.

title: Investors, Seeing End of Trying Quarter, Push Markets Up
description: Reassuring comments by Procter & Gamble about earnings helped pull stock prices out of a late-September slide yesterday as two major gauges posted their biggest advance since May 30 and the Nasdaq market jumped 3.34 percent to regain more than half the ground lost in the preceding five sessions.

title: Next, a Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Color-Shifting Baby
description: WITHIN the color labs of the world's 12 major paint companies, chemists continually tinker with formulas, searching for new effects that will dazzle and entice the auto-buying public.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro slipped against the dollar as voters in Denmark appeared to reject a proposal to adopt the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 88.13 cents, down from 88.30 cents on Wednesday.

title: ITT Is Buying TRW Unit
description: ITT Industries, a maker of telecommunications and aerospace equipment and pumps, agreed today to buy the mobile-telephone keypad and switch business of TRW Inc. for $60 million to bolster sales of communication gear. The business, Man-Machine Interface, will have sales of about $54 million in 2000, pushing ITT's total telecommunication sales to more than $900 million in 2001, ITT said. TRW will use the proceeds to reduce debt from its 1999 purchase of LucasVarity P.L.C. Man-Machine Interface, based in Hampton, Va., has 380 employees and factories in the United States, England and China, TRW said. ITT is based in White Plains.

title: Once-Shielded Mob Figure Is Charged by U.S. in Murders
description: Federal prosecutors unsealed an indictment today charging Boston's most infamous, and elusive, mob figure and his longtime associate with involvement in the killings of 21 people between them -- from rivals to strangers in the wrong place at the wrong time to their own girlfriends -- in ''a reign of intimidation and murder that spanned some 25 years.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONO, MARYANN
description: DONO-Maryann, GOING-Mary Ann, MOLLICK-KELLY-Kathleen, WALSH-Joan Ellen. The Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York mourns the loss of four invaluable members of the Saint Vincent's family. They were longstanding members of our Nursing Staff who devoted their lives and careers to the ministries of healing and teaching at St. Vincent's. They are irreplaceable and their loss is immeasurable. Collectively, they leave behind an indelible legacy of compassion and dedication to our patients and their families. Individually, they will long remain in our hearts and minds. We extend our condolences to the families of these exemplary caregivers and will keep them in our prayers. Joseph M. Jabbour, MD, FACS President, the Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York

title: U.S. Renews And Revises Organ Donor Network Plan
description: The federal government today renewed its contract with the private organization that runs the nation's organ transplant system, a move that appears to end two years of dispute over how scarce livers and other organs are distributed.

title: OPEC's Unity Is Undercut By the Saudis
description: A display of unity by OPEC heads of state at the conclusion of their summit meeting today was undercut by the leading oil producer Saudi Arabia, which caused a sell-off in the petroleum market with a unilateral pledge to pump more crude to weaken prices that have recently hit 10-year highs.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Albums of the Week
description: TOM TOM CLUB: "The Good, the Bad and the Funky" (Rykodisc). The female bass player is a fixture in countless punk and indie bands. But the stereotypical role owes its existence to real pioneers, especially Tina Weymouth of the Talking Heads and the Tom Tom Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTERMAN, SHIRA
description: SCHUSTERMAN - Shira. The Board and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum are deeply saddened by the tragic death of Shira Schusterman, granddaughter of our National Committee Member and generous supporter, Lynn Schusterman. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Lynn, Charles and the entire family. James S. Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Judy Steinhardt, Co-Chair, AFIM Carolyn Cohen, Exec Dir, AFIM

title: Sharon Touches a Nerve, and Jerusalem Explodes
description: Tightly guarded by an Israeli security cordon, Ariel Sharon, the right-wing Israeli opposition leader, led a group of Israeli legislators onto the bitterly contested Temple Mount today to assert Jewish claims there, setting off a stone-throwing clash that left several Palestinians and more than two dozen policemen injured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUELL, FLORENCE
description: BRUELL - Florence. Flossie Schweitzer, 85, of Hewlett Bay Park, N.Y., on September 27. Beloved wife for fifty-four years of the late Frederick. Adored mother of Chris, Margaret, Lucy & Emily. Loving grandmother of Harry and Jenny Bruell, Katie and Scott Watson, Ada Rubin and Jesse Ruigomez and great-grandmother of Leo Bruell. Devoted mother-in-law of Marjorie Bruell and Christopher Ruigomez. Also mourned by her loving sister Helen Brooke and many dear nieces, nephews and friends. Athlete, social worker and humanitarian. Lifelong friend of the community, Florence's irrepressible spirit touched all that knew her. The family will announce a memorial service at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Making Her Case Against Foreign Leaders
description: A JURY in Manhattan came down hard on Radovan Karadzic this week, ordering the former Bosnian Serb wartime leader to pay $4.5 billion in damages to victims of rape, torture and genocide.

title: Dire Forecast on Impact of Cuts to Nassau's Parks
description: Hallmarks of suburban life in Nas sau County pristine parks, swimming pools and baseball fields -- would suffer in myriad ways under County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's budget proposal, the head of the Department of Parks and Recreation told county lawmakers today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 17 about the Oakland Table, a program of intellectual seminars organized by Mayor Jerry Brown of Oakland, Calif., referred imprecisely to some criticisms of the series. The terms ''Jerrification'' and ''pointy-headed table talk''were the article's paraphrase of local critics, not the words of Wilda White, president of the Jack London Neighborhood Association and an Oakland school board member. Ms. White said academic discussions should not take precedence over the city's problems with crime, education and the lack of affordable housing.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a report by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences that criticized the Clinton administration's AIDS policy misidentified an educator who spoke in Washington about the report. He was Dr. Michael H. Merson, dean of public health at Yale, not Dr. Harvey V. Fineberg, provost of Harvard.

title: 2 Ex-Executives Are Indicted In Fraud Case
description: Two former top executives of a Georgia medical software company were indicted yesterday, accused of costing investors more than $9 billion in one of the largest financial frauds in American history.

title: CYBERWORKS JOINT VENTURES
description: Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., an Internet investment company that has lost two-thirds of its value since February, announced at least five joint ventures to try to restore investors' confidence. The announcement came after CyberWorks said it lost 34.9 million Hong Kong dollars ($4.48 million) in the first half. The new ventures are in addition to three dozen already started since Richard Li formed the company by taking over an unprofitable mobile handset distributor 18 months ago.

title: Giuliani Plans To Overhaul Buildings Unit
description: Acknowledging that the city's Buildings Department has been mired in systemic corruption for at least three decades, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced steps yesterday to overhaul the agency by the end of the year.

title: Abortion Changes, But How Much?
description: The RU-486 announcement yesterday arrived with a lot of emphatic declarations attached: "historic moment," "milestone," "most significant technological advance in women's reproductive health care since the birth control pill." That last characterization was from Gloria Feldt, president of Planned Parenthood, responding to the news that the Food and Drug Administration had finally approved the marketing of what's come to be known as the abortion pill.

title: La Guardia's Traffic Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Says Bush Tax Plan Threatens Prosperity
