description: Vice President Al Gore said today that ''prosperity itself will be on the ballot'' on Nov. 7 and then repeatedly portrayed Gov. George W. Bush's proposed income tax cut as a serious threat to the country's economic health.

title: 'Barenaked in America'
description: Directed by Jason Priestley

title: Supply vs. Demand Ideas Separate Gore and Bush
description: With oil prices up, consumers agitated and the winter heating season looming, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush are going at it on energy policy, seeking to draw sharp distinctions over an issue on which both candidates have political vulnerabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANAHAN, GERALD F.
description: SHANAHAN-Gerald F. On September 27, 2000 of Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Beloved husband of the late Dolores. Loving father of Laura Shanahan, Karen Dufour, Susan Rule, Diane Handlmaier and Gerald Shanahan. Cherished granfather of T.J. Kristen and Lauren Dufour, Ryan, Garrett and Austin Rule and Michael and Katherine Handlmaier. Dear brother of Vincent, James, Mary Kuefner and the late Raphael Shanahan. Loving companion of Rose Otrin. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, NY 2-5 & 7-9PM Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City at 11 AM Monday. Interment Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Of Lennon, Time, Loss And Parole
description: IT was impossible to suppress a gulp when a copy of Modern Maturity crossed the desk a few months ago, and there on the cover was Paul McCartney. Odd enough that he is called Sir Paul these days. But to have the former Beatle turn up as a poster boy for codgers-in-training was a startling reminder of time's relentless passage.

title: TELEFONICA TO SELL SHARES IN MOBILE UNIT
description: Telefonica S.A. told regulators in Spain and the United States that it planned to sell new shares of its Telefonica Moviles S.A. unit, paving the way for the biggest initial public offering in Spain's history. Telefonica, the largest telecommunications company in Spain, said it had not decided on the size or starting date of the share sale, which reports suggested would be worth around $5.3 billion. The official filing means the offer could start as soon as next month.

title: Seeing Jazz as a Folk Art Awaiting Fusion With the Classical
description: Thursday night's ''Classic Ellington'' concert at Carnegie Hall had Sir Simon Rattle conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke's through grand and frequently hokey rearrangements and orchestrations of Duke Ellington's music by Luther Henderson. Ten excellent jazz musicians were on hand, too. But you can't really out-arrange Ellington, who had so much classical music within him in the first place. Aside from the record-business instinct that crossovers are good, what could have been the theory behind this?

title: Our Uninsured Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Remaking the Manhattan Mall; Owner Sees Stern's Departure as Chance to Freshen Up
description: Camille Andia, an office manager for a lighting company, visits the Manhattan Mall on 33rd Street and the Avenue of the Americas almost every day during her lunch hour. The shopping center has seven levels, but Ms. Andia has never traveled above the fourth floor.

title: A Disturbing Interloper In the Samurai Circle
description: Nagisa Oshima's elegant historical film ''Gohatta'' recycles a familiar metaphor -- male homosexuality as a symbol of decadence -- that is so loaded with dramatic implication it simply refuses to die. Most of the movie is set in a school for samurai warriors in Kyoto in 1865, a moment when the samurai tradition was crumbling with the advent of more efficient weapons technology. At this strict academy where minor infractions of the samurai code are punishable by death there suddenly appears an effeminate 18-year-old warrior whose seductive appeal wreaks havoc.

title: HEAT SIGNS FREE AGENTS
description: The Miami Heat yesterday signed guard Rick Brunson and guard/forward Jamal Robinson, both free agents.

title: Leave the Mall Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: A Maker of A.T.M.'s Finds A Niche in Brazil's Needs
description: On Sunday, Brazilians from the heart of this city to the depths of the Amazon will step up to a beige, toaster-sized terminal and punch a number on a keypad that corresponds to the candidate of their choice. The face of the potential mayor or city council member will pop up on the screen, and with a simple tap of a key, the candidate will be one vote closer to victory.

title: Time Warner and EMI Are Said to Offer to Sell Virgin Label
description: In an 11th-hour attempt to rescue their $20 billion joint venture from rejection by European regulators, Time Warner and the EMI Group have offered to sell off EMI's Virgin record label to win approval, people close to the companies said today.

title: Home Team Gets Date With American Dream
description: The kid from Adelaide finally caved in three weeks ago. Between the interview requests, the slippage in her game and the mounting expectations of a nation, Lauren Jackson no longer felt like the star of the Australian national basketball team.

title: G.E. Switches Its Web Site About PCB's
description: Three letters. On the surface, that's the only difference between Hudsonwatch.com and Hudson watch.net -- two Web sites devoted to the subject of the General Electric Company and the controversy over PCB pollution in the Hudson River.

title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's Many Factions Come Together to Mourn Trudeau
description: In a rare moment of national unity, Canadians suspended political and regional differences yesterday to take stock of how much their nation, and their lives, had been molded in the image of their prime minister of 16 years, Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: J. A. Ball, 97, Counsel to Warren Commission
description: Joseph A. Ball, a California trial attorney who was a senior counsel to the Warren Commission, which investigated the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, died on Sept. 21 in Long Beach, Calif. He was 97 and a longtime resident of Long Beach.

title: MANY NOT ELIGIBLE IN STATE PROGRAM TO INSURE CHILDREN
description: As many as half of all New York children who are enrolled in a special government health care plan do not actually qualify for the plan and will be removed from it over the next several months.

title: Transit Policeman Is Accused of Abuse
description: Atransit police officer with 14 years on the force was arrested Thursday and charged with sexually abusing two women while on the job, the police and the Queens district attorney's office said yesterday.

title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Milosevic Foes Stage Protests To Force Him To Concede
description: Thousands of people across Serbia rallied today in protest against President Slobodan Milosevic as opposition leaders called on foreign governments, including Russia and Greece, to examine the disputed results of the presidential election last Sunday.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Turkish Journalist Cleared of Insulting Army
description: In a case watched closely by advocates of press freedom and human rights, a Turkish journalist was acquitted today of charges that she insulted the military in a book about the war against Kurdish separatists.

title: Urbane Atlanta Considers the Color of Its Late-Night Revelry
description: In a trendy stretch of town called Buckhead, the seemingly frivolous business of clubbing and cruising has turned into a matter of civic soul-searching, revealing how easily the city's delicate fabric of race relations can tear.

title: The Rural Life; Bone Tired
description: The farmers I buy hay from said it wasn't frost, the other morning. I saw them walking across high rocky ground, beyond a barbed wire fence and an old truck body, driving heifers from one pasture into another. Each man carried an old, smooth stick with a wide crook in the end. The elder farmer walked as though he hated cattle -- would like for just one autumn morning to sleep in and not have to wonder what spooked the cows through the fence during the night. He was hunched, sore from what might be Lyme disease or what he calls ''sugar'' -- meaning diabetes -- or just lingering stiffness from the ribs he broke when he fell from a hay wagon in June. He looked cold, as if the frost had gotten into him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANAHAN, GERALD F.
description: SHANAHAN-Gerald F. On September 27, 2000 of Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Beloved husband of the late Dolores. Loving father of Laura Shanahan, Karen Dufour, Susan Rule, Diane Handlmaier and Gerald Shanahan. Cherished grandfather of T.J. Kristen and Lauren Dufour, Ryan, Garrett and Austin Rule and Michael and Katherine Handlmaier. Dear brother of Vincent, James, Mary Kuefner and the late Raphael Shanahan. Loving companion of Rose Otrin. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, NY 2-5 & 7-9PM Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City at 11 AM Monday. Interment Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Pyatt Impresses Islanders
description: He may not have earned a spot on the Islanders' roster -- yet. But the rookie Taylor Pyatt has earned himself a long, hard look.

title: Westchester Officials Join Forces to Oppose County Airport's Predawn Flights
description: Saying that their constituents were being deprived of sleep by airplanes taking off before dawn from Westchester County Airport, a bipartisan group of congressmen introduced legislation today that would impose a mandatory curfew on the airport.

title: Together in Death as in Life, 3 Nurses Honored
description: They had gone to school together, worked together, traveled together. And in death, with caskets lined up side by side, three of the four St. Vincents Hospital nurses who died in a freak car accident were honored together.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: FINKELSTEIN-Samuel. 9/16/069/30/96. The years have not diminished the wonderful memories nor eradicated the tears. Mim, Berne, Billy, Barbara and the kids

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by Bristol-Myers Squibb to sell some businesses and focus on prescription drugs referred incorrectly to an earnings projection made by Charles A. Heimbold Jr., the company's chairman, at a meeting with securities analysts and investors. He said the company's earnings per share would increase 14 percent this year, not 11 percent. The company expects earnings per share to increase 11 percent in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIS, SUSAN
description: BAILIS-Susan. Americans for Peace Now mourns the passing of our friend and Board member, Susan Bailis, daughter of our longtime Board member Sanford Solender. May her memory always serve as a blessing. Our condolences to the entire family. Pat Barr, Debra DeLee and the Board of Directors of Americans for Peace Now

title: WARNING ON IRISH INFLATION
description: The Irish government's central bank warned in its quarterly bulletin that increased inflation and rising wages put the economy at risk of recession, despite growth of 8 percent for the last six ears. The bank said that inflation, which is expected to surpass 7 percent shortly, should diminish to an average rate of 4 percent next year. Wages are currently growing at 7.25 percent. Brian Lavery

title: 2 Moderates in a Close (and Polite) Race for an Open Seat
description: This town about 40 miles north of Chicago is prime territory for Democrats. Economically downtrodden and racially diverse, it has problems including pollution in Lake Michigan and crime in the streets.

title: Victims of Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Cameroon Succeeds Nigeria as Champ
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30 -- Cameroon won the men's soccer gold medal today, becoming the second consecutive Olympic champion from Africa and sending out a message that the continent has a big future in the game.

title: Jail Term for Leader Of Teachers' Strike
description: A state judge sentenced the president of the Buffalo teachers' union to 15 days in jail and fined him $1,000 yesterday for defying a court order barring teachers from striking during this month's tumultuous contract negotiations.

title: Armstrong Cared Enough to Ride Here
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Lance Armstrong did not have to be here. These Olympic races had nothing to do with the Tour de France, the European circuit, where he makes his very considerable living.

title: Bush Aide Taped Mailing a Parcel, Newspaper Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Federal agents investigating a leak of confidential debate material from Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign said today that they remained focused on a low-level Bush aide despite her claims of innocence, The Washington Post reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 21 about efforts by Singapore to control its population of crows characterized the country's size incorrectly. With 225 square miles, it is about 10 times as large as Manhattan, not the same size.

title: If Teachers Are Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: UNILEVER TO SHUT CHICAGO MANUFACTURING PLANT
description: Unilever, the largest maker of food and soap products, said it would close a manufacturing plant in Chicago and lay off 600 workers as it consolidates production to cut costs and spur growth. Unilever, the maker of Dove soap, will move production of deodorants, shampoos and skin lotions from Chicago to plants in Clinton, Conn.; Raeford, N.C.; and Jefferson City, Mo. Unilever said the Chicago plant would close by the end of 2002. Unilever has offices in London and Rotterdam.

title: Kangaroo On Menu Is a Worry For Some
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29  Jennice Kersh is relieved that the Olympics are ending, and not just because of the 18-hour days.

title: SHARES OF AIRBORNE FREIGHT POST A DECLINE OF 17%
description: Shares of the Airborne Freight Corporation fell 17 percent after it said it would post a third-quarter loss partly on slow shipment growth and higher fuel costs. The stock of Airborne Freight, the parent of the No. 3 express-delivery service, Airborne Express, fell $2.06, to $10.19. The company expects to lose 5 cents to 10 cents a share in the quarter. Earnings of 28 cents a share had been the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Net income was $21.6 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Yesterday's announcement was the third time in the last four quarters that Airborne had warned that profits would not meet analysts' forecasts.

title: More a Loop Than a Knot
description: There have long been two competing visions of Europe's future. The first envisages a loose association of democratic nations; the second dreams of a federal United States of Europe, a power that the French see balancing American ''hegemony.''

title: Jets Are Idle, but a Trip To Florida Is No Holiday
description: They were headed for a rare weekend back home: Scott Frost to Nebraska, Victor Green to Atlanta, Al Groh to the 85th birthday party for his old coach at Chaminade High School in Mineola.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: TEXTILE COMPANY OFFERING
description: The Chengde Dixian Textile Company, the first privately owned Chinese company to sell shares to foreigners, gained 30 percent from its offering price on its first day of trading. Few of China's privately owned companies have been allowed to go public, and most have little access to capital. Many people see Dixian's share sale as a symbolic step toward broader government support for the private sector. Dixian sold $25.6 million worth of Class B shares, which are designated for foreign investors and are officially off-limits to Chinese citizens. Craig Smith

title: MERCK WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR OSTEOPOROSIS DRUG
description: Merck & Company's bone-building osteoporosis drug Fosamax was approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in men. The approval will expand the market for Fosamax, which has already been approved for treating women with osteoporosis. The drug, which has become an important source of revenue for Merck, is expected to generate more than $1 billion in sales this year. Fosamax is the first therapy approved in the United States for men with the disease. Up to 20 percent of osteoporosis patients are men.

title: Police in Idaho Searching For a Long Island Woman
description: Federal investigators and the police in Boise, Idaho, are searching for a newly married flight attendant from Long Island who never showed up for a flight on Monday morning. They believe she disappeared on Sunday after taking a walk from her hotel in Boise, where she was on a one-night layover.

title: California Governor Rejects Electricity Aid
description: SACRAMENTO, Sept. 29  A $150 million emergency aid plan for San Diego's electricity customers was rejected today by Gov. Gray Davis, who called it premature and an incentive for energy traders to gouge.

title: Palestinian, Israeli Forces Exchange Fire on Third Day of Clashes
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- Israeli troops and Palestinian police exchanged fire in a third day of clashes on Saturday, further damaging chances of securing an Arab-Israeli peace deal. About 200 Palestinians were wounded in the violence sweeping the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the death toll rose to at least seven from violence earlier this week. It started after right-wing Israeli politician Ariel Sharon -- a figure of hatred for Palestinians -- visited a site in Jerusalem's Old City on Thursday that is sacred to both Jews and Muslims. Witnesses said Palestinian police and Israeli soldiers opened fire during clashes near a Jewish settlement in Gaza on Saturday, and medical sources said more than 70 Palestinians had been injured in the violence there. Israeli security forces also opened fire in the West Bank city of Nablus when hundreds of Palestinians marched towards an army checkpoint. Witnesses reported three people hurt. Thousands of demonstrators gathered in the divided West Bank city of Hebron. Some threw stones and others hurled petrol bombs at Israeli soldiers and at least 60 people were injured. In Jerusalem, Israeli police said Palestinians threw stones at cars and buses and, as a security precaution, police evacuated worshippers from the Western Wall of the Old City where Jews were reciting prayers on the Jewish New Year. Dozens of other people were reported injured in isolated clashes across the West Bank. The Israeli army said it had used live ammunition in Gaza to target people ``endangering soldiers,'' as well as rubber-coated metal bullets and teargas there and elsewhere. ``PROVOCATIVE'' VISIT BY SHARON BLAMED Palestinian leaders had called a one-day general strike in memory of Palestinians killed on Friday during clashes at the Jerusalem holy site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Harim al-Sharif. They blamed the violence on the Israeli authorities' show of force and the ``provocative'' visit by Sharon to the Old City. A total of at least 400 Israelis and Palestinians, and several tourists, have been reported injured so far. The explosion of Arab-Israeli violence soured not only Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak's Barak's New Year, or Rosh Hashanah, weekend but also his push for lasting peace with the Palestinians. In New York, U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan telephoned Barak as well as Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Friday. ``He expressed his concern over the recent violence in Jerusalem and urged the leaders to do everything they can to reduce tensions, restore security and continue to work towards a peaceful settlement of the remaining issues that divide them,'' U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said. Arafat arrived in Cairo to discuss the violence with Egypt's Hosni Mubarak, a close ally of Washington and president of one of the only two Arab states to have made peace with Israel. Egyptian radio reported Mubarak had issued a statement blaming ``provocative Israeli actions'' for Friday's clashes in Jerusalem, the main stumbling block in the peace process. ``A statement issued by the Egyptian Presidency noted that, at a time when the peace-loving forces were looking forward to a breakthrough in the Palestinian-Israeli negotiations, they were taken aback by the bloody incidents that too place yesterday (Friday),'' the radio said. SAUDIS BLAME ISRAEL Palestinian Minister Nabil Shaath said he was due to leave on Sunday to meet foreign ministers of Luxembourg, France, Britain, Ireland and Belgium and top European Union officials at Arafat's request to brief them on the bloodshed. Saudi Arabia, another staunch ally of the United States and supporter of Washington's role as Middle East peace broker, put the blame for the violence squarely on Israel. ``Saudi Arabia condemns the brutal assaults inflicted on Palestinian citizens in Jerusalem by Israeli occupation forces,'' the Saudi Press Agency quoted an official statement as saying on Friday night. Saudi Arabia is the birthplace of Islam and home to the world's two main Muslim shrines. Gulf media railed against the ``horrific massacre'' of Palestinians in Jerusalem and one newspaper in Qatar said the killings showed Israel was still the Arabs' foe. ``The events prove that Israel was neither a neighbour nor a peace partner. It is no more than an enemy,'' Al-Sharq's editorial said. In south Lebanon on Saturday, thousands of Palestinian refugees demonstrated against the killings. They marched through Ain el-Hilweh, the biggest refugee camp in Lebanon, chanting anti-Israeli slogans and burning an effigy of Sharon. ``Sharon, we will never forget your massacres in Sabra and Shatila. The Aqsa Mosque (in Jerusalem) is Arab and will remain Arab,'' read one banner. In 1983 an Israeli inquiry found Sharon indirectly responsible for the killing of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in Beirut. He was defence minister at the time, during an Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Russia called on Palestinians and Israelis to stop further bloodshed from derailing the peace talks. ``Moscow is extremely alarmed,'' a Russian Foreign Ministry statement said on Saturday. ``These tragic events are the consequences of provocative acts in the area of Muslim holy sites on September 28,'' it said in apparent criticism of Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount.

title: Mistrial Declared in Senate Nominee's Trial
description: A mistrial has been declared in the trial of Pedro Espada Jr., the Democratic State Senate nominee for the 32nd District in the Bronx, because a defense lawyer in the case had a death in the family.

title: Unusual Legal Conflict in Lockerbie Case
description: Moving to a new phase of the Lockerbie trial, Scottish police officers described today how they had acquired the personal diary of one of the two Libyans accused of putting a bomb aboard Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988.

title: Ebersol Has Few Regrets About Olympic Coverage
description: In his sanctuary, his Olympic control room, Dick Ebersol hears no critical evil. Inside the nerve center of NBC Sports' 75,000 square-foot compound, the chairman of NBC Sports happily controls the prime-time production. During 20-hour days he has rarely seen his wife and youngest son. He looks as if he needs a vacation.

title: Tea With Cher, and Other Stops on the Fund-Raising Trail
description: The cars stretched down the street outside the bigger-than-average tract house in the San Fernando Valley suburb of Northridge, and the sound of ''Misty'' drifted from speakers in the backyard.

title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; From Lithuanians, a Startling Lesson
description: THERE should be no complaining now about the result, the near shocking upset. No whingeing (whining), as they like to say here. We wanted competition, didn't we? We've been crying out for actual basketball contests of shooting and strength and will, and not the dunk-and-pony shows that became so tedious the minute Michael, Magic and Larry departed their grand Olympic stage.

title: Mideast Violence Continues to Rage
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30  Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli troops left at least 12 Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the third day of fierce fighting that was set off by the defiant visit Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the steps of the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City.

title: Article 2000093091814200240 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Fujimori Asks Washington for Backing on Peru Transition
description: Just four months after he claimed re-election in a vote widely seen as flawed, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru implored senior Clinton administration officials today to give him the backing necessary to put Peru on a track toward full democracy, officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Koreans Win Enough, but Not Too Much
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30 -- The last impression the people running taekwondo want its Olympic debut to leave is that it is just too Korean for the rest of the world to really break into.

title: SALOMON SMITH BARNEY ACCUSED OF BIAS AGAINST BLACKS
description: The Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup Inc. was accused by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission of discriminating against black employees. In a complaint filed yesterday in federal court in Manhattan, the E.E.O.C. said that supervisors, managers and co-workers of five ''Haitian, Nigerian or West Indian employees'' had directed offensive jokes at them and other minority workers. The five worked as technicians. The complaint said the investment bank had paid the five lower wages and denied them promotional chances. Salomon Smith Barney called the suit ''meritless.''

title: Just Next-Door Neighbors Till Love Breaches Walls
description: ''It is a restless moment. Hong Kong 1962,'' reads a title card at the beginning of ''In the Mood for Love,'' and a restiveness that's almost voluptuous -- like that first blush of love when you can barely concentrate on anything else and the world seems new and strange -- fills the movie. ''Mood'' is a great word, because a lot of the movie is mood. The principals are caught as the camera peers at them through the edges of doorways. Its writer and director, Wong Kar-wei, is one of that gifted new breed of moviemakers who think through the lens, and he uses that talent to give the film a heated, rapturous quality; the camera floats along, sneaking a look at the performers out of the corner of its eye. Narrative has rarely been a motivating factor for him; instead his heart spills out onto the screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINN, ELEANORE
description: ZINN-Eleanore. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: Matthaus Plans to Play Again, but Where?
description: As the MetroStars prepared today for what could be their final game of the season, Lothar Matthaus said he planned to play next year, but no one is saying where he intends to be plying his trade.

title: Robert W. Blanchette, 68, Former Head of U.S. Railroad Agency
description: Robert W. Blanchette, a former head of the Federal Railroad Administration and a former chief executive of the Penn Central Transportation Company, died Monday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 68 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Armstrong Has to Settle For Bronze
description: Winning the Tour de France has proven easier than winning an Olympic gold medal for Lance Armstrong.

title: Rail Tanker Leaves Tracks In New Jersey
description: A rail tanker carrying more than 27,000 gallons of butane derailed near a residential neighborhood in Woodbridge, N.J., yesterday morning, prompting officials to evacuate 300 people from their homes as a precaution.

title: Rogues' Gallery? Three Accused of Mob Art Scam
description: Rose Period. Blue Period. Cubist phase. Fuggedaboudit.

title: Beverly Marries Manhattan, And Is Taking the Name Too
description: Two of the oldest clubs in New York City are combining this weekend. In the 70's, there was the Colony, on the Upper West Side, and the Colony East in Midtown. The first became the Manhattan Club and the second the Beverly Club. The proprietor of the Beverly, Joan Dziekanski, recently moved to the City Club, 50 West 54th Street, and starting tomorrow, the Beverly will become part of the Manhattan at 27 West 72nd Street.

title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking to Oprah Isn't Enough
description: It really was a beautiful thing: presidential candidates making nice to a black woman and meaning it. You don't see that every day in America. But when Oprah calls, even would-be presidents answer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, JOAN F.
description: REILLY-Joan F. Of New City, NY, on September 28, 2000. Wife of David. Mother of Elizabeth Reilly, Joan Vetter, David, Timothy, James and Matthew Reilly. Sister of Mary Dillon, Patsy Hoffman and Peggy Stefano. Also survived by 13 grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11AM, Saint Paul's Church, Congers, NY. Burial at Gethsemane Cemetery, Rockland Lake, NY. Friends may call at Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main St, New City, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 & 7-9.

title: Editors' Note
description: An art review in Weekend on Sept. 1 about the history and collections of seven small museums in Maine commented briefly on a temporary exhibition that had recently opened at the Ogunquit Museum of American Art, ''Painted Air: American Impressionism,'' on view through Oct. 15. After listing some artists represented in the show, the reviewer wrote, ''It needs pruning.''

title: Kayaker Realizes Ambition of Racing for U.S.
description: SYDNEY,Australia September 30 -- Angel Perez, 29, an Olympic kayaker for Cuba eight years ago, today raced for the United States after fighting for months through the rough water of Olympic rules and Havana's opposition.

title: One Family, Two Faiths
description: To the Editor:

title: In 'No' Vote, Danes Show Doubt Over EU's Course
description: PARIS  Denmark's rejection of the euro is a political event far more meaningful as a gesture distancing the country from any future European Union integration than as some kind of early-term, failing grade for its common currency.

title: SYDNEY 2000: VOLLEYBALL; World Champion Italians Surrender Another Gold
description: As Vladimir Grbic drove the final spike into their Olympic obsession tonight, the Italians did not even wait for the ball to hit the floor before turning to trudge to the net for the ritual handshakes.

title: NBC to Allow Local Choice Of Playoff Or Debate
description: A week after declaring it would broadcast a baseball playoff game instead of the first presidential debate, NBC changed its position yesterday, saying it will give its 222 local affiliates the option of carrying either the debate or the game on Tuesday night.

title: Article 2000093093325140490 -- No Title
description: The College Search Game, Spam Included

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Putin Offers Moscows Help With Yugoslavias Election Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said today that Moscow is ready to take a more active role in resolving the political standoff in Yugoslavia and offered to send his foreign minister to Belgrade.

title: Abortion Pill Distributor Energized by New Mission
description: For years, Danco Laboratories, the small private company that will distribute the abortion-inducing pill, mifepristone, has kept a low profile.

title: Abroad at Home; Bush And the World
description: When Slobodan Milosevic's forces ravaged Croatia in 1991, and then began their campaign of genocide in Bosnia, President Bush decided that the United States would do nothing meaningful to stop him. It was one of the most shameful episodes in the history of American foreign policy.

title: Americans Beat Brash Upstarts to Gold Medal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  One by one, the options kept fading for Lauren Jackson. Worn down on the inside, barely able to get free on the perimeter, Jackson, the young star of the Australian team, resorted to the only move she had left against the Americans, a move straight out of a heated schoolyard:

title: Debate Stakes Seen as Critical By Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  When Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore appear side by side in Boston on Tuesday before the largest single television audience of the presidential campaign, officials in both camps say the stakes will be far greater than they had anticipated because the contest is so excruciatingly tight.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It would have haunted us for the rest of our lives.''

title: With Ease Comes Expense: E-ZPass Starts on Turnpike, but So Do Toll Increases
description: After months of delay, the E-ZPass toll-collection system goes into effect today on the New Jersey Turnpike, along with both a toll increase and a new three-tiered structure of fees intended to reduce rush-hour traffic.

title: A Tumultuous Year for Former Kiwi Skipper
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  On the eve of an election campaign some 30 years ago, Richard Nixon described himself as being "tanned, rested and ready." Three decades along, on the threshold of yet another America's Cup crusade, the same could be said of Russell Coutts.

title: WEB SITE AUCTION
description: China auctioned off dozens of Internet companies, domain names and Web sites as part of a government plan to consolidate the cash-starved industry. Foreign investors were not allowed to bid for the 50 Internet sites on sale. China's fledgling Internet industry has boomed over the last two years, but it is running short of investment capital to keep it going. Few of the Chinese companies or Web sites have any revenue. Craig Smith

title: Montenegrins Gauging Effects of Yugoslav Vote
description: Even while the outcome of the Yugoslav presidential elections remains uncertain, Montenegro's leaders are sizing up the leading candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, and maneuvering for negotiations over the future of their republic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 17 about the opening of a subway system in Istanbul referred imprecisely to the relative ages of the city's original one, in 1875, and New York's. The New York subway opened in 1904, although the Long Island Rail Road had a limited underground line operating in the mid-19th century.

title: Corzine Trying to Avoid the Pitfalls of Wealth
description: For all the concern over campaign finance reform and rich businessmen buying elections, the sobering reality for wealthy candidates is that they are no more successful than anyone else. From 1990 to 1998, 38 non-incumbents spent more than $1 million of their own money running for the United States Senate, and 32 of them ultimately lost.

title: Waste Hauler Is Told to Keep Customers It Sought to Cut
description: The nation's largest trash disposal company, Waste Management, was ordered by a city agency yesterday to continue its service to 3,300 businesses in the city to which it had sent termination notices.

title: State Dept. Unfreezes Hundreds of Promotions After Delay for Security Review
description: A continuing security crackdown at the State Department led to the freezing of promotions for more than 200 senior officials, pending a review of their security records, department officials said today.

title: Relays Reveal the Most About Jones
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Four years ago, had you told Marion Jones that in the 2000 Games she would win five medals, most likely she would have been ecstatic. Some runners train a lifetime to reach the Games, competing but never winning a medal. Their careers are defined by simply getting there.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the trial of two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which went down in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misidentified the defendant whose clothes were found in the debris. A store owner testified that Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi had purchased the clothes, not his co- defendant, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah.

title: Our Uninsured Children
description: To the Editor:

title: With 4th Gold Medal, Edwards Can Finally Retire
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- In the United States' Olympic women's basketball team media guide, there is a team photo from the 1984 Los Angeles Games, where the Americans won all six games and the gold medal. The picture of youth, Teresa Edwards stands in the second row, far left corner, with a hairstyle she doesn't wish to remember and a set of clothing she won't forget.

title: A Tactical Challenge
description: In the long struggle over abortion, each side has periodically changed tactics to adapt to an altered political or legal climate.

title: He's Stony and Noble, Like the West Itself
description: At times ''Seven Men From Now,'' the compact and efficient 1956 Budd Boetticher western starring Randolph Scott, plays like a work by Harold Pinter. Oh, sure, there's the revenge motif that always put the fire in Scott's belly in his collaborations with Boetticher, a series of saddle-bum dramas in which the star looks bronzed and healthy even in a rainstorm in the dead of night.

title: Bush Will Address Christian Group After All
description: After some prominent Christian conservatives grumbled about Gov. George W. Bush's decision to skip the Christian Coalition's annual conference this weekend, the Bush campaign reversed itself today and announced that the governor would address the convention by videotape on Saturday.

title: MATTEL TO SELL EDUCATIONAL SOFTWARE UNIT
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it was selling the Learning Company, its educational software unit, to the Gores Technology Group, a private equity buyout firm based in Los Angeles. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Mattel said it would take an after-tax loss from discontinued operations of about $430 million. Mattel paid $3.6 billion for the Learning Company in May 1999. The move was meant to broaden Mattel's reach, but instead it contributed to huge losses, a steep drop in the company's stock and the resignation of Jill Barad as chief executive. Mattel also said yesterday that it would cut about 350 jobs at its headquarters and reduce its dividend from a quarterly 9 cents a share to an annual 5 cents a share. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: High Hopes For Israel's New Son
description: The burly man with the powerful forearms and the peach-fuzz hair steered his kayak by the side of the dock, and came to rest. His chest swelled as he inhaled, before releasing the tension of another hurdle passed, another heat survived, and a doubling of the chances of living his dream.

title: ROCKWELL TO LAY OFF 350 ELECTRONIC COMMERCE WORKERS
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it would lay off 350 workers at its electronic commerce business, or about 35 percent of the unit's staff, to cut costs. Rockwell, based in Milwaukee, also makes factory-automation and aerospace equipment. The company said the jobs would be eliminated in about 120 days. The electronic-commerce business makes call-management equipment for telephones, faxes, e-mail and the Internet. Earnings will not be affected, the company said.

title: Debate Tips From J.F.K.
description: I entered the candidate's hotel suite in the mid-afternoon. The room was silent. As I quietly walked over to a table to retrieve some files we had been using as preparation for that evening's televised presidential debate, the candidate's sister and her small child entered the room, laughing and talking. ''What the . . . ?'' John Kennedy called out, indignant at being roused from sleep. Later I was to marvel that he had been taking a nap only hours before what we now know to have been the most important moment of his campaign for the presidency in 1960.

title: NTT-KPN MOBILE INTERNET VENTURE
description: The NTT DoCoMo mobile phone company of Japan and KPN Mobile N.V. of the Netherlands said they would start an Internet portal for mobile phones. The service, which is expected to be available in Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands next year, would allow individuals to gain access to news, sports, entertainment and financial services on the Internet via their mobile phones. KPN and NTT said they would set up a new mobile joint venture to manage the service. The portal will use NTT's i-mode technology, which has been widely successful in Japan, where it has about 12 million subscribers. Suzanne Kapner

title: Battle at Jerusalem Holy Site Leaves 4 Dead and 200 Hurt
description: Violence erupted in the sacred, contested center of Jerusalem's Old City today as stones and bullets interrupted a day of prayer for Muslims and Jews, turning it bloody.

title: Peter Gennaro, Choreographer of 'Annie,' Dies at 80
description: Peter Gennaro, whose choreography for the 1977 hit musical ''Annie'' won him a Tony and whose dance sequences and dancing entertained millions on Perry Como's ''Kraft Music Hall'' in the 1960's, died on Thursday. Mr. Gennaro, who lived in Manhattan and maintained a home for many years in Oxford, Conn., was 80.

title: California Governor Rejects Electricity Aid
description: SACRAMENTO, Sept. 29  A $150 million emergency aid plan for San Diego's electricity customers was rejected today by Gov. Gray Davis, who called it premature and an incentive for energy traders to gouge.

title: Cuban Boxers Match A Storied Tradition
description: Cuba won its 24th and 25th Olympic boxing gold medals since the 1972 Olympic Games today when the bantamweight Guillermo Rigondeaux and the lightweight Mario Kindelan easily won their finals in the 2000 Olympic tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMLEY, TARQUIN JAY
description: BROMLEY-Tarquin Jay, Councilman of Scotch Plains, N.J.; former New York Assistant Attorney General and co-founder of the Pearl Theater in New York. Husband of Linda (nee Van Fossen) Bromley; father of Alexander; son of Haila Stoddard and sibling of Robin, Christopher and Erin. Funeral service, today, September 30th, at 11:00 AM at the Rossi Funeral Home, 1937 Westfield Avenue in Scotch Plains, New Jersey.

title: Lithuanians' Best Shot Puts Scare Into U.S.
description: The shot left his hands an instant before the final horn blared, an arching rainbow from 22 feet.

title: Sports of The Times; And a Day Later, a Close Bunch of Teammates Shares the Pain
description: NOBODY on the Dream Team ever wailed, ''Oh, God, stop this,'' the way Mia Hamm did to inject a note of levity during her team's cry-a-thon yesterday.

title: Speak, Cultural Memory: A Dead-Language Debate
description: Over the last seven years, Jessie Little Doe Fermino, a member of the Mashpee tribe on Cape Cod, has been on a single-minded mission to revive the language of her ancestors, Wampanoag, the one that greeted the Pilgrims when they landed at Plymouth Rock and that gave the state of Massachusetts its name. But when she applied to the National Endowment of the Humanities for a grant to create a Wampanoag dictionary, she was turned down.

title: Devils Trim Roster
description: For the first time this season, the Devils are not including Scott Niedermayer and Jason Arnott as members of the team.

title: Mets Win, And Try to Shore Up Plans
description: Perhaps the main intrigue involving the Mets last night came a little more than an hour before the start of the game with Montreal, when Benny Agbayani and Derek Bell stepped into the batting cage at Shea Stadium and came out healthy and ready to play this weekend. It was the lone clue that the Mets would supply as to just who would be participating when their division series begins next Wednesday.

title: At Least 12 More Arabs Die in Confrontations With Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli forces in the West Bank and Gaza today left a reported 12 Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the third straight day of pitched street fighting provoked by the defiant visit Thursday of the rightist Israeli opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, to the plaza outside the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City.

title: Reaching for College Against the Drag of Her Roots
description: As Lydia DeLucca, the working class heroine of ''That's Life,'' Heather Paige Kent carries herself with the wary toughness of an attractive woman accustomed to deflecting leers.

title: Sports of The Times; Real Yankees Need to Stand And Deliver
description: They are the Yankees. Proud and feisty, talented and competitive, they are a team that expects greatness and a team that has achieved it by securing three of the last four World Series titles. They are the Yankees. That phrase is usually enough to describe a team that succeeds.

title: Sports of The Times; A Gold Quest Now Includes A Little Bronze
description: FUN is winning.

title: Gore Says Bush Plan Will Cause Lasting Damage to the Environment
description: Vice President Al Gore today sharply criticized his opponent's proposal to open Alaska's protected wilderness to oil drilling, saying it would bring ''decades of environmental damage to reap just a few months of increased oil supply.''

title: Indonesians Ponder the Law, Their Hearts, Suharto's Fate
description: Along drab Kebon Kacang Raya Avenue, where street vendors eke out a living by hawking clove cigarettes and meat kebabs, talk was of little else today but the court decision that set off riots on Thursday with its ruling that former President Suharto was too ill to stand trial on charges of embezzling $590 million.

title: Article 2000093091892072305 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Carl Sigman, 91, Songsmith Who Made Generations Hum
description: Carl Sigman, who wrote music or words for dozens of songs to which generations have tapped their toes, including the theme song to the 1950's ''Robin Hood'' television series (''Robin Hood, Robin Hood, Riding through the glen'') died at his home in Manhasset, N.Y., on Tuesday. He was 91.

title: Agreement Reached On Conservation Bill
description: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed on a plan to set aside $12 billion over six years for a sweeping federal land conservation effort.

title: Pill Seen As Offering Privacy To Women
description: Natalie Ferrol spoke of the humiliation of a friend, a frightened young woman who went to have an abortion, but first had to walk past the pickets and protesters outside a clinic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNARO, PETER
description: GENNARO-Peter. On Sept. 28, 2000, at age 80. Beloved husband of Jean. Loving father of Michael and Liza and their spouses, Donna Lee & Scott Alan Evans. Adoring grandfather of Brendan and Fiona. Dear brother of Emile. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, 3-8 PM. Interment private. Memorial Mass at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 W. 71 St., Tuesday, 10 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to SLE Foundation, 149 Madison Avenue, Suite 205, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Police Investigate 2 Pipe Bomb Explosions
description: The police yesterday were investigating two pipe-bomb explosions beneath parked cars in Woodhaven, Queens, that caused minor damage to the vehicles but no injuries.

title: Yankees Win the East, Thanks to the Red Sox
description: The Yankees filed sullenly into their clubhouse tonight, champions of the American League East. They didn't know whether to spray Champagne and hug, or to dress quietly and leave, absorbed by their slump.

title: The Lieberman Method of Dismantling Opponents: Subtle as a Ton of Brickbats
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman came here today to deliver a blistering assault on Gov. George W. Bush's environmental record, depicting him as hellbent on ravaging the Alaskan wilderness, and Texas as choking in smog.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: PORTRAIT OF A SCANDAL
description: The arrest of one corrupt Los Angeles police officer has led to the biggest scandal in the history of the city's police department, and has done what even Rodney King didn't: brought the troubled department under federal supervision. A report by Lou Cannon in The Times Magazine.

title: INSIDE
description: New Firestone Inquiry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, SYLVIA ADLER
description: RODGERS-Sylvia Adler. Devoted mother to Marc, Kenneth and Rand. Adored grandniece to Minnie Cohan. Loving sister to Abner and Howard. Childhood and lifelong friend to Margery Aronstein.

title: Sarajevo Journal; Olympics on TV Unite the Bosnians
description: In the fractured city where the old Communist Yugoslavia played host to the 1984 Winter Olympic Games, Bosnia's Serbs, Croats and Muslims are making a different kind of Olympian effort.

title: The Tangled Tale Of Wen Ho Lee
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000093092928072583 -- No Title
description: It would have haunted us for the rest of our lives.

title: Pockets of Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bull Market for Grant, A Bear Market for Lee; History's Judgment of the 2 Civil War Generals Is Changing
description: For the better part of the last century the images of two of the greatest icons of the Civil War remained fixed in the American imagination: Robert E. Lee as the noble and tragic leader of the Confederate forces, the brilliant tactician fighting against overwhelming odds, and Ulysses S. Grant as the heavy-drinking butcher who used the North's superior resources to grind down the South, then became one of the worst presidents in the nation's history.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the trial of two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which went down in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misidentified the defendant whose clothes were found in the debris. A store owner testified that Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi had purchased the clothes, not his co-defendant, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah.

title: U.S. Women Finish Basketball Tournament Perfectly
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- This was a gold medal earned the hard way.

title: Religion Journal; Ascent of Lieberman Inspires Sermon Ideas
description: When Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic presidential nominee, chose Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as his running mate, the decision made history, as Mr. Lieberman became the first Jew on a major party presidential ticket.

title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both
description: To the Editor:

title: A Reaper of the Castoff, Be It Material or Human
description: ''The Gleaners and I'' takes its title, and some of its inspiration, from an 1867 painting by Jean-Francois Millet that shows three women in a wheat field, stooping to pick up sheaves and kernels left behind after the harvest. The image is well known; it appears in the Larousse Dictionary of the French Language alongside the definition of the verb ''glaner'' (to glean). The painting itself, which hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, shows up early in Agnes Varda's wonderful new documentary, thronged by camera-wielding tourists.

title: Mrs. Clinton Is Riding The Trend, Polls Agree
description: Several recent independent polls in the New York Senate race show Hillary Rodham Clinton has secured a modest but solid lead over Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: Knee Injury Slows Longley
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  Luc Longley's plans of arriving at Knicks training camp with fresh legs and a new start backfired Friday night when the Australian team's 7-foot center hyper- extended his left knee in a semifinal loss to France here at the Olympics.

title: Bush, in Energy Plan, Endorses New U.S. Drilling to Curb Prices
description: Gov. George W. Bush outlined a wide-ranging energy plan today that called for more domestic fuel production, better relations with foreign oil suppliers and opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for drilling, all of which he framed as potential remedies for rising oil and gas prices.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about a new Securities and Exchange Commission rule that will let corporate insiders make preset trades of company stock referred incorrectly to an executive of the Intel Corporation who said the company intended to look at alternatives under the rule. The official, Cary I. Klafter, is a man; his title is director of corporate affairs.

title: A Venerable Concert Hall That's the Belle of the Ball
description: Few American orchestras have been so closely associated with their concert halls, and for as long, as the Boston Symphony. Its home, Symphony Hall, was built in 1900, in time for the orchestra's 20th season, and this year the orchestra is celebrating the hall's centenary, and by extension, its relationship with an auditorium that has been revered for its warm, enveloping acoustics since the night it opened.

title: Dutch Beat South Korea In a Shootout for the Gold
description: SYDNEY, Sept. 30 -- South Korea strengthened its claim to be the new force in Asian men's field hockey today, taking the Olympic silver medal after losing a thrilling penalty shootout against the Netherlands.

title: Ecstasy Drug Cited in 6 Florida Deaths
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29  A lethal variant of the drug Ecstasy has killed at least six people in Florida since July, raising victims' temperatures so high that the central nervous system "burns out," the state police said today.

title: SIMPSON, AUTO PARTS MAKER, AGREES TO A TAKEOVER
description: Simpson Industries, an auto parts maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by an affiliate of the private equity firm Heartland Industrial Partners for about $232 million. News of the deal, which also includes the assumption of $118 million of debt, sent Simpson's shares surging 21 percent, or $2.13, to $12.25 on the Nasdaq. The offer represents a 28 percent premium to Simpson's closing stock price Thursday of $10.13. Simpson, based in Plymouth, Mich., supplies powertrain and chassis products.

title: Strip Away The Pretense Of the Games
description: Dear Juan and Dick,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, CHARLES S.
description: McVEIGH-Charles S., Jr. Charles S. McVeigh, Jr. died suddenly at his home in Syosset on September 27. He is survived by a daughter, Lynne McVeigh, two sons, Charles S. McVeigh III and Johnson B. McVeigh, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: Britain Winces Over Denmark's Rejection of the Euro
description: Denmark's rejection of a single European currency has brought home two sobering messages here to a government that probably figured that it had enough to worry about as it was.

title: Starting Off With a Birthday, Then Seeking the Holy Spirit
description: It's not often that choreographers serve audiences cake. But Reggie Wilson did that on Wednesday night when his Reggie Wilson/Fist and Heel Performance Group appeared at Dance Theater Workshop. The occasion was his 33rd birthday.

title: Rangers' Rookies Give Team Some Hope
description: Pavel Brendl finally scored last night. The question is whether Brendl's first goal of the preseason is enough to convince Rangers Coach Ron Low that the forward is ready to play in the National Hockey League.

title: Article 2000093093430388670 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Woman Held in Brooklyn Bank Robbery
description: A 41-year-old Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday morning after she robbed a Sheepshead Bay bank with a pellet gun and made her getaway on a crowded city bus, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYLE, EILEEN JANE
description: COYLE-Eileen Jane (nee Tuohy). Unexpectedly on September 28, 2000. Beloved wife of Daniel Edward. Adored mother of Patricia K. Coyle, M.D., Eileen Dana Flood, Daniel Edward Coyle, Jr., Claudia Coyle, Mary Jane Herkenham, and Christopher Coyle. Loving grandmother of Danny, Peter, Billy, Eileen, Mackenzie, Laura and Katie. Her early career was as a fashion designer, her later career was a wife and mother. Visiting Saturday 2-5 and 7-9 and Sunday 25. Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, 212-475-2024. Services Monday, 10 A.M., at Epiphany Church, New York. Interment at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Coram, Long Island. Any donations to Long Island Chapter National MS Society, Hauppauge, New York.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: HOLY DAYS

title: A Man Gets Mad, a Load of Blows Follows, and Now Two Golds May, Too
description: From his corner ringside perch tonight, the United States boxing coach, Tom Mustin, watched the first round unfold between his fighter, Ricardo Williams Jr., and Cuba's powerful Diogenes Luna and had just one thought: we're in trouble.

title: Compromise Reached on Conservation Bill
description: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on a plan to set aside $12 billion over six years for a sweeping federal land conservation effort.

title: Turks and Armenians
description: To the Editor:

title: United Airlines Parent Says It Will Have Quarterly Loss
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that labor disruption over the summer, coupled with the higher cost of jet fuel and an expensive new pilot contract, would force it to report a loss for the quarter that ends today and probably for the next quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROVE, MARGERY G.
description: GROVE-Margery G., 78, of Freehold Twp, NJ, on September 29, 2000. Widow of Marmaduke V. Grove; mother of Barbara Baier and Margaret Grove; sister of Edgar P. German; grandmother of George F. Baier, III; great-grandmother of three. Calling hours will be 2:30-4:30 and 7-9 PM Monday at Freeman Funeral Home, 47 East Main Street, Freehold, NJ. Services and interment are private. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Osteoporosis Foundation, 1232 22nd Street NW, Washington, DC 20037, are appreciated. E-mail condolence letters to freemansfh@aol.com

title: Delays Double At La Guardia Within a Year
description: The Federal Aviation Administration reported yesterday that delays at La Guardia Airport in August were more than double what they were during the same period last year, a jump mostly caused not by weather or mechanical problems but because the airport simply has too much traffic.

title: Access to RU-486
description: After more than a decade of legal and political roadblocks, RU-486 has at last been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for abortions in early pregnancy. The widespread use of this drug is far from certain since it is to be employed only during the first seven weeks of pregnancy, and requires more visits to a doctor than surgical abortion does. But it nonetheless represents a breakthrough for better access to safe, legal abortions, particularly in areas of the country where abortion services are rare or nonexistent.

title: Great, Gaudy Hyacinths Make Hearts Go Pitapat
description: I seldom feel the slightest tug of restraint when I stand in front of the bulb bins at a garden shop in the fall. It is usually the opposite. The stacked bins, each labeled with a glossy floral portrait, appeal to my otherwise latent sense of order, and the brown paper bags and stubby yellow golf pencils provided by the proprietors are pleasantly reminiscent of school supplies. It is more tempting to me than a pastry shop.

title: Splashed Across Life's Canvas, Dripping
description: Ed Harris's powerful biographical film ''Pollock'' may be the first movie about a painter to transcend the gushy cliches found in movies that try to unravel the mysteries of artistic creation. It helps, of course, that Jackson Pollock, the Abstract Expressionist giant whom Mr. Harris portrays with a riveting blend of pent-up passion and unleashed physicality, threw his entire body into his work.

title: White House Holds Back Payment to Ad Agency
description: The White House is withholding millions of dollars in payments to a major advertising firm after allegations that the firm may have overbilled the government for its work on a huge media campaign aimed at discouraging young people from using drugs.

title: Giants Seek Insurance With a Second Kicker
description: The visitor at the Giants' practice field today had a familiar face and he shared laughs on the sideline with the incumbent place-kicker, Brad Daluiso. The presence of Jaret Holmes, a kicker who was on the Giants' practice squad last season, did not seem to bother Daluiso.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUBY, ROBERT
description: TUBY-Robert, M.D. Grandpa, the chain has been broken, but our love lives on forever. Love, Wendy and Michae

title: Article 2000093094271086153 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, BART M.
description: ROGERS-Bart M. Of Monmouth Beach, NJ at home on Thursday, September 28, 2000. He was the General Agent for the Manhattan Life Insurance Company since 1952. Loving husband of Adele. Loving father of Bart, John and Marcy Rogers, Jane Von Richthofen, Marianne Drozak and Janice Clark. Loving grandfather of Ann, Candice, Matthew, Bart, Andrew, Melissa, J.C., Krista and Christina. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held today at noon at Star of the Sea R.C. Church in Long Branch, NJ. Entombment will take place at Woodbine Cemetery, Oceanport, NJ. John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ, 732-747-0332.

title: Cubans Continue Their Boxing Domination
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  Each Cuban fighter leaves his locker room the same way  walking briskly without conversation and without making eye contact, his gaze at the ring up ahead. His coach, Alcides Sagarra, strides behind the fighter, ramrod straight, with a towel on his shoulder but nothing in his hands.

title: Police Charge 13-Year-Old In Death of Newborn Son
description: A 13-year-old girl who had given birth by herself in her Brooklyn bedroom was charged with criminally negligent homicide yesterday after an autopsy revealed her newborn son had suffocated, police officials said.

title: Lazio Gets a Hand From the Governor
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Lazio campaign planned to begin broadcasting last night.

title: Talks Fail To Settle The Dispute On Schedule
description: Baseball officials held lots of discussions, but made no decision yesterday on whether to change the plan to have the Yankees play a makeup game Monday, the day after the regular season is scheduled to end.

title: On the Attack, Politely
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has a rare talent for making harsh attacks that do not come across as attacks. He has stepped up criticism of Gov. George W. Bush, but he often sounds less like a politician than like a neighbor sharing a troubling bit of gossip.

title: 2 Koreas to Set Up Joint Economic Panel
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Sept. 30  North and South Korea agreed today to set up a joint committee to push forward economic cooperation and trade, a joint statement said.

title: Apple and UAL Lead Market Downward as Quarter Ends
description: Stocks closed a shaky third quarter shakily yesterday, as negative earnings warnings from Apple Computer and United Airlines pulled down a wide swath of companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAUSLAND, JEAN C.
description: MacAUSLAND-Jean C. Of Palm Beach, Fla. On September 24, 2000. Predeceased by her husband, Earle R. MacAusland, and a niece Jean Dickson. Survived by her brother, Robert Cowger, her sister, Helene Dickson, both of Santa Fe, New Mexico, eight nieces and nephews and many grand nieces and grand nephews. A service celebrating her life will be held October 4, 2000 at 11AM at the Sconset Chapel, Nantucket, Mass. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nantucket Garden Club.

title: Article 2000093092884533200 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Our Uninsured Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Cruises to Third Straight Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  The thick gray hair of the Russian coach, Nikolai Karpol, bounced as he barked at his blank-faced players, and his thick eyeglasses slid down his nose while he shook his fists at them.

title: Mayor Won't Be Questioned On Demolition, Judge Rules
description: A federal magistrate judge has reversed himself and ruled that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani does not have to submit to questioning under oath in a lawsuit over the emergency demolition of a Lower East Side apartment building in 1998.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Gardner Will Carry U.S. Flag at Closing
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 30  Rulon Gardner, whose victory over Aleksandr Karelin in Greco-Roman wrestling provided one of the biggest upsets of the Sydney Games, will carry the flag for the United States in Sunday's closing ceremony.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOMINION RESOURCES INC., Richmond, Va., a diversified utility holding company, said its telecommunications unit, Dominion Telecom, agreed to pay $41.1 million to use 6,000 miles of fiber optic lines of the Williams Communications Group, Tulsa, Okla., to expand its network in the northeastern United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans to conduct confidential blood tests door to door on Staten Island to detect exposure levels to West Nile virus referred incompletely to the methods used in an anonymous testing program last fall in northern Queens. Blood samples were collected in door-to-door visits, not just at vans in the neighborhood.

title: Hockeyroos Don't Bend and Don't Break, and They Win
description: The train that winds into Olympic Park was slowly easing by the hockey stadium earlier this week when a boy sprung from his seat like a trick snake out of a can.

title: Brand-Name Auctions, Cut-Rate Connoisseurs
description: To many both inside and outside the art world, seeing the names Sotheby's and Christie's next to the words ''collusion'' and ''price-fixing'' has come as something of a shock. The auction houses have long maintained an air of white-glove purity, of aristocratic connoisseurship. The fact that the houses are now facing considerable public embarrassment, not to mention a $512 million settlement to the customers they allegedly defrauded, has sent nervous tremors throughout the art market -- many collectors especially are wondering how this will undermine the sanctity of art transactions.

title: Grimsley's Arm Troubles Add to Torre's Bullpen Frustration
description: The emotion that Jason Grimsley tried to hide escaped around his eyes as he buckled his belt and finished dressing in street clothes this afternoon. Bernie Williams had been headed to the field for batting practice, but he saw Grimsley, stopped and asked what was wrong.

title: Hillary Clinton's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: About the Tables
description: Beginning next week and continuing through Dec. 29, Business Day will include a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays. That section will consist of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: Can the President Come Out and Play?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones Leaps Far Enough, But Foul Costs Her Gold
description: Marion Jones stood on the runway, blew air from her cheeks and shook her arms as if she were shivering on this hot, windy night at the Olympics. This was her sixth and final long jump. She crouched and swung her arms, and then she leaned back, hopped slightly and began her final urgent sprint toward history.

title: Retroactive Deportation
description: To the Editor:

title: Traipsing Along Jovially All the Way to the Pub
description: The Birmingham Royal Ballet has clearly won many American friends in its season at City Center. Cheers, mid-ballet applause and appreciative laughter greeted the company on Thursday night when it presented ''Jazz Triple,'' the second of two programs in this first American tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITZLING, MORTON
description: WITZLING-Morton, a caring, kind, devoted cousin whose lunch meetings I looked forward to. Heartfelt condolences to all the family. David D. Wallerstein

title: Hokies Add WWW To Their X's and O's
description: Virginia Tech Coach Frank Beamer calls it a sign of the times: an Internet site where, for an annual fee of $39.99, Hokie-soaked football fans can peruse injury and scouting reports prepared by his staff or settle into a chat room with the coach himself. It is called, modestly or not, BeamerBall.com and actually is tempered with a down home sentiment -- part of the revenue will be parceled among his coaches.

title: FRENCH UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS
description: The unemployment rate in France fell back in August to the same level as in June -- when the rate was at its lowest in almost nine years. The jobless rate fell to 9.6 percent in August from 9.7 percent in July, the Labor Ministry said in a statement. The number of registered job seekers, based on International Labor Organization standards, fell 4,000, to 2.527 million. That compares with an average decline of 43,700 in each of the first six months of the year.

title: Gay Man's Death Led to Epiphany for Wyoming Officer
description: HE said he grew up like so many other people he knew from small rural towns, unaware of gays and lesbians living among them. Besides, nobody back then used words like ''gay'' or ''lesbian,'' anyway.

title: Article 2000093090482660304 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Contesting Jerusalem's Holy Sites
description: The violent clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians in the center of Jerusalem's Old City yesterday were disheartening. Just when Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, need to make another attempt to conclude a peace agreement, renewed tensions prevail. Ariel Sharon, the Likud leader, did Israel no favor by provocatively leading his supporters to the Temple Mount on Thursday, asserting Jewish claims to the Muslim holy site at a moment when authority over the area is the most sensitive remaining issue in the peace talks. The Sharon visit led to a series of confrontations that culminated in bloodshed hours before the beginning of the Jewish High Holy Days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGASHIMA, HIDEO
description: NAGASHIMA-Hideo, M.D. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore community are deeply saddened by the death of Hideo Nagashima, M.D. An esteemed member of our Department of Anesthesiology for more than 4 decades and director of Anesthesiology Research, Dr. Nagashima was highly regarded as a pioneer in the use of anesthesia during open heart surgery. A revered teacher, he founded a fellowship program which for 30 years trained many of the leaders of academic and anethesiology in Japan. Dr. Nagashima will be remembered by his colleagues, students, patients and friends as a man of warmth and grace who fulfilled the highest tenets of medicine. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Sachiko; his sons, Robert, Hidalgo and Richard, his grandchildren and entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Hear the One About the Goofy Robot?
description: Machines have always seemed to possess imposing and threatening powers. Their clanking, humming energy and inhuman abilities have promised utopia -- a world of leisure and convenience and plenty. But they have also threatened apocalypse: a world in which their brutish, infernal mechanisms demolish everything we cherish. The Industrial Revolution gave us these machines; then 20th-century science amplified both their promise and their menace.

title: DISCOVER VS. VISA
description: The Wall Street investment firm Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said it opened legal proceedings against Visa International, the European arm of Visa USA Inc., accusing it of discrimination. Morgan Stanley, which operates the Discover card in the United States, said Visa had broken British and European competition rules by refusing to allow Morgan Stanley to join the Visa card network in Britain. Morgan Stanley said Visa's action prevented it from acquiring the British and Canadian credit card businesses of Bank One. Alan Cowell

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: UAL Says It Expects a Loss, And Its Stock Falls Further

title: Jones and Teammates Win Gold and Bronze
description: SYDNEY, Australia -- Marion Jones didn't get her five golds, but still sprinted into history by becoming the first woman to win five track medals in one Olympics.

title: Airbus Wins $8 Billion Deal For Its New Jet
description: In a major defeat for Boeing, Airbus Industrie won an $8.6 billion order today for 25 superjumbo aircraft from Singapore Airlines.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil ended a string of declines and rallied after the European Union declined to release oil supplies from its reserve. In New York, crude oil for delivery in November rose 50 cents, to $30.84 a barrel.

title: At Edgemont, Sets of Brothers Have Made Football a Family Tradition
description: For more than a decade, the varsity football teams at Edgemont High School in Westchester have spent the night before games eating together at a player's house and watching game films.

title: European Company Will Buy Entire Crop of Corn in Recall
description: The company that makes the genetically modified corn linked to the recent recall of taco shells agreed with the government yesterday to buy back this year's entire crop to prevent the grain from getting into the food supply.

title: Many Doctors Find Array of Obstacles To the Abortion Pill
description: Dr. Mitchell Creinin runs an abortion clinic in Pittsburgh and has become something of an expert on the abortion-inducing pill, mifepristone, which was approved for sale in the United States on Thursday.

title: A 2nd Front In the Inquiry Into Firestone
description: Federal regulators said today that they had opened a second investigation into Firestone tires, this time involving Steeltex tires used on the largest sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans.

title: A Texas-Size Whodunit; On the Trail of Genetically Altered Corn Flour From Azteca
description: When trucks laden with corn roll up to the gate of the huge Azteca flour mill here at the base of the Texas Panhandle, they must stop at a little shack. A long thin probe is inserted into the truck and 10 to 15 pounds of corn is sucked through a tube into the shack, where the corn is tested for a fungal toxin, moisture, color, cracks and broken kernels.

title: An Iranian Woody Allen Can't Even Keep His Burial Plot
description: Bahman Farmanara's ''Smell of Camphor, Fragrance of Jasmine'' has a pixilated charm and, under the surface, a current of despair. Mr. Farmanara's sense of humor flows into this three-part story about Bahman, a filmmaker coming to terms with his own mortality; he could be an Iranian Woody Allen using his own life for scoring laughs off himself.
